title: REAGAN AND REGAN SHOW RELUCTANCE TO WHITE HOUSE TESTIMONY ON ARMS
description: The Administration raised the likelihood today of creating a clash with Congress by declining to provide more information about the secret arms shipments to Iran.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND OPENS 75TH DRIVE AMID RISING SUPPORT
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 75th annual appeal today, urging help for the destitute, the ill and the disabled.

title: CONCERT: YOUTH SYMPHONY
description: THE New York Youth Symphony occupies a healthy middle ground between music education and the professional performing world. Its continuing commissioning program, moreover, forms a similar bridge for young composers, soliciting new works and providing them a public forum.

title: HIS, HERS AND THEIR CHILDREN
description: ELIZABETH CRONK, 34 years old, had served as stepmother through two previous marriages. Now she was eager to have a child of her own. But her current husband already had a 6-year-old son and was not quite ready for another child.

title: NOTRE DAME'S ALL-TIME SCOREKEEPER
description: What was the only car to be named for a football coach? How was the fox hunting in Leicestershire in 1907? Did Notre Dame football players really wear glittery pants to blind opponents?

title: THE UNBOUNDED HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives has not had desks since 1912, when the entrance of new states into the nation expanded the membership and overcrowded the chamber. Members now sit anywhere they choose on long, padded benches, but some interesting patterns have developed anyway.

title: DEADLY BACTERIA ELUDING SEARCHERS
description: Two weeks ago, in the kitchen of an inviting nursing home in this placid town just north of Hartford, something went terribly wrong.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT RESTAURANT STALL BRYANT PARK REDESIGN
description: After six years of discussion and planning by city officials, community leaders and business executives, the redesign of Bryant Park has still not received final approval.

title: Junk Bonds Face Challenge
description: The ''junk bond'' market is being tested, as investigations of insider trading in the stock market produce subpoenas for officials of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the leading underwriter and trader in the relatively new market for low-quality, high-yielding corporate bonds.

title: A Sharing Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: 49ERS, LIKE GIANTS, LOOK TO DEFENSE
description: The last time the Giants played the 49ers was in a wild-card playoff game last December. The Giants manhandled the Super Bowl defending champions and beat them soundly, 17-3.

title: Tiger-Cats Score Upset in Grey Cup
description: The emotionally charged Hamilton Tiger-Cats staged one of the most unexpected upsets in Canadian sports history today when they routed the Edmonton Eskimos, 39-15, in the Grey Cup title game.

title: AGENDA
description: Lighting the Great Tree Tens of thousands of onlookers are expected to crowd the surrounding streets this evening for the lighting of the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. The crowd, in the area between 49th and 50th Streets and Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, is expected to delay midtown traffic during the late afternoon and early evening. 30 Rockefeller Center, 5:59 P.M. Issues Facing the Schools Robert F. Wagner Jr., president of the city's Board of Education, is to discuss sex education and other issues affecting the public schools in a lecture at the New York University School of Education, Health, Nursing and Arts Professions. Education auditorium, 35 West Fourth Street, 4 P.M.

title: Article 824486 -- No Title
description: American Brands Inc., the large tobacco company, said yesterday that it had sweetened its $66-a-share takeover bid for Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. to $69 over the weekend, but that the consumer products company, which makes such well-known brands as Vaseline and Pond's beauty creams, had turned down the offer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHEN one thinks of books to give as gifts, what comes to mind are usually art books and coffee-table books and books that dazzle and amaze. In the baker's dozen of recommendations that follows, there are indeed a couple of beautiful doorstops as well as attractive books you could easily serve tea on. But there are also books that are fun or fattening or even edifying. In fact, if you read just these in 1987, you could dazzle and amaze your friends in any number of ways and even be improved at crossword puzzles.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Peter Fonseca, 28, Is Dead; A Soloist of Ballet Theater
description: Peter Fonseca, a leading soloist with the American Ballet Theater, died Saturday at his home in Wheaton, Md., after a long illness. He was 28.

title: OUTDOORS: THE DEER STALKERS
description: SWEATING and panting -more like a draft horse hauling a stone boat than a Natty Bumppo drifting silently through the forest primeval - I was two-thirds of the way up the ridge that forms the northern extension of Half Moon Mountain before I persuaded myself that finding deer -not executing the climb as rapidly as possible - was my primary quest.

title: Black & Decker Unit
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said Friday that it intends to stop production by its French subsidiary and close a plant in eastern France during the first half of 1987 as part of a worldwide restructuring. The Brezins plant is to be shut down, and the 650 employees will be offered transfers, retraining or early retirement as far as possible. Black & Decker's headquarters at Dardilly, near Lyons, however, will be reorganized to house a European research center for household products.

title: THE LURE OF THE GAME SHOW
description: Before Beryl Arbit appeared on ''Jeopardy'' last January, she decided not to tell anyone. Then, if she lost, she could ''ignore it,'' she said. But now, after her four-day, $41,001 winning streak, she is frequently stopped on the street by strangers, who offer their congratulations.

title: Giuliani Says Others Will Disclose Crimes
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, said yesterday that he had ''concrete reasons'' to believe that the convictions of Stanley M. Friedman and three co-defendants would prompt others with knowledge of municipal corruption to cooperate with investigators.

title: ISRAELI ARMS DEALER DENIES PROFITING IN SALE
description: One of the Israeli arms traders reported to have been at the center of Israel's dealings with Teheran publicly denied today that he had made any profits by shipping American weapons to Iran and insisted he had acted solely on ''humanitarian'' grounds.

title: Loan Talks By Argentina
description: Argentine finance officials will open talks Monday with the International Monetary Fund and private banks in Washington as they seek $2.5 billion in fresh loans, Treasury Secretary Mario Brodersohn said today.

title: PURCHASERS SEE MODEST GROWTH
description: The economy continued to grow at a moderate pace in November, according to the monthly report of the National Association of Purchasing Managment, released today.

title: CHILDREN WITH CHILDREN: COPING WITH A CRISIS
description: Throughout New York City, ever-younger girls are becoming pregnant ever more frequently. Over the last five years, even as pregnancies among 15-to-19-year-olds have remained nearly steady, the rate among younger girls - some not even teen-agers -has risen.

title: REDSKINS CLINCH BERTH IN PLAYOFFS
description: In the emotional roller coaster ride of a National Football League season, flat periods inevitably disrupt the flow.

title: McDonnell Copter Deal
description: The McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company, based in Culver City, Calif., was awarded a $804.9 million modification to an Army contract for the AH-64 advanced attack helicopter production program, the Defense Department said on Friday.

title: AUSTRIAN STEELMAKER TESTED
description: Austria's two largest parties suffered serious losses in last week's national elections, but it is likely to be a while before anyone knows just how the country's huge nationalized industries, rocked last year by losses and scandals, will be affected.

title: Is There No Decency?
description: It was a small thing, as the arrogance of power goes in Washington these days. But it was so nasty, and so revealing.

title: CONTRA CHIEFS SAY THE IRAN AFFAIR MAY HAVE DOOMED THE INSURGENCY
description: They have survived four years of battles and blunders, but leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels say they may now finally face defeat, not inside Nicaragua, but in a Washington political uproar beyond their control.

title: Market Place; The 'Bargains' In U.S. Stocks
description: JOHN M. TEMPLETON is widely regarded as the dean of international investors. But the founder of the $6 billion Templeton Group of mutual funds is more bullish on America these days.

title: The Geography Factor
description: Not to discourage the dedicated backers of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th, Senator Gary Hart and Senator Paul Laxalt, but the political history is immutable: Since the founding of the Republic, no one from Delaware, Colorado or Nevada has ever won the White House or even the nomination of a major party. And, not to discourage Gov. Bruce Babbitt, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Bob Dole, but only one political leader each from Arizona, South Carolina and Kansas has ever been nominated for President by a major party, and all three lost.

title: THEATER: 'HOUSE ON MAYHEM STREET'
description: STREET theater, even at its most primitive, can often transcend its limited vocabulary and lack of means through the shared communal exuberance of cast and audience. But when the chemistry fails, as in the Mass Transit Street Theater's production, ''House on Mayhem Street,'' the most well-intentioned populist theater can seem hopelessly simplistic.

title: 4 Wounded by Police Gunfire At a Political Clash in Malta
description: The police shot and wounded four people today during a clash between supporters of the opposition Nationalist Party and followers of Prime Minister Carmelo Mifsud Bonnici, the Nationalists' leader said.

title: Catching Up
description: Boise State, the school that installed an artificial turf of blue in its football stadium last summer, now has a mood to match. Beaten at home by Idaho in the season finale, the Broncos were left with a record of 5-6 and their first losing season in 40 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It has often been said that Marcos was the first male chauvinist to underestimate me. He was not the last to pay for that mistake.'' - President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: PATRIOTS TIE JETS FOR FIRST
description: Mosi Tatupu raced 17 yards for a touchdown with a blocked punt late in the fourth quarter and Brent Williams ran 21 yards for a score with a fumble recovery two minutes later, giving the New England Patriots a 21-20 victory over the New Orleans Saints today.

title: Kaiser Steel Dissident Is Thriving on Distress
description: Bruce Hendry, who is leading a group of dissident preferred shareholders in a battle to take over the Kaiser Steel Corporation, has built a career on finding distressed business situations and trying to take advantage of them.

title: Clean Needles Are Just Part of the War on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ELWAY TOO MUCH FOR BENGALS
description: John Elway, who had not thrown a touchdown pass in the previous three games, fired three of them in a single quarter today to lead the Denver Broncos to a 34-28 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Pramotton of Italy Wins Giant Slalom
description: Richard Pramotton of Italy won a men's World Cup giant slalom race today, edging Hubert Strolz of Austria and the favorite, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland.

title: THE BLACK VIEWERS' NEW ALLURE FOR THE NETWORKS
description: Black television viewers, who until recently have felt virtually ignored by television networks, advertisers and ratings companies, are becoming more of a force in the medium, network analysts and advertisers say.

title: KOCH ACCUSED OF BYPASSING CIVIL SERVICE
description: The hiring and promotion of provisional workers - employees given Civil Service jobs before passing Civil Service tests - has risen sharply under the Koch administration. Thousands of these workers have remained on the payroll for years, in violation of a state law requiring testing in their first nine months on the job.

title: AUSTRALIANS AT 'BARBIE' LIFT THEIR BEER TO JOHN PAUL
description: Pope John Paul II has been acclaimed in many ways in many places. Today for the first time thousands of beer cans were hoisted high in his honor, though not in his presence.

title: Frederick William Heim, 72; Philharmonic Piccolo Player
description: Frederick William Heim, a flutist and the principal piccolo player for the New York Philharmonic for 35 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday en route to Florida. He was 72 years old and lived in Pittsboro, N.C.

title: A Surge of Sorts
description: The good news from Women's Election Central, which tracked women's progress in the elections this year, involves statewide office, and it sounds even better if you translate it into percentage increases. The number of women as Governors, beginning in January, will increase from 1 to 2 (100 percent), and the number of Lieutenant Governors from 2 to 4 (also 100 percent).

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: O'BRIEN SHOULDERS HIS SHARE OF BLAME
description: ''No,'' Ken O'Brien said after the game, ''the wind was not a factor.''

title: British Seek Bank Curbs
description: The British Government urged Parliament Friday to approve legislation to strengthen supervision of banks, a reaction to the collapse two years ago of the London banking firm of Johnson Matthey Bankers.

title: 4 Drown in Malaysia Floods
description: The bodies of three men were recovered today near this northeastern town, bringing to four the number of people drowned in floods since Thursday, the national news agency Bernama reported.

title: AIRCRAFT WITH A PARACHUTE WING DRAWING RAVES
description: In the annals of aviation there are places of high honor: Kitty Hawk, N.C., where the Wright brothers first experienced the exhilaration of flight, Roosevelt Field, L.I., where Lindbergh took off for his celebrated Atlantic crossing.

title: French Education Bill To Be Re-examined
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said tonight that the Government would re-examine the text of an education bill that has prompted student protests and might modify it if some points were ''unclear.''

title: WORKER SLAIN IN WEST SIDE DELI
description: An employee of a Columbus Avenue delicatessen was stabbed to death yesterday morning by a customer who became enraged when the worker refused to let him have a package of cigarettes on credit, the police said.

title: Airwick Assignments To Drossman Lehmann
description: Airwick Industries has assigned a few recently acquired products to Drossman Lehmann Marino, one of its major agencies.

title: Italian Visitor Slain in Queens
description: An Italian visiting his brother-in-law in Staten Island was found shot to death in a car parked on a road in Broad Channel, Queens, the police said.

title: CARBIDE TO BUY BACK BILLIONS IN DEBT
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, free of an Indian court injunction, said yesterday that it would offer today to repurchase more than $2.5 billion in high-yield debt securities, as part of a recapitalization plan announced on Nov. 4.

title: 'I DON'T MIND CHOKING'
description: WITH two wisecracks near the 15th green at the PGA West Stadium course, Fuzzy Zoeller and Jack Nicklaus defined golf's Skins Game better than anyone else ever has.

title: JETS, BEATEN ON THE BIG PLAYS, DROP SECOND STRAIGHT
description: Suddenly, those quirky little breaks that had worked for the Jets are now haunting them - in short, the kinds of things that happen to losing teams are happening to the Jets at the most critical part of the season.

title: PICK A SEAT, (BUT NOT) ANY SEAT
description: Over the next few weeks, a biennial ritual will take place on Capitol Hill. Two Senate officials, one a Democrat, one a Republican, will start making discreet phone calls to individual Senators.

title: Canadian Bank Deal
description: The Canadian Parliament has passed a law allowing the takeover of the Bank of British Columbia by the Canadian unit of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. The legislation was rushed through the House of Commons and Senate after the bank, Canada's seventh largest, agreed Wednesday to sell most of its $2.08 billion (United States) of assets for $45.9 million. Government spokesmen said Friday that the sale was necessary to insure the bank's survival.

title: KOCH PERSUADES GROUP OF MAYORS TO EMPHASIZE ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS
description: Mayor Koch brought his anti-drug message here to delegates of the National League of Cities today and won not only a standing ovation, but also a pledge to turn the fight against drugs into a goal of the five-day convention.

title: CONCERN IS VOICED OVER CIVIL AVIATION
description: The prestige and political muscle of the aviation industry have eroded, many of its leaders say, since the time two decades ago when the jet engine revolutionized commercial air travel and recreational flying became a popular pastime.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS SEEK SPECIAL UNIT ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: Congressional leaders from both parties urged today that a special committee like the one used during the Watergate affair be set up to control the spreading investigation into the Administration's arms deal with Iran and funneling of funds to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Bridge; Top Fall National Pair Grew From Fraternity Card Table
description: Two New York experts who were fraternity brothers, and bridge opponents, at Duke University 15 years ago combined to capture a major title here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Jim Krekorian and Paul Kiefer, both Manhattan, revived their friendship two years ago, became partners, and now own the Life Master Men's Pair Championship.

title: End Diplomatic Ties With Kabul Regime
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. SAID TO THINK A SPECIAL PROSECUTOR FOR IRAN AFFAIR IS NEEDED QUICKLY
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are disturbed by the Justice Department's inquiry into the arms sales to Iran and believe a special prosecutor must be named quickly, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Jerome Cohen Is Dead; Former Dean of Baruch
description: Dr. Jerome Bernard Cohen, an economist who served as dean and acting president of the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York before retiring from academic life in 1971, died Saturday at his home after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander's Inc., operator of the department store chain, named Donald J. Trump and Robert S. Trump directors. The move follows the Trump purchase of a 20 percent stake in the company.

title: IOWA WINS ALASKA TOURNAMENT IN ROUT
description: Roy Marble scored 29 points and Jeff Moe added 26 as Iowa crushed Northeastern, 103-80, to win the ninth annual Great Alaska Shootout basketball tournament today.

title: RANGERS, PENGUINS TIE ONCE AGAIN, 2-2
description: It takes a lot of time and thought and anxiety to dismiss one coach and hire another. So perhaps it's not farfetched that when Phil Esposito sat down with Tom Webster to agree on a contract last week, he insisted on one unusual clause: no more overtime.

title: Hadassah Magazine Banning Cigarette Ads
description: Hadassah Magazine, with a circulation of 385,000, is banning cigarette advertising from its 72-year-old publication and will announce the fact as a full back cover in its January issue.

title: Lear Siegler's Chief Calm Amid Turmoil
description: Norman A. Barkeley, chairman and chief executive of Lear Siegler Inc., has had few quiet moments since taking the top post at the diversified aerospace, automotive and manufacturing concern in August. Within two months, the company retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for a possible restructuring, and on Oct. 31 received its first unsolicited takeover offer, from AFG Partners.

title: RIFT EXAGGERATED, U.S. PRELATES SAY
description: Key conservative and moderate bishops say tensions between the American Roman Catholic Church and the Vatican have been seriously exaggerated, with dissenters receiving far too much attention.

title: DISPUTE OVER DAY TO HONOR KING EMBROILS ARIZONA GOVERNOR-ELECT
description: More than a month before he takes office, Governor-elect Evan Mecham has become embroiled in a dispute over whether Arizona will celebrate an official holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as most states do.

title: NOW AT 20: REASSESSMENT IN A NEW ERA
description: The year was 1966, and the setting was a luncheon for the state commissions on the status of women in Washington. A small group of women attending the event tried to propose a resolution calling for the enforcement of a law prohibiting sex discrimination in employment; they were turned down. One of them, Betty Friedan, scrawled on a paper napkin the words ''National Organization for Women'' and then the notation ''To take actions needed to bring women into the mainstream of American society, now, full equality for women in fully equal partnership with men.''

title: CITY BEGINS USING TEACHERS TO TEACH TEACHERS
description: Seasoned New York City teachers will begin training their newest colleagues today in a pilot ''master teacher'' program being closely watched by education officials who are considering making it a permanent feature of the city's schools.

title: Retailers Have High Hopes for Weekend
description: When the results are tallied, retailers predict, sales for the first weekend of the Christmas shopping season will be 6 to 12 percent higher than last year.

title: How 'Bout Some Seconds?
description: When the committee choosing the site for its party's Presidential nominating convention travels around the country inspecting accommodations, members tend to be wined and dined generously by local officials, all of them anxious to leave a favorable impression of their community.

title: VOTING OUT SEAT BELTS IS FAULTED
description: When Dan Staples drives through town, he usually wears a seat belt. But when he went to the polls Nov. 4, Mr. Staples voted with the majority of Nebraskans to repeal the state's seat belt law.

title: ISRAEL AGREES TO ARBITRATION
description: Israel's Cabinet formally accepted an agreement with Egypt today to submit to arbitration their four-year-old dispute over the tiny coastal strip called Taba. A five-member international arbitration panel will begin deliberations next month in Geneva over the sliver of Red Sea beach, which Israel retained after withdrawing from the rest of Sinai in 1982.

title: Top Secret: Those On Parking Panel
description: The new management of the Parking Violations Bureau has a secret: the names of the people reviewing proposals for its most lucrative contract. With the conviction of Stanley M. Friedman and others on charges of using the bureau as a tool for personal profit, the agency's current team says it is eager to avoid even a faint whiff of impropriety.

title: U S West Sues Seattle
description: U S West Inc. said Friday that it was suing the City of Seattle, seeking an injunction, declaratory relief and damages. The suit contends that the city violated competitive bidding laws in its purchase of a telecommunications network. The company said it believed that Seattle plans to resell telecommunications services in competition with private vendors and spent $10 million more than necessary on a new system, greatly exceeding the city's needs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1986
description: Companies

title: Tennessee Youth Wins 1st Joseph Duell Award
description: The first Joseph Duell Memorial Scholarship, named for the New York City Ballet principal dancer who died in February, has been awarded to Eric Lindemer, a 17-year-old from Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Swedes Plan Soviet Project
description: The Swedish engineering concern Sandvik A.B. looks set to become the first Western company to start a joint venture in the Soviet Union under new rules encouraging foreign trade, a Sandvik spokesman said Friday.

title: New Waldbaum Phase For Hands-On Leader
description: In 1948, Ira Waldbaum quit business college to take charge of his family's six grocery stores in Brooklyn after his father became ill.

title: Airliner Is Stuck in Mud
description: A Western Air Lines Boeing 727 ran off a runway in thick fog and became stuck in mud at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport today after landing and slowing down.

title: Teen-Agers Face More Crime
description: Teen-agers are twice as likely as adults to be the victims of violent crimes, and most of the attacks are near schools by casual friends or relatives, according to a Justice Department study made public today.

title: THE JETS' 14-POINT COLLISION
description: WESLEY WALKER got the number of the vehicle that hit him. It was not a truck of a lineman or a van of a linebacker but the sleek sports car of a defensive back.

title: U.S. ENVOY DENIES DISCUSSING IRAN ARMS
description: Maxwell M. Rabb, the United States Ambassador to Italy, whose name has arisen in a court case involving the sale of arms to Iran, emphatically denied today that he had discussed Iranian arms or hostages with anyone.

title: SENEGALESE BRINGING AFRICAN ROCK TO THE GARDEN
description: For what is probably the first time in Madison Square Garden's history, a rock singer will step onstage tonight and sing for a full house in Wolof, a Senegalese tribal language. The singer is Youssou N'Dour, Senegal's reigning rock performer; with the 10 musicians and two dancers of his band, Super Etoile du Dakar, he is opening concerts for the British songwriter Peter Gabriel's tour, which plays the Garden tonight and tomorrow.

title: Sweepstakes Channel Sets Basic Cable Service
description: The Sweepstakes Channel of Fort Lee, N.J., is promoting itself as a new basic program service for cable TV.

title: UTILITIES EXPERT
description: Brig. Gen. Ephraim F. Jeffe, retired, a former official of Con Edison and the New York City Transit Authority as well as president of Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., of leukemia. He was 89 years old. As vice president of sales for Con Edison in the 1930's and early 1940's, Mr. Jeffe led a series of promotion campaigns to interest consumers in purchasing electrical appliances. He became an expert on public-utility rates and was an advocate of low rates to win new utility customers. He also urged low-cost appliances.

title: Someone Missing at Climax of the Peace March
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Misses Kick And 333 Complain
description: After missing the live showing of the field goal that gave Notre Dame a 38-37 victory over Southern California on Saturday, CBS received more than 300 telephone calls from angry viewers.

title: 2 Officers Suspended In Hit-Run Crash
description: Two police officers were suspended yesterday for leaving the scene of an accident involving their patrol car in Manhattan and for not being at their assigned post in Queens, the police said.

title: Ms. Moses Weds Jeffrey Manocherian
description: The marriage of Cynthia Marie Moses, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Moses of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y., and Jeffrey Manocherian, a son of Eskandar Manocherian and Bernice Manocherian, both of New York. took place yesterday. Rabbi David Posner officiated at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Nixon Papers to Be Made Public
description: About two million pages of White House papers that Richard M. Nixon once hoped to keep secret will be opened to public inspection Monday after a 12-year battle over them.

title: INSIDE
description: NOW's 20th Anniversary The National Organization for Women enters its third decade facing decisions about its focus and goals in a new era.

title: East-West Trade Gain
description: East-West trade rebounded in the first half of this year, paced by Soviet oil and natural gas exports to the West, a United Nations study said Friday.

title: Trade Pace Accelerated
description: World merchandise trade grew more rapidly in 1986 than previously predicted because of a sharp recovery in fuel exports, according to a report by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to be published Monday.

title: Terrier Is Best
description: An Irish-bred wire fox terrier, Ch. Galsul Excellence, who answers to the name of Paddy, today was gaited by Peter Green to best in show in a field of 2,040 dogs at the Boardwalk Kennel Club fixture in Convention Hall.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did a Dodger or Giant player hit the first home run in a major league game on the West Coast or was it a member of another National League team? Who was the first American League player to accomplish it?

title: MAYORS FEAR LOSS OF AID TO CITIES
description: The nation's city officials served notice today that they wanted a major role in the growing national debate on welfare to make sure other Federal urban programs were not eliminated in the process.

title: HOLIDAY IN NEW YORK: STUDENTS GORGE ON CITY LIVING
description: Tony Kaye needed a haircut.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1986
description: The World

title: Woman Dies in Fall From Brooklyn Roof
description: A woman who had apparently been living on the roof of a seven-story apartment building in Brooklyn plunged to her death yesterday morning, the police said.

title: People
description: * Kathleen McSherry and Norman Sherman promoted to senior vice presidents at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/New York.

title: SIKH EXTREMISTS HIJACK PUNJAB BUS AND KILL 24 PEOPLE
description: Four Sikh extremists hijacked a bus in a rural area of the Punjab today, ordered Hindu passengers off the bus and then shot them with submachine guns and revolvers. At least 23 men and women were reported killed and several others were wounded, according to Indian news agencies tonight.

title: Counting the Casualties
description: It seems unlikely to affect government policy, but word has come from Cambridge that faculty and students in the political science department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have organized a Reagan Survivorship Pool, with proceeds to go to the person who most accurately guesses the number of Administration officials who are discharged or who resign from Nov. 13, when the President acknowledged arms sales to Iran, to April 1.

title: Mild 1986 Hurricane Season Officially Is Declared at End
description: The mild hurricane season of 1986 officially ended today with only four tropical storms having become full-fledged hurricanes.

title: LIKELY SUCCESSOR SAYS FRIEDMAN FRIENDS CAN STAY
description: Assemblyman George Friedman, who is likely to be elected the new Bronx Democratic leader tomorrow, said yesterday that he would not oust Bronx Democrats close to the current county leader, Stanley M. Friedman, simply because they were under investigation.

title: IF EUROPE IS TO BE DEFENDED
description: The possibility of an agreement to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear weapons in Europe presupposes the ability of the United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies to finance enhanced conventional forces to take their place. One critical concern is how the West can create the economic climate necessary to support such a strategy.

title: Peru Proposal To Pay Debt
description: Peru has held preliminary talks with more than 20 of its 280 foreign bank creditors on repaying its debt in goods instead of cash, the nation's top debt negotiator said Saturday.

title: Despite an Outpouring of Friendship, Gandhi Stays Outside the Soviet Orbit
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's four-day visit to New Delhi, which ended Friday, was widely seen to have strengthened India's friendship with the Soviet Union. But there was no evidence that the two countries had advanced their military ties or lessened New Delhi's determination to look to the West for help in developing high-technology weapons systems.

title: 4-12 KNICKS SENDING OUT SIGNS OF 1985-86
description: Through 16 games last season, the Knicks were 4-12, well on their way to a injury-plagued year they hoped would soon be forgotten. That season was to be erased by one bouyed by the addition of a healthy Bill Cartwright, a talented rookie in Kenny Walker and a seasoned Patrick Ewing.

title: Carbide's Chief Also Chairman
description: Robert D. Kennedy, president and chief executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, was named chairman of the company yesterday, as expected. Mr. Kennedy, 54 years old, succeeds Warren M. Anderson, 65, who has retired after 41 years with the company.

title: Vice President Named By Bangladesh Leader
description: President H. M. Ershad appointed a Vice President today and dismissed the Home Minister in a major Cabinet shuffle.

title: MOUNT SINAI CHIEF EXECUTIVE ANNOUNCES HIS RESIGNATION
description: The president and chief executive of Mount Sinai Medical Center has announced his resignation, a spokesman for the hospital said yesterday.

title: 'Cavanaughs,' a Sitcom, Is Premiering on CBS
description: STARTING off with a wake, a sitcom could be asking for trouble, but ''The Cavanaughs'' - making its debut on CBS at 9:30 this evening - seems not to be terribly worried. Besides, this is an Irish wake, the kind you're supposed to enjoy. The multigenerational family in this particular television clan is Irish-American and is headed by a crusty old codger named - what else? - Pop Cavanaugh. Fortunately for Leonard Goldberg, Robert Moloney and Richard Corrall, the assorted producers, Pop is played by Barnard Hughes, complete with a brogue that stood him in good stead for his Tony Award performance in Broadway's ''Da'' several seasons ago.

title: CONCERT: PURCELL'S 'FAIRY QUEEN'
description: HENRY PURCELL would surely count among the greatest composers of opera if opera had gained an English foothold in time for him. Had he lived even to middle age he would have seen the London success of Handel in the early 18th century and would surely have responded with works that gave him fuller range than ''The Fairy Queen,'' which the 92nd St. Y Chamber Symphony presented Saturday night in a concert version.

title: BETWEEN CALIFORNIA'S 2 BIGGER PLACES, AN UPSTART
description: ''Sometimes,'' says Jim Gibbons, an executive of the Corbett Canyon Vineyards near here, ''I wonder if a lot of people in New York and back East understand that there's any land at all between San Francisco and Los Angeles.''

title: NEW PROJECTS HELP BUFFALO LIFT DOWNBEAT IMAGE
description: Winter here - nasty, brutish, but never short - is generally greeted with a grim, self-deprecating sort of humor. Thus, some people interpreted Santa Claus's recent arrival by streetcar as a sign that he was afraid that if he came by sled, he might get stuck in a snowstorm.

title: 3 TENNIS PROS LEAVE NIGERIA AFTER SAYING THEY SAW GOD
description: Three American tennis players, all born-again Christians, have been sent home after saying they saw God. The visions came after Bible-reading sessions that ended with their destroying their passports, cash and possessions, officials said today.

title: 'FRONT PAGE' A WELCOME HIT FOR JOHN LITHGOW
description: John Lithgow barrels through the crowd on the stage of the Vivian Beaumont Theater with the cocky snap and swagger of Al Capone on St. Valentine's Day - as though he owns Chicago and you don't. To Walter Burns, the bruising, manipulative editor Mr. Lithgow inhabits in ''The Front Page,'' the press room at City Hall is home territory, a place where your lieutenants had better come up with the goods and your competitors ought to be shot.

title: First Lady
description: Ballots start going out next week to the 150 or so racing writers and track officials who choose the Horse of the Year. And, as in several recent Decembers past, the voters will have cause to reflect on the meaning they give to the award, not because they're necessarily inclined to contemplation of the abstract, but because they'll otherwise be unable to perform their task.

title: 52 ARE KILLED IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: Fierce fighting continued today around Palestinian districts in Lebanon and the Palestine Liberation Organization called for an emergency meeting of Arab League foreign ministers to discuss the situation.

title: BBC Show Features The Argentine Tango
description: THE Argentine tango is back.

title: Tourists Flock to See Hawaiian Lava Flow
description: Thousands of residents and tourists flocked to the southeast side of the Big Island of Hawaii today to see the lava flowing from Kilauea Volcano into the ocean.

title: CARY GRANT, MOVIES' EPITOME OF ELEGANCE, DIES OF A STROKE
description: Cary Grant, the dashing former acrobat whose gift for sophisticated comedy made him one of Hollywood's greatest stars, died of a stroke late Saturday night in Davenport, Iowa, where he had been scheduled to appear in a fund-raising event. He was 82 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Laurie J. Citak Becomes The Bride of Scott Wolf
description: Laurie J. Citak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Citak of Flushing, Queens, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Scott Wolf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Wolf of Secaucus, N.J. Rabbis Ezra Finkelstein and James Michaels and Cantor Mark Kula performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.

title: Israeli Technician Gets Hearing in Treason Case
description: A former nuclear technician charged with treason for revealing Israel's atomic secrets was seen in public today for the first time since his disappearance from London two months ago and his arrest.

title: Lisa Berger Is Married To Dr. M. M. Amzallag
description: Lisa Helaine Berger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Berger of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Michel Meyer Amzallag, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moise Amzallag of Paris. Rabbi Robert Widom, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Rax, D'Arcy Parting Ways
description: After less than two years together, Rax Restaurants of Columbus, Ohio, and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/New York are going their separate ways. Split day is Feb. 20.

title: Talks Continue On Debt, Trade
description: BARBER B. CONABLE JR., president of the World Bank, flew 16 hours each way to Punta del Este, Uruguay, in October, to give a 10-minute speech.

title: Pilots Said to Get Treatment for Cocaine
description: Scores of commercial airline pilots have received treatment in clinics around the nation for cocaine addiction, a newspaper reported today.

title: British Phone Answer Is a Wrong Number
description: To the Editor:

title: A Buying Service's Challenge
description: ONE must assume that Donald B. Miller, a longtime advertising agency executive, has really taken to the life in a media buying service. As recently noted, he is about to become president and chief executive of Media General Broadcast Services.

title: Mudakhil in Iran, Then and Now
description: It's old, published in 1892, and thick, two fat volumes. Yet ''Persia and the Persian Question'' remains an indispensable guide to Iran. Would that America's most recent innocents in that country had better understood its lessons.

title: CHALLENGERS SEEK WAY TO ADD SPEED
description: Boat speed has become a preoccupation among would-be challengers for the America's Cup as defeat closes in on three-quarters of the fleet.

title: Pact Seen For Europa Programs
description: An executive of the five-nation, Dutch-based Europa television service that collapsed in debt last week said today that he had reached an agreement under which programs made for the unit would still be broadcast.

title: Judge Upholds Convictions Of Sect Leaders in Michigan
description: A Federal district judge has refused to overturn the convictions of seven leaders of the House of Judah on charges of conspiring to enslave children at an encampment the sect used in Allegan County in southwestern Michigan.

title: SOCIALISTS LEAD BASQUE VOTE, BUT ELECTORATE IS SPLINTERED
description: The Socialist Party emerged from elections Sunday as the leading party in the Basque region for the first time. But no party came close to winning a majority, and the region's political future was uncertain.

title: IN LEONARD'S MIND FIGHT HAS BEGUN
description: ''The best thing Marvin Hagler has going for him, his special quality, is that he's a proud champion. He's a rare breed. He loves his craft. He walks into the ring with the kind of vanity that a select few movie stars have. Not like some guys - certain heavyweights - who look like used cars.'' Ray Leonard on the world middleweight champion, March 1986, one and a half months months before Leonard declared he would come out of retirement if Hagler would agree to fight him. NOT long ago, in a dressing room one flight up at the Sugar Ray Leonard Boxing Center in Palmer Park, Md., images of Hagler fighting Roberto Duran flickered across a color television screen.

title: Let Corporate Takeovers Keep Rolling
description: Congress will compound the financial treachery of Ivan F. Boesky and Dennis Levine if it uses the insider trading scandal as an excuse to suppress ''raider'' takeovers.

title: Farm Bank Woes
description: More than 200 farm banks have more ''problem'' loans than capital, a rise of more than 50 percent since the end of 1985, according to the Independent Bankers Association of America.

title: IOWA TO WITHDRAWW FROM LIQUOR SALES
description: After more than 50 years, Iowa is giving up its attempt to discourage citizens from drinking liquor and is putting the retail liquor business into the hands of private enterprise.

title: SEOUL DISSIDENTS PLEDGE PEACEFUL COURSE
description: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean dissident leader, said today that despite the police suppression of a large anti-Government rally this weekend, the political opposition would follow a ''steady but peaceful'' course in pressing for democratic changes.

title: New York Milk Licensing Depends on Much More Than Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTESTERS IN TAIWAN BATTLE THE POLICE
description: Demonstrators battled the police today near the international airport here, hurling stones and demolishing 33 police cars before being repelled by tear gas and water cannon.

title: The Big Race
description: For an event that has never attracted a corporate or even a corpulent sponsor, let alone a fat television contract, the annual 5-kilometer run in upstate Skaneateles, N.Y., has proved enormously popular - a resounding, even rotund success for the fifth straight year. Why? Well, with not so much a world-class as a world-size field, the Short Fat Guys Road Race simply doesn't have much competition on the 5K circuit.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: WILANDER CRUISING AT HIS OWN PACE
description: No one has ever likened Mats Wilander to a Sunday morning preacher, a fist-shaking, crowd-stoking Elmer Gantry, eliciting shouts of hallelujah from an admiring courtside congregation. Rather, Wilander's passion for tennis is cloaked beneath layers of apparent indifference, a coverup that has helped him cope with expectations that are not necessarily his own.

title: MUSIC: VIVALDI AND HANDEL
description: THE Academy of Ancient Music under Christopher Hogwood brought Vivaldi and Handel to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. This program by the 10-member British ensemble promised an interesting contrast - six concertos from the first composer's ''Estro armonico'' against two cantatas by the latter -but Lynne Dawson's influenza forced her to abandon Handel's ''Armida abbandonata'' and substitute yet another, less taxing Vivaldi piece, the motet ''In furore.''

title: Treasury Offering Schedule Is Light
description: The supply of new Treasury securities will remain light for two more weeks. This week's financings are limited to today's regular weekly sale of new bills due in three and six months.

title: Dr. Mary Jumbelic Weds
description: Dr. Mary Jumbelic, a resident pathologist at the Northwestern University Memorial Hospital, and Dr. Marc J. Safran, a resident in ophthalmology at the University of Illinois Eye and Ear Infirmiry, both in Chicago, were married yesterday. Rabbi Donald Rossoff performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El of Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn. The couple's parents are Esther Jumbelic of Baltimore and the late Stephen Jumbelic and Mr. and Mrs. Martin Safran of Brooklyn.

title: Shamrock Further Cuts Its Stake in Foote, Cone
description: Shamrock Holdings, which at one point had Foote, Cone & Belding Communications worried about a takeover attempt, has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has once again sold off 100,000 shares of the agency's stock, bringing its holdings down to 4.4 percent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REMEMBERING HAROLD

title: 7-6 Plus 50
description: It was 50 years ago last week that New York University pulled off what is still regarded as the greatest college-football upset in the city's history. At the end of a season that had begun with a 60-0 loss to Ohio State and had included only four victories in eight games, all over weak teams, the wilting Violets blossomed into legend by defeating previously unbeaten Fordham and its Seven Blocks of Granite, 7-6, in a Thanksgiving Day game that drew 50,000 to Yankee Stadium.

title: ROCK: DAVID AND DAVID
description: ''WELCOME to the Boomtown, and all that money makes such a succulent sound,'' begins the chorus of one of the year's meatiest hit singles. Written by David Baerwald and David Ricketts, the Los Angeles-based duo who call themselves David and David, ''Welcome to the Boomtown'' offers the sort of insider's vision of Hollywood hedonism that groups such as the Eagles popularized in the late 1970's, but with a grittier post-punk edge.

title: THE MOOD OF WHITE HOUSE OFFICIALS: DESPAIR AS DAMAGE BUILDS
description: A senior White House official noted with irony recently how pleased some of President Reagan's staff members were when front-page reports appeared that reflected controversy over the President's decision to abandon the strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: Chevron's Angola Unit Copes
description: In the United States, his boss appears in satirical ''wanted'' posters charged with the crime of ''supplying $2 billion-plus of aid and comfort annually to America's Soviet enemy in Cuban-occupied Angola.''

title: ADMINISTRATION DRAFTS 3D PLAN FOR SCHOOL VOUCHERS
description: Education Department officials say they will propose letting school districts offer vouchers that parents can use to obtain federally financed remedial education for their children at a school of their choice if their own school's remedial help is not adequate.

title: AUDIT FINDS FARMERS IN WEST TRESPASSING ON FEDERAL LAND
description: Farmers in many Western states are trespassing on Federal land with impunity, growing crops, storing farm machinery and in one instance building five houses, Federal auditors have found.

title: LEADERS IN PRETORIA REJECT A PROPOSAL FOR REGIONAL POWER-SHARING
description: South Africa's white authorities tonight rejected a proposal for regional power-sharing that had been depicted by moderate blacks and whites as a potential model for racial cooperation to end the nation's crisis.

title: ALTERING UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
description: A month before he is scheduled to succeed Harry J. Gray as chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, Robert F. Daniell has already moved quickly to trim management jobs, reduce costs and dismantle the company's strategy of growth through acquisition.

title: Pittsburgh Paramedics Say City Rebuffed End to Strike
description: The union for almost 200 striking paramedics agreed late tonight to return to work without a new contract, but a union official said the city had refused the offer.

title: BIG BATTERY PARK CITY DREAMS
description: Battery Park City ranks as the largest and most-expensive real estate venture ever undertaken in New York City, more than twice the size of Rockefeller Center. But that does not satisfy Meyer S. Frucher, the president of the public development agency that oversees the project that lies along the lower edge of Manhattan's Hudson River shore. He wants to nearly double it. Like most successful land developers, Mr. Frucher, president and chief executive of the Battery Park City Authority, never stops dreaming up ways to start his next great project. He always wants more land to develop, more office towers to build and more people to live in the communities he creates.

title: Carter Hawley Silent on Offer
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the owner of Bergdorf Goodman Inc. and Neiman Marcus, said yesterday that it would not comment on whether it had responded to a $1.8 billion cash offer for the retailer made a week ago today.

title: U.S. Is Acting to Curb Spying
description: Without public announcement, President Reagan is carrying out a sweeping overhaul of the nation's defenses against foreign spies that calls for more than 100 security changes, White House and Congressional officials say. The chanaes range from improving the security of communications satellites to safeguarding doors at defense plants.

title: Doctor Is Critically Hurt By Trap Set for Burglars
description: A doctor who set booby traps after several burglaries at his home was in critical but stable condition today after being shot in the chest by one of the devices, the authorities reported.

title: Schmidhauser Captures Slalom
description: Corinne Schmidhauser of Switzerland won today's opening World Cup women's slalom race.

title: Account
description: * Arizona Biltmore Resort and Patchen Brownfeld Inc., Phoenix, have ended their relationship.

title: Michael Braude Dies; Writer and Publisher
description: Michael Braude, a writer and founder of the Quadrangle Books Inc., died Saturday of a stroke suffered at his home in East Hampton, L.I. Mr. Braude was 77 years old. He also had a home in Chicago.

title: Elisa Gottesman Is Bride Of Steven Leonard Kadish
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Elisa Gottesman and Steven Leonard Kadish, students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, were married by Rabbi George Finkelstein.

title: OPERA: 'PURITANI' AT THE MET
description: BELLINI'S ''Puritani'' ideally calls for four major vocal personalities - technically and artistically on the highest level, musically creative and impassioned - in the four principal parts. Joan Sutherland has been showing that it can get by on one, even when the one is in the autumn of her career, in recent weeks at the Metropolitan. Saturday afternoon her ''cover,'' Francoise Garner, made her regularly scheduled appearance in the soprano part, and, though she carried through creditably enough in her own terms, the opera does not work this way.

title: Risk Is Too Large
description: To the Editor:

title: California Fridge, New York Toaster
description: One of the lasting lessons of the energy crisis is the need for minimum energy efficiency standards for household appliances. Disclosure rules already in effect have done much to promote painless conservation. That's why formal standards are championed by almost everyone - economists, environmentalists, thrifty consumers, even by utility companies eager to avoid construction of new plants. Appliance manufacturers go along, too, worried that without national rules, they'll face a state-by-state balkanization of rules.

title: A LIGHTNESS OF HEART AND TOUCH
description: Cary Grant was one of those great Hollywood stars about whom it was seldom said that he could do anything. He could do a lot of things, up to a point, as the Hollywood community seemed to agree when it dutifully nominated him for an Oscar for his performance as the Cockney wanderer in the exceedingly poetic ''None but the Lonely Heart'' (1944).

title: Vendors: Good, Bad and Good-Bad
description: The most contentious issue in New York City is probably not capital punishment or abortion but street vendors. On this issue, however, given a little patience, it's possible to achieve reasonable remedies because it's possible to distinguish among vendors. There are good vendors and bad vendors, even good-bad vendors. But so far, the City Council and City Hall refuse to make and enforce the distinctions. What are they afraid of?

title: Balanced Trade
description: If the United States were to succeed in balancing its trading accounts in the next five years, Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, noted recently, it would mean much more rapid growth in industrial production - about 5 percent a year - than has been sustained for a long time. And the production would have to be in new and advanced products where the United States has an edge in world markets.

title: A HONG KONG DYNASTY WEATHERS THE STORM
description: Simon Keswick dislikes being photographed against the Hong Kong skyline. ''It's too Clavellian,'' he explained, wincing as he referred to the best-selling novels by James Clavell that loosely chronicle Mr. Keswick's clan and company.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 1, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Penn State Loses In Soccer Playoff
description: David Wells scored the game-winning goal in a shootout after two overtime periods today as Akron defeated Penn State, 2-1, in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: Liberal Leader Wins Party Vote in Canada
description: John Turner won a resounding endorsement today for his continued leadership of the Liberal Party at a national convention.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 1, 1986: *2*MONDAY Albertson's Inc Standard Products Cincinnati Bell *2*TUESDAY Alaska Air Group Flight Safety Intl Allen Group Inc JWT Group Inc Bristol-Myers Riblet Products Browning-Ferris Indus Southwest Gas Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Bay State Gas Pennwalt Corp Collins Food Intl Peoples Energy Corning Glass Works Starrett (LS) Co Federal Co Times Mirror Fieldcrest Cannot Inc U S Shoe Louisville Gas & Electric USF & G Corp Pacific Scientific Wynn's Intl *2*THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Kaiser Cement American Medical Intl SPS Technologies Atlantic City Elec Supermarkets Genl Brown Group Tektronix Inc Chrysler Corp Universal Leaf Tobacco Grubb & Ellis Witco Corp *2*FRIDAY Piedmont Nat Gas Univar Corp Roper Corp

title: BRITISH PHONE ANSWER IS A WRONG NUMBER
description: To the Editor:

title: Agriculture Dispute
description: American and European trade officials are glum about chances for settling a dispute over agriculture in which the United States has threatened to curb imports of European wine, beer, spirits and chocolate in retaliation for restrictions by Europe on American grains.

title: AQUINO ADDS BIT OF SWAGGER TO HER STYLE
description: A week after she dismissed Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, President Corazon C. Aquino has acquired enough new confidence to step out of her old image as reticent housewife and chide her male challengers.

title: Seven Rooms to Stay Closed In School Tainted in Cleaning
description: School officials decided today to reopen an elementary school, but to ban students from seven rooms found to have high levels of borax, which parents say has sickened their children.

title: POLAND'S UNION ALLIANCE CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT
description: Poland's union federation approved resolutions today criticizing the Government for not dealing more effectively with the country's economic, housing and environmental problems.

title: Becker Turns Back McEnroe
description: Boris Becker, ranked second in the world, stalled John McEnroe's comeback, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, today in winning the AT&T Challenge tennis tournament and the $150,000 top prize.

title: BEARS, IN OVERTIME, WIN DIVISION TITLE
description: Kevin Butler, who had missed a field goal near the end of the fourth quarter, redeemed himself with a 42-yard kick 3 minutes 55 seconds into overtime today as the Chicago Bears clinched their third straight National Conference Central Division title with a 13-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Arms Deal Condemned By Parliament in Iraq
description: The Iraqi Parliament condemned American arms shipments to Iran today as a ''dirty and very mean game'' that only fueled Iran's war effort against Iraq.

title: Reagan in the Woodshed
description: Look into the crystal ball. 1. An independent counsel will be appointed. After a decent investigative interval to demonstrate that the Justice Department is a professional organization, Attorney General Ed Meese will announce that evidence of enough wrongdoing has been uncovered, at a high enough level, to justify asking the courts to appoint a special prosecutor. 2. The President will appoint a prestigious and mediagenic chief of staff to replace the embattled Don Regan. Paul Laxalt and Howard Baker spring to mind; Drew Lewis might have problems with the acid-rain matters in the concurrent Deaver investigation. Timed to follow quickly on the naming of independent counsel, and coupled with the announcement of a new national security adviser to replace the scuttled Poindexter, this will give the President the appearance of contrition implied by a fresh start. 3. Fresh revelations by hard-digging reporters will give the scandal new impetus. The subject has achieved liftoff, and a bloodlust is in the air; during December, every major media organization will compete to get credit for the triumph over another secrecy-bedeviled White House. The Pulitzer Prize cannot be awarded to the Syrian press that first broke the arms-sales story. 4. The Democratic Senate will appoint its select committee in January. Televised hearings will create new household names; Daniel Moynihan, shunted aside in committee-chairman assignments so far, has made his bid for chairmanship with his ''Administration is tottering'' judgment; Democratic club members are pushing Sam Nunn, but Joe Biden's supporters see this as their dark horse's ticket to the White House. 5.

title: MONTANA CAUTIOUSLY PROCEEDS
description: If a normal human being underwent surgery to remove a herniated disk, he might spend a few weeks in the hospital, a few more weeks at home and a week or two in the Caribbean sun, take long walks and hot showers and, a few months after the fact, try gingerly to resume normality.

title: A Collection Bought; A Promise Protected
description: For many years, Moses Asch was a hero of the American folk music movement. He had founded Folkways Records, which gave a national audience to the likes of Pete Seeger, Woody Guthrie and Leadbelly, and he had kept his promise to the artists that anything recorded on the Folkways label would always be available to record buyers.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from utilization of loss carryforward of $99,000.

title: MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM SESSION WITH PRESIDENT'S PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday by John G. Tower, Edmund S. Muskie and Brent Scowcroft, members of a Presidential panel reviewing the National Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network: ...

title: MAJOR PERSONALITY STUDY FINDS THAT TRAITS ARE MOSTLY INHERITED
description: THE genetic makeup of a child is a stronger influence on personality than child rearing, according to the first study to examine identical twins reared in different families. The findings shatter a widespread belief among experts and laymen alike in the primacy of family influence and are sure to engender fierce debate.

title: PURCELL SAYS HE WILL LEAVE POST IN NASSAU
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, announced his retirement today. He said he intended to take a job that was ''an opportunity that comes once in a lifetime.''

title: 10,000 Brazilians Flee Town After Earthquakes
description: More than 10,000 people have abandoned a northeastern town struck by a series of tremors in the last two days, a civil defense spokesman said today. No one was reported killed, however.

title: Landing Plot Wins at $23.80
description: Landing Plot, the only New York-bred and the second longest price in the field of six, won the $40,000 Celtic Ash Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, narrowly beating the favored I Rejoice.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING SAYS HE WAS FORCED TO PARTICIPATE IN BURGLARIES
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who is accused of strangling a woman companion in Central Park and of participating in three burglaries last year, admitted his involvement in the burglaries almost a year ago, according to defense documents filed in Manhattan State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: SENATOR FAULTS U.S. VIEW OF ABM PACT
description: A Democratic member of the Senate Armed Services Committee asserted today that the State Department has provided Congress with an ''incomplete and misleading analysis'' of the negotiating record of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty.

title: U.S. TO DETERMINE IF VACCINE TEST IN ARGENTINA VIOLATED GUIDELINES
description: The National Institutes of Health began an investigation today to determine whether a biomedical research laboratory violated Federal guidelines when it tested a genetically engineered vaccine in Argentina last summer.

title: Chess: Women's World Champion Wins Match to Defend Title
description: Maya Chiburdanidze of the Soviet Union, the 29-year-old women's world champion, defended her title by defeating her compatriot, 25-year-old Elena Akhmilovskaya, in a match played half in Sofia, Bulgaria, and half in Borzhomi, U.S.S.R.

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: E.D.S.'S PROSPECTS IN THE AFTERMATH
description: When the General Motors Corporation purchased the Electronic Data Systems Corporation two years ago for $2.5 billion, it gave E.D.S. perhaps the most challenging project ever to face a computer company: unify G.M.'s huge but badly fragmented data-processing operations, from the showroom floor to the design laboratories to a sprawling network of auto-parts suppliers.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WITNESS DESCRIBES OFFICER'S SHOOTING
description: The former partner of a policeman who was shot in the neck and paralyzed in July in Central Park gave a graphic account of the shooting yesterday.

title: Navy Deal to G.E.
description: The Navy announced today that it had chosen the General Electric Company over the Grumman Corporation for full-scale engineering development of an automated system to help maintain carrier-based aircraft. No figures were announced, but published reports have indicated that the Consolidated Automated Support System could be worth $2 billion to its developer. G.E. and Grumman have been fighting for the go-ahead to develop the standardized equipment that will be used to maintain the Navy's carrier-based aircraft.

title: Tender Offer For Ponderosa
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, has begun a $27.50-a-share tender offer to buy all the outstanding shares of Ponderosa Inc., a chain of steakhouses and Mexican restaurants.

title: Sharon Steel Sale
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said it was negotiating to sell its Mueller Brass Company subsidiary to unidentified purchasers for about $55 million. Sharon, based in Miami Beach, said the Mueller deal was contingent on several conditions, including wage concessions from the United Steelworkers of America. Last year, Sharon lost $64 million on sales of $800 million.

title: 90% in Poll Back Patients' Right to Die
description: MOST Americans appear to believe that mentally competent adults should have the right to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment and that any patient's potential quality of life should be considered in deciding whether doctors should use extraordinary technological measures to prolong life, according to the results of a poll.

title: FINE GAME, FLAWED TELECAST
description: No matter what you think of CBS Sports, you must admit it is consistent. Its telecast of the Notre Dame-Southern California game last Saturday was flawed at the beginning and at the end.

title: Transportation Unit And City Get U.S. Aid
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and New York City were formally awarded $216.9 million in Federal aid yesterday for several major transit improvement projects.

title: Dow Off 1.69 After Strong Comeback
description: Concern about the Iranian arms sale controversy sent stock prices into a steep decline yesterday morning on Wall Street, but the market recovered much of the loss by the end of the session.

title: 2 Near-Misses Reported By Pilots in Chicago Area
description: Airline pilots today reported taking diversionary tactics to avoid mid-air collisions with small private aircraft over the Chicago area, a Federal official said.

title: EARLY TESTS DETECT TUMORS
description: Researchers have successfully tested an experimental method of detecting tumors that did not appear on X-rays, a physician reports.

title: A Miami Allegation
description: Amid calls for an independent inquiry into the shipments of arms to Iran and diversion of profits to the Nicaragua insurgents, there is growing interest in a somewhat related allegation: that top officials of the Justice Department, including Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, reputedly intervened last spring in a Federal investigation in Miami into the ostensibly private network supplying aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Pro Football Notebook; DOWHOWER GONE AS COLTS' COACH
description: Rod Dowhower became the latest coach to lose his job this season when he was dismissed yesterday by the Indianapolis Colts, who, at 0-13, are three losses away from becoming the losingest team in National Football League history.

title: PANEL OF CITY LAWYERS CLEARS STEISEL OF CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: Former Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel ''did nothing corrupt, unethical or improper'' when he was negotiating for the job he now has with the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Company, according to a city report released yesterday.

title: Ready, Set, Draw!
description: Such a total would even have them flirting with this list of the most frequently tied clubs in N.H.L. history.

title: Walking Right
description: In most places in America, traffic moves on the right. Cars do it. Boats do it. In most crowded cities people do it.

title: PARTNERSHIP RENEWS BID FOR LEAR
description: AFG Partners, intent on controlling Lear Siegler Inc., renewed its $1.51 billion bid for the aerospace and manufacturing conglomerate today in the event that a $1.7 billion acquisition agreement between the Wickes Companies and Lear Siegler falls through.

title: PEROT SAYS NORTH GOT HIM TO PUT UP RANSOM MONEY
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, said tonight that for the last five years he had put up ransom money in secret efforts with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to try to obtain release of various Americans held hostage abroad.

title: BELZBERGS' GTE STAKE IS REPORTED
description: The GTE Corporation disclosed late yesterday that the Belzbergs of Canada, who are active corporate raiders, had notified the company that they held a stake in the big electronics company.

title: SEMITIC SCHOLARSHIP
description: THE scholar Ephraim Isaac was arranging a meeting over the telephone with a reporter he had never seen before. They would meet in front of the big fireplace in the lounge of an inn here. And how would a stranger recognize Dr. Isaac?

title: Determining Motion
description: Even in this era of giant telescopes, infrared and ultraviolet telescopes, telescope arrays and telescopes in space, the business of estimating the distance of far-away objects remains astonishingly uncertain.

title: 7 TO BE CONSIDERED FOR APPEALS COURT
description: A list of seven candidates from which Governor Cuomo will fill an upcoming vacancy on the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, was submitted to him yesterday by the Commission on Judicial Nomination.

title: SURVIVOR IS CONVICTED OF MURDER PLOT AT JONESTOWN
description: A former member of the People's Temple cult was convicted today of conspiring to murder a Congressman who was killed in Guyana shortly before 913 members of the cult committed suicide in 1978.

title: DONORS SENDING EARLY GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: One of the first gifts to the 75th appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was given by Samuel Phillips of Manhattan.

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a one-time interest charge of $62,500 related to a prior financial commitment and a charge of $123,564 related to exploration property abandonments.

title: MUSIC: PARKENING ON GUITAR
description: CHRISTOPHER PARKENING'S smoothly played, warmly received evening of guitar music at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday touched on most of the instrument's historical points of interest. From Dowland's Tudor England through the age of the Baroque to Fernando Sor's summations of Classical style, Mr. Parkening went on to give us transcriptions of later music - Granados, Debussy, de Falla and Ravel included.

title: Lucky to Sell Car Parts Unit
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its Checker Auto Parts subsidiary for $155 million to the Northern Pacific Corporation, which is owned by Eddie and Julius Trump and operates 95 Schuck's Auto Supply stores in Oregon, Washington and Idaho.

title: At the Zoo
description: The Yuletide Season is upon us, and the National Zoo is looking forward to an outpouring of affection for creatures great and small, furry, finned and fanged.

title: JOHN A. BOHN
description: John A. Bohn, chief architect of Guam's legal system and co-editor of the Alaska state code, died here last Tuesday. He was 75 years old.

title: MTS SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Schooling Is Not Education
description: For more than 40 years, a controlling insight in my educational philosophy has been the recognition that no one has ever been - no one can ever be - educated in school or college.

title: STROBER ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are on a pro-forma basis.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
JUSTICES ARE TO CONSIDER SUIT OVER DRINKING AGE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if Congress can withhold some highway construction money from states that fail to adopt a minimum drinking age of 21.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $20,000 pre-tax loss on the sale of an investment. c-Net loss

title: HERBURT VIGRAN
description: Herburt Vigran, a veteran character actor who appeared with Ronald Reagan in the movie ''Bedtime for Bonzo'' and played on television shows ranging from ''I Love Lucy'' to ''Superman,'' died here Saturday.

title: DEALING IN NUMBERS
description: BACK in school, math was not a subject in which I shone, although there were aspects of it that I genuinely enjoyed. One reason for my difficulties with the discipline was that I couldn't play with numbers the way I could with words. A well-turned sentence was fun to produce, a rigorous proof less so. The advent of the electronic calculator and the personal computer did little to change my sentiments.

title: French Flock To Gobain Sale
description: Investor demand appeared strong today for the first stock flotation in the French Government's move to privatize state-owned enterprises, with banks predicting an oversubscribing for Saint-Gobain, a glass and building materials concern.

title: BALLARD FINDS LEAFS A VALUED PROPERTY
description: Harold E. Ballard was in fine fettle last week at a meeting of the stockholders of Maple Leaf Gardens Ltd. - alternately cantankerous, shrewd and charming.

title: Collaborative Program By 3 Choreographers
description: Three noted experimentalist choreographers will participate in ''Solo to Solo,'' an evening of collaborations at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, tomorrow through Sunday.

title: LE PEEP RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARRIS DEAL: QUESTIONS RAISED
description: Federal officials investigating insider trading on Wall Street are taking a close look at the takeover earlier this year of the Harris Graphics Corporation, in which Ivan F. Boesky was a large investor, according to a source close to the investigation. Other large investors in Harris included Drexel Burnham Lambert and several institutional clients that have worked closely with the firm.

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 18
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $270,000 for the latest quarter and $1,212,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 2, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DOZENS KILLED IN LEBANON BATTLES
description: Dozens of people were killed today in the eighth day of fighting between Shiite Moslem militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut and southern Lebanon, the police reported.

title: INSIDER ASPECT INFERRED
description: Guinness P.L.C., the brewer and one of Britain's largest companies, has apparently become a target of the British Government's widening inquiry into insider trading.

title: POLL RATING DIVES; DECISION FOR MEESE
description: President Reagan said today that if the Justice Department recommended it, he would welcome the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the diversion of millions of dollars to Nicaraguan rebels from United States arms deals with Iran.

title: USING A GRONK AND WAIL, AUDIOLOGIST STUDIES SIRENS
description: ''Rrrr-RRRR-rrrr,'' Dr. Thomas H. Fay intoned, his pitch slowly rising way up, then sliding way down. The audiologist, who heads the speech and hearing department of Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, was imitating a foe: the siren wail with which emergency vehicles rend the nerves of New Yorkers.

title: Ross to Leave Maryland
description: Bobby Ross, who had been given a deadline of yesterday to decide whether he would remain as Maryland football coach, has decided to resign effective Jan. 14, with three years remaining on his contract. The 50-year-old Ross cited several reasons for his decision, including promises he said he had been made, but not kept, on improvements to Byrd Stadium.

title: Latest Resorts Bid Is for $135 a Share
description: The Pratt Hotel Corporation has made its third offer to buy Resorts International Inc., this time at $135 a share, but a family trust that holds 44 percent voting control of the company said it was continuing its negotiations with other parties.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE SAFEST BLOOD: ONE'S OWN
description: WHEN Loretta Norrell's doctor recommended back surgery, he told her to donate blood ahead of time so that if she needed a transfusion she would get the safest kind -her own. In her hometown of Little Rock, Ark., Mrs. Norrell gave two units of blood that were shipped to New York to remain in the operating room during her surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Pension Issue Of Los Angeles
description: Los Angeles County is tentatively offering $460.3 million of pension obligation certificates through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: ACTION URGED ON OZONE
description: The United States today urged an international conference here to consider steps to freeze and ultimately eliminate production of chlorofluorocarbons and other chemical gases that deplete the atmospheric ozone shield. The ozone protects the Earth against harmful ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

title: Farmers of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy Manufacturing Is Pullman Target
description: The Pullman-Peabody Company, which makes equipment for trucks and trains, yesterday announced a takeover bid valued at $549 million for Joy Manufacturing, a mining equipment manufacturer based in Pittsburgh.

title: Reagan Calls Nixon As the Crisis Unfolds
description: President Reagan, trying to resolve the most serious crisis of his Administration, has conferred twice recently with former President Richard M. Nixon, whose own problems led to his resignation in 1974.

title: Chinese-Market Agency Starts Cognac Campaign
description: The Chinese community in New York should be well aware of Remy Martin's XO Cognac today after the advertising explosion it got yesterday through its new Chinese-market agency, L#3 Advertising.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEY RATES
Colleges Seeking Shoe Toehold
description: Even the heftiest salary can seem like so much small change to a major-college coach who keeps his eye on the financial ball. In addition to the radio and television contracts that have become an industry standard, coaches routinely sign lucrative endorsement agreements with equipment manufacturers, especially shoe companies. And, in a growing trend, basketball coaches have been demanding and receiving personal fees for taking their teams to holiday tournaments.

title: 'MAIN STREET,' VARIETY FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: TELEVISION for young people is at its best when it neither bursts with heartiness nor panders with false sophistication. ''Main Street,'' NBC's monthly series, gets it right. As Bryant Gumbel, the series host, says to a presumably teen-age audience at 4 P.M. today, this is ''a program designed especially for you.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Department of Justice investigation is continuing with my full support and cooperation, and if they determine an independent counsel is called for, I would welcome that appointment.'' - President Reagan. [ A14:4. ]

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MICROSIZE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POLL RATING DIVES; 46% APPROVE REAGAN'S WORK, DOWN 21 POINTS
description: President Reagan's overall public approval rating has plunged to 46 percent, from 67 percent a month ago, amid deep public concern over his Administration's arms deal with Iran and the funneling of funds to Nicaraguan rebels, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: DIAGNOSTIC MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Europe Backs Chips' Status
description: European Community finance ministers reached agreement today on measures to protect chips against unauthorized copying. The accord means European producers will be able to keep selling in the lucrative American market.

title: BRANDED PRO-POL POT: 30,000 UNWANTED REFUGEES
