description: Ravy Srey is only 27 years old, but he has been struggling for more than a decade to escape the bitter legacy of the Khmer Rouge.

title: Washington State Plans 8.878% Yield
description: The State of Washington yesterday tentatively priced a $168.8 million issue of general obligation refunding bonds with a maximum yield of about 8.878 percent for a 6 3/4 percent bond coming due in 2016 at a price of 98 1/2 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. SUNS, at Phoenix, 9:30 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.) SAN ANTONIO SPURS VS. CLEVELAND CAVALIERS, at Richfield, Ohio, 8 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS.

title: KEY WITNESS ALTERS PREVIOUS TESTIMONY IN FILM DEATHS TRIAL
description: A key witness in the trial of five men on charges of involuntary manslaughter in the 1982 filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' reversed himself today and supported a prosecution theory that a last-minute change in a helicopter's course preceded the crash that killed three actors.

title: Sakharov Is Reported To Shun Soviet Doctors
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, has refused to visit doctors in his place of exile in Gorky, asserting that they are not to be trusted because they allowed his medical examination to be filmed, his family here said today.

title: Both Sides in Manila Are Promoting the Truce
description: Defense Minister Rafael Ileto urged generals today to support a 60-day cease-fire with Communist rebels beginning next week, and the Communists vowed to ''faithfully implement'' the accord.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 8
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $774,000 for the quarter and $1,150,000 for the 9 months. c-After income of $10,877,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Kodak to Merge Atex and Eikonix
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would combine Atex Inc. and Eikonix Inc. to form a new unit, Electronic Pre-Press Systems, that would focus on high-volume electronic publishing applications.

title: RANGERS RESPOND TO RELAXED STYLE
description: The blackboard in the Rangers' locker room at Madison Square Garden is on the wall near John Vanbiesbrouck's dressing stall. On Sunday night the coach did not go near it, the players did not look at it until someone scribbled on it at the end of the night, ''Optional skate tomorrow.''

title: Board May Remove Book on Youth Sex
description: A Board of Education spokesman said yesterday that a book that stated there were ''no special medical dangers'' in anal intercourse would be referred to the curriculum division for possible removal from a reading list for students.

title: Business and the Law; Fear of Sharing Data Increases
description: THE many subpoenas issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the wake of its $100 million settlement with Ivan F. Boesky have touched off widespread fears of an S.E.C. manhunt that could ensnare dozens of people who dealt with the arbitrager - and stretch the laws against insider trading to new limits.

title: BACK ON THE STREET
description: Hubie Brown seemed to know it was over on Saturday, more than 24 hours before he received the news. One experienced Hubie-watcher caught him using the pronoun ''I,'' a word seldom heard around Hubie Brown teams.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Help for the Sexually Harassed A resolution calling for city-financed programs to aid women who have been sexually harassed by their landlords is to be discussed at a public hearing today before the City Council Committee on Women. 10 A.M., City Hall. Teen-Age Suicide A discussion of adolescent suicide prevention, led by the medical director of Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, N.Y., is to be sponsored by the local branch of the National Council of Jewish Women. It is open to the public. 5 to 7 P.M., 9 East 69th Street, Manhattan.

title: Paris May Bar A.T.&T. Deal
description: France is unlikely to sell its second-largest telephone switching concern, the state-owned Compagnie Generale de Construction Telephonique, to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company or any other foreign concern, ministry sources said today.

title: Carter Tender Bid Is On; Minimum Shares Cut
description: The group formed by The Limited Inc. and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation proceeded yesterday with its $55-a-share cash tender offer for Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., but it reduced the minimum amount of shares it was seeking in a bid to diminish the influence of the General Cinema Corporation, the largest shareholder.

title: CREATIVE COMPUTER APPLICAIONS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: TAIWAN OPPOSITION CANCELS 20 RALLIES
description: Taiwan's newly formed opposition party canceled plans today for 20 campaign rallies, a day after violent clashes erupted between opposition members and soldiers near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

title: IRANIAN PAYMENTS SHARED, AIDES SAY
description: Reagan Administration officials, saying that the Nicaraguan rebels had received less aid than reported by the Attorney General, suggested today that some of the money from Iran arms sales might have been diverted to anti-Commmunist insurgents in other countries.

title: FOR GIANTS: 15 PLAYS, 10 MINUTES, 3 SCORES, 1 VICTORY
description: Down 17-0 at the half, it was pretty evident what the Giants had to do.

title: PROSPECT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MEDCHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $97,227 for the quarter and $322,227 for the year.

title: PROTESTS IN INDIA AFTER BUS ATTACK
description: Rioting and strikes erupted in New Delhi and other northern areas today as Indians reacted with shock, grief and anger to the massacre on Sunday of 22 bus passengers by Sikh extremists.

title: Pet Dairy's Account
description: The Burton-Campbell agency in Atlanta has won an agency competition for the account of Pet Dairy's of Johnson City, Tenn.

title: Roger Smith's Active Tenure
description: Jan. 1, 1981 - Roger B. Smith takes office as chairman and chief executive officer of General Motors. Aug. 12 - G.M. buys 5.3 percent of Suzuki Motor Co. of Japan. March 25, 1982 - G.M. forms GMF Robotics, a 50-50 venture between General Motors and Fanuc of Japan that will develop and produce robots in the United States.

title: ALLISON'S PLACE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company went public in June 1986.

title: NOMINEE SUGGESTS A FUND DRIVE TO AID FRIEDMAN
description: Assemblyman George Friedman, who is expected to be elected Bronx Democratic leader today, has suggested that friends should consider raising money for legal fees for the convicted outgoing Bronx Democratic chairman, Stanley M. Friedman.

title: Pardee to Texas?
description: According to reports in two Texas newspapers yesterday, Jack Pardee, a former coach in the National Football League and the current coach of the Generals in the inactive United States Football League, is the choice to suceed Bill Yeoman at the University of Houston. If the reports turn out to be true, Pardee beat out candidates that included Jim Dickey, a former Kansas State coach; Lynn Amedee, the Texas A&M offensive coordinator; Larry Lacewell, the Arkansas State coach and athletic director; Wade Phillips, the Philadelphia Eagles' defensive coordinator, and Gary Mullins, a former Mississippi State assistant coach. The Dallas Times Herald and The Houston Chronicle said Pardee is expected to receive $100,000 annually.

title: Von Bulow Tested After a Collapse
description: Claus von Bulow, who was acquitted last year of trying to kill his wealthy wife twice with insulin injections, collapsed in the lobby of his apartment building yesterday and was admitted to New York Hospital for tests.

title: Grace Will Sell Home Centers
description: W.R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Channel and Central Region Home Centers in a leveraged buyout. A new company, Channel Home Centers Inc., will be headed by the management of the two divisions, including Leon Berger, who will be president and chief executive of the new company.

title: TOKYO'S OFFSHORE BANKING MARKET
description: An offshore banking market opened here today amid official praise but low expectations from the general banking community.

title: Zale Suitor's Plans
description: People Jewellers Ltd., bidding to acquire the Zale Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned to review Zale's operations after completing the deal and might sell some assets or change Zale's corporate structure.

title: Work at Home Invites the Exploiter to Come In
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HEAD OF SENATE BUDGET PANEL FEARS OVERHAUL PLAN WON'T WORK
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, the incoming chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, says he is worried that White House efforts to overhaul the Congressional budget process will be used to obscure the need to cut the Federal budget deficit.

title: Nimrod's Nemesis Stalks the Woods
description: VIN BERNSTEIN put his Dodge Ram Charger in low gear and began the steep drive up the mountain path. Deer season had come around again, and as usual he was hot on the trail of a pack of backwoods hunters.

title: A Mood of Gloom in the Corridors
description: The disclosures about weapons sales to Iran purportedly in exchange for the release of hostages have been a wrenching experience for many State Department officials.

title: F.B.I. to Investigate The Citadel for Racism
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that it had begun an investigation to determine if racial harassment at The Citadel had been committed, because of possible civil rights violations at the 144-year-old military college.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of land of $1,105,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: CITY COUNCIL CONSIDERS RISE IN MEDALLIONS
description: The number of taxi medallions would increase by 300 every year for the next six years under a compromise being discussed by members of the City Council, industry and Council officials said yesterday.

title: ISRAELIS ARE BAFFLED BY A REAGAN REMARK
description: Israeli officials said today that they were baffled by President Reagan's remark in a magazine interview suggesting that ''another country'' - apparently Israel - had overcharged Iran for weapons and then knowingly put the profits in bank accounts belonging to Nicaraguan rebel leaders.

title: RIDERS STRANDED AFTER BUS STRIKE AT BRONX LINE
description: A strike by 500 drivers, mechanics and other employees of New York Bus Service curtailed transportation for thousands of commuters and schoolchildren yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ray Knight, who didn't seem to be a big part of the Mets' plans in the spring and was the World Series most valuable player in the autumn, was overwhelmingly named the National League's Comeback Player of the Year by United Press International. . . . Rick Cerrone, assistant director of the news department for the baseball commissioner since 1982, is leaving to become the producer of a radio sports program aired by WNEW-AM in New York. . . . Chris Nilan, the Montreal Canadiens right wing, has been fined and suspended for three games by the National Hockey League, which announced fines of $14,300 for a brawl between the Canadiens and the Boston Bruins on Nov. 20. Nilan received the suspension for striking Ken Linseman. . . . The Detroit Lions claimed the offensive tackle, Eric Sanders, on waivers from the Atlanta Falcons.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING CLIMBED 1.6% IN OCTOBER
description: Construction spending jumped 1.6 percent in October, the biggest increase in 10 months, as builders rushed to complete projects before the new tax law takes effect, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Why and How to Raise New York Auto Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1986
description: The World

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Buying a Home Found Easier
description: An index measuring the ability of a typical family to buy a home rose to its highest level in more than eight years in October, a real estate trade group said today. The National Association of

title: PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Let the Viewer Control Courtroom TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Santa Fe Reaches Pact With Union Pacific
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation and the Union Pacific Corporation yesterday announced a far-reaching agreement to exchange trackage rights on major routes in the southern corridor of their railroads.

title: CMO Trust Obligations Sold Abroad and in U.S.
description: A six-part $500 million issue of fixed- and floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations was offered yesterday by CMO Trust 16 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. About $296.75 million of the floaters will be offered in the Euromarket.

title: 2 Time Inc. Officers Will Exchange Jobs
description: Kelso Sutton, the architect of Time Inc.'s magazine efforts for the last six years, will exchange jobs with Reginald K. Brack Jr., the head of Time's book division, the company said yesterday.

title: Bad News Bears
description: A sign put up Sunday at Soldier Field by fans of the Chicago Bears, who have scored fewer than 20 points in six of their last seven games: ''Offense, we're going to the Super Bowl. Are you coming along?''

title: Chairman Resigns Post At Bank Leumi Trust
description: Ernest I. Japhet has resigned as chairman of the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York in the wake of an Israeli banking investigation that forced him to leave earlier this year as head of the parent, Bank Leumi le-Israel.

title: Jim Johnston's President To Set Up Own Agency
description: Stephen R. Seiter, for a year the president of Jim Johnston Advertising, has left to set up his own agency. Going with him are three accounts that he was responsible for delivering to J.J.A., and together they bill some $5 million.

title: Blast at Mississippi Arsenal
description: An explosion and flash fire ripped through the Mississippi Army Ammunition Plant today, injuring five workers, but the blaze was immediately extinguished, officials said. Capt. Jason Annitto, a plant spokesman, said the explosion was apparently caused when a spark touched off a propane gas leak at 8:15 A.M.

title: Duties Sought On TV Tubes
description: Four trade unions said today that they had asked the Government to impose duties on color television picture tubes from Japan, Canada, Singapore and South Korea reportedly being sold here for less than cost.

title: United Banker Bid
description: United Banker Inc. said it had told the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and BancTexas Group Inc. that it would end its proposed acquisition of four BancTexas banks in the Houston area. The F.D.I.C. had said on Nov. 20 that it was not willing to provide the amount of aid United Banker had sought for the acquisition. At the time, the company said it would proceed, but it said today that it would drop the bid.

title: D H HOLMES CO., LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After the recovery of $4,254,000 in surplus assets from the company's terminated pension fund this year for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a net gain of $1,584,000 from sale of property.

title: Books: Like Wolves
description: RETAKING THE PHILIPPINES: America's Return to Corregidor and Bataan; October 1944-March 1945. By William B. Breuer. Illustrated. 284 pages.

title: CRESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
BRITAIN PROPOSES ENDING ULSTER LAW
description: The British Government today proposed repealing one of the more volatile factors in the province's strife, a law regulating display of flags and emblems.

title: GALAXIES REPORTED MOVING AT HIGH SPEED
description: THIS galaxy and its thousands of neighbors in a gigantic portion of the universe appear to be streaming across space at speeds of more than 400 miles per second, a group of astronomers has found.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''IT seems like a dirty word now, but I was involved with arbitrage,'' Josie Natori, president of the lingerie company that bears her name, said last week in her midtown showroom. Mrs. Natori, a Philippines native, became an investment banker at the age of 21, working in brokerage and arbitrage, which is speculation in the stocks of companies that are takeover targets, before becoming one of the first women to be a vice president at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. She left Wall Street nine years ago, moving from a field some now consider notorious to one she has dubbed ''natorious.''

title: PRECISION TARGET reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $91,000 and $93,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Treasury Issues Edge Up
description: Discount rates of Treasury bills edged up slightly yesterday at the weekly auction.

title: SHOWDOWN AT GENERAL MOTORS
description: Few executives have been longer on vision and more plagued by reality in recent years than Roger B. Smith, the embattled chairman of the General Motors Corporation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centerre Bank, St. Louis, elected to its board Andrew E. Newman, chairman of Edison Brothers Shoe Stores Inc.

title: L.I. MAN ACCUSED OF NAZI ATROCITIES LOSES APPEAL
description: The Supreme Court today turned down the last appeal of Karl Linnas, a Long Island man facing deportation to the Soviet Union, where he has been condemned to death for his reported role in Nazi executions and abuse of Jews and other prisoners.

title: Shifted Precinct Commander Retires After Being Demoted
description: A former commander of the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, reassigned last year during an undercover investigation of police corruption, retired yesterday after being demoted to captain, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Coca-Cola Company said the recent public offering of 51 percent of its bottling unit had resulted in a pretax accounting gain of about $376 million in the value of the 49 percent it retained.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
VERTEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
SALE OF MANET WORK SETS RECORD FOR PERIOD
description: Edouard Manet's ''Rue Mosniers With Street Pavers,'' a masterpiece in the artist's full Impressionist style, was sold yesterday at Christie's in London for a record at auction for an Impressionist painting, and the second-highest price ever paid for a painting of any period.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF WETLANDS ON STATEN ISLAND AND IN NEW JERSEY
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS BEND AS BREAKS GO THE OTHER WAY
description: In the world of the Jets - at least, according to Coach Joe Walton today - the end is not at hand.

title: PEROT IS REMOVED FROM G.M. BOARD, BUT HAS BIG PROFIT
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who was the largest stockholder in the General Motors Corporation, was ousted from G.M.'s board of directors today after months of bickering with top executives of the world's largest auto maker.

title: Ariane Rocket Reported To Have Exploded
description: The third stage of a French Ariane rocket exploded in orbit Nov. 13, nine months after launching, creating a cloud of debris that poses a potential threat to other satellites, the magazine Aviation Week & Space Technology reported Monday.

title: DOLLAR HITS 6-YEAR LOW AGAINST MARK IN EUROPE
description: The dollar firmed yesterday in moderately active domestic trading after it fell to a six-year low against the West Germany mark in Europe over concerns about the implications of the Iranian arms scandal.

title: TRACING LOST ROYALTIES: A WHITE KNIGHT OF ROCK
description: When Chuck Rubin hears a rock oldie, it's likely to remind him of battles won, letters to be written or research to be completed. Through the 1980's, Mr. Rubin has been helping the performers who shaped rock-and-roll to receive what their songs have earned.

title: MEDINET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuomo Ends 1986 Campaign With a Surplus of $4 Million
description: Governor Cuomo ended his easy re-election race against Andrew P. O'Rourke with a surplus of almost $4 million that could help finance a Presidential race, aides reported today.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes after-tax LIFO charges of $97,000 for the quarter and $305,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes after-tax LIFO charges of $145,000 and $413,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Sweating the Worker
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Hole at Work
description: Two Ohio State University astronomers have pieced together what they believe to be the first blow-by-blow record of a black hole devouring a star.

title: Careers; Year-End Concerns On Benefits
description: AS the new year approaches, there are more than the usual number of potential worries for many employees: lower pay increases, higher inflation, the loss of pension benefits due to job changes and higher health costs.

title: POSTMASTER GENERAL FILES PLAN TO KEEP HIS STOCK IN LOEWS
description: Preston Robert Tisch, the new Postmaster General, will keep his stock in the Loews Corporation and remain on its board of directors as a nonvoting member, according to a conflict-of-interest disclosure plan to be filed with the Federal Government.

title: To Rent or Not to Rent U.S. Offices
description: In the 1960's, when Federal programs proliferated and the Federal work force swelled, the Government began a relatively new practice of renting office space for its employees.

title: U.S. NOW REASSESSING IRAN ARMS-SMUGGLING TRIAL
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan obtained an unusual 10-day court delay yesterday to reassess a case against 18 defendants who planned to sell arms to Iran.

title: Alcoa Cuts Back Smelting Volume
description: The Aluminum Corporation of America has shut down 39,000 metric tons of aluminum smelting capacity at a plant in Massena, N.Y., and trimmed another 40,000 metric tons of capacity at Alcoa, Tenn.

title: YOUNG AND UNWED: NEW FOCUS ON THE FATHERS
description: It was the regular Monday night meeting of what is known as the Young Fathers Program. A film on birth control was cued, and a round of introductions was about to begin. In its measured way, this was New York City's attempt to deal with the one participant often absent from the national debate about illegitimate children - the father.

title: CARNEGIE'S ALLEGRO FACELIFT: PAST LIVES
description: The discordant tones of banging hammers and slapping plasterers' trowels still fill the space that rightfully belongs to music, but Carnegie Hall is beginning to re-emerge.

title: Advertising; Marketing Shoes for Marching
description: JONATHAN FARBMAN is a man of intense interests. He has been a racing car driver and a bicycle racer. In the agency business, which he entered after a short turn with the family plumbing company, he made the unusual switch from account man to copywriter. He loves classical music.

title: Cyprus Police Officer Slain
description: An assistant police chief was shot dead by an unknown assailant ouside his home tonight, the first senior police officer to be slain in Cyprus since the island gained independence in 1960. The officer, Pandelis Frydas, 52 years old, formerly headed the criminal investigation department of the Limassol police and was recently promoted to assistant police chief of the island's westernmost Paphos district.

title: HUNGARY IS CLOSING UNPROFITABLE BUSINESSES
description: Just after dawn the other day, two black Mercedes sedans pulled up at the Red Star foundry, delivering high-ranking officials who had come to hear complaints of workers about to lose their jobs.

title: Brother of Fugitive Charged in Robbery
description: The brother of Larry Davis, the man sought in the shooting of six police officers last month in the Bronx, has been charged with a Suffolk County robbery, the police said.

title: STAGE: 'SAY GOODBYE,' A STORY OF FAMILY LIFE
description: FACED with tragedy, some people manage to cope while others can only escape. It is a sign of Mary Gallagher's artistry that in her plays she can make us regard both reactions with empathy. In works that range from ''Father Dreams'' to the current ''How to Say Goodbye,'' there are no villains, not even home wreckers, only people tested for endurance.

title: SWISS COMPANY CALLS DEALINGS LEGAL
description: The chairman of a Swiss finance company thought to have played a role in the Iran arms deal said today that his company had done ''nothing illegal, nothing outside the activity of a fiduciary company.''

title: Slayings and Mass Suicide
description: The news flashed out of Georgetown, Guyana, on Nov. 19, 1978, that an American Congressman and several members of his party had been shot and killed in a remote area of Guyana. Over the next few days it would be learned that 913 people had died in a mass suicide at a religious commune after the shooting of the California Congressman, Leo J. Ryan.

title: MUSIC: JORGE BOLET AT THE PIANO
description: JORGE BOLET is a master of pianistic technique - by which is meant not the loud-hard-fast barrages into which so many technical display pieces have been allowed to degenerate, but rather a full palette of expressive choices made possible by the fingers' capacity to respond to the musical imagination under however difficult conditions. His variety of touch, and security of control at the lower dynamic levels that are risky for less accomplished pianists, allow him to achieve what used to be thought of as a ''singing'' tone at the keyboard. As he ''sang'' the alternately doleful and sunny songs of Liszt's ''Venezia e Napoli,'' which closed his program at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon, one could hardly want more.

title: U.C.L.A. UPSETS N. CAROLINA, 89-84
description: Reggie Miller scored 21 of his 32 points in the second half tonight as U.C.L.A. held on to upset North Carolina, 89-84.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NEVER SATISFIED. A Cultural History of Diets, Fantasies and Fat. By Hillel Schwartz. Illustrated. 468 pages. The Free Press. $19.95.

title: LOADMASTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: KEMP CAMP SETS UP PRESIDENTIAL COMMITTEE
description: Advancing Jack F. Kemp's bid for the White House a step further, supporters of the New York Representative announced today the formation of the Jack Kemp for President Exploratory Committee.

title: REAGAN'S REMARKS TO HIS INVESTIGATIVE PANEL
description: Following is a transcript of remarks today by President Reagan to a Presidential panel reviewing the National Security Council, as provided by the White House, and a subsequent exchange with reporters:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOVIES AT THE PUBLIC The Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place, has become one of the city's more established revival houses, but with trimmings that make it somewhat different from others of the breed. At the Public, which is best known as a legitimate theater, an important role is given to film, with an eclectic schedule of works that perhaps could not succeed in general release. Occasionally, a new film or a foreign film that has not appeared in New York is presented, but most offerings in the Film at the Public series are revivals with a special twist.

title: 'As if We Were Free'
description: Life in Poland goes on. There isn't much news, which some Poles say is a good sign that things aren't so bad, and others say is a bad sign of how glum and depressing things have become. Even the usual daily supply of fresh, tart political jokes seems to have narrowed to a trickle.

title: GENE GOTTI CALLS BROTHER A 'POWERHOUSE' OF MOB
description: Gene Gotti was heard on a tape recording played yesterday in court referring to his brother, John Gotti, as a ''powerhouse captain'' in the Gambino crime family.

title: Florida Road Unit Offers Refunding
description: A $134.56 million general obligation refunding by the Broward County Expressway Authority in Florida was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber.

title: Utility Takes Loss
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana said it would take a $140 million charge in the current quarter to cover losses related to its Marble Hill nuclear project near New Washington, Ind.

title: TENNIS UNIT LOOKS INTO NIGERIA INCIDENT
description: A spokesman for the Men's International Professional Tennis Council said yesterday that the Council's administrator, Marshall Happer, would ''look into'' an incident involving three American players at a satellite series tournament in Lagos, Nigeria, last week.

title: HISTORIANS TO HELP MARK YEAR 200 OF CONSTITUTION
description: While the official Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, headed by former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, is monitoring cultural programs and weighing commercial tie-ins for next year's celebration, an unofficial organization called Project '87, run by a small group of the country's leading historians and political scientists, has been quietly at work for nearly 10 years. It is telling the public about the significance of the Constitution today.

title: UNILEVER SETS DEAL FOR POND'S
description: Unilever N.V., the British consumer products company, said late yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. for $3.1 billion in cash, or $72.50 a share.

title: ONE QUARTER BUYS PLAYOFF TICKET FOR GIANTS
description: The Giants pulled another victory out of the hat tonight, their sixth straight triumph, and clinched at least a wild-card berth in the National Football League playoffs.

title: MARINE LOOKS BACK ON BEIRUT BOMBING
description: Jeffrey Nashton scrawled ''Semper Fi'' abbreviating the Marines' motto, as he lay wounded in a military hospital after the bombing of a barracks in Beirut, Lebanon. For his countrymen, it made him a symbol of the corps' fighting spirit.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
President Reagan and His Operators
description: Against news of a startling plunge in his popularity, President Reagan has gone from blaming the press for the Iran arms scandal finally to some constructive steps to end it.

title: BALLETS COMMISSIONED BY CITY ARTS FESTIVAL
description: A ballet based on the life of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., to be choreographed by Arthur Mitchell and Billy Wilson, is one of several major works commissioned by the first New York International Festival of the Arts. Details of the festival, a citywide event scheduled to run June 13 through July 11, 1988, were announced yesterday at Gracie Mansion by Martin E. Segal, the festival's chairman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Syracuse 82, George Washington 69: Greg Monroe scored 8 points in the first four and a half minutes of the second half as Syracuse used a pressing full-court defense to overcome a 3-point halftime deficit and pull away from George Washington last night at Syracuse. Monroe hit two 3-point field goals and another long jumper as Syracuse reeled off a 15-2 streak to turn a 36-33 deficit into a 48-38 advantage with 15 minutes 30 seconds to play. (AP) Cleveland St. 135, Clarion 61: Clinton Ransey fired in 28 points and Ken McFadden added 24 for Cleveland. The victory broke several school record's for Cleveland State, including the most points scored, breaking a record of 118 set last season. (AP) Wagner 88, Staten Island 71: The Wagner center, Largest Agbejemisin, scored a career-high 23 points and pulled down 18 rebounds and Terrance Bailey added 20 points for Wagner. Staten Island (0-2) got 20 points from Jay Zieris, 18 from James Long and 17 from Stephen Karische and trailed only by 36-33 with three minutes remaining in the half. But Agbejemisin and Bailey helped push the lead to 85-61 with 4:35 remaining. (AP) Manhattan 73, St. Francis (N.Y.) 59: Bill Wheeler registered 20 points to lead three scorers in double figures for Manhattan as the Jaspers (1-1) won for the first time in a 10-game span. Darrwin Purdie tallied 19 points for St. Francis (0-2), which trailed at home at the half, 36-29.

title: BOLIVIA DRUG TRAFFIC BUILDS AGAIN AS AMERICAN TROOPS WITHDRAW
description: With the departure of United States troops, who spent four months helping to search out clandestine cocaine laboratories, narcotics experts say the drug has begun to make its way out of Bolivia again.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES SOUTH KOREA FOR THWARTING OPPOSITION PROTEST
description: The United States criticized the South Korean Government today for thwarting an opposition demonstration over the weekend.

title: L.S.U. Candidate
description: The Louisiana State University Athletic Council recommended Mike Archer, the L.S.U. defensive coordinator, yesterday as the successor to Bill Arnsparger, who is resigning Jan. 1 as L.S.U.'s head football coach. If the L.S.U. board of supervisors accepts the recommendation when it meets Friday, Archer, who is 33 years old, would become one of the youngest head coaches in major college football. . . . ''I fully expect to be at Miami in 1987,'' said Jimmy Johnson, the coach of the Hurricanes.

title: Hammer and Tongs
description: The Senate Press Gallery is usually quiet this time of year, with most legislators home for the holidays.

title: Bridge: Fall Board-a-Match Series Moves Into Final Sessions
description: The teams in two major championships were in hot competition going into the final session at the American Contract Bridge League Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: Market Place; G.M.'S E STOCK: ANALYSTS WARY
description: THE class E stock of the General Motors Corporation has often shown wide price swings - it rose 93 percent in 1985 - but its sharp decline yesterday reflected an executive suite conflict at the world's largest automotive company.

title: PESKY ENTREPRENEUR: HENRY ROSS PEROT
description: He has never been able to keep quiet. Perhaps that should have warned everyone that the maverick and the auto giant were not going to make it together.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1986
description: Upheaval at General Motors

title: Trade Official Talks on Japan
description: A top Reagan Administration trade official raised the prospect today of new American trade restrictions on Japan, saying that nation could not afford ''an angry America slamming the door shut to its products.''

title: Bomb Scare in Los Angeles
description: A bomb threat forced more than 200 people to leave Delta Airlines Flight 810 to Cincinnati shortly before takeoff at midday Sunday. Bomb-sniffing dogs found no explosives and the jetliner left after two hours, officials said.

title: Man Pleads Guilty In Pennsylvania Killing
description: The man accused in the hammer slaying of a millionaire restaurateur, George Keys, surprised a Bucks County courtroom today by changing his plea from not guilty to guilty shortly before his trial was to begin.

title: Softness and Cloth
description: What makes one kind of cloth feel better against the skin than another? Scientists at Yale University have studied the comfort of fabrics at different temperatures and humidities. In the experiments, male volunteers sat on webbed lawn chairs in an environmental chamber.

title: ADJUSTMENT PERIOD DRAGS ON FOR NETS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 1 -

title: Mexico Seeks Japan Aid
description: Mexico's President, Miguel de la Madrid, today asked Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, for increased Japanese investment in Mexico, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. Mr. de la Madrid arrived in Japan Sunday for a five-day state visit.

title: COAST BANK BRACING FOR HOSTILE BID
description: The BankAmerica Corporation began bracing yesterday for any hostile takeover efforts by the First Interstate Bancorp.

title: Poetic License
description: An apparently private automobile parked with equally apparent impunity in a tow-away zone on Connecticut Avenue the other day had an interesting license plate: FUZZ 2.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The share earnings were retroactively adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock distribution effective Feb. 3, 1986.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: Mark Moffett, Theodore H. Shaine and Helayne Spivak, associate creative directors, have been elected senior vice presidents at Ammirati & Puris.

title: TOP COURT DENIES APPEAL OF WEST SIDE CHURCH ON LANDMARK STATUS
description: In a disappointment for many religious groups in New York City, the Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge by a Methodist congregation to the city's designation of its Upper West Side church as a historic landmark that cannot be rebuilt without a special permit.

title: RECITAL: TREBLE SINGERS
description: THE New York Treble Singers, a choir of 12 female voices under the direction of Virginia Davidson, covered the territory of ensemble music for high voices from the madrigalists through Brahms (who directed women's choirs for a time) to Stravinsky, Britten and Louise Talma on Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. It's a well-disciplined group, with well-nourished and healthy-sounding voices.

title: Wade Williams, Consultant For Arts and Dance Groups
description: Wade Williams, a dance administrator and consultant, died on Nov. 9 at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BOWATER INSTRUMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of White Technology Inc. on a pooling of interests basis.

title: INSIDE
description: Barricades at BankAmerica The board of directors at the BankAmerica Corporation acted to thwart a possible hostile takeover effort by First Interstate Bancorp.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an increase of $160,000 and $481,000 from adoption of a change in pension accounting for both periods; the quarter includes a reduction of $137,000 from the elimination of fedeal investment tax credits, and for the 9 months includes a pre-tax charge of $1,700,000 related to the company's successful takeover defense against an unsolicited tender offer from Baron Capital Inc. in April.

title: 3 LAWSUITS LATER, NIXON'S FILES OPEN
description: After a dozen years of contention, including three lawsuits to block the release, the National Archives today made public the first 1.5 million pages of 40 million pages of White House documents from the Nixon Presidency.

title: PERU SEES HIGH GROWTH
description: The Government forecast today that Peru's gross domestic product would grow about 7.8 percent this year, its highest rate in 12 years. The central bank said that last year's growth in the total value of goods and services produced amounted to 1.9 percent.

title: PICKING THE YEAR'S BEST
description: DECEMBER means Christmas shopping, and this year many people are shopping for computers. Unfortunately, the computer marketplace seems to be more confusing than ever, with a baffling array of products to choose from. Even Santa Claus might have trouble deciding which products are naughty and which are nice.

title: The Importance of Wetlands on Staten Island and in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Northview Picks Acting Chief
description: The Northview Corporation, a California-based hotel chain once controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager, announced yesterday that it had named Dante C. Fabiani acting chairman and acting chief executive.

title: 4 Delaware Inmates Escape Using Prison Sewer System
description: Four inmates, including two convicted of murderer and one convicted of rape, cut their way through a steel-reinforced window and escaped through a prison sewer system today at the Delaware Correctional Center, the authorities said.

title: REFORM-SCHOOL REPORT
description: IT costs approximately $30,000 a year to keep a juvenile offender in reform school, about twice as much as sending a student to an Ivy League college. In theory, reform schools are educational institutions; in practice, there are serious questions about how much effective teaching takes place in what are called correctional institutions.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What prevents an igloo from melting inside? A. Eskimos build their igloos of large blocks of ice shaped into a dome. Small openings between the blocks are filled with snow.

title: Saints Waive Moore
description: The New Orleans Saints yesterday waived Derland Moore, the defensive lineman who outlasted five head coaches and became a favorite of fans over 14 years with the team. Moore played in 169 games for the Saints, most by any player in the 20-year history of the franchise.

title: AN UPSTATE MURDER IN 1983 IS REPORTED LINKED TO IRAN ARMS SMUGGLING
description: A slain businessman whose body was found in an upstate New York lake in 1983 was apparently involved in procuring contraband arms for Iran, a former State Police investigator said yesterday.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADER IN SENATE ASSERTS IRAN-NICARAGUA AFFAIR HURTS G.O.P.
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the departing Republican majority leader, said today that the Republican Party was beginning to suffer political damage from the Reagan Administration's sale of arms to Iran and the transfer of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Reagan Can Still Rebound
description: Grim as things look, we do not yet know how badly President Reagan has been damaged by the Iranian scandal. Assuming that investigations do not reveal that he was much more directly involved than has been indicated so far, the President still has a chance to restore order and regain his position. The American people will not tolerate an attempt to dissemble or cover up, but they generally forgive mistakes.

title: BARING THE SHOULDERS FOR WARM WEATHER
description: Shoulders are back. Not the broad, heavily padded shoulders that could make even a slender women look like a football linebacker, but naked shoulders framed in taffeta, crepe or jersey.

title: DANCE: PLAYERS' PROJECT
description: FOR many, Anna Sokolow represents the heart and conscience of the dance world, and her convictions about the art and discipline of dance have offered standards to several generations of dance and theater students. The enduring timeliness of her social concerns was made evident on Saturday night, when Ms. Sokolow's Players' Project performed ''Ellis Island,'' a dance about immigrants who found homes in America early in this century. The program of dances was presented at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where an organization of America's new homeless was meeting that very day.

title: Documents Are Stolen At Latin Study Center
description: The head of a group that has investigated American activities in Latin America said today that documents linked to weapons shipments in Central America were stolen and files ransacked during a weekend burglary at the group's office here.

title: Cary Grant's Promise
description: Cary Grant was not supposed to die. Sure, we all knew he was getting on - he had the silver hair to prove it - and that his last movie was 20 years behind him.

title: A CLASH OVER AID EFFORT ON THE FIRST 'SKID ROW'
description: At midweek an early winter wind and rain storm whistled in from the Pacific, giving Pioneer Square a temporary respite from the alcoholics, pushcart people and the mentally ill who have used the downtown area for decades and forcing many of the homeless to seek shelter.

title: U.S. WORKING TO CLOSE FOREIGN-LANGUAGE GAP
description: At a time when American interests are increasingly intertwined with those of other nations, many leaders in Government, business and education say the nation has been hurt by its inattention to foreign languages, cultures and affairs.

title: FASHION: READ ALL ABOUT IT
description: Fashion that fits is not always the easiest Christmas present to find. Fashion books, on the other hand, come in all sizes and this season there are enough new offerings in the city's bookstores to fit almost any taste.

title: Topics: Walk, Do Not Run Friedman Redux
description: Barely a week after Stanley Friedman's conviction by a jury in New Haven, it's back to politics as usual in the Bronx. At a hastily arranged meeting tonight, the Bronx Democratic organization is expected to anoint as its new chairman Assemblyman George Friedman, no relation to Stanley Friedman but his hand-picked choice.

title: MAGNA CARD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW COCOA RULES NEAR
description: Cocoa-producing and cocoa-consuming countries began a weeklong session today to draw up rules to keep cocoa prices stable. The International Cocoa Organization's 60 members agreed on a new pact in July, and moCt producers-including the biggest, the Ivory Coast-said tney would abide by it provisionally

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misstated changes in the numbers of women who will hold state offices as a result of the 1986 elections. The changes are: Governors, from 2 to 3; lieutenant governors, from 5 to 6; elected secretaries of state, from 11 to 12; elected treasurers, a reduction from 11 to 10.

title: NORTH SAID TO USE FIFTH AMENDMENT
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the White House aide who was said to have directed the diversion of proceeds of the Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebels, invoked his right against self incrimination during testimony before a Senate committee today, two sources familiar with the session said.

title: Asbestos Risk for Wives
description: Wives of asbestos workers show some of the same signs of chronic asbestos exposure as their husbands and may also be at risk of disease from the substance, scientists said at a radiologists' meeting in Chicago.

title: Olympic Skaters Cancel December Appearances
description: Christopher Dean and Jayne Torvill, the 1984 Winter Olympics gold medal ice-skating team, have canceled their scheduled New York appearances because of a wrist injury by Mr. Dean, a press representative reported yesterday.

title: DEFENDANT FLEES, 7 ARRESTED IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: A defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial has disappeared, resulting in the arrest of seven others who were free on bail during the 14-month trial in Manhattan.

title: POPE RETURNS TO THE VATICAN, ENDING LONGEST TRIP ABROAD
description: Pope John Paul II returned to the Vatican late tonight after completing the longest trip of his Pontificate.

title: BLENDING OF FUTURE AND PAST
description: Above the ground at Cape Kennedy, scientists labor to reach the stars. Nearby, below the ground, other scientists labor to reach back in time to touch ancient history.

title: DENPAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gary Allen, 50, Dies in West; Spread Conservatives' View
description: Gary Allen, an author whose books ''None Dare Call It Conspiracy'' and ''Tax Target: Washington'' articulated conservative goals for the past two decades, died Saturday of a liver ailment. He was 50 years old.

title: A TRADITIONAL CHINESE THERAPY HARNESSES THE 'VITAL FORCE'
description: SLOWLY at first, as if plumping an invisible pillow, the doctor's hands explored the air before him. Gradually, they began a silent minuet, turning, tumbling, twisting. Now, as if shaping a clump of clay, his hands pounded, then undulated across an invisible surface.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: The latest quarter includes a charge of 1 cent a share from retroactive provisions of the 1986 Tax Reform Act. The year-ago revenue includes about $1.9 million relating to 13 Rax Restaurants refranchised after the first fiscal 1986 quarter.

title: KNICKS, 4-12 AND GOING NOWHERE, DISMISS BROWN
description: Hubie Brown was hired four years ago to guide the Knicks toward a new identity. But a seemingly unending string of injuries over the last two seasons created an atmosphere of frustration that he was not able to overcome and yesterday he was dismissed as head coach.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Advest Group, Inc., Hartford, said it had acquired the T.O. Richardson Co. of Farmington, Conn., an employee benefits and personal and institutional assets concern that manages more than $200 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET
description: ON Sunday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet offered its last repertory program before the opening of its annual engagement of ''The Nutcracker.'' Like many previous repertory programs this season, it featured dancers in new roles. Some of the performances were fine, others were on the way to being fine and still others were competent, but unexciting.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest results reflect the inclusion of operations from two companies purchase late late year. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to a Jan. 31 fiscal year-end closing, which went into effect this year. The share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split issued Jan. 6, 1986.

title: Centel Places Issue With 2 Syndicates
description: The Centel Corporation yesterday awarded $100 million of five- and 10-year notes in competitive bidding to two syndicates, one led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, one by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: BOBBY LAYNE, HALL OF FAMER IN PRO FOOTBALL, IS DEAD AT 59
description: Bobby Layne, the combative Hall of Fame quarterback, died today of cardiac arrest at Methodist Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: Chicago Mayor to Seek Second Term of Office
description: Mayor Harold Washington has announced that he would seek a second term but said he had not yet decided to run under the standard of his party, the Democratic Party, or as an independent.

title: The Gods Are Crazy in Pretoria
description: It was a plan calculated to make South Africa's white minority Government look good. It was known as the ''KwaNatal option,'' the idea being to scrap political apartheid in a new region merging the province of Natal and the Zulu tribal homeland. Its promoter was Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, the most moderate of recognized black leaders. Because he condemns violence and opposes sanctions, Chief Buthelezi was feted at the White House only two weeks ago. Now Pretoria has rejected even this controlled experiment, claiming that it would ''lead to domination,'' the code phrase for resisting votes for blacks.

title: Floating Stock
description: What being an America's Cup crewman makes up for in glamour and excitement, it usually lacks in pay. Sailors and support staff of the world's best 12-Meters generally get room, board and weekly pin money, maybe enough to buy toothpaste and a few beers.

title: NASA TO LAUNCH ATLAS ROCKET
description: AFTER eight delays over seven months, influenced by caution stemming from the Challenger disaster and two other rocket failures, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is finally set to launch an Atlas-Centaur rocket. The rocket, carrying a Navy communications satellite, is scheduled for a liftoff at 9:04 P. M. Thursday at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a one-time charge pertaining to investment tax credits which have been retroactively abolished by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: 2 Blacks Gunned Down In Town Near Pretoria
description: A black South African doctor and his wife were gunned down outside their home in the Mamelodi township near Pretoria on Monday, the Bureau for Information said today.

title: 2 Men Shot to Death On Quiet S.I. Street
description: Two men were shot to death last night while walking down the street in a quiet residential neighborhood in Westerleigh, the police said.

title: TAXI PROTEST CREATES TRAFFIC MESS
description: More than 1,000 drivers of nonmedallion taxicabs converged on lower Manhattan yesterday morning in slow-moving convoys, turning vital highways and streets into parking lots and tying up traffic for more than five hours, the City Transportation Department said..

title: SPANISH RIGHTIST QUITS, ENDING AN ERA
description: The longtime leader of Spain's rightist opposition resigned today, two days after the conservatives were routed in Basque regional elections.

title: Player Seeks Asylum
description: A member of the Polish national basketball team has applied for asylum in the United States, according to the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service office in Providence, R.I. The player, Waldemar Sender, 23 years old, who had been traveling in the United States with the Polish team since early November, made the request last week, according to Michael Devine, the Immigration official.

title: NEW BUILDING FOR BROADCAST MUSEUM
description: The Museum of Broadcasting plans to move into a new 17-story, $40 million building that will be designed by Philip Johnson and will provide about four times more space than the museum's current quarters.

title: METS REWARD THEIR MANAGER
description: The Mets settled their No. 1 family flap yesterday when they raised Dave Johnson's salary past the $300,000 level paid by the Yankees to Lou Piniella, and thereby headed off a holdout by the manager of the best team in baseball.

title: FORMER CITY TRANSPORTATION CHIEF IS INDICTED ON CHARGES OF PERJURY
description: A former New York City transportation commissioner, Anthony R. Ameruso, was indicted yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury on perjury charges stemming from testimony he gave to a city commission investigating his real-estate holdings.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $384,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $339,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $408,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,126,000 for the 9 months.

title: DEVIL POWER PLAYS DEFEAT RANGERS, 8-5
description: Three goals on their first three manpower advantages put the Devils in an enviable position tonight against the Rangers, who entered the game second in the league in killing penalties.

title: STUDY OF FALLS
description: THE Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City is undertaking a comprehensive study of age-related falls so that their causes can be more accurately determined and more effective preventive measures designed.

title: Economic Scene; Foreign Fears About the U.S.
description: THE stock market soared yesterday on heavy volume despite the Iranian imbroglio and President Reagan's steep drop in the public opinion polls. But uncertainties about a beleaguered Administration's ability to cope with the nation's economic problems have been upsetting foreign investors and driving down the dollar.

title: Color Her Pleased
description: To the Editor:

title: A Contretemps Among Republicans
description: A nasty little fight is brewing among Republican senators as they prepare to become the minority party in the new Congress.

title: MESA PLANS OFFER FOR SHAMROCK
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, whose chairman, T. Boone Pickens, is known as one of the most tenacious of corporate raiders, said last night that it and a partner would offer almost $2.03 billion in securities to acquire all of the shares of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, another big oil and gas concern.

title: Noel Arnold Levin, a Lawyer And Labor Relations Expert
description: Noel Arnold Levin, a lawyer and former chairman of the International Foundation of Employee Benefit Plans, died of cancer last Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Real Estate; A Decision To Stay in Manhattan
description: LIKE many other industrial companies that have found the cost of expanding into larger space in Manhattan too high, Nobart Inc., a graphic design and production company now in rented loft space at 33 East 18th Street, was on the verge of leaving the city last year.

title: IN ALCOHOL, URETHANE'S POTENTIAL HAZARDS
description: THE Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer advocacy group based in Washington, last week accused the Federal Food and Drug Administration of failing to warn the public that some alcoholic beverages contain high levels of urethane, which it describes as a ''cancer-causing chemical.'' The center, in conjunction with the National Council on Alcoholism, formally petitioned the F.D.A. ''to inform the public of the risk and to take regulatory action to reduce the hazard.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Boston dispatch on Nov. 14, about a lawsuit by Robert J. Manning against Mortimer B. Zuckerman, who bought the Atlantic magazine from Mr. Manning and others, characterized the case incorrectly. It is a suit for money that Mr. Manning says he is owed; libel is not involved. The article also cited the case's status incorrectly; documents were introduced in pretrial proceedings, but it has not gone to trial.

title: Enhancing a Tomato
description: If on special occasions you take the time to prepare a labor-intensive meal for friends or family, it is worthwhile to pay attention to small details that can add a visual luster to the finished product. Many sauces and colorfully garnished dishes call for diced tomato.

title: Market Place; Greeting Card Makers Falter
description: THE class A shares of the American Greetings Corporation in recent years have dispatched the sort of tidings that Wall Street welcomes: rising profits and a steadily climbing stock price. But now that pattern has been interrupted for the world's largest publicly owned maker of greeting cards and a perennial institutional favorite.

title: The Travels of Jihan Sadat
description: In the five years since her husband was assassinated, Jihan Sadat has made a new life for herself. The widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt now divides her time between Cairo and Washington, having established a career in this country as a well-paid lecturer and teacher and as a champion of women's rights and peace.

title: 2 MORE LOSE POSTS IN MANILA CABINET
description: President Corazon C. Aquino removed two more Cabinet ministers today and announced a package of new benefits for soldiers.

title: MacGregor Sale
description: Finland's tobacco, consumer and sporting goods company Amer-Yhtymae O.Y. said it had agreed to acquire an 80 percent stake in the MacGregor Golf Company, which is controlled by Jack Nicklaus, the American golf star. Amer said that negotiations were continuing but both parties hoped to conclude the deal, worth some $8 million, before the end of the year.

title: WITNESS TERMS GOTTI'S RULE IRON-HANDED
description: John Gotti was described in Federal District Court testimony in Brooklyn yesterday as a crime boss who ruled with an iron hand. The witness said Mr. Gotti once told someone who wanted to leave his organization, ''You don't get released from John Gotti's crew - you live with John Gotti, you die with John Gotti.''

title: Atwood to Confront G.M. Cultural Rifts
description: Donald J. Atwood, a low-key, soft-spoken executive with a grasp of technology, finance and sales, now has a high-profile assignment at the General Motors Corporation that will tax all of his areas of expertise. The executive has been given the task of guiding the company's diverse high-tech operations, including the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.

title: Biden's Strategy
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, contemplating the possibility of a 1988 Presidential campaign and the reality of being chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee for the next two years, is seeking ways to share the committee's workload with his Democratic colleagues.

title: California Phone Issue in Two Parts
description: The General Telephone Company of California is offering $175 million of debt securities, divided into two parts, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 0.6%
description: The Government index designed to foretell the economy climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in October, the largest gain since July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TAIWAN TURNS BACK DISSIDENT SEEKING RETURN AFTER 7 YEARS
description: Officials here turned back a prominent dissident leader at the airport today as he arrived after seven years of exile in the United States.

title: WITNESS SAYS HE APPROVED EXPLOSION IN FILM
description: The special effects technician who set off the explosions that led to the fatal helicopter crash on the set of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' testified today that he had final responsibility to make sure the filming sequence was safe.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances in Contact Lenses; Soft Bifocal Designing Is A Challenge
description: MORE than half of all Americans wear eyeglasses or contact lenses, and of those, half wear bifocals or trifocals. Yet while single-vision contact lenses have gained great popularity, bifocal contact lenses have yet to find commercial success. They are difficult to make and difficult for ophthalmologists and optometrists to fit, and as many as four of every five people who try to wear them go back to spectacles, eye-care specialists say.

title: CORRUPTION PROSECUTIONS OF CITY OFFICIALS
description: Parking Violations Bureau Stanley M. Friedman, former Bronx Democratic leader and a major stockholder in Citisource Inc.

title: Acting Like a President
description: After three weeks of contradiction and evasion over arms dealings with Iran and the Nicaragua rebels, Ronald Reagan has started acting like President Reagan again. In just a few minutes yesterday, he took three steps, each of which advance the difficult process of restoring confidence in his shaken Presidency.

title: Jets Notebook; EVERYBODY HAS A REMEDY BUT NO CURES
description: Mark Twain would have loved the Jets. Everybody talks about the team, but nobody does anything about it.

title: ART HISTORIAN CULITVATES KINSHIP WITH CEZANNE
description: John Rewald has never stopped discovering Cezanne. He published his prize-winning Ph.D. dissertation, ''Cezanne and Zola,'' 50 years ago, and has been revising it ever since.

title: Unilever Deal Spurred By 'Innovative' Market
description: Unilever N.V.'s $3.1 billion deal to acquire Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. is aimed at strengthening its presence in the ''innovative'' American consumer products market, an executive of the giant British company said yesterday.

title: Mediation in Bus Strike
description: As a strike continued for a second day yesterday against a Bronx bus company, the State Mediation Board said that it had offered its assistance. Union and management accepted the offer, according to their spokesmen, but they added that no new talks had been scheduled. The strike by 500 drivers, mechanics and other employees, represented by Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, began Monday against the New York Bus Service.

title: ADLER & SHAYKIN IN REVLON ACCORD
description: The investment firm of Adler & Shaykin has accepted $23.7 million from the Revlon Group Inc. and MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., ending a yearlong dispute over who should own the Revlon beauty business.

title: Of Names, Zeal and Appetite
description: Importance of Names:

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: SEVERAL years ago I spent the day at a family planning clinic in one of New York City's poorest neighborhoods. I sat around a Formica table with a half-dozen 16-year-old girls and listened with some amazement as they showed off their knowledge of human sexuality.

title: Juilliard String Quartet To Give Free Concert
description: The Juilliard String Quartet will play works by Beethoven, Roger Sessions and Henri Dutilleux in a free concert on Dec. 16 in the Juilliard Theater. The ensemble -the violinists Robert Mann and Joel Smirnoff, the violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick - are members of the Juilliard faculty. The concert is one of 12 New York appearances scheduled this season to celebrate the group's 40th anniversary.

title: Afghan Air Attacks On Pakistan Intensify
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH SENTENCES IN GANDHI KILLING
description: The Delhi High Court today upheld the death sentences handed down earlier this year to three Sikh men convicted in the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: BRAVES PASS YANKS FOR TOP SALARIES
description: The Atlanta Braves, aided significantly by their trade of Claudell Washington for Ken Griffey, have supplanted the Yankees as the team with the highest average salary in baseball. This marks only the second year in the past nine years that the Yankees have not been No. 1 in the salary standing.

title:
DISCOVERIES;
FOR A SEASON OF COMFORT AND CHEER
description: 1. For Keeping Warm

title: NEW RULES WOULD WIDEN USE OF PLASTIC PACKAGING FOR FOOD
description: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed rules that would open the way for wider use of the plastic polyvinyl chloride for packaging foods and beverages.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS URGE DEEP CUT IN STATE TAXES
description: Republicans who control the State Senate proposed a sharp cut in personal income taxes today. They said they expected to pass the plan in their own house by the end of the year.

title: Ex-Prosecutor's Conduct Questioned in California
description: The State Attorney General's office has asked the California State Bar to examine a former prosecutor's conduct in the molestation case involving the McMartin Preschool institution.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $29,000 for the quarter and net of $104,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: People
description: * Brian Barry has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor at TBWA Advertising.

title: Small, Quiet Building in Geneva Had Wide Use
description: A squat one-story building in a quiet Geneva neighborhood appears to have been used more widely in secretly channeling Iranian payments to Nicaraguan rebels than was previously believed.

title: Unisys to Sell Unit
description: The Unisys Corporation has agreed to sell Sperry Microwave and Systems Support to Hercules Aerospace Company for $42 million in cash by year-end.

title: MUSIC: OPPENS AT THE PIANO
description: THE pianist Ursula Oppens chose an unusually varied program for her Monday night recital at Town Hall -Bach's Partita No. 5, Schoenberg's Suite (Op. 25), two works by Liszt, ''La Valse'' by Ravel, miniatures in tango style by William Bolcom, Michael Sahl, David Jaggard, Lukas Foss and Conlon Nancarrow, and a substantial recent work for piano solo, ''The Blue Bamboula'' by Charles Wuorinen.

title: Transcript of Reagan Broadcast
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's broadcast statement in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SOON, CATAMOUNT AMBER, A 'BRITISH' PALE ALE FROM VERMONT
description: WHEN Stephen P. Mason was in college, he brewed beer in his off-campus apartment in five-gallon containers. That was 11 years ago. Mr. Mason is still brewing beer in small batches, only today it is as a part owner of Vermont's only ''microbrewery,'' the Catamount Brewing Company. His goal, he says, is to produce a fresh, unpasteurized, additive-free beer for distribution in New England and New York. According to Mr. Mason, Coors beer is the only unpasteurized bottled beer regularly available in the region. ''We think that so many New Englanders are used to drinking stale beer,'' he said, ''we want to give people the chance to drink a beer that is really fresh, really pure and of very high quality.'' The attraction of pasteurization, or heating the beer to kill bacteria, he added, is that the process extends the product's shelf life.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 18
description: b-Net income

title: MODEL GIVES GRIM ACCOUNT OF NIGHT SHE WAS SLASHED
description: Marla Hanson, a striving but little-known model until her face was slashed with a razor outside a West Side bar six months ago, took the witness stand yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to recount - in often chilling detail - events on the night of her attack.

title: 4 KILLED IN ATTACK ON PRO-ISRAELI FORCE ON LEBANON
description: At least four soldiers of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army were killed and 20 were wounded in southern Lebanon today in the largest such attack by Lebanese Moslem guerrillas in two months.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $43,000.

title: U.S. TAKES 2D STEP TO MEET GUIDELINES ON TOXIC DISPOSAL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed that several hazardous substances be treated and brought down to acceptable levels of toxicity before they were disposed of in waste facilities on land.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a one-time reduction of $114,000, or 3 cents a share, to reflect the repeal of the investment tax credit under the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: O'Rielly's First Client
description: O'Rielly, O'Brien, Clow/RSCG, which opened its doors on Nov. 13, has just picked up its first client, the 3M Company, for its Travelmation Corporation, a new Stamford, Conn., company that will be marketing an electronic travel agency service called Trip Planner, which it thinks will revolutionize corporate travel departments. New York will be the first market under attack and there will be a press conference there in January to announce that. No billings were announced, but the promise is for an aggressive campaign and that doesn't come cheaply.

title: SHARP RISE SEEN IN PENICILLIN-RESISTANT GONORRHEA
description: Reported cases of penicillin-resistant gonorrhea have doubled in the last year and the disease has become a very serious health problem in the United States, according to officials of the Centers for Disease Control, a Federal agency based in Atlanta.

title: STOCK PRICES SOAR TO PEAK IN RELIEF OVER IRAN INQUIRY
description: Stock prices soared to record levels yesterday as the market, relieved that President Reagan had acted to support a full investigation of the Iranian arms sale controversy, staged the third-best rally in its history.

title: AN EXPLOSION OF CALCIUM-FORTIFIED FOODS
description: CALCIUM is the latest nutritional bandwagon on which food manufacturers are piling. There are calcium-fortified cereals, cheese substitutes, yogurts, margarines, fruit drinks and juices, soda pop and, interestingly, milk.

title: 2 JETLINERS AVERT MIDAIR COLLISIONS IN CHICAGO AREA
description: In separate encounters half an hour apart, the pilots of two airliners took evasive action to avoid possible collisions with small planes in the Chicago area Monday morning, according to Government and airline officials.

title: MUSIC: 3 NEW WORKS AT A TRIBUTE TO ARLEN
description: ''A TRIBUTE TO HAROLD ARLEN,'' the American Jazz Orchestra's concert program at Cooper Union on Monday evening, led musicians and audience further afield than anyone familiar with Mr. Arlen's outstanding popular songs might have expected. Three new compositions in honor of Mr. Arlen presented the orchestra with some challenges it did not seem well equipped to handle.

title: Security Council Aides Play Down Restrictions
description: Members of the National Security Council staff today played down the impact of President Reagan's order that it stop conducting sensitive diplomatic, military or intelligence operations.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AMERICA II UPSET BY MELGES'S YACHT
description: The man who is known in his hometown as the Wizard of Zenda because of his sailing feats worked his magic in the America's Cup challenger trials today by upstaging America II.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Would Critics Write Off Hostages?
description: The taking of hostages is an old if not venerable practice. After falling into disuse in the past century, it has been revived as an important psychological and terrorist weapon. Its use is especially effective against liberal democracies that are uniquely ill-equipped to respond.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Purcell to Become A Cable TV Analyst
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, said yesterday that he would become a political analyst and commentator on local cable televlsion when he retires from public office in mid-January.

title: JWT Group Increasing Its Board by One, to 12
description: The JWT Group, parent company of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising, and Hill & Knowlton, public relations, announced yesterday that it was increasing its board by one, to 12, which, because of three retirements, will mean four seats to fill.

title: ARGENTINA CONVICTS EX-POLICE OFFICIALS
description: Gen. Ramon Camps, former police chief of Buenos Aires Province, was convicted today and given a 25-year prison term for human rights crimes.

title: Baseball Still a Hit
description: Perhaps fond memories of exciting playoff games and the Mets' hair-raising comeback in the World Series were more vivid than those of baseball's ho-hum regular-season competition. Whatever the stimulus, readers of USA Today responding to a poll about their preferences in sports decisively named baseball ''the all-American sport.''

title: Guilty Plea on Corruption
description: The former head of the City Water Department's collection section pleaded guilty Monday to Federal extortion charges. The former official, Carmen Aiello, 36 years old, admitted receiving bribes of $2,000 last year to help steer collection contracts to Systematic Recovery Services, a New York City-based collection agency. He will be sentenced Jan. 21 and faces a maximum penalty of 40 years in prison and a $500,000 fine.

title: LTV Prices to Rise
description: The LTV Steel Company, a unit of the LTV Corporation, said that it would raise the prices for its hot-rolled, cold-rolled and hot-dipped galvanized sheet steel, beginning with shipments on March 29.

title: JAZZ PARTY IN MEMORY OF ZOOT SIMS, 'ON THE ROAD'
description: ON Sunday, Dec. 14, Paul Weinstein - who produces the Heavenly Jazz concerts at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, on Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, and the ''Jazz at Six'' series at the New School - will fulfill a promise he made to the saxophonist Zoot Sims two years ago, a few months before Mr. Sims's death in March 1985. At that time, Mr. Sims appeared to be in good health and Mr. Weinstein was startled when he spoke of dying.

title: HOMOSEXUALS IN ATLANTA FEAR RISE IN RANDOM ATTACKS AND KILLINGS
description: Among the more than 170 homicides the city has recorded over the last year, the killings of six men described by the police as street hustlers had not suggested any kind of unusual pattern to detectives in Atlanta.

title: DOROTHY RODGERS CONTRIBUTES $10,000 TO THE NEEDIEST CASES
description: A $10,000 gift to the 75th appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund came from Dorothy Rodgers, widow of Richard Rodgers, the composer. Mrs. Rodgers, who has contributed annually, made the gift through the Richard and Dorothy Rodgers Foundation.

title: Sabres Drop Bowman
description: Scotty Bowman was dismissed yesterday as general manager and director of operations for the Buffalo Sabres, who are in last place in the Adams Division. Bowman stepped down as coach last month.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I recently served chicken breasts stuffed with shrimp, a guest asked if the combination was not a trifle eccentric. Actually, the blend of meats with seafood can be found in almost all civilized cultures. Such marriages are commonplace in Chinese cooking.

title: The M.T.A. Needs State Support
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. to Challenge Purchase by Kidde
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted to seek a court injunction to block the purchase by the nation's leading supplier of mobile hydraulic cranes of the No. 2 provider of such equipment.

title: H&R BLOCK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Summons Set In Insider Case
description: The Government initiated criminal proceedings today against Geoffrey S. Collier, an investment banker who resigned last month in an insider-trading scandal.

title: Now About Puerto Rico's Hard Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: CARLUCCI IS NAMED FOR N.S.C.; 2 Moves By President
description: Saying that illegal acts may have been committed in the diversion of millions of dollars to Nicaraguan rebels from United States arms sales to Iran, the Administration said today that it was requesting an independent prosecutor to look into the case.

title: Connecticut Official Faults Nursing Home
description: Officials of a Windsor nursing home where a salmonella outbreak led to the deaths of five elderly patients waited too long before notifying state officials of the infection, State Health Commissioner S. Douglas Lloyd said yesterday.

title: Pillsbury Earnings
description: The Pillsbury Company said it expects earnings for its second quarter ending Dec. 17 to be ''somewhat below'' earnings a year earlier of $56.6 million, or 65 cents a share.

title: THE DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO AT THE JOYCE THEATER
description: BALLET HISPANICO OF NEW YORK offered six works by five choreographers last night when it opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater. It was certainly an evening of abundance. Yet there was unity within the variety, for the works could be called variations on a few basic themes.

title: Braque Painting Sells for $9.5 Million
description: Georges Braque's ''Woman Reading'' (1911), the artist's largest Cubist painting at 51 inches high by 32 inches wide, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's in London for $9.5 million, the highest price paid at auction for a 20th-century painting.

title: Spinks-Cooney Is Reported Set
description: A report surfaced yesterday that Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, may fight Gerry Cooney early next March.

title: COURT FAULTS E.P.A. ON RATING FUEL EFFICIENCY
description: A Federal appeals court panel held today that the Environmental Protection Agency erred when it revised its formula for measuring fuel efficiency in a way proposed by the nation's two largest car makers. The court ordered the agency to make adjustments in the fuel efficiency ratings that could cost the car makers about $300 million.

title: Bullets End Celtics' Streak
description: Jeff Malone scored 36 points last night as the Washington Bullets defeated the Boston Celtics, 117-109, to end the Celtics' home winning streak at 48 games. The victory was the first for the Bullets on the road this season after seven losses.

title: The Washington Uproar: A Cast of Characters
