description: William J. Cooper: Pilot killed in crash of C-123 carrying weapons for the contras in Nicaragua. A contra leader, Adolfo Calero, said Mr. Cooper was chief pilot of the program. Manucher Ghorbanifar: Exiled Iranian businessman, said to have raised issue of trading parts to Iran for hostages.

title: Babies and SleepTO THE LIVING SECTION
description: Jane Brody's Personal Health column [ Nov. 12 ] on how parents ''teach'' their children to cry at night is one that cannot go unchallenged. Research now suggests that because of an infant's naturally immature nervous system, they simply cannot be expected to sleep as an adult does.

title: Prosecutors and Counsels: Those Who Have Served
description: In May 1973, during the height of the Watergate scandal, Attorney General Elliott L. Richardson set up an office of the special prosecutor to investigate the burglary of the Watergate offices and other cases related to the 1972 election. Archibald Cox: The first special prosecutor, he was dismissed in October 1973, after five months on the job, on orders from President Nixon. Leon Jaworski: Mr. Cox's successor. He made the Nixon tapes public. Several of President Nixon's aides, including H. R. Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman and John N. Mitchell, were convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice and other offenses.

title: Article 396686 -- No Title
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. announced yesterday that its $3 billion deal with Larry A. Silverstein, a real estate developer, to move its headquarters to his new building at 7 World Trade Center had collapsed, partly as a result of changes in tax laws and partly because of the Boesky insider-trading scandal.

title: E.P.A. ASKING $40 MILLION FINES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was seeking $40 million in penalties from four companies it has accused of producing gasoline containing illegally high levels of lead.

title: PATTERN SEEN IN BREAK-INS AT LATIN POLICY GROUPS
description: A New York-based lawyers' group says that a break-in at the Washington offices of a group opposed to Reagan Administration policy in Central America is only the latest in a series of such burglaries.

title: LAWYER ASSAILS ROLE OF WITNESS IN ZACCARO CASE
description: The lawyer for John A. Zaccaro, who is charged with soliciting a bribe from a cable-television company, says that if the crime occurred, the state official who is the major witness against Mr. Zaccaro ''could well be an accomplice.''

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in July and a 5 percent stock dividend distributed in May.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO GET FERRY PERMIT
description: It took Arthur Imperatore two years to obtain a permit from New York City for the Hudson River ferry service that will link Weehawken and Manhattan beginning tomorrow, Mr. Imperatore's spokesman, Alan C. Marcus, said yesterday.

title: HILL EXPECTS TO ADD UPBEAT TO KNICKS
description: ''Good luck, coach.''

title: STAGE: 'RAGGED TROUSERED PHILANTHROPISTS,' A DRAMA
description: ''THE Ragged Trousered Philanthropists'' represents the inelegant side of Edwardian England, where the working class - in this case a group of housepainters and decorators - struggles for a living in a society that has relegated it to the bottom of the ladder. The Robert Tressell novel first appeared in England in 1914, several years after the author had died, and it gradually became a classic of socialist literature. Among other things, the novel is credited with being instrumental in winning the election for the Labor Party in 1945.

title: Zoning Treatment Penalizes Community Church
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bildner & Sons After a series of delays, James L. Bildner is finally taking on the Big Apple. The Boston-based supermarket developer, who owns 14 upscale, full-service stores in Massachusetts, Georgia and Alabama, is opening the glass doors of the first J. Bildner & Sons store in New York with a party tonight at 330 East 75th Street.

title: HUMAN CUTOUT USED AS TARGET, LANDLORD SAYS
description: Thomas W. Manning practiced shooting at human silhouette and bull's-eye targets behind a Pennsylvania farmhouse he rented in the months before the slaying of a state trooper, according to Superior Court testimony from a witness today.

title: Research on Smoking Finds Link to Hormone
description: Researchers have identified a possible mechanism by which smoking may reduce levels of the hormone estrogen in women.

title: ARCHBISHOP SERVED VATICAN 2 DECADES
description: Archbishop Martin J. O'Connor, one of the leading Americans in the Vatican hierarchy for more than two decades, died Monday at Mercy Hospital in Wilkes-Barre. He was 86 years old.

title: Shuttle Commander Retires
description: Joe H. Engle has retired from active duty as an Air Force colonel and has also resigned from the astronaut corps, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: Sleep Still Knits Up the Ravell'd Sleave of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Prison Fugitive Charged In Delaware Murder
description: Three Delaware convicts who escaped throught the prison sewers were last seen heading north toward Pennsylvania today, but a fourth fugitive was captured after the police said he had killed a woman and stolen her car.

title: RONALD A. PLACZEK
description: Ronald A. Placzek, an art director for CBS who won an Emmy for the network's daytime series ''Guiding Light,'' died Thursday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. Mr. Placzek, who lived in Manhattan, was 36 years old and had pneumonia.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ON Sunday, the Statue of Liberty Gallery, 525 Hudson Street, closed its doors forever. The shop, which sold only Liberty memorabilia, opened for business in April 1984 on the same street where the proprietor, Mervin Bendewald, had sold antiques for a quarter of a century. The business of selling items depicting The Lady atop ashtrays, on pennants, paperweights, caps, T-shirts, neckties, and visors, as the shape of cookie cutters, you-name-it, got better and better as the Big Weekend got closer and closer. But once this year's Fourth of July celebrations were over, Mr. Bendewald says sales dropped 80 percent, while his rent went up 150 percent.

title: Pittsburgh Pact Is Approved
description: The city's paramedics overwhelmingly approved a new contract tonight, one day after the emergency medical workers ended a four-day strike. The contract will freeze their pay through 1987 but will give them raises in 1988, 1989 and 1990, said the union's secretary, Jim Weslager.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOLIDAY GIFTS FROM THE KITCHEN
description: WHEN it comes to the holiday gift list, there is much to recommend spending a day or two in the quiet of the kitchen with the oven lighted and the preserving kettle simmering instead of bucking department store crowds. The food gifts that result are usually doubly appreciated because they are homemade.

title: Excerpts From Attorney General Meese's Washington News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: LETTERS: BABIES AND SLEEP
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ISRAELI COURT UPHOLDS A CONVERT
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today in favor of a new immigrant from the United States who had challenged the Interior Ministry's labeling her a convert to Judaism in her Israeli identity papers.

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NASA Plans Use of Satellites To Predict Spread of Malaria
description: The National Areonautics and Space Administration has begun work on a satellite project for predicting outbreaks of malaria, a disability that afflicts 250 million people worldwide, the space agency said today.

title: ON THE MENUS OF 2 MUSEUMS, KITCHENS
description: ''I TAKE it for granted that you are too intelligent to share in the vulgar prejudice against labor-saving machines,'' wrote Marian Harland in ''Common Sense in the Household,'' an 1872 cookbook. Her assumption was correct. Americans have always thought highly of speed and convenience, and there is no more tangible evidence than the array of beaters, choppers, pitters, peelers and processors devised to free housewives from kitchen drudgery.

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR most of the year, the average wine enthusiast is a mixed blessing. Urbane, cultured, world-traveled and definitely plugged in, he or she can, with their vintages and chateaus and all that, quickly turn into a bore.

title: Peru in Cocaine Crackdown
description: Three cocaine laboratories and 1,600 pounds of coca paste were seized in a police drive in the heart of Peru's coca-growing region this week, Deputy Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla said today. The operation is in the upper Huallaga River valley, where about half the illict coca leaf for the world's supply of cocaine is believed to be grown, narcotics experts say.

title: Kemp's Invitation
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp may need more than the Presidential exploratory committee that was announced this week if he is serious about the 1988 Republican nomination. One of the upstate New Yorker's latest personal invitations to become a major Kemp contributor - a gold-embossed, heavy-stationery, color-photograph mailing seeking $1,000 to $5,000 a year - went to Anne Wexler, a veteran Democratic political adviser who was an assistant to President Carter the last time the Democrats held the White House.

title: Cards: 2 Experienced Teams Take Major Titles at Fall Nationals
description: Two highly experienced teams won major titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Monday night.

title: PHRASE IS REMOVED FROM SEX TEXT
description: The publisher of a sex education book on a Board of Education reading list for New York City students said yesterday that a statement that anal intercourse was not medically dangerous had been removed from a new edition of the book.

title: TEST OF EUROPEAN ROCKET TO DELAY LAUNCHINGS
description: Western Europe's Ariane rocket program, suspended after a disastrous misfiring last May, will be unable to meet its goal of resuming launchings next February because it will take several more weeks to complete testing of a redesigned rocket ignition system, officials announced yesterday.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. DETROIT PISTONS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. OILERS, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9:35 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 9:30 P.M.) TENNIS NABISCO MASTERS: at Madison Square Garden, 6 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 6 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: St. Francis at Rider (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) St. Peter's at Seton Hall (Radio -WSOU-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15P.M. and 12:30 A.M.) Meadowlands, 8P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight)

title: MOSCOW'S MUSICAL COMPETITION
description: TONIGHT'S presentation of ''The Eighth International Tchaikovsky Competition'' on Channel 13 at 10 doesn't hold many surprises. The competition ended last summer, and it is no secret that the winners were Barry Douglas of Northern Ireland for piano and Raphael Oleg of France and Ilya Kaler of the Soviet Union in a tie for violin. And, as is not uncommon in such art ventures, the production reaches for sports analogies as it focuses on the intense training and pressures connected with what has been called ''the Olympics of music.'' We have been through this territory before, not least in the documentary that was done four years ago, ''The Seventh International Tchaikovsky Competition.''

title: Israeli Leader Rejects Hint By Reagan of Role in Aid to Contras
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today publicly rejected President Reagan's apparent assertion that Israel helped to channel money to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Poor Neighborhood May Get Academy
description: The Police Department is seriously considering selling the Police Academy building, a gray brick structure at 235 East 20th Street in Manhattan, and moving the training center to an economically depressed area in another borough, city officials say.

title: Computer Venture Links Honeywell, Bull, NEC
description: Compagnie des Machines Bull, France's state-owned computer maker, will become the largest player in a venture to form a new company out of Honeywell Inc.'s faltering computer operations, according to an agreement announced yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: A G.O.P. Split Over Rank Both Richard G. Lugar and Jesse Helms want to be the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: A Democratic Delay
description: Cities competing for the 1988 Democratic national convention are going to have to wait two months to learn which of them won. The party's site selection committee was to have inspected facilities in New Orleans this weekend, but that visit has been postponed until Jan. 18-20 at the request of city officials.

title: Takeovers, a Symptom of 'Corpocracy'
description: The Ivan F. Boesky imbroglio has raised increasing questions about the value and virtue of large corporate takeovers. This sort of questioning is surely healthy. But whatever the value of takeovers, they are clearly symptoms of a more serious disease afflicting American business - a rash of elephantine, inefficient and self-serving corporate bureaucracy. Since the public now interprets the word ''bureaucracy'' to stand specifically for ''Federal bureaucracy,'' we thought it necessary to coin a different word, ''corprocracy,'' to describe Washington's corporate cousin - those companies that have excessive layers of staff between managers and markets.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS a Minnesota grandmother stepped into her bathtub, the bathmat scooted from under her feet and she fell hard, breaking her hip.

title: Rohm & Haas Selects Chief 18 Months Early
description: The Rohm & Haas Company has had only three chief executives in its 77-year history, and as a company spokesman put it, the big chemical and plastics manufacturer places ''a high priority on orderly succession.''

title: U.N. Asks Independence For New Caledonia
description: Over strong French objections, the General Assembly adopted a resolution today placing New Caledonia on a list of ''non-self-governing territories.'' The vote was 89 to 24.

title: JAPAN TACKLES SOFTWARE CRISIS
description: IN a nondescript bank building in Tokyo's Akihabara electronics district, more than 50 computer engineers are taking a first crack at solving Japan's growing software crisis.

title: GAINSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $8,385 for the quarter and $124,820 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $33,740 for the quarter and $97,196 for the 9 months. The 9 months also includes a tax credit of $63,553.

title: HORACE HEIDT, A BAND LEADER
description: Horace Heidt, a band leader who on his radio talent shows helped start the careers of such stars as Art Carney and Gordon MacRae, died here Monday after a long siege of pneumonia following a heart attack suffered last summer. He was 85 years old.

title: DESI ARNAZ, TV PIONEER, IS DEAD AT 69
description: Desi Arnaz, an actor, musician and producer and an important figure in the history of television, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Del Mar, Calif. He was 69 years old. With Lucille Ball, to whom he was married from 1940 until 1960, Mr. Arnaz created the situation comedy ''I Love Lucy.'' The program, which featured Mr. Arnaz and Miss Ball as Ricky and Lucy Ricardo, a Cuban band leader and his wacky, high-spirited wife, was produced from 1951 through 1956 and achieved unprecedented popularity.

title: BOND PRICES REGAIN STRENGTH
description: Prices of Treasury issues advanced sharply yesterday as bond buyers returned to the market in force in the belief that President Reagan would weather the Iranian arms sale crisis.

title: PRETORIA RESTRICTS ACTIVITIES OF APARTHEID FOE
description: The authorities pressed a campaign today against the United Democratic Front, the leading nonparliamentary opposition movement, by serving a restriction notice on its national treasurer.

title: In Celebration of Decor
description: For about 20 years, the decor of the three State Department reception rooms adjacent to the sixth-floor office of the Secretary of State was starkly unadorned. Many furnishings in the rooms, where foreign chiefs of state and heads of government are received for the signing of international agreements and other ceremonies, had a distinctly Government-issue look about them.

title: AGENDA
description: Restructuring Estimate Board A State Assembly committee is to conduct a hearing today on a plan that would remove budgetary authority from the New York City Board of Estimate, whose voting structure was ruled unconstitutional last month by a Federal judge. Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan and the City Council's majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, are to testify on the proposal. 10:30 A.M., 11th floor, 270 Broadway, Manhattan.

title: CUTBACKS SET FOR 1987
description: Faced with declining profit margins and prospective price cuts by A.T.&T., the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would write down the value of older equipment by $500 million to $700 million pretax in the fourth quarter.

title: U.S. Links Of British Firms Rise
description: A BRITISH public relations firm has not only acquired an American communications company but a company that is based in our nation's capital with a client list chock-full of United States Government agencies, at least one involved in national security.

title: FERRY IS TO START RUNS TOMORROW ACROSS HUDSON
description: The first regular trans-Hudson ferry service between New York and New Jersey in nearly 20 years is to begin at 6:20 A.M. on Thursday when the 77-foot Port Imperial pushes off from Weehawken, N.J. The three-minute run will end at 38th Street in Manhattan near the Javits Convention Center.

title: Britain in Talks To Sell Off Rover
description: The British Government said it was talking to two concerns about a possible bid for Rover, its ailing truck and van manufacturer. Trade and Industry Minister Paul Channon told Parliament that Rover, the Government-run concern formerly known as British Leyland, was in the early stages of negotiations with Paccar Inc., a Bellevue, Wash.

title: 3 Homes Burn in Georgetown
description: The home of a prominent lawyer sustained heavy damage today in a fire that spread to two neighboring townhouses, including one belonging to the mother of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, fire officials said.

title: INSITUFORM GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend and a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 29.

title: GIANTS BEST IN THE N.F.L., SAYS TITTLE
description: Now that the Giants have played their best game since Y. A. Tittle was their quarterback, they might need to play an even better game Sunday if they are to win in Washington.

title: LENDL TRYING TO EARN RESPECT
description: For those such as Boris Becker, Yannick Noah and Stefan Edberg, the Nabisco Masters is an opportunity to lay some groundwork for next year, to give Ivan Lendl something to ponder for the holidays. Tennis may be played with a racquet, but it is also a word game, and the task facing the top 10, among others, is talking Lendl into believing that the sound he hears is not their voices, but a stampede of players closing in on him.

title: Lear May Weigh Other Bids
description: The board of Lear Siegler Inc. said tonight that it would give unnamed parties interested in acquiring the company a chance to make offers before it decided what action it would take if its $1.7 billion acquisition deal with Wickes was not consummated.

title: NICHOLS, S E INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
GENERATIONS OF DEVOTEES PAY TRIBUTE TO DANILOVA
description: Lincoln Kirstein recalled watching early performances by Alexandra Danilova, for him ''the paragon of excellence and elegance.'' Andrei Kramarevsky, Madame Danilova's colleague at the School of American Ballet, hoisted his glass and exuberantly quoted some ''poesy'' by Longfellow. And there were cheers and laughter from several generations of students and friends gathered at the school on Monday to celebrate the publication of ''Choura,'' Madame Danilova's memoirs.

title: Why Waver on Decency in Chile?
description: Washington's credibility as an active supporter of decency and democracy in Chile is on the line again this week, as the United Nations moves toward a final vote on a resolution condemning that country's abuses of human rights. Last month, the Administration backed off its threat to vote against a World Bank loan for Chile.

title: Printouts
description: Iowa Seeks to Take Leadership in Lasers James Freedman, president of the University of Iowa, has seen the light, and it is lasers. ''The University of Iowa can grasp the opportunity for national and world leadership in laser science,'' Dr. Freedman said yesterday, if only the Legislature agrees to a request from the university and the state Board of Regents for $25.1 million for a proposed Center for Laser Science and Engineering.

title: Man, 75, Guilty in Shooting
description: A 75-year-old man charged with murder for shooting a 16-year-old boy who was delivering a newspaper to his home pleaded guilty today to reckless homicide as part of a plea agreement. The man, Nokomis W. Toombs of Indianapolis, faces up to eight years in prison. He admitted in court here that he shot the boy, Scott P. Lawson, with a shotgun on Sept. 25.

title: Ex-Bozell Executives Form Own Agency
description: Two former top executives of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Public Relations have gone into business for themselves with five former Bozell clients that should give them a first-year fee income of $1 million.

title: BRONX DEMOCRATS PICK NEW LEADER
description: Assemblyman George Friedman was elected Bronx Democratic chairman yesterday and, saying the party's image needed refurbishing, declared that he would not represent clients of his private law practice before any governmental agencies.

title: Testaverde Honored
description: Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback who is heading for an almost sure Heisman Trophy on Saturday night, was named winner of the 50th annual Maxwell Award. Testaverde, from Long Island, was the unanimous choice of the Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia as the outstanding collegiate player in the nation, beating out, among others, Paul Palmer, the running back from Temple; Jim Harbaugh, the Michigan quarterback, and two linebackers, Brian Bosworth of Oklahoma and Shane Conlan of Penn State.

title: Suriname Declares State of Emergency
description: The Government declared a state of emergency in remote areas of the country today after 21 people were killed in four days of fighting between the military and guerrillas.

title: YOUNG PROFESSIONALS: NEW SKILLS IN OLD JOB OF VOLUNTEERISM
description: THE young woman in low-heeled black pumps and a trenchcoat leaned forward intently as the group of 100 volunteers in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine discussed suggested ways to collect food and distribute it to the needy.

title: Illinois Yields 3.6% to 6.65%
description: A $120 million tax-exempt issue of Illinois general obligation bonds was priced for offering yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Indiana 67, Notre Dame 62: Steve Alford scored 26 points, including two free throws with 11 seconds remaining, to lead Indiana last night. Notre Dame (0-2) trailed by 12 at halftime, but cut the Hoosiers' lead to 63-62 when Scott Hicks stole a pass and scored on a dunk. Seconds later, Hicks fouled Alford, who made both foul shots. Kreigh Smith added two more free throws to seal the victory for Indiana (2-0).(AP) >Oklahoma 93, Texas A&M 79: Harvey Grant scored 16 of Oklahoma's last 24 points as the Sooners (2-1) downed the Aggies (0-1). (UPI) Creighton 80, Iowa State 65: Matt Roggenburk, a freshman, scored 19 points, including four 3-point shots, to lead Creighton to a season-opening victory. Creighton's Renard Edwards hit every basket he attempted in racking up 17 points against Iowa State (1-1).(AP) Western Kentucky 90, Kentucky State 58: Kannard Johnson scored 19 points and Western Kentucky jumped to an 11-0 lead and coasted past Kentucky State (2-3). The Hilltoppers (4-1) finished second in the N.I.T. Classic last week.(UPI) Iona 81, Hofstra 66: Richie Simmons scored 27 points, 17 in the second half, as Iona won its home opener. Alvin Lott, a transfer from St. Bonaventure, added 19 points for the Gaels (1-1), who led at halftime, 35-28. Steve Rebholz scored 18 for the Flying Dutchmen (1-2). Temple 70, La Salle 66: Nate Blackwell scored 33 points to lead Temple (5-1) at home.

title: Another Chemical Spill Along the Rhine
description: About 2.7 tons of a chemical leaked from a factory into the Rhine today in the eighth industrial accident along the river in a month, officials said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Electronic Data Systems Corporation identified a computer industry analyst incompletely. He is Barry F. Bosak of Eberstadt Fleming Inc.

title: Stand Up to the Cab Cartel
description: After several false starts, Mayor Koch may have found a weak spot in the taxi industry's defense of its cartel. The question now is whether the City Council and the Taxi Commission have the courage to withstand the industry's counterattack.

title: Sheriff's Plan to Stop Blacks Ignites Protests
description: Blacks traveling in white neighborhoods of Jefferson Parish will be stopped routinely in an effort to reduce crime, the sheriff in this New Orleans suburb said today in announcing a new policy that provoked a storm of protests from black leaders and civil libertarians.

title: Meese Defends Conduct of Justice Dept. Inquiry
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today vigorously defended the Justice Department investigation of the diversion of money from Iran to the Nicaraguan rebels. He disputed accusations that investigators had moved too slowly to preserve sensitive documents in the case.

title: G.M.'S BRIEF FLING WITH PEROT
description: When Roger B. Smith announced that the General Motors Corporation would buy the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 1984, he made it clear that he wanted to acquire H. Ross Perot's entrepreneurial spirit as well as the assets of the company.

title: Article 239486 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Moynihan's 48 Hours
description: They're feeling a heady sense of power in the office of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan these days. On Nov. 13 the New York Democrat said President Reagan should ask his national security adviser, Vice Adm.

title: MURDER JURY TOLD OF SECT INTRIGUES
description: The murder trial of a one-time Hare Krishna member, who is at the center of investigations into charges of criminal misconduct by the sect, began here today with defense lawyers describing intrigues involving sex and drugs among members of the sect.

title: Pacific Western To Buy CP Air
description: The Pacific Western Airlines Corporation, a profitable regional carrier, said today that it had agreed to buy Canada's second-largest airline, CP Air, for $300 million Canadian ($217 million American).

title: U.S. REVIEWING HELMSLEYS' BILLS FOR RENOVATION
description: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said yesterday that it was conducting a ''review'' to determine whether Harry and Leona Helmsley had illegally billed their real-estate and hotel business for renovations on their Greenwich, Conn., estate.

title: THE NONMEDALLION CABS: WHO PROVIDES THE SERVICE
description: Most drivers who participated in yesterday's demonstrations work for community car services, which account for about 20,000 of the estimated 47,000 for-hire vehicles that provide car service to residents of New York City.

title: MISSING DEFENDANT IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL IS FOUND SLAIN
description: A defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial who had been reported missing last Thursday was found slain yesterday, his body wrapped inside a plastic garbage bag and dumped on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: DON MALKAMES
description: Don Malkames, a cinematographer, inventor and authority on the technical history of the motion picture, died Nov. 24 at his home in Yonkers. He was 82 years old.

title: Foote, Cone Units Get Berlin Promotion
description: As it prepared for its 750th anniversary next year, Berlin, or at least the part in the west, has retained the various units of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications to stimulate tourism to the city.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization Nov. 28 Nov. 21 Nov. 29 1986 1986 1985 Gasoline production, daily 7.0 7.1 6.5 Distillate production, daily 3.1 3.0 3.3 Gasoline stocks 224.5 223.3 213.4 Distillate stocks 147.5 150.2 135.9 Crude imports, daily 3.4 4.7 2.5 Product imports, daily 1.8 2.3 2.2 Crude stocks 347.0 343.9 314.8 Crude production, daily 8.5 8.5 8.9 Refinery utilization (%) 84.4 84.2 80.2 Source: American Petroleum Institute

title: CML GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
REAGAN TO OFFER BUDGET JAN. 5
description: President Reagan has decided to send the key elements of his budget for the fiscal year 1988 to Congress on Jan. 5, a full month earlier than Administration officials had previously indicated, his budget director, James C. Miller 3d, said today.

title: Ex-Gaming Official Tells of His Doubts On Newton Candor
description: A former Nevada gaming official testified today that he believed Wayne Newton was not entirely truthful with investigators looking into the entertainer's relationship with a reputed crime figure.

title: How to Talk High Tech
description: Of all the world's languages, perhaps none is so foreign to most English speakers as the one used by scientists and engineers.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Notes
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday began offering $200 million of 7 3/4 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.75 to yield 7.81 percent, or about 1.14 percentage points over Treasury notes with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Golden Touch Remains
description: Mike Schmidt, the Phillies' third baseman, won his 10th Gold Glove award, the most among active major leaguers, and Keith Hernandez of the Mets was cited for his fielding at first base for the ninth time. The Yankees had two players on the American League Gold Glove team, Don Mattingly at first base and Ron Guidry, the pitcher. The Gold Glove teams are chosen by a vote of managers and coaches.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AMERICAN TALK. The Words and Ways of American Dialects. By Robert Hendrickson. 230 pages. Viking. $18.95. ''IT seemed to me that regional speech is in the process of disappearing, not gone but going,'' wrote John Steinbeck, describing a trip he took across America in the early 1960's. ''Forty years of radio and twenty years of television must have this impact. Communications must destroy localness, by a slow, inevitable process. I remember a time when I could almost pinpoint a man's place of origin by his speech. That is growing more difficult now and will in some foreseeable future become impossible.''

title: North Told Group He Met Reagan Often
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the ousted White House aide, told a church delegation in February that he personally briefed President Reagan twice a week on terrorism and Central America, according to members of the group.

title: The Limited Sets Expansion Plan
description: The Limited Inc. said it plans to build several office buildings and other operations here at a cost of $241 million.

title: NOW TO RENEW RIGHTS DRIVE IN 1987
description: At a bittersweet gala celebrating its 20th anniversary, the National Organization for Women announced Monday night that next year it would renew the fight to have an equal rights amendment to the Constitution ratified.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CUBICULO The Cubiculo Theater is a small but professional theater in a five-story brownstone at 414 West 51st Street, an unusually tidy and quiet West Side block between Ninth and 10th Avenues. In 1963, Elaine Sulka and Philip Meister established the National Shakespeare Company, dedicated to the performance of intimate, chamber-scale productions of classics. The troupe has spent a good deal of its time on the road, but it is returning this month to share the house with a new resident company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We think that we have a statutory basis to believe that a Federal law may have been violated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1986
description: Markets

title: Doremus Adds Financial Head
description: John E. Eckelberry, 52-year-old director of financial advertising at Doremus & Company, the largest of the Wall Street ad agencies, has been promoted to president, Doremus Financial Advertising, a new title.

title: Flames Tie Islanders
description: Joey Mullen scored on a penalty shot with less than seven minutes left in the third period, boosting the Calgary Flames to a 3-3 tie tonight with the Islanders.

title: IN YONKERS, STUDENTS ADJUST TO INTEGRATION
description: As desegregation came to classrooms here this fall, school officials warned privately that if rumblings of Little Rock or South Boston were to be felt anywhere in this blue-collar Westchester County city, Lincoln High School would be the place.

title: Norway Lifts Key Rate
description: Norway's central bank announced an increase today of two percentage points in its key interest rate as a result of pressure on the krone in foreign-exchange markets. The overnight lending rate was raised to 16 percent in an effort to halt a run on the currency that started two weeks ago.

title: 16 Medallion Replicas Missing at Taxi Panel
description: The City Comptroller charged yesterday that the Taxi and Limousine Commission was unable to account for 16 replicas of taxi medallions - identical to the genuine article - that were minted last year for use in movies or on retirement plaques.

title: In a Smuggler's Paradise, Truffles Amid Trouble
description: ''We never had poor people here before,'' said a merchant in the labryinthine Hammadiya souk, the traditional center of this city's commerce, as he waited for the lights to come back on after the daily morning power interruption. ''Now we have them.''

title: France to Buy Norway Gas
description: France has approved its part of a $70 billion deal to buy natural gas from Norway after earlier threatening to pull out, Norway's Oil and Energy Minister, Arne Oeien, announced.

title: Reagan Changes His Tune
description: President Reagan has changed his tune and moved part way to quell the crisis over Iran and Nicaragua, but the uproar goes on.

title: L.I.R.R. Union Votes For 4 1/2-Year Contract
description: Long Island Rail Road conductors and trainmen have overwhelmingly approved a new four-and-a-half-year contract, the general chairman of the United Transportation Union, Edward Yule Jr., said yesterday.

title: Fryar's Mistake With a Receiver
description: When Irving Fryar, the New England Patriot wide receiver, lost control of his car and crashed into a tree in Foxboro, Mass., on Nov. 23, the accident raised a few eyebrows.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RAIL ACCIDENT
description: A passenger train backed into a stationary freight train at rush hour this morning, injuring 125 black passengers and two crew members, officials said. Ten of the injured were hospitalized.

title: A NEW COACH, SAME OLD RESULT
description: As promised, the players were more relaxed. Rather than waiting for a booming voice to orchestrate their every step, they played basketball instictively, running at every opportunity.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
BREAKFAST'S BEST
description: BREAKFAST with Ceres is always a good idea. Invite her to the table in the morning and her warm ministrations will propel you through the day. Even if the Roman goddess of agriculture is busy freelancing in Nebraska that day, sample her handiwork in the form of hot breakfast cereals. The more basic, the better.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago results include Intercredit Corp., which was sold in April 1986.

title: State Dept. Aides Criticize Ransom
description: A Texas billionaire's revelation that he was asked by a White House aide to put up $2 million as ransom for the release of four Americans in Lebanon was described by senior State Department officials today as further evidence that White House officials were ready to violate the Administration's anti-terrorism policy to free the hostages.

title: CHIP MAKER TURNING TO JAPAN
description: Signaling that it would join the race among American semiconductor makers to find Japanese partners, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it would begin to explore possible ''alliances and cooperative agreements'' with its customers and other industry manufacturers worldwide.

title: For Chairmen, Less Influence
description: County chairmen of political parties in New York State wield considerable influence, particularly in the nomination and selection of judges from the State Supreme Court level down.

title: Plan for a Special Counsel Is Welcomed in the Congress
description: Congressional leaders said today that they welcomed President Reagan's decision to have a special prosecutor investigate the secret Iran dealings.

title: Bear Is Suspended
description: Otis Wilson, a linebacker for the Bears, was suspended for one game without pay yesterday in connection with an incident in Chicago's game against the Steelers last Sunday. Commissioner Pete Rozelle, in announcing the ban, cited Wilson's ''flagrant forearm blow to the jaw'' of Louis Lipps, a wide receiver.

title: Pardee Goes to Houston
description: Jack Pardee, a Southwest Conference star fullback in the 1950's at Texas A&M, returned to the conference as head coach at the University of Houston.

title: Maximum of 6.75% Set In Dormitory Repricing
description: A $152.37 million refunding by the New York State Dormitory Authority for New York University is offering a maximum yield of 6.75 percent for a 6.7 percent bond, due in 2011, at a price of 99.402, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds, which were tentatively priced earlier this week, were repriced yesterday with some yields adjusted up slightly and others down slightly.

title: CHICAGO G.O.P. SELECTS A DEMOCRAT FOR MAYOR
description: A special Republican search committee here has chosen Donald Haider, a business professor who is a Democrat, as the party's officially endorsed nominee for Mayor next year.

title: Time at the Top
description: Everyone now knows that Mike Tyson became the youngest heavyweight champion in history at the age of 20 years 4 months 22 days - ''and I'm going to be the oldest,'' he said. For that to happen, he would need to retain his crown for more than 18 years 4 months.

title: NOW ABOUT PUERTO RICO'S HARD PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: TEAMSTER CHIEF WAS INFORMER, U.S. AIDE SAYS
description: Justice Department official acknowledged for the first time today that Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: NO PATTERN TO N.B.A. INJURIES
description: Enroute to the Midwest Division title last season, the Houston Rockets were 36-5 at home. After 20 straight victories, they finally lost their first home game when the Utah Jazz beat them Jan. 14. The Rockets are 5-3 at home so far this season and 7-7 overall going into last night's game against the Golden State Warriors in Oakland, Calif.

title: A Potential for Rivalries Is Seen in Investigations
description: Tension is likely to develop between simultaneous investigations by Congress and an independent counsel into the Reagan Administration's dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, legal experts said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.9 billion of debentures with maturities of 3 years, 7 years and 10 years through various securities dealers.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $600,000 for the latest year and $639,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: JACKSON LENDS HIS ASSISTANCE
description: Mark Jackson led the nation in assists last season, and for the first two games this season, the senior guard concentrated on his playmaking again.

title: Chief Repays F.H.L.B.B.
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has repaid $13,868 for a chartered private jet and $11,899 in expense money he received as reimbursement for trips taken by his wife, his lawyers said today.

title: THE THEATER: 'DREAM'
description: WHEN Sparrow, a young black painter from South Africa, sets foot in Greenwich Village for the first time, he prays out loud: ''New York, are you the New Jerusalem in the desert? You are a long way from Jo-burg, the city of gold and blood.'' No sooner has Sparrow (Lanyard Williams) set up shop as a street artist than he meets Sharon (Lorey Hayes), a bright, attractive hospital technician, and soon they have set up housekeeping in her apartment. Sparrow's first weeks in America are heady, and he marvels at his expatriate life in the language of a love-struck child. ''Chicken and rice, paradise'' sums up his vision of America's bounteous promise. His artistic goal, he announces, is nothing less than ''to paint our race - to paint our dreams.''

title: U.S. Offers New Rules Covering Child Support
description: Regulations to improve interstate enforcement of orders for the support of children were proposed today by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Otis R. Bowen, who said states must give more attention to the problem.

title: PROPOSAL WOULD TAP SOCIAL SECURITY PAYMENTS
description: Government report recommends deducting from monthly Social Security checks the charges for unpaid hospital bills of individual recipients who have not paid their share of Medicare-covered treatment.

title: Moscow Reaction Restrained So Far
description: The Soviet Union's reaction to the foreign policy crisis in Washington has been relatively restrained so far, and Soviet officials have made clear they are not yet prepared to write off President Reagan as a negotiating partner.

title: FUJI, ISUZU PLAN U.S. AUTO PLANT
description: Two major Japanese manufacturers, Fuji Heavy Industries and Isuzu Motors Ltd., announced plans today to build a $500 million car and truck assembly plant in what is now mostly cornfields near Lafayette, Ind.

title: Bus Accident Injures 18 Riders and Driver
description: Nineteen people were injured, none seriously, when a city bus crashed into an the pillar of an elevated line in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: WHEREIN SANTA MEETS HIS MATCH IN FOOD AND WINE
description: It was three weeks before Christmas, and all through the City, There were grumblings and mumblings and moans of self-pity; ''The cops are on sickout, the cabbies on slowdown, And Wall Street's disgraced by in-trading on lowdown; The mild winter weather's turned frigid and rainy And Washington's drenched once again by Khomeini, For the President's stirred universal aversions By furtively trading TOW missiles to Persians.'' Distraught by the wearisome state of the hemisphere I was trying to decide between Mars and Australia. When out on the street there arose such a clatter, I sprang from my couch to see what was the matter. Below pranced a figure, as festive as Saturn, Crying ''Let me persuade you to stay in Manhattan.

title: DISTILLER'S PARTY, A CAR CRASH, A DEATH AND A WIDENING SUIT
description: Sometime after midnight last July 19, Donald James, a 54-year-old marketing executive for the Brown-Forman Corporation, left a party given by that liquor distilling concern at the exclusive Jefferson Club and headed toward home in his 1986 Dodge van. A few minutes later, as he hurtled out of a curve on River Road, the van crashed head on into a 1976 orange Volkswagen driven by Don E. Payton.

title: HOW GIANTS MIRED, THEN BURIED, 49ERS
description: The five major plays for the Giants in their remarkable victory over the San Francisco 49ers on Monday night began with the tackle of Don Griffin by Pepper Johnson on the second-half kickoff.

title: LETTERS: BABIES AND SLEEP
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SCREEN: 'HALF LIFE,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: ON March 1, 1954, the United States dropped a hydrogen bomb on Bikini Atoll, in the Marshall Islands, which came under American trusteeship after World War II. Radioactive fallout from the powerful test, called Bravo, spread over hundreds of miles, settling in the form of whitish particles on three tiny atolls downwind from the blast.

title: A GUIDE TO AGENCIES IN NEED OF HELPING HANDS
description: IN nearly every community, volunteers and donations are regularly needed by churches that help the homeless and hungry, day-care centers, centers for the elderly, hospitals, youth centers and cultural groups.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 21 about the criminal record of Larry Davis, who is accused of having shot six New York City police officers, misstated details of another assault, on Oct. 30, in which he is suspected of having killed four men. According to the police, the shootings occurred at 829 Southern Boulevard in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, not at No. 839 in the Longwood section. And the victims - all in their 30's, not their 20's - were killed the same day they were found.

title: JACOB C. RICH
description: Jacob C. Rich, who was a writer and editor for nearly 60 years for The Jewish Daily Forward, died Saturday at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx. He was 93 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: HORACE GRAY
description: Horace Gray, an economist who was a member of the War Labor Board under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died Monday.

title: BRZEZINSKI DEMURS
description: ''President Reagan and His Operators'' (editorial, Dec. 2) contains an allegation that I and other National Security advisers were involved ''as operators in activities that skirted the law.'' Speaking for myself, I can say categorically that this statement is untrue. I was never engaged as an operator in any activity that skirted the law. Zbigniew Brzezinski Washington, Dec. 2, 1986

title: SANTA'S HELPERS TRY TO ASSIST YOUNG NEW YORKERS
description: The letter was short, but its message clear: ''Dear Santa, I am asking you if you would please give my sister and me and my mom and dad a new house. If you do, I promise we will never ask you for anything else again.''

title: LETTERS: BABIES AND SLEEP
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: How Contras Got Arms: An Account From a Crew
description: The same planes and crews that were contracted by the State Department to carry ''humanitarian aid'' to the Nicaraguan rebels were used at other times to supply them with weapons, according to two sources who worked in the covert program.

title: HILL DISMANTLES TWIN TOWERS
description: The Twin Towers have tumbled.

title: Dismissal in Jostling Is Denied by Judge
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge refused a defense request yesterday to dismiss a jostling charge brought against Kirk Lightsey, the jazz pianist.

title: BRITISH HOUSE TOURS MIX HISTORY AND ART
description: IN In the old kitchens of Elton Hall, a stately 17th-century country house in east England, stands a large coach, specially made to transport the earl of the manor to Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee. It is an elaborate creation, typical of its time, with carved ivory window frames. The coachman's greatcoat is equally well preserved. ''And when we opened an old chest, we found the big muffs and traveling rugs the family used for the journey,'' said Meredyth Proby, who lives at Elton Hall with her husband William and three small children.

title: STAGE: 'THE FOX,' AN ADAPTION OF LAWRENCE TALE
description: D.H. LAWRENCE was a hunter of symbols, and his story ''The Fox'' exhibits a prize specimen. In Allen Miller's intelligent adaptation now at the Westbeth Theater, the title applies both to the animal that has been raiding the henhouse and the soldier who enters through the front door. The farm is run, not very well, by two 30-year-old women who have determined to find freedom by striking out on their own. When we meet Jill and Nellie in the homey room designed by Byron Taylor, they seem about to strike out altogether. ''The fox is stealing all our hens,'' says Jill. Winter is upon them, and they may not have the cash to survive.

title: Market Place; Approaching A 2,000 Dow
description: NOW that the Dow Jones industrial average has decisively broken out of a seven-month trading range between 1,720 and 1,920, some investment professionals see it sweeping ahead to 2,000 - and beyond.

title: Dr. Robert Morison, 8, Dies; Sciences Chief at Foundation
description: Dr. Robert S. Morison, a neurophysiologist and a former director of medical and natural sciences at the Rockefeller Foundation, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Nashua, N.H. He was 80 years old and lived in Peterborough, N.H.

title: Lee Goodwin, Ex-State Housing Chief
description: Lee Goodwin, a former New York State Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. She was 56 years old and lived in Southampton, L.I.

title: SEXUAL POLITICS AND A SLAYING: ANGER AT CHAMBERS'S DEFENSE
description: In the more than three months of publicity and pretrial maneuvering since the death of Jennifer Dawn Levin, the killing of the 18-year-old in Central Park has grown from a criminal case into a conflict over the treatment of women under the law, according to lawyers, journalists and feminists who have followed the case.

title: BCI Selling Unit
description: BCI Holdings signed a definitive agreement to sell the Beatrice Companies' personal products operations - known as International Playtex Inc. - for $1.25 billion to an investment group led by Joel E. Smilow, the chairman and president of Playtex. The payment would consist of $1.15 billion in cash and $100 million in new preferred stock. BCI would retain a 20 percent stake in the company. In addition to Mr. Smilow, the investors include 22 Playtex managers and several institutional investors led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1986
description: International

title: Dr. Theodore Curphey Dies; Was Coroner for Los Angeles
description: Dr. Theodore Curphey, the pathologist who became the first medical examiner for Los Angeles County and presided over the inquiry into the death of Marilyn Monroe, died Nov. 27.

title: GOTTI WITNESS RECOUNTS PLOT TO KILL F.B.I. AGENT
description: A hired killer testifying for the prosecution in the trial of John Gotti told a Federal jury yesterday that he plotted in 1982 to murder an F.B.I. agent who had made him angry.

title: S.E.C. Requests Icahn Records
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that he had been asked to supply some documents to the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the Boesky insider-trading investigation. But he said he had not been asked to testify in the case.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Tinkering With Justice
description: The criminal justice system, its students warn, is hopelessly interdependent. The simplest tinkering with any part may have drastic consequences for others, and nowhere is that more evident than with the process of sentencing criminals. Small changes may create impossible burdens. That should have been the first concern of a panel established to reform sentencing by the Federal courts. Yet the group's initial report makes it seem secondary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Desi Arnaz yesterday listed a survivor incorrectly. His wife, the former Edith Mack Hirsch, died in 1985.

title: Bernstein and Ronstadt Issue Appeal on AIDS
description: In conjunction with a benefit scheduled for this Sunday, Leonard Bernstein and Linda Ronstadt have made an urgent appeal to the public to support AIDS research.

title: The Arms Market: Shadowy World
description: Operating in the shadows of the international arms market is an army of globe-trotting private entrepreneurs with contacts in high places and access to warehouses of weapons.

title: Beck Invited to Return
description: Barry Beck played in only 25 games last season and during the summer he quit the team. But the new Ranger coach, Tom Webster, wants him back.

title: BankAmerica to Sell Italian Unit to German Bank
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Italian subsidiary, the Banca d'America e d'Italia, to Deutsche Bank A.G. of West Germany for $603 million.

title: CHANGES IN LABOR LAW STUDIED BY BOTH PARTIES
description: As part of an effort to meet problems linked to the nation's high trade deficits, leaders of the new Democratic-controlled Congress and the Reagan Administration are separately exploring sweeping changes in the labor laws.

title: Costly 'Victory' in South Korea
description: The 70,000-man army deployed on the streets of Seoul last weekend was not meant to repel a Communist invasion from the North but a democratic mobilization in the South. In that, South Korea's Government succeeded all too well. This inappropriate show of force can only complicate the crisis over the South Korean presidential succession in 1988. The democratic opposition now threatens to boycott the National Assembly. By frustrating the most prudent opposition forces, the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan jeopardizes its own legitimacy and American security interests.

title: POLICE PURSUING IDEA FOR MOTIVE IN PIZZA SLAYING
description: Detectives investigating the murder of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial are leaning toward the theory that he was killed because he was preparing to cooperate with prosecutors, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Joseph R. Bolker Dead at 62; Major California Developer
description: Joseph R. Bolker, a Southern California developer and philanthropist, died of cancer last Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, an aide said today. He was 62 years old.

title: Reward in Kidnapping
description: A person providing a tip that led to a kidnapped baby last month will be awarded $42,000, the reward fund's administrator said today. Week-old Phillip Worthington had been taken from his mother's arms at a Bucks County hospital by a woman posing a nurse. A Maryland couple was arrested on kidnapping charges.

title: British Gas Filings
description: An estimated 5 million investors have applied to buy shares in the British Gas Corporation by the deadline for the world's biggest stock offering, bank officials said.

title: FRANK McCARTHY DEAD AT 74; GENERAL WAS FILM PRODUCER
description: Frank McCarthy, a motion picture producer and retired brigadier general whose 1970 film ''Patton'' won seven Academy Awards, died Monday night at the Motion Picture and Television Fund Hospital at the age of 74. The cause of his death was not announced.

title: DEFENDANT WARNS PARIS JURY AT OPENING OF TERRORIST TRIAL
description: Three defendants, all said to be members of the ultraleftist terrorist group known as Direct Action, went on trial here today for the murder of two policemen on a Paris street three years ago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: British Caledonian Airways said today that it had placed a $1 billion order for nine McDonnell Douglas MD-11 aircraft, becoming the first carrier to order the proposed wide-bodied jets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sidney Moncrief's right leg has been placed in a cast, and the Milwaukee Bucks' all-star guard is not expected to return to the Milwaukee Bucks for several weeks. Moncrief, who has missed seven of the team's 18 games this season, has been on the injured list since Nov. 26 with tendinitis in his right knee. . . . Mary Decker Slaney will likely miss the indoor track season while she is recovering from surgery last week to repair damage to her right Achilles' tendon.

title: Shredders: Better Than Bonfires
description: In this capital city of paper and secrets, one thing that often comes between the most classified of documents and the eyes of a curious public is the paper shredder.

title: Baxter to Cut 5,000 by April
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said today that it would eliminate about 5,000 salaried jobs by April 1987, ending redundancies that resulted from the acquisition of the American Hospital Supply Corporation.

title: KEEPING BULBS IN ORDER
description: HOMEOWNERS have for years resorted to old grapefruit boxes to store fragile Christmas bulbs, but now ornament boxes are made specifically for this purpose.

title: Nancy Reagan Denies She Advised Changes
description: President Reagan's wife, Nancy, denied today that she had urged her husband to dismiss the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz over the Iran arms affair.

title: SEMINARY LEADER'S MANIFEST DEFINES CONSERVATIVE JUDAISM
description: The Chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary, in a major speech on the state of Conservative Judaism, has sharply distinguished it from the Orthodox and Reform branches on two important issues in contemporary Jewish life: the participation of women and patrilineal descent.

title: 'Analytical' Engineer Beats a Speeding Ticket
description: An electrical engineer, acting as his own attorney, was acquitted of a speeding charge after persuading a judge that the speed limit signs violated state standards.

title: C.I.A. DEIES HANDLING FUNDS DIVERTED TO CONTRAS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, in an unusual public statement, denied today that its bank accounts had been used for diversion of money from the proceeds of the Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels ''or any other covert action programs.''

title: 'MIX-UP,' MOTHERS WHO GOT EACH OTHER'S BABIES
description: IT must be every parent's nightmare. In 1936, two women entered a hospital in Nottingham, England, where each gave birth to a daughter. Leaving the hospital, one woman, Margaret Wheeler, was absolutely convinced that she had been given the wrong child (''I had a full-term baby, this one had signs of prematurity''). The other, Blanche Rylatt, was just as certain that no mistake had been made.

title: Accounts
description: * Clairol to Calet, Hirsch & Spector for Logics Colorcreme Collection and another unnamed professional haircare product.

title: Acknowledge Nazi Past, Austria Is Urged
description: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky urged Austrians today to acknowledge their country's Nazi past and accept their share of the guilt and responsibility.

title: FIRST COMMODITY CORP. SAYS IT WILL LIQUIDATE
description: Faced with one of the most serious scandals to strike the commodities industry, executives of the First Commodity Corporation said today that they planned to liquidate their company and sell its assets to an unnamed British buyer.

title: Lewis Carroll Drawings Bring a Record Price
description: Nine drawings from ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' that were identified recently by a New York book dealer as copies made by Lewis Carroll of John Tenniel illustrations were sold yesterday at Sotheby's in London for a record at auction for a children's manuscript.

title: 2 Guards Disciplined After Prison Escape
description: Two guards who were on duty the night four inmates escaped from an AIDS ward at a state prison were suspended yesterday for neglect of duty, a Corrections Department spokesman said.

title: CATHOLICS MAY CUT CITY FOSTER CARE
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has warned the Koch administration that because of a recent court agreement, it is giving serious consideration to discontinuing the foster care it now provides to more than 3,000 city youngsters.

title: MURDOCH TO PURCHASE AUSTRALIAN NEWS GROUP
description: In a move that surprised Australia's business and media community, Rupert Murdoch on Wednesday began a $1.17 billion bid for the nation's largest newspaper group, The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd.

title: THEATER: 'SOLDIER'S TALE'
description: THE Flying Karamazov Brothers, those amiable juggling comedians from San Francisco, have assayed something rather more ambitious in an expanded version of Stravinsky's ''Soldier's Tale.'' The performance, lasting over two hours with one intermission, opened Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Carey Playhouse as part of the Next Wave Festival, and it will continue every evening through Sunday, with a Sunday matinee.

title: Muller, Jordan to Get All of Stroehmann
description: Stroehmann Bakeries, the largest independent in the Northeast, will consolidate all of its advertising at Muller, Jordan, Weiss on Jan. 1.

title: F.D.A. IS FAULTED ON IMPORTED FOOD
description: Less than 1 percent of the fruits and vegetables imported annually into the United States are inspected for pesticides and other chemicals that are barred for domestic use because of safety concerns, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Taipei dispatch on Monday, about clashes between Taiwanese demonstrators and the police, misstated President Chiang Ching-kuo's position on martial law. He has promised to lift all martial law provisions, but not until formal legislative approval is obtained early next year.

title: VETERANS SEEKING COUNSEL OF CHOICE
description: A Federal district judge heard testimony today in a case in which a group of veterans are seeking to overturn a 19th century law that they say prevents them from properly pursuing claims against the Veterans Administration.

title: Emil Jonsson, 84, Dies; Iceland Leader in 50's
description: Emil Jonsson, a former Prime Minister and venerable Icelandic politician, has died, his family said Tuesday. He was 84.

title: KEY RATES
ENCYCLOPEDIC MUSEUM: REVIEWING THE ORSAY
description: Long awaited, and in principle much contested for its mixture of great and famous Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings with long-forgotten paintings and sculptures of quite another kind, the Musee d'Orsay in Paris will open its doors to the public on Tuesday. It has been inspected by present, past and aspirant heads of the French state, as befits a project that was approved under President Georges Pompidou, furthered under President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and brought to fulfillment under President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Former Congressman Is Granted a Parole
description: Former Representative George V. Hansen, an Idaho Republican, will be paroled Dec. 20 after serving six months of a 15-month prison term for fraud and lying on his Federal financial disclosure forms, the Federal Parole Commission said today.

title: Firestone to Sell Unit
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it had agreed to sell its Firestone Steel Products division to the Accuride Corporation, which was formed by the division's management and Bain Capital. Firestone did not disclose a price, but said the division had sales of about $215 million in the year ended Oct. 31. The unit, which has facilities in Henderson, Ky., and London, Ontario, produces wheels and rims.

title: Husky Oil Sells 43% Stake
description: The parent of Husky Oil Ltd., a major Canadian oil and gas producer, said today that it would sell a 43 percent stake in Husky to Hong Kong interests in a complex deal valued at $1.5 billion, or $1.08 billion in United States currency.

title: Wine, Roses and Song
description: In the race for House whip, the third-ranking leadership post, the favorite, Representative Tony Coelho of California, sent a gift of wine and roses to an uncommitted Representative, who prefers not to be identified.

title: Unilever May Sell 2 Pond's Divisions
description: Unilever N.V. said today that it might sell Chesebrough Pond's Inc.'s Prince tennis racquet and Bass shoe divisions, after it completed its $3.1 billion acquisition of Chesebrough.

title: Foreign Cars in Japan
description: The Japanese are buying a record 65,000 foreign cars this year, up 30 percent from 1985, because of the strong yen and lower oil prices, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.

title: JARUZELSKI LAUDS POLICY REVERSALS
description: Uncustomary reversals of policy decisions in Parliament and by the Government-backed trade unions are being described by Polish Government officials as proof of growing democratic practices here.

title: Boxing Notebook; SALOON CHAMPION SWINGS FOR PRO TITLE
description: Greg Haugen fights Jimmy Paul for Paul's International Boxing Federation lightweight championship tomorrow night in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Broadcasting Museum Offers Carnegie Shows
description: The Museum of Broadcasting is presenting more than 30 hours of Carnegie Hall radio and television broadcasts in a series timed to coincide with the reopening of Carnegie Hall after seven months of renovation. Jack Benny, Arturo Toscanini, Margaret Truman, Liza Minnelli, Vladimir Horowitz, Ethel Merman, Benny Goodman, Julie Andrews, Carol Burnett, George Carlin, Andy Kaufman and others will be presented in performances that date from 1934 to the present.

title: SAFETY OF ACTORS CITED BY WITNESS
description: The special effects technician who detonated the explosions that caused the fatal helicopter crash on the set of''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' testified today that because of his concern for the safety of the actors on the ground he never looked up to see the aircraft before he set off the explosives.

title: Goring Tries Comeback
description: He owns four Stanley Cup rings, has played in more than 1,000 National Hockey League games and has been a head coach in the N.H.L., but this week he is in Massachusetts working out with the junior varsity team at Merrimack College.

title: Trump-Padres Report
description: Donald Trump, the real-estate developer who owns the United States Football League's New Jersey Generals, has shown an interest in purchasing the San Diego Padres, according to a published report. The Los Angeles Times reported yesterday that Trump had joined Steve Garvey, the Padres' first baseman, in negotiations to purchase the club.

title: Agency Changes Name To Winkler McManus
description: Winkler Tawa McManus, one of the hot shops in Silicon Valley, has dropped its middle name and opened a Los Angeles office in addition to its original one in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: TURNOVER TOPS 200 MILLION FOR A SECOND DAY
description: Trading volume on Wall Street surpassed 200 million shares yesterday for the second consecutive session, but stock prices declined moderately as investors, while still euphoric over Tuesday's big rally, decided it was wise to collect some of the profits.

title: Yale Protesters Cleared by Judge
description: A Superior Court judge has dismissed misdemeanor charges against 20 people who were arrested in anti-apartheid demonstrations at Yale University in September.

title: An Executive at Aetna Takes on Added Role
description: William O. Bailey, the 60-year-old president of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of MBIA Inc., a new municipal bond insurer.

title: LEFTIST BOOKS SEIZED BY POLICE IN WAKE OF TROOPER'S SLAYING
description: Books and pamphlets on political protest, communism and revolution were seized at a farmhouse after it had been hastily abandoned by two men on trial in a state trooper's slaying, testimony and exchanges in Superior Court revealed today.

title: PERU'S IMPORT PRICES
description: Peru's Government raised the effective price of more than 2,000 types of imported goods by 25 percent today in a measure aimed at reversing Peru's first monthly negative trade balances since 1982. The measure was ordered by the central bank.

title: OUTLOOK UNCERTAIN FOR MESA'S OFFER
description: The $2.03 billion offer for the Diamond Shamrock Corporation begun today by T. Boone Pickens is a logical step by the head of Mesa Limited Partnership to bring together two complementary oil and gas concerns, analysts said.

title: DEAL ON HUGHES CASINO PURCHASE IS LINKED TO 1970 PLEA BY LAXALT
description: John N. Mitchell, a former Attorney General of the United States, says one reason he approved Howard R. Hughes's purchase of a Las Vegas hotel in 1970 was that Paul Laxalt, then Governor of Nevada, personally intervened in Mr. Hughes's behalf, according to The San Jose Mercury News.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Bush in Capital: 'And if the Truth Hurts, So Be It'
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Bush's speech to the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network.

title: HAWAII IN N.Y.: SCENTS AND SHIRTS
description: WHEN Gregory Frangipani, near left, went to high school in Hawaii, he was so enamored of the scent of the native frangipani flower that he named his new shop after it and legally changed his name from Pettigrew to Frangipani. He and his partner, Raymond Strickland, far left, sell Hawaiian orchids, cigar flowers and other exotic blooms, leis, new and antique vases and Hawaiian shirts in their shop, designed by Wayne Turett of Turett/Freyer Collaborative Architects and Karen Heafitz.

title: Kirk Pleads Not Guilty
description: Dana Kirk, former basketball coach at Memphis State, pleaded not guilty yesterday to all 11 counts in a Federal indictment that included charges of tax evasion, fraud and obstruction of justice. A trial date would normally be set in the next two months, but Kirk's attorneys have asked for more time to prepare their case, according to Hickman Ewing, a United States attorney.

title: MINATURE TV'S AND CD'S AND OTHER ELECTRONIC GIFTS
description: IN their effort to keep the kettle boiling, electronics manufacturers churn out new products at a pace alarming to sober-minded bystanders. Especially when choosing gifts for the holidays, consumers may be perplexed by the plethora of new products with highly technical claims of superiority. Even retailers complain that by the time a new stereo component, video device or home computer reaches their shelves, an updated version is already waiting at the factory loading dock.

title: CONFLICTS ABOUND IN OFFICIALS' ACCOUNTS
description: The Reagan Administration's evolving account of arms sales to Iran and the diversion of money to Nicaraguan rebels contains many inconsistencies, a thorough review of remarks by Administration officials shows.

title: Sanson Candelaria, 45, Dies; Danced With the Trockadero
description: Sanson Candelaria, a dancer who performed with Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, the Boston Ballet and Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, died Oct. 30 at the Cabrini Medical Center in New York after a long illness. He was 45 years old.

title: Blackmun Won't Take Family Planning Prize
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United State Supreme Court has declined a family planning organization's top annual award after a protest by an anti-abortion group.

title: Sydenham Hospital Gets a New Role
description: The doors of Sydenham are about to reopen. Not as the municipal hospital for which hundreds of Harlem neighbors did battle six years ago. Instead, the vacant 10-story building at 565 Manhattan Avenue has been turned into 102 apartments for the elderly and handicapped by a nonprofit development group.

title: Acronym Gap Less Severe Than Reported
description: To the Editor:

title: GUINNESS INVESTIGATION LOOKS AT STOCK ACTION
description: The British Government's investigation of Guinness P.L.C. is focusing on suspicious movements in the stock prices of companies involved in the bitter battle to take over the Distillers Company earlier this year, according to sources close to the inquiry.

title: Heisman Landslides
description: Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback who has already won the Maxwell Award as the nation's outstanding college football player, is a heavy favorite to add the Heisman Trophy to his shelf Saturday at the Downtown Athletic Club. He may even be a threat to top O. J. Simpson as the most lopsided winner in the trophy's history.

title: JUSTICES WEIGH ANTI-BIAS LAW IN HEALTH RISK CASE
description: In a case that may affect the rights of AIDS victims, the Supreme Court was told today that a Federal law banning discrimination against people with disabilities did not protect people with contagious diseases.

title: We Get Letters
description: Readers of this page may recall the recent disclosure of an ''acronym gap,'' a Pentagon vulnerability arising from the ability of the Russian alphabet, with more letters, to produce more abbreviations than the English.

title: Senators Weigh Giving Immunity to 2 Who Invoked Fifth
description: The refusals of Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to testify in Congressional hearings means Congress may have difficulty getting to the bottom of the Iran arms sales controversy unless it confers limited immunity on them, legal experts say.

title: Looking Ahead: A Reagan Rebound?
description: President Reagan's effort to rebound from the crippling effects of the Iran arms controversy, which he launched on Tuesday by taking several steps his advisers had been pressing upon him, may have more chance of success than many politicians think. A New York Times/CBS

title: THE DANCE: 3 WORKS BY AILEY
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's annual galas are always family affairs and each year we learn how extended that family is. Tuesday night's opening of the company's four-week season at the City Center featured two New York premieres by Mr. Ailey and, perhaps more symbolically, the kind of heartwarming curtain speeches we have come to expect.

title: Lawmaker Charges T.W.A. With Hiring Discrimination
description: Trans World Airlines discriminates against blacks in its hiring and promotion procedures, the chairman of a House subcommittee investigating employment practices in the airline industry charged yesterday.

title: 11 DESIGNERS ARE HONORED
description: WITH the fanfare typical of an awards ceremony for performing artists, more than 1,000 design professionals gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria Tuesday night to honor this year's inductees to the Interior Design Magazine Hall of Fame.

title: Reliance Raises Mercury Holdings
description: The New York investor Saul P. Steinberg has raised his stake in Mercury Securities by 2 percentage points, to 15.06 percent.

title: William Sandifer, Architect; Planned Empire State Tower
description: William Roper Sandifer, an architect who participated in the design of the Empire State Building and supervised its construction in the early 1930's, died Nov. 25 at Presbyterian Hospital in Denver. He was 85 years old and lived in Evergreen, Colo.

title: MORRIS GROUP'S 'GUESTS' A CHOREOGRAPHIC FROLIC
description: MARK MORRIS'S ''Esteemed Guests,'' for the Joffrey Ballet, and the three works his Mark Morris Dance Group recently presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music were all set to 18th-century music. Since Mr. Morris occasionally lets choreographic ideas just tumble forth, one hoped that, by using music from a period in which wit, fancy and passion were always formally structured, he might develop his own powers of organization. Instead, these works attested to his love of romping choreographically through scores that please him.

title: E.P.A. Imposes Lead Penalties
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will assess $40 million in penalties against E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and three other companies. The agency said Tuesday that there was too much lead in gasoline they handled.

title: VIRUS HELD CAUSE OF A NERVE DISEASE
description: Researchers who last year found a new virus in multiple sclerosis patients now say it is likely that the virus is the long-sought cause of at least some forms of the disease.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A HOLIDAY THRILLER To judge by current interest, the season for thrillers never ends. Styles and outlooks may change in other areas, but the spine-tingler remains a perennial. This observation is prompted by a revival that begins tonight at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street near Riverside Drive (663-2028).

title: CONNER OVERCOMES ROUGH SEAS TO BEAT AMERICA II
description: Stars & Stripes could do little wrong today as it powered through pounding seas and high winds to beat America II by 13 minutes 4 seconds in the America's Cup challenger trials.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Earle Palmer Brown Gets USAir Account
description: USAir, which started out by screening 22 ad agencies, has selected the Earle Palmer Brown Companies of Bethesda, Md., to replace J. Walter Thompson, Washington, which resigned in September to search out bigger flying clients.

title: 2 Fire I. Communities Flooded by Tides
description: The Atlantic Ocean swept across Fire Island to the Great South Bay at two locations yesterday, damaging stores and houses. No injuries were reported.

title: BIAS IS RULED IN DISCIPLINING OF TRANSIT POLICE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the New York City Transit Authority, in disciplining members of its police force, had shown a pattern of favoritism toward white officers and had responded ineffectively to complaints of unequal treatment.

title: Iran and Our Supplicant Psychology
description: America's Iranian arms fiasco has been blamed on the weaknesses of President Reagan's foreign policy approach, chiefly the lack of a coherent strategy and an infatuation with covert operations. In fact, this operation also reflects the misguided way that the United States has dealt with friend and foe for decades - bargaining as if they did not need a deal at least as much as we did.

title: Street Protests Planned By South Koreans
description: South Korea's opposition, thwarted by the police in its bid to hold a huge anti-Government rally in Seoul last week, announced plans today to hold street protests across the country Dec. 13.

title: Coke Classic Makes A Quiet Switch
description: Two of the more interesting telephone calls yesterday were on the same subject: Coca-Cola Classic, which is the original Coca-Cola, is being switched back to McCann-Erickson from SSC&B:Lintas USA after about a year.
