Now, moneywise this is not so important since both agencies are part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, but it is a matter of agency honor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As the various investigations proceed, I have this to say: let the chips fall where they may.

title: USG BUYS BELZBERGS' SHARES
description: Eliminating a potential takeover threat by the Belzberg family of Canada, the USG Corporation said yesterday that it had paid $139.6 million to repurchase 3.1 million of its shares from the First City Financial Corporation, which is controlled by the Belzbergs.

title: Among Newcomers, a Studied Perspective
description: Twenty-three years after he first came to Washington to be a student intern in a Senate office, David E. Price returned this week to start the next phase of his career as a student of Congress.

title: VARIED HOLIDAY CRAFTS SHOWS AND SALES
description: Holiday Decoration Program, auditorium of Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 718-622-4433.

title: B.Y.U. Suspends 3
description: Three starters charged with altering drug prescriptions for powerful painkillers were suspended yesterday by Brigham Young University from playing in the final regular-season game against the Air Force Academy. J. C. VonColln, a junior linebacker from Clearfield, Utah; Trevor Molini, a junior tight end from Reno, and Ladd Akeo, a senior linebacker from Pearl City, Hawaii, will not play Saturday, according to Paul Richards, a university spokesman.

title: Police Clear Building In Search for Davis
description: Acting on a telephone tip, the police evacuated and searched a building in the Melrose section of this borough early yesterday, believing they would find Larry Davis, the fugitive wanted in the shooting of six police officers.

title: 10-YEAR PLAN FOR HOUSING UNDER ATTACK
description: In the first phase of a $4.2 billion, 10-year housing plan, the Koch administration is planning to ask developers for proposals to rebuild up to 3,000 apartments in abandoned city-owned buildings.

title: CABINET GETS FIRST LOOK AT PROPOSED BUDGET
description: President Reagan's Cabinet members got their first look today at what the White House's Office of Management and Budget says their departments would get in the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1988.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Citicorp Global Payment Products, Chicago, appointed Robert V. Christiansen director of its global operations center in Tampa, Fla.

title: Car Sales Up 5.1%; G.M.'s Share Falls
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 5.1 percent in the last 10 days of November over the corresponding sales period in 1985, the nation's major manufacturers reported today.

title: Nicklaus Shortens Play
description: ''I don't think I'm going to be looking for my golf game to be going up,'' Jack Nicklaus said as he announced plans yesterday to cut back his tournament schedule to 10 or less in 1987. Nicklaus, who won the Masters last spring at age 46, played in 16 events this year, not including appearances in Australia and Japan.

title: Statement by Wedtech Says It Faces Big Losses
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that has been the focus of Federal and state investigations, said yesterday that it was facing substantial losses and that its future was in jeopardy.

title: Best Products
description: The Best Products Company yesterday began offering $200 million of 12 5/8 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 1996 at a price of 98.472, to yield 12.90 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The speculative-grade issue, noncallable by the company for three years, is rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by S.& P.

title: ACRONYM GAPLESS SEVERE THAN REPORTED
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: IT was 1973. For months I had been sitting in the archives of the British Museum Library conducting a passionate search for precedent: Like so many of my compeers in the heady days when the Women's Movement was in its ascendency, I was looking for ''lost'' heroines. I saw my mission as a kind of archeology of the passed-over and day after day sifted through letters, memoirs, diaries, court records, hoping to draw some reality from the shards of women's lives.

title: Panel to Require Oaths
description: When the House Foreign Affairs Committee meets next week to look into the Iran-Nicaragua arms connection, it will take the unusual step of putting high-level Reagan Administration officials under oath.

title: TEXAS MURDERER DIES AFTER APPEAL IS REJECTED
description: Michael Wayne Evans, a double murderer, was executed by injection early today for the slaying of a church pianist who was shot and slashed to death as she prayed to God to forgive her attacker.

title: JAZZ: TRIO WITH JACK WALRATH
description: THE trumpeter and composer Jack Walrath, one of the major performers to develop in Charles Mingus's group in the four years before Mr. Mingus's death, is playing at Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street, through Sunday under challenging circumstances.

title: Two Teen-Agers Deny Killing Parents of Actor in 'Dallas'
description: Two young men pleaded not guilty today to charges that they killed the parents of Patrick Duffy, the star of the ''Dallas'' television series, in a robbery last month.

title: Proposed Panel on Salaries
description: City Council leaders have proposed creating an outside committee to advise on salary increases for the Mayor, City Council President, Comptroller, Borough Presidents, City Council members and District Attorneys. A bill to establish the three-member panel are to be considered by the Council's Governmental Operations Committee at a public hearing today. Noon, Committee Room, City Hall

title: 4 BOSTON STUDENTS WIN A TEST ON FREE SPEECH
description: A Massachusetts Superior Court judge ruled Tuesday that Boston University violated the free speech rights of four students when it threatened to evict them from their dormitories for hanging political banners out their windows.

title: Toy Helicopter Recalled
description: A flying toy helicopter sold by a Wisconsin company is being recalled, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES BRIGHAM YOUNG - Suspended J. C. VonColln, linebacker; Trevor Molini, tight end, and Ladd Akeo, linebacker, for the game Saturday against Air Force.

title: OUT-OF-STATERS JOIN IN HELPING NEEDIEST CASES
description: Out-of-state residents are among those contributing to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: AQUINO DISMISSES A CLOSE AIDE FROM HER CABINET
description: President Corazon C. Aquino announced the dismissal today of one of her closest colleagues in government, but failed to announce a second Cabinet change, aparently because of difficulties in settling on a replacement.

title: SURROGATE PARENTHOOD LAWS OPPOSED BY JERSEY BISHOPS
description: New Jersey's Roman Catholic Bishops today called surrogate parenthood ''a legal outrage and a moral disaster'' in a letter to the chairman of the state Senate Judiciary Committee, which is studying bills that would legalize and regulate the practice.

title: The Peace on Earth Gala
description: Peace Links, an organization led by 130 wives of members of Congress, held its first fund event the other night in the ballroom of the Capital Hilton Hotel. Billed as the Peace on Earth Gala, it included dancing to the music of Peter Du-chin's orchestra. Russell Schweickart, a former astronaut who was the evening's principal speaker, looked up at those in the elegant crowd who had paid $250 a ticket and said, ''This is one of the few times I've seen peace people actually having fun.''

title: The Other Wild Arms Deal
description: Lost in the scandal over the Iran-''contra'' arms deal is President Reagan's decision to abandon the SALT II strategic arms treaty. By this extraordinary arms misadventure he removes the present caps on superpower nuclear arsenals, an action almost as baffling as the arms sales to Iran.

title: DEFENSE SUGGESTS SLASHED MODEL WAS LEFT CONFUSED BY THE ATTACK
description: The lawyer for a man accused in the razor slashing of a model last summer suggested yesterday that the model's ''disorientation'' and ''shock'' at the time of the attack may have colored her account of the incident - particularly about the defendant's behavior.

title: Inquiry on Clinic Fire
description: Federal agents who specialize in suspicious fires at abortion clinics have joined state and local investigators searching for the cause of a blaze that destroyed a Planned Parenthood center here.

title: Inquiry at Intelsat Continues
description: The directors of Intelsat, scheduled to meet here Thursday and Friday, may consider dismissing their top two operating executives because of a disputed payment to a mortgage broker, sources close to the international communications satellite consortium said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IS there a certain age when we outgrow children's picture books? Yes and no, to judge from a limited and local sampling. The 8-year-old around our place has more or less lost interest in the simple counting and alphabet books (with one exception to be mentioned shortly) and the books whose primary focuses are shapes and colors. He now leans toward books about machines and whales and the books that come with cassette-tape recordings by movie stars. Yet we who are in our early 50's seem to have regained our simplicity. We almost prefer the colorful and wordless, especially when we are tired. The following list of 10 outstanding picture books represents a compromise between the 8-year-old and the 52-year-old. The younger lobbied for the more sophisticated books. The older was nostalgic for familiar fairy tales.

title: U.S.-Mexico Trade Study
description: A Federal study shows that trade between the United States and Mexico is not being helped much by Government programs.

title: PUNJAB SEEKS ARMY'S HELP ON EXTREMISTS
description: The moderate Sikh leaders who govern Punjab, under pressure to step up the drive against Sikh extremists, agreed tonight to seek help from the army in quelling disturbances and tracking down suspects in several districts in the state.

title: PISTONS BEAT NETS IN OVERTIME
description: Isiah Thomas, at 6 feet 1 inch the smallest player on the court, sneaked in under the boards tonight where little guys are not supposed to go and tapped in a basket that led to the Detroit Pistons' 107-106 overtime victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: 2 Grocery Workers Are Slain By Holdup Men in Brooklyn
description: During the attempted robbery of a Brooklyn grocery store Tuesday, three gunmen shot and killed two employees.

title: PENS OF CARTOONISTS VS. IDEA OF WAR TOYS
description: Many of the country's best-known editorial cartoonists plan to use their newspaper and magazine spots to protest the sale of war toys for Christmas, a time when much of the world celebrates peace on Earth.

title: CUOMO CALLS EXTRA SESSION OF LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would convene a special session of the State Legislature next week to create 23 new judgeships in New York City and to work out a financing plan for the city's subways, buses and commuter rail lines.

title: Carolina Legislators Toughen Dress Code
description: The State House of Representatives on Tuesday voted to bar women wearing slacks and men without ties from the House chamber.

title: BIG PURCHASES BY PUBLISHER
description: The International Thomson Organization Ltd. long ago made a name for itself in the fractious world of British newspapers, led by the fabled Canadian businessman Roy Herbert Thomson, who started out with a small radio station and became one of the press barons of Fleet Street.

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Rise
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities continued to rise yesterday, although the day's best gains were slashed by late profit taking.

title: When Addicts Who Go for Treatment Outside New York Return
description: To the Editor:

title: All Yields Off Slightly
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: OL' BOBBY'S TIME RAN OUT
description: Before Super Bowl XVI in Pontiac, Mich., nearly five years ago, Bobby Layne arrived to toss the ceremonial coin at the kickoff. Then 55 years old, the Hall of Fame quarterback who drove the Detroit Lions to the National Football League championship in 1952 and 1953, was talking in his Texas twang about his philosophy of life. How he hoped he would ''run out of money and breath at precisely the same instant.'' And then, as he did so often, he laughed at himself.

title: 2 MORE OFFICERS SUSPENDED OVER ACCIDENT IN PATROL CAR
description: Two police officers were suspended yesterday after admitting that they drank wine with two other officers while on duty Saturday night and were in a patrol car with them when it struck a car and left the scene, the police said.

title: G.M. to Lay Off 4,500 Employees
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off about 4,500 employees in Michigan and Missouri early next year and reduce production at three assembly plants to avoid offering incentive financing.

title: OFFICIALS OF CITIES VOICE DESPERATION
description: The nation's top city officials ended their annual convention today with even more than their usual demands on the Federal Government. But they also served notice that they were looking increasingly to private assistance for urban social needs.

title: MANLEY THE TALK OF WASHINGTON
description: Here he comes, wearing a running jacket, athletic tights and a toothy grin, ready to talk.

title: He Can Run, Too
description: Nigeria, splendidly represented in the National Basketball Association by the Houston Rockets' 7-foot center, Akeem Olajuwon, and in the National Football League by Donald Igwebuike, a place-kicker with Tampa Bay, may soon have another of its athletes performing for pay in a predominantly American sport. He is a 6-foot-2-inch, 250-pound tailback named Christian Okoye, a 26-year-old member of the Ibo tribe.

title: THE INFLUENTIALS: POWER BROKERS TO CONSUMERS
description: CARL OPPEDAHL is the kind of man who installs telephones for fun. He writes to electronics equipment manufacturers for circuit diagrams, disassembles modems to see what they are made of and subscribes to Portable 100, a magazine for owners of the Tandy Radio Shack model 100 lap-top computer.

title: Dutch Extradite Two I.R.A. Fugitives
description: The Netherlands extradited two Irish Republican Army prison escapees to Northern Ireland today, making them the first I.R.A. men to be extradited from Continental Europe.

title: STUDENTS TERMED WEAK ON WRITING
description: Most of the nation's students can write at a minimal level but they lack the communication and critical thinking skills needed in an advanced society, educators said today in releasing a report on writing achievement in American schools.

title: Denmark Offering
description: Denmark began offering in the United States bond market yesterday a $250 million issue of 7 3/4 percent non-callable notes due in 1996 at a price of par through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The 10-year notes, rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., yield about 7/10 percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: U.S. WITHHOLDS $250 MILLION OVER FLAWS IN NEW BOMBER
description: Citing flaws in the newly deployed B-1B strategic bomber, Air Force officials said today that they had withheld more than $250 million in payments to companies that produce systems for the plane.

title: Sentencing Proposals Faulted by U.S. Aide
description: A Justice Department official said Tuesday that the department was concerned about some revisions proposed for Federal sentencing by the United States Sentencing Commission.

title: Penalty Is Costly As Islanders Lose
description: Glenn Anderson and Mike Krushelnyski scored on a major penalty in the first period to spark the struggling Edmonton Oilers to a 7-1 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: Albany's $85,000-a-Year Nothing Job
description: Every four years New Yorkers elect a lieutenant governor, thereby conferring $85,000 a year on someone for sitting at an empty desk. What's worse, this nothing job can complicate life for the governor. The Legislature might abolish the office, as other states have done. Or it might at least change the nonsensical rule that prevents the governor from choosing his own running mate.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN paint starts to crack, blister or peel most people blame the paint. Usually there are other reasons for the problem.

title: DANCE: BILL T. JONES AND ARNIE ZANE AT NEXT WAVE
description: ''THE ANIMAL TRILOGY'' spills out dance that is as typically the work of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane as anything these choreographers have created. The pieces in the trilogy, which opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a four-performance run in the Next Wave Festival, are filled with punchy acrobatic movement and carefully designed stage pictures and arrangements of dancers and their bodies. Undercurrents of emotion and suggestions of narrative or incident often seethe restlessly below the surface.

title: OHIO CARROUSEL HORSES MAY PRANCE IN BROOKLYN
description: SOME are jumpers, some are prancers and some are standers. But all 48 horses from a classic carrousel that spun for 62 years in an Ohio amusement park are now locked inside a dusty warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: DEFENDANT ADMITTED KILLING, WITNESS TESTIFIES IN SECT CASE
description: A man on trial on a charge of killing a fellow resident of a Hare Krishna religious commune admitted that he had killed the man and asked how to ''dissolve'' the body, a witness testified today.

title: GIVING THE FINEST FINISH TO MAHOGANY
description: Among 18th-century cabinetmakers, some mahoganies may have seemed a little less exciting than others, and ways were often found to enrich the woods' colors and make the figurations more striking.

title: Antihomosexual Violence Begins With Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: A GALA IN LOS ANGELES FOR NEW ART MUSEUM
description: An honor roll of people who make and show art in New York joined their West Coast counterparts Tuesday night at a high-spirited gala to mark the opening of the new Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

title: CONNECTICUT NEWSPAPER REPORTS ON OWNER'S ARREST
description: Two prominent real-estate developers and a former zoning official have been charged in what prosecutors called a bribery conspiracy in Enfield, a suburban town on the Massachusetts border.

title: Iran's New Political Trends
description: The costly mistakes that the United States has made in its covert overtures toward Iran, or toward ''moderate'' elements in that country, suggest the Reagan Administration's assumptions about the political makeup of Iran are seriously misguided.

title: REUVEN FRANK TO LEAVE NBC NEWS
description: Reuven Frank, a prize-winning news producer who was twice the president of NBC News, has been notified that his contract will not be renewed, as part of NBC's campaign to reduce costs.

title: FOR WELL-FURNISHED HOME, GIFTS ON PARADE
description: THE youngsters parading across this page and page C-1 are the festive bearers; their offerings, gifts to embellish the home and make it a place of year-round comfort and cheer.

title: SCHOOLS TAKE ON A SHIFTING JOB MARKET
description: As New York City's economy shifts from manufacturing to service industries, its high schools are struggling to prepare students for the changing job market.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Lebenthal Ends Sojourn At Grace & Rothschild
description: James Lebenthal, advertising spokesman for the family's Lebenthal & Company, the bond house, and an admittedly difficult client, is splitting with his latest agency, Grace & Rothschild, after a brief honeymoon.

title: PRETORIA DETAINS 13 FOES OF DRAFT
description: Armed with emergency powers, the South African police detained 13 young white anti-conscription campaigners overnight and clamped restrictions on 12 others in what opponents called a crackdown on white dissent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cablevision Systems Corp., Woodbury, L.I., said it had offered to buy all of the equity interests in Rainbow Program Enterprises, an affiliate and certain other interests of Rainbow partners in a transaction valued at about $57 million.

title: NEW-HOME SALES OFF
description: Sales of new homes fell 9.6 percent in October, the sixth setback in seven months, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts attributed the decline to rising home prices and supply problems in the Northeast.

title: L.S.U. Censured
description: James Wharton, chancellor of Louisiana State University, said the school will not appeal the year of probation and loss of two basketball scholarships imposed yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: CONCERT: 'FOR LOVE OF MUSIC'
description: ''FOR the Love of Music,'' a chamber-music series directed by Richard Sortomme, opened its season at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night with a program of seldom-played Romantic music. The 200th anniversary of the birth of Carl Maria von Weber was noted with the inclusion of his ''Grand Duo for Clarinet and Piano'' and a Piatigorsky cello transcription of variations originally written for violin and piano.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CLIPPERS, at Los Angeles, 10:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 10:20 P.M.)

title: ARBITRATION OFFERED RAINES AND DAWSON
description: The Montreal Expos, whose contract offers have not tempted Tim Raines and Andre Dawson to sign, offered salary arbitration to their two star free-agent outfielders yesterday. Three other clubs offered arbitration to a total of six other free agents.

title: Choose True Federalism or a Tyranny of Clerks
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Sues to Delay Offer
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., attacking on the third day of the hostile tender offer for its shares by The Limited-DeBartolo group, filed suit in Federal District Court in Los Angeles to delay the $55-a-share bid. If the bid is stalled, shareholders who tender their stock would miss the year-end deadline for tax advantages.

title: The Electronic Informer
description: Suppose Robert (Bud) McFarlane is brought before a grand jury by the Independent Counsel looking into the Iranian ransom profit diversion.

title: PAPER IS UPHELD IN LIBEL LAWSUIT
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court yesterday dismissed a $5 million libel suit against The Boston Globe and Ellen Goodman, a syndicated columnist, over a column prompted by a widely publicized rape trial.

title: LOSS OF SOVIET STAFF STRAINING OPERATION OF MOSCOW EMBASSY
description: The work of the United States Embassy has been more seriously impaired by the withdrawal of Soviet employees than expected, according to American diplomats.

title: From the Mideast to Washington: How a Month of Crisis Has Unfolded
description: Nov. 3 A Lebanese weekly magazine, Al Shiraa, discloses that the United States sent Iran spare parts and ammunition for fighter planes and tanks, after a secret visit to Teheran in early September by Robert C. McFarlane, a former national security adviser. The White House says the United States would not send arms to Iran to free hostages.

title: MUSIC: JOAN ROWLAND
description: THE most notable attribute of Joan Rowland's pianism is an abiding clarity. Not necessarily digital clarity - for there were some blurred passages in her Tuesday evening recital at the 92nd Street Y - nor always contrapuntal clarity.

title: Shcharansky Urges Israelis To Oppose Soviet Exit Laws
description: Anatoly Shcharansky and other Jewish campaigners urged Israel today to speak out against new Soviet emigration laws, which they said would make it more difficult for Jews to leave.

title: Woman Is Jailed Over Cats
description: A 59-year-old woman was sentenced Tuesday to 30 days in the Stark County jail for refusing a judge's order that she stop feeding 30 stray cats or have them spayed. The woman, June Greene, who claims to own only three cats herself, has been feeding and caring for the strays regularly, prompting complaints from her neighbors.

title: IMMUNITY BID SEEN; Bush Concedes U.S. 'Mistakes' In Iran Dealings
description: Vice President Bush said today that he had not been aware of the transfer of millions of dollars worth of support to the Nicaraguan rebels from secret arms sales to Iran.

title: Advertising; 2 Movers At Stereo Review
description: CONSIDERING the overall economic climate in magazine publishing, Stereo Review, one of the CBS magazines, has had spectacular advertising growth in 1986.

title: O'Connor Plans Visit To 3 Mideast Nations
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced last night that John Cardinal O'Connor will leave for a 10-day visit to Israel, Jordan and Egypt immediately after Christmas.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I bought what I thought was a brass faucet for my bathroom sink. However, after six months it is losing the brass look and has blackened. I tried Brasso, but it would not remove the black spot. Is there a brass paint or some other finish I could apply to restore the brass? A. If the faucet is solid brass, you should be able to polish it to a bright luster. If it is just brass-plated, then I'm afraid you are out of luck. You could paint it with a so-called brass paint, but this would soon wear off and it seldom looks like real brass anyway.

title: NIGERIA CURBS AIRLINES
description: Nigeria today banned the sale of plane tickets in any currency other than the Nigerian naira. The military Government has been battling the 29 foreign airlines that operate here since September. At the time they suspended naira transactions when the currency fell 60 percent in value with introduction of a foreign hard currency auction.

title: Inquiry Causes F.B.I. Head To Postpone His Retirement
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William H. Webster, had planned to retire soon but changed his plans because of the bureau's inquiry into the sale of American weapons to Iran, according to a Reagan Administration official.

title: Robins's Records Are Subpoenaed
description: The A. H. Robins Company said its records had been subpoenaed in two criminal investigations, one of which involves its Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth control device, which led to the pharmaceutical company's bankruptcy filing. A spokesman for Robins said records relating to the Dalkon Shield are to be submitted to a Federal grand jury in Wichita, Kan., next Tuesday.

title: Israel Ready to Cooperate
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today that it would allow American investigators to interview members of the Israeli Government involved in the arms deal with Iran, if Washington makes such a request, Government sources said.

title: Court's Contribution
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGURES ARE TOO HIGH FOR HARVARD PROFESSORS
description: It may have begun as early as the time of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.

title: JAPANESE LEADERS OUTLINE OVERHAUL OF THE TAX SYSTEM
description: Japan's ruling party today formally outlined its proposals for the most sweeping overhaul of the tax system since World War II.

title: ORDER ON HALTING BLACKS IS RESCINDED IN LOUISIANA
description: The chief law-enforcement officer in this predominantly white suburb of New Orleans said a day ago that, to fight rising crime, his officers would routinely stop blacks seen in white neighborhoods.

title: Can Reagan Govern?
description: For nearly six years Ronald Reagan governed on his terms. He reigned and ruled. It did not matter if he was inconsistent, if he said one thing and did another, if he got the facts wrong. He got the images right. He dazzled the public. He bent Congress to his will. That is over. With the facts on Iran and Nicaragua coming out over many months and in many forums, there is no prospect that the Reagan magic will dominate again. Concerned voices ask now whether the President can govern at all. In foreign policy, especially, is this country inevitably in for two years of drift and danger?

title: Celtics Basketball Team Goes Public
description: The Boston Celtics, one of the nation's most profitable and popular professional sports franchises, went public yesterday, but the offering was less successful among investors than the Celtics have been on the basketball floor. The Celtics priced 2.6 million shares yesterday, or 40 percent of the company, which will be sold to the public today.

title: Classic Stage Company Names Artistic Director
description: The Classic Stage Company has appointed Carey Perloff as its artistic director. Best known by its initials, CSC was founded 20 years ago by Christopher Martin, who left in 1984.

title: BRASH TOON INSISTS NOTHING IS WRONG
description: Displaying that same cool evasiveness with which he has snared 74 passes this season, Al Toon responded easily today to a question about why his receptions are down.

title: STAGE: WILSON'S 'KNEE PLAYS' AT ALICE TULLY HALL
description: ''THE KNEE PLAYS'' by Robert Wilson and David Byrne is presented as the American section of ''The Civil Wars,'' Mr. Wilson's monumental, multilinear extravaganza. However, in keeping with the global aspect of the complete epic, ''The Knee Plays'' is decidedly international - with a specific Japanese flavor. In fact, one could regard the work as a Wilsonian ascent into Orientalism, as his ''Noh Plays,'' with more than a touch of Bunraku and Kabuki. As seen in its New York premiere Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall, this is an eclectic piece, filled with visual puns; it is one of Mr. Wilson's most sheerly enjoyable and accessible works.

title: COUNCIL HEAD VOWS REFERENDUM ON ESTIMATE BOARD BUDGET POWER
description: The City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, vowed yesterday to force a citywide referendum in November to take away the Board of Estimate's budget powers and give full control to the Council, if the State Legislature fails to make the change first.

title: MASTERS OPENS AT GARDEN
description: His strawberry blond hair is always neatly trimmed and combed. In a sport in which players favor the casual look, Boris Becker will often wear a jacket and tie to dinner, looking very much like a young executive on the way up. He has poise and polish uncommon for a teen-ager, an air of self-confidence that radiates success and makes any setback appear temporary, like John Travolta taking a bad step rehearsing for ''Saturday Night Fever.''

title: West Coast Thrift Unit In Fast Sellout of Bonds
description: Strong investor demand assured the quick sellout of a $100 million issue of collateralized annuity bonds by the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association in California.

title: Lockheed Contract
description: The Lockheed Corporation has been awarded $1.14 billion for development and production of Trident-2 missiles, the Navy said. The work for the submarine missile program will be performed by Lockheed's Missiles and Space Company unit in Sunnyvale, California.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about burglaries of groups opposing Administration foreign policy misstated Robert E. White's former ambassadorial post. He was Ambassador to El Salvador, not Nicaragua.

title: QUINONES ANNOUNCES REVIEW OF SEX-EDUCATION MATERIALS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones, responding to criticism of a sex-education book recommended to students in New York City schools, said yesterday that all reading lists in the sex-education curriculum would be reviewed.

title: On the State of the Union
description: Six years of divided control of Congress tended to produce compromises between the Republican Senate and Democratic House and to give the Reagan White House the whip hand on joint executive-legislative decisions. But now that the Democrats will enjoy majorities in both houses beginning next month, the balance of power has shifted, even on small questions.

title: Talking Deals; A Realty Bid, On a Deadline
description: WHEN Bernard Mendik teamed up with E. F. Hutton & Company earlier this year to raise up to $500 million for a real estate limited partnership, he knew just where he wanted to put the money: into older office buildings that he could renovate and then raise the rents.

title: Weinberger Awaits New Iran Chiefs
description: Calling the leaders of Iran lunatics, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger suggested today that future arms trade with Iran would have to await a new government there.

title: 2 HURT, 1 FATALLY, IN CON ED BLAST
description: An explosion in a Con Edison substation in the Bronx last night killed a utility employee, severely burned a co-worker and dimmed lights in 120,000 homes in Manhattan and the Bronx, authorities said.

title: FEWER JOBS SEEN FOR '87 GRADUATES
description: College graduates next June will have more difficulty finding jobs but will earn higher salaries than the previous year's graduates did, according to a national survey and leading experts in career placement.

title: IMMUNITY BID SEEN; Meeting Is 'Formal'
description: Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, appeared today at a closed hearing of the Senate Intelligence Committee and repeatedly refused to answer questions. He cited his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination.

title: Colonel North's Career: Decorations for Combat
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, who was dismissed from his National Security Council staff job last week but later praised by President Reagan as a ''national hero,'' had a relatively orthodox, modestly successful career as a Marine Corps officer.

title: Bridge: Top Player May Be Headed Toward Another U.S. Title
description: The top American in world standings seemed headed for another national title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: Illinois Legislator Gets 6-Year Prison Term
description: State Representative Larry Bullock was sentenced today to six years in prison for using his legislative office to enrich himself at the expense of Illinois taxpayers.

title: Nepal Prince Warns Of Threat to Wildlife
description: The brother of King Birenda warned today that a paper mill that China helped build threatens rare crocodiles, dolphins and the fabled Bengal tiger.

title: Utah Power Issue
description: The Utah Power and Light Company began offering a $92 million issue of 30-year first-mortgage bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Underwriters are offering investors the bonds with a 8 3/4 percent coupon, at a price of 98.95, to yield 8.85 percent, or about 1.3 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016. Nonrefundable for five years, the securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: NUCLEAR WAR SMOKE TEST HALTED AS COPTER CRASHES
description: The first large-scale experiment to study the possibly devastating effects of smoke that might be generated in a nuclear war was abruptly halted today after a helicopter crashed just after igniting a test fire in the Angeles National Forest.

title: LIFE IN A SEVEN-STORY BELL TOWER
description: FOR Gina Gervasoni, a room full of cathedral-style rose windows and a view of an archangel statue are not the only reminders that her seven-story apartment used to be a church bell tower. Once, a stranger knocked on the Romanesque door and asked if she were the minister's wife.

title: COMEBACKS BOLSTER GIANTS' CONFIDENCE
description: The Giants will play the Redskins in Washington Sunday in a football game with immense rewards for the winner. The Giants are ready, said Phil McConkey, because their almost weekly last-minute heroics have taught them how to win.

title: Cabinet Drops Political Football
description: When the University of Florida announced recently that it would end its regular football rivalry with the University of Miami after next year and play the Hurricanes only two years out of every six, there were those in Florida who were dismayed by the news.

title: CHAMBER: MANHATTAN ENSEMBLE
description: FOUR substantial pieces composed within the last decade began the Manhattan Contemporary Ensemble's chamber concert Tuesday evening at the Manhattan School of Music, and all four composers were on hand to introduce their work. Tod Machover led off, telling something of the technological genesis of his ''Deplacements'' (1979) for guitar and tape, which was then played by Mark Delpriora. The composer intended the piece to be about, in part, the experience of searching for tranquillity and finding oneself ever farther from it, with the tape representing reposeful murmurs and the guitar embodying the agitated mind's response.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CONCERT: E. DUBOURG, SWISS PIANIST
description: EVELYNE DUBOURG, a Swiss pianist active mainly in Europe, reintroduced herself locally in a Merkin Concert Hall recital Monday. She is an artist of vigorous temper and has the ability to communicate with an audience, though she is also inclined to favor energy over detailed command.

title: FRANK A. SEITZ Jr.
description: Frank A. Seitz Jr., the founder of radio station WFAS in Westchester County and a former teacher at Fordham University, died Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Seitz was 75 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 4, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Texaco U.S.A. Unit Gets New President
description: Texaco Inc. named James W. Dunlap president of its biggest division, Texaco U.S.A., as the nation's third-largest oil company continued a realignment of its management.

title: BLACK ENROLLMENT IS REPORTED STAGNATING IN SOUTH
description: A new report on higher education in the South finds stagnating enrollment of black students, comparatively little financial aid being given on the basis of need and increasing enrollment in two-year colleges.

title: ORBITING OBSERVATORY SIGHTS ICE BLAST ON HALLEY'S COMET
description: An Earth-orbiting observatory watching Halley's comet last March recorded what was apparently an explosion that blew 100 cubic feet of ice out of the comet's nucleus, an astrophysicist reported today.

title: INSIDE
description: Transit Police Bias Found A Federal judge found that the New York City Transit Authority, in disciplining its police officers, had shown favoritism toward whites.

title: RESCUING ANCIENT GLORIES FROM MODERN RAVAGES
description: The Parthenon, perhaps the world's most revered building, has been invaded by a huge construction crane, and scaffolding covers stretches of its columned facade and flanks.

title: Selling of the Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 More Homes in Hawaii Are Threatened by Lava
description: Waist-deep molten rock threatened eight houses today as it crept away from a main lava flow, which has added dozens of acres of new land to the coast as it surges into the ocean.

title: IMMIGRATION CHIEF ON WEST COAST PRESSING FIGHT ON ILLEGAL 'INVASION'
description: Harold W. Ezell, the chief enforcer of immigration law on the West Coast, says his mission is to stop the ''invasion'' of illegal aliens entering the United States from Mexico and other countries.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. DENVER NUGGETS, at Byrne Medowlands Arena, 8 P.M. (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:05 P.M.) KNICKS VS.

title: ART: WORKS BY FONTANA, A STAGE-SETTER, ON VIEW
description: THE Lucio Fontana exhibition takes up both the fourth- and the ninth-floor spaces of the Marisa del Re Gallery at 41 East 57th Street. On view through Dec. 24, this show is far from perfect, but it whets the appetite for a more extensive look at the artist and it is very timely. Fontana was one of several European and American artists who, during the 1950's, extended and subverted the ideas of Abstract Expressionism and Tachism in the direction of a greater reality, thereby helping to set the stage for the art of the second half of this century. Fontana's colleagues in this endeavor included Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Cy Twombly, Joseph Beuys and Yves Klein.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes income of $139,802,000, representing equity in unremitted earnings of DuPont Co., compared with similar income of $34,371,000 a year ago; Seagram has a 22.5-percent interest in DuPont.

title: RAGAN, BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Babbitt and Motherwell Are Honored
description: Milton Babbitt, the composer, and Robert Motherwell, the painter, have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, it was announced by the poet Stanley Kunitz, secretary of the academy.

title: WAR-TOUR OBSERVANCE
description: Sixty-two teen-agers from 18 war-torn countries will join Harry Belafonte, the jazz musician David Amram, and the Abyssinian Baptist Church Youth Gospel Choir this evening at 7:30 at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place at East 16th Street, near Union Square. The event will commemorate the completion of the Children of War Tour.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,197,000. c-After extraordinary credits of $601,000 for the quarter and $1,332,000 for the 9 months.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 18
description: The company said the latest first quarter results include Starn's Markets Inc., acquired July 31, which accounted for 33.3 percent of the total sales increase, while 6.6 percent of the increase was due to continuing stores.

title: THEATER: SIMON'S 'BROADWAY BOUND'
description: IN an Act II monologue that's the indisputable peak of Neil Simon's ''Broadway Bound,'' a middle-aged Jewish mother named Kate Jerome tells her younger son, Eugene, about the most glamorous incident of her life - a night at the Primrose ballroom, 35 years earlier, when George Raft asked her to dance. Both as written by Mr. Simon and acted by Linda Lavin, Kate's reminiscence spirals upward like the opening clarinet glissando in Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' It's a mesmerizing journey to a bygone working-class Brooklyn where first-generation American Jews discovered the opportunities and guilt that came with the secular temptations of a brash new world.

title: AMY CARTER TODAY: CAUSES AND ARRESTS
description: Amy Carter, who as an elementary pupil brought a tree house to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, now lives in a cooperative of vegetarians near the campus of Brown University and spends much of her time struggling to change United States policy on South Africa, Nicaragua and hunger.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PACT TO CURB FOSTER CARE UPSETS KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday took issue with a court stipulation on foster care - an agreement that his administration has already accepted.

title: GENERAL PARAMETRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,736,000 in the first quarter ended July 31 from the sale of Sizzler Restaurants common stock. The company said that the 1986 second quarter revenue includes $28,101,000 from Naugles Inc., in which a controlling interest was acquired during the third quarter of last year. The company also said that the tax rate for this year's second quarter was 65 percent compared with 42 percent a year ago, that the pre-tax income for the quarter was $12,879,000 versus $11,385,000 a year ago, and that the higher tax rate for this year's second quarter was due to adjustments related to the recently passed tax reform act of 1986.

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $14,500,000 relating to write-off of inventory and other costs in the curtailment of the ion implanation division. Results for 1985 include Sloan Technology Corp., acquired in June 1985, in a pooling of interests.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EUROPEANS GIVEN U.S. MISSILE-DEFENSE CONTRACTS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger announced contracts today for seven international consortia to study ways to defend Europe against short-range ballistic missiles.

title: PHONE PROBLEMS SAID TO HAMPER SEARCH FOR DAVIS
description: The search for Larry Davis, the fugitive wanted in the shooting of six police officers, has been complicated by the telephone company's difficulties in tracing calls the suspect has made to tapped telephones, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $4,086,000 for the quarter and $13,354,000 for the year from litigation. c-After an extraordinary charge of $743,000 from litigation for the quarter and a charge of $3,979,000 for the year.

title: SWIFT RIDE TO THE CITY: THE FERRY
description: ''This sure beats sitting in the Lincoln Tunnel,'' John Richey said as he sipped coffee from a container and looked out the window of the 77-foot ferryboat, Port Imperial, that was carrying him across the Hudson River at 35 knots.

title: CABBY KILLS WIFE AND COMPANION, POLICE SAY
description: A man and a woman were shot to death near Queens Borough Hall yesterday by the woman's estranged husband, who used his taxicab to force the victims' car to the side of the road, the police said.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $1.8 million for the quarter and $4 million for the year. The year also includes a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $424,000. c-After tax benefits of $200,000 for the quarter and $4.5 million for the year. The year also includes a pre-tax gain of about $2.6 million on sales of real estate.

title: General Cinema's Chief Amid a Battle for Carter
description: Richard A. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the General Cinema Corporaiton, operates from a modest headquarters in a shopping mall in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The company's plain style, however, masks its accomplishments. It is the largest motion picture exhibitor in the nation, with 1,254 screens at 340 locations. It is also the largest independent Pepsi-Cola bottler, from which it derives 70 percent of its profits.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a charge of $38,010,000 for restructuring.

title: LADERMAN PROGRAM
description: The Jewish Museum will present a program entitled 'Ezra Laderman: Jewish Sources in My Music' Sunday at 4:30 P.M. Mr. Laderman will introduce the program; four of his works will be played, including the New York premiere of ''Scenes From an Imagined Childhood.''

title: Gillette Stock Rise
description: Just one week after it disposed of a takeover threat from the Revlon Corporation, buyout rumors once again sent the shares of the Gillette Company skyrocketing yesterday.

title: Westinghouse, NBC End Deal
description: The National Broadcasting Company said that it would not proceed with a plan to merge its radio stations with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The companies had proposed creating a new company spun off from the two parent companies.

title: Miami Coach Staying
description: The Miami coach, Jimmy Johnson, who was reportedly under consideration for jobs at Texas and Southern Cal, has ended the speculation by saying he will stay with the Hurricanes. Johnson announced his intentions on his weekly radio show on Wednesday night.''

title: JUDGE QUASHES EVIDENCE AGAINST AN EX-AGENT IN PRESSER CASE
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that statements by a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledging he lied about his role in a case involving Jackie Presser, the teamsters' union president, are inadmissible as evidence at the agent's trial.

title: BROADWAY
description: ANNE BOGART, a director who has been described as both controversial and visionary, is obviously not afraid of challenges. She was behind an unusual presentation of ''South Pacific'' last year and now she's staging a new version of the German playwright Georg Buchner's play ''Danton's Death.'' This time she's following in the footsteps of a trio of heavyweights - the drama has had three notable productions here in the last 60 years. Max Reinhardt directed a German production in 1927, Orson Welles staged his version for the Mercury Theater Company in 1939, and Herbert Blau and Jules Irving presented it during their opening season at Lincoln Center in 1965.

title: Datapoint Stake
description: James Grosfeld, chairman of the Pulte Home Corporation, said today that he had sold his entire 7.3 percent stake in the Datapoint Corporation. Mr. Grosfeld gave no reason for the sale in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Datapoint, a computer products company based in San Antonia, was acquired last year by the New York financier Asher B. Edelman. Between Nov. 23 and Nov. 26, Mr. Grosfeld sold his 1.42 million Datapoint shares on the open market for $10.03 million, or an average price of $7.03 a share.

title: Wreckage of a Copter Crash That Killed Three Is Found
description: Searchers today found the wreckage of a helicopter ambulance that crashed in fog Wednesday, killing three people.

title: U.N. IN VIENNA INVITES WALDHEIM TO A CEREMONY
description: The United Nations office in Vienna has invited President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to be guest of honor at a ceremony next month commemorating the world organization's first Secretary General, Trygve Lie.

title: 2 Houses Plan Special Panels On Arms Deal
description: Both houses of Congress will choose their own special committees to investigate the secret Iran arms dealing and the funneling of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels, Congressional leaders announced today.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2-Year Recruit
description: On Wednesday, the National Collegiate Athletic Association restored the eligibility of Raymond Bottse of St. Peter's, only three hours before the team was to play Seton Hall. Bottse, a 6-foot-2-inch freshman guard from the Netherlands, was declared ineligible for five games last October on the ground that he had violated the N.C.A.A.'s rules on professionalism and extra benefits by playing for his club team in his native country.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Evan Parker Trio and Hamiett Bluiett, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (362-3366). Each in his own way, the American baritone saxophonist Hamiett Bluiett and the British soprano saxophonist Evan Parker have pushed their instruments beyond ordinary capabilities. Both can make extraordinary sounds - honks, squeaks, clicks, sighs, bleats - but they're not just sonic daredevils; they use their extended techniques in far-reaching but coherent improvisations. Mr. Bluiett, a member of the World Saxophone Quartet, is steeped in jazz and rhythm-and-blues; he'll play solos that are likely to use his cavernous bottom register as well as flights into territory usually claimed by piccolo players. Mr. Parker, who is making a rare New York appearance, is a British ''free'' improviser who determinedly avoids references to fixed traditions in favor of a thoughtful but spontaneous succession of sounds. He'll be leading a trio with a bassist and a percussionist. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: FINANCING IS SET FOR EXPANSION, RUTGERS U. SAYS
description: Rutgers University officials announced today that they had assurances of $200 million that will enable them to start a major construction program of academic buildings.

title: Dismissal Averted War, Manila Forces Chief Says
description: The chief of the Philippine armed forces, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, said today that he had not opposed the dismissal of Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile because to have done so might have led to civil war.

title: OPERA: NEW 'FLEDERMAUS' AT THE MET
description: ABOUT halfway through the first act of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Die Fledermaus'' it became painfully clear that the most generous approach to the remainder of the evening would be to look for bright spots amid the gloom. Yes, Kiri Te Kanawa was doing her best on Thursday night to frolic about as Rosalinde, and her buttery tones at times almost made one overlook the fact that she was miscast as that madcap lady. And yes, Gunther Schneider-Siemssen's lavishly realistic sets were just the spectacular sort that bring Pavlovian oohs and aahs from Metropolitan audiences. But such bright spots, if they can be called that, became increasingly difficult to find as this evening wore on. Otto Schenk, who both directed and took the speaking role of the drunken jailer Frosch, accomplished what any admirer of this queen of operettas might think impossible: he made ''Fledermaus,'' a masterpiece of blithe charm, into a bore of serious proportions.

title: Guidry, Randolph Given a Deadline
description: Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph, the senior Yankees who between them have 22 years of service with the team, could find their Yankee careers ended at midnight Sunday if ''a real possibility'' becomes fact.

title: Koch Is to Sign Bill Creating Pay Panel
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would sign into law a bill to create a commission every four years to review pay levels of the mayor, council members and other elected city officials.

title: Drug Used to Ease the Gout Found to Reduce Cirrhosis
description: A drug used for centuries to ease gout is the first safe and effective therapy for a fatal form of cirrhosis that primarily strikes women, researchers say.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BETWEEN THE WOODS AND THE WATER. On Foot to Constantinople From the Hook of Holland: The Middle Danube to the Iron Gates. By Patrick Leigh Fermor. 248 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $18.95. IN 1933 Patrick Leigh Fermor decided to see the world. He was 18 years old at the time, hanging around in London; two years earlier he had been expelled from his English public (i.e., private) school, after which he had drifted from preparing for a career in the army to playing around with the idea of pursuing a career as an author. Then, suddenly, he had an inspiration - he would tramp across Europe on foot, all the way to Constantinople.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The prior year share earnings have been restated to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split effected in the form of a 33 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: BRITISH BARON WANTS TO BE CLEARED OF RUMORS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher responded noncommittally today to an unusual plea from a member of the House of Lords that the Government unequivocally clear him of rumors that he is the long sought ''fifth man'' in Britain's most notorious espionage scandal.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,657,000 and a charge of $9.3 million for disposal of discontinued operations.

title: MILITARY SATELLITE LOFTED INTO ORBIT
description: A powerful rocket propelled a $125 million military communications satellite into orbit tonight in the fourth straight space launching success after a string of disasters earlier this year.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ONE Saturday in September 1985, Ted Seaton, a British antiques dealer, took his metal detector on his usual weekend treasure hunt into the meadows of North Yorkshire. This time, Mr. Seaton and two friends focused their search on a field about 200 yards from Middleham Castle. There Mr. Seaton struck gold, unearthing a 15th-century diamond-shaped gold pendant, measuring 2 1/2 inches high and 2 inches wide, embellished on the front with a large sapphire and engraved with religious images - the Trinity is depicted on the front, the Nativity on the back.

title: U.S. WITHHOLDING $250 MILLION OVER FLAWS IN A NEW BOMBER
description: Citing flaws in the newly deployed B-1B strategic bomber, Air Force officials said Wednesday that they had withheld more than $250 million in payments to companies that produce systems for the plane.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Notre Dame 60, Cornell 56: Notre Dame prevented an upset on its home court last night when Scott Hicks hit two free throws with 25 seconds left after Cornell (0-3) had cut its deficit to 58-56 on a 3-point goal by John Bajusz, who finished with a game-high 18 points. Hicks and David Rivers each had 16 points for Notre Dame (1-2). Cornell outrebounded Notre Dame, 18-8, on the way to a 33-26 halftime lead. But the Big Red went scoreless for five minutes of the second half as Notre Dame scored 8 consecutive points for its first lead, at 44-41. (AP) Boston College 87, Harvard 86: Troy Bowers hit a fallaway jumper with 25 seconds remaining to give Boston College (2-1) the victory. Dana Barros had 26 points for the Eagles, and Arne Duncan of Harvard (0-3) led all scorers with 29 points. (AP)

title: GOODYEAR'S UNEASY AFTERMATH
description: Robert E. Mercer, chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, pointed recently to the company's stock price flashing on the computer terminal in his plush office here.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WE wish you a merry Christmas.'' ''Bah, humbug!''

title: Emergency Drill Held in Westchester
description: Westchester County conducted a surprise evening drill Wednesday to test the county's response time in event of a natural disaster or accident at the Indian Point nuclear plants, officials revealed Thursday.

title: Rose Butler Browne Is Dead; A Black Pioneer in Education
description: Rose Butler Browne, an author, educator and civil rights activist who was the first black woman to earn a doctorate in education from Harvard University, died Monday. She was 89 years old.

title: SCANDINAVIA FUND reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: This fund was started June 17. Net income represents net assets.

title: ONTARIO SEEKS OPENING OF SECURITIES MARKETS
description: Seeking to enhance Toronto's role in international finance, the Government of the province of Ontario announced yesterday that it would introduce sweeping legislative changes in its securities industry.

title: Poindexter at White House To Do 'Administrative Tasks'
description: Vice Adm. John Poindexter, who resigned last week as President Reagan's national security adviser because of the uproar over the sale of weapons to Iran, returned to the White House today to handle what was called final paperwork.

title: JAFFE TO HAVE IMPRINT
description: Marc Jaffe, formerly the editor in chief of Ballantine Books and editorial director of Villard Books, will publish books under his own imprint for the Houghton Mifflin Company. The company announced this week that Mr. Jaffe, who has also been president and publisher of Bantam Books, will develope a list of general fiction and nonfiction titles.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Auto Dealer Groups Choose Their Agencies
description: Two New York-based ad agencies, David Deutsch Associates and Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, have picked up motor vehicle dealer advertising associations as clients.

title: AUDIO-VIDEO AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CLARK IS SMALLER BUT NO EASIER
description: In last year's first game between the Giants and the Washington Redskins, Gary Clark of the Redskins caught 11 passes for 193 yards. The Giants won, 17-3.

title: Beware That Mandate
description: The Greeks had a word for it, which can be loosely translated as ''wanton . . . arrogance resulting from excessive pride.'' In our more scientific time, it might be called the Mandate Syndrome, and Ronald Reagan has become the fourth President of the modern era to be felled by it.

title: Israel's Denials It Knew of Diversion of Arms-Sale Profits to Contras Are Questioned by U.S. Officials
description: Despite Israeli denials, American officials remain firm in their belief that Israel knew about profits from the Iran arms sales being passed on to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Great Peace Journey
description: The Great Peace Journey, which began in Sweden in 1985, has visisted 116 countries and asked their leaders if they would be willing to abolish destructive weapons, keep their armed forces at home and stop exporting military equipment if all other members of the United Nations promised to take these steps. According to organizers, 66 Governments including Australia, China, India, Israel and Japan have agreed, and others have indicated they would comply in part.

title: AGENDA
description: How to Improve Mail Service Preston Robert Tisch, the Postmaster General, is to discuss ways to improve mail service in the city at a breakfast meeting of the Association for a Better New York. Mr. Tisch, the former president of the Loews Corporation, is also expected to talk about efforts to make the Postal Service's express-mail service competitive with Federal Express's overnight delivery service. Registering and Inspecting Vehicles

title: F.B.I. Director Talks Of Reagan and Inquiry
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William H. Webster, said today that there was ''no indication'' that President Reagan failed to tell the truth about the sale of American weapons to Iran and the subsequent diversion of money to Nicaraguan rebel groups.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Ceco Suit Accord
description: Ceco Industries, a closely held construction products company, said it had agreed to pay $1 million to settle a class-action suit filed against the company last month. The suit had said the terms of a managment-led buyout were ''grossly unfair and inadequate'' to shareholders.

title: WHITE HOUSE PREPARES FOR SEASON
description: ''The President and Mrs. Reagan extend to you their warmest wishes for a joyous holiday season and a happy new year,'' is the message in gold engraved script on this year's White House Christmas Card, a reproduction of a watercolor of the East Room at Christmas by Thomas William Jones of Bellevue, Wash.

title: YOUTH, 14, IS HELD
description: A 14-year-old student shot to death a teacher and wounded a vice principal and two classmates at his high school today, then fled to his home where his parents turned him over to the police, the authorities said.

title: SPEAKES WILL LEAVE WHITE HOUSE TO TAKE POST WITH MERRILL LYNCH
description: Larry Speakes, the White House press spokesman who has been the public voice and image of the Reagan Presidency, announced today that he would resign Feb. 1 to join Merrill Lynch & Company, the Wall Street investment concern.

title: Pursuing Stardom In Smith Haven Mall
description: SHE is only 15, but when she saw the ad for the ''Why I Want To Be A Star'' contest at the Smith Haven Mall, Venus Rentas-Seda felt they meant her.

title: Hospital Electrocution Of Child Is Investigated
description: The case of a 4-year-old girl with severe birth defects was electrocuted when her heart monitor line was connected to an electric circuit is under investigation.

title: McCann Adds Detroit Bottlers
description: McCann-Erickson's Detroit office has joined those other McCann offices that are serving local Coca-Cola bottlers.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INSIDE
description: Violence in Paris Protest Dozens of people were injured in Paris when the police clashed with students protesting an overhaul of the French university system.

title: Ciccarelli Too Much for Devils
description: Dino Ciccarelli does not have the dominance or flair of Wayne Gretzky or the size of Mario Lemieux, but his quickness and vision have helped make him the league leader in goals and power-play goals thus far this season.

title: MONTANA IN PASSABLE, NOT SUPER, FORM
description: These are the times Bill Walsh used to be able to look to Joe Montana for an inspiring game. Instead, this is what Walsh says now about his one-time Super Bowl quarterback:

title: SURVEY COUNTS 175 INTRUSIONS INTO AIRPORT ZONES IN 6 HOURS
description: A survey of 23 major airports found 175 intrusions of restricted airspace by private aircraft in a single six-hour period, a Federal Aviation Administration official testified today.

title: Fund Diversion May Have Involved 2 Swiss Banks
description: The diversion of Iranian arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels appears to have been carried out with the help of stringent secrecy regulations affecting numbered bank accounts at the third largest Swiss bank, as well as at a small Geneva trust company.

title: FILM: 'MODERN GIRLS,' ON THE TOWN
description: THE three heroines of ''Modern Girls'' aren't nearly as modern as the three heroines of ''How to Marry a Millionaire,'' who at least knew what they wanted and how to get it. In ''Modern Girls,'' Cece and Margo and Kelly hold pointless daytime jobs and live from one night of Los Angeles club-hopping to the next. They dress up in junk-laden outfits that even Madonna might consider obvious, then go out to drink and take drugs and make themselves idly available to whichever men happen to strike their fancy. But there's no sex in the movie - the possibilities for it are so omnipresent that the idea isn't even interesting. In any case, it certainly took nerve to attach a ''Modern'' to this.

title: 2 KILLED, 11 HURT IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israeli soldiers killed 2 Palestinian students and wounded at least 11 others today while trying to break up a demonstration outside Bir Zeit University in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: PROTEGE OF FINK IS LIKELY VICTOR IN SPEAKER RACE
description: Melvin H. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat whose liberal stand on criminal-justice issues has often put him at odds with Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch, tonight appeared virtually certain to be the next Speaker of the State Assembly.

title: Afghans Shake Up 2 Cabinet Ministries
description: The Afghan radio announced a Government shake-up today, including the demotion of the Foreign Minister in an apparent move by the country's leader, Najibullah, to strengthen his control.

title: A DRAMA OF SAVING SEA LIVES
description: An ancient sea drama was enacted in the last two days as about 60 pilot whales were stranded on Cape Cod beaches from Dennis to South Wellfleet.

title: G.I. BILL, ONCE A REWARD, IS NOW A LURE TO SIGN UP
description: At the end of World War II, Congress voted the first G.I. Bill of educational benefits to help transition back to civilian life for those who had served. Later the bill was extended to those who served in Korea and Vietnam.

title: NO STOPPING NEW ZEALAND
description: Stars & Stripes fought hard today to block New Zealand's march toward challenging for the America's Cup, but to no avail.

title: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: The Guarneri String Quartet will play Music by Mozart, Schubert and Schoenberg at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $15. Information: 570-3949.

title: EVERYONE WANTS A SEAT ON THE IRAN ARMS PANEL
description: The Senate majority leader is always a popular figure, the target of constant pleas and requests from his colleagues. But this week Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who will not officially take over as Senate leader until next month, has been besieged by more favor-seekers than usual.

title: Iranian Agents Built Wide Network To Smuggle In Weapons From U.S.
description: Even as secret arms deals with Iran were being arranged at the White House, Iranian agents were separately planning to buy, steal and smuggle vast stores of contraband American weapons and technology, according to Government investigators and dozens of prosecutions around the country.

title: 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE'
description: The Village Light Opera Group will present Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Pirates of Penzance'' at the Faashion Institute of Technology Haft Memorial Theater, 227 West 27th Street, tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission is $9 to $16. Information: 243-6281.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $414,000 from the termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss The company said its business forms division in Nashua, N.H., has renewed its $2.4 million forms management contract with State Street Bank & Trust Co. through December 1987.

title: Eurobond Notes Slump
description: The Eurobond market was shaken by a further slump in the prices of perpetual floating-rate notes today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a charge of $6,209,000 related to the redemption of notes.

title: HOLIDAY SPECTACLES FOR THE YOUNG AND YOUNG AT HEART
description: SUGARPLUMS dancing in a magical kingdom, Red Riding Hood scurrying through a frightening forest and Wilbur the Christmas mouse dodging the family cat are all vying for the attention of young theatergoers this holiday season with the likes of Alan and Jane, the winsome runaways who are transformed into the ''Babes in Toyland.''

title: The Word for Takeovers: Pernicious
description: For almost a decade, I have felt like a voice in the wilderness, warning of the evils of hostile takeovers. But Ivan F. Boesky has succeeded where I have failed and, at least in that respect, we may all owe him a debt of gratitude.

title: 2 Groups Differ on Sex Education
description: The sex education curriculum for the city's public schools was supported and criticized yesterday by two different religious coalitions. Each stated it would act to make its views felt.

title: FESTIVALS FOCUS ON ASIAN FILMS AND CLARA BOW
description: From Japan, there comes a satire on that nation's preoccupation with the ''proper'' way to do things and a documentary on young protesters. From China, there is a deceptively scenic film on the harshness of peasant life, and a movie on the difficult relationship between the Han majority and the country's 55 ethnic minorities. And from the Philippines, there are two films that portray different facets of the Filipino experience with colonialism.

title: STERLING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Net loss The company went public May 14. The share earnings are not available for the year-ago 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' figures reflect the operations of Sterling Inc. for the 17 weeks ended Oct. 26, 1985, and Sterling Merchandise Co., the predecessor company, for the balance of the period.

title: Unreal Rooseveltiana
description: An article in the current Washingtonian magazine purporting to quote directly from long-secret diaries of President Franklin D. Roosevelt has such a ring of authenticity that excited National Archives officials attempted to approach the Roosevelt family. Librarians in Aiken, S.C., tried to check with the daughter of the woman who reportedly preserved 16 handwritten volumes there for 40 years.

title: Ban Upheld on Visits To AIDS Inmate
description: An Auburn state prison inmate diagnosed as having AIDS was properly denied permission by the state's prison chief to have a conjugal visit with his wife, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: GROUP TELLS OF A STEP TOWARD AIDS VACCINE
description: Scientists have taken another step toward producing a vaccine against AIDS by showing that only a fragment of protein from the AIDS virus is necessary for developing antibodies against it.

title: USX Unit Shift
description: The USX Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced transfer of most of its chemical division into a new company, the Aristech Chemical Corporation. The company said that it had received proceeds of $526 million from selling stock in the new company.

title: PASQUALE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 38
ORDERS AT U.S. FACTORIES PLUNGED 3.6% IN OCTOBER
description: Orders received by the nation's factories plummeted 3.6 percent in October, the sharpest decline in more than six years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MUSIC: FRANKIE MANN
description: WHEN Frankie Mann, a talented composer from North Carolina, first came to New York several years ago by way of the Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio and Mills College in California, she seemed to specialize in eerie but powerful electronic and tape collages. On Wednesday at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street, she offered two keyboard-based pieces that were altogether cheerier and more formally clear-cut.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
THE SHIITE-PALESTINIAN BATTLE: ANGUISH GROWS IN TORN LAND
description: Two months of particularly savage fighting between Lebanese Shiite Moslems and Palestinians has produced suffering on a scale that is huge even by the standards of this long-suffering country.

title: JP STEVENS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a net gain of $4,250,000 from income from discontinued operations and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes $19,277,000 in net from discontinued operations and from a gain on disposal of the company's commercial printing segment.

title: NEW YORK CITY SHOES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EGYPT ACCUSES 33 OF ANTI-MUBARAK PLOT
description: Egypt's top prosecutor accused 4 military officers and 29 civilians today of plotting to topple the Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: 2 TOP INTELSAT EXECUTIVES DISMISSED
description: The two top executives of Intelsat have been dismissed ''immediately and for cause'' by the board of governors of the international communications consortium, Robert D. Leahy, an Intelsat spokesman, said tonight.

title: The Questions Asked Abroad
description: IN the midst of the Iranian crisis that has shaken confidence in the Reagan Administration and its ability to manage the nation's affairs, foreign investors, worried about their dollar holdings, are asking some fundamental questions about the future stability of the United States economy.

title: Trinity School Trustees Pick Headmaster From California
description: The board of trustees of the Trinity School said yesterday that it had chosen a British-born educator, Christopher Berrisford, to become headmaster of the 277-year-old private school on the West Side of Manhattan next year.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Levins Fight Order For Daughter's Diary
description: The family of Jennifer Dawn Levin, who was killed in Central Park last August, will ask a Manhattan judge today to reject a subpoena for Miss Levin's diary, a lawyer for the Levin family said last night.

title: HEART IMPLANT PATIENT IS DEAD
description: Betty Shields, a mother of two who became the world's 29th artificial heart patient, died today at the University of Arizona Medical Center, eight days after receiving the implant. She was 40 years old.

title: Backer and Chiat Win 'Most Creative' Awards
description: Norman Glenn's Marketing and Media Education organization has disclosed the winners of the second annual creative media awards.

title: THOMPSON'S 'NATIVITY'
description: The New England Youth Ensemble and the Atlantic Union College Choir will present the American composer Randall Thompson's rarely heard ''Nativity According to St. Luke'' - the Christmas story in music, pageant and biblical costume - at the Church of the Advent Hope, 111 East 87th Street, tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. There will be no admission fee - an offering will be taken. Information: 534-8245.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1986
description: Markets

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Fighting Catastrophe for $4.92 a Month
description: For many aging Americans, devastating illness could also mean financial ruin. President Reagan called in his last State of the Union Message for a study of ways to ease the economic anxiety. Now his Secretary of Health and Human Services, Otis Bowen, responds with a sound proposal for at least partial relief.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $834,483 from the sale of property and a charge of $439,862 related to the closing of the company's San Bernardino home center. c-Net income

title: Woman Is Jailed Over Cats
description: A 59-year-old woman was sentenced Tuesday to 30 days in the Stark County jail for refusing a judge's order that she stop feeding 30 stray cats or have them spayed. The woman, June Greene, who says she owns only three cats herself, has been feeding and caring for the strays regularly, prompting complaints from her neighbors.

title: Treasury Securities Advance
description: The Government debt market strengthened further yesterday as prices of Treasury securities advanced and interest rates fell in active trading.

title: G.A.O. IN INSIDER INQUIRY
description: The General Accounting Office is studying whether the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are adequately equipped to deal with the growing problem of insider trading in the securities markets, G.A.O. officials said today.

title: Razzmatazz and Pain In a Raccoon Coat
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE PROPOSES BASEBALL STADIUM FOR CONEY I.
description: The State Urban Development Corporation proposed yesterday that a $58 million stadium-and-arena complex for amateur sports, minor league baseball and cultural events be built in an economically depressed section of Coney Island.

title: WITNESS IN GOTTI TRIAL SAYS PROSECUTOR THREATENED HIM
description: A key Government witness in the racketeering trial of the reputed mob boss John Gotti and six co-defendants said yesterday that a Federal prosecutor yelled at him and threatened him to force him to testify.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Olympic Skating Team Cancels American Tour
description: Christopher Dean and Jayne Torvill, the Winter Olympic gold medal-winning ice dancers, have canceled the remainder of their United States tour because of a fractured wrist Mr. Dean suffered last weekend in Portland, Me.

title: Poe's 'Rue Morgue' on CBS, Starring George C. Scott
description: Edgar Allan Poe's early American whodunit-thriller ''The Murders in the Rue Morgue'' has been neatly translated into a television account, to be seen Sunday on CBS at 9 P.M. Here is a story told with respect for the book and respect for the medium in which it is now set.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MORE LENIENT DEBT AID FOR THIRD WORLD URGED
