description: The Reagan Administration's ''Baker Plan'' for helping poor countries manage their debts has proved inadequate, economists, bankers and public officials said in New York yesterday, just slightly more than a year after it was set forth.

title: CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said the cumulative effect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 reduced the latest third quarter net loss by about $360,000.

title: 'ANASTASIA,' A NEW VERSION, ON NBC
description: RARELY has so much talent been so lavishly expended on a project that remains so steadfastly inert. ''Anastasia: The Story of Anna,'' a four-hour production on NBC at 9 P.M. Sunday and Monday, was directed and produced by Marvin J. Chomsky (''Roots,'' ''Holocaust,'' ''Peter the Great''), written by James A. Goldman (the films ''The Lion in Winter,'' ''Nicholas and Alexandra,'' the musical ''Follies''), and has a cast that, with Amy Irving in the title role, includes Rex Harrison, Olivia De Havilland, Claire Bloom, Omar Sharif and Jan Niklas, the West German actor who brought a welcome touch of energy to ''Peter the Great.'' They all work hard, even superbly at times, but to no avail.

title: EDITH STERBA
description: Edith Sterba, a child psychoanalyst who studied under Freud, died Monday at her home.

title: Israeli Gunboats Off Lebanon Shell 2 Palestinian Positions
description: Three Israeli gunboats today shelled two Palestinian positions outside Sidon.

title: THE MANSFIELD TOUCH: A 3,466 DAY PERFORMANCE
description: Mike Mansfield glanced out the office window from which he has surveyed central Tokyo for nearly a decade, and allowed that the skyscrapers had grown bigger over the years.

title: REUBEN NAKIAN, U.S. SCULPTOR, DIES
description: Reuben Nakian, one of the most distinguished American sculptors of the 20th century, died of heart failure yesterday at Stamford Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 89 years old, and had been in poor health for several years.

title: Thrift Board's Travel Policy
description: Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, ordered his staff today not to accept reimbursement for business-related travel expenses from any source other than the bank board.

title: Touch Football After the N.F.L.
description: After four years as a backup quarterback in the National Football League, Bob Holly filled the same role this season, but in a far less glamorous milieu - a touch football league.

title: Trail Blazers Fine Berry
description: Walter Berry, the former St. John's player, has been fined ''a substantial amount'' by the Portland Trail Blazers, the team announced. Club officials said that Berry had informed the team he would not attend Tuesday night's game against the Los Angeles Clippers but did not ask permission to do so.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $817,000 for the quarter and $1,537,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: F.A.A. MAY REQUIRE TESTING OF PILOTS FOR USE OF DRUGS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it was considering random testing for drug use and alcohol abuse among private and airline pilots and other airline employees.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''BEVERLY HILLS COP,'' which its producers say is the most successful comedy ever made, is about to undergo a minor change of identity not uncommon in Hollywood. It will henceforth be known as ''Beverly Hills Cop I.'' ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' is in the works, with Eddie Murphy returning as the wild, irreverent Detroit cop who gets his man while setting local bureaucratic authorities on their ears. Judge Reinhold, John Ashton and Ronald Cox will also re-create their original roles.

title: Dining Out Guide; American Sampler
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, #20 West 50th

title: ROLAND GELATT, 66, A MUSIC CRITIC AND AN EDITOR
description: Roland Gelatt, an American music critic and editor, died of cancer Wednesday morning in Philadelphia. He was 66 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: TEXAN EXECUTED BY INJECTION FOR MURDER IN 1977
description: Michael Wayne Evans, who fatally shot and slashed a woman ''to get her to quit talking'' as she asked God to forgive him, was put to death by injection today for the murder.

title: Movie Audiences to Get Message From Marines
description: The Marine Corps will be using the 60-second version of that smashing recruiting commercial entitled ''The Sword'' in movie houses in 12 Western markets over the Christmas holidays in hopes of giving young America the itch to enlist.

title: New York City Refunding Bonds
description: A $665 million issue of New York City refunding bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Bring New York's Skilled-Service Contracts Into the Daylight
description: To the Editor:

title: Jump Hurts 27 Paratroopers
description: Twenty-seven members of the 82d Airborne Division were injured in a night jump Tuesday when they missed the landing zone on Fort Bragg, a post spokesman says. The paratroopers landed in a nearby area in which explosives are detonated in training exercises.

title: NOTHING SILLY IN LAMPOON BIDS
description: Executives of National Lampoon Inc. - who produce movies and a magazine marked by a winning, sophomoric silliness - stood by in awe yesterday in their inappropriately fashionable Madison Avenue offices as their company became the object of a spirited bidding war.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Sept. 16.

title: CHICAGO MOUNTS AMBITIOUS BATTLE AGAINST A SURGING LAKE MICHIGAN
description: With an air of concern, a note of awe and a sense of futility, Chicago has begun an ambitious battle against the rampaging, record-high waters of Lake Michigan.

title: TOP AIDE TO SHULTZ TO UNDERTAKE TRIP TO SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned today that time was running out on possibilities to forge a peaceful solution in South Africa and that he was sending a top deputy to the region for talks.

title: Brazilian President Appeals for Support
description: President Jose Sarney, speaking to the nation for the first time since price increases last month bruised his image, made an emotional appeal to Brazilians today not to lose faith in their country and to continue supporting his Government.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest quarter and 6 months reflect an adjustment for the elimination of investment tax credits under the new federal tax provisions.

title: WILSON NOURISHING THE ROOTS
description: When they were growing up in Bamberg County, S.C., between the Salkehatchie River and the south fork of the Edisto River, Mookie and Rosa Wilson saw only one way of life - the annual struggle to scratch a living from the soil.

title: 4 FAMILY MEMBERS KILLED IN BRONX FIRE
description: Four people were killed and eight others, including six firefighters, were injured early yesterday morning in a fire that swept through a home in the Wakefield section of the Bronx.

title: WHERE THE LAUGHS ARE: COMEDY IS KING ON CITY STAGES
description: ONE of the oldest theatrical saws is that this or that great actor could move an audience to tears ''just reading from the New York telephone book.'' While one has yet to witness such a demonstration, in various Off Broadway shows, clubs and performance spaces around town, actors and comedians, sometimes without even the benefit of words, are reducing audiences to helpless laughter. In some cases, all it takes is an insistently infectious grin to infuse a rickety show with enough laughter to make it worth seeing.

title: Perry Voted Top Hero
description: William (the Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears was named the top sports hero in a poll conducted among United States teen-agers.

title: Pleading the Fifth Is No Crime
description: Should Americans be outraged that Vice Adm. John Poindexter, President Reagan's former national security adviser, and Lieut. Col. Oliver North, his key aide in arms deals for Iran and Nicaraguan rebels, have ''taken the Fifth'' before the Senate Intelligence Committee? Yes, say Ohio Senator John Glenn and others, but they're overreacting.

title: Time To End Sanctions
description: Sporadic talks are going on between Poland and the U.S. on lifting the remaining sanctions imposed after the declaration of martial law here in 1981.

title: SPECIAL SESSION ON DEFICIT OPENS IN LOUISIANA
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards opened a special session of the Louisiana Legislature today, telling members that the oil-depressed state's $6 billion budget was ''woefully out of balance.''

title: SCREEN: MATT DILLON IN 'REBEL
description: THE performances of Matt Dillon and a new (to American audiences) Australian actress named Debbie Byrne are the principal reasons to see ''Rebel,'' set during World War II, in Sydney, about an American Army deserter and the woman who redeems him. It opens today at the U.A. Twin and other theaters.

title: Court Delays Are Not Caused by Permissiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFIT PRICES: IT'S ONLY MONEY
description: The tickets were $150 in 1973 to see the preview of the annual Costume Institute exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and to dine and dance there. As Sisi Cahan recalled, ''People said that was awfully expensive.''

title: Coca-Cola Sets Stock Buyback
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would buy back 10 million shares of its common stock on the open market, at a cost of more than $400 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Bass Group Adds To Taft Holding
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas investor, has raised its stake in the Taft Broadcasting Company to 24.9 percent, or 2.14 million shares, from 22.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that there was no change to its previous statement that the shares were bought for investment purposes only.

title: ALBERT COLLINS'S BLUES GUITAR IN 2 SHOWS THIS WEEKEND
description: THE bluesman Albert Collins can make his presence known with a single guitar note - a high, sustained, penetrating note with a jagged vibrato, held out and then cut off with pitiless precision. He also tosses off saw-toothed riffs and twangy, long-lined solos with a tone that's a product of an unconventional tuning, a capo (which raises the pitch of the strings) and more than three decades of honky-tonk experience. This weekend, Mr. Collins will make two New York appearances - one that recalls his apprenticeship in Houston, and one that brings him to a plush concert hall. Both shows should offer definitive Texas blues.

title: LUTANIST'S DEBUT
description: The Lutanist Robert Barto will make his New York debut with a program of works by Sylvius Leopold Weiss, Adam Falckenhagen and J.S. Bach at the Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Sunday at 4 P.M., as part of the church's ''Music Before 1800'' series. Admission is $8; $5 For students and the elderly. Information: 666-0675.

title: Rwanda to Hold Trial In Gorilla Expert's Death
description: A New Jersey man accused of the machete murder of Dian Fossey, the gorilla specialist, will be tried in absentia by the Government of Rwanda, a United States Embassy spokesman in Rwanda said today.

title: Catholic U. Board
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: CLINT EASTWOOD IN 'HEARTBREAK RIDGE'
description: ''HEARTBREAK RIDGE,'' which stars Clint Eastwood, who also directed and produced it, is about Sgt. Tom Highway of the United States Marine Corps, a character made to Mr. Eastwood's impressive measurements as a man, an actor and an icon of the popular cinema.

title: Michigan Police Disarm Bomb in Abortion Clinic
description: The police disarmed a bomb at an abortion clinic today in this Detroit suburb as a fire that had destroyed a Planned Parenthood clinic in Kalamazoo was ruled arson.

title: VREST ORTON, 89, FOUNDER OF STORE
description: Vrest Orton, an author and founder of the Vermont Country Store in the mountaintop village of Weston, Vt., died Tuesday at Springfield Hospital in Springfield, Vt. He was 89 years old and lived in Weston.

title: Playoff Leaders
description: The Chicago Bears, who clinched the N.F.C. Central Division title last Sunday, will become the 10th major professional football team to play in at least 20 postseason games since the National Football League began championship playoffs in 1933 and the American Football League ran them from 1960 to 1969. The Super Bowl began as a competition between the leagues after the 1967 season and has continued as the N.F.L. title game after their merger in 1970.

title: GENE TRANSPLANT CAUSES FERTILITY
description: Scientists have produced fertility in genetically infertile mice by transplanting a gene from normal animals.

title: Saatchi's Smashing Year
description: BRITAIN'S Saatchi & Saatchi, which last year laid out a total down payment of $525 million for three United States ad agencies, reported yesterday on what that did for its bottom line. It was smashing.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $670,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a net gain of $1,555,000 from tax credits, a gain on sale of land and loss on redemption of 11 percent convertible subordinated debentures. c-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $177,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a tax credit of $301,000.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $955,000 and $2,042,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Aid to Contras: High Risk, Low Budget
description: The first flight to El Salvador had to jettison $50,000 worth of cargo over the countryside and nearly crash-landed last January.

title: ART: NEWMAN SCULPTURE AND ITS LINKS TO THE 60'S
description: JOHN NEWMAN straddles different sculptural generations.

title: Policy on Iran: Right and Wrong
description: As the Reagan-bashers have their field day, it is important to sort through what the Administration did, and separate right from wrong. First, the Administration's chief goal - to encourage moderate elements in Iran and develop influence with them - was and remains necessary. But how can this best be done?

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Kinnock Denounces Iran Deals
description: The leader of Britain's chief opposition party today denounced President Reagan's sale of weapons to Iran and expressed concern that the growing preoccupation with the affair would slow movement toward disarmament.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I really don't like it when there's a political action involving many students, and there's a story written about me, and not the action.'' - Amy Carter. [ A20:1. ]

title: JIMMY ROGERS PLAYS
description: The blues guitarist Jimmy Rogrs, who was a member of Muddy Waters's band, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are around 9:30 P.M. and midnight, wht John Campbell opening. There is a $12 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Visions of Plums
description: For most of 200 years, reform-minded members of the House, working to increase the power of rank-and-file lawmakers, have struggled with House leaders, who insist they need more power to keep the legislative enterprise in motion at all.

title: REDSKIN ROOKIE WEIGHS THE TASK
description: Alvin Walton was one of those viewers who did not turn off the game at halftime Monday night when the 49ers were leading the Giants, 17-0. He stuck it out, so he knows how the Giants stormed back to win, 21-17. He also understands why some Giants have credited Mark Bavaro with making the play that ignited the turnabout.

title: Extra Time Is Allowed In Drive to Save Farm
description: A drive to save the farm of a widow whose husband killed himself fell more than $64,000 short today, but a businessman said the Federal Land Bank had given him an two extra weeks to raise the missing money.

title: Holiday Plans Sale of Hotels
description: The Holiday Corporation said today it would sell 110 hotels over the next three years to concentrate further on managing its casinos and franchise property.

title: GIRL DETAINED FOR REFUSAL TO TESTIFY
description: A Superior Court judge has held a 15-year-old girl in contempt of court for refusing to testify in a statutory rape case against a 28-year-old bus driver who she says is her lover.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 375 money market mutual funds decreased $1.03 billion, to $233.9 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Nathan Milstein Cancels Three Performances
description: Nathan Milstein has strained the muscles and tendons in his left arm and hand, forcing him to cancel two performances this weekend at the 92d Street Y and another on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: MAYOR'S FOE ENTERS CHICAGO RACE
description: Edward R. Vrdolyak, longtime opponent of Mayor Harold Washington, announced today that he would be a candidate for Mayor in 1987.

title: HILL GETS HIS FIRST VICTORY
description: Strange things happen when two desperate teams cross paths. Bad passes. Bad shots. And sometimes, just plain bad basketball.

title: FIVE PIANISTS
description: Five young pianists - Thomas Kaurich, Ori Steinberg, Brent Runnels, Patricia Tao and Arrieta Rowena, all winners of the Frinna Awerbuch International Competition - will play a concert of works by Bloch, Liszt, Brahms, Schumann and Prokofiev at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission is $8. Information: 362-8719.

title: TV SPORTS;
description: There is almost no indignity the folks from network sports won't endure when a hot event is up for grabs.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
14 SENTENCED TO DEATH IN GRENADA IN 1983 KILLING OF PRIME MINISTER
description: The former Deputy Prime Minister of Grenada and 13 other people were convicted and sentenced to death today for the 1983 slaying of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sun Rhythm Section, the Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue at 13th Street (242-1664). They slipped in and out of town with little fanfare several months back, played two sets at the Lone Star Cafe and left their listeners devastated. Who were those masked men? In the 50's, they were in the forefront of Memphis rock-and-roll, heard on hit records by Jerry Lee Lewis, Johnny Burnette and scores of others. The last time they played here, they were easily one of the most exciting rock-and-roll bands in the world. The Sun Rhythm Section will be playing three sets tomorrow between 9:30 P.M. and 3 A.M. Admission is $10.

title: Dramatic Drop in Dropouts
description: About 256,000 students attend New York City's 111 high schools - more or less. By the Board of Education's latest estimate, 33 percent will drop out before graduating. Reducing that percentage is, rightly, a top priority of the board president, Robert Wagner Jr., and Chancellor Nathan Quinones. They have a successful model in Long Island City at Middle College High at La Guardia Community College. The idea is collaboration to serve ''at risk'' students. It works.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the sale of nine drawings from ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' misidentified the London auction house at which the sale occurred. The drawings were sold at Christie's.

title: Bond Redemption Guidelines Issued
description: In an effort to free the backlog of full or partial redemptions of municipal debt securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday issued six new guidelines designed to ''promote maximum efficiency and safety'' in bond redemption.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $7,239,000. c-Net income

title: Bridge: Top American in Standings Leads in Blue Ribbon Pairs
description: The top American in the standings of the World Bridge Federation seemed headed for another title at the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 15 of Erich Koch, the wartime Governor of East Prussia, incorrectly described Konigsberg, now the Soviet city of Kaliningrad. It was German before 1945, not Polish.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HOLIDAY FAIR What with Christmas only three weeks away, the WBAI Holiday Crafts Fair has arrived just in the nick of time. Those looking for the unusual might consider a one-of-a-kind, hand-carved guitar or a handmade kaleidoscope, a candle in the shape of a dragon, a hand-carved domino set, a glass-blown perfume bottle, a handmade bridal gown, a feathered shawl or a hand-carved spaghetti strainer. Altogether, 300 artisans from 33 states will be on hand at the fair, which will take place in Columbia University's Ferris Booth Hall, at 115th Street and Broadway. The fair is open today from 5 to 9 P.M., and tomorrow and Sunday from noon until 7 P.M. If you miss this weekend, the same hours apply next weekend and the weekend after. Admission to the fair, now in its 15th year, is $5 per person, with proceeds going to benefit the nonprofit, listener-supported radio station. Those who pay $10 will gain unlimited entry to the fair for any days of their choice. Information: 279-0707.

title: Sammy White to Retire
description: Sammy White, the Minnesota Vikings' career leader in receiving yardage, said he planned to retire at the end of the season. White has been on injured reserve since suffering a broken finger in training camp, and unless the Vikings make the playoffs, he cannot be activated without being subject to waivers.

title: INDUSTRIAL TRAINING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PACIFICARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
1784 WINE FETCHES $56,000
description: A 202-year-old bottle of white wine believed to have been owned by Thomas Jefferson was won at auction today by a mysterious bidder who quickly left the room without savoring his victory.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ALONG sun-streaked Melrose Avenue in Hollywood, that buoyant runway of West Coast with-it-ness, Tommy Tang has been nurturing the dressed-to-thrill set for six years with his pop renditions of Thai cuisine. While purists may scoff at some of his unorthodox creations, the bangle-to-bangle crowds that jam Tommy Tang's Siamese Cafe nightly are not the types to cavil over gastronomic morphology -they are having too much fun.

title: Champale Is Assigned To Doner of Baltimore
description: The G. Heileman Brewery of LaCrosse, Wis., has acquired the Champale malt liquor brand from Iroquois Brands and has quickly assigned it to W.B. Doner & Company, in Baltimore, which has been doing a hot job for Heileman's Colt 45 Malt Liquor.

title: 5 Hospitals Approved To Widen AIDS Care
description: The State Health Department has approved applications for five New York City hospitals to be designated as AIDS centers.

title: SCS-COMPUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RESIDENTIAL FOCUS FOR SHEEPSHEAD BAY
description: Far advanced in construction along Emmons Avenue on the Sheepshead Bay waterfront in Brooklyn is a 135-unit condominium development called Waterview Village. To most of the buyers - about 80 percent, the seller says - it has represented an opportunity to make their first housing purchase. Buyers have mostly been in the $30,000-to-$70,000-a-year income range.

title: Ex-Aide To Reagan Is Said To Link Him To Early Iran Sale
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, is said to have told the Senate Intelligence Committee that President Reagan gave advance approval to Israel's sale of arms to Iran, despite Administration assertions to the contrary.

title: TREE AT RUTGRS MARKS JOYCE KILMER'S CENTENNIAL
description: A German sniper's bullet fired near the Ourcq River in France on July 30, 1918, during the second Battle of the Marne, ended the life of Joyce Kilmer, poet, journalist and sergeant, born in New Brunswick, N.J., 100 years ago tomorrow.

title: FAIRNESS STRESSED BY NATION'S PRESS
description: On the day after President Reagan's Nov. 25 revelation that money from arms sales to Iran had been diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, the editor of The Chicago Tribune interrupted a news meeting with his staff to make what he called ''a speech.''

title: TOP MOZAMBICAN ACCUSES PRETORIA
description: Mozambique's new leader, Joaquim Chissano, accused South Africa today of breaking a security pact with his beleaguered land by dropping supplies and providing other logistical support for a new offensive by rebels here.

title: EFFORTS LAG TO FREE A BARGE FROM UNDER BUFFALO BRIDGE
description: More than 100 men from the United States Army Corps of Engineers, the Coast Guard and a marine salvage company, have been at work all week in the 45-degree water of the Niagara River, trying to remove a wrecked barge from beneath the bridge that links this city with Ontario.

title: Henley Buyback
description: The board of Henley Group Inc. has approved the repurchase, from time to time, of up to 10 million shares of the company's common stock.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $256,000 of non-recurring charges.

title: Nicole Nicholas Becomes Bride Of C.E. Hambro
description: Nicole Nicholas, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Nicholas of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married at the Greek Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York yesterday to Charles Edward Hambro, a son of Charles Eric Alexander Hambro and Rose Evelyn Hambro, both of Cheltenham, England. Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, performed the ceremony.

title: ART: NEW MALCOLM MORLEY PAINTINGS
description: MALCOLM MORLEY calls himself a ''venture painter'' and it's a buccaneerish term that jibes nicely with his career. The bearded artist today may look like a British naval officer in plain clothes, but as man and painter he has passed much of his life as an outlaw doing time in prison as well as at the Royal College of Art (in that order) and, since settling in the United States, getting away with his own version of esthetic murder.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a writedown of $692,000.

title: Omaha Mayor to Stay And Face Recall Vote
description: Mayor Mike Boyle said today that he would not resign, and would face a recall election.

title: EDBERG HANDLES NOAH AGAIN
description: He may eventually gain recognition as the Gary Cooper of tennis, the strong, silent type who lets his big serve-and-volley game do his talking for him. But for the time being, Stefan Edberg of Sweden plays in the shadow of his contemporary, Boris Becker, scoring most of his tournament victories in faraway places where the publicity spotlight does not reach.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1 million and $2,660,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $650,000 and $1,180,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Third-quarter net from operations is after a LIFO inventory charge of $225,000 this year compared with an inventory credit of $144,000 in the year-ago quarter; the nine-month net from operations is after LIFO charges of $750,000 this year and $661,000 a year ago.

title: CAPTAIN CRAB INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year includes losses of about $550,000 incurred by Cryotech Industries and the prior year includes about $1,380,000 in Cryotech losses. c-Net loss Capt. Crab holds about 32 percent of Cryotech's class A common.

title: EDUCATION SECRETARY ASSERTS COLLEGES ARE LAX ON DRUG USE
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett today accused colleges and universities of failing to take a sufficiently tough stance against student drug use.

title: House Panel Studies Whether Pentagon Was Adequately Paid for Arms
description: The House Armed Services Committee is investigating whether the Pentagon was adequately compensated for the American weapons that were transferred from Army stocks and eventually sold to Iran.

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from dividended operations of $1,187,000. c-Includes income from dividended operations of $327,000 for the quarter and $1,176,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago figures were restated to reflect the spinoff of Florida Rock and Tank Lines Inc. in July 1986.

title: Couple Arrested In Crack Operation
description: Agents arrested a man and his wife on charges of running a $1 million-a-month drug operation and seized five pounds of crack, 45 pounds of cocaine and $713,000 in small bills, narcotics authorities said yesterday.

title: Restaurant Chain Stocks
description: RESTAURANT stocks, which have been marking time over the last couple of years, appear poised for a march to higher ground, according to some analysts. Although they agree that the industry is indeed showing new life as sales growth accelerates and capacity is absorbed, they differ on where current buy opportunities lie.

title: CITY TO BEGIN EFFORT TO FIND $1 BILLION IN UNPAID TAXES
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would begin a major effort to identify individuals and businesses that evade an estimated $1 billion in city taxes each year.

title: VETERANS AGENCY DENIES DESTROYING RECORDS
description: An anonymous letter giving detailed charges of broad abuses within the Veterans Administration figured large today at a hearing into charges that the agency destroyed thousands of documents to prevent their disclosure in a lawsuit.

title: LaRouche Documents Linked to Palme Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation obtained documents during a raid of the headquarters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. that could be helpful to Sweden in the search for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme, American law enforcement officials said today.

title: GIFTS OFFERED AS MEMORIALS AID NEEDIEST
description: Gifts in memory of friends and relatives were received yesterday from contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Time to Clean Up This Country's Water Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYOFF PICTURE STILL LACKS MOST OF THE INGREDIENTS
description: With three weeks left in the regular season, only nine teams have been eliminated from the postseason tournament that leads to Super Bowl XXI on Jan. 25.

title: THE DANCE: 'BAD BLOOD,' BY DOVE
description: ''BAD BLOOD'' is the name of the exciting and strange dance work by Ulysses Dove that was given its local premiere by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Wednesday night at the City Center.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Article 371686 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury has ordered Conrail to pay $966,112 to a train conductor who suffered whiplash when an engineer applied emergency brakes to avoid hitting a stalled car on the tracks, officials said. The jury awarded the money Wednesday to the conductor, Donald Callops of Syracuse, 54 years old, for the Oct. 14, 1983, accident near Amsterdam.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A correction in this space on Nov. 15, regarding an article the previous day about a group of young people planning an international peace tour, carried an erroneous description provided by the tour's sponsor for the role of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. The organization worked with the sponsor, the Religious Task Force, but is not a financial participant.

title: STUDENTS CLASH WITH PARIS POLICE
description: Dozens of people were injured here today when students clashed with the police at the end of a march through the streets protesting a French Government proposal to overhaul the university system.

title: Two Teen-Agers Deny Killing Parents of Actor in 'Dallas'
description: Two young men pleaded not guilty Wednesday to charges that they killed the parents of Patrick Duffy, the star of the ''Dallas'' television series, in a robbery last month.

title: APARTHEID PULLOUT BY REVLON
description: Facing demands by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and a boycott of its products by black consumers, the Revlon Group Inc. announced yesterday that it will sell its South Africa subsidiaries by the end of next year.

title: Trading Starts In Celtics Stock
description: The stock of the Boston Celtics basketball team closed yesterday at $18.375, down slightly from its initial offering price of $18.50, in a busy first day of trading. More than 800,000 shares traded as a 40 percent stake in the Celtics, one of the nation's most popular and profitable sports franchises, was offered to the public.

title: Unisys Set to Shut Two Plants in 1987
description: The Unisys Corporation, in the first major layoffs since the computer giant was created through the merger the Burroughs and Sperry companies, said today that it would close two American plants next year, eliminating 1,830 jobs.

title: STEP RIGHT UP, FOLKS!
description: For some tourists, the symbols of New York City are still the Statue of Liberty, the Rockettes and the Empire State Building. But for others -especially those in the 12-to-15-year-old category - the Big Apple's main attraction can now be found beneath the Cadillac tail fins on West 57th Street.

title: Our Tacit Support for Pinochet's Chile
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman Retiring From Ahmanson
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the parent company of Home Savings of America, said yesterday that William H. Ahmanson would retire as chairman, effective Jan. 1. He will be succeeded by Richard H. Deihl, who has served as chief executive since 1983 and will retain that title as well.

title: FLORIDA ROCK & TANK LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was spun off from Florida Rock Industries, effective July.

title: MANY QUESTIONS RAISED ABOUT NEW ALIEN LAW
description: One employer asked what happened if an illegal alien now on his payroll qualified for legal status, or amnesty, under the new immigration law but his wife did not. Would the couple be separated in the name of immigration reform?

title: BIGGS IN BID FOR A TITLE
description: Tyrell Biggs, the undefeated heavyweight, may replace Tony Tubbs as the challenger against Tim Witherspoon, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, in the bout scheduled for Dec. 12.

title: ARBOR DRUGS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest first quarter net is pro forma, reflecting pro forma tax provisions that would have been reported assuming the company's wholly owned subsidiary was not an S corporation prior to the date of its acquisition by Arbor.

title: J. Richard Eimers, 69, Dies; Ran News Election Service
description: J. Richard Eimers, the former exec-utive director of the News Election Service, a cooperative that collects and distributes returns for Presidential, gubernatorial and Congressional elections, died Monday at Bayley Seton Hospital on Staten Island, after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT may not be the most rarefied repast in midtown, but for sheer quantity it has to be among the best deals. Every Wednesday Cabana Carioca and Cabana Carioca II, both on West 45th Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, mix up batches of the Brazilian national dish, feijoada. For $8.95 you get an individual Dutch oven heaped with enough black beans, ham hocks, smoky sausage and shoulder of beef to feed an Amazon riverboat crew. The gelatin in the ham hocks combined with the earthy richness of the sausage impart a heady edge to the inky black beans. Brazilians like to sprinkle it with a spoonful of farofa, a condiment that is notable for its visual and textural kinship to sawdust. I prefer it with some of the buttery chopped kale that is served on the side.

title: Tamils' Captain is Cleared
description: Prosecutors said today that they had dropped criminal proceedings against Capt. Wolfgang Bindel of the freighter Aurigae, who dropped 155 Tamil refugees off the coast of Canada in July. He had been under investigation on suspicion of abandoning the Tamils at sea. A spokesman said no evidence of a criminal offense had been found.

title: THE SCREEN: 'PLACE OF WEEPING'
description: THE South African film ''Place of Weeping'' has been made in a plain, sometimes clumsy style that does nothing to diminish its power. As written and directed by Darrell Roodt, it has rough edges and a lot of momentum, as well as great reserves of strength and moral urgency. It concerns a white South African farmer named Tokkie Van Rensburg (Charles Comyn), who is infuriated when a black worker named Joseph (Siphiwe Khumalo) complains about insufficient rations. Van Rensburg catches Joseph stealing a chicken soon thereafter, and beats him to death for this transgression.

title: Bennett Wins Lombardi
description: An outside linebacker, Cornelius Bennett of Alabama, was awarded the Lombardi Trophy last night honoring the nation's outstanding college lineman. Other finalists were Jerome Brown of Miami, Brian Bosworth of Oklahoma and Chris Spiel= man of Ohio State.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After tax credits of $165,000 for the quarter and $270,000 for the year. The year also includes a gain of $150,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $50,000.

title: DOW DECLINES 7.59 MORE, TO 1,939.68
description: Wall Street suffered its second consecutive setback, as investors continued to take profits yesterday after Tuesday's dramatic rally.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Named Frank Franchi and Terry Logan scouting supervisors. Signed Butch Davis and Tommy Dunbar, outfielders, to minor league contracts.

title: Gunman in Colombia Kills 19, Wounds 11
description: A gunman killed his mother and 18 other people today, including 14 in a restaurant in a fashionable section of Bogota, the police said.

title: CONCERT: MEHTA CONDUCTS BRUCKNER
description: Zubin Mehta has made an international conducting career without being widely admired in any one area of the repertory - as Neville Marriner and Raymond Leppard are in 18th-century music, for instance, or Pierre Boulez and Michael Gielen are with the masterpieces of modernism. But if Mr. Mehta has a love, and a love he can effectively translate into performance, it is the music of Anton Bruckner, and above all Bruckner's towering Symphony No. 8.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Kodak Donations To Charity Cut 5%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will cut its corporate contributions to charity by 5 percent next year, a move that could mean difficult times for some nonprofit organizations.

title: U.S. TO END ITS SOVIET NICKEL BAN
description: The United States plans to end its three-year-old ban on imports of Soviet nickel, and both Washington and Moscow will intensify efforts to help American companies obtain more Soviet business, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: UNSOUND MINORITY-BUSINESS PROGRAMS
description: The recent indictments and investigations into possible corruption involving New York City and national political leaders and minority-owned businesses in the Bronx is just a local manifestation of a nationwide problem. Even as the investigations run their course, we can say this much about the so-called minority business enterprise programs, which set aside a percentage of government contracts for companies owned by minority members: they have failed to encourage members of minority groups to become entrepreneurs.

title: Lampoon's 2 Bids
description: Matty Simmons, chairman of National Lampoon Inc., said that the company's board was still considering two bids made Thursday by competing groups of investors. The two competing groups are headed by Anthony Cassara, who has offered $7 a share for the Lampoon stock and 75 cents per warrant, and Mark E. Shanker, who has offered $7.10 a share and 75 cents a warrant.

title:
PATENTS;
System Sets Meetings And Invites Participants
description: A method of scheduling meetings and notifying the people expected to attend was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y. The procedure is licensed to users in the I.B.M. professional office system, called Profs.

title: INDEBTED BLACK COLLEGE NEARS BRINK
description: Early Thusday afternoon most of the 928 students of Bishop College walked up the gentle slope to the school's chapel to hear its interim president, Levi Watkins, deliver the kind of talk few college presidents will ever have to give. In a soft voice mixed with hope, determination and frustration, he did his best to convince students their school would survive.

title: Former 49er's Task: Stopping Montana
description: Jim Stuckey may have been Joe Montana's teammate for six years, but he was never allowed to get next to him. At least, not on the field. ''Practicing against him was pretty easy,'' Stuckey said with a laugh. ''Nobody hits Joe.'' Now, that will be Stuckey's job. He will be a virtual regular for the Jets on Sunday when they face Montana's 49ers in San Francisco.

title: LENDL REACHES SEMIFINAL
description: The briefing was given by Ivan Lendl, the No. 1 seed and henceforth honorary tournament director of the Nabisco Masters round robin. After three days of matches involving eight players jockeying for berths in tomorrow night's semifinals, the first ''what ifs?'' were raised following last night's play. And Lendl, among the players anyway, appeared to be the only one with answers.

title: TAIWAN VOTERS TODAY GET A CHOICE OF PARTIES
description: Taiwan voters go to the polls Saturday to choose legislators in the first election in modern Taiwan history that includes an organized opposition party.

title: MAN GETS 10 YEARS FOR SMUGGLING COCAINE
description: A man the authorities described as a principal figure in the largest documented cocaine ring ever uncovered was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and was fined more than $260,000.

title: FAILING GRADE IS LINKED TO SHOOTING OF TEACHER
description: A teen-ager intended to kill his French teacher because he was failing, but instead shot to death her substitute on Thursday, according to classmates.

title: CHANGES IN SENIOR STAFF ARE MADE BY THE TIMES
description: Appointments to senior positions in the news department of The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the executive editor.

title: Bally Acts to Block A Trump Takeover
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation moved today to discourage any takeover efforts by the real estate developer Donald Trump.

title: Snags in Gates Deal
description: The Gates Corporation of Denver has failed to consummate a deal selling its 65 percent share in the Gates Learjet Corporation to a New York investment firm for $62 million in cash and stock. Gates announced termination of the deal with M. J. Rosenthal & Associates on Thursday, but said it was still talking to Rosenthal and ''other potential buyers for Gates's holdings in Learjet.''

title: SAILING 18,000 TONS OF TRASH A DAY ACROSS THE BAY
description: ''Tower to Margot,'' a voice crackled over the radio. ''What is your position?''

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $98,000 and $1,222,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,000 and $17,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Mary Dunham Marries William G. Thompson
description: Mary Huntington Dunham, the daughter of Mrs. Theodore Dunham Jr. of Chocorua, N.H., and the late Dr. Dunham, was married yesterday to William Goodrich Thompson, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goodrich Thompson of New York and South Tamworth, N.H. The Rev. Joseph Majeau performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Portland, Me.

title: NETS PROVE TO BE GOOD HOSTS
description: The Denver Nuggets came to Byrne Meadowlands Arena Friday night as one of only two National Basketball Association teams without a victory on the road. They had lost all eight games away from home and their last four games over all.

title: Levin Family Lawyer Says Diary Is Secure
description: The attorney for the family of Jennifer Dawn Levin, who was killed in Central Park in August, said yesterday that ''proper security arrangments,'' had been made to safeguard Miss Levin's diary, which is being sought by the attorney for Miss Levin's accused killer.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 7:30P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M.; Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) COLLEGES: Hofstra Classic, consolation game, 3 P.M., final at 5; R.P.I. at N.Y.U.. 4 P.M.; Mercy at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; Wagner at St. John's, 8 P.M. (TV - MSG, 8 P.M.; Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Princeton at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio -WSOU 89.5, 7:30 P.M. and WNEW 1130, tape after Nets game); Iona at Marquette (Radio - WRTN 93.5, 8:25 P.M.).

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. A seven-month crash program for the restoration of Carnegie Hall is nearing completion in time for a gala reopening concert on Dec. 15. 2. 21. 3. The wood stove. 4. Is not related. 5. Genetic makeup. 6. Joyce Kilmer. ''Trees.'' 7. A week after she successfully blocked a challenge to her Presidency by dismissing Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines alluded to a remark her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos, had made in January, that a woman's place was in the bedroom. 8. Seattle. 9. H. Ross Perot. The General Motors Corporation. 10. Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek. 11. The city is trying to combat the rampaging record high waters of Lake Michigan, which, like all the Great Lakes, is at its highest level since the Civil War. 12. Betty Friedan. National Organization for Women. 13. Pope John Paul II. Australia. 14. Hill, who had served as an assistant coach in college basketball and then with the Knicks, was named the New York coach after Hubie Brown was dismissed. 15. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street concern, canceled a $3 billion deal with Larry A. Silverman to relocate its headquarters to the building, partly as a result of changes in tax laws and partly because of the Ivan Boesky insider-trading scandal. 16. Transfusions in which the patient gives his or her own blood for use in elective surgery or after. 17. The first selection from 40 million pages of White House documents from the Nixon Presidency, released by the National Archives, were papers of interest largely to historians of arcane, rather than controversial, matters. 18. Japan. 19. 90. 20.

title: Trio at Cafe Jupiter
description: The pianist Vladimir Shafranov, the bassist Rufus Reid and the drummer Victor Lewis are performing tonight at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: CONTEMPT RULING URGED OVER YONKERS HOUSING
description: The Justice Department asked the judge in the Yonkers desegregation suit today to hold the city in civil contempt for failing to comply with a Federal court order that would establish integrated housing.

title: SIKH 'SUICIDE SQUAD' IN TRUCK KILLS 3 NEW DELHI POLICEMEN
description: Seven people were reported killed here today when a truck driven by Sikhs roared suddenly out of a Sikh temple and ran over a group of policemen, killing three of them before it crashed into a wall.

title: Coffee Prices Tumble Amid Market Rumors
description: Coffee futures fell sharply today amid talk that supplies were likely to remain plentiful and that a major producer might let prices decline.

title: WORK BEGINS ON THE METS' NEW ERUOPEAN WING
description: Excavation has quietly begun for the last building in the Metropolitan Museum's expansive master plan of 1970. The $35 million structure is known acronymically as the ESDA wing, for the European sculpture and decorative arts it will house, along with a capacious new gallery for loan exhibitions.

title: THE EAST VILLAGE FLEA MARKET SWAMP
description: A flea market that sprung up several years ago on the sidewalks of New York City's East Village has grown from an informal gathering of peddlers to a free enterprise zone gone haywire. It should be regulated.

title: Jamaica Airline Fined $1.3 Million for Drugs
description: Inspectors found 162 pounds of marijuana in bogus Postal Service bags aboard an Air Jamaica jetliner Friday, and Customs officials seized the aircraft and levied a fine of nearly $1.3 million, officials said.

title: RANGERS WIN FOR WEBSTER, 6-3
description: Walt Puddubny scored three goals and Doug Soetaert made 37 saves tonight to lift the Rangers to their first victory since Tom Webster took over as coach four games ago, 6-3, over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SUSPECT IN A SERIES OF RAPES ISEIZED AT BMT STAKEOUT
description: A suspect in as many as 16 Brooklyn rape cases was arrested Thursday night after a victim identified him at a subway stakeout, the police said.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AT VIDEO FESTIVAL, SATIRE, WELLES AND TECHNOLOGY
description: Nearly 200 hours of shocking, boring, surreal, political and abstract videos from more than 15 countries are on display here this week at the sixth annual National Video Festival sponsored by the American Film Institute.

title: Westinghouse Contract Quest
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation joined the battle for the contract to build a new generation of British surveillance planes, announcing a deal that would give a British company $1.6 billion in work if the American Airborne Warning and Control System plane is selected. The Westinghouse agreement is with the Plessey Company, a leading British electronics concern.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 27 misstated the age of the Barnes & Noble bookstore chain. It was established in 1873 and was incorporated in 1965.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Upsets at Trials Rocking the Boats
description: America II buckled under fierce competition from the 12-Meter French Kiss today and lost its third major race of the December America's Cup challenger trials.

title:
PATENTS;
Diagnostic Aid Makes 3-D X-rays
description: A THREE-DIMENSIONAL display of X-ray images, made with a medical diagnostic tool patented this week, is expected to interest hospitals and research institutions. The inventor, who received patent 4,627,087, is Alvin M. Marks, president of Advanced Research Development Inc., in Athol, Mass.

title: Army's Top Gun Taking Aim at Navy
description: Whenever Tory Crawford, the nifty quarterback, gained more than 100 yards rushing this season, the Army team won. When he did not top the 100 mark, it did not win. The Cadets, with a 5-5 record, play Navy in their season finale in Philadelphia today, and if Crawford gains his 100 yards, Army should win, right?

title: Sweet Holiday Wines
description: EVERYONE looks for new ways to brighten up traditional holiday occasions, for something special to add a touch of elegance to dinners and suppers. One place to look is the little-known but delightful world of sweet, late-harvest wines.

title: CONCERN FOR HOMELESS CITED BY DONORS TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Concern for homeless people in New York City is often expressed by contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: YOUTH GETS PERFECT SCORE ON SCHOLASTIC TEST
description: Almost perfect was not good enough for 17-year-old Daniel Pak, so he tried again and made a flawless score of 1,600 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: 16-Year-Old Boy Sentenced For Murder of His Playmate
description: A teen-ager convicted of killing an 11-year-old neighbor while they were playing the game Dungeons and Dragons was sentenced today to five and a half years to life in prison.

title: CORRECTION
description: Quotation marks were misplaced in a statement attirbuted to Samuel Johnson in ''The Game of the Name,'' by Nardi Reeder Campion on Nov. 29. The quotation should have read: ''The true art of memory is the art of attention.''

title: The Clockwork Heart Of London Skips Beat
description: Big Ben missed a chime today, and for Londoners it was like skipping a heartbeat.

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $183,770 of pretax income from the sale of 208,000 shares of Meston Lake Resources Inc. c-Includes a tax credit of $90,000 for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes income of $160,431 from the company's discontinued Ferrotherm Co. unit.

title: BRENDLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
EX-GENERAL PROVIDED ARMS CHANNEL The following dispatch is based on reporting by Fox Butterfield, Jeff Gerth and Bernard E. Trainor and was written by Mr. Butterfield.
description: Unable to rely fully on conventional Government channels, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North apparently turned to a network of former intelligence agents and arms dealers run by Richard V. Secord, a retired major general, and his Iranian business partner to help manage the Administration's arms deal with Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: LIVING BREATHING MONEY
description: The sequence seems to go like this: 1. An American is kidnapped in Beirut. 2. Somebody at the White House hears that Iranians have influence with the kidnappers. 3. Humane impulse motivates the President to approve secret contacts with Somebody in Teheran. 4. The Iranian Somebody says Iran will use its influence to free the kidnap victim if the White House will change policy and sell it some weapons for its war with Iraq. 5. The President, humane impulses overpowering common sense, agrees to sell the guns secretly to Iran. 6. Through sinuous mercantile channels, the goods arrive in Iran, which pays a substantial price for them. The hostage is freed. 7. Back in Washington, creative accounting begins. The cooked books show that what the Iranians paid for the guns was only what they orginally cost the Pentagon; actually, they pay a steep markup which makes the deal very profitable for the seller. 8. Instead of using this profit to cut the budget, Somebody Somewhere or-ders it deposited in a secret bank account in Switzerland. 9. Somewhere Somebody empowered to write secret checks on this secret account sends Somebody Else Somewhere the money to finance the Administration-backed effort to overthrow the Marxist Government of Nicaragua. 10. Learning that money from the secret guns-for-hostage deal has been spent to fund the not-so-secret effort to undo the Nicaraguan Government, the President is appalled, for Congress has forbidden such financing, which means Somebody Somewhere, possibly in the White House, has broken the law.

title: IS PUBLIC POLICY THE PROPER PROVINCE OF BISHOPS?
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAD SEEKS S.E.C. EXPANSION
description: John S. R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today that he would be seeking a ''substantial increase'' in the commission's budget and staff for the coming fiscal year, the first such major expansion in five years.

title: U.S. ATTORNEYS LOSING INTEREST IN ARMS CASES
description: Many Federal prosecutors are no longer interested in pressing investigations into more than a dozen suspected attempts to smuggle arms to Iran, Federal officials say.

title: FRENCH POWER-SHARERS CLASH ON LONDON SEATS
description: France's experiment in political power sharing between a Socialist President and a conservative Prime Minister produced an unsual crisis over seating arrangements when a European Community meeting opened here today.

title: Surgery for Howser
description: Dick Howser, who underwent surgery earlier this year for removal of part of a brain tumor, was alert and feeling well yesterday following experimental brain surgery.

title: Bush Losing Key Aide
description: In what some Washington observers see as a setback to Vice President Bush at a time when he needs a smartly functioning and politically savvy staff to run the store while he courts the Presidency, a key aide, his deputy chief of staff, Frederick Khedouri, has decided to leave.

title: HOSPITAL WORKERS REJECT PACT WITH 2 WAGE SCALES
description: A six-week strike by more than 9,000 workers at 26 hospitals and clinics in northern California continued today after union members rejected a contract proposal that included a lower wage scale for new employees.

title: THE PERSONAL VALUE OF IVORY TOWERS
description: Higher education has emerged once again as an important issue. Not long ago, the Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett, ruffled feathers by questioning the wisdom of Federal student aid programs. Then there were the studies by the National Institute of Education and the American Association of Colleges that warned that the quality of higher education was declining, that undergraduates in particular were not receiving adequate attention and that the baccalaureate degree was in danger of losing its academic and intellectual integrity. And now the Carnegie Foundation reports that undergraduate education is in serious trouble.

title: Santos Sidelined
description: Jose Santos, Aqueduct's leading jockey this meeting with 31 winners and the rider of 18 stakes winners in New York this year, will probably be sidelined for the rest of the year because of a back injury suffered in a spill in the ninth race Thursday at Aqueduct. X-rays at Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream, L.I., revealed ''a small fracture of the spine,'' according to Dr. Harvey Orlin, an orthopedic surgeon, who said the fracture would ''take three to four weeks of rest to heal.''

title: Positions of the Probable Speaker Can Be Volatile
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who is expected to become Speaker of the House when Congress convenes in January, has the reputation of a moderate conservative and his voting record over his 22 years in the House generally reflects this bent.

title: 11 KILLED ON MINDANAO; MOSLEM REBELS BLAMED
description: At least 11 people were killed and 5 seriously wounded when armed men thought to be Moslem rebels ambushed a logging truck on Mindanao island, the Philippine News Agency reported today.

title: PANEL SAYS TISCH'S CBS HOLDINGS MAY LIMIT ROLE IN POSTAL INCREASE
description: Because of his substantial interest in CBS Inc., which owns several magazines delivered by mail, Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch may have to stay out of any discussion of postal rates, a lawyer for the postal board of governors said Friday.

title: AT BRAZIL'S ATOM PLANT, FAMILIAR FEARS AROUSED
description: Some 15 years ago, when the ruling generals decided to build Brazil's first nuclear energy plant on a beach 10 miles west of here, they considered it unnecessary to consult the inhabitants of this fishing and farming region on a matter of such strategic importance to the nation.

title: FOR WOMEN, DAZZLING GIFTS
description: Spree!

title: U.S. DECLINES TO PRESS CASE IN ENVOY'S USE OF FUND
description: The Justice Department said today that it believed there was not enough grounds to prosecute Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the United States Ambassador to Switzerland, who had been under investigation because of reports that she misspent money from an embassy entertainment fund.

title: TOWARD TOTALITARIANISM
description: TO the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., announced the completion of the sale of its Amax Chemical Corp. subsidiary to FCS Energy Inc. of Leesburg, Fla.

title: Imprisoned in the Self
description: NOVEMBER. By Janet Hobhouse. 198 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. $6.95.

title: BROKERAGE SUES OVER GOODYEAR DEAL
description: Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company filed a $17 million lawsuit against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Sir James Goldsmith yesterday, contending that both fraudulently misled investors during their recent takeover battle.

title: LABATT, JOHN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Homestead Doctors Fill a Gap in Queens
description: A COUSIN who married well and escaped the old neighborhood for the suburbs tells Denise Williams from time to time about the good life out there, about the nice homes, the two cars, the fine schools.

title: State Moves to Cut Shoreham Hot Line
description: State officials have asked Lilco to remove a hot line connecting the Shoreham nuclear power plant to the state police.

title: KRISHNA ADHERENT GUILTY OF MURDER
description: A jury decided today that the disappearance of a man from a Hare Krishna compound was a case of homicide and convicted a fringe member of the sect on murder charges.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,190,000, and the tax reform act increased income tax cost by $2,129,000, or 8 cents a share, consisting of a $1,099,000 reduction of 1986 investment tax credit and a $1,030,000 excise tax on the gain from settling the accumulated benefits under a retirement plan earlier in 1986; third- quarter figures also include an after- tax gain of $5,681,000, or 22 cents a share, from All American Gourmet Co.'s sale to the public of one million newly issued shares. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,828,000 and a loss from the extinguishment of debt of $3,000,000, and the excise tax lowered the after-tax retirement plan termination gain to $4,315,000, or 16 cents a share; nine-month earnings also include an after-tax gain of $5,681,000, or 22 cents a share, from All American Gourmet Co.'s sale to the public of one million newly issued shares. d-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,574,000 and $9,222,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also includes an after-tax gain of $8,259,000, or 31 cents a share, from the company's initial sale of a minority interest in All American Gourmet Co. for both periods.

title: Texaco Canada Chief
description: Peter I. Bijur, an executive of Texaco Inc., has been named president and chief executive of Texaco Canada Inc. Mr. Bijur, 44 years old, succeeds James L. Dunlap, who was named earlier in the week as president of Texaco U.S.A. in Houston, Texaco's largest division.

title: Robinson at Tramps
description: The blues songwriter Fenton Robinson will perform tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: NATO MINISTERS BACK CUT IN U.S.-SOVIET ATOM ARMS, BUT WARN OF SPENDING EFFECT
description: Defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance today endorsed the goal of cutting American and Soviet strategic nuclear arsenals in half, but they warned that substantial increases in military spending for conventional forces would result from such a cut.

title: Yanks Sign Scurry
description: The Yankees reduced their free-agent list from eight to seven yesterday by reaching agreement with Rod Scurry on a one-year, nonguaranteed contract. Scurry, a left-handed reliever, appeared in 31 games last season and had a 1-2 record, 2 saves and a 3.66 earned run average.

title: 4 ARE ACCUSED IN JURY FROM PARIS TERRORISM TRIAL
description: Four jurors on a nine-member panel were excused today from participation in the murder trial of suspected members of the terrorist group Direct Action, raising the possibility that the trial would be stopped.

title: KISSINGER, HALDERMAN AND MITCHELL TO FACE TRIAL IN WIRETAPPING SUIT
description: Henry A. Kissinger, H. R. Haldeman and John N. Mitchell must go to trial in a 14-year-old lawsuit against them by a former National Security Council aide growing out of the Nixon Administration's warrantless tapping of his home telephone, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: NO MORE WORLD'S FAIRS IN AMERICA?
description: My great aunt Katie got married in the summer of 1893 atop the first ferris wheel at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago. Like hundreds of other couples, she and her fiance rented one of the enclosed passenger cars for the ceremony, saying their vows while gently swaying in the breeze 260 feet above the teeming midway.

title: THATCHER IS QUIETLY MOVING CLOSER TO EUROPEAN PARTNERS
description: For most of her nearly eight years as Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher has been routinely castigated for making Britain Europe's ''odd man out'' and putting up obstacles to closer political and economic cooperation among the members of the European Community.

title:
PATENTS;
Princeton Inventions Tied to Fusion Power
description: Two inventions related to fusion power that can be produced with hydrogen isotopes in a nuclear reactor were patented this week for the Department of Energy under a contract with Princeton University.

title: Homosexuals Settle Coast Suit
description: About 250 homosexual men and women who said they were denied jobs or promotions by Pacific Bell because of a policy discriminating against homosexuals will receive up to $3 million in settlement of a lawsuit, their lawyers said Thursday.

title: Antidotes for Panic When the Doorbell Rings
description: There is something about the holiday season that makes drop-in company acceptable in big cities, as acceptable and customary as it used to be, and perhaps still is, in small towns.

title: MIKHAIL GORBACHEV LOOKS EAST
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's India visit highlights a spate of Soviet diplomacy in Asia and the Pacific that the West has been watching intently. All the activity has been interesting but hasn't much affected the balance of power in a part of the world still more subject to American influence.

title: Navy Player Quits
description: ''I made a mistake and I've learned a very important lessson,'' said Nathan Bailey, the 6-foot-6-inch sophomore basketball player after he resigned Wednesday from the Naval Academy in the wake of disciplinary action for an unspecified administrative violation of the honor code.

title: 'DEM BUMS' HAUNT PLAN FOR MINOR LEAGUE TEAM
description: Minor league baseball? In Brooklyn? Picture this: a roster filled with the has-been and the unheard of, rivals such as the Toledo Mud Hens and the Tucson Toros; no All Star Game, no World Series. The Boys of Summer it is not. Even so, for many baseball fans and civic leaders it would be an amazing victory if the State Urban Development Corporation is successful in its embryonic attempt to attract a minor league franchise to Brooklyn.

title: ROTECH MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FRANCE TO DROP PART OF UNIVERSITY PLAN
description: The Government, trying to quell the largest student protests in France in nearly two decades, said tonight that some provisions of a university bill fiercely opposed by students would be deferred.

title: MERCHANTSBANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $962,000 and $1,737,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $167,000 and $305,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $69,000.

title: BENNETT FOR TEACHING PERILS OF COMMUNISM
description: American schools should be teaching high school students more about the evils of Communism and less about the consequences of nuclear war, William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, said today.

title: BROOKLYN DELEGATION STARTS PLEADING CASE FOR A BASEBALL TEAM
description: A delegation from Brooklyn arrived in Florida yesterday and began the next and most difficult phase of efforts to get a minor league baseball team for Coney Island: convincing the minor leagues to start a franchise and the major leagues to let them.

title: Guard Injured in Fire Ignited by Explosion
description: An explosion in an underground gasoline tank set fire to a tank truck and seriously injured a security guard last night on upper Broadway in Manhattan, the authorities reported.

title: Japan's G.N.P. Growth Slowed by Strong Yen
description: Japan's economic growth slowed further in the third quarter of this year as the strong yen took a toll of exports and manufacturing, official figures released today showed.

title: ISRAELI ASSURED THE U.S. ON CAPTIVES, AIDES SAY
description: A high-ranking Israeli official won President Reagan's approval to ship 500 antitank missiles to Iran in 1985 by telling him that Israel believed the action would lead to the freeing of all the Americans then held hostage in Lebanon, American and Israeli sources said today.

title: Japan Dumping Charge
description: European manufacturers said today that they had filed a complaint with the European Community commission, charging that Japanese companies were dumping microchips on the European market. The European Electronic Component Manufacturers' Association said some Japanese suppliers undercut them by up to 36 percent in the market for computer memory chips.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE REMAINS 6.9% DESPITE RAPID CREATION OF NEW JOBS
description: The nation's unemployment rate remained at 6.9 percent last month despite a continued rapid creation of new jobs, the Labor Department said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: F.A.A. IS PROPOSING BANNING ALL FLIGHTS IN THE GRAND CANYON
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today proposed banning all flights below the rim of the Grand Canyon, where a collision of an airplane and a helicopter killed 25 people earlier this year.

title: REAGAN TURNS DOWN CALLS TO DISMISS SENIOR OFFICIALS
description: President Reagan today rejected Republican appeals to oust additional senior officials from his Administration in connection with the diversion of funds from Iran arms sales to the contras.

title: Reversal of Ruling Is Asked in Sex Case
description: A judge who sentenced a 15-year-old to a suspended jail term for her refusal to testify against a 28-year-old man in a sexual assault case was asked yesterday to reverse his contempt ruling.

title: All-Cash Provision In Offer for Allied
description: In an effort to speed up their merger, the Allied Stores Corporation and the Campeau Corporation said they had amended their agreement to provide that if the merger is effective by Dec. 31, Allied shareholders would have the right to receive $69 in cash. The previous offer was for $44 in cash and $25 in debt securities.

title: 2 JERSEY TEEN-AGERS CHARGED IN SLAYING OF WOMAN
description: Two teen-age boys were charged today with fatally beating an 86 year-old woman with their fists and sexually assaulting her Wednesday night after the police said she found them burglarizing her South Toms River home.

title: PLAN WOULD CURB FEES OF PHYSICIANS PAID BY MEDICARE
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year proposes dramatic changes in Medicare to restrict Federal payments to physicians for services provided to elderly people in hospitals.

title: Wiesel Leaving One Post
description: Elie Wiesel has resigned as chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, but he is staying on as a member and says that his decision has nothing to do with any unhappiness with the Reagan Administration.

title: Murdoch Bid May Face Test
description: A bid by Rupert Murdoch to take over Australia's largest newspaper group has been thrown into doubt as Robert Holmes a Court, the country's richest man, ponders whether to join the fray.

title: Cabdriver Enters Plea In Two Fatal Shootings
description: A taxi driver pleaded not guilty yesterday to second-degree murder charges in the fatal shooting of his estranged wife and a man on a street near Queens Borough Hall Thursday.

title: Bus Service Reaches Accord With Strikers
description: A five-day strike against the New York Bus Service by 500 mechanics and drivers ended yesterday morning with a tentative contract agreement, a Federal mediator said.

title: Thrift Agency Travel Funds
description: Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has ordered his staff not to accept reimbursement for business-related travel expenses from any source other than the bank board.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.D.A. Plans Warnings On Drugs With Sulfites
description: Warning labels on the 1,100 prescription drugs that contain sulfites will be required to protect the 500,000 Americans who have allergic reactions to the chemicals, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

title: Broken Dream for Sale
description: ''Unique Industrial Opportunity,'' trumpets an advertisement in The Wall Street Journal. ''Picture Your Company Here.''

title: Patriots Reject Move to City
description: William Sullivan has rejected an invitation to relocate his New England Patriots in New York City.

title: THE VAN GOGH SHOW
description: Maybe it's the planning ahead, the standing in line, the buying the tickets: whatever the reason, going to a hit show at the Metropolitan Museum is a lot like going to a hit show on Broadway. The audience seldom arrives alone but in twos, threes, even quartets.

title: WTD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Syracuse Defeats Oklahoma State
description: Greg Monroe scored 20 points, Sherman Douglas had 15 and Derrick Coleman, a freshman, led several second-half plays as Syracuse defeated Oklahoma State, 73-62, in the first round of the Carrier Classic tonight.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the decline in earnings for the quarter was principally the result of advertising and promotional expenses of $2,897,000 for its glycel product line.

title: AUDIT SAYS IT CAN'T VERIFY THE USE OF 'HUMANITARIAN' AID TO CONTRAS
description: A special State Department office set up last year by President Reagan to distribute $27 million in ''humanitarian assistance'' to Nicaraguan rebels has been unable to verify how most of the money was spent, according to a report published today by the General Accounting Office.

title: Alphonse and Gaston
description: In a recent speech at a convention of the National League of Cities, meeting in San Antonio, Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona had high praise for his host, Mayor Henry Cisneros, who in addition to being the current president of the league, is often mentioned as a possible Vice Presidential choice.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'FLEDERMAUS' AT MET
description: About halfway through the first act of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Die Fledermaus'' it became painfully clear that the most generous approach to the remainder of the evening would be to look for bright spots amid the gloom. Yes, Kiri Te Kanawa was doing her best on Thursday night to frolic about as Rosalinde, and her buttery tones at times almost made one overlook the fact that she was miscast as that madcap lady. And yes, Gunther Schneider-Siemssen's lavishly realistic sets were just the spectacular sort that bring Pavlovian oohs and aahs from Metropolitan audiences. But such bright spots, if they can be called that, became increasingly difficult to find as this evening wore on. Otto Schenk, who both directed and took the speaking role of the jailer Frosch, accomplished what any admirer of this queen of operettas might think impossible: he made ''Fledermaus,'' a masterpiece of blithe charm, into a bore of serious proportions.

title: TRUCE PROCLAIMED IN PALESTINIAN-SHITE FIGHTING IN LEBANON
description: The head of the Shiite militia declared a cease-fire tonight in the fighting with Palestinian guerrillas near Beirut, Sidon and Tyre that has taken 550 lives in the last two months. The Palestinians said they would go along.

title: MAIL BOXES ETC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $770,541 net of income taxes from the defeasance of bonds in April 1985. The company said that operating results reflect the operations of the Nashville Gas Co. division from the date of acquisition, March 15, 1985, in accordance with the purchase method of accounting.

title: Gulf Oyster Reefs Closed
description: State officials have closed all oyster reefs off Mississippi's Gulf Coast after the runoff from recent heavy rains caused high bacteria counts. The State Health Department said that it had found unacceptable levels of fecal coliform bacteria in the Mississippi Sound.

title: WEDTECH CITES CASH SHORTAGE AS PLANT IS SHUT
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a military contractor at the center of Federal and state investigations, abruptly shut down a South Bronx factory with more than 200 employees yesterday. Company executives said they were struggling to find financing to keep the company in business.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said that net sales include franchises, and the increase in sales in the latest 9 months is primarily due to operations of Lawson Co. being included for the entire current year-to-date compared with 18 weeks of the prior year. The company also said it had a higher tax rate in the latest quarter because of the elimination of investment tax credits; pre-tax earnings were 4l percent higher in the latest quarter compared to the year-earlier quarter.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Harper Case Settled
description: The Red Sox and their former coach Tommy Harper have settled racial-discrimination complaints he lodged against the club. The settlement, ending cases filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination, included a provision that details of the accord could not be disclosed.

title: 'LES MISERABLES' READY FOR ITS AMERICAN DEBUT
description: An epic portrait of 19th-century Paris, from its teeming streets and factories to its brothels and sewers, ''Les Miserables'' encompasses three tumultuous decades of French history and incorporates into its vast scope so many episodes and characters that they are often described as innumerable.

title: AUSTRALIA LINKS 70 TO WAR CRIMES
