description: A Government-appointed investigator said today that 70 people living in Australia warranted investigation for Nazi war crimes, but he recommended that only those suspected of major atrocities be prosecuted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $408,936. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,368,524 and a gain of $621,763 from pension accounting changes. Figures for 1985 are restated to reflect changes in the gains reported from pension accounting changes.

title: NOVEMBER JOBLESS RATE DECLINES IN NEW YORK CITY AND NEW JERSEY
description: The unemployment rate in New York City and New Jersey declined slightly last month as seasonal jobs in the retail trades provided employment for many, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: S.M.U. Football Coach, Athletic Director Quit
description: Southern Methodist University's head football coach, Bobby Collins, and its athletic director, Bob Hitch, resigned today amid allegations of recruiting violations in the university's football program.

title: A $37,000 PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Aspartame Sweetening Frozen Diet Desserts
description: A New Jersey chemical engineer received a patent this week for a variety of dietetic frozen desserts with a low-calorie content.

title: Hijacker of Jet Pleads Guilty to Kidnapping
description: A former member of the Black Panther Party who spent 18 years in Cuba after hijacking a jet to Havana pleaded guilty today to kidnapping charges in the case, and a Federal district judge said he must go to prison.

title: Taiwan-U.S. Trade Vow
description: Business leaders from the United States and Taiwan pledged at the end of three days of talks today to increase trade and investment ties between their countries. David Kennedy, a former Treasury Secretary, told a news conference the talks had helped pave the way for American businesses to sell more to Taiwan and attract more investment in the United States from the island.

title: HONG KONG MUST CLOSE VIETNAMESE CAMPS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,306,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Two Officers Injured When Cruiser Is Hit
description: Two police officers were injured, one of them seriously, when a livery car struck their cruiser in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: N.C.A.A. Penalty For Iowa State
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has told Iowa State University the penalties it will impose for rules violations in the football and basketball programs, but school officials refused to reveal the sanctions.

title: FirstSouth Closed In F.S.L.I.C. Action
description: FirstSouth, a savings and loan association based in Pine Bluff, Ark., has been closed in what Federal regulators say is the biggest such action ever handled by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: DOW LOSES 14.62 POINTS AND VOLUME FALLS OFF
description: Stock prices fell yesterday for the third consecutive day, turning a week that could have been fabulous into a mediocre one. After the market soared to new highs on Tuesday, traders became increasingly skittish over insider trading, the sale of arms to Iran and the economy.

title: TWO VETERAN PLAYERS TAKE THE BLUE RIBBON PAIRS TITLE
description: Two players with great experience, though not as partners, captured the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship here Thursday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: STATE WINDFALL MAKING TAX OVERHAUL DIFFICULT
description: Unless New York State takes action, its taxpayers will pay hundreds of millions - perhaps billions - of dollars a year in increased taxes to the state as a result of the new Federal tax code, which begins to go into effect in four weeks.

title:
PATENTS;
DNA Disease Detector
description: A labeled DNA was patented this week for Integrated Genetics Inc. of Framingham, Mass. by Greg M. Landes, a staff member.

title: KEY RATES
KAISER STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3.5 million from the restructure of the security portfolio to retire pollution control bonds previously defeased and a charge of $4.2 million for expected losses on the sale of certain surplus assets. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: NEW REQUIEM SOLOISTS FOR THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic has announced changes in the roster of soloists for the four performances of the Verdi Requiem, Dec. 11, 12, 13 and 16 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WEBSTER CLOTHES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Texas Picks Alumnus
description: David McWilliams, who in his first season as coach led Texas Tech to a 7-4 record and a berth in the Independence Bowl against Mississippi on Dec. 20, is returning to his alma mater, Texas, as successor to Fred Akers, who was dismissed last week. McWilliams, who spent 20 years as a player and assistant coach at Texas before taking the Texas Tech job, had four years remaining on his contract and received a five-year deal as the 26th coach in the 95-year history of Longhorn football.

title: Concepcion Re-signs
description: Dave Concepcion, who became a free agent this fall, signed a one-year contract yesterday to play his 18th season with the Cincinnati Reds. That puts him second in Reds history only to Pete Rose in games played (2,300) and total hits (2,198).

title: PHI BETA KAPPA NAMES BOOK-AWARD WINNERS
description: Phi Beta Kappa, the national scholarly honor society, has announced the winners of its annual book awards. The awards, given annually since the 1950's, carry prizes of $2,500 each.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $343,000 from the writedown of an investment and a gain of $211,000 from the sale of a check authorization business.

title: Texas Instruments Pact Is Reported
description: Japanese newspapers said today that Texas Instruments Inc. had arranged a technology exchange agreement with the Mitsubishi Corporation. A Texas Instruments spokesman declined to confirm the reports but said that the company for some time had had mutual sourcing agreements for certain chips with several Japanese companies, including Mitsubishi.

title: Knicks Routed By Jazz
description: Darrell Griffith scored 19 points tonight to lead seven Utah players in double figures as the Jazz walloped the Knicks, 123-96.

title: Storage's Tax Recalculation
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a troubled computer equipment maker in Louisville, Colo., said yesterday that, based on recalculations, it owed the Internal Revenue Service between $22 million and $32 million in back taxes, rather than the $650 million sought by the I.R.S. The new total - if the amount is accepted by a Federal court -would allow the company to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Maxwell Loses His Bid for AE
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell suffered a setback today to his aim of creating an engineering-based industrial empire when shareholders of a major company he was seeking to buy selected a rival bid.

title: ISRAELIS KILL WEST BANK BOY WHO THEY SAY THREW ROCKS
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a 14-year-old Palestinian boy in the West Bank today after he and other youths threw stones at their military patrol, an army spokesman said.

title: TIME TO BENCH S.M.U.?
description: ''If it becomes clear that we should go so far as to abolish football on this campus, we will do it,'' the chairman of the Southern Methodist University board of governors said last week. ''We have a great opportunity for a redirection of our priorities.''

title: THOMAS STOPS MUGABI IN 3d
description: Mickey Duff, manager of John (the Beast) Mugabi, said today he would ask the World Boxing Council to grant his fighter a rematch against Duane Thomas. Duff contended that Mugabi was thumbed in the eye Friday night when Thomas won the vacated W.B.C. super welterweight title by stopping Mugabi in the third round of a scheduled 12-round bout.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: The Traffic Outlook

title: Nathan's to Be Acquired In a $17 Million Deal
description: Nathan's Famous Inc., the company whose hot dogs have become a New York institution, agreed to be acquired yesterday by Equicor Group Ltd., a private investment group based on Long Island, for $7.50 a share, or a total of about $17 million.

title: IRANIAN SAYS U.S. 'BEGGED' FOR TIES
description: Iran's President said today that the United States was conducting a propaganda campaign about arms sales to cover the fact that it ''begged'' for relations with his Government and was rejected.

title: U.N. CHIEF WON'T ATTEND CEREMONY IN VIENNA
description: Scheduling difficulties will prevent Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar from attending a ceremony at United Nations offices in Vienna next month to which President Kurt Waldheim of Austria has been invited, his spokesman said today.

title: BRAZIL SAYS IT WILL ASK BIG DEBT CONCESSIONS
description: The Brazilian Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, told American and foreign bankers yesterday that he was determined to extract large concessions on the $103 billion in loans they had made to his country.

title: G.M.-HUGHES: A SMOOTH FIT
description: When the General Motors Corporation paid $5.2 billion for the Hughes Aircraft Company a year and a half ago, Roger Smith, the chairman of G.M., said that Hughes's wizardry in electronics would lead to ''redefining the basic car or truck.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54. 1. This stage is almost set for a gala opening. Explain. 2. Amid public concern over the Administration's arms deal with Iran and the diversion of funds to Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan's overall public approval suffered the largest one-month decline ever recorded by a public opinion poll measuring approval of Presidential job performance. How many points did it drop? 3. The new target in the war against air pollution is neither the smokestack nor the tailpipe, but a device found in some homes. What is it? 4. Assemblyman George Friedman, who was elected Bronx Democratic chairman, (is related to/is not related to) the man he succeeded, Stanley M. Friedman, who resigned after his recent conviction on Federal charges of racketeering, conspiracy and mail fraud. 5. Which, according to the first study to examine identical twins reared in different families, is a stronger influence on personality, genetic makeup or child rearing? 6. To commemorate the centennial of a writer whose name is forever associated with one 12-line verse, a 10-foot white oak was planted in New Brunswick. Identify the poet and the verse. 7. ''It is not I who have been consigned to the bedroom of history,'' said a head of state, with a touch of swagger that suggests an image of new confidence. Who made the comment and to what does it refer? 8.

title: Nike to Cut Staff
description: Nike Inc. said it would reduce its domestic work force by about 10 percent.

title: Consumer Borrowing Increased
description: Americans, still borrowing heavily to finance new-car purchases, took out $6.78 billion more in consumer debt in October than they paid off, the Government reported today.

title: WORD GAMES OVER CONTRA AID
description: When Congress last year voted $27 million in ''humanitarian'' aid for contra rebels in Nicaragua, it assigned the task of delivery to the State Department. Congress's intent was plain: to keep the C.I.A. out of this program and to limit help to ''non-lethal'' shipments of food, clothing and medical supplies. Now it appears that State evaded that restriction by allowing the use of the same plane to send both humanitarian aid and weapons.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE'S 'NUTRACKER'
description: It must be winter. The holiday season is nipping at our heels. George Balanchine's production of ''The Nutcracker'' was performed by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater on Thursday, opening a four-week season of the holiday classic.

title: NICARAGUA WATCHES, YAWNING
description: Between the Christmas toys that are to go on sale soon, the rumors about disappearing children in Managua and the cave-in at the Masaya volcano, there has been plenty to talk about here these days.

title: JOSEPH STELLA'S 'TREE' SELLS FOR A RECORD PRICE
description: Joseph Stella's ''Tree of My Life,'' a Futurist work from 1919, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $2.2 million, a record price at auction for the artist.

title: CHURCH DIRECTIVE ON SPEAKERS IS QUESTIONED
description: A prominent monsignor in the Archdiocese of New York has written an article in an influential Roman Catholic magazine that strongly questions the archdiocese's policy of discouraging speaking engagements by people who differ with church teachings.

title: SOVIET TO ABIDE BY ARMS TREATY 'FOR TIME BEING'
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would continue to adhere to the 1979 strategic arms treaty ''for the time being,'' despite Washington's deployment of a bomber last Friday that exceeded the limits of the unratified accord.

title: ADOPTION ALSO A CHOICE IN TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: MUSIC, A MOVIE AND 'MYSTERY!' ON CHANNEL 13
description: However hobbled it may be by money problems, public television is still the only game in town for viewers looking for something other than sitcoms, action-adventures and jarring commercial breaks. Consider some of the fare to be found on Channel 13 this weekend. There's the return of Miss Marple, a documentary about Robert Wilson and his mammoth stage project, ''The Civil Wars,'' and an early movie by Jim Jarmusch, whose latest film, ''Down by Law,'' opened this year's New York Film Festival.

title: Treasury Issues Hurt By Job Data
description: Treasury securities opened moderately lower yesterday and continued to retreat throughout the session. Traders took the report of a relatively strong gain in non-farm employment as a sign that an easing of monetary policy was not imminent.

title: SIR EDWARD YOUDE OF HONG KONG DIES
description: Sir Edward Youde, the Governor of Hong Kong, who negotiated the agreement that will return the British crown colony to China in 1997, died Thursday night while on a visit to Beijing. He was 62 years old.

title: G.M. Unit Plant Is Put up For Sale
description: The General Motors Corporation's Fisher Guide division is putting its 2,080-worker component plant in Elyria, Ohio, up for sale to buyers who would continue running the operation, the company said. ''A successful sale to an operating buyer will keep an important manufacturing operation and corresponding employment base here in the Elyria community,'' said Rudolph Schlais Jr., a Fisher Guide product manager.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO TELL PANEL THAT NORTH MISLED IT ON ARMS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has told Congress that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North persuaded the agency to help in a 1985 arms shipment to Iran by giving a middle-level employee misleading information about what was being sent, according to people familiar with the Congressional investigation.

title: How to Cage Hockey Goons
description: ''We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills. . .'' The author of those lines was not a hockey coach, but Winston Churchill, speaking before the House of Commons in wartime.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's now clear that Britain belongs to Europe forever. It's becoming a European country, like any European country.''

title: JAKI BYARD STOMPERS
description: The pianist-saxophonist Jaki Byard will lead his Apollo Stompers big band tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight. Admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 15
description: The company said there were 24 weeks in the latest 6-month period and 25 weeks in the year earlier period.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TENANT'S FRIENDS RALLY TO THWART AN EVICTION
description: Ila Muniagurria, who is 75 years old, hardly knew she had so many friends. She was happy yesterday when more than 50 of them turned out to support her.

title: 2-HOUR SENTENCE GIVEN IN TAX EVASION CASE
description: A man trapped for two hours in a courthouse elevator on his way to plead guilty to income tax evasion will receive a sentence equal to the time he spent in the elevator, a Federal district judge says.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1986
description: International

title: WHAT ONE LANDLORD THINKS OF WATER METERING
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavia Drops Coins
description: The National Bank of Yugoslavia said today that it would eliminate small coins and double the denomination of the largest bank note early next year, as the Government continues to battle inflation.

title: 28 DIE AS COLOMBIAN GOES ON A RAMPAGE WITH KNIFE AND GUN
description: A man killed 28 people, including his mother and 20 diners at a restaurant, Thursday night in a rampage that ended when he was shot to death by the police, the authorities said today.

title: BRITISH BARON CLEARED OF SPY RUMORS
description: The British Government made a rare comment tonight on its counterintelligence activities and responded favorably to a peer's plea that he be cleared of rumors that he was the missing ''fifth man'' who spied for the Soviet Union in the notorious Cambridge espionage ring.

title: ITALY SENTENCES YOUTH IN ACHILLE LAURO CASE
description: A juvenile court convicted a Palestinian today in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro and sentenced him to 16 years in prison.

title: REVAMPING OF PARKS SERVICE PLANNED
description: The Interior Department is planning a reorganization of the National Parks Service, including shifting a number of senior service officials, department officials said today.

title: BUT THE JAPANESE NEVER COPIED OUR S.A.T.'S
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Former Mill Town, Two Surprising Arrests
description: At a time when fewer and fewer big cities have competing daily newspapers, this former mill town of 50,000 people near Hartford still has two afternoon dailies.

title: JUDGES REJECT BID TO WIDEN KANSAS CITY DESEGREGATION
description: A divided Federal appellate court today rejected an appeal to broaden a court-ordered plan to desegregate the city's schools by including suburban districts.

title: Commercial Credit Plans to Cut 125
description: The Commercial Credit Company said that it would lay off 125 employees, or 2.9 percent of its staff.

title: PROSECUTORS IN CHILD MOLESTATION CASE ASK JUDGE TO START TRIAL
description: The prosecution in the McMartin preschool molestation case, saying defense motions to scuttle the case were based on the pecuniary interests of a former prosecutor and his screenplay writers, today asked a state judge to move the case to trial.

title: Robin F. Healey Is Bride Of Gary Thomas Gibson
description: Robin Felix Healey, the daughter of Barbara Cahill Healey of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., and William Francis Healey of New York, was married yesterday to Gary Thomas Gibson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson of New York and Bogota, Colombia. The Rev. Thomas Birmingham performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: POTVIN SCORES WINNER
description: Denis Potvin scored with 4 minutes 40 seconds left in the third period tonight as the Islanders beat the Vancouver Canucks, 4-3, to end a three-game streak without a victory.

title: BULGARI PLEADS GUILTY IN A SALES-TAX SCHEME
description: A Fifth Avenue jewelry salon and two of its executives pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges for helping customers evade sales taxes and agreed to pay nearly $2 million in fines and penalties.

title: POLICE CONTINUE SEARCH FOR DAVIS IN BRONX PROJECT
description: Heavily armed police officers looking for Larry Davis, the fugitive wanted for shooting six officers, searched a Bronx housing project from yesterday afternoon into the early-morning hours today but failed to find him, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described a lawsuit involving a building at 2 Park Avenue. It was brought by one of the 1,040 limited partners in the syndicate that owned the building, and the initial trial court decision was reversed in the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court.

title: Two Sentenced in Deal To Export Ammunition
description: Two Paraguayans who pleaded guilty to illegally exporting ammunition in an arrangement that originally involved Nancy Reagan's maid received two-year suspended sentences today and were placed on probation.

title: ARGENTINE SEEKS RIGHTS-TRIAL CURB
description: President Raul Alfonsin called today for an end to trials of military officers for human-rights violations committed during seven years of military rule than ended in 1983.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECALLING 1941 Tomorrow is the 45th anniversary of that day when Japanese planes attacked the United States Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor. Half a world away, in New York Harbor, this anniversary will be marked aboard a Navy aircraft carrier, the Intrepid, a ship that was being built at that time.

title: VINOCUR IS APPOINTED TO EDIT INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
description: John Vinocur, metropolitan editor of The New York Times, has been appointed executive editor of The International Herald Tribune, published in Paris. The announcement was made at the newspaper's headquarters yesterday by Lee W. Huebner, the publisher.

title: HANSON TRUST reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are stated per U.S. ADR, and each ADR represents 5 ordinary shares. The company is a diversified industrial corporation, and in the United Kingdom owns such companies as Allders Dept. Stores, Imperial Tobacco, Ever Ready Batteries, London Brick, Smith Meters, Ross Foods, Young's Seafoods, and Lea & Perrins; in the United States the company owns such companies as Smith- Corona Typewriters, Endicott Johnson Shoes, USI Lighting, Hygrade Food Products, Carisbrook Industries, O. Ames Tools and Hanson Building Products.

title: Life Insurance And Tax Law
description: ALTHOUGH many types of investments have been hard hit by the new tax law, the major tax break for life insurance remains intact.

title: INSIDE
description: Church Policy Questioned A prominent priest has questioned the policy of the New York Archdiocese to discourage speeches by those who differ with the church.

title: Wall St. Nervously Expects More Insider Shoes to Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -

title: DRESSING UP FOR THE BIG GAME
description: In his first nine weeks as a Giant, Raul Allegre appeared to be the answer to the erratic kicking that had plagued the team since 1984. He made 19 of 24 field goals and 20 of 20 extra points. He boomed the field goals and he boomed his kickoffs.

title: Dealing With California
description: ENGLISH IS THE OF-ficial language of California. It was so decreed by the voters on Nov. 4.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION: TOPICS
description: THE compelling truths of the season spawn unique blends of thoughts as well as hues. The industry of the pattern of nut harvesting and nut storing of the squirrels invites more than the passive accepting glance at a familiar, consistent scurry.

title: A Real Footrace
description: Competing in the athletic shoe business is a real footrace. Take L. A. Gear. The company specializes in the aerobic shoes that Reebok International invented, and in an ''ath-leisure'' shoe, which emphasizes fashion rather than fitness.

title: Dealing With Drunk Drivers
description: As director of an alcoholism clinic, I believe that Adam Clymer's plea to do something more about drunk drivers the first time they are caught is most appropriate. When individuals convicted of driving while intoxicated are referred to us for treatment, our goal is not only to convince them never to drink and drive, but also to break down their denial in regard to their dependency on alcohol.

title: ARAFAT TRIES A COMEBACK IN LEBANON
description: ALL week, President Hafez al-Assad has been trying to get Damascus-based Palestinian guerrillas and the Lebanese leftist militias under his sway to stop killing each other in Lebanon and put an end to Yasir Arafat's military comeback.

title: POP: JUDY COLLINS IN YEAR'S-END AUTOBIOGRAPHICAL CONCERT
description: JUDY COLLINS'S annual December concerts are retrospective occasions on which the singer and her loyal audience share the past through songs that span the 25-year breadth of the singer's recording career.

title: Jazz
description: For the past year, Frank Morgan, at the age of 52, has been picking up the thread for his life that he dropped 33 years ago when he became addicted to heroin. By then the alto saxophonist had been hailed as a new Charlie Parker, including admiration and support from Mr. Parker himself.

title: If Risk-Taking Boomerangs
description: Since the days of Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, strong players have deliberately adopted provocative, inferior systems when playing black against lesser opponents. The question of this strategy is always how far you can go in working to obtain the complications that can befuddle the opponent.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MAX'S CHRISTMAS Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells. Unpaged. New York: Dial Press. $7.95. (Ages 3 to 5) MERRY CHRISTMAS, AMELIA BEDELIA By Peggy Parish. Illustrated by Lynn Sweat. 63 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $10.25. (Ages 5 to 9) MERRY CHRISTMAS, STREGA NONA Written and illustrated by Tomie dePaola. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: YALE HONORS FOUNDER OF CHILD STUDY CENTER
description: IN 1911 a young man, Arnold Gesell, joined the Yale University faculty with a plan to study childhood development. He was eventually given a room with a table and chair in the New Haven Dispensary, where he set about establishing a clinic for children.

title: NEW FORTUNE CHANGING TRIBAL LIFE IN AMAZON
description: When the last shots of the day rang through this stretch of rain forest, the Indian hunters carved up a tapir and a deer, wrapped them in leaves, and carrying them on their bare backs filed behind their chief on the long trail home.

title: Jodi Kase Weds J.L. Pliskin
description: Jodi Lynne Kase, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Kase of Woodbury, L.I., was married last night to Jeffrey Lawrence Pliskin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Pliskin of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated at the Cold Spring Country Club in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride graduated from Brown University. Mr. Pliskin, a real-estate associate in the New York law firm Robinson, Silverman, Pearce, Aronsohn & Berman, graduated from Yale College and the Columbia Law School.

title: STILL MISSING
description: Gen. Ramon Camps, who is ill, and his co-defendants, who defiantly reject the court, were not present to witness their conviction and sentencing for torture this week, but many other Argentines packed the courtroom. The rest of the civilized world also took approving note.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Medal for a Papal Visit
description: Coins and medals have chronicled a number of major events in the pontificate of Pope John Paul II.

title: FRIENDS HELPED DAVIS TO STAY IN SHADOW
description: Larry Davis eluded an intensive manhunt for 17 days by relying on a network of street friends and family contacts who gave him money and shelter as he slipped from place to place in the Bronx and upper Manhattan, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Foreign Stars Have Impact In Bridge Play
description: Two major contract bridge championships continued here this afternoon with a distinguished foreign visitor in contention in each.

title: SHE'S A BELIEVER
description: BOBBY'S GIRL By Rochelle Ratner. 116 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: ARTFUL HOLIDAY SHOPPING
description: New York City department stores come to life at this time of year.

title: THE GUIDE
description: CANDLELIGHT CONCERTS The first in this season's series of hourlong Candlelight Concerts of Larchmont is an all-Bach program at 7 P.M. today in St. Augustine's Church on Larchmont Avenue. A 25-piece orchestra and 30-member chorus will be under the direction of Hugh Berberich, assistant to Zubin Mehta, conductor of the New York Philharmonic.

title: U.S. AND MOROCCO MOVE TO 'CLOSE FRIENDSHIP'
description: Ever since the time of George Washington, the United States has been pledging to repay diplomatic favors from Morocco, whose 1787 friendship treaty predates any other pact still in force.

title: Q AND A
description: Harassed Manager Question: As the manager of a 59-unit rental apartment building I believe I am being harassed by a tenant who constantly complains about odors coming from the tenant above him. I have spoken with the tenants who live on either side of him and to the tenant above him and no one else smells the ''offensive odor.'' The complaining tenant has had the Environmental Protection Agency, the Buildings Department and the police check out this odor, all to no avail. Yet I continue to receive complaints. How can I have this tenant stop these unfounded complaints? . . . D. W., Brooklyn

title: VATICAN ASSESSING SOVIET INTENTIONS
description: The Vatican is increasingly concerned that the Soviet Union has undertaken a propaganda effort to create the impression of improved relations with the Roman Catholic Church while continuing to take a hard line on several key issues, according to senior church officials.

title: 'HEY, I JUST FELT IT. A TWINGE OF FEAR.'
description: IT WASN'T UNTIL THIS MOMENT, THE SEC-ond I conceived this first sentence, that I began to feel the reality, the enormity of what I had done.

title: SINGAPORE DECIDES IT WANTS LOTS OF CHILDREN, AFTER ALL
description: LIKE many developing countries, Singapore in the early 1970's instituted population control. ''Boy or girl, two is enough!'' was the slogan, and officials warned that the island country would run out of room if population growth was not curbed. Now they say the policy may have succeeded too well.

title: Monumental Game in Washington
description: In 1983, Bill Parcells's first year as the head coach, the Giants finished 3-12-1 and his job seemed in jeopardy. In 1984 and 1985, the Giants made the playoffs, and last Monday night, with three weeks left in the season, they clinched at least a wild-card playoff berth again.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Riding the Transport Index

title: ARSON AND MURDER OUTLINE A MYSTERY
description: In this picturesque town dotted with country inns and antiques shops in the wooded foothills of the Berkshires, there is a continuing mystery of arson and murder.

title: Headliners; Alliance Confirmed
description: Wherever he was, Jimmy Hoffa must have rolled over.

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Jimi Hendrix's Johnny B. Goode EP Sony Video Software. 26 minutes. 6.95. This video combines concert footage of Jimi Hendrix, which aspiring guitarists will want to study, and ''conceptual'' videos featuring Mr. Hendrix's music, made long after the singer's death.

title: CBS Scores Winning Bid
description: CBS outbid NBC and ABC for the broadcast rights to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, paying more than $150 million to televise the games for three more years, the N.C.A.A. announced today.

title: Keeping Out Of Touch
description: Russell Baker is in good company when he says he is so out of touch that he had to inquire, ''Who or what is Cyndi Lauper?'' (''Keeping Out of Touch,'' Sunday Observer, Nov. 9). Years ago, one of the country's most distinguished Federal judges, Learned Hand, was honored at a dinner. After several speakers extolled him, he was introduced with the climactic words, ''I now bring you the Mickey Mantle of the bench, Judge Learned Hand.'' The Justice is reported to have begun his remarks by inquiring, ''This Mickey Mantle, is it a person or a thing?'' NORMAN DORSEN New York City

title: Lebanese Cease-Fire Ends After 24 Hours
description: A cease-fire disintegrated today, less than 24 hours after going into effect, when Shiite Moslem militiamen battled anew with Palestinian guerrillas with mortars and rockets in Beirut and south Lebanon.

title: EDUCATOR'S PLIGHT IS TO PLEASE THE PUBLIC
description: THE public has once again gone on a holy crusade against the public schools, and teachers across the state and nation are already leaping into their trenches. A Federal judge in Tennessee has ruled that students may ''opt out'' of classes their parents find objectionable. Henceforth, children may ''withdraw to the safety'' of a study hall or library rather than be exposed to state-approved texts that parents deem offensive to their religions.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bayport $155,000 534 Bayport Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; new kitchen, family room, basement, new carpeting, 1-car garage; taxes $3,100. Commack $199,000 3 Old Pine Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; porch, in-ground pool, patio; taxes $4,000.

title: Question Of the Week; How Can N.F.L. Control Violence?
description: Rule ''changes'' are not necessary. Game officials already have jurisdiction to eject players for flagrant fouls, yet this action is rarely taken. What is needed is the support of owners. With such backing, the commissioner of officials could direct crews not to be lenient in enforcing rules pertaining to personal fouls. BILL SULLIVAN Dorchester, Mass.

title: The 'American' Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: GIFT OF A GOYA PAINTING ENHANCES ART MUSEUM
description: FOLLOWING one of the most distinctive art exhibitions ever held at Bridgeport's Museum of Art, Science and Industry, a Westport couple has donated a painting by Goya to the museum's collection.

title: INSIDE
description: V.A. Bureaucracy Laid Bare Testimony in a court hearing depicts a bureaucracy in which the processing of veterans' claims is marked by abuses.

title: Hitting The Heights at Jackson Hole
description: One thing about the start of a new ski season: It provides sharp perspective on the passage of time.

title: THEISMANN TESTS SIDELINES OF THE FRENZY BUT...
description: It has been said that the quarterback of the Redskins gets more attention than anyone in town, except possibly the President. The capital is obsessed with the art of winning and losing, in football as well as in politics.

title: APPEAL OF CUOMO IN SUBURBS NOTED
description: Governor Cuomo's popularity in New York State is anchored not only in traditionally Democratic New York City but in normally Republican suburbs - a combination that could be projected to national electoral success, according to a new book by two political scientists that draws upon four years of election and polling data.

title: Small Vermont Town Finally Finds a Doctor
description: This small town's search for a doctor has finally ended, with the promise of a Montana physician to come to Corinth next fall.

title: Knicks Activate Tucker
description: The Knicks activated Trent Tucker, their shooting guard, and placed Stewart Granger on the injured list today. Tucker had missed five games with a shoulder injury while Granger has a sore Achilles' tendon.

title: 2 on Hostage Mission Cite 'Israeli Terrorism'
description: Two American Moslem leaders seeking the release of Americans and other foreigners kidnapped in Lebanon urged President Reagan today to condemn ''Israeli terrorism'' against Arabs.

title: CHANGES SWEEPING ROSLYN VILLAGE
description: A NEW automobile agency and a shopping center will open in the next several months in Roslyn Village. Another shopping mall is planned, and office buildings and apartments may be in the offing.

title: NEW DELHI CURFEW FOLLOWS VIOLENCE
description: The Indian police and army troops were on patrol here today as a curfew was being enforced in neigborhoods around three Sikh temples, where there was violence on Friday.

title: Smith Will Fight
description: IT'S official: James (Bonecrusher) Smith will replace Tony Tubbs as the opponent for Tim Witherspoon, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, next Friday at Madison Square Garden. The Witherspoon-Smith fight is part of Home Box Office's heavyweight-unification series, and the winner is scheduled to fight Mike Tyson, the new World Boxing Council champion, in late February or early March. On Thursday, Tubbs withdrew, saying that doctors had advised him not to box or train for the next 5 to 10 weeks because of a shoulder injury.

title: YESHIVA U. TO OPEN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS IN FALL
description: Yeshiva University, responding to growing student interest in finance, marketing and economics, will open an undergraduate school of business next fall.

title: Don't Play Politics With Airline Safety
description: AIRLINE travel isn't what it used to be. As we all know, it is plagued by delays, missed connections and lost baggage. What is worse, reports of in-air collisions and near misses are being heard more frequently.

title: 3 Fast Tracks: The Trade-Offs
description: MONEY MATTERS MOST when you don't have it. No wonder, then, that so many aspiring corporate lawyers, management consultants and investment bankers are discussing their future salaries this winter with a nonchalance usually reserved for choosing a breakfast muffin. They've survived the fall recruiting season, and M.B.A.'s heading for any of the top investment-banking houses can look forward to a base salary of $50,000, plus another $50,000 in bonus their first year. Management consultants and lawyers will have to tough it out with salaries around $65,000, though consultants are likely to receive hefty bonuses as well. Yet for all the largess, the graduates insist that other factors govern their choice of employment.

title: UP IN THE AIR
description: RESIDENTS of North Salem and Lewisboro, two of Westchester's northernmost towns, may have to wait still longer before they can subscribe to cable television. But after almost four years of planning and negotiating, no one seems surprised.

title: CAMBRIDGE EYES RULES ON ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS
description: In a city whose residents in recent years have proposed bans on such things as genetic engineering research, pornography, smoking in restaurants, toxic-chemical tests and nuclear weapons research and work, another fight has erupted. This time it is over the use of animals in laboratory research.

title: A Guide To Holiday Shopping
description: AS A reflection of the increasing diversity of objects handcrafted in America, this year's holiday buyer may discover that one-stop craft shopping is a thing of the past.

title: Architecture
description: What does it say that so many of this year's architecture books deal with houses? That we are retreating once again into a concern with domesticity, with our own private worlds, at the expense of public places? Perhaps it is just that we realize that now as much as ever the private house is the great laboratory of architecture, the place where ideas are given their first, and sometimes their purest and most exhilarating, test.

title: PRETORIA SIGNALS NEW PRESS CURBS
description: An alliance of civil rights movements and activists, many of them whites, opened a campaign this week for the release of young blacks from detention.

title: Staying at Home With the Children
description: Relative to Susan Bonnici's reply [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, Nov. 16 ] to my letter on her Opinion Page article ''Summer With the Children - Not as Planned'': I was very happy to learn that she spent 16 years at home with them before going to work full time. She's a woman after my own heart. The bottom line is that that is exactly what this country needs - more mothers at home taking care of their young children. ANN WAITZ Cutchogue

title: IT'S THE FRAGRANCE THAT COUNTS
description: When our oldest greenhouse came into the family nearly a century ago, it was fully equipped with a resident jasmine. The previous owner, a shoemaker by trade, grew more showy flowering plants and ferns, but he knew that a garden, whether it was indoors or outdoors, is hardly worth keeping without fragrance.

title: Article 435786 -- No Title
description: A New Jersey company has been fined for failing to control a noxious weed growing on its Delaware property, Delaware officials said. State Secretary of Agriculture Bill Chandler said Monday that the Vineland Construction Company had been notified repeatedly of the presence of Johnson grass on five acres it owns near Seaford, Del., but had refused to respond. He said Vineland was fined $100 plus court costs at Magistrate Court in Seaford. Mr. Chandler says the charges were brought to emphasize the department's serious attitude toward the weed, which interferes with crops and under Delaware law must be controlled.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Height Limitations Touching Off Disputes
description: LONG ISLAND'S suburban landscape has been shaped by the two- and three-story height limitations imposed by many municipalities. But here and there, where zoning permits, taller structures have begun to make a noticeable imprint.

title: Eiko and Koma Slow Time Down
description: Often, as one watches the dances of Eiko and Koma, one cannot be sure if one is beholding creatures at the dawn of time or at the end of history. And as the strange beings created by these Japanese-born dancers and choreographers creep and fumble their way across the stage, time may seem to have stopped.

title: COPING WITH SEXUAL STATIC
description: I AM AFRAID TO INVITE FEMALE COL-leagues to lunch,'' says the 27-year-old manager of a high-tech company. ''I'm afraid they'll think I'm coming on to them.''

title: MASSACHUSETTS CHANGES ITS SEAT-BELT SIGNS, BUT THE MESSAGE STAYS THE SAME
description: For the past year motorists entering Massachusetts have been greeted by signs advising them, ''Take the Law to Heart - Massachusetts Requires the Use of Seatbelts.''

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION: TOPICS
description: WHEN it's the time of year I have to practice triage on my house plants, I must decide which plants to save and bring into the sun porch and which to abandon to the cold and leave outside. But I find it very difficult to make that decision.

title: Peru Ends Price Freeze To Help Spur Economy
description: Prime Minister Luis Alva Castro, detailing measures to prolong an economic boom next year, announced an end to a price freeze imposed in August 1985 and said it would be replaced by a series of controls.

title: TRADERS AND TAKEOVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Rufino Tamayo: The Sources Of His Art Directed by Gary Conklin. 1972. Mystic Fire Video. 28 minutes. $50. This video has modest ambitions, but achieves them admirably.

title: Pretoria Rejects Power-Sharing
description: Blacks and whites representing 35 groups in South Africa's Natal Province and the so-called black homeland of KwaZulu worked eight months to produce a proposal for regional power-sharing based on universal suffrage.

title: A Booming Market For Asian Art
description: Dealers in Asian art are increasing in number and becoming more visible in New York - opening new galleries and presenting specialty exhibitions. Last week, for example, a major gallery opened on 57th Street, a Madison Avenue dealer moved to larger quarters, two private dealers presented their first combined exhibition and several others initiated specialty shows.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FROM PLAINS INDIANS At least once a year, says its director, Madeleine Burnside, the Islip Art Museum mounts an exhibition that leaves the mainstream of Western civilization to explore other cultures. There have been shows about Africa, Mexico and Central America. This year, the cross-cultural interest doesn't go that far afield geographically, but instead looks back chronologically: to the late 19th century and the Great Plains of North America.

title: 'Powder Room': Two Plays, One Set
description: THE last few Broadway seasons have brought us ''Steambath,'' set in a London bathhouse, and ''Doubles,'' set in the locker room of a Connecticut tennis club. One reason playwrights choose such a setting is that the characters, in baring their bodies, find it easier to bare their souls.

title: BEST SELLER: DECEMBER 7,1986
description: Fiction

title: MEXICAN BORDER ARRESTS FALL IN WAKE OF NEW ALIENS LAW
description: Just one month after President Reagan signed the new immigration control law, arrests of illegal aliens along the Mexican border have dropped dramatically.

title: Town and County Get A $3 Million Surprise
description: This small town, rebuilding its economy after the loss of a major employer, has received a gift from a former resident who made good in the big city.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT BLACK
description: THE conductor Robert Black is an adept Modernist; this listener recently heard him conduct the American premiere of a violent and challenging 45-minute work by the late French composer Jean Barraque. As such, it was something of a surprise to find him conducting the New Amsterdam Symphony Orchestra in two of Tchaikovsky's most familiar war horses at the Symphony Space Friday night.

title: Chicago Politics: A Guessing Game
description: The official Republican nominee for Mayor is a Democrat who says he is bipartisan. The Mayor, who won as a Democrat three years ago, will run but may do so as an independent.

title: DATA UPDATE: DECEMBER 7, 1986

description: INNER-CITY students from Passaic, Morris and Sussex Counties will benefit from the record $350,000 raised by the Tri-County Scholarship Fund this year.

title: IMPROVING ON NATURE TO BE HOSPITABLE TO SUBURBAN WILDLIFE
description: EVERY winter morning, Alison Olivieri uses a shovel to break the ice over a small brook that runs alongside the backyard of her rural Fairfield home. The water that she frees draws deer in from the woods to drink, and entices mallard ducks to light and swim.

title: BROTHERS AT ODDS
description: IT WOULD BE THE LAST TIME THE WHOLE family was together - Christmas 1979. In the Tudor stone mansion across the street from the Wichita Country Club, Mary Koch and her four sons celebrated the holiday in the spacious living room, scattered with photographs of the brothers as carefree boys. A large oil portrait of the late patriarch of the clan, Fred C. Koch, looked down from one wall.

title: OPPOSITION PARTY STRONG IN TAIWAN VOTE
description: A new opposition party, the first allowed to compete in an election in Taiwan's modern history, showed unexpected strength in legislative elections Saturday, according to incomplete returns this morning.

title: Politics and Judges Shouldn't Mix
description: THE judicial election results and the campaign leading up to them highlighted as never before the need for a dramatic change in the process by which judges reach and remain on the bench.

title: Southern Yemen Cites Death Of 4,230 in January Fighting
description: The Government said today that 4,230 members of the ruling Marxist party were killed in 12 days of fighting last January, ending with the ouster of President Ali Nasser Mohammed.

title: Ivar Kreuger: Sweden's Match King
description: IVAR Kreuger, the Swedish match king, may have been the biggest thief of all time. Mr. Kreuger, a mechanical engineer from Kalmar, Sweden, was among the world's most powerful industrialists back in the 1920's, when he supplied 75 percent of the world's matches from factories in 34 countries.

title: Tarkenton's Gospel Of Good Management
description: Blazered, loafered, Rolexed and, at 46 years of age, in close-to-Super Bowl shape, Fran Tarkenton is delivering his gospel of good management to 80 or so executives of I. U. International, the transportation and diversified services company. On this September morn among the palmettos and loblollies at Hilton Head, S.C., the former quarterback for the Minnesota Vikings and New York Giants holds them in sway.

title: ON THE 14TH FLOOR, SIEGE ENDS IN QUIET TALK
description: At times, the police said, the man holed up in the apartment next door spoke very much like a ''frightened child,'' concerned solely with his personal safety. At other times, they said, he changed strategies, threatening violence and saying he had a gun and a hand grenade.

title: Israel's Ruling on Converts Eases Tension in U.S.
description: A ruling last week by the Israeli Supreme Court that barred officials from labeling converts to Judaism as converts on their Israeli identity papers removes a source of tension for Reform and Conservative leaders in the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday on Dory Vogel, the Long Island woman taking part in the America's Cup challenger trials, incorrectly reported the college from which she was graduated, and the headline incorrectly identified the yacht syndicate with which she is involved. She was trained at the New York State University of Maritime College at Fort Schuyler and she is a backup navigator for Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes.

title: CASINO ROLE IN PLANNING PROPOSED
description: A BILL designed to create a superagency to govern Atlantic City and other casino-affected municipalities is being revived after having died in an Assembly committee six years ago.

title: Miss Thompson Engaged To Marry John Hughes 3d
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Thompson to John Edward Hughes 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hughes Jr. of Madison, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Thompson Jr. of Hopewell, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clifton $160,900 10 Hugo Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, finished basement, patio, modern eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,471. Independence $156,000 24 Heather Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old contemporary; wood-burning stove in family room, deck, one acre; taxes $1,776.

title: 360 Queens Units
description: Stephen Shalom cruises Queens neighborhoods looking for garden apartments, particularly those with some architectural distinction that might respond well to a restoration.

title:
DINING OUT;
OLD MANSION WITH NEW POLISH
description: IF you haven't been to Tappan Hill for a few years, now might be the time for another visit. For the information of first timers, this old stone mansion, once a private home, gives the curious a peek into what must have been early 20th-century high life.

title: IN NEW HAVEN, INSIGHTS INTO THE VICTORIAN VIEW OF CHILDREN
description: THE Yale Center for British Art's current production is one of a series devoted to Victorian painting. And, like two of its more memorable predecessors, ''The Shadow and the Substance'' of 1982 and a show drawn from the Bancroft and McCormick collections of pre-Raphaelitism, it is the work of the center's assistant curator of paintings, Susan P. Casteras.

title: BOBBY SHORT: KEYS TO A LYRICAL LIFE
description: In a description as understated as his superbly tailored dinner jackets, Bobby Short refers to himself as a ''saloon piano player.'' This fall, this saloon piano player is celebrating 50 years as a professional performer and 20 years at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Betsy Donovan to Wed
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Anne Donovan to Edward A. Nolan Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan of Wantagh, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Collins Donovan of Bronxville, N.Y. Ms. Donovan, known as Betsy, and her fiance plan to be married March 7.

title: SHORT OF STAFF, AMBULANCES CUT SERVICES
description: RISING costs and a shortage of volunteers are sharply curtailing the activities of a traditional form of community service - the volunteer ambulance corps.

title: WOMAN'S WORK?
description: A couple recently arrived at Newark Airport after a long flight with a 6-week-old baby in desperate need of a diaper change. The task fell to the husband, who followed the signs in the airport to the nursery.

title: ATOMIC ARMS OFFICIAL IS RETIRING IN MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union has announced the retirement of Yefim P. Slavsky, an 88-year-old Cabinet minister in charge of the nuclear weapons program.

title: DISPUTE ON LILCO RATE REQUEST
description: THE longstanding dispute between the Long Island Lighting Company and New York State over electricity rates erupted again last week, this time over the extent of an increase the utility is requesting and whether it plans to pay dividends to its stockholders.

title: Staying With NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Roads To the Title
description: Both the Giants (11-2) and the Redskins (11-2) have clinched at least a wild-card berth in the playoffs, and one of them is assured of winning the National Conference East Division. But neither can clinch the division with a victory today.

title: CORNERED IN MANHUNT, DAVIS SURRENDERS IN BRONX
description: Larry Davis, the fugitive accused of shooting six police officers and murdering five drug dealers, surrendered peacefully at a Bronx housing project early yesterday after a tense, all-night siege in which a woman and her two young children were held hostage.

title: EXPANDED YULE CONCERT SEASON OFFERS A VARIETY OF PROGRAMS
description: EVER since the Halloween pumpkins began to wilt, Connecticut's sackbut and recorder players, handbell ringers, organists and choirs have been rehearsing their Christmas carols and oratorios. The early start was necessary to meet the demand for more holiday music programs.

title: From the 19th Century
description: On Nov. 22, the United States Postal Service released a new stamp. With little advance notice, the 25-cent bread wagon stamp was issued in Virginia Beach, Va. It is the latest addition to the Transportation Coil series.

title: Case of Mrs. L: She Gave Once, and Now Is Helped
description: Emma L. smiles nostalgically when she recalls the suburban home she once shared with her husband and children. Framed by a manicured lawn and filled with the sounds of familial activity, the home she described seemed the picture of domestic bliss.

title: REAGAN DOOMS HIS FOREIGN POLICY
description: For six years, Ronald Reagan has, in my opinion, performed the duties of his office with a larger measure of greatness than any predecessor in decades. But by stubbornly insisting that his covert arms deals with Iran were ''no mistake,'' he is dooming the remainder of his Presidency.

title: M.I.T. Honors Astronaut
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology dedicated its space studies building Friday to Ronald E. McNair, one of seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded in January. The six-story concrete building near the center of the campus houses 100,000 square feet of classrooms, laboratories and offices dedicated to ''reaching, exploring, understanding and operating in space,'' Paul Gray, the school's president, said.

title: DANCE: AN AILEY PROGRAM 'IN THE BLACK TRADITION'
description: THE performances of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater often serve as reminders of how broad this company's repertory is. Yet, on occasion the company can deliberately - and eloquently - narrow its repertory. Among such occasions are the programs listed as being ''In the Black Tradition.''

title: The Eternal Question: What to Do on Sunday
description: OLD habits die hard. As a child, I always found Sunday the worst day of the week. Sunday was the day when there wasn't anything to do. You just hung around. The big event was the drive from one end of Brooklyn to the other to visit aunts and uncles and grandparents. The trouble was, nobody talked to you; the adults talked to one another about other relatives you scarcely knew.

title: SHORTAGE OF SOCIAL WORKERS?
description: HEALTH-CARE providers have expressed concern that local universities soon may not be graduating enough trained professionals in the social service field to serve Long Island's increasing needs.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $237,500 Dogwood Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 26-year-old frame/ brick ranch; eat-in kitchen, pool, deck, walk to school; taxes $2,926. Peekskill, N.Y. $250,000 Mountainside Trail 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 8-year-old frame/brick contemporary; eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car attached garage, cul-de-sac; taxes $4,253.

title: DOS AND DON'TS FOR STOCKING STUFFERS
description: SOMEWHERE back in the early days of their parenthood, my oldest daughter and her husband, with a total lack of concern for their parental responsibilities, cast me, a brand-new grandmother, in the role of surrogate Santa Claus. They felt it entirely logical that I, as the expert on family tradition and custom, should assume the duties of Jolly Old Whosis on Christmas Eve.

title: IMPACT OF BARBIE TRIAL ON STUDENTS STRESSED
description: TEACHERS and school officials involved in Holocaust studies say they see the trial of the alleged Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie - expected to begin early next year - as an opportunity to give students further insights into what happened in Europe during the Nazi regime.

title: Not Yet Total Mania
description: The fate of Washington will be hanging in the balance for at least three hours this afternoon, but some of the transient power-brokers who run the Government may not be aware of that. While the Redskins and Giants throw the football and each other around Robert F. Kennedy Stadium before frenzied thousands, a number of the nation's political leaders will probably not be swept up in the excitement.

title: Farrell Wins Metro Bowl
description: Monsignor Farrell, the Catholic High School Football League champion, won the Metro Bowl's A Division game, as well as the battle of Staten Island, with a 34-8 victory over Susan Wagner yesterday at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title: Iceland
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Katha Pollitt for giving your readers some of the feel of ''Iceland's Bleak Beauty'' (Travel, Oct. 19).

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Tar Heels Make Their Points
description: Dean Smith, the North Carolina coach, has been pointing to his team's loss at U.C.L.A. five days ago as evidence that the Tar Heels did not deserve their early top ranking in the polls. But after a 122-77 victory over Miami today, including a school-record 72 points in the first half, even Smith had to concede some satisfaction with his squad.

title: Berlin 1900-1933: Capital Of Pragmatism and Fantasy
description: ''Berlin 1900-1933: Architecture and Design'' is not a title that in itself would fill Madison Square Garden. In all that pertains to popular acclaim and addictive fantasy, the once-great city of Berlin has lately lagged far behind Vienna. For every hundred people who went to ''Vienna 1900'' at the Museum of Modern Art and came away thinking of themselves as Viennese by adoption, hardly a one feels the same way about Berlin at any time in its 749 years of existence.

title: An Original Foursome
description: Those who make a record of an interesting deal in order to send it to a bridge columnist sometimes have to wait for an answer. The record wait certainly belongs to the diagramed deal, played in England, although no blame attaches to the British Post Office, the United States Post Office or this department.

title: F.A.A. ORDERS REVIEW OF PILOTS' MEDICAL APPEALS
description: Donald D. Engen, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, has ordered a special review of the way the agency approves medical appeals by commercial pilots. He took the action amid complaints that some pilots who are unfit to fly are recertified anyway.

title: 'CAMILLE' GETS A MODERN RETELLING
description: SHE was called the most fascinating and alluring woman in Paris, circa 1840. In life, she changed her real name, Alphonsine Plessis, to a classier one, Marie Duplessis, and amassed aristrocratic admirers for pleasure and profit. But she became better known on the page and on the stage as Marguerite Gautier (in Alexandre Dumas's novel and subsequent play, ''La Dame aux Camellias''), in the opera world as Violetta Valery (in Verdi's ''Traviata''), and in the movies as, simply, ''Camille.''

title: A TIMES POLL OF M.B.A.'S
description: THERE IS AN UNEASI-ness among key American business leaders. While they are not exactly scared to death, they are deeply troubled by foreign competition: many are concerned that the American century is over and that some other nation either has, or will soon take, the leading economic role in the world.

title: Q AND A
description: French Visas Question:I plan to travel by rail from Luxembourg to Zurich, Switzerland, via Strasbourg, France, with no change of train. Will I need a visa to pass through France? - O. D. S., Richmond, Va. Answer:Yes. Like other Americans, who need a French visa to enter France, passengers aboard trains that pass through the country must also hold one. On the journey to Strasbourg, a French official gets on the train near the Luxembourg border and asks to see passengers' passports and visas. Since Oct. 1, the French Government has required foreign visitors - except citizens of the Common Market countries and Switzerland - to apply for visas. For someone in Virginia, the nearest place to obtain one is the French Consulate, 4101 Reservoir Road N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007 (202-944-6000).

title: Aquino Drops Cabinet Member To Please Military
description: When Corazon C. Aquino ran for President of the Philippines a year ago, President Ferdinand E. Marcos advised her that a woman's place was in the bedroom. Last week, Mrs. Aquino took a moment from affairs of state - shaking up her Cabinet and consolidating support in the military - to return the slight.

title: HAUPPAUGE TRAFFIC STUDIED
description: IN an effort to combat traffic congestion in the Hauppauge area, state, county and town officials are working on projects recommended by a committee set up to study the problem.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline on Nov. 23 about the wedding of Elizabeth Louise Williams misidentified the bridegroom. He is Gregg Joseph Borri.

title: ARTS GROUP TO FIGHT REJECTION OF SCULPTURE
description: THE whole process was supposed to be routine: the arts organization would submit materials describing the sculpture it planned to install temporarily on city property and the New Rochelle City Council would expand its liability insurance to cover the art work.

title: Newsman Tells of leak From Khomeini's Heir
description: The journalist who first reported the American arms sales to Iran says the deal was disclosed by the office of Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, the designated heir to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: World's Four Corners Offer Food Treats Foods of All Nations is just south of Lord & Taylor on White Plains Post Road in Eastchester, with a Scarsdale mailing address. The shelves hold the elements of survival packages for college crammers and corporate gifts and thoughtful morsels for specialized palates of all ages. Health considerations can be accommodated with salt-free mustard or crackers, sugarless preserves, decaffeinated teas, fresh-ground coffee or beans and Cafix, a natural cereal beverage.

title: SPECTACULAR AND SIMPLE
description: Museum Milestones Dec. 8 - The Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is celebrating its 50th anniversary and its 15th annual costume exhibition organized by Diana Vreeland with a party in the museum. The black-tie benefit will begin with cocktails at 7:30 P.M., after which there will be dinner and dancing to the music of Peter Duchin in the Temple of Dendur as well as to Dixieland in the Charles Engelhard Court. Tickets, $750, or $125 for the dance alone, from 212-572-3956. Saving the Children Dec. 8 - They are the lost children of the poorer sections of New York City, the abused and emotionally disturbed who can find no school to tolerate their violence or home to care for them. About 100 of them a year, some as young as two years old, find refuge in the city's Blueberry Treatment Centers. The annual benefit will begin with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. preceding a black-tie dinner-dance at Doubles in the Sherry Netherland. Tickets, $250, from 212-355-6363. East Hampton Benefit Dec. 8 - Three notable residents of the east end of Long Island, E. L. Doctorow, Sidney Lumet and Saul Steinberg, will be honored at a benefit for Guild Hall, the museum and theater in East Hampton. The black-tie evening starts with 7:30 P.M. cocktails in the Delegates' Dining Room of the United Nations. Dinner is afterward. A Champagne-bearing bus will provide round-trip transportation, leaving East Hampton at 5 P.M. Tickets, $200, from 516-324-0807.

title: Today's Sports
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Trail Blazers At Portland, Ore. Television MSG, 10 P.M. Radio WPAT 930, 9:50 P.M. Football Giants vs.

title: Stimulus To Serve Gaining
description: SERVING as a co-op or condominium board member is increasingly considered a risky and burdensome chore by potential candidates. Thus it is no wonder that there is new momentum for the idea -aired in the past in jest - that officers be compensated for their time and trouble.

title: GOGOL'S SOUL RAIDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Exasperating Airline Delays
description: ''A few weeks ago I had to fly to Miami,'' Ray Kane said the other day.

title: U.S. RULED OWNER OF IMPERILED LAKE
description: A court ruling that the Federal Government, not the State of California, owns thousands of acres of land uncovered by the receding waters of Mono Lake has been applauded by environmentalists.

title: Radio Address by Reagan From Camp David
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's radio address today from the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., as recorded by The Associated Press: I'm speaking to you today from Camp David. And because the atmosphere here is a bit more informal than every day in Washington, I thought it would be a good opportunity to think and reflect with you about those crucial foreign policy matters in the news lately.

title: How Amenities Run Up the Tab
description: ''I don't want people to buy the house and then discover there are a million extras they have to pay for,'' asserts Calvin Danzig, a Long Island developer. Indeed, the 93 town houses in the Hunt Club in Jericho, his most recent undertaking, will come with nearly every amenity imaginable, from a central vacuuming system to electronic garage doors.

title: New Toques Held High
description: IT IS THAT TIME OF YEAR when critics of all stripes and persuasions are asked to polish off their divining rods and prophesy about what the public can expect by way of new tastes and vogues within the next 12 months. To gaze into the future, it is, to my mind, best to take inventory of where we are at now.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last week on special holiday events, an item on Ocean Grove was in error.

title: LOW INCREASES IN L.I. PAY SURPRISE THE EXPERTS
description: PAY increases for Long Island's 15,000 clerical and electronic data-processing workers in 1986 were the lowest in the 11 years that the data have been available, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: A SELF-TAUGHT SCULPTOR
description: Seymour Lipton, a self-taught sculptor who used metal innovatively, died Friday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., where he had been undergoing treatment for bone cancer. He was 83 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I. He also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Ann Marie Smith Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Smith of Old Forge, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Marie Smith to Dr. Richard J. Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Friedland of Hewlett, L.I. Miss Smith is an intensive-care nurse at the Hospital of the Medical College of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, at which her fiance is a senior medical resident. She graduated from Pennsylvania State University. He graduated cum laude from Union College and is an alumnus of the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center.

title: READING PROGRAM IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: THE meeting was over and an exuberant group of children rushed to a table. Were there doughnuts on the table? Sodas? Free music tapes? No, there were books, and this cluster of fifth and sixth graders could not wait to get their hands on them.

title: Jason Fish Marries Courtney Benoist
description: Genevieve Grace Courtney Benoist, a daughter of Courtney M. Benoist of Kentfield, Calif., and Joseph Grace Benoist of Palm Springs, Calif., was married last night at Old St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco to Jason Marshall Fish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Fish of Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Walter Anthony of Old St. Mary's and Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THERE will be an all-star cast tomorrow night when Guild Hall, the East Hampton arts showcase, presents its second annual Lifetime Achievement in the Arts Award to three notables who have homes on the East End: the novelist E. L. Doctorow, the film director Sidney Lumet and the artist Saul Steinberg.

title: MARRIAGE HAS A LANGUAGE ALL ITS OWN
description: SOME things you can learn in high school or in college, other things you just can't.

title: James Woods: More Than A Villain
description: In 15 years of working in television and films, James Woods has specialized in portraying eccentric, troubled, obsessed and sometimes sinister characters. Among the more memorable have been the embittered Jewish artist in the NBC mini-series ''Holocaust'' and, in feature films, the remorseless murderer in ''The Onion Field,'' the crafty gangster in ''Once Upon a Time in America'' and the sleazy, opportunistic journalist in ''Salvador.'' Without resorting to sentimentality, he has managed to uncover the humanity and the weaselly charm of these ''off center'' characters, as the 39-year-old actor calls them.

title: No Headline
description: Donna Elizabeth de Varona, a sports commentator for ABC-TV, and John H. Pinto Jr., a managing director of the Boston International Group Securities Corporation, plan to be married Jan. 10. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. de Varona of Santa Clara, Calif., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mrs. Pinto of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Pinto.

title: MANHATTANVILLE DANCE CELEBRATES 10th
description: THE Manhattanville College department of dance this year celebrates its 10th anniversary. Depending on one's perspective, it is somewhat surprising that a former Catholic womens' college has a modern dance department, or it makes great sense, given the school's long tradition in the arts, especially music.

title: REAGAN'S BEST SHOT?
description: Forget those ''sweeping potential agreements'' - such as the elimination of all nuclear weapons, or was it only strategic nuclear missiles? - that the Reagan Administration insisted were still ''on the table'' after the breakdown of the Iceland summit.

title: IVAN BOESKY OWES ME $57
description: Here's the way I figure it. Ivan Boesky owes me $57 and it's going to cost me a trip to Hawaii.

title:
FOCUS: Downzoning;
Slowing The Pace Of Growth
description: THIS resort city's population has surged from 110,000 to more than 319,000 in just 20 years, making it the largest city in the state, with 36,000 more people than Norfolk. And 100,000 more people are expected here by the year 2000.

title: Track Stars Honored
description: TWO track stars who staged convincing comebacks afer a year's layoff and one who broke ground in the women's heptathlon received the major awards from The Athletics Congress at its annual meeting Friday and yesterday in Tampa, Fla.: Edwin Moses, the hurdler who extended his nine-year unbeaten streak to 118 by winning nine races this year, and Evelyn Ashford, who turned in the world's fastest time in the women's 100-meter dash and won the event at both the Goodwill Games in Moscow and the U.S. Olympic Festival in Houston.

title: ...PISARCIK HAUNTS THE GIANTS FANS
description: Scratch a Giants fan here at Manny's Restaurant, a few miles from Giants Stadium, and you'll hear brave talk about this year's team going where none has gone before: the Super Bowl.

title: Rematch Is Sought
description: THE manager of John (the Beast) Mugabi said yesterday in Las Vegas that he would ask the World Boxing Council to grant his fighter a rematch against Duane Thomas. Mickey Duff contended that Mugabi was thumbed in the eye Friday night when Thomas won the vacated W.B.C. super welterweight title by stopping Mugabi in the third round of a scheduled 12-round bout.

title: The New Fuller Figure
description: PAULINA PORIZKOVA is 36-23-35. She is also beautiful. It is no surprise, therefore, that she is currently considered America's No. 1 model for bathing suits. Her image in a suit on the cover of a magazine has been said to contribute significantly to moving that issue off the nation's newsstands. What is surprising is that Paulina is also a ''10'' when it comes to high fashion. In the 1960's, a young, stick-thin waiflike but charming English model named Twiggy summed up high style. Since then, models in general have had almost anorexic proportions - the fewer bulges, the better to display soignee fashion. But now that curves count, Paulina - with her generous bosom, small waist and curving hips - constitutes a stunning example of the current ideal.

title: Fomon Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN LEADERS VOICE CONCERN THAT IRAN AFFAIR IMPAIRS ALLIANCE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed concern today over President Reagan's problems with the Iran arms affair, saying, ''Anything that weakens America weakens Europe, indeed weakens the whole of the free world.''

title: STONY BROOK FACES HURDLES IN GETTING HEART TRANSPLANT UNIT
description: THE State University of New York at Stony Brook is facing a number of hurdles in its attempt to establish the state's second heart transplant center.

title: CONSENSUS ON THE THREAT TO THE OZONE
description: THE depletion of atmospheric ozone by man-made chemicals is what William D. Ruckelshaus, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, once called a ''megaproblem.'' As with acid rain, deforestation and climatic changes, confronting such a vast and complex phenomenon would require planetary cooperation, something that so far has proved elusive.

title: The Uses of Television And the Pitfalls of Politics
description: The Better World Society, organized by Ted Turner, has high and significant aims: to make ''people aware of global problems that threaten life on our planet'' and ''to build a global constituency'' for dealing with the problems. The society uses television as its instrument; it ''produces and acquires solutions-oriented programming for international distribution.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is my great hope that things will soon return to normal in the United States.'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher

title: No Headline
description: Announcement has been made by Joel Marie Blumenthal of Larchmont, N.Y., of the engagament of her daughter Ann Marie Blumenthal to Scott Phillip Heineman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas A. Heineman of Stamford, Conn., and Block Island, R.I. A July 4 wedding is planned.

title: 6 'NUTCRACKERS' FOR EYE AND EAR
description: ''LIFE'S not over at 35,'' Denise Jackson said. ''But when you hit your mid-30's, the body simply isn't the same instrument it was at 20. People used to tell me that like some others I'd be dancing till I'm 60. But you know, you couldn't pay me enough to crawl up on these toes at 55.''

title: MORE EMPLOYERS OFFERING CHILD CARE BENEFITS
description: American corporations, which are facing drastic changes in the work force, have increased the number of child care programs they sponsor or pay for from 110 in 1978 to 2,500 in 1985, according to a study made public today.

title: Egypt Frees More Policemen Accused in February Rioting
description: Egypt's Supreme State Security Court today ordered the release without bail of 161 police conscripts pending their trial on charges of rioting last February, inciting unrest and damaging property.

title: PIANO: WILLIAM DOPPMANN
description: WILLIAM DOPPMANN'S piano recital Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall was one of the season's most distinctive. Mr. Doppmann is also a composer, and he plays like one - re-creating whatever music he chooses to play, with freshness and originality. A purist might suggest that his approach is rather too personal: Mr. Doppmann played a set of etudes by Debussy, Scriabin and Stravinsky without a pause, and he made these three diverse composers sound like one and the same.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: RHODE ISLAND HOLIDAY, 1904

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Natural Resources Defense Council has announced its intention to sue both the state's Department of Environmental Protection and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for their failure to meet the Federal ozone standard in New Jersey.

title: Cortes Randell: Student Market Hoax
description: IN 1965 an ambitious young entrepreneur named Cortes W. Randell founded the National Student Marketing Corporation.

title: COLLEGE TEACHERS RANK 85 COUNTRIES
description: Two Syracuse University professors are the editors of a monthly newsletter that tries to forecast the political stability of 85 countries.

title: Melanie W. Hardy to Wed Paul R. Hardin on Feb. 14
description: Melanie Wilson Hardy, an interior designer at Travis Interiors in Atlanta, and Paul Russell Hardin, an associate in the Atlanta law firm of King & Spaulding, plan to be married Feb. 14.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article in Sports People Nov. 16 misidentified the posted winner of a disputed race at Saratoga race course. Festivity, who finished second behind Allumeuse, was posted as the winner after Allumeuse was disqualified for a foul.

title: IN THE HEART OF AFRICA
description: THE ROAD TO Nsukka in eastern Nigeria is rutted and crumpled, the aging asphalt torn like a ragged strip of tar paper.

title: Youth Becomes Guardian Of Younger Brothers
description: A judge has allowed a 19-year-old to keep a promise made to his mother to become his brothers' keeper.

title: PUTTING A CAREER ON HOLD
description: IN THE FAMILY room of her stone and shingle house in Darien, Conn., Carol Guthrie is hostess to her weekly mothers group. On the carpeted floor of the sunlit room, three babies have staked out their territory on brightly colored quilts, surrounded by plastic rattles and stuffed animals. Mary Lou Parker and Anne Finan, the two other mothers in the group, frequently interrupt their conversations to retrieve a wayward toy or calm a fussy child.

title: Virginia Byrne, Teacher, Weds D. M. Marzonie
