description: Virginia Marie Byrne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Byrne 3d of Florham Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Michael Marzonie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Marzonie of Northville, Mich. Msgr. Francis Lo Bianco performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: INDIAN BUS CRASH KILLS 16
description: A bus and a truck collided nead Madras today, killing 16 people and injuring 20 the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said the accident occurred near the town of Chengalpattu.

title: Again, U.S. Backs A Plan for School Vouchers
description: For the third time, the Reagan Administration is floating the idea of educational vouchers. The plan, which the Education Department has written into its proposed legislation extending federally financed remedial services, would allow parents to send a child to another school if their home district's remedial services were, by as-yet-undetermined criteria, inadequate.

title: WARREN ANDERSON SAYS THERE'S A CRISIS COMING IN ALBANY
description: WHEN Warren M. Anderson was first elected majority leader of the State Senate, he recalled last week, ''I looked up on the wall at the pictures of all the other fellows who had done it and thought, 'Gee, I'd like to stay long enough so somebody doesn't say that he only served once and then they threw him out.' ''

title: UNSTABLE NEIGHBOR
description: MEXICO Chaos on Our Doorstep. By Sol W. Sanders. 222 pp. Lanham, Md.: Madison Books. $18.95.

title: In Praise of Teachers
description: In 1985, after 17 years as a primary-school teacher, I received an invitation to the wedding of a former third-grade student. At the reception, the bride's mother told me that, when making out the guest list, she and her daughter had tried to include people who had been important in her daughter's life.

title: Next Week; Is There Collusion On Free Agents?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools
description: THERE is a storm brewing over the Five Towns schools, a storm that may blow over other school districts on Long Island that face a similar situation.

title: THE SAGA OF A HOTEL: WILL IT BE BUILT?
description: EIGHT or 10 architects, facing the loss of a city contract, were working around the clock last week to design a pared-down version of a luxury hotel for White Plains, according to Jack Parker, president of Parker Meridian Hotels.

title: About Cars; Two Books to Delight Devotees
description: CAR nuts are notoriously gadget-oriented. We like things with knobs, levers, dials. Things with innards. But the two gifts that ought to be at the top of any fanatic's holiday wish list have only their pages as moving parts.

title: CREATING HANDICAPS
description: THE MAGIC FEATHER The Truth About ''Special Education.'' By Lori Granger and Bill Granger. 259 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: Protest Accuses Sandinistas Of Raiding a Honduran Post
description: The Honduran Government has protested what it said was an attack by Nicaraguan soldiers on a Honduran Army outpost.

title: GETTING TO KNOW YOU
description: Gerard R. Roche, chairman of Heidrick and Struggles, the executive search firm, will go to any lengths to drive home a point. On the lecture circuit this year, he has been provoking strategic laughter with the following anecdote:

title: Howard Activated; Burt on Roster
description: Jim Burt, ailing back and all, remained on the Giants' roster today for Sunday's big game against the Redskins.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND REACTOR TO BE STORED
description: The damaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island will be put in storage indefinitely after a $1 billion cleanup is completed, but an eventual restart is not out of the question, officials say.

title: FOURTH $1 BILLION MONTH
description: New York savings institutions in October closed more than $1 billion in mortgage loans, marking the fourth month this year in which home lending exceeded $1 billion, according to the latest figures from the New York League of Savings Institutions.

title: The Undergraduate Colleges: Disappointment All Around
description: AMERICA'S undergraduate colleges are, it seems, bigger and worse than ever - ''ready for renewal,'' the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching said, hopefully, in a recent report. Most complaints fasten on soaring costs, declining literacy, sclerotic faculties and failures of administration. But more elusive problems - a loss of common scholarship, a declining appreciation of liberal education, a surge of professional preoccupations - dominated the discussion last week at a forum on undergraduate education sponsored by The New York Times. Excerpts follow. A NARROWING OF VISION

title: A DRUG PROGRAM FOCUSES ON TALK
description: Cookie, a sophomore at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan, found out about Spark after an overdose of mescaline put her in a hospital for a month.

title: 'Reckless Disregard'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Not-So-Ritual Trial by Fire
description: IT was one of those weeks when one feels like pounding walls with bare fists or throwing plates through windows. First, my daughter Tanya had been whisked away by helicopter to a distant hospital following a car crash (she is fine now). Then the boiler in the office blew up, showering all the computers and software in my study with a fine layer of soot of which the Cabots would have been proud, not to mention leaving the premises heatless for the holidays.

title: Gift Books
description: NOAH'S ARK. By Rien Poortvliet. 240 pp. (Abrams, $37.50.) However you read the story of Noah and the ark - as fact or as fable - you should take delight in this gallery of dignified and playful animal portraits. Best known in this country for his illustrated books on gnomes, the Dutch artist Rien Poortvliet here turns his eye to the less fanciful, if no less amazing, creatures that share the planet with us. Owls and elephants, warthogs and ladybugs, cows and crocodiles, the beasts rub shoulders on these pages as they might have rubbed shoulders in the ark. The inwardness of creation stares back at us from their eyes. Their colors are autumnal - russet of fox and gold of lion - but the spirit of the book is springlike, celebrating the inventiveness of nature. Mr. Poortvliet muses on Noah, to be sure, yet in his images and brief accompanying notes he is more deeply captivated by Noah's passengers. ''I cannot imagine life without animals,'' he writes. The effect of ''Noah's Ark'' is to make it harder for us, as well, to imagine life without animals. Knowing how many species have vanished during our reign and how many are endangered, one comes away from this tender and spirited book feeling that Earth itself is now the ark, and that we two-legged beings are both creators of the flood and custodians of the flock. SCOTT RUSSELL SANDERS

title: STELLA ELUCIDATES ABSTRACT ART'S LINK TO REALISM
description: IN a six-lecture series at Harvard University in the fall of 1983, the artist Frank Stella posed a paradox. Abstract painting today, he said, is in crisis, having grown obsessed with narrow concerns and in danger of losing its vitality and interest forever.

title: CITY'S TAXI AGENCY BLOCKS A JOB ACTION PLANNED BY DRIVERS
description: New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday obtsained a temporary restraining order blocking a job action by a coalition of taxi drivers and owners planned for tomorrow. A leader of the coalition said his group would comply with the order, adding, ''We move within the law.''

title: In Today's Issue: The Business World
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is The Business World, including these special reports:

title: SERIES BY PIANISTS
description: DAVID DUBAL, music director of Station WNCN-FM in New York and the author of ''Reflections From the Keyboard,'' will open the new Pianists Series this afternoon at Fairleigh Dickinson University's Lenfell Hall.

title: Tina Patterson Plans to Wed
description: Edward Patterson of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter Maria Christina Patterson to Patrick Michael Fay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Fay of Joliet, Ill. An April wedding is planned.

title: Klecko's Return Gives Jets Emotional Lift
description: The huddle will be livelier and the trenches noisier when the Jets' defense trots onto the Candlestick Park grass Sunday to face the 49ers. For Joe Klecko is back. ''Anytime you bring back someone of Joe's stature, his leadership, his enthusiasm, will rub off,'' says Marty Lyons. ''He takes control of the whole huddle.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THEY hunt the deer this week.

title: Christie's Offers Letter By Einstein to Roosevelt
description: A version of a letter written by Albert Einstein on Aug. 2, 1939, to President Roosevelt, urging him to coordinate research on nuclear energy, will be auctioned at Christie's Dec. 19.

title: 2 FRENCH RIGHTISTS BARRED BY SWISS
description: Two Frenchmen who have questioned the Holocaust and the existence of Nazi death camp gas chambers in World War II have been barred from Switzerland for three years after they held an illegal news conference here last month.

title: HOMELESS GROUP PRESSES BOSTON FOR BUILDING
description: When Susan Tracy showed a six-unit building on Fuller Street to a group of men this week, it was not the usual real estate tour.

title: SELF-HELP AT A SHELTER
description: In past years, the mothers at the Brooklyn Arms Hotel say, they looked on helplessly as the squalor and crime overwhelmed the homeless families there.

title: Cuba Says Severe Drought Calls for Conserving of Water
description: The Communist Party newspaper Granma said Friday that Cuba was in the midst of its worst drought in 27 years.

title: We Are All Less Than Perfect
description: Re: ''When Society Is the Handicap,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 16:

title: BIG ISSUES EVADED IN COMMON MARKET
description: Western European leaders acknowledged at a meeting here this weekend that the 12-nation European Community was on the brink of bankruptcy and facing conflicts with the United States and other trading partners over food trade.

title: A Bit of Flair, Little Foxes
description: THE man-tailored suits and coats so popular this fall are nothing if not chic, but they could use a little something extra in the way of flair. As if on cue, along comes the fox collar, an accessory that can make a dramatic gesture with the best of them.

title: TESTING PLAN INDICATES REAGAN'S 'OUTRAGE' OVER DRUG ABUSE
description: THE Reagan Administration is forging ahead with its plan for random drug tests of Federal employees even as another judge ruled it unconstitutional for the Government to test people who were not suspected of using drugs.

title: Headliners; Departure Announced
description: Larry Speakes spoke for himself last week, saying, essentially, ''I quit.'' Mr. Speakes, the longest-serving Presidential spokesman in a generation, announced that in keeping with plans begun long before and unrelated to the White House crisis over arms sales to Iran, he would be leaving Washington for Wall Street come February. His utterances there will be on behalf of Merrill Lynch & Company as senior vice president for communications at a salary reported to be around $250,000 a year.

title: SEVERAL NATIONS REPORTEDLY AIDED U.S. EFFORT ON HOSTAGES
description: The United States has used several friendly countries to solicit Iran's help in gaining the release of American hostages held in Lebanon, according to Administration, Iranian and diplomatic sources.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: RECITAL IN MONTCLAIR The pianist Murray Perahia will play Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin at Montclair High School Friday evening. In reviewing a Perahia concert at Avery Fisher Hall in New York, Tim Page wrote in The New York Times:

title: SEVILLE, IN HARD TIMES, SEES HOPE IN '92 FAIR
description: This sensuous city in the heart of Andalusia that is the mythical home of Don Juan, Carmen and Figaro is reaching into its past to leap into the future.

title: Rangefinder vs. Single-Lens-Reflex
description: MARK McHARRY, a West Coast reader of this column, has asked me to discuss the practical differences between rangefinder cameras and single-lens-reflex cameras. Mr. McHarry now owns an older-model Nikon FTn (essentially a Nikon F with a through-the-lens meter in the finder), which he is thinking of trading for a Leica M6, Leitz's latest and most sophisticated version of its classic M series. The Nikon is an SLR system; the Leica is a rangefinder.

title: BRONX, AS USUAL, UNRUFFLED BY SCANDAL
description: IN an era when politicians move on and off stage at frequent intervals, Assemblyman George Friedman stepped into a crisis situation when he was elected Bronx Democratic leader last week. But he also continued an amazingly stable line.

title: THE MATING GAME FOR '88
description: IN THE DARK OF AN EARLY AUGUST MORN-ing, Duane B. Garrett, a wealthy San Francisco art merchant, steered his 34-foot Sea Ray, the Laura, underneath the Golden Gate Bridge and made way four or five miles into the open ocean. His passengers were Bruce E. Babbitt, the Governor of Arizona; Babbitt's 10-year-old son, Christopher, and Ronald Lopez, one of the Governor's top aides. Garrett, who loves to fish, was happy, and the boy was excited, but the Governor and his man were distracted. On this particular morning in 1985, they were fishing for more than fish.

title: Advice for Detroit's Humbled Giant
description: The case study method of teaching business requires students to study a corporation and suggest ways to solve its problems. This article takes the same approach, but with a twist: The subject is General Motors, and the ''students'' are auto analysts, dealers, consumer activists and former industry insiders with ideas on how the troubled carmaker can regain its luster.

title: 200 Notable Books of The Year
description: are the subjects of this novel in which the author's ''prose is so easygoing, so companionable, that he appears to accomplish this act of literary ventriloquism without moving his lips.'' PERFUME: The Story of a Murderer. By Patrick Suskind. Translated by John E. Woods. (Knopf, $16.95.) ''As a disquisition on sensibility and as an instrument of historical analysis,'' this first novel, set in 18th-century France, ''is both well conceived and carefully sustained.'' THE PIANOPLAYERS. By Anthony Burgess. (Arbor House, $16.95.) The author's 29th novel ''comes equipped with overtones of parable and hints of autobiographical significance.''

title: Stowe
description: The big news in Stowe this year is the addition of a high-speed chairlift, seating four abreast and put in at a cost of $1.4 million. As a result, the sometimes windy and bitterly cold ride up Mount Mansfield, at 4,393 feet the state's highest mountain, has been cut just about in half, to seven minutes. The lift should also cut waiting time in half: to under 20 minutes.

title: AFTER ISRAELI'S VISIT, DEBATE IN ASIA CONTINUES
description: Nearly three weeks after President Chaim Herzog of Israel ended a visit to Southeast Asia and the Pacific, a heated political and diplomatic debate is still going on over charges of ''Zionist influence'' in the region.

title: Dealing With Drunk Drivers
description: As a physician who has seen senseless loss of life and as a mother who fears for her child's safety, I was moved by Mr. Clymer's article.

title: McGuire-Based Unit Picks Up Patients For Flights to States
description: ''LET'S make sure that we know exactly what we're up against here,'' said First Lieut. Lisa Marie Loeser of Port Republic, as a group of 32 uniformed medical technicians and nurses settled down to a briefing at McGuire Air Force Base here.

title: A COUNCIL OF 'WISE MEN' FOR REAGAN
description: The covert funding of the contras, the murky connection between Iranian arms shipments and hostages, the foray into uncharted territory in Reykjavik -each new disclosure reveals a President who seems to conduct foreign policy by the seat of his pants, following gut instincts rather than well-wrought initiatives based on national principles. Responding to the disarray, Democrat Sam Nunn and Republican Richard Lugar, two of the Senate's most thoughtful members, have been among those endorsing the same proposal: the appointment of a panel of ''wise men,'' an outside group of elder statesmen to give regular foreign policy advice to a foundering President.

title: THE NEW BOYS FROM DOWN UNDER
description: The ambiance of the Salon Vendome in the Hotel Parker Meridien is arguably Continental, but the accents issuing from the dais on this morning last October are certifiably Australian. A dozen corporate chieftains from Down Under have come to New York to extol the virtues of their companies to some 200 international money managers.

title: GUINNESS'S PLANS GO DRY
description: LAST Monday, the same day the British Government began an investigation of Guinness P.L.C, the company's chairman, Ernest Saunders, went ahead anyway to host a stylish fete at London's National Gallery. Confronted by reporters and photographers on the museum steps, Mr. Saunders said, ''I see no reason why I should let it spoil my party.''

title: Betting That a Stock Will Drop
description: ONE of the most enduring of the stock market's many mysteries is why so few people are willing to bet that stocks will fall. Fewer than 10 percent of stockholders have ever sold ''short'' - that is, sold borrowed shares in anticipation of a price decline, hoping to profit by replacing the borrowed shares with others bought at a lower price. Put another way, short selling involves a sale followed by a purchase, rather than the more usual procedure of a purchase followed by a sale.

title: THE GRANDEUR OF THE TIBER: JUST A MEMORY
description: When Mark Twain first saw the Tiber in Rome nearly 120 years ago, he asked his hosts why they didn't put a little water into it. Later, in ''The Innocents Abroad,'' the former Big River pilot noted, hardly to the point, that the celebrated Tiber ''is not so long, nor yet so wide, as the American Mississippi.''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Grad Partnership, a Newark-based architectural firm commissioned by the General Services Administraton to design the $50 million Martin Luther King Jr. Federal Courthouse and office building in Newark, will submit plans later this month.

title: ANGST IS HOBBLING JAPAN IN GREAT SOFTWARE RACE
description: UNTIL a few months ago, the sign outside Hitachi Ltd.'s main research laboratory here read ''Lead the '80's.'' But recently the director replaced it with one a shade less ambitious: ''Impact on the '90's.''

title: BUT DON'T QUOTE ME
description: To the Editor:

title: Pointless Matches Dull Masters Tennis
description: Last winter, the best minds in men's tennis met to resolve, once and possibly for all, this business about finding the proper format for the Nabisco Masters.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES TAX CUT TO AVERT LARGE WINDFALL
description: Governor Cuomo today called for tax cuts to offset the automatic increase in state tax collections that would result from the new Federal tax code. But he ruled out, for now, the deeper cuts Republicans had demanded, saying the state could not afford them.

title: TESTAVERDE AWARDED HEISMAN
description: In a ceremony at the Downtown Athletic Club that combined all the suspense of a Soviet election with the drama of a Harlem Globetrotters game, Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback, was awarded the Heisman Trophy yesterday as the nation's outstanding college football player.

title: ART IN THE DESERT
description: Five times in the course of a recent 3,200-mile drive through the Southwest, we left superhighways to follow ever narrower, rougher macadam, then gravel, finally dirt roads to where lunar landscapes opened before us and, dead center of each one, a monumental work of art solemn and enigmatic as a moon man's shrine.

title: BEST SELLERS: DECEMBER 7, 1986
description: Fiction

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TRACING STAGE SUCCESS Regional theaters in Connecticut have certainly done their share in providing material for Broadway. The concept of how regional theaters operate as seedbeds for new plays, ideas and techniques is being explored in a series of lectures organized by the Museum of American Theater in New Haven. At 5:30 P.M. Thursday, the latest session will be conducted by Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Drama School, and the noted stage designer Ming Cho Lee, who is a resident adviser to the stage design department of the school.

title: 'Reckless Disregard'
description: To the Editor:

title: Festival Of Sports For City
description: EVEN as the Knicks and the Rangers stumble along, the good ol' days of New York sports are now.

title: Caroline Reed Weds Frederick Taylor
description: Caroline Stevens Reed, a daughter of Mrs. Roslyn Thomas Reed Jr. of Manhattan and North Haven, Me., and the late Mr. Reed, was married yesterday to Frederick Blackburn Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Taylor of Denver. The Rev. T. Guthrie Spears performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel and Other Stories CC Studios 30 minutes. $29.95. In a world short of heroes, this program, which includes adaptations of three deservedly classic children's books, is a treasure.

title: Probation for Ex-Atom Aide
description: A Federal judge has placed on probation a former Atomic Energy Commission member who covered up a 1982 spill of cobalt-laden water at an irradiation plant.

title: GIVING TO THE NEEDIEST CASES A TRADITION FOR MANY DONORS
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are continuing a tradition that goes back many years.

title: THE U.S. GIVEAWAY
description: TWENTY years ago, the Raytheon Company won a contract to sell its Sparrow air-to-air missile to the Italian government. As part of the deal, Raytheon agreed to transfer technology, equipment and know-how to Rome's Selenia Industrie Elettroniche Associate, a big Italian electronics company. Raytheon even trained Selenia engineers at its Lexington, Mass., plant.

title: IT'S TOO LATE FOR MANY WHO DWELL CLOSE TO THE GREAT LAKES
description: WHEN the season's first big storm roared across the Great Lakes last week, many people living on the shoreline redoubled their demands that someone do something about the water level. But no one can just pull a plug.

title: EUROPEAN ALLIES ARE WATCHING NERVOUSLY
description: WITH a respectful silence appropriate to an emergency ward, the European allies watched anxiously last week to see if another American Presidency was about to destroy itself. ''The auguries are not all that good,'' observed a senior Western European envoy. ''We live, especially since Reykjavik, in a complicated and turbulent situation, and we need a confident and competent team in Washington.''

title: Editors' Choice: The Best Books of 1986
description: The best books of the year, chosen by the editors of The Book Review from those reviewed since last year's Christmas Books issue, are seven volumes of fiction and 10 nonfiction. The list, longer than it has been for a number of years, has six more titles than the 1985 one. Are the editors growing more generous or authors more brilliant? The tone of weekly discussions on the list that went on for more than two months, and the firm, contradictory opinions that persisted to the end, inspire caution about answering the question.

title: Amy L. Harrison to Wed Bradley G. Ball on Jan. 17
description: Amy Louise Harrison and Bradley Garland Ball, both of whom graduated in June from Williams College, plan to be married Jan. 17. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Harrison of Chatham., N.J., and Piseco Lake, N.Y., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Chesley Ball of Hanover, N.H.

title:
GARDENING;
BOUNTIFUL CHOICES FOR A COOL GREENHOUSE
description: PERHAPS the most rewarding benefit of owning a greenhouse comes from the opportunity it affords for year-round gardening in cold climates.

title: SUMMER JOBS PROGRAM FOR TEACHERS TO EXPAND UNDER GRANT
description: A $141,000 Federal grant will help the Connecticut Business and Industry Association expand its program to help teachers find summer jobs in their fields of expertise.

title: HIS ART, HIS LIFE, HIS LAUNDRY LISTS
description: JE SUIS LE CAHIER The Sketchbooks of Picasso. Edited by Arnold Glimcher and Marc Glimcher. Illustrated. 349 pp. Boston: Atlantic Monthly Press. $65.

title: St. John's Routs Wagner by 102-69
description: St. John's defeated Wagner, 102-69, at Alumni Hall last night, though one would have thought, after listening to Coach Lou Carnesecca, that his Redmen had lost by 30 points.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch last Sunday about President Reagan's radio address, misstated Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's role in the Nixon Administration during the Watergate scandal. Mr. Moynihan served as a White House counselor from 1969 to 1973, when he was appointed Ambassador to India.

title: MASTERPIECES RISE AND FALL ON A TIDE OF NEW EXPERTISE
description: That indelicate word, ''deattribution'' - meaning a downgrading in the authorship of a work of art - has surfaced again, this time at the Metropolitan Museum (where officials prefer the word ''reattribution''). Two Rembrandts there have been questioned by the Foundation Rembrandt Research Project, a committee of five Dutch scholars whose weighty mission is to determine what exactly Rembrandt did and did not paint.

title: A 'Mews' Mall
description: Somehow, the idea of a shopping mall, even a little one, did not seem to be in keeping with the character of Brooklyn Heights. But there was a good site for such a complex at the corner of Montague and Henry Streets.

title: Non-Savers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Marvelle Colby, an Educator, Weds Selig Alkon
description: Dr. Marvelle S. Colby of New York and Somers, N.Y., and Selig J. Alkon of New York and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Saltaire Village Hall on Fire Island by Jerome M. Leitner, the Village Justice.

title: SECRET SIGNALS NET A $1 MILLION CHAIR
description: Successful bidders at art auctions pride themselves on their secret signals. Crossed arms, a wink or a tug of an ear lobe can catch the auctioneer's eye without making other bidders aware that a knowledgeable collector is in a buying mood. Contrarian behavior has made Eddy G. Nicholson, an industrialist from Portsmouth, N.H., one of the most visible big spenders in the auction market.

title: Ms. Schreiber, Actress, Marries M.N. Ruthberg
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., last evening, Catherine Schreiber, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Schreiber of Great Neck, was married to Miles N. Ruthberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Ruthberg of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony.

title: LEADERS READY FOR FIGHT OVER ENGLISH-ONLY BILL
description: Hoping to repeat their recent victory in California, proponents of laws that would make English the official language of the United States have begun to intensify their efforts in the Northeast.

title: UNION DENIED A REHEARING IN ITS DISPUTE WITH COAL COMPANY
description: A labor dispute that prompted a violent, 15-month strike by the United Mine Workers against the A. T. Massey Coal Company may be headed for the Supreme Court.

title: Gifts for Glossolaliacs
description: ONLY TWO GIFTS are suitable for a word lover: a new word or a new lover. At the holiday season, let us look at ways to stimulate the ecstatic sighs of the most discerning glossolaliac.

title:
GARDENING;
BOUNTIFUL CHOICES FOR A COOL GREENHOUSE
description: PERHAPS the most rewarding benefit of owning a greenhouse comes from the opportunity it affords for year-round gardening in cold climates.

title: New Problems For Nonprofit Groups
description: The excellent article ''Fewer Volunteers, More Innovations'' on Nov. 23 illustrates the new and more difficult climate in which Long Island's nonprofit groups must operate. Changing demographics are compelling many organizations to adjust to the schedules of volunteers who have professional demands on their time.

title: Late Mistake Beats Ithaca
description: A crucial mistake with just over 2 minutes to play today and a record-setting touchdown effort by Mike Coppa of Salisbury State today sent Ithaca to its first defeat of the season. The loss cost Ithaca a chance to avenge next Saturday the defeat it suffered last year to Augustana in the Division III championship game.

title: STORMS RISE FEAR OF EAST END BREACH
description: TWO recent storms have increased the threat that the severely eroded barrier island at Westhampton Beach may soon be breached by the Atlantic Ocean, property owners and Southampton Town officials said last week.

title: WHAT WENT WRONG?
description: AFTER THE INTRIGUE with Iran, and the desertion of principle that it represents, Ronald Reagan is finally failing to escape his own effects. He is being held accountable. However much the President knew, however much the President didn't know, those 18 months of engagement with Iran were not merely hypocrisy in high places; they made a mockery of one of the Administration's finest articles of faith, that terrorists and their taskmasters not be appeased.

title: ANALYZING THE DROP IN REAGAN'S RATINGS
description: IT used to take a lot longer for Presidents to lose as much support as Ronald Reagan lost last month. But just as it had been a public opinion phenomenon that his level of approval remained solid for three years, even when people said they disliked his policies, his sudden decline also broke polling records.

title: 'Front Page' Affirms the Melodrama of Journalism
description: As the reporters begin their cynical vigil in the press room of Chicago's Criminal Courts Building, two things are immediately self-evident. Given the proper play (''The Front Page'') and director (Jerry Zaks), the Vivian Beaumont Theater is a most viable stage, despite its reputation as a white elephant. Secondly, and most emphatically, ''The Front Page'' proves its mettle. Almost 60 years after it was first produced, this portrait drawn by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur from their own life on the newspaper firing line is still the quintessential play about journalism. A trip back to ''The Front Page'' is also an affirmation of the melodrama of journalism. In the world of ''The Front Page,'' you can fight City Hall - if not the city editor. The mystique of a rambunctious, individualistic age is rousingly conveyed in Mr. Zaks's revival.

title: GRAFFITI GROUP IN FILM
description: A NEW JERSEY NETWORK documentary, ''The Writing on the Wall,'' scheduled to be telecast Thursday at 9 P.M., presents a frank picture of a Newark graffiti group called Vandals on the Street.

title: MacLean Gets 2 as Devils Top Sabres, 4-3
description: When the leading scorer of a team has four goals in 26 games, it isn't surprising that it has the worst record in the league. The Buffalo Sabres are the team, and it is no wonder that they have one victory in their last 13 games.

title: A PLEASANT DISCORD
description: POSTCARDS FROM SURFERS By Helen Garner. 106 pp. New York: McPhee, Gribble/Penguin Books. Paper, $4.95 THE CHILDREN'S BACH By Helen Garner. 96 pp. New York: McPhee, Gribble/Penguin Books. Paper, $4.95

title: EFFORT TO ESTIMATE LEVELS OF RADON RAISING CONCERN IN NEW ENGLAND
description: A recently drafted map designating New England locations where high concentrations of a dangerous gas are likely is worrying real estate planners and developers, who fear misinterpretations of the map may affect property values and land investment.

title: AUTO INSURANCE IN LEGISLATIVE SPOTLIGHT
description: THE New Jersey motorist was on everyone's mind in the State House last week as Senate and Assembly committees released identical bills designed to head off large automobile-insurance increases and the state Attorney General requested additional money to improve services provided by the Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: Dealing With Drunk Driving
description: Broad-based social re= forms of the kind that Mr. Clymer desires can be achieved through the civil-liability-tort system.

title: A PHOTO SHOW OUT OF HISTORY AND THE EAST END
description: IN a departure from its usual showing of paintings and sculpture, the Vered Gallery in East Hampton has unveiled an exhibition entitled ''Masterworks by 19th-and 20th-Century Photographers.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
COLLEGE HEADS HONORED
description: One hundred college presidents - about 3 percent of the top administrative officers of colleges and universities in the United States - were recently named by their peers as ''the most effective college presidents in the country.'' Among those cited are two from Westchester, Dr. Alice Stone Ilchman of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers and Dr. Joseph N. Hankin of Westchester Community College in Valhalla.

title: CRACKDOWN ON TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: IN the shoreline community of East Lyme, police and school officials are getting tough with teen-agers found drinking alcohol, vandalising property or causing disturbances.

title: SUGAR MAPLE FACES EXTINCTION THREAT
description: The sugar maple tree is threatened with extinction in the Northeast unless drastic environmental protection measures are taken, according to forestry experts here.

title: PURCHASE OFFERS LIFE ACCORDING TO STEIN
description: SOMEWHERE in the middle of act two, each of the play's 14 characters says the word ''it.'' And so goes the whole scene: the word ''it'' is spoken 14 times - no more, no less - in 14 ways, by 14 people. Fourteen ''its'' -and that's it.

title: Sandra Manee Is Married to George M. Evans Jr.
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Sandra Manee, a daughter of Mrs. John Templeton Strong of Greenwich and Monte Stewart Manee of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married to George Monroe Evans Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans, also of Greenwich. The Rev. John W. Bishop, rector of the church, performrd the ceremony.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 88, Celtics 86: John Williams hit two free throws with three seconds remaining last night at Richfield, Ohio, giving Cleveland its fifth straight victory. Williams and Ron Harper, both rookies, led the Cavaliers with 26 points each. The Celtics again played without Larry Bird, who has a strained right Achilles' tendon. With the score tied at 86-86, Williams grabbed an offensive rebound off a Mel Turpin miss and Robert Parish fouled him.(AP) Sonics 136, Rockets 80: Tom Chambers scored 29 points and Dale Ellis added 24 to lead Seattle as Houston suffered its worst lost in the team's 20-year history. The game was played at Houston. Chambers and Ellis combined for 42 points by halftime and neither played in the fourth quarter. Houston's previous worst defeat was a 53-point loss to Chicago, 129-76, during the 1981-82 season. (UPI)

title: No Headline
description: RAY MYERS DIDN'T LIKE THE SOUND of it. Roger E. Anderson, the chairman of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, was not in the habit of calling unscheduled meetings in the middle of the afternoon.

title: JOBS THAT A PRESIDENT SHOULD NOT DELEGATE
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC TRUST AND THE MARKET IN THE BOESKY ERA
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance
description: Some welcome visitors are appearing on New York stages. From North Carolina comes the North Carolina Dance Theater, the lively professional troupe attached to the North Carolina School of Arts in Winston-Salem.

title: 3-Point Shot: A Welcome Transfusion
description: WELCOME to the basketball revolution. Welcome to the emancipation of the long forgotten ability to shoot a basketball from great distances. And welcome to the long overdue increase in value for those with the greatest talents.

title: RAIDERS OF THE SACRED SITES
description: AT THE SOUTH-eastern tip of Utah, by the mouth of the cave known as the Mummy's Hand, the old woman they call Khe-tha-a-hei fell to her knees in prayer. Her anguished cries were carried for miles by the desert wind. She chanted of death, of desecration.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION: TOPICS
description: FOR months, no matter which major road I took, the workers were there ahead of me, repairing surfaces, erecting dividers or installing towering new lights. Waiting in traffic, I would recall those old highway signs that apologized, ''You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs.'' As a New York motorist, I complained futilely about the disruptions and continued to use the parkway, but the pheasant, less hardy, has flown.

title: Blue Is Let Go
description: HE has 209 career victories and a Cy Young Award, but his stat sheet also shows that he's 37 years old, and that, apparently, is one too many for the San Francisco Giants: The club has decided not to offer Vida Blue a contract for next year. Blue, who won both the American League Cy Young and Most Valuable Player awards in 1971 when he had a 24-8 record, a 1.82 earned run average and 301 strikeouts with the Oakland A's, spent six seasons with the Giants in the National League, posting a 72-58 record. He was 10-10 last season, with a 3.27 earned run average.

title: A SAVINGS BANK RISES FROM DESPAIR
description: IN the days before deregulation, as one of 132 state-chartered savings banks, the business at Peoples Westchester Savings Bank was routine: the bank accepted passbook savings deposits from customers, for which it paid low interest rates, and invested the funds in long-term fixed-rate mortgages - just as it always had, since its founding in Tarrytown in 1853.

title: DESPITE SEASON, ALL IS NOT HOLIDAY FARE
description: THERE is plenty of Christmas music all over the county, but there are nonholiday concert blessings as well. Today at 3 P.M., for example, the Hoff-Barthelson Festival Orchestra, seeking larger performing quarters than the school can provide at its Scarsdale home, offers a handsome selection of music by Bach, Purcell, Grieg and Mozart at the Bryn Mawr Park Presbyterian Church in Yonkers. Emanuel Vardi conducts and another faculty artist, Carl Hane, is the clarinet soloist. The program will be repeated at 8 P.M. Dec. 21 in the Scarsdale Synagogue on Ogden Road.

title: 'Men, Creating Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: Men and Abortion
description: Michael Blumenthal's article comes closer to explicit details of abortion than anything I have seen. If pornography in all forms can be tolerated, then more accurate descriptions of the emotional and physical aspects of abortion should be available to influence teen-age (and adult) attitudes toward promiscuous sex. ERNEST ULMER New York City

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Labels Should Not Be Required For Special Reading
description: LARGE numbers of parents of handicapped children in New Jersey are voicing deep outrage over the proposal of the state's Department of Education to revise the state's system of special education.

title: Ms. Dinneen Has Wedding
description: At St. Margaret Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Winter Park, Fla., yesterday Carol Ellen Dinneen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Dinneen of Winter Park and Sherburne, N.Y., was married to Samuel Brady Sutphin 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Reid Sutphin of Zionsville, Ind. The Rev. John Bluett performed the ceremony.

title: Cabbies Resist the City's Embrace
description: Hailed only by themselves, drivers of more than 1,000 nonmedallion taxicabs converged in slow convoys on lower Manhattan one morning last week, tying up traffic - and 300 policemen - for five hours. They were protesting a plan to put them under the control of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS;
New From Our Dead Author: 'Jeeves Comes Through at Dienbienphu'
description: IN 1885, R. Gustav Hall of the now extinct Hall House turned down ''50 Bison Dishes,'' a collection of recipes believed to be the first cookbook.

title: PRESSER'S LAWYER TELLS OF F.B.I. LINK
description: In the latest twist in the Government's investigation of Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union, his lawyer has acknowledged that Mr. Presser had a ''relationship'' with Government officials that began in the early 1970's.

title: TEFLON, THEN AND NOW
description: Needling President Reagan is nothing new. He does it to himself - complaining, for instance, about a problem that caused him a lot of sleepless afternoons. What's new is that the ridicule has been sticking. Wiseacres who remember Watergate snipe: What did the President forget and when did he forget it?

title: A SILENT BATTLE SURFACES
description: UNDER THE four oceans and the seven seas, American and Soviet submarines fight a near-war every day of the year. Relentlessly, they search for one another, trailing an adversary when they can and trying to evade one when detected. They make every move of a real war, except shoot.

title: COUNTY SEEKS CHANGES FOR LEGAL STAFF
description: EACH of the last three years, Westchester County has spent $1 million to hire outside lawyers to handle special cases - a practice County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke hopes to expand in one way and curtail in another.

title: JUDGE APPROVES USX BIAS AWARD
description: A $3.3 million settlement of a sex discrimination suit against USX Corporation has won final court approval.

title: HOME CARE FOR CHRONICALLY ILL CHILDREN EXAMINED
description: Eighteen-month-old Michael Brennan is already defying the odds.

title: SOUP OFFERED UP AS A FIRST COURSE OR AS A DINNER IN ITSELF
description: THE winter menu invariably includes soup. Steaming bowls hearty with meat and vegetables, enriched with well-flavored stock or thick cream are the seasonal delights.

title: Arizona Governor Proposes Plan for U.S. Welfare System
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt, who says the Reagan Administration's answer for the welfare system is ''to shove it overboard,'' is proposing increased Federal spending for the poor and work requirements for the able-bodied.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing Oct. 19 of food outlets cited for health-code violations carried an incorrect identification supplied by the New York Health Department for a restaurant at 1497 Third Avenue. The restuarant, formerly known as Oren's, was sold before the inspection. After the sale it was known first as Charlie & Y.A.'s, then as the Post-Game Cafe.

title: WHEN SCHOOL IS TOO NEAR, YET TOO FAR
description: EVERY school-day morning, a half-empty school bus heads down Raritan Road toward the J. Ackerman Coles Elementary School in Scotch Plains-Fanwood, passing a handful of children waiting to go to the same place. A few moments later, a private bus comes by to take those children to school.

title: Bluebird Flies Once More
description: After many years of relative obscurity, the recorded jazz and swing of the 30's and 40's has experienced a remarkable resurgence in the last decade. One of the milestones of the revival was RCA's re-releases on its revived Bluebird label.

title:
ART;
Women's Place in Surrealism
description: ONE of the most familiar icons of Surrealism is Meret Oppenheim's ''Fur-Covered Teacup, Saucer and Spoon,'' created in 1936 and now in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. However, even those who immediately recognize this disturbing transformation of the familiar as a quintessential Surrealist statement may not know that it was made by a woman, or that she was only one of several female artists active in the movement almost from its inception.

title: HIPPOCRATES ON A TOUGH BLOCK
description: MANHATTAN COUNTRY DOCTOR By Milton Jonathan Slocum. 271 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $16.95.

title: INCREASE IN RABIES IS FEARED
description: AN incident that began with one rabid dog last month and affected 36 people as of last week is the first recorded case of a rabid dog in the county, but it may not be the last, according to health officials. The rabid dog was brought here from Africa but the officials say that rabies, a disease fatal to humans if not treated in time, is heading north from Pennsylvania and areas to the south, carried by raccoons, foxes and skunks.

title: INTEGRATION IN YONKERS: OUTSIDE EXPERT URGED
description: A LAWYER for one of the plaintiffs in the Yonkers desegregation case asked a Federal judge last week to consider appointing an independent expert to develop integrated housing in the city.

title: Lawyer Will Cooperate In Corruption Inquiry
description: A lawyer who was elected judge last month but was jailed when he refused to testify about alleged judicial corruption has been freed after agreeing to cooperate with a Federal inquiry.

title: Headliners; Alarm Down Under
description: Rupert Murdoch, once an Australian communications mogul who terrified the American newspaper industry, is evidently a fair-minded guy. Last week, Mr. Murdoch, now a naturalized American mogul, upset the industry Down Under with a $1.17 billion bid for Australia's largest newspaper group.

title: MOUNTAIN OF TROUBLE IN GYPSUM HILLS
description: Between the Mississippi River and the fertile swamps west of here, chalky white hills of gypsum are growing, along with anger and confusion over what to do about them.

title: East End Inspires Paean in Poetry
description: IS the South Fork the stuff that dreams are made of? Its expansive beaches, windswept dunes, yawning gardens, quiet bays and warbling birds have attracted poets for years and inspired their musings.

title: Nets Fall To 76ers, 105-100
description: Andrew Toney returned to center stage tonight. The Philadelphia guard, limited to six games last season by stress fractures that required surgery in both feet, forgot about the leftover pain he says still hounds him, and rallied the 76ers to a 105-100 victory over the Nets at the Spectrum in Philadelpia.

title: NEXT BALTIMORE MAYOR KEEPING FAITH
description: Clarence H. (Du) Burns has come a long way in politics since 15 years ago, when he was dispensing towels to student athletes as the locker room attendant at Dunbar High School in Baltimore.

title: Cookbooks
description: COOKBOOKS this season, many of them lavishly illustrated with mouthwatering full-page photographs, have the personal touch.

title: Struggling With Himself, A Player Seeks Greatness
description: MOMENTS after Navy had lost an 86-84 decision to North Carolina State in the Tipoff Classic two weeks ago, David Robinson, Navy's center and perhaps the nation's most dominating college basketball player, made his way to the middle of a silent locker room and faced his teammates.

title: 5 Convictions In Argentina
description: The former police chief of Buenos Aires Province, Gen. Ramon Camps, was convicted last week of human rights crimes, including 73 counts of torture, and given a 25-year prison term. Four other former police officials were convicted on torture charges and sentenced to terms ranging from 4 to 23 years.

title: IN BOLIVIA, ONLY A FAINT HUE AND CRY FOLLOWS COCAINE CORRUPTION CHARGE
description: CORRUPTION by Government, police and military officials is an old story in Bolivia, which has long been a primary source of the world's cocaine. During previous administrations, notably the one headed by Gen. Luis Garcia Meza in the early 1980's, the United States Embassy actively made public what it knew about the drug ties of Government and military officials. Washington saw no interest in maintaining the repressive Garcia Meza Government.

title:
GARDENING;
BOUNTIFUL CHOICES FOR A COOL GREENHOUSE
description: PERHAPS the most rewarding benefit of owning a greenhouse comes from the opportunity it affords for year-round gardening in cold climates.

title: DANCE: BEVERLY BROWN COMPANY
description: INTELLIGENCE and a sense of craft were clearly at work in the dance presented by the Beverly Brown Dancensemble at the Marymount Manhattan Theater on Friday. Ms. Brown has a distinctively grave and lyrical sensibility, and the themes of the dances on the Marymount program ranged from male and female rituals to a soldier's life and memories. But all but one of the dances wandered off after clear and promising starts.

title: A MASSACRE TEARS OPEN OLD WOUNDS IN INDIA
description: FOR the 75 people aboard Bus No. PJG 7284 in the northern Indian state of Punjab, the trouble started at dusk last Sunday when four young men began shouting slogans for an independent nation for Sikhs. It ended on a remote country road as they singled out passengers they believed to be Hindus and shot them dead. Killings by Sikh separatists in Punjab are reported almost daily. But the massacre of 22 people shocked the nation and raised fresh doubts about Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's strategy against terrorism. A wave of killings and clashes between the police and protesting mobs of Hindus and Sikhs ensued in New Delhi and elsewhere in northern India.

title: FATE OF HISTORIC HOUSE EMBROILED IN A DISPUTE
description: THE fate of Branford House, the historic mansion overlooking the Thames River in the city of Groton, is still unclear.

title: Miss Pepperell Wed To William Dietrich
description: Elisabeth Pepperell. a vice president in the investment banking sector of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, was married yesterday to William Dietrich, a principal of Alex Brown & Sons, investment bankers in Baltimore. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: TOEHOLD ON A FAST TRACK
description: I WAS SITTING IN THE CONFERENCE ROOM of a California bank on a bright March morning, running my fingers along the edge of a teak table.

title: 'Messiah' Leads Concert Choices
description: AS a deeply religious man, George Frederick Handel probably would have been delighted to know that his ''Messiah'' would come to be synonymous with the celebration of Christmas - musically, at least. Few if any holiday concerts these days would be considered complete without church or community choirs singing at least some segments of the oratorio.

title: A Partial Victory In a Wiretap Case
description: Last week's Federal appeals court rulings in two wiretap cases do not appear to have substantially changed or clarified what officials may legally do in the name of national security, and they provided only partial victory for only one of the plaintiffs. But they added substantially to the cases' dramatic background.

title: Opposition in Seoul Postpones Rallies
description: Opposition leaders said today that they would postpone nationwide rallies originally scheduled for the coming week until next year.

title: LONDON'S CALM HAVENS FOR BIBLIOPHILES
description: Some people collect restaurants when they travel; I collect libraries. When visiting a city, knowing where I can find the nearest library is every bit as essential to my peace of mind as having a three-star recommendation for dinner. Once inside a library's portals, the rush of sightseeing can be put aside; in hushed silence I can rest my feet, collect my thoughts, browse through best sellers, and even take a look at a historical manuscript or two.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's a very compelling offer for a Diamond shareholder. Bricker is going to have to pull a rabbit out of his hat to beat it.'' Alan L. Edgar, analyst at Schneider, Bernet & Hickman, on T. Boone Pickens's offer for Diamond Shamrock.

title: COURT TOLD OF U.S. ABUSES IN DENIAL OF VETERANS' AID
description: Details of the inner workings of one of the Federal Government's largest bureaucracies, the Veterans Administration, have been laid out before a Federal district judge here.

title: Sense of Scale At Holy Cross
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Fun, That Antique Feeling To ask what fun meant for your mother or father is to realize what a gulf exists between them and you. This is from a story in ''Bluebeard's Egg'' (Houghton Mifflin), by Margaret Atwood. Having fun has always been high on my mother's agenda. She has as much fun as possible, but what she means by this phrase cannot be understood without making an adjustment, an allowance for the great gulf across which this phrase must travel before it reaches us. It comes from another world, which, like the stars that originally sent out the light we see hesitating in the sky above us these nights, may be or is already gone. It is possible to reconstruct the facts of this world - the furniture, the clothing, the ornaments on the mantelpiece, the jugs and basins and even the chamber pots in the bedrooms, but not the emotions, not with the same exactness. So much that is now known and felt must be excluded. . . . Life was more joyful and innocent then, and at the same time permeated with guilt and terror, or at least the occasions for them, on the most daily level. It was like the Japanese haiku: a limited form, rigid in its perimeters, within which an astonishing freedom was possible.

title: PARENTS WIN BATTLE TO ALLOW DAUGHTER TO DIE
description: A couple who have seen three of their four children stricken by a disease that causes blindness and certain death have won a court battle to withhold life-sustaining systems from one of them, their 22-year-old daughter.

title:
CABLE TV;
Jonathan Miller Stages 'Cosi'
description: Nowadays, perhaps the most uncharacteristic directorial liberty for Jonathan Miller to take is to take no directorial liberties at all. Mr. Miller is the director, after all, who transplanted Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' from 16th-century Mantua to New York's Little Italy smack in the 1950's. And who staged a version of ''The Mikado'' that seemed to take its cues more from the Marx Brothers than from Gilbert and Sullivan.

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Mon Oncle Directed by Jacques Tati. 1958. Embassy Home Entertainment. 110 minutes. $29.95. Because the comedy of Jacques Tati doesn't depend on dialogue, it makes no difference that the subtitles on this video cassette are only legible about half the time.

title: Fielder's Choice
description: FRED PRESSMAN, president of Barneys New York, trains an eye on a customer shopping for neckties on his store's main floor.

title: RHODE ISLAND POLICE SUSPECT JERSEY LINK IN DOGS' SLAYINGS
description: The arrest of a Pawtucket man on charges of maliciously killing a dog may provide a link to a series of hangings of dogs in New Jersey and Massachusetts, according to the police.

title: Another Hazing Incident Is Reported at Citadel
description: Three military cadets have been suspended in the second hazing incident within a month at the Citadel, but details surrounding the incident are not being disclosed, school officials said.

title: Aileen Marie Skislock To Wed David Sarda
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Skislock of Woodbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Aileen Marie Skislock to David T. K. Sarda, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Runy M. Sarda Jr. of Tarrytown, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 11. The future bride, a senior office representative of Cort Furniture Rental in Dallas, graduated from Skidmore College and studied at the City of London Polytechnic.

title: Uncle Wiggily's Karma and Other Childhood Memories
description: For many of us, books received as holiday gifts when we were children remain vividly with us as adults. The Book Review asked a number of writers which book read as children influenced them the most. Some replies show a straight-arrow route from the child's taste to the adult's work; others reveal unsuspected, even astonishing, twists in later literary paths. Susan Sontag Fiction writer and critic, author of ''Under the Sign of Saturn''

title: Cable TV
description: An exceptionally varied cable film week offers a little something for everybody. ''Kagemusha'' (1980), the great Kurosawa's dramatic pageantry of samurai court intrigue and battle, is an exotic experience -Sunday at midnight on Bravo. For an eye-opener, there's the Astaire-Rogers ''Top Hat'' (1935) at an unstylish 8 A.M. over Cinemax on Monday; then at 10 A.M. a frisky comedy with Bette Davis and George Brent, ''The Golden Arrow'' (1936) on Showtime, which also has the delightful 1973 musical ''Tom Sawyer'' at 5 P.M. and Thursday at 10 A.M.

title: John Law: Selling New World Dreams
description: JOHN LAW was a Scottish financial wizard who founded the Banque Royale in Paris in 1716 to try to repay the enormous debts brought on by King Louis XIV's wars. Mr. Law then combined his bank with the Mississippi Company, which held title to enormous tracts of land in North America.

title: The Ear, a Tenor's Age and Advice for Conductors
description: Somewhere, Thoreau remarks acidly on the spiritual poverty of his fellow humans who go regularly to the post office although they haven't heard from themselves in a long time. That is a pretty harsh way to put it, but, yes, mail - even catalogues, so long as they are not addressed to Resident, CART-SORT, can be a reassurance that someone out there is convinced of our existence. So, I suppose, most people do go through life opening their mail with a sense of gratitude mingled with anticipation. Ah, we think, this one in the shaky handwriting looks like a note from dear, rich uncle George. Or, this one must be from a close friend because our name is spelled almost right. And what's this, a check of some sort?

title: Norwalk Twins
description: Norwalk may have only 52 office buildings to Greenwich's 110, but Norwalk is catching up, with hundreds of thousands of square feet of commercial space under construction and more being planned. Cheaper rents and an abundant work force have enticed many corporations, including Exxon and I.B.M., to establish offices in Norwalk.

title: Croton-on-Hudson Wary on Condo Plans
description: LATE last month, Croton-on-Hudson approved a site plan for the largest residential project in its history, a 342-unit riverfront condominium. Five other projects are well into the planning stage, creating the potential for unprecedented growth in a village proud of its rustic setting and single-family homes.

title: COLONIALS IN THE CITY
description: There was a time, a few short years ago, when the life of the London broker was a highly civilized affair. The commissions were fat and fixed; the relationship with competitors was genteel. Leisurely lunches were mandatory, and offices were apt to be empty on Friday afternoons as brokers deserted the City for a weekend in the country.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: NEW YORK is a city full of interesting anomalies. Not the least of these is some of its citizens. Take, for instance, the portion of the male population that, in most other cities, goes by the name of extra men. New York has extra men, too, but at least in the posher circles of Manhattan, they're few and far between. That's because unattached men seem to be in genuinely short supply, and because whatever there is of the supply is merchandised by other names.

title: L.E. King Jr. Wed To Lynn Dudgeon
description: Lynn Martina Dudgeon, the daughter of Mrs. Edward Norman Dudgeon of Plandome Manor and Shelter Island, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dudgeon, was married yesterday to Loren Edward King Jr., the son of Theresa King of Jersey City and the late Mr. King. The Rev. Thomas Lamont, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church in Manhattan.

title: TIMES SQUARE PLAN MARKED BY DELAY
description: Right about now, according to the latest timetable for the redevelopment of Times Square, cranes should be wrecking buildings at the corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue and construction workers should be converting the area's tacky movie palaces into legitimate theaters.

title: Gloomy Start to Berry's Pro Career
description: As a curtain of fog rolled behind the fir trees that line the elegant Willamette River, the morning sun began to shine, replacing the rain and haze that blanketed Portland for the last several days. But the change was not enough to brighten Walter Berry's day.

title: ROCK: THE PRESIDENT
description: LUMINARIES of Lower East Side rock appeared Thursday at CBGB in a new configuration - the President, a six-piece instrumental rock band led by the keyboardist Wayne Horvitz. Although its members have delved into jazz, funk, noise-rock and free improvisation, the President focuses on one style of rock - the Southern funk of the 1970's band Little Feat.

title: Casting a Line in Bhutan, Voyaging From Florida
description: A fresh destination beckons fly fishermen. It is Bhutan, the Himalayan country closed to the outside world until 1974 and today admitting only 1,900 tourists annually.

title: A Commission Faults Upstate Judge for Bias
description: A state panel has recommended the removal of an upstate town justice on grounds of misconduct, including the making of racist remarks on and off the bench.

title: 'Twin' Debussy and Ravel Quartets Get New Readings
description: The Debussy and Ravel string quartets are such close cousins that they are nearly always paired in recordings.

title: INFORMATION ON SENIOR VOLUNTEERS
description: I am writing in reference to the Nov. 9 article titled ''Senior Volunteers Offer Helping Hands.'' In the article, extensive reference was made to the volunteers from the Retired Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP) who work at Hillside School.

title: A Warning on Imported Food
description: About a fourth of the fresh fruit consumed in the United States comes from abroad. But less than 1 percent of all imported produce is checked for traces of pesticides that are barred in this country, the General Accounting Office reported last week.

title: FRANCE'S PAGNOL AND PAGNOL'S FRANCE BASK AGAIN IN NOSTALGIC WARMTH
description: It's probably fair to say that every true devotee of French film classics has his favorite scene from Marcel Pagnol, the novelist and director who raised the humble hills around Marseilles to mythic heights. Mine comes in the 1939 movie ''Harvest,'' starring Fernandel, about the rebirth of a crumbling, stony village in what Pagnol himself called ''the harsh, hard Provence of the hills north of Aubagne,'' his native town. Fernandel plays a charmingly knavish artisan who tugs a knife-sharpener's cart over corrugated tracks from village to village, at one point finding a woman companion, played by Orane Demazis, and then losing her to the stoutly sentimental peasant who had begun the village's renaissance.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Resident Artist In a High-Rise
description: THIS fall, John Arndt, a struggling young photographer, moved into an apartment in a luxury high-rise overlooking Lake Michigan.

title: Choosing the Best of Recent Releases And Reissues On Compact Disks
description: Compact disks have so rapidly and completely established themselves as the norm for classical-music recording that a list of recent recommended CD's almost amounts to a list of recommended classical releases, period, in any format. Actually, it amounts to a list of new releases combined with reissues, since, with the CD in mind, record companies are spending at least as much time and energy remastering and re-releasing their catalogues on CD as issuing brand new items.

title: In Praise Of Teachers
description: As a former elementary-school teacher and college professor, it was a joy to read Mark Medoff's article ''In Praise of Teachers'' (Nov. 9).

title: GULOTTA CAUTIOUS ON FUTURE PATH
description: WHEN Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell announced last week that he was retiring and taking a job as a political analyst with a local news organization, the stage had already been set for Hempstead Town's Presiding Supervisor, Thomas S. Gulotta, to succeed him.

title: THE LATIN LEFT IS FREE TO BE UNPOPULAR
description: IN the election campaign here last month, the tiny pro-Albanian Communist Party of Brazil mobilized its activists, waved its red flags and violated a good many Marxist-Leninist precepts in supporting Wellington Moreira Franco, the nominee of a right-of-center coalition. When he won, defeating two candidates long identified with socialist causes, the party was able to claim victory.

title: City's Former Transportation Chief Is Indicted
description: When he resigned 10 months ago as head of the Transportation Department, the parent agency of the scandal-ridden Parking Violations Bureau, Anthony R. Ameruso said that while he had been charged with no crime, he would ''take my share of accountability.''

title: Captive in Prague
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A Christmas Wish
description: 'Dear Santa, I am asking you if you would please give my sister and me and my mom and dad a new house. If you do, I promise we will never ask you for anything else again.' - A homeless boy who lives in a New York City welfare hotel, in one of about 2,600 letters addressed to Santa Claus that have been received at the General Post Office.

title: THE INVITATION SAYS 'BLACK TIE'
description: Executive calendars overflow with appointments, even after dark. There are invitations that specify ''black tie'' for industry banquets, awards dinners, corporate-sponsored museum galas and private parties -at the chairman's penthouse or aboard his yacht. Business in the guise of play is part of the capitalist ethic, after all.

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Crusade in the Pacific, Vols. 5 and 6 Produced by March of Time TV Embassy Home Entertainment 115 minutes each. $24.95 each.

title:
ART;
AT THE CASTLE GALLERY, A CLEAR CASE OF ART IMITATING LIFE
description: ONE sinks rather effortlessly into ''Diner: An American Artform'' at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle. After all, eating is a basic appetite and any visual art that can be spun out of this natural proclivity is, well, just dessert.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Tokyo dispatch in The Week in Review on Aug. 10 misstated the dispositon of the case against Nobusuke Kishi, who was Commerce Minister in the Japanese Cabinet during World War II. Although imprisoned from 1945 to 1948 as a suspected war criminal, Mr. Kishi was never convicted.

title: STAGE: 'LADDER AND CLARINET'
description: ''THE LADDER AND THE CLARINET'' at Symphony Space Wednesday night was one of those amiable - if unlikely - syntheses of the arts. One of its constituents was Murph, who bills himself as a ''physical comedian''; the other was Jean Kopperud, certainly the most mobile of clarinetists now appearing on stage.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S WORLD OIL PIPELINE STARTS TO DRY UP
description: Giving way to public pressure, companies and countries are starting to pull out of the lucrative but shadowy oil trade with South Africa.

title: Saluting the Jewish Mother
description: ALTHOUGH not running for office, Fred A. Bernstein is clearly a people's choice who is in favor of motherhood and access to higher education.

title: 'Going Private'
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THEY DEFECT...
description: DEFECTING DIPLOMATS, MILI-tary men and intelligence officers from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have found in recent years that despite their intimate knowledge of the Soviet bloc, the United States Government does virtually nothing to help them use their expertise or adjust to the baffling array of choices in American life. The result, many say, has been that they suffer considerable hardship in entering American society. A few prominent defectors, such as Arkady N. Shevchenko, the former Soviet official who was Under Secretary General of the United Nations, write successful books, lecture for lucrative fees and give occasional advice to the White House and the State Department. Viktor Belenko, a Soviet pilot who flew his MIG-25 jet fighter to Japan in 1976, works as a consultant to the aerospace industry. But most defectors begin their lives in America in menial jobs entirely unrelated to their skills.

title:
MEETING MEDICAL EMERGENCIES CLOSE TO HOME AND OVERSEAS;
Drill At Mall Simulates Coping With Explosion
description: VICTIMS of the explosion in the truck tunnel at The Mall in Short Hills lay scattered along the dark underground passages and loading docks beneath the stores. Millburn firefighters, alien-like in their gas masks and oxygen tanks, doused fires started by the blast and combed the smoke-filled area for survivors.

title: BEHIND L.I. CRIME: DRUGS, POVERTY
description: A 24-YEAR-OLD Glen Cove man is arrested on Prospect Avenue in New Cassel after police officers see him take a wallet from a friend. He sees the officers and throws the wallet over a fence. After a brief search it is found, filled with cocaine and crack.

title: CHICAGO EXPECTING A 3-WAY CAMPAIGN
description: The announcement by Edward R. Vrdolyak that he is a candidate for Mayor of Chicago has set the scene for a three-way game of political ''chicken.''

title: Nora Ephron's Revisions
description: To the Editor:

title: ICELAND
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading the article on Iceland. In addition to the beautiful waterfalls, thermal areas with geysers, boiling springs and volcanic features discussed in the story, one should not neglect the coastline.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO MEMORY, HIS MIND'S A STEEL-TRAP SIEVE
description: ''HOW was last night's party, Sue?'' I asked.

title: Resorts That Blazed Western Trails
description: The three queens of Western ski resorts - jazzy Aspen, homey Alta and venerable Sun Valley - still reign over their snowy realms after nearly half a century. Each had its beginning as a mining town, fell on hard times during the silver slump and was later transformed into a winter playground. Aspen has grown and changed a lot; Sun Valley has grown a lot and changed a little; only Alta has remained much the same.

title: The Organization Man: A Rejoinder
description: SOME YEARS AGO I WROTE A book about the people who work for large organizations. I called them organization men. Some people got mad at me for this. They said I was calling them dirty conformists. But I wasn't. I was an organization man myself (Vicks, Fortune magazine, the Marine Corps), and I meant no slight. Quite the contrary. My point was that these were the people who were running the country, not the rugged individualists of American folklore. And that they had better beware of the bureaucratic ethic.

title: POL POT MYSTERY: ILLNESS AND CONFLICT
description: Thai military officials and some Cambodian exiles are saying that Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, is terminally ill in China, but that a power struggle within his organization may be holding up statements about his condition.

title: FATHER OWNS THE WORDS
description: INSIDE By Helene Cixous. Translated by Carol Barko. 136 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $14.95.

title: Travel
description: I HAVE in my possession two wooden boxes of color slides meant to be projected by a simple magnifying device onto a plain wall. The projector was long gone when, as an acquisitive kid, I discovered them in the attic, so I have only seen my views in miniature - Mt. Fuji, the Matterhorn, the Taj Mahal and the Pyramids - the wonders of the world instantly recognizable in their shrunken, luridly touched-up state. It was hard to imagine the darkened parlor in which a chorus of ''ohs'' and ''ahs'' greeted a costumed camel train, an elephant romp, a panorama of the Tyrol. I felt that given the advanced art of the travelogue at the neighborhood movie house and the superior photos in our monthly National Geographic, I was on the cutting edge of telecommunications, which would obliterate the distant and exotic. Many years later, having traveled too carefully to civilized places, I've developed respect, even a minor passion, for fine travel books that like palm trees and wild beasts quivering on the living room wall, may seem outmoded projections but like all good reading deliver the thrill - a bit of magic in the dark.

title: THE PRICE OF THE UNBUCKLED BELT
description: ''I don't think seat belts should be forced on anybody,'' said Dan Bauer of Lodgepole, Neb. Neither did the majority of voters in Nebraska and Massachusetts, who voted last month to repeal mandatory-belt-use laws.

title: REPEAL OF LAW ON SEAT BELTS IS SOUGHT
description: DAVID SOLAN says he will start wearing a seat belt the day the state's seat belt law is repealed.

title: Tati's 'Oncle,' Tamayo's Art, And 'Arabella'
description: Arabella With Ashley Putnam. 1984. HBO/Cannon Video. 154 minutes.$39.95. Richard Strauss's ''Arabella'' re-examines old operatic conventions of disguise, sexual intrigue and mistaken identity by placing them in the wry context of Viennese society - its charms, its false fronts and its honest passions.

title: Guess Who Gets the Nod
description: Joe Theismann has a new career as a color commentator for CBS Sports. And except for some gibes that he still talks too much and a blooper in last Sunday's Redskins-St.

title: 24 Killed in Sri Lanka In Ethnic Violence
description: Twenty-four people have been reported killed in violence between Moslems and Tamils in the eastern district of Batticaloa, and a 27-hour curfew was imposed in the area beginning today.

title: IN MEXICO CITY: GOOD VISIBILITY, BAD POLLUTION
description: Just after dawn most mornings now, Mexico City residents are treated to a rare sight. So clear is the fall air that the two volcanoes that tower over the city are clearly visible, starkly etched against the lightening sky.

title: Non-Savers
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics And Playoffs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TENSION RISES IN PARIS AFTER THE DEATH OF A STUDENT
description: The two-week-old confrontation between student protesters and the French Government worsened today when a student died, apparently after being beaten by the police during a demonstration.

title: SPIKE'S PIQUE
description: BAD GUYS By Elizabeth Arthur. 262 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: LISA PINES TO WED ROBERT LESLIE HORNSBY IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan A. Pines of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Pines to Robert Leslie Hornsby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby Hornsby of Fort Worth. The wedding is planned for April. Ms. Pines, a painter, graduated from the Friends Seminary in New York and Connecticut College and studied at the Showhegan School of Painting and Sculpture.

title: MISS RHODEN PRICE ENGAGED TO MARRY ALEXANDER ANTON
description: Charles H. Price 2d, United States Ambassador to Britain, and Mrs. Price of London have announced the engagement of Mrs. Price's daughter Melissa Rhoden Price to Alexander Anton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Graeme Anton of Kidderminster, England. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1986   ; The World
description: The President noted ''mistakes'' made in the ''flawed'' execution of his secret policy initiatives toward Iran. His remarks were a clear shift away from his previous defiant stance.

title: VARIETY THRIVES ON NEW-MUSIC DISKS
description: Looking at the array of styles that make up today's new-music world, it can be difficult to believe that there was once a time, scarcely a century and a half ago, when composers couched their statements, however individualized, in the terms of a common stylistic language, and when audiences could attend evenings of new music with reasonable expectations about the symmetry and syntax of the sounds they were about to hear. These days, even listeners familiar with major works by specific composers can't be sure those composers won't break the mold from one score to the next; and it's virtually impossible to know what to expect of a newcomer.

title: Another Bayh in Politics
description: Washington friends and neighbors of Birch Bayh, the Democrat who represented Indiana in the Senate from 1962 to 1980, were pleased to learn that his son, Evan Bayh, was elected attorney general of Indiana last month. Former Senator Bayh, who now practices law here, earlier served in the Indiana Legislature, including a term as Speaker of the House.

title: Joan Collins to Be a Bride
description: Joan Elsa Collins and John Scott Mueller, both graduates of the Catholic University of America, plan to be married May 2. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Collins of Rye Brook, N.Y., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack G. Mueller of Centerville, Mass. Miss Collins is a media coordinator for Abramson Associates Inc., an advertising agency in Washington, where her fiance is a training specialist at Health Communications Inc.

title: PREACHER 'CATALYST' FOR FERVOR OF 3 TENNIS PROS
description: Two American tennis players who tore up their passports, money and traveler's checks in a religious frenzy last week had fallen under the influence of a Nigerian evangelical preacher, officials say.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Photography
description: ARASH of seriousness has hit the world of photography book publishing, which usually can be counted on to supply visual fruitcake this time of year. There are more scholarly and issue-oriented books of photographs and far fewer tomes designed mainly to impress themselves on coffee tables. The environment, both social and natural, figures large in the scheme of things. Leading the pack in this regard is Aperture, the once-dominant photography specialty house, which has made a transition from photography-as-art monographs to thematic books, by and large without sacrificing its tradition of fine reproduction. At the other end of the continent, geographically and esthetically, is Twelvetrees Press of Pasadena, Calif., which has produced the year's most deluxe photography books, calm in design and voluptuous in content.

title: WILDLIFE MUSEUM SOUGHT FOR BATTERY
description: Can vampire bats, mandrills, snow-white mountain goats and deep-sea spider crabs with legs 11 feet long give ''soul'' to a multibillion-dollar office and apartment development?

title: Take the F.A.A. Out of Traffic Control
description: AIRLINE traffic has soared in recent years, to more than 400 million passengers in 1986 from 286 million in 1981. And as the traffic has increased, so has the number of delays traceable to the air traffic control system. While the nation should be indebted to the air-traffic controllers for their service since the strike in 1981, systemic improvements are needed to meet future growth demands.

title: ASSEMBLY'S BUDGET OFFICE PUTS SURPLUS AT $164 MILLION
description: ROBUST buying by Connecticut consumers is pushing the state's surplus higher for the fourth straight year, raising the prospect of tax cuts and increased state aid to the cities and towns when the new General Assembly convenes Jan. 7.

title: Kathryn P. Overbagh, TV Producer, Weds Rudolph R. Croxton, Architect
