description: The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Kathryn Pilgrim Overbagh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Overbagh of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Randolph Rudisill Croxton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Blackwell Croxton of Burlington, N.C. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bryant Kirkland of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Cast Out by G.M., Perot Still Has A Word to Say
description: It would make a great movie: Brash billionaire meets corporate giant and shakes up staid boardrooms with a clarion call to ''get competitive.'' But Hollywood might want to change the ending.

title: ISRAELIS SEIZE 70 ARABS IN WEST BANK CLASHES
description: The Israeli Army and police arrested more than 70 Palestinian youths today during a third day of clashes with West Bank Arabs.

title: The Turn in Rental Rehabilitation
description: ''WE can turn out these buildings like pancakes,'' says Abram Gin. ''But the local authorities must cooperate.''

title: SHARING: HUNT FOR ROOMMATES
description: In the epic quest that can be the search for affordable, desirable housing in Manhattan, roommate services play an especially sensitive role.

title: Elizabeth P. LaForge Weds Norman Steisel
description: Elizabeth Porter LaForge and Norman Steisel were married yesterday at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn. Judge Jo Ann Ferdinand of the New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: CHORUS HELPS NEW SONGS GRACE SEASON
description: BARELY able to remain in their chairs, but with their feet joyously stomping, the members of the Choral Club of Hartford raised their voices, singing out the words to ''Christmas Contradance,'' while the conductor, Don McKeever, played the spirited tune on the piano and the composer, Charles Outwin, beamed.

title: COLD-AFFLICTED STUDENTS FIGHTING IT THEMSELVES
description: FEELING rotten? Is a headache beating your brain like a jackhammer? Does your throat feel like it was sandpapered? And not even a dose of Drano could unclog your sinuses?

title: FOOTBALL TEAM HANGS IN THE BALANCE
description: FOR Buddy Amendola, the football coach at Central Connecticut State University, last season looked like the best of times.

title: Alice Meade Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Alice Belknap Meade to Gard Landgrave Little has been announced by Barbara M. Meade of Washington and David E. Meade of Takoma Park, Md., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. George Robert Little Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Little.

title: 'THE NUTCRACKER' BALLET USHERS IN A SEASON OF TRADITIONAL ENTERTAINMENT
description: AS much a part of the holiday season as an office Christmas party or a visit to a tree farm, ''The Nutcracker,'' in various forms by various ballet troupes, is once again gracing stages around the state.

title: ON REREADING 'NATIVE SON'
description: I FIRST BEGAN RICH-ard Wright's ''Native Son'' in the winter of 1971, when, as an undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania, I was taking a course called ''Readings in Black Literature.''

title: Dealing With Drunk Drivers
description: Unfortunately, Adam Clymer's moving story ''Death of a Daughter'' (Nov. 2), is not a unique one to us at Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

title: Barry Evan Schklair Weds Diane D. Boas
description: The marriage of Diane Doris Boas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Boas of New York and Newtown, Conn., to Barry Evan Schklair, the son of Rose Schklair of New York and the late Jack Schklair, took place last night at the St. Moritz Hotel in New York. Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer performed the ceremony.

title: Questions at 6, Answers at 9
description: Elyse Trevers can stop worrying about the precocious questions her 6-year-old daughter asks [ ''The Lost Age of Innocence,'' Opinion Page, Oct. 19 ] . Soon the girl will be 8 or 9 years old, and she'll be giving her mother the answers. The time for ''mother-daughter'' talks will have long passed. RICKI ENGLANDER KOSUT Astoria, Queens

title: Now, Tax Revision For the Japanese
description: The most sweeping overhaul of Japan's tax system since World War II was proposed last week by the country's ruling party. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has made the plan one of his key objectives over the last several years.

title: TENSIONS RISE ON NORWEGIANS-SOVIET BORDER
description: Along the banks of the Pasvik River, which marks the border between Norway and the Soviet Union, military officers from both countries occasionally go fishing together. During the winter they usually hold snowmobile races, followed by a round of vodka.

title: Art
description: It is now 200 and some years since a very young Australian painter went to London and made a little stir. His name was Colin Lanceley, and he was alert, well-informed and not at all puffed up. He fitted in very well in London, which at that time was a euphoric sort of place and disposed to think well of British art in all its forms. Lanceley had a way of painting that was halfway to sculpture. It had its flat surfaces, as paintings normally do, but it also had bits that reached out into the room, almost as if they wanted to catch our sleeves. They were bright, jaunty, sociable pieces, and endearing.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kansas City, Mo.;
A New Lease For the Prairie
description: A HALF-HOUR west of downtown Kansas City, in the Kansas suburbs where development has been booming, is a pocket of land that recalls a time when much of the Middle West was a sea of rustling tall-grass prairie. That pocket of land, the Prairie Center, consists of 300 acres of woods, clear-running streams, wildflowers and wildlife. It is one of the last vestiges of the prairie that once covered the land from North Dakota to Oklahoma and from Ohio to Kansas.

title: Ecological <u4Protests <u4in <u4Soviet Halt Oil Drilling in the Baltic
description: The Soviet Government has ordered a halt in drilling for oil in the Baltic Sea off Lithuania after conservationist protests.

title: Darcy L. Chappel To Marry J.S. Ahl
description: The engagement of Darcy Lynn Chappel to Jeffrey Sanders Ahl has been announced by Mrs. Davis S. Margold of Darien, Conn., and Stratton, Vt., and Barry H. Chappel of Rowayton, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Watkins Ahl 2d, also of Rowayton.

title: NEW DIRECTOR OF AREA F.B.I. AIMS AT SPIES
description: Counter-intelligence will be the top priority of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in New York, the new director of the office said last week.

title: ABANDONED IN IRAN
description: WHIRLWIND By James Clavell. 1,147 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: TAKING A CHANCE ON LAS VEGAS
description: What better place to have a bankers' convention?'' asked Evon Emerson, a financial marketing consultant in Pensacola, Fla. ''You can take risks without fear of the consequences. In banking, the risks always have to be calculated.'' She was on her way to the 64th annual convention of the National Association of Bank Women - in Caesars Palace, Las Vegas.

title: WHY NOT COMMON SENSE?
description: Washington has a genius for complicating things, maybe because there are so many lawyers, politicians and reporters in the neighborhood, but it is now breaking the obfuscation record in the Iranian-Nicaraguan case.

title: Art
description: MORE and more in the 1980's, the exhibition catalogue is the winged messenger that brings us both word and image and makes a bottom-heavy landing on the top of our mailbox. For the publisher the catalogue has the advantage that it has a mandatory publication date and a preordained public. For the customer it means a presentation that may well smack as much of the successful trial lawyer as of the deskbound drudge. There never yet was a catalogue that did not have a case to plead.

title: THE ORDEAL OF LESTER CROWN
description: FOR THREE DAYS LAST MARCH, BURT Smith, a Defense Department hearing examiner, sat in a stark chamber in the Ballston Towers office complex of Arlington, Va., and received testimony from two dozen of the most powerful and distinguished figures in the nation -all vouching for the integrity of one man.

title: A Soviet Cult Hero
description: Craig R. Whitney's perceptive ''Letter to Gorbachev'' (Oct. 26) justly emphasizes the Soviet cult of Vladimir Vysotsky, the semi-underground balladeer who died of a heart attack, in 1980, at the age of 42.

title: MORE SOUTH AFRICAN AID SEEN
description: A SOUTH AFRICAN minister, jailed twice for his role in apartheid protests there, recently predicted that donations of foodstuffs from churches and university students in the United States and the Red Cross would ''definitely pick up again'' in the wake of the Botha Government's renewed uprooting of blacks.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MIRRORSTONE By Michael Palin. Illustrated by Alan Lee. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title:
GARDENING;
Bountiful Choices for a Cool Greenhouse
description: PERHAPS the most rewarding benefit of owning a greenhouse comes from the opportunity it affords for year-round gardening in cold climates.

title: OPERA: IN PHILADELPHIA, A NEW 'DEATH IN VENICE'
description: In his short novel ''Death in Venice,'' Thomas Mann returns to a theme that dominated his literary life - the corruptive force of passion. In this recurrent proposition, commitment outside oneself is the fatal act of surrender. It is little wonder that Mann retained his fascination for Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' until he died.

title: DANCE: HONDURAS'S FOLKLORICO GARIFUNA COMPANY
description: MANY nations have folkloric companies that seek to theatricalize regional dances. Most such troupes are charming. But many, in adapting folklore to the stage, sentimentalize it so much that the results resemble animated travel posters.

title: PLANTS FOR HOLIDAYS
description: NEW JERSEYANS may be wrapping their mufflers around their necks these mornings, but at Geerlings Greenhouses here, it is spring.

title: LEGISLATOR TO TRY AGAIN TO BROADEN STATE LAW TO PROTECT USED-CAR BUYERS
description: STATE REPRESENTATIVE JOHN J. WOODCOCK 3d has received so many complaints about new and leased cars that, he said, he will continue trying to expand the state's ''lemon law.''

title: Fighting City Hall With a Brush
description: IT was a case that stirred - yes, as the headline writers noted - a hue and cry.

title: DRIVERS IN VIRGINIA SHUN NEW CAR POOL LANES
description: Special expressway lanes designed to encourage car pooling here are carrying less traffic than a country road.

title: CALORIES AND THE CRISIS OF CAPITALISM
description: NEVER SATISFIED A Cultural History of Diets, Fantasies and Fat. By Hillel Schwartz. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
3-Point Shot: A Harmful, Unnecessary Distortion
description: COVERING Yankee baseball without a helmet these past few seasons has made Spencer Ross a little soft in the head. The only reason Spencer likes the new 3-point field goal in college basketball is that with his limited range as a youth even he could nail a few from 19 feet 9 inches. If Spencer can make a few shots, you know the line should be moved out.

title: Venice Reclaims Its Glory From the Ravages of Time and Tide
description: Decaying but never dying, shabby but still sumptuous, Venice has come to seem eternal. We expect her palaces to lean and her marbles to become cloudy. Melancholy is part of her appeal, safe as we are in the knowledge that the 1,500-year-old city, built on sand and water, is in fact as perennial as if its foundations were the hardest rock. That, however, like so much of Venice's lore, is a romantic illusion. Just 20 years ago the lagoon rose to unequaled heights, flooding, damaging, destroying. Venice, on Nov. 4, 1966, came close to obliteration, and tomorrow or next year or the year after that, a similar or worse ''high water'' may compound the earlier damage.

title: Iran Arms Sales Are Said to Damage Reagan's Credibility in Middle East
description: The secret arms sales to Iran appear to have damaged the Reagan Administration's credibility in the Middle East and worsened American relations with Jordan, Egypt, Iraq and some other Arab countries, at least temporarily.

title:
ART;
Jung as Root of Abstract Expressionism
description: WHEN the Swiss psychiatrist Carl Jung published his explanations of the creative process, the psyche and the collective consciousness, he provided source material that would prove inspiring to a number of American artists reading his works in the late 1930's.

title: Can A Big 10 Alumna Find Happiness in the Ivy League?
description: I SHOULD probably begin by explaining to you Easterners that I'm from Ohio. I was born in the shadow of the Ohio State University stadium and, although I was a girl, my father saw to it that I received the standard education of any Ohio child.

title: Egypt Accuses 33 Of Plotting Coup
description: Since President Anwar el-Sadat was assassinated in 1981 by Islamic zealots, the Egyptian Government has carefully watched fundamentalist religious organizatons such as Jihad, or Holy War. Last week, the nation's chief prosecutor accused 4 military officers and 29 civilians of plotting to overthrow the Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: DETOXIFICATION
description: Yonkers General Hospital opened its substance-abuse unit only last September, but finding that the 22 beds were filled instantly and that the waiting list was growing quickly, 14 more beds were added.

title: Charles Ponzi: A Pyramid of Postage
description: CHARLES Ponzi's ingenious thievery won him a lasting place in the rogue's hall of fame: any scheme in which the original investors are paid off with money supplied by the succeeding round of investors is now known as a Ponzi scheme.

title: SEASON OF LIGHTS, AND COMPASSION
description: Holiday throngs gathered to watch the lighting of the Christmas tree this week in Rockefeller Center, an event that, like the Thanksgiving Day parade, clicks off the beginning of Christmas in New York. It is a time when a surge of energy enlivens the city - a time of shopping, of lights, of parties, of crowds, a time for gratitude and good cheer.

title: VERMONTERS SAY 'NON!' TO A CABLE TV SWITCH
description: The French-Canadian community of northwestern Vermont will soon be able to savor a victory - in French - now that it has won a fight to bring French-language television back to the Burlington area.

title: JUDGE CLEARS POLICE ADVANCES
description: A state judge has resolved the last challenged questions on the New York City Police Department's 1984 sergeant's examination, clearing the way for the promotion of officers to fill many of the 640 vacancies in that rank within weeks, according to city officials.

title: Fun and Games for Future Financing
description: IF you want your child to learn something about finance, Santa can be of help. Holiday gift givers will find a plethora of presents - from computer games to more traditional books and ''banks'' - to teach kids about money. Following is a list of some prize-winning products, and others that have proven popular, compiled with the help of toy retailers:

title: NORTHEAST FACING LAWSUITS OVER ELEVATED OZONE LEVELS
description: Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and other locations in the Northeast will almost certainly fail to cut ozone concentrations to acceptable levels by next December, the deadline set by the Federal Government.

title: Church Disavows AIDS Work
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles today withdrew support for a program for Hispanic Americans that recommends use of condoms to prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: Co-op Meetings
description: To the Editor:

title: TRACKING JUNK BOND OWNERS
description: ASK a pension fund administrator who owns junk bonds, and he will answer that the mutual funds are big holders. Ask a mutual fund adviser the same question, and - after pointing out that the preferred term is ''high-yield'' bonds -he will confide that thrift institutions and insurance companies are the biggest holders, and that pension funds are hardly strangers to the market.

title: SERIES OF FIRES LEAVES MAINE TOWN BEWILDERED
description: In the early morning hours of Oct. 14, fire destroyed the only high school in this small blue-collar town in central Maine. It was a heavy blow to townspeople, but the loss has paled in comparison with what was to come.

title: Rogers Carries Burden Of the Redskins' Offense
description: When the offense uses a one-back system, and you're the one back, it's not to hard to figure out who assumes the ultimate responsibility for generating rushing yardage.

title: REVELATION RAYS AND PAIN STARS
description: MAUS A Survivor's Tale. By Art Spiegelman. 159 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: Cadets Defeat Middies
description: ''It was just line up and play ball,'' said Tory Crawford, the Cadet quarterback, about an Army-Navy game today that had few mysteries or innuendoes.

title: Brewster
description: OFFICIALLY, Brewster is only a part of Southeast, the town in the southeastern corner of Putnam County. But whether people live in the Village of Brewster itself or in the unincorporated areas of Brewster Hill, Brewster Heights, Dykemans, Deans Corners, Sodom or Tilly Foster, ''almost everybody says they live in Brewster,'' said Vivien Hannigan of Fowles Gallery of Homes.

title: MORE PSYCHIATRIC OUTPATIENT CARE SOUGHT
description: THE state's Department of Human Services would like to move more mental patients into the community while continuing to provide them with medication and counseling.

title: U.S. ASKED BRUNEI TO ASSIST CONTRAS
description: Brunei, an oil-rich Southeast Asian nation, agreed to a State Department request earlier this year to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, Administration officials said today, contributing several million dollars to a secret Swiss bank account run by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: MEN And Abortion
description: In his article ''The Clinic'' (About Men, Nov. 2), what is it that Michael Blumenthal refers to when he says he is ''learning . . . something of what it means to be a man''? Is it learning to feel one's age? Is it realizing regrets about one's own life? Or perhaps it is frustration at being placed at the periphery of difficult personal decisions of others we may care about. If these are the things the author has learned, they are not part ''of what it means to be a man,'' but, rather, part of what it means to be alive.

title: SCHOOL SITE DEBATED
description: MERRICK residents are becoming sharply divided on a proposal to create housing for the elderly on the grounds of Brookside Junior High School in North Merrick, which was closed in June for lack of enrollment.

title: JUST HOW SHOULD A TEACHER BE TAUGHT
description: TEACHER preparation has been a major issue since the publication of ''A Nation at Risk.'' However, there seems to be an enormous amount of confusion on the part of the public about how one prepares to become a teacher. The public seems to feel that students in education programs are taught in some kind of isolation chamber separated from the rest of the college students.

title: THEY'LL TAKE MANHATTAN
description: TWO YEARS HAD PASSED SINCE RICH-ard A. Kahan left his imperial post as chairman of three state agencies, responsible for launching the construction of office buildings, housing and hotels in New York City worth more than $3 billion. Now, on this Friday afternoon last July, the intense, barrel-chested 40-year-old found himself presiding over a small, private development company with just a single project on the drawing boards.

title: 2 EAST END MUSEUMS GETTING RENOVATIONS
description: BACKED by Federal and foundation grants, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton and Guild Hall in East Hampton are undertaking renovations aimed at bringing the two venerable East End cultural institutions up to present museum standards and expanding their services to changing and increasing year-round populations.

title: SCHOOLS CLOSE AS TAX IS REJECTED
description: About 2,200 students cleaned out their lockers Friday as classrooms closed because voters had rejected financing for the high school, junior high and four elementary schools here.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; A 'Spec Job' Beats the Odds
description: AGAINST all the odds, and in office space markets that are soft and overbuilt, some new buildings find tenants. One such building, now in the final stages of construction, is the 34-story Fox Plaza office tower in Century City, the well-known office center sandwiched between Beverly Hills and Westwood.

title: Miss Garland Is Wed to B. T. Whitman
description: The marriage of Margaret Garland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Garland Jr. of Baltimore, to Benjamin Thornley Whitman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Earle Whitman of Roxbury, Conn., took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert P. Patterson, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Shipman, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore.

title:
DINING OUT;
Whippany: On Keeping A promise
description: IT IS always gratifying when a restaurant lives up to its promise, and Il Capriccio, the plush northern Italian dining spot in Whippany, is by and large doing just that.

title: SCHOOLS USING LEASE-PURCHASE
description: GROWING numbers of school boards in New Jersey are using privatization - entering into logn-term lease-purchase contracts with banking investment houses - to get new schools or expand old ones.

title: Nassau Shift: New Job Seen for Mondello
description: THE chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party, Joseph N. Mondello, is presiding over a far-ranging change of government leadership in Nassau that is expected to result in a major new post for himself.

title: DISPUTE CLOUDING RIVER LAND'S FATE
description: As it flows south through this city and other desert communities in the Southwest, the Rio Grande nurtures a vital green ribbon of cottonwoods and willows that threads through otherwise treeless brown expanses.

title: Delaware Routed By Arkansas State
description: Rickey Jemison, a fullback, rushed for 159 yards and two touchdowns to help second-ranked Arkansas State trounce Delaware, 55-14, in a Division I-AA quarterfinal playoff today.

title: DEBT BURDEN REMAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE SERIES, SPOTLIGHT DIMS
description: PERHAPS, by now, the videotapes have been stored away. For nearly six weeks, they were played and rewound and played again, and the glorious moments were kept alive for another delicious day. The Mets won the World Series in October, and many times since.

title: Fixing the Fees Of Doctors, Too
description: Though the fiscal effects of the Reagan Administration's program of flat fees for Medicare payments to hospitals is clear - health care costs are increasing less rapidly than they have for 20 years - the impact on the quality of care for the elderly and disabled is a matter of growing debate. Now White House officials are considering going a step further.

title: VOLUNTEER HANDS OUT GROCERIES AND TAKES IN SOME OBSERVATIONS
description: IT is Wednesday morning at this Congregational church in Westchester. I have come to help fill grocery bags for the hungry. My local volunteer organization was asked to send people, and this is my first day.

title: 'Reckless Disregard'
description: To the Editor:

title: REFUNDS FOR FANS OF 'FLOYD'
description: FANS of Uncle Floyd say that, although they have lost the fight to keep his television show on the New Jersey Network of the Public Broadcasting Authority, they have won a political war whose spoils are thousands of dollars in donations.

title: Pamela Callander And S. P. Fulton Exchange Vows
description: Pamela Anne Callander, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Callander of Oldwick, N.J., was married in Stanhope, N.J., yesterday to Stephen Powell Fulton, the son of Donald R. Fulton of La Jolla, Calif., and Celeste P. Fulton of Playa del Rey, Calif. The Rev. Virginia Jackson-Adams, United Methodist chaplain at Drew University, performed the ceremony at the Church in Waterloo Village.

title: Drug Defendant Slain in Brooklyn
description: The body of Gaetano Mazzara, one of 20 defendants in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial, was found in a garbage bag in Brooklyn last week, five days after he was reported missing from his New Jersey home.

title: POLAND SAYS NON-COMMUNISTS WILL JOIN AN ADVISORY COUNCIL
description: The Polish Government reached agreement today with lay Roman Catholics and scholars to create a Consultative Council giving them an advisory voice unusual in a Soviet-bloc country.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID FIGHT DETENTIONS
description: An alliance of civil rights movements and activists, many of them whites, opened a campaign this week for the release of young blacks from detention.

title: Lyons
description: To the Editor: We were in Lyons this past summer and can attest to the charm and beauty of the city and to the excellent service and cuisine at Leon de Lyon.

title: The Leg In The Christmas Stocking: What We Learned From Jokes
description: OUR parents would have sooner left us out of Christmas than leave us out of a joke. They explained a joke to us while they were still laughing at it; they tore a still-kicking joke apart so we could see how it worked. When we got the first Tom Lehrer album in 1954, when I was 9, Mother went through it with me, cut by cut, explaining.

title: Notable Paperbacks
description: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1985 Christmas issue. It includes novels, stories, biography, memoirs, history, essays and science. THE ABANDONMENT OF THE JEWS: America and the Holocaust, 1941-1945, by David S. Wyman. (Pantheon, $8.95.) An inquiry into the question: Where was America during the Holocaust? THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.50.) A Baltimore travel writer, drifting into lonely eccentricity after his son dies and his wife leaves him, becomes involved with an animal trainer.

title: HOW ISRAEL'S ECONOMY GOT HOOKED ON SELLING ARMS ABROAD
description: ISAIAH hoped it would be different.

title: America's Fickle Tastes
description: SUPPOSE SOME-one had announced 10 years ago that a mixture of wine and fruit juice and soda water, sold in small bottles in packs, just like beer, would become a marketing miracle in the 1980's? Even longtime veterans of the spirits industry would have laughed or, worse, yawned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: A SMALLER DURAN DURAN FINDS DISILLUSIONMENT
description: Can Duran Duran grow up by shrinking? With just three out of five orginal members still in Duran Duran, that's the fondest hope of the British band, which enjoyed teenybopper frenzy throughout the 1980's, selling millions of records in the process. And by casting themselves in video clips as romantic, fashion-plate playboys romping through glamorous locales, the five founding members of Duran Duran became prize pinups of the video era.

title: Sweet Memories of a Bitter Rivalry
description: FOR most Redskin fans, beating Dallas at R.F.K. Stadium is the highlight of the season. For others, beating the Giants is.

title: Maggie Fay Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tate Fay of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maggie Reynolds Fay to E. Merritt McDonough Jr., a son of Mr. McDonough and Judith G. McDonough, both of West Hartford, Conn. Miss Fay and her fiance both graduated with the class of '83 from Boston College. She is an assistant treasurer at the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York and he an assistant vice president at Alexander & Alexander, insurance brokers in Hartford.

title: 6 Riot in Australian Jail
description: Six inmates set fire to their cells in a Brisbane jail on Friday, and then shouted abuse at guards from the roof for four hours until the police forced them down with tear gas, officials said. The inmates were protesting overcrowding and demanding more contact with their families.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Worcester Bans Cheer With Spirits

title: THE N.R.C. STRUGGLES TO FILL A NEW ROLE IN A CHANGED WORLD
description: EVER since the Three Mile Island accident, the nuclear industry has been pointing to a silver lining in the fallout: Very little radiation escaped from the building, even though the accident destroyed most of the power plant's nuclear core.

title: 3 DROWN IN VIETNAM FLOODS
description: Floods in southern vietnam caused by heavy rains drowned three people, inundated several towns and burst two dams, the Hanoi radio reported. The radio, monitored here, said rain on Tuesday and Wednesday had swept away a truck with three people inside in Quang Nam-Danag Province and left the town of Quang Ngai under as much as six feet of water. Other towns were also affected, and in Phu Khanh Province, two dams collapse.

title: BUDGET PANEL APPROVES PILOT PROGRAM ON HOMELESS
description: COUNTY legislators stepped boldly into the crisis over the homeless last week, creating a $1 million experimental program to subsidize the rents of tenants facing eviction. By doing so, they hope to avoid the higher costs of providing shelter for the tenants in hotels and motels.

title: In a New Tower, a Waiting Rental Strategy Works
description: SHEARMAN & STERLING, one of New York City's largest law firms, has contracted to take 11 floors of space at 599 Lexington Avenue, pushing the 50-story office tower over the halfway point in filling its 917,000 square feet of space.

title: AMERICA'S BLACK ARTISTS ARE SEEN IN NEW LIGHT
description: BLACK American artists of the 20th century as teachers of, students of and partners of white artists, are the focus of an exhibition that will open Saturday at the Jamaica Arts Center in Queens.

title: FOUNDATION HELPS RENEW CITY AREAS
description: Six years ago the Ford Foundation and six business partners founded an organization with a forgettable name but a formidable goal: to provide loans and grants to help revitalize blighted neighborhoods, working with fledgling community associations.

title: 33 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Miss Clapp Weds Jeffrey W. Earls
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Beard Clapp, the daughter of Mrs. Russell Adams Clapp of Southport and Stuart, Fla., and the late Mr. Clapp, to Jeffrey Wilder Earls, a son of Mrs. Alexander Moore of Cincinnati and Yemassee, S.C., and the late John Vincent Earls. The Rev. M. Jennings Matheson officiated.

title: A Timeless Collection of Skulduggery
description: ALTHOUGH the annals of business are replete with rogues and rascals, most are quickly forgotten. But every so often, a scoundrel walks upon the stage with such grandeur and audacity that he captures the public's imagination and wins a prominent place in the history of the errant.

title: Gun-Control Struggle
description: With both houses of Congress coming under Democratic control next month, advocates of stricter control on firearms control plan a strong push soon after the 100th Congress convenes.

title: The Public's Secret Weapon vs. Boesky
description: DID the Securities and Exchange Commission let Ivan F. Boesky off too lightly? Many people are disgusted by the idea of Mr. Boesky waltzing away from the scandal with the bulk of his personal fortune apparently intact, the $100 million he paid in fines and illicit profits notwithstanding. And Wall Street was outraged that the S.E.C. permitted Mr. Boesky to quietly unload $440 million in stocks from the estimated $2 billion portfolio he controlled. This allowed him to avoid the substantial losses he would have incurred when the Dow Jones index plummeted 43 points on the news of the scandal.

title: MAYAN INDIANS' PLIGHT LEADS TO PLAYS
description: A CHANCE collaboration between a Jewish playwright haunted by the plight of Central American peasants and a Dominican nun concerned with social justice is behind the drama to be presented Friday at Caldwell College.

title: Jane Adams Saul To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Saul of Haverford, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Adams Saul, to Jonathan Gregory Kraus, a son of Conrad J. Kraus of Reading, Pa., and the late Mary Ellen Kraus. The wedding is planned for May 30.

title: Slaying of L.I. Couple Brings 50-Year Term
description: A 26-year-old resident of the Shinnecock Indian Reservation in Southampton has been sentenced to 50 years to life in prison in the murder of a couple who walked in on him during a burglary.

title: NUT MUSEUM EXCLUDED FROM VACATION GUIDE
description: THESE are hard times for Elizabeth Tashjian of Old Lyme. Vandals have stolen the four-foot-high statue of a squirrel that stood outside and indicated to visitors that they had arrived at the Nut Museum, Miss Tashjian's aging mansion tucked away in the woods less than five minutes from Interstate 95.

title: SHARP RISE IN TRUCK CRASHES PROMPTS ACTION ACROSS U.S.
description: A rise in accidents and violations involving trucks is causing concern across the nation among the police, experts on safety and insurance and officials of the trucking industry.

title: BIG BAND: BUDDY RICH AT BLUE NOTE
description: ON the surface, the Buddy Rich Band, which is playing at the Blue Note through tonight as the final entry in the club's current Big Band Festival, is much the same as the Buddy Rich Band of the last 20 years - aggressive, eruptive and focused on Mr. Rich's drumming.

title: THEY'RE SWELL, THEY'RE WITTY
description: THE COMPLETE LYRICS OF LORENZ HART Edited by Dorothy Hart and Robert Kimball. Illustrated. 317 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $40. SONDHEIM & CO. By Craig Zadan. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.95. THE MUSICAL THEATRE A Celebration. By Alan Jay Lerner. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $24.95.

title: NBC MOVES FOR ACQUITTAL IN NEWTON LAWSUIT
description: Both sides have rested their cases in the singer Wayne Newton's defamation suit against NBC, and a lawyer has asked the presiding judge to acquit the network.

title:
TO START WITH...;
MOLLYCODDLING BATS
description: When real-estate entrepreneurs Thomas Kennedy and Michael Tucker leased 135 acres in Glen Park, N.Y., to develop a hydroelectric plant in October of 1984, they knew all about the tax breaks available for their $40 million project. But they didn't know much about the hibernation habits of Indiana bats. Now they do.

title: MARYLAND BISHOPS' ECONOMIC PLAN SEEN AS MODEL
description: In a move that Roman Catholic officials hope will be repeated around the nation, the nine bishops of Maryland yesterday released a plan for putting into practice in their state the pastoral letter on the economy issued by the American Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Celebritiy Cult
description: THE ADAGE THAT THERE IS NO place like home is truer today than ever. Your home, along with everyone else's. Indeed, the subject of home design is no longer simply a casual topic of conversation; now, it has become something of a spectator sport. As the number of books and magazines devoted to interiors, architecture, gardening and the decorative arts has increased in recent years, people are transfixed by page after page of luscious photographs, enjoying the fun of seeing how others live.

title: Purcell Resigns For Cable TV Job
description: Francis T. Purcell, re-elected as Nassau County Executive a year ago, announced last week that he was resigning to become a television commentator.

title: WHEN RISK IS IRRESISTIBLE
description: THE HELICOPTER CORKSCREWS down to a plateau high in the snow-covered peaks of British Columbia. You stumble out, dragging your skis. Then the blades of the copter accelerate - a deafening drumbeat in your ears - and the copter climbs toward the sun. The sound dies quickly.

title: PRESIDENT ADMITS FLAWS IN PURSUING SECRET IRAN POLICY
description: President Reagan, adopting a highly personal and apologetic tone, said today that the execution of his secret policy initiatives toward Iran was ''flawed,'' and that ''mistakes were made.''

title: FIGHTING 'CITY HALL' AND WINNING
description: I read your article about the successful campaign residents of Yonkers, Hastings and Greenburgh waged to prompt the State Department of Transportation to reconsider their plans to turn the Saw Mill River Parkway into what many of us would call an ''expressway'' [ ''Victory on Parkway Issue Leads to New Watchdog Role,'' Nov. 9 ] .

title: Dana Kroll Is Engaged To Joel D. Weingarten
description: The engagement of Dana Kroll and Joel David Weingarten has been announced by the future bride's parents, Marilyn Kroll of Astoria, Queens, and Eliezer L. Kroll of Jerusalem. A June wedding is planned.

title: Holocaust Museum Receives $3 Million
description: The Helena Rubinstein Foundation has contributed $3 million toward the building of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington honoring the six million Jews and other victims of the Nazis.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS UNION MARKS 50 YEARS
description: IN 1971, this city's teachers struck for the second time in two years. And for the second consecutive year, the Board of Education responded with legal action.

title: FROM PAGE TO STAGE: HOW A PLAYWRIGHT GUARDS HIS VISION
description: Room 407 at the New School on West 12th Street in Greenwich Village is a long way from Broadway. In fact, it's a long way from anything resembling a working theater anywhere. There are no sets, no lights, no anything to create a theatrical illusion. It is a classroom with hard seats, fluorescent lighting and a green blackboard where the cyclorama should be. It's where the play I'm working on had its first hearing not long ago.

title: A Skyline Stage for New York Cranes
description: ON any working day, as many as 200 cranes are flitting lightly above the Manhattan skyline, swooping, diving, arching, darting, climbing, dipping and pirouetting, their booms, like batons, setting the tempo for the symphony of construction below.

title: Nancy Kestenbaum Is Wed
description: Nancy V. Kestenbaum, a vice president and director of group advertisings sales for Penthouse International Ltd., a publishing concern in New York, was married last night to William L. Moses, chairman of William Moses Inc., an international trading corporation in Washington.

title: OUTGUESSING THE MARKET
description: ''WARNING: FINANCIAL SHAKEOUT AHEAD! ALL BETS ARE OFF. All forecasts you've read about stocks, gold, inflation, interest rates, etc. could all be radically wrong. Because a new element has entered the economic arena. One that could throw the most intelligent forecasts completely askew. THAT NEW ELEMENT IS AIDS.'' THIS CHEERY message was emblazoned in orange and black on a fat envelope that arrived uninvited in some 300,000 mailboxes last summer. Inside was a 16-page single-spaced invitation to subscribe to Predictions, a $78-a-year monthly investment letter that had been warning that acquired immune deficiency syndrome could trigger renewed inflation -and boost stocks like Beverly Enterprises, an operator of health-care facilities.

title: Terry Attwood Bride Of Thomas Beckmann
description: At the Reformed Church of Bronxville (N.Y.) yesterday, Terry Jo Attwood and Thomas J. R. Beckmann were married by the Rev. Dr. Robert Bedingfield. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James A. Attwood of Bronxville and Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Beckmann of Bedford, N.Y.

title: FREEPORT ABANDONING FAILED PEDESTRIAN MALL
description: More than a decade ago, village officials decided to compete with the growing number of shopping malls in the area by banning vehicles from Main Street in the aging downtown and turning it into a pedestrian mall.

title: COUNTY INVENTORY FINDS WILDLIFE FLOURISHING
description: AS Westchester's human population grows, the wildlife population is keeping pace. While some species have declined as their habitats have been turned into houses and shopping centers, others have flourished, growing in numbers and vigor. A wildlife inventory being conducted by the County Planning Department attempts to list the various forms of wildlife and their habitats so that municipalities can plan development accordingly.

title: Indiana Turns Back Kentucky, 71-66
description: Steve Alford, Daryl Thomas and Joe Hillman made two free throws each in the final 42 seconds, preserving Indiana's 71-66 victory over Kentucky today.

title: INTRIGUING CHINESE IN WESTPORT
description: NOT in name, decor or menu is Panda Pavilion a clone of any of the Sichuan-Hunan-Beijing-Cantonese restaurants that have multiplied in Fairfield County in the last 10 years. Westport's newest Chinese restaurant is very much itself, with paintings of playful pandas setting the stage for meals that offer quite a few surprises.

title: Japan Maps a Plan To Alter Tax Laws
description: Japan plans to overhaul its tax system as a means of spurring its economy. Among the changes, which take some cues from the United States tax bill, are tax cuts for individuals and businesses, abolition of tax-free savings accounts and a new sales tax. The moves, which have been in the works for some time, are mostly at the behest of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who has been under pressure for years to balance his nation's needs with those of its trading partners.

title: Catholics May Curtail Child Care
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which has often clashed with the city over issues of doctrine and legality, may cut back its foster care services rather than comply with a court order requiring, among other things, that children be given ''meaningful access'' to birth control.

title: For Music Publishing, Technology Means Hard Times
description: Serious music publishers are in trouble. Like breweries and piano makers, they have become fewer and larger. Those who have survived face a disquieting future.

title:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS;
Is Santa Claus Really St. Nicholas Or Just Some Jolly, Beert Old Elf?
description: ''T WAS the night before Christmas,'' reported Dr. Clement Clarke Moore excitedly, ''when, all through the house, / Not a creature was stirring . . .'' Christmas Eve of what, according to my calculations, must have been the year 1821, came the first recorded sighting in the continental United States of a certain now-familiar seasonal phenomenon. Dr. Moore, professor of divinity at the General Theological Seminary, New York, and therefore a witness of impeccable integrity, later recorded how he had been privileged to observe the touchdown on his snowy roof of a flying sleigh, a team of reindeer and their fur-clad, heavily bearded, sack-toting driver. Dr. Moore was no slouch at identification:

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN ARREST ON TV PROGRAM
description: Charges of cocaine possession have been dismissed against a woman who was jailed for three days after her arrest was nationally telecast in a live report for a syndicated program.

title: MISS SAUNDERS WEDS DR. R. A. RASKIN
description: Arlene Saunders, an operatic soprano, was married in New York last night to Dr. Raymond A. Raskin, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in private practice in New York. Judge Shirley Fingerhood of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the home of Constance Emmerich, a friend of the couple.

title: WGBH in Boston Tests Digital FM Broadcasting
description: A small group of listeners in and around Boston is getting a taste of what music broadcasting may be like in the 1990's. They are tuning in to a series of experimental transmissions from WGBH, a television station widely known as the originator of ''Masterpiece Theater'' and other acclaimed PBS programs. But in addition to its TV facilities, WGBH also operates an FM station, and it is this unusual combination that enables it to presage the shape of things to come, with the first digital music broadcasts in the United States.

title: Selling a Park To Highest Bidder
description: AS a park, it was not much - a 30-by-100-foot tract known as the Bond Street Park - but Providence, R.I., put it on the auction block because it was run down and the city no longer wanted to maintain it.

title: The Allure of the Walkman, Or How to Do 2 Things at the Same Time
description: TEN years ago all those runners or commuters plugged into their Walkman stereos would have drawn puzzled second glances. Today, they are commonplace.

title: Iceland
description: To the Editor: Having spent a week traveling around Iceland this past June, I found Katha Pollitt's article interesting and accurate.

title: ZERO ROYALTY
description: THE FORTUNES OF MITCHELL KENNERLEY, BOOKMAN By Matthew J. Bruccoli. Illustrated. 337 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Italian Fare in a Historic Setting
description: FOR a number of years the historic Willet Titus House in Roslyn has been occupied by restaurants. The latest, Il Pavone, has done a felicitously low-key job of decorating, with walls in soft pink, gauzy curtains at the window and formal, traditional appointments. It is a feminine setting, suggestive of the Victorian era and far more effective a scheme than in the past.

title: WITNESS SAYS FILM DIRECTOR IGNORED WARNING
description: The director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' told his script supervisor to ''shut up'' when she warned him that filming a battle scene with special effects explosions and a low-flying helicopter appeared ''too dangerous,'' a witness has testified.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Along 9W, a Rare Tract for Development
description: IN the 1950's and 1960's, a strip of Route 9W from the the George Washington Bridge 11 miles north to the New York State border emerged as one of New Jersey's early growth corridors.

title: BALANCHINE VERISON IN STAMFORD
description: THE ''Nutcracker'' ballet choreographed by George Balanchine decades ago for his New York City Ballet will be performed by the American Ballet Company of Stamford Dec. 18-24 at the Palace Theater.

title: U.S. SENATE AIDE IS TO BE MARRIED TO MISS WILKINS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Wilkens of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Ann Wilkens to Christopher Van Hollen Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Hollen of McLean, Va.

title: Where To Put Your Feet Up
description: The vast majority of skiers must travel to get to the mountains - for a day, a weekend, a week or more - and many of them making plans that include accommodations are weighing the choices for this year's trip. Will it be a family condominium with Jacuzzi and pool and shops nearby? A grand place with three restaurants and a nightclub under one roof? Or a modest lodge, perhaps an old-fashioned, rustic inn?

title: SUCCESS OF BROOKLYN ACADEMY STRAINS RELATIONS WITH HOTLE FOR HOMELESS
description: They are right across the street from each other, but the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which has become one of the city's leading showcases for the avant-garde, and the Brooklyn Arms Hotel, which houses more than 200 homeless families, are separated by a gulf of distrust.

title: MIRACLE MERCHANT
description: THE PARTY LAST AUGUST AT THE banker's villa overlooking the Lake of Zurich had been under way for more than an hour when a tall, sturdy woman arrived, apologizing profusely in a whispery voice. She disappeared for a moment, then returned, her schoolmarmish bun of silver-blond hair transformed into a jaunty ponytail, her blue eyes framed by a fresh coating of midnight blue mascara. A silver and gold Cartier bangle lightened the severity of her navy wool dress. Chantal Simone Burnison, president and C.E.O. of the Los Angeles-based Chantal Pharmaceutical Corporation, was ready to join the other guests.

title: THE NEXT LEAP IN COMPUTERS
description: IT IS EARLY MORNING IN CAM-bridge, Mass., and W. Daniel Hillis, the 30-year-old founding scientist of Thinking Machines Corporation, is staring wearily at a blank video display screen. He enters a few commands on a keyboard and an image of black and white lines resembling a dart board appears on the screen. As Hillis punches the keys, a sleek, black, five-foot glasslike cube in a room down the hall - a computer designed by Hillis and known as the Connection Machine - is punctuated by thousands of tiny red lights that flash frantically in no discernible pattern.

title: Much Development, But No Loss
description: I live in an area that once was very suburban; now we have a double standard in Great Neck. There are new apartment houses, new malls and, of course, much more traffic.

title: On a Tropical Island Invaded by Smokestacks, a Fight of Save a Lagoon
description: Two decades ago, in the rush for development dollars, few obstacles were placed in the way of two huge industrial plants on the unspoiled south shore of St. Croix, the southernmost of the three Virgin Islands belonging to the United States.

title: GUIDE FOR LEARNING-DISABLED
description: A NEW guidebook for learning-disabled young adults offers information on opportunities available after graduation from high school and on major programs in colleges and vocational schools.

title: At the White House, Suspense, Surprise and Even Optimism
description: DONALD T. REGAN, the chief of staff, was sitting in his office in the West Wing of the White House last Tuesday, examining the vagaries of the President's popularity polls as well as the stock market. As the uproar continued over the sale of arms to Iran and the diversion of millions of dollars to Nicaraguan rebels, the poll reports reaching Mr. Regan showed a sharp drop in the President's popularity -decisive confirmation that the Reagan White House was in its worst crisis.

title: IVY LEAGUERS IN THE N.F.L.
description: IN THEIR BATTLE for a spot in the National Football League playoffs, the Dallas Cowboys have received help from an unlike-ly source - Yale. Jeff Rohrer, class of '82, is the team's starting right line-backer. ''He's really been doing the job for us,'' said Gil Brandt, the Cowboys' vice president of personnel devel-opment.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DRIVEN
description: THERE are people for whom the car is - well, a car. They use it to get to work, take the children to school, to move from Point A to Point B on summer vacation.

title: Stacy Robinson: A Player Who Won't 'Hi, Mom'
description: THE phone was jangling as soon as Stacy Robinson got home from San Francisco.

title: E.P.A. Sent Back To the Calculator
description: On gasoline conservation as on many other matters, the Reagan Administration has long argued that the marketplace, not the Government, should set standards. Last week, a Federal appeals court panel in Washington disagreed, holding that the Environmental Protection Agency erred last year when it retroactively changed fuel efficiency formulas in a way proposed by the Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation.

title: Newark Theater Is Planning A Busy Season
description: WHEN Osayande Baruti was asked to join the staff of the Theater of Universal Images - in public relations - he didn't think he'd wind up running the theater.

title: Data Bank: December 7, 1986
description: THE ECONOMY Gross National ProductIII Q'86II Q'86Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions$3,687.3$3,661.4$3,603.8 Real G.N.P. title: SOME OF THE Founding Fathers Vigorously Opposed Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Iranian Calls for Hostage-Arms Deal
description: A key Iranian leader involved in the secret arms negotiations with the United States said today that Iran was still willing to intercede for the release of American hostages in return for weapons.

title: Stop The Prose- I Want to Get Off
description: THE first light verse I ever heard was alarming, but fortunately I didn't know a word of English at the time, so was not distressed. It was the one that begins, ''Rock-a-bye-baby on the tree top,'' and ends with that nasty business of the breaking bough hurling baby, cradle and all, down to earth.

title: TEA IN THE AFTERNOON
description: When, at the beginning of Edith Wharton's ''House of Mirth,'' the heroine Lily Bart misses her afternoon train at Grand Central Terminal, a gentleman friend comes to the rescue with ''Shall we go over to Sherry's for a cup of tea?''

title: NASA CHIEF MIGHT NOT TAKE PART IN DECISIONS ON BOOSTER CONTRACTS
description: Dr. James C. Fletcher, the NASA Administrator who awarded the contract for the space shuttle rockets that led to the Challenger disaster, says that he will ''seriously consider'' removing himself from all future determinations on shuttle booster contracts.

title: Special Publication On Fund Is Available
description: On Nov. 30, The New York Times published a special supplement in recognition of the 75th anniversary of the Neediest Cases Fund. Copies of the supplement may be obtained by writing to Fred M. Hechinger, president of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.

title: TOWNS SEEKING 'LAND BANKING' TAX FUND TO PRESERVE OPEN SPACE
description: AS development continues to surge throughout the state, a number of towns are looking to a concept called land banking for help in saving open space.

title: Help for Bettors
description: NOW that a second court has thrown out a suit by bettors stemming from the wrongful disqualification of Allumeuse in the second race at Saratoga last Aug. 2, the New York Racing Association is continuing to voice support for legislative remedies. ''I think it is becoming apparent,'' said Gerard J. McKeon, president of the N.Y.R.A., ''that there is little legal recourse in this matter.'' One such bill, introduced by State Senator Martin Knorr, Republican from Glendale, Queens, would reimburse those who had wagered on Allumeuse from state funds realized through uncashed tickets.

title:
ANTIQUES;
The Subtleties of Oriental Rugs
description: NO LESS than the glyphs on an Egyptian monument, a Mayan stele or the pictorial expressions woven into Navajo textiles, Oriental rugs project both message and image to those skilled enough to interpret the symbolism.

title: No Sense of Urgency in Anti-Drug Talk
description: ON the day before the start of the World Series, Congress climaxed a great gush of nationwide concern over drug abuse by passing a $1.7 billion anti-drug act. The timing was ironic because baseball, the year before, had generated probably more talk about cocaine than any other outlet or industry, and yet, as this year's season ended and the World Series began, talk about drugs in baseball had become virtually non-existent.

title: Kristina Muller-Eberhard Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Ursula Muller-Eberhard of New York and Dr. Hans Joachiem Muller-Eberhard of La Jolla, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Kristina Muller-Eberhard to Michael Dermod Perry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Osgood Endecott Perry of Wilton, Conn. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Article 524586 -- No Title
description: Paul Mellon, the philanthropist, has made a $10 million gift to Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn., for the construction of a science center.

title: A Joy Not Shared
description: LAST YEAR, WHEN I WAS IN Japan, I sought out Kenzaburo Oe, the stormy, controversial novelist whose book ''A Personal Matter,'' I admire. I had written him from America, but Oe was not an easy catch. Notorious for resolute protection of his privacy, he did not, at first, respond. Then word retubned that Oe had not granted an interview for months, that he was hard at work on essays about America and did not wish to be disturbed.

title: SHOPPERS SNAP UP DEDUCTIONS
description: CONSUMERS have been moving up their purchases of automobiles, boats, computer systems, home appliances and other expensive items in order to take advantage of the sales tax deduction that will be eliminated next month under the Federal tax revision program.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: THE REV. JERRY FALWELL said Hustler magazine had attacked him from ''the very pits of hell.'' The sexually explicit magazine and its publisher, Larry Flynt, argued that what had been published was ''not to be taken seriously.''

title: THE MASTER OF THE FAST LANE AND MENACE TO ALL
description: LAST week I almost ran off the road in my little Volkswagen Bug, forced into the predicament by a man driving a BMW and talking on the telephone. Not a particularly slow driver, nor a poor one, I was simply not going as fast as he wanted to go, which my untrained eye judged to be close to 75 miles an hour.

title: 'Men, Creating Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRANS-ATLANTIC PRODUCER CALLS THE TUNE
description: Opening night of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' on Oct. 9 sparked with a rare electricity on both sides of the footlights at Her Majesty's Theater in London: Barely out of sight in the wings, a nerve-racked Phantom watched jealously as Christine, his reluctant protege, sang. The veteran director Harold Prince scanned faces in the audience for evidence to suggest whether his latest multimillion-dollar extravaganza would hit or miss.

title: Falling Through an Insurance Gap
description: WHEN WE went to get out the silver last spring for the first time since Thanksgiving, it was gone.

title: WATER PIPES IN WINTER: THE BIG CHILL CAN MEAN BIG TROUBLE
description: FROZEN water pipes can burst and cause damage in an unoccupied or unheated home, but they can also do so in a home that is heated and occupied.

title: 'Mosquito Coast,' Where Is Thy Sting?
description: ''F orget it, Louis. No Civil War picture ever made a nickel,'' Irving Thalberg reportedly said to Louis B. Mayer on the occasion of their turning down ''Gone With the Wind.'' This anecdote, recounted in ''City of Nets,'' Otto Friedrich's fascinating compendium of Hollywood lore, is of a type much more likely to surface than its polar opposite, the bad-luck story of how an unworkable film project actually did find its way to the screen. Stories of the latter sort might reveal a lot more about the movie-making process and its attendant logic than tales about opportunities not taken.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAKING HAY. By Verlyn Klinkenborg. Illustrated. 157 pages. Nick Lyons Books. $14.95. VERLYN KLINKENBORG grew up in a small town in Iowa. Though most of his relatives were farmers, his father and mother took up teaching and nursing, respectively, and he himself wandered further afield to get a Ph.D. in English at Princeton and wind up teaching at Fordham University.

title: ENSNARED AND RETURNED: CHINA'S MIGRANT YOUNG
description: A siren sounded at 2:45 P.M., as it does every day, and two buses slowly rolled from beneath a British flag to beneath a Chinese one.

title: Misuse of Motions by Lawyers Slows the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: ETHICS PANEL DID TOO LITTLE, SOME ON IT SAY
description: The special commission appointed by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to recommend ways to prevent municipal corruption is completing its work with nearly half of its members protesting that the panel could have - and should have - done much more.

title: Tom Wolfe Wins Medal
description: Tom Wolfe, the author of ''The Right Stuff'' and many other books, has won the Washington Irving Medal for Literary Excellence, given by the St. Nicholas Society. Douglas Fairbanks Jr. won the society's Medal of Merit. Members of the society, founded by Washington Irving in 1835 to preserve the historical and literary heritage of the City of New York, are descendants of people who lived in New York State before 1785.

title: CLUCKING OVER IRAN
description: Some of them acknowledge that their first reaction was a kind of guilty satisfaction.

title: DRIFTING APART: A LOOK AT HOW RELATIONSHIPS END
description: The word that Dr. Diane Vaughan seeks to add to the everyday vocabulary of human relationships is ''uncoupling,'' the process by which two people who have been living together find that they are drifting apart. ''Uncoupling occurs in a regular, patterned way, a transition through a series of fairly predictable stages,'' said Dr. Vaughan, an assistant professor of sociology at Boston College.

title: THE UNVEILING OF TIP IN OIL
description: The official portrait of Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will be unveiled at ceremonies Tuesday morning in the House chamber, followed by a luncheon in the Capitol's Statuary Hall in honor of the retiring Massachusetts Democrat.

title: Group's Husky Oil Deal Worries Hong Kong
description: When Li Ka-shing and some of his associates bought a stake in Husky Oil in Canada last week, it had reverberations in Hong Kong, which is nervous about capital flight.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAIDERS VS. SEAHAWKS, at Seattle, 9 P.M. (TV - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.) TENNIS NABISCO MASTERS, final, at Madison Square Garden, 8 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 8 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Vassar at N.Y.U. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M.) Columbia at Lafayette, (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 8 P.M.) Cornell at Syracuse, (Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (TV - MSG, 12:30 A.M.

title: END OF BOESKY'S FIRM MAY BE NEAR
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator who traded stocks on illegal insider information, will, for all practical purposes, go out of business this Friday, according to Wall Street sources.

title: BRITISH GAS OFFERING
description: British Gas P.L.C. said its stock offering, the world's biggist, attracted 4.5 million applications.

title: Police Investigate Shutoff Of Oxygen Flow to Incubators
description: The Denver police said today that they had expanded their investigation into an incident in which oxygen was shut off to nursery incubators at Children's Hospital.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales November Friday Producer Prices November Inventory-Sales Ratio October

title: BASS STAKE IN HERITAGE
description: An investment group led by Ronert M. Bass of Forth Worth has purchased 5.8 percent of Heritage Communications Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of Friday, the Bass group said that it bought the Heritage shares for investment purposes, ''without any view to control or influence management'' of the Des Moines-based cable television system operator.

title: ENTANGLED SAUDI WHO LIVES LIKE KING
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi Arabian billionaire who built his reputation and his fortune on financial wheeling and dealing from Salt Lake City to the Sudan, has found himself in an arms game with higher stakes than he may have bargained for.

title: ADAPTING IN DUCK BLINDS
description: A brisk southwest wind with rain in its teeth swept off the ocean and across the barrier beach to a field where we stumbled about in the pre-dawn darkness trying to rebuild a duck blind with water-soaked bales of hay.

title: BASEMENT SYNAGOGUE CAUSES A CLASH IN ROCKLAND
description: Rabbi Solomon Rottenberg left his home in Brooklyn last spring and retired to a ranch house in this wooded hamlet in Rockland County that has often seen tensions between Orthodox Jews and their neighbors.

title: ANOTHER DAY IN SURGERY
description: IN the hours before the Giants collided with the Redskins, one headline billed it as a ''monumental'' showdown between two 11-2 teams with first place in the National Conference East at stake. But the Giants' 24-14 domination turned out to be almost surgical. Another day in the operating room for these Giants, who deserve to be acclaimed as the National Football League's best team this season. And at his locker later, Phil Simms displayed the casual confidence that permeates this Giants team.

title: ROAD PLAN, CITY LIGHTS AND VIEWS
description: In 1866, a Colorado trapper called Uncle Dick Wootton built a toll road on the Santa Fe Trail and began charging passing travelers: $1 for a wagon and 25 cents for a horse and rider.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Murder Will Out
description: Cynicism, mendacity, secrecy:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1986
description: The Economy

title: HONDURAS'S ATTACK IS SEEN AS A GESTURE TO TWO AUDIENCES
description: The Honduran Government's decision to attack Nicaraguan troops operating inside Honduras appears to be a political gesture aimed both at the Sandinistas and at Honduran public opinion, according to political analysts in Honduras reached by telephone tonight.

title: Catching Up
description: * Whether Britt Burns will pitch in the major leagues again is a question that no one, not even the 27-year-old left-hander who underwent major hip surgery in May, can answer at the moment. The Yankees, who a year ago traded with the Chicago White Sox to acquire Burns, who won 18 games in 1985 but missed all of last season, say through General Manager Woody Woodward that they are ''not optimistic his hip can take the pounding that comes with delivering pitches.'' The club said reports from Dr. John Bonamo, the team physician, ''are not good.'' Dr. William Petty, who performed the surgery after cautioning Burns that resuming his career was ''not a good idea,'' says that Burns has healed well and has full walking capabilities, but ''it will be some time before we know if he will be able to pitch again.''

title: MUSIC: COSMOPOLITAN GROUP
description: THE Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra is one of New York's better occasional ensembles, and, on Saturday afternoon, the group offered polished and professional readings of Milhaud's ''Suite Francaise,'' Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor (Op. 64) and Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 in A (Op. 92) at Town Hall, under the direction of Stephen Simon.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Among the perfect games pitched in the major leagues, has there ever been one where the opposing pitcher also had a perfect game going into the seventh, eighth or even ninth inning?

title: Murdoch Bid Is Challenged
description: Foreign Minister Bill Hayden today called for an investigation of Rupert Murdoch's effort to acquire Australia's largest newspaper chain.

title: CONCERT: Y SYMPHONY PERFORMS 'PULCINELLA'
description: THE Y Chamber Symphony gave us an unusual chance to hear all of Stravinsky's ''Pulcinella'' Saturday night - not simply the familiar suite assembled by the composer in 1922 but all 18 numbers of the original ballet music written two years earlier.

title: 10 Are Killed in Fights At South African Mine
description: In a second night of factional fighting, 10 black miners were killed and 21 wounded at the world's second-largest gold mine, the mine's management said today.

title: CHEMICAL IS MOVED OUT AFTER DISPUTE IN MIDWEST
description: The last truckloads of a cancer-causing chemical that has heated up municipal tempers in two states have finally rolled on for reprocessing in Liberty, Mo., about 20 miles to the north.

title: MOZAMBICANS TRYING TO FLEE WAR HORRORS
description: The rebels appeared in the shadows of evening, the old woman recalled, and demanded to know if her husband worked for the Marxist Government. He insisted that he did not, but the intruders stabbed him to death.

title: Ernest G. Swigert Dies at 94; Led Group of Manufacturers
description: Ernest Goodnough Swigert, founder of the Hyster Company, manufacturers of heavy equipment, and a former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, died Nov. 30 at his home in Portland, Ore.

title: BENGALS SHOCK PATRIOTS
description: Cincinnati gained a club-record 584 yards today, shut down the National Football League's highest scoring team and defeated the New England Patriots, 31-7. The loss kept the Patriots from clinching a wild-card playoff berth.

title: AIDE ENDURES STORMY YEARS IN ULSTER POST
description: The sense of being under siege can be pervasive in Northern Ireland, particularly on a rainy day at Stormont Castle, where Nicholas Scott reigns in uneasy solitude as a kind of a British proconsul.

title: Firefighter Dies In Fall From Engine
description: A Yonkers firefighter was killed when he fell off an engine that was responding to an alarm, authorities said yesterday.

title: Jetliner Skids Into Mud
description: A jetliner skidded off an icy taxiway today after landing at the Rochester-Monroe County Airport and became mired in mud. The six crew members and 17 passengers on board the American Airlines DC-980, arriving from Chicago, left safely, said an assistant manager at the airport, Frederick Iekel.

title: Modest '87 Rise In Oil Use Seen
description: Western industrialized nations will not be consuming as much oil in the first half of next year as earlier forecasts had predicted, according to the International Energy Agency.

title: Topics: Unseasonal; Too Much Too Soon
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that if Christmas came every day it would be a crashing bore. As of now it is coming every day of December, and boredom isn't far behind.

title: KENNEDY CENTER HONORS 6 IN THE ARTS
description: It was celebrity time here this weekend as the worlds of theater, music, film and dance joined with Washington's political and cultural establishments to honor six people for their lifetime achievements in the performing arts.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNDER THE BIG TOPS The nippy climate of a New York autumn is once again drawing people in search of a respite off the midtown streets and out of the parks and propelling them into atriums, those high-roofed, private domains that offer shelter from all sorts of New York elements in attractive surroundings.

title: CABARET: DONNA McKECHNIE
description: ''INSTEAD of seeing Betty Grable, we get Dr. Ruth on cable,'' sings Donna McKechnie in ''Nobody Knows,'' a specially rewritten version of Cole Porter's ''Anything Goes'' that is one of the snappier numbers in her new cabaret act. Ms. McKechnie, who recently returned to the Broadway production of ''A Chorus Line'' as Cassie, the role she originated 12 years ago, is giving after-theater performances at Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street, on Friday and Saturday nights through Dec. 20. And ''Nobody Knows'' typifies the spirit of show-business nostalgia that permeates her act.

title: Venezuelan Economic Plan
description: Jaime Lusinchi, Venezuela's President, has announced a series of economic measures that include a partial devaluation of the country's monetary unit, the bolivar; a new plan affecting private sector foreign debt, and minor wage increases for a broad range of workers.

title: A TEMPEST IN A CARAFE: U.N. DEBATES ICE WATER QUESTION
description: Issues of economic justice, human rights and national sovereignty have long stood in the way of harmony at the United Nations. On top of that, there is the issue of the drinking water jugs.

title: Elisa Singer Is the Bride Of Thomas David Cohen
description: Elisa Singer, the daughter of Cantor and Mrs. Isadore Singer of Passaic, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas David Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cohen of Manhattan. Dr. Rabbi Leon Katz, Rabbi Harlan Wechsler and the bride's father officiated at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Foster Care Hits a Snag
description: New York City's agreement, approved in October, to settle a 13-year-old lawsuit about the care of foster children offered a promise: fairer care for them and reduced dominance of the city's foster- care services by private agencies with religious affiliations. Now the promise has dimmed as the agencies balk at the settlement's terms and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York threatens to discontinue some foster-care services.

title: Bridge: World Champions Fighting To Win Board-a-Match Title
description: A small army of world champions was fighting for a major title here tonight as the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League drew to a close.

title: WORKING PARENTS' WORRY
description: WHEN Dolores McKinney of the Bronx went back to work after being a full-time mother for nine years, she noticed that her children's relationships with their friends changed. Her 15-year-old son started spending all his free time with his football teammates and her 7-year-old daughter argued constantly with her best friend.

title: LENDL AND BECKER TO MEET IN FINAL FOR SIXTH TIME THIS YEAR
description: The rankings have already been determined. No matter what occurs in the final of the Nabisco Masters, Ivan Lendl will finish as the No. 1 player in 1986 and Boris Becker, No. 2. But when they walk on the dark blue Supreme Court surface at Madison Square Garden tonight, Lendl and Becker will be thinking ahead to the new year, giving a sneak preview of what is to come.

title: It's Not Easy to Remake A Board of Estimate
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: 'MORPHINE,' BY NEIL GREENBERG
description: JEFFREY ROTH'S setting for ''Morphine,'' the dance Neil Greenberg presented Saturday night at St. Mark's Church, included a bed littered with hypodermic needles. No one touched them. Yet because the dancers did occasionally point toward their arms as if displaying needle marks, that set and those gestures were reminders that morphine is a narcotic.

title: Advertising; A New Health Magazine
description: MARK M. EDMISTON, who resigned three months ago as president of Newsweek magazine, is helping a group of alumni of Science '85 start a new magazine called Hippocrates, The Magazine of Health and Medicine.

title: Town and County Get A $3 Million Surprise
description: This small town, rebuilding its economy after the loss of a major employer, has received a gift from a former resident who made good in the big city.

title: SURROGATE BIRTHS AND THE FAMILY
description: The sprawling white frame house in a suburb outside Detroit looks like a setting for a Norman Rockwell painting. An American flag flies from a tall pole in front and there are 35 wooded acres, with a barn for eight horses, in back.

title: Nikko Securities Shifts Top Officers
description: The Nikko Securities Company, Japan's second-largest securities firm, has announced top changes at its Tokyo headquarters and in its New York unit, Nikko Securities International.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RAPID USE AND POLLUTION THREATEN L.I. WATER SUPPLY
description: Long Island is so rapidly consuming or polluting its water supply that in 10 to 15 years, officials say, water shortages could be widespread.

title: DIFFICULTIES AT PENSION AGENCY
description: Looming red ink at the Government agency that insures the pensions of nearly a third of the nation's workers is likely to lead to much stricter treatment of companies that go bankrupt, according to Administration officials.

title: WORDS, LIKE OFFENSE, FAIL JETS
description: They are trained to be big boys. The nature of their profession demands that all responsibilities are precisely defined. The stakes of their game require that the Jets be prepared for everything.

title: CARIBOUS GOING TO MAINE COURTESY OF EX-TRAPPER
description: Game officials today fought against poor visibility, snow and rain as they tried to catch the final 7 of 30 caribous destined for Maine, where the last native caribous died in 1908.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Inkster, Purtzer Take Mixed Event
description: Juli Inkster and Tom Purtzer shot a 69 today and cruised to a two-stroke victory in the J. C. Penney Mixed Classic.

title: DREXEL'S MUNICIPAL BOND TIE
description: At a time when the eyes of Wall Street are on Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s ''junk bond'' activities, the firm is quietly raising billions of dollars in another corner of the financial world - money that is going directly into the coffers of the Executive Life Insurance Company, one of the biggest buyers of junk bonds.

title: Koch Warns Against Demeaning Reagan
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that it would be ''dangerous'' for the country and the world if the Iran affair made President Reagan ineffective, and he warned fellow Democrats they would ''rue the day'' if they tried to use the issue for partisan purposes.

title: CITY U. HAILS THE ORIGINS OF ITS OPEN ADMISSIONS
description: Two educational programs of the 1960's that became the forerunners of the City University of New York's open admissions policy are to be celebrated by the university this week.

title: Flooding in Leningrad Is Worst in 16 Years
description: Storms in the northern Atlantic and the Gulf of Finland swept a tidal surge into the Neva River delta, causing the worst flooding in Leningrad in 16 years, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Gordon Danis, Lawyer, Is Wed to Dr. Robbins
description: Dr. Amy Robbins, an attending anesthesiologist at the Montefiore Medical Center and an instructor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, was married yesterday to Gordon Danis, an associate at Eppinger, Reingold & Fremont, a law firm in Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman offictaed at the bride's home in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Treasure Hunter Sells Company to Investors
description: The treasure hunter Mel Fisher has sold most of his salvage company, his museum and some items from a sunken Spanish galleon for $7 million to four men who said they would preserve the goods for posterity.

title: NEW ELECTION SOUGHT IN PAKISTAN
description: Opposition leaders said today that they would push for parliamentary elections in six months, but they stopped short of issuing an ultimatum to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: 'Religious' Idea Denied In the Mugging of a Jew
description: A judge who freed a Jew convicted of mugging a rabbinical student, ruling the violence was a ''religious argument,'' has been ordered by an appeals court to sentence the defendant to jail.

title: U.S. KNEW OF IRAN'S ROLE IN TWO BEIRUT BOMBINGS
description: The Reagan Administration arranged arms shipments to Iran despite convincing evidence, gathered over two years, of that country's complicity in terrorist bombings in Beirut that killed many American marines and diplomats, senior officials confirmed today.

title: The Anti-apartheid Act Boomerangs
description: While the imposition of sanctions on Pretoria appears to have satisfied a widely felt need among Americans to ''do something'' in the face of repression and injustice, there can no longer be any doubt that the Anti-apartheid Act of 1986 has made it even more difficult than it was before for the United States to influence the course of events in South Africa.

title: Photo of Mary McDonnell and Gerry Bamman (T. Charles Erickson); THEATER: 'DOLL'S HOUSE' AT HARTFORD STAGE CO.
description: Mary McDonnell is a vibrant Nora Helmer in the Hartford Stage Company's production of ''A Doll's House'' (which for some reason is being called ''A Doll House''). She fairly dances her transformation, over three days of Christmas, from playfulness to bewilderment to the defiance that has made Nora a heroine of modern drama.
