title: Bryant a Star for Redskins
description: As a member of the Philadelphia/Baltimore Stars, Kelvin Bryant played in three United States Football League championship games, two of which the Stars won.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corp. appointed Leonard H. Mogil president and division chief executive of Joske's of Texas, a 27-store department store chain in Dallas. He replaces Robert L. Mettler, who resigned.

title: KEY DEMOCRAT SAYS REAGAN IS NOT COOPERATING ENOUGH
description: The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said today that despite President Reagan's pledge of full cooperation, the Administration had hardly answered any of the panel's questions about the Iran arms dealings.

title: FOES NO MORE, CATTLEMEN SIT WITH SHEEPMEN FOR WEEKEND
description: Another Western myth - the sometimes violent conflict between cattlemen and sheepmen - is biting the dust. Over the weekend, the New Mexico Cattle Growers' Association and the New Mexico Wool Growers' Association held their annual conventions together, the first joint meeting for the two organizatons since 1917.

title: Volcanic Flow Resumes Course in Hawaii
description: Fiery molten lava from the Kilauea volcano has resumed its flow to the sea after pushing through a jam beneath the solidified surface crust.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Hearing on Police Management A special mayoral panel has reported that the city's Police Department suffers from management problems and should change the way officers are recruited. The panel is to hold a public hearing today, before issuing its final report to the Mayor.

title: 4 IN NEW OPPOSITION PARTY GET MOST VOTES IN TAIWAN
description: The four top vote-getters in the legislative elections Saturday were all members of a new opposition party, according to final results made available today.

title: FRATELLO HAS HAWKS ON A ROLL
description: WHEN you have assembled a team that is the second-youngest in the National Basketball Association yet is so ambitious that it recently beat the Celtics and the Lakers back-to-back, a feat no one had pulled off since 1982, what is there for a coach to worry about?

title: REVIVED CLEVELAND FINDS OLD JOKES HARD TO SHAKE
description: The city that launched 1,000 jokes, defaulted on its loans in 1978 and had a river so polluted it caught fire is finding that old stereotypes have long lives.

title: America II Regains 4th Place by Default
description: America II inched back into fourth place today in the America's Cup challengers' trials, but the position is tenuous at best.

title: Two Hotel Clerks Are Killed
description: Two hotel clerks were killed last night in separate, unrelated incidents at two Manhattan hotels, the police said.

title:
Washington Watch;
Competition Jolts the Banks
description: SOMETIMES only a costly jolt can make an industry unite and push for major changes.

title: Martha J. Wachtel Weds Judd Burstein
description: Martha Jean Wachtel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Wachtel of Westport, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Judd Burstein, a son of Justice Beatrice S. Burstein of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Herbert Burstein. Rabbi Nathan Fish, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: OFFICIALS REPORT POINDEXTER URGED SHIFT ON IRAN ARMS
description: After deciding in December 1985 not to approve any more arms shipments to Iran, President Reagan was persuaded by his new national security adviser last January to resume the sales, former and current Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Who's Calling?
description: Institutional jealousy between the Secretary of State and the White House national security adviser did not originate with the Reagan Administration.

title: TV Networks to Cover House Hearings Today
description: The television networks will cover the hearings today on the Iran arms deal before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs. Secretary of State George P. Shultz is tentatively scheduled to appear at 8:30 A.M. and Robert C. McFarlane, former national security adviser, at 2 P.M.

title: Small Bomb Is Found At Bonn Aide's Home
description: A device described as amateurish and ''not highly explosive'' was discovered today outside the home of the chief West German Government spokesman, Friedhelm Ost.

title: Anniron Takes Iroquois Stakes
description: Anniron, the odds-on choice, carried 119 pounds and Robert Cook to a four-length victory in the Iroquois Stakes for New York-bred fillies and mares three years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 8, 1986: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs Interco Inc Burroughs Corp Unocal Corp Dayco Corp TUESDAY Boise Cascade Corp Handleman Co Chesapeake Corp Intl Flavors & Fragrances Culbro Corp Lomas Mortgage Corp Esterline Corp Oklahoma Gas & Electric Fleetwood Enterprises Premier Industrial Fluor Corp Toro Co WEDNESDAY Deere & Co Heinz (HJ) Co DeSoto Inc Hunt Mfg Ennis Business Forms Kidde Inc Fairchild Industries Nicor Inc General Re Corp Soo Line Corp Harper & Row Publishers Southern N E Telecom THURSDAY Apache Corp Natl Fuel Gas Basix Corp Research-Cottrell Rogers Central Corp Trinity Industries FRIDAY Abbott Laboratories James River Corp of VA General Cinema MCA Inc Hospital Corp Amer Pueblo Intl Inc Huffy Corp Varian Associates

title: Off to Poland
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy will spend part of his Christmas holiday in Poland.

title: KEAN WARNS OF PARALYSIS ON IRAN
description: Governor Kean warned today that the deepening preoccupation with the Iran affair could paralyze the country and leave the United States vulnerable in its dealings with hostile countries.

title: A.T.&T. Seeks Waiver Shift
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to ask a Federal judge to change the process for deciding whether to grant waivers of the rules that govern some operations of A.T.&T. and the seven regional telephone companies it spun off in 1984, a spokesman said.

title: GUIDRY, RANDOLPH OFFERED ARBITRATION
description: Abandoning their threat to let Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph go at midnight tonight, the Yankees gained another month of negotiating time today by offering their co-captains salary arbitration.

title: After 13 Losses, Colts Finally Win
description: Eugene Daniel returned a blocked punt 13 yards for a touchdown with 20 seconds remaining today to give the Indianapolis Colts their first victory of the season, a 28-23 decision over the Atlanta Falcons in Ron Meyer's debut as coach. Indianapolis had lost its first 13 games this year under Rod Dowhower, who was dismissed last week.

title: Was Greenwich Village Ever What It Used to Be?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Sometimes when you get back from a fire and you've worked really hard, there is this sense of camaraderie.

title: Red Sox, Yankees Say No to Seaver
description: Tom Seaver's 20-year career as one of the most glamorous pitchers in major league history might have ended today. The Boston Red Sox said they would not be re-signing Seaver and the Yankees' general manager, Woody Woodward, said they had no interest in signing him.

title: U.S. Offerings Limited to Bill Sale
description: The supply of new Treasury securities this week is confined to today's regular weekly sale of new bills due in three and six months.

title: Motion Picture Group Hires Rubin, Postaer
description: Rubin, Postaer & Associates, formerly the Los Angeles office of Needham Harper Worldwide, has been named to handle several advertising assignments for New Century/Vista Films, a new distribution company that will handle 13 motion pictures in the next 11 months.

title: AUDITORS FAULT BRONX HOSPITAL ON CONSULTANTS
description: The Bronx Municipal Hospital Center improperly authorized more than $400,000 in payments to four consulting concerns hired in violation of City Health and Hospitals Corporation policy, an audit by the City Comptroller found yesterday.

title: London Braces for Fallout From Eurobond Crisis
description: The Eurobond market received one of the worst jolts of its two-decade-long history last week, when prices plummeted and many dealers stopped normal trading in the market for perpetual floating-rate notes.

title: 2 SENATORS FAULT NASA DIRECTOR AS ROCKET-DESIGN DEBATE PERSISTS
description: New information warrants a Congressional investigation into the contract for the space shuttle rockets that failed last January, a key senator said yesterday. Another said the NASA Administrator should remove himself from future decisions on such contracts.

title: U.S. COPTERS FERRY HONDURAN TROOPS TO FACE NICARAGUA
description: President Reagan has authorized United States Army helicopters to ferry Honduran troops into action against 1,000 Nicaraguan soldiers reported to have crossed into Honduras in pursuit of Nicaraguan rebels, State Department officials said today.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND STRIKING CHANGE IN CANCER STUDY
description: The death rate from breast cancer in young and middle-aged white women has swerved sharply upward after more than a decade of steady decline, the National Cancer Institute has reported.

title: DEFENSE MAKES SIX INTERCEPTIONS
description: It gets better every week for the Giants. Today, they won their seventh straight game, raised their record to 12-2 and took sole possession of first place in their division. With one more victory or one Redskins loss, the Giants will win a division or conference title for the first time in 23 years.

title: Strong Quake Hits Bulgaria
description: A strong earthquake shook most of Bulgaria this afternoon and caused some damage, the state-run Bulgarian press agency reported.

title: TWO PILOTS DIE AS SMALL PLANES COLLIDE IN JERSEY
description: A small plane landing at a New Jersey airstrip struck another small plane taking off yesterday morning, killing both pilots, the authorities said.

title: Le Trong Tan Is Dead; Hanoi's Chief of Staff
description: Gen. Le Trong Tan, Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese Army since 1978 and a key commander in the offensive that brought victory to Communist forces in 1975, has died of a heart attack in Hanoi, the official Vietnamese press agency said today. He was 72 years old.

title: Congressman, 70, Responds To a Bar Critic With His Fist
description: Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat who is 70 years old, responded in a bar to a man who called him a Communist by punching him, and the man said later that he was too shocked to do anything but sit there.

title: Waiting for Lefties
description: Neil Kinnock, head of Britain's Labor Party, is visiting the U.S. to demonstrate that he is not an isolationist kook. Note was taken here that Mr. Kinnock was asked by Gary Hart to attend Sunday's Giants-Redskins game in Washington, which is how ''special relationships'' are perpetuated.

title: Wright's Choices Awaited
description: House Democrats, anxious to discover what kind of a Speaker and party leader Representative Jim Wright of Texas will make, are eagerly awaiting the appointments he will announce to the powerful Steering and Policy Committee after he succeeds Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. this week. That 30-member panel recommends committee chairmen to the Democratic caucus, makes all committee assignments and sets the legislative agenda for the party under the Speaker's leadership, so Mr. Wright's choices will be carefully scrutinized for clues to his philosophy and procedures.

title: 3 Rescued Whales Are Watched for Clues
description: Three rescued pilot whale calves clung to life today at the New England Aquarium, while marine researchers awaited results of autopsies on 26 whales who did not survive a mass beaching Wednesday on Cape Cod.

title: Books; 2 Odd Men Out
description: WORDS IN COMMOTION and Other Stories. By Tommaso Landolfi. Translated and edited by Kathrine Jason. Introduction by Italo Calvino. 273 pages.

title: LINDA LAVIN'S PATH TO SIMON MATRIARCH
description: When Linda Lavin first read the script for Neil Simon's new play, ''Broadway Bound,'' she immediately decided she wanted to play the role of Kate, the mother of the young Eugene Jerome. However, although Kate turned out to be the play's star turn, Ms. Lavin was the last person cast in the ensemble. And it was not until after all the actors assembled for the first reading that a crucial decision gave Kate the most moving scene in the entire play.

title: Virginia Defeats George Mason for Title
description: Richard Morgan scored 14 points and Tom Sheehey added 13 today as Virginia posted a 73-58 victory over George Mason in the Investors Classic tourney.

title: 49ERS BEAT SPUTTERING JETS, 24-10
description: It was in their eyes after the game, in their sagging shoulders, in their attempt to make sense of what has happened after the finest beginning in the history of the Jets.

title: Influx of Refugees Disturbs Costa Ricans
description: To the Editor:

title: Shift in Psychology Is Debated
description: After last Friday's sharp break in bond prices, credit market analysts are wondering whether a profound change in psychology has taken place.

title: Holiday Welding
description: A friend who commutes from Connecticut reports that Metro North's managers remain eternally optimistic - willing even to deny the inevitable arrival of winter and holiday crowds. How else to explain their policy on track repair?

title: 3d World Trade Deficits
description: Poor countries in Asia, Europe and the Western Hemisphere are plunging deeper into debt, posting a $4.9 billion trade deficit for the first quarter of this year, according to the International Monetary Fund. The monthly I.M.F. memorandum said the trade deficit for those countries, along with developing nations in the Middle East and Africa, totaled $3.1 billion in 1985, compared with a surplus of $10.5 billion in 1984.

title: Coolidge and the Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: LAUREN LOOK PERMEATING CITY
description: It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas in New York. And Christmas in the nation's largest marketplace is beginning to look a lot like Ralph Lauren.

title: BALLISTICS LINK 2 DAVIS PISTOLS AND SHOOTINGS
description: Ballistic tests show that the gun seized with Larry Davis Saturday was used in the execution-style killing of four drug dealers in the Bronx in October as well as the shootout that left six police officers wounded last month, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: AT A MEXICAN UNIVERSITY, TOO, PLANS FOR CHANGE STIR PORTEST
description: The giant National Autonomous University here has become embroiled in controversy in recent weeks over a plan to raise fees and toughen academic standards. A student group protesting the changes has grown increasingly powerful, raising concern among university officials and within the Government.

title: 3 WHO DISAVOWED SOLIDARITY JOIN WARSAW COUNCIL
description: Three men who have disavowed their Solidarity connections are among the 57 Poles named by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski to serve on a new consultative council with power to debate but not institute social policies.

title: INSIDE
description: 32 Rhodes Scholars Named Thirty-two American students, including a refugee from Vietnam who is at the Air Force Academy, were named Rhodes Scholars.

title: Results Mixed For Retailers
description: Several of New York's largest retailers had average November sales gains of 5.2 percent in the city and 7 percent in suburban areas, compared with the comparable period of 1985, according to a spot-check of merchants on Friday.

title: SINGAPORE SHAKEN AFTER RECESSION...BUT CONFIDENCE IN FINANCE THRIVES
description: After suffering its first recession in two decades, the economy of this island-state seems to be creeping forward again. But Singapore lost some of its confidence during the downturn, according to economists and business executives. Even the Government says a return to the growth rates of the 1960's and 70's, when the Singapore economy was a global pace-setter, is virtually impossible.

title: HAGLER-LEONARD IN ROADSHOW
description: On the stage of a hotel ballroom in New York last month, a curtain rose and there, in the opening tableau of a cross-country tour to publicize their April 6 fight here, stood Ray Leonard in a white Italian-leather jacket and Marvelous Marvin Hagler in a black business suit.

title: Nevada Route Reopens
description: Crews worked to clean up a leaking truckload of potentially explosive chemicals, reopening the westbound lanes of Interstate 80 today after 20 hours, the Nevada Highway Patrol said.

title: SEX BIAS LINGERS IN FIREHOUSES OF NEW YORK
description: During her first year with the New York City Fire Department, Lorraine Cziko would drive up to her firehouse in Queens and stand outside taking deep breaths, trying to work up the courage to go in.

title: 5 Reports by Commission
description: Here are the principal recommendations of the State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, compiled from the commission's five reports:

title: MALAYSIA TIGHTENS SECRECY ON OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS
description: The Malaysian Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has made jail sentences mandatory for anyone convicted of unauthorized possession of a wide range of Government documents.

title: SWISS ACCOUNT LINKED TO ARMS DEAL IS FROZEN
description: A major Swiss bank has frozen an account believed to have been used to divert Iran arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels, officials here said today.

title: FUND GOALS SPUR GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: Many contributors to the 75th annual appeal to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have expressed high regard for goals of the campaign.

title: One-Page Document Is Key to DeLorean Defense
description: When a Federal jury begins its deliberations this week in the criminal fraud trial of former auto maker John Z. DeLorean , much of its attention is expected to be directed to a single typewritten page that is the center of his defense.

title: JAPAN MISSING A CHANCE TO FILL A NICHE IN SPACE
description: On the rugged Pacific island of Tanegashima 600 miles southwest of here, Japan is rapidly expanding its largest space center, adding launch pads and constructing a giant vehicle assembly building. But eight months a year the island is quiet: Fishermen have forced the Government to limit sharply the launch season, complaining that falling solid rocket boosters rip through their nets.

title: Outdone in Print
description: It's not every day that a Republican organization issues an announcement when the Democrats have outdone the G.O.P. at something. Last week, however, came word from the National Republican Foundation that a survey of editorial endorsements by 50 larger newspapers in the 1986 campaign showed Democratic candidates getting 59 percent of them as against 41 for Republicans.

title: Big Brothers Official Held in Sex Abuse
description: The Somerset County prosecutor has begun an investigation of the county's Big Brothers-Big Sisters organization after three volunteers were charged with sexually assaulting youngsters, officials said.

title: Foreign Affairs
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is apparently serious about its plan to monitor foreign athletes playing for United States universities.

title: Honeymoon Over For Capitals' Star
description: JUST five years ago, Bobby Carpenter, an 18-year-old schoolboy from Beverly, Mass., had the stuff of which National Hockey League franchises are made. At least that's what the Washington Capitals thought when they worked some sleight of hand at the 1981 draft to select third, one spot ahead of the Hartford Whalers, the team that had the Carpenter family's endorsement.

title: U.S. Heads Down the Road to Scientific Dotage
description: To the Editor:

title: How America Can Compete
description: Suddenly, there is a hopeful glimmer of compromise on foreign-trade legislation. While the Administration and Congress still fill the air with the pros and cons of curbing imports, both sides are now starting to talk sense on a key issue: helping displaced workers find new jobs.

title: Offer for Holly Sugar
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation, a leading beet sugar producer, has received a proposal from Arcanum 1 Partners and some senior Holly officers to acquire the company. The company said on Friday that the offer for each Holly share was $35 in cash and one share of a new preferred stock with a $90 redemption value and an annual dividend of $7.20 starting March 31, 1988. Holly's common shares rose $3.125, to $109, in trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CLASHES IN PARIS WORST SINCE 1968
description: The Government appealed for calm today after the worst night of rioting in Paris in 18 years.

title: 4 Killed and 50 Hurt in Riots Over Indian Magazine Article
description: Four people were killed and nearly 50 were injured in riots here today after a newspaper published an article that offended Moslems.

title: SANDINISTAS' FOES PLAN TO UNITE FOR LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: Opposition political leaders say they plan to confront the governing Sandinistas with a united front in local elections scheduled for next year.

title: CONSUMER SPENDING LULL SEEN
description: Consumer spending, which has been running at a healthy level all year long despite declining disposable income and increasing debt, could begin to taper off as early as this holiday season, some economists say.

title: Bishop for Los Angeles Cancels AIDS Seminar
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles announced Saturday that it would not allow an AIDS education group to hold seminars in its churches because the organization condoned the use of condoms.

title: Officials Close 3 More Banks
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday that regulators had closed three banks in Kansas, Texas and Minnesota, bringing the total number that have failed or required Federal aid this year to 136.

title: Ford-Nissan Talks Reported
description: Ford and Nissan have held talks involving a possible joint venture to build automobile engines in the United States, an auto industry official said here today.

title: Accounts
description: * California magazine has retained Scali, McCabe, Sloves/West.

title: TWO SIDES OF BRITISH HUMOR ON 13
description: BRITISH television humor can range from the music-hall zaniness of a Benny Hill to the straight-faced, understated lunacy of an essay on bathrooms. Tonight, WNET's salute to the ''BBC Television 50th Anniversary'' offers a couple of representative examples. The first, at 11, is an episode of ''The Lenny Henry Show.'' The other, at 11:45, is a documentary about hair and is called, succinctly enough, ''Hair.''

title: ALL GOES WRONG FOR WASHINGTON
description: He had so looked forward to this game. Like an expectant kid on Christmas morning, he couldn't wait to get to R.F.K. Stadium today to unwrap the Giants.

title: LUDWIG NADELMAN
description: Rabbi Ludwig Nadelman, a leading figure in the Jewish Reconstructionist movement, died Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Blaze at Tire Yard Emits Thick Smoke
description: About 100 firefighters from throughout Atlantic County battled a fire at a tire junkyard yesterday that emitted high flames and plumes of thick, black smoke, authorities said.

title: Numbers Don't Tell All On Highway Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Landry Is Threatened
description: Coach Tom Landry of the Cowboys was the target of several telephone threats tonight and, flanked by security guards, left the field for several minutes during Dallas' game here with the Los Angeles Rams.

title: EVERYMAN'S ADVOCATE: ESTHER PETERSON
description: Since the 1930's Esther Peterson has been enlisting young soldiers in her fights for women's rights, trade unionism and consumer protection. Now, at 80 years of age and with a battalion or two of her followers in the field, she is still seeking recruits.

title: U.S. OVERSAW SUPPLIES TO REBELS, OFFICIALS SAY
description: United States officials in Central America were more involved in the covert program to supply Nicaraguan rebels than they at first indicated, according to three American diplomats and to Americans who flew guns to the rebels.

title: Gunmen on Malta Kill Opposition Backer
description: A supporter of Malta's opposition Nationalist Party has been killed by shots fired from a passing car, the police said.

title: Duke and Akron Gain Soccer Final
description: John Kerr, the Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year, scored two goals and assisted on another to lead Duke to a 3-1 victory over Harvard today and a spot in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I soccer championship game.

title: METS SAY GOODBYE TO KNIGHT, WORLD SERIES M.V.P.
description: Ray Knight, the hero of the World Series and baseball's comeback player of the year, came to the end of his days with the Mets tonight when they refused to meet his demand for a salary of $1 million for next year and also refused to submit the dispute to arbitration.

title: Career Start Was Hard For a Pickens Partner
description: One of the investors who has quietly but profitably joined T. Boone Pickens Jr. in his acquisition moves is John M. Harbert 3d, a construction executive in Birmingham, Ala.

title: More Credit Set by LTV
description: The LTV Corporation, which filed for reorganization under the bankruptcy law last July, says its 22 bank lenders will increase its credit by $100 million as part of new debt agreements completed Friday.

title: TEARS AT GROUND-BREAKING FOR HOLOCAUST MUSEUM
description: A museum project dedicated to memorializing Holocaust victims while challenging visitors to explore their own prejudices was somberly begun here today. Two hundred survivors of concentration camps marked the ground-breaking by pouring out small glass vials of earth taken from eight of the camps.

title: Market Place; 'Opportunistic' Zenith Fund
description: IN Boston, G. Kenneth Heebner manages the portfolio of Zenith Fund-Capital Growth in a style he described as ''highly aggressive and opportunistic.'' He concentrates on companies believed to possess strong appreciation potential based on their earnings outlook.

title: U.S. AIDES FEAR CRISIS WILL END CONTRAS' EFFORT
description: Many Reagan Administration officials say they are coming to the conclusion that the Nicaraguan insurgency is probably doomed.

title: BRUINS' HARD WORK BEATS ISLANDERS, 3-1
description: By their own admission, the Islanders abandoned a proven strategy tonight at Boston Garden where they were beaten, 3-1, by the surging Bruins, whose two victories this weekend vaulted them into a tie for first place in their division.

title: Nuclear Plant Taken Off Line for Repairs
description: The Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant was taken off line yesterday to allow repairs to a steam heating device in the nonnuclear part of the installation, a Northeast Utilities spokesman said.

title:
WASHINGTON WATCH;
S.E.C. Hearing on Listings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will hold two days of hearings on Dec. 16 and 17 on a New York Stock Exchange proposal to abandon its decades-long tradition of listing only those stocks that give equal voting power - also called one-share, one-vote.

title: Kenyan Takes Hawaii Marathon
description: Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya today won his second successive Honolulu Marathon, in 2 hours 11 minutes 44 seconds, to better his course record of 2:12.08 set last year. The former University of New Mexico runner earned a $10,000 first-place prize and a $10,000 bonus for breaking the record.

title: Louis Gordon Crovitz Weds Anne L. Alstott
description: Anne Lester Alstott, a third-year law student at Yale University, and Louis Gordon Crovitz, the assistant editorial page editor of The Wall Street Journal and a member of the paper's editorial board, were married in New Haven yesterday. Rabbi James Ponet performed the ceremony at Yale University's Dwight Chapel.

title: Filipino Rebel Warns Against Army Patrols
description: A Communist guerrilla leader said today that the scheduled cease-fire could be jeopardized if the military insisted on patrolling areas held by the rebels.

title: Prisoners Damage Cells In Idaho Rampage
description: Inmates have broken windows and damaged plumbing and wiring in disturbances in a maximum security section of Idaho State Prison, the authorities said.

title: KNICKS LOSE A HEARTBREAKER IN OVERTIME
description: The Knicks had lost two games on this road trip by a combined total of 53 points, blowouts that left them discouraged and disheartened. But neither of those defeats was as difficult to accept as tonight's loss.

title: Sydney Harris, a Columnist And Author, Dies in Chicago
description: Sydney Harris, an author and syndicated columnist whose work appeared in more than 200 daily newspapers, died today after heart bypass surgery at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: BATTLE IN LEBANON ON EVE OF TALKS
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas clashed in Beirut and southern Lebanon today. The fighting occurred despite efforts by Syria and Iran to put into effect a cease-fire before an Arab foreign ministers' meeting opens Monday.

title: Emily L. Grifo Is Married To Adam Gilbert, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Emily Louise Grifo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gene Grifo of Grosse Pointe, Mich., to Adam Brenner Gilbert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Gilbert of Riverdale, the Bronx, took place yesterday at the 24 Fifth Avenue Restaurant. Justice Burton Roberts of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: Experimental Plane Is Ready For Attempt at Global Flight
description: Preparations for a 12-day, unrefueled flight around the world by the Voyager experimental aircraft have been completed and the flight could begin as soon as Tuesday, a spokesman says.

title: BEARS, WITH A LIFT FROM FLUTIE, TROUNCE BUCS AND GO TO 12-2
description: Doug Flutie made a strong bid for the starting quarterback job but Mike Tomczak held his own today as the two led the Chicago Bears to a 48-14 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: ARAB WOUNDED IN GAZA STRIP
description: Israeli troops shot and slightly wounded an Arab man in the Gaza Strip today during continuing unrest in response to the killing of three Palestinians by the Israeli security forces last week, army spokesmen said. They also said two Israelis were hurt when buses were stoned in the West Bank.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM PLAYS DALLAPICCOLA
description: AS the years following World War II recede from memory, we begin to gain historical perspective on the remarkable group of composers who rose to international prominence from the devastation of postwar Europe.

title: No Kibitzing Needed for Cory
description: What a difference a fortnight has made for that remarkable former housewife, President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines. In swift order, she has managed three difficult feats: firing a disloyal defense minister, reconfirming her authority over a reshaped Government, and signing the first nationwide cease-fire since Communist rebels took arms 17 years ago. She has bought time at the crucially right time. The 60-day truce begins this Wednesday, just before Christmas, and extends just beyond the Feb. 2 vote on a new constitution whose approval would build her momentum.

title: BRAZIL OFFICIALS WILL TRY ANYTHING, EVEN ORTHODOXY
description: Seeing his popularity tumble in the days of protests and nervousness that followed sharp price increases here last month, President Jose Sarney finally concluded that the time had come for politicians to take over the job of explaining economic policy.

title: SINGAPORE SHAKEN AFTER RECESSION...BUT CONFIDENCE IN FINANCE THRIVES
description: Bankers usually lower their voices when talking about the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Partly, it is because they are sometimes not saying very nice things; partly, it is a reflection of the awe, laced with fear, that the authority commands.

title: 32 FROM U.S. NAMED RHODES SCHOLARS
description: The names of 32 Rhodes Scholars from 24 colleges in the United States were announced yesterday.

title: No Shake-Up Seen In Cuomo Cabinet
description: FOR weeks, the capital has been preoccupied with newspaper accounts that Governor Cuomo would shake up his cabinet before his second term began. But now comes this word from top Cuomo advisers: no shakeup.

title: DAVIS SURRENDER LEADS TO REUNION OF A FAMILY
description: The family who waited for six hours as police negotiators used their apartment to convince Larry Davis to surrender were glad yesterday to see him - and his .45-caliber pistol - gone. But they also found themselves happy that he came.

title: NASA Chief Is Gloomy On Budget for Shuttle
description: The space agency has run into budget problems and Dr. James C. Fletcher, the Administrator, says its new replacement shuttle and the space station could be delayed.

title: YUGOSLAV FACES IMPRISONMENT
description: Milan M. Nikolic, a Yugoslav sociologist sentenced to five months in prison for a thesis he wrote at Brandeis University, said Saturday that unless the Yugoslav authorities acted on his plea for postponement, he might have to begin serving his sentence ''any day.''

title: DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO'S 'BERNARDA'
description: ANY two of the six works performed by Ballet Hispanico on Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater would have suggested the increasingly wide range of the company's interests and skills. Vicente Nebrada's new ''Bernarda,'' for instance, offered a dark dramatic work, and Talley Beatty's recent ''Recuerdo de Campo Amor'' showed the youthful dancers at their sleekest.

title: FOR NEW SPEAKER, NEW ROLE IS SEEN
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who is due to be chosen as the next Speaker of the House on Monday, is expected to play a very different role on Capitol Hill from that of his predecessor, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Congressional experts say Mr. Wright is more interested in the details of legislation than Mr. O'Neill, whose strong point was broad political strategy, and they expect the new Speaker to put a more personal stamp on bills emerging from the House.

title: GEORGE MURPHY Jr.
description: George Murphy Jr., former editor of the Washington Afro-American, died Nov. 29 at Howard University Hospital after a long illness that ended in a stroke.

title:
WASHINGTON WATCH;
Succession at the Fed
description: With Emmett J. Rice's resignation as a member of the Federal Reserve taking effect at month's end, the Reagan Administration is said to have sharply narrowed its list of possible successors.

title: The Smart Set
description: As invitational tournaments go, the Lopata Classic at Washington University in St. Louis doesn't go very far in the world of big-time college basketball. It doesn't have a television contract, a couple of thousand fans is considered an outstanding turnout and when its players talk about becoming professionals they aren't referring to the National Basketball Association but to careers in law, medicine and engineering.

title: STATES MOVE TO EASE LAW COMMITTING MENTALLY ILL
description: A NUMBER of states are changing their laws to make it easier to commit the mentally ill for involuntary treatment. The changes are reversing a trend that made a person's danger to himself or to others the sole legal grounds for involuntary commitment.

title: Arms Are Costa Rica's Last Need
description: Reports that the Reagan Administration is pushing Costa Rica to rearm are particularly distressing to those acquainted with the most recent United Nations data on the dramatic health improvements in that country since it shifted resources from military to social programs.

title: India Moslems Continue To Riot Over an Article
description: Six people were shot to death today by policemen trying to disperse mobs of Moslems rioting over a Sunday magazine article they considered an insult to the Prophet Mohammed.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, an investment management concern, named Joseph Cattivera president and chief operating officer.

title: Bolivian Copter Downed By Drug Suspects
description: Suspected drug traffickers shot down a Bolivian military helicopter in the cocaine-producing area of Chapare on Sunday, killing a doctor and wounding three other passengers, the police and the military said today.

title: SENTENCING BID DEEPENS NEW MEXICO DISPUTE
description: A man who has pleaded guilty to kidnapping and murder has asked to be sentenced before Gov. Toney Anaya leaves office on Dec. 31 because the Governor has promised to commute a possible death penalty.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The latest share earnings include 3 cents a share reduction from reversal of previously accrued investment tax credits and include 3 cents a share gain from the sale of assets.

title: Textile-Fiber-Apparel Industry Opposes Caribbean Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: AIFS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $42,000 and $157,000 for the quarter and year, respectivley. Revenue represents program revenue.

title: AIDE TO PRESIDENT TRIES TO SOOTHE G.O.P. GOVERNORS ON IRAN AFFAIR
description: With humor, a soothing tone and a quotation from Disraeli, a White House official tried to reassure Republican Governors today that America was not reliving the Watergate ''nightmare.''

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RIGHTS GROUP SEEKS TO BLOCK CROSS ON MISSISSIPPI BUILDING
description: The American Civil Liberties Union today asked a Federal court to overturn Mississippi's decision to light a cross on a 20-story state office building for the Christmas season.

title: ATLANTA HOMELESS FIND PLACE IN PUBLIC EYE
description: Sometime in late October, someone came up behind James Roane in the nest of boards and plastic that he had fashioned as a home amid the kudzu vines, beat him to death and left him lying in the idled and unfinished sweep of the Jimmy Carter Presidential Parkway. Mr. Roane, a drinking, homeless man of 34, was found with his canned goods and whisky and beer by a construction worker.

title: Wilfred American
description: The Wilfred American Educational Corporation, the New York-based operator of the Wilfred Beauty Academy and the American Business Institute, has retained Smith/Greenland to promote its schools in Los Angeles, Hollywood and Houston. The corporation operates 33 other beauty and 10 business schools whose advertising is done by Fairfax Inc., New York.

title: SUBPOENAS GO TO 15 AT SHEARSON
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is gathering information from more than a dozen officials at General Felt Industries and Shearson Lehman Brothers as part of an investigation into possible insider trading in the buyout by the two companies of the Sheller-Globe Corporation earlier this year.

title: WEDTECH FOUND TO BE IN DEFAULT ON NAVY WORK
description: The Navy yesterday found the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is at the center of Federal and state corruption inquiries, in default on the company's largest contract, $134 million to manufacture portable floating causeways.

title: 24 ARE ACCUSED IN COCAINE RING THAT USED SHIPS
description: A cocaine smuggling ring that used Caribbean cruise liners to bring the drug into this country has been broken with the arrest of 24 people and the seizure of 432 pounds of cocaine over the last six months, the Drug Enforcement Administration announced yesterday.

title: ROGER B. BROWN
description: Roger B. Brown, advertising manager of business electronics at The New York Times, died of cancer Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N.J. He was 46 years old and lived in Cranford, N.J.

title: Banner Continues Pursuit of Rexnord
description: Banner Industries disclosed that it holds 14.6 percent, or 3.7 million shares, of Rexnord Inc., ''with a view to a possible acquisition'' of the industrial component manufacturer based in Milwaukee.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $729,000 charge from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and year.

title: THE THEATER: 'CORK,' BY SAMM-ART WILLIAMS
description: IN his new play, ''Cork,'' Samm-Art Williams throws a reflective light on the changing role of the black artist in our society. The present is represented by a black American actor-playwright (Bernard J. Lunon), who, after years of invisibility, finally triumphs on the London stage in a monodrama of his own authorship. Sitting in his dressing room, basking in his sudden celebrity, he is startled by the appearance of a flamboyantly dressed man in top hat (Geoffrey C. Ewing), who calmly introduces himself as an actor from the mid-19th century. He is the ghost of black theater past, and the modern man is skeptical to the point of hostility.

title: Noel Frankel Is Off Helmsley Hotel Account
description: Noel Frankel & Associates, started recently by the creative director of the New York office of Beber Silverstein & Partners to handle the Helmsley Hotel account after the Beber Silverstein agency was discharged, has quit the account.

title: CUOMO URGED TO DECIDE SOON ON A ROLE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Governor Cuomo of New York has only ''a few days'' to decide if he will get involved in the early politics of the 1988 Presidential primary here, according to George Bruno, chairman of the New Hampshire Democratic Committee.

title: BASEBALL TRADE TALK A WHISPER FOR NOW
description: This was the day after the deadline for salary-arbitration offers to free agents, and it marked the start of a period that could be the prelude to free-agent life after Jan. 8. Players such as Gary Ward, Lonnie Smith, Ray Knight and Dave Kingman could serve as the test cases for the clubs' pursuit of such stars as Jack Morris, Lance Parrish, Tim Raines, Andre Dawson and Bob Horner if they don't sign with their teams by the deadline.

title: Tollner Dismissed
description: Ted Tollner, who guided Southern California to three bowls in four years but consistently lost to U.C.L.A. and Notre Dame, was dismissed as the Trojans' football coach yesterday. The university president, James Zumberge, said the move is effective Jan. 2, after the Trojans play Auburn in the Florida Citrus Bowl. He said the university will pay Tollner for the final two years of his contract. ''A decision of this magnitude is not arrived at without considerable personal pain and agony,'' Zumberge said. ''These considerations, however, must be set aside when the best interests of the university are at stake.'' Tollner said he was disappointed and ''shocked, because I personally think the decision is wrong -based on criteria I think a football program should be judged.'' Zumberge said he made the decision with the athletic director, Mike McGee. McGee said a search committee for a new coach had been formed and said one will be named ''as quickly as possible.'' Although U.S.C. posted a 7-4 record and earned a bowl berth, the season was tarnished when the Trojans were trounced by U.C.L.A, then blew a 17-point fourth-quarter lead and lost to Notre Dame the following week. The 46-year-old Tollner, who replaced John Robinson in 1983, had a 26-19-1 mark in four seasons, with trips to the Rose and Aloha bowls. But he was 1-7 against U.C.L.A. and Notre Dame. Tollner was named U.S.C.'s 18th coach in November 1982 after serving nine months as offensive coordinator and running back coach.. . . Another West Coast head-coaching job was filled when Bruce Snyder, who coaches running backs for the Los Angeles Rams, was chosen as the new football coach at the University of California, replacing Joe Kapp, who was dismissed last month.

title: MEESE SEEKS A BROAD BRIEF FOR SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
description: The Justice Department is seeking broad powers for the special prosecutor who will eventually be chosen to investigate American arms sales to Iran and the diversion of profits to Nicaraguan guerillas, according to a court document made public today.

title: FAMILIES REMEMBER THEIR KIN WITH DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST
description: For many people, memorial gifts are a traditional part of contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 2 TOWNS BOMBED, NICARAGUANS SAY
description: Unidentified combat planes dropped several small bombs on this northern village Sunday afternoon, residents and soldiers said today.

title: Trade Criticism From Europe
description: A senior European Community official today criticized the increased economic cooperation between Japan and the United States.

title: Henderson Advertising Elects Senior Officers
description: James F. Brandhorst Jr., 45 years old, has been elected president and a board member at Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., while John Kennedy, 46, has been named executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer. The announcement was made by Ralph W. Callahan, the 44-year-old chairman.

title: HEINZ (H.J.) CO (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $47,000.

title: THE SWISS ARE ASKED TO HELP CLEAR UP THE BANK MYSTERY
description: Swiss officials said today that the United States was asking for help in investigating possible fraud in connection with Iranian arms payments diverted through Swiss bank accounts to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Topics: Clean Sweeps; To Catch a Tape
description: The arrival of the VCR and the neighborhood video club offered new hope for movie fans - an opportunity to see films whole rather than ''edited for television.''

title: IRAQ REPORTS 12 DEAD, 39 HURT
description: Iran said today that it had shelled Basra, and Iraq reported air raids on Iranian bases and industrial targets.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Thursday about changes in Japan's tax system described that nation's national debt incorrectly. It is expected to exceed $880 billion by next spring.

title: RISE IN COLLEGE COSTS CHALLENGED
description: AS college costs have risen dramatically in the past five years, questions have been raised over whether the tuition increases are justified and who is being hurt by them.

title: JAPANESE-U.S. KIN PRESS RIGHTS CASE
description: Friends and relatives of Minoru Yasui, a pioneer in the legal redress of the treatment of Americans of Japanese ancestry in World War II, have called for a continuation, despite his recent death, of his 44-year-old legal battle.

title: Pro Football Notebook; POLICE ARE INVESTIGATING LANDRY INCIDENT
description: The police in Anaheim, Calif., yesterday were still investigating an incident Sunday night in which a caller to Anaheim Stadium said his brother, ''a mental patient,'' was at the game and intended to shoot Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys.

title: DAVIS CITED AS MEMBER OF VIOLENT ASSAULT GANG
description: Larry Davis was part of a small, loosely organized, ''very violent'' group of gunmen who have robbed, assaulted and slain drug dealers in the Bronx and northern Manhattan in recent months, the Bronx District Attorney said yesterday.

title: HARPER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Elderly People Studied
description: A study released today showed many elderly people avoid hearing aids, may not take their high blood pressure pills and sometimes have trouble getting to sleep at night.

title: YOUTH IS GUILTY IN JULY SHOOTING OF A POLICEMAN
description: Shavod Jones, a 15-year-old East Harlem youth with a history of juvenile delinquency and emotional problems, was convicted yesterday of the attempted murder of a police officer.

title: 2 Makers Get Plane Orders
description: The European Airbus consortium has beaten the competition with a $1 billion contract from a Japanese airline, while the McDonnell Douglas Corporation received the second order for its proposed wide-bodied jet.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Allied-Signal To Sell 7 Units
description: Allied-Signal Inc. will seek to sell the seven units that make up most of its electronics and instrumentation division, the company said. The proceeds are expected to top $1 billion.

title: Clabir-Atlantic Bid
description: The Clabir Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., and its General Defense Corporation subsidiary said they hold a 7.4 percent stake in the Atlantic Research Corporation ''as a step to acquire all of the outstanding shares'' of the diversified high-technology concern. Clabir said it had purchased all of its 559,200 Atlantic common shares on the open market, at prices ranging from $23 to $23.25 a share.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Treasury-Issue Yields Mixed
description: Short-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday, but yields on long-term Treasury bonds declined after a day of erratic price changes.

title: Two Angry Cities
description: It is strange returning from Poland to find Paris seething with student protest, cleaning up the debris of willful destruction in some streets, planning a general strike.

title: ELECTRONIC 'ANKLE OF THE LAW' JAILS L.I. MAN
description: A Nassau County man has been jailed, caught by a computer that contends he paid two unauthorized visits to his girlfriend.

title: WRIGHT, PICKED AS HOUSE SPEAKER, URGES LIMIT ON TAX CUTS FOR RICH
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas was chosen today to be the new Speaker of the House, and he quickly suggested that Congress might delay the tax cuts for higher-income taxpayers in an overhaul of the tax code adopted earlier this year.

title: NOTES ON FASHION a pair called ''Bad Breath'' is studded with plastic scallions and garlic cloves. Terry Neidzialek shows hairpieces for $800 to $1,700: one called ''Under Construction'' features hair sculptured like an uncompleted roadway with a broken yellow stripe down the center. Julius Vitale makes montage neckties for
description: SUNDAY was Pearl Harbor Day and the Cockpit was filled with armchair flyboys attacking racks full of World War II-style bomber jackets. The Cockpit, a store decorated like an aircraft hangar, opened last month at 595 Broadway, at Houston Street, selling aviation clothing, flight gear and memorabilia. It is also a miniature flying museum, with a DC-3 cockpit in its window and an AT-6 attack plane inside. The store's authenticity even extends to its owner, Jeff Clyman, who talks as if he's been touched with the right stuff.

title: Trade Pact Set With Taiwan
description: Following a threat of trade retaliation, Taiwan has agreed to open its market to American beer, wine and cigarettes in a move expected to increase United States exports by about $150 million in the first year, both Governments announced today.

title: REBELS TO EVACUATE HONDURAS
description: The Nicaraguan rebels have agreed to a demand from the Honduran Government that they move all their troops into Nicaragua by spring, Honduran and rebel officials said today.

title: A Switch by Steinway
description: After about 20 years with Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a subsidiary of J. Walter Thompson, the tuneful folk at Steinway & Sons, Long Island City piano maker, after an agency review, are switching their advertising account. The new agency is Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, which expects to handle the assignment largely with direct response advertising. The client says the budget will be in seven figures, all to the left of the decimal point, one hopes.

title: GIULIANI PROPOSES A COMMISSION TO DEAL WITH UNETHICAL OFFICIALS
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, called last night for the creation of a commission that would bring to public view what he described as ''noncriminal, unethical behavior'' by New York public officials.

title: Why the Debacle Shouldn't Hearten Liberals
description: Most Democrats, like most other Americans, are concerned about the effect of the Iranian-contra scandal on the standing of the United States in the world. But many Democrats are also privately gleeful that the affair seems to be scrubbing the Teflon off President Reagan. Such a visceral reaction is natural. Yet the President's debacle is no cause for a liberal celebration. By an ironic twist, Mr. Reagan - an antigovernment man to the core -has managed to accomplish something that the liberals had not: revival of the public's faith in government. Should that faith erode once more, the liberals would suffer along with everyone else.

title: ANTICANCER SUBSTANCE REVEALS ITS DARK SIDE
description: A POTENTIALLY important anticancer substance is leading a double life that promises to help clarify the bright and dark sides of the human body's reaction to disease.

title: Market Place; Large Demand For British Gas
description: THE record $8 billion public offering of British Gas P.L.C. was greeted yesterday with strong investor demand worldwide, and American institutional investors showed a particularly robust appetite for the new issue.

title: Army Suspends Firing Of Anti-Tank Missile
description: The United States Army has suspended training and test firing of TOW anti-tank missiles of the type shipped to Iran because of two recent accidents with aging launch motors, Army officers said today.

title: ADMINISTRATION PREDICTS 3.2% GROWTH NEXT YEAR
description: The Reagan Administration today predicted a fifth straight year without a recession, with the economy growing by a relatively healthy 3.2 percent next year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a London dispatch on Saturday, about a British baron's exoneration in a spy case, was omitted from page 3 in some copies and replaced by duplicate sections of a Paris dispatch that appeared on the same page. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: 7.6% Rise Seen In '87 Spending
description: Death, taxes and a Bob Coen forecast in December. Those are sure things. And you can also bet that

title: JAZZ: INNOVATIVE SAXOPHONE
description: A CASUAL listener encountering solo performances by the saxophonists Evan Parker and Hamiet Bluiett might assume that recorded tapes or electronics were being used. But while many contemporary instrumentalists have been using technology in their search for new sounds, others have concentrated on developing new instrumental techniques. Mr. Parker and Mr. Bluiett gave impressive demonstrations of some of these techniques on Saturday at Washington Square Church.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $229,000 and $420,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bulgarian Quake Kills Child
description: One child was killed, at least 60 people were injured and more than 3,000 were left homeless by a Bulgarian earthquake on Sunday. Its epicenter was near Strazhitsa, 145 miles east of Sofia.

title: Yugo Likes Its New Campaign
description: WILLIAM E. PRIOR, president of Yugo America, took a chance on a relatively unknown ad agency and it seems to be paying off.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nothing ever gets settled in this town. It's not like running a company, or even a university.

title: JACKSON CAUTIONS JAPANESE ON BIAS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, accusing Japanese corporations of ''redlining'' minority-group businesses in the United States, said tonight that he would encourage a consumer boycott of Japanese products unless a ''new relationship'' was created.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension expense.

title: Beverly Hills Hotel to Davis Group
description: A partnership led by Marvin Davis, as expected, said today that it would purchase the Beverly Hills Hotel from Ivan F. Boesky, his wife and her family. Sources said the price was about $135 million.

title: Dow Gains 5.20 as Prices Are Mixed
description: Wall Street stock prices closed mixed yesterday, with blue-chip issues snapping a three-day slump.

title: HIGHER BID ENDED AFTER CARTER REBUFF
description: The Limited-DeBartolo group abruptly withdrew its tender offer for Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. yesterday after the California company rejected a sweetened bid and announced it was splitting off its specialty-store businesses into a separate chain that would become publicly owned.

title: LOUISVILLE DEFEATS FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON
description: Pervis Ellison scored 21 points and Tony Kimbro added 17 to lead Louisville to an 82-74 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight.

title: STAGE: 'NIGHT WATCH,' BY LUCILLE FLETCHER
description: THE main mystery about ''Night Watch'' is what possessed the Equity Library Theater to serve up this turkey, which has not been seen in New York since its original 1972 Broadway run, without the excuse of Thanksgiving. Written by Lucille Fletcher -who, if she is fortunate, will be remembered for the radio play, ''Sorry, Wrong Number'' - it's an attempt to carry off an American version of a British specialty: sneaky goings-on in a houseful of suspects. Sorry, wrong number. This being New York, the premises are a fancy apartment in Kips Bay, from which one can see into an abandoned tenement. Did Elaine Wheeler really see a body or two there, or is she, as her husband, John, and her best friend, Blanche, apparently believe, going cuckoo? But can John and Blanche, who are having an affair, be trusted? Blanche is the sort of woman who wears a black negligee. Are they trying to spirit Elaine off to a clinic in Switzerland so they can commit hanky-panky on her money? (Elaine is an heiress.) What are those pills they keep feeding her? (Blanche is a nurse.) Is somebody trying to drive Elaine even battier by reminding her of an accident eight years before in which her first husband was killed, along with his 20-year-old blond mistress?

title: PHILIPPINE COMMUNISTS SAY ARMY MOVE IMPERILS TRUCE
description: Communist negotiators said today that a cease-fire scheduled to begin in two days could be jeopardized by a military order allowing troops to patrol in rebel areas and to seize weapons from insurgents.

title: CAPTURED ISRAELIS CITED IN ARMS DEAL
description: Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon were to have been freed under the transaction in which United States arms were sent to Iran, and they would have been released if the deal had remained secret, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M.

title: Malaysian Car Deal
description: Bricklin Industries said it would import a Malaysian subcompact car, the Proton Saga, beginning in February 1988.

title: Asbestos Case Settlements
description: The Raytech Corporation said its Raymark Industries unit had agreed to settle between 10,000 and 15,000 asbestos injury cases for about $2,821 a case, or about $42 million.

title: ECONOMY BOOMS IN SWAMPY AMHERST
description: Once an uninviting swamp, this suburb of Buffalo is emerging as a major economic force in upstate New York. Dubbed the ''boom town on the rust belt,'' Amherst is currently the state's fourth-largest municipality north of metropolitan New York, and it continues to grow while much of the rest of the region declines.

title: LOS ANGELES SCHOOL BOARD VOTES TO DELAY YEAR-ROUND SCHEDULING
description: The board of the Los Angeles Unified School District voted late today to postpone its plan to put more of its 618 schools on a year-round schedule for the 1987-88 school year.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $128,000 for the quarter and $230,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter includes reversal of a $328,000 tax benefit recorded in the first quarter of this year and the latest 6 months includes the approximately $500,000 nonrecurring expense of a contractual obligation related to the resignation of the company's former president, expensed in the first quarter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Dec. 2 about preparations for the bicentennial celebration of the Constitution misidentified the author of a book, ''The Enduring Constitution: An Exploration of the First 200 Years,'' which is to be published in connection with the event. He is Jethro K. Lieberman.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PERPETUAL ORGY. Flaubert and Madame Bovary. By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated from the Spanish by Helen Lane. 240 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $17.95.

title: A Sinister Role for Honduras in U.S. Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOBACCO TAX FINANCING NEW CANCER INSTITUTE IN FLORIDA
description: In the mid-1970's, Joseph Lumia, a prominent young accountant and civic leader here, developed cancer and slowly, painfully, began to die. He was the close friend and campaign treasurer for a State Representative from Tampa named H. Lee Moffitt. ''I saw the anguish and deterioration, and the pain he endured,'' Mr. Moffitt said. ''It hit me very hard.''

title: COUPLE IN WEST KILL 6 IN DISPUTE THAT MAY HAVE BEEN OVER A DOG
description: A man and a woman today killed six people, including two young girls, in what may have been a quarrel over the ownership of a dog, relatives of the victims and the police said. Three other people survived the attack.

title: FRANCE POSTPONES A TERRORIST TRIAL
description: A French judge today indefinitely postponed the murder trial of suspected members of the terrorist group Direct Action after a juror's withdrawal left the court without enough jurors to try the case.

title: Venezia Is Injured
description: Mike Venezia was thrown and kicked in the head and chest yesterday by his mount, Champagne Split, while in the walking ring before Aqueduct's fifth race. The 41-year-old jockey was conscious and had movement in his extremities when taken by ambulance to Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre for precautionary X-rays. Mauricio Vasquez replaced Venezia aboard the 2-year-old filly who finished seventh in the field of 10.

title: Continental Stock Is Sold by F.D.I.C.
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had sold 52.5 million shares of the bank holding company's common stock for $5.25 a share, and thus had completed its offering. The F.D.I.C., which became the majority shareholder in Continental Illinois as part of a $4.5 billion Federal bailout in 1984, had originally announced it would sell 50 million shares. However, the company said, the F.D.I.C. sold 2.5 million additional shares because the underwriters exercised their option to buy more shares to cover overallotments that resulted from investor interest.

title: MAYOR AND FORMER MAYOR ENTER CHICAGO PRIMARY
description: Mayor Harold Washington officially filed nominating petitions here today, seeking re-election as a Democrat - for now, anyway.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $159,300.

title: Transamerica Unit Will Be Spun Off
description: Continuing its divestiture of subsidiaries that are not part of its core business, the Transamerica Corporation said it had approved the spinoff of its manufacturing unit, Transamerica Delaval Inc., to shareholders effective Dec. 18. The manufacturing subsidiary will become a publicly traded company, which will be renamed Imo Delaval Inc.

title: STUDENTS PREVAIL IN FRENCH DISPUTE
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac surrendered to the key demand of protesting students today and announced that the Government was withdrawing legislation to overhaul the country's university system.

title: 2 Soviet Soldiers Flee To West Germany
description: Two 19-year-old Soviet soldiers serving in East Germany fled on foot across the heavily guarded border to West Germany over the weekend.

title: Labor Seeks Blood
description: Blood donations always decline this time of year, not out of any Scroogelike reaction to the holidays but because so many people are busily occupied by shopping and celebrating. Now, amid the persistent though mistaken concern that AIDS could somehow be transmitted in the course of donating blood, this year's holiday falloff in blood donations is expected to be even greater, and organized labor is joining with the American Red Cross in an attempt to encourage donors to come forward.

title: Judge Denies Dismissal In Friedman Stock Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday denied motions to dismiss state charges of securities and antitrust violations against Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and five others in connection with their involvement with Citisource Inc., a computer company that did business with the city.

title: JUDGE WON'T DISMISS PRESCHOOL MOLESTATION CASE
description: The judge in the McMartin preschool molestation case told the defense today that possible prosecution errors did not necessarily warrant dismissal because the truth would be buried forever if there were no trial.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1986
description: The World

title: INSIDE
description: Pretoria Detaining Children South African authorities acknowledged that children between the ages of 11 and 15 are being held under the nation's emergency decree.

title: Adm. Arthur Moreau Is Dead; NATO Chief in South Europe
description: Adm. Arthur S. Moreau Jr. the commander of NATO forces in southern Europe and United States naval forces in Europe, died of a heart attack today at a military hospital here.

title: MUSIC: BRONX ENSEMBLE IN A PROGRAM OF HANDEL
description: YOUNG Handel began to smooth and solidify his talents during a three-year residence in Italy beginning (we think) in 1706. One of the products of this quasi apprenticeship was a series of ''Serenatas'' - literally evening entertainments but in this context cantatas that appear operalike in their casts of characters and story lines.

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CBS WINS THE WHOLE KITTY
description: There is little about Peter Lund that suggests a riverboat gambler. Clean-shaven and silver-haired, his button-down manner is pretty much what you might expect from the president of CBS Sports.

title: Careers; Concern On Ethics Is Growing
description: ETHICS has become a common topic of conversation in the Wall Street area now that investment banking, the field chosen by the largest percentage of M.B.A. graduates from leading business schools, is the subject of insider trading investigations.

title: KIWANIS CLUB CAN BAN JERSEY WOMEN, COURT SAYS
description: Kiwanis International can refuse membership to women in New Jersey, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: AFTERSHOCK FROM DESCARTES' QUAKE THEORY
description: UNTIL last week, scientists thought they knew what caused almost all earthquakes: movements along faults, or cracks, in the earth's crust.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A Miami Dolphins defensive lineman, T.J. Turner, suffered a stiff neck yesterday when his car flipped over on a Miami highway. . . . Rueben Mayes of the New Orleans Saints, the N.F.L.'s leading rookie rusher with 1,241 yards, is expected to undergo surgery after the season to repair a frayed Achilles' tendon. . . . The Rangers yesterday recalled Raimo Helminen from their New Haven farm club. He will replace on the roster Lucien DeBlois, who will be out for about six weeks with sprained knee ligaments. . . . Brian Propp, the Philadelphia Flyers' highest scorer, will miss nine weeks because of a knee injury that required arthroscopic surgery yesterday, the team said.

title: ENDING BILINGUAL SCHOOLING
description: No sooner had the voters here overwhelmingly made English the official language of California than the campaign's sponsors began preparing legislation to put an end to bilingual education in the state. The legislation is part of what will be a major political battle over the survival of bilingual education in California.

title: Ex-FirstSouth Units Reopen
description: The Riverside Federal Savings Association opened with little commotion today as the successor to insolvent FirstSouth, which became the largest institution ever closed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: 'LEGENDS' TURNS A PROFIT WITHOUT BROADWAY
description: Who needs Broadway, or for that matter, who needs good reviews when you can play 21 cities over the course of a year and gross nearly $8 million? No show in recent years has posed that question more dramatically than ''Legends,'' in which Mary Martin and Carol Channing have been touring the country.

title: Hackensack Water Option
description: The Hackensack Water Company is offering $100 million of tax-exempt bonds through the New Jersey Economic Development Authority in an unusual transaction that gives investors the option of buying common stock in the water company rather than taking interest payments.

title: 2 Killed, 3 Hurt in Shootings Described as a Family Feud
description: Two men sprayed a pool hall and restaurant with rifle fire Sunday, killing two men and wounding three others in what investigators described as a family feud.

title: Sallie Mae Notes With Floating Rate
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million of short-term floating-rate notes at a price of par through various securities dealers.

title: OFFICIALS OFFER PLAN TO EASE ELECTION LAW
description: Sweeping changes to open the electoral process for both voters and candidates were proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch, the City Bar Association and several legislators.

title: Kilauea Eruption Destroys 11th House
description: Flowing molten rock from the erupting Kilauea volcano oozed across an 11th home and threatened three other houses in the evacuated area today.

title: NEWTON AND NBC TRADING FINAL TRIAL CHARGES
description: Brian Ross and Ira Silverman of NBC News set out to damage the reputation of Wayne Newton by falsely linking him to organized crime in a series of reports six years ago, the singer's attorney charged today.

title: THRIFT REGULATOR APOLOGIZES
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board apologized to Congress today for permitting large amounts of travel and personal expenses incurred by him and other bank board officials to be paid by organizations within the thrift industry, which he regulates.

title: Hamilton Job Cuts
description: The Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corporation said it planned to eliminate about 1,000 jobs from its salaried work force during 1987.

title: DR. LEO GOLDBERG
description: Dr. Leo Goldberg, director emeritus of urology at Queens Hospital Center, Creedmore State Hospital and Jamaica Hospital, died of a heart attack Saturday at Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif. He was 82 years old and had lived in Queens until he retired two years ago and moved to La Jolla.

title: In Search of Niceties, From Space to Art
description: In its quest to quantify the experience of the more than 460,000 people who squeeze onto Manhattan-bound subway trains at the height of the morning rush, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has come up with a ''crowding index.''

title: 3 DEMOCRATS RISE IN 100TH CONGRESS'S HOUSE LEADERSHIP: JAMES C. WRIGHT JR.
description: After he was chosen today by his fellow Democrats to be the new Speaker of the House, Representative Jim Wright of Texas praised the calming influence of Thomas S. Foley, the new majority leader.

title: OFFICIALS DEFENDING SCRIPT IN UPROAR OVER TELEVISED DRUG RAID
description: Law-enforcement officials were scrambling to bolster their evidence today as a dispute continued over a live national telecast of a drug arrest in a Houston suburb.

title: Q&A
description: Q.How do antiseptics kill bacteria and which are the most effective? A.The three most widely used antiseptics are alcohol, hydrogen peroxide and iodine, according to Dr. David Govaker of the Truman Medical Center East in Kansas City, Mo. Alcohol melts away the fat and protein layers of the bacteria cell membrane, killing the cell. Hydrogen peroxide bubbles when an enzyme peroxidase in the bacteria breaks down the hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. The bubbling dislodges the bacteria so it can be washed away. Like alcohol, iodine dissolves the cell membrane but it is much more powerful. Dr. Govaker said iodine is the safest and most effective antiseptic. Three drops will sterilize a quart of water. All three antiseptics will prevent infection of minor scrapes and bruises, Dr. Govaker said, but the best first aid is to wash the wound with soap and water twice a day. QHow is paternity determined and with what degree of accuracy? A.Paternity is established by comparing inherited characteristics of blood cells from the father, mother and child. For example, the membranes of white blood cells contain surface proteins known as antigens. Unrelated persons almost never have the same type of antigen, according to Dr. Wilma Bias, director of immunogenetics at The John Hopkins University School of Medicine. The most accurate paternity test uses antigens on white blood cells called leucocytes. On average, the test can rule out 90 percent or more of men as a child's father.

title: What's Wrong With Superstar Lecturers
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDENT KILLED IN SUBWAY DISPUTE
description: A 22-year-old Queens man was stabbed to death on a subway train in Queens yesterday afternoon after an argument that began when the victim asked his assailant, ''What are you staring at?'' the transit police said.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $4,100,000 for the quarter and $10,800,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: Savin President Resigns
description: Mel A. Mahler, president and chief operating officer of the Savin Corporation, a maker of office copying machines, has resigned to pursue investment-related activities, the company said yesterday. Savin, based in Stamford, Conn., said the position of president would not be filled and that the responsibilities of the chief operating officer would be assumed by David G. Sadler, chairman and chief executive. Mr. Mahler will remain as a director.

title: United States Envoy To Costa Rica Resigns
description: Lewis A. Tambs, the United States Ambassador to Costa Rica, has resigned effective Jan. 15, American officials in Washington and Costa Rica said today.

title: PANEL PRESENTS ROADWAY PLAN FOR WEST SIDE
description: A state panel announced plans yesterday for a $530 million roadway to replace the West Side Highway.

title: Foxboro Follies
description: The National Football League's controversial instant-replay process reached a new dimension in confusion Sunday at Foxboro, Mass. In one end zone, an official was signaling a touchdown for New England. In the other end zone, another official was signaling a touchdown for Cincinnati. And when the officials were finished spinning their inscrutable magic, neither team had scored.

title: Mr. Metaphor
description: If the networks are all listening, here's a nomination for a future jock-in-the-booth.

title: Koch Names Members To City Charter Panel
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named the rest of his 15-member Charter Revision Commission, which he decided to form after a Federal court ruled that the structure of the city's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional.

title: Promising Changes in Taiwan
description: The unexpectedly strong showing by the opposition in Taiwan's legislative elections will not much affect the day-to-day governance of the island. Yet it is another sign of change that Americans can welcome.

title: Bernard A. Rittersporn, 61, Former Republican Official
description: Bernard A. Rittersporn, a former Republican district leader in Manhattan and an authority on international trade and development, died of cancer Saturday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old.

title: SHULTZ 'SHOCKED,' DISCLOSES WHITE HOUSE SECRETLY USED U.S. ENVOY IN HOSTAGE TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz complained today that the White House, without informing him, had jumped the chain of command and established secret communications with the United States Ambassador in Lebanon on negotiations for the release of hostages.

title: Joy Manufacturing Rejects Pullman Bid
description: The Joy Manufacturing Company, a coal mining and petroleum equipment manufacturer based in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that its board had rejected an unsolicited $31-a-share, $527 million offer made last week by the Pullman-Peabody Company, a maker of train and truck equipment.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $217,000 and $701,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: In Washington, Revenge of the Nitpickers
description: The nailing of Ivan F. Boesky and the discovery of the Iranian-contra deal don't, on first blush, seem to have much in common. In fact, however, in both cases, events have gotten the better of the President's rhetoric. Ronald Reagan, like Jimmy Carter before him, campaigned against Washington, against the bureaucracy, against a stereotyped Federal nitpicker. Now - in the Boesky scandal, the Iran fiasco and a number of other cases - the nitpickers are getting their revenge.

title: SOFTWARE FOR THE AVERAGE USER
description: OVER the last couple of years, the path trod by personal computer users has forked into two distinct tracks. The so-called power users, like the hot-rodding teen-agers of yore, gladly spend much of their time customizing and reworking complex software to squeeze just a little more speed, a little more power, out of their machines. The second group more parallels the average commuter or shopper, who asks only that his vehicle deliver him to his appointed destination with as little hassle as possible.

title: Homosexual Seeks Job
description: A stenographer who worked for two years recording and transcribing President Reagan's speeches and press conferences has won a round in his court fight to regain the access to the White House that he lost when the Government discovered that he was a homosexual and cited security concerns.

title: TWICE SIGNED, LEGISLATION IS STILL CHALLENGED
description: A typographical error in the city's official newspaper has forced Mayor Koch to sign eight pieces of legislation a second time. And he may not be through yet.

title: Right League
description: Duane Kuiper, the former major league infielder, who's already playing in the Equitable Old-Timers Series at the relatively tender age of 35: ''It's not how old you are, it's how old you feel. And I feel as old as any of those guys.''

title: Mary St. John Villard Dies Was Head of Vassar Trustees
