description: Mary St. John Villard, a drama teacher and former chairman of the Vassar College board of trustees, died of cancer Friday at the home of her daughter, Elizabeth, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and Edgartown, Mass.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOKYO, OLD AND NEW The I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, 57th Street and Madison Avenue (407-6100), may have outdone itself with the exhibition that opens today: ''Tokyo: Form and Spirit.''

title: Canadian Tire Gets an Offer
description: Cara Operations Ltd., the Toronto-based food-services concern, has offered to buy the Canadian Tire Corporation under a plan that would pay holders of the company's common stock $100 (Canadian) a share. The total deal is estimated to be worth $1.58 billion (Canadian), or $1.14 billion (American).

title: New Melville Chairman To Keep to Strategies
description: The Melville Corporation, the giant specialty retailer associated with such names as Thom McAn shoes, Marshall's and Kay-Bee Toy and Hobby Stores, has named Stanley P. Goldstein chairman and chief executive effective Jan. 1.

title: Barge Removal Effort Is Postponed Again
description: Salvage crews were delayed again today in attempts to lift a partly submerged cargo barge pinned against the Peace Bridge out of the Niagara River.

title: NBC HEAD PROPOSES STAFF POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS
description: The president of NBC has urged that the network start a political action committee and that NBC employees who refuse to contribute to it ''question their own dedication to the company,'' according to sources at NBC.

title: IN SOCIALIST VINEYARD: WILL JAN. 25 TASTE SWEET?
description: ''We have no reason to be resigned,'' insisted Johannes Rau, twisting to the side of the podium and thrusting up the fingers of his right hand as if they contained a ball. ''The opinion pollsters have often been wrong.''

title: The Past in the Shuttle's Future
description: The Challenger space shuttle exploded last Jan. 28 because of a decision made 13 years ago - the choice of a flawed design for the shuttle's booster rockets. Yet even with seven astronauts dead, NASA seems set to brush past alternatives and continue with the same contractor and a new version of the same flawed design.

title: SANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: 3 DEMOCRATS RISE IN 100TH CONGRESS'S HOUSE LEADERSHIP: THOMAS S. FOLEY
description: Representative Thomas S. Foley has become the chief problem solver for House Democrats in the last two years and it was this skill that propelled him unopposed today into the No. 2 job in the House, majority leader.

title: Chess: Cuban Is the Surprise Victor In Junior Champion Match
description: The world junior championship in Gausdal, Norway, for players under 20 years old, was won unexpectedly by Walter Arencibia of Cuba. Arencibia and Simen Agdestein, a grandmaster from Norway, each scored 9 1/2-3 1/2 in the 60-player, 13-round Swiss-system tournament, but the Cuban was given the title because he won his individual third-round encounter against Agdestein.

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $417,472 and $337,246 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary credit of $205,427 from the termination of certain pension plans. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $47,613 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $187,886 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $1,670,397 from the termination of certain pension plans for both the quarter and year.

title: BOOK CIRCLE NOMINATES 25
description: Twenty-five books were nominated yesterday as the best of 1986 by members of the National Book Critics Circle. The books are:%T Fiction ''A Summons to Memphis'' by Peter Taylor (Alfred A. Knopf). ''The Beet Queen'' by Louise Erdrich (Henry Holt).

title: A Contractor Dismissed Over Schuylkill Delays
description: State transportation officials said today that the inability of a contractor to finish work on time had pushed back the expected completion of the Schuylkill Expressway overhaul from 1987 to 1989.

title: Carriage Horse Bolts, Dashes Down 51st St.
description: A carriage horse, apparently fightened by the heavy, noisy holiday traffic that was bottlenecked around the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, bolted free from its harness last evening and dashed down 51st Street, startling pedestrians and motorists.

title: U.S. TRADE WITH LIBYA CONTINUES
description: Scores of American companies, using more than 200 foreign-based subsidiaries, continue to trade with Libya despite the Reagan Administration's economic sanctions aimed at isolating the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi, according to Government investigators and unpublished Treasury Department data.

title: Brandeis Library Occupied in Protest
description: Students staged an all-night study-in at the Brandeis University library to protest the school's refusal to sell off its South Africa-related investments, a school official said Monday.

title: State's Job Authority To Offer Taxable Paper
description: The New York Job Development Authority announced plans yesterday to supplement its regular sales of tax-exempt bonds with offerings of up to $50 million of commercial paper in the taxable securities market.

title: MEN'S GIFTS: TOUCH OF ADVENTURE
description: The two young boys were standing on line to see Macy's Santa the other afternoon. During the long wait one youngster turned to the other and said: ''If you've been bad, you'll get underwear and socks. If you've been good you'll get good things.''

title: ELOQUENT ENFORCER
description: The life that A. C. Green left behind is around every corner, behind every door and outside the locker room of virtually every arena in the National Basketball Association. It's the parties, the friendly faces, the exciting places.

title: Robins Officer Leaves Post
description: Robert P. Wolf, vice president, general counsel and secretary of the A.H. Robins Company, announced his resignation yesterday.

title: Just Like The Big Guys
description: The Public Schools Athletic League is trying to find a solution to some recent misconduct on the football field. Too frequently, it seems, New York City's schoolboys have been cheap-shotting and engaging in other unnecessary rough stuff against their opponents, with the result that at least four games in the season's last two months degenerated into brawling between the teams.

title: Cuba Reports Millions Join Five-Day Defense Exercises
description: Millions of Cubans are taking part in military exercises aimed at preparing the population to defend the island against a surprise air attack, the Cuban press agency Prensa Latina reported today.

title: L.I. Train Derails, But No One Is Hurt
description: FAR ROCKAWAY (AP)

title: Brazilian Output Rises
description: Brazil's industrial output set a record in October for the second consecutive month, the Government reported today. The nation's production index rose to 144.98 (on a 1981 base of 100) from 139.04 in September. But the rate of growth slowed.

title: Bridge: Team of World Champions Wins Major Title in Atlanta
description: A team of world champions demonstrated its strength by winning a major championship at the conclusion here of the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: TROOPS WOUND 6 IN WEST BANK PROTESTS
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded six stone-throwing Palestinians in the West Bank today as Arab demonstrations against Israeli occupation of the area continued for a fifth day, Israeli Army spokesmen said.

title: Topics: Clean Sweeps; Custodial Control
description: Who runs New York City's public schools? Not the principals but the custodians, goes a familiar joke. Nowadays, it's no joke. The Board of Education has ceded a surprising amount of authority to custodians.

title: The Difference A Year Makes
description: These are the season's most improved Division I-A football teams, ranked according to their number of games ahead (GA) of last year's records:

title: Bad Weather May Bar Light Plane's Trip
description: Nasty weather over the tropics has delayed the experimental Voyager airplane's attempt to fly around the world without refueling and could ground it indefinitely, project officials said today.

title: America's Cup USA Upsets Conner's Yacht
description: Tom Blackaller's USA knocked off one of the giants in the America's Cup trials today by beating Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes.

title: Panel Criticizes Plan To Drop King Holiday
description: A reported move by the Arizona's Governor-elect to cancel a state holiday next month honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was criticized today by the King Federal Holiday Commission.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 8 P.M. (TV -MSG, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) SACRAMENTO KINGS VS.

title: FINDING THE MEAN STREETS JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: ONE day this semester in Social Welfare 308, Mark Harrigan raised his hand and said that instead of just talking theory, it might make sense to go see some poverty on Long Island first-hand.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS RISE IN 100TH CONGRESS'S HOUSE LEADERSHIP: ANTHONY L. COELHO
description: For the last six years, Representative Tony Coelho has devoted himself to elections - other people's elections. So there was a certain symmetry, if not inevitability, to his comfortable victory today in the first election ever held for majority whip of the House of Representatives.

title: Lane Rejects Offer
description: The Lane Company said its board had rejected an acquisition offer from Interco Inc. as inadequate and had authorized its legal advisers and its financial adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, to explore ways to achieve maximum shareholder values.

title: A G.P.U. Director To Add 2 Top Jobs
description: John F. O'Leary, who joined the board of the General Public Utilities Company several months after the March 1979 accident at its Three Mile Island nuclear plant, was named yesterday to be the utility's chairman and chief executive.

title: What'll Ya Gimme For a Rufus King?
description: It may never come to a youngster offering to trade a Thomas Mifflin, a William Blount and an Alexander Martin for a single George Washington as young fans once exchanged, say, a Zeke (Bananas) Bonura, a Marv Throneberry and a Van Lingle Mungo for one Joe DiMaggio. But who knows? Financed partly by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Miracle at Philadelphia project has just published a set of what ordinarily would be described as baseball cards except that they depict the delegates to the Constitutional Convention instead of ball players and, rather than batting averages, the statistics relate to their votes on the Constitution and their places in history. Timed for the Bicentennial of the Constitution next year, they are to be distributed free to schools in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware.

title: U.S. COPTERS FINISH HONDURAN MISSION; CLASHES MAY GO ON
description: Nine United States helicopters today finished ferrying Honduran troops to the border area where fighting has reportedly been taking place between Honduran and Nicaraguan forces.

title: People
description: * Cynthia Webber has been named a senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: PISTOL PRESENTED AS EVIDENCE IN STATE TROOPER SLAYING TRIAL
description: The state entered in evidence today a black 9-millimeter, semiautomatic Browning pistol it says Richard C. Williams used to kill State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Temple 103, Penn 67: Nate Blackwell scored 22 points and Mike Vreeswyk and Tim Perry each added 18 as Temple defeated rival Penn (0-3) last night in a Big 5 game. The Owls converted 11 of 20 3-point attempts, including four by Vreeswyk, as they won their 24th straight home game. Temple (6-1) led, 40-25 at the half. (AP) Ohio State 89, Bowling Green 52: Dennis Hopson scored 24 points and Jerry Francis added 18 to lead Ohio State to a rout in Columbus. The Buckeyes (5-0) jumped to a 7-0 lead and were in command all the way. They led, 37-18, at halftime. The Falcons (1-2) cut Ohio State's 23-point lead to 52-36 six minutes into the second half on consecutive 3-point goals by Frank Booker. But the Buckeyes then went on a 29-8 spurt. (AP) Boston College 72, Utica 60: Dana Barros got 13 of his game-high 19 points in the first half as Boston College powered past Utica. Barros, who had eight rebounds and five assists, led Boston College to a first-half lead, 37-23. In the second half, the Eagles unloaded the bench while holding off the visitors by as much as 18 points.(AP) Illinois 85, Eastern Illinois 51: Ken Norman scored 21 points to lead Illinois. No other Illini player reached double figures as Coach Lou Henson substituted early and often en route to the victory that improved Illinois' record to 5-0. Eastern Illinois (2-1) was led by Dave Stein, who scored 11 points, and Norm Evans with 10.

title: Some Seek to Say 'Senate'
description: For nearly 150 years now, members of the House have been required by their rules to speak of ''the other body'' instead of ''the Senate,'' but this small vestigial inconvenience may finally be on its way out. This week, the House Democratic Caucus will vote on a proposal to per-mit representatives to refer to actions taken by the Senate on legislation without using the archaic euphemism.

title: Mortgage Lag Narrows
description: The percentage of homeowners who are 30 days or more late on their mortgage payments is at the lowest level in more than two years, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today. A survey of 10 million mortgage loans made by more than 400 lenders showed that overdue payments declined to 5.42 percent in the third quarter from 5.71 percent in the second quarter.

title: Talking Business with Wingfield of CIT Group; Asset-Based Lending Grows
description: Corporate borrowing that uses equipment, real estate and other assets as collateral became a $57 billion-plus industry last year and is still increasing its penetration in the business world. Moreover, for those companies that use this asset-based financing, typically private concerns with annual sales ranging from $1 million to $250 million, it is likely to be the only way to finance their growth.

title: Leprosy Vaccine Is Tested
description: The World Health Organization is testing a new anti-leprosy vaccine that, if proved efficient, could help eradicate the disease within the next 10 years, Director General Halfdan Mahler said today. He said at a news conference that the vaccine was being tested in Venezuela, Malawi and Norway and would soon be tested in Japan. The vaccine could be on the market in three to five years, he said.

title: Greenhouse Calculations
description: Scientists worry that dangerous climatic changes may ensue from the so-called greenhouse effect: the excessive trapping of the sun's heat by growing levels of carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere.

title: PRETORIA ADMITS DETAINING CHILDREN
description: The South African authorities acknowledged for the first time today that children between the ages of 11 and 15 are being held under the nation's emergency decree, which permits detention without trial.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Controlling Nonmedallion Taxi Service A bill giving the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission regulatory authority over an estimated 35,000 nonmedallion, or livery, vehicles providing taxi service is expected to be voted on by the City Council today.

title: 3 Maryland Candidates
description: Mack Brown, head football coach and athletic director at Tulane, is one of three candidates being considered to replace Bobby Ross as Maryland coach, The New Orleans Times-Picayune reported. Maryland's search committee, headed by the acting athletic director, Charles Sturtz, interviewed Brown Friday, and another meeting reportedly was scheduled for this week, the newspaper said.

title: Cadbury-Coke British Venture
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. and the Coca-Cola Company have established a joint venture to bottle, can and distribute soft drinks in Britain. The new concern, called Coca-Cola and Schweppes Beverages Ltd., will be that country's largest marketer of soft drinks.

title: AIDS in the Third World
description: AIDS, already rampant in Africa, may soar in Latin America and Asia unless swift preventive measures are taken, according to a World Health Organization official. In many developing countries with only a small number of reported cases up to now, the rise in the disease parallels that of the United States several years ago, when the epidemic was silently spreading.

title: LENDL DISPOSES OF BECKER AND HIS CLAIM TO THRONE
description: It was time for Ivan Lendl to silence his critics in men's tennis, to serve notice that his days as No. 1 were not dwindling to a precious few. Boris Becker, the brash 19-year-old West German, had fueled such talk in recent weeks, suggesting he was the likely successor. In his familiar dispassionate way, Lendl listened and plotted his reply.

title: Scientists Study Fidgeting
description: Fidgeting is an important way of burning up calories, and some people squirm and wiggle away the equivalent of jogging several miles each day, researchers have found.

title: Shearson to Raise Stake in McLeod
description: McLeod Young Weir Ltd., one of Canada's largest securities firms, said Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. would increase its stake in McLeod to 30 percent, from 10 percent.

title: USAIR TO BUY P.S.A. FOR $400 MILLION
description: USAir Group Inc., whose airline serves mainly the Eastern United States, announced yesterday that it was acquiring Pacific Southwest Airlines, which mostly flies between Los Angeles and San Francisco, for about $400 million.

title: A New Field For Citicorp
description: Citicorp is entering the business of public money transfers, long dominated by the Western Union Corporation.

title: AMIABLE PEROT AND SMITH DISCUSS SPLIT AT G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation made its offer to buy back the stock of H. Ross Perot after Mr. Perot hinted that he would vote against executive bonuses and threatened to provoke a confrontation on the G.M. board of directors over the management of his company, the Electronic Data Services Corporation, Mr. Perot said today.

title: Perot on Iran Role: No Second Thoughts
description: H. Ross Perot declined to respond today to criticism of his financing of actions to free hostages held in Iran, except to comment that officials in Washington responsible for foreign policy ''are under a lot of pressure.''

title: WHAT IS THE MEANING OF CANNIBALISM?
description: CANNIBALISM has at once fascinated and repelled virtually every known society, including those said to have practiced it. Anthropologists think the study of something that resonates so powerfully in the psyche can illuminate human nature.

title: REAGAN WON'T ASK EX-AIDES FOR DETAILS
description: President Reagan has rejected the pleas of close political allies that he personally ask two former National Security Council officials to tell him the details of the shipments of United States arms to Iran and the subsequent funneling of profits to Nicaraguan rebels, according to Administration officials.

title: COURT TO HEAR LSD CASE AGAINST GOVERNMENT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the Government's contention that a former sergeant who was given the hallucinogenic drug LSD without his knowledge in secret Army experiments in 1958 has no right to bring a damage suit against the Government and responsible officials.

title: Japanese Fund Leeway
description: Japan's postal savings system will be allowed to invest some of its funds in foreign bonds, beginning April 1, the Finance Ministry said today. Half of the money must go into Japanese Government bonds. Until now, all of it has been in the Finance Ministry's trust fund, used for public purposes.

title: IN STUDY, EXPERTS CALL FOR IMPROVING NEW YORK CITY POLICE
description: The New York City Police Department must improve its ability to recruit, train and manage qualified officers if it is to fight crime effectively and retain public trust, leading law-enforcement experts told a mayoral panel yesterday.

title: COAST BANK PURSUER IN FED PLEA
description: The First Interstate Bancorp, dramatically stepping up its pursuit of the BankAmerica Corporation, asked the Federal Reserve Board today for permission to acquire BankAmerica, through a hostile offer if necessary.

title: In Signing Bills, Reagan Tries to Write History
description: The traditional battleground for fighting over the meaning of a new law is the courtroom, where Federal judges scrutinize the language and history of a disputed statute to figure out what Congress intended and how the law should be applied.

title: Eight Children Killed in Fire
description: Eight children left alone at home died in a fire Sunday when they used gasoline in trying to rekindle a wood-burning stove, the authorities said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS (NYT COLUMN)BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: STUDY DISPUTES TEACHER SHORTAGE PREDICTIONS
description: Widespread predictions of a teacher shortage that will reach crisis levels within the next several years were disputed today in a new study that describes those views as alarmist and unrealistic.

title: Assembly Approves Curbs on Drug Tests
description: A bill limiting the right of private employers to force workers to submit to drug tests was approved yesterday by the New Jersey Assembly.

title: O'BRIEN'S SLIPPAGE IS ENIGMA FOR JETS
description: Through all the Jets' victories earlier this season, through the last-second heroics against the Dolphins, through fourth-quarter comebacks, Ken O'Brien's poise was a matter of record.

title: 3M Agrees To Tests In Space
description: NASA and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company have signed an agreement for the firm to carry out 62 materials processing experiments during future shuttle flights over a 10-year period, the space agency announced today.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GIANTS WERE WINNERS IN BATTLE OF WITS
description: Were those really the Washington Redskins the Giants beat so decisively Sunday? You could hardly prove it by Bill Belichick, the Giants' defensive coordinator.

title: British Get New Contract For 'Star Wars' Work
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger assigned $10 million worth of work today on the anti-missile project known as ''Star Wars to the British Ministry of Defense. It was the second time in a week, that he used a visit to a European capital to award research contracts on the system.

title: HOUSE HEARINGS ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: VISUALLY, it wasn't great; dramatically, it lacked crescendos. On television yesterday, the House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing did not have the urgency of, say, a correspondent's stand-up on the White House lawn. If you missed it, however, you were so much the poorer. At the very least, it showed the democratic process at work. It also showed that the process, on television, is played out in an arena in which the winners are those who stay self-possessed.

title: RETIRED AIR FORCE GENERAL NAMED AS CENTRAL FIGURE IN SECRET TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today identified a retired Air Force officer, Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, as a central figure in the Reagan Administration's secret diplomacy with Iran.

title: ELIE WIESEL'S HOMETOWN: FEW TRACES OF PAST
description: From this small town in the Carpathian Mountains, where Rumania, Hungary and the Soviet Union meet, Elie Wiesel began his long and searing journey that led to the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: CHIMPS STOLEN FROM AIDS LAB
description: Animal rights activists have stolen four baby chimpanzees to be used for AIDS and hepatitis research from a medical laboratory here, representatives of an animal rights group said today.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago 9 months' sales includes about $2.4 million of sales related to a Canadian subsidiary that was sold during December 1985.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Chicago is tentatively offering $110 million of water revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber.

title: PERCEPTION TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $37,500.

title: CLEVELAND MAYOR FEELS SAFE IN ISRAEL, BUT SORRY
description: Mayor George V. Voinovich, who is on an official trip to Tel Aviv, stirred up controversy at home in absentia today when he was quoted as saying that he felt safer in Israel than in some parts of his own city.

title: Ohrenstein Offers Mass Transit Plan
description: Manfred Ohrenstein, the minority leader of the State Senate, called yesterday for $963 million in state aid over the next 30 years to help rebuild the New York City region's mass transit system.

title: Frailty and Finality
description: To the Editor:

title: SYMBOL OF DEBATE: SORBONNE'S LOST LUSTER
description: Just inside the entrance to the Sorbonne is a touch of grandeur: an inner courtyard of cobblestones and ancient arcades, of mosaics and sculpted columns suitable to one of history's great institutions of higher learning.

title: 'Gray Market' Grew With Rise of Dollar
description: The American consumer's opportunity to buy a wide range of imported luxury goods and electronic devices from unauthorized dealers at steep discounts is now in the hands of the United States Supreme Court.

title: METS DRAFT PITCHER TO BOLSTER STAFF
description: For the first time in five years, the Mets drafted a player from somebody else's farm system today, and they conceded that it was a sign of thinning ranks in their own farm system.

title: Syntex Fills Two Key Posts
description: The Syntex Corporation said today that Paul E. Freiman had been elected president and chief operating officer and that Thomas L. Gutshall had been elected executive vice president. Albert Bowers, 56 years old, Syntex's chairman and chief executive officer, has served as president of the Palo Alto, Calif., pharmaceutical company since the retirement of Richard G. Rogers in December 1985.

title: Unusual Visit By Whales
description: An unusual appearance of as many as three dozen blue whales in Monterey Bay has given researchers a rare close-up look at Earth's largest creatures.

title: At Hearings, Trade Gets Personal
description: They came to the Commerce Department to air the pros and cons of higher tariffs on softwood lumber from Canada. But the issue just as easily could have been lamb meat from New Zealand, porcelain-on-steel cooking ware from Mexico or baby's breath, carnations and chrysanthemums from Peru.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income of $233,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss of $2,735,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-After losses of $144,000 and $1,215,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. d-Net income The company said the 1985 year figures reflects results of Drew National Corporation, prior to the distribution of Drew Industries common stock in May 1985.

title: A LESSON FROM SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who was once a professor, used his appearance before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today to teach the Congress and the country a little about the way the country is and is not governed in the Reagan era.

title: OMAHA MAYOR RAISES DRINKING HABIT AS ISSUE
description: Mayor Michael Boyle, facing an election in which residents will decide whether to remove him from office, has begun his campaign to stay on as Mayor by raising an issue that has not been mentioned by his opponents: his drinking habits.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TESTIMONY BY SHULTZ AND McFARLANE IN HOUSE
description: Following are excerpts from testimony of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Robert C. McFarlane, former national security adviser, at the House Foreign Affairs Committee in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: High Court To Rule On Imports
description: In a case that could affect the ability of consumers to buy cameras, watches, perfumes and other costly imported goods at steep discounts, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the validity of Federal regulations that allow ''gray market'' imports.

title: Ford Recalls 74,000 Autos For Emission Control Flaws
description: The Ford Motor Company is recalling 74,000 1986 Ford Escort EXPs and Mercury Lynx cars because of emission control problems, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: CONCERT: VIRTUOSI SYMPHONY
description: THE New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony chose a brief, engaging program for its Sunday night concert at Alice Tully Hall - unfamiliar works by two Americans (Gideon Waldrop's ''Pressures'' and Arthur Foote's Suite in E for strings), Mozart's Overture to ''The Impresario'' and Beethoven's Symphony No. 1 in C (Op. 21).

title: METRO AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Florida Infant Treated After Eating Cocaine
description: An 18-month-old boy who the police say ate four chunks of the highly potent form of cocaine called crack after a party in his mother's home was treated at a hospital, officers said today. The woman's boyfriend was arraigned on drug and child abuse charges.

title: Behind the Shortage Of Donated Organs
description: To the Editor:

title: Frontiere Sentenced
description: Dominic Frontiere, an Emmy-winning composer and the husband of Georgia Frontiere, the owner of the Los Angeles Rams, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and fined $15,000 yesterday on Federal tax charges. He had pleaded guilty on Oct. 22 to tax charges stemming from the scalping of thousands of tickets to the 1980 Super Bowl. He also was sentenced to three years' probation by United States District Judge William D. Keller, who ordered the 55-year-old Frontiere to surrender Jan. 5.

title: Swiss Reject a Plan to Serve Surplus Wine to the Soldiers
description: The federal Government rejected a legislator's suggestion today to offer surplus wine and grape juice free to members of the Swiss militia army.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said its latest first quarte results include expenses of about $925,000 for fees paid to legal and investment advisers and for costs associated with its aborted self-tender offer.

title: BOWEN PROTESTS REAGAN PLAN TO CUT HEALTH BUDGET
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today challenged many of the budget cuts proposed for his agency by the White House Office of Management and Budget.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings for the latest periods have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effected as a stock dividend in April 1986.

title: A&E OFFERS 'WATERS OF THE MOON,' A 50'S PLAY
description: WHATEVER happened to the well-made play? One answer is that it is hanging around waiting for a revival on television whenever an actress like Penelope Keith might be looking for a suitable vehicle to display and stretch her special talents. Miss Keith is best known over here for her appearances in some first-rate British sitcoms (''Good Neighbors,'' ''To the Manor Born''), but she is also a working stage actress with something of a cult following in England. Her more ambitious work for television has included a sparkling production of Frederick Lonsdale's ''On Approval,'' seen here a couple of years ago, and now ''Waters of the Moon,'' which cable's Arts & Entertainment Network is presenting tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: Japan Reforms Taxes, but Not Trade
description: Prime Minister Nakasone's plan for tax reform, announced with fanfare last week in Tokyo, is certain to be popular with Japan's overtaxed wage-earners. But it isn't going to please policy makers, on both sides of the Pacific, who are trying to ease trade frictions between Japan and America. Sadly, the reform will do little to stimulate domestic demand for Japanese products or reduce Japan's dependence on exports for its prosperity.

title: SAW PERIL IN ATOM BOMB HE HELPED DEVELOP
description: Harrison Brown, who played a key role in producing plutonium for the first atomic bombs, then spent much of his career trying to prevent further use of such weapons, died yesterday in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 69 years old.

title: JUDGE CONTINUES BAN ON LIMITING TAXICAB SERVICE
description: A Manhattan judge issued an injunction yesterday that extended a ban on taxi drivers' refusing to pick up passengers at La Guardia Airport, Pennsylvania Station or other heavily traveled areas.

title: Gates to Sell Cobey Its Stake in Learjet
description: The Gates Corporation said it had signed a contract to sell its 64.8 percent interest in the Gates Learjet Corporation to the Cobey Corporation, an investment concern, for $62.7 million.

title: THE METS' $200,000 MISTAKE?
description: Over more than three decades, from Johnny Podres to Bret Saberhagen, the winner of the World Series most valuable player award had always returned to the same team the next season. And usually for several seasons. But on opening day Ray Knight won't be wearing a Mets uniform.

title: COSMETIC & FRAGRANCE CONEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Dissident Seeks Support
description: Without fanfare, Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident released earlier this year, is making a quiet visit to Washington for meetings in the White House, the State Department and in Congress, leading up to a ceremony on Human Rights Day tomorrow.

title: RAIL UNIONS' POWER BASE SLOWLY ERODING
description: For more than a century the nation's railroad unions have been the aristocracy of American labor. But mergers, deregulation and technical innovations are eroding that status.

title: Seahawks Stun Raiders, 37-0
description: Dave Krieg passed for two touchdowns, Curt Warner ran for two and Seattle's defense recorded 11 sacks tonight as the Seahawks kept their National Football League playoff hopes alive with a 37-0 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Books; Making the Law
description: THE U. S. SENATE. Paralysis or a Search for Consensus? By George E. Reedy. 218 pages. Crown. $16.95.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1986
description: Companies

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armstrong World Industries, Lancaster, Pa., said it had terminated talks with Summitville Tilers Inc. regarding its intention to acquire Summitville.

title: LINK OF 'PIZZA' MURDER VICTIM TO A HEROIN DEAL IS SUSPECTED
description: Authorities investigating last week's murder of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial are studying a suspected link between the victim, Gaetano Mazzara, and an accused heroin dealer, according to police and Government investigators.

title: Quake Risk at San Jose May Be Overstated
description: A study of ground slippage in San Francisco's catastrophic 1906 earthquake suggests that scientists may have overstated the risk that a devastating quake could rock the high-technology area of California sometime soon.

title: Asia Has a Stake in Arms Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Arctic Pollution
description: One thinks of polar air as the purest on Earth. Yet last March, as a research plane flew over the Arctic pack ice north of Point Barrow, Alaska, it encountered a sooty cloud so dense that Dr. Russell Schnell, one of those on board, said ''we thought we had flown into the plume of a volcanic eruption.''

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES SLASH PRICES IN WAVE OF SALES
description: For a limited time, it is possible to buy all seven volumes of ''The Papers of Andrew Johnson'' for $117.25 instead of the usual $234.50, or three volumes of ''The Letters of Samuel Johnson'' for $82.50 instead of $113.50. And anyone willing to wait until next month can buy the 19 volumes of ''A Social and Religious History of the Jews'' by Salo W. Baron for $350, less than half the $786 list price.

title: 2 BISHOPS OF SEATTLE STRIVING TO WORK WITH SPLIT POWERS
description: In adjoining offices in the chancery here, two Roman Catholic Bishops are searching for a formula that will allow them to divide their ministry of the Archdiocese of Seattle in a way satisfactory to themselves, to the Vatican and to their fellow bishops in the United States.

title: WITTY PROGRAM OFFERS HELP FOR WINE LOVERS
description: A TOAST to the latest celebrity software package: Hugh Johnson's Wine Cellar ($69.95 from Simon & Schuster Software, 800-624-0023). Mr. Johnson is one of the world's leading wine experts, and he has poured his wisdom into a brace of floppy disks that go well with I.B.M. PC's and compatibles. A version for the Apple II series will be ready in February.

title: Puerto Rico Sets Mortgage Bonds
description: The Puerto Rico Housing Bank and Finance Agency is tentatively offering about $476.5 million of bonds to help finance mortgage subsidy payments to home buyers and a mortgage loan insurance program.

title: Friends at Last
description: It's a rare moment when they agree on anything at all, but the nature of their concurrence Monday night was cause for special notice at the America's Cup races in Fremantle. Tom Blackaller's USA had just upset Stars & Stripes, skippered by Blackaller's bitter rival, Dennis Conner, when a question at a post-race news conference had the two helmsmen taking each other's part like lifelong friends.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNDER GLASS The New York Aquarium is 90 years old today, which makes it one of our city's venerable institutions. The aquarium went public in 1896, when it opened at Castle Garden, the former immigrant station, theater and fort at the Battery that is now converted into a museum called Castle Clinton. The aquarium moved inland to the Bronx Zoo in 1941 and, in 1957, pitched its tanks in the spacious installation it now occupies in Brooklyn's Coney Island, at West Eighth Street and Surf Avenue, where it and its stock of 20,000 specimens have been getting along swimmingly ever since.

title: TRADING IS LIGHT
description: Stock prices on Wall Street fell yesterday on light trading volume, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down to almost its same level before its surprise rally a week ago.

title: SUIT AGAINST NBC NEARING THE JURY
description: The trial in a multimillion dollar defamation lawsuit brought by the entertainer Wayne Newton against NBC neared completion today after two months of bitter courtroom fighting.

title: Software Liability Suit Is Withdrawn
description: In Cambridge, Mass., meanwhile, the holiday spirit was in evidence at the Lotus Development Corporation. A Florida contractor yesterday withdrew a $254,000 product liability lawsuit against Lotus, ending a yearlong dispute over whether software companies are responsible for errors made by people using their programs.

title: December Dilemma For Non-Christians
description: The pamphlet is called ''The December Dilemma'' and it has just been issued to alert public-school principals and teachers to an uncomfortable predicament faced at Christmastime by children who are not Christian.

title: Sale of Mets Approved
description: The sale of the Mets to Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon was unanimously approved by the club owners in both major leagues today. The owners similarly confirmed the sale of the Cleveland Indians from the estate of Steve O'Neill to the brothers Richard and David Jacobs.

title: Tribe Shuts Part of Road In the Phoenix Area
description: Indians frustrated with lease negotiations closed a portion of one of this Phoenix suburb's north-south thoroughfares that is on tribal land.

title: H.J. PORTER, KEY REPUBLICAN IN TEXAS IN 50'S, IS DEAD AT 90
description: H. J. (Jack) Porter, an oilman who was instrumental in transforming the Texas Republican Party from a small group into a potent statewide organization, died Sunday in Houston. He was 90 years old and had been in failing health.

title: AMID COSTUMES, A LITTLE NIGHT MUSIC
description: SOME of the most spectacular fashions of the last 200 years - from elegantly embroidered 18th-century pannier dresses for the minuet to Day-Glo minidresses of the 1960's for the twist - have been assembled at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for its Costume Institute's newest exhibition, ''Dance.''

title: POLAND BARS A VISIT BY KENNEDY TO PRESENT AWARD TO 2 DISSIDENTS
description: The Government today ruled out a Christmas visit to Poland by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who had sought to travel here to present the Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award to two dissidents associated with the outlawed Solidarity movement.

title: Famine-Stricken Sudan Says It Will Export Food
description: The Sudan's Prime Minister said today that his country has a food surplus and will begin exporting, which he acknowledged might seem ''ridiculous'' for a nation in which relief officials say two million people face starvation.

title: U.S. COUNCIL URGES BIRTH CONTROL TO COMBAT TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES
description: Contraceptives should be distributed free or at low cost to teen-agers to combat the problem of teen-age pregnancy, the National Research Council said today.

title: Chip Industry Gains
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to rebound, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported a slight increase in orders in November while shipments remained flat, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.99 for the three-month period ending in November, up from 0.97 in October and 0.93 in September.

title: Applications Requested For Voice Competition
description: Applications are being accepted for the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition for singers, the hall's general manager, Judith Arron, has announced.

title: LENDL'S GOAL FOR '87: GETTING EVEN BETTER
description: Tennis seasons are like waves breaking on the shore, tumbling in one after another in an endless succession. The top players learn to ride those waves for as long as possible, pausing briefly now and then to reflect on their accomplishments, but otherwise rarely stepping out of the water.

title: PHILIPPINE ARMY AND REBELS START CEASE-FIRE
description: A 60-day cease-fire in the Communist insurgency went into effect at noon today after negotiators reached a compromise on the role of the military during the truce.

title: Four Change Positions In Xerox Restructuring
description: The Xerox Corporation announced moves yesterday to revise its marketing operation and to further integrate its copier and office-systems businesses. It reassigned four executives as part of the changes.

title: Walter Foran, State Senator And G.O.P. Official in Jersey
description: Walter E. Foran, a State Senator in New Jersey since 1977, died Monday at the Hunterdon County Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Flemington, N.J.

title: A 'Perfect' Timepiece Sought in West Germany
description: Here's a timely gift idea. Junghans Uhren G.m.b.H. of Schramberg, West Germany, says it is working to develop the ultimate wristwatch, a timepiece so accurate it will lose only one second in 150,000 years.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said the revenue includes gains from sale of land of $226,100 in fiscal 1986 and $1,175,000 in fiscal 1985.

title: Benefits of New York City Water Metering Will Outweigh Costs
description: To the Editor To answer objections by Corey B. Bearak and Amy Vickers, both connected with the New York City Council (letter, Nov. 20), on the efficacy of water meters to produce water conservation:

title: Timely Seminar
description: The Brookings Institution lined up its speakers for today's forum on terrorism several months ago, long before President Reagan's attempts to negotiate with Iran had emerged, but the program could not have been more timely. The forum will be keynoted by Parker W. Borg, former principal deputy at the State Department Office of Counterterrorism, and closed by Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead. In the day, representatives of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Department of Justice will address such subjects as the efficacy of military and nonmilitary responses to terrorism and on policy criteria for responding to terrorists.

title: Crayola Picks Avrett, Free
description: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg emerged triumphant yesterday as the new agency for the Crayola Products division of Binney & Smith. The client says the budget for next year is $5 million.

title: NETS SLIDE TO 3-16, POOREST IN LEAGUE
description: The game tonight between the Nets and the Sacramento Kings paired two of the worst teams in the National Basketball Association. But considering that home teams have won 70 per cent of their games this season, it was a game the Nets should have won, especially since the Kings arrived with a six-game losing streak.

title: DANCE: VICTORIA MARKS
description: WHEN people get together, they may try to break apart. But once apart, they may try to get together again. That's what Victoria Marks choreographically suggested Monday night when the Victoria Marks Performance Company appeared at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: 2-Star Restaurant
description: Ron Darling, Art Shamsky, Jerry Casale and Tony Ferrara are opening a new restaurant in Manhattan, and they're billing themselves as four partners who've all been with championship teams. Darling and Shamsky won World Series with the Mets, of course, but Casale, a five-year major league pitcher who was never in postseason play, is stretching things a bit: Seems he was on the St. Francis Xavier team that won Brooklyn's C.Y.O. crown in 1950.

title: CLASHES CONTINUE IN ARAB TERRITORY
description: A 16-year-old Palestinian was shot and wounded in the Gaza Strip today, as sporadic clashes between Israeli soldiers and Arab demonstrators broke out for the sixth consecutive day.

title: GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST CONTINUE MANY COMPANIES' TRADITIONS
description: Several New York corporations have continued their custom of giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with contributions to the 75th annual appeal.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESORS SBI reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on real estate sales of $10,000 for the quarter and $883,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes gains on real estate sales of $7,000 and $5,643,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: MCA, CINEPLEX SET VENTURE IN FLORIDA
description: MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal City Studios and Universal Pictures, and the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a leading movie theater chain in North America, have formed a joint venture to build a studio tour attraction and production facility in Orlando, Fla.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE director of the school broke the news to me last year that my elder son would probably have to be held back a grade. It seemed that most of the private schools had a cutoff date of Sept. 1, and he had been born on Sept. 11 but had somehow slipped into the class ahead. If he stayed, he would always be the youngest.

title: Cholesterol Levels
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: TISHC'S PORTFOLIO: WOW
description: Although various Mellons, Rockefellers, Harrimans and du Ponts have taken jobs with the Federal Government, none of these superich ever produced a financial disclosure statement like the one just filed by Preston R. (Bob) Tisch, the new Postmaster General.

title: THE COMPLETE MEAL, SALMON TO FROZEN SOUFFLE
description: Gravlax #2 pounds center-cut fresh salmon #1 tablespoon sugar #1 tablespoon salt #1Y tablespoons coarsely ground black pepper #2 large bunches dill #2 lemons, sliced for garnish Mustard sauce (see recipe).

title: Joy Fights Pullman With Court Action
description: The Joy Manufacturing Company, the mining equipment manufacturer, said it had initiated litigation against the Pullman-Peabody Company, a Princeton, N.J., maker of equipment for trucks and trains as well as material-handling and food service equipment, and its directors in connection with a hostile $527 million takeover offer. The complaint contends Pullman violated Federal securities laws in connection with the offer and the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act by failing to make required filings.

title: Choosing Investigators: Outside the Public Eye
description: During the next few weeks a handful of people, operating out of the public eye and following no set procedures, will select individuals destined to become key participants in the unfolding drama of the Iran affair.

title: CASE OF 3 RAGGED CHILDREN PUZZLES AUTHORITIES
description: Three children have been sent to a Queens hospital after authorities at Kennedy International Airport said they appeared too squalid and undernourished on their arrival from Portugal to continue on to Virginia with their father.

title: Baked Acorn Squash
description: IF I am in a pinch to come up with a quick, easy vegetable dish this time of year, I often turn to acorn squash, a highly versatile and nutritious winter staple. This squash is well suited to baking and can be attractively displayed by using this simple technique:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Source:

title: EASTERN'S EMBATTLED UNIONS
description: After winning a bigger and bigger say in Eastern Air Lines' management under the embattled leadership of Frank Borman, union leaders are finding themselves with virtually no say at all under the carrier's new owner, the Texas Air Corporation, and its cost-cutting chairman, Frank Lorenzo.

title: Chinese Students Protest In a Provincial Capital
description: Several thousand students staged an anti-Government demonstration in a Chinese provincial capital today, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported.

title: NEW ZEAL FOR GEMSTONES: REAL SEARCH FOR THE UNREAL
description: New York would be a more peaceful place if everyone wore a clear quartz crystal over the solar plexus, Luna Crystal Devin was saying the other day at a gem and mineral show in Manhattan.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month earnings include a charge of $125,000 from the settlement of litigation.

title: SATELLITES LET EXECUTIVES BE TWO (OR MORE) PLACES AT ONCE
description: ON Sunday, choirs of children in eight cities in North and South America will sing a song of peace. At the same instant, through a technology called video teleconferencing, they will be linked in sight and sound across thousands of miles, able to see and hear one another as if they were all in a single meeting place.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Brookhaven Scientists To Share Fermi Award
description: Ernest D. Courant, a senior physicist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., and the late M. Stanley Livingston, a former professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who had long been associated with Brookhaven, have received the 1986 Enrico Fermi Award, the highest scientific award given by the Department of Energy.

title: FOX PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
DANCE: ECLECTIC TROUPE FROM NORTH CAROLINA
description: LOVERS of stylish dancing will surely enjoy the North Carolina Dance Theater, which opened a week's season last night at the Joyce Theater. It was a festive occasion. The company's 17 members looked pleasant. They danced well. And they always put on a good show.

title: Council Votes to Delay New Asbestos Controls
description: The City Council yesterday voted to delay New York City's new asbestos-control program for four months because the Koch administration was not ready to proceed.

title: Goodyear Receives $4 Billion Backing
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it had received commitments for a $4 billion line of credit from 17 United States and international banks to help carry out a restructuring program sparked by an unsuccessful, hostile takeover bid.

title: INSIDE
description: Latin Fighting Ebbs Fighting was reported to have virtually ended along the border between Nicaragua and Honduras, which wants the contras out.

title: ACCREDITATION WITHDRAWN FROM 3 BLACK COLLEGES
description: The accreditation of three small black colleges in Texas and Tennessee was withdrawn today by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools, the major school accrediting agency in the Southeast.

title: Long-Term Debt Rating For Merrill Reviewed
description: Long-term debt ratings for Merrill Lynch & Company are under review for possible reductions, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Sid Caesar to Appear In New Miller Play
description: Sid Caesar will return to the New York stage in ''I Can't Remember Anything,'' part of a double bill by Arthur Miller that will have its premier Jan. 23 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, Gregory Mosher, artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, announced yesterday.

title: New Superintendent For State Police
description: A 24-year veteran of the Division of State Police was nominated to be police superintendent yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: Indiana Utility Mortgage Issue
description: The Northern Indiana Public Service Company yesterday began offering $125 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at a price of par through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: CHARLES A. WAGNER
description: Charles Abraham Wagner, a former executive director of the Poetry Society of America, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: PRETORIA EXPELS A U.S. JOURNALIST
description: The Government said today that it had refused to renew the work permit of the correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, and told him to leave South Africa by Dec. 31.

title: French Government Denies Selling Arms to Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Brien's Biggest Job Is Regaining His Poise
description: For better or worse, a picture of Ken O'Brien will emerge today for the public. It may not be the picture his teammates have; it may not even be an accurate portrait of the strong-armed young quarterback who has suddenly lost the magic touch in the Jets' three straight losses.

title: BENEFITS OF NEW YORK CITY WATER METERING WILL OUTWEIGH COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HANUKKAH OR CHRISTMAS GIFTS TO DELIGHT CHILDREN
description: Music 101

title: A Dismissal Is Sought In Police Graft Case
description: A defense lawyer in the 77th Precinct police corruption case has asked that the charges be dismissed because, he asserted, prosecutors urged two cooperating officers to commit crimes to implicate other officers.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE other morning, Valerie Pessirilo caught the 11:58 from Rosedale, L.I., to Manhattan where she was to meet her former college roommates in front of the Booth Theater on West 45th Street and take in a matinee of ''I'm Not Rappaport.'' A few minutes after she had left, the roommates telephoned Miss Pessirilo's home to tell her mother they had missed their train and would be late.

title: SUPERMARKET EXECUTIVE MISSING AT SEA OFF FLORIDA
description: Camillo J. D'Urso, a food industry executive in the New York metropolitan area, has been missing at sea off Florida since going on a fishing trip almost two weeks ago, his family and the authorities in Florida said yesterday.

title: THE SAFFRON HARVEST IS IN AND THE U.S. HAS GOT IT
description: FARMERS here in the world's saffron capital are celebrating the end of a successful harvest of the spice they call La Mancha's ''red gold.''

title: NBC CANCELS MAGAZINE SHOW '1986'
description: NBC's 15th try at a weekly prime-time magazine program, ''1986,'' which network management once vowed would stay on the air forever, was canceled yesterday by Lawrence K. Grossman, president of NBC News.

title: KEY SCHOLAR OF SOVIET IS HONORED
description: To celebrate the 40-year career of Marshall D. Shulman - one of the nation's best-known scholars in Soviet studies - Columbia University announced last night that an endowed professorship of Soviet Foreign Policy has been established in his name.

title: Pictures on the Screen
description: WASHINGTON

title: Market Place; Bright Outlook In Auto Parts
description: IMPROVING prospects for automotive replacement parts - including a projected increase in repair and maintenance expenditures for older vehicles - have buoyed shares of several leading companies in this industry. Last week Echlin Inc., a leading manufacturer of replacement parts, reached a record high of 20 5/8, up from 14 1/4 in January. Yesterday the stock was unchanged at 20 1/4.

title: Soviet Delegation in a Visit to Iran
description: The Soviet Union and Iran today held their first high-level economic talks since the 1979 Islamic revolution.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Company, elected Robert T. Budenbender senior executive vice president, Alan Langley to the additional post of treasurer and Ian Jardine deputy treasurer.

title: FINAL DRIVE FOR DANCE CENTER FUNDS
description: Cora Cahan, known in the dance world as a fund-raiser who can do anything, is in a race with time. Since mid-October, she has been working with other members of the New York Dance Center, a nonprofit foundation created recently to operate 890 Broadway, to raise enough money to save the building as a home for its current theater and dance tenants.

title: Printouts; Christmas Tree Goes Fiber-Optic
description: O Christmas tree, O Christmas tree, how lovely are thy branches, especially when they are adorned with solar-powered fiber-optic tubes and light-emitting diode ornaments.

title: KUSTOM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $67,000 for the quarter and $322,000 for the year, and tax credits of $177,000 and $703,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a tax credit of $45,000.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
WHOLE-GRAIN BREAD
description: ALTHOUGH whole-grain breads are often superior to white breads in terms of flavor, the picture is not so clear in terms of nutrition.

title: STATE ASSAILS CITY'S AGENCY ON CHILD CARE
description: New York City's child-abuse agency has not fulfilled its responsibility to protect children and ''continues to experience serious problems,'' according to a state report that calls for prompt corrections.

title: High Bail Is Set for 3 In Wells Fargo Theft
description: A Federal judge yesterday set bail of up to $1 million each for three defendants in the $7 million Wells Fargo robbery who have been imprisoned for the last 15 months.

title: Not Like Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Weightman to Handle Wendy's-Owned Units
description: Weightman Inc., the Philadelphia ad agency, has been named to handle local advertising and promotion for the 225 company-owned Wendy's fast-food outlets from New York south to Virginia. That's the Eastern division, and its budget is $5 million, according to the agency.

title: PANEL FAULTS CHARGES OF SABOTAGED AIDS RESEARCH
description: An independent panel said yesterday that an AIDS laboratory at the Federal Centers for Disease Control had suffered serious morale problems, but it disputed allegations that data had been suppressed and that research had been derailed by sabotage.

title: Lee Dorsey, 59, Rock Singer Popular in the 50's and 60's
description: Lee Dorsey, the New Orleans rock singer, died Dec. 2 in New Orleans of emphysema. He was 59 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CANADA'S SEALERS PREPARE FOR REDUCED HUNT
description: Canadians are planning to go out on the ice again this winter to kill young seals, but at dramatically lower levels than five years ago and with scant prospect of selling pelts commercially.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Includes restructuring program charges of $87,105,000, loss from discontinued operations of $7,054,000, loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $47,200,000 and a gain from cumulative effect of an accounting change of $6,734,000. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $490,000. The company said that all the results have been restated to reclassify as discontinued operations the results of operations scheduled for divestiture.

title: Where the Buck Stops
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN the refrigerated section of my local supermarket, I recently came across an excellent ''new'' convenience food labeled ground turkey. The uses recommended on the package included ground turkey as a substitute for ground beef - ''meat loaf, sloppy Joes, burgers, chili, tacos, spaghetti sauce, pizza topping.''

title: High Noon
description: The Dallas Cowboys are 7-7 and fading, which means that one of the longest streaks of consecutive winning seasons in the history of major professional sports is now in jeopardy.

title: 90 PATROL OFFICERS IN 77TH PRECINCT ARE SHIFTED ELSEWHERE IN BROOKLYN
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday ordered the transfer of nearly half the patrol officers in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn - 90 people - in his effort to reshape the precinct where 13 officers have been indicted on corruption charges.

title: MARCHENKO IS DEAD IN A SOVIET PRISON
description: Anatoly T. Marchenko, one of the best known Soviet political dissidents, has died in prison, his wife learned here today. He was 48 years old.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WHITE HOUSE AIDE SEES HEALTH PLAN AS ECONOMIC RISK
description: President Reagan's top economic adviser has denounced a health insurance plan to deal with catastrophic illness proposed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Otis R. Bowen.

title: Williams to Nets: Your Move
description: When Buck Williams was selected by the Nets as the third pick in the 1981 draft, he was billed as the anchor around which management would rebuild what was once a proud, successful franchise. Yet although Williams has developed into one of the league's fiercest rebounders - a player every franchise covets - the foundering Nets have not lived up to their end of that deal.

title: Closings by Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, responding to reports in Crain's New York Business, confirmed yesterday that it was studying closing branches in the New York metropolitan area. Chase, the nation's third-largest banking organization, would not respond to the Crain's report that as many as one-fifth of the 230 Chase branches in the area might be closed, saying a decision would be made soon. It said that the branch system would be reconfigured over a 12-month period and that branches might be opened during this period.

title: Pre-empting Big Bird
description: TO THE LIVING SECION:

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
JAPANESE INVESTORS SPUR HIGHER PRICES IN U.S. ART MARKET
description: Over the last few months, Japanese art dealers and collectors have surged into American auction houses and galleries, setting record prices and becoming the second largest force in the art world, behind the Americans, art dealers and auctioneers say.

title: Goldman View On Its Options
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company last Friday received the first installment of the $500 million the Sumitomo Bank has agreed to invest in the firm, but it may still have to take other steps to bolster its capital, according to an internal memo circulated at Goldman on Monday.

title: NEW ORLEANS'S 'EIFFEL TOWER'
description: John Onorio, who grew up in Brooklyn, will never forget his first look into the gigantic crate that held his dream of a New Orleans restaurant. The 11,000 pieces of metal inside, looking like a giant Erector set, were nothing less than a chunk of the Eiffel Tower -not actually the tower, but the restaurant that once perched there, 562 feet above Paris.

title: Speaker Wright, Meet Mr. Wright
description: Robert D. Wright, the new president of NBC, asks employees to ''invest some portion of their earnings'' in political action contributions, to insure that the network is well represented before Congress. Assuming no coercion, his position is probably not illegal. The issue is not corporate rights but odious appearances, and it reaches to the leaders just chosen for the next Congress.

title: Envoy Returns to Answer Charge
description: John Hubert Kelly, 47 years old, the Ambassador to Lebanon, was back at the State Department today, having been summoned to answer for his actions in conducting a ''back channel'' operation involving American hostages and the secret Iran arms sale.

title: Baker to Hold Europe Talks
description: As part of a process that could lay the ground for new reductions in world interest rates, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will meet Friday and over the weekend with the finance ministers of the major European countries, according to European and Administration officials.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $839,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the 1986 results reflects adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 86 in the third quarter, which resulted in an increase in net income in the fourth quarter of $181,000, or 2 cents a share, and $701,000, or 8 cents a share, for the latest year. In the second quarter, the company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 87, which resulted in an increase in net income in the fourth quarter of $176,000, or 2 cents a share, and $478,000, or 6 cents a share, for the latest year.

title: Long Feud Cited In Oakland Killings
description: Detectives are investigating relatives' contentions that a dispute over a lost dog led to the killing of six people Monday, but a Lieut. Richard Brierly of the Oakland police said today that the crime ''may be the culmination of several different arguments.''

title: KEY RATES
MAP OF EARTH'S CORE SHOWS VALLEYS AND TALL MOUNTAINS
description: Maps of the depths of the Earth show that its molten metal core is not a smooth sphere but instead has mountains taller than Mount Everest and valleys that are six times deeper than the Grand Canyon, researchers said today.

title: Special Counsel Candidates Said to Include New Yorker
description: Harold R. Tyler Jr., a prominent New York lawyer and former Federal judge, emerged as a leading candidate to serve as the special prosecutor to investigate the sale of American weapons to Iran and diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said it went public in May.

title: Carter Stake Raised to 47.3%
description: The General Cinema Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased 3,555,000 common shares of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. for $177.9 million, raising its voting interest in the California retailer to 47.3 percent, from 38.6 percent.

title: Food Riots in Zambia; Borders Are Closed
description: At least three people have been killed in two days of food riots in the copper mining towns of north-central Zambia, and the riots are continuing, the state-run press agency reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think there is another person in America that wants to tell this story as much as I do.'' - Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. [ A18:1. ]

title: Doctor Terms Model Permanently Scarred
description: The plastic surgeon who treated a model on the night she was slashed with a razor testified yesterday that the model, Marla Hanson, had been permanently scarred.

title: SOVIET EXIT LAW FAULTED BY SHCHARANSKY
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident who was released last February in an East-West exchange, has added his voice to concern in the West over a Soviet emigration law that takes effect Jan. 1.

title: SOME OF DAVIS REWARD MAY GO TO A RELATIVE
description: Some of the $25,000 in reward money for the capture of Larry Davis may go to the estranged husband of one of his sisters who told the authorities that the fugitive was hiding in the sister's apartment in the Bronx, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: America II First in a Race It Had to Win
description: America II weathered rough seas and howling winds today to win a pivotal race in the America's Cup challenger trials.

title: MORE WOMEN POSTPONING MARRIAGE
description: American women are postponing marriage longer than ever before, marrying later than even their great-great grandmothers of the 1890's, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS RULE OUT INCREASE IN TAXES FOR RICH
description: Congressional leaders from both parties today rejected a suggestion by the new Speaker of the House that taxes of higher-income people be raised beyond the levels set by this year's sweeping tax revision law.

title: Poindexter Sign Is Stolen
description: A street sign honoring a native son, Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, was stolen here on Thankgiving.

title: ROOM-DRAW TIME FOR FRESHMEN, AND OTHERS
description: The fifth floor of the Cannon House Office Building is a renovated storage attic that reverberates with the roar of a generator behind one of its walls. Offices there are so small that some aides have set up desks in cage-like storage rooms, where they work without heat or air-conditioning behind steel grates.

title: JUDGE DECLINES REQUEST TO HALT SEX ABUSE CASE
description: The judge in the McMartin Preschool molestation case today denied a motion by a defense lawyer to dismiss the case or disqualify the Los Angeles District Attorney's Office from prosecuting it.

title: Iran, Dole, Bush and 1988
description: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader who will become minority leader next year, has seen his prospects of winning the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination enhanced as a result of the Iran arms controversy, in the judgment of many key party leaders.

title: Real Estate; L.I. Water Resources Examined
description: FOR the past several years suburban developers, like their counterparts in New York City, have been giving former factories and warehouses a second life by converting them into office buildings. In both cases the developers have been responding to a basic shift in the economy from manufacturing to services that is manifesting itself in declining demand and low rents for industrial space and a waxing market and higher rents for office space.

title: The Iran Policy Was Wrong, Too
description: Acknowledging finally that mistakes were made, President Reagan concedes only that the ''execution'' of his Iran policy was flawed. He and his aides talk as if their policy were sound because their objectives were noble.

title: Don Mischer to Produce '87 Tony Show on CBS
description: Don Mischer, an award-winning director and producer of television variety specials, will produce the 1987 Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards broadcast, Harvey Sabinson, the executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, announced yesterday.

title: Payment Rejected In Arson at Club
description: The owners of a Willingboro country club destroyed in a fire that was set in 1984 cannot collect $1.2 million in insurance money, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Crackdown
description: The issue of college athletes' drug use has generally been focused on the four-year schools, but the problem can be just as big on junior-college teams. On one of them, it may be even bigger.

title: CHEFS TRADE SAUCEPANS FOR TYPEWRITERS
description: FOR a prominent or aspiring chef today the insignia is not merely a toque, but a glossy cookbook. Several books by chefs have been published this fall. A look at four is a study in contrasts not only of personal style, but of cuisine. Yet all reflect the contemporary American restaurant scene.

title: WINE TALK
description: A FEW people got together here the other night to celebrate Harvard University's entry into the wine business. There won't be any retail shop in Eliot House, and no one is going to tread grapes in the Business School basement, but it's been a remarkably successful little venture. More than enough so to warrant breaking out the Haut Brion '53 to celebrate.

title: Iran Arms Held in U.S. Called Useless
description: Hundreds of million of dollars in arms paid for by Iran but impounded by the United States in the 1979 hostage crisis have deteriorated in American warehouses and are believed largely worthless, according to Administration officials and other sources.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 9-month results were restated to reflect a pension accounting change.

title: DOCTORS WITHHOLD SERVICES IN PROTEST ON INSURANCE
description: With an increase in malpractice insurance rates just around the corner, some Florida physicians, already paying the highest premiums in the country to protect themselves against suits, are starting to withhold their services as a protest.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE dozens of letters I have received in response to recent columns on fats and cholesterol in foods indicate that many readers remain uncertain about how to choose a heart-healthy menu. Before I try to clarify the most common sources of confusion, a word about the latest findings, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association on Nov. 28 - just as this season of dietary excess got under way.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Headlines of two charts in Business Day last Friday, with an article about the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, were reversed. It is the company's capital spending that will be cut to $1 billion a year, while the cut to $270 million applies to spending on research and development.

title: SOME TO PAY MORE IN PLAN ON STATE TAXES
description: The Cuomo administration acknowledged yesterday that its preliminary plan to block tax increases would, in fact, raise state taxes slightly for New Yorkers who earn between $50,000 and $100,000 a year.

title: A PANIC-PROOF GUIDE TO CHRISTMAS DINNER: TIMING IS EVERYTHING
description: TWO weeks and counting to Christmas. So much to do. So little time, what with the presents to purchase, the parties to attend, the house to clean, the silver to polish, the tree to trim. And looming in the middle distance is Christmas dinner.

title: HONDURAS EAGER TO HAVE REBELS OUT
description: Fighting was reported to have virtually ended today along the border between Honduras and Nicaragua.

title: Lear Siegler Bid Ended by Wickes
description: The Wickes Companies, as anticipated, said tonight that it had terminated its agreement to acquire Lear Siegler Inc. for $1.7 billion. Wickes, which said Nov. 18 that it had encountered difficulty in securing bank financing for the deal, said that both companies had agreed to scrap the acquisition without liability to either company.

title: OFFICIALS SAY C.I.A. KNEW OF DIVERSION BEFORE MEESE DID
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, learned about the diversion of millions of dollars to the Nicaraguan rebels a month before it was uncovered in an investigation by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, three Government officials disclosed tonight.

title: MAX & IRMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net loss The prior year included a $150,000 charge to close a restaurant in Kansas City.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUESAmerican Can
description: The American Can Company is offering $100 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99 to yield 8.45 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable for life, the 10-year bonds yield about 1.4 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

title: Not About Iran
description: Any number of people - well, at least five - have written noting that I was wrong when writing that John Ehrlichman once proposed to let John Mitchell ''twist slowly in the wind.''

title: AGENCY TO MAKE RULES FOR NONMEDALLION CABS
description: The New York City Council yesterday empowered the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission to regulate an estimated 35,000 vehicles that provide taxi service in lower-income areas and the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: 2 Former Reagan Aides Invoke 5th Amendment in House Hearing on Iran
description: Two former White House officials linked to the diversion of Iran arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels declined again today to answer questions before Congress, invoking their Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

title: DEVILS MISS CHANCE
description: All around the locker room, the Devils boasted about their new status symbol: the big game.

title: St Germain Asks Inquiry
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee asked the General Accounting Office today to open an investigation into the travel and other personal and administrative expenses of five Federal agencies that regulate financial institutions.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LETTERS FROM WESTERBORK. By Etty Hillesum. Introduction and notes by Jan G. Gaarlandt. Translated by Arnold J. Pomerans. 156 pages. Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: Facial Foliage
description: Is the House of Representatives being overcome by some version of Wild West days? Or is it political? As members of the new Congress assembled this week to choose leaders and adopt rules, observers noted at least four survivors of the November election had grown beards: three Democrats - Representatives Les AuCoin of Oregon, Dennis E. Eckart of Ohio and Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut - and a Republican conservative, Bob Dornan of California.

title: Europeans in Accord On Who Backs Terror
description: The Interior Ministers of the European Community, except Greece, agreed here today on which countries backed terrorism. But, for security reasons, they did not make public the list.

title: RUSSIAN STRESSES LEBANON PEACE
description: The Soviet Ambassador said today that his Government was trying to mediate in the 16-day-old battle between Shiite Moslems and Palestinians that has killed 460 people and wounded more than 1,000.

title: Is All This Education Really Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reinstatement Sought
