description: Mike Bell, a defensive end under contract with the Kansas City Chiefs, has requested a meeting with Commissioner Pete Rozelle to discuss his possible return to the league after serving four months of a one-year sentence for a drug conviction. Mike and his brother, Mark, a former National Football League player, were to be released today from a Federal prison in Duluth, Minn. Mark Bell was not on a roster Nov. 20, 1985, when he and his brother were indicted.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Rating Fast Foods ''The Fast Food Guide'' by Michael Jacobson and Sarah Fritschner (Workman, $4.95) is based on the wall chart published earlier this year by the Center for Science in the Public Interest (Dr. Jacobson is executive director). The chart gave ''gloom ratings'' based on the fat, sugar and sodium in various fast foods. The book goes further, providing background about the fast-food industry and various chains, basic nutrition information and complete nutrition data for foods from 17 major chains. The gloom ratings are included. Haute Cuisine in a Bag

title: Buchanan Pursues Attack on Critics of the President
description: Despite the reported opposition of other senior White House staff members, Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, pressed an attack today on the national press, the Republican Congressional leadership and the critics of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: Only Unity Can Beat Pinochet
description: On a recent visit to Chile, the first in 13 years, I was struck, as in the late 1960's, by the Chileans' aspiration for democracy - by how essential an open society is for them. Somehow a return to democracy must be achieved or the innate character of Chile will be frustrated and the populace will perceive itself a failure.

title: Article 202286 -- No Title
description: The United Technologies Corporation, one of the nation's largest manufacturing companies and a major military contractor, said yesterday that it would take a $592 million charge against its fourth-quarter earnings. The company also said it would reduce its work force by about 11,000, or nearly 6 percent, by the end of 1987.

title: SCRIPT CHIEF OF 'TWILIGHT ZONE' DENIES TELLING OF CRASH PERIL
description: The script supervisor on the set of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' testified today that she did not tell the director, John Landis, that the movie's ultimately fatal helicopter scene would be ''too dangerous.''

title: FOREIGN TIE TO SHELLER IS STUDIED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been focusing on a number of Canadian investors in its investigation of possible insider trading in the buyout earlier this year of the Sheller-Globe Corporation, according to sources with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: EMBATTLED CHIRAC PUTS OFF LEGISLATIVE PLANS
description: A day after withdrawing a plan for a university shake-up in the face of violent protests, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac postponed other legislation today as students prepared to renew demonstrations.

title: Iran Requests Output Cuts
description: In a statement issued two days before the start of an OPEC conference, Iran called on its fellow OPEC members to cut their oil output to drive up world prices.

title: 8 Workers Are Injured At Two Nuclear Plants
description: A water line in the nonradioactive turbine building at Virginia Power's Surry Nuclear Power Station burst today, scalding eight workers and causing a nuclear reactor to shut down.

title: Willing Herzog Can't Strike Any Deals
description: Whitey Herzog, the St. Louis Cardinals' manager, who was instrumental in the movement of 23 players in six days at baseball's 1980 winter meetings, was lamenting today the plight of Jack McKeon, the San Diego Padres' general manager, who is known as Trader Jack.

title: THE REV. JESSE JACKSON ON 'AMERICAN INTERESTS'
description: ''AMERICAN INTERESTS'' is a weekly news and interview series shown Wednesdays on Channel 13 at 1 P.M. It is an infelicitous time - who watches television at lunch hour? -but presumably this can't be helped. Channel 13 has other demands on its programming schedule. ''American Interests,'' however, is still worth checking out.

title: Riot at Italian Atom Plant
description: The police fired scores of tear-gas grenades and made repeated charges with riot sticks today to disperse hundreds of firebomb-throwing demonstrators who blocked the entrance to a nuclear energy plant 72 miles northwest of Rome.

title: Iranian Again Suggests Help on U.S. Hostages
description: Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, told a visiting Soviet official today that Iran was prepared to help obtain the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: GAIN REPORTED IN AFGHAN TALKS
description: Pakistan, Afghanistan and the Soviet Union have reached ''full agreement'' on one issue that has been an obstacle in the talks on Afghanistan, the monitoring of a Soviet pullout, a high-ranking United Nations official said today. But disagreement remains on the timing of a withdrawal.

title: BIDDER CITES PLAN FOR BANKAMERICA
description: First Interstate Bancorp plans to divest most of BankAmerica's Seafirst Corporation unit, as well as branches in 15 California markets, if it is allowed to buy BankAmerica, according to documents made public today.

title: The Arrogance of Power in Another Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENDA
description: Wooing the Conventioneers The committee choosing the site for the 1988 Democratic convention arrives in New York today for the last of its visits to the six cities competing to be host of the convention. On the panel's itinerary Thursday: a reception at Gracie Mansion and a tour of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1986
description: The Economy

title: ITT Official Picked For Military Unit
description: The ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it would consolidate its military and government services businesses into a new company, and named V. William Souveroff to head it.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has the commendable habit of reviving its premieres, commissions and ventures into contemporary literature rather than leaving them on the shelf after one publicized outing. One can sometimes question the astuteness of the group's discrimination in modern music - the Menotti ''Suite for Two Cellos and Piano,'' which had its premiere in 1973 and was revived at Sunday afternoon's Alice Tully Hall concert, is only intermittently engaging - but the policy is a better one than some ''mainstream'' institutions follow.

title: ACCUSED TERRORITST HELPING TO SUPPLY THE CONTRAS
description: Three veterans of the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba, all with long ties to the Central Intelligence Agency and one of them an accused international terrorist, have emerged as key figures in the clandestine air network that delivered tons of weapons and ammunition to the anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua.

title: ONE IS CAPTURED
description: Three prisoners, including two convicted of murder, escaped tonight from Sing Sing, the state prison here, the authorities said.

title: FORMULA AIDS PLANNERS AT BELL LABS
description: A new mathematical formula for solving staggeringly complex variations on the ''traveling salesman's problem'' - finding the most efficient route for visiting a number of cities - is now being used successfully at Bell Laboratories to plan the growth of the national long-distance telephone network of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Chub Feeney Is a Fan Again
description: The Dartmouth man who once was almost the baseball commissioner will pass the torch of the National League presidency at the baseball meetings today to the Yale man and former Yale president who someday is expected to be the next commissioner.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: G.O.P. GOVERNORS' POST GIVES KEAN NEW STAGE
description: Governor Kean was installed today as chairman of the nation's 24 Republican governors. He and others say the post will enable him to play a role in shaping the party's national platform in the year leading up to the 1988 Presidential election.

title: 'PREDICTABLE' KILAUEA VOLCANO RADICALLY CHANGES
description: Kilauea, the Hawaiian volcano whose 48 almost evenly spaced eruptions over the past four years had appeared remarkably predictable, has confounded scientists by radically altering its behavior.

title: CITY'S EX-HOSPITALS CHIEF GIVEN JAIL TERM FOR CHEATING A CLIENT
description: John J. McLaughlin, the former president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for misappropriating a client's funds and filing a false financial disclosure statement.

title: FEW POLITICAL COMMITTEES IN PUBLISHING AND MEDIA
description: The suggestion by the president of NBC that the network start a political action committee is not likely to persuade book or magazine publishers to follow suit.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Announced that the owners had unanimously approved the sale of the Cleveland Indians to Richard and David Jacobs. CHICAGO (AL) - Named Deron Johnson batting coach. Announced a working agreement with Daytona Beach of the Florida State League for the 1987 season. Announced a working agreement with South Bend, an expansion franchise in the Midwest League, beginning in 1988.

title: Yankees Shop for Pitcher
description: Continuing their quest for another starting pitcher, the Yankees talked today with the Minnesota Twins about Mike Smithson, a right-hander who had a 13-14 record this year. The Yankees also spoke with the Chicago Cubs about Dennis Eckersley (6-11).

title: MUSIC: EZRA LADERMAN
description: ''EZRA Laderman: Jewish Sources in My Music'' at the Jewish Museum late Sunday afternoon asked but did not answer a very old question - whether music speaks specifically about anything outside its own realm of sound.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The late Alabama coach Paul (Bear) Bryant and two of his former players, Charley McClendon, who played under Bryant at Kentucky, and Jack Pardee, who played for him at Texas A&M were among 14 players and coaches inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame at the annual dinner in New York. . . . The San Francisco Giants have re-signed to one-year contracts Mike LaCoss, a pitcher, and Harry Spilman, a first baseman. Both had declared for free agency. . . . Chris Nilan, the Montreal Canadien right wing injured in Monday night's game with Calgary, will miss at least two months with a torn medial ligament in his left knee. . . . Brian Propp, Philadelphia's leading scorer this season, was injured in Sunday's 5-2 victory over the Edmonton Oilers and has undergone surgery on his left knee that will keep him from playing for at least nine weeks. Propp leads the Flyers with 16 goals and 25 assists.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Net loss

title: ...And Carter Urges Reagan to Talk
description: Former President Jimmy Carter accused President Reagan on Monday night of damaging the institution of the Presidency by not telling the American people the facts of the Iran affair.

title: 2d Quake Rocks Bulgaria
description: A second earthquake struck northern Bulgaria about 24 hours after a quake killed 3 people and left more than 3,000 homeless, the official Bulgarian news agency, BTA, said today. BTA said the second quake hit at 4:44 P.M. on Monday and measured about 5.5 on the Richter scale.

title: California Housing Finance Offering
description: The California Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $197.2 million of mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7 percent for an issue due in 2016 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Times Fills New Ad Post
description: John Guerin, national advertising director of The New York Times, will become director of advertising sales operations next Monday, Erich G. Linker Jr., vice president for advertising, announced yesterday.

title: FRANCE'S UNIVERSITIES: HOTBEDS OF STATUS QUO
description: The French, known for a fondness for paradox, like to say of themselves that they have a passion for revolution but an abhorrence of change.

title: To Cleveland With Love
description: Mayor George V. Voinovich of Cleveland said today that he was just joking when he told reporters Israel was safer than parts of his hometown.

title: TAX DATA OF PAT ROBERTSON GROUPS ARE QUESTIONED
description: At least three tax-exempt organizations founded and directed by the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who is considering a bid for the Presidency, have given incomplete and false information to the Internal Revenue Service, according to interviews with former top officials of the organizations and an examination of public records.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the advertising agency that serves the Wilfred American Educational Corporation wherever it has schools except in Texas and California. It is H. Richard Silver Inc.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Convention Citi
description: The Republican National chairman, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., is expected to announce Friday that the list of possible sites for the party's 1988 national convention has been narrowed to New Orleans and Kansas City, Mo. Party sources report that New Orleans is the strong favorite of the site selection committee, also headed by Mr. Fahrenkopf, which will make its final recommendation Jan. 20.

title: G.E.-China Deal
description: The Chinese Government has indicated that it plans to buy General Electric Company engines to power five new Boeing airplanes, a deal valued at about $130 million to G.E. According to a G.E. spokesman, Sandy McCord, the Beijing regional administration of the Civil Aviation Administration of China has signed a memo of understanding to purchase G.E. engines for three four-engine 747's and two twin-engine 767's, plus spare engines. Deliveries of the 767 engines are scheduled to begin in early 1988, and of the 747 engines in early 1989.

title: COURTROOM THEATER: THE BLACKS TURN THE TABLES
description: A trial of black anti-apartheid figures in this somnolent white-run settlement has been turned by its defendants into a vehicle of protest, as if the accused themselves were placing on trial the white powers that indicted them.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a charge for restructuring of $65 million for both the quarter and year, income from discontinued operations of $4 million and $16 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year includes income from a change in pension accounting of $66 million. c-After a charge for restructuring of $57 million for both the quarter and year, income from discontinued operations of $4 million and $21 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $4 million for the quarter and $9 million for the year. The 1985 results are restated for discontinued operations.

title: For Shared Custody
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SUPREME COURT RESTRICTS CHALLENGES TO MERGERS
description: The Supreme Court, in a significant antitrust ruling that clears the way for a large merger in the beef-packing industry, today restricted the ability of companies to challenge in court proposed mergers by their competitors.

title: Insult Piles Upon Calumny, an Arab Objects
description: AT a Toys ''R'' Us in Brooklyn, 7-year-old Jeremy Snyder was pointing out some Christmas gift ideas to his mother, calling special attention to a She-Ra action figure, ''whose cape opens to a burst of shimmering stars'' and to a Puffling Popple doll, who ''folds inside out and has a joke card inside.''

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. WASHINGTON BULLETS, at Landover, Md. 7:30 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M., tape delay) NETS VS. CELTICS, at Boston, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. LOS ANGELES KINGS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Virginia Tech at West Virginia (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Louisville at Western Kentucky (TV -ESPN, 9 P.M.) Manhattanville at Army (Radio - WFAS 1230, 7:25 P.M.) Columbia at Merchant Marine (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 7:45 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (TV - MSG, 12:30 A.M.

title: JAPAN'S TRADE SURPLUS DECLINED IN NOVEMBER
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell in November to $7.35 billion and is showing clear signs of a downward trend, economists said today.

title: Knee Injury to Sideline Kinard for the Playoffs
description: The Giants, bearing down on their first division title in 23 years, lost a key player today for the rest of the regular season and the playoffs. Terry Kinard, the starting free safety since the middle of his rookie season in 1983, will undergo surgery for a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee.

title: The Promise of National Service
description: Two potential 1988 Democratic Presidential candidates, Gary Hart and Charles Robb, are on record in favor of it. Polls say two out of three Americans want it. A host of scholars and policy analysts recommend it as one remedy for what ails American youth. The idea is national service.

title: METS ARE UNSETTLED AT THREE POSITIONS
description: Can the Mets do it again? Manager Dave Johnson considered the question today, conceded that he already had three problem positions that would test his talent for innovating and said:

title: NEW POLL SHOWS 47% HOLD VIEW REAGAN IS LYING
description: About half the public says that President Reagan is ''lying'' when he asserts that he had no knowledge that funds from the sale of arms to Iran were being diverted to Nicaraguan insurgents, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Dubious Record
description: New York City Marathon officials announced yesterday that 24 runners had been disqualified for cheating, including three of the top 100 finishers in the men's division. All 24 failed to pass video camera checkpoints, according to Fred Lebow, the race director.

title: ABRAMS IS SAID TO BE PURSUING HELMSEYS CASE
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has opened a grand jury investigation into allegations that Harry and Leona Helmsley illegally billed their real estate and hotel businesses for renovation of their Greenwich, Conn., estate, law enforcement officials said.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the results for the 1985 6-month period are pro forma. Prior to the company's public offering on July 17, 1985, the company elected to be treated as a subchapter S corporation. Upon becoming a public corporation, the company terminated its subchapter S status. The pro forma results reflect a provision for federal and state taxes as if the company had not been treated as a subchapter S corporation.

title: LONG-TERM U.S. SECURITIES OFF
description: In the second consecutive day of quiet trading, prices of Treasury issues due in 10 years and longer fell slightly yesterday, while shorter-term issues were little changed.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 14
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL: A3-21

title: By Evasion, Nicaragua and Honduras Avoid Showdown, but Tensions Rise
description: In recent years, relations between Honduras and Nicaragua have been played out through a series of diplomatic exaggerations that border on outright mendacity, diplomats and others say.

title: Ending a Bad Habit
description: Bob Quinn, the interim head basketball coach at Fordham who replaced Tom Penders last month, was still disturbed Tuesday about his players dumping a bucket of water over him last Saturday, and he blames the Giants players' habit of dousing Coach Bill Parcells during victories for the incident. Quinn's dousing occurred when Fordham's players began to celebrate their eventual 91-88 double overtime victory over Wichita State in the final of the Shocker Classic and it almost cost the Rams the victory.

title: THE POLICE SAY STABBING VICTIM BAITED THE KILLER
description: A vocational-school student stabbed to death on a Queens subway Monday had been trying to grab a shoulder bag from the man who killed him, the transit police said yesterday.

title: MUSIC: UNCUT 'MESSIAH'
description: ANY ''Messiah'' performance that is not guided by a strong, particular point of view on Baroque musical style - and there are reasons both for asserting and questioning the value of such guidance - is bound to reflect the fragmentation of approaches characteristic of our musical generation. That the Masterwork Chorus presentation of Handel's masterpiece Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall should be a case in point is not surprising. What the performance stood to benefit from, though, was not so much musicological consistency as the older virtues of fervor and absorption. Perhaps all the stylistic question marks make this harder to achieve, or perceive, nowadays; at any rate, up to the point at which this listener had to depart for the chamber concert next door at Alice Tully Hall, inspiration was elusive.

title: STAGE: SPOOF OF MOVIES IN 'EPIC PROPORTIONS'
description: THE Building of the Pyramids! The Fall of Rome! Gladiators Struggling! The

title: MUSCLE FASHIONED INTO AUXILIARY HEART IN DOG
description: In a revolutionary advance aimed at assisting victims of human heart disease, doctors yesterday reported that they had used a dog's own back muscle and fashioned it into a pump alongside the heart to increase blood circulation.

title: Three Receive '86 Guild Hall Awards
description: Guild Hall, the arts center in East Hampton, L.I., has presented this year's awards for ''lifetime achievement'' to E. L. Doctorow, the novelist, Sidney Lumet, the film director, and Saul Steinberg, the artist.

title: Advertising; No Place Like Home For Insurer
description: HOME INSURANCE, the largest operating unit within the Home Group, today begins its first national advertising campaign since 1979, with its agency, Waring & LaRosa, milking the positive images of the word ''home'' for all it's worth.

title: Berry Rejects Offer
description: Raymond Berry, coach of the New England Patriots and a former star player at Southern Methodist University, has rejected an offer by S.M.U. to talk about returning to the school as athletic director of the embattled sports program. Jim Greenidge, Patriots' director of publicity, confirmed that representatives of S.M.U. contacted Berry yesterday morning by telephone and wanted to talk about the move, but the coach said no.

title: Drug Tests: The Kickoff
description: In what amounts to a preview of mandatory drug urinalysis for teams headed to the bowl games, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been quietly testing players in the lesser-division football tournaments. And so far, at least five players from three schools have been dealt 90-day suspensions after each turned up positive for one of 84 banned or restricted substances.

title: LAKERS SPOILS HILL'S HOME DEBUT
description: Throughout the last frantic week since their former coach was dismissed, the watchword for the Knicks has been progress. And slowly things had indeed seemed to change, away from the malaise that gripped them during the early part of the season to an energetic and excitable attitude under their stylish new coach, Bob Hill.

title: U.S.O. and the Family
description: Many in the armed services are young, most between 18 and 25 years old.

title: N.F.L. TO REVIEW 1980 TICKET SCALPING
description: The National Football League intends to conduct an ''administrative review'' of a 1980 Super Bowl ticket-scalping incident involving Dominic Frontiere, who was sentenced Monday to a year and a day in prison and fined $15,000 for failing to report income from the sale of the tickets and for lying to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: A.T.&T. to Join Boeing in Bid
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Boeing Company said yesterday that they would join forces to bid for a $4.5 billion contract to provide telecommunications services to the Federal Government.

title: Panel of Georgia Regents Votes for Divestment
description: A committee of the Board of Regents voted today to direct the state's university system to divest itself of $1.18 million in holdings in companies doing business with South Africa.

title: Dr. WINIFRED B. LELAND
description: Dr. Winifred Bronson Leland, an allergist in private practice in Manhattan for more than 40 years, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 81 years old. Dr. Leland was known professionally as Dr. Bronson during her career, which began in World War II and ended with her retirement in 1973.

title: Hard Seats
description: The three dozen reporters covering the closed hearings of the Senate Intelligence Committee have discovered what it was like in the days when most newsworthy committee meetings were closed to the press. Each of the first two days of the inquiry into arms shipments and rebel aid last week, they stood for 12 hours in the second-floor corridor of the Hart Senate Office Building, since a more relaxed posture was interpreted as violating the Senate ban on sit-ins.

title: Bridge: Shirley Hewitt Remembered As Hostess and Fine Player
description: The bridge players of the New York metropolitan area lost their leading hostess when Shirley Hewitt of Irvington, N.Y., died Sunday.

title: CRIME AND CITY SOLUTION FINDS MIX OF ITS OWN
description: ENCOUNTERED backstage at the Cat Club this year at the beginning of their first American tour, Crime and the City Solution's five musicians seemed to take up defensive positions naturally. Mick Harvey, the mostly Australian band's principal strategist and most articulate spokesman, stood half-blocking the door into the tiny dressing room. The band's singer, bassist and drummer were in a loose huddle behind him. At the very back of the room, as far from the door as possible, the rail-thin guitarist Rowland S. Howard paced like a caged animal, his eyes nervously scanning the traffic outside the door.

title: 9 Injured in Explosion At Boston Skyscraper
description: An explosion and fire today in a 42-story office building in downtown Boston injured nine people and forced the evacuation of hundreds of workers, the police said.

title: Economic Scene; A Season Of Cassandras
description: THE Reagan Administration has marked its forecast for the economy's growth next year down to 3.2 percent, from 4.2 percent, but this did not upset the securities markets. On the contrary, the markets seemed to welcome the new forecast as representing a gain in realism; the Administration's forecast is now within the band of forecasts of most private economists, though still a bit above the consensus.

title: 'Get Off His Back,' Nixon Urges...
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon said today that President Reagan's critics should ''get off his back'' and allow him to continue his ''quest for peace'' with the Soviet Union.

title: THE SINGAPORE CONNECTION
description: The Singapore International Monetary Exchange finally appears to be living up to its advance billing. Though still not bursting with energy on most days, the Simex recently showed why it was hailed as a prototype of the time when financial exchanges would be linked across international boundaries 24 hours a day.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations and a provision for disposal of discontinued operations of $2,126,000. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations and a provision for disposal of discontinued operations of $203,000.

title: To Make Better Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS TROUNCED
description: Bill Smith, the losing goalie, grimaced at the mirror as he ungently knotted his tie. Ken Morrow, the veteran defenseman who managed to be on the ice for just one of the opposition's five even-strength goals and one of its two power-play goals, bowed his head and stared into a bin of damp towels.

title: Cuomo's Insufficient Tax Cuts
description: Governor Cuomo has called for tax cuts to offset the automatic increase in state tax collections that would result from the new Federal tax code. But New York State's personal income tax rates must be reduced far more dramatically than the Governor proposes if the state hopes to survive in the new competitive environment created by the Federal code.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes gains of $531,000 and $3,073,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the disposition of rental properties. c-Net loss d-After gains on the disposition of rental properties of $345,000 for the quarter and $1,130,000 for the 9 months.

title: AN EFFICIENT BATTLE PLAN FOR WILSON 'CIVIL WARS'
description: Late Tuesday afternoon, Robert Wilson arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the first time in three months, having been whisked straight from Kennedy Airport. Sunday night is the American stage premiere of the fifth act of his ''Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down.'' Itself a two-hour-plus, full-dress opera with music by Philip Glass, this fifth act is as complex and visually intricate a production as any Mr. Wilson has assayed.

title: PLAN TO END BEIRUT FIGHTING GOES AWRY
description: A last-minute hitch stopped an Iranian effort today to halt 17 days of battles between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite Moslem militiamen in Beirut and southern Lebanon.

title: Rape Protests Bring Charges at Wesleyan
description: The Student Judicial Board at Wesleyan University has filed charges against six students, saying they interrupted campus tours by telling prospective freshmen and their parents about sexual assaults on campus.

title: LOUISVILLE WINS, 60-58
description: Pervis Ellison had 18 points and 13 rebounds as Louisville (3-3) used a strong inside attack to defeat Western Kentucky, 60-58, tonight.

title: BUYING THE RIGHT TREE AND CARING FOR IT
description: ON some sidewalks these days, one can hardly see the buildings for the trees. These sudden street forests are cut species of pine, spruce and fir that have been trucked here from far away groves to be sold for the holidays.

title: COLUMN ONE: 8th Ave. Scenes; Present to Future: Dowdy to Jaunty
description: Eighth Avenue's identity crisis is growing acute.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 11, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M.

title: U.S. AID SOUGHT BY WISCONSIN
description: Gov. Anthony S. Earl asked President Reagan today for $17 million to help combat erosion along the shores of 15 Wisconsin counties bordering Lake Superior and Lake Michigan.

title: SKI RACING TEAMS GROW IN POPULARITY
description: Skiing is an individual sport and skiers like to think of themselves as individualists. But in recent years, the fastest-growing ski competitions involve racing as teams.

title: OIL WORRY: IMPORT RELIANCE
description: Crude oil production in the United States will decline on an annual basis this year for the first time since 1980, according to newly available data. And it is expected to fall even more in 1987, raising concerns that the country's already-growing dependency on oil imports could create an ''oil shock'' in the 1990's as great as those of the 1970's.

title: 2 Marist Players Allowed to Play
description: Officials at Marist College said the National Collegiate Athletic Association informed them last night that the eligibility of two basketball players -Rudy Bourgarel and Miroslav Pecarski - has been restored immediately and that the eligibility of a third, Rick Smits, will be restored as of Jan. 1.

title: PARACHUTIST PLEADS GUILTY
description: A parachutist who floated down onto Shea Stadium during the sixth game of the World Series pleaded guilty yesterday to a criminal trespass charge in a plea deal in which prosecutors agreed to drop the more serious charge of reckless endangerment.

title: Recall Vote Set in Omaha
description: The City Council voted unanimously Tuesday to set the recall election for Mayor Mike Boyle on Jan. 13.

title: A Few Good Hands
description: Keith Hernandez won yet another Gold Glove last week, something he has now done more often than any other first baseman in history.

title: Hunts Hire New Lawyers
description: The wealthy Hunt brothers said today that they had replaced their principal lawyers, Edward P. McCabe and Stephen Gordon, in two lawsuits in which they are seeking $13.8 billion in damages from 23 banks.

title: Suspended Officer Is Seized With Brother on Gun Charge
description: A suspended police officer and his brother were arrested in Harlem late yesterday afternoon by undercover narcotics officers and charged with criminal possession of two shotguns, the police said.

title: Freud's Complaint
description: To the Editor:

title: WANG LABS' CRITICAL JUNCTURE
description: Frederick A. Wang bristled visibly at the inevitable request: to contrast his management style with that of his father, An Wang, the computer pioneer, philanthropist and founder of Wang Laboratories Inc.

title: A Change of Makeup for Pan Am Building Lobby
description: I NEVER thought that anything could make me feel wistful about the Pan Am Building, but something has. It is the design for the new lobby of this massive skyscraper, and it is so dreadful that it inspires only a disquieting nostalgia for the Pan Am Building as it used to be.

title: COLLECTORS: THEIR FINDS FURNISH THEIR HOMES
description: THOUGH most people live with a smattering of furniture from different eras - an 80's camelback sofa mixed with 60's directors' chairs and an 1890's grandfather clock, for example - a handful of dedicated collectors live surrounded by furniture of only one design period. Their finds become their furnishings and set their decorating styles.

title: Secretary Lehman and His Spaniels
description: Navy Secretary John Lehman is among the most effective service secretaries in years. But his skin is strangely thin and his sensibility thick when Navy policies come under criticism. Far from welcoming dissent, he prefers to stifle it.

title: WOMEN'S JOBS HELP SAVE MANY FARMS
description: THE American farm family is undergoing dramatic changes as increasing numbers of wives take jobs off the farm to keep their families from losing their legacy and their way of life. In some cases the wife's paycheck supplements the family's income; in others it has become essential to economic survival.

title: WAR OVER TV SATELLITES PITS N.F.L. AGAINST BARS
description: Lawyers from the National Football League have blown the whistle on Dirty Al's Saloon.

title: A MULLAH'S RELATIVE CONFESSES TO MURDER AND HOARDING ARMS
description: A relative of the designated successor to the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini confessed to murder, hoarding weapons and collaborating with the Shah's secret police, the Teheran radio said today.

title: MISSILES FOR IRAN LINKED TO THE ARMY IN EUROPE
description: The military commander of NATO indicated today that there was circumstantial evidence that some of the American arms sold secretly to Iran might have been taken from Army stocks in Europe.

title: Carter's Ally Called the Tune
description: WHEN a company is under takeover attack, it often turns to a friendly ally known as a passive ''white knight'' - a sort of corporate buddy who will nestle away a big block of stock but not pose an immediate threat. But a white knight can, over time, become more menacing: a possibility the board of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the big department chain, recently faced.

title: The Subway Stop in Albany
description: Any New Yorker who wants to see the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's financial plan in action only needs to ride the IRT. Old, disfigured cars have largely disappeared from the 1, 2, 3 and 4 lines. Most riders travel in new or overhauled cars. The change is as welcome as a green light. The message for the State Legislature as it begins its special session is, don't let the light turn red.

title: Lendl No. 1 Again
description: The International Tennis Federation has declared Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia the official men's world champion for the second successive year.

title: Henkel Set to Buy Shamrock Business
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that it had agreed to sell the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company process chemicals business to the Henkel Corporation, a unit of Henkel of West Germany.

title: A Chat With Meese
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the Attorney General, will provide an off-the-record briefing today on the Iran-Nicaragua arms and funds crisis to a very exclusive audience, alumni of the early years of the Reagan Administration now working in the New York area.

title: Reagan Physician Chosen
description: President Reagan has selected Army Col. John E. Hutton, who has served as assistant Presidential physician for two years, to succeed Dr. T. Burton Smith as the President's physician, the White House announced today. Colonel Hutton is a former chief of surgery at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington.

title: POLICE SUPERVISORS IN SURVEY FAIL TO IDENTIFY THEIR BOSSES
description: A survey of sergeants and lieutenants in the New York City Police Department has found that many do not know the names of the patrol officers they supervise or of the commanders in their boroughs, senior police officials said yesterday.

title: Maryland Picks Krivak
description: Joe Krivak, a longtime assistant at the University of Maryland, was promoted to head football coach yesterday. He received a four-year contract, but financial details were not disclosed.

title: TUTU, IN U.S., SEES IRAN CRISIS HELPING BLACK AFRICAN CAUSE
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa, on his first visit to the United States since Congress imposed economic sanctions on his country, said today that the Iran arms controversy would probably help the black cause in South Africa.

title: New Parisian in Town?
description: French officials say they are confident that their man, Michel Camdessus, governor of the Bank of France, will soon be coming to Washington as the new head of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Article 534286 -- No Title
description: A group of new prizes of $50,000 apiece will be awarded to outstanding American graduate students and other promising researchers starting in 1988, an officer of the American Nobel Anniversary Committee said yesterday.

title: Federal Court Upholds Suit by Baylor Doctors
description: The Baylor College of Medicine illegally kept Jewish doctors from participating in a program at a Saudi Arabian medical complex used by that nation's royal family, a Federal appeals court ruled Tuesday.

title: STEINBERG SELLS MOST OF BRITISH STAKE
description: Saul P. Steinberg, the American financier, sold most of his 15.1 percent stake in the British financial group Mercury Securities today for almost $142 million after the company repeatedly rejected his proposals to increase its earnings.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Cambridge, Mass., on Nov. 24, about a Harvard University policy statement on research financed by Government agencies, incorrectly described one result of a Harvard investigation of Nadav Safran, a professor of Middle Eastern studies. There was no finding of wrongdoing in Professor Safran's acceptance of $107,430 from the Central Intelligence Agency to finance a book on Saudi Arabia.

title: 'Things Will Get Worse'
description: Once in a rare while we read a book that puts the urgencies of our time and ourselves in perspective, making us confront the darker realities of human nature. That has just happened to me. The book is by Heda Margolius Kovaly. It is called ''Under a Cruel Star: A Life in Prague 1941-1968.''

title: Gospel Truth
description: James Donaldson, the Dallas Mavericks' 7-foot-2-inch, 277-pound center: ''Let's see, who's stronger than I am? Goliath had a good reputation, but he was stuffed by a point guard.''

title: All the President's Men Should Be Replaced
description: To the Editor:

title: USX CHIEF CITES TALKS WITH B.P.
description: David M. Roderick, the chairman of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that several parties, including the British Petroleum Company, had expressed interest in acquiring various oil operations of the giant energy and steel company.

title: AID FOR CONTRAS: THE CUBANS OF MIAMI SEND IT WITH GUSTO
description: In the last three years, the big, fervently anti-Communist Cuban-American population here has provided the Nicaraguan rebels with combat advisers, medical teams and more than $1.5 million in medical equipment and supplies, food and clothing, its leaders say.

title: COURT CLEARS WAY FOR PRIMARY VOTE BY INDEPENDENTS
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for independent voters to take part in a political party's primary election if the party permits them to do so.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reorganization by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was reorganizing its North American operations to place its de Mexico subsidiary under the Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada car group. G.M. de Mexico had been in the overseas group.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in Science Times on Dec. 2 about a proposal to protect the earth's ozone layer misstated limits on the use of chlorofluorocarbons in the United States. They are generally banned as spray can propellants but are used in most air-conditioning systems and in many other applications.

title: U.S. ADMIRAL SAYS PHILIPPINE BASES ARE ESSENTIAL
description: The commander of the United States Pacific Fleet said today that if the United States lost its naval and air bases in the Philippines, it ''would be turning over our friends and allies to Soviet political and military domination in that region.''

title: No Further 'Star Wars' Panel Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks to Get Stake in Mexico's Alfa
description: In the largest restructuring of private-sector debt of Mexico's debt crisis, about five dozen foreign banks will acquire a majority stake in Grupo Industrial Alfa S.A., the nation's largest privately held conglomerate, according to Mexican Government and banking sources.

title: CITY'S TEACHERS ARE TO RECEIVE $250 PAY RAISE
description: The United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education said yesterday that the salaries of all New York City teachers' salaries would be raised by $250 a year in February as part of an agreement on how a $30.7 million allocation from the State Legislature would be spent.

title: REQUIEM FOR SUBWAY CAR 6321, AGE 31
description: Car No. 6321 was pronounced dead last week at the Transit Authority East New York maintenance shop after a long illness. It was 31 years old. No ceremony was held, no tears were shed.

title: Too Much Heat
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Alexander Hollaender Dead; Pioneer in Radiation Biology
description: Alexander Hollaender, a radiation biologist who was a former director of the biology division of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tenn., died of a pulmonary embolism Saturday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

title: STUDY REPORTS RISE IN LOW-PAYING JOBS OVER 5-YEAR PERIOD
description: More than half the eight million net new jobs created from 1979 to 1984 in the United States paid less than $7,000 a year while jobs paying $28,000 or more fell, according to a new study.

title: Japanese Workweek
description: apan should gradually lower the legal limit on weekly working hours from 48 to 40 to help improve workers' health and welfare, an advisory panel proposed today. A Labor Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said such a change would be the first important revision in the Labor Standards Law since its establishment in 1947.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Take sides. Neutrality helps the oppressor, never the victim. Silence encourages the tormentor, never the tormented.''

title: ISRAELIS' ACCOUNT ON ARMS: HOW U.S. SET UP THE DEAL
description: In the last few days, Israeli officials have been quietly divulging to the Israeli press their inside account of the Iran affair - a version they say details precisely how the United States Government, ''with the knowledge and approval'' of President Reagan, used Israel to exchange arms for hostages with Iran.

title: Fujitsu-I.B.M. Pact Report
description: Fujitsu Ltd. agreed in 1983 to pay the International Business Machines Corporation stiff penalties and submit to periodic inspections of Fujitsu software development and new products to settle a dispute over copyright violations, a leading Japanese newspaper reported today.

title: MARCOS AND MANHATTAN PROPERTY CASE: ENTER SAUDI BILLIONAIRE
description: Four Manhattan properties long believed to belong to Ferdinand E. Marcos appear to be the property of the Saudi billionaire Adnan M. Khashoggi, according to documents introduced in court proceedings begun by the Aquino Government.

title: INSIDER SURVEILLANCE FELL SHORT, PHELAN SAYS
description: Despite widespread suspicion of illegal insider trading by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York Stock Exchange's computer surveillance and other policing systems did not provide enough evidence to prove it, the exchange's chairman plans to tell a House panel on Thursday.

title: CONCERT: THE PRISM ORCHESTRA
description: DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH is known for his grand, brooding, brassily public symphonies. But his final symphonies came in his last, introspective period, dominated by chamber music: the Symphonies Nos. 13, 14 and 15 were composed in the midst of fully eight of the late, gloomy string quartets.

title: Rapist Is Sought In 11 Sex Assaults
description: A man raped and robbed an 18-year-old woman at 1505 Park Avenue in East Harlem yesterday, and the police said it was the 11th incident in a pattern of sexual assaults that began Oct. 6.

title: Dodgers Get Leary for Brock
description: Baseball's trading market finally came alive today in a flurry of deals that sent Danny Tartabull to Kansas City, Greg Brock to Milwaukee and Tim Leary to Los Angeles. And, backstage, the Mets held a ''meeting of minds'' with San Diego that could trigger the blockbuster trade they have been pursuing for Kevin McReynolds.

title: TOP U.S. OFFICIALS MAY GET BIG RAISE
description: A Federal commission will recommend that that top elected officials and political appointees receive pay raises of as much as 25 percent, a spokesman for the House committee that will receive the report said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alliance Capital Management Corp., which provides investment advisory services, named the following executive vice presidents: Frank W. Burr, Bruce W. Calvert, Alfred Harrison and John D. Carifa.

title: Gulf Resources Drops Its Offer
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation dropped its hostile $970 million offer to acquire Imperial Continental Gas Association of Britain today after the British Government said it would review the bid. A review by the Britain's

title: KNICK COMEBACK FALLS SHORT
description: Long ago, when there was still a lot to be optimistic about, the Knicks thought that this juncture of the season would serve as a barometer. It was to be the end of a strenuous stretch, 15 of 22 games on the road. Little did they know then that they would also be faced with a sudden coaching change, injuries and the addition of two players.

title: Airport Talks in Japan Went Badly, U.S. Says
description: Despite intervention by President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, ''extremely limited progress'' has been made in efforts to enable American companies to compete in the construction of an $8 billion airport in Osaka, a United States Commerce Department official said today.

title: Chevron Sees Sizable Charge
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it expected to record about $320 million in charges against its fourth-quarter earnings. The charges relate primarily to oil wells whose development would not be justified by current oil prices, the company said, and they include a provision for accelerated amortization of some domestic leases.

title: Purdue Signs Akers
description: He coached for 10 years at the University of Texas, where his football teams compiled an 86-31-2 record, but the reward for Fred Akers after a 5-6 record this season was dismissal. Now he has taken on what he calls ''a great challenge,'' becoming the 31st head coach at Purdue.

title: TRANSNATIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
VICTORY AND SORROW FOR PARIS STUDENTS
description: They were out again in the streets of Paris today, tens of thousands of students, their parents and members of labor unions, walking silently and carrying black banners with a single word printed on them -''mourning.''

title: Davis Held Responsible
description: A Superior Court jury in San Diego decided yesterday that Al Davis, managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, was responsible for a heart attack suffered in 1981 by Eugene V. Klein, former owner of the San Diego Chargers.

title: Discover's Logical Prospects
description: SINCE Science '86 and Science Digest have gone out of business, nice things have been happening to Discover magazine quite beyond the addition of their subscriber lists to its own.

title: A FORMER AMBASSADOR TO MOSCOW
description: Walter J. Stoessel Jr., a career diplomat who was an Ambassador to the Soviet Union, died here Tuesday of leukemia. He was 66 years old. Mr. Stoessel joined the Foreign Service in 1942 and served until his retirement 40 years later. He was often a key figure in world events, including the normalization of relations between the United States and China.

title: France to Sell 20% of Paribas
description: The French Government said today that it would sell 20 percent of the state-owned investment bank, Paribas, to specially selected French investors when the bank is privatized by early next year.

title: All the President's Men Should Be Replaced
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline's Dutch Auction
description: STOCKHOLDERS who may wish to sell their shares of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation are being given an unusual opportunity known as a Dutch auction by the giant producer of ethical and proprietary drugs.

title: KEY LEADERS BACK NASA AND ITS CHIEF
description: Two senators who will assume leading roles on space issues in the new Congress said yesterday that they ''strongly'' supported the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its head, Dr. James C. Fletcher, in their efforts to redesign the space shuttle's flawed booster rockets.

title: HISPANIC UNIT SAYS CITY FAILS TO MEET NEEDS
description: City agencies are failing to meet the basic needs of New York's Hispanic residents, the Mayor's Commission on Hispanic Concerns said yesterday.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 25
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5-for-2 stock split May 2, 1986.

title: Geer, DuBois Chosen For Amaretto Business
description: The Paddington Corporation, which took over the importing of Amaretto di Saronno from Glenmore Distilleries, has assigned the advertising of the Italian liqueur to Geer, DuBois Advertising.

title: 5 ARRESTED AT BRANDEIS IN INVESTMENT PROTEST
description: Five Brandeis University students who oppose their school's investments in companies that do business in South Africa were arrested today after they occupied an office in the main campus administration building for two hours.

title: SAUDI ARMS TRADER DESCRIBES ROLE IN IRAN WEAPONS DEAL
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the billionaire Saudi arms dealer, said that he moved at least $10 million of the money for the Iran arms deal into a Swiss account he believed could be used by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord.

title: DIRECTOR'S WORDS RECALLED AT TRIAL IN FILM DEATHS
description: Told the special effects explosions had come ''pretty close'' to the helicopter in a scene filmed before the fatal crash of the aircraft in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' the director, John Landis, responded, ''You haven't seen nothing yet,'' a witness testified today.

title: Government Issues Advance
description: While trading activity in the Treasury market remained light, prices of outstanding Government issues rose modestly yesterday and investment bankers offered a heavy supply of new corporate issues.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. HAILS PRIMARY RULING
description: Jubilant Connecticut Republicans said today that the United States Supreme Court's decision allowing independents to vote in the party's major primaries could help them break a pattern of statewide election losses to the Democrats.

title: DONOR GIVES SWIFTLY TO EASE PLIGHT OF NEEDY
description: ''Because the need is so much greater this year, I am making certain that my contribution is sent off without delay,'' Gladys Moon of Manhattan said in a note accompanying her gift of $75 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Blue Chips Set Pace; Dow Up 16.03
description: Blue-chip issues scored a fairly sizable gain yesterday on Wall Street because of a price aberration in the stock index futures market, even though the bulk of the stock market was only moderately higher.

title: BUSINESS, LABOR AND THE STATE ACT TO AID DISPLACED WORKERS
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that state economic development officials, key business executives and top union leaders had worked out a plan to soften the shocks of factory shutdowns and major layoffs.

title: Cox Supports Panels' Inquiry
description: Archibald Cox, the first special prosecutor in the Watergate crisis, said today that the Reagan Administration has engaged in ''high-level duplicity'' in the Iran affair and that Congress must take the lead in investigating it. In a letter to all members of Congress, Mr. Cox also said the select committees being appointed in the House and Senate should refrain from granting immunity until all sources of information have been fully explored.

title: Storage Plan On Bankruptcy
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a troubled computer equipment maker based in Louisville, Colo., said that it would emerge from bankruptcy proceedings in the second quarter of 1987, now that creditors and security holders had approved its reorganization plan and the court had declared the plan feasible.

title: Role of Care-Givers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Manuel Limits Workout
description: Lionel Manuel, the Giants' most dangerous wide receiver, was scheduled to return to practice today for the first time since he sprained his left knee more than 10 weeks ago.

title: For GFI Chief, Scrutiny Of His Sheller Purchase
description: When he was a teen-ager growing up in Boston, Marshall S. Cogan spent his summer vacations working at his Uncle David's Chevrolet dealership.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: DANCE: 'SURVIVORS,' TRIBUTE TO MANDELAS
description: MAX ROACH, the distinguished drummer and composer, has joined forces with Alvin Ailey to create a stirring tribute to Nelson and Winnie Mandela.

title: VIBRANT FORMS CREATED BY METAL-GLASS MELDING
description: The master glass blower Michael Glancy has developed an unusual process for electroplating copper, silver and gold onto his glass forms. His 32 pieces currently on display at the Heller Gallery are encased in thin layers of smooth or textured metal.

title: Assessing the 5th Amendment Issue
description: Two great issues now swirling about this city - the flow of Government information to the public and the constitutional right not to have to testify against one's self -have long been on the mind of Erwin N. Griswold.

title: REAL-ESTATE FIGURES FIGHT NEW CITY LAW ON LISTING OF INCOME
description: Representatives of New York City's real-estate industry went into court yesterday seeking a public referendum on a new city law, one of several measures the city needs to reduce its budget deficit.

title: Under the Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Q.Is there an effective way to de-wallpaper a room in order to make it paintable? A.I assume that when you say

title: LAMBERT A WINNER IN DEBUT AS RANGER
description: There was Walt Poddubny scoring once, Tony McKegney scoring twice, and then Lane Lambert joining them last night as the Rangers' latest unexpected hero. In his first game with the Rangers, Lambert scored the first goal and the last in a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD CELEBRATES EVICTIONS AT CRACK HOUSE
description: The light drizzle and nippy breeze yesterday morning made it a terrible time for a street festival, even a spontaneous one. But jubilant neighbors on Manhattan Avenue between 105th and 106th Streets turned out anyway to celebrate as sheriff's deputies evicted a dozen squatters from the crack house at No. 124.

title: Campaigns Don't Belong to Candidates
description: During one of my political campaigns in Florida, I was marching in a parade and shaking hands with spectators. As I approached a man with a little boy perched on his shoulders, the child looked down and said excitedly: ''Daddy! Daddy! There's the man who lives in our TV!''

title: Why Torpedo Tax Reform?
description: Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House, speaks a mouthful of truth when he says tax revenue must be increased if the Government is to harness the towering budget deficit. But by proposing to collect the revenue by postponing tax reductions for ''the rich,'' he distorts the message with cornball populist politics. His objective is sound, his method destructive.

title: Gunshot Killing Doctor Is Called Unintentional
description: A former surgical patient accused of second-degree murder in the killing of the chief of surgery at a Brooklyn hospital said at the start of his trial yesterday that he had fired the fatal shot but had not done so intentionally.

title: 6 DIE IN PLANE CRASH IN BERKSHIRES
description: A twin-engine plane from the Middle West with six people aboard crashed into the side of a low mountain and burst into flame today, killing all those aboard, officials said.

title: S.&P. Increases Ratings for Ford
description: The ratings on the Ford Motor Company's short- and long-term debt were raised yesterday, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced.

title: Deliberations Started In Wayne Newton Case
description: A jury began deliberations today in Wayne Newton's multimillion-dollar defamation lawsuit against NBC after a lawyer for the entertainer said the network showed a ''total absence of institutional conscience.''

title: AFG Offers Lear Assistance
description: AFG Partners, which has renewed a $1.51 billion to acquire Lear Siegler Inc., said tonight that it would be interested in helping Lear Siegler if the aerospace and manufacturing company decides to restructure rather than accept its $85 a share bid.

title: Markets, Banks Open Dec. 26
description: Most of the nation's major markets and many of New York's big banks said that they would be open on Friday, Dec. 26, even though President Reagan yesterday designated the day a Federal holiday.

title: All the President's Men Should Be Replaced
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KEY PIECE Franz Liszt has been dead for 100 years now, and it seems improbable that the only piece he wrote specifically for two pianos is having its New York premiere tonight. The 21-minute piece, which was composed in 1834, will be played by the duo-pianists Richard and John Conti-Guglia at Alice Tully Hall in a concert that begins at 8 o'clock (362-1911).

title: BIRD'S RECOVERY IS PAINFUL FOR NETS
description: With about five minutes remaining in the opening quarter tonight, the Celtics' 281st straight capacity crowd in Boston Garden began to applaud. On the bench, Larry Bird, who had missed the last three games with a strained right Achilles' tendon, was removing his warmup suit.

title: Repeal Sought On Jet Trainer
description: The Air Force will ask Congress to repeal a provision of the military spending law calling for a competition to select a new jet training aircraft. Among the contenders in the competition is the Fairchild Republic Company's T-46A, which is built on Long Island.

title: Fannie Mae Offers A Mortgage Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association sold $310 million of 6 percent mortgage-backed securities yesterday at an average price of 93 20/32 to yield 7.56 percent. The securities are backed by a pool of mortgages guaranteed or insured by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration.

title: OPERA: BEETHOVEN'S 'FIDELIO' AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: LEONORE, the plucky and resourceful heroine of ''Fidelio,'' is a role into which Hildegard Behrens fits with hand-in-glove snugness. The German soprano's ardent temperament and searching interpretative mind find a subject suited to them in Beethoven's only opera. Moreover, her vocal equipment, which often betrays serious weaknesses in more lyric parts, can serve her not only well but excitingly when the moon is in the right dramatic quarter. Last evening's ''Fidelio,'' the first of the Metropolitan's season, found Miss Behrens in her best current voice and in a mood to sweep aside any reservations one might have entertained in advance about the cast as a whole or the somewhat clumsy old Otto Schenk production.

title: U.S. JURY IN MIAMI LOOKS INTO CHARGES CONTRAS BROKE LAWS
description: A Federal grand jury in Miami is examining evidence of gunrunning and Neutrality Act violations by Nicaraguan rebels and some American backers, a Federal official said today.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $27,773,000 for the quarter and $32,417,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $68,325,000 and $63,291,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary charges of $9,719,000 for the quarter and $16,361,000 for the year. The company said the latest year loss includes a one-time gain of $26.9 million associated with restructuring, and the year-ago quarter and year losses both include a one-time charge of about $400 million from restructuring.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GREAT AMERICAN MAGAZINE:

title: MITSUI UNIT GETS EXXON BUILDING
description: The 54-story Exxon Building, part of Rockefeller Center, has been sold to a subsidiary of the giant Japanese conglomerate Mitsui & Company for $610 million, the owners of the 13-year-old skyscraper announced yesterday.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $228,000 for the quarter and $609,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $2,366,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $3,764,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. The latest 9-month results from continuing operations includes a $5 million credit from the proceeds of an insurance policy and a $5.1 million credit from the withdrawal of excess funds from an overfunded pension plan. The year-ago 9 months results include pre-tax charges of $16.8 million in connection with the realignment and disposal of certain of the company' apparel operations.

title: Bethlehem Seeks Wheeling Rail Mill
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it was negotiating to buy a federally financed modern rail mill that the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said it would close because of sagging demand and surging imports in the transportation industry. Wheeling-Pittsburgh still owes the Economic Development Administration $64 million for the rail mill and up to $90 million under the public loan that financed the mill and related improvements.

title: A New 'Cosi Fan Tutte' From Jonathan Miller
description: HAVING transposed Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' to a modern setting in New York City's Little Italy a couple of years ago, Jonathan Miller is now taking pains to show ruffled operagoers that he can, if they insist, be safely ''traditional'' - more or less. For the third time in the past couple of decades, Mr. Miller is tackling Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'' The decidedly charming result, sung in an English translation by Ruth and Thomas Martin, can be seen tonight at 8 on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network. With commercial interruptions, the presentation runs for just over three and a half hours.

title: Humidifiers Quieter Than a Dropped Pin
description: COMPARED with the nebulizer in an ultrasonic humidifier, a hummingbird's wings move at a sloth's pace. A hummingbird beats its wings 50 times a second; a nebulizer, the dime-size disk that turns water into mist in ultrasonic humidifiers, beats or oscillates 1.7 million times per second.

title: Trade Deficit Sets a Record
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit from July through September swelled to $37.7 billion, the largest quarterly imbalance on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dollar Off in Quiet Day; Gold Gains $2.55 in U.S.
description: The dollar fell against major currencies except the Canadian dollar in quiet trading yesterday, on what analysts said were technical and economic factors.

title: Blue Skies
description: The state-of-baseball address that Peter Ueberroth delivered at the winter meetings the other day was decidely upbeat, and fittingly so. No earlier commissioner could ever have found so many signs of good health in the game, a circumstance that is beginning to make the major league owners' dire predictions of recent years seem woefully dated now.

title: IRAN'S DROPPED WORD STIRS KHOMEINI RUMOR
description: The Iranian press agency issued a report today describing the designated successor the Ayatollah Rudollah Khomeini as ''spiritual leader of the Islamic revolution,'' implying that Ayatollah Khomeini might be dead.

title: NO EASY CHEERS IN THE GARDEN
description: Let's see now. The problem with the San Francisco 49ers was that their fans were effete ''white-wine drinkers'' who didn't always give 100 percent effort out there. At least, that's what Randy Cross, the 49ers' offensive guard, said last week before the fans apparently switched to the harder stuff and helped the 49ers beat the Jets.

title: 8 in East Join Irish in TV Pact
description: Eight of the nine Eastern Division I-A football programs have joined with Notre Dame in a television agreement that, in the opinion of some athletic directors, may lead to the forming of a league with the attraction of the Big East Conference in basketball.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $411,000 which represents a distribution of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation stock by the Federal Home Loan Bank which occurred during the first fiscal quarter of 1985.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PRESS ARMS LIMITS
description: House Democrats today approved a resolution in favor of keeping the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty that the Reagan Administation breached earlier this month.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: MOYNIHAN GIVES SIGNALS OF A BID FOR RE-ELECTION
description: Signaling his intention to seek a third term in 1988, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan last night collected at least $500,000 for a campaign war chest at a $1,000-a-plate dinner in Manhattan.

title: U.S.-INDIA ACCORD ON COMPUTER SALE
description: High-level negotiators from India and the United States reached a tentative agreement today on a set of safeguards that would permit India to buy an American supercomputer for weather forecasting, according to officials involved in the talks.

title: Bulgarian Athlete Defects
description: A Bulgarian weight lifter, Neum Shalamanov, is seeking political asylum in Australia, the Foreign Ministry said today. Mr. Shalamanov, 19, disappeared Sunday after winning a third world cup title in Melbourne.

title: Soviet Deals Set With Four American Concerns
description: Soviet trade officials said yesterday that four American companies had signed formal agreements for joint business ventures in the Soviet Union under new, liberalized trade regulations that Moscow expects to have in place by next month.

title: Smoke and Fire and Smoke
description: Aware that the Surgeon General plans to issue yet another report next week on the health consequences of smoking, the Tobacco Institute plans to make something of a pre-emptive strike today.

title: Marchenko Had Heart Failure
description: The widow of Anatoly T. Marchenko, the dissident, was told by prison authorities in Chistopol today that he died Monday of heart failure, her friends here said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT PLANS NEW PRESS RESTRICTIONS
description: South Africa's information chief said today that the Government was planning sweeping new steps to restrict news reports about unrest in this country.

title: US West Cuts
description: US West Inc., the Denver-based regional telephone company, said it would no longer sell business communications equipment outside of its operating region because of low profits.

title: Japan Trade Inquiry On Supercomputers
description: Moving to a new front in its high-technology battles with Japan, the Reagan Administration today announced a formal investigation of Japanese barriers to the import of supercomputers. The move could lead to retaliation against Japanese products here.

title: Chargit Credit Service
description: Chargit, a telephone ticket reservation company, said yesterday that it is trying to restore immediately, at least on an interim basis, credit-card processing services. The services were halted after the Bowery Savings Bank announced earlier this week that it would end an arrangement under which Chargit processed Visa and Mastercard credit-card transactions for the Bowery.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Topics: Supportive Voices; Travelers' Aide
description: In a city of perpetual irritation, small official courtesies are precious. That's why subway travelers smile when the occasional conductor embellishes his announcements with ''Be careful when you get off the train'' and ''Have a nice day.''

title: REAGAN STRESSES HE KNEW NOTHING OF FUND SHIFT
description: President Reagan assured members of Congress today that he knew nothing about the diversion to Nicaraguan rebels of millions of dollars from arms deals with Teheran.

title: ART: A CONTEMPORARY MUSEUM FOR LOS ANGELES
description: WITH the opening yesterday of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, contemporary art has a new frontier. Los Angeles has had prominent artists, but it has never before had an institution of contemporary art of this ambition and scale. Not only does it now have one but the Museum of Contemporary Art may also enable Los Angeles to be the art center it has wanted to be but never has been.

title: A MASTER WOODWORKER CRAFTS AN ALTAR
description: THE idea of creating an ''Altar for Peace'' from a 125-foot English walnut tree came to the woodworker George Nakashima in a dream.

title: LIBRARIAN OF CONGRESS QUIT POST
description: The Librarian of Congress, Dr. Daniel J. Boorstin, announced today that he will leave his position as director of the world's largest and most diverse library in June to devote more time to writing. He has held the post for almost 12 years.

title: Sony Mae Plan Allows Mortgage Flexibility
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency is offering $372 million of bonds in the second part of a financing that will give it more flexibility in setting interest rates on the low-cost mortgage loans it makes available to home buyers in the state.

title: Debentures Issued By Union Pacific
description: The Union Pacific Corporation is offering $250 million of 7 7/8 percent, 10-year debentures at 99.05 to yield 8.015 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: WINTER GARDENS, HOME TOUR AND CRAFTS
description: Winter Gardens and Holiday Trees, Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard at 200th Street, Bronx, 212-220-8700.

title: TRUCE BEGINS IN THE PHILIPPINES, WITH MANY WARY
description: As the nation's first cease-fire in 17 years of insurgent warfare went into effect at noon today, a police patrolman watched an armed military patrol pass through the tiny plaza outside his bullet-scarred station house.

title: For Gardeners, Tools With Handles That Extend
description: Manufacturers never stop inventing better tools. The newest ones, called Twools, have a special feature: an add-on extender that converts short-handled tools to long-handled tools. With a quick twist, the add-on extender makes a three-prong cultivator, a wide-bladed trowel or a small rake into a long-handled tool.

title: JUSTICES HEAR 2 VIEWS ON 'CREATION' LAW
description: In oral argument sprinkled with references to the Bible, Aristotle, St. Thomas Aquinas and Spinoza, and with echoes of the Scopes ''monkey trial'' of the 1920's, the Supreme Court today confronted a Louisiana law that requires teaching of ''creation science'' in any public school that teaches the theory of evolution.

title: Hercules Promotes Executive to Chief
description: Hercules Inc., a producer of chemicals and aerospace products, said yesterday that David S. Hollingsworth would become chairman and chief executive on March 24, when Alexander F. Giacco retires.

title: State Dept. Expresses Regret On Poland's Barring Kennedy
description: The State Department expressed regret today that Poland had barred a planned visit by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Long, the rookie quarterback who was the Detroit Lions' top choice in the draft, will make his first pro start Monday night against the Chicago Bears. Injuries had limited the Lions' other quarterbacks, Joe Ferguson (sore knees) and Eric Hipple (sore elbow). The Bears said that Mike Tomczak would start but that Doug Flutie would see considerable action. . . . The Los Angeles Raiders will be without Lester Hayes, starting left cornerback, for the final two weeks of the regular season because of a broken bone in his left foot. . . . Lawyers for Brad Shearer, a former player for the Chicago Bears, said the team would pay $350,000 to Shearer in settlement of a lawsuit that contended that the team had failed to give him adequate care for an injured knee.

title: GUINNESS PLC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4.3 million. The company said the 1986 results were translated at 1.4335; the equivalent pound/dollar exchange rate that prevailed on Sept. 30, 1986, while the 1985 results were translated at 1.409.

title: FRESHMAN LEGISLATORS
description: Newly elected members of Congress entering the White House to meet with President Reagan yesterday. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)

title: THE DANCE: PROGRAM BY PILAR RIOJA
description: PROGRAMS by Pilar Rioja are, in a sense, as much about performing as they are about the dances she performs. The first half of the evening of Spanish music and dance that Miss Rioja presented at the Gramercy Arts Theater (138 East 27th Street), where she will perform through Dec. 21, featured her version of ''La Cachucha,'' made famous by Fanny Elssler, the 19th-century Viennese ballerina. It also included dances of Bolero or ''school dance'' style, characterized by fleet footwork and curving, changing epaulements, that suggest the influence 18th-century Spanish folk and ballet dancing were said to have had on each other. As dance, this was more interesting than the second half of the program, which boasted a new flamenco solo. In this section, Miss Rioja had a chance to draw on a darker, more powerful stage presence. But this was an evening that raised some questions.

title: Navistar to Trim Debt
description: Stockholders of the Navistar International Corporation have approved a recapitalization plan that the truck manufacturing company said would reduce interest expenses by $86 million a year.

title: A.T.&T.-Ford Link
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company Corporation has agreed to acquire all of the Ford Aerospace Satellite Services Corporation for $2.7 million in cash and other considerations, the companies announced today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1986
description: Companies

title: PREFIGHT INFIGHTING IN NEED OF A REFEREE
description: Madison Square Garden's fight card tomorrow night is becoming a seminar in boxing's semi-lunatic convolutions.

title: C.I.A. RECRUITING ON CAMPUSES: A RESURGENT DEBATE
description: After a post-Vietnam decade of relative hospitality for the Central Intelligence Agency on college campuses, the issue of recruiting by the agency among graduating seniors is once again raising protests from students who object to the C.I.A.'s role in world affairs.

title: Federal Holiday Dec. 26
description: President Reagan decided today to designate Friday, Dec. 26, as a Federal holiday, giving Government workers an extended Christmas weekend. He said an executive order would be forthcoming.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the deadline given by Buck Williams to the Nets for signing him to a new contract. It is Jan. 1, 1987.

title: POLICE CAPTURE GUNMAN ON KENTUCKY CAMPUS
description: The police today captured a former University of Kentucky employee who dressed in a ninja warrior costume, sprayed the campus with bullets that wounded two men, and then held the police at bay for more than 10 hours.

title: Highway Bonds Offered by Jersey
description: A $200 million issue of the New Jersey Transportation Trust Fund Authority was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.10 percent in 1988 to 4.80 percent in 1991, 5.80 percent in 1996 and 6 percent in 1997 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: INSIDE
description: Albany's New Tax Plan The Cuomo administration, trying to avoid tax increases for upper-middle-income residents, has revised its plan for changing the tax code.

title: WAVERTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
