description: WHEN the first cordless electric drill was introduced by the Black & Decker Corporation about 25 years ago it was an expensive, heavy tool that had a bulky battery of limited capacity. However, in recent years battery technology has improved to the point where today's cordless tools are more compact, lighter, much more powerful and run longer than the older versions.

title: TWO ESCAPED MURDERERS ARE CAPTURED
description: Two murderers who escaped from the state prison here Tuesday night were captured tonight, hours apart, prison officials said.

title: Europe Is Baffled and Annoyed
description: Americans have once again shown an admirable passion for getting to the bottom of their President's apparent disregard for the rules of government, inspiring in Europe, and particularly in France, renewed respect for American democracy. Yet we Europeans remain deeply troubled by the way that Washington has treated its Western allies during the shadowy Iranian affair.

title: LABOR MAY AGAIN MAKE EARLY PRESIDENTIAL CHOICE
description: A senior committee of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., seeking to strengthen the labor federation's political influence, gave preliminary approval today to a plan to endorse a Presidential candidate before the 1988 primaries, according to an official of the federation.

title: NEGLECT OF CHILDREN IS DENIED
description: A Virginia man whose children were taken into custody by city officials denied yesterday that they had been neglected.

title: JETS CUT JACKSON, BENCH 2 IN BID TO REVERSE SLIDE
description: In the wake of the Jets' three-game losing streak that has jeopardized their successful season, Coach Joe Walton shuffled six starting positions today. He cut one starter from the team and demoted two others.

title: COALITION CITING ZAIRE ABUSES ASKS WHITE HOUSE TO END AID
description: A coalition of civil and human rights groups and Congressional leaders urged the Reagan Administration today to withdraw all foreign and military aid to Zaire and cut ties with its leader, President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has been accused of running a one-party dictatorship.

title: GROUP RENEWS CRITICISM OF TV TREATMENT OF SEX
description: An official of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America said yesterday that a report released by the National Research Council this week about the country's teen-age pregnancy problems supported the group's complaints that network television programs promote sexual activity among teen-agers.

title: IRAN MIDDLEMAN CALLED INITIATOR IN HOSTAGE DEAL
description: Months before the Administration says it began its dealings with Iran, the key Iranian middleman had approached a former American intelligence official with a proposal to trade hostages for money, participants in the talks say.

title: Don't Worry, World
description: Reagan Cabinet members are in Europe this week ostensibly for arms and terrorism conferences. In reality, they are here to reassure our allies that the aftershocks of the Iran arms scandal will not shake the Reagan Administration out of office.

title: 3 COLLEGES ALARMED BY LOSS OF ACCREDITATION
description: The newspaper advertisements tacked on bulletin boards in classroom buildings at Bishop College here show a picture of the interim president, Levi Watkins, and the stark headline: ''Should Bishop College Be Left to Die?''

title: Soviet Stepping Up a Drive For Economic Performance
description: The newspaper Pravda today criticized several Soviet regions for poor economic performance.

title: OLD FLUSHING AIRPORT MAY REOPEN FOR USE BY COPTERS OR BLIMPS
description: The city is seeking to reopen a portion of Flushing Airport in Queens by next summer, most likely for use by helicopters or blimps.

title: FEDERAL PANEL CALLS FOR PAYROLL TAX TO AID DISPLACED WORKERS
description: A special Reagan Administration advisory council has recommended that a new payroll tax be imposed to help dislocated workers find jobs.

title: Mayor and 2 Officials Shot at Iowa Meeting
description: A man walked into a City Council meeting late today and shot the Mayor and two Council members with a pistol, then surrendered, witnesses said. The gunman was not immediately identified.

title: Panel Approves Plan For Coliseum Site
description: A proposal to build offices, apartments, an atrium with shops and a movie-theater complex on the site of the New York Coliseum was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

title: A CAUTIOUS SEARCH FOR A PROSECUTOR
description: The search for a special prosecutor for the Iran arms investigation could last for several more days, perhaps a week or more, according to Government officials and others knowledgeable about the search.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: PATH Station With a Mural

title: REVISION MADE IN CUOMO PLAN ON STATE TAXES
description: The Cuomo administration, faced with mounting criticism of its preliminary proposal for changes in the state tax code, issued a sharply revised plan yesterday that it said would be more equitable to upper-middle-income taxpayers.

title: ARCHIE M. STEVENSON
description: Archie MacNicoll Stevenson, a lawyer and former vice chairman and director of the Chubb Corporation, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: DRUG TESTS LOSING MOST COURT CASES
description: Random drug testing of Government employees appears to be in serious trouble in the courts, legal scholars and lawyers say.

title: BLACK POLICE UNITS IN SOUTH AFRICA ACCUSED OF WIDE RIGHTS ABUSES
description: A black law-enforcement agency has been set up in black townships by the white authorities, and civil rights workers and anti-apartheid workers say it has instituted a harsh regime of beatings and torture.

title: CONTRADICTION IS REPORTED IN SHULTZ STATEMENTS ON IRAN
description: As recently as Oct. 1, after Secretary of State George P. Shultz had evidence of American arms sales to Iran, he said at a luncheon meeting of Persian Gulf foreign ministers in New York that the Reagan Administration had stepped up its campaign to block such sales. He also criticized the Soviet Union for failing to do so.

title: GREENS FOR TINY SPACES
description: ROPES and wreaths of evergreens play supporting roles as trims for staircases, doors, mantels and table tops. These are available at florists and garden centers including: West Side Plant Center, 654 Amsterdam Avenue (92d Street); 212-874-4500.

title: Italian Modern on Second Avenue
description: AN Italian architect, Riccardo Sirignano, center above, and an American businessman, Jeffrey Mechanic, above right, met in Italy. With Anna Maria Properzi, above left, they opened Atmosphere, which sells Italian home furnishings. Mr. Sirignano, who designed the shop, works there.

title: Parcells Plays It Safe at Safety
description: Of the 336 players chosen in the National Football League's 1985 draft, the 326th was Herb Welch, a safety and cornerback from U.C.L.A. The Giants took him because he had speed, quickness, tackling ability and intelligence. Besides, in the end of the 12th and final round, few gems remain.

title: MOTION DENIED NEW MEXICO KILLER
description: The New Mexico Supreme Court today refused to speed up a hearing so that an admitted killer could be sentenced before Gov. Toney Anaya's departure from office. The Governor has commuted every death sentence in the state.

title: Yields Fall On C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were down slightly for the week ended yesterday, while those of money market mutual funds rose.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 15
S.E.C. Accord With Insider
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that a defendant in the insider-trading case involving five young traders and investors had agreed to pay back $150,000 in penalties and profits.

title: HENLEY CREDIT PUT AT $3 BILLION
description: The Henley Group, a diversified company that was formed earlier this year, will increase its bank credit line to $3 billion next week, according to Wall Street sources, who predict that this is a prelude to to a multibillion-dollar acquisition attempt.

title: Art Laws Don't Protect Films From Alteration; On Being Without Price
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLEMENT IN AIDS DISPUTE CALLED 'VICTORY' BY SUPPORTERS
description: A $190,000 settlement that reinstated an employee who has AIDS and paid his medical bills is ''a tremendous victory'' for others victims of the disease, civil rights advocates say.

title: Motorists Can't Pay for Roads and Mass Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORIC WINDOWS: REPLACE OR RESTORE?
description: When a building is renovated, should historic windows be replaced or restored? If the building is a historic landmark, local, state and Federal preservation standards may dictate that windows be restored. But if the building's historic qualities are less clearly defined, the decision may depend on energy efficiency and cost.

title: CONCERT: THE PHILHARMONIC AND HORNE IN HARLEM
description: AT a time when so much classical music is accessible instantly - sometimes almost meaninglessly - through the electronic media, it is good that the New York Philharmonic recognizes the importance of taking its musicians to play in person for audiences who don't typically hear them at Lincoln Center. In Harlem, as throughout the city, anyone can turn on the radio at the right times and hear Zubin Mehta and his players, but there is a more valuable accessibility in the orchestra's annual visits to the Abyssinian Baptist Church, where they returned Tuesday evening for an enthusiastically received concert.

title: MORRIS ENDS HIS TIGER TALKS
description: Jack Morris, who declared himself a free agent Oct. 28, declared himself freer today. Acting to shake up what the players' union charges is an owners' conspiracy, Richard Moss, Morris's lawyer, said the pitcher would no longer negotiate with the Detroit Tigers but instead would pursue negotiations with four other clubs - the Yankees, Minnesota, California and Philadelphia.

title: Joint Chiefs of Staff Shifting Gears
description: Amid the thud of hammers and the shriek of circular saws, the offices of the staff serving the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the Pentagon are being reconstructed, as is the staff itself.

title: Play on Br'er Rabbit Banned in Savannah
description: School officials canceled performances of a play about ''Br'er Rabbit,'' a character in the Uncle Remus tales of Joel Chandler Harris, who once edited a local newspaper.

title: New York's Invisible Man
description: Five weeks ago John Bell, a 44-year-old business executive from Marion, Ind., finished first in the masters division of the New York City Marathon. Today he's accused of having cheated in both that race and the 1985 edition, where he finished sixth in the masters division, for runners 40 and over.

title: Wilkins Outsoars Jordan by 57-41
description: Dominique Wilkins matched his career high with 57 points tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 123-95 victory over the Chicago Bulls. Wilkins's performance offset the 41-point effort of Chicago's Michael Jordan, who scored more than 40 points for the eighth consecutive game although he was scoreless for almost the entire first quarter.

title: UNCERTAINTIES MARK OPEC MEETING
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet here beginning Thursday in what is expected to be a divisive attempt to lift crude oil prices to $18 a barrel.

title: ST. JOHN'S, SETON HALL IN EARLY MEETING
description: For many of the stronger college basketball programs, December is a time for experimentation and for building momentum toward the conference schedule.

title: Ex-Mob Leader Gets 6 Years for Extortion
description: A once powerful but now ailing leader of the Lucchese crime family, who pleaded guilty to running an extortion ring at Kennedy International Airport, threw himself on the mercy of the court yesterday but was sentenced to six years in prison and fined $25,000.

title: GOVERNORS' JERSEY VISIT
description: In politics, one must seize one's moments in the sun.

title: Jewel Food Stores To Grey Advertising
description: Grey Advertising, Chicago, has been named agency by Jewel Food Stores, a prominent regional supermarket chain that is owned by American Stores.

title: FOR PEOPLE WHO LIVE IN CARNEGIE HALL, 3 DUSTY YEARS END
description: NEXT Monday when Carnegie Hall reopens, restored to an earlier glory, the landmark building's newly plastered, freshly painted cream-colored walls can be expected to resound with cheers and bravos. But there will be other cheers as well: cheers of relief from, no pun intended, those unsung heroes and heroines, the occupants of the hall's upstairs studios who have, for over three years, lived and worked through a major restoration. Despite the trials, tribulations, dust, debris and noise, it is unlikely that many inhabitants of the 30 studios (out of a total of 135) used for both living and work space ever seriously considered the possibility of moving anywhere else.

title: Top-Level Promotions At William, Douglas
description: Irwin C. Gerson, the 56-year-old president of William, Douglas, McAdams, the country's largest independent health care ad agency, has stepped up to chairman but remains chief executive.

title: PLIGHT OF INDIANS ON RESERVATIONS IS WORSENING, INTERIOR DEPT. SAYS
description: Economic conditions on American Indian reservations are bad and worsening with no immediate help in sight, the Interior Department said today.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
KINNOCK RETURNS HOME TO HAILS AND TAUNTS
description: Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party leader whose campaign to be the next Prime Minister is pinned to a pledge of nuclear disarmament, returned this week from a crucial visit to the United States to find supporters hailing him as a visionary and critics denouncing him as a Willy Loman back from peddling unsalable notions on the New England circuit.

title: CHURCHYARD AIR RIGHTS MIGHT BE WINDFALL
description: Landmark churches can sell the air rights over their adjacent cemeteries to developers because of an unintentional loophole in regulations, according to the chief legal adviser to the New York City Planning Commission.

title: CONFESSIONS OF MENTALLY ILL UPHELD BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that confessions by mentally ill defendants may be used against them even if they are not the product of ''free will.''

title: Art Laws Don't Protect Films From Alteration
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT IN 2 SLAYINGS GIVES UP
description: A 19-year-old suspect sought for nearly three months in the fatal shooting of two owners of a Blimpie's restaurant in Union Square surrendered early today after being ferreted out by a police robot in his mother's Harlem apartment.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL ST. JOHN'S VS. SETON HALL, at Alumni Hall, Jamaica, Queens, 7:30 P.M. (TV -ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 7 P.M., WNEW 1130, 6:55 P.M., WSOU-FM 89.5, 6:30 P.M.) OKLAHOMA VS.

title: HERS
description: APHRA BEHN was the first Englishwoman to become a professional writer. By 1687, she had had 17 plays staged in as many years - in a London that afforded its playwrights only two theaters. She wrote 13 novels and published several collections of poems and translations. Her novel ''Oroonoko'' was one of the first popular portrayals of the horrors of slavery.

title: Young & Rubicam Sets A New Rate Structure
description: After 13 months of negotiations with newspapers coast to coast, Young & Rubicam, the country's largest agency, announced yesterday that it had arranged for new national advertising rate structures for its package-goods clients that will bring them very close to the much lower retail rates.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: America's Cup Trials Heat Up: In the trials to select a defender for the America's Cup off Fremantle, Australia, Kevin Parry's Kookaburra II defeated Alan Bond's Australia IV by 5 minutes 11 seconds yesterday. Syd Fischer's Steak 'n Kidney came close to beating Parry's first-string boat, Kookaburra III, which held on to win by 26 seconds. Winds were moderate, at 14 knots for the start, then dropped to 10 knots, and were 18 knots for the finish. TENNIS Swedes Lose in Doubles: Hans Gildermeister of Chile and Andres Gomez of Ecuador, the world's top-ranked team, beat the defending champions, Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 7-6, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, on the opening day of the masters doubles championships in London. The only American representatives in the competition, Gary Donnelly and Mike DePalmer, won their first match in the $255,000 event. Theyoutlasted Sergio Casal and Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 3-6, 6-1, 3-6, 7-6, 6-4. (AP)

title: Correct Contract in Theory May Be Wrong in Practice
description: It is not always easy to say what the ''right'' contract is on a particular deal: the right theoretical contract may not be the right practical contract.

title: A REMBRANDT PORTRAIT SELLS FOR $10.3 MILLION IN LONDON
description: Rembrandt's ''Portrait of a Young Girl Wearing a Gold-Trimmed Cloak'' from 1632, was auctioned yesterday for a record price at Sotheby's in London.

title: JACOBS SEEKING HELP IN BID TO BUY BORG
description: The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, apparently frustrated by the lack of attention given his offer by the Borg-Warner Corporation, said today that he was seeking outside support to help finance his $3.4 billion bid for Borg-Warner.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $1.8 million after-tax charge for anticipated costs to be incurred in the shutdown of a facility. c-After a gain of $500,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and after a loss of $33 million from discontinued operations.

title: Bonn Will Investigate A Sale to South Africa
description: The West German Parliament voted today to set up a commission to investigate a suspected illegal sale of submarine plans to South Africa. Opposition members say that Chancellor Helmut Kohl was involved.

title: Prison Inmate Guilty Of Heroin Charges
description: A convicted drug dealer was found guilty yesterday of operating a major heroin ring from inside a Federal prison.

title: FRIEDMAN, SHAFRAN AND LAZAR BARRED FROM PRACTICE OF LAW
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic chairman who was found guilty last month of bribery and other charges in the New York City corruption scandal, was suspended from the practice of law yesterday by a state court in Manhattan.

title: HIGH-LEVEL EFFORTS TO REPLACE REGAN ARE REPORTED
description: Michael K. Deaver and Stuart Spencer, two of President Reagan's closest political advisers, are pressing for the early removal of Donald T. Regan as White House chief of staff with the active support of Nancy Reagan, according to people with longstanding ties to the Reagan family.

title: WIESEL'S SPEECH AT NOBEL CEREMONY
description: Following is the prepared text of the acceptance speech by Elie Wiesel, the winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, at a ceremony in Oslo yesterday, as made available by an aide:

title: Women's College in Georgia To Be Shut After 137 Years
description: Tift College, one of the nation's oldest colleges for women, is closing at the end of the school year after 137 years.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Topics: Supportive Voices; Not Just Academic
description: Milan Nikolic faces prison in Yugoslavia for an academic paper he wrote in the United States.

title: HONDURAN ENVOY TELLS OF BOMBING OF NICARAGUANS
description: The Honduran Ambassador here said today that planes used against Nicaraguan Army units on Sunday were A-37 Dragonflies of the Honduran Air Force. But he expressed uncertainty about whether the planes had crossed into Nicaragua.

title: GARLANDS AND WREATHS
description: LARGE trees or profuse decorations may overwhelm some apartments. And there are small rooms - foyers and hallways -where a scaled-down arrangement may be appropriate.

title: GOTTI WITNESS RECEIVED IMMUNITY IN FOUR SLAYINGS
description: A key Government witness in the racketeering trial of the reputed mob boss John Gotti and six co-defendants said yesterday that he thought he made ''a fantastic deal'' in agreeing to testify in exchange for immunity from prosecution for four homicides he committed.

title: C.I.A. AIDES MADE 'SERIOUS ERRORS,' LEGISLATOR SAYS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, gave five and a half hours of secret testimony today on the Iran arms operation, and afterward a key Republican legislator said it appeared ''serious errors of judgment'' had been committed by senior C.I.A. officials.

title: WIESEL, ACCEPTING THE NOBEL, ASKS THE LIVING TO REMEMBER
description: Elie Wiesel dared not speak for the dead today as he accepted the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: On the Georges Bank, a Game of Cat and Mouse
description: Two years after the International Court of Justice divided the Georges Bank between the United States and Canada, tensions are rising over what is considered one of the world's richest fishing grounds.

title: Nuclear Test Set for Friday
description: An underground nuclear test has been scheduled for Friday at the Department of Energy's Nevada Test Site, the agency said today. The test at 8 A.M. will be conducted 2,100 feet below Pahute Mesa, about 100 miles north of here. The announcement said it would be the 13th such test at the site announced this year, and the 659th since testing began there in 1959.

title: Quaker Sets Sale of 3 Units
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it had agreed to sell the three businesses of its specialty retailing group to three separate buyers for between $215 million and $220 million. Quaker said its Jos. A. Banks

title: Bridge: World Championships Offer Chance for East-West Bonds
description: The 1986 world championships in Miami Beach were not only a test of skill that engaged almost all the world's best players. They were also an opportunity for East to meet West and demonstrate, on a personal level, friendship and good will.

title: HONDURANS IN 3-WAY CROSSFIRE
description: Disputing official accounts, Honduran refugees in this border hamlet say Nicaraguan rebel units, as well as Honduran forces, took part in the heavy fighting against Nicaraguan troops in recent days.

title: Marcos Aide Is Linked To Arms Sales to Iran
description: The former Chief of Staff of the Philippines armed forces, Gen. Fabian Ver, took part in a plan to keep Secretary of State George P. Shultz from learning that American weapons were being sent to Iran, a report today said.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Concerts in Memory of John Haley (Zoot) Sims. From tonight through Sunday, memories of the late saxophonist Zoot Sims will draw a variety of musicians together in a series of jazz concerts at the New School and its new Jazz and Contemporary Music Program, for which a scholarship has been established in Mr. Sims' name. Tonight at 6, ''Jazz at Six,'' Paul Weinstein's six-year-old series, will offer a string trio - Jack Wilkins and Gene Bertoncini, guitars, and Michael Moore, bass - with the alto saxophonist Arnie Lawrence, who is director of instruction of the New School Jazz Program (New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street; $7 admission; 741-8950). Tomorrow at 3, the students and faculty of the New School Jazz Program - including Chico Hamilton, Larry Willis, Mino Cinelu and Mr. Lawrence - will honor Mr. Sims at their first public concert (Parsons School of Design Auditorium, 66 Fifth Avenue near 12th Street; free; 741-8950). On Sunday afternoon at 3, the New School Jazz Program's regular weekly open jam session will be presented by Art D'Lugoff at the Village Gate (Bleecker and Thompson Streets; no cover charge; 475-5120). And on Sunday evening at 7, a ''Party for Zoot'' with an all-star lineup of musicians who were friends of Mr. Sims will play to raise funds for the Sims scholarship at the New School (New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street; $50 admission; 741-8950).

title: Musica Antiqua Koln
description: The Baroque chamber ensemble Musica Antiqua Koln will play works by Telemann, Auber, Handel and Prince Johann Ernst of Saxe-Weimar on Sunday as part of the ''Original Instruments'' series at Alice Tully Hall.

title: An Unusual Phone Pledge
description: The Putnam Management Company, the big money management firm that was temporarily forced out of its offices by an electrical explosion and fire Tuesday night, has formed an unusual partnership to keep in touch with clients.

title: YANKEES ACQUIRE HUDSON
description: The Yankees sent Mike Easler to the Philadelphia Phillies for Charles Hudson today in a trade, a source familiar with the deal said, that only George Steinbrenner among Yankee officials wanted.

title: Suzanne Vega
description: The songwriter Suzanne Vega will perform tonight through Sunday at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. today and tomorrow, 8 and 11 P.M. Sunday; tickets are $11.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Frank Morgan, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Thirty-one years ago, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan recorded his first album as a leader. Between then and now, his problems have included heroin addiction and prison sentences. But now he is finally performing in New York. Mr. Morgan is steeped in be-bop - he had known Charlie Parker since his childhood - but while he can dodge and weave around a song's harmonies, he also spins warm, long-lined melodies. He is performing through Sunday with the redoubtable trio of Cedar Walton on piano, Buster Williams on bass and Billy Higgins on drums. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum. Reservations are recommended.

title: Arizona Prison Riot Quelled
description: More than 100 prisoners set fires and smashed windows in a four-hour riot touched off by an inmate's refusal to give up an orange he had in his cell contrary to the rules, the authorities said today.

title: HOW NEW RULES WILL WORK
description: A reporter, photographer, cameraman or other journalist witnessing violent protest without police or other official permission is required to go ''to a place where that unrest, gathering or action is out of his sight.''

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 75 money market mutual funds rose $976.9 million, to $234.87 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Salomon Picks 20 Directors
description: Salomon Brothers Inc., Wall Street's largest investment bank, said yesterday that it had appointed 20 new managing directors, the largest such group ever named by the firm.

title: Is There a Fuel Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: WITHERSPOON PLANS TO DEFEND HIS TITLE
description: Tim Witherspoon, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, made it to the weigh-in early yesterday for his title defense against James (Bonecrusher) Smith tonight at Madison Square Garden. But whether Witherspoon, a 29-year-old fighter from Philadelphia, would make it into the ring against Smith was a question that remained unanswered until last night.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net loss

title: A Christmas Party In Early 1900's Style
description: An early 20th-century Christmas party will be held tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M at the Clermont State Historic Site in Germantown, N.Y., in Columbia County, as a reminder of the way the Livingston family, which lived in the area beginning in the 1700's, celebrated the holidays.

title: MACMILLAN CHAIRMAN WILL RETIRE
description: Jeremiah Kaplan, who founded the Free Press book publishing company when he was 19 years old and then sold it to Macmillan, will retire Jan. 1 as president and chairman of the Macmillan Publishing Company. Macmillan officials say that the 60-year-old Mr. Kaplan's retirement is unrelated to the publishing company's recent sharp cutback of its adult hard-cover publishing program.

title: Other Christmas Offerings Around Town
description: Today Actors Outlet, 120 West 28th Street. ''The Dangerous Christmas of Red

title: SCREEN: 'GOLDEN CHILD'
description: AFTER his triumphant ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' Eddie Murphy could have done anything. Why, then, did he choose to head for the mysterious Orient to make a film as rich in mumbo jumbo as ''The Golden Child''? It's true that the outsider's role has always suited Mr. Murphy well, but this time he takes it to an unreasonable extreme, one that compromises both his credibility and his street-smart humor. In the service of a plot only Indiana Jones could take seriously, he winds up venturing to Katmandu, and to a twilight realm somewhere between situation comedy and rip-snorting juvenilia. He should have stayed much closer to home.

title: Uillean Pipes
description: Jerry O'Sullivan will play Irish music for uillean pipes tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275), with the guitarist Steve Johnson. Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5. Information: 475-7092.

title: ISLANDERS SURGE ON 7 GOALS IN ROW
description: The Islanders, who had only one victory to show in their previous six games, scored seven unanswered goals tonight on the way to an 8-4 triumph over the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: REAGAN AIDES, CONCERN RISING, SEEK GUIDANCE
description: Aides to President Reagan are said to have concluded, for the first time in his tenure, that they are unable to quell a major crisis and have begun to ask former White House officials for advice.

title: Lux-Burstein Show
description: Lillian Lux-Burstein, an actress and singer in Yiddish theater, will give a one-woman show of songs and reminiscences Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Beyond the Facts
description: An editorial last week criticized the State Department for going beyond the law in assisting contra rebels in Nicaragua. Some of the criticism went beyond the known facts.

title: KEY RATES
PREMIER LOSES FOREIGN AFFAIRS JOBS
description: The Government of Cambodia, struggling to cope with a widening guerrilla war and severe economic problems, has dismissed its Ministers of Defense and Planning, according to a radio announcement in Phnom Penh.

title: SYNTRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and for the year includes a tax credit of $51,000.

title: 8 CHARGED IN CREATION OF PHANTOM EMPLOYEES
description: For a full year no one noticed that Stanley Kubersky, a part-time Brooklyn College student and former hospital clerk, did not show up for work at his data-processing job with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Obtained Kevin McReynolds, outfielder; Gene Walter, relief pitcher, and Adam Ging, outfielder, in a trade with the San Diego Padres for Stanley Jefferson, Shawn Abner and Kevin Mitchell, outfielders, and Kevin Armstrong and Kevin Brown, pitchers.

title: FILM: HENLEY'S 'CRIMES OF THE HEART'
description: ''CRIMES OF THE HEART,'' Beth Henley's Pulitzer

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: The company said the latest 9-month figures do not reflect the results of a start-up venture which was added to the company's core business earlier this year.

title:
POLAND, FIVE YEARS AFTER MARTIAL LAW;
A 'Second' Society Flourishes
description: The idea of an alternative society has proved very attractive to Poles in the five years since martial law was imposed, and there is hardly an adult in Poland unaware of the existence of the underground. Many of those involved have said their participation in this parallel society has given them a feeling of freedom unavailable to citizens of most Communist countries.

title: A GOOD YEAR FOR CUT-YOUR-OWN CHRISTMAS TREES
description: The rains earlier this year have resulted in what the region's growers are calling an excellent stand of Christmas trees. They are now available to venturesome New Yorkers willing to travel to farms in nearby rural areas to cut their own trees for the holiday season.

title: U.S. HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dallas Cartier Store Robbed
description: An impeccably dressed man robbed a Cartier jewelry store of 80 percent of its merchandise Wednesday, ''a nasty loss,'' the store owner said. The owner, Nirmal Vaswani, said the man accosted him near the store in the Galleria mall Wednesday morning, and had him open the store and put the contents of the safe in two Cartier suitcases. He said a 120-carat Burmese ruby necklace valued at $200,000 was among the jewelry taken.

title: Depositions Yield J. D. Salinger Details
description: Fan mail sent to J. D. Salinger is never forwarded, at the author's request. And perhaps 500 letters that Mr. Salinger wrote to his agent, Dorothy Olding, at Harold Ober Associates from the 1940's through the 1960's -some of which contained his philosophy, his views of World War II and other observations - were destroyed in about 1970 while Ober was preparing to deposit its papers at Princeton University.

title: A GOVERNMENT WITNESS PRAISES GOTTI
description: Sounding at times more like a witness for the defense than the prosecution, a key Government witness said yesterday under cross-examination that he had recently described John Gotti as the ''finest man'' he had ever known. Mr. Gotti is accused as the head of a crime family.

title: Boesky's Old Post Filled by Northview
description: The Northview Corporation, a California-based hotel chain formerly controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, said yesterday that it had named Robert M. Loeffler, a Los Angeles lawyer, to the posts of chairman, president and chief executive.

title: LDBRINKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Iowa State Penalized
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has stripped Iowa State of four football scholarships and placed the program on probation for two years for violations committed under its former coach, Jim Criner, the university has announced. In addition, the N.C.A.A. banned Iowa State from television appearances and bowl games in 1987, but suspended those penalties because of ''actions taken by the university,'' according to the school's statement.

title: Diner's Journal
description: NEGOTIATING the Pamplona-like shopping herds in midtown this time of year can build a substantial appetite, not to mention a lightweight wallet. Here is a selective guide to restaurants offering reasonably priced lunches within a short walk of Fifth Avenue's major shopping district.

title: Canadiens Rout Rangers
description: Claude Lemieux scored 79 seconds into the game and John Kordic followed with his first National Hockey League goal at 2 minutes 45 seconds tonight to spark the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 victory over the Rangers.

title: EXXON AGREES TO SELL RELIANCE
description: The Exxon Corporation, in a move to close the book on one of its most controversial chapters, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Reliance Electric Company for $1.35 billion to an investment group made up of the unit's management, Citicorp Capital Investors and Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: Jury Selection Starts Today in Goetz Case
description: Jury selection begins today in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz, accused of the attempted murder of four youths he said were about to rob him on IRT train in December 1984.

title: VITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $63,000 and $92,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: TEXSTYRENE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $293,000 for the quarter and $1,230,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago share earnings were unavailable because the company went public in February. The company said it was changing its fiscal year to Dec. 31 from Jan. 31, which will make its fourth quarter a two-month period.

title: Topics: Money Managers; Why Not Japan?
description: A falling out between France and the Netherlands is rattling the trans-Atlantic club that controls the top jobs at the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The issue is whose man shall run the fund when Jacques de Larosiere leaves at the end of the year.

title: Doctor Charged in 13 Deaths
description: A Pakistani-born American heart doctor was arrested today on charges of killing 13 people, including a slow waiter, ''for the fun of it,'' the police said.

title: 'New Sounds' Series
description: The Daniel Lentz Ensemble, the flutist Steve Gorn, the tabla player Ray Speigel and the pianist Elodie Lauten will play original compositions at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday afternoon at 2, as part of the ''New Sounds'' series, under the direction of John Schaefer. Tickets are $10; information: 362-8719. The concert will be broadcast live on WNYC-FM.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cutco Industries, Jericho, L.I., said its investment banker, Montgomery Scott Inc., had found the proposed $5-a-share leveraged buyout offer by its chairman, Marvin W. Marcus, and its president, Don Von Liebermann, to be too low.

title: What Houston Teaches About New York Rents
description: To the Editor:

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 PARTIES DOUBTFUL ABOUT OPENING PRIMARIES
description: Republican and Democratic Party leaders from around the country said today that it was doubtful they would allow independent voters to take part in party primary elections despite a Supreme Court ruling Tuesday allowing them to do so. But they may face new court challenges if they do not, and it was unclear how they would respond.

title: JAMES GARNER IN 'PROMISE,' FILM ON SCHIZOPHRENIA
description: A TELEVISION movie has finally done it - tackled a disease for which there is no cure, no comforting bromides, and, therefore, no opportunity for easy uplift. ''Promise,'' on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M., is about schizophrenia, generally considered the worst mental health problem facing the nation.

title: Oratorios and 'Messiah' Sing-Alongs
description: Today Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West 57th Street. Christmas portion of Handel's ''Messiah''; with chamber ensemble; Paul Liljestrand, organist and choirmaster. At 7:30 P.M. Information: 975-0170, extension 32. Tomorrow Cathedral of St. John the Divine (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Schutz's ''Christmas Story''; with Grande Bande of New York, Court Dance Company of New York, Ensemble for Early Music's Boyquire and soloists; Fred Renz, director. At 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $15. Information: 662-2133.

title: Pre-1980 Textbooks Must Be Reapproved
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones has ruled that all textbooks published before 1980 that appear on the approved reading list of the sex education curriculum in New York City schools must be resubmitted for approval, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: WILSON FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a gain of $341,000 from tax credits. c-Net loss and includes a pre-tax charge of $21.4 million for restructuring operations.

title: OIL TRADER HELPED INQUIRY INTO IRAN MONEY DIVERSIONS
description: An oil trader who was a marginal participant in the Iranian arms deal appears to have played a significant role in helping investigators to unravel the financial network behind the transactions.

title: Grenfell Seeks C.J. Lawrence
description: Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., the London-based investment bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., the Wall Street brokerage house, for $70 million.

title: Smart Stars
description: Brian Bosworth, the linebacker who has helped Oklahoma to a 10-1 record, and John Shaffer, the quarterback of Penn State's 11-0 team, have been named to the Academic All-America team chosen by the nation's sports information directors.

title: BRITISH TELECOM PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represents American Depository Receipts (ADR). Each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. The 1986 results are in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.45 to the pound, that prevailed on Sept. 30, 1986. The 1985 results are in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.41 to the pound, that prevailed on Sept. 30, 1985.

title: Former Actress Killed; Police Arrest Her Son
description: Susan Cabot-Roman, a former actress, was beaten to death and her 22-year-old son was arrested in connection with the slaying, the police said today.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The share earnings do not reflect the company's 4-for-3 stock split payable Dec. 26, but share earnings reflecting the split will be 20 cents for the latest quarter and 18 cents for the year-ago period. The shares outstanding, after the split, will be 36,727,000 for the latest quarter and 36,313,000 for the year- earlier quarter.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,080,000 for the quarter and $3,412,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,095,000. The results for 1986 include a pre- tax charge of $52,912,000 related to the writedown of certain assets recorded in the second quarter.

title: Rumanian Court Sentences Four in Fire at a Synagogue
description: A court found four people guilty of setting a fire at a synagogue, sentenced three of them to prison terms and sent the fourth to a reformatory, an official of the Jewish community of Bucharest said today.

title: VIENNA RE-CREATES A LIVELY CAFE OF 1856
description: In the beginning, before Elaine's, Cafe Luxembourg and the Odeon, there was Cafe Central, ''a village in the center of the metropolis, steaming with gossip, curiosity and slander,'' in the words of Alfred Polgar, a Viennese writer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Manager Dick Howser of the Kansas City Royals was released from Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif., where he underwent additional treatment for a cancerous brain tumor last week. . . . Odis McKinney, who played safety for the Raiders for six years before being cut before this season, has been rehired as a free agent by Los Angeles, a day after the Raiders placed their all-pro cornerback, Lester Hayes, on injured reserve with a broken bone in his foot. McKinney also played for the Giants.

title: Note and Bond Prices Off a Bit
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell modestly yesterday, with some traders attributing the decline to a modest rise in oil prices.

title: Litvack Takes New Post
description: Sanford M. Litvack, the managing partner of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine who stunned his partners in October when he announced that he was planning to leave the firm, has chosen a new firm: Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. Mr. Litvack, 50 years old, a former head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said he would join Dewey, Ballantine's litigation department next month. Mr. Litvack had said he was leaving Donovan Leisure because he was exhausted by the burden of running the firm.

title: Delta and Western
description: The Transportation Department gave final approval to Delta Air Lines' $860 million acquisition of Western Airlines, concluding that the merger poses no competitive problems. The department had given tentative approval on Oct. 23 to the merger, which creates the country's fourth-largest airline, behind the Texas Air group of carriers, United and American.

title: Time to Consider a Federal Capital Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE URGES PEACE ON ALL TERRORISTS
description: Pope John Paul II issued a peace message for 1987 today in which he begged terrorists to give up violence and denounced development programs that he said deny poor nations their rightful freedoms.

title: NOT WEAKENED, U.S. TELLS MOSCOW
description: The American arms negotiator in Geneva has cautioned the Russians not to try to take advantage of the Iran furor in the course of the arms control talks, a senior Administration official said today.

title: INFANTS LINGER IN HOSPITALS, AWAITING FOSTER HOMES
description: More and more healthy babies waiting for foster homes are being kept for months in New York City hospitals despite calls from thousands of families offering homes.

title: STATE AND KEY TRANSIT UNION AGREE TO REDUCE STRIKE THREAT
description: Governor Cuomo announced an agreement yesterday to overhaul labor relations on the city's subways and buses, which for decades have been marked by illegal strikes and strife.

title: Market Place; Yield, Safety Lure Investors
description: ''THE retail brokerage customer is buying income and safety, and a good track record,'' said John Till, manager of a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., office for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''At the present time, one thing customers want to avoid is surprise.''

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
East German, 22, Flees Across the Berlin Wall
description: A 22-year-old East German man, apparently using a new escape route, fled over the Berlin Wall to West Berlin early today unnoticed by border guards, the West Berlin police said.

title: STRIKE NEARS END AT HEALTH GROUP
description: A tentative accord in a seven-week strike was reached today between the Kaiser Permanente Medical Care Program and Local 250 of the Service Employees International Union.

title: SOUTHBROOK INTERNATIONAL TELEVISION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The U.S. figures have been translated from pounds sterling at a rate of $1.42 a pound.

title: Despite a Court Order, New Law Takes Effect
description: A State Supreme Court justice issued a temporary restraining order yesterday preventing the city from enforcing a new law that affects some commercial property owners. But the order, issued by Justice Arthur W. Lonschein in Queens, was automatically stayed when the city appealed, so the law is now in effect.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. PHILADELPHIA 76ERS, at Byrne Medowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on Nov. 6, portraying the electorate for the House of Representatives as reflected in a New York Times/CBS News Poll, misstated percentages for some voter categories. The correct figures are: White Protestants, 47; union household, 28; moderate Democrats, 19; conservative Democrats, 8; white Democrats, 30; black Democrats, 5; white men, 43; black men, 4; men aged 60 and older, 14; married men, 36; unmarried men, 12; whites in the East, 23; whites in the Midwest, 33; whites in the South, 10; blacks in the South, 1; whites in the West, 21; blacks in the West, 1; men in the East, 13; men in the Midwest, 18. Corrected copies of the chart are available by mail from the News Surveys Department, Room 666, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Benson Shuns the Spotlight
description: Brad Benson is embarrassed by it all.

title: FROM HAITI, THE RHYTHM OF AYIZAN
description: FOR seven weekends and four days before Easter, Haiti is awash in festivities known as ''rara'' - a community celebration that, like Carnival, includes dancing in the streets. Ayizan, a New York-based Haitian band that will perform tomorrow at Jazztrack, has put the sounds of rara celebrations into its own dance music.

title: Experts Favor Sensible Diet As the Way to Curb Diabetes
description: Controlling body weight remains the best way to manage most diabetes, and the right way to do that is with a sensible diet that may include a little sugar, according to a panel of experts.

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Inhibitor Identified A type of human white blood cell inhibits duplication of the AIDS virus in a test tube, suggesting a new treatment tack, scientists said.

title: SLAIN WOMAN FOUND IN POOL OF CONNECTICUT HOME
description: The body of a 63-year-old woman was found today floating in the swimming pool of her elegant country home here in what the police believe was a robbery and murder.

title: Woolridge Hurt
description: The Nets, who have been forced to play without the injured Darryl Dawkins, Otis Birdsong and Albert King, suffered another casualty in Wednesday night's 108-98 loss to the Celtics in Boston, their fifth straight defeat and 13th in 14 games.

title: BLOOD CELL SAID TO INHIBIT AIDS VIRUS IN TEST TUBE
description: Scientists in San Francisco have found that a type of human white blood cell inhibits duplication of the AIDS virus in a test tube, suggesting a possible new approach to treatment of the fatal disorder.

title: ESCAPED KILLER IS FOUND ASLEEP IN A PARKED CAR
description: Three convicts who escaped from the state prison here Tuesday evening were back in their prison cells today, after a 30-hour manhunt through the woods, ponds and roads of several Westchester communities.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR several years, certain French restaurants have tried to get a leg up on the competition by hiring famous consulting chefs who, aside from giving culinary advice, also stir the stockpot of publicity. Not to be outdone, Indian establishments have joined the act - the two Nirvana restaurants in Manhattan solicited the help of the teacher and cookbook author Julie Sahni, and now Dawat, a stylish new East Side establishment, is touting its affiliation with Madhur Jaffrey, the actress and author of three books on Indian cooking who is supervising the kitchen.

title: Away on a Steam Grate
description: Washington may have no more or no fewer homeless people than any other major American city. But here their plight somehow seems especially acute as they huddle for warmth on passageways in the shadow of the nation's great monuments and public buildings.

title: SPELLING, AARON, PRODUCIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $750,000 for expenses related to the company's reorganization in August. The year-earlier results are pro forma. The company went public Aug. 11, 1986.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: America's Cup

title: Auctions
description: THE Duchess of Windsor's collection of magnificent jewelry will be auctioned in Geneva in April, John L. Marion, Sotheby's chairman in the United States, announced yesterday. He said it was ''coincidental'' that the announcement was made 50 years to the day after the King of England abdicated his throne to make ''the woman I love'' his wife. The Duke of Windsor and Wallis Warfield Simpson, the socialite from Baltimore who became the Duchess of Windsor, were married later, on June 3, 1937.

title: HOPE DIMS ON HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: Two Arab-Americans seeking the release of hostages in Lebanon said their hopes had dimmed of returning home with at least one freed captive.

title: ISRAELIS USE TEAR GAS TO ROUT GAZA PROTESTERS
description: Israeli soldiers fired into the air and used tear gas today to rout dozens of stone-throwing Arab protesters chanting nationalist slogans at a United Nations junior high school here, the headmistress said.

title: Soviet Research Site Intact
description: A Soviet Antarctic research station has drifted into the Wendell Sea on an iceberg but remains intact, the official press agency Tass said today. The agency said the Druzhnaya-1 station had failed to show up on satellite photographs after the breaking up of the Filchner ice shelf, where it was situated. But a helicopter crew later spotted the station and found it undamaged on a large section of the ice shelf.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ADT Inc., a maker of electronic life and property protection systems, named as a director Philip E. Beekman, chairman and chief operating officer of Hook-SuperX, a new drug chain that recently bought most of Kroger Co.'s drugstore operations.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS OF BUSINESSES AID THE NEEDY
description: A law firm, a commodities company and several foundations were among contributors yesterday to the 75th annual appeal to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Bayonets And Sharp Arguments
description: Keep in mind, the Army says, that this is not ''just'' a bayonet.

title: Newhouse Buys Trenton Times
description: The Allbritton Communications Company and its subsidiary, Trenton Times Newspapers, have sold The Times to the Newhouse newspaper group, company officials said.

title: SCREEN: 'TYPHOON CLUB'
description: ''TYPHOON CLUB,'' the Japanese film opening today at the Public Theater, is about the lives of a half-dozen junior high school students who are trembling on the brink of their high school entrance exams.

title: SUN ELECTRIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $317,000 for the quarter and $557,000 for the year. The fourth quarter also includes a $608,000 gain recognized by the company resulting from the renegotiation of certain financing lease agreements. c-Net loss and includes gains on sale of net assets of $1,321,000 for the quarter and $2,290,000 for the year, a charge of $8,870,000 resulting from an out-of-court settlement on certain litigation for the quarter and year, and an extraordinary tax credit of $173,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Boxers to Be Tested
description: All foreign professional boxers who fight in Britain will be screened for AIDS, the British Boxing Board of Control said yesterday. Because boxing is a close-contact sport in which blood frequently is spilled, the board said it wanted to make boxers aware of the dangers of the disease, but also allay fears that the sport could become a breeding ground for it.

title: VETERAN COMMANDER NAMED CITY'S NEW CHIEF OF DETECTIVES
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday named his Chief of Patrol, Robert Colangelo, a 56-year-old veteran commander with an anti-corruption background, to be Chief of Detectives.

title: CHINA NEARING OIL GOAL
description: China's oil industry is expected to surpass its production quotas of 130 million tons of crude oil and 13 billion cubic meters of natural gas this year, the official China Daily said today.

title: RYMER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After tax credits of $1,586,000 for the quarter and $3,745,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,045,000 for the quarter and $4,248,000 for the year.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I CAN'T believe it,'' Leonard Bernstein said. ''It's a bloody miracle.''

title: B. Dalton Chief to Leave
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation said today that Sherman Swenson would leave as chairman and chief executive of B. Dalton, the nation's second-largest bookstore chain, when the sale of the subsidiary is completed later this month. Last month, Dayton-Hudson agreed to sell Dalton to Barnes & Noble, the nation's leading discounter, for a price estimated at $275 million to $300 million. It said that Leonard Riggio, the owner of Barnes & Noble, would also run B. Dalton.

title: ISRAEL IS SAID TO SEEK NICARAGUAN DIPLOMATIC TIES
description: Israel has been trying since 1982 to restore diplomatic relations with Nicaragua rather than supply arms or money to anti-Government rebels, Israeli officials say.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IT was probably inevitable that Norman Mailer, whose creative juices have spilled over from novels to journalism to screenwriting and directing, would eventually try his hand at directing one of his own best-selling novels for the screen. He is now in Provincetown, Mass., shooting ''Tough Guys Don't Dance,'' from his screenplay based on his novel. Ryan O'Neal, Isabella Rossellini and the newcomer Debra Sandlund star in the Cannon Group film. Among Mr. Mailer's recent screenplays are a television script for ''The Executioner's Song'' and two films not yet produced. He also directed, produced, wrote and starred in three low-budget films in the late 1960's and early 70's.

title: A Long Way, Tear Gas to Tax Law
description: These were not naifs. They were a hard-edged and rather world-weary crowd that had gathered in a Georgetown town house on a night in October.

title: Preventive Detention Still Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS RAID PALESTINIAN BASES IN NORTH LEBANON
description: Israeli jets attacked bases of two radical Palestinian groups in northern Lebanon today, killing 6 people, including a guerrilla official, and wounding 20, the police said.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,379,000 for the quarter and $4,014,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months also includes a loss of $293,000 from discontinued operations. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $3,608,000 for the quarter and $7,886,000 for the 9 months. The periods also include income from discontinued operations of $297,000 for the quarter and $211,000 for the 9 months.

title: Ekaya at Sweet Basil
description: The pianist Abdullah (Dollar Brand) Ibrahim is leading his septet, Ekaya, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: LAWSUITS CHALLENGE AID BY CITY FOR CONCRETE PLANT
description: A group of concrete-supply companies yesterday filed lawsuits in Federal and state courts to prevent New York City from helping a new private company build a concrete plant on the West Side.

title: Mississippi Tax-Exempts
description: The Mississippi Housing Finance Agency is offering $285 million of bonds, which include ''pure'' tax-exempt bonds and ''tainted'' tax-exempt bonds on which the interest may be subject to the alternative minimum income tax for individuals.

title: PIONEER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $404,000 from a prepayment penalty charged by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: PRETORIA IMPOSES HARSH NEW RULES AIMED AT UNREST
description: The Government tightened its six-month-old emergency decree today, outlawing more forms of political expression and imposing near total censorship on news reports about the nation's black revolt.

title: Pepsico Diet Cola
description: Pepsico Inc. said it plans to test a new 15-calorie per serving diet cola called Jake's Diet Cola in several markets, which it would not name, starting next month. The company described Jake's as the first full-flavored diet cola, and it said Jake's beat Diet Coke in taste testing over the past year.

title: OIL CONFEREES STUDY MARKETING REPORT
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries closed the first day of a full ministerial meeting here today still deeply divided over how to reach their stated goal of raising petroleum prices to $18 a barrel.

title: Soviet vs. Chinese Reform
description: One way and another, almost all Communist countries are talking reform nowadays, recognizing at last that they have made ''big mistakes.'' Each has its own approach.

title: Reputed Crime Figure Freed
description: The reputed organized-crime figure Joseph Paterno has been admitted at a hospital for treatment of terminal lung cancer after a state judge, citing his condition, ordered him freed on $250,000 bond and placed him under round-the-clock surveillance. Mr. Paterno, 62 years old, was admitted at Mount Sinai Medical Center Wednesday, officials said. He has been in the Dade County Jail for 20 months awaiting trial on a charge of conspiracy to commit murder.

title: Dining Out Guide: Game
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: APPLIED MATERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective April 25.

title: Big Jay McNeely
description: The saxophonist Big Jay McNeely will return this weekend to Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Port Authority Plans New Auto Terminal
description: The Port Authority, responding to an increase in automobile imports, said yesterday that it would build a $31 million distribution center for foreign cars on 145 acres at Port Jersey and the Greenville Yards in Bayonne and Jersey City.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

POLAND, FIVE YEARS AFTER MARTIAL LAW;
What Can The West Do?
description: Tomorrow marks five years since Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski imposed martial law, bringing down Poland's ''bloodless revolution.'' Such periodic convulsions have become a regular feature in Eastern Europe. Is there anything the West can do - or should do - to avert them and to encourage greater democracy and prosperity in that region? Or must we remain merely impotent well-wishers and phrase-mongers - shaking our fists and hurling imprecations that salve the conscience but accomplish nothing?

title: DANCE: NORTH CAROLINA TROUPE WITH GUEST ARTIST
description: REGIONAL ballet companies are rarely top-notch in all respects. But when they are good, they can be very good - and this is what the North Carolina Dance Theater proved splendidly in its second program Wednesday night.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the latest third quarter earnings reflect a negative impact equal to 9 cents a share from repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS SETON HALL
description: St. John's ushered in the 1986-87 Big East Conference season last night, and while the Redmen's game with Seton Hall came amid a somewhat lazy preconference schedule, it quickly turned into a typically intense confrontation between league rivals.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
FRETTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Heisman for Dad
description: Vinny Testaverde last night dedicated his Heisman Trophy to his father, Al, a construction worker. In an acceptance speech at the annual $150-a-plate Heisman banquet in midtown, the Miami quarterback said: ''I know that if my dad didn't have to go to work at an early age to help support his family, he probably would have won his own Heisman Trophy.

title: ALBANY LIMITS JERSEY DAIRY'S NEW YORK CITY SALES
description: The New York State Agriculture Commissioner yesterday denied a New Jersey dairy a license to sell milk throughout New York City, saying that the license would be harmful to competition.

title: Article 860786 -- No Title
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the giant oilfield service company, said today that it would take a pretax charge of about $1.7 billion against fourth-quarter earnings.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $2,648,000 and $3,820,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $1,110,000 for the quarter and $1,732,000 for the 6 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a desperate action by desperate people who demonstrate that they are unfit to govern.'' - The Pretoria News, commenting on new South African restrictions. [ A1:4. ]

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $680,000 from the disposition of subsidiaries and from discontinued operations, and a charge of $300,000 from marketing expenses to introduce products.

title: Textron Offering Of Debentures
description: Textron Inc., is offering $150 million of 9 1/2 percent subordinated debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99 1/8 to yield 9.589 percent.

title: 2 SEEN AS LIKELY TO LEAD IRAN PANELS
description: The leading candidates to head the two special committees that will investigate the Iran arms deal are Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, according to senior Democrats on Capitol Hill.

title: Insider-Trading Case Settled
description: A San Antonio businessman, Melvin N. Pomerantz, today settled Federal insider-trading charges stemming from his use of nonpublic information on an impending offer to take the SFN Companies private in 1984.

title: Books: Perspectives
description: IN AFRICA WITH SCHWEITZER. By Dr. Edgar Berman. 308 pages. Illustrated.

title: THE STORMY VISIONARY PAINTINGS OF KOKOSCHKA
description: WHEN Oskar Kokoschka died in 1980 at the age of 94, he was a household name. For the general public, his high-voltage portraits of bohemians and aristocrats and his swirling visions of rapture and struggle have been a bastion of intelligibility and passion. For art professionals, Kokoschka is an Expressionist pioneer and a great draftsman whose work raises the question of how far an artist can go whose entire career is plugged into the Expressionist socket.

title: SCHEDULE OF FILMS IN FESITVAL
description: ''Homage to the Cinematheque Francaise'' will run through Jan. 5 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. All of the films have French intertitles; English synopses are available. Those screenings with live piano accompaniment are noted. Admission to the screenings is included in museum admission: $5 ($3.50 for students; $2 for the elderly). Information: 708-9490.

title: ALBANY VOTE ADDS NEW YORK CITY JUDGES
description: The State Legislature convened in special session today, passing legislation to add up to 23 judges in New York City but remaining split on three other key issues - tax revision, mass-transit aid and drug subsidies for the elderly.

title: LACK OF 'SMOKING GUN' CONCEDED BY SOLARZ ON THE PRESIDENT'S ROLE
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz conceded yesterday that testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee had produced ''no smoking gun'' linking President Reagan to the diversion to Nicaraguan rebels of profits from the secret Iran arms sale.

title: Jet 'Changes' May Be a Tactic
description: Joe Walton wore the smile today of a coach who may have turned his confused Jets back in the right direction.

title: STAGE: 'DREAM OF A BLACKLISTED ACTOR'
description: ALTHOUGH Conrad Bromberg, the author of ''Dream of a Blacklisted Actor,'' isn't the first son who ever hoped to resolve his rage at his father by writing a play, his pursuit of this ambition is more problematic than most. Mr. Bromberg's real-life father, the actor J. Edward Bromberg, was a McCarthy-era victim who died at age 47 of heart disease, not long after the Hollywood blacklist had destroyed his career. How does a child settle scores with the ghost of such a famous father without appearing to aid and abet the witchhunters who unjustly hounded him to the grave? The solution on view at the Ensemble Studio Theater isn't satisfactory. If Conrad Bromberg avoids sullying his father's memory in this autobiographical drama, he does so at the price of neglecting the very issues he intended to address.

title: Emhart Plans Sale
description: The Emhart Corporation said that as part of the $150 million restructuring progam it announced Sept. 25, it had selected 16 units for sale and would eliminate 1,100 jobs.

title: A MONTAGE OF MUSIC WITH A HOLIDAY LILT
description: WHO hasn't participated in the collective music-theater experience that is Christmas in New York? Strung with holiday lights, its sidewalks and shops ringing with music, New York City becomes a festive music-theater environment in December. Anyone who has ever stood around a piano singing carols, acted in a Nativity pageant, marched in a candle-lit holiday procession or attended a tree-lighting ceremony has played a part in the annual ritual - a multimedia extravaganza with a cast of millions.

title: GEONEX CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest year includes a reduction of $51,000 due to the reversal of investment tax credits previously included in net income for the first nine months of fiscal 1986.

title: Addendum
description: * Arrow Direct Marketing, Long Island City, has acquired the John Chapman Agency, a creative group in direct mail.

title: Family Farm Suffers From Too Much Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: GAF HOLDS 9.9% OF CBI INDUSTRIES
description: The GAF Corporation, which has been acquiring stakes in chemical companies for many months, said yesterday that it owned about 9.9 percent of the stock of CBI Industries.

title: OF FACTS AND FICTIONS IN THE PAPAL SHOOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthquake Shakes Bay Area
description: A minor earthquake shook the San Francisco Bay area today, but no damage or injuries were reported. The quake struck at 6:18 A.M. The earthquake registered 3.9 on the Richter scale, according to the University of California at Berkeley. The U.S. Geological Survey's earthquake scientists in Golden, Colo., said the quake had a magnitude of 4.0 and was centered 12 miles northeast of Fremont.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
DAVIS IS INDICTED IN FOUR SLAYINGS OF DRUG DEALERS
description: Larry Davis was indicted and arraigned in the Bronx yesterday on charges of shooting four suspected drug dealers to death in a robbery six weeks ago. In other cases, he faces charges of shooting six police officers last month and of killing a drug dealer in September.

title: ROBB TELLS DEMOCRATS IRAN ISSUE IS NOT A FREE PASS
description: Urging Democrats not to view the Iran arms operation as a ''free pass to the White House,'' former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia convened a group of centrist Democrats here today to explore a new message for the party as it heads toward the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: J. Walter Thompson Gets Jake's Diet Cola
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, already a Pepsi-Cola agency, will be doing the advertising for a new soft drink called Jake's Diet Cola, which the company expects to put into a number of test markets in January.

title: IRANIAN TELLS OF LEBANON TRIP TO OBTAIN HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: The Iranian middleman who negotiated the Administration's secret arms dealings with Iran asserted today that he had personally gone to Lebanon to arrange the release of American hostages.

title: Here's a Pony To Be Proud Of
description: Given the recruiting scandals that regularly rock the Southern Methodist University football program, Doug Rice is something of a maverick Mustang.

title: S.E.C. LET BOESKY PARE $1.4 BILLION FROM FUND'S DEBTS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that while negotiating terms of his settlement with the Government, Ivan F. Boesky was permitted to pay off $1.4 billion in debt carried by his principal investment fund. He did so through the sale of stocks and in other transactions.

title: TWISTS AND TURNS STILL IN STORE ON BUMPY ROAD TO PLAYOFFS
description: With two games remaining, the playoff picture in the National Football League is much clearer than it was a week ago but still somewhat murky in the American Conference, where only one of five positions has been clinched and eight teams are still competing for the other four.

title: LAWMAKERS URGE BUDGET TALKS WITH REAGAN
description: The chairmen of the next Congress's two budget committees, both Democrats, said today that they wanted a ''summit meeting'' of Congressional leaders and President Reagan early next month to try to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $55,000 for the quarter and $50,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $59,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the sale of the company's material handling operations.

title: CHARLES RAY WILSON
description: Charles Ray Wilson, the Miami University vice president for academic affairs and provost from 1961 until his retirement in 1970, died Wednesday after a long illness, the university has announced.

title: Despite Owens Surge, Dow Dips 9.28
description: Stock prices declined broadly on Wall Street yesterday in slightly slower trading.

title: NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After a tax credit of $225,000.

title: ZILA PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Study Challenges View On How AIDS Occurs
description: The AIDS virus seems to trick the body into attacking itself, an AIDS researcher said today.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of Slattery Group Inc. of $423,000 for the quarter and equity in a loss of $571,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes equity in earnings of Slattery Group of $41,000 and $450,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the earnings and dividends per share for the periods ending Oct. 31, 1986, and 1985 have been adjusted to reflect all stock dividends declared as well as the 4-for-3 stock splits declared in March 1986.

title: Fly Pattern
description: John Madden, who figures he has averaged 100,000 miles a year on trains since he quit as coach of the Oakland Raiders in 1978 and vowed never to fly again, thought he had experienced all the interesting problems that rail travel can offer, from snowstorms and derailments to the truly bizarre: ''Once a guy who had just robbed a bank in the Midwest jumped on my train, but they got him off at the next stop.''

title: WEDTECH, IN MIDST OF INQUIRY, SHUTS DOWN, DISMISSING 1,500
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor at the center of a corruption investigation, suspended operations yesterday and dismissed all its 1,500 employees.

title: GOODYEAR OFFER BEGINS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company began a tender offer today for up to 40 million of its common shares at $50 each in a previously announced plan to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the financier Sir James Goldsmith.

title: NEW ENTRANT IN CHICAGO'S CONFUSED MAYORAL RACE
description: This city's topsy-turvy race for Mayor was thrown into further confusion today when Thomas C. Hynes, the Cook County Assessor, announced that he intended to run as an independent.

title: Calling All Fawners
description: Capital literati are aquiver once more with anticipation, for the Osric Dining Society's annual award for the ''most fawning, toadying piece of writing'' in Washington, always sharply contested, will be made tonight at Otello, the Dupont Circle restaurant. The society was named to honor the foppish and groveling courtier in Hamlet. The announcement of its meeting, anonymous as all Osrician dispatches, stressed factors on which the winning entry will be judged: ''deference, flattery and self-serving vacuity,'' with secondary consideration given to ''concealment of interest, reliance upon cliche, mutual back-scratching and unfamiliarity with the English language.''

title: BLUES: EARL KING, GUITARIST
description: ROOMFUL OF BLUES, the New England-based rhythm-and-blues band, has recorded and performed with Joe Turner, Eddie (Cleanhead) Vinson and other celebrated blues artists. But Earl King, the New Orleans songwriter, singer and guitarist who appeared with the band at the Bottom Line on Tuesday, represents a different sort of challenge.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday about the opening of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles misidentified the sculptor of a mural. He is David Smith.

title: Festivals And Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture. Today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Pottery Show and Sale, Baldwin Potters, 534 La Guardia Place. Today, 5:30 to 8 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. 15th WBAI Crafts Fair, Columbia University, Ferris Booth Hall, Broadway and 115th Street. Today, 5 to 9 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 7 P.M. Admission, $5 ($2.50 for children and the elderly.) Also Dec. 19-21. Information: 279-0707.

title: First, Stop the Tax Windfall
description: What's the best way to prevent a windfall in state taxes in the wake of Federal tax reform? Governor Cuomo's plan, revised just days after it was made public, would add more patches to the state tax crazy quilt. The Republican leadership's alternative, by contrast, is elegantly simple, creating a mere two brackets and dramatically reducing marginal tax rates.

title: CHARGIT REPORTED IN CHAPTER 11
description: Chargit Inc., one of the nation's biggest telephone ticket reservation companies, was reported yesterday to have filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Cubans Charge U.S. Spying
description: About 100,000 demonstrators rallied at dusk today outside the former United States Embassy building, protesting the purported flight of an American espionage plane over Cuban territory, which the Cuban Government said took place Monday. The gathering coincided with the final day of Bastion '86, the biggest military exercise ever held by Cuba. In Washington, the United States Government refused to confirm or deny Cuba's assertion.

title: NAVY EMPLOYEE HELD IN ESPIONAGE-RELATED CASE
description: A civilian employee at a Naval air base in the Philippines has been arrested for espionage-related activities, the Navy said today.

title: LAWSUIT DISMISSED ON SHIP THAT STRUCK MINE
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that sought $1.6 million from the United States Government in connection with a Norwegian cargo ship that was damaged by a mine two years ago in a Nicaraguan harbor.

title: BONN CHARGES EX-AIDE WITH SPYING FOR SOVIET
description: West Germany charged a former secretary in the President's office with treason and espionage today, alleging that she had been spying for the Soviet Union since 1971.

title: PHILIPPINE REBELS CHALLENGE MANILA
description: Communist leaders challenged the Government today, bringing a company of armed guerrillas into this small town near an American naval base in a dramatic test of the provisions of a day-old cease-fire.

title: Christmas as Celebrated By Eleanor Roosevelt
description: For those who want to see how Eleanor Roosevelt celebrated Christmas, her home at Val-Kill in Dutchess County, now a national historic site, will be open to the public without charge tomorrow and Sunday between 1 and 4 P.M., with refreshments served.

title: MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES DECLINE FOR THIRD MONTH
