description: Interest rates on both fixed- and adjustable-rate mortgages fell in November for the third consecutive month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday. Many banks are now offering their lowest rates since 1978.

title: Offer Accepted By Lampoon
description: National Lampoon Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a Los Angeles-based group of private investors in a deal valued at more than $12 million. Matty Simmons, chairman of

title: More Layoffs at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had laid off 1,500 hourly workers indefinitely at various assembly and components plants. G.M. also placed 1,700 hourly workers on temporary layoff at its Pontiac West truck and bus plant at Pontiac, Mich.

title: VANGUARD TECHNOLOGIES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Man Is Convicted In Betting Parlor Fire
description: A man authorities described as the enforcer for a Cuban organized crime ring was convicted yesterday of hiring two men to set fire to a Brooklyn betting parlor. Two people died in the blaze.

title: HANFORD REACTOR TO BE SHUT FOR SAFETY MODIFICATION
description: The Department of Energy will shut down a nuclear reactor at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation to make safety modifications, an Energy Department official said today.

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
CUOMO PANEL SUGGESTS HOW TO CHANGE WELFARE
description: A panel appointed by Governor Cuomo issued its recommendations yesterday for reducing poverty and improving the nation's welfare system.

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SPEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SSC&B:Lintas USA Wins Hotels Campaign
description: SSC&B:Lintas USA has won the competition to be the ad agency for Leading Hotels of the World, which plans a $3 million print campaign to let the traveling public know of its existence.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: 11,787 Cabs and Counting The number of medallion taxicabs in the city has remained constant at 11,787 for almost 50 years, but the City Council's Transportation Committee is holding a public hearing today to consider a bill that would grant the Taxi and Limousine Commission the power to increase the number by 1,800. The commission's chairman, Gorman Gilbert, and representatives of taxi owners' and drivers' organizations plan to testify at the hearing. 1 P.M., City Council Chambers, City Hall A Bad Day to Drive About a million vehicles are expected on the city's streets today, possibly the highest number all year, on another ''Gridlock Alert'' day.

title: One Foot Equals Thousands of Yards
description: Here are the busiest punters in N.F.L. history.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A WORD OR TWO BEFORE YOU GO. . . .

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC EVENTS FOR THE CHRISTMAS SEASON
description: Following is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. Today Trinity Church (Episcopal), Broadway and Wall Street. Shaw's ''Fanfare for Christmas''; and traditional and English carols; Down Town Glee Club; George Mead, conductor. At 8 P.M. Tickets, $6.

title: CHINA TAXING THE RICH
description: China announced a new tax on its richest citizens today in an attempt to prevent wide disparity in earnings. The official New China News Agency said more people were earning extra income because economic reforms allowed a bit of free enterprise, straining the supply of goods.

title: RARE FOURSOME: NICKLAUS AND SONS
description: The Bear and his cubs huddled this morning under broad green-and-white and red-and-white umbrellas to ward off the rain that was just starting. After a moment, Ursa Major said to his Ursa Minors, ''Let's go, guys!''

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KILLING IN COUNCIL CHAMBER STUNS CITY IN RURAL IOWA
description: It was a quiet City Council meeting here Wednesday night until the fatal ending.

title: ALLIES AKS NEW TALKS ON EUROPE FORCES
description: The NATO foreign ministers proposed a new forum today to discuss the reduction of conventional forces in all of Europe, from the Atlantic to the Urals.

title: Need a Singer Fast? Stan Wiest Can Help
description: THE phone rang once, Stan Wiest grabbed it and started scribbling notes madly. ''So this is an emergency situation?'' he said. ''O.K., how can I help you, Phil? O.K., you want a strolling accordion? Right. O.K., you want this tomorrow night? As soon as possible? Possibly tonight. At 7? OK. Would a strolling guitarist be acceptable? O.K., now this person will have to be able to sing in Italian? O.K. And you want Christmas carols? O.K. Right. (Sigh.) Let me put you on hold, Phil.''

title: WIESEL, IN OSLO, LAUDS PEACE AS 'OUR GIFT TO EACH OTHER'
description: Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, raised an impassioned cry today against persecution, terrorism, hunger and war. He said peace was not bestowed by God but ''is our gift to each other.''

title: Intel Sells Unit
description: The Intel Corporation said it would sell its magnetics division to a newly formed company called Memtech Inc. Intel said in October that it would seek a buyer for the division, which produces bubble memory, a type of magnetic memory used primarily in military applications, including Air Force fighters and satellites. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article on Wednesday about winners of the 1986 Guild Hall achievement awards, presented by the arts center in East Hampton, L.I., misidentified one of last year's winners. They were Kurt Vonnegut, Alan Alda and Willem de Kooning.

title: Advertising; Kane Ford Broadens Horizons
description: DESPITE all of the gloomy talk about mass firings in adland, there are still agencies looking for people, including some of those that have been doing the firing.

title: OIL WOES PUT LOUISIANA IN QUANDARY
description: With revenue falling and the elections coming, the Louisiana Legislature is wrestling this week with a political nightmare: It must either raise taxes or cut services, in a state where for decades people have been accustomed to being lightly taxed and generously served.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago results restated to reflect adoption of revenue deferral on the sale of extended warranties.

title: 45 HURT IN COMMUTER TRAIN CRASH
description: An airport shuttle train collided with a commuter train taking on passengers Wednesday, slightly injuring about 45 people and delaying evening rush-hour traffic, transit officials said.

title: 5 SKETCHES BY EHRLICHMAN RE SOLD AT AUCTION
description: Five autographed pages of doodles and notes by John D. Ehrlichman, the high-ranking adviser in the Nixon Administration, were sold at auction in Manhattan last night.

title: JERSEY MAYORS SEEK INCREASES IN TRENTON AID
description: Saying they were tired of coming to the Capitol each year to beg for money to run their cities, a group of New Jersey's urban mayors announced support today for a package of bills designed to provide an additional $170 million in state aid annually.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday NUTS AND BOLTS FOREVER Mix one part mime, one part video. Now throw in a few hair dryers. What you have are the makings of ''Autobahn,'' a satire about America's obsession with technology. The work, written and directed by Tony Brown and Kari Margolis, features original musical compositions by Neil Alexander and Charles Haynes and performances by the dramatic troupe known as the Adaptors. The ''new vaudeville'' piece - which infuses images of the 50's into its freewheeling structure - will be presented at 7:30 and 10 tonight and 8 and 10:30 tomorrow night at the American Folk Theater, 241 West 55th Street. Tickets are $12.50 tonight; $15 tomorrow. ''Autobahn,'' with lighting by Peter Anderson and sound by Kyle Chepulis, runs through Dec. 28. The number for reservations is 757-0220.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-After a provision of $5 million, or 7 cents a share, for frozen food plant consolidation. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 1.

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $511,000 on the purchase and retirement of debentures for the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said its 1986 fiscal year included $4,016,000 in unusual charges for the writedown of Tertiary enhanced oil recovery projects and similar unusual charges of $6,085,000 in the 1985 fiscal year.

title: Economic Scene; Trade Swing May Be Slow
description: THIS year, despite the depreciating dollar, the United States trade deficit has continued to deteriorate; it is expected to expand to perhaps $170 billion for 1986, compared with $132 billion in 1985.

title: LIFE TERM ASKED FOR EX-U.S. AIDE IN SPY CASE
description: Federal prosecutors have recommended a life prison sentence for Ronald W. Pelton, who was convicted of espionage, despite his cooperation in a 210-hour interrogation and his expressions of remorse.

title: The Bean Tube
description: In anticipation of 1987 as the first full year of televised sessions of the Senate, C-SPAN, the cable network that broadcasts Congress live, is sending friends as a holiday ges-ture a can of U.S. Senate Bean Soup, which it identifies as ''a lunchtime favorite'' with the lawmakers.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
MUSIC: MEHTA CONDUCTS THE VERDI REQUIEM
description: MUSIC, the cliche has it, is a universal language, but most of the time it exists as a scattering of dialects, each in its own distinctive city-state. Verdi's Requiem, on the contrary, occupies common ground and speaks a common tongue with concert music, church music and opera, which seems to have bothered many serious listeners in former times. Nowadays, Verdi's mass, composed in memory of the novelist Alessandro Manzoni, is happily listened to for what it is: an unduplicable masterwork in a genre of one. When performed with passion by first-rung artists, as it was under Zubin Mehta last night, it can stir the blood and grip the imagination like no other work in the concert repertory.

title: Siegler Response
description: Lear Siegler Inc., in response to a letter from AFG Partners, said that the partnership has not demonstrated its ability to finance its offer of $85 a share, or $1.51 billion, for the diversified aerospace and manufacturing concern. Lear Siegler also contested AFG Partners' assertion that Lear had denied it access to financial information by asking the partnership to enter into a standstill agreement. A spokesman for AFG had no comment.

title: FILM: 'THREE AMIGOS'
description: THE Three Amigos are silent-screen stars who forsook their gay-caballero image to make films like ''Those Darn Amigos,'' in which they traded their sombreros for top hats and toured Manhattan. Not surprisingly, such miscalculations have led to a serious career setback. And the three have further pushed their luck by demanding ''real money - Amigo money'' from a studio head who thinks they're barely worth bus fare. Consequently, when the Amigos receive a telegram from a beautiful but naive Mexican woman named Carmen who mistakes them for bona fide heros, they are conveniently unemployed.

title: 2 JAPANESE FIRMS GIVEN FED STATUS
description: The Federal Reserve, in an economic and political decision of high sensitivity, today approved applications by two Japanese investment houses to join the Fed's elite group of primary dealers in United States Government securities.

title: People
description: * Michael Stanke named publisher and George H. Oestreich 3d, ad director, of Home magazine.

title: RATING STATE LAWS ON WOMEN
description: From the point of view of women's rights under state laws, Washington is the best state to live in and South Carolina is the worst, according to a list compiled by the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Like Lincoln, Like Reagan
description: Citizens for America, a political group that lobbies for the Reagan agenda between elections, is organizing a national campaign, complete with television commercials, to support the President on the Iran-Nicaragua controversy.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Students in the Streets, Then and Now
description: The massive French demonstrations, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's withdrawal of the legislation that triggered them, have plunged France into controversy. For Americans, they raise a different thought. The last time such protests gripped France, American campuses seethed along with them. Why not now?

title: A FESTIVAL OF RARITIES CELEBRATES CINEMATHEQUE
description: TO mark the 50th birthday of one of the world's first and most important film archives - the Cinematheque Francaise in Paris - the Museum of Modern Art is borrowing some of its rarities.

title: JUSTIN LIPMAN
description: Justin Lipman, the head of Cuddlecoat, a coat manufacturing concern, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Westbury, L.I. He was 63 years old.

title: THE SCREEN: 'CHILDREN'
description: JUST as you're about to get a little ill at the idyllic carryings-on at the start of ''Where Are the Children?,'' watching a pair of made-in-Hollywood kids frolic amid the fall foliage in Cape Cod while their mom looks on adoringly (yet with a shadow of concern), the kids are kidnapped - and a storm begins that lasts all day and all movie. What follows in this tortuously torpid thriller, which opens today at the Guild Embassy 4, may not leave you feeling any better.

title: Champion Bid
description: Champion Products Inc., which makes athletic uniforms and sportswear, said a major shareholder had rejected a $85 million takeover offer.

title: Reagan Physician Chosen
description: President Reagan has selected Army Col. John E. Hutton, who has served as assistant Presidential physician for two years, to succeed Dr. T. Burton Smith as the President's physician, the White House announced Wednesday.

title: OPERA: BEHRENS STARS IN BEETHOVEN'S 'FIDELIO'
description: LEONORE, the plucky and resourceful heroine of ''Fidelio,'' is a role into which Hildegard Behrens fits with hand-in-glove snugness. The German soprano's ardent temperament and searching, interpretative mind find a subject suited to them in Beethoven's only opera. Moreover, her vocal equipment, which often betrays serious weaknesses in more lyric parts, can serve her not only well but also excitingly when the moon is in the right dramatic quarter. Wednesday evening's ''Fidelio,'' the first of the Metropolitan's season, found Miss Behrens in her best current voice and in a mood to sweep aside any reservations one might have entertained in advance about the cast as a whole or the somewhat clumsy old Otto Schenk production.

title: Waiting on Regan's Status
description: The uncertain future of Donald T. Regan as White House chief of staff is complicating the selection of someone to succeed Larry Speakes as chief spokesman for President Reagan. Administration officials, who had hoped to have a successor in place by early January, say they don't know whether they can safely clear a new spokesman with Mr. Regan or should postpone that decision for a new chief of staff.

title: 'WHOSE CHILD AM I?' LOOKS AT FOSTER CARE
description: The holidays are a time for children. This makes ''Whose Child Am I?'' timely. It also makes it touching. The half-hour program on Channel 2 at 7:30 tomorrow night looks at the foster-care system in New York. The program, the first in a three-part series that continues for the next two Saturdays, finds the system to be strained; this is, after all, New York. The program, however, has something to say.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 28 about the New York City Board of Education's dropout-prevention programs misidentified a social services organization that works with Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx. It is Pius XII Youth and Family Services.

title: SCREEN: 'CLASS OF NUKE 'EM HIGH'
description: NOT since Sherwood Anderson wrote ''Winesburg, Ohio,'' has Smalltown, U.S.A., come under such ruthless scrutiny as it's receiving from some budget-minded producers calling themselves Troma Inc. Troma's specialty: satiric comic-horror films of stomach-turning grossness and exhilarating tackiness with a built-in publicity gimmick.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marchenko Buried Near Jail In Rites of Orthodox Church
description: Anatoly T. Marchenko, the Soviet dissident who died in prison on Monday, was buried today in Russian Orthodox rites near the prison in Chistopol in the Tatar republic, friends reported.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chief Leaves Agency
description: Arnold Winer, 53, is leaving Shaller, Rubin & Winer, where he has been president and chief executive, to establish Adplan, a consultancy firm that will work with advertisers and agencies to evaluate various aspects of agency service and compensation structures. Mr. Winer, who is opening Adplan in his Scarsdale, N.Y., home, was at the agency 17 years. Before that he worked for McCann-Erickson; Hicks & Griest; Seagram, and Chirurg & Cairns. Shaller, who were co-chairmen during Mr. Winer's presidency, are now back to being chairman and president, respectively.

title: OPTIMISM IS SUBDUED
description: Retail sales rebounded strongly last month from October's record drop, the Government said today, bringing cheers from the White House but only restrained optimism from private analysts.

title: INTIMIDATION CITED IN ATOM PLANT INSPECTIONS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that agency officials were so eager to complete the Comanche Peak reactor in Texas that they took many actions to downgrade the magnitude of flaws found in safety inspections.

title: BIG ARMS CASE PUT OFF AGAIN
description: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan obtained a second court adjournment yesterday of its case against 18 defendants charged with selling arms to Iran because of a need for more evaluation on how or whether to proceed.

title: FORD AND CHRYSLER GIVE PLANS ON INSTALLING AIR BAGS BY 1990
description: Two of the top three United States automobile makers said today that they planned to equip at least half of their 1990 model cars with air bags.

title: AS PROTEST TURNS UGLY, CHERCHEZ LE PROVOCATEUR
description: Last weekend, after what was intended as a peaceful student demonstration against the Government's education plans had dissolved into rioting that left cars ablaze and shop windows shattered, French television gave viewers a brief glimpse of a mysterious figure.

title: METS TRADE FIVE FOR McREYNOLDS IN EIGHT-MAN DEAL
description: The Mets, obsessed with strengthening the team that won 108 regular-season games and the World Series, finally won Kevin McReynolds and his home-run bat tonight when they swung a blockbuster trade with the San Diego Padres that cost them five young players but none of their major league pitchers.

title: Celtics Make Move
description: The Celtics placed Scott Wedman on the injured list for the second time this season and replaced him with 6-foot-8-inch Darren Daye, a free agent who played three years with the Washington Bullets and one game with the Chicago Bulls this season before he was cut. The 6-7 Wedman has not fully recovered from surgery before the season on his left heel. . . . Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Lakers' playmaker and top scorer, suffered a bruised right kneecap during Wednesday night's loss to the Bucks in Milwaukee. With the knee still sore and puffy yesterday, he is listed as doubtful for tonight's game against the Celtics.

title: GERMAN DROPS ANTI-SEMITISM SUIT
description: The director of Frankfurt's repertory theater agreed today to drop legal proceedings against the authors of two books that quoted him as saying the ''no-hunting season'' for Jews was over in West Germany.

title: Performance Art
description: Eleven soloists and groups will appear in ''A Wild Evening of Performance Art'' tonight at 8:30 at Taller Latinoamerico, 19 West 21st Street.

title: Hawkeye Agrees On Debt Program
description: Hawkeye Bancorporation said it had agreed with its lenders to restructure its $102 million debt.

title: BROADWAY
description: PUT the words Broadway and musical together, and a big, big budget - to the tune of $4 million or $5 million - dances in front of producers' eyes. Not so for T. Harding Jones, who with Steve Gideon is a principal in an enterprise called the Zephyr Entertainment Company. The two men and Zephyr plan to put on a Broadway musical next spring, and their projected costs are slightly more than $1 million.

title: MALAYSIAN CAR TESTED
description: Malaysia's auto maker, which plans to begin exporting to the United States in 1988, flew a Proton Saga car there today to see if it meets American standards.

title: Two Different Gates
description: Secretary of State Shultz said in Brussels that Reagangate was ''absolutely in total contrast with Watergate'' because President Reagan, unlike Richard Nixon a decade ago, wants all the facts disclosed. That remains to be seen; but the two scandals are different, all right.

title: Real Estate; A Rental Tower for West Side
description: RISING amid the parking garages and industrial buildings on the far West Side of midtown Manhattan is the first conventionally financed high-rise apartment building in that keenly eyed part of town.

title: ORDER TO BYPASS CONGRESS ON IRAN CALLED C.I.A. IDEA
description: Government officials said today that the Central Intelligence Agency originally proposed the idea of keeping the Iran arms sale secret from Congress. They said the agency took the unusual step in the first draft of what became a Presidential order guiding the program.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and the prior year is after a $3,055,000 gain on the sale of Optical's interest in Applied Solar Energy Corp.

title: Scouting; Fix-Up Special
description: A note left hanging anonymously on the bulletin board of the Diplomat Hotel in Hollywood, Fla., the scene of baseball's winter meetings: ''FOR SALE: Used baseball team.

title: Cafe Jupiter Trio
description: The pianist Kirk Lightsey, the bassist Santi DeBriano and the drummer Eddie Gladden are playing trios tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Change Is Inevitable
description: To the Editor:

title: Hasenfus Sentence Confirmed
description: A revolutionary appeals court today confirmed the guilty verdict and 30-year prison sentence imposed on the American Eugene Hasenfus.

title: MEAN JOE WARNS JETS ABOUT STEELERS
description: Chuck Noll sounded surprised when somebody told him his Pittsburgh Steelers have a perfect 8-0 record against the Jets. The coach wanted to know, ''Is that right?'' and then he proceeded to say the past will mean nothing when the teams tangle tomorrow.

title: Debut of the Wrong Bomber
description: Bombers are a valuable part of America's strategic nuclear forces; unlike missiles, they can be recalled and reused. But the B-1B bomber now coming into service looks very much like a turkey. As the Air Force recently conceded to Representative John Dingell of Michigan, the plane has so many defects that $250 million in payments is being withheld from its makers.

title: MEDICAL JOURNAL ASSAILS THE USE OF AN EXPERIMENTAL CANCER DRUG
description: The Journal of the American Medical Association has harshly criticized treatment of cancer with an experimental drug that has been much publicized as a potential ''breakthrough'' against malignant disease.

title: Zambia Halts Food Increases After Rioting and 11 Deaths
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia canceled increases today in the price of high-grade corn meal after four days of food riots, in which at least 11 people have died.

title: CANDIDATES FOR PROSECUTOR REPORTED
description: The three-judge panel searching for a special prosecutor in the Iran arms investigation has submitted a short list of candidates to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a preliminary security check, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the search.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1986
description: Markets

title: New Lawyer for Hunts Not Aiming to Settle
description: As the newly hired lawyer handling the Hunt brothers' $13.8 billion lawsuits against 23 banks, Stephen D. Susman said the change in legal representation signaled neither a softened approach by the Hunts nor a decision to settle the cases out of court.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., one of the world's biggest producers of bottles and other types of packages, said yesterday that it had received a $3.3 billion buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Article 776586 -- No Title
description: Disque D. Deane, a New York financier, pledged $20 million yesterday to Duke University in Durham, N.C., to ''establish a research institute on the human future.''

title: ART: IN THE MID-70'S, EXPLORING THE IMAGE
description: THE group show at Blum Helman Warehouse (80 Greene Street) reviews a point in the mid-1970's when scores of ambitious young New York painters and sculptors turned away from pure abstraction and, somewhat tentatively, began to use the strategies of Minimalism and Process Art to refer to the world around them. Ponderously titled ''From Icon Toward Symbol: Developments of Imagery in American Art, 1973-1979,'' this show actually offers an expanded definition of the phenomenon of new image painting, a trend acknowledged, but only partially covered, by an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1978.

title: Bah, Bureaucrat-Bashing WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: A group of 150 business executives, most of them former public servants, are trying to curb the common practice of running against the Government in political campaigns. Concerned by what they call ''mindless bureaucrat-bashing,'' the businessmen today will announce the formation of the Center for Excellence in Government, with the goal of elevating ''the importance and respect accorded to public service and public servants.''

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $55,095 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $50,185 for the 6 months.

title: REPORT SAYS POLAND IS MASKING RIGHTS VIOLATIONS
description: Since the lifting of martial law in July 1983, the Polish Government has embarked on ''a systematic effort to mask'' continuing human rights violations, a private New York-based rights group said yesterday.

title: PICKENS MEETS DIRECTORS
description: After a two-day meeting that included a discussion with its unsolicited suitors, led by T. Boone Pickens, the board of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today that it was still evaluating the $2.03 billion takeover offer from Mesa Limited Partnership.

title: CLOSE CALLS FOR 2 TOP YACHTS
description: White Crusader of Britain pushed New Zealand to the limit today in a race that Chris Dickson and his Kiwi Magic team came close to losing. On a race course not far away, New York's America II fought off a heavy onslaught from Canada II.

title: South Africa Blinds Itself
description: The Pretoria regime's Christmas gift to itself is a press purged of unwelcome news. Its 24-page censorship proclamation goes further than requiring clearance for stories dealing with security or ''subversive'' statements. Also forbidden is any indication, such as blank spaces, showing busy scissors at work. That may please the Government and its supporters. But for everybody else, no news is terrible news. It is the willful self-blinding of a country stumbling on a precipice.

title: The U.N. Population Fund Needs the U.S.
description: United Nations members - developed and developing countries representing the spectrum of political and religious thought - last month pledged a record of nearly $140 million in 1987 contributions to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. Regrettably, the United States, which for 17 years had been the largest contributor, was conspicuously absent from the list of donors.

title: U.S. Honda Unit In Taiwan Deal
description: Taiwan's San Yang Industry Company has signed a one-year agreement to import up to 2,000 Honda Accord cars next year from the Honda Motor Company's American subsidiary, San Yang's chairman, Huang Shi-Hui, said. Honda's American unit had said in Detroit Thursday that it was negotiating a deal to export cars made in its Ohio plant to Taiwan.

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $303,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. The company said preferred dividend requirements exceeded income for the 9-month periods.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. ATLANTA HAWKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.). NETS VS. INDIANA PACERS, at Indianapolis (Radio - WNEW 1130, 6 P.M.) COLLEGES: Hofstra vs. Marist and St. John's vs. U.C.L.A., at Madison Square Garden, 12:30 and 2:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 12:30 P.M. and 2:30 P.M.; Radio - St. John's game only, WCBS 880, 2:30 P.M.); Arizona at Georgetown (TV - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.); DePaul at Louisville (TV -Channel 4, 3:30 P.M.); Staten at City College, 4 P.M.;Worcester Poly at N.Y.U., 4 P.M.: Manufacturers Hanover Classic, at Iona, consolation at 6 P.M., final at 8 P.M.: Rutgers vs. Seton Hall and Duke vs. Alabama, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7 and 9 P.M. (Radio - Seton Hall game only, WSOU, 89.5, 6:30 P.M.); Canisius at Syracuse (Radio - WNYE 91.5, 7:30 P.M.); Villanova vs. Connecticut (TV -ESPN, 8:30 P.M.).

title: MORRIS WOULD LIKE TO GO HOME AGAIN
description: George Steinbrenner, who in past years has romanced and enriched some of the best free agents, said yesterday the chance to get Jack Morris would be ''tempting.'' Steinbrenner, though, will have to wait in line because Morris designated his hometown Minnesota Twins as the first team he will talk to in his effort to leave the Detroit Tigers.

title: BIGGS TOPS SNIPES IN DECISION
description: Tyrell Biggs, the undefeated heavyweight from Philadelphia, won a unanimous 10-round decision from Renaldo (Mister) Snipes at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Kay Under Treatment
description: Clarence Kay, a tight end for the Denver Broncos, has been placed on the club's reserved list for four weeks because of drug use. Jim Saccomano, a club spokesman, said Kay's drug problem was discovered four or five weeks ago during normal urinalysis testing approved by the league.

title: AIDS MAY SPREAD OUTSIDE BLOODSTREAM
description: Federal scientists, carrying out test-tube experiments in the laboratory, have found for the first time that the AIDS virus can infect cells from the colon and rectum and may enter the body by a route other than directly into the bloodstream.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about recommendations of a New York State welfare panel included a misplaced passage in some copies. It should have read, ''However, its recommendations -some of which could be viewed as too politically liberal or expensive to put into effect - are issued at a time when Cuomo aides, hoping for a Presidential race by the Governor, are trying to play down any perception of him as a big-spending Northeastern liberal.''

title: BONUSES ON WALL STREET MAY BE THE FATTEST EVER
description: The Christmas bonus, a time-honored tradition on Wall Street, is likely to be fatter than ever this year, as the financial industry races to complete its best year ever.

title: Travels With Tito
description: Is he Jean Valjean or is he Al Capone? Or neither? Will he become Akeem or Kareem? Or neither?

title: Holtzman Employee Charged in Drug Case
description: A clerical worker in District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman's office was arrested yesterday on charges that she sold cocaine to an undercover police officer while on the job.

title: HANFORD REACTOR IS TROUBLED LINK IN AGING PRODUCTION CHAIN
description: The plutonium production reactor at Richland, Wash., whose temporary shutdown was announced yesterday, is one of the most troubled links in an aging chain of facilities used by the United States Government to make the raw material for nuclear weapons and fuel for submarines.

title: 2 AIDES IN MIAMI REPORT ORDER TO STOP AN INQUIRY
description: Two Federal court officials said today that last March, a Federal prosecutor ordered them to stop investigating reports of an illegal arms shipment from Florida to the Nicaraguan rebels that purportedly had its roots in the National Security Council.

title: Murdock Advances Australia Media Bid
description: The News Corporation Ltd.'s bid to acquire Australia's largest media company, the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., for $1.2 billion received a boost today when an institutional investor sold its 12 percent stake to the News Corporation.

title: Oil's Rise Hurts Bond Prices
description: Bond market sentiment was depressed again yesterday by a further rise in oil prices, as well as rising volumes of corporate and municipal bond offerings.

title: Kind Words a Prelude to the Showdown
description: When Willie Glass and Reggie Miller talk publicly about each other, they speak with the reserved politeness of country gentlemen.

title: Trouble Spots for Traffic
description: According to the City Department of Transportation, among the most severe traffic trouble spots today in the New York metropolitan region will be these:

title: Satellite That Aids Shuttles Suffers Malfunction in Orbit
description: A tracking and communications satellite similar to one that was blown up with the space shuttle Challenger has suffered a partial failure in orbit, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: SOVIET JET, WITH 81 ABOASRD, CRASHES IN EAST BERLIN
description: A Soviet jetliner crashed in heavy fog while approaching an East Berlin airport today, killing most of the 81 people aboard, the East German press agency reported.

title: Oil Above $16 a Barrel; OPEC Meeting Is Cited
description: As an OPEC agreement on production cuts took shape, prices of crude oil advanced above $16 a barrel yesterday for the first time in three months. Other petroleum products also rose markedly in world markets.

title: A Place Where the Poor Dine On Cornish Hens and Mousse
description: HE found the cheesecake rich and creamy, the ambiance pleasantly informal and the service most accommodating, yet Ernie said he could not help but be a bit disappointed that the luxurious chocolate mousse cake with shaved walnuts was not on the menu yesterday at the Saint Luke's Lutheran Church soup kitchen.

title: Walter Werner Is Dead; Retired Law Professor
description: Walter Werner, the Adolf A. Berle Professor emeritus of law at Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 71 years old and had residences in Manhattan and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Met Batters Cheer McReynolds Trade
description: ''Fabulous,'' said Gary Carter, who bats fourth for the Mets. ''Real good,' said Darryl Strawberry, who bats fifth. And Kevin McReynolds, the newest member of the cast, who will bat sixth, said: ''Everybody wants to be in a lineup like that.''

title: FILM: UNDERSEA DERRING-DO IN FRANK HARRIS'S 'PATRIOT'
description: ''The Patriot,'' now playing at theaters in Manhattan, is an exceptionally slow-witted, technically inept suspense melodrama about a crazy United States Navy officer who steals several nuclear warheads to sell to the Russians via Cuban intermediaries.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1986
description: International

title: Hearing Held on Costs Of Housing Homeless
description: Spurred by President Reagan's recent remarks about the cost of housing the homeless in welfare hotels, a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee held a hearing in New York City yesterday.

title: BRITISH INFLATION UP
description: Inflation in Britain rose to an annual rate of 3.5 percent in November, from 3 percent the previous month, the Government said today.The increase was caused mainly by a rise in interest rates in October as the Treasury defended the slumping pound, the Government said.

title: INTELSAT CANCELS PLANS TO BUY I.B.M. UNIT SATELLITE
description: Intelsat has decided to cancel its planned purchase of a satellite for $38 million from a subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation after questions were raised about the transaction, American and Intelsat officials said today.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Koch Aides Defend Taxi Medallion Plan
description: Mayor Koch's plan to increase the number of taxi medallions was defended yesterday before a New York City Council committee.

title: Wright's Cricket Story
description: Jim Wright told this story the other day to illustrate his new job as Speaker of the House:

title:
PATENTS;
Loudspeaker Produces Undistorted Bass Notes
description: A new loudspeaker system that efficiently produces low bass notes without distortion was patented this week for the Bose Corporation, Framingham, Mass.

title: VARITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $7 million for the quarter and $20 million for the 9 months. After preferred share dividends, there were no earnings applicable to common shares. All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Hubbard Quartet
description: The trumpeter Freddie Hubbard is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $425,000. c-Net loss The latest first quarter results include Sports Specialties, acquired by MacGregor Aug. 1, 1986.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: A MESSAGE FROM McFARLANE; ISRAEL REPORTS U.S. PLAN TO DENY ROLE
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, warned a senior Israeli official last year that if the arms deal with Iran was exposed, the Reagan Administration would deny any involvement and say all the responsibility was Israel's, the Israeli television has reported.

title: NETS GET HOT AS 76ERS GO COLD
description: There were some strange happenings tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, among them a victory by the Nets.

title: PRETORIA ORDERS A 'SWOOP' ON FOES IN SECURITY MOVE
description: A day after South Africa drastically tightened controls on political expression and news reporting, the police announced today that they had carried out a series of actions against their adversaries.

title: The New New York Rudeness
description: New Yorkers are notoriously rude: taxi drivers hold up traffic, garbage trucks block side streets, people push and shove one another to squeeze on to the subway and in busy coffee shops waiters practically throw the food at customers.

title: Jockeys' Walkout Cancels 4 Races
description: Jockeys forced the cancellation of the last four thoroughbred races tonight when they walked out of the Meadowlands race track after one rider was hurt in a spill.

title: FOR THE LOCAL ECONOMY, FEARS OF WORSE TO COME
description: Like many others in this city whose fortunes have been inextricably linked to atomic weapons for almost half a century, Steve Servin lashed out today at what he saw as faceless bureaucrats who were threatening the community's economic foundation.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 13
THEATER: KATHLEEN TURNER RETURNS TO STAGE AS CAMILLE
description: Though shadowed by Greta Garbo and all the dramatic and operatic grand dames aux camelias (as well as Charles Ludlam's ridiculous version), Kathleen Turner is a rapturous ''Camille.'' In her return to the stage at the height of her movie stardom, she radiates magnetism and sensuality.

title: 'GOING OUT': STILL AS COMPLEX AS TEEN-AGERS
description: From a distance, it looks as simple as boy-meets-girl. But what is not so simple, according to the girls, is meeting a boy - at least one who is handsome, funny, reliable, not a nerd or a wimp, and free on Friday night.

title: Gunman Kills Youth And Dies in Shootout
description: A gunman fatally wounded a 13-year-old boy at the youngster's home and then held the police at bay for 35 minutes today before being killed in an exchange of gunfire with officers who entered the building, the police said.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in January.

title: MUSIC: VERDEHR TRIO IN FIVE RECENT WORKS
description: From a marketing standpoint, the Verdehr Trio was a little overambitous to book Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night for a program of five works composed just last year. However prestigious the Lincoln Center credit may look on their resume, the many empty seats were a dispiriting sight at the actual concert.

title: A FORMER TEAMSTER OFFICIAL IS SENTENCED IN RACKETEERING
description: The former vice president of a teamster local was sentenced last night to 12 years in prison for using the union to extort air freight trucking companies at Kennedy International Airport.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $47,000.

title: AN IRREVERENT MODEL SHAPES CHANEL'S NEW IMAGE
description: ''Would you like to meet Coco?'' a voice boomed from a speaker on the main floor of Macy's one recent morning. ''Come and meet the embodiment of Chanel.''

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: All of the 1985 figures are reclassified. Share earnings for all periods are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 1.

title: WAS A TOP BRITISH DIPLOMAT
description: Sir Roger Jackling, a former Ambassador to West Germany and one of Britain's top diplomats during a career of more than 35 years, died Nov. 23 at his home in London. He was 73 years old.

title: Under Two Flags
description: To the Editor:

title: No Territories for Peace
description: To The Editor:

title: WEDTECH VOWS NOT TO TERMINATE ITS BUSINESS
description: The Wedtech Corporation, the South Bronx military contractor that furloughed its entire work force and suspended its operations Thursday, said yesterday that it has ''no intention'' of terminating its business.

title: 2 CORRECTIONS OFFICERS AND A PRISONER FROM L.I. DIE IN UPSTATE CRASH
description: Two Nassau County Corrections Department officers and a prisoner they were transporting died today when their car and a dump truck collided on a slippery country road here, the authorities said.

title: BASIC IRAN DETAILS STILL NOT CLEAR, LEGISLATORS SAY
description: After two weeks of Congressional investigations into the United States arms sales to Iran and the diversion of money to the Nicaraguan rebels, legislators said today that they still could not understand the essential elements of how the policy was developed, financed and set into motion.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DART GROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,705,000 on early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the results for the latest periods include a gain on the sale of a portion of common stock of Safeway Stores Inc. The revenue increase in the latest results is primarily due to the consolidation of Crown Books Corporation and Trak Auto West Inc.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED AT AUTISITC SCHOOL
description: A legal dispute over the treatment provided at a school for severely autistic teen-agers and young adults was settled today with an agreement that would allow the school to give punishment as therapy in individual cases with a judge's approval.

title:
PATENTS;
TV Pictures Upgraded With Coding Apparatus
description: William E. Glenn, director of the research center maintained in Dania, Fla., by the New York Institute of Technology, got a patent this week for apparatus to encode and decode high-definition television pictures.

title: MARITAL FAILURES: CAN THEY BE PREDICTED?
description: Is it possible to predict the success or failure of a marriage as early as the time a couple gets engaged? David H. Olson, a psychologist who is a professor of family social science at the University of Minnesota at St. Paul, thinks so. He bases his view on an analysis of the opinions and expectations of each partner before marriage and the state of their marriages three years later.

title: NYSTROM, FAN FILE CHARGES IN SCUFFLE
description: After the Islanders defeated the Devils, 8-4, at the Meadowlands Thursday night, both clubs cleared their benches and started brawling, and an assistant Islander coach went racing through the arena in pursuit of a spectator who had dumped beer on him.

title: City Marathon Appeal
description: Antoni Niemczak, the 31-year-old Polish runner who finished second in the New York City Marathon but was disqualified after a drug test found traces of anabolic steroids in his system, said yesterday that Polish sports authorities would soon appeal to the International Amateur Athletics Federation to reverse its decision to ban him from competition. ''My situation is a special situation,'' the runner said at a news conference at the New York Road Runners Club.

title: DeLorean Jury To Start Again
description: Jurors in the fraud and racketeering trial of former sports-car maker John Z. DeLorean adjourned for the weekend without reaching a verdict today after being ordered to start deliberations anew when the judge removed one juror.

title: Lebanese Kept Up Tradition With Entry in World Event
description: The war-torn country of Lebanon has a considerable bridge tradition, and in happier days Beirut was the scene of a European Championship that wandered slightly outside the normal continental boundary.

title: MANUEL GEARING FOR PLAYOFFS
description: Lionel Manuel, the Giants' best wide receiver, has missed the last 10 games, and he will not be reactivated for Sunday's game here against the St. Louis Cardinals. Emotionally, he has gone up and down - happy that the Giants are 12-2 and in the playoffs, frustrated that he has not been a part of it, happy that the Giants have kept winning without him.

title: NEW YORK CITY MILK PRICES ARE CRITICIZED AS TOO HIGH
description: New York City consumers pay among the highest milk prices in the country and the state's dairy farmers are paid among the lowest prices in the country for their milk, city officials, consumer groups and agricultural economists said yesterday. They were criticizing a state ruling that bars a New Jersey dairy from selling milk in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

title: A CITY STILL GROWING UP AT THE TENDER AGE OF 198
description: Mark Twain once said that if the world ended, he would rather be in Cincinnati because things here happen 10 years late.

title: NATO MINISTERS SPURN PROPOSAL TO ABOLISH ALL BALLISTIC MISSILES
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization distanced itself today from President Reagan's goal of eliminating all American and Soviet ballistic missiles in the framework of an arms-control accord.

title: New Speaker For Assembly: Melvin Howard Miller
description: Melvin H. Miller is the first to admit that he has changed his image since he learned he might be the next Speaker of the Assembly.

title: Don't Despair, Complain
description: MARK BERNSTEIN was fighting mad Monday because Citibank owed him $4,003.72 that he had overpaid on his mortgage. He had been waiting for his refund since Oct. 24, when he paid off the mortgage, and he was not going to take it any more.

title: THE FRENCH DENY IT
description: A newspaper here reported today that two French hostages in Beirut were freed in June after France paid the kidnappers a ransom of more than $2 million.

title: AIDE TO BUSH SAYS NEITHER KNEW OF FRIEND'S LINK TO CONTRA ARMS
description: Vice President Bush's national security adviser, Donald P. Gregg, said today that neither he nor Mr. Bush knew until August that Mr. Gregg's protege, a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, was deeply involved in ''private'' arms shipments to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Col. Richard S. Stark, An Actor and Novelist
description: Col. Richard Salisbury Stark, U.S.M.C.R., retired, who also had a long career in films, radio and on television, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Sotogrande, Spain. He was 75 years old and also maintained a residence in Alexandria, Va.

title: GRUEN MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company went public in October and is 76 percent owned by Jewelcor Inc.

title: THE MOUNTIES ARE TOLD TO INVESTIGATE IRAN DEAL
description: The Government ordered the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today to investigate reported statements by William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, that Canadian business executives were involved in financing Iranian purchases of American weapons.

title: JAPAN REJECTS PLEA FOR DEVICE TO CURB TAPE-COPYING
description: Japanese electronics manufacturers have rejected American requests to include in new digital audio tape recorders a lockout device that would prevent home taping of commercially recorded music.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Lorimar Ends Sale
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said it had terminated its agreement to sell its Metrocolor Lab to Processing Partners, a limited partnership of which MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc. is a partner. MacAndrews & Forbes is controlled by Ronald O. perelman, chairman of Revlon Group Inc. Lorimar sai the agreement had been canceled becasue of oppostition from the antitrust division of the Justice Department. Mr. Perelman Already owns Technicolor Inc., another large film processing concern. Lorimar said the acion would not have a negative financial impact because of an indemnity clause contained in the original agreement.

title: OPEC PACT ON OIL CUTS IS SHAPED
description: A majority of the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed in principle today to significant cuts in official production quotas in a move designed to raise the price of oil to $18 a barrel, delegation sources said.

title: Inventories Swelled 0.6% in October
description: Business inventories climbed at the fastest pace in more than two years in October as sales dropped a sharp 1.6 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Floatable Platform Can Hold 20 Survivors
description: A floatable platform patented this week can be used to help rescue as many as 20 people from open water.

title: Samuel Leveston Dies at 88; Advised Families on Finances
description: Samuel Leveston, an insurance agent who handled financial planning for families such as the Kennedys, the Du Ponts and the Rockefellers, died Wednesday at Hartford Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: RIVER OAK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3,883,000 and a tax credit of $39,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $158,000.

title: Shelterless Partnerships
description: LIMITED partnerships, an investment category that provides direct pass-through of earnings in such fields as real estate, oil and gas, and equipment leasing, will lose much of their appeal as tax shelters next year.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review of ''The Golden Child'' in Weekend yesterday incorrectly described J. L. Reate, who plays the title role. She is a girl, in the role of a boy.

title: KENNEDY ENDS ISRAEL VISIT
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, ended a three-day visit to Israel today and left for Jordan after assuring his hosts that Israel retained Congressional support despite its role in American arms sales to Iran.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a court order preventing New York City from enforcing a new law affecting some commercial property owners described the city's reaction and the status of the law incorrectly. The city has not yet decided whether to appeal, and the law is not in effect.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $9,192,000 on the sale of the company's interest in Gruen Marketing Corp. for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the 1985 results are restated to reflect accounting changes. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter yesterday from Charles D. Reich gave an incorrect figure for the percent of American agriculture that survives without Government supports. It should have read 51 percent, not 5 percent.

title: KEY RATES
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: N.R.C. Fines A-Plant For Radiation Level
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission fined the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant $50,000 because a worker exceeded his quarterly radiation limit, Northeast Utilities, the operator, said Thursday.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A Jerusalem dispatch yesterday reported Israeli officials' statements that their Government has been seeking since 1982 to restore diplomatic relations with Nicaragua. The Israeli newspaper Maariv was quoted as having reported early this month that Benjamin Netanyahu, now chief representative at the United Nations, urged several years ago that Israel aid the contras.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
description: The Government indexes that tally prices at various stages of production continued last month to indicate only a mild pickup in inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: The Library Apologizes
description: Already having had to cut back its services as a result of Federal budget reductions, the Library of Congress now acknowledges a gaffe that may have strained relations with the House Appropriations Committee.

title: NEW FACTORS INDICATED IN SPACE SHUTTLE ACCIDENT
description: An independent analysis of videotapes of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger indicates that factors other than the booster rocket's flawed joint seals may have contributed to the craft's disintegration, it was reported yesterday.

title: Boom Over, Nigeria Tries Its Luck on the Farm
description: Visitors who turn left at the sign advertising ''Day-Old Chicks and Dressed Chickens'' and drive to the end of the country lane will usually find Nigeria's former head of state down on the farm.

title: JURORS ASSESS MONSANTO $108 MILLION OVER DEATH
description: A Federal jury in Galveston, Tex., today ordered the Monsanto Company to pay $108 million to the family of a chemical worker who died of leukemia after working with the chemical benzene for five years at a Monsanto plant near here.

title: TRIAL OF GOETZ OPENS AS JUDGE TRIMS JURY LIST
description: The trial of Bernhard H. Goetz began quietly yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan with the judge questioning the first prospective jurors in a back room of the court because he said he feared their privacy would otherwise be violated - and their possible jury service tainted.

title: Lakers End Celtic Streak
description: Magic Johnson scored 31 points and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 14 of his 26 in the fourth quarter tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers stopped the Boston Celtics' 49-game winning streak at Boston Garden with a 117-110 victory.

title: PARIS PROTEST: AGAIN THE CENTER HOLDS
description: French commentators, looking for an explanation for the huge burst of student anger that stopped a favorite program of the conservative Government in its tracks, have been seeing some telling similarities in the experience of the conservatives in power and the Socialists who preceded them.

title: 2 Are Dead in Pipe Rupture At Nuclear Plant in Virginia
description: Two workers at the Surry nuclear power plant near Williamsburg died after a pipe ruptured and sprayed them with superheated nonradioactive water and steam, officials said today.

title: SUPPORT FOR REAGAN IS URGED
description: Citizens for America, a conservative lobbying group, announced a nationwide campaign today to bolster support for President Reagan, which has decreased since the Iran arms affair came to light last month.

title: Officer Is Arrested Over Bogus Tickets
description: A Queens police officer was arrested and suspended from duty yesterday on charges that he had issued more than 100 bogus parking summonses to nonexistent cars, the police said. The effort was an illegal shortcut to meet the Police Department's unofficial quotas for tickets, the police added.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-9

title: PRECEDENTS AREN'T PROMISING FOR THE JETS
description: The football demons that threaten to turn the Jets' season into a nightmare converge at Giants Stadium on Saturday.

title: WHY FEWER AMERICAN WOMEN MARRY
description: ''Single-Minded College Girls Put on Shelf at 30!''

title: Tulsa Names Henshaw
description: George Henshaw, an assistant football coach under Ray Perkins at the University of Alabama for the last four seasons, has been named head coach at the University of Tulsa, replacing Don Morton, who left Nov. 28 to move to the University of Wisconsin.

title: DANCE: LARRY RICHARDSON
description: Each of the three works that Larry Richardson and Dance Company presented Thursday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater got off to a pictorially interesting start. Then, instead of strengthening or developing his images, Mr. Richardson let them choreographically fall apart.

title: Elisha Hoffman Weds Michael Untermeyer
description: Elisha Anne Hoffman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. David Hoffman of Philadelphia and Atlantic City, and Michael W. Untermeyer, the son of Mrs. Harold Aks and Walter Untermeyer Jr. of New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi George Martin performed the ceremony at the Hoffman home in Atlantic City.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A DIFFERENT PICTURE

title: DOW DROPS ON TALK ON OPEC PACT
description: The possibility that OPEC would soon cut its oil production caused stock prices, with the exception of energy issues, to fall on Wall Street yesterday.

title: State Takes a Look At Correction Policy
description: By the middle of next year, New York State's prison population is expected to reach 40,000 for the first time, a prospect that is bringing a re-evaluation of state corrections policy.

title: SMITH FLATTENS WITHERSPOON
description: After much sound and fury, there was a World Boxing Association heavyweight championship bout after all. What it signified, in the end, was that James (Bonecrusher) Smith could punch big enough to be a champion.

title: JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI BARS A CROSS DISPLAY ON A STATE BUILDING
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the display of a 20-story lighted cross on a state building was unconstitutional, and he ordered an end to the nine-year Christmas tradition.

title: Nonretirement Tales
description: With the cost of political campaigns soaring, major office holders now seem to be in a continuous process of raising funds.

title: Bird as Unlikely Hero
description: DODO. By Tony Weeks-Pearson. 158 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: Noll Keeps the Edge on Steelers
description: When the Jets last saw the Steelers, they were, well, the Steelers. That was 1984 and a struggling Pittsburgh team still managed to make it to the American Conference championship.

title: NOISE CANCELLATION TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There were no revenue figures for the latest and year-earlier quarters.

title: Grantsmanship and Envy
description: If there is one subject that arouses even more lustful interest in this city than personal scandal or politics, it is fund raising.

title: SWISS MAY REOPEN IRAN ARMS ACCOUNTS IF U.S. DOESN'T ACT SOON
description: Swiss Government officials said today that the United States had so far failed to lodge a formal request for legal assistance in blocking Swiss bank accounts linked with the diversion of covert Iranian arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People have different views about it. And some are intrigued and some are enthusiastic and some are reserved and some don't think it's a very good idea.''

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ontario Insider Penalties
description: In the wake of the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading scandal on Wall Street, the government of Ontario has proposed radically tougher penalties for illegal securities trading.

title: Nathan's Gets A New Offer
description: Nathan's Famous Inc., the New York-based restaurant chain known for its hot dogs, said yesterday that it had received a new offer that is 30 cents a share higher than one made last week by a group of investors based on Long Island.

title: MANILA DEFENSE CHIEF SEES RIFTS HEALING
description: Recent threats of a coup by military officers have widened latent divisions within the armed forces, but these are being healed by a slow tightening of discipline, Defense Minister Rafael M. Ileto said today.

title: PROCESSING FOR CHARGIT RESUMES
description: One day after Chargit Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection, anxious merchants who had used Chargit to handle their credit-card receipts began to collect some of the money owed them as the Bowery Savings Bank, under a court agreement, resumed processing yesterday for the troubled company.

title: Armacost to Meet Rebels
description: Under Secretary of State Michael H. Armacost will meet with representatives of South Africa's main rebel group, the African National Congress, as part of a four-nation trip to southern Africa next week, the State Department said today. Mr. Armacost, the department's third-highest official, will meet with representatives of the rebel group in Lusaka, Zambia, where the group has its headquarters.

title: Greetings
description: The Yuletide, it seems, stirs similar sentiments among disparate elements. A Washingtonian who appears to be on a wide number of Christmas mailing lists received two identical cards by recent post, handsome embossed designs depicting a dove of peace bearing an olive branch. One came from an executive of the Lockheed Corporation, a leading arms manufacturer, and the other came from the Embassy of Nicaragua.

title: REVIVAL CHANGES THE FACE OF RED HOOK
description: The Red Hook section of Brooklyn once was one of the most intensively developed sections of the New York Harbor. Its residential blocks were squalid and overcrowded, and the district for years rivaled the Hell's Kitchen area of Manhattan.

title: U.S. and Turkey Initial New Accord on Bases
description: Turkey and the United States today initialed a five-year agreement on military and economic cooperation that includes provisions for continued American use of military bases here.

title: What West Bank and Gaza Population Crisis?
description: To the Editor:

title: PUPILS SEEK TO LEND AID TO NEEDIEST
description: The fourth grade of the Browning School in Manhattan collected and gave $207 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, accompanied by greetings to children of all races and religions.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
KOCH SELECTS NEW AUDITOR, AIDES REPORT
description: Mayor Koch will appoint Karen S. Burstein as New York City's first Auditor General, a post created 10 months ago as one of the Mayor's key responses to the city's corruption scandals, according to city and state officials.

title: THE BIG BOARD PROHIBITS MEMBER TIES TO BOESKY
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had suspended Ivan F. Boesky from association with any member firm of the exchange, and suspended a direct electronic link that he had with the exchange's floor.

title:
PATENTS;
Radio Tied To Quake Predictions
description: AN earthquake warning system, which involves monitoring radio broadcasts and recognizing any sharp decline in their strength, was patented this week by two California engineers.

title: FIRE CODE DULLS CHRISTMAS DECOR AT CARTIER
description: Cartier, the Fifth Avenue emporium where almost nothing is artificial, was ordered by the Fire Department yesterday to remove 30 live Christmas trees from its diamond-glittering, poinsettia-draped selling floors.

title: When the Best Way to Help Is Not to
description: One of my best friends has dinner parties every week and almost never has help in the kitchen. She also has an inflexible rule about guests in her kitchen. Although she will accept your offer to clear the table, you are barred at the kitchen door. No washing, no drying. Guests can't even rinse the dishes and put them in the dishwasher. ''Out, out, out,'' she says, and she closes the kitchen door firmly.

title: McMahon Has Surgery
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bear quarterback whose injured right shoulder has pained and hampered him for most of the current National Football League season, underwent surgery yesterday on the rotator cuff in the troubled joint. Dr. Frank Jobe, who performed the operation at Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, Calif., said, ''It'll be about six months before he can determine for sure whether he can throw well enough to be in the kind of game he's in.''

title:
PATENTS;
Barking of Dogs Curbed
description: A device that dissuades dogs from barking is described in patent 4,627,385, awarded this week to Rene Vinci of Perpignan, France. When a bark is detected electronically, a pressure tank on the dog's collar directs a spray of material selected to discourage barking to the nose and eyes. The spray can also be released by a trainer some distance away.

title: Yamani on Hong Kong Trip
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the recently dismissed Saudi Arabian oil minister, has turned up in Hong Kong.

title: Beatrice Unit Sale
description: The BCI Holding Corporation, which acquired Beatrice Companies last April, said that it had completed the sale of Beatrice's consumer products unit for $1.15 billion in cash plus preferred stock.

title: Access to New York Property-Income Data Was Long Overdue
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMS FUND SEEM ENTWINED IN OTHER DEALS BY KHASHOGGI
description: Two investors who joined Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman, in financing the American arms sales to Iran were also in other business deals with Mr. Khashoggi, according to public records and sources familiar with the deal.

title: I.R.S. Blocks '86 Deduction
description: The Internal Revenue Service slammed the door today on a widely promoted idea for getting around a provision in the new tax law.

title: XL/DATACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. OPPOSES ALBANY GAS TAX RISE
description: Senate Republicans today ruled out a nickel-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes, saying that the state should either scale down an $8.3 billion plan to rebuild the New York metropolitan area's subway, bus and commuter rail lines or find other ways to help pay for it.

title: BOARD AGREES ON QUINONES UNTIL JUNE '88
description: Unable to agree on a replacement and seeking to avoid a divisive search, the Board of Education has decided to reappoint Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones, but only for a year, according to sources involved with the question.

title: Action on Human Resources Recommendations
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAMROCK'S SLIDING FORTUNES
description: Be patient. That is Diamond Shamrock's request to investors as it continues to weigh an unsolicited $2.03 billion takeover bid from the oilman and corporate raider T. Boone Pickens. Today, the company said it had still not decided on its response but would meet again within a week.

title: NETWORKS ARE JUGGLING LINEUPS AT MIDSEASON
description: Midseason changes are under way at all three major networks. Some shows have already been canceled, others are being rescheduled and new series are being introduced. Since the 1986-87 season has produced only a couple of solid hits, more changes can be expected over the next month.

title: IN TOWN OF TRADITION, ROOM FOR AVANT-GARDE
description: Although the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art has stood on the main street of the conservative picture-postcard town of Ridgefield, Conn., for 22 years, New York license plates outnumber those from Connecticut in its parking lot. And local citizens - from bankers to gas station attendants - still have trouble telling visitors where to find it. Attuned to the very new in painting and sculpture, it lacks the lure of the nearby Keeler Tavern, a pre-Revolutionary structure that attracts hordes of history-minded visitors.

title: REAGAN DESCRIBES DOMESTIC MOVES TO PRESS 'BUSINESS OF GOVERNING'
description: President Reagan said today that the Administration intended to get on ''with the business of governing,'' and the White House announced that a series of domestic policy moves would be developed over the next few weeks.

title: U.S. SAYS IT BRIEFLY DELAYED CONTRA CASE OVER HOSTAGES
description: Justice Department officials said today that the department had briefly delayed an investigation into private schemes to aid Nicaraguan rebels because of concern that the inquiry would jeopardize negotiations to free American hostages in Lebanon.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A.M.C. Layoffs
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had placed 2,000 hourly workers on temporary layoff at its car assembly plant at Kenosha, Wis., effective next Monday, to reduce inventories of its unsold cars. A.M.C., controlled by the French car group Renault, said the workers would be recalled Jan. 12.

title: Mattel Predicts Loss in Quarter
description: Mattel Inc., the world's second-largest toy maker, which has already predicted significantly lower profits for this year, said it expects a fourth-quarter loss because of sagging American toy sales.

title: INSIDE
description: East Berlin Plane Crash A Soviet jetliner crashed on approach to an East Berlin airport, killing most of the 81 people aboard, East Germany reported.

title: Other Needle Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY U.S. REACTOR TO SHUT 6 MONTHS FOR SAFETY STEPS
description: A reactor at Richland, Wash., a ''key source'' of plutonium for the nation's nuclear weapons, will be shut down temporarily for expensive safety improvements, but the nation's military needs rule out a permanent shutdown, the Department of Energy announced today.

title: RUSSIAN UPSETS BECKER
description: Boris Becker was upset today by Andrei Chesnokov in the $150,000 Young Masters tournament.

title: LURIA, L & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month includes an inventory credit of $570,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: BANKS GRANTING PHILIPPINES 3-MONTH EXTENSION ON DEBT
description: The Philippines, struggling to make payments on its huge foreign debt, has won a three-month respite, Finance Minister Jaime Ongpin said today.

title: Downhill Skier Hurt
description: The 1984 Olympic downhill champion, Bill Johnson, crashed at high speed in training yesterday and will miss the rest of the World Cup season with an injured knee. The team doctor, Dave Donaldson, visited the 26-year-old Johnson in the hospital where he was taken after the fall in practice for the World Cup race today at Val Gardena, Italy.

title: AVIS PLANS OIL CENTERS
description: Avis Service Inc., the second-largest American car rental company, has announced that it wil franchise as many as 1,700 fast oil change centers nationwide over the next 10 years under the name of Avis Lube. Joseph V. Vittoria, Avis president and chief operating officer, said that, according to industry estimates. there are about 2,000 fast oil change centers in the United States, with more than 6,000 expected to be in operation by 1990. Avis hopes to franchise about 600 centers by 1992, the company said.

title: STRIKE SLOWS, BUT DOESN'T STOP, BRAZIL
description: A 24-hour general strike, the first coordinated labor action in Brazil since the return of civilian rule last year, slowed economic activity in much of the country today. But it failed in its primary objective of paralyzing the country.

title: 3 Banned for Steroids
description: Two defensive linemen from Nevada-Reno and an offensive guard from Georgia Southern have been declared ineligible for today's Division I-AA playoff game because they tested positive for steroids. The National Collegiate Athletic Association suspended for 90 days Scott Martin, a Nevada-Reno starting defensive tackle, and Lindon Lilly, a backup defensive tackle, and the Georgia Southern starting offensive guard, James R. Carter. The N.C.A.A. randomly tested 24 players - 18 of them starters - from each of the winning quarterfinal teams after last Saturday's games.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Let's Be Fair to Edward and Wallis
description: The extraordinary story of the abdication of Edward VIII in December 1936 has never lost its hold on the public. In the long history of the British monarchy, he was the only one to abdicate voluntarily. And he did it for an American, Mrs. Wallis Simpson, formerly a Mrs. Spencer, with two husbands living: that was the snag Edward and Wallis could not get over or around.

title: DANCE: 'NATURE DANCING' BY BERTRAM ROSS
description: Bertram Ross took a peculiar subject and made it even more delightfully peculiar in his new ''Nature Dancing,'' performed by the Mary Anthony Dance Theater/Phoenix on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. ''Nature Dancing'' is an evocation of the ''natural dancing'' that was a craze in America early this century, movement that was part daisy chain and decorous gymnastics class and part Greek-style wafting of the sort practiced by devotees of Isadora Duncan.

title: 'ARROGANCE' SEEN IN IRAN DEALINGS
description: Robert C. Byrd, the incoming Senate majority leader, today described the Reagan Administration as the most ''arbitrary, arrogant, partisan White House'' he had seen in 34 years in Congress.

title: STINGERS AIDING AFGHANS' FIGHT, U.S. AIDES SAY
description: United States officials said today that the Afghan guerrilla forces had begun using newly provided Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, causing significant problems for Soviet and Afghan aircraft and helicopters.

title: Steel-Jaw Trap Bill Is Vetoed on L.I.
description: A bill that would have prohibited the use of steel-jaw traps in Suffolk County was vetoed yesterday by the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, who said it was contrary to state law.

title: Marchenko's Heroism
description: ''When they have you by the throat your feelings of helpless protest may drive you to any extremes.'' So wrote Anatoly Marchenko, the Soviet dissident who died in prison Monday.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A REPORT TO PRESIDENT ON WELFARE
description: Following are excerpts from a report to President Reagan by the Low-Income Opportunity Working Group of the Domestic Policy Council, issued today by the White House.

title: REAGAN SEEKS CHANGE IN WELFARE SYSTEM
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed major changes in the Federal welfare system that would give state and local officials much more discretion in distributing aid to poor people.

title: Such A Swell Gang
description: The committee was so understanding, so sympathetic. Some members were obsequious. One or two who must have heard of Uriah Heep oozed oily insincerity. How delightful to watch them, aware of the cameras, playing the anguished truth-seekers pained by having to do their cruel duty.

title: Dailey Signs Offer Sheet
description: Quintin Dailey has signed a offer sheet with the Los Angeles Clippers, the club announced yesterday. Dailey, a 6-foot-3-inch, 180-pound free-agent guard played in 35 games for the Chicago Bulls last season, averaging 16.3 points. The Bulls have 15 days to match the offer if they wish to retain the 25-year-old Dailey, whose four years in the National Basketball Association were marked by various personal and legal problems, among them drug abuse.

title: Retirement Tales
description: Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana borrowed a phrase from an uncle, Earl Long, the colorful three-time Governor, the other evening to explain why he was retiring voluntarily at the age of 68 in full possession of his faculties. ''As Uncle Earl used to say,'' Senator Long declared, ''I wanted to leave office while there was still some snap left in my garters.''

title: Governor Cuomo and the Milk Cartel
description: Who is responsible for the fact that milk drinkers in four New York City boroughs pay 29 cents a gallon more than those in Staten Island?

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $10.1 million pre-tax writeoff of the company's entire investment in and advances made to the Dawn Enterprises ethanol refinery project, a limited partnership in North Dakota, and a tax credit of $1.9 million. c-Net income

title: BRUSH SET AFIRE TO TEST NUCLEAR WAR AFTERMATH
description: Federal Forest Service experts set off a 500-acre brush fire today to test whether dense smoke from a nuclear war would plunge the earth's climate into a devastating chill.

title: How Many Larry Davises?
description: Larry Davis allegedly shot six police officers during a gun battle last month. Shavod Jones shot a police officer in Central Park last summer and left him paralyzed. James Ramseur, now serving time for rape, was one of Bernhard Goetz's victims in the subway shootings two years ago.

title: Georgia Tech Cleared
description: RECORDS released by the Georgia Tech Athletic Association show that the Yellow Jackets reported nine possible rules violations to the National Collegiate Athletic Association over the last six years but received no sanctions. No wonder. The most serious offense, one that drew an actual admonishment from the N.C.A.A., was that Coach Bill Curry, along with several other college coaches in Georgia and Florida, had allowed his name to be used in a program ad endorsing a 1985 game between Florida and Georgia high school all-stars.

title: YAWNK BLEEROPP
description: UNDER THE WHEAT By Rick DeMarinis. 157 pp. Pennsylvania: The University of Pittsburgh Press. $14.95. THE BURNING WOMEN OF FAR CRY By Rick DeMarinis. 315 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95.

title: Maverick Composers Make Their Own Choices
