description: Every so often, as if in response to some cyclical law, a cry of pain arises Out There, in the unexplored lands beyond the walls of Manhattan. It is the sound of a neglected American composer lamenting that a few capos of the contemporary-music establishment control his nation's serious music, to its great detriment. There is, I believe, a good deal of truth in that charge, and probably always was. The latest plaintiff is Andrew Stiller, a Philadelphia-based composer who has written an attack on the system in this month's Opus under the title, ''Who Owns American Music?''

title: A.C.L.U. OFFERS JOB TO LAW PROFESSOR
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has offered one of its top three national posts to a University of San Francisco law professor, according to officials of the group.

title: Money Crisis Deepens for Small Black Colleges
description: WHEN President Reagan issued a 1981 executive order supporting the nation's 101 historically black colleges, many educators hoped the institutions would rebound from a troubled past. During the previous decade, black enrollment in all colleges had declined, and the merit of keeping separate black schools that were established in the days of segregation was widely doubted.

title: Recent Sales
description: Freehold $174,500 37 Brick Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; wall-to-wall carpeting, in-ground pool, brick patio, attic, fan; taxes $3,223. Maplewood $231,000 2 Berkshire Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 18-year-old split-level; eat-in kitchen, den, central air-conditioning, 2-car attached garage; taxes $4,569.

title: FIFTH AMENDMENT: BACK IN THE NEWS WITH 'INTRIGUING TWIST'
description: One of the oldest principles of Anglo-Saxon law is that no one is bound to betray himself, and in 1789 it was incorporated into the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

title: DOCTORS PRESS DEMANDS
description: THE scene outside the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla is beginning to look familiar. There's often a crowd of 75 to 150 interns and residents slogging through the rain and distributing fliers that read, ''Hey, Andy'' and ''Equity is good medicine.''

title: Hawaiian Volcano Clogs Up
description: Clogging has choked off the lava tube system that sent molten flows down the slopes of Kilauea Volcano and destroyed 11 homes, a scientist said Friday. The scientist, Reggie Okamura of the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, said the volcano, which earlier was producing 33 million cubic yards of molten material in 10 hours, was now putting out only 600,000 cubic yards a day because of the blockages.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
NEW TAX LAW CALLS FOR INVENTIVE GIVING
description: IN the midst of the perennial countdown to Christmas, there is another deadline that, ironically, does not bode so well for the spirit of giving: the end on Dec. 31 of the current tax law that encourages charitable support for our country's nonprofit arts, cultural, educational, health, civic, religious and social service institutions.

title: Books and Mass Appeal
description: As an assistant manager in a million-dollar-a-year Waldenbooks store in suburban Philadelphia, I found it amusing to read about the concerns of certain publishing houses that Harry Hoffman is forcing good books out of print. Are books by Jackie Collins or Stephen King the works of high art about which these gentlemen are so concerned? All of the publishing world has to produce and sell large volumes of books of this type to keep Faulkner in print.

title: The Hellman Record
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASHING STYLES IN THE BUCKEYE BOWL
description: THERE is the theory that when ivory-haired quarterbacks were being passed out, somehow Phil Simms got mixed up with Boomer Esiason. And so there is Simms, the mild Kentucky man, under scrutiny with the Giants, and there is Esiason, the impetuous Long Islander, living in Kentucky and imposing his brazen Eastern style upon the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Catholic Theologian David Tracy
description: I enjoyed Eugene Kennedy's finely drawn profile of the Roman Catholic theologian David Tracy (''A Dissenting Voice,'' Nov. 9), complemented by the cover photograph of a modestly hirsute Samson applying pressure to the pillars. WALTER RATNER Randallstown, Md.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING POINSETTIAS THROUGH THE YEAR
description: HOW about that poinsettia that you kept from last season? Has it colored so that it will be presentable for the Christmas holiday? If not, why has it turned out to be a disappointment?

title: CHATTANOOGA SCHOOL INTEGRATION CASE CLOSED
description: An often stormy public school desegregation case filed here 26 years ago has been dismissed by a judge who ruled that the Board of Education had finally met an order to racially integrate students and faculty.

title: Ellen McCurdy Engaged
description: The engagement of Ellen Steele McCurdy to John Jackson Burchenal Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burchenal of Wilmington, Del., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCurdy 3d of Summit, N.J. Miss McCurdy, an alumna of St. Lawrence University, is an assistant trader in the municipal bond department at Wertheim & Company in New York. Her fiance, who graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, is an account executive at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Inc. in New York.

title: MOBUTU SEES HIMSELF AS DISINFORMATION'S VICTIM
description: PRESIDENT MOBUTU SESE SEKO of Zaire, who met with President Reagan at the White House last week, is one of Africa's most durable leaders, having seized power in 1965 in the former Belgian Congo. Reagan Administration officials consider the 56-year-old Mr. Mobutu an ally, and he is said to be a channel for covert American aid to Jonas Savimbi's rebels in Angola. But Zaire's economy, despite aid from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank and $70 million a year from the United States, is in dire straits after years of mismanagement and corruption. In Washington, Serge Mukendi, a Zairean dissident, accused Mr. Mobutu of having amassed a fortune of $5 billion, more than Zaire's $4.5 billion foreign debt. And human rights advocates said his single-party Government had committed ''gross and systematic'' abuses.

title: SAMANTHA SMITH'S VISION AN INSPIRATION TO MOTHER
description: Before daybreak on Aug. 26, 1985, Jane Smith got out of bed after a sleepless night and wearily headed for a gym near her home here to work out. The workout was the normal way to start her day on a day when nothing was normal.

title: Mary Anne Flynn to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Flynn of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Anne Flynn, to Wayne Starke Mueller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Mueller of Oshkosh, Wis. The bride-to-be, an associate in the New York law firm of Martin, Clearwater & Bell, graduated from Barnard College and the Fordham University Law School. Mr. Mueller, an electrical engineer at Teradyne Inc. in Boston, graduated from the Columbia University School of Engineering.

title: Tway-Hulbert Duo Leads
description: Bob Tway and Mike Hulbert held the lead at the $600,000 Chrysler Team Championship for the third consecutive day today, shooting an eight-under 64 for a one-shot advantage over Brad Faxon and Denny Hepler in the best-ball tournament.

title: INSTITUTE EXAMINES QUALITY OF WORK LIFE
description: WHENEVER the subject is work, it is not uncommon to find the Work in America Institute quoted as an acknowledged authority in the field. A nonprofit research organization headquartered in Scarsdale, Work in America is the brainchild of Jerome M. Rosow, a former Assistant Secretary of Labor and a longtime Exxon executive. ''Founding the institute started me on my fourth career,'' said the 67-year-old Mr. Rosow. ''And it's been the one that's brought me the greatest measure of satisfaction.''

title: Penelope Bennett Becomes a Bride
description: Penelope Bennett, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Smith Bennett 4th of Paoli, Pa., and Avalon, N.J., was married yesterday to John Anthony Marzulli Jr., the son of Judge and Mrs. Marzulli of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobs performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. David's Epipscopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LAMPPOSTS IN A NEW LIGHT THE Trumps of Manhattan may have their tower, but the Schiavonis of Sag Harbor now have their lamppost. Actually two lampposts, according to Diane Schiavoni, the past president of Sag Harbor's Ladies Village Improvement Society.

title: Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. $195,000 1 Partridge Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old town house; mountain view, basement; monthly common charges $242, taxes $1,548. Bridgeport, Conn.

title: PIPELINE WOULD POSE ENVIRONMENTAL THREAT
description: While Mr. Ellis is ''treading along a trail or stopping to watch the progress of a foraging jay'' and commiserating with those of us who feel that the pipeline is an environmental threat to our communities, he might also pause a while longer to explain exactly why this Canadian gas, if indeed it is needed, cannot be brought in through existing pipelines or failing that, why a new pipeline cannot be built along existing rights of way.

title: SCHOOL FOR THE DEAF HAS DANCE PREVIEW
description: ''IF I weren't dancing, I wouldn't feel good about myself -I can't go without dancing,'' said Alexandra Mendoza, a 15-year-old student at the Dance Theater in Westchester and a performer in the company's coming production of ''A Colonial Nutcracker.'' Alexandra, who is hearing impaired and lip-reads with the assistance of hearing aids, was meeting one recent morning with a group of students at the New York School for the Deaf, in White Plains.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS ANALYZED
description: In 1970, a private commission formed to study charitable organizations found a ''scarcity of previously existing information'' on nonprofit foundations. Sixteen years later a clear picture is beginning to emerge about the private and public nonprofit sector, revealing common characteristics for organizations as diverse as public schools and art galleries.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS PUT UP POSTERS CALLING FOR MORE DEMOCRACY
description: Students at Beijing University put up posters on campus today calling for more democracy, students said. The action followed student demonstrations in the provinces.

title: AT SHOPS THAT SELL THE TRIMMINGS, CHRISTMAS IS YEAR-ROUND
description: THE signs of Christmas so prevalent now will disappear quickly come January.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LEGISLATORS FOCUS ON UNFILLED JOBS IN '87 BUDGET PLAN
description: A ''PHANTOM ARMY'' of 764 county employees, who do not exist although their jobs and salaries appear in the proposed 1987 budget, became the focus of a growing debate last week as the Board of Legislators turned its attention to possible cuts in the spending plan.

title: West Bank Arabs Protest Shootings
description: Young Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza staged angry demonstrations and threw stones at Israeli soldiers last week. The soldiers struck back with tear gas and occasional bullets.

title: Iran 2: How Best to Find It Out
description: There may have been a moment when President Reagan could have cut to the heart of the crisis. A close friend, Paul Laxalt, urged him to do it. So did a not-so-close friend, Jimmy Carter. So did others: Summon the people who should know into the Oval Office, interview them and then tell the public.

title: Neil Simon Dramatizes The Truth Of Experience
description: At the end of Neil Simon's new play, ''Broadway Bound,'' the author's hero and alter ego, Eugene Morris Jerome, leaves his family in Brighton Beach and moves to Manhattan.

title: A SPOT FOR A LEISURELY BRUNCH
description: HUCKLEBERRY'S, near the railroad station in New Canaan, had its beginnings as the dining adjunct to an indoor tennis club. New ownership, a new name and various decorating changes subsequently ensued. Renovation several years ago created a lighter, more spacious looking dining area. This is especially evident in the airy, garden-like adjunct to the main dining room.

title: Photo of families harvesting Christmas trees at the Dzen Tree Farm in South Windsor TREE SEEKERS ARE DOING THEIR HOLIDAY CHOPPING EARLIER
description: FAMILIES planning to visit the Maple Roe Farm in Easton today in the hope of finding and cutting down the perfect Christmas tree are in for a disappointment. Business was so good last weekend that Jim Edwards, who runs the 250-year-old family farm, decided to close the fields after only one weekend of operation.

title: BUCHWALD ADVISES NEW CITIZENS, WITH JESTS
description: Art Buchwald, the syndicated columnist, has demonstrated to a group of people about to become American citizens that he would not be arrested for telling jokes about President Reagan.

title: They Don't Give Medals for Pleading the Fifth
description: To the Editor:

title: MIKHAIL AMONG THE BYZANTINES
description: SHADOWS AND WHISPERS Power Politics Inside the Kremlin From Brezhnev to Gorbachev. By Dusko Doder. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: OPERA: JUILLAIRD STUDENTS IN 'MARRIAGE OF FIGARO'
description: SOME promising young singers are being presented in unpromising circumstances at the Juilliard School, where Friday's cast of ''The Marriage of Figaro'' contributed some enjoyable moments amid staging and conducting that were not what should be expected from a major professional training institution. (An alternate cast performed the opera Thursday and will repeat it this afternoon.) The best showing Friday was made by Young Ok Shin as Susanna. She has a clear, pretty voice, intelligible diction, and confidence of manner -though here the manner was all too readily that of the standard too-cute soubrette; that is where better guidance could have helped. Elmore James sang with generally good, uncomplicated tone as Figaro, and had the germ of a dramatic grasp on the role at certain key moments. The others - Jose Garcia, Peiwen Chao, Yanyu Guo, Daniel Colanero, Jeffrey Morrissey, Ana-Gloria Vazquez and Mi-Hae Park - all stand to benefit from further training in fine points and in some basics, though several clearly show promise.

title: MOVIE PLOT TWISTS: FERRY GETS STRANDED (FOR REAL)
description: A movie chase scene involving two Staten Island ferries strayed from its script yesterday when one of the ferries ran aground on a sand bar, stranding the actor Billy Dee Williams and about 75 other people for almost five hours.

title: WON'T ANYBODY TALK TO ME?
description: MY husband and I moved to Long Island 10 years ago from the Midwest. I was not a total stranger to the Island. I had grown up in Manhattan and had spent summers on the East End in (at that time) a quiet little town.

title: Kathleen Murphy Married To Richard C. Pietrafesa Jr.
description: The marriage of Kathleen Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Murphy of Ridgewood, N.J., to Richard C. Pietrafesa Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pietrafesa of Syracuse and North Palm Beach, Fla., took place yesterday at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Syracuse. The Rev. Robert Yeazel performed the ceremony.

title: AUDITIONS SCHEDULED
description: Accomplished musicians from high schools throughout New Jersey are invited to audition for a 35- to 40-member chamber orchestra that will travel to Moscow for one week next spring as part of a cultural-exchange program established between Trenton and the Lenin District, Moscow.

title: Cambridge Restricts Work Area Smoking
description: The Cambridge City Council has passed an ordinance aimed at restricting smoking in all work places in the community.

title: 2 OFFICERS NOT LIABLE FOR FATAL CAR CHASE IN CONNECTICUT TOWN
description: Two Bethel police officers are not liable for a car chase that ended with the deaths of four teen-agers, a Superior Court jury decided this week.

title: WHAT'S IN A WORD? A $1 MILLION PRIZE
description: SOMETIME in February, a jury is going to have to wrestle with semantics and decide who is to be out $1 million: the Sands Hotel-Casino, a Lloyd's of London underwriter or Michael Sherry, a 37-year-old self-styled ''humanitarian.''

title: Nanci Hilf Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Anita D. Bier of Clark, N.J., and Paul Hilf of Edison, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Nanci Renee Hilf, to David Levi, a son of Sima Levi of Union, N.J., and the late Isaac Levi. Miss Hilf, a graduate of Pace University, and her fiance, who graduated from Seton Hall University, are both accountants. The wedding is planned for May.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Offerings to Meet Holidays' Needs Ellie Conason has gathered unusual gifts and crafts for holiday sale at the Hudson River Museum's Red Grooms Bookstore, the Craft Gallery and the Holiday Shop Annex.

title: Planning for a Brighter Times Sq.
description: WENDING its way through the city's land-use review process is a set of proposed zoning changes designed to preserve, restore or create - the preferred verb depends upon one's point of view and method of analysis -a Great White Way along and beyond the northern stretch of Times Square. The area covers 17 blockfronts from 43d Street to 50th Street on Broadway and Seventh Avenue.

title: BEST SELLERS: DECEMBER 14, 1986
description: Fiction

title: WANTED IN CAPITAL: LARG RM W/VIEW
description: A ROOM with a view, spacious accommodations and convenience to the Capitol are what most lawmakers say they desire in the biennial ritual of finding the best office in town.

title: DUKAKIS ASSAILED OVER CONSULTANTS
description: Only one month after winning re-election by a landslide margin, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has come under criticism for relying on expensive consultant contracts to provide many routine government services.

title: CONGRESSMAN FORHEAD AIMS TO PLEASE
description: MORE WASHINGTOONS By Mark Alan Stamaty. Unpaged. New York: Prentice-Hall Press. Paper, $8.95. ''I DREAMED I was no longer larger-than-life,''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
ACID RAIN LECTURE
description: ''Acid rain is the most important regionwide environmental problem we have,'' said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York, who will speak on that subject on Thursday at the I.B.M. Research Center in Yorktown Heights.

title: U.N. CITES SUCCESS IN 2 CHILD HEALTH PROGRAMS
description: Two inexpensive methods for protecting the health of children have saved the lives of more than four million children since Unicef began a campaign to promote the methods four years ago, according to an annual Unicef report issued this week.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
INVESTING;
Singer's Sluggish Spinoff
description: Ever since October, when the Singer Company spun off its sewing machine operations as a separate corporation, the new entity - SSMC Inc. - has rated low in investor esteem. The shares, which trade on the Big Board, were around $14 last week, in the middle of a two-month range of $11.50 to $17.50.

title: Mickey Mouse Marches On
description: Mickey Mouse - Walt Disney's outrageously exuberant rodent - lives on in the minds of millions and in memorabilia that thousands collect. From now through Christmas Eve, period examples of Mickey Mouse collectibles - windup toys, books, games, a circus train, watches, a telephone and more than a score of original illustrations - dominate an exhibition at the Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS NEED NOT BE SO GRIM
description: ONLY a small number of rejection slips convinced me that I could never write good fiction. Part of the reason, I think, is that my experience has been altogether too pleasant. I have no tortured childhood memories or sadistic relatives to evoke horrified fascination from my readers.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas; J.R.'s Tower Gets New Look
description: IN many cities across the country, historic buildings are being refurbished in efforts to transform them into usable and attractive new office or retail projects. But in downtown Dallas, with one of the highest office vacancy rates in the country, the story is slightly different.

title: The Ancient Relationship Of Goddesses and the Dance
description: The goddess in history was not exclusively worshiped through dance, but dances performed in devotion to a goddess or the number of danced personifications of goddesses stretch back to ancient times. It was ingenious of the Asia Society's rich and lively two-day symposium on ''The Universal Goddess'' last week to bring this connection to the fore. This was not a dance conference. Yet the linking, on the same program, of dances and scholarly lectures on the role of the goddess in Eastern and Western traditions brought out the vitality of certain principles that still animate dance - not to speak of life.

title: The Grand Exit, Plus Snow
description: THE scene is so familiar it has almost become a cliche. You come out of a party or a late movie to find that it's snowing, or raining, or both, and there isn't a cab in sight.

title: Advice to I.M.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSEUM REOPENING Larry Aldrich's Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is to reopen today with three new exhibitions housed in its original 200-year-old building and in a new million-dollar addition designed by Robert A. Faesy, a Wilton architect. The privately funded museum has occupied a former colonial general store on Main Street for 22 years. The new wing adds 4,000 square feet of gallery space to the original 7,500 square feet, joined by a glass-walled atrium.

title: Yale Record Trove, At 25, Is Monument To Avid Collector
description: Want to hear Bertolt Brecht singing ''Mack the Knife''? Want to hear the sexiest recording ever made of ''Begin the Beguine'' (Lawrence Tibbett, in a unique copy from the private collection of Cole Porter)? ''Ol' Man River'' or ''O Mio Babbino Caro'' or ''Oh Promise Me'' from the lips that first gave them voice?

title: UTAH BACKS NAVAJO TRIBE IN AN ADOPTION CASE
description: The Utah Supreme Court has acknowledged the sovereignty of a Navajo tribal court in family matters by reversing a lower court that approved the adoption of a Navajo boy by non-Indian parents.

title: DELAWARE POLICE MEDICS TAKE TO SKY
description: A blue and white State Police helicopter whirling above the Delaware countryside is three times more likely to be on a mission of mercy than in hot pursuit of lawbreakers.

title: South Africa Shuts the Door on News Of Dissent
description: South Africa has been trying for months to put a lid on dissent, but protests, which officials describe as part of a ''revolutionary onslaught,'' have continued. Last week, harsh penalties were announced for an expanded list of activities deemed subversive and censorship was imposed on reporting of dissent and Government countermeasures.

title: FINE FOODS AS HOLIDAY GIFTS
description: AS THE holiday shopping countdown begins in earnest, what better - and simpler - way to capture the festive spirit than with a gift of fine food?

title: Newton Jury Is Adjourned
description: Jurors adjourned for the weekend Friday without deciding whether the entertainer Wayne Newton was defamed in a series of 1980-81 NBC News reports. The 10-member jury recessed until Monday, when it will start its fourth day of deliberations.

title: Miss Bottomley Wed To Robert Philip Smit
description: Anne Louise Bottomley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Bottomley of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Philip Smit, the son of Patricia Smit of New York and the late Philip Daniel Smit. The Revs.

title: An Envelope Please
description: The United States Postal Service released the 8.5-cent Mayflower embossed envelope on Dec. 4 in Plymouth, Mass. Although a formal first day ceremony had been planned for June 17, the envelope was issued without ceremony due to an uncertainty about the postal rate.

title: U.S. ENVOY REPORTS ADMIRAL TOLD HIM SHULTZ KNEW PLAN
description: The United States Ambassador to Lebanon reported to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that he had been personally assured by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter that Mr. Shultz had no objections to private ''back channel'' communications to handle negotiations for the release of American hostages in Lebanon, State Department officials said.

title: DOLE URGES REAGAN TO MEET U.S. ALLIES TO CLARIFY IRAN CASE
description: Calling the diversion of profits from Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebels ''just plain stupid,'' Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, urged President Reagan today to call a summit meeting with allies on the foreign policy crisis.

title: U.S.-Soviet TV Swap
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TOUGH KIDS': READERS RESPOND
description: Since I live in Mastic and attend William Floyd High School, I am interested as to where the reporter got her statistics. Many of the facts in the article I am not aware of as true: The average gross adjusted income in the Mastic-Shirley area is $18,000, the second lowest in the county, and most homes are headed by a single parent.

title: MOTORISTS FIND FRIENDS ON HIGHWAYS
description: Stranded on Route 128 with a flat tire, Jim Gasse waited in his gold-colored Volvo for a good Samaritan.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Sunday starts the TV week with some rounded, well-timed film fare. ''Those Daring Young Men in Their Jaunty Jalopies'' (1969) - at 12:15 P.M. on Channel 5 - is good, frisky family fun about a picturesque assortment of 20's cars in a madcap continental race. The sporting cast is headed by Tony Curtis, Susan Hampshire and Terry-Thomas. Though unoriginal, ''White Christmas'' (1950) - at 2:30 P.M., same station -makes pleasant listening with Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye, Rosemary Clooney and Vera-Ellen and seasonal Irving Berlin songs. With the toddlers tucked in bed, try ''48 Hours'' (1982) - 9 P.M. on NBC. This tough, fast and funny police-sleuthing package teams Nick Nolte and, in his screen debut, Eddie Murphy, to wonderfully salty effect.

title: Some Sympathy For Knight . . .
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 4 Players Ejected As Sheffield Wins
description: Four players were sent off before halftime of an English League Second Division soccer game today.

title: STATE HAILS ALTERNATIVE TEACHER ROUTE
description: THE New Jersey provisional teacher program -the alternative route to teacher certification -continues to draw a substantial number of highly qualified candidates, according to the state's Department of Education.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULES BY PRETORIA
description: Following are excerpts from South Africa's tightened emergency regulations, announced Thursday: 'Subversive Statement'

title: RECITA: CONTI-GUGLIA PIANO DUO
description: HALF of the Conti-Guglia brothers's evening of duo-piano music at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night was made up of ''authentic'' versions of orchestral works. The authenticity lay in the fact that these arrangements - the Brahms ''Haydn Variations'' and ''Les Preludes'' by Liszt -originated from the composers themselves.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Practical Traveler column of Nov. 9 gave an incorrect telephone number of a newsletter known as The Privileged Traveler. The number is 914-769-3833.

title: Toxic Gas Forces I-80 Closure
description: A small cloud of potentially lethal gas escaped today during the cleanup of hazardous chemicals from a truck that ran off Interstate 80 a week ago, and the authorities closed a 35-mile stretch of the road for a second time.

title:
FILM VIEW;
At 50, the Cinematheque Looks Ahead
description: The gray curtain slid open in the Cinematheque Francaise theater the other evening and the audience settled down for a nightlong, 11-hour festival of old films - ending with breakfast at 8 A.M.

title: ST. JOHN'S OVERCOMES U.C.L.A.
description: Willie Glass had just finished his post-game interviews yesterday and was leaving when Reggie Miller, U.C.L.A.'s star forward and Glass's archrival, began to answer his first question.

title: ASSESSING WAYS TO MAKE TEACHING MORE ATTRACTIVE
description: IMAGINE a public school where teachers earn $60,000 a year or more. Also, these teachers -freed from tasks such as monitoring halls, lunchrooms and playgrounds, and assisted by aides, teacher interns and local business people - can spend their entire day working directly with students. Suppose, too, that a committee of teachers runs the school and that there are plenty of opportunities for professional growth.

title: Hanford Closes For Upgrading
description: Among the aging facilities used by the United States Government to make raw material for nuclear weapons and fuel for submarines, the plutonium production reactor at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Richland, Wash., is one of the most powerful and troubled. For national security reasons it cannot be shut down permanently, the Energy Department asserted last week, but it will be closed for a $50 million upgrading, to start up in six months under a new contractor.

title: A CHRISTMAS TRADITION: HELP THE NEEDIEST
description: Caroline S. is very excited about her future. When the 21-year-old woman talks about her plans to become a nurse, her eyes glow and her warm smile grows larger than ever.

title: Audrey Canning, Editor, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Canning Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Canning's daughter, Audrey Kate Canning, to Karl Hendricks Trieschman, a son of Nancy Eaton Trieschman of Concord, Mass., and the late Dr. Albert Ewell Trieschman. A June wedding is planned.

title: Jazz
description: Last summer Vince Giordano broke up his 12-piece band, the Nighthawks, after 10 years of increasing success in the jazz styles of the 1920's and early 1930's. Fortunately, this was just a hiatus during which Mr. Giordano reconsidered the makeup of his band and put together a lecture and concert for use at colleges.

title: Audio Accessories To Stuff Stockings
description: If your audio gift list doesn't require the low-priced, mid-priced or high-end equipment discussed here over the last few weeks, there still remain the stocking-stuffer-priced gifts - a cornucopia of gadgets collectively known as audio accessories.

title: GEORGETOWN STOPS ARIZONA TO GO 5-0
description: Reggie Williams scored 26 points and Georgetown held off a late threat for an 82-74 victory over Arizona at the Capital Centre today.

title: TEXAS IS TAKING A SWAT AT LITTERBUGS
description: CHECK out the latest pop music video to hit Texas. Here come the Fabulous Thunderbirds, a hot 50's revival group out of Austin, roaring along in a 1953 convertible: Well you're ridin' down that highway In your big ol' fancy car. Got that radio a blastin', And you're feelin' like a star. Zoomin' down that Texas highway, And you've got a heavy load.

title: DON'T TELL A BABY BOOMER WHAT TO DO
description: THE CLASH OF CULTURES Managers and Professionals. By Joseph A. Raelin. 299 pp. Boston: Harvard Business School Press. $19.95.

title: TEACHING IS NOT SHOW BUSINESS
description: In response to ''A Sponsor for the Teacher?,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 23:

title: MUSIC: SELLARS, BYRHARD AND BLACK IN NEW WORKS
description: The Friday night collaborative program of works for voices, synthesizer and double bass featuring James Sellars, Finn Byrhard and Robert Black at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation was most successful when the composers and performers put aside their theorizing and concentrated only upon making music.

title: Save the Lectures, Give Us Some Help
description: COMMERCE Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has singled out the consumer electronics industry as a ''notable example'' of an American management system that ''failed to apply and follow through'' on its own inventions. In a recent speech, he stated: ''Our loss of the color television market is unforgivable. We pioneered that technology.''

title: Soviet Retires Iceland Envoy
description: The Soviet Union has announced the retirement of its Ambassador to Iceland, who reportedly mishandled arrangements during the Soviet-American summit meeting in October.

title: Japanese Evacuees Allowed To Go Home After Eruptions
description: Thousands of people who were evacuated last month from a small Japanese island because of volcanic eruptions will be allowed to return home next week, the Governor of Tokyo said Friday.

title: A Charge Denied
description: When one's pockets reach a certain depth, the authorities sometimes take a keen interest in how money moves from one to another. Last week, the New York State Attorney General's office disclosed that it had a question or two about which bundle of money Harry and Leona Helmsley had dipped into to finance renovations at their $8 million estate in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Helmsley's company, Helmsley-Spear Inc., owns properties valued at about $5 billion, including the Empire State Building.

title: IN HONG KONG, WANING BRITISH INFLUENCE YIELDS -- TO YANKS
description: A British broadcaster here made a provocative suggestion to his viewers the other day.

title: Finding Memorable Tempura in Tokyo
description: Along with sushi, soba (buckwheat noodles) and unagi (eel), tempura is one of the four best loved foods of Tokyoites. It is probably the dish that most readily comes to mind with the words Japanese food. But tempura is not a native Japanese dish; it was brought to the islands by the Portuguese in the late 16th century. It is said that the name derives from a corruption of the word temple (pronounced tenpuru in Japanese) where, unnamed sources say, tempura, as it is commonly called in English, was enjoyed every Friday. This spurious etymology aside, there is no question that tempura was one of the favorite foods of the people of the burgeoning city of Edo (present-day Tokyo) and now of Japan's urban centers.

title: Heron Island
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from Heron Island, on the Great Barrier Reef off the northeast coast of Australia, and have just caught up with ''Walking Along the Great Barrier Reef'' by James V. Risser (Travel, Nov. 2).

title: DOESN'T ANYBODY 'BUY AMERICAN' THESE DAYS?
description: BEHIND all the official hand wringing over the size of the United States trade deficit lies a rather simple truth. American consumers - sometimes by choice, sometimes by necessity and sometimes without even knowing it - increasingly fill their shopping carts with goods produced abroad.

title: ADDRESSING NEEDS OF 'AT RISK' PUPILS
description: ''WHEN students drop out,'' observed Marie Ramirez, executive director of the Center for Multinational and Comparative Education in Albany, ''what do they drop into? Drugs, alcohol, prostitution and crime. Our most recent statistics on the relationship of alcohol to substance use among secondary students paints a very gloomy picture for the future of our youth. When we look at students enrolled in grades seven through 12, we find that 40 percent, or 601,000 have used alcohol, 8 percent or 122,000 kids have used drugs and alcohol and 25 percent or 382,000 have used both in combination, destroying their lives - that is a slow form of suicide.''

title: LE GRAND DOCTEUR
description: IN AFRICA WITH SCHWEITZER By Edgar Berman. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: New Horizon Press/ Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: Raid on French Villa Ends Inmates' Escape
description: Police officers filled a suburban villa with a disabling gas today and captured two escapees from a Rome prison, the Interior Ministry said.

title: STORES IN COUNTY STRUGGLE TO FIND SEASONAL SALES HELP
description: IT has become a sign of the season. In Westchester's shopping malls it is almost as ubiquitous as holly and ivy and huge banners advertising sales. It is the ''help wanted'' sign. Others offer ''management opportunities'' or ''career advancement,'' but the theme is the same: extra employees to stock shelves and run cash registers and show off the Christmas line to the expected hordes of shoppers.

title: NEW DISPUTE ON PINE BARRENS
description: A PROPOSED Suffolk County law designed to broaden the environmental review for projects planned in the pine barrens has put officials concerned about the environment at odds with builders and other officials who say the law is not needed.

title: 2 QUESTIONED IN PALME CASE, BUT MYSTERY GOES ON
description: Two men identified as Kurdish political activists were arrested after a barroom shootout and questioned by the police tonight in their investigation into the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: NEW FEDERAL TAX RULES MAKE WAVES AMONG STATES
description: SO intertwined are the levels of American government that almost any change in the fiscal arrangements of one can have important consequences for the others.

title: INSIDE EACH GARDENER ARE TWO PLANTSMEN
description: There are two gardeners at war inside each one of us. Gardener N1 wants a garden with form and an easily, recognizable beauty. His ideal may be England's Sissinghurst or America's Longwood Gardens. It may be a Japanese garden such as the one at Ryoan-Ji or it may even derive from Versailles. In other words a formal garden.

title: Women as Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Blues Are Sold
description: IT took a second round of round-the-clock negotiations to do it, but three years after Harry Ornest, a Los Angeles businessman, saved the Blues for St. Louis, Ornest has completed his sale of the team to an investor group headed by a local businessman, Michael F. Shanahan.

title: Raiders Free 2 Basques
description: Ten armed men broke into a prison in southern France early today, seized the warden and his daughter, and freed two Basque separatist prisoners before releasing the captives and fleeing, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Berkeley, Calif., (Travel, Nov. 9) gave an incorrect telephone number for Bed & Breakfast International. The number is 415-525-4569.

title: Some New Twists In the Boesky Affair
description: Ivan F. Boesky paid off $1.4 billion in debts with the S.E.C.'s knowledge just before he was charged with insider trading. The sum stunned many Wall Street traders, who had difficulty swallowing the $400 million figure previously disclosed. The S.E.C. had said it allowed Mr. Boesky to continue to protect participants in his investment funds and to prevent a broader selloff once the news of his involvement in the scandal became known. But many traders are angry that the S.E.C. would allow such activities. The S.E.C., meanwhile, has expanded its investigation of Mr. Boesky's activities to see if and how they were tied to other investors and to Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: HEBREW SCHOOLS LOSING STUDENTS IN NEW YORK
description: Enrollment in afternoon Hebrew schools in the New York metropolitan region is steadily declining, and educators say they are seeking to attract young Jews back to the classroom.

title: FACULTY IN RHODE ISLAND SPLITS ON VANE
description: An antique copper weather vane depicting a Wampanoag Indian chief is at the eye of an emotional storm that has split the faculty of Roger Williams College here.

title: COMPUTERS TO SPEED AID TO THE NEEDY
description: A NEW computer system to speed the awarding of Federal and state grants to the needy will also save millions of dollars and help implement new aid programs, state welfare officials say.

title: FOCUS: Affordability; Now More Can Buy A Home
description: THANKS to declining mortgage-interest rates and stable home prices, buyers will find that both new and old houses are more affordable now than they have been since 1978, according to two industry groups that regularly chart the relative affordability of housing in the nation.

title: MUSIC: DAVID SIMONS
description: IT was an evening for improvising at the Alternative Museum Wednesday night. David Simons and three colleagues brought us his ''Quartet for Improvisers,'' and the Jeffrey Schanzer Ensemble played three of Mr. Schanzer's half-planned, half-spontaneous pieces - ''Movement,'' ''No Pasaran'' and ''Vistas.''

title: 'Crime Story'- A Tale Of Formula Takeover
description: Watching the new series ''Crime Story'' on NBC this season has been a little like being a witness to a nasty accident, as violent as the show itself. While ratings slump to levels considerably below minimum-subsistence, the original concept for the gangster saga has been left so twisted and battered that it is now barely recognizable.

title: Recent Cassettes
description: Audubon Society's VideoGuide to the Birds of North America: Vol. I Written, directed and narrated by Michael A. Godfrey. Edited by John Ferrand Jr. MasterVision.

title: Books and Mass Appeal
description: As Waldenbooks expands, independent bookstores fold. The independents cannot compete with the chain's buying power or marketing apparatus. Since independents are usually the only outlets for literary works, especially those by new or less well-established authors, can we expect Waldenbooks to fill the void its expansion creates (short of requiring publishers to pay $3,500 to have a title listed in its brochure, ''Fiction Finds'')? DAVID $:OUIE Galesburg, Ill.

title: Stephanie L. Doering Weds Peter Clement
description: The wedding of Stephanie Lowell Doering to Peter Withington Clement took place yesterday at Old St. Davids Episcopal Church in St. Davids, Pa. The Rev. Rudolf A. Moore performed the ceremony.

title: ROBYN HITCHCOCK: PAIN UNDER THE WIT
description: The ground floor of the Tower Records downtown store was crowded wall to wall with curious onlookers on a recent afternoon. Choice standing room had been claimed an hour earlier; even the stairs leading to the store's second floor were packed.

title: NEW BRIDGE, AT A BARGAIN PRICE, ELATES TOWN
description: The people of this Northern Michigan hamlet are using their new steel swing bridge with a special feeling of triumph, even though it is incomplete.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Why One Team Will Peak While Another Falters
description: THE only thing in common that Giant and Jet fans (designation in alphabetical order) could have at the start of the 1986 season was the same dream: their team's trip to the Super Bowl. Since then, Giant and Jet fans' anxieties and opinions have to differ - with reason. Each team has played in some ball games that say ''We're a contender,'' and some that say ''We could well wind up a loser.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are no buyers. It's not profitable. No passenger service in the world is profitable.''

title: Tax Revisionism
description: 'One of the fairest ways to increase revenue will be to delay the tax-rate reductions for the wealthiest - families earning more than $150,000.'

title: STAGE: CYNTHIA HEIMEL COMEDY, 'GUIDE TO CHAOS'
description: EARLY in the play ''A Girl's Guide to Chaos,'' Cynthia, the leading character and alter ego of the author and wit Cynthia Heimel, asserts, ''I am Dorothy Parker - everyone knows that.'' The comparison, though offered ironically, is nevertheless apt. Like Dorothy Parker, Ms. Heimel is an urban romantic with a scathing X-ray vision that penetrates her most deeply cherished fantasies.

title: Hans Wiessmann and Judith Schwartzstein Wed
description: The marriage of Judith Ann Schwartzstein, a daughter of Etta Danilow Schwartzstein of Trenton and the late Frederick Schwartzstein, to Hans Dietrich Wiessmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wiessmann of Frankfurt, took place last night at the Spanish Institute in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ''DON'T come back,'' she said to me. ''Not as a patient. Maybe as a visitor, but not as a patient. Please.''

title: TV TRIBUTE TO MICHALAK
description: FROM 9 to 11 P.M. on Christmas Eve, WOR-TV (Channel 9) will repeat its broadcast of ''The Cathedral Symphony of Newark,'' a concert originally performed at the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Newark on Oct. 27, 1985.

title: Catholic Theologian David Tracy
description: The most one can glean from the excerpts of David Tracy's vague musings and the text of his interview is that his theology is not theology at all, but a tedious and overblown elaboration of a single modernist dogma: Staunch defense of orthodoxy is bad; ''change'' (apparently endless) and ''new interpretation'' (i.e. abandonment) of ''old'' doctrine are good.

title: Marcia Pearson Weds a Dentist
description: The marriage of Marcia Ayer Pearson, an account executive at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, an advertising agency in New York, to Dr. Victor Irven Sendax, a dentist in New York, took place yesterday in Washington. Canon Charles Martin performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Little Sanctuary at St. Albans School.

title: MATCHING ISRAEL :SYRIAN GOAL SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: Western diplomats based in Damascus say Syria appears unlikely to be able to achieve its stated goal of attaining strategic military parity with Israel in the foreseeable future.

title: RAFTING THROUGH EVOLUTION
description: THE RIVER THAT FLOWS UPHILL A Journey From the Big Bang to the Big Brain. By William H. Calvin. Illustrated. Maps. 528 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: Galbraith's View
description: To The Editor:

title: BY TROLLEY OR TRAIN, SANTA BRINGS MAGIC
description: FOUR-YEAR-OLD Dianne Riter of Meriden clapped her hands in delight, her ponytail bouncing.

title: Paris Evokes A Golden Past In a Restored Train Station
description: The newly opened Musee d'Orsay in Paris is above all things a historical adventure of a high order. Easier to enjoy than to define, it begins before the revolution of 1848 and comes to a halt around the time of the Salon d'Automne of 1905, in which Henri Matisse and others got themselves called ''the wild beasts'' by the critics of the day. (The name stuck, though not in a pejorative sense). The new museum represents this period with must pieces that everyone knows. Greater human statements than Gustave Courbet's ''Studio'' and Paul Cezanne's ''Woman With Coffee-Pot'' would be hard to find. It also covers the period in terms of not-so-great painting that not everyone knows, and of the architecture, the furniture, the household objects, the photographs, the jewelry and many another auxiliary domain. It reminds us of the cardinal dates, artistic and political, and it makes frontier raids on the social history of the times. No human being could respond with equal enthusiasm to everything that is on show, but then we are dealing not with a popularity contest but with history itself in all its guises.

title: AMERICA'S SERVICE ECONOMY BEGINS TO BLOSSOM -- OVERSEAS
description: SEVERAL times a week, a plane arrives in China carrying financial statements, mailing lists and other paperwork from several dozen American companies. In Beijing and other Chinese cities, about 500 key-punch operators, most of whom have no knowledge of English, transfer the information to computer tapes or disks. The electronic data are then flown to the United States. While the salary and benefits for an American doing equivalent work might be $6 to $12 an hour, the Chinese worker earns about $6 a day.

title: 'HISTORY WILL BEAR ME OUT'
description: WINSTON S. CHURCHILL Volume Seven: Road to Victory 1941-1945. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 1,417 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $40.

title: Put Lieutenant Governor On Utilities Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWNS KEY TO SEARCH FOR SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE
description: SUFFOLK County Republican leaders, searching for a County Executive candidate, are looking at some critical numbers.

title: COOL U.S. PARK ON FRINGE OF A DESERT
description: Al Hendricks swung his pickup off the road and stepped out into the cold mountain air. To his right was Wheeler Peak, a snow-crowned summit higher than any mountain in Yellowstone National Park. To his left was 60 daunting miles of sun-scorched desert.

title: FRIENDS AND FOES OF CONTRAS RALLY AT FLORIDA BASE
description: With signs, slogans and flags, two groups came together in opposition here today at the gate of Hurlburt Field.

title: Islanders Sweep Devils, Tie For Second
description: The Islander coach spoke of his team's ability to win those games they deem necessary to their stature. The Devils coach spoke of his team's inability to win in key situations and gain that type of stature.

title: ANNA RUSSELL TO MAKE LAST APPEARANCE AT 'Y'
description: ANNA RUSSELL, who has been called the prima donna of musical parody, has chosen the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey here as the last stop on her farewell tour.

title: Anne Hahn Plans Winter Wedding
description: The engagement of Anne Elizabeth Hahn to Dr. Jeffrey Peter Block has been announced by Anne Shriver Hahn of Berwyn, Pa., and Stephan Rene Hahn of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan A. Block of Camarillo, Calif.

title: MOSCOW, OFTEN A CAPTIVE
description: HUNGARY AND THE SOVIET BLOC By Charles Gati. 244 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. Cloth, $40. Paper, $14.95.

title: Miss Prine to Wed Matthew Neumeier
description: Annmarie Prine, the executive assistant to the director of political affairs at the White House, and Matthew M. Neumeier, who is to join the New York law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore as an associate at the end of the month, plan to be married Jan. 31.

title: Employee Incentives Will Increase Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Names, Young Readers
description: SOMETIMES it begins with a bedtime story, told over and over until it takes on the resonance of a beloved myth. Sometimes it begins as a publisher's scheme to make more money. And sometimes the idea just seems to pop out of the air like a genie.

title: WRITERS CAN BE FRIENDS
description: WE hear a great deal about writers' quarrels, and very little about their friendships. Why is that? This one got drunk and slept with that one's lover; then each took apart the other's book in a review. Famous writers are like our gods or our parents, figures whose charisma is so great that we can never get over their bad behavior behind the scenes. Writers' letters, moreover, are full of mean, brilliant remarks about other writers, and these little bursts of hatred are irresistible to chroniclers of the literary life. Literary friendships, on the other hand, are left to the writers of boring dissertations, like the one being written in Virginia Woolf's ''To the Lighthouse.'' ''The Influence of Somebody on Somebody'' is how this tract is invariably referred to.

title: They Don't Give Medals for Pleading the Fifth; That Man Grant
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH KOREA: THE NEXT WAVE
description: KIM JUNG SOO arrived at the Hyundai Motor Company nine years ago with all his belongings in two suitcases. He worked long hours at the factory in the small South Korean city of Ulsan, struggling to make cars on an assembly line that had yet to be automated. He had no place to live, so he slept on the floor of a friend's apartment. ''I was very poor,'' he recalls. ''The working conditions were not so good. I thought, 'How can I continue to work here in the future?' ''

title: YOU CAN'T GET THERE FROM HERE
description: THERE has been a lot of discussion lately about testing the vision of elderly drivers to insure that they can see well enough to drive. I agree with this proposal - but why should it be restricted to the elderly? Shouldn't every driver, whatever age, have good eyesight?

title: Mariners Reinforce the View They Run a Tight Ship
description: KEVIN McREYNOLDS and Danny Tartabull clearly were the two best players who were traded last week during the lethargic winter meetings. In trading McReynolds, the San Diego Padres acquired three players who they hope will help catapult them toward the top of the standing in a couple of years. In trading Tartabull, the Seattle Mariners helped insure themselves of maintaining their firm grip on last place in the salary standing.

title: The Big Bang
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison Hart Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Hart of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Leigh Hart to Peter Jay Schlosser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Schlosser of Livingston, N.J. Miss Hart and her fiance graduated from the Cornell University School of Architecture. She is an architect in the San Francisco office of the Architects Collaborative Inc. He is an architect at Stone, Marroccini & Patterson, architects in San Francisco.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHANCEL PLAYERS The Chancel Players of the Scarsdale Congregational Church will present their production of ''Gloria!'' at 3 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday in the church's Dyckman Hall at 1 Heathcote Road.

title: Japan's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael B. Exstein Weds Lida Greenberg, Executive
description: Lida Beth Greenberg and Michael B. Exstein were married yesterday at the Westbury Hotel by Rabbi Sydney H. Brooks.

title: POLAND'S UNMARKED, UNRESOLVED ANNIVERSARY
description: Five years after Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski ordered the army into the streets to crush the Solidarity trade union movement, Poland remains the most politically volatile nation in the Soviet bloc, facing deep economic problems and nagged by the yearnings born when the independent unions flowered.

title: ATLANTA IN A PINCH AMID PAY DEMANDS
description: Officials in Atlanta, pinched by cutbacks in Federal funds, are scrambling to find the money to pay next year's bills, including demands by the police and other city workers for better pay and benefits.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE New Jersey Environmental Federation held its second annual conference last weekend and celebrated its first year by recounting the successes of its member organizations in local efforts to have environmental laws enforced.

title: BUYERS WOO SAG HARBOR BANK
description: THE proposed sale of the Sag Harbor Savings Bank, the second oldest bank in Suffolk County, is viewed by some state and local banking officials as an indication of how small, independent banks could become a thing of the past.

title: FAMILY LIFE: LET TRENTON PUT ITS MONEY WHERE ITS MANDATE IS
description: STATE officials, legislators and the State Board of Education recently received some very important news:A poll taken in October by the independent polling firm of Penn and Schoen Associates of New York City showed ''sex education in the schools is now a 'consensus' issue because it is supported by over 90 percent of New Jerseyans.''

title: GIVING BABIES THE STAFF OF LIFE
description: CYNTHIA CALLOW and the Human Milk Bank at North Shore University Hospital were both born in 1979. Neither could have survived its first year without the other.

title: Can't Prague Even Leave Jazz Alone?
description: Of all the triumphs of life-haters today, of fun-haters today, of beauty-haters today, of thought-and-love-haters today, of the Forces of Satan, if you will, the one that most troubles my heart is the inducement of some Czechoslovak politicians and police to behave like cannibals toward the most humane and generous and gifted members of their own society.

title: PHILADELPHIA HOPES RISE BY 60 STORIES
description: Blue laser beams flashed across a city that sparkled in crisp winter darkness, dancing with orchestrated fireworks to the rhythms of ''Rhapsody in Blue'' and playing about the girders of One Liberty Place, the new skyscraper that was the evening's guest of honor.

title: Splendor of a Fading Venetian Art
description: Legend has it that lace-making began when a Venetian sailor, returning after a long voyage, brought his ladylove a gift of exotic seaweed called mermaid's lace. To while away the hours once the sailor was back at sea, the girl tried to re-create the intricate design of the seaweed in lace.

title: IT'S THAILAND NOT TAIWAN, BANGKOK SAYS
description: ''It is not so much what foreigners think of us, but rather their lack of information about this country that is the problem,'' Suvit Yodmani said as he tried to explain his job.

title: West Virginia's Aid For Welfare Resumes
description: West Virginia has resumed issuing welfare checks after a brief halt was ordered when the State Auditor said he had only $5 million to pay $65 million in bills, officials say.

title: OPEC IS STALLED ON PLAN TO RAISE PRICES
description: An agreement in principle by oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut output to raise prices ran into political and technical difficulties today, according to the ministers, who said they had decided to suspend their full conference sessions until Monday to bargain individually.

title: Airline Discount For Not Smoking
description: THE same day that the National Academy of Sciences urged a ban on smoking on all domestic airline flights for health and safety reasons, Continental Airlines said it would offer a 10 percent discount to any of its passenger who did not smoke.

title: SETON HALL OUTGUNS RUTGERS
description: James Major hit 14 of 15 shots from the field and scored a career-high 32 points tonight as Seton Hall made 82 percent of its field-goal attempts in the first half and went on to defeat Rutgers, 109-81. Seton Hall improved to 5-1 and Rutgers dropped to 2-3.

title: The Prepaid Room That Vanished
description: Among resorts, the Banff Springs Hotel in Alberta is classic. Built like a Scottish baronial castle, it is nestled in the Canadian Rockies and has an 18-hole golf course, five tennis courts, miles of trails for hiking and horseback riding and magnificent views. Like many other couples before them, Aaron and Lorraine Newman Mackler of Rockville, Md., thought it an ideal place to begin their honeymoon. The only problem was that upon arriving there about midnight last July 21, exhausted after 10 hours of travel, the Macklers found that despite their prepaid reservation, they could not get a room.

title: CUOMO NOMINATES 23 FOR JUDGESHIPS
description: Governor Cuomo sent 23 nominations to the State Senate yesterday afternoon to fill new judgeships to help relieve the paralyzing backlog in drug cases in New York City.

title: Dr. Eleanor Bellucci Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday, Dr. Eleanor Bellucci, the daughter of Dr. Eleanor DePaoli Belluci and Dr. Richard Bellucci of New York and Sands Point, L.I., was married to Russell Hartmann Handler, a son of Marjorie Brickman Kern of Kings Point, L.I., and Julian Handler of New York. The Rev. Ambrose Eckinger performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Silverman Plans To Wed Michael
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Silverman of Great Neck, L.I., have announced that their daughter Susan Silverman and Michael A. Braun plan to be married in March.

title: Mystery Man
description: BY THE TIME MY father killed himself, I'd met him on three occasions as a child in Costa Rica, one of which I may have imagined. I was 22 years old in May 1976, and at the Yale Graduate School, immersed in Old English, the Commedia, ''Lazarillo de Tormes,'' Hegel and the Romantics, Baudelaire and Rilke, practicing a discipline curiously defined as ''comparative literature.''

title: QUICK TRIP TO BANK IS A BALANCING ACT
description: IT was the holiday season and while everyone else was wondering what gimmick the banks would be offering to get people to start a Christmas club for next year, I was looking for a new bank in a different city altogether. You see I have no friend at Chase Manhattan and my Anchor Banker would rather I drift far away.

title: DANCE: DUDLEY WILLIAMS IN AILEY'S 'LOVE SONGS'
description: IT was Dudley Williams night when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed at City Center on Wednesday. Mr. Williams, an early member of the Ailey company, can still fill the stage with his subtle presence.

title: Patricia J. Owens And B.C. Hurlock To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Stuart Owens of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Jane Owens to Burton Charls Hurlock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bickford Hurlock of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: NO ONE IS SAVED BY LOVE
description: NOVEMBER By Janet Hobhouse. 198 pp. New York: Vintage Books/Random House. Paper, $6.95.

title: Loosing a Whirlwind on Your Files
description: By nature I'm a pile builder, as regular readers of this column know, and were I wont to post clever signs by my work space, no doubt the one proclaiming that ''an orderly desk is the sign of a deranged mind'' would be the most suitable. My stacks of press releases, news clippings, software and scribbled notes on narrow-lined yellow pads overflow my three desks onto a number of adjoining 4 by 8 trestle tables and from there onto the couch and (embarrassingly enough for a father who stresses to his children the virtues of a tidy room) even the floor.

title: No Place for Peace
description: NATIONAL Hockey League officials have brushed off a warning from Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston that he will send the police on the ice if necessary to stop fighting among hockey players in Bruin games at Boston Garden.

title: DANCE: CHAING CHING IN SOLO CONCERT OF DIVERSE STYLES
description: CHIANG CHING'S solo dance concert on Friday night at the Asia Society included contributions from distinguished artists in other fields. It is as an integrated picture in which choreography is only one element that her dancing must be viewed.

title: MASTER OF THE SENTIMENTAL SELL
description: FROM ITS BEGINNINGS, ADVERTISING HAS appealed to or (depending on one's point of view) manipulated peoples' emotions. Traditionally, these were emotions associated with self-interest: hunger, vanity, insecurity and the sex drive. This year, a 54-year-old named Hal Riney is coming to prominence in the ad industry by touching loftier sentiments.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMONG FRIENDS: Who We Like, Why We Like Them, and What We Do With Them. By Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.)

title: Sensitive Restoration Has Made A Great Building Better
description: If you seek evidence that civilization has made some small bits of progress in the last generation - that all has not been total decline - then it is worth taking a look at a page in the Life magazine of Sept. 9, 1957. It is headlined ''A Red Tower Replaces Carnegie Hall,'' and it announces, with a tone almost amounting to pride, a skyscraper that at that time seemed certain to take the place of the great concert hall.

title: TWOSIES...THREESIES: WINNING THE GAME AND MY DAUGHTER
description: ''NO kidding, Ma, you really know how to play jacks?'' my almost-10-year-old daughter asked me in disbelief.

title: A Daughter Found
description: Two widely disparate searches ended when New York City police officers took over the Bronx apartment of Judith Cottes and her children and talked a fugitive gunman in an adjacent unit into surrendering. In news stories about the arrest of Larry Davis, an accused mass murderer, the Cottes name caught the eye of Raymond Bryant of St. Petersburg, Fla. Mr. Bryant is a retired New York transit worker who had spent years searching for a former girlfriend named Cottes and the daughter she bore him in 1964.

title: GROUPS RESPOND TO STUDY OF AGING
description: A NUMBER of suggestions for new programs for the elderly and for improving and coordinating existing services in the county emerged from the first Westchester County Aging Society Project Conference held recently in White Plains.

title: Margaret Saul Weds C. J. G. Hutchings
description: Margaret Mary Saul, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Saul of Summit, N.J., and Christopher John Greaves Hutchings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Keell Hutchings of Perth, Australia, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Puckett performed the ceremony at the Northside United Methodist Church in Atlanta.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Old Steel Site Goes High-Tech
description: FOR 122 years, the bright red glow from the blast furnaces of the Second Avenue plant of Jones & Laughlin Steel Company, later the LTV Corporation, was a tangible symbol of this city's industrial might.

title: Disclosures Are Burying Key Issues
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S initial strategy for containing the damage after the disclosures of Iranian arms deals seemed to be collapsing last week.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY PLAN LETS CHECK CASHERS SELL SUBWAY TOKENS
description: The Transit Authority has approved an experimental effort to sell tokens in 320 check-cashing shops around New York City.

title: REAGAN BUDGET PROPOSES SELLING PART OF AMTRAK
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year proposes the sale of Amtrak's Northeast passenger line, serving New York, Washington and Boston, Administration officials said today.

title: MAGAZINE AIMED AT PARENTS
description: MANY adults build sandcastles in the air. But when Jacqueline McCord Leo and Mary Anne Sommers hosted a sandcastle-building party for children last August on the beach in Sagaponack, they were celebrating the birth of their joint offspring, Child, a bimonthly designed for parents who can afford to give their children the best of everything.

title: Ms. Voute Plans To Marry Officer Of Marine Corps
description: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Voute to Lieut. Peter Anthony Gudmundsson, U.S.M.C., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Voute of Bronxville, N.Y. Lieutenant Gudmundsson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivar Gudmundsson of McLean, Va.

title: Scientists Teach A Dog's Muscle A Vital New Trick
description: Like any muscle, the heart needs a constant supply of nutrients and oxygen. In cases of atherosclerosis, fatty deposits constrict the vessels feeding the heart.

title: COMMISSION SET TO RECRUIT AND SCREEN NEW JUDGES
description: CONNECTICUT is changing the way it selects and approves its judges after the adoption of a constitutional change and a series of battles over judicial nominations this year in the General Assembly.

title: FARMERS FINDING A VOICE IN NEW VERMONT GROUP
description: Farmers are a quiet bunch, Jack E. Starr Sr. was saying, unlikely to tell their neighbors their problems. But farmers, he said, are learning that silence does not pay.

title: Question Of the Week; Is There Collusion On Free Agents?
description: Ha! To pose the question is to answer it. Besides, how else to explain George Steinbrenner's nonpursuit of Jack Morris? JEFFREY KANTOWITZ

title: L.I.R.R. MOVES TO KEEP ROLLING THROUGH WINTER MONTHS
description: The Long Island Rail Road is running with scattered 10-minute delays systemwide. -From a recent radio broadcast on a cold, sunny day.

title: Challenge on 'Ceremony'
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTORS IMPROVISE VIOLENCE FOR POLICE
description: DRESSED in camouflage pants and a sweatshirt, the thin man sat tensely in an armchair, staring at his mother as she paced back and forth, sobbing.

title: LITERARY CHANGE IS SEEN IN WRITERS' CONFERENCE AT PRINCEETON
description: FIVE award-winning authors, all women associated with Princeton University, gathered here last week to read from their works and discuss topics of concern for female writers.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AMAHL AND THE NIGHT VISITORS By Gian Carlo Menotti. Illustrated by Michele Lemieux. 64 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15. (Ages 5 and up) THE TWELVE DAYS OF CHRISTMAS Illustrated by Jan Brett. Unpaged. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $13.95. (Ages 2 and up) q

title: REBELS IN THEIR OWN WAY
description: COLLECTED STORIES #1948-1986. By Wright Morris. 274 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Medicaid Irregularities Found in Inspections
description: New York State officials have barred 53 South Bronx doctors and druggists from the Medicaid program after a series of unannounced inspections turned up evidence of unnecessary prescriptions and medical services.

title: TWO CULTURES ARE ONE TOO MANY
description: LANGUAGES OF NATURE Critical Essays on Science and Literature. Edited by L. J. Jordanova. 351 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $30.

title: SAN JOSE STATE TAKES BOWL
description: Mike Perez passed for three touchdowns to pace Sna Jose State to a 37-7 victory over Miami of Ohio in the California Bowl today.

title: A CLASH THAT'S NO LONGER RHETORICAL
description: THE Honduran and Nicaraguan military have much to disagree about. The Honduran officer corps is traditional, conservative and, above all, anti-Communist. Across the border, it faces Marxist revolutionaries dedicated to class struggle and radical social change. Honduran military power depends on weapons from the United States, while Nicaraguan hardware comes from Cuba and the Soviet bloc. Each ruling group would be happy to see the other overthrown. ''They are natural enemies,'' a Latin American diplomat said.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.;
Condos Come To the Charles
description: IN a neighborhood once home to nothing but small factories like the one where the original Davenport sofa was made, ground has been broken for a condominium housing complex that to many people marks this neighborhood's arrival as a prime residential attraction.

title: PLANT FINALLY FINDS A VERMONT HOME
description: When Decker Energy International proposed a energy plant burning wood chips in Randolph earlier this year, residents fought it fiercely, citing environmental and health concerns.

title: Bishops Providing Leadership on Social Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: Flight Benefits
description: To the Editor: I found Paul Grimes's article on deeply discounted foreign flights (Practical Traveler, Nov. 23) very interesting. However, I believe his pessimism about reimbursement by airlines for time in transit in intermediate cities to be unwarranted.

title: NOT LIKE THE REST OF US
description: LEARNED PIGS & FIREPROOF WOMEN By Ricky Jay. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Villard Books. $29.95.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: 18 REPORTED KILLED IN RENEWED BATTLES IN SOUTHERN BEIRUT
description: Heavy fighting broke out again today around Palestinian districts on the southern outskirts of Beirut, with shells and rockets falling on residential areas. The police said 18 people were killed and 55 were wounded.

title: LIBRARY CLOCK PAYS TRIBUTE TO BIBLIOPHILE
description: In the quiet of the Mercantile Library, the chimes of the new wall clock only enhance the serenity of the place. And this is what the donor, Paul Hofstein, hoped for when he recently gave the handsome glass and mahogany timepiece to the library in memory of his brother, David.

title: Suspect Kills a Man, Then Flees 2 Officers
description: Moments after killing a 34-year-old man yesterday on a Brooklyn streetcorner, a man pointed a Uzi submachine gun at two approaching police officers, then fled when they opened fire on him, the police said.

title: Meg Marion to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Haig Costikyan of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter Margaret Wood Marion to John Brooks Lobkowicz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin G. Lobkowicz of Dover, Mass. The future bride, known as Meg, is a daughter also of the late B. Pope Marion. She is an advertising sales account manager for Good Housekeeping magazine. Mr. Lobkowicz is an account executive with McCann-Erickson Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: NOVELIST MYTHICIZES SUBURBS
description: ''I DON'T make fun of the suburbs,'' said Meg Wolitzer, the 27-year-old author of the recently published novel ''Hidden Pictures,'' set in the Long Island suburbs. ''I'd rather mythicize them than parody them.''

title: RADIO READING PROGRAM SERVING BLIND
description: DOROTHY HUDAK and Olan Turner sat behind microphones at the large round table scanning the carefully clipped and laid-out news articles and pausing occasionally to check the time on the wall clock.

title:
WINE;
SPARKLING CHOICES AT SPARKLING PRICES
description: A RECENT sampling of sparkling wines selling at local retail outlets for less than $10 a bottle revealed some outstanding bargains. The products evaluated were 8 of the 16 top choices in a blind tasting of more than 100 different brands available in the New York City area, conducted by Manhattan's International Wine Center.

title: Boycott Is Suspended At Emergency Rooms
description: Neurosurgeons have halted for 60 days a boycott of emergency rooms at five Dade County hospitals while medical leaders search for answers to soaring malpractice costs.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING POINSETTIAS THROUGH THE YEAR
description: HOW about that poinsettia that you kept from last season? Has it colored so that it will be presentable for the Christmas holiday? If not, why has it turned out to be a disappointment?

title: Bored With C. S. Lewis?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran 1: What Needs to Be Known
description: Six weeks into the Iran-contra crisis, the public remains adrift with only scattered facts to grasp in a sea of questions. They are pressing questions. The crisis arises not because of a partisan desire to punish the President but because of the widest fears that leadership and orderly governmental process have broken down.

title: DO MAYORS HAVE COMPARABLE WORTH?
description: MAYOR Koch was dubbed the ''Million-Dollar Mayor'' when he said he could get 10 times his municipal salary -$110,000 - in private business. Now some kind of raise appears probable, not only for Mr. Koch but for other elected city officials, under a new system whereby a panel of outside compensation experts will make recommendations. The legislation was passed unanimously by the City Council last week, at the behest of Majority Leader Peter F. Vallone, and Mr. Koch has said he will sign it.

title: Boesky's Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUBLES INFEST SYSTEM FOR MAKING PLUTONIUM
description: The nation's system for producing nuclear material for bombs and submarines is antiquated, ailing and sloppy, posing dangers to thousands of workers in the plants and to some of the people who live near them, according to many experts familiar with the situation.

title: DANCE: FAISON'S 'SUITE OTIS'
description: GEORGE FAISON'S ''Suite Otis'' is subtitled ''A Tribute to the Late Otis Redding.'' It is a vibrant tribute that captures the spirit of six funny and tender songs sung by Mr. Redding, and it received a mostly vibrant performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday at City Center.

title: THE STAGE: 'KILL,' BY HUGH LEONARD
description: AWORLD-CLASS tennis player, a circus aerialist, anyone, even a fine playwright, can have an off day. This is the most plausible explanation for ''Kill,'' a new play by Hugh Leonard, at the Apple Corps Theater. Although there is a death in the play, this is not, as one might assume from the title, a murder mystery. It is an unfunny comedy, written with -in Mr. Leonard's case - uncommon vulgarity.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The illustration credits with Business Forum last week were incorrect. The artist was Cathy Hull.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Recount Sought In Boston Census BECAUSE of a dispute over the accuracy of the 1985 Massachusetts state census, the City of Boston may begin an unusual effort to pinpoint what its population was two years ago.

title: FAST'S AIM IS DEATH OR A HALT IN ARMS
description: Dr. Charles Hyder has spent much of his life fighting the spread of nuclear arms, and now he says he is ready to die for his beliefs.

title: Social Events; Season for Helping
description: Two AIDS Benefits Dec. 15 - More than a score of Broadway songwriters and singers including Cy Coleman, Jerry Herman, Tom Jones, Larry Kert, Stephen Schwartz, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, will perform at an 8 P.M. benefit at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. The evening benefits several groups concerned with helping those afflicted with AIDS. Tickets, which may be charged, $100 for performance and party with the cast afterwards, or $15, $25 and $50 for performance alone, 1 to 8 P.M. from 212-279-4200. Dec. 16 - A special performance of Alvin Ailey's newest work, ''Caverna Magica,'' will be the highlight of a benefit evening for Aidsfilms, a not-for-profit group that promotes educational information on AIDS. Tickets, $50 for 8 P.M. performance alone at the City Center; $100 for a 6 P.M. Champagne reception and the performance; $250 for preferred seating at the performance and supper afterward in the homes of ''distinguished New Yorkers,'' all from 212-997-1950, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Humanitarian Dinner Dec. 16 - For the past 31 years, United Cerebral Palsy of New York has raised $7.5 million from its annual Humanitarian Awards Dinners to help maintain 21 facilities for children and adults. This year's black-tie dinner starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails at the Waldorf-Astoria will honor Walter H. Annenberg, chairman of Triangle Publications, and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, whose son, James, has cerebral palsy. Tickets, $300 and $350, from 212-683-6700.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of the medical adviser to the Millburn-Short Hills Volunteer First-Aid Squad was misspelled last week in an article about a disaster drill at The Mall at Short Hills.

title: House Democrats Pick Their Leaders
description: Celebratory House Democrats caucused on Capitol Hill last week to select the men who will lead them when the 100th Congress convenes in January. For the two top jobs, balloting was a matter of form.

title: RAISING BARGE: A NEW SETBACK
description: A salvage crew of more than 100 workers began carefully raising a wrecked barge out of the Niagara River today in an operation that was delayed for two weeks.

title: IT'S BETTER IN AMERICA
description: SEA CHANGES By Robert Kotlowitz. 275 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $17.95.

title: Curricula Vitae
description: Representative Claude Pepper, fresh from being renamed chairman of the House Rules Committee this week, will now be able to add another line to his record-length biography in the Congressional Directory. At 94 lines, Mr. Pepper's already is substantially the longest entry of all senators and rep=resentatives listed.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This looks to me like the old bait-and-switch: Take away deductions by promising lower rates, then jack up the rates as soon as you can get away with it.'' - Senator Bob Dole, Kansas Republican, on House Speaker's proposal to raise taxes for the wealthy.
