title: University of Vermont Gets >Biggest >Gift >Ever
description: A graduate of the University of Vermont has given the school $1.3 million toward the construction of a building for the School of Business Administration.

title: JUSTICE DEPT., FIRST PRAISED, NOW DRAWS BLAME IN CRISIS
description: The Justice Department, which initially drew praise for its handling of the Iran arms investigation, is coming under increasing scrutiny by legislators and others who ask whether the department should now share blame for the crisis.

title: Privilege and Limits
description: I am writing in response to Joanne Friedman's letter concerning the death in October of a 17-year-old girl, from a private school, who was killed by a hit-and-run driver at 3 A.M. on the Upper East Side (Letters, Nov. 9, in response to ''The Right Age at the Right Time,'' by William Hamilton, About Men, Oct. 12). Ms. Friedman ''sympathizes'' for a moment with the girl's parents but then goes on to suggest that they failed to provide their daughter with ''love,'' ''responsibility'' and ''limits.''

title: POSTINGS: Catskills Expansion; 60 Rooms At Kutsher's
description: Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., which stretches across 1,000 acres in the Catskill Mountains, has for 80 years tried to make sure that there never would be a dull moment for its guests. Those who stay at this family resort are kept busy with aerobics, bridge, folk dancing, games of Simon Says and formal discussions whose topics can range from the stock market to cosmetics.

title: BURLINGTON: THE FRUITS OF EFFORT
description: MORE than 300 years after its founding, and a decade after the beginning of a continuing restoration effort begun by local residents, this former capital of the colonial province of West New Jersey is evolving into a showcase of what can be accomplished when architectural preservation becomes a community priority.

title: When 'No Plans' Means 'Get Ready'
description: PREVARICATE IS rooted in the Latin for ''to walk crookedly'' and is now a highfalutin synonym for the verb ''to lie.'' A more subtle form of misleading can be called postvarication; this word has been freshly minted to denote the technique of setting forth an untruth in such a way that the listener will later find that the postvaricator had not actually been lying. Indeed, this verbal device, frequently used in Washington and other political capitals, includes a deliberate signal to the listener that less than the truth is being told.

title: Joan E. Stearns Wed To Robert J. Johnsen
description: Joan Ellen Stearns, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Stearns of Boca Raton, Fla., and Robert J. Johnsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Johnsen of Oakwood Heights, S.I., were married yesterday at Bargemusic in Brooklyn. Rabbi Joel Goor and Msgr.

title: VIDEOTAPES USED TO PLACE ORPHANS
description: In the two-minute videotape segment taped at a zoo, Maggie, a 14-year-old who is up for adoption, comes across as a spunky, talkative girl with a lively face. ''Stop looking so serious, lion!'' she exclaims. Later she says jokingly, ''He keeps looking at me like he knows me.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE FUNERAL BUSINESS
description: THE funeral business has changed dramatically since Jessica Mitford's 1963 best seller, ''The American Way of Death,'' brought the industry's abuses to national attention.

title: SCHOOL LAB STIRS SAFETY DEBATE
description: THE Lawrence High School Parent-Teacher Association has charged that the district's Board of Education has failed to take action to make the school's chemistry laboratory safe.

title: FUN LIKE VERDI WANTED IT
description: ZEFFIRELLI The Autobiography of Franco Zeffirelli. By Franco Zeffirelli. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: TOWN MOURNS LOSS OF ITS OLD HOTEL
description: A BIT of this historic community along the Toms River was lost earlier this month when fire destroyed the late-19th-century Edgewater Hotel.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOST. By Gary Devon. (Knopf, $17.95.) Gary Devon's suspenseful psychodrama begins with a rush when 12-year-old Sherman Abbott shoots himself in the head while his 8-year-old sister, Mamie, watches.

title: ROCK: THE BAND ANTIETAM
description: ANTIETAM brought its furiously intricate rock to Speakeasy on Wednesday night, tearing into songs in which so much happens so fast that they threaten to fly apart.

title: CHAMPIONING THE NEW MUSIC
description: STUTTGART, SAARBRUCKEN, BONN: the meat-and-potatoes circuit of German music. One of its busier and more respected conductors these days is a 42-year-old American. At a time of heightened anti-Americanism in Europe, he is about to take over as general music director of Bonn - conducting its symphony orchestra and in charge of its festivals, music programming and opera house - and this in West Germany's capital, Beethoven's birthplace, no less. To do so, he leaves his post as music director of the $60-million-a-year state opera house in Stuttgart. And yet, his musical ''home'' is with the American Composers Orchestra, a pioneering group founded a decade ago in a smoky jazz bar in Greenwich Village. On January 11, Dennis Russell Davies, a founder and music director of the now highly respected A.C.O., will conduct the first concert of its season in Carnegie Hall.

title: Competition for the Nuclear Family
description: Unmarried couples living together (as a percent of all households)

title: CONCERT FEATURES PERIOD INSTRUMENTS
description: FOR Thomas Crawford, conductor of the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra, organizing a concert of early music on authentic and period instruments goes beyond the mystique of gut strings.

title: RESPITE MASKS PHILADELPHIA HIGHWAY WOES
description: There was good and bad news here this week for the thousands of commuters who use the Schuylkill Expressway.

title: Augustana Wins Title Again
description: Brad Price ran for 169 yards and three touchdowns as Augustana of Illinois defeated Salisbury State, 31-3, today for its fourth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III championship.

title: Ewing's 43 Not Enough
description: The Atlanta Hawks, pro basketball's most successful and exciting team this season, held a special evening practice last night at Madison Square Garden and 14,425 spectators came to watch. The Hawks invited the Knicks to participate, but only eight were healthy enough to play.

title: Elizabeth Brown To Marry in April
description: Mrs. Moreau D. Brown Jr. of Darien, Conn., has announced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Elizabeth Thayer Brown, to John Berwick Warters, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Warters of Lincroft, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: Galbraith's View
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: VIRGINIUS DABNEY'S VIRGINIA: Writings About the Old Dominion. By Virginius Dabney. Introduction by Tom Wolfe. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill/Taylor Publishing, $24.95.)

title: TASTING CUBA IN MIAMI'S LITTLE HAVANA
description: Well-to-do Cubans flock to the Little Havana neighborhood of Miami to return to their culinary roots - sweet potato, cassava, malanga, carrots, yams and potatoes, to name just a few.

title: MODERNIZING L.I.'S MAIL FACILITIES
description: I would like to clarify some points of information in the Nov. 16 story ''New $30 Million Mail Facility to Speed the 22-Cent Letter.''

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: WASHINGTON. By James Reston. (Macmillan, $17.95.) This collection of columns by James Reston, who writes the Washington column on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, ranges through five Presidencies, China, sports, universities, Congress and the press, among other subjects.

title: Lisa Hutchings and Richard C. D. Cox Plan to Be Married in Bermuda in Jun e
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Ford Hutchings of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Hutchings, to Richard Carlyle Darrell Cox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carlyle Darrell Cox of Devonshire, Bermuda. A June wedding in Bermuda is planned.

title: Cancer Statistics Rise Unexpectedly
description: Officials at the National Cancer Institute do not know whether they are faced with a setback or a statistical fluke.

title: FOR WOMEN, AT LAST, THE CHOICE TO MAKE A CHOICE
description: THE multifaceted success of women is one of the things that I have been noticing lately - a change, I believe, in the way women now live their lives. It has not been ever so.

title: Nets Lose to Pacers
description: John Long scored 20 points, including two foul shots with 10 seconds left, to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 95-91 victory over the Nets tonight.

title: Giants Get Their Title
description: Four weeks ago, after the Giants had rallied with a miracle finish to beat the Minnesota Vikings, the whooping and screaming in their locker room could be heard through the walls. Last Sunday, when the Giants beat the Washington Redskins to clinch a playoff berth and all but clinch their division title, the postgame locker room was so businesslike that it was difficult to tell whether the Giants had won or lost.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
AMERICAN ROBIN
description: Turdus migratorius Size: 9 to 11 inches.

title: Jets Suffer 4th Straight Loss, 45-24
description: The Jets' late-season collapse continued today even with the emotional high generated by returning veterans, a home crowd pleading for victory, and a revamped lineup.

title: Another Look at NASA's Utah Link
description: Last spring, about four months after a defective booster rocket caused the Challenger explosion, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, complained of a ''Utah conspiracy.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
New Brunswick's Revival Still Bubbling
description: OVER the last dozen years, good fortune has gradually returned to New Brunswick, transforming it from a shabby city of dilapidated buildings, empty storefronts and littered lots into a community on the rise.

title: AT NESTLE, CHANGE AND TOGETHERNESS
description: NESTLE FOODS Corporation's striking new headquarters building in Purchase, which opened in November, has brought the company's 1,000 Westchester employees together under the same roof for the first time. The building's ''open landscape'' office plan also promotes greater employee togetherness. Both the consolidation and the emphasis on face-to-face contact are changes initiated by C. Alan MacDonald, who has been president and chief executive officer of Nestle Foods for the last three-and-a-half years.

title: SYSTEM BYPASSED, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: When the Defense Department supplied the Central Intelligence Agency with arms for sale to Iran, it bypassed the department's ordinary system for such covert transfers, according to Government officials.

title: SANTA FE'S GALLERY ROW
description: For nearly a century, Santa Fe has attracted artists with its old adobes, turquoise skies and special feeling of space and light. Early Santa Fe paintings depict sunlight sharply slanting off adobe walls and winter snow. For admirers of strong contrasts and color, Canyon Road - the city's gallery row - remains a special delight in winter: red dirt, brown adobe, white snow and a late-afternoon violet wash over all.

title: Norman Acclaimed
description: GREG NORMAN of Australia, who won prize money worth $1.2 million with eight victories worldwide in 1986, has been named World Player of the Year by Golf Digest.

title: Bangkok Cools Off on Ice Skates (and Tries On Its Mittens)
description: When the world's big cities are ranked by their superlatives - the cheapest, the highest, the dirtiest, the safest -this sprawling capital is always sure of one trophy.

title: Sweet Land of Mystery
description: By now we know quite a lot about the effects of the Iranian scandal, but very little attention has been paid to the deeper causes of these bizarre events.

title: Garbage Worth $1,000 and Up
description: RESIDENTS in Rockford, Ill., began paying more attention to their garbage when they learned that a bagful could be worth $1,000 or more.

title: THAI FARE: SOME LIKE IT HOT
description: THE number of restaurants on Long Island specializing in Thai food doubled in October with the opening of Seeda in Valley Stream. Seeda is a branch of a fine, well-established restaurant of the same name in Manhattan's theater district, and its meny on the Island is identical.

title: STANDARD'S BID TO REGAIN STATURE
description: THE new, 45-story headquarters of the Standard Oil Company rises dramatically above the heart of Cleveland's downtown to scan Lake Erie and the Ohio plains -a powerful symbol of Standard's historic status as the cornerstone of the Rockefeller family fortune and, arguably, of the American oil industry.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Boyd Wins His First Downhill: Rob Boyd, an unheralded 20-year-old downhill competitor, scored his first-ever World Cup victory yesterday to cap a triumphant day for the Canadian team at Val Gardena, Italy. Boyd upset the elite of Alpine skiing in the fourth men's downhill race of the season, one hour after another Canadian, Laurie Graham, took a women's World Cup downhill in Val d'Isere, France. Boyd clocked a winning time of 2 minutes 1.76 seconds down the icy Saslong track. Graham won her downhill as four North Americans finished among the top six. Graham was timed in 1:26.42, followed by Maria Walliser of Switzerland in 1:27.14. France's Catherine Quittet finished third in 1:27.45. Debbie Armstrong of Seattle, the 1984 Olympic giant slalom champion, was fourth in 1:27.60. Liisa Sarijarvi of Canada finished fifth in 1:27.74 and Tori Pillinger of Park City, Utah, followed in 1:27.89.(AP) Norwegian Wins in Jumping: Vegaard Opaas of Norway won the 90-meter event at the World Cup jumping championships in Lake Placid yesterday for the second consecutive year. The Norwegian, who entered the final round in third place, finished with 223.5 points for his two 114-meter jumps to overtake the first-round leader, Primoz Ulaga of Yugoslavia.(AP) Tennis France vs. Sweden: Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd of Sweden, the defending champions, and the French team of Yannick Noah and Guy Forget won semifinal matches in London yesterday in the Nabisco Masters World Doubles Championship.

title: 'LANDSCAPE AND AGE OF ANXIETY' AT LEHMAN: COMING TO GRIPS
description: ANXIETY is like the weather: everyone complains about it but no one does anything about it, although ''Landscape and the Age of Anxiety'' tries. And in so doing the show comes to grips with contemporary realism, a mode that is a problem in itself and one that, like anxiety, may well be a byproduct of the apocalyptic atmosphere enveloping the world.

title: Drugs Are Not The Problem
description: To the Sport Editor:

title: EAST GERMANY PUTS DEATH TOLL IN AIR CRASH AT 69
description: East Germany said today that 69 people, including members of a school group, were killed in the crash Friday of a Soviet airliner near East Berlin.

title: TEACHING ART AND HERITAGE TO HOMELESS
description: As he looked at the face of his grandfather re-created in clay, Luis Cruz said, ''I used to live with him in Puerto Rico before he died, and he had this really big backyard.''

title: Reagan Receives A Welfare Plan; More to Come
description: Though official after official declared there was no attempt to divert attention from the Iran crisis in last week's announcement of a sweeping series of domestic policy initiatives, President Reagan's own language invited the connection. ''We cannot and will not let this stop us from getting on with the business of governing,'' Mr. Reagan told a group of state legislators at the Old Executive Office Building.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OF PRISONS AND IDEAS. By Milovan Djilas. Translated by Michael Boro Petrovich. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) Milovan Djilas has spent his career in the shadow of Yugoslavia's prisons.

title: ANOTHER EMBARRASSMENT FOR TROUBLED
description: THE Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx manufacturer, was transformed from a small machine shop to a $100-million-a-year military contractor almost entirely through its participation in a Federal program set up to help minority-owned businesses.

title: Next Week; What Does Sports Need for Christmas?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: WEAVER TRANSFORMS RAGS INTO ART
description: IF something about the rag rugs and wall hangings crafted by Missy Stevens seems vaguely familiar, perhaps it is the memory of a favorite old pair of corduroys, soft and worn.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Nov. 30, about Walter E. Fauntroy, the delegate to the House of Representatives from the District of Columbia, incorrectly ranked the District in terms of population. According to the 1980 Census, it had a smaller population than Nevada, North Dakota and South Dakota.

title: TV AND EDUCATORS JOIN IN YOUTH PROGRAM
description: A GROUP of educators and child-care professionals have teamed up with a Hartford television station on a yearlong campaign devoted to the problems and experiences of children.

title: TRIAL IS UNDER WAY ON LAWSUIT BROUGHT BY GURU'S FOLLOWERS
description: When Robert Kropinski first came in contact with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's transcendental meditation in 1972, he thought he had found the key to a new life.

title: May Wedding Set By Diane Ruotolo And M.F. Webber
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Joseph William Vollmerhausen of Summit, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter Diane Sweeney Ruotolo to Mark Freeman Webber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Richard Webber of Westfield, N.J., and Waynewood Lake, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: PLANT CLOSING DEALS TOWN A $30 MILLION LOSS
description: Icy winds shearing through this small east Texas community have not cut nearly so deep as the news that Kirby Forest Industries, the area's largest employer, will close its plant here Jan. 1 and take more than 800 jobs with it.

title: WE ARE ALL CONTRAPTIONS
description: THE BLIND WATCHMAKER By Richard Dawkins. Illustrated. 332 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Charting Stars Across the Decades
description: The death two weeks ago of Cary Grant, who was equally at ease in dinner clothes, a Salvation Army uniform or a solar topee, was a page-one reminder that, unlike Grant, the majority of today's real stars no longer have anything to do with movies. There are a handful of film giants still going strong - Clint Eastwood and Paul Newman, among others at the moment - but the truly representative stars of our era belong to television.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING POINSETTIAS THROUGH THE YEAR
description: HOW about that poinsettia that you kept from last season? Has it colored so that it will be presentable for the Christmas holiday? If not, why has it turned out to be a disappointment?

title: Shoring Up Waterfront Preservation
description: WHALING, oystering and shipbuilding used to be the predominant way of life for the people who lived along the Connecticut coastline. And the wharves, warehouses and stores that grew up to serve those industries, as well as the clapboard row houses where the people lived, created a colorful, seagoing flavor to the 41 communities washed by Long Island Sound.

title: Come Clean, Mr. President
description: Like a grade B Hollywood remake, the arms-for-hostages deal is rapidly degenerating into President Reagan's Watergate. It recalls the adage that historical phenomena always happen twice - the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce.

title: Kennedy Praises Hussein
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy praised the role of King Hussein in the quest for peace in the Middle East and said today that he would study Jordan's $1 billion development plan for Arab territories occupied by Israel. The Massacusetts Democrat was in Amman on a Middle East fact-finding tour after having been in in Israel.

title: ORATORIOS AND ANTHEMS RINGING IN HOLIDAY SEASON
description: OVER the centuries, Christmas has been a remarkable source of inspiration for Western ccmposers, who have brought forth works in every style. Although Handel's ''Messiah,'' either Part I or complete, remains a mainstay of the season, the repertory also includes an enormous number of motets, anthems, oratorios, cantatas, hymns and carols.

title: Whistle Blowers
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMS OF THEATERS ARE COMPOUNDED BY PUBLIC OWNERSHIP
description: WHILE several actors have started successful careers in politics in recent years, the difficulties faced by some publicly owned playhouses in Connecticut indicate it is more difficult for politicians to go into theater.

title: NAVY SHIP HEIGHTENS NEW HAMPSHIRE JOB DISPUTE
description: The arrival of a United States Navy ship in Portsmouth Harbor earlier this month has undercut union workers in a bitter labor dispute with the Simplex Wire and Cable Company, local labor leaders say.

title: CORRECTION
description: The source of part of the information in a graph in The Week in Review Dec. 7, reporting on President Reagan's approval ratings, was omitted. The data came from New York Times/CBS News polls and New York Times polls.

title: Rules Adopted in Name of Democracy Appear Only to Erode It Even More
description: When South Africa's white rulers sought Friday to justify their newest and most draconian tightening of emergency rule, they did so in a manner that seemed to some critics to defeat the very goals they sought to pursue. By casting the outlawed

title: PHONE ERROR THWARTS PLAN FOR A SUICIDE
description: A suicidal man who dialed a wrong number reached a woman who kept him on the line long enough for the authorities to trace the long-distance call and send the police in Augusta, Ga., to rescue him, the authorities say.

title: FRENCH TERROR CASE: POLICE SUCCESS, COURT FIASCO
description: It was on a spring afternoon on the avenue Trudaine in central Paris that two French plainclothes policemen, sensing something suspicious about two men carrying heavy nylon bags in a particularly crime-ridden area of this city, decided to investigate.

title: HIGHWAY FATALITIES STUDIED
description: AN unusual number of fatal pedestrian accidents on a 20-mile stretch of Sunrise Highway in Suffolk County has raised concern among police officials in the Towns of Babylon and Islip.

title: INSIDE
description: Taiwan's Risky Refrain More and more young Taiwanese are hinting that perhaps Taiwan should try to end its isolation by abandoning its claim on mainland China. Page 14.

title: JERSEY LAWYERS GIVEN MORE FREEDOM FOR ADS
description: Lawyers have been given wider latitude in advertising for business by the New Jersey Supreme Court, but were warned against ''relying in any way on the shock or amusement value of absurd portrayals.''

title: Steelers Look Back and Sympathize With Jets
description: They could certainly commiserate with the Jets.

title: Books and Mass Appeal
description: Mr. Kleinfield's article came as a pleasant surprise. Given the enterprise that goes into the buying and selling of books, and the mass appeal and success of bookstores in this country, reading must be an important pastime for Americans.

title: KEAN PONDERS FAVORITE-SON ROLE TO UNIFY DELEGATION
description: ALTHOUGH the conference at which he became chairman of the Republican Governors Association last week was overshadowed by the growing controversy over the Reagan Administration's arms sales to Iran, Governor Kean's plans for the 1988 national elections were still a topic of discussion.

title: The Opposition in Taiwan Does Well
description: Taiwan voters got a tentative taste of two-party politics last weekend after 37 years of rule by Chiang Kai-shek and his heirs. A new opposition party, the Democratic Progressives, made a surprisingly strong showing in legislative elections against the Kuomintang, which has ruled since the Communists drove Chiang from the Chinese mainland in 1949.

title: Classical Music
description: What a week in music this is for New York! The re-opening of a bright, shining, reorganized and refurbished Carnegie Hall tops everything, of course, but there are several things going on elsewhere that are of uncommon interest. So, let us assume each music-lover will get to Carnegie Hall in due time, which is bound to happen, and consider other possibilities.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IT'S AN anniversary of sorts for Charles Neider. Then again, it's an unplanned coincidence, for almost exactly 10 years ago this author - he is known as both an authority on Antarctica and for his works about Mark Twain - was interviewed in this newspaper about his plans for the coming year.

title: CONSIDERING WHAT TO MAKE OF 'CREATIONISM'
description: ''THE First Amendment mandates governmental neutrality between religion and religion, and between religion and nonreligion.'' So said the Supreme Court in 1968, as it struck down an Arkansas law that banned the teaching of evolution in public schools.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MAGIC WAGON. By Joe R. Lansdale. (Doubleday, $12.95.) Somewhere in east Texas in 1909 rolls ''the Magic Wagon.'' Riding along on top is the rawboned orphan Buster Fogg, who narrates this slim novel, and Buster's four companions: the trick shooter Billy Bob Daniels, who wears ''his blond hair long like them old gunfighters you read about in the dime novels''; Albert, the black man who has a strange hold over Billy Bob; Rot Toe the Wrestling Chimpanzee; and the half-petrified corpse of Wild Bill Hickok.

title: JAZZ: JOEY CAVASENO
description: JOEY CAVASENO, a young saxophonist from Rutgers University who has been breaking into the New York jazz scene as a sideman during the past two years, is making his first appearance here as a leader this week at Carlos 1, Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and 10th Streets.

title: BUSINESSES ADVISED TO LOOK EASTWARD
description: NEW JERSEY'S ''export-sensitive'' businesses should look to the Far East for trade and investments in the next decade, an economist told a group of business executives here last week.

title: FROM HERE TO THERE IN THE COUNTRY: OUR WONDERFUL ROADS
description: MAPS are reassuring - 95 percent of the time you can follow a road map and get to where you want to go: reality really is what you expected. How often is that true? Our highways connect us and tell us we are in control of things.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE FUSS OVER POISON PILLS;
A Recipe for a Management Autocracy
description: POISON pills are bad medicine for American shareholders.

title: 24-HOUR NEWS CHANNEL WILL BOW ON CABLE
description: AL ITTLESON, the president of News 12 Long Island, said he plans on ''keeping the Alka-Seltzer handy'' at 5 P.M. tomorrow. That's the hour that Long Island's new 24-hour all-news television channel is scheduled to make its live debut on the Island's cable systems.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS SEE NEW PROMISE ON THE SMALL SCREEN
description: Sixty years ago, the screen writer Herman J. Mankiewicz sent a telegram from Hollywood to one of his New York cronies, the playwright-journalist Ben Hecht: ''Will you accept 300 per week to work for Paramount Pictures? All expenses paid. The 300 is peanuts. Millions are to be grabbed out here and your only competition is idiots. Don't let this get around.'' Tantalized by the promise of gold in the streets, Hecht and his playwrighting partner, Charles MacArthur, followed Mankiewicz to Hollywood to write for the movies. And during the next two decades virtually all the major New York playwrights - Clifford Odets, Robert Sherwood, Thornton Wilder and Lillian Hellman among them - spent some time in Hollywood turning out movie scripts.

title: Diana Davies and Brian Barrett Marry
description: Diana Ruth Davies, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joshua William Davies Jr. of Middletown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Brian Barrett, the son of the late Ellen Hendrixson Barrett and the late George Barrett, both of New York. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Dr. Elise Renning, in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Trying to Repair The Election Laws
description: The elections are over, but campaigns to revamp the electoral process in New York and Connecticut are moving ahead.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
It's a Grown-Up Baby Now
description: The Crescent City is a wellspring of contemporary popular music - jazz, reggae and commercial gospel as well as rhythm-and-blues-derived rock. Under the slick production techniques of many current hits lie the strong rhythms, quirky language play and devotion to instrumental study that New Orleans slaves and free Creoles practiced.

title: Ladies Mile
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sensible Deterrent to Takeover Mania
description: THE poison pill is under attack.

title: U.S. SPY ARRESTED, NICARAGUANS SAY
description: A United States citizen has been arrested at an airbase in northern Nicaragua and is being held on suspicion that he was spying, the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann said today.

title: LUTANIST, CELLIST, PIANIST AND FLUTIST
description: Robert Barto It was an excellent week for debuts: every one of the four concerts this listener heard was of more than usual interest. On Sunday afternoon the lutanist Robert Barto made his formal New York debut at Corpus Christi Church under the auspices of the ''Music Before 1800'' series.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Woodhaven
description: TWENTY days before Christmas there was a tree-lighting ceremony beside the Chase Manhattan Bank at Jamaica Avenue and Forest Parkway in Woodhaven. Other Christmas trees may stand taller, but for the residents of this closely knit Queens neighborhood, their 20-foot blue spruce, planted in the ground and decorated with items handmade by local children, does just fine.

title: STATE AGRICULTURAL MUSEUM: A COLLECTION WITHOUT A HOME
description: WHEN John Deats, a Hunterdon County black-smith, patented a horse-drawn plow in 1828, he had no idea that it would lead to the formation of an agricultural museum on the Rutgers University campus.

title: STATE BRINGS PHEASANTS TO L.I. FOR HUNTING
description: WHILE many birds have flown south for the season, ring-necked pheasants are now being trucked south from upstate to Long Island - not for the winter, but for the hunting season.

title: POSTINGS: Circa 1865; Peekskill Restoration
description: Two years ago, about 10 building owners in downtown Peekskill, N.Y., failed to pay their taxes, and the city seized the dilapidated properties. ''We saw this as a negative trend, but also as a real opportunity,'' said City Manager Joseph J. Seymour.

title: VACANT OFFICE PITS MAYOR VS. TRUSTEES
description: THE Village of Rockville Centre has been without an administrator since June.

title: BENEFITS SOUGHT FOR VOLUNTEERS
description: UNDER a bill now before a State Assembly committee, as many as 200,000 volunteer firefighters, police officers and first-aid rescue workers in the state would be eligible for workers' compensation benefits for heart attacks and strokes suffered on the job.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Of Contras and Consumers

title: Bach, Fife and Drum
description: When the National Endowment for the Arts moved its headquarters into the restored Old Post Office Building, the agency wasn't prepared for all the incidental problems. The building has a large public atrium on the ground floor, with a stage used by professional and amateur entertainment groups from time to time.

title: QUICK TRUCE: POLITICAL WAR COOLS IN SEOUL
description: After edging to the brink of a new and potentially explosive confrontation this weekend, South Korea's governing and opposition parties suddenly pulled back and settled into a temporary truce.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE U.S. SENATE: Paralysis or a Search for Consensus? By George E. Reedy. (Crown, $16.95.) There are 55 people in Washington who should probably read this book in the weeks ahead - the Democratic members of the new Senate that convenes in January.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOMERS RESTAURANT RETURN
description: NO doubt more than a few up-county diners have mourned the mysterious closing of A Country Place last January.

title: April Wedding Set By Miss Mathews
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hayden Mathews of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Holladay Mathews, to Giovanni Pasquale Prezioso, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fausto Prezioso of Towson, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: Stamford Acts to Humanize Downtown Renewal
description: WHILE New York City teetered on the verge of bankruptcy a decade ago, Stamford, Conn., was blossoming as a new kind of suburban metropolis. But over the years, a message began to emanate from the huge new office buildings, shopping mall, garages and hotels, and from the broad new avenues that bore Mercedeses and Porsches directly from Interstate 95 to their destinations - that Stamford was no longer a city for the people who lived there.

title: MAKERS GIVE CLOTHES TO NEW YORK HOMELESS
description: It was early morning and 25 degrees outside when a van pulled into a street near City Hall, was loaded with boxes of new woolen hats and gloves, warm shirts, slacks and shoes and headed for Brooklyn.

title: MUSCOVITES VISIT YALE FOR 10 DAYS
description: A bit wiser about the ways of the West, a group of students and professors from Moscow State University returned home from Yale University last week after 10 hectic days of lectures, meetings, sightseeing and just hanging out in New Haven and New York.

title: 'TOUGH KIDS': READERS RESPOND
description: I am writing this letter to help clear up a misconception brought up in the article ''Helping 'Tough Kids' Turn Around,'' which deals with a new project that William Paca Junior High School has installed to help change the attitudes of ''tough kids.''

title: A Prescription for Contraceptives
description: The most promising way to prevent teen-age pregnancy, the National Research Council has found, is contraception that is available and affordable.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: Reflections on a Labor Federation Anniversary
description: Without fanfare, the American Federation of Labor, the forerunner of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., celebrated what many historians agree is its 100th anniversary this week.

title: A Regret Expressed
description: Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, raised no protest as members of the industry he regulates paid his $649-a-night bill at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and a lot of other expenses incurred by him and other bank board officials and members of their families. But Mr. Gray is sorry about that.

title: Dance
description: The annual ''Christmas Revels'' production comes to the Symphony Space on Thursday night and while its delightful solstice celebrations are usually rooted in traditions from the British Isles, this year's edition has a Gallic touch. The overall format is that of a masque ''in the French mode,'' director John Langstaff and his merry troupe promise.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE IRONBOUND? NO, PISCATAWAY
description: LOVERS of Spanish and Portuguese food invariably turn to Newark's Ironbound area when they want to indulge themselves. The choice of restaurants there is large, prices are more than reasonable and the food makes up in quantity for what it sometimes lacks in quality.

title: A COMEBACK FOR THE PRACTICE OF BREAST-FEEDING
description: ''BREAST-FEEDING was the way of the world until about 50 years ago,'' said Judy Palsgraf, nursing coordinator of the Human Milk Bank at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. ''And now it's the wave of the future.''

title: DIAL 0 FOR NOTHING
description: RELATIONS Selected Poems 1950-1985. By Philip Booth. 259 pp. New York: Viking. Cloth, $25. Penguin. Paper, $12.95.

title: Miss Powell to Wed T.C. Smith in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Powell of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Eileen Patricia Powell to Townsend Cary Smith, a son of Mrs. Howard H. Steel of Villanova, Pa., and Dr. Edward C. Smith of Spokane, Wash.

title: PLUMBING THE DEPTHS OF SCANDAL ON WALL STREET
description: DENNIS B. LEVINE and Ivan F. Boesky, who have settled insider trading charges with the Government, seem only to await sentencing and a chance to get on with their shattered lives. But they and their lawyers are facing another question: Will this be known as ''the Levine scandal,'' ''the Boesky scandal'' or something else altogether?

title: Kathleen Streett To Marry in June
description: Dean and Mrs. William B. Streett Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Ann Streett, to Eric Joseph Werblow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Werblow of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June. The future bride attended the Cherwell School in Oxford, England, and graduated from Cornell University, where she and Mr. Werblow are candidates for M.B.A. degrees at the Johnson Graduate School of Management.

title: CLASS STUDIES WAYS FOR SINGLES TO MEET
description: On the heels of the success of a course called ''50 Ways to Find a Lover,'' an adult-education program based in Hamden is expanding the ways it helps single people find each other in a ''nonthreatening'' atmosphere.

title: Don't Understand Me!
description: IN NEW YORK I WAS always irritated by the admiration that otherwise intelligent people professed for subway graffiti. Occasionally, you saw a pleasing paint-up job rattle by, but 99 percent of the stuff struck me as deeply depressing.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: My husband and I just returned from two weeks in Paris.

title: Behind The Jets' Slump
description: HE stood at his locker, putting on a white T-shirt and a white sport shirt over it, then Ken O'Brien turned around to face the inquisition of the notebooks and the microphones.

title: Cleansing Action
description: MOST WOMEN learned early on to scrub their faces until they shone.

title: Its Leaders Plan Events To Keep It in The Artistic Forefront
description: Tomorrow evening's festive reopening of Carnegie Hall, with its facilities lovingly restored and a gala program offering Zubin Mehta, Frank Sinatra, Isaac Stern, the New York Philharmonic and a new composition by Leonard Bernstein, will rightly seize the city's and the nation's attention. It will be a time for reaffirmation and celebration, the final step in the salvation process begun 27 long years ago, when Mr. Stern saved Carnegie from a wrecker's ball and restored it as America's No. 1 concert hall.

title: FILM MAKER ASKS QUESTIONS ABOUT LIFE
description: ELDA HARTLEY'S latest documentary is the most personal one of her 30-year career, which she has devoted to making films she acknowledges have a limited audience.

title: FACTS DON'T SUPPORT NEED FOR PIPELINE
description: This letter is a response to the essay by William B. Ellis, ''Pipeline Gas: Indeed There Is Need'' [ Nov. 16 ] , in which he proclaims himself an authority on the future needs of Connecticut for ''additional supplies of competitively priced gas'' and claims that ''Iroquois is the only project in substantive form that meets this need.''

title: Smith Discusses Fighting, of All Things
description: In his first moments as the new World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, James Smith, known as Bonecrusher, sounded very much like a novelty.

title: City's Water System: A Wonder of Engineering
description: ONE of the engineering marvels of the world, New York City's immense and complex water system, is the subject of ''On Tap,'' an exhibition that opened at the American Museum of Natural History last Friday.

title: KATE NELLIGAN HAS 21 NEW CO-STARS, ALL UNDER 13
description: THE director is late. Only 6 of the 23 actors have shown up for a rehearsal that was to have started half an hour ago. And the play opens in three days.

title: City Urged to Help Hispanic People
description: Fourteen months ago, when Mayor Koch appointed a Commission on Hispanic Concerns to prepare yet another study of ways to improve services to the 1.4 million Hispanic people who make up 20 percent of the city's population, he declared that New York ''can and should do more'' for those residents.

title: Books and Mass Appeal
description: N. R. Kleinfield's article on Waldenbooks reflects the schizophrenia which has always affected the world of book publishing (''The Supermarketer of Books,'' Nov. 9).

title: HOW WARNER GOT BACK ITS GLITTER
description: SITTING in the elegant conference room adjoining his New York office high atop Rockefeller Plaza last week, Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., recalled a much bleaker December day almost exactly four years ago.

title: POSSIBLY TAINTED MEDICAL WASTE FOUND IN BROOKLYN
description: A 40-foot tractor-trailer loaded with 100 cubic yards of possibly infectious medical waste has been found at an abandoned power station in Brooklyn, and environmental sleuths of the City Sanitation Department say they have ''very strong leads'' on how it got there.

title: Priscilla Jennings To Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. William M. Jennings of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter Priscilla Hite Jennings to Neil V. Pultz Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pultz, also of Greenwich. A June wedding is planned.

title: PARTIES STUDY PRIMARY RULING
description: THE decision last week by the Supreme Court of the United States upholding the right of Connecticut's Republican Party to let independents vote in its major primary elections may bring even more changes in the state's election system, according to politicians of both parties.

title:
ART;
NEWARK'S GEM: 'AVANT-GARDE AMERICAN PAINTING, 1911-1946'
description: RENOVATION of the Newark Museum - completion is at least two years away -will have to be superb to match the jewel that is its current exhibition, ''Avant-Garde American Painting, 1911-1946.''

title:
RECORDINGS;
Three Versions of 'The Nutcracker' Herald the Season
description: ''The Nutcracker'' ballet is as much a part of the Christmas season as the tree itself, yet when Tchaikovsky was first commissioned to write the work in 1890 he would have been greatly surprised at the outcome.

title: RHODES CHOICES GOOD NEWS AT YALE
description: AFTER a disappointing result last year, administrators at Yale University were pleased last week when they learned that four of the university's students have been named Rhodes Scholars.

title: JAZZ: STEIN AND VIGNOLA
description: THE violin and guitar duo of Andy Stein and Frank Vignola can usually be counted on for programs that draw on the work of the two classic jazz violin-and-guitar teams - Joe Venuti and Eddie Lang, and Django Reinhardt and Stephane Grappelli. On Wednesday evening at J's, Broadway at 97th Street, Mr. Stein and Mr. Vignola expanded to a trio with the addition of the pianist Dick Wellstood, whose speciality is stride piano.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEARTBREAK HOTEL. By Gabrielle Burton. (Scribners, $15.95.) Reading this novel is like watching a boisterous, surrealistic three-ring circus on the theme of being a woman in America.

title: L.I. DOCTOR STUDIES A SILENT KILLER
description: SUDDEN death from a heart attack is no longer the medical mystery it once was. The ''healthy'' person who keels over while raking leaves, shoveling snow or running had, in almost all cases, extensive coronary artery disease but without the symptoms -particularly pain - that send others to the doctor.

title: SOUTHERN AREAS HAVE PIPELINE CONCERN ALSO
description: Mr. Ellis's article raises several points of interest to those concerned with Connecticut's environment.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ADVENTURES WITH JULIA. By Candace Denning. (North Point, $13.95.) Julia Murphy is one bored woman. ''Very little happens,'' she complains. ''Days go by.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: TALKING: New Houses; Reducing Risks in Deposits
description: IT often comes as a shock to someone buying a single-family home before it is built to learn that not only will the deposit be greater than the customary 10 percent, but also that the builder will use it to cover part of the construction costs rather than hold the money safely in escrow.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: NASA POSTPONES BURIAL OF SHUTTLE
description: Acting on last-minute orders from its lawyers, the space agency has delayed burying wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo. But the agency has reiterated that it will not allow news organizations to view the shuttle's badly damaged crew compartment or obtain pictures of it.

title: CONCERT: AMERICAN BRASS
description: THE American Brass Quintet's concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night was impressive for virtuosity and ensemble rapport and disturbing from an artistic standpoint.

title: Breaking the $200 Hotel Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
House Prices Soften in a Glutted Market
description: IT is probably a sign of the season, traditionally the slowest time of the year in the housing market, that the average sale price of a house on the Island was down sharply in October from the month before.

title: Nun Finds Ministry in a Gym
description: LAST spring when the members of the search committee interviewed the finalists for the women's basketball coaching job here at Marquette University, they had the strange notion that they were in charge.

title: White House Pulls Back on Forecast
description: ''It isn't gangbusters,'' Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said last week of the White House's revised forecast for 1987. ''It isn't as big growth as you wish you could see.

title: THE CHOREOGRAPHY OF A SHORT-ORDER COOK
description: IF it's lunchtime in Scarsdale, Victor Cucolo Jr. is cooking. With a flourish, the wiry, 36-year-old owner of the Parkway Coffee Shop drops bread in the toaster, pivots to slice a bagel and pivots again to turn a hamburger. Not a motion is wasted in the circle of space he calls home from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.: everything he needs to keep the orders coming is within reach of his muscular arms.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. St. Louis Cardinals At Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. Television Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130 12;50 P.M. Los Angeles Rams vs. Miami Dolphins At Anaheim, Calif.

title: Gain for Women in Air Force
description: The Air Force will open 1,645 positions to women, a move that would permit them to be members of crews of reconnaissance and electronic warfare airplanes, Secretary Edward C. Aldridge Jr. has announced.

title: Ex-Hospitals Chief Gets Six Months For Cheating
description: When the corruption investigations are over and all the big worms in the Big Apple are counted, the former president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, John J. McLaughlin, probably will not be among them.

title: The Bottom Line
description: Not who is the first one to gain the lead, but who is on top at the end, is what counts. That was the bitter lesson that Boris Kogan swallowed in this year's United States Championship in Estes Park, Colo.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH new Federal trucking regulations do not take effect until next month, the State Police already have stepped up their efforts to apprehend illegal drivers.

title: ...and Applause For Cashen
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Blending Yuletide Traditions
description: IN AMERICA, WOLF-gang Puck was saying, there really isn't a single traditional meat dish that symbolizes the Christmas feast.

title: BOSTON MUSEUM OF FINE ART GETS A NEW WING
description: The uncovering of Eve, a couple of Canalettos and a roomful of Copleys are among the many surprises in the Museum of Fine Arts's newly renovated Evans Wing, which has doubled the museum's space for American and European painting and which opened to the public on Friday.

title: Progress Against PAC's?
description: Members of Congress who have been trying for years to reduce the money that political action committees can contribute to candidates think they will have improved prospects in the 100th Congress, which opens next month.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Seasonal Specials Span Wide Spectrum
description: While the number of new programs on cable marking the Christmas season has fallen off this year compared with last, there is a compensating increase in diversity, ranging from a show-biz parody to grand pageantry to live coverage of religious services abroad.

title: 3 CHORAL GROUPS WILL PERFORM AND ''AMAHL' WILL BE OFFERED
description: THE American Boychoir, under its music director, James Litton, will present its traditional ''Family Christmas Concert'' in Princeton (twice), Trenton, Newark, Ridgewood and New York City.

title: SCHOLARS PRAISE ITALY'S ROLE IN HELPING JEWS IN WORLD WAR II
description: Despite its participation in the Axis alliance, Italy in World War II provided a safer haven for Jews than most other European countries, a number of scholars agreed at a conference last week.

title: POPULARITY POSES PROBELM FOR KEAN
description: BEING New Jersey's most popular Governor has its moments, and not all of them are pleasant.

title: Boards Vote on South Africa
description: Representatives of New Jersey school boards today overwhelmingly approved a resolution that would allow districts to refuse to award contracts to companies that do business with South Africa. Representatives from 200 of the state's 600 school districts attended the meeting of the New Jersey School Board Association, a group spokesman said. Under the resolution, the association will seek an amendment to the public school contracts law to permit local school boards to decide whether they wish to award contracts to companies that do business in or with South Africa.

title: REWARDS OF THE SEARCH FOR CHURCHILL: ANGRY DUKES AND GOLDEN EGGS
description: WHAT interests me is the truth.'' With these words Randolph Churchill introduced me to his concept of history, and to five years of serving as one of his research assistants. It was March 1962. Six months had passed since he had been asked by his father to write the official Churchill biography, based on the exclusive use of Churchill's private papers. Randolph's idea of the truth was clear; the facts had to be found, and presented without distortion. Our task on the team (we fluctuated in number from one to six) was to seek the truth and his task as our boss was to tell it.

title: DECEMBER'S SPIRIT BECKONS AUDIENCES
description: THE Christmas floodgates are opening. But at least for the next couple of days, listeners not so inclined to holiday programs can find a few possibilities.

title: GIVING HELPS NEEDIEST CASES
description: To many people, giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a tradition of the holiday season.

title: SOME THOUGHTS ON TOLL CHEATING
description: The Nov. 23 article on toll cheating shows that the New Jersey Turnpike must be doing something right if it lost only $5,000 to cheaters last year, while the Garden State Parkway must be doing something wrong if it lost $1.2 million.

title: AGENTS TO AID N.F.L. UNION IN TALKS
description: The National Football League Players Association, which certifies the agents who represent players in individual contract negotiations, has appointed an advisory committee of six agents to assist the union during the upcoming negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Edna M. Waters Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. Leighton Kinsley Waters of Rumson, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Edna Mae Waters to George Joseph Orr Jr., a son of Mrs. James E. Downs of Baltimore and Mr. Orr of Beverly, N.J.

title: Bucks Hold Jordan to 11
description: The Milwaukee Bucks not only ended Michael Jordan's streak of 40-point games at nine, but they held him to only 11, his season low, as they defeated the Chicago Bulls, 112-90, tonight.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: EASE. By Patrick Gale. (E. P. Dutton, $15.95.) If you are a successful English playwright, possessed of wealth, fame, love and a house written up in Architectural Digest, what do you do next? Domina Tey, the protagonist of ''Ease,'' packs her bags and runs away to London.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Bliss Too Blest Emily Dickinson thought that ''marriage might bring a bliss too blest to endure,'' according to Cynthia Griffin Wolff. In her ''Emily Dickinson'' (Knopf), she quotes a letter on this anxious subject, written by Emily to her friend, Susan Gilbert. You and I have been strangely silent upon this subject, Susie, we have often touched upon it, and as quickly fled away, as children shut their eyes when the sun is too bright for them. . . . How dull our lives must seem to the bride, and the plighted maiden, whose days are fed with gold, and who gathers pearls every evening; but to the wife, Susie, sometimes the wife forgotten, our lives perhaps seem dearer than all others in the world; you have seen flowers at morning, satisfied with the dew, and those same sweet flowers at noon with their heads bowed in anguish before the mighty sun; think you these thirsty blossoms will now need naught but - dew? No, they will cry for sunlight, and pine for the burning noon, tho' it scorches them, scathes them; they have got through with peace - they know that the man of noon, is mightier than the morning and their life is henceforth to him.

title: IN PARIS, PRECURSORS OF THE MALL
description: The passages of Paris, architectural gems that offered a respite from dreary 19th-century streets, have become welcome urban amenities.

title: WALSH FORMER U.S. JUDGE, LEADS CANDIDATES FOR SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
description: A former Federal judge in New York who once served as president of the American Bar Association has emerged as the leading candidate to become the special prosecutor in the Iran arms investigation, according to people knowledgeable with the search.

title: Campaign Video
description: For a holiday gift for the incurable politics addict, a Washington concern has produced a one-hour video of what it considers to be the best campaign commercials of 1986, about 80 of them end-to-end. Aristotle Industries, at 205 Pennsylvania Ave. S.E., Washington, D.C. 20003, sells the tape for $75 in either VHS or Beta format. The company also stocks two other videos: a similar summary of the 1984 campaign and a historical review of the best commercials before 1984.

title: Helpful Son Leads to Arrest
description: A drug dealer suspect is under arrest because his 3-year-old son tried to be helpful. When a plainclothesman stopped the suspect, Rubin P. Dexter, and asked if he had any drugs, he said no. But Mr. Dexter's son blurted out, ''Daddy, daddy, I got some,'' and pulled several bundles of white powder from his pocket, the police said Wednesday. Mr. Dexter was arrested on charges of possessing cocaine for sale and of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

title: RUTGERS BEGINS MAJOR BUILDING PROGRAM
description: TWO years after starting a new financial strategy to become ''one of the nation's premiere public research universities,'' Rutgers, the State University, has begun the largest building program in its history.

title: STAR OF ''THE FANTASTICKS'' MOVES ON TO THE 1920's
description: It could have been called ''The Girl:

title: Kathie Mead Horton Plans To >Marry >John >G. >Sarrett
description: The engagement of Kathie Mead Horton to John Garrison Sarrett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lee Sarrett of Virginia Beach, Va., has been announced by Mrs. William Leonard Horton of Summit, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla., mother of the bride-to-be.

title: Buying Burial on the Installment Plan
description: EARLY this fall, Carl Lowitz, a 72-year-old retired grocer, and his wife, Irene, met with a salesman from Mercer Mortuary in Phoenix to plan their funerals. They selected caskets, discussed memorial services and wound up choosing funeral packages that cost $3,000 each.

title: INVESTOR'S HOMETOWN BASKING IN $3 MILLION FUND
description: The usual crowd gathered before sunup today for ham and eggs, biscuits and gravy, and good talk around the long, family-style tables down at the Homestead Restaurant.

title: ARTICLES DRAW READERS' PRAISES
description: Alvin Lebar's story about the Old Bridge junk dealer (Nov. 23) moved me to both laughter and tears.

title: Assembling Some of the Pieces of the Puzzle
description: WHAT has come to be called the White House Crisis first crept into the public view early last month with a report in an obscure Lebanese magazine that American arms had been sold to the Iranians. Relentlessly, the story has grown day by day with a rush of confusing reports from around the world. There have been startling revelations - the most riveting of them about the diversion of some sale proceeds to the Nicaraguan rebels - and secret hints, contradictions and accusations, admissions following denials. Trails have led to a dozen countries, with a dizzying and ever-larger cast of characters, preoccupying Congress and the Government. There are still far more questions than answers. What follows is an attempt to assemble some of the pieces of the puzzle. THE MANAGERS President Reagan

title: Choose a Casket, Get a Tree For Free
description: FOR every coffin purchased, Batesville Casket, the country's largest coffin maker, donates money to a fund that plants a tree in a national forest in memory of the deceased.

title:
ART;
A 'WONDERLAND' IN PHOTOS, AND SCULPTURE IN PAPIER-MACHE
description: THE recent photographs of Joan Harrison, on view through Jan. 9 in the Media Port Gallery of the Port Washington Public Library, are collectively titled ''Wonderland.'' The term could hardly be more apt.

title: KANSAS CITY MUSEUM TO BUY BENTON PAINTING
description: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art will buy Thomas Hart Benton's painting ''Persephone'' for a reported $2.5 million, the highest price ever paid for one of the artist's works. The price is also the highest ever paid by the museum for a single painting.

title: Laser-Played Disks Draw New Interest
description: After lying dormant in the shadow of the videocassette, videodisks have lately shown signs of resurgence. These disks do not endanger the predominance of cassettes in the broad market, but the LaserDisk Corporation, the main supplier, has announced that in response to the rising demand it will double its production to 400,000 disks a month by early spring. This is a clear indication that the merits of laser-scanned videodisks are being discovered by a widening audience of video perfectionists.

title: ROLL THE DICE AND CROSS YOUR FINGERS
description: THE FINANCIAL REVOLUTION By Adrian Hamilton. 268 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. CASINO CAPITALISM By Susan Strange. 207 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $24.95.

title: Curb on Cruising By Young Drivers
description: CRUISING - the sport of young drivers seeking a casual date or a chance to see and be seen - came under strict control in Newark, Del., after it was blamed for giant weekend traffic tie-ups at night.

title: Dual Ladders
description: To the Editor:

title: Galbraith's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Hyman Becomes A Bride in Great Neck
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue last night Linda Hyman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Avrum Hyman of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married to Jeffrey Botwinick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Botwinick of Kew Gardens, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Peretz Steinberg, Irving Greenberg and Jonathan Rosenblatt.

title: PERSPECTIVES ON ARCHITECTURE, AT ROYAL ACADEMY
description: In recent years, new architecture in London has been like a three-ring circus that plays most of its engagements out of town, even out of the country. But this fall, the circus finally came to town in a major exhibition at the Royal Academy called ''New Architecture'' (through Dec. 21), which features work by the three British architects best known internationally: Norman Foster, Richard Rogers and James Stirling.

title: KOHL'S PARTY, EYES ON VOTE, SHIFTS TO RIGHT
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party has started to sound truculently anti-Communist and faintly nationalist tonalities as it seeks a major victory in the general election next month.

title: 6 Killed in Sri Lanka
description: Three policemen and three civilians were killed in a guerrilla ambush and an ensuing gunbattle in eastern Sri Lanka today, the police said. A 19-hour curfew was imposed on the town of Kalmunai in Eastern Province after the violence.

title: Galbraith's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Heron Island
description: To the Editor: Mr. Risser gave too short shrift to the green turtles on Heron Island. The best night life on the island is achieved by getting up in the middle of the night and going to the beach to find a turtle that is laying eggs.

title: Preserving the Perks of a Home Office
description: WRITING off some of the costs of maintaining an office at home became difficult when Congress changed the law more than a decade ago, but it will become even tougher under the newest tax reform.

title: MULE HANDY IN REPAIRING CANYON PHONE LINE
description: Marvin Hanchett flings his telephone repair equipment over the saddle horn and gets on his mule. In the darkness before sunrise, they plod down a treacherous wall of the Grand Canyon to inspect a phone line covered by a rock slide.

title: MUSIC: JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA AND NEW-MUSIC GROUP
description: WHEN the youngest of talented musicians come together with the music of their own time, the results can be unpredictable. One awaits some kind of adherence to ideology - an attachment to some new principle or style of composition - but Friday night's concert by the Juilliard Orchestra and Contemporary Music Ensemble at Alice Tully Hall showed no such loyalties, only three very individual responses to three very different pieces.

title: TO SPECTATOR, TRIAL IS FAMILY DRAMA
description: To neighbors, business associates and even the county sheriff, the Evolas of Temperance, Mich., were frugal folk who worked hard at the family drywall construction business and did not attract much attention.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE MANTLE OF THE PROPHET: Religion and Politics in Iran, by Roy Mottahedeh. (Pantheon, $9.95.) Roy Mottahedeh weaves a narrative of Iran's history and culture around the story of Ali Hashemi (a pseudonym), a scholarly young Shiite mullah who fears that the Islamic traditions he values are being swept away by the politics of wrath. This is ''an exquisite book on the culture of Iran, the Shiite clerical class responsible for the revolution and the madresehs, the religious seminaries from which the clerics emerged,'' Fouad Ajami said in The Book Review last year. A FINE MADNESS, by Elliott Baker. (Shoreline/Norton, $7.95.) A middle-aged poet who supports himself by shampooing carpets is the hero of Elliott Baker's novel, which our reviewer, Richard P. Brickner, in 1964 called ''a masterpiece of what one might call rebellious farce.''

title: Looking at U.S. Stocks From 'Abroad'
description: ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE was a brilliant and prescient analyst of American politics and society, but he probably didn't know a balance sheet from a bed sheet. So why name a new investment fund and advisory service after him?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WRITING IN RESTAURANTS. By David Mamet. (Viking, $15.95.) A writer's first duty is to communicate clearly. But clarity is conspicuously absent from many of these 30 essays by David Mamet, one of America's most innovative playwrights.

title: Valium Slows Down Intruder
description: An intruder broke into an elderly woman's home, terrorized her at knifepoint and then unwittingly swallowed several Valium tablets she kept by her bed and fell asleep, the police said.

title: 27 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 27 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: 15 STATE POETS FEATURED IN ANTHOLOGY
description: A COMBINATION of talent, technology and tenacity have contributed to the publication of the first book from a newly formed small publishing company in Stamford, Yuganta Press.

title: Wearing Fur
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS ABOUND
description: FAMILIAR traditions established years ago in many Westchester churches will be followed again this year by congregations and choirs. Christmas Eve at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, for example, brings a resonance of carols as the trendle, or circlet, is lighted and raised to the roof beam, symbolizing the star that guided the Wise Men. At Union Church in Pocantico Hills, Marc Chagall's stained-glass windows gleam in the candlelight as the organ and choir perform the music of Bach and Widor. And worshippers will pack the the tiny, 300-year-old Dutch Reformed Church in North Tarrytown, as they do every Christmas, warmed only by a woodstove.

title: Fordham-N.Y.U. Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: YELLOWSTONE BISON ELUDE FIRST HUNTERS OF YEAR
description: Bison are continuing to show disregard for the boundaries of Yellowstone National Park, defying the efforts of the Federal Park Service to keep them inside.

title: NOT-SO-INSTANT REPLAY
description: EARLY THIS MORNING, camera crews of up to eight people each arrived at 13 stadiums around the United States, sites of today's scheduled National Football League games. By the time each game starts, three cameramen will be at the ready: the ''tree,'' fixed in place high above the field on the 50-yard line; the ''mole,'' burrowing along the sidelines in search of spectacular close-ups; and the ''weasel,'' popping up anywhere to unearth human-interest color. Each will film the entire game.

title: Thoreau at Walden
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. SURGEON REBUTS CHARGE ON UNFIT PILOTS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's top medical officer has defended his record of recertifying commercial pilots against charges by airline officials and others that his decisions pose serious air safety problems.

title: Rams Drop Brock
description: ONE year after he became the oldest rookie in the National Football League, Dieter Brock has been released by the Los Angeles Rams. The 35-year-old former Canadian Football League quarterback -who set a Ram team record by completing 59.7 percent of his passes last year - has been on the injured-reserve list all season, first because of a knee injury suffered in the first exhibition game and later because of an aggravated back problem.

title: Meet My Whatsit
description: My thanks to William Safire for looking at the sensitive subject of premarital cohabitation (''Meet My Whatsit,'' On Language, Nov. 9).

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: NAST SHOW IN YONKERS An exhibit of original Thomas Nast wood engravings with Christmas themes opens to the public today at the Hudson River Museum, Trevor Park-on-Hudson, in Yonkers, and will remain on view through Jan. 4.

title: Philadelphia's Hall
description: An era is drawing to a close in Philadelphia. Since its foundation in 1900, the Philadelphia Orchestra has been associated with the stately Academy of Music, at the corner of Broad and Locust Streets in the center of town. This is the hall where Leopold Stokowski conducted the first American performances of Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 8 and Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder,'' and where some of the first pioneering stereo recordings were made in the early 1930's. It was here that Eugene Ormandy presided over the Orchestra from 1936 until 1980; it is the home of the ''Philadelphia Sound.''

title: Broncos Edge Redskins And Give Giants Title
description: John Elway and Sammy Winder each accounted for two touchdowns today, rallying the Denver Broncos from a 13-0 deficit to a 31-30 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: FLORIDA'S GRAND OLD HIGHWAY
description: It's another easy afternoon under the live oaks on the deck at Miss Genevieve's Lighthouse Landing Raw Bar and restaurant overlooking Ponce Inlet.

title: A Compliment Misplaced
description: Just when he thought he was safe, Mayor George V. Voinovich of Cleveland came under long-distance fire last week. Mr. Voinovich, visiting Israel for a conference at Tel Aviv University, remarked at a news conference that despite that nation's reputation as a terrorist target, he felt ''safer here than in some neighborhoods in my city.'' Some Democrats back in Cleveland were quick to take issue with the Republican Mayor.

title: Sally Barkan Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Barkan of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Sally Joyce Barkan to Richard Andrew Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Miller of Manhasset Hills, L.I. Miss Barkan and her fiance graduated last year from the Touro College School of Law. She is a lawyer for the Mental Hygiene Legal Service at the Bellevue Hospital Center. He has a law practice in Brooklyn.

title: Death Wish and Taxes
description: Like dogs with a bone, or little boys playing with matches, some Democrats just can't seem to leave alone the idea of a tax increase. Just as some Republicans can't seem to get it through their heads that threatening Social Security is political hara-kiri, these Democrats seem to have a sort of death wish to raise taxes.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CRISIS IN THE PHILIPPINES: The Marcos Era and Beyond. Edited by John Bresnan. (Princeton University, Cloth, $30; Paper, $10.95.) Since 1898 the Philippines has maintained a precarious relationship with the United States.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TROLLEY TOURS Cape May's annual Christmas Lights Trolley Tours have started and will continue through Dec. 28, offering visitors the spectacle of Victorian Cape May aglitter in Yule decorations.

title: New York Plays Reluctant Landlord
description: THE three-story brownstone at 110 Hart Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn is little more than a shell, a sagging husk without heat, hot water or toilets.

title: TAIWAN'S RISKY REFRAIN: 'SELF-DETERMINATION'
description: Dr. Hong Chi-chang, a psychiatrist and opposition leader, tried to explain why he was dancing around a foreigner's questions.

title: In Season of Ups and Downs, Patriots Climb Back to the Top
description: FIRST, a few words about the recent winning streak.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Beyond Narration
description: During the winter of 1983-84, while the Museum of Modern Art was closed for alterations, something happened in the New York photography world. A new type of art photography appeared in which staged events, rather than real life, provided the subject matter - staged events, furthermore, with a strong narrative element missing from art photography since the Victorian era.

title: G.M. Replacing Faulty Tires On 25,000 Cars and Trucks
description: The General Motors Corporation says improper alignment on about 25,000 1985 and early 1986 model cars and light trucks has prompted it to replace all-season radial tires that wore prematurely on the vehicles.

title: ''AFFORDABLE HOUSING''
description: AN American flag appears on the screen, and a man's voice says, ''America is about choices,'' and then a few seconds later, ''But for many Americans, the choice of housing is narrowing, and in Westchester is very limited.''

title: LIKE ACHILLES IN HIS ARMOR -- 'A VERY MALE THING TO DO'
description: I FOUND myself avoiding the issue. ''So you're going on a bike trip?'' they ask, and I say, ''That's right. A bike-bike - the kind you pedal. Savannah, Georgia, to Cape May, New Jersey.'' And then the inevitable question: ''But why are you going alone?''

title: 'ANNIE' IN DARIEN BALANCED AND BRISK
description: THE musical tonic for the real cockeyed optimists among us is not ''South Pacific,'' which recently closed at the Darien Dinner Theater. It's ''Annie,'' which just opened there.

title: POSTINGS: Southbury Shift;
description: Southbury, Conn., is known for its 2,580-unit Heritage Village retirement community and its antiques dealers. But a recent influx of corporations in the immediate area has created a new demand, and a $17 million hotel and conference center will soon meet it.

title: Wilkins Continues to Amaze
description: The conversations usually begin: ''This one you had to see.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in last Sunday's sports section on a chart that showed the Giants' effectiveness against running plays this season incorrectly described the information presented.

title: PALLY, THE TALK OF ORFAX
description: BOBBY REX'S GREATEST HIT By Marianne Gingher. 308 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Recent Cassettes
description: Juarez With Paul Muni, Bette Davis, Brian Aherne and John Garfield. Directed by William Dieterle. 1939. Key Video. 132 minutes. $59.98.

title: Defense Aide Ends Sentence
description: Paul Thayer, the former No. 2 official at the Defense Department and chief of the LTV Corporation, has been released from a halfway house after serving a 19-month sentence for his involvement in an insider trading scandal.

title: FOR BRAZIL AND ARGENTINA, NEW AMITY
description: Using such innocuous instruments as trade in onions and carrots, as well as more sophisticated exchanges on nuclear energy and biotechnology, Brazil and Argentina have begun burying their political rivalry and assuming the challenge of integrating their economies.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 12, 1986
PAINTING THE WILDERNESS
description: Even before you reach the gallery building there's something that suggests you're in another world.

title: THE STRIKES AGAINST THE HANDICAPPED
description: Re: ''When Society Is the Handicap,'' by Robin Mayr, Opinion Page, Nov. 16:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Getting Rid of the Ghoulish Image
description: TWO years ago, after losing a brother in December, a great-grandmother in January and an uncle in February, Bostonian Diane Latham left a successful career as a broadcast engineer and entered mortuary school.

title: MURDER CASE IN SUSPECT'S PAST
description: Ralph Davis, who the authorities say shot and killed Mayor Edward King and wounded two members of the City Council, was acquitted seven years ago of a murder charge in California, police records show.

title:
ART;
FROM THE ARCADES OF THE PAST, AN EXHIBIT THAT IS PURE FUN
description: PURSUING the notion that a holiday exhibition should be a good time, the Bruce Museum and the Hurlbutt Galleries, Greenwich institutions collaborating for the first time, have imported fun by the truckload. There was one handy but remarkable source, the collection of arcade and musical machines of Dr. James W. Smith of Greenwich.

title: Susan Bartlett Wed in Boston
description: The marriage of Susan Appleton Bartlett, an associate at the New York law firm Engel & Mulholland, to Douglas Edmondson Crater, who received a master's degree last month from the Columbia University School of Architecture, took place yesterday at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Blainey Colmore performed the ceremony.

title: PAINFULLY BECOMING HERSELF
description: WILLA CATHER The Emerging Voice. By Sharon O'Brien. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: RADON COUNTS ARE HIGH IN 3 UPSTATE COUNTIES
description: A quarter of the houses in three upstate counties and 5 percent of all houses in New York State, have radon levels above the Federal safety standard, according to a study by the State Energy Authority.

title: Albany Rejects Dairy Competition
description: The New York State Agriculture Commissioner, Joseph Gerace, last week denied a New Jersey dairy permission to sell milk throughout New York City. While his office defended the decision on legal grounds, criticism ranged from Governor Cuomo's ''disappointing'' to Mayor Koch's ''unconscionable'' - and Attorney General Robert Abrams's call for changes in the law.

title: POSTINGS: Updating the Updates; Plain-English Housing Law
description: The Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit civic group in New York City, does a commendable job of translating arcane housing and rent codes into plain English. The volatility of the regulations, however, makes it hard for the council, and everybody else, to keep up with changes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
The Silver Bullion
description: The United States Mint has achieved substantial success with its new American Eagle silver bullion coin.

title: HOW TO GET THAT SQUEAKING FLOOR TO STAY QUIET
description: A wood floor that makes squeaking or creaking noises is seldom an indication of a serious maintenance problem. But it can be very annoying -- and the problem will rarely go away by itself.

title: LAST REUNION AT THE FAMILY RETREAT
description: On a drizzly afternoon last summer, my 82-year-old grandmother and I returned for the last time to the cabin in Minnesota that had linked four generations of my family. Her two older sisters, my great-aunts, had reluctantly decided to sell the cabin to someone outside the family.

title: 'TOUGH KIDS': READERS RESPOND
description: The article ''Helping 'Tough Kids' Turn Around'' on Nov. 2 has outraged the majority of our community.

title: Catholic Theologian David Tracy
description: The photograph of David Tracy in his office at the University of Chicago shows works by or about Merton, Marx, Calvin and Hume, Bonhoeffer, Barth and Rahner, Augustine and, beyond easy reach, Aquinas.

title: Stop Hiding, Colonel North
description: There is only one course of action for Lieut. Col.

title: Flurocarbons
description: To the Editor: Richard Barnett argues that a unilateral ban on chlorofluorocarbons, which it is now widely agreed are destroying the ozone layer, will fail to bring about the necessary worldwide ban we need (''The U.S. Can't Do the Job All Alone,'' Forum, Nov. 16).
