He fails to note that the majority of CFC's are probably produced and used here, for air conditioning, refrigeration, sterilizing medical supplies, etc., and that a United States ban in itself would be a tremendous step toward solving the increasingly ominous ozone-depletion problem. There would be much more incentive for industry scientists to find nonpolluting, cost-effective alternatives - which, once found, will bring the rest of world around. LARRY EPHRON Director, Institute for a Future Kensington, Calif., Nov. 16

title: Japanese Fall In Love With The 'Peeping Tom' Press
description: A JAPANESE comedian who uses the stage name Beat Takeshi became the unlikely spark last week for a debate over where an individual's right to privacy ends and the journalist's right to information begins. The issue is hardly new, in Japan or elsewhere, but Mr. Takeshi gave it sudden urgency. With 11 friends whom he described as part of his ''army,'' he marched into the offices of Friday, a scandal magazine, and roughed up a senior editor and four staff members. The comedian, one of the most popular entertainers in Japan, told the police that he could no longer restrain himself after a Friday photographer had intrusively taken pictures of his female companion.

title: ...And L.A. Greets the Future With a Contemporary Museum
description: With all the excitement and controversy surrounding the opening of the Museum of Contemporary Art last week, one thing is clear: Los Angeles now has one of the finest facilities for contemporary art in the world. With two splendid buildings, the support of the city, a thriving community of artists and a growing number of collectors, there is very little that the Museum of Contemporary Art, better known as MOCA, does not have the potential to do.

title: 'DO EVERYTHING,' SHE SAID
description: FRANCES WILLARD A Biography. By Ruth Bordin. Illustrated. 294 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. $25.

title: Questionable Bargains in Gray-Market Equipment
description: FOR prospective camera buyers, the big news this week was that the Supreme Court has agreed to hear a case that will decide the future of so-called gray-market imports. The gray market consists of consumer goods - cameras, watches, stereos, perfumes - that are diverted from foreign markets and imported through channels outside the established American distribution network. The consequences of the gray-market system are twofold: For the American distributor, it means fewer sales and less profit. For the typical camera buyer, it means a less expensive camera.

title: PRETORIA ASSAILED ON SECURITY STEPS
description: South Africa's newest tightening of emergency rule, which includes stringent censorship, was sharply criticized today by the Government's white adversaries on both its left and its right.

title: UNABLE TO WAIT FOR THE GODS
description: MISHIMA A Vision of the Void. By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Alberto Manguel with the author. 152 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Iraqis Bomb Teheran; Raid First in 7 Months
description: Iraqi warplanes destroyed an antiaircraft defense network and a power plant in Teheran today in the first air raid on the Iranian capital in seven months, the Baghdad radio said.

title: DAVIS, ESCAPE PLAN THWARTED, DAMAGES HIS CELL
description: Larry Davis, thwarted in an attempt to pass an apparent escape plan to two visitors at Rikers Island, ripped the sink from the wall of his cell yesterday, flooding his cell block and damaging the jail infirmary.

title: MASSACHUSETTS PRESSED ON WELFARE PAYMENTS
description: Advocates for homeless families and other welfare recipients will argue in court next week that the state should be ordered to present a plan by Dec. 31 for raising welfare grants.

title: LEARNING ON THE JOB
description: I HAVE BEEN THINKING A LOT about something that happened to me when I was The Times's correspondent in India, long ago just yesterday. I had been based in New Delhi for some time and, feeling full of India and myself, went in one day to talk to the Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, a man I admired a great deal. Smart and sassy, I asked him a question about a very sensitive subject, India's occupation of Kashmir. I wanted to goad him a little and I succeeded; it didn't take much, this man of intellect and power was a sensitive fellow. He looked at me, jumped up, smacked his bald pate in magnificent irritation and shouted, ''Rosenthal, you have been in this country for four years and you have not learned one damned thing yet!''

title: PICKING UP WHERE CHEKHOV LEFT OFF
description: No one knows what Anton Chekhov called the long, cluttered but precociously talented play that, remodeled by the British dramatist Michael Frayn and titled ''Wild Honey,'' arrives at the Virginia Theater on Thursday. No one can even be sure when he wrote it. Maybe it was in 1878, when he was 18 and still a restless schoolboy in rural Taganrog. More probably it was in 1881, when he was a full-time medical student at Moscow University and a part-time contributor of comic sketches and articles to the humorous magazines. But whatever his and his play's respective ages, one thing seems certain. Chekhov came very rapidly to accept that he'd written a mess, muddle and unstageable fiasco, a strong candidate for theatrical oblivion. It was certainly the very last piece to celebrate its centenary as ''Wild Honey,'' with Ian McKellen in the lead, has in fact been celebrating it: by triumphing in London and coming in search of a similar success to the New World.

title: IN SUPPORT OF SCHOOL TAKEOVERS
description: IN A pluralistic society such as ours, governance emerges from the resolution of the needs of contending interest groups. However, I view as singularly unfortunate the opposition of the New Jersey School Boards Association to the plan of the state's Department of Education to take over certain school districts that have gone into educational bankruptcy.

title: U.S.-SPANISH DISCORD OVER BASES IS GROWING
description: Discord between the United States and Spain over American bases in this country has sharpened, with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Spanish officials separately threatening to shut down the bases altogether.

title: SUBURBS ABSORB MORE IMMIGRANTS, MOSTLY THE AFFLUENT AND EDUCATED
description: Many new immigrants are bypassing congested central cities and settling in affluent suburban neighborhoods, skipping what historically has been the first and most difficult step of becoming assimilated into American life, recent studies show.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING POINSETTIAS THROUGH THE YEAR
description: HOW about that poinsettia that you kept from last season? Has it colored so that it will be presentable for the Christmas holiday? If not, why has it turned out to be a disappointment?

title: HANFORD HAS LINK TO NUCLEAR DAWN
description: Plans for the Hanford Engineer Works, which became the world's first atomic power plant, were started within minutes of the world's first nuclear chain reaction, achieved 42 years ago under the football stadium at the University of Chicago.

title: NBC Is Seeking A Louder Voice
description: Even a television network needs some help in getting its message across. Or so the new president of NBC, Robert D. Wright, declared in a memorandum urging the company to form a political action committee to insure that its interests are ''well represented'' before Congress.

title: Penn State Fraternities Ban Alcohol at Recruiting Parties
description: Fraternities at Pennsylvania State University will ban alcohol from recruiting functions and ask that guests at parties where drinks are served show identification, a spokesman said.

title: Jerusalem
description: Jerusalem offers a white Christmas about once every five years, and even then it's usually a token dusting of confectioner's sugar over the domes and spires of the Old City. No telling yet if they'll be busing the schoolchildren up from the coast to see snow this year. What is certain as 1986 gives way to 1987 is a number of chilly, drizzly stretches alternating with gloriously sunny days warm enough for lingering at outdoor cafes, bazaars and pedestrian malls.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about junk bonds last week misstated the number of high-yield specialists used by pension plans. SEI estimates that 7 of 1,600 plans it monitors have such specialists.

title: MADISON: A PLAY ABOUT ALCOHOLISM
description: WHAT drives one to start drinking? And what can make the alcoholic stop?

title: Psychoanalyzing Wharton
description: To the Editor:

title: TIPS AID EFFORTS TO FIND ARSONISTS
description: THE guarantee of anonymity for information leading to the arrest and conviction of arsonists or prevention of arson has been the key to the success of the state's three-year-old Arson Tip Award Program, state fire officials say.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MODELS ON THE COURT
description: On Friday night at 8 P.M., a group of professional models - male and female - will don basketball attire and take the court against a co-ed team of Scarsdale High School seniors. Anyone who wants to watch this display of youth, beauty and athletic prowess needs simply to show up at the Scarsdale High School gymnasium, pay $3 or $4 (student and adult prices), and climb into the stands for a seat.

title: PROTESTORS TAKE ON HUNTERS IN FOREST
description: HUNTERS entering the Yale forest in the northeastern part of the state Thanksgiving morning found that, like the deer they were pursuing, they, too, were quarry.

title: NEGOTIATIONS STALLED ON EXTENDING BAN ON S.R.O. CONVERSION
description: As the expiration nears for a city moratorium on the conversion or demolition of single-room-occupancy hotels, city officials are still debating how to proceed.

title: Nikolais's Creative Vision
description: Alwin Nikolais, at 74, is not one to rest on his laurels - or even to rest. On Tuesday, the Nikolais Dance Theater will open at the Joyce Theater for a three-week season of new and old explorations by Mr. Nikolais of his world of magical color, shape and sound. The season's repertory will include four new and recent pieces as well as work that stretches back over 30 of his nearly 50 years in dance.

title: Catholic Theologian David Tracy
description: In a quotation from his forthcoming book, David Tracy writes, ''The hope proclaimed by all religious ways is well expressed by the classic Buddhist apothegm: 'The unlived life is not worth reflecting upon.'

title: Q & A
description: Caribbean Choice Question:What can be done when the hotel you prefer in the Caribbean is not included in an airline's package offer of flight and hotel. I want to stay at the Golden Lemon on St. Kitts, but the cost of the regular air fare is keeping me away. - J. M. D., New York Answer:A possible solution is to ask a travel agent to book the hotel and to ask an airline to issue an I.T.X., or inclusive tour excursion, fare. That fare, which is ostensibly linked to the purchase of accommodations as part of a package plan, is lower than regular fares and competitive with the fares that wholesalers buy for their group tours. According to travel agents, they can sometimes obtain an I.T.X. fare even if the passenger has booked a hotel that does not figure in package arrangements. The round-trip I.T.X. fare from New York to St. Kitts during the winter, high season is $485 on weekends and $429 midweek. The regular fare the year round is $598.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER. By Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute Press, $15.95.) In the autumn of 1972, despite rumors of peace, United States Navy pilots flew A-6 Intruder attack planes in bombing raids over North Vietnam.

title: Maradona Moving?
description: Diego Armando Maradona, the 26-year-old striker who led Argentina to victory in the World Cup tournament last summer in Mexico, will soon play for Real madrid of Spain, according to El Pais, a Madrid newspaper. The newspaper quoted Maradona as saying he had talked with Ramon Mendoza, the president of Spain's top pro soccer team, and expected soom to leave Naples of Italy, with whom he has a $1.1 million-a-year contract running through 1988.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DINING INS AND OUTS
description: DR. Gerald Greitzer didn't eat out like this in childhood. Then, ''special'' meant dinner at the St. Regis Restaurant - the one on 101st Street, not the famous one. Now he was sitting down to an $87.50-a-person feast at Le Guerdon, a restaurant on Old Route 22 here that specializes in haute cuisine with a French and Scandanavian flavor.

title: THAWED BY GHOSTS
description: THE COMPLETE SHORT STORIES OF L. P. HARTLEY Introduction by Lord David Cecil. 760 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $24.95.

title: Q and A
description: No Proprietary Lease

title: NIGHTMARE IN COUNTRY WALK
description: UNSPEAKABLE ACTS By Jan Hollingsworth. Illustrated. 592 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $18.95.

title: ROCK: BRITISH NEW ORDER
description: THE British band New Order does its best to take the fun out of dance music. It concocts propulsive rhythm tracks and simple but insistent tunes, in order, it seems, to show how hollow and mechanical that music can be.

title: CONTENTION SURROUNDS CONTRACT FOR PORT CHESTER REDEVELOPMENT
description: THE contract for a $130 million redevelopment of Port Chester's aging business center is under review by three consultants, but, meanwhile, nine businesses are suing the members of the Village Board of Trustees for signing it, one board member is attempting to dissociate himself from the contract and the Mayor is being accused of a conflict of interest.

title: F.A.A. CRACKING DOWN ON AIRSPACE VIOLATIONS
description: In a crackdown prompted by a midair collision over a Los Angeles suburb Aug. 31, the Government has taken action to suspend the licenses of more than 30 private pilots accused of illegally flying into the restricted zone over the Los Angeles International Airport.

title: SECRET FILES OPENED TO PUBLIC
description: People who believe they might have been the subject of New York City Police Department political surveillance during the 1960's can now apply for any secret files kept under their names.

title: Patricia Maroni and Julian Saldanha Are Married
description: The Memorial Church at Harvard University was the setting in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday for the marriage of Patricia M. Maroni and Julian A. Saldanha. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Maroni of North Providence, R.I., and her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Saldanha of Bombay, India.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE'S no point in saying there aren't any hornets' nests in New York. There probably are, literally, and there certainly are figuratively. In fact, the figurative ones are absolutely essential to the health of the city. New Yorkers need to stir up the odd hornet now and then to feel really alive.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SOME BRASS When it comes to music, all-brass ensembles are not your common garden variety group. So it has to be the epitome of coincidence to have two brass ensembles scheduled for one afternoon within miles of each other. Given that coincidence, today's the day that those who like their holiday music brassy can choose between the Canadian Brass, the versatile quintet that takes over the Tilles Center at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, and the Brass Ring, another quintet that provides the entertainment for '' Christmas at Coe Hall,'' at the Planting Fields Arboretum in nearby Oyster Bay.

title: AUTUMN AT NIGHTFALL, WINTER IN THE MORNING
description: I SIT here at my bedroom window sleepily gazing at a familiar sight; so familiar that most days I'm afraid I look and do not see.

title: Violence in Paris Blocks Reforms
description: After three weeks of large and sometimes violent demonstrations in the streets of Paris, the French Governmnent gave in last week to student protests against a proposed reform of the national university system.

title: SEEKING THE ELUSIVE MANATEE
description: On a clear, quiet day in early winter, Florida's St. Johns River evokes images of jungle waterways in distant lands. Trees garlanded in Spanish moss conceal the banks; majestic birds stare down from the branches and from the buoys that mark the river's channel. The St. Johns River, largest in the state, flows through unspoiled areas for much of its 300-mile course. The multitude of pleasure boats that ply the tranquil waters in warm weather is not in evidence early in the season. Only the cry of birds and the subdued hum of a boat disturbs the morning silence.

title: WESLEYAN CITES 6 FOR HARASSMENT
description: As prospective students and their parents took the 11 A.M. daily tour of the hilltop campus of Wesleyan University here in October and November, they were told more about campus life than the usual description of the food in the cafeteria and the closets in the dormitories.

title: Regal Is Going Out In A Grand Manner
description: THE old-fashioned American hot rod is not dead. Not quite. Not yet.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
HANDS OF AN ARTIST, VOICES OF DRUMS
description: ONE recent Sunday afternoon, as a dozen or so visitors to the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art wandered through the current exhibition of African traditional and modern art, they came upon an impromptu pot drum concert.

title: Meet My Whatsit
description: The term I prefer is place-mate, which my sister coined in 1982, as far as I know.

title: RESTAURATEUR BRINGS A TASTE OF ITALY TO LA GUARDIA
description: Rocco Manniello has expanded.

title: TREE POACHERS FACE FINES -- AND BAD ODORS
description: ANYONE who cuts evergreens along New Jersey highways, or in forests and parks, for holiday decorations could suffer costly and bizarre consquences.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Recent Cassettes
description: Strauss' Fledermaus Starring Joan Sutherland. Conducted by Richard Bonynge. The Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra.

title: SCHOOLS DENIED USE OF LANDFILL
description: IN a case pitting schools against town and town against state, the Town of Islip has banned its 11 school districts from using the Blydenburgh landfill to dispose of their trash.

title: Accidental Success
description: The laws of bridge are designed to make the dummy a totally passive participant, with very limited rights to be invoked when some infraction has taken place. This department recently reported a sensationally bad piece of ''dummy'' play, and it is time to redress the balance with a remarkably successful, though accidental, intervention by the dummy.

title: FAMILY PORTRAIT PAINTED WITH FLAIR
description: ''PAINT us? Paint us?''

title: PAPERS REPORT CANADIAN SHIFTED MILLIONS IN BANK
description: Ernest Miller, one of two Canadians reportedly involved in financing secret American arms shipments to Iran, was depicted in published accounts here today as a shadowy figure who passed more than $24 million through a personal bank account in Toronto's Chinatown a few months before the deal that purportedly helped finance the arms transfers.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: In Paris there are weird ways to flush a toilet. Some have chains that you pull down. And black things you step on the floor.

title: CAMPUS CONGRESS FOR JOHN JAY
description: GOVERNMENT ''by the people'' took on new meaning at John Jay High School in Cross River last week as students, teachers, bus drivers, secretaries and cafeteria workers elected representatives to a new communitywide student government.

title: A June Wedding For Ellen Nalle
description: The engagement of Ellen Ritchie Nalle to John Randolph Hass has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Horace D. Nalle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. Mr. Hass is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Hass of Washington and New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: IS LILCO PREPARED FOR ANOTHER MAJOR STORM?
description: IS the Long Island Lighting Company prepared to maintain service if a major snowstorm or another Hurricane Gloria devastates the Island?

title: Nuclear Bomb Set Off In a Test After Delays
description: Federal scientists set off a nuclear bomb beneath a desert plateau on the Nevada Test Site today.

title: Catholic Theologian David Tracy
description: With the large and varied number of issues facing the Roman Catholic Church, is it unnatural that it finds among its scholars a diversity of opinion? It would seem a credit to the depth of the Roman Catholic faith that several answers, or opinions, be put forth on how best to practice the faith while facing the problems and issues of today. PATRICK J. GERAGHTY Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Off-Season Biking, Cooking in Lausanne
description: Cycling Tours For Winter Travelers

title: U.N., FACING PINCH, SEEKS NEW BUDGET RULES
description: In an attempt to avert the most severe financial crisis in its history, United Nations members are agonizing over a package of changes that would overhaul the world organization's budget-making process.

title: DANIEL BARENBOIM RENEWS LINK TO CHOPIN
description: WITH tonight's concert at Avery Fisher Hall, Daniel Barenboim will conclude his New York cycle of the Beethoven sonatas. He has played them in several cities in recent seasons, and Madrid and Tokyo are to come. ''Then,'' he said over lunch at his hotel Friday, ''I will give them a rest, probably for a long time.'' Before that, though, he will turn to music far removed in style, technique and spirit: his all-Chopin recital will be the first regularly scheduled public concert at the renovated Carnegie Hall, Tuesday afternoon at 3.

title: NOW, THE AGE OF FAST-BUCK BANKING
description: Snapshots of American banking practices, 1986:

title: ARTICLES DRAW READERS' PRAISES
description: Congratulations on the Pete Dunne ''In the Natural State'' articles. They are always enjoyable. In this world of chaos, it's great to read something nonpolitical and noncontroversial. LYNN MARTIN

title: Recent Sales
description: Albertson $350,000 27 Woods Lane 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, pool, 2-car garage, extra building lot; taxes $2,250. Bay Shore $77,000 19 Spruce Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; basement, enclosed porch, 2-car garage, corner location; taxes $2,400.

title: Robin Slater Weds Marc Wolpow in Massachusetts
description: Robin Sue Slater, a daughter of Mrs. Allyn Levy of West Newton, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Paul D. Slater of Newton, Mass., and Naples, Fla., was married last night to Marc Brian Wolpow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Wolpow of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Richard Yellin performed the ceremony at the Belmont (Mass.)

title: Good With the Bad
description: HE still thinks he got a bum rap, but after spending four months in a Federal prison camp, Mike Bell, a former defensive end for the Kansas City Chiefs, says some good came out of the experience. ''The education I received at that place is one that no one wants to get.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Block Magazine Deductions
description: The Internal Revenue Service has served notice that it will not permit full deductions on 1986 tax returns for the cost of subscriptions to business magazines or investment publications paid several years in advance.

title: They Don't Give Medals for Pleading the Fifth; A Waiver Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Barrett Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. C. Redington Barrett Jr. of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Adams Barrett, to Benjamin Gardner Dawson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dawson of Dover, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: A HUSBAND, A WIFE, A CORPORATION
description: LAST week wasn't the week to look for Sheryl and Mel London in their usual haunts in Manhattan's East Village or in Saltaire on Fire Island. Last week was the week to look for Symbiosis Inc. - ''which is a description of our company and our marriage,'' Mr. London said - in Mexico.

title: America II Loses to USA, Fights For Survival
description: Tom Blackaller's USA stunned John Kolius's America II in a crucial America's Cup race today, beating the New York Yacht Club's team by 2 minutes 17 seconds.

title: WAR GAMES IN OMAN: THE LESSONS LEARNED
description: After five days of demanding military effort for 5,000 British troops and their Omani friends, it was time to look at the lessons learned.

title: Psychoanalyzing Wharton
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRISTMAS IS A TIME WHEN CHLDREN CAN GET INTO THE ACT
description: ONE of the most loved Christmas treats of my childhood was tiny mince pies, over which I spent many a happy hour in the kitchen. With the first bite of the year, you got a wish. Unfortunately, the wish made by many of the grownups who bit into my pies was that they had sunk their teeth into something else. My pastry had been rolled out, punched back into a ball and squeezed through my hot little fist until it was a nice warm gray mass, like plasticine. Luckily, the pies were small and filled with a rich mixture of suet, spices and dried fruit marinated in enough brandy to make up for the shortcomings in the pastry department.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Strengthening Law on Ties to South Africa The City Council's Governmental Operations Committee is to debate a bill that would strengthen a 1985 law requiring contractors doing business with the city to certify that they do not sell goods or services to agencies of the South African Government. The new proposal would require the city to reject a low bid by a contractor doing business with South Africa if another is within 5 percent of the lowest bid. 10 A.M., City Council Chambers, City Hall.

title: CITY MAKES BARTER OFFER TO DEVELOPERS
description: The Koch administration, struggling with the city's housing shortage, is offering developers a valuable piece of city-owned property on a barter basis: an East Side site in Manhattan in exchange for privately built or rehabilitated housing elsewhere.

title: G. G. MIRCHANDANI
description: G. G. Mirchandani, former chief editor and general manager of United News of India, died in New Delhi today.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
The Royal Courts
description: As Emilio Sanchez of Spain tossed a tennis ball to serve, the music of rustling crockery and crystal floated down from above him. Sanchez caught the toss and stared through the vastness of the Royal Albert Hall at a box filled with spectators in evening dress.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Sidney Myer, Satire And Songs in Cabaret
description: Sidney Myer, a cabaret singer whose tastes lean toward sharply rhymed comic patter songs, has Groucho Marx's eyebrows, Peter Allen's postvaudevillian song-and-dance attitude, and a nickname, ''Mr. Panache,'' earned from his having performed off and on at Panache (149 East 57th Street) for five years.

title: GIANTS KEEP ROLLING ALONG
description: When the Giants took the field today against the St. Louis Cardinals, they had already won their division title. So they could have rested their regulars and taken it easy and preserved their bodies and played out the string.

title: Advertising; Black Angus Account Moving to Thompson
description: Stuart Anderson's Black Angus and Cattle Company, a subsidiary of the Marriott Corporation with 117 restaurants out west, has finished a major agency review and has selected J. Walter Thompson, San Francisco, to replace Hal Riney & Partners, also of that city.

title: QUESTIONER OF THE PRESIDENT'S MEN
description: Senator William S. Cohen has seen it all before: the drama of a major White House scandal, a beleaguered President, an inquisitive Congress and an aggressive press.

title: U.S. SPY ARRESTED AT AIR BASE, NICARAGUA SAYS
description: A self-styled counterterrorist identified as the brother of a United States Congressman has been arrested in a restricted area of Nicaragua and detained by the Sandinista Government on suspicion of espionage.

title: Ulster's Minority, Yes, but Ireland's Majority
description: To the Editor:

title: Quarter Loss for Varity
description: Weak demand for farm machinery and diesel engines and several plant closings caused the Varity Corporation, the former Massey-Ferguson Ltd., to report a third-quarter loss of $19.7 million on Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If it were easy, it would have been done before.'' - Jeana Yeager, co-pilot of plane attempting nonstop flight around the world. [ B16:1. ]

title: Protesters Given Deadline on Charges
description: Fifty-eight antinuclear activists arrested during demonstrations Saturday protesting the launching of the country's most powerful Trident submarine have until Dec. 26 to pay a fine or plead not guilty, officials said.

title: DANCE: YVES MUSARD AND SHEILA KAMINSKY
description: YVES MUSARD and Sheila Kaminsky, two modern-dance choreographers who would seem to have little in common, were presented on the same bill in the Algaia Dance Productions series Thursday night at the Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East Seventh Street.

title: Sheara Avital, a Lawyer, Is Bride of David Arbit
description: Sheara Avital, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Moshe Avital of Whitestone, Queens, and David Lewis Arbit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Arbit of Highland Park, N.J., were married yesterday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Yakov Hilsenrath, Rabbi Zelig Block, Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik, Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz and the father of the bride officiated.

title: BOOM IS PFFT, POLITICIANS GO, MONEY ALWAYS TALKS
description: It is not just the unsettling specter of the Hunt brothers battling through bankruptcy proceedings, the Dallas Cowboys struggling to avoid a losing season or the presence of post-boom monuments like the 90-foot abyss in an abandoned construction site north of downtown that everyone calls ''the Hole.''

title: HANOI PARTY OPENS KEY PARLEY TODAY
description: Vietnam's Communist leaders meet this week in a crucial party congress that they say will have to set a new course for the country if Hanoi is to overcome debilitating economic and political problems.

title: BankAmerica Capital Search
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, in what could be the next step in its recovery plan, has begun to look for an outside infusion of capital, according to industry sources.

title: Steelworkers Reach Accord to End Strike
description: Union negotiators and the Carpenter Technology Corporation reached tentative agreement yesterday to end a 15-week strike by nearly 500 steelworkers, a mediator announced.

title: COURT APPROVES PLAN FOR INSECT-DAMAGED PINE
description: Almost as fast as they advanced to attack the valuable pine forests of the South, the Southern pine beetles are now retreating. Left in their wake is a crippled lumber industry and a bitter debate over the uses of national forest land.

title: STAGE: ROGER HEDDEN'S 'BODIES, REST AND MOTION'
description: THE voice of a talented young playwright is a precious but fragile phenomenon. Roger Hedden is talented, yet since his auspicious debut with ''Been Taken,'' a one-act comedy in the 1984 Ensemble Studio Theater Marathon, his striking voice has been harder and harder to discern. Mr. Hedden's follow-up plays at the E.S.T. have been marked by mimicry, intended and not, of writers as various as Buchner and Mamet. In ''Bodies, Rest and Motion,'' his new effort at Lincoln Center's Newhouse Theater, the mannerisms and attitudes of theatrical fashion form a hermetic seal that locks out not only Mr. Hedden's distinctive sensibility but also most vital signs of human life.

title: TOY PETS VS. THE REAL THING
description: There is a cat scooting around at the new F. A. O. Schwarz store in the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue at 58th Street. To the delight of the adults and children that crowd around it all day, it easily navigates a maze of metal pipes that look like a miniature Jungle Gym, meows, purrs and likes to be petted.

title: KHASHOGGI REPORTEDLY MADE $250,000 IN DEAL
description: The Saudi Arabian businessman Adnan Khashoggi made $250,000 on a seven-day loan to finance the first shipment of United States arms to Iran, the Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported today.

title: For Mobutu: A Handshake, Not a Hug
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire got a warm welcome at the White House last week, the sort he's grown used to in 20 years of official visits. President Reagan called him ''a voice of good sense and good will.'' Secretary of State Shultz excused himself early from a Congressional hearing on the Iran scandal to meet with Mr. Mobutu.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Big V Supermarkets Inc., Florida, N.Y., named its president, A. Richard Rosenberg, to the additional post of chairman, replacing the supermarket chain's founder, William Rosenberg, who will become chairman of the executive committee. It also named its chief operating officer, David G. Bronstein, to the additional post of president, and appointed Cornelius J. J. Madera and Gary S. Koppele senior vice presidents.

title: TRUCK BLAST KILLS WORKER
description: A gasoline tanker truck exploded Saturday, crushing to death one worker, injuring four and leveling a trucking office. The explosion, at Lamar Transport on the city's southwest side, came at 8:30 A.M.

title: Bridge: Wei Is Honored by League For Contributions to Game
description: For the past 60 years the American Contract Bridge League has designated an ''honorary member,'' recognizing long and meritorious service to the game.

title: Advertising; Ayer Said to Be Near Acquisition of C.&W.
description: N. W. Ayer, founded in 1869 and the country's oldest ad agency, is getting ever closer to acquiring Cunningham & Walsh, according to a source in the agency industry whose news tips have never been wrong. The source said the announcement is scheduled for this week.

title: AMERICA II BEATEN AND ELIMINATED
description: The New York Yacht Club's ties with the America's Cup unraveled today as America II was eliminated from the challengers' series.

title: THE IRAN MONEY FLOW: TRACING THE COMPLEX STEPS
description: Investigators are still trying to map the complex flow of money used in the Iranian arms transactions, but they have concluded that the operation had three main reasons: The arms sales themselves required secrecy; the relationship among the participants was politically sensitive, and the disposition of the proceeds may have involved illegalities.

title: Jennifer Baker Is Wed To G.R. Dotti in Nepal
description: Jennifer Lea Baker, the daughter of John Milnes Baker of Katonah, N.Y., and Mrs. Eivind P. Rynning of Weston, Conn., was married at the Buddhist Monastery in Katmandu, Nepal, yesterday to Gerard Robert Dotti, the son of Mrs. Louis Marius Dotti of Nice, France, and the late Mr. Dotti. The civil ceremony performed by the Venerable Rimpoche Chokyi Nima was witnessed by David Gandle, the United States Consul General in Nepal, and Ian A. Baker, the brother of the bride and director of the Experiment in International Living's study abroad program in Nepal.

title: TAYLOR IS UNAVOIDABLE SUBJECT
description: The statistics for Lawrence Taylor today were nothing special: four tackles, three assists, one sack. So much for statistics.

title: Lobbyist on Education Is Convicted in Scheme
description: A Federal jury has convicted Dan Alexander, founder and director of Save Our Schools, a national education lobby, on charges of racketeering and extortion.

title: Man Trying to Detain Theft Suspect Is Slain
description: A Queens man was shot to death yesterday when he tried to capture a man he suspected of robbing him three weeks earlier, the police said.

title: Washington Watch; Judge Is Focus Of Phone Fight
description: THE Big Seven regional Bell Telephone holding companies, anxious for an all-out war of competition in the telephone business, have abandoned nearly all hopes of getting help on this effort from Congress.

title: Fed Approves Citicorp Plan
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced Friday that it had approved the application of Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, to deal in futures contracts on stock indexes.

title: HUMANITIES GROUP AWARDING $14.2 MILLION TO ORGANIZATIONS
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has awarded grants totaling $14.2 million to 41 educational and cultural institutions in the United States. The largest single award this year was a $1 million grant to the American Council of Learned Societies in New York.

title: 2 Treasury Note Auctions in Week
description: Treasury auctions this week include a two-year note issue on Wednesday and a four-year issue on Thursday, as well as today's regular weekly sale of new bills due in three and six months.

title: Don't Decommission Civil Rights
description: John Bunzel's tenure as a member of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights has expired. He asked President Reagan not to reappoint him, claiming the agency has lost credibility and ''moral strength.'' And because he thinks the goal of equal rights has largely been achieved, he suggests that Congress should abolish the agency when it comes up for reauthorization in 1989.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Yakov Kreizberg Leads City Symphony at Tully
description: The work of a promising young conductor, Yakov Kreizberg, was the most notable element Saturday night at the New York City Symphony concert in Alice Tully Hall.

title: MUSIC: MENOTTI PROGRAM
description: CHAMBER music has always been a prominent part of Gian Carlo Menotti's Spoleto Festival, where the daytime concerts have given many an important young artist the first taste of international exposure. It is also the kind of music Mr. Menotti himself has been most likely to write when he is not writing for the stage. ''Spoleto Comes to BAM,'' a new series that will bring to the Brooklyn Academy of Music players both long- and newly associated with Spoleto and its American counterpart in Charleston, S. C., was inaugurated Saturday evening with an all-Menotti program.

title: Pileggi Is Named as Recipient Of Kihss Award for Reporting
description: Nicholas Pileggi, contributing editor of New York magazine, has been named the recipient of the third annual Peter Kihss Award, for excellence in reporting on New York City government.

title: POWER OF KENYA'S LEADER IS GROWING
description: The Kenyan authorities appear to be moving to place increasingly greater power in the hands of President Daniel arap Moi and the nation's sole political party, as some church leaders and other critics warn that such steps border on totalitarianism in a country that professes to be a democracy.

title: President of Reliance Is Credited With Gains
description: John C. Morley, a career executive with the Exxon Corporation whose experience was in oil and chemicals, was given a formidable assignment in 1980: to go to Cleveland and run the Reliance Electric Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1986
description: International Report

title: NORTH ROLE CITED IN BID TO UNSEAT CONTRA AID FOES
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, then an official of the National Security Council, helped a conservative political action committee mount a campaign this year that was designed to defeat Congressional opponents of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, people familiar with the effort said today.

title: DANCE: MIMI GERRARD IN STOCK-MARKET SATIRE
description: THE Mimi Garrard Dance Theater is aptly named. Ms. Garrard is on firmer ground with theatricalized works than with pure dance. At any rate, so it seemed when the company performed Saturday at the Garrard Studio at 155 Wooster Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described the future earnings of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. as the company estimated them in a recent Government filing. The company estimated that the rate of growth in earnings for its department store businesses from 1987 to 1990 would exceed the growth rate in earnings for the specialty store company it plans to spin off.

title: 1980 SOVIET TEST: HOW TO INVADE IRAN
description: The Soviet Union carried out an ambitious exercise of its ability to invade Iran six years ago, according to a newly disclosed ''top secret'' Pentagon evaluation and interviews with present and former Government officials.

title: Disney Studies Its Arvida Unit
description: The Walt Disney Company is considering a variety of options for restructuring its Arvida Disney Corporation real estate subsidiary, a source close to the company said Friday.

title: OFFICIALS VOICE GROWING CONCERN OVER RACIAL INCIDENTS IN U.S. CAMPUSES
description: Educators and civil rights leaders are becoming increasingly worried over what they fear is a proliferation of racial incidents on college campuses around the country.

title: Gunman Surrenders After Nine Hours
description: A man armed with an automatic rifle who held off state and local police officers for nine hours surrendered yesterday without firing a shot, the authorities said.

title: BROWNS TAKE TITLE IN ROUT OF BENGALS
description: Bernie Kosar, the Cleveland quarterback, had gotten the play from Coach Marty Schottenheimer, who got it from Lindy Infante, the Browns' offensive coordinator, who got it from Gary Danielson, the injury-sidelined quarterback who suggested the play in the locker room before the game.

title: PRETORIA REPORTS KILLING A REBEL SUSPECT
description: The South African authorities reported today that they had shot and killed a suspected insurgent from the outlawed African National Congress and that two policemen had been wounded in a land-mine explosion.

title: Audit Finds Lapses In Transit Repairs
description: Poor bookkeeping and inadequate supervision of workers hamper the Transit Authority's station repair program, according to an audit released over the weekend by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: CANNON FACES DEBT DEADLINE
description: The Cannon Group Inc., a fast-growing but financially troubled independent film producer and distributor, may face bankruptcy if the deadline on a $79.6 million debt payment due Monday is not extended.

title: Playoff Picture
description: The National Conference playoff participants were decided yesterday while the Super Bowl remains a possibility for nine teams from the American Conference.

title: Catching Up
description: * Kathy Ormsby, the North Carolina State runner left paralyzed from the waist down when she bolted from a race and jumped off a bridge in June, has been showing the same gritty determination that had helped her break the collegiate 10,000-meter record just seven weeks earlier. According to her mother, Sallie, Ormsby hasn't yet decided whether to return to North Carolina State in January to resume her pre-med studies but in the meantime is making a courageous adjustment to ''a new way of living.''

title: ROLE OF OFFICERS GROWING IN N.S.C.
description: The growing role of military officers in the National Security Council may come under special scrutiny by the commission appointed by President Reagan last month to examine the N.S.C., according to a spokesman for the commission.

title: CHIEFS TOP RAIDERS AND EYE PLAYOFFS
description: Bill Kenney passed for 180 yards and one touchdown and Kansas City forced seven turnovers today en route to a 20-17 triumph over the Los Angeles Raiders that pushed the Chiefs within a victory of their first trip to the playoffs in 15 years.

title: ROCK: LONE JUSTICE
description: WHEN Lone Justice emerged from Hollywood last year, it was a country-rock band with a promising singer, Maria McKee. Now, Ms. McKee is leading an all-new band, and she's more ambitious. At the Ritz on Saturday night, Lone Justice was mixing soul, rock and country. And Ms. McKee sang with a quivering emotionality that could explode into gospel ecstasy, as if she wanted to be Patsy Cline, Janis Joplin and Shirley Caesar rolled into one.

title: Casey at the Source?
description: Let me tell you why I'm scratching my head about my old friend William J. Casey.

title: Advertising; Medical Assignment For Smith/Greenland
description: Hoffman-LaRoche, which is prominent in the vitamin area of the pharmaceutical industry, has turned to Smith/Greenland for a $3 million to $4 million print advertising campaign to tell consumers about the possible benefits of beta-carotene. Research indicates that it may reduce the risk of getting some types of cancer.

title: PIANO: SHURA CHERKASSKY
description: PIANO devotees seeking to recapture the age of Romantic pianism from its early 20th-century past have several alternatives. One is to root through hissing 78-rpm records, player-piano rolls or deteriorating Edison cylinders.

title: The Rest Is Silence
description: If there is a rational future for South Africa, and there should be, Zwelakhe Sisulu will play an important part in it. Character, intellect and history make him someone who can help the center hold if and when the country moves toward a nonracial democracy.

title: THE MISSISSIPPI'S MIGHT IN 'GREAT RIVER,' ON 13
description: THE Mississippi looks menacing on ''The Great River.'' It is one of the ''natural razors that score'' the land. It is also a ''dangerous giant'' that may defeat the best efforts to tame it.

title: Japan TV Suit Is Dismissed
description: A Federal Appeals Court in Philadelphia on Friday dismissed an antitrust suit brought by the Zenith Electronics Corporation and another company against 21 Japanese television manufacturers.

title: DEVILS REBOUND TO BEAT CANADIANS
description: Alain Chevrier, the goaltender who has been the Devils' ultimate defender in all 14 of their victories, looked worried for just a moment as he attempted to explain the significance of subduing the Montreal Canadiens, 4-2, tonight.

title: Yields Still Bolster Junk Bonds
description: The promise of double-digit interest rates continues to sustain the market for junk bonds, even while investors and securities dealers have not yet shaken off their nervousness over investigations into insider trading in the stock market.

title: Advertising; Hill, Holliday Adding Business at 2 Offices
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos has gotten new business in both its Boston and New York offices.

title: U.S. COMPETITIVENESS IS KEY ECONOMIC ISSUE
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 13 -

title: JETS MAKE PLAYOFFS WITH SIGH OF RELIEF
description: In the comfort of their living rooms, a day after they had dropped their fourth straight game, the Jets learned yesterday that they had made the playoffs.

title: RECITAL: HOROWITZ PLAYS MOZART, CHOPIN AND LISZT
description: VLADIMIR HOROWITZ was back at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon - peeking out shyly from the wings, wiggling his fingers in greeting, mugging gently for the first few rows, rubbing his hands in vigorous anticipation. Mr. Horowitz made sure we knew this was no ordinary concert even before the first note was played.

title: Licensed Vendors Are Harassed While the Others Pack and Run; What About the Litter?
description: To the Editor:

title: Liza Dundes Married To Edward Schaeffer
description: Liza Dundes and Edward Schaeffer were married yesterday at the Nichiren Shoshu Buddhist Temple in Flushing, Queens, by the Rev. Maekawa Jishin. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Dundes of New York and the bridegroom the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Schaeffer of Linden, N.J.

title: CUOMO OPPOSES CUTS IN TRANSIT PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday ruled out any cuts in a proposed $8.3 billion plan to rebuild New York City's subway, bus and commuter-rail lines. The cuts are being sought by Republicans as a way of avoiding a nickel-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes.

title: IN CHERNOBYL'S ZONE, STREETS ARE STILL VACUUMED
description: A neat yet barren mosaic of small roads and yellow brick homes with corrugated roofs has been laid down amid the expanse of plowed fields 20 miles northeast of the Ukrainian capital, a microcosm of the world Soviet officials are trying to rebuild from the debris of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: NO REUNION FOR HOYA COACH
description: HE was never offered the job, nor is it likely that he ever will be. Nonetheless, John Thompson wants to make it clear that he has no interest in coaching the Knicks.

title: Why AIDS Pattern Is Different in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., IN A REVIEW, FOUND OUTLOOK POOR FOR CONTRAS
description: Even before the Iran arms affair jeopardized the Nicaraguan contras' chances of success, Administration officials were apparently re-evaluating the rebels' prospects.

title: Lawyer Married To Nitza Berger
description: The Lincoln Square Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nitza Berger, the daughter of Mrs. Julius Zvi Berger of Netanya, Israel, and the late Mr. Berger, to Micah Warren Bloomfield, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Morton W. Bloomfield of Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Saul Berman performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1986
description: International

title: Washington Watch; F.C.C. Review on Licensing
description: The Federal Communications Commission this week is expected to order its staff to conduct a formal review of all agency policies favoring women and minorities in broadcast-licensing procedures.

title: Market Place; Witching Hour Watch Nears
description: A LITTLE nudge from the Securities and Exchange Commission and a better knowledge among institutions about how to use stock index futures seem to be making ''triple witching hour'' Fridays a less turbulent time for the stock market, participants and regulators say.

title: Kohlberg Bid Aids Owens-Illinois Chief
description: Takeover threats have been one of the worries facing Robert J. Lanigan as chairman and chief executive of Owens-Illinois Inc. Now, with a bid for a leveraged buyout from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, he may have solved that problem.

title: YESHIVA U. RAISES $150 MILLION
description: Yeshiva University has raised $150 million in a seven-year fund-raising effort, the school announced last night at its Centennial Dinner at the Marriott Marquis Hotel.

title: KIM PEYTON-McDONALD
description: Kim Peyton-McDonald, who won a gold medal in swimming at the 1976 Olympic Games, died Saturday of a brain tumor.

title: Patriots Prolong A.F.C. East Race
description: It will go down to the final game of the regular season to decide the winner of the American Conference East.

title: Boycott Is Suspended At Emergency Rooms
description: Neurosurgeons have halted for 60 days a boycott of emergency rooms at five Dade County hospitals while medical leaders search for answers to soaring malpractice costs.

title: 1901 Chair by Wright Sold for Record Price
description: A high-backed oak dining chair designed in 1901 by Frank Lloyd Wright for the Ward Willits house in Highland Park, Ill., has been sold at Christie's for a record price at auction for a 20th-century chair and for any architectural design object by Wright, ''I've been a Frank Lloyd Wright fanatic since I was 12 years old,'' Thomas Monaghan said after he bought the spindle-backed chair for $198,000 on Friday. Mr. Monaghan, chairman and owner of Domino's Pizza Inc., of Ann Arbor, Mich., acquired the chair, he said, for the National Center for the Study of Frank Lloyd Wright, which he is building in Ann Arbor. Mr. Monaghan also owns the Detroit Tigers baseball team.

title: Republican Convention Sites Are Narrowed to Three Cities
description: The Republicans will hold their 1988 Presidential nominating convention in either Kansas City, Mo., New Orleans or Atlanta, the Republican National Committee announced Friday.

title: CARNEGIE ACOUSTICS GET A PUBLIC TEST TONIGHT
description: Tonight, after about 29 weeks and $50 million, the ''new'' Carnegie Hall will reopen. It has gone through an extensive renovation in a crash program, the idea being to restore the building to its 1891 estate.

title: Nathan's Bidders Mix Food and Real Estate
description: Richard E. and Steven H. Buckley, 37-year-old twins who started a successful food service business after they left college, are making a new foray into the restaurant business. Along with four associates, they have made a bid for Nathan's Famous Inc., the chain whose hot dogs have been well-known in the New York area since the company was founded in 1916 at Coney Island.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: McFARLANE INTERVIEWED, DEAVER RESTORED; U.S. PLANNED 3 ARMS SHIPMENTS TO IRAN
description: As part of an agreement with Iran to free all American hostages in Lebanon, the United States planned an airlift of three separate planeloads of arms from Israel to Teheran last May, but only one was delivered because Iran did not free any hostages, Reagan Administration and Congressional sources said today.

title: BLASTING CAP EXPLODES, BUT BOMB FAILS TO GO OFF AT ABORTION CLINIC
description: A man wielding a gun forced his way into an unoccupied Planned Parenthood abortion clinic on the East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon and planted a dynamite bomb that later misfired, the police said.

title: CHILDREN OF DEAF SHARE THEIR LIVES
description: ''I say to my brother now, 'Why couldn't we ever talk about these things?' '' said 22-year old Annjoy Marcus. ''It's been such an important part of our lives.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about the television broadcast of the 1987 Antoinette Perry Awards misstated the role of Roy A. Somlyo. Mr. Somlyo will be liaison between Don Mischer, executive producer of the broadcast, and Tony Awards Productions, a joint venture of the League of American Theaters and Producers and the American Theater Wing, created to administer all Tony awards activities.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Jury Finds Woman Defamed by CBS
description: A jury has ordered CBS Inc. to pay $280,000 to a woman who said she had been defamed by statements her former neighbor made to a St. Louis television reporter.

title: GOODEN, METS' STAR, IS ARRESTED AFTER FIGHT WITH TAMPA POLICE
description: Dwight Gooden, the Mets' premier pitcher, and four companions were arrested in Tampa, Fla., late Saturday night and charged with assaulting several police officers in what the police described as a routine traffic offense that turned into a furious fight.

title: REACTOR SHUTDOWN IN NORTHWEST THREATENS FRAGILE PROSPERITY
description: Henry M. Jackson, the long-term United States Senator, often told the voters of eastern Washington that as long as he lived, the Hanford nuclear reservation would never be closed.

title: Bombing in Copenhagen
description: A bomb exploded at the Soviet Embassy in Copenhagen Saturday night, breaking 20 windows but causing no injuries, the police said today.

title: THRIFT UNIT INVESTMENT RULE DUE
description: Federal regulators are expected to decide this week whether to renew a rule that sharply limits the ownership positions of savings and loan associations in office buildings, apartment complexes and other projects for which they ordinarily make loans.

title: 25 DIE AS SRI LANKA REBELS CLASH
description: At least 25 Tamil separatist guerrillas were killed in fierce fighting between two rival rebel groups over the weekend in Sri Lanka, residents and military sources said today.

title: Ulster's Minority, Yes, but Ireland's Majority; A Way to Live Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 556486 -- No Title
description: The record stock market flotation earlier this month of British Gas brought $:5.25 billion, or about $7.5 billion, into Government coffers, an Energy Department spokesman said Friday.

title: FIRE AT A JERSEY APARTMENT COMPLEX DISPLACES 50
description: A fast-moving fire spreading from a boiler room destroyed half a four-story apartment complex in West New York, N.J., yesterday, leaving more than 50 people homeless, the authorities said. No serious injuries were reported. Most of the displaced families were from Central and South America, and many spoke little English.

title: STAMFORD ACTS ON MUGGINGS OF COMMUTERS
description: There have been more than 80 muggings near the train station here this year, prompting the police to form an undercover team to patrol commuter parking lots and other high-risk areas.

title: Of Takeovers and Trade
description: Some members of Congress can hardly wait for the 1987 session so they can begin legislating to stem the rising tide of corporate mergers and takeovers. One proposal that seems certain to surface in the Senate Finance Committee would involve changing the tax laws so that interest companies pay on low-quality, high-yield securities ''junk'' bonds they issue would no longer be deductible, thus sharply inhibiting use of this form of borrowing to finance takeovers.

title: Advertising; Four Outside Directors Named by Omnicom
description: The recently created Omnicom Group, the holding company that includes BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham, has named four outside directors to join the 11 inside ones.

title: Inquiry Set On Fermenta
description: Stockholm's stock exchange said today that it would investigate dealings of the biotechnology company Fermenta A.B., whose entire board offered to resign Saturday after auditors questioned the company's latest results.

title: A SENATE PANEL TO CALL REAGAN ON IRAN AFFAIR
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee plans to question Donald T. Regan, the President's chief of staff, and the White House has decided to let him testify, according to White House and Congressional sources.

title: PLAN FOR BEIRUT PEACE BLOCKED
description: Palestinian fighters loyal to Yasir Arafat refused today to withdraw from positions they had captured in clashes with Shiite Moslems, scuttling a peace plan proposed by Iran.

title: EISENREICH SAYS HE'S SET TO TRY AGAIN
description: THE temperature had already fallen below zero in St. Cloud, but the sun emerged as the day grew longer and Jim Eisenreich warmed to the idea of another afternoon indoors. The bitter cold was of little concern; Eisenreich has spent virtually all of his winter months for all of his 27 years in St. Cloud, a smallish town about an hour's drive north of Minneapolis. This day was like any other in December.

title: AIRPLANE BEGINS RECORD ATTEMPT, DISPITE MISHAP
description: Despite damaging its wing in takeoff, the experimental Voyager airplane and its crew of two headed out over the Pacific Ocean today in a daring attempt to fly around the world without stopping or refueling.

title: Hallberg-Hoch Team Rallies and Wins
description: Gary Hallberg and Scott Hoch, second-place finishers the last two years, played the final five holes in five-under par today to rally from a two-shot deficit and win the $600,000 Chrysler Team Championship at Boca West.

title: BRAZIL CALLED LAX IN AIDS TREATMENT
description: Despite warnings by the World Health Organization that Brazil could suffer an epidemic of AIDS, federal health authorities have been slow to respond with adequate prevention and treatment programs, according to state officials, doctors and homosexual groups.

title: HIRING ON FOR '88: QUICK, BEFORE TRAIN PULLS OUT
description: David Keene is a political consultant for Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination. In the last few weeks, he has received dozens of calls from eager job-seekers hoping to land a spot with the Dole campaign.

title: Palestinians Condemn Stabbing in Jerusalem
description: Twenty prominent Palestinians, most of whom are associated with the Palestine Liberation Organization, issued an unusual statement this weekend condemning the stabbing of an Israeli in Jerusalem on Friday.

title: NORWAY CHIEF FACING FIGHT ON THE BUDGET
description: The fragile new Government of Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland is expected to weather its toughest parliamentary test next week with the economy still debilitated by Norway's plummeting fortunes as an oil exporter.

title: CONFEREES TACKLING OIL SNAGS
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries held bilateral meetings here today, delegates said, in an effort to iron out differences blocking a proposed cut in crude oil production intended to raise prices.

title: Holiday Sells 8 Hotels
description: The Holiday Corporation said Friday that it had sold eight Embassy Suites hotels to partnerships between it and the General Electric Company's General Electric Pension Trust for about $195 million.

title: Reagan Is Scapegoating Israel
description: All eyes here are fixed on Washington, and we Israelis are horrified by the way our country is being turned into a scapegoat in the Iranian affair. To us, it looks as if President Reagan may be trying to save his own skin by sacrificing ours. Many Israelis are surprised. They should not be. Ronald Reagan has never been as good a friend or devoted an ally as he was thought to be.

title: NEW SAUDI MINISTER BEGINS TEST OF SKILL
description: Now and again, he swept wordlessly past knots of waiting reporters, a Don Ameche smile on his neatly mustachioed face. Except for those brief appearances, however, Hisham M. Nazer, Saudi Arabia's acting oil minister, remained largely invisible at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that began here last week.

title: 4 DROWN, 26 SURVIVE IN INDIA
description: Four people died and 26 others were saved from drowning when a pleasure launch sank off the Bombay coast today, the Press Trust of India reported.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
An All-Night Inning
description: Early one morning two weeks ago, just about the time the sun was coming up, Mike Cieslinski arrived at a full appreciation of what the Mets had accomplished in the wildly improbable sixth game of the World Series.

title: SCHOOL BOARD ORDERS INVESTIGATION OF CONTRACT WITH A CRIME FIGURE
description: The Board of Education has asked its inspector general to investigate an allegation that a reputed organized-crime figure convicted recently of Federal conspiracy charges has a $500,000-a-year contract to transport hundreds of schoolchildren.

title: Robin Manners Weds Dr. James Majors West
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York yesterday Robin Manners, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney Howard Manners of New York, was married to Dr. James Majors West, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ashton West of Seminole, Okla. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: McFARLANE INTERVIEWED, DEAVER RESTORED; DEAVER IS RE-EMERGING AS A KEY ADVISER TO REAGAN IN FUROR IN IRAN
description: Within recent weeks Michael K. Deaver, the maestro of many of President Reagan's most successful public events, has re-emerged as a key adviser to the White House in its efforts to control the damage from the Iran crisis.

title: The Unparallel Doles
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican Senate leader and 1988 Presidential possibility, has taken some pains to put political space between himself and President Reagan in the current controversy over the President's sale of arms to Iran and the distribution of profits to Nicaraguan rebels. Capital observers thought that some parallel movement by Mr. Dole's wife, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, away from the Administration might now become discernible.

title: Yanks No. 2 With Morris
description: If Jack Morris, the premier free-agent pitcher, does not reach agreement with the Minnesota Twins in a meeting tomorrow, he will meet with George Steinbrenner in New York Thursday and try to work out a contract with the Yankees.

title: RANGERS WIN, 3-1, AS ESPOSITO FILLS IN
description: The victory might have had something to do with that big, familiar face behind the bench in the third period. It also had quite a bit to do with John Vanbiesbrouck performing some familiar, but recently absent, goaltending heroics.

title: MUSIC: A NEW QUARTET FOR STRINGS, BY CARTER
description: FOR consistent seriousness and high purpose, Elliott Carter's works are without rival in contemporary American music. That much, hardly anyone would dispute. If to those qualities are added virtuosic composing skill and apparent indifference to general approval, it is easy to understand Mr. Carter's toplofty status as a favorite of the academic avant-garde.

title: Shift in SCI-Storer Setup
description: SCI Holdings Inc., the closely held successor to Storer Communications Inc., said Friday that it would liquidate and transfer its operations to a limited partnership called Storer Communications L.P. The company said the move was intended to take advantage of provisions in present tax laws that favor the partnership form over the corporate form for holding companies disposing of subsidiaries. It said it would repay, in full, about $660 million of existing bank debt.

title: A Sign of the Times
description: Capitol Hill staff members whose bosses retire or are defeated customarily spend the last two months of an election year scrambling for new jobs. Representative Gene Snyder, Republican of Kentucky, did not seek re-election in November, and his personal secretary, office manager and receptionist, Sandy Hayward, decided to take advantage of the strategic location of the departing Congressman's office in the Rayburn Building.

title: 17-YEAR-OLD SON HELD AS SUSPECT
description: Four members of a household were found shot to death in their home in Canaan, N.Y., a rural wooded community just over 20 miles southeast of Albany, and the police yesterday charged a family member, a 17-year-old boy, in the slayings, and said another arrest was expected soon.

title: Influencing One's Own
description: Checking up on the political performance of its members in the elections last month, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has found that 76 percent of them voted for Senate candidates endorsed by the labor federation and 75 percent voted for endorsed House candidates. The figures are based on a telephone poll of 1,333 members taken Election Night, a survey whose margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.

title: Help Dr. Bowen Conquer Catastrophe
description: President Reagan knows how to keep the conservative faith. Does he also know how to put doctrine aside to help millions avert nightmare? A new health-care plan proposed by Dr. Otis Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, offers a chance to show that kind of leadership.

title: OUTDOORS: BLUEBILL IS TOUGH PREY
description: BLUEBILL hunting on Long Island Sound is not a casual endeavor.

title: Quake Jars Central Greece
description: A moderate earthquake shook this central Greek town today, causing minor damage but no injuries. An official at Athens Seismological Institute said the tremor measured 4.2 on the Richter scale and occurred at 9:40 A.M., with an epicenter in this mountain town 125 miles northwest of Athens. An aftershock measuring 3.5 occurred two hours later.

title: HISTORIC L.I. QUAKER HOUSE REOPENS
description: One year after fire ravaged the historic Matinecock Meeting House here, the pregnant silences of Quaker worship once again filled the plain wooden building, now restored to its original simplicity.

title: Goodbye, Goodyear
description: It should come as no surprise that the television coverage of the Super Bowl next month will include a blimp's-eye view of the proceedings. What's new, however, is that the craft carrying a CBS camera high above Pasadena won't be one of the familiar Goodyear ships that have had an aerial monopoly since Super Bowl I. Instead, it will be a newcomer known as the Slice blimp. And if that suggests a pizza connection, Pepsico executives will wish they hadn't paid Airship Industries $300,000 for a month's lease of the craft, one of five that the London-based company operates in the United States. Slice is a new line of soft drinks marketed by Pepsico, which is banking on the Super Bowl blimp to help the product penetrate the public consciousness.

title: MAKING NEW YORK WORK: 8 QUIET HEROES OF THE CITY
description: New York City has no shortage of tragic problems, infamous people, spectacular failures. But it also works, in its own way, and perhaps that is because of the quiet heroes - people who not only help the city muddle along, but try to make it a better place to live.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DEMOCRATS SAVORING PLANS
description: The mood of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrist Democrats who have held a two-day conference here, was ebullient from the start.

title: 2 HELD IN CONNECTION WITH DEATH OF WOMAN AT NEW CANAAN HOME
description: Two New Canaan, Conn., men were arrested yesterday in connection with the murder last week of a 63-year-old woman whose body was found in the swimming pool of her New Canaan home.

title: JAPANESE PUSHING UP PRICES OF U.S. COMMERCIAL PROPERTY
description: Japanese investors have become major players in key real estate markets in the United States, snapping up hotels at Waikiki and stepping over each other to grab skyscrapers from Los Angeles to New York City.

title: Phone Rates in Britain Cheaper Than in U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Still Alive In Convention Race
description: New York City, a long shot earlier this year for the 1988 Democratic National Convention, is still battling the odds but has moved up to among the three finalists, according to New York Democrats familiar with the maneuvering involved in selecting a convention site.

title: WALTON DEFENDS JETS AS INJURY TOLL RISES
description: This was the Joe Walton whom Y. A. Tittle once described as the best third-down receiver in football, ''bar none.'' In other words, Walton reacts well in the clutch.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With Bob Ojeda (18 victories), Dwight Gooden (17), Sid Fernandez (16), Ron Darling (15) and Roger McDowell (14), the Mets just missed having five 15-game winners on their pitching staff this past season? Would that have been a first?

title: Maia Spiegelman Marries Sam Hunter
description: Maia Natasha Spiegelman and Sam Hunter were married yesterday at Prospect House at Princeton University by Judge Philip S. Carchman of the Superior Court of New Jersey. The bride is the daughter of Gail C. V. Barrnett of New Haven and Joel Spiegelman of Bronxville, N.Y. Mr. Hunter is the son of Lottie Hunter of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Morris Hunter of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: NOT QUITE SO TOWERING
description: IT seemed too much to resist. Less than a mile away from where he was sitting, in a hotel room in Arlington, Va., Patrick Ewing could have found some measure of solace on the campus of Georgetown University. How easy it would have been to escape from an existence marred by criticism, disappointment, frustration and two aching knees and return to a place where he could revel in what once was - adulation, domination, success and health.

title: CUOMO WEIGHS A NEW PANEL ON CORRUPTION
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he may soon appoint a new state commission, armed with subpoena power, to investigate what he called ''widespread'' corruption in New York City and make recommendations for change.

title: SLAIN MAYOR IN IOWA EULOGIZED AT SERVICE ATTENDED BY 2,000
description: More than 2,000 people gathered today to mourn the death of Mayor Edward King, who was shot last week in a City Council meeting by a man apparently upset over a sewer that had backed up on his property.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEEING STARS

title: BALLET'S FORMER 'BAD LAD' IS BACK WITH OWN TROUPE
description: What ever happened to Dennis Wayne? That ''bad lad of ballet'' with the beach-boy good looks and a romantic reputation to match, danced in the 60's and 70's in a wide variety of classical and contemporary roles with the Harkness and Joffrey Ballets and the American Ballet Theater. Teeny-boppers screeched. Critics reached for sensuous superlatives. And interviewers found the brash young dancer eminently quotable.

title: Advertising; A Camera Victory For Bloom
description: THE Bloom Agency, New York, won the Pentax camera business by beating Ally Gargano/ MCA of New York, Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis and Foote, Cone & Belding of San Francisco. Sort of a coast-to-coast victory.

title: NOVA SCOTIA FISHERMEN VS. OIL
description: The lines etched in the faces of about 75 fishermen gathered here testified to the punishing weather in which they and their ancestors have long worked. The anger in their voices reflected a new threat - Big Oil.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Lydia Artymiw, Pianist, In Recital at 92d St. Y
description: Lydia Artymiw is a young pianist with a beautiful touch, a creative imagination, a feeling for her instrument's possibilities of color and texture far in advance of that cultivated by most of the young virtuosos we hear, and a cluster of pronounced rhythmic idiosyncracies whose effects can be useful, interesting, puzzling or maddening.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 15, 1986: MONDAY Barry Wright Corp Pay'N Pak Stores General Mills RTE Corp Horizon Bancorp Rochester Tel Corp NBD Bancorp Thompson Medical TUESDAY Amer Bldg Maintenance HI Shear Indus Ames Dept Strs House of Fabrics Bankers Tr NY Corp Joy Mfg Co Brunswick Corp Lear Petroleum Corp CPC Intl MONY Real Estae Inv Federal Paper Bd Public Service Co Colo Firestone Tire & Rubber Upjohn Co First Boston Inc Vestaur Securities WEDNESDAY American Inform Tech Natl Intergroup Arkansas Best Corp Natl Serv Indus Bell Atlantic Corp Northern States Power MN Carolina Power & Lt Stone & Webster Inc. Keystone Intl THURSDAY Ampco Pittsburgh Corp Nynex Corp Central Maine Pwr Pep Boys Comm Energy Sys Russ Togs Gillette Co Southern Cal Edison Ingredient Technology Transamerica Corp Knight Ridder Inc U S West Inc FRIDAY Central Hudson G & E Rexham Corp Iowa Resources Southeast Banking Corp Perry Drug Stores Southwestern Bell Corp

title: Perot Decision On G.M. Due
description: H. Ross Perot will face a decision on Monday on what to do with the approximately $700 million the General Motors Corporation paid him for his G.M. stock.

title: Out of the Strike Zone
description: DURING the World Series, it was clear that Dwight Gooden was not Dwight Gooden anymore, at least temporarily. He could not put the ball where he wanted it to go, and it bothered him, maybe even frightened him a bit, because here is a young man who was supposed to be perfect in every way.

title: NEW DONORS JOIN IN AIDING THE NEEDIEST
description: ''Your fund is what goodness is about,'' said Kathleen and Wayne Rose of Williamsport, Pa., in sending a $25 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, ''This is our first year as a contributor, and we hope to be on your list for many more to come.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LOST. By Gary Devon. 355 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: INSIDE
description: Racial Concerns on Campus Educators and rights leaders are worried about what they fear is a proliferation of racial incidents on American college campuses.

title: DANCE: CHOREOGRAPHY BY KALERIA FEDICHEVA
description: KALERIA FEDICHEVA, a former star of the Kirov Ballet, has been training young dancers in this country since the late 70's. A performance Saturday afternoon at the Symphony Space by the Fedicheva Ballet Company that featured students and guest performers was proof again that Miss Fedicheva has much to tell us about the background that nurtured her and her contemporaries - Rudolf Nureyev, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Natalia Makarova.

title: OVERCOMING THOSE WEST COAST HILLS
description: The magnificent marine views afforded by the hills of some Pacific Coast cities have a dark side: It is the climb up the hill, not the view, that takes your breath away, and this causes pedestrians to shun some areas used for retail trade.

title: LOSSES BY 'ARBS' PUT NEAR $2 BILLION
description: Wall Street's arbitrage trading community was lashed by sharp declines in several major stock holdings late last week, and its cumulative losses since the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading scandal arose a month ago are approaching $2 billion, several of the largest arbitragers said Friday.

title: BOEING FLIES INTO BRITISH POLITICAL FLAK
description: Within days, the British Government is expected to make a military procurement decision that will have a great impact not only on a multibillion-dollar segment of the global aerospace business, but also on domestic politics.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Swiss Women Dominate: Maria Walliser of Switzerland won the women's super giant slalom yesterday as Swiss skiers dominated the three weekend World Cup ski races. Walliser was timed in 1 minute 23.46 seconds on fresh snow in Val d'Isere, France. Catherine Quittet of France was second in 1:23.61 with Walliser's teammate, Vreni Schneider, third in 1:23.87. (AP) Pramotton Wins Again: Richard Pramotton won his second consecutive World Cup giant slalom race, leading the Italian team to a 1-2-3 sweep in Val Badia, Italy. Ingemar Stenmark, the Swedish veteran, finished fourth, skiing the fastest second heat and improving 12 places from the first run, on the same course on which he had scored his 80th World Cup victory last year. The 22-year-old Pramotton achieved his third World Cup triumph with a time of 2:45.26, edging Alberto Tomba and Oswald Toetsch.(AP) Tennis Becker Wins in Germany: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany fought off a stubborn challenge from Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden in Stuttgart, West Germany, to retain the Waterford Crystal Young Masters tennis title for the third time. The 19-year-old, two-time Wimbledon winner needed 2 hours 36 minutes to beat Svensson, 7-6, 7-6, 6-3. Becker was rewarded with a check for $30,000, while Svensson earned $20,000.(AP) Track Lynch Triumphs: Shola Lynch of Hunter College High School won the 1,000-meter race and the 600 meters at the Metropolitan Athletics Congress All-Comers Track and Field Meet at Manhattan College yesterday.

title: CHRISTMAS TREE'S BEAUTY IS IN THE EYE OF THE SELLER
description: In New York City, it is not easy to be a tree in any season. Over Christmas, it is brutal.

title: TWO ARE KILLED IN FIRES IN HOMES
description: A 71-year-old Queens woman and a 46-year-old Brooklyn man were killed in two separate fires that swept through their homes yesterday, officials reported.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL CHICAGO BEARS VS. LIONS, at Detroit, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.)

title: KILEY AND SAINT CO-STAR IN 'A YEAR IN THE LIFE'
description: THERE are soap operas - the most visible being television's so-called daytime dramas - and then there are soap operas - the tonier efforts such as the British series ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' and the films ''Terms of Endearment'' or ''Kramer vs. Kramer.'' Somewhere in the middle is ''A Year in the Life,'' a six-hour production that, beginning this evening at 9, will be broadcast on NBC over three consecutive nights. The story traces a year, from Christmas to Christmas, in the lives of a fictitious Seattle family named the Gardners. At first glance, the Gardners might have stepped out of some glossy magazine ad as they cheerfully exude warmth and togetherness.
