Up close, of course, they are mired in enough problems to keep a typical domestic drama at a vigorous simmer.

title: Only One Celebration
description: NEAR the end of the first half in the Giants' 27-7 victory, their defensive unit had pushed the St. Louis Cardinals into a fourth-and-34 at the 7 yard-line on three consecutive sacks of Neil Lomax - two by Jerome Sally, one by Lawrence Taylor. And now, as Greg Cater was about to punt out of his own end zone, the Giants Stadium message board lit up.

title: Washington Watch; Hope for Intelsat Competition
description: American officials are hoping new leadership at Intelsat will increase chances for competition in the international satellite communications arena.

title: Meatpackers in Iowa Accept A Cut in Pay, Ending Strike
description: Meatpackers voted today to accept a wage cut and end a bitter strike at the Swift Independent Corporation plant here, union officials announced.

title: IT'S SHOPLIFTING SEASON AGAIN
description: For retailers, Christmas is the season of the shopper - and shoplifter.

title: Licensed Vendors Are Harassed While the Others Pack and Run; The Damage Fakes Do
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE BARRIERS SLOW MOTOROLA MOBILE PHONE
description: A two-year effort by Motorola Inc. to sell cellular telephones in Japan is threatening to become another point of friction in the key area of United States-Japan telecommunications trade.

title: COMPANIES IN SWITZERLAND APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN FRONTS
description: Emerging evidence points to a tightly knit web of dummy companies in the Swiss cities of Geneva and Fribourg that were apparently used as fronts to mask the diversion of Iranian arms payments to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Sharon D'Lugoff Wed
description: The marriage of Sharon D'Lugoff to Geoffrey Ian Blythe, a saxophone player and composer, took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Art D'Lugoff.

title: The Drug Law's Generic Hang-Up
description: Albany's long struggle over prescription-drug subsidies for the elderly comes down to a debate over brand-name versus generic drugs. Governor Cuomo and the Assembly Democrats want to encourage generics; Senate Republicans resist.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Thursday misidentified the Conrac Corporation. It is a maker of electronic components.

title: Toll in Berlin Crash at 70
description: East Germany revised the toll upward today from the crash last Friday of a Soviet passenger airliner to 70 dead, including 19 members of a school party returning home for the Christmas holidays. The official East German press agency previously said 69 people died when the aircraft crashed in woods while approaching Schonefeld Airport.

title: DEVELOPING FRIENDSHIP BY PHONE
description: IT starts casually enough. It is nothing out of the ordinary. One professional calls another. It is congenial though a little stiff. A month later there is more business and another conversation. This one is longer, more relaxed. By year's end there are many conversations. They are familiar and friendly, spoken in tones usually reserved for old friends.

title: U. N. Anti-Americanism Will Backfire in the Senate
description: For 40 years, the United States has been the United Nations's most generous benefactor -largesse we have provided while asking little in return. But the patience and good will of the American people are exhausted. They are increasingly unwilling to underwrite one-fourth of the cost of an organization that seems to defy accountability even as it devotes a large part of its energies to attacking the United States.

title: STAGE: FOLD THEATER'S 'AUTOBAHN'
description: WHEN you enter the American Folk Theater, the stage is already occupied by the talented ''movement actors'' known as Adaptors, wearing backyard fashions of the 1950's and engaged in mindless yet menacing day-off activities. To the accompaniment of measured, slightly churchlike music, a couple in sunglasses are grilling a wiener -but why do the two suddenly turn on each other so murderously, or is it seductively? Is that woman really trying to hang herself with a garden hose? Is that beach chair engaged in a wrestling match with that other woman - and winning? All of them - along with the man with the puppet, the woman with the baby carriage, the girl with the mechanical rabbit - seem to be at risk as they go through their slow-motion displays of demonic domesticity.

title: Licensed Vendors Are Harassed While the Others Pack and Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Bates Selected By New Yorker
description: Ted Bates Worldwide, long known as a hard-sell giant ad agency, has whipped several shops with creative reputations to win The New Yorker's advertising account. The agency will promote advertising in the magazine, and the budget may be a little over $1 million.

title: TWO SONS OF AN OHIO MAYOR: GOLDEN FAMILY TORN BY POLITICS
description: A park is named for Dave Hall in this southern Ohio city where he once served as mayor, and his portrait hangs in a second-floor gallery in the brick-and-marble municipal building.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said its board had approved a restructuring that would create a new holding company to be controlled by the British investor Alan Clore, Kaiser's largest shareholder. Shares in the existing company will be exchanged for shares in the new entity and current Kaiser management will remain in place. If the agreement is approved by Kaiser's shareholders, Mr. Clore, who holds a 30 percent stake, will be entitled to elect a majority of the new entity's 14 directors.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Binns-Page Team Captures Laurels
description: Todd Binns of Toronto and Tom Page of New York captured the $15,000 Xerox North American Doubles Squash Racquets Championship tonight with a 15-9, 15-10, 15-12 victory over Ned Edwards of New York and Dave Johnson of Southport, Conn., at the Greenwich Country Club.

title: CANADIAN INDUSTRY LAGS
description: Canadian manufacturing ran at 76.5 percent of capacity in the third quarter, down 1.3 percent from the second quarter, the Government said today. It was the fourth consecutive decline.

title: MAKING HISTORY BEGAN ON OPENING DAY IN 1891
description: From the spring evening it first opened its doors as the Music Hall through its near demise by a wrecker's ball, Carnegie Hall has been at the center of some of the most dramatic moments in the musical world.

title: PANAMA LAWYER SET UP CONCERNS TIED TO CONTRAS
description: A prominent Panamanian lawyer appears to have played a key role in setting up three companies here that apparently served as financial vehicles in the supply network for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BUTLER'S FIELD GOAL TURNS BACK LIONS
description: Kevin Butler kicked a 22-yard field goal on the final play of the game tonight to lift the Chicago Bears to a 16-13 comeback victory over the Detroit Lions, spoiling the first National Football League start by the Lions rookie quarterback, Chuck Long.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WITNESS SAYS HE DESERVES TO DIE FOR TESTIFYING
description: A key Government witness testified yesterday that he thought he deserved to be killed for having informed on John Gotti.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mapping the Stars
description: Astronomers at the Palomar Observatory have begun the first detailed map of the heavens in almost 30 years in an effort to chart the locations of never-before-seen galaxies, stars, quasars, asteroids and coments.

title: 83 Shifted at 77th Precinct
description: Eighty-three police officers were transferred yesterday from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, where 12 officers face indictments on various criminal charges. The move, taken a week after the department had transferred 90 other officers out of the precinct, are the final transfers to be made, police officials said. The precinct supervisors have also been transferred.

title: SENATE PANEL CALLS REGAN, MEESE, SHULTZ, WEINBERGER
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d will testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee this week on the secret arms sales to Iran and the transfer of proceeds to Nicaraguan rebels, the panel's chairman said today.

title: Dow Gains 10.55 After Early Decline
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as a late rally by blue-chip issues helped reverse an early broad and steep decline.

title: OF HOSTS, GUESTS AND STAY-AT-HOMES
description: With one weekend of games remaining in the National Football League regular season, the five playoff teams in the National Conference have been established but only three teams have clinched in the American Conference.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $59,000 and a gain from the disposal of discontinued operations of $204,000. The year-ago net is adjusted for 6 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1986.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains of $146,000 for the quarter and $377,000 for the 6 months from the sale of idle facilities.

title: Chicago Board Sets New Expirations
description: In a major move designed to end the havoc created by ''triple witching hours,'' the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it planned to change the expiration dates of its stock index futures and stock index option contracts.

title: Ex-NBC Head In Gannett Venture
description: The Gannett Company, in a major expansion into television programming production, announced an agreement in principle to form a joint venture production company with Grant Tinker, former chairman of NBC Inc. The production company will produce television programming, but may also be involved in television movies, feature films and other types of programming. Mr. Tinker, who stepped down in August after five years as chairman of NBC, will head the company.

title: LAKELAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
USA TURNS UP LOSER AND ALSO WINNER
description: Tom Blackaller, the skipper of USA, handed Chris Dickson, New Zealand's skipper, a check for $5,000 soon after round-robin trials had ended with both boats in the semifinals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We seek the earliest possible end to the war, without victor or vanquished, and with the sovereignty and territorial integrity of both Iran and Iraq intact.

title: Navy Picks Uzelac
description: Elliot Uzelac, an assistant at the University of Michigan, has been named Navy's new head football coach. Uzelac was an assistant at Navy in 1971 and 1972 before going to Michigan as an assistant coach for two years.

title: LEGAL AID AGENCY LOSES PRESIDENT
description: The president of the Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed agency that supports legal help for the poor, has resigned.

title: GENERAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Market Place; Aluminum Lag Tied to Prices
description: AFTER reporting deficits for 1985 - a bleak year marked by plant closings and large write-downs - major aluminum producers generally will swing into the black this year and are expected to report higher profits in 1987. With an earnings upturn in sight, why are stocks in this traditionally cyclical industry coming under renewed pressure?

title: OPEC SAYS ACCORD IS NEAR
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is very close to reaching formal agreement to cut production to lift prices toward $18 a barrel, OPEC oil ministers said today.

title: L.I. SCHOOL MAY JOIN THOSE ENDING CLASS RANKINGS
description: Academic rigor and competition are sacred traditions in this North Shore community's schools.

title: In Perspective: Some New Developments
description: Frank C. Carlucci, the new director of the National Security Council, plans a thorough overhaul of his organization and has begun by picking aides who are specialists on the Soviet Union and Latin America. [ Page A15.

title: STUBBORN POCKETS OF ILLITERACY
description: THE United States faces a serious deficit of young adults who read and write well enough to perform the complex technological, scientific and managerial tasks on which the nation's future depends.

title: Junk Bonds: Medium, Not Message
description: Wall Street's old guard has long eyed the sale of risky corporate debt known as ''junk bonds'' with distaste and envy. Now, as the Ivan Boesky scandal reverberates, the envy has evaporated. The Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly is investigating Drexel Burnham, the investment house that generated great fortunes by papering corporate America with junk. The prices of many issues have fallen sharply, and Congress is talking about new regulation.

title: RENAULT TO APPOINT BESSE'S SUCCESSOR
description: Directors of Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French state-owned automobile company, will meet today to appoint a president to succeed Georges Besse, who was assassinated in Paris last month, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $166,000 charge against earnings relating to legal and accounting expenses incurred with respect to an unsuccessful merger.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Favoritism for Fish; The Case for Chlorine
description: Bad enough that 92 sewage treatment systems discharge effluent into streams feeding New York City's drinking water reservoirs. Now the state's Department of Environmental Conservation proposes to allow one such plant -serving the village of Delhi (pronounced Dell-High) in the western Catskills - to stop disinfecting its effluent with chlorine. For that, give the agency a worm.

title: Bridge: For the Ant, Working Hard Is No Guarantee of Reward
description: One of Somerset Maugham's tongue-in-cheek short stories concerned ''The Ant and the Grasshopper.''

title: Kissinger and the Press
description: A herd of reporters being led from the White House to the Executive Office Building for a briefing yesterday suddenly found themselves confronted by a familiar figure headed for the White House. Seeing the approaching phalanx of press and apparently fearing the worst, Henry Kissinger muttered, ''Oh my God.'' When the wave of reporters simply split and swept by him with no more than a few friendly ''Good mornings,'' the former Secretary of State and national security adviser appeared as much puzzled as pleased.

title: Allegheny Offer
description: The Allegheny Generating Company is offering $100 million of 9 1/8 percent debentures due 2016 at a price of 99.625, to yield about 9.16 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Nonrefundable for five years, the debentures yield 1.45 percentage points more than the Treasury's 9 1/4 percent 30-year bond. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Hearst Is Seen Close To Acquiring Esquire
description: The Hearst Corporation is close to acquiring Esquire magazine, according to sources familiar with the negotiations. Executives at both companies declined to comment.

title: KANSAS CITY 'DOORSTEP' FACING A MAJOR CLEANUP
description: The sign ''Afterglow'' on an empty building at Fourth and Delaware Streets is dark now, a forlorn reminder of the tinkling pianos and the harmony of barbershop quartets in a bar there that helped brighten this old river area in a brief revival only a few years ago.

title: LOBBYIST SAID TO HAVE SEVERAL TIES TO WHITE HOUSE
description: The head of a political action group that campaigned against Congressional opponents of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels had a number of links to the White House, White House and other officials said today.

title: GATEWAY MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $249,407 and $376,151 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ACCOUNTS AT BANK FROZEN BY SWISS
description: A Swiss bank froze at least two accounts today that are thought to have been used by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others to divert Iranian arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: REJUVENATED CARNEGIE IS AGAIN PREMIER HALL
description: Carnegie Hall, venerable at 95 years of age but brilliantly rejuvenated over the last seven months, reopened last night, instantly reclaiming its position as America's premier concert hall.

title: ADVISER TESTIFIES ON MOVIE DEATHS
description: A state child welfare worker testified today that the location manager on ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' had expressed an unusual interest in where he would be stationed for the filming of a war scene that proved fatal to two children.

title: CONCERT: VIENNA CHOIR BOYS
description: THE popularity of the Vienna Choir Boys has more to do with the natural appeal of children than with musical substance. It is a unified, disciplined choir, to be sure, but there are several organizations that are its equal or better in Great Britain alone.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOTEL SAVOY. With ''Fallmerayer the Stationmaster'' and ''The Bust of the Emperor.'' By Joseph Roth. Translated from the German by John Hoare. 183 pages. The Overlook Press. $16.95.

title: NYTEST ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ALBERT C. VALENTINE
description: Albert Chester Valentine, a retired owner and vice president of the Black Diamond Steamship Lines, died last Thursday at the Sprain Brook Manor nursing home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 87 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: Now that the boos for Phil Simms have subsided, the Giants' passer deserves to be hailed not only as this season's all-Pro quarterback but also the National Football League's most valuable player.

title: WESTERN PUBLISHING GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,665,000 for retirement of bank term loans prior to maturity. The company, because of passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, incurred a charge of 1 cent a share against third quarter earnings as a result of the reversal of tax benefits arising from investment tax credits that were reflected in earnings during the first half of the latest fiscal year.

title: JERSEY LEGISLATURE VOTES AN INSURANCE RESCUE
description: Motorists with bad driving records would have to pay more for auto insurance under a plan approved by the State Legislature today to rescue the New Jersey Joint Underwriting Association.

title: Officials Blame Arson In Ft. Worth Explosion
description: Arson has been blamed for an explosion that rocked downtown Fort Worth on Dec. 7, demolishing six businesses and shattering hundreds of windows, investigators said today.

title: KEY RATES
UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $159,633 from discontinued operations.

title: JUMPING JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MANATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Business and the Law; Ohio's Tough Takeover Curb
description: WHEN Sir James Goldsmith abandoned his recent bid to acquire the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, he said that one of the main reasons was Ohio's tough new antitakeover legislation. There is little wonder that Sir James cited the statute because many corporate law experts have called it ''a management entrenchment act.''

title: Treasury Statement
description: Amounts are in millions of dollars; fiscal years run from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30.

title: PLEXUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $42,000 for the quarter and net of $42,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and $418,000 for the year.

title: Metromedia Cleared on Sale
description: The $1.2 billion sale of the majority of Metromedia Inc.'s cellular telephone and paging operations to the Southwestern Bell Corporation was approved today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Court in Los Angeles Upholds Ouster of Medical Examiner
description: The demotion of Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi, the former Los Angeles chief medical examiner, has been upheld by the state Court of Appeals, which said the ouster was justified.

title: Chicago Mayor's Foe To Run on New Ticket
description: Alderman Edward Vrdolyak said today that he would try to unseat Mayor Harold Washington under the banner of the Solidarity Party.

title: Minolta Keeps Esty for Photos
description: Usually when an advertiser decides to have a review and invite other ad agencies to vie for its business, the incumbent agency, even if it is included in that review, can wave bye-bye to the business.

title: 'TRAINING CAMP,' AN HBO SITCOM
description: TAKING stock of its more obvious exploitation ploys, Home Box Office seems to have put them all together in a series of half-hours called ''First and 10'' and ''Training Camp.'' Here we have a kind of sitcom expose of football, a subject likely to appeal to male viewers while, at the same time, the locker-room scenes of beefy jocks in various stages of undress attract the female contingents. Sprinkle liberally with ''dirty'' words and smutty jokes, the kind of material that is still - although just barely - banned from commercial television, and the gang in audience marketing can almost be heard smacking their lips over the entire ''give 'em what they want'' exercise.

title: 2 ARE OUT AT L.F. ROTHSCHILD
description: The chairman and vice chairman of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc. have agreed to resign their positions at the investment bank because of ''differences of philosophy'' with the board of directors, the firm announced yesterday.

title: SANTA'S LIST: TOOLS, DISKS AND BYTES
description: HERE are some last-minute gift ideas for the computer owner who has everything, almost. Tool Kit

title: BOYHOOD EFFEMINANCY AND LATER HOMOSEXUALITY
description: MOST young boys who persistently act like girls grow up to be homosexuals or bisexuals, a 15-year study of ''sissy boys'' has shown. According to the findings, neither therapy designed to discourage the extremely feminine behavior nor ideal child rearing could guarantee that the boys would develop as heterosexuals, although parental discouragement of the boys' girlish behavior tended to result in a more heterosexual orientation.

title: BUSH STAFF GOT CALLS ABOUT CONTRA PLANE
description: A day before the Nicaraguan Government announced the downing of a rebel supply plane in October, Vice President Bush's staff received word that the plane was missing, Mr. Bush's office announced tonight.

title: Parole Urged for Smuggler
description: A Federal judge, citing the recent American arms sales to Iran, has recommended the release of a man he sentenced to three years in prison for conspiring to ship weapons to Chile and Iran. In a Dec. 10 letter to the Federal Parole Commission, Judge Robert L. Vining recommended the immediate release of Lemuel L. Stevens 3d of Marietta, Ga., who ''was prosecuted for doing little more than what the Government was doing.'' Mr. Stevens pleaded guilty in September 1985 to charges that included conspiracy to send aircraft gyroscopes to Iran.

title: WEST SIDE CO-OPS GO ON SALE IN HUGE OFFERING
description: The first of the 3,800 apartments of the Lincoln Towers complex on West End Avenue between 66th and 70th Streets went on sale last night, marking the beginning of one of the largest and most expensive conversions of rental apartments to cooperatives in New York City's history.

title: Manville Settles
description: The Manville Corporation said it had settled its insurance disputes with the Columbia Casualty Company and the Continental Casualty Company, both units of the CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago. The two carriers, the last remaining defendants in insurance litigation pending in San Francisco, had agreed to pay a total of $38.5 million, Manville said. It also said that the confirmation hearing in New York on its plan for reorganization had been delayed until noon Tuesday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Arbitragers Sell Beneficial Holdings
description: Arbitragers bailed out of the Beneficial Corporation yesterday, after an announcement on Friday suggesting the troubled financial services company may not be as close to selling off its businesses as Wall Street had hoped.

title: Nassau Property Tax Is Going Up 8.4%
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors yesterday approved a budget for 1987 that will raise property taxes 8.4 percent, costing the average homeowner $70 more a year.

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TESTIMONY IS OFF
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, was hospitalized today after suffering a ''minor cerebral seizure'' while conferring with his aides in his office, spokesmen at Georgetown University Hospital said.

title: Work-Release Plan
description: Tony Robinson, the former Tennessee quarterback who is serving a 90-day sentence for cocaine charges, can work for a landscape company during the day, a judge ruled yesterday. Judge Ray Lee Jenkins of Knox County Criminal Court approved the work release for Robinson and a former teammate, Kenneth Cooper.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW N.S.C. CHIEF IS SAID TO PLAN A NEAR-TOTAL OVERHAUL OF COUNCIL
description: The new director of the National Security Council, Frank C. Carlucci, plans a virtually complete overhaul of the council, and has already selected key aides on the Soviet Union and Latin America, Administration officials said today.

title: Washington Water Bonds
description: The Washington Water Power Company is offering $80 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at a price of par through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: NEW GIANTS MAKE MARK ON DEFENSE
description: First and foremost, Bill Parcells is a defensive coach.

title: JETS ARE PERPLEXED BY PASSING
description: In the Jets' season of brilliant success followed by abysmal failure, the sharpest distinction of all has been the productivity of the long-ball passing attack.

title: Runner Refuses Postrace Testing
description: Lynn Valley, who placed fifth in the White Rock Marathon, may face banishment from running after refusing a postrace drug test.

title: Hundreds Flee Propane Leak
description: Highly flammable propane vapors leaked from a tanker truck in downtown Springfield today, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of employees from businesses, closing roads and halting trains. There were no reports of injuries. Emergency crews sprayed water to dissipate the vapors.

title: ATTEMPTED BOMBER OF CLINIC IS SOUGHT IN 2 OTHER ATTACKS
description: The man who entered a Planned Parenthood clinic in Manhattan Sunday and planted a dynamite bomb is believed to be responsible for attempted bombings at two other clinics in the city in the last month, officials said yesterday.

title: MORE USE OF GUNS WORRYING CANADA
description: A series of incidents in which storekeepers have opened fire on intruders has stirred concern over the increasing use of handguns in Canada.

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FILES ON CONTRA SUPPLIER ARE STOLEN
description: Detectives said today that burglars broke into a lawyer's office over the weekend and took confidential files pertaining to arms transactions involving Albert Hakim, a businessman who has been linked to the transfer of arms to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes revenue of $12.2 million and an after-tax gain of $8.3 million from the sale of interest in a joint venture.

title: BIDDING RISE SEEN FOR TEXAS BANKS
description: Chemical New York's agreement to acquire Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. for $1.1 billion is likely to touch off fresh bidding for other Texas banks, according to several banking analysts who predicted that more takeover announcements were possible within weeks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp in New York, and First Interstate and Security Pacific in Los Angeles, are known to be exploring takeovers in Texas, the nation's third most populous state. So are NCNB and First Union, both of Charlotte, N.C.

title: 'HANNAH' WINS NEW YORK CRITICS AWARD
description: Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters'' was named best picture and Mr. Allen best director yesterday in the New York Film Critics 52d annual awards. Bob Hoskins won the best actor award and Sissy Spacek best actress.

title: Kellogg Head Sets Retirement
description: Gerald D. Robinson, president and chief operating officer of the Kellogg Company, said yesterday that he would retire Jan. 31.

title: CROSSLAND APPOINTMENT
description: Maurice L. Reissman, 43 years old, the president of Crossland Savings, was named yesterday to the additional post of chief executive.

title: STAGE: 'THE MAGICIAN,' WITH PETER SAMELSON
description: ''MAGIC is a crime because it breaks the laws of nature,'' the illusionist Peter Samelson teasingly suggests near the beginning of his one-man show, ''The Magician.'' Manipulating shoelace and rings, he proceeds to make interlocking metallic circles separate and rejoin and knots vanish and re-form in a skillful display of standard magical expertise.

title: Accuray Gets Bid From Combustion
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said that it planned to begin a $35-a-share, or $147 million, tender offer for the Accuray Corporation. Accuray produces measurement and control systems for the pulp and paper industry.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How does a depilatory cream or powder work? A.Common depilatory creams and powders used to remove hair contain chemical agents that dissolve the sulfide bonds in a protein found in the hair and the outer layer of the skin, causing the hair to break at the surface of the skin, according to Dr. John Romano, a dermatologist at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York. Because the follicle is undamaged, the hair will grow back.

title: TECHNOLOGY FROM RUSSIA FINDS A NICHE IN U.S. LIFE
description: An American these days might start his morning by putting in his contact lenses, switching on the television set, downing a glass of fruit juice and brewing coffee on the gas range. Then he might ride to work by subway to a plant making machine tools, automobile parts or perhaps even military rocket casings. He might end his day by popping open a can of beer, unaware that Soviet-bloc technology purchased by American companies had played a role in each of these activities.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NIGHT OF CELEBRATION SALUTES CARNEGIE HALL
description: It's hard to imagine anything important happening in New York without at least one party to make it official. And so it was with the reopening of Carnegie Hall after a seven-month renovation. There were parties before last night's gala concert and parties afterward, and the guest lists, it seemed, included everyone who has ever appeared at a social or cultural occasion in this city.

title: OPERA: PROLOGUE AND ACT V OF ROBERT WILSON WORK
description: AN opera is best measured when it is produced. So it is welcome news that one act, at least, of Robert Wilson's quirkily titled 12-hour opera, ''the CIVIL warS: a tree is best measured when it is down,'' arrived on Sunday evening for 10 performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The fervent hosannas that were so faithfully relayed back to us for six years whenever a segment of the work was tried out anywhere in the world no longer need be taken on faith.

title: CUOMO SEES UNETHICAL ACTS AS FOCUS OF NEW COMMISSION
description: Governor Cuomo said today that if he appointed a new commission on corruption, it would not conduct criminal investigations but would expose questionable practices and work for passage of anti-corruption proposals that have been made by a state-city panel.

title: Premark to Take 4th-Period Charge
description: Premark International Inc. said that it would take an after-tax charge of $115.1 million in the fourth quarter, resulting in a loss for the year.

title: DRUG AID FOR ELDERLY NEAR
description: Governor Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature reported tonight that they were close to agreement on a plan to subsidize the purchase of prescription drugs by low- and middle-income elderly people.

title: A LEAVE IS GRANTED TO PRIEST IN SANTA DISPUTE
description: A Roman Catholic priest who created a stir after he was quoted by some parents as having said Santa Claus was dead has been granted a temporary leave of absence, a spokesman for the Diocese of Metuchen said today.

title: DEMOCRATS' ROLE IS SLIM AS CUOMO PICKS JUDGES
description: Governor Cuomo relied almost exclusively on personal choices and recommendations by court administrators and Republican politicians in choosing 23 new Court of Claims judges, politicians from both major parties said yesterday.

title: Davis's Visiting Rights Curbed After Incident
description: Larry Davis's visiting privileges have been restricted after an incident last weekend at the Rikers Island Infirmary, where he has been held since his arrest on Dec. 6, according to a spokesman for the city's Department of Correction.

title: Cannon Gets Debt Extension
description: The Cannon Group Inc. said today that Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. had agreed to extend until Friday the deadline for an initial debt payment of $:53.3 million, or $76.2 million at current exchange rates.

title: Oscar, Emmy, Sleezy?
description: At a recent awards banquet of the American Association of Political Consultants, the political comic Mark Russell noted that the association's awards for outstanding political commercials lacked a catchy name like the Oscar and the Emmy. He suggested the Sleezy.

title: Knight Book Popular
description: Bookstores from Fort Wayne to Indianapolis have waiting lists of up to 200 names for ''A Season on the Brink,'' the book about Indiana's basketball coach, Bobby Knight, which was written by John Feinstein, national college basketball writer for The Washington Post. ''It's one of Macmillan's fastest selling titles, but it's not strictly a regional seller,'' said Tara Phethean, publicist for Macmillan. When the fourth printing is completed this month, Macmillan will have published 72,500 copies.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A 351-GAME STREAK ENDS FOR GIANTS
description: Most of the fans had abandoned Giants Stadium for someplace warmer, with the knowledge that their team's first championship of any kind in 23 years had been secured the day before and a methodical Giant victory was only minutes away. The teeth-gnashing years seemed a long time ago. Of all the Sundays to miss a Giant game in the last half-century, this was not the one. For Cy Fraser, this was the one. Since the start of the 1936 season, Fraser said, he has worked for the Giants on game day. He is 82 years old and has been with them at five stadiums in three boroughs and three states over more than five decades. He has stood near the entrance to solve problems with the customers, when there were not nearly so many customers. ''It floated along that way for a reasonable time,'' Fraser said. ''Or maybe an unreasonable time.''

title: BRITISH MISSILE CONTRACT
description: Shorts, a plane maker based in Northern Ireland, said today that it had won a $320 million contract from the British Government for its Star-streak missile system, designed to destroy low-flying aircraft.

title: Pro Football Notebook; BUCCANEERS SO BAD, IT COULD BE GREAT
description: The Indianapolis Colts' two-game winning streak has pushed the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to the brink of clinching the first pick in the 1987 National Football League draft, and that, of course, means Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback and recent Heisman Trophy winner.

title: PRECISION AEROTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PAYLESS DECEMBER PUTS SOME IN FOOD STAMP LINES IN TEXAS
description: More than 2,000 of the state's employees have applied for food stamps because their December paychecks are being delayed until Jan. 5 to help the state's cash flow problem, officials say.

title: DANCE: DENNIS WAYNE AND TROUPE AT TRIPLEX
description: DENNIS WAYNE'S new company, Dancers, got off to a disarmingly good start last night in its New York debut when each dancer, microphone in hand, stepped forward to introduce himself or herself to the audience.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: IS HE A JEW IN DANGER, OR JUST A FRENCH OUTLAW?
description: A major legal dispute has erupted here over the case of a French Jew who reportedly murdered an Arab in France, quickly emigrated to Israel, became a citizen and is now demanding that the Government not extradite him.

title: CALGENE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COETZEE WINS WRITING PRIZE
description: J. M. Coetzee, the South African novelist and professor of general literature at the University of Cape Town, has been named winner of the 1987 Jerusalem Prize for writing that contributes to ''the freedom of the individual in society.'' The prize will be presented by Mayor Teddy Kollek on April 9, in a ceremony that coincides with the biannual Jerusalem International Book Fair.

title: AMERICAN TO FACE MANAGUA TRIBUNAL
description: An American who was captured in Nicaragua on Friday and charged with spying will be tried before the same people's tribunal that last month sentenced another American, Eugene Hasenfus, to a 30-year jail term, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: BOMB KILLS NEO-GAULLIST'S DRIVER
description: A bomb exploded today in a car belonging to Alain Peyrefitte, a former Gaullist Justice Minister, killing the driver, who had come to take Mr. Peyrefitte to work.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $461,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: AFTER TRADES, A CHANCE AT LAST TO FIT IN
description: Dale Ellis and Mike McGee, long-range shooters with fat college scoring averages, arrived in the National Basketball Association as first-round draft choices primed to show off their outside shooting skills. But life in the pros was not as they had planned until offseason trades brought Ellis to the Seattle SuperSonics and McGee to the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Heather Angel, 77, Is Dead; Acted in More Than 60 Films
description: Heather Angel, an actress whose 50-year stage and screen career included the role of a suicidal mother in the Alfred Hitchcock movie ''Lifeboat,'' died Saturday at her home here. She was 77 years old.

title: Baker Holds French Talks
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, ending a series of talks with his West European counterparts, met Finance Minister Edouard Balladur today for what French Government officials described as fruitful discussions on a wide range of economic issues.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $706,000. The company said the share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the partial 3-for-1 stock split effected as a result of the recapitalization Dec. 5, 1985. The stock split affected only those shares not redeemed.

title: FUNDAMENTALISTS GET $50,521 IN RULING ON SCHOOL READINGS
description: A Federal district judge today awarded $50,521.59 as reimbursement for expenses to Fundamentalist Christian parents who had challenged the public school reading program as offensive to their religious beliefs.

title: WALLICH, 72, IN ILL HEALTH, RESIGNS FROM FED POST
description: Henry C. Wallich, one of the Federal Reserve's most vigorous inflation fighters, resigned today from the regulatory body's seven-member board of governors because of poor health.

title: NAVY FRONTIER: SUBMARINES RENDEZVOUS AT NORTH POLE
description: The Navy has begun pushing submarines deeper into the Arctic Ocean, the new frontier for possible naval warfare with the Soviet Union.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Quarterback's 10 Worst Nightmares
description: With 20 1/2 sacks this year, Lawrence Taylor is taking aim at not only the N.F.L.'s single-season record - 22 by Mark Gastineau in 1984 - but also the No. 1 spot on the career list.

title: ARMED FORCES SET AVIATION SAFETY RECORD IN 1986
description: Despite an increase in major accidents in the Navy, the nation's military services set a combined aviation safety record in the fiscal year 1986, according to the Defense Department.

title: INDEPENDENT AIR HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was formed in April 1985.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. CALLS FOR SPECIAL PROSECUTOR ON LOBBYING BY NOFZIGER
description: The Justice Department has decided to seek a special prosecutor to investigate Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, and his lobbying work on behalf of a military contractor in the Bronx, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1986
description: Companies

title: GOODEN SAYS POLICE HAD HARASSED HIM
description: Dwight Gooden said yesterday that he had been ''harassed and abused'' by the police in Tampa, Fla., who arrested, handcuffed and manacled him after a fight that grew out of a routine traffic violation Saturday night.

title: On Allowing Soldiers to Sue
description: When the Supreme Court ruled that members of the armed services could not bring suit for injuries caused by the Federal Government's negligence, Justice Robert H. Jackson, writing for the unanimous Court, noted that there was no evidence that Congress had ever considered the question.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax recovery of $2,132,000 and $4,248,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Favoritism for Fish; Reclaiming the Square
description: The New York City Parks Department hoped that a recent facelift of Washington Square would begin to reclaim the Greenwich Village park from drug dealers. The effort remains in jeopardy because the city hasn't followed through with serious law enforcement.

title: DESPITE DAMAGE, CRAFT HOLDS PACIFIC COURSE
description: The spindly airplane Voyager got a boost today from a tailwind spun off a storm near Guam. A chase plane found the craft was sound despite the loss of its wingtips on takeoff Sunday as it began its attempt to circle the globe non-stop without refueling.

title: Catholic Priest Who Fought Forced Feeding Is Dead at 84
description: An 84-year-old Roman Catholic priest, whose efforts to remove a surgical feeding tube led to a court case over his medical treatment, died Sunday night of natural causes at a Bronx nursing home.

title: COMMTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company went public July 8, 1986.

title: The Divestiture Con Game
description: Industrial giants announcing with great fanfare that they are leaving South Africa seem to be trying to pull the wool over the public's eyes.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES UP BY 5.2%
description: New-car sales by the nation's major manufacturers rose 5.2 percent in early December, the companies reported today. The increase from the comparable period last year was based on a daily sales rate, with nine selling days in the Dec. 1-10 period this year compared with eight in 1985.

title: MEMOIRS OF A CHINESE, 71, SELECTED BY BOOK CLUB
description: The memoirs of a 71-year-old Chinese woman who spent six and a half years in solitary confinement during China's Cultural Revolution and whose daughter was beaten to death by Maoist revolutionaries have been chosen as a main selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LAST week's gala opening of the Costume Institute's ''Dance'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art hinted at a problem that will often be facing the friends of fashion followers in nights to come -the art of accompanying a woman wearing tons of tulle.

title: TERRA MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MAYS, JW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago quarter figures reflect nonrecurring gain representing a refund of real estate taxes for prior years totaling $95,988.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AERONSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Broken Hill Proprietary Co., Melbourne, Australia, said it had formed a venture capital limited partnership with Advent International Corp. of the U.S. with an initial commitment of about $15 million (U.S.).

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
The Pope At the Parks
description: His visit is nine months away, too distant to know yet whether he plans to pack his spikes along with his cassocks. But church officials have already mapped out an intinerary that will have Pope John Paul II spending a lot of time in American stadiums next September. During his nine-day tour of the United States, the Pontiff will make appearances at five sports venues, starting with an ecumenical prayer service in Williams-Brice Stadium at the University of South Carolina and ending with a farewell at Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

title: DR. GORDON NORTON RAY, SCHOLAR AND AUTHOR
description: Dr. Gordon Norton Ray, a literary scholar and author who presided over the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation until September 1985, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. South. He was 71 years old.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-earlier quarter's revenue includes sales of $2,026,000 from the company's Canadian operations, which were sold in July 31, 1986.

title: Analysts Given Merger Details
description: The Chemical New York Corporation wined and dined banking analysts last night on the third floor of its headquarters, 227 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A PEOPLE IN TRANSITION Although the Jewish people have for millennia lived in dispersion, the Jews of Ethiopia have seized the world's imagination in recent years as news of their dramatic migration from Africa to new homes in Israel became known. Their arrival has created conflict with old customs and ways of life. The curiosity about these people, who have long been cut off from the Jewish mainstream, may be satisfied by a new exhibition opening today at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (860-1888). It continues through April 19.

title: MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Death Toll Now 4 in Accident At Nuclear Plant in Virginia
description: Two workers who were burned a week ago when a pipe burst at a nuclear plant in nearby Surry died today, bringing the death toll in the incident to four.

title: DETAILS LINGER TILL THE LAST MOMENT
description: After all the months of work, it looked for a moment as though the reopening of Carnegie Hall might be delayed by a few more details. Banks of television cameras and a curious crowd assembled yesterday morning at 9:45 under the new marquee, waiting for Isaac Stern and James D. Wolfensohn, who were to be saluted by the board of trustees at the opening ceremony.

title: BOND PRICES FALL MODERATELY
description: A combination of year-end caution by investors and speculators, worries about higher oil prices and a heavy supply of new Treasury and corporate issues expected later this week led to modestly lower prices for notes and bonds yesterday.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: A Preview of New TV Network Headquarters Capital Cities/ABC is moving its network headquarters to the Upper West Side, and the neighborhood will get its first glimpse of the first phase of development - on a T-shaped lot from 66th to 67th Street, just east of Columbus Avenue. The former St. Nicholas Arena and a small maintenance shed are now on the site.

title: TOP LEADER OF COMMUNISTS IN U.S.
description: Henry Winston, chairman of the Communist Party, U.S.A., died Saturday in Moscow after a long illness, it was announced there by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency. He was 75 years old.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CUOMO WARNS OF M.T.A. FARE INCREASE
description: Governor Cuomo warned Republicans tonight that if they did not agree to an increase in the gasoline tax, fares would be raised on New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail lines.

title: We the Pamphlets
description: With the 200th birthday of the Constitution coming up next year, the Senate Republican Policy Committee was a bit taken aback last spring to discover that the only readily available pamphlet-size versions of the Constitution were offered by the Government Printing Office at $1 and $2. The Bicentennial Commission has since brought out a free pocketsize version, but with a scant chronology.

title: 57 SENATORS, IN LETTER, ASK REAGAN TO OBSERVE '79 ARMS PACT
description: A majority of members in the new Senate sent a letter to President Reagan today urging him to reverse his decision to exceed the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty.

title: PARK SLOPE IS OF TWO MINDS ON ITS SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: In the blocks around the 14th Regiment Armory in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn are well-kept Victorian brownstones, some with oak front doors and wrought-iron fences. Mothers stroll with babies in carriages, stopping to chat with their neighbors.

title: ARCHITECTURE: TOKYO SHOW AT I.B.M.
description: TOKYO, as a city, is no more easily grasped than Japan itself - it is dense, intense and full of contradictions. It is at once new and old, closed and open, relentlessly inventive and fiercely traditional. Its symbol is the neon sign as much as the ancient shrine, and if the city has any essence that can be defined, it lies in the interaction between these two things.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Matrix said the actual quarter this year and the pro-forma quarter last year are not comparable because of a change in work scheduling and a change in the fiscal year.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Dr. Gifford Ewing, 82; Oceanography Expert
description: Dr. Gifford C. Ewing, one of the first oceanographers to explore the use of satellites and remote sensing devices, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 82 years old and also maintained a residence in Sorrento, Me.

title: Burstein Is Named City Auditor General
description: Karen S. Burstein, the head of the State Civil Service Commission, was appointed the city's first Auditor General by Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Advertising; Merrill's Magazine Special
description: THE first single-sponsor issue of Fortune has begun coming off the presses, and pulses are racing and hearts beating stronger at Merrill Lynch, whose bull dominates the scene.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $191,000 for the quarter and $360,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $121,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $22,853 for the quarter and $127,000 for the 9 months.

title: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF HISTORIAL DOCUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Greeks Died for Great-Power Rivalries
description: To the Editor:

title: FARADYNE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DSP TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $60,000 and $118,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $20,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 9 months.

title: Greeks Died for Great-Power Rivalries
description: To the Editor:

title: The Perils of Slapdash Journalism
description: As a mix of features, banter, predictions and updates, CBS's ''NFL Today'' and NBC's ''NFL '86'' are breezy viewer warm-ups to Sunday's game telecasts. They are, by and large, cheerful ventures long on laughs, so much so that NBC's studio audience often sounds like the crowd at a comedy club.

title: Lava Threatening 4 More Homes
description: A 150-foot-wide lava flow carrying hot, jagged boulders from Kilauea Volcano tumbled through a wooded area today, burning its way to within one-quarter mile of four homes.

title: IRAQ GETS REPORTS FROM U.S. FOR USE IN WAR WITH IRAN
description: Over the last two years, the United States has periodically supplied Iraq with military intelligence about Iran, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: Broadway Bomb
description: The Giants may have clinched a division title the day before, but the lack of drama when they met St. Louis didn't hurt them any in the overnight Nielsen standings. In a rare Sunday afternoon TV-ratings matchup between New York football and hockey teams, it was Big Blue 22.9, Broadway Blues 1.6. The Rangers' number was the lowest for the time slot except for the 1.4 drawn from 1 to 2 P.M. by William F. Buckley Jr.'s ''Firing Line'' - yet another reason for Phil Esposito to abhor a conservative game.

title: MOBSTER TELLS ON NEIGHBORS IN TOKYO COURT
description: This is a country where the organized criminals have been known to call news conferences and to hold their gangland funerals on national television.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LAWYER RAISES ISSUE OF JEALOUSY IN SLASHING CASE
description: The lawyer for a man accused of hiring two others to attack and disfigure a fashion model said yesterday that jealousy could have prompted the attack.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Israel's Sliding Standstill
description: The Israeli Government has ''rotated,'' fulfilling the improbable 1984 agreement to trade political power in midterm. But nothing much has changed.

title: CONGRESS STREET PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said results include gains of $25,000 in the latest quarter, $42,000 in the latest year and $106,000 in the previous year on the sale of real estate.

title: 'Night Watch' Really a Joyful Sunlit Scene
description: To the Editor:

title: SETBACK FOR BIOGEN
description: Biogen N.V., a biotechnology company, said today that the European Patent Office's review unit had issued an oral decision to revoke the patent for a cancer drug made by the company.

title: Kaiser Steel Seeks To End Dispute
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation is continuing discussions with Bruce Hendry in a bid to resolve a dispute about control of the company's board, a Kaiser spokesman said. An election inspector last week granted control of the board to a slate of directors backed by Mr. Hendry.

title: SCHOOL CHIEF SAYS SYSTEM IS PROBLEM
description: New York City's decentralized school system is so mired in politics and patronage that it has become an impediment to ''the real change which is needed'' in the schools, according to the president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Mr. Wagner said he favored several changes intended to turn the attention of local school boards from politics back to matters of educational policy. The changes, all of which would need approval by state agencies, include appointing, rather than electing, local school boards and stripping them of their powers to hire and dismiss principals and other administrators.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. BOSTON CELTICS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES CHARGES AGAINST TOPLESS PROTESTERS
description: A City Court judge here dismissed charges today against a group of seven women who bared their breasts in a park to protest a state law prohibiting women from going topless in public.

title: 70 MORE DIE AS RIOTING CONTINUES IN PAKISTAN
description: Seventy more people were reported killed today as rioting among the city's ethnic groups and clashes with the police and army spread to new sections of Karachi, and army troops used tear gas and gunfire to enforce a curfew.

title: Arms and the Holiday
description: Over the past few years, John M. Snyder, chief lobbyist for the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, one of Washington's more ardent pro-gun groups, has established something of a reputation for the militancy of his Christmas cards.

title: DIFFICULT NIGHT FOR SOETAERT
description: There is a fine line that plays in a goalie's mind when he sees two opposing skaters bearing down. Should he move toward the one holding the puck, he may be leaving the net open for the other. If he leaves the shooter alone to shoot, that will mean trouble. But whatever he does, he must be sure to do it at the right time. He should not sit still too long. He must not commit too early.

title: JEWELMASTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Careers; Promoting Overseas Markets
description: SOME American companies are not capitalizing on opportunities to sell more goods and services abroad, according to Egon Zehnder, a large worldwide management recruiting firm. The firm commissioned a telephone survey of 100 top managers of major companies and 67 percent agreed that there had been a failure of top management to ''seize opportunities available'' and 66 percent agreed that American managers were ''woefully ignorant about foreign markets.''

title: PREHISTORIC SOCIETY: A NEW PICTURE EMERGES
description: Archeologists and anthropologists are discerning a major, previously unrecognized phase in the development of early civilization. The gradually unfolding discovery promises to revolutionize standard textbook notions about the nature of human life in the millennia just before recorded history began.

title: South African Film Accident
description: A father and son burned to death during the filming of a fire sequence in a wooden castle on the set of a science-fiction movie, the police said today. John Stodel, production supervisor for the film ''Gor,'' said Martin Wenzel, 50 years old, the film company's transport manager, and his son, Conrad, 19, were standing on part of the castle when it was set afire for a battle scene Sunday.

title: U.S. Agency Bar For Beech-Nut
description: The Government said it had suspended the Beech-Nut Corporation, the second-largest maker of baby food in the nation, from doing business with all United States agencies because the company had been indicted for selling mislabeled juice.

title: REAGAN ADVISERS OPPOSE KEY POINT OF HEALTH PLAN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they had tentatively decided there should be no additional coverage of nursing home care in any health insurance plan for catastrophic illness that President Reagan will propose next month.

title: WINANS CASE TAKEN BY JUSTICES
description: In a major case that could clarify the law on insider trading and securities fraud generally, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear the appeal of a former Wall Street Journal reporter who was criminally convicted for passing on and profiting from his advance knowledge of what was to appear in the newspaper.

title: Soon, the Return of the MX Debate
description: The debate on the MX nuclear missile, one of the longest playing political dramas in Washington, is about to reopen, almost certainly to a cacophony of renewed disputes over nuclear strategy, arms control and military spending.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1986
description: International

title: Disappearing Needle
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: ANTIQUA KOLN GROUP
description: THE German early-music ensemble Musica Antiqua Koln has recently undergone a substantial change in personnel; indeed, it is virtually a new group, with only the violinists Hajo Bass and Reinhard Goebel remaining. While Mr. Goebel has always been the ensemble's leader and its natural center of attention, he seemed even more so at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night; at times, in fact, this program of works by Handel, Bach, Telemann and the lesser-known Jacques Aubert and Prince Johann Ernst of Saxe-Weimar, seemed a solo showcase rather than the wonderfully balanced evening of chamber music the group's earlier incarnation might have provided.

title: Setback for Walton
description: Bill Walton, the backup center for the Boston Celtics who has not played a game this year because of an ankle problem, has had another setback in his latest injury report.

title: CBS Broadcast Group Trims Executive Layer
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had reorganized its Broadcast Group, eliminating a group of executive vice presidents and hence an entire tier of management.

title: Barcelona Bombs Wound 19
description: Nineteen people were wounded early today in bombings at two French-owned businesses here, the authorities said.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 29
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $7,700,000 and $26,000,000 for the 12 weeks and 40 weeks, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $8,400,000 for the 12 weeks and $26,900,000 for the 40 weeks.

title: PULLMAN-PEABODY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $784,000 for the quarter and $3,871,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $293,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the year. The year also includes an extraordinary tax credit of $4,880,000. Results for 1986 and 1985 have been restated for discontinued operations which reflect the previously announced sale of certain manufacturing businesses and an equipment leasing company.

title: ARREST OF A MODEL STUDENT IN 4 SLAYINGS STUNS TOWN
description: To those in this Columbia County town who thought they knew him, soft-spoken, dutiful Wyley Gates was among the last people anyone would have suspected of doing something violent.

title: ATI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: AFG Partners Halts Lear Bid
description: AFG Partners, in an abrupt turnaround, said today that it had withdrawn its $1.51 billion bid to acquire Lear Siegler Inc.

title: BLACKS PRESSING LEGAL EFFORTS ON CAROLINA VOTING DISTRICTS
description: An increasing number of lawsuits against local governments are being filed in North Carolina by civil rights groups who say that existing election boundaries dilute the voting strength of blacks.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains of $1,120,000 and $7,047,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, on the disposition of investments. c-Net income d-Includes a gain of $2,851,000 on the disposition of investments for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Chess: Russian Grandmaster Wins Tournament in Netherlands
description: The 10th Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, was won by the Russian grandmaster Alexander Belyavsky, who will be 33 years old tomorrow. Belyavsky scored 8 1/2-5 1/2 in the elite double-round competition.

title: DIVI HOTELS NV reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $537,000.

title: Yankees Sign Sakata
description: The Yankees, who previously signed two of their own free agents, yesterday signed their first free agent who belonged to somebody else in 1986, but it wasn't Jack Morris. The new Yankee is Lenn Sakata, a utility infielder, who agreed to a one-year, non-guaranteed contract.

title: JUSTICES LIMIT EFFECT OF ELECTION LAW
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Congressional ban of direct corporate spending in political campaigns was unconstitutional as applied to a Massachusetts anti-abortion group and other small, nonprofit advocacy groups organized as corporations.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Perot Renews Offer to G.M.
description: H. Ross Perot, the feisty Texan who got $700 million from the General Motors Corporation to leave its board, said today that the auto maker could still have its money back if it changes its mind about ousting him.

title: F.I.T. HELPS START A NEW FASHION PROGRAM IN ITALY
description: The leaders of Italy's fashion industry do not readily admit to any weakness. But recently they conceded there was something they needed to learn: how to teach. Out of that realization was born the Politecnico Internazionale della Moda - the International University of Fashion - a school for the study of fashion design and merchandising, which opened here in October in a villa overlooking the Arno.

title: PRETORIA MOVES AGAINST 3 PUBLICATIONS
description: South Africa was said tonight to have ordered restrictions on three publications - the first individualized actions of their kind since tightened censorship regulations were promulgated under emergency rule last week.

title: LAPTOP ON A STONE WALL
description: I'VE never been enamored of laptop computers. My introduction to the species was in 1979 when a Japanese manufacturer whose identity I mercifully can no longer recall began running a full-page ad in the computer magazines showing two fishermen in a boat, one landing a four- to five-pound bass, the other paying no attention to the catch, his eyes instead fixed raptly on the screen of his personal computer. Never mind that there were no battery-operated personal computers in those days, so the fisherman in question must have been moored to shore by a mighty long extension cord. The real question was why anyone on earth who enjoyed fishing would lug a personal computer along on his piscatory pursuits in the first place.

title: CALIFORNIA JOURNAL;
description: Californians are being urged to choose an unusual Christmas gift for friends this year - a light bulb for the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. Price: $100. In commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the bridge's opening last month, officials draped a temporary three-mile strand of lights along its arc-shaped suspension cables between San Francisco and Yerba Buena Island in the center of San Francisco Bay.

title: What Happened to Follow-Up on Fetal Health
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGING OF COLOR GUARD AT EMPIRE STATE BUILDING
description: They gave a retirement party on the observatory deck yesterday for the man who decides what color to make the Empire State Building at night. His successor said he envisioned no major chromatic changes, but then added as an afterthought, ''My college color is blue.''

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on April 1.

title: SAUL, BF REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the quarter and year, gains on the sale of properties of $7,739,000 for the quarter and $24,245,000 for the year, and tax credits of $362,000 and $719,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,444,000 for the quarter and $2,391,000 for the year, and gains on the sale of properties of $220,000 and $2,741,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: City Rejects Proposal To Convert Theater
description: A plan to convert the landmark Beacon Theater into a nightclub has been rejected by Buildings Commissioner Charles M. Smith Jr., who said it would not comply with zoning rules.

title: CAT SCANS USED TO EXPLORE THE EARTH
description: WHEN doctors first usedCAT scans to look deep inside the body for tumors they could otherwise find only through surgery, scientists in other fields were quick to realize the method could be applied to a variety of solid objects. The earth, for example. Geophysicists recognized that seismic waves - those vibrations set off by earthquakes - could be construed as equivalent to the low-energy waves of a CAT scan, formally known as computerize axial tomography. In both cases, the waves would be affected by the density of the material through which they passed.

title: Why Toy With the Ozone Shield?
description: At ground level, ozone is a pollutant. Higher up, the oxygen-derived gas serves as a shield for all life against the ultraviolet rays of the sun. This vital screen is at serious risk of erosion from an otherwise beneficial class of industrial chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's. After a decade of controversy, a consensus has emerged that world production of CFC's should at least be capped. But a meeting at Geneva this month produced little agreement on practical steps, largely because of foot-dragging by Europeans.

title: To Climb Out of the Foreign Policy Pit
description: American foreign policy is in crisis. President Reagan can recoup, however, provided he recognizes the depth and extent of his foreign policy problems.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $201,000 and $465,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectivley. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflects a 1-for-14 reverse split of common on Feb. 14, 1986.

title: U.S. OUTPUT ROSE 0.6% LAST MONTH
description: Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest increase since April, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: U.S. PANEL SUGGESTS BIG RISE IN SALARIES FOR SENIOR OFFICIALS
description: A Presidential advisory commission today recommended substantial salary increases, some more than 80 percent, for Federal judges, members of Congress and executive branch officials.

title: Embassy Shift in Israel
description: The Ivory Coast has moved its embassy to Tel Aviv after Arab nations protested its location in Jerusalem, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Perry Drug's President Announces Resignation
description: Donald Fox, president and chief operating officer of Perry Drug Stores Inc., announced his resignation yesterday to spend more time on other business and personal interests.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a special after-tax gain of $899,000 which resulted from the completion of the initial public offering of CCC Franchising Corp., a partially owned subsidiary of Cosmopolitan Care Corporation.

title: NEW OFFER FOR WESTERN UNION
description: A group that includes such high-powered investors as Jay A. Pritzker, the Chicago businessman, and Harold S. Geneen, the former head of the ITT Corporation, has proposed taking control of the ailing Western Union Corporation.

title: Surgery for Skier
description: Bill Johnson will miss the rest of the World Cup ski season after undergoing a two-and-a-half-hour operation today to repair ligament damage in his left knee, the United States Ski Team said. The Olympic downhill skier was injured last Friday when he fell during a practice run at Val Gardena, Italy.

title: People
description: * Charles Mandel will join the East/ West Network as associate publisher of the inflight magazine group and Dial magazine.

title: GRANITE COOPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: There are no 1985 per share earnings because the company went public in April.

title: LOST DOCUMENT DISCUSSED IN SEX ABUSE CASE
description: A document that the defense says is crucial in the child molestation case involving the McMartin preschool was found in the files of a former prosecutor in the case, according to testimony today.

title: On Phoning Home
description: Courtesy of US Sprint's long distance telephone service and the Military Affiliate Radio System, members of the armed services will be able to make free calls home over the Christmas season.

title: Unusual Erk
description: You'll have to travel a long way down home to find a football coach whose methods are more unconventional than Erk Russell's. It was Russell, you may recall, who brought a 6-foot-long rattlesnake to a team meeting back in September, watched his Georgia Southern players scatter in fear and then told them they'd better react the same way ''whenever somebody brings cocaine into the room.'' And just before a game against Western Kentucky not long ago, he sought to fire up the Eagles by taking the field and ramming his shiny 60-year-old pate into their shoulder pads. Georgia Southern won by 17 points, and Russell appeared as scheduled on his postgame TV show despite scrapes and bloodstains that were clearly visible all over the top of his head.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Temple 76, U.C.L.A. 65: Nate Blackwell scored 22 points and Mike Vreeswyk added 21 last night as Temple broke open the game with a 9-0 spurt in the second half. The victory was the sixth straight for the Owls (8-1). U.C.L.A. lost its second straight after winning its first three games. Temple, playing at home, held a 32-29 lead at halftime, but a 3-point goal by Reggie Miller tied the score at 36-36 with 17:25 to play. Temple then scored 9 straight points, with two free throws by Howie Evans giving the Owls a 45-36 advantage. Tim Curry added 11 for Temple, while Jerome Richardson had 15 points for U.C.L.A. and Montel Hatcher added 14.(AP) Auburn 97, Eastern Kentucky 82: Jeff Moore, the center, scored 32 points and Chris Morris, a forward, added 25 to lead Auburn. The visiting Tigers (5-0), who trailed by 48-47 at halftime, outscored Eastern Kentucky, 21-10, in the first six minutes of the second half. Eastern Kentucky (4-2) could get no closer than 76-69 on Jeff McGill's two free throws with 8:55 remaining. Antonio Parris, a guard, led Eastern Kentucky with 34 points, including five 3-point field goals.(AP) Horse Racing Ms. Eloise Wins: Ms. Eloise, shipped in from Thistledown in Randall Park, Ohio, provided a mild upset in the $45,000 Cosmah Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Carrying 117 pounds and ridden by Mark Salvaggio, the 3-year-old outlasted the favored Flying Heat to reach the wire 2 3/4 lengths in front.

title: INSIDE
description: New Nofziger Inquiry The Justice Department has decided to seek a special prosecutor to investigate Lyn Nofziger's lobbying, Administration officials said.

title: Ad Investigative Chief Is Ready to Move On
description: After seven years as paid head of the advertising industry's self-regulation machinery, Lorraine Reid has decided to try something else, but she is not quite sure what it will be.

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CLAUSEN ASSAILS INTERSTATE
description: The head of the BankAmerica Corporation today accused First Interstate Bancorp of ''reckless'' conduct in its pursuit of BankAmerica.

title: Ex-Patient Guilty In Surgeon's Murder
description: A State Supreme Court jury yesterday found a former surgical patient, James Miley, guilty of murdering the chief of surgery at the Kings County Hospital Center last Dec. 30.

title: Dare to Call It Tyranny In District of Columbia
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESSURES BUILD TO ACT ON SCANDALS
description: Since the municipal corruption scandals erupted a year ago, New York's governmental leaders have been under great pressure to respond, or at least to appear that they are responding.

title: The Switch to Adobe
description: WOOD for housing, as well as cooking and other needs, has become more scarce and expensive in many parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America as forests shrink and human numbers grow. The arid deserts and mountains of northern Niger, in West Africa, are no exception.

title: BAN URGED FOR SOME GENE RESEARCH
description: A committee of distinguished French scientists, doctors and other experts called today for a ban on medical research on modifying human genetics in ways that could be passed on from generation to generation.

title: OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The year-ago quarter and year results include a tax credit of $924,000.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change from the LIFO method of valuing inventories to the FIFO method.

title: New Herpes Drugs
description: A new class of drugs has shown promise in the treatment of oral and genital herpes, an incurable viral infection characterized by recurring sores on the face or genitals.

title: Restructuring Plan Seen for Ponderosa
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman, who is trying to buy Ponderosa Inc. for $27.50 a share, or about $220 million, said today that he expects the restaurant chain to announce a restructuring or recapitalization plan.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RESEARCH FRONTIERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE SHOW'S THE STAR IN ADS FOR BROADWAY
description: The dramatic highpoint of Neil Simon's new comedy, ''Broadway Bound,'' is a wistful monologue delivered by Linda Lavin, an actress well known to television audiences (and thus to a large part of the Broadway ticket-buying market) as the star of ''Alice,'' the long-running television comedy. Ms. Lavin drew the kind of notices for her performance that make for long lines at the box office. Yet the show's producer, Emanuel Azenberg, waited a week before deciding how to promote the show, and what he went with was a newspaper advertisement featuring a favorable quote about the play, not the star.

title: AFTER ICELAND: SOVIET FOILED
description: The Soviet Union is displaying impatience and frustration at its inability to exploit divisions in the Atlantic alliance since the Iceland summit meeting and the eruption of a major political controversy in Washington, according to senior officials in several West European capitals.

title: CARNEGIE, AT 95, REOPENS WITH SEVERAL SURPRISES
description: Rest easy, Andrew Carnegie. Your great music hall has survived another crisis. Carnegie Hall's reopening last evening, after a seven-month shutdown for a $50 million remodeling, contained several surprises, mostly pleasant. The 95-year-old auditorium began a new chapter in its existence last night, and the best news of all was that, in view of the extensive and ambitious refurbishing, the famous sound was so little changed.

title: WEDTECH SEEKS TO REORGANIZE
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor at the center of a series of investigations, filed for reorganization in bankruptcy court yesterday, saying it hoped to resume limited operations and rehire some employees before Christmas.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
