description: b-Includes a special charge of $437,000 for the retroactive elimination of investment tax credits. c-Net income The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in August.

title: RESEARCH SUGGESTS NEW AIDS WEAPON
description: SCIENTISTS' fascination with the links between the brain and the immune defense system has led them to a potentially valuable weapon against AIDS.

title: DOUBLE OBJECTIVE COMPLICATES AGREEMENT ON MERGER
description: The agreement for the Chemical New York Corporation to acquire Texas Commerce Bancshares is extremely complex because it is intended to accomplish two things: to protect Chemical's shareholders as much as possible against downside risk if Texas Commerce should experience serious losses and to give Texas Commerce shareholders more money if the Texas bank does well.

title: 'NOT A SAINT,' BOKASSA SAYS AT HIS TRIAL
description: Smartly attired in a business suit and silk tie, Jean-Bedel Bokassa, this country's former Emperor, went on trial here today on charges ranging from killing schoolchildren to procuring human bodies for cannibalistic meals.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday about Governor Cuomo's nominees to fill 23 judgeships in New York City misidentified one. He is Harold J. Rothwax, a Criminal Court judge serving as an Acting Supreme Court justice.

title: NEW ARTIFICIAL HEART IS TRIED
description: An Austrian heart surgeon has designed an artificial heart similar in concept to the American Jarvik-7, and doctors say the new device has been implanted in four patients in Vienna and Salzburg in the last 10 months.

title: HOCKEY'S TOP GUNS CHASING CICCARELLI
description: Dino Ciccarelli, the stocky right wing for the Minnesota North Stars, has had plastic toys and even a brand of peanut butter named after him. Lately he has had two premier players after him, and that delights him. Wayne Gretzky, the Houdini of hockey, and Mario Lemieux, his heir apparent, are both chasing him in the National Hockey League goal-scoring race, a fact that amazes everyone connected to the sport.

title: 'Meeting of Minds' On Illegal Aliens
description: If Mayor Koch has his way - and all indications are that he will - illegal aliens convicted of drug-related offenses will soon be deported from the Rikers Island jail before completing their sentences.

title: STATES BLAZING INTERSTATE TRAIL
description: New banking laws that permitted the Chemical Bank of New York today to make a $1.19 billion bid for Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. were not the product of Congressional legislation, but rather part of a broad movement by dozens of state legislatures that has opened up most of the country since 1984 to some form of cross-border banking.

title: MACY'S SANTA CLAUS JOINS LIST OF THOSE AIDING THE NEEDIEST
description: Among those answering the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is Santa Claus -specifically, a Santa at Macy's, who sent a check for $10. Santa said in an accompanying note that he had ''always intended to contribute to your very worthwhile fund, but never got around to it.''

title: MARCOR DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Figures are not comparable since the company was, at that time, F & M Importing Inc. Marcor said all revenue for the third quarter and 9 months were from F & M's operation of a wholesale food distribution business which was not profitable and was sold in June 1986.

title: MANILA PROHIBITS A VISIT BY MARCOS
description: The Cabinet of President Corazon C. Aquino decided in a special meeting today to prevent the return of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos for the funeral of his sister, who died Sunday, and his expressed desire to spend Christmas here.

title: Bishops' Letter Offers an Economic Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEMICAL IS BUYING A BIG TEXAS BANK
description: The Chemical New York Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Houston-based Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. for about $1.1 billion. The deal would be one of the biggest bank mergers in the nation's history.

title: 2 Jewelers Arrested In Insurance Fraud
description: The owners of a jewelry company in mid-Manhattan were arrested yesterday and charged with trying to defraud their insurance company by falsely reporting that they had been robbed of $1.5 million in gems, the police said.

title: SHAKE-UP IN VIETNAM IS EXPECTED
description: Vietnam's leaders opened the Communist Party's sixth congress today with statements that the Communist Party and the Vietnamese Government had made serious mistakes and that it was time to ''purify'' both institutions.

title: Egypt Arrests 44, Citing Plot
description: The authorities have arrested 44 members of an underground group that was planning to overthrow the Government and set up a Communist regime, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: Wood-Stove Makers Want Emission Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW HOTEL RISES AT KENNEDY AIRPORT
description: The first generation of hotels built near the nation's airports tended to be basic no-frills facilities to accommodate airline crews and stranded passengers.

title: Altobelli Is Honored
description: Dean M. Altobelli, a Michigan State football player who achieved a 3.94 grade-point average in mechanical engineering, was honored yesterday as Toyota's leader of the year.

title: Embattled Chief Of Fermenta Quits
description: Refaat el-Sayed resigned yesterday as president of Fermenta A.B., the Swedish pharmaceutical and biotechnology company that he founded, Until recently, Mr. el-Sayed had been viewed as one of Sweden's top businessmen and his company had been hailed as one of the fastest-growing concerns in Western Europe. But their fortunes quickly soured.

title: KING ALOOF IN FINANCIAL FUSS
description: In the past, when Don King promoted a fight card, he was never shy about being stage center.

title: Advertising; Advertising Council's Urban League Effort
description: The Advertising Council yesterday displayed the latest public service multimedia effort by Young & Rubicam in behalf of the National Urban League. The TV, radio and print facets of the campaign will all stress the league's particular readiness to help elderly blacks, unemployed teen-agers and pregnant teen-agers.

title: Destination Beijing
description: Considerable turnover is anticipated at the National Security Council with the arrival of Frank C. Carlucci as its head, but the imminent departure of Raymond F. Burghardt from the staff is reportedly not part of any White House exodus. Mr. Burghardt has been posted by the State Department to the United States Embassy in Beijing, where he will become political counselor in January. That assignment was already in the works before the security council's reputed involvement in arms shipments to Iran and profits diversion to the Nicaraguan rebels became known.

title: Europe to Cut Farm Surplus
description: European Community farm ministers have agreed to reform a costly and controversial farm subsidies program, community officials said today. The change is aimed at ending the overproduction of milk and beef.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's statement today urging the Senate Intelligence Committee to seek limited immunity for Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North for them to testify about the secret sale of arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to Nicaraguan rebels:

title: SYLLABUB: VELVET GLOVE OF DESSERT DRINKS
description: NOBODY sets a finer table, it is said, than the women of the South, and a lingering visit among their dessert tables during the holiday season will dazzle eyes and ruin diets. It's not the pyramids of sweetmeats in Staffordshire bowls, the macaroons nestled in silver epergnes, the almond custards, brandied peaches and Savoy cakes arrayed on Spode that artfully waylay a visitor. It's the light yet potent dessert drink called syllabub, served in its own lily-shaped glass and sipped from a special silver spoon.

title: DEAVER INQUIRY SUGGESTS OTHERS WERE INTRODUCED
description: The special prosecutor investigating Michael K. Deaver and his lobbying activities has found evidence that he and his associates may have conspired to violate Federal ethics laws, according to a court motion made public today.

title: Pennsylvania Sets $103 Million Issue
description: The State of Pennsylvania is offering $103 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: Murphy Write-Off
description: The Murphy Oil Corporation said it would take a $230 million fourth-quarter write-down against earnings.

title: With All Undue Respect
description: I shall write something here about exceedingly rich people like the Sultan of Brunei, H. Ross Perot and Adnan Khashoggi, who are mixed up in the subterranean government that seems to operate from the White House.

title: Sports Today
description: HOCKEY RANGERS VS. WASHINGTON CAPITOLS, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) DEVILS VS. TORONTO MAPLE LEAFS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Yeshiva at N.Y.U., (TV - -MSG, 11 P.M. tape delay; Radio - WNYU-FM 89.1, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: Driver Charged in Bus Crash
description: The driver of a bus that plunged into a river and killed 21 elderly people May 30 was charged today with 21 counts of felony vehicular manslaughter. The driver, Ernst August Klimeck, was also charged with 21 misdemeanor manslaughter counts.

title: Japan Ship Line In Debt Crisis
description: Japan Line Ltd., one of the world's leading tanker operators, has asked a group of its creditor banks for urgent financial help to stave off bankruptcy, a company spokesman said today.

title: WAGNER REVIVES DEBATE ON SELECTION AND AUTHORITY OF COMMUNITY PANELS
description: In calling for ''real change'' in the selection and authority of community school boards, Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the New York City Board of Education, has reignited familiar but fierce educational debates. Some are as old as the mid-19th-century struggle to give parents a greater voice in control of fledgling public schools, some as fresh as the contemporary effort to improve American schools by enhancing the ''professionalism'' of classroom teachers.

title: TESTS POINT TO KEY MINERALS IN EARTH'S INTERIOR
description: Testing of minerals heated and compressed enough to mimic conditions deep within the earth has led researchers to conclude that most of the earth's interior is formed of perovskites, minerals whose crystal structure is basically cubic.

title: CONCERT: EMERSON QUARTET
description: THE highlight of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday afternoon concert at Alice Tully Hall was an exquisite performance of Haydn's Quartet for Guitar and Strings in D, played by members of the Emerson String Quartet and the guitarist David Starobin. This quartet - actually an arrangment of the String Quartet in E (Op. 2, No. 2) -took on a nocturnal, almost Italianate character in its transcription for guitar. Mr. Starobin was at his best, playing with a genuine legato and an infinite variety of shading.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONCE upon a time it was easy to recommend a wine book as a gift. There weren't that many around and only a few were any good. Now it seems that there are two or three new wine books a month. Much of what is written on wine is still lightweight nonsense, but the overall quality has improved considerably. Soon it will be possible to concentrate on, say, the new books about Burgundy or California.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: MacFail
description: Andy MacPhail, vice president of the Twins, on his stature around Minneapolis after talks with Jack Morris fell through yesterday: ''I'm going to be a household word. Like 'toilet.' ''

title: U.S. GOT REPORTS ON CONTRA ARMS
description: United States military and intelligence personnel in El Salvador sent regular reports to numerous Government officials in Washington detailing covert shipments of arms through Salvador to the Nicaraguan rebels last spring and summer, State and Defense Department officials acknowledged today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEFORE SHE MET ME. By Julian Barnes. 174 pages. McGraw-Hill. Paper, $4.95. IN his most recent novel, the dazzling ''Flaubert's Parrot,''

title: SAGA OF 8 PLUM PUDDINGS
description: The Grinch touched down in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn last week. He didn't steal Christmas, but took an important part of it from a hatchback owned by Jane Dawkins-Whiteman of Pine Bush, N.Y.

title: AFGHAN REBELS HIT MORE PLANES
description: The Soviet Union has been losing an average of one plane or helicopter a day for the last three months to Afghan guerrillas armed with better weapons, the State Department said today.

title: FOR SUN DEVIL FANS, A RUSHING GAME
description: Arizona State's football fans will be put to a test of stamina with the coming of the New Year. The Sun Devils will make their first appearance in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1 when they face Michigan, a game not to be missed by Sun Devil fans.

title: Reaction Favorable to Shift at Futures Exchange
description: Traders of stock index futures and options reacted favorably yesterday to news that one of the nation's leading futures exchanges is about to change the rules governing the way it does business. They expect that the sharp volatility in stock prices that has occured more often than not on ''triple-witching hour'' days is likely to abate as a result of the changes. ''People are generally supportive,'' said Louis Margolis, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc., one of Wall Street's biggest users of stock index futures and options. ''Some people are questioning the need for a change. But I have not come across anybody who is dramatically unhappy.''

title: 25 Seized by Police As Heroin Ring
description: Twenty-five people, including a New York City firefighter, were arrested yesterday as part of a ring that sold at least $100,000 of heroin each day under various brand names, the police said.

title: Bausch Names New President
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it had named Thomas C. McDermott president and chief operating officer.

title: The Water Gap Doesn't Need Bowling
description: The Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, two hours from New York City, is a 70,000-acre refuge of rolling hills and winding river on the Pennsylvania-New Jersey border. The National Park Service wants to improve it to accommodate more visitors. Yet one proposal could sacrifice nature to dubious commercial development.

title: Inouye Heads Senate Panel For Iran Affair Investigation
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Hawaii Democrat who served on the committee that investigated Watergate, was named today to head a special, 11-member Senate panel that will study the Administration's secret arms deal with Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Soviet Pilot Is Blamed For East Berlin Crash
description: An East German Government inquiry blamed the Soviet pilot today for the crash of an Aeroflot jet near East Berlin last week that killed 70 of the 82 people aboard, the East German press agency said.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Deciding Who Should Control Special Education The Board of Education is to vote tonight on a measure that would give local school boards authority over the city's 97,000 mildly and moderately handicapped students. Under the proposal, direct responsibility for the teaching of the special education students would be transferred from the board's division of special education to the local districts. Public Hearing on the West Side Highway Proposal

title: TWO IN ARMS DEAL DIDN'T REGAIN CASH
description: Canadian businessmen who provided a $10 million loan to finance secret United States arms shipments to Iran received only $1.1 million in repayment before the arms shipments were cut off, according to a New York-based energy consultant familiar with the deal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: U.S. REACHES AGREEMENT ON USE OF TURKISH BASES
description: After a year of negotiations, the United States has reached an agreement on extending its rights to use Turkish military bases, American officials said today.

title: GOT NO IRAN FUNDS, CONSERVATIVE SAYS
description: Carl R. Channell, president of the conservative National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty, issued a statement today categorically denying reports that his organization received money diverted from Iranian arms dealings.

title: PANEL TO STUDY WAY CONTRACTS GAIN APPROVAL
description: The approval process for city contracts, which has been at the heart of the New York City corruption scandal, will be ''exhaustively'' explored by the commission established by Mayor Koch to overhaul the city's Board of Estimate, the commission's chairman said yesterday.

title: COLLEGE HEADS ENDORSE A WORLD PEACE CURRICULUM
description: College presidents from this country, the Soviet Union, Japan and China have endorsed a ''worldwide curriculum for peace,'' the president of Tufts University said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A DOG-LOVER writes:

title: Antitrust II
description: When Ira Millstein arrives at Federal Court in Manhattan this afternoon, he'll be well armed. Millstein is the lawyer who today begins arguing the United States Football League's case for injunctive relief against the National Football League, and among the documents he'll submit are supporting briefs filed by five athlete unions and a number of state and local officials who want pro football in their communities.

title: Advertising; Travelers H.M.O. Unit Won by William Esty
description: The folks at the William Esty Company, still savoring the rewinning of the Minolta photographic equipment account, were additionally basking in the obvious favor of the Travelers Corporation of Hartford yesterday.

title: 3 LaROUCHE AIDES CHARGED WITH OBSTRUCTION
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted three associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., including the treasurer of two of Mr. LaRouche's Presidential campaigns, on charges that they participated in a conspiracy to ''obstruct and impede'' a grand jury investigation of fund raising by Mr. LaRouche.

title: FATAL MOVIE EXPLOSION HIT 'LIKE TIDAL WAVE'
description: A camera operator testified today that the special effects explosion that caused the fatal helicopter crash in the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' hit the aircraft ''just like a tidal wave.''

title: ANTI-ABORTION CLINICS FOCUS OF HEARING IN HOUSE TODAY
description: Anti-abortion centers that have caused increasing dispute in a number of cities and states will be the subject of House subcommittee hearings in Washington today.

title: Anglican Envoy Says He Didn't Deal in Arms
description: Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy who has worked for the release of hostages held in the Middle East, said today that ''at no time'' had he dealt in arms and money to free the prisoners.

title: RECORD PRICE FOR SKYSCRAPER
description: A family-held Japanese concern that is the world's largest manufacturer of corn syrup purchased a two-year-old Manhattan skyscraper yesterday for a record price for office space in New York.

title: HILL MANEUVERS ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: Bob Hill tried everything - pre-game inspiration, an unexpected shakeup in his starting lineup and even a second-half reconstruction of the twin-tower front line of Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright that he junked nearly two weeks ago.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IN the Barbie aisle at the toy store under false pretenses. Around me there is a feeding frenzy: over the glow-in-the-dark ball gown, the wicker furniture, over Barbie's video recording studio and her Corvette. ''Has anyone seen the hot tub?'' asks one mother plaintively. ''I need the hot tub.''

title: TRIAL REVIVES MEMORY: WHAT WAS IN THE FREEZER?
description: The lion cages were empty, the crocodile pits were aswarm with mosquitoes, and an odd smell came from the walk-in freezer, but students at the Kolongo campus of Bangui University said they were having a wonderful time today.

title: Market Place; Doubts Linger On E.D.S. Role
description: EVER since Dec. 1, when the General Motors Corporation paid H. Ross Perot $700 million to buy out his holdings in the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, relations between the automotive giant and its E.D.S. subsidiary have posed a mystery to the investment community. The buyout followed Mr. Perot's mounting criticism of Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive.

title: Reagan Clears Disaster Aid
description: President Reagan has declared a major disaster for the state of Washington, clearing the way for Federal assistance to repair damage caused by flooding. The White House said Monday that surveys by state and Federal agencies indicated more than $8 million in Federal assistance might be needed.

title: Home Loan Banks Price 3 Offerings
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday announced interest rates of 6.55 percent for $1.045 billion of three-year bonds, 7 percent for $970 million of seven-year notes and 7 3/8 percent for $670 million of seven-year notes. All three issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities firms.

title: JOB CORPS PLANNING TO SCREEN ITS TRAINEES FOR AIDS VIRUS
description: Job Corps students, applicants and staff members will be tested for exposure to the AIDS virus under a program expected to begin Feb. 1, Labor Department officials said today.

title: GEORGIA SATELLITES UPDATE ROCK'S CLASSIC FORMS
description: ROCK-AND-ROLL used to be dependable. Blaring guitars, crunching drums and singers who whooped and hollered would pretty much guarantee that the songs were dedicated to all-out, promiscuous hedonism. Not any more.

title: FLORIDA MOVING TO PRESERVE VAST AREA ALONG GULF COAST
description: With the help of a private conservation group, the Florida today moved to acquire and protect 60 miles of unspoiled Gulf Coast shoreline.

title: POLITICS AND A LEASE AFFLICT PARK IN JERSEY
description: The Kean Administration's first attempt to have private developers build the major recreational attractions of Liberty State Park here is bogged down by long negotiations on a lease and opposition by city officials.

title: Making the Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Concern About Deaver
description: The involvement of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House official, in attempts to control damage to President Reagan from the Iran crisis has raised some eyebrows in political Washington and stirred animosity among some of Mr. Reagan's longtime supporters. Several of the supporters are complaining in private that Mr. Deaver is using the appearance of leading a rescue mission to try to rehabilitate himself and revive the image of his close association with the Reagans.

title: TEXAS BANKS: PLUMS ARE GONE
description: With the Chemical New York Cor-poration's proposed buyout of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. and the planned merger of the Republicbank Corporation with the Interfirst Corporation, potential acquirers of Texas banking companies are left with much less desirable choices, banking experts said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Davidson 58, Princeton 56: Jeff Himes scored a layup with seven seconds left in overtime as the Wildcats came from behind to defeat Princeton. Davidson was down by 6 points with 30 seconds left in regulation time, but consecutive 3-pointers by Chris Heineman tied the game at 50-50, sending it into overtime. Davidson led by as many as 4 points in the overtime period, but Alan Williams hit a jump shot for the Tigers and then both ends of a one-and-one free-throw opportunity with 22 seconds left to tie the game, setting up Himes's game-winner on Princeton's court.(AP) Northwestern 56, Marquette 54: Jim Wyss sank a layup to break a 50-50 tie, and Shawn Watts sank two free throws with 22 seconds left to allow Northwestern to upset Marquette in Evanston, Ill. Marquette (4-1) lost its first game after four victories at home.(AP) Florida 96, Louisiana State 75: Andrew Moten scored 32 to lead the Gators to a Southeastern Conference victory over Louisiana State at Gainesville, Fla. Moten, who had been struggling offensively this season, scored 13 of the Gators' first 17 points in the second half as they stretched their lead from 8 to 22 points. Moten's heroics overshadowed a brilliant performance by Jorge Vargas, the L.S.U. center, who scored 33 points and grabbed 18 rebounds.(AP) C.W. Post 75, Sacred Heart 72: Keith Malone scored 24 points, including two free throws with 15 seconds remaining as Post upset the defending Division II national champions in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Smallest Military Rise Sought
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to call for the smallest increase in military spending that it has yet proposed, officials said Monday.

title: Archbishop Undergoes Operation for Cancer
description: Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen underwent prostate cancer surgery today and will remain hospitalized for at least two weeks, a spokesman said.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Keep the Fed Fit
description: Paul Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will soon be its only member who wasn't originally appointed by President Reagan. Will this make him a minority of one, outvoted at every policy turn by go-go, grow-grow Reaganauts? On the evidence of Reagan appointees so far, that won't happen. But instead of counting noses on unknown faces, serious Fed-watchers will want Mr. Reagan to fill two new vacancies promptly, and with well-qualified candidates.

title: GOODEN LAWYER SEEKS TO SETTLE
description: Lawyers for Dwight Gooden and for the prosecutor's office here met this afternoon to attempt to settle criminal charges against the Mets' pitcher stemming from an episode that has raised racial tensions in Tampa.

title: Without Pact, Oil Sags; Sugar Contracts Drop
description: Prices of crude oil and oil products sagged in world trading yesterday because of disappointment that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had not yet reached an agreement to cut its oil output.

title: SCREENWRITER SAYS EX-PROSECUTOR MADE A DEAL IN CHILD ABUSE CASE
description: A screenwriter testified today that a former prosecutor in the McMartin preschool child molestation case agreed to tell the inside story of the case for $1,000 and 5 percent of the project's profits.

title: PHILIP ROTH AND THE WORLD OF 'WHAT IF'
description: In ''The Counterlife,'' Philip Roth's new novel, which will be published next month, Nathan Zuckerman writes a eulogy to be delivered at his funeral. ''For all the seeming self-exposure of the novels, he was a great defender of his solitude,'' Zuckerman writes about himself, ''not because he particularly liked or valued solitude but because swarming emotional anarchy and self-exposure were possible for him only in isolation.''

title: Trump Cites Bally in Suit
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, filed suit yesterday against the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, charging that the company - in attempting to block takeover efforts - had hurt its shareholders, violated Federal securities laws and breached its fiduciary duties.

title: FLUTIE TO START AGAINST DALLAS
description: Mike Ditka, the coach of the Chicago Bears, said yesterday that Doug Flutie would start Sunday when the Bears play the Dallas Cowboys in their last game of the regular season. That would make Flutie the fourth quarterback to start a game for the Bears this season.

title: Perhaps Lawless Act
description: To the Editor:

title: WATER, WATER EVERYWHERE: 130 CHOICES
description: A French osteopath has just opened what he calls the world's first water bar, serving only bottled water - though fruit juice and vitamin-spiked milkshakes are available for those desperate for something stronger.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A San Francisco dispatch yesterday, about a break-in involving files pertaining to the transfer of arms to Nicaragua, misidentified the target and date of a previous burglary, in Washington. It was at the offices of the International Center for Development Policy over the weekend of Nov. 29-30. It was cited by the Center for Constitutional Rights as one of at least 25 break-ins of small political groups that oppose Administration policy in Central America.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1986
description: Companies

title: AIDS IMMUNIZATION TESTED ON HUMANS
description: Scientists from Zaire and France have begun the first human experiments for what they hope will be a form of immunization for people who are infected with the AIDS virus but do not have the disease, according to medical sources.

title: Fuel Rich, Fuel Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Weighs Lampoon Bid
description: The Giggle Acquisition Partnership No. 1, a private investment group, hinted yesterday that it might make a hostile bid for National Lampoon Inc.

title: BROWN'S TOUCH FINISHES NETS
description: Michael Jordan has converted Chicago Stadium into his personal theater. The Bulls' fans cheer him wildly when he is introduced, touches the ball, scores, makes a pass or grabs a rebound.

title: POLL FINDS REAGAN'S CREDIBILITY CONTINUES TO DROP
description: President Reagan's overall job rating remains stable but his image as a singularly honest public figure has continued to slip, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Moss Gets Poetry Prize
description: Howard Moss has been selected by the chancellors of the Academy of American Poets to receive the $10,000 fellowship for ''distinguished poetic achievement.'' Mr. Moss is the author of 12 books of poetry, including ''New Selected Poems,'' and four books of criticism, including ''Minor Monuments, Selected Essays.'' He is poetry editor of The New Yorker.

title: The Rights of Defendants and Other Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rest of the Panel: 10 Senators Who Will Look into the Iran Arms Deal
description: DAVID L. BOREN: Democrat of Oklahoma . . . 45 years old. . . Former Governor. . . Elected to Senate in 1978 . . . After only two years on the intelligence committee, will become chairman in the new Congress, because the panel's four senior Democrats all chose to become chairman of other committees . . . Among the Senate's more conservative Democrats, particularly on economic and foreign policy issues . . . Supports aid to contras and a constitutional amendment to balance the budget . . . A self-described ''consensus builder,'' viewed by colleagues as hard working and thoughtful . . . Yale graduate, Rhodes scholar, lawyer and former political science professor . . . Son of a five-term Congressman.

title: Drew Arrested Again
description: John Drew, the former National Basketball Association all-star who was banned from the league for repeated drug problems, was free on $1,000 bond yesterday after his second drug-related arrest in less than three months. An Atlanta police spokesman, Kevin Forier, said the 32-year-old Drew was one of 33 people arrested Friday night at a ''known drug location'' in Atlanta.

title: BIG BOARD DEFENDS PLAN ON 2 CLASSES OF SHARES
description: Getting conflicting recommendations from the nation's largest stock exchanges, the Government today began two days of testimony on a proposal by the New York Stock Exchange to permit companies to list stocks with different classes of voting rights.

title: Printouts
description: Highly Sensitive Bomb Detectors The State Department has a new best friend, and it isn't a dog. Rather, the Government is enthusiastic about a new portable bomb detection system developed by Thermedics Inc. of Woburn, Mass., a biomedical company. The device, called Egis, details of which are still classified, was demonstrated publicly this week and correctly zeroed in on a briefcase that contained a dummy explosive.

title: RIGHT-WING GROUP ACCUSED OF BANK ROBBERY PLOT
description: Several members of the Arizona Patriots, a right-wing group, were arrested here Monday and accused of planning to blow up an Internal Revenue Service complex in Utah and rob a armored bank car in Nevada.

title: Bridge: Top Players' Superstitions Don't Extend to the Table
description: Expert bridge players, by and large, are not superstitious.

title: Israel Asserts It Heeded U.S. in '84 on Bombing
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that Israel refrained from bombing targets in Lebanon two years ago in response to a request from the United States.

title: An Esteemed Colleague: Daniel Ken Inouye
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, who was appointed today as chairman of the special Senate committee to look into the Iran arms crisis, is no stranger to investigations involving intelligence practices or national crises.

title: Paper Cites C.I.A. Aid To Amin's Army in 70's
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, acting through two aircraft companies in the United States, delivered bombs and other military equipment to Idi Amin and took part in military operations for the Ugandan ruler in the 1970's, it was reported today.

title: Palestinians in Protest At West Bank School
description: Palestinian students threw stones and blocked roads with burning tires today as Al Najah University in Nablus opened its doors after being shut down for a week by the Israeli authorities, the Israeli radio said.

title: ABC DISCLOSES PLANS TO BUILD HEADQUARTERS
description: A 23-story, barrel-shaped tower would be built between West 66th and 67th Streets as the new headquarters of the ABC television network, under a plan made public yesterday by executives of Capital Cities/ABC.

title: SPANISH-LANGUAGE TV NEWS SERVICE NAMES OFFICIALS
description: Two former senior executives at United Press International will head a new Spanish-language television news service being formed by the Spanish International Network, it was announced yesterday.

title: Shift of Battlefield In Parking War
description: New York City's Transportation Department has a warning for government employees who work downtown and leave their cars illegally in convenient Chinatown: Don't even think of parking there.

title: Microsoft Regains Licensing Rights
description: The Microsoft Corporation, based in Redmond, Wash., said it had agreed to buy back seven licensing agreements from Seattle Computer Products Inc. for $925,000.

title: Philip Roth and the World of 'What If'
description: In "The Counterlife," Philip Roth's new novel, which will be published next month, Nathan Zuckerman writes a eulogy to be delivered at his funeral. "For all the seeming self-exposure of the novels, he was a great defender of his solitude," Zuckerman writes about himself, "not because he particularly liked or valued solitude but because swarming emotional anarchy and self-exposure were possible for him only in isolation."

title: Corrections
description: A London dispatch last Thursday, about the arms policies of Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party leader, misstated the deadline for Britain's next general election. It is June 1988, not early 1987.

title: GORBACHEV OUSTS BREZHNEV FRIEND
description: In what was seen as a consolidation of power by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a long-standing member of the Politburo lost his position today as a Central Asian regional party leader.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $600,000 from the sale of a facility.

title: DANCE: TWO PREMIERES BY NIKOLAIS
description: ALWIN NIKOLAIS'S dance company, absent for three years from New York, opened last night at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, with a bag of splendid tricks. Absence does make the critical heart grow fonder. Here was Mr. Nikolais at his illusionist best.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 23
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $9.7 million and $8.5 million for the 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the 13 weeks and $1.5 million for the 26 weeks. The company said prior-year results have been restated to reflect discontinued furniture operations separately. All share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 7, 1986.

title: Concern About the Counsel
description: The special three-judge panel searching for an independent counsel to investigate the Iranian arms sales is said to have chosen Lawrence E. Walsh, a former Federal judge who once served as president of the American Bar Association.

title: TEXAS-SIZE MERGER IN BANKING AGAIN
description: The Republicbank Corporation, the healthiest and second-largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it had agreed to merge with the troubled Interfirst Corporation, a combination that would create the nation's 12th-largest bank holding company, with $35 billion in assets.

title: Mary M. F. Mannix, 83, Dies; Led Catholic Women's Group
description: Mary Margaret Friel Mannix, a former president of the National Council of Catholic Women, died Saturday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 83 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

title: TWINS REJECT MORRIS DEMAND
description: The Minnesota Twins thwarted Jack Morris's effort to return home yesterday by rejecting all four proposals the pitcher made to them. Morris, looking for a new place to pitch after nine highly productive years in Detroit, is scheduled to meet tomorrow with George Steinbrenner, who desperately has been trying to bolster the Yankees' shaky staff.

title: RECITAL: ITZHAK PERLMAN PLAYS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: OPENING week at the remodeled Carnegie Hall is turning out to be one surprise after another. On the first night, Monday, there were unscheduled appearances by Vladimir Horowitz and Leonard Bernstein. And yesterday afternoon, because Daniel Barenboim had taken ill earlier in the day, his piano recital had to be canceled. To the rescue, however, came Itzhak Perlman, who put together one of his typically varied programs at the last minute and played it with his usual flair and technical dexterity.

title: BLAZE IN BASEMENT FORCES EVACUATION OF SHERATON CENTRE
description: A smoky electrical fire in a transformer in the basement of the Sheraton Centre Hotel plunged the 48-story building into darkness early last night and forced its evacuation.

title: Hoyt Is Sentenced
description: Over the objections of a prosecutor who urged more prison time, LaMarr Hoyt, the San Diego Padres' right-hander, was sentenced to 45 days in Federal prison on a misdemeanor drug conviction yesterday. United States Magistrate Roger McKee rejected the plea by the United States Attorney, Pat Swan, for a four-month term, saying the shorter term was appropriate.

title: Economic Scene; A Worldwide Glut Crisis
description: AMONG the celebrated phrases of 1986, ''glut economy'' made the list as a vivid description of an unsettling situation.

title: New York's Board of Estimate: Don't Lose It Without a Fight
description: The New York City Board of Estimate is under attack. Judge Edward R. Neaher of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn has issued a long-awaited decision finding that the board is unconstitutional because it fails to comply with the principle of one man, one vote. That should not, however, be the last word. The Board of Estimate is too valuable to give up without a fight.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net of $57,000 for the quarter and a loss of $704,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the quarter and $134,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $13,000 and $107,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net income

title: Why Is the Iran Deal a Surprise? Reagan Has Long Been Deceptive
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that nearly half the American public believes that President Reagan has been lying when he denies any knowledge of the Iranian-Nicaraguan arms deal.

title: 23 Hurt in Accident On L.I. Expressway
description: Twenty-three people suffered minor injuries yesterday when a bus and car collided head-on during the morning rush on the Long Island Expressway in Queens, the police said.

title: Advertising; Four Seasons Hotels Selects Warren/Kremer
description: Warren/Kremer Advertising, specialists in travel and hospitality industry advertising, has won more than $1.5 million in new billings from Four Seasons Hotels Ltd., Toronto.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
NEEDIEST CASES FUND IS URGED TO AID HOMELESS AND YOUNG
description: Contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often urge that children in need and homeless people receive aid.

title: EX-SECURITY AGENCY EMPLOYEE GETS LIFE IN SPYING FOR SOVIET
description: Ronald W. Pelton, a former National Security Agency employee who sold military secrets to the Soviet Union, was sentenced to life in prison today by a judge who said Mr. Pelton had betrayed a ''special position of trust.''

title: Taiwan in Cash Glut
description: Taiwan's surging exports have produced a glut of cash that is pushing stock prices and foreign currency reserves to record highs.

title: SHULTZ CITES SURINAME 'BRUTALITY'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz accused Suriname's leftist military Government today of gross violations of human rights, and he called for the restoration of democracy in the South American country.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
WEST BERLIN OUSTS 2 SYRIANS DEFYING BAN
description: Two Syrian diplomats have been unceremoniously returned to East German territory after defying a ban on crossing into West Berlin, American diplomats said.

title: ELIMINATING NETWORK CLUTTER
description: IT seemed like a typical telephone phone call yesterday between an executive of Illinois Bell and one from the McDonald's Corporation. Yet as they spoke from two separate locations at McDonald's sprawling headquarters, computer data and video images were simultaneously being sent along with their voices over the same phone line.

title: Chase Leaving Lebanon
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank will close its Beirut office shortly, officials of the bank said today.

title: Western Union To Disregard Plan
description: The Western Union Corporation says it does not intend to act at this time on an alternative restructuring proposal received from Resource Holdings Investors.

title: Albany Aide Named Commission Counsel
description: A law professor and counsel to the Democratic minority in the State Senate, Eric Lane, was named yesterday as counsel to the commission appointed by Mayor Koch to overhaul the Board of Estimate.

title: 'Expensive' Babies
description: The Reagan Administration budget maker who chose the word ''expensive'' to characterize low-birth-weight babies was right on the mark. The cost of treating small babies in a neonatal intensive care unit is more than $1,000 a day, and a course of treatment for the smallest of them can run as high as $170,000.

title: Fatal Fire in Sutton Place
description: A 60-year-old woman died last night in a fire in her Sutton Place apartment, the police said. The woman was identified by the police as Jane Goldberg of Apartment 9-D, 14 Sutton Place. The fire, which was quickly brought under control at 10:30 P.M., was caused by the victim's smoking in bed, according to Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman.

title: SURGEON GENERAL, CITING RISKS, URGES SMOKE-FREE WORKPLACES
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, said today that the health danger to nonsmokers from co-workers who smoke cigarettes is so clear that smoke-free workplaces ought to be made available to nonsmokers.

title: New Renault Leader
description: The French Government, as expected, named Raymond Levy to the Renault board today. He will replace Georges Besse, who was shot to death by terrorists last month, as president of the Government-owned auto maker. Mr. Levy, a Frenchman, has been head of Belgium's state-controlled steel company, Cockerill-Sambre.

title: Big Investors Support Sale of Bank
description: Institutional shareholders of the BankAmerica Corporation said they would be willing to tender their shares if the First Interstate Bancorp goes ahead with its exchange offer to buy BankAmerica for $21 a share in securities.

title: COURSE OF INVESTIGATION: EXPERTS WEIGH OPTIONS
description: The prospects for successful prosecution of the two prime figures in a criminal investigation of the Iran arms sale-contra affair could be greatly compromised if Congressional investigators immediately granted them limited ''use immunity,'' legal experts said today.

title: U.S. Limits German, Swiss Machine Tool Imports
description: President Reagan said today that the United States had put limits on machine tool imports from West Germany and Switzerland and would take action if the limits were exceeded.

title: STARTS OF HOUSING DOWN 1.8%
description: Housing construction, depressed by a building slump in the South, fell 1.8 percent in November, to the lowest level in more than two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Overqualified
description: Jerry Glanville, coach of the 4-11 Houston Oilers, returns some of the heat he's been receiving from the local press: ''No matter how bad things get, I still have my intelligence, my mind and my honesty. So I know I can't write a column.''

title: U.S. ASKS STUDENTS TO WRITE AN ESSAY ON THE CONSTITUTION
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett handed out an assignment today to the nation's schoolchildren: Write 250 words or less on the topic, ''What the Constitution Means to Me and to Our Country.''

title: NEW YORK SAILORS SLOW TO REALIZE THEY WERE TOO SLOW
description: The three boats built for the New York Yacht Club's ill-starred America's Cup campaign are being packed to go home.

title: FINK PROPOSES A VEHICLE TAX TO AID TRANSIT
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink today proposed a new property tax to help break a deadlock in negotiations over plans to finance mass-transit improvements and freeze fares in New York City.

title: FILM: 'FUTURE OF EMILY'
description: THE FUTURE OF EMILY,'' a French-German co-production written and directed by Helma Sanders-Brahms, is one of those anguished domestic dramas about people who simply can't-go-on-like-this, but somehow do - for far longer than anyone cares.

title: New Mass of Hot Lava Oozes Down Kilauea Toward Homes
description: A new flow of hot lava from Kilauea Volcano, which has forced the evacuation of four homes, moved only a short distance overnight, oozing downhill in fits and starts, scientists said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FROM the first sip of eggnog to the last bite of honey cake, traditional fare for the upcoming holidays could easily supply celebrants with a year's ration of sugar and reverse any efforts at sugar withdrawal. But it is possible to make the Sugar Plum Fairy dance to a less-sweet tune, and it can be done without relying on artificial sweeteners of questionable safety and without forgoing the treats of the season.

title: Delta-Western Merger Approval
description: Stockholders of Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines approved the $860 million merger of the two companies, which would create the nation's fourth-largest air carrier.

title: 10 on Airliner Injured In Hitting Turbulence
description: A United Airlines Boeing 727 was shaken by severe turbulence as it approached Anchorage International Airport, injuring 10 of the 102 people aboard, one seriously, officials said today.

title: Notes, Bonds Up in Quiet Day
description: While prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly yesterday in extremely quiet trading, underwriters of corporate bonds pressed ahead with plans to sell large new issues of ''junk bonds.''

title: JARVIS OF WHALERS: THE NEXT ICEMAN
description: The classic punch line in a lot of hockey stories goes something like this, ''But I felt all right in the pre-game skate, so I played.''

title: Mortgage Bond By Pacific Gas
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday offered $250 million of 8.65 percent first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2020 at a price of 96.125 to yield 9.02 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: High Tech in Europe
description: Foreign and research ministers from 19 countries meet in Stockholm Wednesday to expand the Eureka research program, billed as Western Europe's answer to Japanese and American domination of high technology. The ministers are expected to add about 40 projects to the 72 that now carry the Eureka label.

title: Archdiocesan Foster Care Does Not Discriminate
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATOR SAYS CASEY CALLED NORTH OVER CRASH
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, telephoned Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North after an American plane was shot down in Nicaragua to ask whether C.I.A. personnel or equipment were involved, according to a member of the House of Representatives familiar with Mr. Casey's testimony.

title: Union Carbide Countersuit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, while continuing to deny its own liability, filed a countersuit today against the governments of India and the State of Madhya Pradesh, accusing them of ''contributory'' responsibility for the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: WARD PROMOTES 2 COMMANDERS TO CHIEF POSTS
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward promoted two senior commanders yesterday to head the Police Department bureaus that manage its 18,000-member patrol force and handle the recruitment, training and promotion of all officers.

title: On Flight and Politics
description: Representative Jim Wright, the next Speaker of the House, said it was a bother. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a fellow Texan, said it was silly.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $188,000. c-After a tax credit of $35,000. d-Net income and is after a tax credit of $157,000.

title: QUESTIONS ON T.V.A. MANAGEMENT PERSIST AS REACTORS REMAIN SHUT
description: The crippled nuclear power program of the Tennessee Valley Authority came under new criticism today from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: STAGE: 'BLACK SEA FOLLIES,' A MUSIC-THEATER PIECE
description: IT was predictable that, in a show about Dmitri Shostakovich and Josef Stalin, the autocrat would upstage the composer. This is most definitely the case in ''Black Sea Follies,'' the new Stanley Silverman-Paul Schmidt music-theater piece that opened last night at Playwrights Horizons. ''Black Sea Follies'' proves that, given a degree of cleverness, it is easy to ridicule a dictator, but, no matter how serious or comic the intention, it is difficult, if not impossible, to portray genius.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A SPECIAL TREAT The lower reaches of Fifth Avenue recall an older New York, Christmasy in season, with its old well-kept buildings and churches decorated for the holidays. But one of the best treats in town, for kids and others, is in a prosaic office building at 62 Fifth Avenue, corner of 12th Street, and it is not a seasonal treat, it is there all year round.

title: Slashing Defendant Tells Court He Lied
description: A Manhattan man accused of arranging the razor-slashing of a model's face last summer admitted yesterday under questioning by his lawyer that he had lied repeatedly to the police and witnesses after the attack.

title: REAGAN ASKS SENATE PANEL TO GIVE LIMITED IMMUNITY TO 2 EX-AIDES
description: President Reagan urged the Senate Intelligence Committee today to grant limited immunity to two former White House aides to compel them to testify about the Iran arms affair.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is my desire to have the full story about Iran come out now - the alleged transfer of funds, the Swiss bank accounts, who was involved - everything.'' - President Reagan. [ A18:4. ]

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page article on Monday, about the arrest of an American on spying charges in Managua, described Nicaragua's air power incorrectly. The Sandinista Air Force does not possess MIG fighter planes.

title: KARACHI IS CALMER AFTER 3-DAY RIOT
description: Rioting among ethnic groups in Pakistan's largest city subsided today as thousands of soldiers and policemen enforced a tight curfew in much of the city.

title: RIVAL OBSERVANCES IN A DIVIDED SOUTH AFRICA
description: In moods that varied from the subdued to the boisterous, South Africans of different races observed a day of contradictory anniversaries today. Some marked the supremacy of white power, others the beginnings of violent attempts to overthrow it.

title: INSIDE
description: Texas Banks to Merge The state's healthiest banking company, Republicbank, agreed to merge with Interfirst, a large but troubled lender.

title: LOGRANDE ASSUMES SUFFOLK POST AND IS TO BECOME COUNTY'S CHIEF
description: Michael A. LoGrande, a 48-year-old politician with a background in urban planning, was sworn in today as the chief deputy county executive in Suffolk County.

title: Options Seem Fewer For Beneficial's Head
description: Finn M. W. Caspersen is a busy chief executive these days. The head of the Beneficial Corporation has been trying to sell the company before the year ends to take advantage of better treatment under the tax laws.

title: CHANGES PLANNED ON FEDERAL WAGES
description: President Reagan's budget for the next fiscal year will propose eliminating the pay increases that civil servants receive automatically at specified intervals, Administration officials said today.

title: TEST FACILITY OFFERS GLIMPSE OF THE FACTORY OF TOMORROW
description: HUNDREDS of engineers journeyed here last week to a modest machine shop known as the Automated Manufacturing Research Facility, where the National Bureau of Standards tests ideas, machinery and information systems that experts expect to see widely deployed in American factories in the 21st century.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE often said I am fascinated with foods that are essentially neutral, foods that almost demand to be matched with other foods to give them an identity. Potatoes, for example, take on stature when spiced with a little cheese. Snails emerge from their culinary shells when served with finely minced garlic, butter and parsley, while the shapes and textures of different pastas can be discerned only when the pasta is blended with a sauce, any kind of sauce, from tomatoes to mushrooms, vodka or caviar.

title: FEAR OF ENTERTAINING: FIRST-TIMERS ...AND A PRO
description: AS newlyweds, Jonathan Lockwood Smith and Laura Carusone Smith are still discovering their second identity: ''we'' as against ''I.'' As part of that exploration, they decided to give their first serious party - sort of a starter-pistol send-off for their new life together. In doing so Mr. Smith, a 27-year-old photographer, and Mrs. Smith, a 28-year-old dancer, confronted what experts regard as the Three Big Fears of home entertainment: fear of opening one's home to others, fear of selecting inappropriate food and fear of disaster. The First Big Fear: Open House

title: PARCELLS WON'T REST STARTERS
description: In this year of years, the Giants are 13-2 and have clinched their division title. If they beat the Green Bay Packers here Saturday in their final game of the regular season, and they are heavy favorites, they will have clinched the home-field advantage throughout the playoffs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Health Services Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a drug wholesaler, said it would acquire Archer Drug Co. of Little Rock, Ark., which has annual sales of $35 million.

title: Bowie Has No Pain
description: ''I have no pain at all in my leg,'' says Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazers' center who underwent surgery on the right leg he broke Nov. 7.

title: 'FLEDERMAUS' IN BALLET
description: ''DELICIOUSLY silly,'' is how Ruth Page describes the plot of ''Die Fledermaus,'' and ''just a little bit naughty.'' The famed choreographer, now in her late 80's, is on hand tonight - at 8 on Channel 21, at 9 on Channel 13 - to introduce her ballet version of the 1874 operetta by Johann Strauss. Dr. Falke, the bat of the title, does have his revenge, she assures us, but no lives are ruined because, as in any enduring bit of froth, all is forgiven.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SALAD AND STORIES AT THE BIRD CAGE
description: SHOPPING and lunching with mother was the major rite of my girlhood, but I would have gladly forgone the shopping. Mother loved to shop, and at times I could be coaxed to preen before her in the dresses she pulled off the racks at Bergdorf Goodman or Best & Co. (which, like my pampered girlhood, sadly is no more). But what fortified me through endless hours of trying on was the promise of a long talk-filled lunch.

title: OIL SPILL IMPERILS GEORGIA SHELLFISH
description: Conservation officials working in the aftermath of a 500,000-gallon fuel oil spill in the Savannah River have turned their attention to protecting nearby Wassaw Sound and its plentiful shellfish from the pollution.

title: THE STAGE: 'PANTOMIME,' PLAY BY DEREK WALCOTT
description: DEREK WALCOTT'S ''Pantomime,'' now at the Hudson Guild, is a vaudeville show struggling to become a play. In a series of witty skits, Harry Trewe, a former English song-and-dance man, down at the heels and trying to get back on his toes, tries to recruit his servant, Jackson Phillip, into joining him in ''a Christmas panto'' about Robinson Crusoe and Friday. Harry wants to work up a bit of light entertainment to bring tourists to his beat-up guest house on Tobago.

title: Hirschfeld Seeks To Block Lundine
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, a millionaire developer who was excluded from New York's Democratic primary ballot for lieutenant governor through the efforts of Governor Cuomo, wants to block the inauguration of Representative Stan Lundine as lieutenant governor, a Hirschfeld aide said yesterday.

title: Sweeney Has Surgery
description: Kevin Sweeney, whose 10,623 yards passing in four years at Fresno State is the most in major college history, has undergone surgery to repair damaged cartilage and a torn ligament in his non-throwing arm. Dr. Thomas Thaxter, the surgeon, said after Monday's operation that he expected Sweeney would be able to play football again without limitations. The quarterback's father, Jim Sweeney, the Fresno State coach, said the right-handed Kevin will be unable to do much throwing until mid-February even though the injury is to his left shoulder.

title: WHEN 'BY APPOINTMENT' MEANS KEEP OUT
description: Timothee Wood says that a ''sixth sense'' guides her when she peers through the door of her shop on Madison Avenue, trying to distinguish customers from criminals.

title: ELLA BAKER, ORGANIZER FOR GROUPS IN CIVIL-RIGHTS MOVEMENT IN SOUTH
description: Ella Baker, a major force behind the civil-rights movement of the 1950's and 60's, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She died on her 83d birthday.

title: SHAPER OF FRENCH BALLET
description: Serge Lifar, the colorful, internationally known dancer and choreographer who, as director of the Paris Opera Ballet, was considered the chief architect of modern French ballet, died Monday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 81 years old.

title: HARRIS POLL REPORTS TEEN-AGERS FAVOR CONTRACEPTIVES AT CLINICS
description: Forty percent of American teen-agers say that clinics where contraceptives can be obtained should be in or near schools, according to a poll by Louis Harris and Associaties this fall. But 49 percent of those polled say that such clinics should be ''somewhere else.''

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 23
Manville Hearing On Bankruptcy
description: A hearing on a bankruptcy plan of the Manville Corporation began yesterday after a Federal appeals court earlier in the day denied a request to delay the proceedings.

title: ISLANDER DEADLOCK ENDED BY LATE BLITZ
description: The longer the game lasted, the more the Islanders and the North Stars began to perform like mirror images of each other. One minute there was a flurry of threatening activity in front of the Islander goalie, Bill Smith, and then the next the action shifted to the immediate environs of Don Beaupre, the Minnesota goalie. That the contest remained snarled in a 2-2 tie with just over six minutes remaining came as no great surprise.

title: NOW, STAR-SPANGLED FOIE GRAS
description: THE drab warehouse, set amid the oil tanks and rumbling truckways of Jersey City's industrial tundra, is hardly the sort of place that chimes with the yuletide spirit. Inside, two young entrepreneurs toil against the calendar to keep up with the surging demand for one of the newest holiday luxury foods: fresh foie gras, the fattened liver of specially bred ducks.

title: CUOMO AND KEY LEGISLATORS AGREE ON SUBSIDIZING DRUGS FOR ELDERLY
description: A new state program to subsidize prescription-drug purchases for up to 1.2 million elderly people was tentatively approved tonight by Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers after one of the longest and most emotional political battles of Mr. Cuomo's term.

title: Izvestia Files a Countersuit Against a U.S. Businessman
description: The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today that it had filed suit for defamation against Raphael Gregorian, a California businessman, who won a lawsuit against the paper in the United States this year.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
HELPING NONDRINKERS FEEL PART OF THE PARTY
description: A HOST offering creative, tasty and nonalcoholic beverages demonstrates care on at least three levels. Most pragmatic is care for guests who have other parties to attend and must also navigate home. Second is care for teetotalers or those who simply wish to reduce the amount of alcohol consumed in the season of excess.

title: CAPACITY USE RISES BY 0.3%
description: American factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.3 percent of capacity in November, the first improvement since July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: On Closing Stations
description: To the Editor:

title:
STEP BY STEP;
Slicing Dessert Oranges
description: CITRUS desserts are refreshing and healthful winter desserts. A quick dessert can be made with plump and juicy navel oranges, which are abundant this time of year.

title: Daniels Puts Hoops on Hold
description: An unlikely recruit of the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team has dropped basketball, but only to improve his chances of ultimately joining the Runnin' Rebels. The youth is Lloyd Daniels, who, though widely regarded as one of the best players ever to come out of the New York City school system, would once have been given virtually no chance of competing at the Division I level.

title: IMMUNITY DIVERSION
description: President Reagan's request that the Senate Intelligence Committee give immunity to Vice Adm. John Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver North is too late, too soon and misdirected.

title: THREE TOP LEADERS RESIGN IN VIETNAM
description: Vietnam's three top leaders gave up their posts today after leading the Communists through five decades of war and revolution.

title: Thinking About Tomorrow
description: It's interesting how other governments reacted to the Reagan Administration's present foreign policy crisis. They were dismayed but canny. Their newspapers condemned and even mocked the President, but their officials didn't confuse Mr. Reagan with America, or today with tomorrow.

title: Soviet Deficit In West Trade
description: The fall in world oil prices kept Soviet trade with the West in the red during the first nine months of 1986, with the volume of both imports and exports falling, according to official data released today.

title: HARNISCHFEGER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $29,590,000 for the quarter and $59,315,000 for the year. The year also included an accounting gain of $15,433,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $406,000 for the quarter and $5,911,000 for the year, and tax credits of $630,000 and $1,745,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also includes an accounting gain of $2,847,000. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter and year.

title: GUN CHARGE FILED IN BORDER CASE
description: The man who led a paramilitary group on a controversial patrol of the Mexican border this summer has been indicted on two counts of weapons violations, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: A PLAY ON VEGETABLES, SWEATER PROGRAM
description: 1. Juggling the Salad

title: U.S. ENVOY REBUKES PENTAGON AIDE
description: The American Ambassador, Richard R. Burt, repudiated a high-ranking Pentagon official today for suggesting that West Germany cut credits to East Germany and spend them on the military budget.

title: Plane Avoids Typhoon On Global Flight Test
description: The experimental plane Voyager threaded its way through the spiraling arms of Typhoon Marge today as it headed toward the Philippines in a bid to make the first flight around the globe nonstop on one tank of gas.

title: C.I.A. DIRECTOR LISTED AS STABLE BY HOSPITAL
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, spent a comfortable day at Georgetown University Hospital and remains in stable condition there, a Central Intelligence Agency spokesman said today.

title: THOSE WHO SHOP ALSO STOP TO LUNCH
description: BACK in the days when shopping was an all-day and sometimes white-gloved affair, Lord & Taylor greeted diners with a seven-piece orchestra and Abraham & Straus served lobster to Brooklyn's elite on tables overlooking its flourishing downtown. While department store dining has adjusted to a more hurried pace, it has experienced a revival of late, coaxed in part by patrons who, although they may want to eat quickly, insist on eating well.

title: SANDINISTA CALLS HALL A TERRORIST
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra asserted today that an American arrested here Friday was not a spy, but a mercenary working ''to promote terrorist actions by the United States Government.''

title: In Perspective: Some New Developments
description: The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, reportedly said in testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee that President Reagan initially rejected selling arms to Iran through Israel, but that after the Israelis shipped the arms anyway, such sales became United States policy. The testimony was considered likely to irritate the Israelis, who say they already feel they have been made a scapegoat for the White House's troubles. Mr. Regan's account contradicted reported testimony two weeks ago by a former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, who is said to have told the same committee that he told Israel to go ahead, after getting oral approval from the President to do so. [ Page A1. ]

title: FILM: 'THERESE,' LITTLE FLOWER OF JESUS
description: ''Therese'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, 63d Street and Broadway.

title: ANOTHER SAUDI OIL OFFICIAL IS TOLD TO RESIGN POST
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia removed another longtime oil official yesterday by demanding the resignation of Abdul Hadi Taher, head of the Saudi national oil company. Last month the King dismissed Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, his oil minister.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adamas Carbide Corp., Kenilworth, N.J., a subsidiary of Panatech Research and Development Corp. that makes cutting materials and devices for the machine tool industry, named James F. McCain president.

title: RATING CUT ON CITICORP DEBT
description: Long-term debt ratings for Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company and one that has borrowed far more heavily in the bond markets than other banking companies, have been reduced a notch, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Applying Military Brain to Military Brawn, Again
description: Every few years the military establishment musters its intellectual energy and produces a new national security strategy.

title: ADVICE REAGAN GOT WAS INADEQUATE, CHIEF ADVISER SAYS
description: Donald T. Regan portrayed President Reagan as a victim of poor advice from aides and others who supported arms sales to Iran, according to several of those who heard his testimony today before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: GOTTI WITNESS REPUDIATES TERMS OF IMMUNITY
description: The Government's key witness in the racketeering trial of John Gotti said yesterday that he would not testify in other trials outside the Eastern District of New York, even if it meant breaking his agreement with authorities.

title: READY OR NOT, TUNNEL IS OPEN FOR PARTIES
description: ''DO we have bathrooms yet?'' asked Laura Jaquays, executive director of the Tunnel, New York's newest dance club, minutes before it opened Monday night.

title: WEST SIDE GANG LINKED TO 30 UNSOLVED KILLINGS
description: Investigations into a Manhattan gang called the Westies, begun after one of its leaders agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, have linked the gang to more than than 30 unsolved homicides over the last 15 years, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Imperial Chemical Selling Oil Interests
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest industrial company, said it had agreed to sell its oil and gas assets to Enterprise Oil P.L.C. of Britain for a 25 percent stake in Enterprise.

title: E.P.A. CITES ACTION ON ENFORCEMENT IN 1986
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that in 1986 it had referred the largest number of cases involving violation of environmental laws to the Department of Justice since the Reagan Administration came into office in 1981.

title: PUERTO RICO SEEN AS BACKDOOR PIPELINE FOR ALIENS FLEEING DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
description: An unstemmed tide of illegal immigrants from the Dominican Republic courses through Puerto Rico every day, headed directly for New York or staying here to work for substandard wages.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 15
TRADE GAP SET RECORD IN QUARTER
description: The deficit in the broadest measure of the nation's foreign trade climbed to an all-time high of $36.28 billion in the July-September quarter, increasing the United States' status as the world's largest debtor nation, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SUSPECTED GRINCH AT F.A.O. SCHWARZ
description: F. A. O. Schwarz, the 124-year-old complement to Santa's workshop, has dismissed a mailroom employee for sending toys to himself, through various addresses, rather than to the children they were intended for.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinay credits of $68,000 for the quarter and $398,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Lovell Thompson Dies at 84; Former Publishing Executive
description: Lovell Thompson, a former publishing executive with the Houghton Mifflin Company who worked with such distinguished authors as John Dos Passos, Anya Seton, John Kenneth Galbraith and Sir Anthony Eden, died of a stroke Monday. He was 84 years old.

title: OPERA: THE MET PRESENTS 'LA BOHEME'
description: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S enormous, distancing sets dominated the season's first performance Monday night of ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera, as they have for several years and presumably will do for the foreseeable future. They are beautiful, impressive, magnificent; every good word can be used about them (and many are, by the spectators, during the music); it may be worth overlooking the inconveniences they pose to performers or audiences who would like to feel anew the intimate, personal poignancy of the beloved piece. But Monday's performance left this observer inclined to regret the scenic wonders. It was cast with singers good enough to be nurtured, inspired and husbanded into giving a performance that would be special and moving, but not strong enough in voice or personal charisma to make that happen against Mr. Zeffirelli's competition.

title: FEAR OF ENTERTAINING: FIRST-TIMERS ...AND A PRO
description: THERE'S no such thing as an absolutely carefree hostess (''Show me one and I'll show you a ninny,'' said one woman who entertains a good deal). But an increasing number of hostesses treat entertaining with a kind of casualness that would have given their mothers palpitations, and perhaps still do.

title: ARBOR HOUSE TO REDUCE HARD-COVER BOOK OUTPUT
description: Arbor House, a hard-cover imprint of the Hearst Corporation, will cut its yearly output of books by 50 percent - from 90 titles to 45. The reduction will occur over three years.

title: ALEXANDER PAULSEN
description: Alexander Paulsen, who built many residential developments in Suffolk County, L.I., after World War II, died Saturday at Winthrop Memorial Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Long Beach, L.I.

title: On Naming the Scandal
description: One contest to find a catchword for the imbroglio over the Iran-to-Nicaragua connection has come up with a winner: ''Iranamok.'' The New Republic, the sponsor of the contest, cut off entries after nearly 1,000 suggestions had been submitted in a week and will award the prize of a year's free subscription this week to Ann Doyle Davis of Lansing, Mich., the earliest of six competitors who sent in this notion, variously spelled.

title: Taking the Legislature's Measure
description: Congress has been studied, analyzed, critiqued, investigated, praised and chronicled. But rarely is Congress quantified, for it is tough to put numbers on this bicameral body of 535 legislators with powers to do everything from write laws to declare war.

title: GORBACHEV URGES REAGAN TO FOCUS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has told Senator Gary Hart that the Iran affair in Washington will not deter the Soviet Union from seeking an arms accord with President Reagan.

title: Expand Evacuation Zones Near Nuclear Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: TRINIDADIAN VOTERS REJECT RULING PARTY AFTER 30-YEAR RUN
description: The people of Trinidad and Tobago voted overwhelmingly for the opposition Monday, ending 30 years in power for the People's National Movement, according to preliminary results made public today.

title: Advertising; New Spot For Meals Program
description: AN aged person living alone, fiercely independent but too infirm to go out to shop and too helpless to prepare a meal - it's an image to which many middle-aged, and frequently affluent, people can relate. It's their mother. Perhaps that is why a charity dedicated to bringing hot meals to such folk got such widespread support when it made its latest commercial to raise funds for this effort.

title: Student-Athletes, In the Real Sense
description: The 1986 Butkus Award to Brian Bosworth - Oklahoma linebacker and communications major with a 3.28 grade-point average - marks the 11th time in history that a player has captured a major postseason football award the same year he was elected first-team academic all-American.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year include net capital gains on the sale of investment securities of 17 cents a share, and the prior year includes 12 cents a share on the sale of investment securities.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Food for the Hungry City Harvest, a volunteer agency that was started four years ago, delivers surplus food - the daily leftovers from restaurants, caterers, retailers, individual households and special projects such as photography sessions - to agencies and soup kitchens that feed the hungry and homeless. The organization even picks up leftovers from dinners that other charities give. It accepts donations as small as a single cake and has occasionally received gifts as large as a tractor-trailer load of food. It costs City Harvest only 25 cents to provide one meal.

title: 5TH ITERATION OF A LITERARY LION
description: ''The Counterlife'' is the fourth novel by Philip Roth to feature the literary lion Nathan Zuckerman. The first was ''The Ghost Writer,'' published in 1979, in which a 23-year-old Zuckerman, eager to find a mentor for his writing career, encounters ''the most famous literary ascetic in America'' as well as a woman he believes may be Anne Frank.

title: Former Batus President To Take Post at Cohoes
description: M. Ronald Ruskin, former president of the Batus Retail Group, plans to join Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd. as its president Feb. 1.

title: OPEC PACT BLOCKED BY IRAQ SNAG
description: Oil ministers here and top government officials in the Middle East struggled today in an effort to persuade Iraq to join an OPEC plan to cut oil production.

title: Abrams Seeks Limit On a Parade Group
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, seeking the appointment of a special master to take financial control of the organization that produces the annual Puerto Rican Day parade in New York City.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dow Rebounds and Closes at 1,936.16, Up 13.35
description: A sleepy stock market awoke in the final hour yesterday when professional traders, although nervous about Friday's ''triple-witching hour,'' decided that it was an opportune time to buy stocks and sell stock index futures.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer

title: AVX Offer for CTS
description: The AVX Corporation said it was offering $35 a share, or a total of $197.8 million, for the CTS Corporation, which makes electronic components and metal products.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it would take charges totaling $200 million, associated with the restructuring of its operations, in the fourth quarter.

title: KNICKS VS. NETS: HAVE-NOT NIGHT
description: Call it the Meeting of the Miserable. Or maybe the Crummy Classic. Whatever the term, it couldn't go far enough to describe the game tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the Knicks and the Nets, two of professional basketball's worst teams, meet for the second time this season. The only certainty is that one team will experience a feeling that has eluded it for much of the year -the thrill of victory.

title: No Quick Fixes For U. S. Trade
