description: The newly elected Congress is expected to make critical decisions about trade policy that will profoundly affect the vitality of the American economy and the stability and growth of the global economy. Congress will likely pass comprehensive trade legislation, and it will also have to decide what kind of negotiating authority to grant to the Administration in the next round of multilateral trade negotiations, in Uruguay.

title: Royals Obtain Beniquez
description: The Baltimore Orioles traded Juan Beniquez, a 36-year-old outfielder, to the Kansas City Royals yesterday for two minor league players.

title: CHICAGO'S NEW FASHION IMAGE
description: The windy city is becoming the trendy city.

title: SRI LANKA DISCOVERS BOMBS AS PEACE TALKS BEGIN
description: Two powerful bombs set to explode were found in the capital today as special envoys of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India arrived for talks with Sri Lankan leaders aimed at ending the guerrilla war here, the police reported.

title: Chief Sells Holding In Apple Computer
description: John Sculley, chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., sold nearly all of his Apple shares last month, according to information filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Sculley sold 107,503 shares, or about 97 percent of his holdings, at $39.81, the reports said. Barbara Krause, an Apple spokesman, said it was company policy not to comment on executives' private financial decisions but added that Mr. Sculley retains 392,497 options to purchase Apple shares at an exercise price of $16.85.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HEALTH AND SAFETY RULES ORDERED FOR WORKERS AT TOXIC WASTE SITES
description: The Government, citing known incidents of death from exposure to toxic chemicals, has issued health and safety regulations aimed at protecting nearly 170,000 workers at toxic waste sites.

title: 3-Mile-Island Worker Hurt
description: A cleanup worker at the damaged reactor on Three Mile Island was injured and contaminated by radiation Tuesday after being hit by lead shielding in the containment building. The 36-year-old worker, who was not identified, was taken to the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center and decontaminated while in the ambulance.

title: Topics: Presidential Papers; The Carter Letters
description: Ridicule remains a President's most formidable foe, a barometer to political popularity, as Jimmy Carter learned repeatedly from television and from jokes that quickly made the rounds. (Why did his Air Force One crew always carry a fresh turkey? Answer: Spare parts.)

title: MUSIC: 'JAZZ NATIVITY'
description: ''BENDING TOWARD THE LIGHT: A Jazz Nativity,'' a semistaged collection of Christmas carols that was written, arranged and produced by Anne Phillips, had a cast of jazz luminaries for its premiere Monday at St. Bartholomew's Church. Despite some enjoyable star turns, however, it was an unimaginative version of the Christmas story - genteel where it should have been jubilant.

title: DRESSING UP THE STAGE WITH TURKEY FEATHERS
description: WOOD is no longer enough for the surface of a stage when earth, sand, sea and turkey feathers are available. ''K2'' brought a glacial mountain to Broadway, Peter Brook had tons of soil delivered to the Vivian Beaumont Theater for ''Carmen'' and Tommy Tune and Twiggy danced in water in ''My One and Only.'' The feathers appeared in Ping Chong's ''Angels of Swedenborg,'' simulating a heavenly cloud on stage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. All these and others called for actors (and dancers) to be nimble-footed.

title: Accused I.R.A. Bomber Seized By U.S. Immigration in Utah
description: United States immigration agents arrested an accused Irish Republican Army bomber, Peter Gabriel McMullen, Tuesday night in his apartment here.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 113, Pacers 101: Larry Bird scored a game-high 34 points, and Kevin McHale and Robert Parish added 23 apiece to lead the Celtics to a fight-marred victory over Indiana last night. Rick Carlisle of Boston and John Long of Indiana were ejected with 7 minutes 11 seconds to play after exchanging punches in front of the Indiana bench. Both benches emptied, but order was quickly restored. The victory was Boston's 20th consecutive at the Boston Garden over Indiana, dating to April 2, 1978. Vern Fleming and Chuck Person led the Pacers with 21 each. Bill Walton of the Celtics underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right ankle in Los Angeles. The Celtics said that ''several tiny pieces of loose bone were removed, including one larger piece of bone'' during the surgery under general anesthesia. The Celtics said that Dr. Tony Daly reported the larger piece of bone removed ''could have been the irritating factor in this persistent joint pain over the last two months.'' (UPI) Cavaliers 110, 76ers 107: Ron Harper scored 6 of his 27 points in the final 39 seconds as Cavaliers handed the heir fourth straight loss. Brad Daugherty had 29 points and 11 rebounds for the winners at Philadelphia. Charles Barkley had 32 points and Julius Erving 20 for the Sixers. (AP)

title: JAZZ: MONTY ALEXANDER
description: MONTY ALEXANDER'S tribute to Nat (King) Cole at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, is much more than Mr. Alexander - a pianist who usually performs as part of a trio - trying to conjure up memories of Cole at the piano.

title: SHUBERTS ARE REJECTED ON 'PHANTOM OF OPERA'
description: The Shubert Organization, the largest theater owner on Broadway, has lost the intense competition to house ''Phantom of the Opera,'' the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical that is the biggest hit of the London theater season, the show's producer said yesterday.

title: GORBACHEV OFFER DISMISSED BY U.S.
description: The State Department today dismissed as propaganda an assertion by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Soviet Union was prepared to be flexible on research and testing for the American space-based missile defense system.

title: Bankers Trust Names 4 To Management Panel
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that four executives had been named to its management committee, which is taking on added responsibility as the bank moves toward what it calls a partnership style of management.

title: NEW THEORY ON NEUTRINOS CHALLENGES THE OLD
description: Neutrinos, the most bizarre of subatomic particles, took on a new aura of mystery today with the presentation of information obtained from almost 20 years of monitoring deep within a South Dakota gold mine.

title: REAGAN MISLED, WIFE SAYS
description: Nancy Reagan said today that her husband felt misled by his former aides and frustrated over their refusal to tell what they did in the Iran-contra affair.

title: MEESE IS DESCRIBED AS THE TARGET OF AN INVESTIGATION BY THE F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an inquiry into why Attorney General Edwin Meese 3rd ordered a delay in an F.B.I. investigation last fall into arms shipments to Nicaraguan rebels, law enforcement officials said today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IT costs so much to keep most houses warm in winter that it makes good sense to do everything possible to economize.

title: Ewing Facing Fine
description: Rod Thorn, vice president in charge of operations for the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that ''there will be fines'' stemming from the incident Tuesday night involving Patrick Ewing and Greg Kite, the Celtics' reserve center.

title: STATE GETS GAS STATIONS IN FRAUD CASE
description: The owner of 50 Gaseteria discount gasoline stations in the New York City area was ordered yesterday to forfeit about $25 million in cash and business holdings after being found guilty of defrauding the state of nearly $5 million in sales tax.

title: Prisoner Free, America Still Bound
description: Eugene Hasenfus is lucky, far luckier than the Reagan Administration he thought he was working for in Nicaragua. He escaped with his life when his cargo plane, loaded with weapons for the contras, was downed in October by Sandinistas. Sentenced to 30 years by a ''people's court,'' he was pardoned yesterday in a shrewdly timed propaganda coup. But his liberation comes at a bedeviling time for President Reagan. His return home serves mainly to remind us of the Administration's growing participation in an unsanctioned war and to draw further attention to Lieut. Col. Oliver North, paymaster and coordinator of the contra crusade.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Kerr, a Duke forward, was awarded the 1986 Herrmann Trophy yesterday as the nation's best college soccer player. Kerr, who led the Blue Devils to a 1-0 victory over Akron in the national championship game. . . . Joe Paterno of Penn State won the Bear Bryant Award as college football coach of the year.

title: RIDLEY HAS 3 IN RANGER ROMP
description: There were early signs that this night at Madison Square Garden would be different. First, before the game was a minute old, Ron Greschner made a pass that was so fine, it barely squeezed between two Washington skaters and right to Mike Ridley's stick. Ridley sped in alone and scored. The Rangers have rarely looked so fine.

title: FRANCE PARACHUTES FOOD AND SUPPLIES IN CHAD
description: France has parachuted several tons of food, munitions and fuel to northern Chad to help local forces fighting against armored Libyan columns moving into the area, the French Defense Ministry announced today.

title: Margeotes, Fertitta Gets Nature's Bounty
description: Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss has added Nature's Bounty Vitamins of Bohemia, L.I., to its client list.

title: Bishop Is Named For Metuchen
description: Pope John Paul II has named the Rev. Edward T. Hughes, the Auxiliary Bishop of Philadelphia, as the next spiritual leader for 500,000 Roman Catholics in the four-county Diocese of Metuchen.

title: Auto Makers That Cooperate
description: THEY do not advertise it much, but the automobile companies do business with each other all the time. Usually it involves unseen internal components, with the buyer seeking to avoid the cost of designing and tooling for a part on its own and the seller taking advantage of the improved economics of a longer production run.

title: Dealing With Pretoria
description: Two years ago this month 35 conservative Republicans in the House of Representatives wrote the South African Ambassador in Washington urging an early end to apartheid. They wanted good relations between our two countries, they said, ''but the reality of apartheid and the violence used to keep it in place make it likely that our relations will deteriorate.''

title: Yields Are Mostly Flat
description: Yields generally remained flat in the week ended yesterday, with only a slight improvement for certificates of deposit and some softening for bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds.

title: 390 DETAINED CHILDREN IN SOUTH AFRICA ARE LISTED
description: Human rights groups monitoring detentions in South Africa have compiled a list of 390 names of children being detained under the emergency decree. Four on the list are 11 years old, and several are 12 or 13.

title: DELOREAN FOUND NOT GUILTY ON CHARGES OF EMBEZZLEMENT
description: John Z. DeLorean was found not guilty today of defrauding his failed sports car company of $8.5 million.

title: Short-Term Rates Up Sharply
description: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, to the dismay of corporate borrowers, and securities dealers who must finance their inventories. But the move delighted money managers looking for short-term investments.

title: HOSPITAL ORDERED TO READMIT PARAPLEGIC LEFT ON SIDEWALK
description: A judge has ordered a city-run nursing home on Roosevelt Island to readmit a wheelchair-bound paraplegic whom it discharged one night last month by leaving him and his belongings on a sidewalk in lower Manhattan.

title: Scott Paper Selling $92 Million Bonds
description: The Scott Paper Company is offering $92 million of bonds at par in a three-part financing through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: THE VANITY, MIRRORING PAST GLAMOUR
description: IT has been over 50 years since Jean Harlow sat at her vanity in ''Dinner at Eight'' and reached through the three tiers of white silk fringes that skirted it, to open the drawers beneath. The elaborate vanities of the era, which acted like adjectives of beauty and femininity modifying anyone who sat before them, gradually fell out of fashion, victims of the Depression, World War II and, later, the trend to practical, modular and minimal furniture. Vanities themselves became a forgotten furniture type. Women simply retreated to the bathroom and made up over the sink.

title: G.M.A.C. Markets $445 Million Issue
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $445 million of asset-backed securities through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Slashing Case Defense Rests
description: The defense rested its case yesterday in the trial of a Manhattan makeup artist accused in the razor slashing of a model last summer. The judge said the jury would begin its deliberations late today after the closing arguments. The defendant, Steven Roth, 28 years old, of 455 West 34th Street, is charged with having arranged the slashing of the model, Marla Hanson, 25.

title: ALCOHOL ACCIDENTS DIP 44% AMONG NEW YORK YOUTHS
description: Alcohol-related accidents involving drivers under 21 years old have declined by nearly half in New York State since the drinking age was raised above 18, according to figures from the state's Department of Motor Vehicles. During the same period fatalities resulting from such accidents dropped by over 40 percent.

title: Water Is Bringing New York State Together
description: To the Editor:

title: The Choice For Inquiry: Lee H. Hamilton
description: Representative Lee H. Hamilton, who was named today to head the House's special committee to investigate the Iran arms affair, is in the position of being the soldier leading the generals. But there are few other people in the House who would be considered up to the job. Of the eight other

title: MAN'S BODY WENT UNCLAIMED IN MORGUE FOR WEEK
description: Through a series of errors and misunderstandings, the body of an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth, who was rushed by ambulance from his parents' apartment to a hospital late on the night of Dec. 8, lay unidentified in a city morgue for a week until it was finally claimed yesterday.

title: JUDGE AWARDS CUSTODY TO HOMOSEXUAL FATHER
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Suffolk County has awarded custody of a 13-year-old boy to his homosexual father. Legal experts said the ruling was the first of its kind in the state.

title: U.S.F.L. Loses Round
description: The United States Football League suffered what could be the final blow in its effort to resume competition after a ruling by Judge Peter K. Leisure in United States District Court. Judge Leisure ruled against the U.S.F.L. in its attempt to break the National Football League into two independent conferences and remove it from at least one television network.

title: VIETNAM'S 3 LEADERS GIVE UP THEIR POSTS, TO BE FILLED TODAY
description: Vietnam announced the resignation of its three top leaders today.

title: Advertising; BBDO's Chief Thinks Big
description: DID Norm Campbell dream of being chief executive of the mighty BBDO International agency network back in 1981 when, as the head of Tracy-Locke, he negotiated its acquisition by BBDO? Probably. Norman W. Campbell, who will be 52 years old until Dec. 29, was born in Dallas. He not only is big, he thinks big.

title: Bridge: A Montreal-Toronto Series Has Lasted Nearly 20 Years
description: Half a century ago there was a series of annual matches between teams representing New York and Philadelphia. From 1960 to 1973 an intercity match was played at the Summer Nationals with the host metropolis challenging the previous winners. Los Angeles won on five occasions and Boston on four.

title: SWITCHED-ON HOMES FOR THE HOLIDAY
description: THIS is the season when adventurous New Yorkers turn their homes into lovingly wrapped gifts to the passersby. Those in search of the season usually need not travel far. They may find it on an unassuming stretch of street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, where John Marinaro, in a yuletide feat of human daring, strings 50,000 Christmas lights while being serenaded by Vic Damone.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today has been a day of great surprise, a day I'll surely remember in my heart forever.'' - Eugene Hasenfus, on being freed by Nicaragua. [ A1:3. ]

title: REAGAN SEEKS TO CUT FUNDS FOR NEW IMMIGRATION LAW, HOUSE PANEL IS TOLD
description: President Reagan wants to cut spending for enforcement of the new immigration law substantially below the levels envisioned by Congress, Administration officials said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A WORLD OF WATCHERS. By Joseph Kastner. With Illustrations by Louis Agassiz Fuertes. 241 pages. Knopf. $25.

title: 'Devastating Effect' Is Seen
description: The general secretary of the National Council of Churches said at a news conference yesterday that the ''Iran-contra affair has had a devastating effect'' on the credibility of the United States in the region and would hamper its effort to mediate a peace settlement for years to come. The official, Arie R. Brouwer, returned from a three-week visit to the Middle East.

title: SULLIMAN SCORES OVERTIME WINNER
description: A shooting tip from his goaltender helped Doug Sulliman of the Devils score 35 seconds into overtime tonight for a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CONCERT: MAHLER 2D BY BOSTON
description: The Boston Symphony has long been an orchestra particularly blessed. At home, it plays in Symphony Hall, one of the two most congenial venues for orchestral music in this country, if not the world. And when it comes to New York on tour, it plays in the other one. Last night, it became the first full-scale orchestra to perform a complete program in Carnegie Hall since the recently completed remodeling.

title: Another New York Ethics Commission?
description: The State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, charged with finding the causes and cures for New York's corruption scandals, winds up with some sound recommendations - which could fall flat because the commission has done little to dramatize their urgency. Should Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch call for another commission to finish that part of the job? Yes.

title: When Does Red Square Resemble Dubuque?
description: Hunched over a table in the ornate National Hotel, Senator Gary Hart and an official of the Supreme Soviet were engaged in delicate negotiations.

title: FURTHER ACCOUNTS BLOCKED BY SWISS
description: The United States today gave the Swiss authorities an additional list of three companies and nine people whose bank accounts it wants temporarily blocked because of their reported use to funnel Iranian arms payments to rebels in Nicaragua.

title: JURY RULES WAYNE NEWTON WAS DEFAMED ON NBC-TV
description: A Federal jury in Las Vegas today found that NBC had defamed the entertainer Wayne Newton in a series of broadcasts in 1980 and 1981 that linked him to organized crime. The jury awarded Mr. Newton $19.2 million in damages.

title: I.M.F. Vote Set for Today
description: Directors of the International Monetary Fund will meet today to vote on a new managing director for the agency.

title: FORSTMANN GROUP TO GET LEAR SIEGLER
description: A group led by Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment firm, has agreed to acquire Lear Siegler Inc., the aerospace, automotive and manufacturing concern, for about $2.1 billion in cash, the acquirer said today.

title: COPING WITH STARDOM AT 16
description: ''I was a very good basketball player'' is Kenny Anderson's response to questions about a rumor that at one time, a few years ago, he had a pretty high opinion of himself. ''And I showed it a little.''

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 22
CALENDAR: MUSEUM SHOP SALE
description: City Spirit Holiday Bazaar, Urban Center Galleries at the the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, 212-935-3960.

title: A Portrait of Clark
description: The Interior Department will unveil an official portrait of a former Secretary, William P. Clark, in a ceremony this morning. Among those expected to be there are the State Department's Ambassador at Large for Cultural Affairs, Daniel J. Terra, and the artist who painted the portrait, Everett Raymond Kinstler of New York.

title: PIANO DUO: WENTWORTHS
description: DESPITE appearances to the contrary, there were some musical events that took place Monday night besides the reopening of Carnegie Hall. A little less than a mile away, at Town Hall, Jean and Kenneth Wentworth played three large works by Franz Schubert for piano, four hands - the Variations in A flat (D. 813), the Fantasy in F minor (D. 940) and the Sonata in C (''Grand Duo,'' D. 812).

title: Nigeria Gets Accord on Debt
description: The Paris Club, a group of Western creditor nations, has reached an accord with Nigeria to reschedule the country's medium- and long-term debt over 10 years, the French Finance Ministry said today.

title: OUSTED FILIPINO RETURNS TO THE FRAY
description: Juan Ponce Enrile, dismissed as Defense Minister three weeks ago, re-entered the Manila political arena today, saying he was ''learning to be in public life again in another role.''

title: S.A.S. Orders McDonnell Jets
description: The Scandanavian Airlines System today ordered 12 of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's long-delayed MD-11 wide-body jetliners, but the order still does not insure that McDonnell will start production of the new plane.

title: NEGLIGENCE ON EVIDENCE ADMITTED IN ABUSE CASE
description: The chief prosecutor in the McMartin preschool molestation case took the stand today and admitted that she waited 10 months before giving defense attorneys information that cast doubt on the credibility of a major witness.

title: FEWER THAN HALF EARNED DEGREES IN 4 YEARS
description: Fewer than half the students in a Federal study got their college degrees in the four years after high school graduation, the Department of Education reported today.

title: RUTGERS RE-EXAMINES DISPUTE OVER NAZISM
description: A bitter 51-year-old dispute between two Rutgers University professors - one a Nazi sympathizer, the other an opponent of Hitler who lost his teaching post - was not the result of political discrimination, a special faculty committee concluded today.

title: MOSCOW PLANNING ANTI-'STAR WARS'
description: The Soviet Union has developed plans that it says will defeat an American space-based defense system. It would use dummy missiles, countermeasures against lasers and other steps to improve the survivability of Soviet missiles.

title: AIRPORTS EXPECT RECORD FOR HOLIDAY TRAFFIC
description: New York City's three major airports are bracing for record-breaking crowds of year-end holiday travelers, many attracted by discount fares.

title: PAY INCREASE FOR OFFICIALS
description: Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers, acceding to a plea from Attorney General Robert Abrams and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, agreed today to raise the salaries of those two officials to $110,000 a year, from $85,000.

title: Boys of Winter
description: Baseball, as everybody knows, is the summer game, with a dash of October to take care of the playoffs and the World Series. November is for football, with a little basketball and hockey thrown in.

title: Gallows Cut Into Firewood
description: A old-fashioned Western gallows built as a tourist attraction has been cut into firewood. Members of a business group, the Wild Bunch, hoped to move the gallows, which was built as part of the Douglas centennial celebration last summer, to a parking lot in town. But they sawed the log structure into small pieces Saturday and gave it away as firewood after the local Chamber of Commerce voted against spending $620 on liability insurance, said Steve Park, a member of the Wild Bunch.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend declared Dec. 18, 1985.

title: THE FAMILY RITUALS THAT CAN LIGHTEN OR BURDEN HOLIDAYS
description: AND now, the 1986 Holiday Family Quiz:

title: NEW PROBLEM FOR TROUBLED WITHERSPOON
description: As if Tim Witherspoon did not have enough problems.

title: PHH Prices Notes For Yield of 8.02%
description: The PHH Group, which provides vehicle fleet management services, is offering $100 million of 8 percent notes due in 1996, priced at 99 7/8 to yield 8.02 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters.

title: WALTON CONTINUES TO SHUFFLE JETS' ROSTER
description: In the confusion of a four-game losing streak, continued injuries and an uncertain playoff fate, the Jets shuttled more defensive players today.

title: MODEST MATERIALS FOR RESTORING GILDING
description: Simply stated, true gilding is laying down thin leaves of pure gold on a prepared surface. If the groundwork has been meticulously prepared -the high cost of the leaf practically insures this - the finished work appears as flawless solid gold, a sumptuous look quite without equal.

title: G.N.P. GROWTH REVISED DOWN SLIGHTLY, TO 2.8%
description: The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the third quarter, the Government announced today, but inflation picked up as well.

title: GORBACHEV'S GREAT PUSH AND THE RELUCTANT PUBLIC
description: There is an old Russian proverb that the muzhik won't cross himself until he hears the thunder.

title: AGENCY SEEKS THE ELIMINATION OF 5,000 HOSPITAL BEDS IN CITY
description: More than 5,000 of New York City's 35,000 hospital beds are wastes of public health resources and should be eliminated, a key governmental health-planning organization said yesterday.

title: ACCENT ON VICTORIAN
description: RENOVATING a Victorian house? Chances are you will need replacement gingerbread such as spandrels, balusters, grilles, molding and trim. A number of companies across the country specialize in Victorian millwork.

title: LATIN MAY BE PRECISE, BUT IT'S A BIT DEAD
description: IN the second chapter of the Book of Genesis, God puts Adam in a garden and gives him a job to do - giving names to every living thing, including plants. Adam's instructions from on high weren't entirely specific, but I presume he was meant to give everything one name only and not assign the same name to two or more things. For the sake of precision and clarity, these criteria make a great deal of sense. We'd wallow in confusion if whales were also called pigeons or if we decided that the family dog and cat would share the name Spot.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1986
description: Companies

title: NEW AIDS VIRUS FOUND DIFFERENT FROM FIRST
description: Scientists at the Pasteur Institute in France said yesterday that they had cloned a newly discovered virus that can cause AIDS in humans and determined that it was quite different from the main AIDS virus and somewhat similar to a third virus that causes the disease in monkeys.

title: Man Wearing Guard Uniform Shoots a Companion on IND
description: A man wearing a security guard's uniform and a badge shot a 21-year-old companion during a dispute in a Manhattan subway station yesterday, the police said.

title: G.M. PLANS TEMPORARY OUTPUT CUT
description: The General Motors Corporation announced plans today to cut production, saying it would furlough 26,400 workers in January, most of them for two weeks.

title: Borg-Warner Stake Raised to 11.3%
description: The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs said that he had increased his stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation, to the equivalent of 11.3 percent, or 9.7 million shares, from 7.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs, the chairman of Minstar Inc., said that Minstar had entered into an option agreement with Bear, Stearns & Company to purchase more than three million Borg-Warner shares for an average price per share of $41.41, or $125.4 million.

title: FINAL HEARING ON WEST SIDE ROAD SHOWS SHARP DIVISIONS OVER PLAN
description: A New York State panel's draft report for highway construction and development along the West Side of Manhattan came under angry attack by elected officials, community groups, residents and environmental advocates last night.

title: People
description: * Terry R. Alday, Richard Baty and Jack C. Sperling have been appointed senior vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: SCIENTOLOGY CHURCH SET TO PAY MILLIONS IN SETTLEMENT OF SUITS
description: In sealed court settlements, the beleaguered Church of Scientology has agreed to pay former members more than $5 million to settle two dozen lawsuits that allege fraud, misrepresentation and other abuses by the organization, sources close to the church said today.

title: Old Ideas, and New, on Welfare
description: Suddenly, the worm seems to have turned on welfare. When the Reagan Administration began, it was social welfare liberals who seemed to be out of gas, and ideas. The energy all seemed to come from analysts eager to get the Federal Government out of the anti-poverty business. Now the roles seem to be reversing.

title: 2 Collapse and Die At Council Hearing
description: Two elderly men collapsed and died of heart attacks at a City Council hearing, officials said yesterday.

title: REPUBLICBANK'S MARKET VALUE DROPS OVER MERGER
description: The Republicbank Corporation of Dallas lost more than one-tenth of its market value yesterday as investors expressed concern over how its proposed merger with another Texas banking giant, the Interfirst Corporation, would affect Republicbank's prospects immediately and long term.

title: Trade Wars Ahead?
description: The Reagan Administration is involved in trade confrontations with the European Community, Canada and Brazil that could lead to full-scale trade wars in the new year.

title: Tampa Bay Blues
description: Here are the coaches who, among all those with an unbroken tenure of more than a year for a current N.F.L. franchise, have fared the worst.

title: Big Losses Seen for Boesky Partners
description: The limited partners in Ivan F. Boesky's securities firm stand to lose more than $100 million of the $335 million of capital they placed in the firm, some of the investors said last night.

title: MET MUSEUM APOLOGIZES FOR A REFERENCE TO JEWS
description: A reference to Jews in a recent issue of the Bulletin of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has drawn a protest from the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and an apology from the museum.

title: Prosecutor: Boasters Need Not Apply
description: Rule No. 1 is simple: If you want this job, don't make it obvious.

title: Rhode Islanders Cautioned After Six Random Snipings
description: Police officers reacting to six random night snipings urged residents of northern Rhode Island today to draw their blinds and stay away from windows while officers search for a gunman ''shooting to kill.''

title: RAIN WORRIES PUERTO RICAN HILLSIDERS
description: At night when rain patters on the roof, Felix Barbosa wakens and seems to count the drops. ''How bad is this rain and how much water will it bring to the hill?'' he asks himself.

title: DR. STANLEY MANDELES
description: Dr. Stanley Mandeles, a research biochemist and educator whose work focused on cancer and aging, died of cancer Monday at his home in Freehold, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: YANKS LOOKING FOR MORRIS'S BEST OFFER
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday he would not rush into an agreement with Jack Morris, but if he likes what he hears and sees when he meets with the pitcher today, he would be free to sign him.

title: PROSTATE SURGERY: COMMON FOR OLDER MEN AND NOT ESPECIALLY DANGEROUS
description: The prostate operation President Reagan is scheduled to undergo on Jan. 5 is one of the most common performed in the United States. Although all surgery has some degree of risk, doctors do not regard the procedure as particularly dangerous. The death rate in a national survey was seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WITHHELD DUES SAID TO CAUSE W.H.O. CRISIS
description: The director of the World Health Organization says the organization faces a crisis because of a ''huge shortfall'' in the contributions of member countries.

title: ABORTION PILL EXPECTED TO BE SOLD IN EUROPE
description: A French pharmaceutical company is expected to market a drug soon in Europe that a study published yesterday has shown can safely end an early pregnancy in at least 85 percent of women who take it within 10 days of missing a menstrual period. The drug is not approved for sale in the United States.

title: It's Put Up or Shut Up
description: Sometime today the 1987 American League East title, alias Jack Morris, will walk into George Steinbrenner's office at the American Shipbuilding Company in Tampa, Fla., to determine if the Yankees' principal owner wants it and him. Put up or shut up.

title: PRESIDENT FACING SURGERY TO EASE PROSTATE TROUBLE
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan would undergo a surgical procedure Jan. 5 to relieve ''discomfort'' caused by an enlarged prostate.

title: Never Too Early to Say Merry Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: COLOMBIA EDITOR IS SHOT DEAD
description: Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot dead a prominent Colombian journalist tonight in Bogota, officials said.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest second quarter figures include a loss of $4 million of previously recorded investment tax credits due to the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split Nov. 30. The latest year results have been restated to include the effect of adoption F.A.S.B. 87 relating to pension costs.

title: F.B.I. Uncovers Wider Role by Saudis in Iran Arms Deal
description: The investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Iran arms deal has uncovered evidence of wider Saudi Arabian involvement than previously disclosed, according to Federal law enforcement officials.

title: 'Neighborly Elements' Form Model Program
description: Daphne Busby described the beginnings of the Sisterhood of Black Single Mothers in the early 1970's as a ''lifting up of those neighborly elements already available'' in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INSIDE
description: Carnegie Hall by Ear Is Carnegie Hall still the Stradivarius of the music world? Four critics assess the sound from different perspectives at one concert.

title: MUSIC: DOES CARNEGIE HALL REMAIN THE STRADIVARIUS OF THE CONCERT WORLD?
description: BECAUSE of the great curiosity about Carnegie Hall's acoustics after the widely publicized renovation, The New York Times asked five music critics to various locations in the hall Tuesday night to report their impressions - reviewing the hall as opposed to the performers. The Orchestra of St. Luke's, with Marilyn Horne as soloist, played works by Mozart, Mahler and Beethoven.

title: BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: THE Sugarplum Fairy is certainly the plum role in ''The Nutcracker.'' Yet, even though her Cavalier does little more than partner her in a pas de deux, he can still create a pleasant impression with his stage presence, as two talented young dancers demonstrated when they made their debuts in this part at recent performances of the New York City Ballet.

title: Minority Business Still Leaping the Highest Hurdles; Much More Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, the page containing the American Stock Exchange tables was omitted in some copies of Business Day Wednesday.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: An inquiry has begun into why Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ordered the F.B.I. last fall to delay an investigation into shipments of weapons to the Nicaraguan contras. The bureau was reportedly told that an inquiry would hurt talks intended to free Americans held hostage in Lebanon. But a senior law-enforcement official said that if it was also intended to hide the fact that profits from the arms sales had been used to buy weapons for the contras, it could lead to charges of obstruction of justice. [ Page A1. ]

title: RECITAL: VON STADE AT THE MODERN MUSEUM
description: FREDERICA VON STADE came to the Museum of Modern Art Sunday evening to sing the recital she had to postpone during the museum's ''Vienna 1900'' series in the fall. At first glance her program looked to have little more connection with that period and place than might have been expected to turn up by chance, but it turns out that Debussy's ''Fetes Galantes'' (Book 1) and Schumann's ''Frauenliebe und -leben'' were interspersed with the works of the adventurous Viennese pioneers on the programs of Arnold Schoenberg's Society for the Private Performance of Music. Here, along with Mahler, early Berg and comic Schoenberg, they formed a program well suited to Miss von Stade's exquisite lyric mezzo-soprano and to the spirit that infuses the best of her singing - though on this occasion the spirit seemed somewhat muted.

title: PROGRAM TO SEEK MORE LOCAL AID FOR CITY'S POOR
description: The Citizens Committee for New York City is starting a major new volunteer effort to build on the city's network of neighborhood associations and bolster poverty projects, such as soup kitchens.

title: AGENDA
description: Moratorium on S.R.O. Conversions

title: F.C.C. TO HOLD INQUIRY INTO PREFERENCE POLICIES
description: The Federal Communications Commission, ignoring recent criticism, today authorized a formal inquiry into its policies that help women and racial minorities acquire radio and television stations.

title: Never Too Early to Say Merry Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 GIANTS AND 2 JETS ARE NAMED TO PLAY IN THE PRO BOWL
description: Eight Giants and two Jets were named yesterday to play in the Pro Bowl game Feb. 1 in Honolulu. The rosters included two surprise selections (Brad Benson and Jim Burt of the Giants) and two notable omissions (Phil Simms of the Giants and Ken O'Brien of the Jets, the quarterbacks).

title: FIGURES ON U.S. EMPLOYMENT SHOW LOSS OF JOBS IN 11 STATES
description: Arizona, Tennessee, Nevada and Florida are leading the nation in producing new jobs, while 11 states with economies dependent on energy or agriculture have fewer people at work than a year ago, the Labor Department has reported.

title: Trust Vehicles To Make Debut
description: ''PRIMES'' and ''Scores'' will soon be joining Cats and Tigers in the lexicon of Wall Street. Just as Cats and Tigers - two of the more popular zero coupon bonds - ''strip'' the interest from the principal of fixed-income securities, Primes and Scores are designed to separate the dividends from stocks.

title: SEAGRAM SAID TO PLAN SALE OF WINE DIVISIONS
description: The Seagram Company, the world's largest producer of wine and spirits, is reportedly about to sell much of its huge wine business.

title: AT A CEMETERY IN LENINGRAD, PILGRIMS SEEK MIRACLES
description: At the center of the old Smolensk Cemetery in a grimy, factory-choked corner of Leningrad is a small chapel surrounded by scaffolding and wooden fencing.

title: WATER IS BRINGING NEW YORK STATE TOGETHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.We want to convert a large uninsulated barn into a tool shed and studio for year-round use. How can we insulate it without tearing off the exterior clapboard siding? A. Most such barns are unfinished on the inside; that is, the studs are open and exposed, and the inner side of the exterior siding is exposed. If that is the case then all that is necessary is to install regular fiberglass batts from the inside, pressing the batts between the studs.

title: Long Island City Looking to the Sky
description: One of the most important neighbors of Citicorp's proposed skyscraper in Long Island City is nowhere near Jackson Avenue. It is La Guardia Airport, some three and a half miles away. And it is the reason that the Federal Aviation Administration is examining the proposed 656-foot tower.

title: PLANE MANEUVERS IN MALAY WEATHER
description: Constantly changing course to avoid thunderheads, lightning and turbulent air, the aircraft Voyager passed over the Malay Peninsula and Bay of Bengal today in its attempt to be the first to fly around the earth on one load of fuel without landing.

title: STUDENTS IN SPAIN, PROTESTING COLLEGE PLAN, SHUT MOST SCHOOLS
description: Most of Spain's high schools were shut today as striking students marched in cities around the country to protest college admission policies.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ON FIRST JERSEY
description: First Jersey Securities charged huge markups this year in the trading of two securities, and may have violated securities and fraud statutes, a court-appointed consultant said.

title: JIM WALTER reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1986 results includes net income of $645,000, or 2 cents a share, from reduced pension expense following adoption of FASB No. 87, as of Sept. 1, 1986. Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to give effect to a 5-for-4 split in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend, distributed April 1986.

title: DECLARING 'FOOD EMERGENCY,' PANEL URGES NEW CITY AGENCY
description: A City Council committee declared yesterday that New York was facing a ''food emergency,'' and unanimously urged the Koch administration to create a new Office of Food Policy that would coordinate hunger relief efforts now shared by more than 20 agencies.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Biogen, Cambridge, Mass., a developer of pharmaceutical products through genetic engineering, elected to its board James W. Stevens, a managing director of the investment banking firm Dillon, Read & Co.

title: CHICAGO, PLAYING HARDBALL POLITICS, TO REPLACE AGING STADIUM
description: In Chicago, where politics is a major league sport, Comiskey Park, the oldest baseball diamond in the major leagues, has become entangled in the Byzantine maneuverings for the elections that this city always seems to be having.

title: Weight Problems
description: Officials at Aqueduct announced during yesterday's program that the weight allowances for three apprentice riders - Jerry Belmonte, Tyrone Carter and David Nuesch - were being reduced from seven to five pounds. The announcement was made shortly before the eighth race.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Coach Quits
description: Archie Cooley, the football coach at Mississippi Valley State who resigned yesterday, said he wants to take his his five current assistant coaches, to his new job, at the Unviersity of Arkansas-Pine Bluff. Fifty-three of his Mississippi Valley players say they also plan to go with him.

title: Meese Finds No News in His Inquiry
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he had not ''seen anything'' to contradict his original finding that only Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North knew of the diversion of Iranian arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: TOP PENTAGON HEALTH OFFICIAL RECOMMENDS KEEPING POLICY ON AIDS
description: Despite some internal opposition, the Pentagon's top health official has concluded that the Defense Department should keep its policy of retaining service personnel who test positively for exposure to AIDS.

title: MURDERER-RAPIST IS EXECUTED AFTER JUSTICES REJECT APPEAL
description: Richard Andrade, who stabbed a woman at least 14 times in raping and murdering her in 1984, died of a lethal injection early this morning after the United States Supreme Court refused to stay the execution.

title: AT THE NEW SCHOOL, RETIRED ADULTS ARE EDUCATING EACH OTHER
description: THE scene is the weekly session of News and Views, one of about 80 study groups offered at the Institute for Retired Professionals, an adult education program at the New School for Social Research.

title: HERS
description: IN a political collective I belonged to in the late 1960's, we had a constant debate: is sexual revolution compatible with feminism? A good many of the women thought not, and a good many of the men thought so. I was part of a rather suspect minority who couldn't make up their minds.

title: ISRAELIS DISPUTE REGAN TESTIMONY
description: Senior Israeli officials today disputed the reported testimony of Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, that Israel did not have President Reagan's approval when it shipped arms to Iran in the summer of 1985.

title: SHULTZ WARNING ENVOYS TO STOP BYPASSING HIM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today formally barred American ambassadors from bypassing him and engaging in private communications with the White House national security adviser unless ''explicitly directed'' to do so by President Reagan.

title: PARAMILITARY LEADER SURRENDERS IN ARMS CASE
description: The former Arizona leader of the Civilian Materiel Assistance, a paramilitary group, turned himself in to Federal agents in Tucson yesterday, a day after he was indicted on firearms charges resulting from a prior drug conviction.

title: Yeager's Flight Marks Wrights' Anniversary
description: The test pilot Chuck Yeager set a speed record of sorts today on the 83d anniversary of man's first powered flight.

title: Lamberti Appoints S.I. Secession Panel
description: Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island appointed a 15-member committee yesterday to study whether it is economically and legally feasible for Staten Island to secede from New York City.

title: MENORAH DESIGNS OF PRESENT AND PAST
description: THIS year Hanukkah, the Jewish celebration known as the Festival of Lights, begins the evening of Dec. 26. Traditionally on each of the eight nights of Hannukah, candles are lighted with another candle, called the shamas.

title: Message Is the Medium
description: A Washington woman apparently opposed to the message on a pair of posters placed on a lampost on Connecticut Avenue carefully covered them over with blue paint. She then thoughfully attached her own sign, which said: WET PAINT.

title: AS FAMILIES CHANGE, SO MAY TRADITIONS
description: TRADITIONAL holidays are not just for traditional families. Terry Greenaway, for example, has been divorced for five years, but her former husband still comes over every Christmas morning so they and their two children can open presents together.

title: Photo of Donald E. Nickelson; BUSINESS PEOPLE Paine Webber Inc. Appoints President
description: After successfully rethinking and rebuilding Paine Webber Inc.'s retail brokerage division over the last four years, Donald E. Nickelson is being asked to try his hand on the entire firm.

title: VOTE INCREASES LOCAL CONTROL OF SPECIAL EDUCATION CLASSES
description: By a 4-to-3 vote, the New York City Board of Education last night approved a plan to give local school boards more control over special education classes in the city's elementary and junior high schools.

title: THE RUSH-HOUR TAXI SHORTAGE: A COMPLEX EQUATION
description: It is the peak of the afternoon rush on a cold and windy December day, and there are scores of empty yellow cabs in New York. They are in Long Island City, Queens, lined up at taxi fleet garages, seeking fuel and fresh drivers.

title: Chinese to Visit Laos; First Time Since 1979
description: China today announced plans for its first high-level official visit to Laos since relations between the two Communist neighbors were frozen in 1979.

title: Harness Race?
description: The electronic message board in the Aqueduct infield got into the Christmas spirit when it flashed a jockey change for the No. 5 horse in the feature race the other day. The new rider was Chris Antley, but the board said, ''5 Antler.'' The race was named, by the way, for the late Joe Palmer, the brilliant turf writer, who would have loved it.

title: Manville Nod Seen
description: By Reuters

title: Padilla & Spear Adding Brum & Anderson
description: Padilla & Spear of Minneapolis, the largest public relations firm in the Upper Middle West, announced yesterday that it had merged with Brum & Anderson, its No. 2 in Minneapolis.

title: HONEYWELL TO TAKE $575 MILLION CHARGE
description: Honeywell Inc. said today that it would report a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $575 million, primarily from the sale of most of its computer business at a discounted price.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.; WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS.

title: ALBANY MOVES TOWARD TRANSIT ACCORD
description: Republicans reacted favorably today to a plan to raise motor-vehicle taxes in the New York City area, signaling a possible break in deadlocked negotiations over how to pay for improvements in the city's transit system and freeze its fares.

title: KEY RATES
A SHELLEY TROVE GOING TO NEW YORK LIBRARY
description: One of the most important private collections of English literature - a trove of original journals, poems, letters, books and paintings that illuminate the Romantic era of Shelley, Byron, Keats and their friends, wives and lovers -are to be presented to the New York Public Library this morning.

title: Haig Nears a Decision
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State and White House chief of staff, has been taking a low-key approach to the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination for several months now, but that may be drawing to a close.

title: Casey Is Said to Face Surgery
description: A physician at Georgetown University Hospital said tonight that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, had been examined by the chief of the hospital's division of neurosurgery. But the hospital's neurological chief, Dr. Alfred J. Lussenhop, would not confirm an examination had been made or comment on a report Mr. Casey would undergo neurological surgery, maybe as early as Thursday.

title: Messages From Washington to U.S. Envoys
description: Following are the texts of messages to United States ambassadors from Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Reagan: SHULTZ'S MESSAGE

title: ROCKET PROGRAM BARS FRENCH LINK
description: Air Force Secretary Edward Aldridge said today that the United States had decided not to use French booster rockets to launch American military navigation satellites.

title: Profit Increase At 3-Year High
description: After-tax profits of United States corporations rose by a revised 5.5 percent in the July-September quarter, the biggest increase in three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GIVING IS AN ANNUAL CUSTOM FOR MANY WHO AID NEEDIEST
description: Many gifts to the 75th annual appeal to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have come from contributors who are carying on a custom started years ago.

title: Stop Manhattanizing Manhattan Island
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'WIDOW CLAIRE,' FROM HORTON FOOTE
description: OF course, almost nothing happens in ''The Widow Claire,'' the latest Horton Foote play to reach a New York stage. In keeping with his writing habits of four decades, the author of ''The Trip to Bountiful'' and ''Tender Mercies'' whisks us into the fictional small Texas town of Harrison and sets his characters about their diurnal business. ''The Widow Claire,'' a 95-minute anecdote in one act, describes only a single long summer night of 1911. Horace Robedaux (Matthew Broderick), a poor but ambitious 21-year-old about to enroll in a six-week business course in Houston, spends the eve of his departure courting the title character (Hallie Foote), a 27-year-old widow with several suitors and two rambunctious kids. Daybreak brings Horace's leave-taking and an exchange of farewells so formal one might wonder whether the couple had in fact stolen a few chaste kisses under the new moon of the night before.

title: ON COLUMBUS, A NEW STORE WHERE ALL IS NOT WHAT IT SEEMS
description: SANDWICHED between a Ray's Pizza and an Associated Supermarket, Giles & Lewis is one of the latest additions in the gentrification of Columbus Avenue. The most striking thing about the store, which sells modern home furnishings and accessories, is its facade, a Lego-like assemblage of what look like rusted steel girders. ''Not steel and not rusted,'' said Lewis Dolin, who with his partner, Dr. Giles Forman, opened the shop last Saturday at 464 Columbus Avenue, near 82d Street.

title: FRAUD IS ADMITTED ON U.S. BOOK ORDERS
description: A private telephone canvassing company has discovered that some of its employees defrauded the Government by inflating the number of requests for a book that has become an important part of the Reagan Administration's campaign against drug abuse in the schools, according to executives of the company.

title: GERMAN FIRM COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF DOUBLEDAY
description: Bertelsmann A. G., the large West German publishing company, announced yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Doubleday, for which it agreed last September to pay more than $475 million.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly listed the yacht club affiliation of the 12-Meter USA. The boat is sponsored by the St. Francis Yacht Club.

title: Black City Manager for Dallas
description: The Dallas City Council has named its first black City Manager, selecting for the city's top post Richard Knight Jr., who had been the acting City Manager.

title: Allied-Signal's Henley Stake
description: Allied-Signal Inc. confirmed yesterday that it was continuing to negotiate its plan, announced earlier this year, to sell its 15 percent interest in the Henley Group. Allied-Signal holds 19.6 million shares of Henley preferred stock, which is convertible to an equal number of common shares.

title: TRANSWORLD SELLING HILTON UNIT
description: The Transworld Corporation said yesterday that a ''major European company'' had bought its Hilton International hotel chain for $970 million in cash.

title: DRUG TESTS FOR 20 BOWL TEAMS
description: About 725 football players from 20 universities scheduled to play in postseason bowl games - including the five major bowls - have been tested for drugs in recent weeks, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which conducted the tests.

title: Ailing Archbishop of Seattle Is to Retain Pastoral Powers
description: Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle, who underwent surgery Tuesday to remove a cancerous prostate gland, will retain all his pastoral power in a convalescence that could last three months, church officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: MUSIC: THOMAS, HORNE AND ST. LUKE'S GROUP
description: MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS'S concert with the Orchestra of St. Luke's Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall was naturally of interest as the first orchestral program in the refubished hall that was free from the noise and glare of Monday's television lighting. From a strictly musical standpoint, the evening had its virtues without satisfying fully.

title: Talks Held in Gooden Case
description: Four days after a fight between Tampa police officers and Dwight Gooden and some of his friends, an effort has begun to end the exchange of recrimination and blame and bring the affair to an end.

title: The Dishwasher League
description: Robert D. Wright, the executive whom General Electric installed as president of its newly acquired National Broadcasting Company, may be learning that the broadcasting business is somewhat different from marketing dishwashers.

title: Driver Charged in Bus Crash
description: The driver of a bus that plunged into a river and killed 21 elderly people May 30 was charged Tuesday with 21 counts of felony vehicular manslaughter. The driver, Ernst August Klimeck, was also charged with 21 misdemeanor manslaughter counts. He was ordered to appear in Mono County Justice Court in Mammoth Lakes on Jan. 26, the District Attorney said.

title: The Other Members: 14 Representatives Selected to Serve on the Iran Panel
description: DEMOCRATS

title: ROCK: TIMBUK 3 PERFORMS
description: ''THE FUTURE'S SO BRIGHT, I GOTTA WEAR SHADES,'' a song about an aspiring nuclear scientist, has become an unlikely hit for Timbuk 3. The group - two lanky singer-guitarists, Pat and Barbara MacDonald, and a squat rhythm machine -brought that song and other bleakly sardonic material to the Bottom Line on Monday.

title: HASENFUS IS FREED BY NICARAGUANS AND HEADS HOME
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American air cargo handler captured when his arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua in October, was pardoned and freed today.

title: 8 IN GANG LINKED TO TAIWAN GET PRISON SENTENCES
description: Eight men convicted of Federal crimes involving an international Chinese gang, the United Bamboo, received prison sentences yesterday ranging from 10 to 25 years.

title: It's Last Call At Riverfront
description: Last Sunday was a dismal one for followers of the Cincinnati Bengals, who were routed at home by archrival Cleveland in an important divisional game. For a few fans who had begun the day in particularly high spirits, though, the outcome was even worse. After issuing warnings before three prior games, Cincinnati police officers wrote up $50 citations against eight people caught drinking in tailgate parties near Riverfront Stadium.

title: PRETORIA SAYS IT SEIZED SMUGGLED AMMUNITION
description: The South African authorities, who assert they are the target of a revolutionary onslaught, said today that they had intercepted three men trying to smuggle thousands of rounds of Soviet-made ammunition into the country from neighboring Swaziland.

title: Minority Business Still Leaping the Highest Hurdles
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $199,352,000 and $227,457,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $14,429,000 for the quarter and $26,650,000 for the 6 months. The company said results have been restated to reflect the discontinuation of Zapmail services.

title: ENVOY DENIES A SWISS REPORT
description: The United States Ambassador to Switzerland, Faith Ryan Whittlesey, took the unusual step today of publicly denying a Swiss newspaper report that she had any connection to the diversion of Iran arms payments to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: WARLORDS ARE HERE; A BLACK-SHEEP BROTHER IS NOT
description: As winter comes to this lovely old city, still perhaps the most graceful of Arab capitals, there is a mood of uncertainty.

title: VIETNAM WAR DESERTER HELD IN AUSTRALIA
description: Australian military policemen have arrested a United States marine who deserted 17 years ago during the Vietnam War and went into hiding in Australia, an American Embassy spokesman said today.

title: JERSEY MAN CHARGED IN 5 MURDERS LINKED WITH FAKE BUSINESS DEALS
description: A 51-year-old man was charged today with murdering five people over two years, three of them drug and pornography dealers he set up and killed for the cash they carried.

title: WHITE HOUSE BUDGET MOVE MIRED IN PREOCCUPATION WITH IRAN CRISIS
description: Work by the White House on one of President Reagan's major policy proposals, overhauling the Federal budgeting process, has stopped because of preoccupation over the arms sales to Iran, Administration officials said today.

title: THE COST OF KEEPING THE HOME FIRES BLAZING
description: IT is not as efficient as central heating, but if your city apartment has a working fireplace a log fire is just the ticket these chilly days.

title: F.C.C. Plan On A.T.&T.
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed a streamlining of its regulation of several lines of services offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the regional Bell Telephone companies.

title: JOHN D. deBUTTS, EX-CHAIRMAN OF A.T.&T., IS DEAD
description: John D. deButts, former chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and one of the nation's leading industrialists in the 70's, died of heart failure yesterday. He was 71 years old and had spent his final days in the Winchester Medical Center near his family farm in Upperville, Va.

title: New Publisher Named At Family Circle
description: Charles H. Townsend, 42 years old, is joining The New York Times Magazine Group as senior vice president and publisher of Family Circle magazine, the group's largest publication. He succeeds Thom Redd, 62, the publisher since 1982, who has been with Family Circle for 35 years. Mr. Redd will be senior vice president/advertising of the group.

title: Settlement Is Reached Over Drunken Driving
description: A Louisville distiller, one of its executives and a private club agreed today to pay a ''substantial'' amount to the family of a Louisville man killed last summer in a traffic accident with the executive, who was said to be intoxicated after a company party, an attorney for the victim's family said today.

title: Plenty of Paper
description: ''Now we know why they were so goosey about leaks,'' says a lawman, speaking of the past year's hypersensitivity about disclosure at the C.I.A. and White House. ''There's plenty of paper on this.''

title: 3 MORE DIE IN PAKISTAN VIOLENCE
description: Three more people were reported killed in scattered sectarian clashes as army and police forces eased their curfew slightly but continued to patrol riot-torn sections of this port city.

title: IRAN ASKS OUSTER OF IRAQ FROM OPEC OVER SNAG
description: The pressure on Iraq to join in an OPEC agreement to cut oil production intensified today as Iran called for Iraq to be suspended from the 13-nation group.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOTHER AND CHILD REVISITED Numerous generations of artists have drawn inspiration from the story of Mary and Jesus, although the mother-and-child theme gets particular attention at this time of year. It may be seen in an exhibition now on view at the Afro-American Institute, 833 First Avenue, at 47th Street, in the United Nations Plaza.

title: 60 Policemen Added To Anti-Peddler Unit
description: Starting this morning, 60 extra police officers are being assigned to enforce laws against illegal street peddling in midtown and lower Manhattan during the holiday season, police officials said.

title: Fannie Mae Is Offering A 2-Tier Mortgage Sale
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $500 million of stripped real estate mortgage investment conduit securities, divided into two issues, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The securities are backed by a pool of 8 1/2 percent fixed-rate mortgages insured or guaranteed by the Government.

title: Cup Officials to Test Hulls
description: Officials here announced today that they planned to test the thickness and relative weight of hulls during routine testing of America's Cup challengers in the next week.

title: House Appoints 15 to Panel on Iran
description: House leaders appointed 15 legislators today to serve on a special committee to investigate the Iran arms deal, and the top Republican immediately rejected suggestions from the White House that key witnesses be granted immunity in order to compel their testimony.

title: Victim in a Noted Rape Case Dies in Automobile Accident
description: A woman who accused six men of raping her in Big Dan's Tavern in New Bedford, Mass., was killed in an automobile accident, the state police reported today. Four of the men were convicted in the rape case and two were acquitted.

title: REAGAN'S HEALTH PROBLEMS
description: 1967: An operation, described as a transurethral prostatectomy, was performed to correct an anatomical abnormality of the neck portion of Mr. Reagan's urinary bladder and to remove about 30 ''seedlike prostatic stones.''

title: VOLUME DROPS
description: Stock prices dropped sharply and trading volume contracted yesterday as fainthearted investors held back with only two days to go before the ''triple witching hour.''

title: Veteran Yale Official to Head Philadelphia Private School
description: Yale University Secretary John A. Wilkinson has resigned to become headmaster of the Germantown Friends School, a private elementary and secondary school in Philadelphia, university officials announced today.

title: Topics: Presidential Papers; Iran, by the Book
description: The Iran arms deal first came to light in a Lebanese magazine on Nov. 3. A week later, the White House issued the following official statement of policy toward Iran, the last such general policy statement issued:

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Strategies in the Quest For a Medallion Taxi
description: Nearly every New Yorker has a strategy for finding a medallion cab, and almost every driver a favorite way of finding passengers. According to taxi industry officials and riders, these are some of the general ground rules:

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on July 7, 1986.

title: CUOMO AND ANDERSON DISAGREE OVER ETHICS PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo and the Republican leader of the State Senate quarrelled yesterday over whether a proposed commission to study government ethics and corruption should operate statewide or focus solely on New York City.

title: Ticket Abuse Is Cited
description: The player-ticket policy adopted by National Collegiate Athletic Association members two years ago at the urging of the troubled Southwest Conference is being ignored by many schools.

title: PENSION FUNDS IRKED AT G.M.
description: In a session with managers of major pension funds, top executives of the General Motors Corporation and H. Ross Perot disagreed today about circumstances surrounding the $700 million buyout of Mr. Perot's G.M. stock and his ouster from the G.M. board.

title: 'COSMIC STRINGS' IN DAWN OF GALAXIES EXPLORED
description: The galaxies that compose the universe may have been created on the fringes of gigantic bubbles expanding from the explosions of what ''cosmic strings,'' a conference on astrophysics was told today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, is offering $380 million of mortgage cash-flow obligations through underwiters led by Salomon Bothers.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TO STUDY WAYS TO SAVE THE OZONE
description: United States and Soviet officials agreed today to widen cooperation on environmental issues, including a joint effort to halt depletion of atmospheric ozone.

title: Destination Capitol Hill
description: Frank A. Sieverts, a veteran of 24 years with the State Department, is moving to Capitol Hill. Effective Jan. 1, he will become spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee under the chairmanship of Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island. Mr. Sieverts is currently special assistant for public afffairs of the Bureau for Refugee Programs.

title: Trade Worry At O.E.C.D.
description: A further drop in the dollar's value and faster economic growth in Europe and Japan will be needed to cure the enormous payments deficit of the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: Petroleum Prices Climb On Hope of OPEC Pact
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products reversed a two-day slump yesterday in frantic trading on world oil markets, as traders counted on OPEC to reduce oil output.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT SEEKS A WAIVER ON EMERGENCY ZONE
description: The operators of the Seabrook nuclear power reactor in southern New Hampshire announced today that they would ask the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to waive the Federal requirement for a 10-mile emergency evacuation zone around nuclear stations and allow them a zone only a mile in radius.

title: SOVIET SEEKS TO JOIN WITH WEST AGAINST TERRORISM
description: The Soviet Union has begun telling some Western European governments that it is prepared to join forces in combating terrorism, according to highly placed West German officials.

title: Write-Offs Hurt Stocks; Dow Off 5.49
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as write-offs by several of the biggest corporations put additional pressure on a market that was already worried about today's ''triple witching hour.''

title: EX-N.S.C. OFFICIAL DENIES IRAN ROLE
description: A former National Security Council official, linked in an earlier report to the Iran arms affair, has denied that he was involved in or had knowledge of either Iran's purchase of American arms or the illegal dispatch of military equipment to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Economic Scene; Service-Sector Wage Issues
description: FOR most of this century, the semiskilled factory worker was the emblem of American labor. The union was his strength, and he came into his salad days in the postwar years, earning for a while a middle-class wage in an almost-tenured job on the assembly line.

title: Billy Harper Performs
description: The tenor saxophonist Billy Harper will lead a quintet tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street (505-5660).

title: Hospital Report on Casey
description: Following is the text of a statement released today by Georgetown University Hospital about William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence:

title: Closing Delayed a Day On Bennett's Building
description: Yesterday's planned closing on the sale of the building at 890 Broadway, at 19th Street, to two dance companies was postponed one day because an inspection document was missing, according to Cora Cahan, executive director of the Feld Ballet, which is purchasing the building with the American Ballet Theater.

title: Greetings
description: Some Washington organizations find it almost impossible to make a mailing without also making a statement. The Cato Institute, a research group of libertarian tendencies, has inscribed its holiday card: ''Wishing You Peace and Free Enterprise.''

title: Coopervision To Sell Unit
description: Coopervision Inc., an eye care company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said today that it had agreed to sell its ophthalmic pharmaceutical products business to Johnson & Johnson for about $260 million. The unit had net sales of about $55 million in the fiscal year 1986.

title: TEXAS MURDERER IS EXECUTED AFTER TOP COURT REJECTS PLEA
description: Richard Andrade, who raped a woman and stabbed her to death, was executed today after the Supreme Court rejected his hand-printed appeal.

title: 2D CONVICTION AS '62 KILLER ENDS A LONG FIGHT
description: Booker T. Hillery Jr., a farm laborer who was given a second chance at freedom by the United States Supreme Court, was convicted today of a 1962 murder.

title: DOMINGO CANCELS LONDON CONCERT
description: Placido Domingo pulled out of a concert tonight at Wembly Stadium, his press agent said today, giving less than 24 hours' notice to the arena and thousands of ticket holders.

title: Blues' Rookie Hurt
description: Jocelyn Lemieux, the rookie wing for St. Louis Blues who was the Blues' top draft choice this year, will be sidelined for up to six weeks because of a tendon he cut in his small left finger in an accident during the team's Christmas skating party.

title: Diner's Journal
description: CHOUCROUTE ALSACIENNE, that gutsy gastronomic antifreeze from northeastern France, has been on my 10 most-wanted list for some time now. Following a tip-off from a self-appointed expert on this homey combination of smoked sausages, pork chops, sauerkraut and potatoes, I stopped by Voulez-Vous, a smart and hospitable French restaurant on First Avenue at 76th Street. Sure enough, the choucroute is a delight, combining all of the above ingredients - in quantities to sate a ravenous mountain climber - plus a section of succulent smoked chicken and a few juniper berries in the sauerkraut to lend a nice sharp aftertaste ($14.50). Try it with a glass of crisp Sancerre ($16 a bottle, from Fournier).

title: No Challenge
description: Garden State Park has canceled its $2 Million Challenge and reduced the Jersey Derby purse by $500,000 for its 1987 thoroughbred meeting in a move to help the financially ailing track.

title: U.S. IS DEBATING ROLE OF 3 NEW SOVIET RADARS
description: Reagan Administration officials are divided over the significance of three new radars under construction on the western periphery of the Soviet Union.

title: ANTIQUES BROWSERS FIND INTIMATE SHOPS IN UPTOWN PLACES
description: ANTIQUES collectors this holiday season are shopping for American and European period furnishings in new places that are upstairs, in town-house settings and hidden away in converted mansions. This is because antiques dealers are on the march again - moving northward and into more discreet spaces, where their presence is acknowledged by little more than a sign on the door.

title: JETS' SEASON RESTS ON O'BRIEN'S ARM
description: Although nothing much ever happens in pro football between weekends, we keyboard warriors must spend our midweek labors trying to sift through the ''test of character'' blather so indigenous to this sport.

title: E.R.A.? They're A-O.K.
description: But who are the leaders in cumulative earned run average for the 80's? The top 10 (minimum of 1,100 innings pitched):

title: Times Co. Adds Director
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., president of the American Express Company, became a member of the board of directors of The New York Times Company yesterday, according to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman. The appointment increased the membership of the board to 13.

title: Faeroese Invent Incident About Whale Activists
description: To the Editor:

title: DERELICT S.I. HOSPITAL IS NOW A 'CASTLE' CONDOMINIUM
description: There was no joy in the New Brighton section of Staten Island seven years ago when the Staten Island Hospital pulled up stakes and moved to a new building miles away. The fear of neighboring homeowners was that the hospital's departure would leave a derelict property in their midst.

title: GAF Raising Stake In Borg-Warner
description: The GAF Corporation, noting that the waiting period under Federal antitrust laws had expired, said it would raise its stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation to 25 percent, from its current holdings of 9.9 percent.

title: The Juilliard Symphony
description: Jorge Mester will conduct the Juilliard Symphony in works by Dvorak, Shostakovich and Saint-Saens tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. Admission is free. Information: 799-5000.

title: Toll in Berlin Air Crash Is 71
description: The death toll in the crash of a Soviet airliner Friday in East Berlin, which carried 82 people, rose to 71 with the death of a 17-year-old East German girl, the state-run East German news agency A.D.N. reported today. An East German Government inquiry Tuesday blamed the pilot, who it said had violated landing rules, for the crash. The entire nine-member Soviet crew died in the crash.

title: OPEC PACT ON OUTPUT LIKELY TO EXEMPT IRAQ
description: OPEC ministers inched closer today to an agreement to curb oil production, but it appeared that any accord would exempt Iraq.

title: Photos of hired hosts aboard ship; 'HOSTS' A WELCOME ADDITION ABOARD SHIP
description: Are you a sophisticated single man over 50? Do you do a nifty tango or fox trot and have a way with women? Well, you might have a chance to become part of a new growth area in the travel industry.

title: Henri Bendel Gets New Chief
description: Mark Shulman's fast rise in the retail business shows no signs of slowing down.

title: RULING BACKS A BOOKSTORE FOR ADULTS
description: Holding that the State Constitution provides broader protection for freedom of expression than the United States Constitution, the New York Court of Appeals ruled unanimously yesterday that an adult bookstore could not be ordered closed because homosexual and heterosexual sex acts had been committed by customers in the store.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). The annual New York appearances by the singing and songwriting sisters from Canada are spontaneous folk musicales that cover a lot of territory. Life's joys, frustrations and contradictions are discussed in songs that run from the plaintive (Anna McGarrigle's ''Heart Like a Wheel'') to the whimsical (Kate's ''Move Over Moon'') to the profound (Anna's ''Sun, Son''). The sisters' original hymns, and inspired taste in cover versions (Bob Seger's ''You'll Accompany Me''), and traditional French songs help give their concerts an aura of timelessness. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $10. Fats Domino, the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664). The 57-year-old rock-and-roll pioneer and New Orleans musical giant brings his classics ''Blueberry Hill,'' ''Ain't That a Shame,'' ''Blue Monday,'' ''I'm Walking'' and others to the relative intimacy of the Lone Star Cafe. The chemistry of the club's friendly atmosphere and Fats Domino's rollicking good-humored music ought to stir up enough warmth to heat up the chilliest December evening. Shows are at 9:30 and midnight tonight. Tickets are $25.

title: Doctor Gets 20 Years For Killing His Wife
description: A doctor was given the maximum sentence yesterday of 20 years in prison for the 1985 slaying of his wife.

title: ART: IN POLITICAL TONE, WORKS BY HANS HAACKE
description: IN today's art world, Hans Haacke may be not only inevitable but also indispensable.

title: Tabou Combo
description: The Haitian band Tabou Combo will appear tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M. and 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with dinner, $15 without.

title: In a Changing Job Market, Reasons for Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Proposes Laws For Financial Changes
description: The Canadian Government today proposed laws expected to foster a broad restructuring of the country's financial institutions.

title: Jury Begins Its Deliberations In Case of Slashing of Model
description: The jury in the trial of a Manhattan makeup artist accused in the razor slashing of a model last summer began its deliberations last night at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, but failed to reach a verdict.

title: Rally Reversal
description: The executive committee of the International Auto Sport Federation (FISA) has voided the results of the San Remo Rally and declared Juha Kankkunen of Finland the world rally driving champion.

title: Volcano Erupts Again On Island Near Tokyo
description: Mount Mihara shot flames and hot rocks into the sky in a new eruption today, just as more evacuees from a volcanic explosion last month were preparing to return home for the holidays.

title: BRITAIN TO GET AWACS FROM U.S., REJECTING ITS OWN AIRCRAFT BID
