description: The Thatcher Government ended its long and controversial search for an airborne early-warning defense system today by rejecting Britain's own Nimrod aircraft and announcing a billion-dollar decision to purchase Boeings from the United States.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT SAYS POINDEXTER ASKED MEESE TO DELAY CONTRA INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department asserted today that a call from Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, prompted Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to seek a brief delay of a Federal investigation of private schemes to aid Nicaraguan rebels.

title: HEAD OF F.T.C. SAYS TAXI LIMITS PROMOTE MUNICIPAL CORRUPTION
description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission has warned Mayor Koch that by restricting taxi medallions, the city is effectively issuing ''an engraved invitation to corruption.''

title: THE CANADIAN LINK: A NEW ELEMENT
description: A business associate of two Canadians who helped finance secret United States arms shipments to Iran has been identified here as a major figure in the World Anti-Communist League, which is believed to have raised at least $10 million to aid Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Mutual Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 377 money market mutual funds increased $670.7 million, to $235.54 billion, for the week ending Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: U.S. SAYS 'STAR WARS' CAN'T BE FOILED
description: The Pentagon, responding to the Russians' description of how they might attack a space-based missile defense system, said today that ''there are a variety of ways'' in which the system can retain its effectiveness.

title: VALUABLE ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES REPORTED THREATENED
description: Wetlands and peat bogs that often contain splendidly preserved ancient human remains and other artifacts are reported to be endangered worldwide.

title: FRENCH NEWS CHIEF RESIGNS IN DISPUTE
description: The head of Agence France-Presse resigned today after an eight-day strike by journalists that brought the agency virtually to a halt.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''NO MERCY,'' which opens today (review on page C22), is a sharp turn in the road for its director, Richard Pearce. His previous movies include ''Country,'' about the plight of American farm families; ''Heartland,'' an American pioneer story told from a woman's point of view, and ''Threshold,'' which dealt with the ethics of unauthorized heart-transplant surgery. ''No Mercy,'' starring Richard Gere and Kim Basinger, is a film noir about a killer, a passionate love affair and the Louisiana bayous. It is what Mr. Pearce calls a ''Saturday-night movie - where people go out and have a couple of beers and enjoy themselves.''

title: 'STAR WARS' CHIEF PROMOTED
description: President Reagan today promoted Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson of the Air Force, head of the ''Star Wars'' missile-defense program since 1984, to the rank of full general. Congress approved legislation this year that increased the number of limited four-star commands in the Air-Force so that General Abrahamson could be promoted.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: David Murray Octet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). The inspiring trombonist Craig Harris and the solidly emphatic bassist Wilbur Morris are the only remaining members of earlier David Murray Octets. But the new players should take care of business nicely. Mr. Murray's writing for the Octet's five horns is a balm and a tonic in any case. And Mr. Murray is the freshest, most formidable young tenor saxophonist around. Shows are around 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight through Sunday, with a $12 cover charge and $6 minimum.

title: AFTER A SLAYING, BOGOTA MOVES AGAINST DRUGS
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas blamed narcotics traffickers today for the killing of a prominent newspaper editor and issued decrees making it easier for the military to crack down on traffickers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls 97, Pacers 88: Michael Jordan scored 14 of his 41 points in the fourth quarter last night to lead Chicago to a victory in Indianapolis. Indiana led, 70-63, after three quarters and expanded the advantage to 76-67 in the final period. The Bulls outscored Indiana, 10-0, to take a 77-76 lead with 5 minutes 16 seconds to play. Steve Colter capped the run with two free throws. Chicago pulled steadily away after that. (UPI) Bucks 104, Hawks 95: Jack Sikma scored 11 of his 18 points in the fourth quarter and made a 3-point play that gave Milwaukee the lead as the Bucks won their third straight, beating the Hawks in Milwaukee. The victory moved the second-place Bucks a game and a half behind the Hawks in the Central Division. Terry Cummings led Milwaukee with 32 points. Atlanta got 22 points from Glenn Rivers. Atlanta scored the first 5 points of the fourth quarter, cutting Milwaukee's lead to 75-72. The Bucks rebuilt their edge to 7 points, but the Hawks got even at 95-95 with 1:32 remaining on Wayne Rollins's jump shot. Sikma's layup and free throw following a foul by Rivers, and Pierce's free throw made it 99-95. Then a turnover by Dominique Wilkins with 51 seconds left was followed by a basket by Cummings. (AP)

title: EXCERPTS ON PANEL'S REPORT: 'FULLEST POSSIBLE DISCLOSURE
description: Following are excerpts from the final report of the State-City Commission on Integrity in Government issued yesterday:

title: Questions And Some Answers
description: Should Donald Regan be dismissed as White House chief of staff?

title: 5TH AVE. STORES ATTACK KOCH ON PEDDLERS
description: Some of the most powerful merchants on Fifth Avenue fired a barrage of complaints at Mayor Koch yesterday over the proliferation of illegal sidewalk peddlers outside their elegant shops at the height of the holiday season.

title: A.T.& T. WILL CUT 27,400 JOBS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 27,400 jobs and take a $3.2 billion charge against earnings, in a program to make itself more competitive in its key businesses.

title: FLYERS CHASE SMITH AND ROUT ISLANDERS
description: It was such a bad night that the Islanders had two losing goalies instead of just one.

title: Giants Ready for Packer Blitz
description: The Giants have a 13-2 record and the Green Bay Packers are 4-11. The Giants have won eight straight games and have clinched their division title. The Packers started the season by losing their first six games, and things have been so bad that they have not won a game in Green Bay.

title: MOSCOW, REBUFFED BY U.S., IS PLANNING TO RENEW A-TESTS
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would end its halt of nuclear testing as soon as the United States conducts its first test in 1987.

title: The Image Group
description: The Image Group at Wells, Rich, Greene, which is working on several assignments from Warnaco, has got an additional assignment.

title: Berry Sent to Spurs
description: The Portland Trail Blazers traded Walter Berry, last season's college basketball Player of the Year, to the San Antonio Spurs yesterday for another rookie, Kevin Duckworth, a reserve center.

title: Officers Charged in Torture
description: Two suburban police officers were charged today with torturing a 17-year-old suspect with a stun gun, and the district attorney said the entire Huntington Park department was under investigation. ''The Huntington Park Police Department has a record that is frankly an embarrassment to all of law enforcement,'' District Attorney Ira Reiner said at a news conference. The officers, William Lustig Jr., 31, and Robert Rodriguez, 25, were charged with torturing the youth, suspected of theft, to obtain a confession.

title: Small Rise Seen in Business Outlays
description: Faced with a sluggish economy and the loss of investment tax incentives, businesses plan to increase capital spending by just two-tenths of 1 percent percent next year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PLANE CRASHES NEAR HOUSTON
description: A private plane crashed north of Houston today, killing the pilot, slicing power lines and leaving about 30,000 customers without electricity for two and a half hours. The identity of the pilot and the cause of the crash were not immediately known.

title: No Headline
description: In Midtown, Drivers Beware New York City expects another especially large swarm of pedestrians and motorists on the streets of midtown Manhattan today, and warns drivers to try to keep vehicles out of the area between Herald Square and Central Park. The volume of traffic in Manhattan is expected to be 100,000 higher than normal, with traffic especially heavy at the inbound Lincoln Tunnel from 7 to 9 P.M.

title: INWOOD HAS A SOFT SPOT FOR A ROCK CITY IS SELLING
description: New York City has decided to sell a rock. A rock nearly three stories high.

title: GLITTERY BOWS, HEAD TO TOE
description: Bows are certainly appropriate at the holiday season, and diamond and rhinestone bows may be the most appropriate of all.

title: Just Say No to the U.S. War Against Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Samuel J. Chisholm joining Mingo-Jones Advertising as executive vice president-general manager.

title: FILM: THE VIETNAM WAR IN STONE'S 'PLATOON'
description: NOTHING that Oliver Stone has done before - including ''Midnight Express,'' for which he wrote the screenplay, and ''Salvador,'' which he wrote and directed - is preparation for the singular achievement of his latest film, ''Platoon,'' which is possibly the best work of any kind about the Vietnam War since Michael Herr's vigorous and hallucinatory book ''Dispatches.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EVEN NETS CAN BEAT KNICKS
description: For a time, the Nets held the dubious honor of having the worst record in the National Basketball Association.

title: CUBAN EXILES' FUND FOR NORTH
description: Complaining that foes of Communism suffer disadvantages under the democratic system, a group of Cuban-Americans today launched a defense fund for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. ''He is a hero,'' said Carlos Perez, an importer who heads Concerned Citizens for Democracy, a mostly Cuban group.

title: Naming of Walsh as Prosecutor Seen by Monday
description: The appointment of Lawrence E. Walsh as the special prosecutor in the Iran arms investigation is expected to be announced Friday or Monday, people knowledgeable about the search said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SENATOR TELLS AGENCY TO EXAMINE ROLE OF NASA CHIEF ON BOOSTERS
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. yesterday made public his order for a Congressional investigation into whether Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the space agency, violated conflict-of-interest rules in awarding the contract for shuttle rockets that proved flawed and led to the Challenger disaster.

title: THE FRICK GETS NEW DIRECTOR
description: Charles Ryskamp, director of the Pierpont Morgan Library for 17 years, will be the new director of the Frick Collection, beginning next June. He replaces Everett Fahy, the Frick's director since 1973, who will move to the Metropolitan Museum as chairman of its European paintings department.

title: Reagan Is Given Honor By Head of Yeshiva U.
description: President Reagan received an honorary degree from Yeshiva University today.

title: U.S. SENDING CHAD $15 MILLION IN ARMS
description: President Reagan has ordered emergency shipments of up to $15 million in military equipment to help the Chadian Army repel attacks by Libyan troops, the State Department announced today.

title: FRENCH BANK CHIEF TO HEAD THE I.M.F.
description: Michel Camdessus, the French Government's top banker, was named managing director of the International Monetary Fund today, ending an uncommon spectacle of open campaigning by two nations for a position of power over the world economy.

title: NORTH 'ABANDONED BY FORMER FRIENDS'
description: As he left home today shortly after 6 A.M., Col. Oliver L. North encountered one of the camera crews that have followed his every public move since the Iran crisis first became known.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Sent Bruce Tanner, pitcher, to Oakland as completion of a trade in which Chicago received Donnie Hill, infielder.

title: 30,000 Marchers Call for End To Indian Sectarian Violence
description: More than 30,000 people marched today through the old city here demanding the separation of church and state and for an end to violence spawned by religious differences.

title: Ritz Double-Bill
description: Jason and the Scorchers, the Nashville rock band, will headline a double bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), with the Georgia Satellites opening at 11. Tickets are $13.50.

title: Levin Diary Ordered To Be Given to Court
description: A judge yesterday ordered the family of Jennifer Dawn Levin to give her diary to the court to determine whether it may be used by lawyers defending the man accused of murdering her in Central Park, Robert E. Chambers Jr. After an emotional request by the attorney for Miss Levin's family, however, the judge agreed to allow the diary to be held in a bank safe deposit box pending an appeal.

title: MORRIS MAKES HIS OFFERS AND STEINBRENNER LISTENS
description: George Steinbrenner received the Jack Morris offer he ''could not refuse'' today - a one-year contract with an arbitrator to determine the salary - and called it novel and innovative. However, he stopped short of accepting it, saying he would make a decision by noon Friday.

title: GASTINEAU BLAMES WEIGHT FOR WOES
description: Mark Gastineau made an unusual admission yesterday - he feels vulnerable.

title: Hirschfeld Bid to Bar Lundine Is Denied
description: A move by the developer Abraham Hirschfeld to halt the Jan. 1 inauguration of Representative Stan Lundine as the state's lieutenant governor was denied yesterday by a Federal judge.

title: 2 U.S. Aides Stick to Contradictions in Iran Testimony
description: The White House chief of staff and a former national security adviser today stood by their contradictory accounts of when President Reagan approved Israel's sale of American arms to Iran in 1985.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ONE of two versions of a letter written by Albert Einstein on Aug. 2, 1939, to President Franklin D. Roosevelt - the letter that sparked the American effort to build the atomic bomb - will be auctioned today at Christie's. The signed, 25-line typewritten document, urging Roosevelt to coordinate research on nuclear energy, is 20 lines shorter than the one hand-delivered to the White House on Oct. 11, 1939. The longer version has been in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park, N.Y., since 1945.

title: American Can Deal
description: The American Can Company, a retailer, packaging and financial services concern, said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Looart Press Inc., based in Colorado Springs, for about $114 million.

title: DISSIDENT SEES SOVIET LETTING WIFE LEAVE FOR CANCER CARE
description: The Soviet Union was reported today to have decided to allow the wife of a dissident to leave the country for experimental cancer treatment in New York.

title: G.O.P. BLOCKS TAX RISE FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: Only a day after Republican leaders reacted favorably to a proposed increase in motor-vehicle taxes, rank-and-file Republican senators rejected it tonight, throwing into doubt whether a plan will be in place by the end of the year to rebuild New York City's mass transit system and freeze its fares for three years.

title: PUBLIC SUPPORT SAID TO CHEER GOODEN
description: He still has some soreness from his encounter with the police in Tampa, Fla., Saturday night, but Dwight Gooden's spirits were reported to have been buoyed yesterday by an outpouring of public support and the start of Federal inquiries into his charges of police brutality.

title: Hasenfus, Back in U.S., Ready to Talk
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American cargo handler pardoned by Nicaragua for helping to fly arms to the contras, arrived here today and said he was prepared to tell United States investigators about his role in the rebels' supply network.

title: BROADWAY
description: FIRST of all, Christopher Hart was born the year it opened. That was 1948. Then, last year, he saw it at the Old Vic in London and, he said, ''here was the quintessential American backstage story, and the English were having a ball, howling with laughter even though they didn't recognize a lot of the references.'' Not the least of the whole thing was the fact that Mr. Hart's father, Moss Hart, wrote ''Light Up the Sky,'' and that it hadn't been done on a major stage in New York since its original production.

title: Minstar to Sell Bekins to Officials
description: Minstar Inc., a company controlled by the corporate raider Irwin Jacobs, said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Bekins Company unit to the operation's management for an undisclosed amount.

title: Martin Sokol Is Dead at 56; Director of Bel Canto Opera
description: Martin L. Sokol, an authority on opera and recordings and the general director of the Bel Canto Opera, died at Roosevelt Hospital Thursday morning of a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Arkansas Democrat Named
description: Reppresentative Beryl F. Anthony, Democrat of Arkansas, was nominated today to be chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which raises money for the party's House candidates. Mr. Anthony, who was first elected to the House in 1978, was selected for the campaign post by Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House Speaker-designate, and would succeed Representative Tony Coehlo, who was chosen earlier this month as the House Democratic whip.

title: SHAMROCK REJECTS BID BY PICKENS
description: The board of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said this morning that it had unanimously rejected a $2.03 billion takeover bid by T. Boone Pickens and Mesa Limited Partnership. By the afternoon, Mesa had withdrawn its all-securities exchange offer, originally announced Dec. 3.

title: Contact: Anonymous
description: The practice of quoting anonymous sources in investigative news articles has become so widely accepted that the Saudi Arabian Embassy has reduced it to announcement form. This week, the embassy issued a five-paragraph press release about ''the U.S.-Iranian arms deal'' that was entirely attributed to ''an information source.''

title: TEAM AND INDIVIDUAL MARKS UP FOR GRABS THIS WEEKEND
description: Consistency may be the most desired but least achieved aspect of play in football.

title: Learning the Art Of Correct Behavior
description: THE Christmas party is always memorable for first-year students in the Barclay Classes. ''This is their first experience with refreshments,'' said Lois Thomson, the co-director. The fourth-grade girls, who had just finished a cha-cha, removed their white gloves and waited for the boys to bring them a Coke and two cookies.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL HOUSTON ROCKETS VS. TRAIL BLAZERS, at Portland, 10:30 P.M. (TV -WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAMS VS. 49ERS, at San Francisco, 8 P.M. (TV - Cahnnel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) ARKANSAS STATE VS.

title: Penn Central Gain Seen
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it expected a fourth-quarter pretax gain of $470 million and after-tax income of $270 million from the sale of its propane distribution and petroleum pipeline businesses. The net cash proceeds of the sales will be about $840 million. Penn Central also said its quarter results would include a charge of about $390 million on a pretax basis - and $220 million after taxes - from the write-down of electronics, drilling-rig manufacturing and other energy businesses.

title: DREW BARRYMORE STARS IN 'BABES IN TOYLAND'
description: CLIVE DONNER, the British director, has come up with one television ''classic'' in the production of ''A Christmas Carol,'' starring George C. Scott as Scrooge. He is evidently trying for a second with ''Babes in Toyland,'' the new three-hour movie having its debut on NBC tonight at 8. Made in West Germany as a co-production of the Finnegan/Pinchuk Company, Orion Television and Bavaria Atelier G.m.b.H., this is still another reworking of the operetta by Victor Herbert and Glen MacDonough.

title: THE FIFTH AMENDMENT VS. THE CHAIN OF COMMAND
description: The decision by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights to remain silent has spurred debate on whether President Reagan can legally force them to abandon those rights - or should at least try to persuade them to do so.

title: Deregulation Proving a Costly Thrill
description: The sharp cost cutting announced today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company shows anew that deregulation is not always kind to business, regulatory and industry analysts said today.

title: Italian Hosiery Maker Chooses AC& R in U.S.
description: Flashlegs, an Italian maker of women's designer hosiery, has retained AC& R Advertising as its first American ad agency.

title: Herbert Dieckmann, An Expert on Diderot
description: Dr. Herbert Dieckmann, a scholar in French literature who in 1949 discovered long-lost manuscripts of Denis Diderot, the 18th-century French philosopher, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Yugoslav Satirist Sentenced
description: Rastko Zakic, 44 years old, a satirist and publisher, was sentenced today to 50 days in jail and fined $250 for publishing his works without proper authorization, a Belgrade court said.

title: ART: ALICE NEEL SHOW
description: ALICE NEEL, who died in October 1984 at the age of 84, was in her last years a well-known fixture of the New York art scene, an eccentric personality and an equally eccentric portraitist of undeniable power. Right now, there is an extensive survey of drawings (in pencil, ink and pastel) and watercolors dating from the late 20's to the mid-60's, plus a room of 30's paintings on view at the Robert Miller Gallery (41 East 57th Street). This show, which runs through Jan. 3, simultaneously reveals the foundation of Neel's achievement and expands her stature considerably, for it gives her a serious historical position prior to the onset of Abstract Expressionism.

title: WHERE CULTURAL LUMINARIES TAKE THEIR HOLIDAY GUESTS
description: AS if Christmas shopping, card-writing and party-going weren't enough to deal with, this is also the season to be inundated with friends and relatives from out of town, all bent on packing as much sightseeing and as many performances of ''The Nutcracker'' and the ''Messiah'' into one visit as the human body can endure.

title: Clearing the Air for Nonsmokers
description: What a difference a few years, and a few Surgeon General's reports, can make. Only yesterday the nonsmoker was perceived as odd man (or woman) out. Today, it's the smoker who sticks out. Only 30 percent of adults smoke now, and they may be feeling a bit hounded.

title: VIETNAMESE NAME NEW PARTY CHIEF
description: A 73-year-old political administrator who built his career as Hanoi's representative in the south before and after the takeover of Saigon was named head of the Communist Party of Vietnam today.

title: I.B.M. SETS $250 MILLION CHARGE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would take a charge of $250 million or more in the fourth quarter because of the early retirement of 10,000 workers.

title: FED DELAYS CONSIDERATION OF BANKAMERICA OFFER
description: The Federal Reserve Board will not begin considering First Interstate Bancorp's application to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation until Feb. 2 at the earliest, it was disclosed today.

title: Nettles a Free Agent
description: Graig Nettles, the third baseman, and Dave LaPoint, the left-handed pitcher, will not be offered contracts to return to the San Diego Padres in 1987.

title: Cecil Taylor and Unit
description: The pianist Cecil Taylor will lead his group, the Unit, tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: ETHICS COMMISSION URGES CUOMO TO FORM PANEL WITH MORE POWER
description: A state-city panel studying the New York City corruption scandal urged Governor Cuomo yesterday to establish a special commission with subpoena power to investigate corruption and ethics in the state and local governments. A top aide to Mr. Cuomo said the Governor would establish ''some version'' of such a commission.

title: CREW ON EXPERIMENTAL PLANE MARKS HALFWAY POINT OF TRIP
description: The experimental plane Voyager passed the halfway mark yesterday in an attempt circle the globe without refueling.

title: A New York Premiere
description: The cellist Sharon Robinson will play works by Marcello, Brahms, Bach and Victor Herbert and the New York premiere of Alan Shulman's ''Kol Nidre'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $11 to $15. Information: 996-1100.

title: ART: 2 SHOWS OF WORKS BY DUBUFFET
description: THE art world abounds in conspiracy theories, not all of which are paranoid. Yet some of the coincidences nourishing such theories make the scene look less like the court of the Borgias than an orchestra responding to a conductor whom the public cannot see. The maestro raises his baton and, lo! the galleries are showing paper works or Neo-Expressionism or Outsider Art or even, as in the case of a current coincidence, the Great Outsider himself, Jean Dubuffet (1901-1985).

title: Personal Spending Up by 1.1%
description: Americans' personal spending climbed 1.1 percent in November, reversing part of a record decline the month before, the Commerce Department said today. Personal income rose three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: PROPOSALS TO TRACK CITY CONTRACTS
description: A group of elected officials yesterday proposed developing a computer system to keep track of city contracts, and the Koch administration responded that it would begin its own version of such a system next week.

title: Tumor Is Removed From Casey's Brain
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, underwent surgery today at Georgetown University Hospital here for removal of a tumor from the left side of his brain, the hospital said.

title: OUTRAGES AND BRAVE DEEDS LIVE ON IN SOUTH TEXAS BALLADS
description: When Representative Henry B. Gonzalez struck a constituent at a local restaurant earlier this month, because the constituent called him a Communist, he did more than create a furor in the city's newspapers, which hew to old-style tabloid journalism.

title: INSIDE
description: Frenchman to Lead I.M.F. The head of France's central bank, Michel Camdessus, will direct the International Monetary Fund as it tries to alleviate the debt crisis.

title: He Gave Moscow No Peace
description: Anatoly T. Marchenko, who died in prison last week, was not an ordinary Soviet dissident.

title: Iowa Nuclear Waste on Rails Goes Astray Into Minnesota
description: A railroad car carrying nuclear wastes to a Washington State dump took a wrong turn to Minnesota, where utility officials found it parked in a small town west of Minneapolis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Who authorized it, how broadly knowledge of it extended within the United States Government and to what uses such funds were actually put, I cannot say, and I do not believe the committee has sufficient evidence to be able to draw firm conclusions.'' - Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. [ A16:4. ]

title: Chase Lowers All Card Rates
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the country's third-largest issuer of credit cards, said yesterday that it would reduce the annual percentage rate on all of its cards by as much as 3.3 points.

title: Plan for Beneficial
description: The Beneficial Corporation said it plans to make an announcement on its restructuring plans early today, after a four-hour board meeting.

title: 16 DISTRICTS IN 8 STATES TO TRY DEREGULATED SCHOOL PROGRAMS
description: Numerous educational changes aimed at reducing the role of Federal and state government in local schools will be put into effect on a trial basis in 16 school districts in eight states, William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, announced today.

title: Bank Mergers Keep An Executive Busy
description: Richard S. Strickler Jr. admits to being a bit weary at this point, having been involved in both big bank mergers announced this week - the Chemical New York Corporation's proposed acquisition of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. and the Republicbank Corporation's plan to take over the Interfirst Corporation.

title: Lou Donaldson
description: The alto saxophonist Lou Donaldson will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $5 minimum on Sunday.

title: New Interco Bid Accepted by Lane
description: The Lane Company has accepted a sweetened takeover proposal from Interco Inc., the companies said today.

title: David Borden
description: The composer-keyboardist David Borden will play new music tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation loft, 224 Centre Street, at Grand Street (431-5127). Admission is $3.

title: Missing Moose
description: Outdoorsmen have found it a simple thing to call a moose in the wild, but the Cincinnati Slammers are finding it nearly impossible to call one at home in South Carolina.

title: Kemp's Super Bowl
description: If any of the 1988 Presidential hopefuls can lay claim to using Super Bowl XXI as a fund-raising device, it certainly should be Representative Jack F. Kemp, the Republican from upstate New York who once was a professional quarterback. And he's doing just that, in spades.

title: Britain Widens Investigation
description: The British Government said today that employees of its own financial watchdog department were being being investigated for illegal insider stock trading.

title: A LOSING FIGHT FOR SECURITY
description: The Communications Workers of America, perhaps more than any other major union in the country, has made lifetime employment security a key goal at the bargaining table. But the huge cutback of jobs that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today suggests such efforts may be fruitless.

title: Johnny Griffin
description: The saxophonist Johnny Griffin will lead his quartet - with Harry Pickens on piano, Curtis Lundy on bass and Idris Muhammad on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: MANILA, ALLEGING TRUCE VIOLATION, REPORTS 3 DEAD IN A REBEL ATTACK
description: The military said today that three people had been killed and two others wounded when Communist rebels attacked a bus. It was the most serious accusation so far that the rebels had violated a eight-day-old cease-fire.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1986
description: Companies

title: CONVICTION IN RWANDA COURT
description: A court in Rwanda convicted an American wildlife researcher in his absence today of murdering Dian Fossey, a gorilla expert, at her camp a year ago.

title: Saatchi Is Named Video Digest Agency
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has been named agency for Video Digest, a monthly magazine due out in January from GP Group, the same people who publish The National Enquirer.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 19, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Europe, Worried, Watches the White House
description: At this writing, and from this side of the Atlantic, there can be no more than an interim assessment of the damage already done by the Iran-Nicaragua imbroglio or of its longer-term consequences for President Reagan's reputation or for America's foreign policy during the remaining years of his Presidency.

title: NBC's 'Christmas Snow,' Starring Sid Caesar
description: Look who's home for Christmas! Sid Caesar, no less, back on Saturday night on NBC, not quite as he was in ''Your Show of Shows,'' in which the strong suit was comedy, but in a simple, straightforward play, geared for the younger set. It goes on at 8 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Ponderosa Agrees To Edelman Buyout
description: Ponderosa Inc., ending its efforts to thwart a takeover by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman, said today that it had accepted a sweetened $29.25-a-share acquisition proposal from Mr. Edelman's investor group.

title: KLM Confirms Bid for Hilton Unit
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines has confirmed hotel industry reports that it is bidding for the Hilton International Hotel chain, part of the Transworld Corporation.

title: THE NEW MAN AT THE I.M.F.
description: At first glance Michel Camdessus, the International Monetary Fund's new managing director, seems to resemble no one so much as the man he is succeeding, Jacques de Larosiere. But the similarity is misleading.

title: 2 Homeless Shelters Approved in Harlem
description: The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the development of two new homeless shelters in Harlem. One shelter is to provide housing for homeless families and the other is to house single adults between 18 and 25 years old.

title: J.P. Stevens President Named Vice Chairman
description: Ward Burns, president of J.P. Stevens & Company, yesterday was named vice chairman of the big textile company.

title: Opera Excerpts
description: The Mannes Opera Workshop will present scenes from operas by Puccini, Strauss and Bizet, among others, tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street. Admission is free. Information: 580-0210.

title: 1986's Legacy: Tumultuous Era for Big Business
description: Big business in America is overhauling itself and its operations faster than at any time since World War II.

title: 50 FAMILIES FLEE LAVA FLOW
description: A molten lava flow from Kilauea Volcano crossed a coastal road here today, prompting the authorities to evacuate people living in about 50 homes.

title: Yank Broadcast Moves
description: The hunt for new players has not deterred George Steinbrenner from another round of moves in the broadcast booth.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TO VERIFY CARDS
description: A pilot program in Texas will enable businesses to verify by telephone whether prospective employees have valid Social Security numbers, the Government said today.

title: Ex-49er Has Cancer
description: Tommy Davis, who kicked 234 consecutive extra points from 1959 to 1965 when he was with the San Francisco 49ers, blames his failure to stop smoking for the lung cancer now threatening his life. ''I'm taking it day by day,'' Davis, 52 years old, a punter and place-kicker on the 49ers from 1959-69, told The Santa Rosa Press Democrat in an interview published yesterday.

title: 2d Suspect in Clinic Attack
description: Federal investigators said yesterday that they were seeking a second person in the attempted bombing of an abortion clinic last Sunday in Manhattan. A sketch of a woman in her early 20's with sunglasses and long hair was shown to employees at the center, the Planned Parenthood Clinic at 360 Second Avenue, but no leads have developed, said Robert J. Creighton, head of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in New York, which has joined the police in the inquiry. The first suspect was described as a white man 32 to 37 years old, between 5 foot 7 and 5 foot 9 with brown hair and brown eyes and a mustache.

title: Market Place; A.T.&T. Move Is Assessed
description: THE American Telephone and Telegraph Company's announcement yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $3.2 billion in the fourth quarter will weaken the price of the company's stock in the short run, according to several analysts. But the austerity moves promise to substantially benefit the telecommunications giant and strengthen the stock's price over the long term, these experts believe.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS'
description: WHO could have imagined that ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' the 1960 comic horror film shot by Roger Corman in two days' time, would continue to grow bigger, mightier and more formidable, much like the man-eating plant that is its unsung star? From Mr. Corman's charming throwaway film to the Off Broadway stage success, ''Little Shop of Horrors'' has evolved into a full-blown movie musical, and quite a winning one. As directed by the Muppet master Frank Oz, this large-scale new film version has just the right mixture of playfulness, tunefulness and blood lust. Never has any screen killer done his job as innocently as Seymour Krelborn (Rick Moranis), the florist's assistant who tries so hard to accommodate the large, potted creature living in the basement of his ''God- and customer-forsaken'' shop that he cannot help thinking of passers-by as plant food.

title: Gillette Charge Is $190 Million
description: The Gillette Company, recently shaken by an unsuccessful takeover attempt by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's Revlon Group, said today that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $190 million in order to restructure.

title: AT THE BASILICA, A BLENDING OF PEOPLE AND OF FAITHS
description: Eduardo Rey, a 27-year-old electrical worker from the state of Puebla, had crawled 30 blocks through Mexico City on his knees toward the basilica of Santa Maria de Guadalupe before the paramedics found him a mile short of his goal.

title: Just Say No to the U.S. War Against Nicaragua; Hondurans Say It Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Can Disconnect Wired Informers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Secrecy Buys Ignorance
description: Top Israeli officials are convincing when they say they responded to American inquiries and thought they were just doing the U.S. a favor by getting involved in the American-Iranian arms deal.

title: SOVIET NATIONALITIES: RUSSIANS RULE, OTHERS FUME
description: The Soviet Union's multiethnic character has long been the Government's public boast and its private burden.

title: DANCE: NIKOLAIS TROUPE
description: The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater's second program at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, started off superlatively on Wednesday night with an early Nikolais work, ''Noumenon.''

title: ITALIANS SAY WHITE HOUSE AGREED TO SECRET U.S. OVERTURES TO LIBYA
description: A high Italian official said today that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter told him last spring that the White House had followed a policy of secret contacts with Libya at a time when Washington was advocating isolating the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THIS is the only place you could possibly have a party for Bernie,'' Iris Cantor said as she greeted partygoers gathering in the Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate the 70th birthday of her husband, B. Gerald Cantor. No one disagreed with her choice of locale. After all, the financier endowed the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Exhibition Hall, the B. Gerald Cantor Sculpture Galleries and the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden, which is to open at the museum in May.

title: Combining of Forces For Omnicom Group
description: When the Omnicom Group was formed earlier this year by BBDO International and DDB Needham Worldwide, the merged Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide agency, all the specialty units that were part of the three were combined as Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services division, under the chairmanship of Barry E. Loughrane, the former D.D.B. head.

title: Robin Auchincloss Married to a Banker
description: Robin Auchincloss of New York and London and Henry Dwight Sedgwick of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Churh of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: SCREEN: RICHARD GERE IN PEARCE'S 'NO MERCY'
description: NO American actor can match Richard Gere in making grandiose and often unreasonable claims for himself with each new role. From ''King David'' to the remake of ''Breathless,'' Mr. Gere has consistently demonstrated more confidence in his own magnetism than anyone else seems to feel. Yet there are times when the perception of Mr. Gere as a tough-talking, quietly mesmerizing figure, a man of keen and unpredictable longings, seems wholly justified, and his latest film is one of them. ''No Mercy'' is a passionate film noir that depends heavily upon Mr. Gere to give it credence, and Mr. Gere delivers.

title: Lombard C. Jones, 80, An Illustrator of Books
description: Lombard C. Jones, a book illustrator and briefly the managing editor of The American Mercury, died Dec. 13 at the Royal Megansett Nursing Home in North Falmouth, Mass. Mr. Jones, a resident of Sandwich, Mass., was 80 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MISSION TO CIVILIZE: The French Way.

title: MAYORS SEEK FEDERAL AID TO CURB POVERTY IN CITIES
description: The United States Conference of Mayors, citing a survey showing urban poverty increased in 1986, called today for a national response to the problem.

title: Reliance Increases Holdings in Tiger
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc. said it had increased its stake in Tiger International Inc. to 16.2 percent, from 14.8 percent. The move came a day after Tiger International said it had reversed its decision to seek buyers for the assets of its air freight subsidiary, Flying Tiger Line Inc.

title: JUDGE AGAIN DELAYS DECISION ON IRAN ARMS CASE DISMISSAL
description: A decision was postponed yesterday on whether to dismiss a Federal incictment charging 13 suspects and 5 companies with conspiring to sell American-made arms to Iran.

title: JOHN ZAREMBA
description: John (Jack) Zaremba, a onetime newspaper reporter who became a familiar character actor on several television series, died Monday of a heart attack at the age of 77.

title: Hal Riney Gets Account For New Zealand Kiwi
description: The latest victory for Hal Riney & Partners amid the hills of San Francisco comes courtesy of the New Zealand Kiwifruit Authority (not to be confused with the California Kiwifruit Commission), which was formerly served by the San Francisco office of Lowe Marshalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which introduced kiwi advertising in June.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee concluded closed-door hearings and the House Intelliegence Committee neared the end of its own investigation still unable to determine how much money from the sale of United States arms to Iran was diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as the contras, and who bore overall responsibility. The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, and a former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, again testified and again stood by their conflicting accounts about when President Reagan approved Israel's shipments of United States arms to Iran.

title: Dining Out Guide: Fireplaces
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, #206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 15, 1985) The glowing hearth at this East Side restaurant along with the rough plaster walls suggest the Southwest, and the decor carries through to the natural-wood floors and tables and lovely arrangements of desert flowers. Starter options include grilled-lamb salad with artichoke and fennel; ravioli with goat cheese, and pan-fried sweetbreads with baked squash. For a main dish, you might order seafood risotto with saffron and roast chili; grilled squab with wild-rice ragu, or grilled rib-eye steak with chipotle hazelnut sauce. Dinner entrees $17 to $23. Fridays and

title: The President's Allies Are Rallying Round...
description: President Reagan's supporters on the right are mounting a vigorous campaign for their beleaguered hero. They say the enemy is a familiar one: those liberal critics who have simmered for six years over the success of a conservative President and a conservative movement.

title: BUDGET PROPOSES SHARP CUTS IN VETERANS' HEALTH BENEFITS
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year proposes sharp cuts in Federal spending for veterans' health care benefits.

title: Coffey Sidelined
description: The back spasms that doctors expected to keep Paul Coffey out of the Edmonton Oiler lineup for a game or two have sidelined the All-Star defenseman for eight games.

title: The 50 Teen-agers Who Aren't Dead
description: According to the new arithmetic of drinking ages, the difference between 18 and 21 is 50. That many young New Yorkers may be alive today because the state raised its legal drinking age from 18 years to 21, according to figures from the state Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: MISSOURI TOWN TAKES HOLD AND REVIVES PROSPERITY
description: For some time visitors accustomed to stopping here in the foothills of the Ozarks to rent canoes to float down the scenic Meramac River have been exposed to a mystery.

title: Why Americans in Paris Get Lost on the Metro
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTHUR HARTMAN PLANNING TO QUIT AS ENVOY TO MOSCOW IN EARLY '87
description: Arthur A. Hartman has asked to be relieved as Ambassador to the Soviet Union early next year, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: ALEXANDER PAYS TRIBUTE TO NAT COLE
description: MONTY ALEXANDER'S affectionate tribute to Nat (King) Cole, at the Blue Note this weekend, is the culmination of influences that go back to Mr. Alexander's childhood in Kingston, Jamaica.

title: Froese Is Traded to Rangers
description: Not prompted by any crying need, but perhaps with an eye toward another deal, the Rangers acquired Bob Froese from the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday to be their backup goalkeeper.

title: Fannie Mae Securities Sold With 8.26% Yield
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, sold $250.1 million of 5 3/4 percent mortgage-backed securities yesterday at an average price of 78 23/32 to yield 8.26 percent.

title: A.M. Rosenthal of The Times To Get Foundation's Award
description: A. M. Rosenthal, former executive editor and now associate editor and columnist for The New York Times, is to be given the National Press Foundation's award for distinguished contributions to journalism Feb. 25 in Washington.

title: Horner Offer Dropped
description: The Atlanta Braves have withdrawn their original offer to Bob Horner, believed to be about $3.5 million for two years, and Bucky Woy, his agent, said the first baseman who is a free agent will continue to pursue a contract with other teams. Horner reportedly was seeking a four-year deal worth $2 million annually.

title: SOVIET REPORTS RIOTING IN CITY IN CENTRAL ASIA
description: The Soviet Union reported today that there had been an outbreak of anti-Russian rioting in the capital of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan.

title: 19TH-CENTURY CHARMS JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: THE Christmas that is famous in New York is the Fifth Avenue one - with the immense illuminated snowflake at 57th and Fifth, the Christmas tree and ice-skating rink at Rockefeller Center, and the Empire State Building decked out in green and red. The scale is imperial, and people come from all over the world to see it.

title: MAKERS OF ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES ASKED TO END SALES FOR YOUNG
description: A Federal safety agency today urged manufacturers to voluntarily stop selling recreational motorized vehicles for children under 12 years old, seeking to stem the rising number of deaths and injuries involving the popular machines.

title: Reagan Picks Keel as Envoy
description: President Reagan will nominate Alton G. Keel, the acting national security adviser, to serve as ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, it was announced today.

title: Little Change in U.S. Issues
description: Investor demand for corporate and mortgage securities remained strong enough for investment bankers to offer several new issues yesterday, while prices of Treasury issues were little changed in lethargic trading.

title: Ronnie Matthews
description: The pianist Ronnie Matthews is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. On Sunday, the pianist Kirk Lightsey will lead a trio at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Rights Group Files Suit In Citadel Hazing Case
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 18 (UPI) -

title: Manville Plan Confirmed
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge, Burton Lifland, has officially confirmed that the Manville Corporation's reorganization plan, positioning the company to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in late 1987, meets statutory requirements.

title: Federated Stores Offers 7 7/8% Notes
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. yesterday began offering $200 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.25 to yield 7.985 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Fritz Goro, 85, Photographer; Recorded Science Advances
description: Fritz Goro, who specialized in scientific photography for Life and Scientific American magazines, died at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y., last Sunday of complications related to cancer. He was 85 years old.

title: CHINA WILL TEST FOREIGN STUDENTS FOR AIDS VIRUS
description: Beginning next month, all foreign students who come to China for more than one year must present proof that they are not carriers of the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome or submit to a blood test administered by the Government.

title: New Realms, High and Low
description: Much of the world looks pretty well thumbed over, yet pristine realms still await discovery. Two recent books describe such explorations, one in the virgin canopy of tropical rain forests, the other in a bizarre jungle that lies beneath the householder's vision.

title: HARLEM AND THE SPECULATORS: BIG PROFITS BUT LITTLE REWARD
description: In the last six years, the apartment building at 215 West 116th Street in Harlem has been sold five times, its price rising from $6,000 to more than $600,000. The fortunes of the building's tenants, meanwhile, have at best held even, and for them, even means miserable.

title: Lymphoma of Brain Was Once Rarely Diagnosed
description: The lymphoma that was removed yesterday from the left side of the brain of William J. Casey, the Director of the Central Intelligence, was once rarely diagnosed. Such diagnosis is now occurring with increasing frequency, but it still makes up only about 2 percent of all brain tumors.

title: THEATER: MCKELLEN IN 'WILD HONEY'
description: IAN MCKELLEN is always exciting to watch, and there's a lot of him to watch in ''Wild Honey,'' Michael Frayn's ingenious new adaptation of Chekhov's first extant play. As Platonov, a village schoolmaster in provincial 19th-century Russia, the English actor spends much of the second act juggling four women (one of them his wife) while simultaneously fending off a legal action, a galloping case of the d.t.'s and a halfhearted murder attempt or two. His pants drooping, his face filthy and unshaven, his mouth gummy, Mr. McKellen has the clotted sound of James Mason's Norman Maine and looks like a derelict Pierrot on speed. If he isn't rocking in a low chair that wasn't meant to rock or undulating elastically like a human Slinky, he may well be crawling on the floor in a soiled blanket, assuming the shape of a huge mutant snail.

title: MUSICIANS IN PHILHARMONIC BOYCOTT HARLEM CHURCH
description: More than a third of the members of the New York Philharmonic refused to play at a free concert at a Harlem church last week because a minister of the church would not denounce the Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Wednesday about a Planned Parenthood poll of teen-agers incorrectly described the financing of an earlier report on teen-agers by the National Research Council. That report was paid for by private foundations, not by Congress.

title: The Sales Sails Of Fremantle
description: The purists winced yesterday at what they saw on the America's Cup race course off Fremantle, Australia. A special fleet race for 12-Meters other than those slated for the cup semifinals later this month drew eight yachts to the starting line, and, as they rounded the leeward mark and hoisted their spinnakers, the names of advertisers took shape like letters on a circus balloon.

title: BOESKY INVESTORS FACE LOSSES
description: The equity investors in Ivan F. Boesky's arbitrage fund appear likely to lose as much as a third of their investment, and perhaps more, according to figures provided to the investors. At the same time, however, newly uncovered details show that Mr. Boesky received more favorable terms in his settlement of insider trading charges than had been known previously.

title: Israeli Soldier on Foot Patrol Is Wounded by Arab With Ax
description: An Arab man with an ax attacked an Israeli soldier patrolling the West Bank town of Ramallah today, wounding him lightly, a military spokesman said.

title: RESCH'S RECORD IS CHEVRIER'S GOAL
description: Alain Chevrier had plunged to his left and to his right in the 60 minutes 35 seconds of the game, making 32 saves in the process of posting his 15th victory, all the victories the Devils have this season.

title: LAWYER FOR COMPANY DENIES ANY LINK TO IRAN
description: A lawyer for a Panamanian company owned by Saudi Arabian interests denied today that he was in any way involved in the sale of arms to Iran.

title: Woman, 67, Fatally Stabbed By Robber in Brooklyn Home
description: A 67-year-old Brooklyn woman was found stabbed to death in her ransacked Brownsville's apartment last night, apparently the victim of a robber, the police said.

title: James Fassett Is Dead at 82; Ex-CBS Radio Music Director
description: James Fassett, a former CBS Radio music director and head of its music division, died Wednesday at Pokono Hospital in Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 82 years old.

title: Performance Sailing Magazine Is Planned
description: J. Patrick Moran Jr., who is apparently making a success of his series of magazines tied to the current America's Cup races, has devised a property that should have greater longevity: Performance Sailing.

title: The President's Allies Are Rallying Around... As Books and Movies Are Hatching Apace
description: When Donald T. Regan testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee the other day that President Reagan and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had never met alone, there was a shudder of relief among Republican Party officials and Reagan loyalists.

title: Reader's Digest Acquisition
description: AS its first domestic magazine acquisition, the 65-year-old Reader's Digest Association has bought Travel-Holiday, which is 20 years its senior.

title: Bridge: New York Winter Regional Opening With New Schedule
description: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center with a schedule that will bring cheers from some players and groans from others.

title: Kelly Fiddlers
description: The fiddlers Joe and Willie Kelly will perform tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Tickets are $5; information, 475-7092.

title: THE SCREEN: 'MISS MARY'
description: ''MISS MARY,'' the new Argentine film by Maria Luisa Bemberg (''Camila''), recalls life in pre-Peronist Argentina, mostly through the eyes of an English nanny, Miss Mary (Julie Christie), who arrives in Buenos Aires in 1938 to care for the children of an aristocratic landowner and leaves in 1945, on the eve of Peron's election to the presidency.

title: Rifts at U.S. Thrift Agency
description: Reflecting deep divisions between the chairman and the two new members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the agency voted today to extend for only two and a half months a limit on direct investments in real estate development by thrift institutions.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR several years, Christian Delouvrier has been a gastronomic George Bush to his own celebrated commander-in-chef, Alain Senderens of the venerable Lucas-Carton in Paris. In 1983, Mr. Senderens was hired as a periodic menu consultant to boost the reputation of Maurice, the French restaurant in the Hotel Parker Meridien on West 57th Street. He garnered most of the applause while his man in the trenches, Mr. Delouvrier, dutifully carried out orders. The Senderens connection ended last year, and Mr. Delouvrier parted with him.

title: RYAN O'NEAL'S SON GUILTY OF NEGLIGENCE IN DEATH OF FRIEND
description: Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, was cleared today of manslaughter in the death of Gian-Carlo Coppola but was convicted of negligently operating a boat.

title: EWING IS FINED $3,000 FOR PUNCHING CELTICS' KITE
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' emotional center who has a history of getting into fights both in the pros and in college, was fined $3,000 yesterday by the National Basketball Association.

title: STUDENTS GIVE LUNCH MONEY TO THE NEEDIEST
description: After a day of fund-raising activities, students at the O. Henry School, Intermediate School 70, at 333 West 17th Street in Manhattan, gave $244.60 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: MODIFIED, BUDGET CAP LAW IS EXTENDED IN TRENTON
description: The New Jersey Senate gave final passage today to a bill modifying and extending the state law that limits the amount that municipal budgets may rise from year to year. The law, which was first enacted in 1976, was scheduled to expire at the end of the year.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Crane Co., a maker of pumps, valves and fittings and building products, elected its chairman and chief executive, Robert S. Evans, to the additional posts of president and chief operating officer.

title: Selective Taxation
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Violations Reported at Center
description: The State Department of Health Services said yesterday that it had found 20 apparent violations of state health codes at a Windsor nursing home where five patients died after an outbreak of salmonella poisoning.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CELTIC SOUNDS The World Music Institute, a nonprofit organization dedicated to presenting the finest in traditional and contemporary music from around the world, needs $75,000 to continue its programming, and some friends have joined forces to help the institute meet its bills. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, will present benefit concerts for the institute. Tonight's program features traditional and Celtic music by the group Nightnoise, which includes some of the most respected musicians in the flourishing Celtic music movement. Triona Ni Dhomhnaill (vocals, clavinet, synthesizer) and Micheal O'Domhnaill (guitar, vocals) are both veterans of the Bothy Band, the seminal Celtic revival group. The quartet is rounded out by the violinist Billy Oskay and the jazz flutist Brian Dunning. The Clan, which shares the bill with Nightnoise, makes Irish folk-rock that is stylistically descended from Steeleye Span and Fairport Convention. Tomorrow night, Inkhay, Aires Colombianos and the duo of Jeff Rehab and Tiberio Nascimento will be on the program. Those groups will present music of South America. Admission each night costs $12. The number for more information is 362-3366.

title: Police Monument Begins
description: A proposal to build a national monument on the Mall to law-enforcement officers killed in the line of duty is getting into motion two years after Congress approved it. Jan C. Scruggs, the moving spirit behind the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, has agreed to become project director of the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund and help organize a $5 million campaign to finance the effort.

title: Maybe Not Just Soviet Propaganda
description: Iran-contra affair or not, says the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, he still wants a nuclear arms pact with the United States and is prepared to make further compromises. ''Propaganda,'' the State Department was quick to snort. Too quick.

title: AFTERMATH OF YOUTH'S DEATH TO BE FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: State and city officials said yesterday that they would investigate why it took a week for a Brooklyn family to find out that their son had died in a hospital emergency room.

title: DEAD BLACKS CITED AS FOES OF REBELS
description: The South African police took the unprecedented step today of releasing the names of 28 young blacks who, it said, had been executed or had taken their own lives as dissidents in black nationalist guerrilla training camps.

title: Sonat Inc. Charge Of $350 Million
description: Sonat Inc. announced that it is restructuring in a way that will produce a total after-tax charge to 1986 earnings of about $350 million and that it will take a non-recurring fourth-quarter charge of about $160 million to reduce its investment in the oil-service business.

title: NATO Leader Has Operation To Remove Prostate Gland
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military forces, underwent successful cancer surgery last week and will return to his duties in Europe next month, the Pentagon said today.

title: Elections Panel Picks Chief
description: Scott Thomas, the newest member of the Federal Election Commission, was elected chairman Tuesday. Thomas Josefiak was elected vice chairman by the six-member panel, which oversees political campaign activity and makes rulings under the Federal Election Campaign Act. Mr. Thomas, 33 years old, was appointed by President Reagan this fall.

title: Filly Wins Dash
description: Forever Special, a 3-year-old filly, raced Demetroula into defeat and then went on to post a 2 3/4-length victory in the $33,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the figures include the results of Cuno Inc., acquired in January.

title: If You Seek to Understand Iran, Don't Consult Lord Curzon
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa St. Penalty Is Confirmed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association confirmed today it had placed the Iowa State football program on a two-year probation and limited its athletic scholarships because of recruiting violations.

title: RISING RIO GRANDE STEMS ALIEN TIDE
description: An amazing thing has happened to the muddy trickle of a river that separates the United States from Mexico here.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Bush Urges Poindexter and North To Make 'Sacrifice' and Tell All
description: Vice President Bush, suggesting that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North should waive their constitutional right against self-incrimination, today called on the two former White House officials to ''tell us the truth'' about their roles in the Iran arms controversy.

title: Graffiti Is What Happens to White Trucks Parked in the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: TO GORKY AND BACK: SAKHAROV'S BITTER ODYSSEY
description: Shortly after World War II a friend brought a young student to the Nobel Prize-winning physicist Igor Tamm, proposing the young man for independent study.

title: CONSUMER PRICES RISE BY O.3%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, continuing the mild pickup in inflation that has accompanied firmer oil prices, the Labor Department reported today.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PLANE PASSES AFRICA AND IS OVER SEA
description: The experimental plane Voyager soared past Africa and into clear skies over the Atlantic today with up to 1,000 pounds more fuel than was previously calculated.

title: This Time in Lebanon, It's Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HASENFUS RECEIVES QUIET HOMECOMING
description: There were no parades or confetti throwers today for Eugene Hasenfus, the American cargo handler pardoned by Nicaragua for smuggling arms to the rebels there. There were a couple of ''Welcome Home'' signs on storefront marquees.

title: HANOVER COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $579,000 and $1,577,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ROSS COSMETICS DISTRIBUTION CENTERS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: SLAYINGS OF FOUR TIED TO A GAME USING FANTASIES
description: The 17-year-old Columbia County honor student who has been charged with fatally shooting four people - his father, brother, cousin and his father's girlfriend - committed the murders last Saturday as part of an elaborate fantasy game, according to a law-enforcement official familiar with the case.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes income of $2,041,000 resulting from the reversal of a tax liability due to the termination of a pension plan related to the Struthers- Dunn Inc. acquisition. c-Net loss The company said the first quarter included net sales of $8,563,000 of Struthers-Dunn, which was acquired in April 1986.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Willy Roy, the Chicago Sting coach, refused to attend a Major Indoor Soccer League game against the New York Express last night, and his status will be considered by team executives next week. . . . Ed Zucker, a Rutgers senior who opened the basketball season with a 27-point performance against Rider, will miss the remainder of the season because of a back problem that has been diagnosed as congenital stenosis, a narrowing of the spinal canal. Coach Craig Littlepage said surgery had not been considered, but that Zucker had been advised to avoid physical activity. . . . Lefty Driesell, who resigned under pressure as head basketball coach at Maryland after the drug-related death last summer of Len Bias, will return to Atlantic Coast Conference basketball in January as a television analyst. . . . Joel Quenneville, a Hartford Whaler defenseman, underwent surgery to have a pin placed in his separated right shoulder and will be out of action for at least three months. . . . George Foreman, the heavyweight boxing champion in 1973 and 1974, has abandoned plans for a comeback that was to begin with a fight in Tucson, Ariz., on Jan 7. The Arizona Republic quoted Johnny Montana of the Arizona Boxing Commission as saying that the fight plans had been canceled.

title: TORA-SAN, A TRADITION IN JAPAN
description: There are several sure-fire ways in Japan to tell that New Year's is coming. Stores have begun to offer doughy rice cakes for the holidays. Elaborately decorated battledores are on sale near the Asakusa Kannon Temple in Tokyo. And posters have gone up everywhere announcing that the latest Tora-san film is about to open.

title: When the Steel City Is Changed to a City of Glass
description: The crown of grimy chimneys, which once symbolized this steel town, gave way some years ago to soaring office towers, whose skins shimmer at sunrise, beckoning commuters crossing the Monongahela River like so many sweet sirens.

title: PENTAGON, IN REVERSAL, SEEKS A MAJOR ROLE IN SPACE STATION
description: In a reversal of policy, the Defense Department is asserting its right to play a major role in a proposed space station because of a potential need to use it for ''Star Wars'' research, Government officials said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 122, Celtics 100: In Philadelphia, Julius Erving scored 24 points and Roy Hinson 21 last night as the 76ers ended a four-game losing streak. Charles Barkley had 15 points, 11 assists and 14 rebounds in the Sixers' second victory in three games this season with Boston. Philadelphia turned the game into a rout in the fourth period with a 10-2 surge for a 103-85 lead with 7 minutes 4 seconds left. Philadelphia led by 57-49 after the first half. Boston rallied early in the third quarter to close the margin to 65-63 with 6:04 left, but Philadelphia came back with a 12-4 rally to lead by 77-67.(AP) Pistons 114, Spurs 84: Adrian Dantley and Isiah Thomas led a third-quarter surge in Pontiac, Mich., that lifted Detroit. San Antonio led by as many as 16 points in the first quarter. But Detroit, behind Dantley's 10 points, rallied in the second quarter and trailed, 53-51, at the half. Dantley, who finished with a game-high 26 points, scored the Pistons' first 7 points in the third quarter and gave Detroit its first lead, 58-57, on a 3-point play with 10:12 left in the period. Walter Berry, acquired by the Spurs from Portland on Thursday, missed his flight and arrived shortly after the game started. Berry sat on the San Antonio bench in street clothes.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 3, Canadiens 2: Mike Foligno returned to the lineup after a five-game absence with a bruised kidney and scored two goals to spark Buffalo to the home-ice victory.

title: ILC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest third quarter it took a writedown of about $1,450,000 relating primarily to inventory and receivables due to suspension of manned space flights and the outlook for aerospace contracts for the future. After a review of its inventory records in the latest fourth quarter, it took an additonal inventory writedown of about $2.6 million.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 21
CHARVOZ-CARSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $95,000.

title: COLORFUL HABERDASHERY, AFTER 67-YEARS STAND ON BROADWAY, CLOSES
description: Out of Leighton's doors on Broadway walked some of the slickest customers in Times Square - pugilists, promoters, swells and sharps, high-rollers who lived at the edge of fashion and the law. Tonight, after 67 years, those doors will close for the last time.

title: KEY RATES
DANCE: SOLOMONS COMPANY IN 'CHRYPTYCH'
description: ''Chryptych'' was a misleadingly punning title for a serious piece of choreography that honored a beautiful building. Choreographed by Gus Solomons Jr. for the Solomons Company/Dance, it was performed Thursday night in the austerely elegant sanctuary of St. Mark's Church, the space that was its inspiration.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ALTAI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Let's Use 'Wise Women'
description: Amid the spate of proposals that Ronald Reagan be restored to respectability by the counseling of ''wise men,'' the question arises, ''Are there no wise women in our nation who might have some sound advice to offer?'' We can hear the groans. Does there have to be a ''woman's angle'' to everything, including the Iranian-Nicaraguan mess? Yes, more than ever.

title: MIXED VERDICT GIVEN IN THEFT OF $8 MILLION
description: A jury acquitted three men last night of charges that they robbed a Wells Fargo depot in Manhattan of almost $8 million. One of the men, however, was convicted of conspiracy.

title: TV: SWEDISH, SUBTITLED 'LYSISTRATA'
description: Along with Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings,'' Channel 31's ''Window on World Television'' has been taking advantage of what is supposed to be a ''global village'' by acquiring outstanding television productions from around the world, not just from English-speaking sources. More often than not, the policy has paid off handsomely. The latest example of clever purchasing is a new production of ''Lysistrata'' by Aristophanes, which Channel 31 will broadcast tomorrow night at 10.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest first quarter net includes a recovery of $93,000 on an investment which had been previously reserved for loss. The year-ago quarter results include a $300,000 recovery on a reserve for a lawsuit.

title: U.S.O. CENTER FACING EVICTION AFTER DECADES AS BEACON TO SOLDIERS
description: The Times Square U.S.O. center - long part of a network known as a soldier's home away from home - may soon become homeless.

title: U.S. Gives Swiss 7 Names in Inquiry in Iran Affair
description: A New York businessman who the Director of Central Intelligence says first alerted him to the diversion of Iranian arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels is one of seven people whose names have been given to Swiss banking authorities for investigation into whether they had accounts used in the scheme.

title: John Adams Spoke as a Friend of Zionism and a Foe of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CANCER PATIENT AND MOTHER REUNITED IN U.S.
description: A cancer patient who has sought to leave the Soviet Union for eight years arrived in New York yesterday and, amid tears and bouquets of pink carnations, was reunited with the mother she thought she would never see again.

title: 3 EX-REAGAN AIDES SAY ENVOY TO VATICAN VISITED LIBYA ON HIS OWN
description: Three former White House national security advisers said today that the former United States Ambassador to the Vatican had been ordered repeatedly to cease unauthorized contacts with Libyan officials, and that the Ambassador had gone to Tripoli in November 1985 without telling anyone in the United States Government.

title: WYNEGAR TRADED TO ANGELS
description: Butch Wynegar, who desperately wanted to leave the Yankees, was traded to the California Angels yesterday and sacrificed $127,000 of his 1986 salary for his freedom.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Both Academician Sakharov and Bonner have the possibility to return to Moscow, and Academician Sakharov has the possibility to actively participate in academic life.'' - Vladimir F. Petrovsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister. [ 8:1. ]

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New News Assignment
description: Ronald E. Cohen, a longtime Washington journalist recently dismissed as managing editor of United Press International, has signed on at Gannett Company headquarters in Roslyn, Va., as a news executive. A 25-year veteran of U.P.I., Mr. Cohen helped hold the organization together in several economic crises but was ousted a month ago by the editor in chief, Malcolm Hughes.

title: ADMAR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INTERCARE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

PATENTS;
Correcting the Position Of a Satellite
description: A satellite communications system patented this week for the RCA Corporation provides for examination of radio transmissions to ground stations, so that any error in the pointing of a satellite antenna can be corrected.

title: FED SESSION LEFT POLICY UNCHANGED
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in early November, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Kerry and the Contras
description: Before he was a Lieutenant Governor and then a United States Senator, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts was a lawyer and Assistant District Attorney in Middlesex County, one of the nation's biggest and most active local jurisdictions.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Time of Uncertainty at C.I.A. With Chief Ill and Critics Busy
description: With the Central Intelligence Agency already facing some of its sharpest Congressional scrutiny in a decade, the agency has been plunged into a period of uncertainty by the absence f its leader.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WERNER DANKWORT
description: Werner Dankwort, a former West German observer to the United Nations, died Monday. He was 91 years old.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY FAVORS PLAN TO ALTER THE BUDGET PROCESS
description: In an effort to save the United Nations from bankruptcy, the General Assembly agreed unanimously today on a resolution to revamp the administration and budget-making process of the world body.

title: NO LONGER SMUG, SAN FRANCISCO LOOKS INTO MIRROR AND PONDERS ITS FUTURE
description: When the San Francisco Opera canceled its 1987 summer season recently, many people here viewed the decision as another sign that this city had passed its prime.

title: MUSIC: TWO IN PHILHARMONIC DEBUT
description: Both the conductor and the soloist of the current New York Philharmonic subscription program are making their first Philharmonic appearances this week at Avery Fisher Hall. Esa-Pekka Salonen, the 28-year-old Finnish conductor, is leading a program - heard yesterday afternoon, with the final performance tonight at 8 - of Niccolo Castiglioni's ''Sinfonia con Giardino''; Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1, with the 31-year-old, Moscow-born Andrei Gavrilov as soloist, and finally Nielsen's Symphony No. 4 (''The Inextinguishable'').

title: Keep an Eye on Hanoi
description: So far only the faces are different in Vietnam, but policy changes could be next. If these bring relaxation of control at home and in Cambodia, they could be of enormous importance to the people of Indochina and open some interesting opportunities in the Soviet-Chinese-American triangle.

title: SURGERY FOR WEBSTER
description: Tom Webster, who began his duties as the new head coach of the Rangers less than a month ago, will undergo an inner ear operation to correct dizziness and imbalance that will interrupt his coaching for more than a month. Webster's interim replacement will be the team's general manager, Phil Esposito, who filled the interim coaching role for three games after dismissing Ted Sator and before hiring Webster.

title: Pinetop Perkins
description: The blues pianist Pinetop Perkins will perform tonight at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are about 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1986
description: International OPEC agreed to cut production and raise prices to $18 a barrel. The accord, signed early this morning by all of the group's members except Iraq, calls for across-the-board reductions in output of more than 7 percent for the first half of 1986. A key question about the agreement is whether the group will maintain enough discipline to defend a fixed price. [ Page 1. ] Prices of crude oil and petroleum products fluctuated in frenetic trading on world markets. [ 41. ] Brazilians were cheered by the agreement of 17 government creditors to negotiate their nation's outstanding debts without insisting on a prior agreement with the I.M.F. [ 39. ] China's Government plans to reduce the $8.1 billion it spends on subsidizing food for its 200 million city dwellers.
