China buys 50 million to 60 million tons of grain a year from its farmers under contract, about 15 percent of its total harvest. [ 38 ] Markets The ''triple witching hour'' produced frantic trading in the final half hour on the New York Stock Exchange. The number of orders that piled up for execution at the closing bell produced the busiest minute ever for the stock exchange, one in which more than 85 million shares traded. In all, almost 244.7 million shares traded on the Big Board, topping the previous record of 240.5 million set on Sept. 12. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 1,928.85, a 16.03-point gain for the day and a 16.59-point advance for the week.

title: NEW HOPE FOR HAIR GROWTH MAY LIE IN DRUG STUDY
description: Every Thursday morning, the waiting room in Suite L at New York University Medical Center is crowded with balding men. Once in the doctor's office, they offer their bald spots for measurement and then collect a month's supply of a clear, astringent liquid.

title: REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,278,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $271,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $211,000 and $320,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bridge; A New Computer Program Generates Hands to Order
description: Experts often feel a need for a bunch of bridge hands with particular characteristics. They may wish to practice a systemic idea with a regular partner, to teach some students a convention, to coach an international team, or to test the theoretical desirability of a lead or a bid.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The heading yesterday on a Washington dispatch about Congressional reaction to the Administration policy on Soviet nuclear testing misidentified Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. He is a United States Representative, not a Senator.

title: SOVIET SAYS HUNDREDS WERE INVOLVED IN RIOT
description: A Soviet official said today that ''several hundred'' students had been involved in the anti-Russian rioting that broke out Wednesday night in Alma-Ata, the capital of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alleghany Corp. said its shareholders had approved a plan of liquidation under which shareholders would receive about $41 a share in cash and stock in the company's Alleghany Financial Corp. unit.

title: NICARAGUANS DEBATE HASENFUS DECISION
description: The official Sandinista newspaper reported today that many Nicaraguans are dubious about the decision this week to pardon Eugene Hasenfus. But the newspaper, Barricada, defended the freeing of the American as a step that could bolster those in the United States seeking to end American aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BAIL IS REJECTED IN CHILD SEX CASE
description: A judge today turned down a plea from Raymond Buckey, the chief defendant in the McMartin preschool molestation case, to be released on bail.

title: FORBES BUYS EINSTEIN LETTER
description: One of two versions of a letter written by Albert Einstein on Aug. 2, 1939, to President Franklin D. Roosevelt -the letter that sparked the American effort to build the atomic bomb -was bought at Christie's yesterday by Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher, for $220,000.

title: Prices of Hogs Decline In Cautious Trading
description: Prices of live hog futures fell today despite expectations that a Government report on Monday will show a decline in the number of hogs on the nation's farms.

title: State 'Lemon' Law Is Upheld by Judge
description: The Ford Motor Company and other car manufacturers must abide by a state law extending warranties on all new cars but do not have to reimburse customers who already paid repair bills, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Sept. 9.

title: Graffiti Is What Happens to White Trucks Parked in the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BOND PRICES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted modest gains yesterday in lackluster trading, intermediate maturities were largely unchanged and discount rates on bills eased further.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1986
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: ANTI-EMERGENCY DRIVE BANNED IN CAPE TOWN
description: The police in Cape Town outlawed a Christmas campaign against South Africa's emergency today, ignoring a strong protest against the nation's crisis issued by the European Community.

title: Bernstein to Speak at Concert
description: Leonard Bernstein will be the principal speaker at the fourth New Year's Eve Concert for Peace at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: MED-CHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
M.T.A., WITH EYE ON ALBANY, ACTS TO RAISE FARES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, unable to win support from the Legislature for its $8.6 billion plan to rebuild the region's transit system, served notice yesterday that it was prepared to ask riders to pay sharply higher fares rather than scale back its efforts.

title: GARDENAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $145,000 for the latest year and $1,022,000 for the year-ago period.

title: CITY FORCES 20 FROM BUILDING CALLED UNSAFE
description: At least 20 squatters were ordered out of a Lower East Side building yesterday where some of them had been living without heat or electricity for as long as five years.

title:
PATENTS;
Solar Energy System
description: J. Eugene Pierce, a retired economist in Augusta, Ga., has patented a solar energy system designed to store power in compressed gas obtained from liquids heated by the sun's rays. Patent No. 4,628,692 was granted this week to Mr. Pierce, who plans to build a model of the compressor system and organize a company named Solar World.

title: Jimmy Ponder
description: The jazz-blues guitarist Jimmy Ponder will lead a trio tonight at Brown's Cafe, 5601 Second Avenue, in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn (718-439-5335). There are four sets nightly, beginning at 10; there is a $6 minimum and no cover.

title: JERSEY SCHOOLS NAMED BY U.S. AS INNOVATIVE
description: In the toddler day-care center at Union Township High School this morning two juniors, Cathy Humphrey and Lisa Graves, were reading a story to Marisa Hanrahan, 20 months old.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effective July 11, 1986.

title: Taping System Limited, White House Aides Say
description: Some of President Reagan's calls with foreign leaders have been recorded, but no tapes are known to have been made through a conference system in the White House Situation Room, the White House said today.

title: AND THE ENVELOPE, PLEASE
description: As another National Football League regular season closes with games last night through Monday, it's only right that certain people be acknowledged for their contributions, some of which have added to (or subtracted from) the general enjoyment of the last four months.

title: 2 CONVICTIONS JOLT PENNSYLVANIA G.O.P.
description: In a growing investigation that threatens to engulf much of the Republican Party's state hierarchy, the State Treasurer and a former Pennsylvania party chairman have been convicted of 11 counts of bribery.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter loss included a $46 million charge reflecting primarily the inability to use tax-loss carryforwards due to operating losses in the U.S. and certain foreign operations. The company said the 1986 results included non-recurring gains of $95 million relating to change in the company's accounting for retirement costs and settlements and curtailments of pension plans as well as special charges of $25.3 million for a writedown of surplus oilfield assets. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter and year included special charges of $269.8 million related to the writedown of selected assets and to estimated net realizable values and to provide for costs to be incurred in the disposition of assets and the shutdown of certain facilities.

title: GIANTS SEEK EDGE FOR PLAYOFFS
description: Saturday is an end and a beginning for the Giants.

title: Group Seeks a Delay In Overhaul of Reactor
description: A national environmental group demanded today that a $50 million modernization program scheduled to begin this month at the main United States nuclear reactor producing weapon-grade plutonium for nuclear warheads be delayed for a study of the plan's environmental impact. Such a study could take months or years.

title: CTS Has Received 2 Acquisition Bids
description: The CTS Corporation, a maker of electronic components, said it had received two acquisition proposals from the Dynamics Corporation of America. Dynamics did not disclose the terms of its offers but said both proposals were greater in value than a proposal from the AVX Corporation, which earlier this week offered securities valued at $35 a share for CTS.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Appointment at Putnam
description: David Shanks, president of the Berkley Publishing Group, which includes Berkley and Jove books, was named senior vice president of the Putnam Publishing Group on Tuesday. According to Putnam, he will deal with corporate policy and planning for all Putnam's publishing divisions, which include Berkley, G. P. Putnam's Sons and the Putnam Young Readers Group.

title: CUOMO TURNS DOWN INVITATION TO SPEAK IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Governor Cuomo will not accept an invitation to be the main speaker at a key Democratic dinner in New Hampshire in March, New York State's Democratic chairman said today.

title: Houston to Make Bid for Olympics
description: Houston is making a run for the 1996 Olympics after serving as host for the United States Olympic Festival last summer, The Houston Post reported today.

title: ORANGE JULIEUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,155,000 for the quarter and $1,599,000 for the 9 months. c-Comparable figures are not available because the Orange Julius business was acquired in December 1985. The 9 months' loss from discontinued operations included a gain on the sale of property and equipment by American Videotronics Inc. of $1,432,000.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 28
description: The company said the latest 13 weeks and 39 weeks included after-tax charges attributed to Elisra Electronic Systems Ltd. of $746,000 and $2,438,000, respectively.

title: Trouble Spots for Traffic
description: According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today:

title: CHARGE OVER PUBLISHER'S PRETORIA TIE IS DISMISSED
description: A Federal judge today dismissed charges against John P. McGoff, a publisher accused of failing to register as a foreign agent of the South African Government.

title: LARGE AND SMALL DONATIONS COMBINE TO HELP THE NEEDY
description: ''To be homeless, hopeless and without family to turn to is one of life's tragedies,'' said Ellen V. Langner of Manhattan, in a note with a $50 gift for the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Mazda Weighing Imports From U.S.
description: A top Japanese car maker said it was seriously considering importing cars from the United States to take advantage of the weak dollar and the growing desire of Japanese buyers for something new. A spokesman for Mazda, the country's fifth-largest car maker, said the company might import some of the output from a plant it planned to build in Michigan.

title: Wiesel Should Lead A Peace Crusade
description: To the Editor:

title: China to Cut Food Aid
description: The Chinese Government announced today that it would reduce the amount it spends on subsidizing food for its 200 million city dwellers.

title: U.S. GROUP CAN STUDY SOVIET A-TEST
description: The Soviet Ambassador to the United States said today that American scientists could monitor a nuclear explosion when the Soviet Union resumes underground testing.

title: BENEATH COLUMBUS AVENUE, BONES BECOME ART
description: A mouse strayed into Maxilla and Mandible the other day and never left. It expired in the middle of a laboratory floor for unknown reasons and now resides in the freezer.

title: Andrei Sakharov Goes Home
description: Finally, after almost seven punishing years of internal exile, Andrei Sakharov, the Soviet Union's most prominent dissident, will soon be back in Moscow. Perhaps the Russians have found some new way of balancing their fear of criticism at home against their wish to be liked abroad. Perhaps they simply found the cost of muzzling someone of Mr. Sakharov's stature to be too high. Whatever the reason, the result is welcome news. He may not be wholly free but at least he's going back home, with his wife, Yelena Bonner, whom the Russians have pardoned. The couple's return warms this holiday season.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS FUNDS FOR BASING MX ON TRAIN CARS
description: The White House said today that it would request funds to design a method for deploying large MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars and to develop a smaller nuclear missile.

title: AND TO ALL A 'PLAY BALL!'
description: 'Twas Game Six of the Series when out of the sky, Flew Sergio's parachute, a Met banner held high. His goal was to spur our home team to success, Burst Beantown's balloon claiming Sox were the best.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $50,000 and $31,500 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively from reduction of income taxes arising from utilization of prior years' operating losses. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,261 for the quarter and $3,453 for the 6 months from reduction of income taxes arising from utilization of prior years' operating losses.

title: Barry Harris Plays
description: The pianist Barry Harris will lead a trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tomorrow Mr. Harris will lead a big band with the first set at 7 P.M. Admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

title: Nynex-British Tie
description: The Nynex Corporation has agreed to buy a British company that offers computer software, professional and other business services for stock valued at $:75 million, or about $107 million. The company, Business International Services Ltd., has been privately owned.

title: WITHERSPOON DRUG TEST CALLED NEGATIVE
description: Tim Witherspoon, it turns out, did not smoke marijuana before he was knocked out in one round by James (Bonecrusher) Smith Dec. 12 in their World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: China Traveler's Checks
description: The Industrial and Commercial Bank in Beijing will start issuing traveler's checks valid in 11 Chinese cities starting Jan. 1, the official New China News Agency said today. The checks will have face values from 100 yuan, about $27 at current exchange rates, to 1,000 yuan and are limited to personal use. People bearing the checks can withdraw money from savings banks in any of the 11 cities within a month after they purchase the checks.

title: College Basketball Notebook; Horford Makes Grade With Translator
description: For the first few weeks of class, officials at the University of Miami were afraid that Tito Horford, the much-traveled player, was having a tougher time than expected in the classroom. But as the first semester ends, Horford, who will make his debut against Dartmouth tonight, has pulled his weight in the classroom.

title: JET TAKES A SHORT 'VACATION'
description: Charles Jackson is a pleasant man who asks few questions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error in some copies, an article yesterday about real estate speculation in Harlem omitted part of a sentence that described increases in sale prices.

title: Ex-N.F.L. Back Jailed
description: Warren McVea, a former University of Houston and National Football League player, was jailed in lieu of $25,000 bond on charges of selling crack to support his drug habit, the Houston police said.

title: ACCORD ON MASS-TRANSIT AID REMAINS ELUSIVE IN ALBANY
description: After days of proposals and counterproposals, Governor Cuomo and key legislators ended the week with no agreement today on a plan to finance a rebuilding of New York City's mass-transit system and freeze its fares. The special session of the Legislature recessed and will resume Monday.

title: USX AND UNION RESUME TALKS TO END DISPUTE
description: Bargaining sessions in the five-month-old contract dispute between the USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America resumed today with both sides under strong pressure to reach a settlement.

title: Why Teach?
description: For a frighteningly large number of teachers, the joy and savor have gone out of their teaching. They feel burned out, bitter, misused. What has happened? They ask themselves, ''Why teach?''

title: SPRAYING OF PORK IS OPPOSED
description: The Department of Agriculture has received complaints from consumer groups opposing a proposal by meatpackers that they be allowed to spray substances on fresh pork to maintain its color.

title: Pactel to Buy Cellular Units
description: Pactel Personal Communications, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, said today that it had agreed to buy a group of Michigan and Ohio cellular telephone companies for $316 million.

title: Lawyer Reports Return Of Businessman's File
description: A stolen legal file about Albert Hakim, a figure in the Iran arms controversy, was returned by a man who put it in an airport locker and left the key for Mr. Hakim's lawyer, the attorney said today.

title: FORCE SELLER TO UPGRADE BUILDINGS, KOCH URGES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would push for a law mandating that anyone selling a building set aside enough money from the sale to correct the most severe housing code violations.

title: Article 824386 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government recorded a $27 billion budget deficit last month, down substantially from the deficit rung up in November a year ago, the Treasury Department said today.

title: STIRLING ATTEMPTING TO SALVAGE SEASON
description: Throughout the first weeks of the 1986-87 season, Hubie Brown and his assistants faced heavy pressures to improve a team that had made a habit of losing. Now those same pressures have shifted to the man who made the decision to dismiss Brown, Scotty Stirling.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: A Jurist in Varied Roles: Lawrence Edward Walsh
description: Lawrence E. Walsh has spent 50 years weaving the threads of public service and private representation into a career that has included frequent troubleshooting missions, occasional controversy, moments in the spotlight, experience as a prosecutor, judge and advocate and service at the highest levels of the profession.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRESSING UP

title: STATE DEPT. CHANGES ITS ACCOUNT OF REPLACING DIPLOMAT IN SOVIET
description: The State Department spokesman said today that he had been mistaken in saying that the departing American Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, had made ''a personal decision'' to leave his post in Moscow.

title: Justice Dept. Seeking Inquiry
description: The Justice Department is seeking appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the personal finances of a former assistant Attorney General, Federal law-enforcement sources said Thursday.

title: INQUIRY FINDS CITY OFFICIAL DID NOT BLOCK INVESTIGATION
description: The official responsible for investigating corruption at New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation was cleared yesterday of allegations that he had impeded an inquiry.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Wrecked Barge Lifted From Bridge in Buffalo
description: Salvagers, wiser after 22 frustrating days trying to remove a wrecked barge, lifted the vessel today from a Niagara River bridge abutment where it had helped boost Lake Erie past record levels.

title: JAPAN'S POLICY ON RICE FACES GROWING CRITICISM
description: The United States is not the only country that protects farmers.

title: INSIDE
description: Stock Volume at a Record A record 244 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange - 85 million in the final minute at the ''triple witching hour.''

title: Virginia Lynch Wed to James H. Dean
description: Virginia Dorothy Lynch, the daughter of Caroline Hudson Lynch of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and Edmund C. Lynch Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to James Howell Dean, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Dean of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Bishop Robert R. Spears performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Electronic Gadgets Captivate Shoppers
description: THE man looked at the teeming masses inside 47th Street Photo and froze in the doorway like a paratrooper making his first jump into combat. ''It's all right,'' said Leah Goldstein in a soothing voice, and she pulled him into the store by the sleeve of his jacket. The man apologized, explaining that he was from Altoona.

title: A. J. ROSS LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
description: b-Includes a loss of $4,166 on the sale of equipment.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $147,000 for the quarter and $235,000 for the 6 months.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FRENCH SAILOR REPORTED MISSIGN IN WORLD RACE
description: A leading contender in the BOC round-the-world race, Jacques de Roux, is missing at sea, race officials said today.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results include gains of $400,000 from an inventory adjustment and health insurance premium refunds and exchange gains totaling about $300,000. The company said during the latest year, it made an accounting change that reduced its 1986 losses by $1.1 million.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: STUDY URGES AFFORDABLE HOUSING' IN SUBURBS
description: New York State officials, saying the New York City suburbs were experiencing a housing shortage of crisis proportions, proposed government incentives yesterday to encourage construction in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Thursday about the donation of the Pforzheimer Collection on the Romantic poets to the New York Public Library misidentified the first editor of ''Shelley and His Circle, 1773-1822.'' He is Kenneth Neill Cameron.

title: Yonkers to End Sunday Racing
description: Yonkers Raceway will end its Sunday racing program for this meeting tomorrow night, meaning that there will be no harness racing at the track next Sunday and Jan. 4.

title: The Button Boom
description: No political crisis is complete these days without its footnotes in the form of lapel button, and the Iran-Nicaragua contretemps is no exception. The Young Republicans came up with ''North, American Hero,'' selling for $2 to aid Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's defense fund, and now the Youth for Democratic Action is selling, for $1, a button that reads, ''Did Reagan know, or was he napping?'' The group says an informal survey attendant to the sale of the button has so far logged 32 respondents favoring napping as against 15 believing the President knew. One repondent, naturally, took the Fifth.

title: What Is the U.S.O.?
description: The U.S.O. is a voluntary, nonprofit organization serving the men and women of today's military and their families.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: RAMS A WILD-CARD
description: Joe Montana passed for two touchdowns and a rookie cornerback, Tim McKyer, made two interceptions tonight as the San Francisco 49ers won the National Football Conference's Western Division title with a 24-14 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title:
PATENTS;
New Preparations To Detect AIDS Virus
description: Preparations patented this week for the Genetic Systems Corporation of Seattle are described as useful in the detection of diseases related to AIDS, or Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome.

title: SPORTS PEOPLD
description: 76ers in Bid for Free

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes gains of $6,809,000 for the quarter and $7,422,000 for the year on the sale of product lines. The year also includes an extraordinary gain of $4,157,000. Fiscal 1986 figures include the results of Technicon Instruments Corp. from Aug. 5.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a provision for restructuring retail operations of $5,730,000, or $1.95 a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes a provision for future losses of liquidation of Canadian operations of $889,000, or 31 cents a share, and a gain on sale of real estate of $185,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Gooden Is Trying To Calm Tension
description: Dwight Gooden, arrested last Saturday night after a scuffle with the police, sought today to calm the racial feelings in Tampa, Fla., that have been stirred by the incident. ''Nobody wants this kind of attention, but hopefully in due time things will get better,'' the Mets' pitcher said.

title: Riot Victims Blame Unseen, Uncontrolled Forces
description: At a dusty and windy campsite on this city's outskirts, a bedraggled and stunned group of refugees from Afghanistan were struggling this week without water, food or the belongings left behind in a Karachi slum colony that had been bulldozed a few days before.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Your Money; Exchanging Mutual Funds
description: WITH more than 1,750 mutual funds to choose from, the 25 million individuals who use this investment vehicle have plenty of alternatives. And more and more of these investors are not limiting themselves to a single fund these days, but are instead moving periodically from one to another.

title: After Tirade, Davis Is Put in Special Cell
description: Larry Davis, who is accused of shooting six police officers in November, was put in solitary confinement yesterday for tearing up his cell last weekend, a City Correction Department spokesman said.

title: No Free M.T.A. Fares on Holiday
description: Fearing that it might send the wrong message to Albany, the Metropolitan Transporation Authority decided yesterday not to offer free fares over the New Year's holiday.

title: G.O.P. FIGURE GETS THREE-YEAR TERM
description: John Gnau, a prominent Michigan Republican, was sentenced today to three years in prison for taking part in a scheme to defraud the United States Postal Service.

title: Gasoline Price Outlook
description: Holiday travelers should find gasoline prices unchanged from Thanksgiving and about 35 cents a gallon less than prices a year ago, the American Automobile Association said today. Travelers should fill up on Dec. 24 because 60 percent of 6,000 service stations surveyed on major routes said they would be closed Christmas Day, the A.A.A. reported. Gasoline prices now average 90.4 cents a gallon compared with $1.256 during Christmas 1985, according to the survey.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
WATER MAIN BREAK FLOODS SUBWAY, DISRUPTIN 120,000 RIDERS
description: A ruptured main that dumped 5 million gallons of water into the Longwood Avenue subway station in the South Bronx, leaving its mark two feet high on the token booth, sent 120,000 riders of the IRT No. 6 line scrambling during yesterday's morning and evening rush hours, transit officials said.

title: Greek and 2 Turks Die As Border Troops Fight
description: One Greek soldier and two Turkish soldiers were killed today in an exchange of fire on the river border between the two hostile NATO allies.

title: Another Forget-'Em Crowd
description: I couldn't wait to get my copy of People magazine and see if its list of the 25 most intriguing people of 1986 matched my own. What a letdown.

title: U.S. PARK SERVICE ROILED BY CHANGE
description: Personnel and institutional changes in the National Park Service ordered by the Interior Department could change the character of the parks over time, Park Service officials asserted today. But Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel defended the changes.

title: 12 OPEC MEMEBRS AGREE TO CUT OUTPUT AND RAISE OIL PRICE
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed early today to cut oil production and promptly raise prices to $18 a barrel.

title: Rizzo Registers With G.O.P.; Seeks a New Term as Mayor
description: Frank L. Rizzo, who served two terms as Mayor of Philadelphia, has changed his party registration from Democratic to Republican and says he will seek another term.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 1
description: b-Net income c-Net loss and after a gain of $1,453,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Aid for Admiral Poindexter
description: Three retired admirals have set up a trust and will soon send out letters seeking donations for the defense of a beleaguered comrade, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the President's national security adviser who resigned after disclosures about the Iran arms deal.

title: LAVA ENGULFS 13 MORE HOMES
description: Lava destroyed 13 houses and forced more than 400 people to flee as molten rock from Mount Kilauea surged into an area of homes early today.

title: A A IMPORTING CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 2

PATENTS;
3-D Pictures On Color Television
description: Three-dimensional color television broadcasts are proposed in a patent granted this week to Alvin M. Marks, an inventor in Athol, Mass.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter, and the 6 months includes a loss from discontinued operations of $128,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,235,000 on an insurance recovery, net of taxes and minority interest. c-Net loss d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $314,000 and $358,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also includes an extraordinary gain of $202,000 on an insurance recovery, net of taxes and minority interest and a charge of $1,103,000 net of taxes and minority interest, which reflected the cumulative effect of a change in method of accounting for inventories from the FIFO method to the LIFO method at the company's textiles segment. The company said the 1985 results have been retroactively restated for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect aggregate stock dividends paid through Dec. 15, 1986.

title: Lloyds Are Separated
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and her husband, John, confirmed in an interview with The Fort Lauderdale News and Sun-Sentinel that they had agreed to a ''very amicable'' separation, which has lasted three months and is the second for the couple since they married on April 17, 1979. ''We tried very hard to do this in a private and dignified way,'' said Chris Lloyd. ''But unfortunately, due to some nasty and untrue stories, epecially from the British press, we both felt it was necessary to set the record straight.''

title: 2 House Races Appear Settled
description: The North Carolina Board of Elections today certified Howard Coble, the incumbent Republican, as the winner in the Sixth Congressional District by 79 votes.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Favoritism Versus Inefficiency
description: Stanley Hill, new head of District 37, the largest of New York City's government employee unions, charges that the Koch administration is unlawfully using more city workers who lack civil service status than its predecessor did: 24,000 against 9,000. He's right about the numbers, but exaggerates the law's implications. The courts have consistently sanctioned use of ''provisional'' employees until Civil Service produces certified candidates by examination.

title: SCALES CLERK FINED IN WEIGHT ERRORS
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has fined the New York Racing Association's clerk of scales, Charles Sullivan, $500 for an error that resulted in several apprentice jockeys at Aqueduct riding with a two-pound weight allowance to which they were not entitled.

title: ALCOHOL, THE ULTIMATE ADDITIVE
description: Someone is putting brandy in your bonbons, Grand Marnier in your breakfast jam, Kahlua in your ice cream, Scotch in your mustard and Wild Turkey in your cake.

title: NO GLITCHES IN WITCHING HOUR
description: Yesterday's ''triple witching hour'' was a unique event in a number of respects, traders and market analysts said.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18. 1. They are Percy Bysshe Shelley's revisions and drawings in a copy of the first edition of ''The Queen of the Universe,'' from a collection of journals, poems, letters, books and paintings that document the lives of the English Romantic poets.

title: Police Commanders Switched in Inquiries
description: The city's highest-ranking uniformed police officer has been reassigned after reports that a Federal grand jury and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were investigating drug-related allegations about the Police Department.

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $143,000. c-Net loss

title: BRAZIL WILL RENEGOTIATE ITS PARIS CLUB DEBTS
description: After a month of consistently bad economic news, Brazil was visibly cheered today by word that 17 government creditors had agreed to renegotiate Brazil's outstanding debts without insisting on a prior agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Art Restoration, So-Called
description: Controversy over the vast ''restoration'' of Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel at the Vatican is growing. And this controversy, in turn, is part of a larger debate over what's known as ''art conservation.''

title: HOLIDAY SALES SLOW SO FAR
description: With just five important days remaining, the Christmas shopping season has so far failed to show more than sputtering sparks, assorted retailers said yesterday.

title: Staking Out the Stakeout
description: Before the Senate Intelligence Committee concluded its hearings Thursday on the Iran arms deal, three dozen reporters had spent three weeks of 12-hour days outside the hearing room. Their duty there involved chasing tight-lipped witnesses through the Capitol corridors and begging senators and aides for scraps of information on the connection between the arms deal and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOCTOR IS SPARED JAIL TERM IN MERCY KILLING
description: Declaring that a jail term would constitute ''a serious injustice,'' a Superior Court judge today sentenced a popular Cherry Hill physician to two years probation for the mercy killing of his mother-in-law.

title: A Man and His Dog
description: MY DOG TULIP. By J. R. Ackerley. 160 pages. Poseidon Press. $7.95.

title: OIL PRICES FLUCTUATED
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products continued to fluctuate in frenetic trading yesterday amid reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was close to signing an accord.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Meese Is Said to Tell of a Key Memo
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reportedly told Congress today that the diversion of millions of dollars from the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels was uncovered when a senior Justice Department official found an undated memorandum in the files of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proposing the idea. According to a Congressional source, Mr. Meese told the House Intelligence Committee that Colonel North was ''ashen'' when he confronted him with the memorandum during an interview in his office on Nov. 23.

title: BENEFICIAL REJECTS BID, PLANS SELLOFF
description: The Beneficial Corporation, one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, said yesterday that it had rejected a $1.74 billion takeover bid from ''a major U.S. corporation'' as inadequate and decided instead to sell some $1.4 billion of its operations to trim debts.

title: Mr. Walsh and the Price of Trust
description: By choosing Lawrence Walsh, an elder statesman among American lawyers, as independent counsel to investigate the Iran-contra crisis, a Federal court in Washington helps calm the controversy while assuring more satisfactory answers to its mysteries.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: PITCHER ACCEPTS ARBITRATION
description: George Steinbrenner, citing ongoing contract negotiations with Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph and upcoming negotiations with Don Mattingly, joined three other club owners yesterday in rejecting a chance to sign Jack Morris for one year. Morris, one of baseball's premier pitchers, then beat last night's midnight deadline and accepted the arbitration offer of the Detroit Tigers.

title: Police Stop Roping Suspects
description: A furor over a black man's arrest and his being led through a neighborhood while attached by rope to a mounted officer's saddle has prompted the Police Department to abandon the restraint policy.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A brief Washington dispatch on the television page on Nov. 27 reported Federal Communications Commission approval for the sale of WOR-TV by RKO General to MCA. The article also included background information on a longstanding dispute between the F.C.C. and RKO.

title: Toyota Predicts Production Drop
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, predicted that its total production in 1987 would decline by 1 percent, to 3.6 million vehicles, from this year's projected output of 3.7 million.

title: John Adams Spoke as a Friend of Zionism and a Foe of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes a charge of $109,000 from the repeal of the investment tax credit in the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: KING ROAD ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ALBANY COURT BARS UTILITIES' GIFTS TO CHARITIES FROM RATE REVENUE
description: The Court of Appeals ruled today that it was unconstitutional for state-regulated utilities to contribute ratepayer money to charity, saying the practice forces customers to subsidize causes they may oppose.

title: SCREEN: THE RETURN OF KING KONG
description: Oh, to have been a fly on the wall at the meeting where it was decided that the rumors of King Kong's death had been greatly exaggerated. Someone must have noted that Kong certainly seemed dead, having fallen off the World Trade Center and been pumped full of buckshot. But that wouldn't have killed Bobby Ewing, and it didn't kill Kong either. In ''King Kong Lives,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, it develops that Kong has spent the last 10 years in a coma, waiting to become the recipient of an artificial heart.

title: PUBLISHING: EISENHOWER BEST SELLERS
description: It may not be unprecedented for both husband and wife to have books on the best-seller list simultaneously, but tomorrow a couple who live in Berwyn, Pa., will find themselves in that enviable position.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Group Attacks 2 Policemen at Bar
description: As many as 70 patrons at a Brooklyn bar watched early yesterday as two off-duty police officers were attacked by a group of men, the police said.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $414,000 for the quarter and a gain of $4,773,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $148,000 and $230,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The year-ago quarter and 9 months' figures were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared on June 26, 1986 to shareholders of record July 7 and distributed July 18, 1986 and a 4-for-3 stock split declared on Dec. 1, 1986 to shareholders of record Dec. 16 to be distributed Jan. 13, 1987.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
Cocaine on Boat Is Seized
description: Customs Service agents seized about 700 pounds of cocaine today from a pleasure boat about 10 miles off Miami and arrested the four people aboard, said a spokesman for the agency, Cliff Stallings. He said agents found the cocaine in special compartments behind walls and under decks on the 38-foot boat, Nice Stuff.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SLASHING-CASE JURY RETIRES
description: The jury in the State Supreme Court trial of a television makeup artist accused in the razor-slashing of a model's face completed its second day of deliberations last night in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. The jury, which was sequestered in a hotel, will resume deliberations at 10 A.M. today. The defendant, Steven Roth, 28 years old of 455 West 34th Street is charged with first degree assault and faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of the attack on the model, Marla Hanson, 25.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CORPORATE MANAGEMENT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Maine Man in Goal Helps Devils Win
description: The Washington Capitals stunned New Jersey with three goals in the game's opening 81 seconds, knocking Alain Chevrier out of the goal, but the Devils recovered marvelously for a 6-4 triumph tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was New Jersey's third consecutive victory.

title: NATION'S 'LONELIEST WOMAN,' DOROTHY MOLTER, IS DEAD AT 79
description: Dorothy Molter, once described as ''the loneliest woman in America,'' died in a log cabin where she lived for 56 years on a wilderness island, officials said today. She was 79 years old.

title: INTERGROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOCH OPPOSED ON HANDLING OF KEY APPEAL
description: In an emerging split with Mayor Koch, the seven other members of the Board of Estimate have decided they want a private law firm to appeal a Federal court ruling that threatens the board's survival.

title: 2 Killed in Punjab
description: Suspected Sikh extremists killed the teen-age son of a police officer and an aide to Punjab state's former education minister in separate incidents today, officials said.

title: SOVIET LIFTS SAKHAROV BANISHMENT AND GRANTS A PARDON TO BONNER
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist who was banished to the city of Gorky for his support of human rights causes, is free to return to Moscow, the Soviet Union announced today.

title:
PATENTS;
New Type Of Plane For NASA
description: A NEW type of aircraft, with a propeller placement that increases the lift while reducing drag, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Models have been built and tested, with considerable improvement in cruise performance and the rate of climb.

title: Doc, Don't Rock the Boat
description: When I became a physician in the 1950's, the fundamental relationship in medicine - doctor and patient - had been unchanged for generations. Only the science was new. In the last few years, however, that core relationship has also been transformed, and not for the better. It is no longer doctor and patient. Now it's doctor, patient and bureaucrat.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. INDIANA PACERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.).

title: DALLAS CHEERS A BANK MERGER
description: When Republicbank and Interfirst, two of the state's biggest banks, announced their merger this week, Wall Street booed. Investors knocked $2.75 off the price of Republicbank's shares, pushing it down to $19. But here in Dallas, city leaders rallied around the deal.

title: From Army to Citadel
description: Charles Taaffe, who served for the last three seasons as offensive coordinator under Coach Jim Young in implementing the wishbone attack so successfully at Army, was named head coach at The Citadel in Charleston, S.C. Taaffe, the 19th head coach of the Bulldogs, succeeds Tom Moore, who resigned under pressure Nov. 24 after The Citadel failed to win a Southern Conference game for the first time in 22 years and finished the season with a 3-8-0 record. Moore's four-year totals were 18-25-1. Taaffe, 36 years old, resigned at West Point Wednesday, but his wife, Jan, will continue to serve as an assistant trainer on Army's athletic staff until the end of the year.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
WALL ST.'S MEMORABLE MINUTE
description: Living up to its name, the ''triple witching hour'' cast a bizarre spell over Wall Street yesterday as stock prices seemingly beat the odds by rising in the final minutes of the most hectic session in history.

title: PHP HEALTHCARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $90,200 for the quarter and $147,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $54,318 for the quarter and $82,622 for the 6 months.

title: LOCAL COSTS DOWN 0.1%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area declined one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CONCERT: THE PHILOMUSICA
description: Olivier Messiaen was only in his early 30's when he composed his ''Quatuor pour la fin du Temps'' in 1941, and he himself may feel that he has progressed much beyond it in the ensuing years. But if he has written a finer, more moving work this listener has yet to hear it. When it was performed as the second and final offering in the New York Philomusica concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, its mystical effect seemed as strong as ever, and the work is 45 years old.

title: Dr. Morton Fried, 63, Anthropology Teacher
description: Dr. Morton H. Fried, a professor of anthropology at Columbia University, died of cardiac arrest Thursday night at his home in Leonia, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: DECLINE EXPECTED IN CHRYSLER OUTPUT
description: Chrysler, the No. 3 American auto maker, will build fewer cars in the January-March quarter than it did a year ago because two of its plants will be out of operation for conversion to build new models, industry sources said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday about Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's arrival for Congressional testimony on arms sales to Iran misidentified the committee that heard him. It was the House Intelligence Committee, not the Senate committee.

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax gains of $134,000 and $271,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: Vice President Bush called on Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, his former aide, to ''tell us the truth'' about their roles in the sale of American arms to Iran and diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Bush, in a speech in Iowa, strongly suggested that the two men should testify regardless of whether they are offered immunity for their statements. President Reagan has declined to ask his former aides to overlook their constitutional rights and instead urged Congressional panels investigating the case to grant Admiral Poindexter and Colonel North limited immunity. Both officers invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination when summoned to testify. [ Page 1. ]

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Canada Prices Up 4.5%
description: Higher food and transportation costs pushed Canada's annual inflation rate in November to its highest level in two and a half years, Statistics Canada said today.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Counsel Selected In Iran Arms Case; Given Wide Power
description: A former Federal judge in Manhattan, Lawrence E. Walsh, was appointed today as special prosecutor in charge of the Iran arms affair and given broad investigative powers.

title: STAGE: TWO BY TALKING BAND
description: In ''Life Simulator,'' the more substantial of two new works being offered at La Mama by Talking Band, the actor-writer Paul Zimet plays Elliot Frank, a contemporary wizard enthralled by his own invention. The clunky gizmo, which resembles a flight simulator cum television set, brings into focus a holographic instructor (Louise Smith), who debates with him in the implacably cool manner of a flight attendant.

title: Career Official in Charge
description: Robert M. Gates, Acting Director of Central Intelligence since William J. Casey was hospitalized, has been Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency since April. Mr. Gates, who is 43 years old, has served in the agency and as a staff member of the National Security Council for 20 years.

title: THE DANCE: DENNIS WAYNE TROUPE
description: The second program presented by Dennis Wayne's Dancers on Tuesday at the Triplex Theater at Manhattan Community College is just the thing for those who like their dance pretty and their dancers personable and beautifully trained. The evening gets off to a friendly start with the dancers introducing themselves, as they do at each program, and so one has the sense of watching friends throughout the evening.

title: A POET: BOLD AND FEARFUL
description: WALLACE STEVENS The Early Years 1879-1923. By Joan Richardson. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

title:
GARDENING;
HOLIDAY PLANTS REQUIRE CARE, TOO
description: IT is not uncommon for Christmas plants to die before the end of the holiday festivities. But they have the inherent ability to last much longer. The secret of prolonging their life is that of providing them with optimum conditions. To do so is not at all difficult. All living plants have certain minimum requirements. Let's examine them one by one.

title: POSTINGS: 192 Units in Canarsie; A Pool Yields to Condos
description: The standard form of housing in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn is still the two- or three-family house in which the owner occupies one floor and rents out the rest. But large down payments, landlord responsibilities and maintenance of such housing have made condominiums an appealing alternative.

title: OPERA: 'DON PASQUALE'
description: Gaetano Donizetti had already composed approximately 70 operas, was wracked with syphilis and near mental collapse when he wrote his comic masterpiece ''Don Pasquale'' in 1842. That the resultant work is so youthful and affirmative, with melodies and characters that have lost none of their vividness in the last 145 years, is something of a miracle. Indeed, one thinks of Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, written on what the composer knew would be his deathbed yet imbued with a graceful, almost teasing wit and serenity.

title: IN CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, 'PLEASE TOUCH'
description: CONNECTICUT'S museums for children offer more than chances to see something.

title: DEATH ON RIKERS I. INVESTIGATED
description: The death of a 25-year-old inmate at Rikers Island last week is being investigated by the police and the Bronx District Attorney's office, authorities said.

title: WOMEN ON ICE
description: ''I thought, 'Here's a bunch of ladies, they'll do it for a week and then give it up,' '' said Michael Bonelli, who coaches a women's ice hockey team at the Harvey School skating rink in Bedford. Instead, the original ''ladies,'' plus about 50 other women 11 to 47 years old, have been playing for more than a year and their progress has been ''fantastic,'' according to Mr. Bonelli, who said they have found a corporate sponsor and their plans include a game at the Meadowlands.

title: 7 LEADERS OF UNOFFICIAL CZECH JAZZ GROUP ARE HELD FOR TRIAL
description: Seven leaders of an unauthorized jazz society are in jail awaiting what their supporters contend will be a show trial intended to control cultural freedom.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GOOD WOMAN. By B. J. Chute. (Vanguard, $14.95.) Long before the homeless became headlines, the image of the bag lady had taken root in fantasy.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: A Sense Of Direction
description: Peter A. Quinn has not only lost track of where he's going, but also of why he's going (''A Sense of Direction,'' About Men, Nov. 9).

title: Lorraine Johnson To Become Bride
description: Lorraine Johnson, chief of the currency verification division of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Peter Donaldson Prentis, an associate vice president for investments with Prudential Bache Securities in New York, plan to be married in February.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW SUSHI BAR IN WHITE PLAINS
description: LONG a familiar sight on White Plains's Hamilton Avenue, the spaceous Japanese steak house, originally occupied by Gissha and then by Karuta, now houses Noda's. The main dining room, just as it did for the restaurant's previous owners, holds the familiar grilling tables around which diner's sit, watching a chef prepare their food from the shelling of shrimp to the frying of rice.

title: KEEPING CHRISTMAS AND HANUKKAH IN PROPER PERSPECTIVE
description: THERE was once a shoe company that sent its two best salesmen to a third-world country.

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: National Geographic's Yukon Passage Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: OPEC Reaches An Agreement
description: A year ago, Saudi Arabia's Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani urged the other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to set off a price war in an attempt to win a bigger share of the world oil market. The result was a precipitous drop in prices, from $28 a barrel in December 1985 to a low of $9 in July.

title: Olivier and Richard III
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice Like A Lion's Roar
description: Benjamin Franklin may have discovered electricity, but Samuel Ramey brought it to the opera stage (''A Voice Like a Lion's Roar,'' by Jane Scovell, Nov. 30).

title: THE SINCEREST FORM OF COMPETITION
description: IF one had to sum up 1986 in personal computing, one would probably call it the ''Year of the Clone.'' In countless businesses throughout the land, the old motto ''You can't be faulted for buying I.B.M.'' has been displaced by ''I saved the company a bundle by buying (fill in the blank) personal computers.''

title: Stamp for Holyoke Founder
description: Mary Lyon, who in 1837 founded the women's school that became Mount Holyoke College, will appear next year on a postage stamp. The 2-cent stamp will be issued Feb. 28, the 190th anniversary of the birthday of the education pioneer. The current 2-cent stamp honors the composer Igor Stravinsky.

title: SHULTZ TO MEET WITH LEADER OF SOUTH AFRICAN GUERRILLA GROUP
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet in Washington next month with Oliver Tambo, president of the outlawed African National Congress, a top State Department official announced today.

title: Britain Decides To Buy American
description: In an action laden with domestic political and economic consequences, Britain decided last week to cut its losses on a $1.3 billion attempt to develop a home-grown alternative to the American surveillance and command planes known as Awacs.

title: Judith Lynn Berman Is Married to Jay S. Goldstein
description: At the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y., last evening Judith Lynn Berman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Berman of Bedford, N.Y., was married to Jay Stuart Goldstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Goldstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, performed the ceremony.

title: AIDS STIRS DONORS TO NEEDIEST
description: The plight of those with AIDS is often cited by contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Chemical to Buy A Texas-Size Bank For $1.1 Billion
description: With Texas banks turning in the performances one would expect in the Texas economy, the Legislature acted this fall to allow their acquisition by out-of-state banks. Last week, the Chemical New York Corporation became the first to move in, announcing that it would buy Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc.

title: THE MIRACULOUS IN THE SERVICE OF THE MUNDANE
description: THERE are times when life flashes out at you so quickly, so blindingly, that you know it happened even though you don't.

title: PORT CHESTER SCHOOLS FACE QUESTIONS ON RACIAL BALANCE
description: PORT CHESTER, a community that has long taken pride in its ethnic diversity, is now facing questions about racial balance in its public schools.

title: The Saudi Link
description: The Saudi Arabian Government has denied having had anything to do with the American arms sales to Iran. But that doesn't seem to square with the discovery by the F.B.I. of Saudi links to a suspect Swiss bank account that may have been used in the complicated transaction; and the denial is taken with a large grain of salt by some Middle East experts who are familiar with Saudi affairs and attitudes.

title: KOCH URGES FASTER FOSTER-PARENT APPROVALS
description: Mayor Koch, acknowledging that the city is not doing enough to place children awaiting foster care into homes, has recommended a drastic reduction in the time it takes to approve foster parents.

title: MAKE LOVE, NOT DINNER
description: ON MODERN MARRIAGE And Other Observations. By Isak Dinesen. Translated by Anne Born. 134 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: JUDGE CURBS PLACING OF HOMELESS IN MIDTOWN
description: A State Supreme Court judge has issued a preliminary injunction blocking the city from placing any more homeless families in a handful of midtown hotels.

title: YES, THERE IS LIFE AFTER LIQUOR ADS
description: WHEN many states raised their legal drinking age to 21 a few years ago, business managers at campus publications began to worry that liquor and beer advertisements, which had long served as the financial backbone of college newspapers, might simply cease.

title: Art
description: As a print medium, the office copier machine has been used by a number of artists. But it's been given new life by the painter David Hockney, as is evident in his series, ''Home Made Prints'' at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, through Jan. 3.

title: ON COLORING FILMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: AFTER being arrested for drunken driving early Friday in Windsor, Ontario, Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings, who had been convicted of a similar charge earlier this year, was suspended indefinitely from the team. . . . Gene Smithson, who was dismissed as Wichita State's basketball coach last March, has reached a $305,000 contract settlement with the school. . . . Louis Espinoza has signed to fight Tommy Valoy for the World Boxing Association junior-featherweight title in a bout in Phoenix Jan. 6. . . . Reggie Jackson lost a bid to dismiss disorderly-conduct charges stemming from a scuffle with an autograph seeker in Milwaukee last May and was ordered to stand trial at a date to be set. . . . Ben Johnson, whose 1986 record included a victory over Carl Lewis in the 100 meters at the Goodwill Games in Moscow, has been ranked No. 1 in the event by Track and Field News. . . . Jack Nicklaus, who hasn't played in the Westchester Classic since 1978, has agreed to play in next year's tournament, set for June 11-14.

title: POLICE SEEK IMMIGRANTS' CONFIDENCE
description: Back in their homelands, some of the children had seen the police beat neighbors with billy clubs and guns. Others had heard of killings, payoffs and disappearances.

title: DOLL BOOKS RE-CREATE FASHIONS
description: A COMPLETE, vintage wardrobe by Coco Chanel for $3.95? A sampling of haute couture from the 50's by Dior, Balenciaga and Charles James for the same low, low price?

title: A CORRECTION
description: A National Notebook item Dec. 7 on an artist-in-residence program at the Regents Park apartment complex in Chicago misidentified the latest recipient of the fellowship. He is Tom Arndt, a photographer.

title: CUOMO SEEKS FIRST UTILITY-RATE CUT SINCE 60'S
description: New Yorkers' utility bills would drop for the first time since the 1960's under a plan proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo to grant consumers some of the savings that utilities will gain from lower interest rates and Federal tax changes.

title: WHY EVERYONE GOES TO THE MALL
description: GREG BERGAN, the man in charge, watched the shoppers filing through the jazzy angles of the Southdale Center, clutching their bulging shopping bags. From the outside, the three-level mall looked like a pile of blocks. Inside, however, everything was engineered to cause people to spend money. The spatial grandeur and the tranquillity acted as a balm to jerky nerves. Christmas ornaments festooned the central walkway, where squalling children were lined up to get their pictures snapped with Santa Claus.

title: FUR COATS, SIZe 6X
description: A GIRL, it seems, is never too young for a fur coat.

title: Amy M. Grabino, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grabino of New York and Orange, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Maude Grabino, to James Kenneth Landau, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton Landau of Rydal, Pa.

title: EXPERIMENTAL WORKS ARE NOT NECESSARILY BUILT TO LAST
description: Some dance works are like articles in an intellectual quarterly. They are interesting when you have them in front of your eyes, but ultimately they are disposable. They are not the equivalent of a classic book, one that you can return to repeatedly. These thoughts came to mind during the recent performances by the company of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane and the one headed by David Gordon in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival.

title: CITY TO OVERHAUL INSPECTOR SYSTEM
description: The city's inspector general system, established by Mayor Koch in 1978 to prevent corruption and waste in government, will be overhauled to correct serious flaws disclosed in the municipal corruption scandal, city officials said yesterday.

title: A TROUBLING DROP IN IMMIGRANT 'QUALITY'
description: THE debate on the hastily enacted Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 has seldom addressed one of the key immigration questions: What is the effect of immigration policy on the job skills of immigrants to the United States? Under our present, nepotistic policy, the workplace ''quality'' of immigrants is declining steadily, putting strong pressures on our already strained welfare system. Obviously, no one wants to return to the racist policies enacted in the 20's, and I want to emphasize strongly that talking about quality is not a racist smokescreen. What we need is a policy that encourages admission of immigrants from anywhere in the world who have the skills to prosper in a post-industrial society.

title: WHOSE FOREIGN POLICY IS IT ANYWAY?
description: A SEASON OF INQUIRY The Senate Intelligence Investigation. By Loch K. Johnson. Illustrated. 317 pp. Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky. $31. PRESIDENTS' SECRET WARS CIA and Pentagon Covert Operations Since World War II. By John Prados. 480 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Court Browns Out Utility Give-Aways
description: It may not save New Yorkers much on their utility bills, but a ruling by the state's highest court last week may have calmed the pulses of a few wrought-up ratepayers. The Court of Appeals declared it unconstitutional for state-regulated utilities to contribute their customers' money to charity.

title: Credit Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan's Doctrine and the Iran Issue
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee met for three weeks about the Iran arms sales and diversion of money to the contras. We learned a great deal but, in the end, nothing really. The who and whom have yet to come out and may never do so. Can we not then pause a moment to ask why all this happened?

title: Ellen F. Ruzinsky Is Married to Evan Jay Lerner
description: At Temple Emanuel of the Pascack Valley in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., last night Ellen Fern Ruzinsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Ruzinsky of Old Tappan, N.J., was married to Evan Jay Lerner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Lerner of Englewood Cliffs and White Meadow Lake, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar, assisted by Cantor Mark Biddelman, performed the ceremony.

title: JAZZ: RONNELL BRIGHT AT PIANO
description: RONNELL BRIGHT, a jazz pianist who has been accompanist to such singers as Sarah Vaughan, Lena Horne, Peggy Lee and Carmen McRae, has a delicately balanced versatility that enables him to play imaginative and relaxed jazz in the guise of dinner music.

title: CUOMO'S RECORD VICTORY OFFICIALLY CONFIRMED
description: Governor Cuomo won 57 of the state's 62 counties and gained a record 64.6 percent of the statewide vote in winning a second term in November, according to the official canvass of the election by the State Board of Elections.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE RICHEST MAN IN THE WORLD: The Story of Adnan Khashoggi. By Ronald Kessler. (Warner, $18.95.) ''For the world's richest man, saving the world was the next logical step in his career.''

title: THE WEEK: WITH ADDED TWISTS, A BIZARRE TALE CONTINUES
description: Sunday: Nicaragua said Sam Nesley Hall, a self-styled counterterrorist and brother of Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, had been arrested at an air base near Managua and accused of spying.

title: A CONNECTICUT GIRL, 15, MAKES WRESTLING HISTORY
description: The end came quickly for Randa Marie Lago, a 15-year-old high school sophomore from Mystic who today became the first girl to wrestle on a boys team in Connecticut.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
LEAVING KNIGHT FOR VALVANO
description: THE atmosphere in Reynolds Coliseum was relaxed as the time drew near for North Carolina State basketball practice to begin. Walker Lambiotte, a black knee brace encasing his right ankle and a white cap set backward on his head, joined a team manager and several football players in launching jump shots. Around them Andy Kennedy and Vinny Del Negro took turns attempting 3-point field goals and guarding one another. At the other basket two forwards, Chucky Brown and Teviin Binns, both native New Yorkers, attempted their most flamboyant power moves.

title: WHEN TV ZOOMS IN ON A WHITE HOUSE CRISIS
description: How well has television been covering the Iran arms affair? All things considered, pretty well.

title:
DINING OUT;
IT'S STILL CHINESE, DESPITE THE NAME
description: WITH a name like Bill & Harry and a slick high-tech interior, who would guess that this East Hanover storefront restaurant is Chinese. It is named for the young owners, Bill Moy and Harry Chu, two engineers originally from Shanghai who opened it eight months ago.

title: A Second Acquittal
description: Battling Federal prosecutors in what his attorneys have characterized as a grudge match, John Z. DeLorean ran the score to 2-0 last week. A Federal jury in Detroit found Mr. DeLorean not guilty of defrauding his failed sports car company of $8.5 million. Mr. DeLorean, a former General Motors Corporation vice president, said the jury's verdict gave him ''a chance to restart my life.''

title: OH NO, - NOT PUBERTY!
description: CHILDREN'S ISLAND By P. C. Jersild. Translated by Joan Tate. 288 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. Cloth, $25.95. Paper, $11.50.

title: LIZA TOUGHS IT OUT
description: THE CENTURY'S DAUGHTER By Pat Barker. 284 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95.

title: 'MARLENE': TALE OF A TALKIE
description: In a stellar career, which spanned the better part of 50 years, Marlene Dietrich earned the adulation of three generations of fans on as many continents. A decade has passed since Miss Dietrich's last public appearance - even her cameo turn in the film ''Just a Gigolo'' some years back was shot within the confines of her Paris apartment - but as the wary subject of Maximilian Schell's ''Marlene,'' the New York Film Critics' choice as the year's best documentary, she is now enjoying one of the strangest triumphs of her singular career.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A VIEW FROM THE STANDS: Of People, Politics, Military Power and the Arts. By John Kenneth Galbraith. Edited by Andrea D. Williams.

title: CONGRESS STANDS READY TO TEST THE EXECUTIVE
description: A MOOD of frustration and uncertainty gripped the capital last week as three Congressional committees tried unsuccessfully to discover the full story behind the Administration's secret arms deal with Iran. The attempts by investigators to follow all the twists in the tale kept running into the same obstacle: the refusal of the two key players, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, to tell what they know. At week's end, Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the Democrat who heads the House Intelligence Committee, said, ''We really don't know the answers to the key questions.''

title: BLACK GROUP IN JEOPARDY
description: THE Afro-American Historical Society in New Haven could soon be forced to close, depriving people of what members say is the chance to learn about the black people of the past who made significant contributions to society.

title: THE SOLO CONCERTO AS A PARADIGM OF SOCIAL STRUGGLE
description: What began as a civilized discourse in the 18th century and became a vehicle for Romantic individuality in the 19th has taken on a political tone in our own age. Our subject is, of course, the solo concerto, with its dual themes of ''the one with the many'' and ''the one against the many.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE REGULATORY WAR OVER A DYING BANK
description: On May 4, 1984, a run began that threatened to wipe out the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, one of the nation's largest banks. A $4.5 billion line of credit from 16 banks, a $2 billion capital infusion from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a guarantee of ''unlimited liquidity'' from the Federal Reserve contained the early damage, but the financial world waited nervously for two months as Federal regulators cast about for a permanent rescue.

title: CAMPAIGNS END WITH SURPLUSES L>By STEVEN HEILBRONNER; States News Service
description: THE Congressional elections this year in Connecticut once again showed how expensive campaigning is. Most of the candidates raised and spent large sums of money. In the end, all the incumbents retained their seats.

title: Today's Sports
description: Football Jets vs. Bengals At Cincinnati, 1 P.M. Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio WABC 770, 1 P.M. Eagles vs. Washington Redskins At Philadelphia, 1 P.M. Television Channel 2, 1 P.M. Dallas Cowboys vs.

title: INDIAN TRIBES SEEK ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: As the Deschutes River flows out of Lake Billy Chinook in central Oregon, it pours through a hyroelectric dam, generating enough electricity to serve more than 2,000 homes a year. Although the Warm Springs hydroelectric plant at the site does not break any record for the power it produces, it represents a milestone for its owners.

title: Trump and Residents Settle a 5-Year Dispute
description: Ending a five-year legal dispute, Donald J. Trump and tenants of a Central Park South building announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement allowing the developer to renovate the structure he once wanted to demolish.

title: MUSIC: THE RIDGE QUARTET IN Y SERIES
description: THE 92d Street Y assembled a formidable assortment of chamber musicians for its program this week, and the Wednesday evening concert was, by and large, a delight. One's reservations had to do with the dubious need to play a mid-1950's pastiche of quintet music by Boccherini when so many fine, unadulterated scores by that composer are waiting to be heard, and the otherwise estimable acoustics of the Kaufmann Concert Hall, which seemed to rob the concluding Mendelssohn Octet of some of its gossamer lightness.

title: JESUS AMONG THE HISTORIANS
description: IN his novel ''Roger's Version,'' John Updike pits a skeptical theologian, desperately clinging to the distant God of Karl Barth, against a conservative and naive divinity student in a fierce debate over whether the existence of God can be proved. As I sit at my desk, looking at a slender volume entitled ''Jesus and the Word'' (1926) by the skeptical and sometimes Barthian Rudolf Bultmann, and the much larger and more confident ''Jesus and Judaism'' (1985) by E. P. Sanders, I wonder whether the 20th century has not witnessed a similar debate over the historical Jesus.

title: Giant Worries
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ROOTING A DOMESTIC POLICY IN THE PAST
description: PEOPLE wise in the ways of Washington say that in publicizing reports on major domestic issues over the last six weeks, the Reagan Administration was trying to shift attention from the controversy over arms sales to Iran.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: ANOTHER HYPOTHESIS ARISES
description: Triad America, the Utah-based investment company of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman and arms dealer who played a key role in financing the American arms sales to Iran, appears to be on the verge of collapse.

title: A FORMULA TO HELP AVOID AN ISLAND ENERGY CRISIS
description: MOST of us - about 70 percent - live and work on Long Island.

title: 30 DIE IN LEBANON AS SYRIANS AND MOSLEMS CLASH
description: At least 30 people were killed and 60 wounded Friday and today as Syrian troops in tanks and armored cars overpowered Moslem fundamentalist militiamen in Tripoli, the police said.

title: KEAN LETTING AIDES CARRY BALL
description: THE first year of Governor Kean's second four-year term is drawing to a close and the atmosphere in the State House is almost serene, despite some serious and nagging problems.

title: TAIWAN'S EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES
description: THE China News, a Taipei newspaper, published a long editorial this month with a stark headline lamenting the ''Worrisome Financial Situation.'' It captured the concern throughout the island over Taiwan's grave economic distress.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CORPORATE ANGELS
description: The article in Guideposts magazine is called ''The Quiet People - At Christmas.'' Barely a page long and unsigned, it tells the story of the Corporate Angel Network, the organization based at the Westchester County Airport that provides free flights across the country on corporate planes for cancer patients needing medical treatment. The article describes the organization's work and notes that ''there is no active fund-raising''; it also provides the address, ''if you feel you can help.''

title: CITY LIBRATY PLAYS TRIBUTE TO WOMEN IN LITERATURE
description: ''LET us now praise famous women,'' says Dr. Lola L. Szladits, curator of the Berg Collection of English and American Literature, backing her words with an appealing new show in the scholarly enclave she bestrides on the third floor of the New York Public Library.

title: NOT ENOUGH JAIL CELLS FOR ALL THE ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: THE new immigration law might result in more arrests of illegal aliens, but there may not be enough jail space to hold them.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A DEPRESION CHRISTMAS: THE DAYS SLIPPED BY AND THERE WAS STILL NO TREE
description: CHRISTMAS during the Depression years of the 1930's was the best day of the year.

title: Parkchester
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Reagan Surgery Is Set for January
description: On Jan. 5, three days after he returns from a week's vacation in California, President Reagan will undergo surgery to relieve ''discomfort'' caused by an enlarged prostate, the White House announced last week.

title: A REASON FOR SHORTAGE OF SOCIAL WORKERS
description: The Dec. 7 article ''Shortage of Social Workers?'' glossed over economic factors that would preclude college students from entering social work. The altruistic values of the 1960's, when it was far more affordable to live on Long Island, have been replaced by the cold reality that Long Island is the most expensive region of the country in which to live.

title: A DISCOUNTER WHO COUNTS ON CONSUMER RESEARCH
description: JOSEPH E. ANTONINI could have stepped out of one of those classic American rags-to-riches tales, where the young hero starts out as a humble stock boy, works just a little harder than everyone else, climbs over all the obstacles and - lo and behold - ends up at the top of the heap.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COLLEGE NEWSPAPERS
description: OFF campus, college newspapers have never been taken too seriously, except perhaps as a training ground for daily newspapers.

title: REAGAN'S REMINDER OF SEASON
description: President Reagan said today that the American family was ''under virtual attack'' and people should not take society's basic social unit for granted amid the holiday rush.

title: Top Carleton College Official Is Named to Head Skidmore
description: The interim president of Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., has been appointed president of Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Without an Oil-Import Duty, OPEC's Going to Get Us Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Allene Russell, a Teacher, Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Allene Russell to Dr. Richard Norris Pierson 3d, the son of Dr. Pierson Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Mrs. Richard T. Wright of Old Lyme, Conn., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Russell of Chestnut Hill, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
