title: Once More, a President Who Would Be King
description: To the Editor:

title: Environment Nobel?
description: To the Editor:

title: VOLUNTEER HOT LINE AT YALE ANSWERS QUESTIONS ABOUT CANCER
description: VOLUNTEERS who answer the telephone information line at the Yale Cancer Information Service still talk about May 1985. That was when the WCBS-TV meteorologist, Dr. Frank Field, gave out their hot line telephone number during a broadcast, resulting in 2,215 calls requesting information.

title: ON COLORING FILMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTS UP TO LOUISIANA'S CHIEF
description: State legislators, unable to decide how to deal with fiscal trouble caused by the depression in the oil industry, went home today after giving Gov. Edwin W. Edwards authority to cut the state budget.

title: IRAN DETAINS ITALIANS FOR A DAY
description: Six Italians were detained for almost 24 hours in Teheran this week when port workers in Genoa blocked the departure of an Iranian ship, the Italian authorities said.

title: Catherine L. Murphy To Wed David Lione
description: The engagement of Catherine Louise Murphy to David Cordiner Lione has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Murphy of West Hartford, Conn. Mr. Lione is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Lione Jr. of Rowayton, Conn.

title: IN A GAMBLE, BOKASSA TRIAL IS BROADCAST LIVE
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa sat in a hard-backed wooden chair today and squirmed under hard questioning from a judge.

title: POLICE OFFICIAL, REMOVED FROM ULSTER INQUIRY, QUITS HIS POST
description: A police official, after quitting his post, said today that only history would show whether a conspiracy forced his removal from an inquiry into purported police brutality in Northern Ireland.

title: AYCKBOURN'S 'ABSURD' STAGED IN FAIRFIELD
description: ''ABSURD PERSON SINGULAR,'' by the English playwright Alan Ayckbourn, appears to be just the show for the holidays. The play takes place over three Christmases: the last one, this one and the next one. And, ostensibly, it's a comedy; a farce, in fact.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JUGGLERS IN POMONA ''The Flying Karamazov Brothers, while neither Russian nor brothers, are certainly the best jugglers anyone would want to see,'' wrote Frank Rich in a New York Times review.

title: 'MR. MALE' IN DEBUT
description: TOMORROW, if all goes as planned, Eugene Brown of Lincroft will compete against men from the 49 other states for the first Mr. Male America title.

title: Bokassa, on Trial, Blames Ex-Aides
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa once spent $50 million to have himself crowned Emperor of the huge, sparsely populated country he had renamed the Central African Empire.

title: College Football; Mississippi Wins
description: Mark Young, a sophomore quarterback and J. R. Ambrose, a junior flanker, set Independence Bowl passing and receiving records, but Mississippi needed Bryan Owen's tie-breaking 48-yard field goal early in the final period to defeat Texas Tech, 20-17, tonight.

title: Dance
description: Bebe Miller is a performer for the most hedonistic of dancegoers. To see her dance her solos is to see performing that is exceptional both for its sensuousness and its sense of measure.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball Hawks 111, Spurs 96: Cliff Levingston scored 6 of his 12 points during a 13-0 first-quarter run last night that put Atlanta ahead to stay. Levingston broke a 16-16 tie with a tip-in and added two more baskets in the streak, which also saw Randy Wittman contribute 5 points. Dominique Wilkins led the Hawks with 28 points and Wittman added 27. It was the 10th home-court victory in 11 outings for the Hawks, who broke a two-game losing streak.(AP) Mavericks 130, Lakers 119: At Dallas, Rolando Blackman scored 39 points to lead Dallas to its first victory in three meetings with the Lakers this season. The Lakers played without Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who returned to Los Angeles earlier in the day because of recurring corneal erosion syndrome in his right eye. Abdul-Jabbar, who had started all of Los Angeles's games before last night, was averaging 17.8 points a game. He was expected to be sidelined for two to three days.(AP) Pistons 98, 76ers 88: Vinnie Johnson scored 14 of his team-high 18 points in the fourth quarter to lead Detroit to its fifth straight victory. The Pistons trailed, 71-66, after three periods, but outscored Philadelphia by 12-0 in the first five minutes of the fourth quarter to take a 78-71 lead. Philadelphia, playing at home, could get no closer than 5 points the rest of the way. The loss was Philadelphia's fifth in six games. (UPI) Jazz 91, Bulls 89: Karl Malone hit a 12-foot jump shot with 12 seconds left to cap a fourth-quarter rally for Utah at Chicago.

title: Tax Amnesty In Philadelphia
description: ON Philadelphia billboards, brochures, trash trucks and television and radio announcements, the message is loud and clear: Those who owe city taxes had better pay up while the current tax amnesty is still on.

title: FROM SCHOOL TO MALL, FLU'S ON THE MARCH
description: INFLUENZA has reached epidemic proportions in Connecticut, state health officials say, and it is likely many of the people jamming shopping malls have been spreading more than holiday cheer.

title: GORBACHEV ORCHESTRATES NEW VARIATIONS ON SOVIET THEME
description: FREEDOM from exile for the dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov. The end of the Soviet nuclear testing moratorium. The ouster of a non-Russian Politburo member and the open reporting of a subsequent anti-Russian riot in Soviet Central Asia. These extraordinary events last week reflected the growing power and boldness of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, although the Soviet leader was invisible most of the week.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DRAGON PORTFOLIO. By Richard Hoyt. (Tor, $15.95.) It is hard to imagine an author pulling off a marriage ceremony between the living and the dead, but this is merely one (and not even the most audacious) of the ploys Richard Hoyt manages with aplomb in his sixth novel.

title: A HERO IN THE WORST OF US
description: THE LAST WORTHLESS EVENING Four Novellas & Two Stories. By Andre Dubus. 214 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: GETTING TO KNOW THE PHOTOGRAPHIC CHRISTMAS GIFT
description: SUPPOSE, just suppose, that Santa leaves a new camera under your tree this week. What is the first thing you should do, besides give your personal Santa a thank-you kiss?

title: THE STRUGGLE TO PROVIDE HOME HEALTH CARE
description: You are to be commended for your thorough and thought-provoking article ''Hospitals Extend Care Into Homes'' [ Nov. 16 ] . As executive director of V.N.A. Care (formerly V.N.A. of Stamford), I underscore the fact that shorter hospital stays coupled with increased Medicare restrictions for home care services is the daily dilemma faced by home health agencies.

title: A SUBSTANTIAL 'POP' HART SAMPLING AT RUTGERS'S ZIMMERLI
description: GEORGE Overbury ''Pop''

title: WITH SOVIET BLOC AID, NICARAGUA IS BUILDING ITS FIRST LARGE EASTERN PORT
description: On this windswept and isolated Caribbean peninsula, the Sandinista Government is building a deepwater port that Nicaraguans have dreamed of for decades.

title: VIEWERS SUPPORT INSTANT REPLAY
description: If football fans had their way, the National Football League would continue to use the new instant replay system next season, despite feelings to the contrary by some of the 28 N.F.L. clubs.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: ASSESSING THE U.S RATIONLE
description: The Reagan Administration has exaggerated the Soviet Union's ability to invade Iran, according to a study made public this week by a Washington-based research group.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: New Orleans; Aquarium Plan Moves Ahead
description: THIS is the dawning of the age of the Aquarium in New Orleans.

title: OVERSIGHT CAUSES BRIEF SCARE ON TEST AIRPLANE
description: The crew on the experimental plane Voyager forgot to add oil to their rear engine today, causing an abrupt rise in engine temperature that gave them the biggest scare of their weeklong effort to become the first plane to circle the globe without stopping for fuel.

title: Rep. Wright Suggests Pardons by President
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who will be the Speaker of the House in the new Congress, says he will advise President Reagan to grant executive pardons to two key figures in the Iran arms affair so they will tell their stories.

title: ISLANDERS DOMINATE RANGERS
description: The Islanders rebounded from their worst defeat of the season two nights ago to score a 5-2 triumph over the Rangers tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: 'WASHINGTON' PREPARES TO CROSS THE DELAWARE
description: WHAT started out 33 years ago as a personal gesture by a theatrical producer and six friends to re-enact George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River on Christmas Day in 1776 has turned into an annual pageant involving 200 costumed volunteers.

title: Jennifer D. Beal Is Bride Of Clyde Cebron Tuggle
description: Jennifer Drew Beal and Clyde Cebron Tuggle, second-year students at the Yale Divinity School, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Concord, Mass.

title: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust
description: Now that a former chief of French intelligence has disclosed the existence of 10 tons of largely unexamined war documents from the French security police, the French Government is transferring them to the army's historical archives, which means they will be legally sealed from scrutiny for 60 years, as Judith Miller points out. In England, none of the records of the S.I.S. (British World War II intelligence service) has yet been declassified.

title: MEESE IS REPORTED TO SUGGEST MEDICINE IMPAIRED REAGAN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Congressional committee that President Reagan might not remember approving the first shipment of American arms to Iran because he was recovering from an operation at the time and may have been taking medication, according to a member of the committee.

title: Christmas in the Philippines
description: The Christmas season has a deep and joyous meaning for many in the Philippines, Asia's only predominantly Christian nation. Beginning Dec. 1, with the hanging of lanterns called parols, the celebration stretches well into January.

title: New Taiwan Influenza Virus Poses Risk for Young People
description: A new Taiwan influenza virus has made its way into the United States, striking children and young adults in 22 states, Federal health officials say.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EARTH ABIDETH. By George Dell. (Ohio State University, $14.95.) ''The Earth Abideth'' is a novel both of and from another time.

title: Nita H. Salzman Plans To Be Married in May
description: Nita Helene Salzman, a fourth-year candidate for a joint M.D. and Ph.D. degree, and Bruce Philip Himelstein, a fourth-year medical student, both at New York University, are planning a May wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Salzman of Maplewood, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morgan Y. Himelstein of Garden City, L.I.

title: STEINBRENNER STIRS QUESTIONS WITH REJECTION OF MORRIS BID
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER paid Britt Burns $750,000 this year for not throwing one pitch. He paid John Montefusco $966,667 for pitching 12Y innings. He paid Al Holland $450,000 for throwing 40Z innings and then a tantrum when he was released. Burns, Montefusco and Holland will not be on the Yankees' payroll next year. Their absence will make the payroll lighter by $2,166,667. Steinbrenner could have had Jack Morris for less than that.

title: Hillary Martin Is Engaged To Bruce Leonard Kanfer
description: Hillary Thomas Martin and Bruce Leonard Kanfer plan to be married May 9, the mother of the future bride, Mrs. John H. Martin of Woodstock, Vt., has announced. Mr. Kanfer is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kanfer of Lauderdale Lakes, Fla.

title: THE DEATH AND LIFE OF MINIMALISM
description: Love it or loathe it, Minimalist music, with its patterned repetition, seemingly endless length and stubborn refusal to come to conventional climaxes, is everywhere these days. Right now, the fifth act of Robert Wilson's controversial ''CIVIL warS,'' a full-blown opera with music by Philip Glass, is in the midst of a run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But no matter where one turns, Minimalism is being enjoyed by eager young devotees and denounced by rival composers and unsympathetic critics.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SAKHAROV PHONE INTERVIEW
description: Following is a transcript of a telephone interview today with Andrei D. Sakharov from Gorky, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:

title: HIGH ACHIEVERS
description: In the United States, as elsewhere in the West, players are pretty much on their own, but a new effort to provide assistance in development - the Samford Chess Fellowship - has just been instituted.

title: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust
description: I recently returned from visiting West Germany and Austria, as did your correspondent. I also visited East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia.

title: PAKISTAN'S CABINET RESIGNS AFTER RIOTS
description: The Pakistani Cabinet resigned today in the aftermath of rioting in Karachi that has more than 160 people dead and hundreds injured.

title: A Voice Like A Lion's Roar
description: Samuel Ramey is a perfectly splendid singer, but to claim, as Jane Scovell does, that he ''has won the international stardom enjoyed by only two other basses in this century - Feodor Chaliapin and Ezio Pinza,'' is absurd, as I'm sure Mr. Ramey would be the first to acknowledge. The following short list of those I have heard at the Met over the years occurred to me as I was reading: Cesare Siepi, George London, Hans Hotter (all bass-baritones, like Ramey and Pinza), Emanuel List, Salvatore Baccaloni, Fernando Corena, Jerome Hines and Alexander Kipnis, perhaps the greatest of them all. MAURICE $:EE Cranbury, N.J.

title: Tar Heel at Home
description: AS the tailback for North Carolina, Derrick Fenner was the leading rusher in the Atlantic Coast Conference this season, but when the Tar Heels go to Hawaii for the Aloha Bowl, Fenner won't be with them. In announcing that Fenner had been suspended from the team for academic deficiencies, Coach Dick Crum said that despite his problems Fenner could have been allowed to play under National Collegiate Athletic Association guidelines, but not under North Carolina's. ''At this institution,'' Crum said, ''academics are also important, and something had to be done about his current situation.''

title: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust
description: Judith Miller writes that Jews seem to be one of the few people who have a collective memory. It appears that Jews also believe in a collective feeling of guilt.

title: SEEING MORE THAN BANGKOK: A BRIEF GUIDE
description: In 1987, Thailand will celebrate its biggest royal festival year in more than half a century of constitutional monarchy. On Dec. 5, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who has reigned since 1950, will reach his 60th birthday. Events will be nationwide, beginning Oct. 16 with a royal barge procession on Bangkok's Chao Phraya River. These magnificent slender boats, built to transport royalty in a country of rivers and canals, are now seldom seen outside their storage wharf. But they have been refurbished for this event.

title: ELDERLY RESUMING A CHRISTMAS CHORE
description: On her 76th birthday Katherine O'Connor received dozens of phone calls from children saying that they loved her. And not a single child knew who she really was.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Out
description: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, the 39-year-old Los Angeles center in his 18th National Basketball Association season, missed last night's game in Dallas and will not be able to play until at least Tuesday, the Lakers said yesterday, because of a painful cornea disorder.

title: LaRouche Aides Face New Charges
description: Three defendants were added last week to the roster of associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. who are facing charges in connection with his fund-raising efforts. A Federal grand jury in Boston said the three had conspired to ''obstruct and impede'' its investigation, which had led to the indictment of 10 individuals, two corporations and three campaign committees.

title: Coach Steps Down
description: AFTER seeing his team get off to a 1-6 start, Ron Kornegay, the Monmouth College basketball coach, has decided that someone else might have a better chance to change things. ''The program needs to go in another direction,'' the 39-year-old coach said as he stepped down and turned the team over to his assistant, Ron Krayel, 41, who will serve as interim coach.

title: YANKS, WHITE SOX REPORTED IN TRADE
description: The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox are at it again. The teams that seem to be engaged in a ceaseless series of transactions have made another, a source familiar with the deal said yesterday. This one has Scott Nielsen, who led the Yankees in shutouts this year, and Mike Soper, an infielder, going to Chicago for Pete Filson, the American Association pitcher of the year.

title: HELP FOR CONTROLLING FAMILY VIOLENCE
description: The educational program referred to in Carolyn Battista's article ''Family Violence Law Has 'Growing Pains' but Is Changing Attitudes'' [ Nov. 23 ] is just getting under way across the state. An important fact not mentioned by the article was that people may attend the classes voluntarily - they need not be arrested first.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: DADDY WAS A NUMBER RUNNER, by Louise Meriwether. (Feminist Press, $8.95.) The central character in this novel of ghetto life in 1930's Harlem is 12-year-old Francie Coffin, whose out-of-work father runs numbers to support his family. Francie is ''a remarkable heroine'' and her father ''becomes, with Louise Meriwether's skillful handling, a figure of heroic proportions,'' Paule Marshall said in The Book Review in 1970. ''The novel's greatest achievement lies in the strong sense of black life that it conveys; the vitality and force behind the despair.'' AN OMELETTE AND A GLASS OF WINE, by Elizabeth David. (Penguin, $8.95.) The English author Eliza-beth David is believed by many to be the most impor tant living writer on food, our reviewer, Charles Rosen, said last year. Her position, he added, is confirmed with the appearance of this collection of her food writing over the previous 35 years. While her style is ''serviceable, plain and a little brusque,'' he said, she is ''a writer of pastoral . . . a literary form that evokes a golden age, a time when life was uncomplicated and pleasures were simple. . . . Books like Elizabeth David's are the last gasp of the Romantic movement.'' THE FAT WOMAN'S JOKE, by Fay Weldon. (Academy Chicago, $5.95.) Betrayed by her husband, diet-conscious Esther Wells retreats to a basement hideaway and goes on an eating binge in Fay Weldon's novel of mid-1960's English domestic life. In 1968 our reviewer, Martin Levin, called it ''a delicious tour de force that the author carries off elegantly.''

title: Miss Kass Weds F.S. Spike
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last night Sharon Mindy Kass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Kass of Merrick, L.I., was married to Frederic Scott Spike, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Spike of Philadelphia.

title: 2 HOUSE MEMBERS CALL FOR OUTSIDE INQUIRY ON F.A.A. DOCTOR
description: Two members of the House have asked the the Federal Aviation Administration to create an independent panel to decide whether the agency's chief doctor should stay on the job.

title: A DEMOCRATIC JUDGE OPTS FOR STATE COURT
description: THREATENED with defeat at the polls next November, the most prominent female judge on Long Island, Marie G. Santagata of County Court, the supervising judge of criminal courts in Nassau County, has taken the unusual step of seeking and receiving an appointment as a judge of the State Court of Claims.

title: FANNY GARB IS STILL GOING STRONG AT 90
description: Older players who have been bridge devotees for half a century or so have seen many changes in the laws of the game. Sometimes they are a little out of date, applying the laws of an earlier period by an unwritten grandfather clause. More rarely, as in the diagramed deal, out-dated laws can be invoked by a tolerant director.

title: SELLING EVERYTHING AND ANYTHING VIA THE MAIL
description: IN the new Center for Direct Marketing on the campus of New York University in Greenwich Village, a communications studio furnished with state-of-the-art audio-visual equipment bears the name of Wesley T. Wood of Laurel Hollow.

title: ONCE IN LOVE WITH EMMA
description: THE PERPETUAL ORGY Flaubert and Madame Bovary. By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen Lane. 240 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: NEW IMMIGRATIONAL LAW STIRS FEAR
description: THE students in Dr. Estrella Pannuto's Thursday night class in English as a second language at the Spanish-American Community Center in Hempstead are upset. They have been hearing disturbing rumors about the immigration law signed by President Reagan Nov. 6.

title: OWNER TAKES EXCEPTION TO A RULE FORCING HIS HOUSE TO HIDE ITS HEAD
description: OREST BLISS applied to build a house on Meadow Lane, off Dune Road in the Village of Southampton, in 1978. It was to be the first house in the area designed by the award-winning Bridgehampton architect Norman Jaffe, who is noted for his modern designs.

title: Player Fails Steroid Test
description: One Arizona State football reserve has tested positive for anabolic steroids and will not play in the Rose Bowl game against Michigan, school officials say.

title: BUT HE ASSERTS HE AND REAGAN WILL REBOUND WHEN TRUTH IS TOLD
description: Vice President Bush has acknowledged that because of the Iranian arms controversy he is ''no longer the front-runner'' in the race for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: FOREVER IN MIND
description: RECENTLY I sat on a quiet beach, watching the water and enjoying the late afternoon sun. A father and two small children approached the water's edge. ''Julie, Jimmie, come sit on the rocks,'' Dad commanded. ''I want to take a picture.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''PEOPLE have a very strong feeling about living here,'' said Supervisor Lois Q. Lippmann of North Salem.

title: 8-YEAR FIGHT ON 150 FEET
description: A 150-FOOT-LONG strip of land running along Rockaway Turnpike, from the back of a professional building to the intersection at Central Avenue in the Village of Lawrence, is the center of an eight-year-long dispute involving the village, the strip's owner and Nassau County.

title: ON RURAL ROUTES THROUGH THAILAND
description: Every now and then, in a moment of uncommon quiet, the distinctive wail of a rural love song rises from some unseen corner of Bangkok, and the urge to get out of town becomes overwhelming.

title: JETS WANT A GOOD GAME AS MUCH AS A VICTORY
description: THIS has been a head-scratching week for the Jets. They are a team granted a reprieve, learning they had made the playoffs a day after they dropped their fourth straight game. In fact, they even can win the American Conference East title.

title: FAMILY'S SUIT RAISES ISSUE OF WHAT A PET DOB IS WORTH
description: HE is so deaf that family members have to jump up and down to get his attention, and his arthritis is so advanced he can no longer negotiate the stairs. But Tucker, a mix of collie, German shepherd and Other, has become in his 15 years with the Zager family in Pleasantville an ''old family friend.'' The Zagers hope the New York State Supreme Court will agree.

title: OPEC, IN OIL OUTPUT CUT, TO LIFT BVARREL PRICE TO $18
description: After days of acrimonious deliberations, the accord reached at dawn today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries - to cut oil production and to raise prices quickly to $18 a barrel -was in line with previous reports from private ministerial sessions.

title: Dore Hammond Plans To Wed James Normile
description: A Feb. 7 wedding is planned by Dorita Hammond and James Sheehy Normile, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. B. Clinton Hammond of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced. Mr. Normile is a son of Margaret Sheehy Normile of Hampton Bays, L.I., and Clearwater, Fla., and the late Daniel Francis Normile.

title: Vast Wilderness Saved in Florida
description: It has worked to preserve tropical forests in Costa Rica, bison in North Dakota, piping plover and ospreys on Long Island, bluestem grass in Oklahoma and blueback char, a rare trout, in Maine.

title: Nanette S. Heilbrun Plans To Marry Robert Saroga
description: The engagement of Nanette Streit Heilbrun to Robert Saroga has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Heilbrun of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: CAROUSEL CREATURES STILL CAST THEIR SPELL
description: Horses prance through the lobby of the Paine Webber building. Tigers prowl, deer leap, a rabbit scampers, a cat jumps and a pig vaults. Most of the menagerie of carved carousel animals exhibited there, however, are strutters - and that includes a zebra, goat, chicken, dog, giraffe, camel and ostrich. Only the big brown bear seems immobile, his shaggy head cocked, his eyes shining and his weighty limbs stock still, on hold, perhaps, for hugging.

title: STUDENTS PLACED BY JOBS PROGRAM
description: IN the basement of the Westchester County Urban League headquarters in White Plains, Marie learned the skills necessary to propel her from her former job as a temporary secretary to a position as a data processor for a White Plains law firm.

title: THE JOYS OF NOT KNOWING TOO MUCH
description: There are people who take up going to concerts and listening to recordings with a singleness of purpose and fervor that would not have been out of place in the Children's Crusade. Rather often, these are authentic melomaniacs, amateur musicians or metamusicians whose whole beings tremble at the sound of music and want nothing more than to allow it to possess them, body and spirit. However, the ranks of the afflicted include many more whose plight is less explainable: people who took piano lessons as children and were quickly persuaded to give up, failed voice students or literary critics who have lost interest in books and turned to record connoisseurship as a substitute.

title: CHIRAC WINS A BITTER CLASH WITH MITTERRAND
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac won a bitter political test of strength with President Francois Mitterrand today.

title: About Chaps
description: To the Editor:

THE county government will be spending more than $1.6 million next year to tell the public what it is up to. The money, included in County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed $774 million budget for 1987, goes to finance his Public Affairs Office, a county information center and public-information offices for various county divisions, including the Board of Legislators, Westchester Community College, the Westchester County Medical Center, and the Departments of Health, Social Services and Transportation.

title: SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE TO VOTE ON POLYGRAPH BAN FOR EMPLOYEES UNDER 21
description: WITH the increasing use of lie detector tests by private employers on Long Island, officials in Suffolk County are grappling with questions about what limits, if any, should be placed on the tests.

title: Once More, a President Who Would Be King; No Profits to C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
CONSUMMATE DESIGNER-CRAFTSMAN
description: IN RENE LALIQUE, uncommon talents combined to produce a prodigious, glittering output of innovative design that brought quality out of the salon and into the marketplace.

title: A MENU WORTHY OF EXPLORATION
description: WINFIELD'S, a new contemporary American restaurant in Glen Cove, is one to watch. The food is stylish and inventive and, while the cooking is not without flaws, it is on the right track.

title: YOUTH HELD IN 8 FIRES IN MAINE
description: A 15-year-old Madison High School sophomore has been charged with setting one fire and is a suspect in seven more.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE CHRISTMAS SPIRIT
description: OH, come all ye to Lyndhurst. The halls of the great Gothic mansion are decked with greenery. Santa has brought toys and goodies in his sleigh to place under the tree in the parlor. And this afternoon, yuletide carols will be sung by a choir.

title: Bad Sports?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Topics: Bold Crossings; Peace Exercise
description: Peace, Jean Mayer acknowledges, has become a flabby notion, and he would like to firm it up. So Mr. Mayer, the president of Tufts University, got university leaders from around the world together to try to arrive at some common understandings about peace and international security.

title: THE CASE FOR HAVING SEAT BELTS ON SCHOOL BUSES
description: ''THANK goodness they were wearing seat belts.'' Capt. Michael Pocchio of the Newark Police Department made that statement last March, following a collision between a school bus and a Newark police car. None of the eight children on the bus was injured, despite the fact that the vehicle turned over on its side.

title: BY VAN AND SATELLITE, LOCAL NEWSCASTS ARE GOING NATIONAL
description: Last August, when a deranged postal worker went on a shooting spree in Edmond, Okla., a nearby television station drove its satellite news-gathering van to the scene and fed live reports the same day to 19 other stations around the country.

title: Sorting Out the Barrage of Airline Promotions
description: Almost daily for many people the mail brings some sort of enticement to travel.

title: Pop Music
description: Of all of the great pre-rock songwriters, none wrote lyrics that speak more directly to the emotions than Lorenz Hart who was born in 1895 and died at the early age of 48. ''The Complete Lyrics of Lorenz Hart,'' a glorious new book, edited by the lyricist's sister-in-law Dorothy Hart, with Robert Kimball and published by Alfred A. Knopf, collects 650 of his song lyrics, 300 of them never before published. The appearance of the book has inspired two different cabaret shows in Manhattan. At Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, the club's ongoing ''All Hart'' tribute will continue through the end of the year with the singer-author-raconteur-disc jockey Jonathan Schwartz serving as host and jazz-singer Mark Murphy, the special guest.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LAST ROMANTICS. By Caroline Seebohm. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The English novelist Vera Brittain once remarked that Somerville, her alma mater and Oxford University's most academically distinguished women's college, might be better remembered for the novelists it nurtured than the scholars it produced.

title: THE BINGHAMS, AFTER THE FALL
description: ON the Bingham estate overlooking the Ohio River outside Louisville, Ky., Barry Bingham Sr. and Barry Bingham Jr. live in houses separated by a short walk across a tended lawn. But each rarely crosses that short space to visit the other's home. ''It's like the green line in Beirut separating the Christians and the Moslems,'' said Joan Bingham, an in-law.

title: KING OLIVER'S SPIRIT, DAVY TOUGH'S DECLINE
description: AMERICAN MUSICIANS Fifty-six Portraits in Jazz. By Whitney Balliett. 415 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: SOVIET PROJECTS DEBATED IN PRESS
description: As the Gorbachev administration in the Soviet Union appears to loosen controls and to encourage more open discussion of public issues, an increasing number of Government-approved construction projects have come into question in the press.

title: THE RELEASE OF SAKHAROV: ITS BROADER IMPLICATIONS
description: Western diplomats said today that the Soviet decision to let Andrei D. Sakharov return to Moscow reflected a more flexible policy on human rights and tacit acknowledgment that the treatment of dissidents was linked to other issues like trade and arms control.

title: Terri Seligman Marries
description: The marriage of Terri Jean Seligman, an associate at the New York law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher, and George David Hagen, a screen writer, took place last night at the Loft at 126 Fifth Avenue. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony. Ms. Seligman, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Seligman of New York. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. David Hagen of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: FOR AMATEURS, AN ORCHESTRA FOR LEARNING
description: IF you are a string player in search of an orchestra but do not like the idea of auditions, take heart.

title: NATURALIST REFLECTS LESSONS OF 30 YEARS
description: HIS 30 years with the White Memorial Conservation Center in Litchfield have convinced Gordon Loery that ''the more you understand wildlife, the more intelligent you can be in their conservation.''

title: MANY STATES MOVE TO CURB DISPOSAL OF CHEMICALS
description: Inspired by California voters' approval of a sweeping new law regulating the disposal of toxic chemicals, environmentalists and political leaders are pressing for enactment of similar controls elsewhere in the nation.

title: Barbara Cushman Marries Executive
description: Barbara McFadden Cushman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. McFadden of New Canaan, Conn., and Anthony A. Sirna 3d, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Sirna of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: ANOTHER RETREAT FROM LOCALISM?
description: COMMUNITY control of New York City's public schools comes and goes. A generation ago, after an extraordinarily bitter teachers' strike, came the elected community school boards, which share responsibility with the central Board of Education; now the president of the board, Robert F. Wagner Jr., contends that the system ''in some ways has led to the worst of all worlds.''

title: Talking: Co-ops; Corporate Purchases Are Eased
description: BEGINNING in January, corporations will be able to own cooperative apartments without endangering the tenant-shareholders' special tax status, a change that raises a host of new issues for co-op boards and their shareholders.

title: UEBERROTH TESTIMONY SOUGHT
description: Acting at the request of the baseball players' union, the arbitrator hearing the free-agent conspiracy case has asked the owners' side to produce Commissioner Peter Ueberroth as a witness. Ueberroth, the arbitrator said after hearing arguments Friday, has important, necessary and relevant information in the case and should testify.

title:
INVESTING;
HOW THE PROS WILL INVEST IN 1987
description: PROFESSIONAL investors rarely agree on anything. And when it comes to managing their own investments their choices for 1987 run the gamut.

title: Silver Shines Bright
description: HEARING SILVER experts describe their prized pieces is not so very different from listening to an architect discuss the details of a room or a furniture dealer talk about the lines of a chair. Words like shape and proportion invariably crop up in the conversation. So do such familiar ornamental motifs as swags or grapes, shells or beads. Indeed, earmarks of any particular design style recur in everything from architectural elements and wallpaper patterns to the designs of tables and chairs, spoons and forks.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Fear Rises on Home-to-Office Conversions
description: THE 182,000-square-foot Nassau County District Courthouse now under construction in the Village of Hempstead, due for completion in the spring, has already attracted several law firms to the village.

title: BREAKFAST REVIVAL IN THE BAY AREA
description: It's about time. Breakfast is finally making a comeback. While the revolution in American cooking swept into kitchens all over the country, transforming dinner and lunch menus, nobody had time to consider the first meal of the day. The restaurant breakfast just continued on its stodgy way. Glitzy brunch got all the press, but take away the bloody mary, and it's breakfast as usual: homestyle fries dumped straight from the freezer bag onto the hot griddle, rubbery scrambled eggs and throwaway toast.

title: Humbled G.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Bus Crash Kills 3
description: A bus carrying soldiers home for the holidays fell into a ravine today, killing three paratroopers and injuring the other 38 paratroopers aboard and the civilian driver, the police said. The accident occurred near Loja, 30 miles east of Granada, the police said.

title: SLUDGE PLAN LIKELY TO MEET OPPOSITION
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is reviewing its draft proposal for a statewide Sludge Management Plan that professes support for reuse and resource recovery but would require few changes in the handling of sewage residues.

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: The Last Metro Starring Catherine Deneuve, Heinz Bennent, Gerard Depardieu. Directed by Francois Truffaut.1980 Key Video. 135 minutes. $59.98.

title: HOSPITAL WORKERS TRAIN FOR NEW JOBS
description: THE Professional Development Center at Westchester Community College and five hospitals in the county have developed a series of courses to train hospital workers for new careers in medical transcription, medical coding and other medical clerical fields.

title: CLASSIC FLOW OF LUMBER HALTS, FLUME AND ALL
description: The Broughton Lumber Company's nine-mile-long lumber chute, thought to be the last flume still in use in the United States, ceased operating today.

title: Monica J. Rich Plans To Wed David Sturm
description: Monica Jane Rich, an architect with SKM and Partners, and David Carl Sturm, a compliance counsel for the Commodity Exchange, both in New York, plan to be married in February. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rich of New York.

title: CLASS RANKINGS FALL INTO DISFAVOR IN GREAT NECK
description: MANY students, parents and teachers have for years criticized standardized college admission examinations, such as the Scholastic Aptitude Test, as superficial and unfair. By attaching a number to such an elusive quality as college preparedness, the critics say, the College Board tests create an illusion of objectivity.

title: CHILDREN GET EXTRA HELP ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: At the age of 11, Aisha Evans has learned that ''even if you don't agree with everything people say, you can still try to understand them.''

title: IRANIAN FAMILY SET FOR HANUKKAH HERE
description: THEY asked to be known only as Manoucher and Sarah.

title: HOLIDAY APPEAL: REMEMBERING NEEDIEST
description: The two-story house that Sarah J. lives in looks like most of the others in her quiet Staten Island neighborhood. A smooth concrete walk slices through the lawn to the front door, and inside, Christmas ornaments hang from the branches of an evergreen and stockings dangle from a railing.

title: GUARINI NOMINATED TO BUDGET PANEL
description: REPRESENTATIVE Frank J. Guarini is likely to become New Jersey's sole representative on the powerful House Budget Committee when the 100th Congress convenes on Jan. 6.

title: IN A WORD, A COACH PROVES HARD TO FIND
description: ''There aren't a lot of people around who have a passion for the whole thing,'' said Edward Hart, principal of Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, referring to the difficulties the school has faced in finding a coach for its debating team.

title: Anne H. Casey Plans to Marry
description: James L. Casey of Peapack, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter Anne H. Casey to A. Markus van den Bergh, the son of Gratia, Baroness Schimmelpennick van de Oye of The Hague, and the late Henri van den Bergh of Wassenaar, the Netherlands.

title: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust
description: For several years now, those of us who have been devoted to remembering the Holocaust have focused our attention on the revisionist movement of pseudo-scholars and neo-Nazis who deny that the Holocaust ever happened (''Erasing the Past,'' by Judith Miller, Nov. 16). Ms. Miller correctly reminded us of the more widespread and much more dangerous - even if not more pernicious - phenomenon of amnesia, the self-willed forgetfulness and the desire to silence painful memories. BENJAMIN MEED President American Gathering/ Federation of Jewish Holocaust Survivors New York City

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: My Sesame Street Home Video: Bedtime Stories & Songs Featuring Jim Henson's Sesame Street Muppets and the Sesame Street Live cast. Produced by Random House Inc., in cooperation with Children's Television Workshop 30 minutes.

title: BOARD URGED TO REDUCE WORK FORCE
description: THE Board of Legislators, nearing the deadline for approving a 1987 Westchester budget, was advised last week by its independent auditors to cut the county work force by 75 jobs. Democratic legislators sought a sharper reduction, saying 400 positions should be eliminated, while other groups sought similarly deep cuts.

title: SAKHAROV SAYS HE PLANS TO RENEW CIVIL RIGHTS ADVOCACY IN MOSCOW
description: Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he planned to continue his advocacy of human rights when he returns to Moscow after nearly seven years of exile.

title: A.T. & T. Cuts 27,400 More Jobs
description: Describing this round as a positive refocusing of strategy rather than a retrenchment, A.T. & T. announced last week its second write-off and its third major set of layoffs since the local telephone companies split from American Telephone & Telegraph in a court-ordered divestiture in 1984.

title: New Old Money?
description: The counterman at a seafood house in downtown Washington noticed recently that he had been getting a fair amount of currency, dollar bills, tens and twenties, looking new but dated 1969.

title: AT LAST, 20TH CENTURY TECHNOLOGY
description: AT Yale University's 109-year-old Daily News, reporters still use manual Royal typewriters to produce copy. Legend has it that some of the typewriters were around in 1920, when Time Magazine founders Henry R. Luce and Briton Hadden ran The News.

title: GA. TECH WINS IN OVERTIME
description: Boston College had Georgia Tech on the ropes, but Bruce Dalrymple and Duane Ferrell would not let the Yellow Jackets lose. Dalrymple led a pair of comebacks and Ferrell broke a 59-59 tie in overtime with two baskets as Georgia Tech (4-2) beat the Eagles, 65-62, today at the Suntory Ball tournament.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: 'YULETIDE AT WINTERTHUR'

title: A TOUCH OF THE MEDITERRANEAN IN NEWARK
description: BEYOND wrought-iron gates on a busy thoroughfare here stands what looks like a dilapidated movie theater.

title: GROUP SPURNS TAX CUT AND CALLS FOR HELP FOR POOR
description: AS the Christmas tree was going up last week in an atrium at the State Capitol, legislators and advocacy groups were preparing their wish lists for the 1987 session of the General Assembly. As usual, not everyone wanted the same thing.

title: JACKIE MASON ARRIVES ON BROADWAY
description: After nearly 30 years wandering mostly in a wilderness of venues more familiar to the Broadway Danny Roses of his world, the comic Jackie Mason may finally have found the spotlight, this time, of all places, on Broadway. Nobody could be more astonished by this than Mr. Mason himself, who must have sometimes felt that luck had abandoned a career marked by the sheer wonder of its perseverance. This turn of fortune for which every comic waits - but rarely with such patience as Mr. Mason - has propelled him to the stage of the Brooks Atkinson Theater where his one-man act, ''The World According to Me,'' opens on Tuesday after a sold-out run at the Canon Theater here.

title: STEERING THE SENATE INTO THE FUTURE: A HOT-SEAT JOB
description: JOHN W. EPLING clutched at the lapels of his jacket as he rushed across the breezy Rutgers Commons, grumbling that he should have brought along an overcoat.

title: DOLE ASKS THE PRESIDENT FOR BOLD NEW ACTIONS TO HELP CLEAR THE AIR
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said today that President Reagan had not yet convinced the American public, including many of his fellow Republicans, that he had done all he could to get at the truth about the Iranian arms sales.

title: TOP NASA AIDES KNEW OF SHUTTLE FLAW IN '84
description: Nearly two years before the Challenger disaster, two of the highest officials at NASA ordered a full review of trouble with safety seals on the space shuttle's solid-fuel rockets, but they left their posts before following up on the problem, according to newly disclosed documents from the shuttle investigation.

title: Topics: Bold Crossings; Making the Light
description: A newcomer's recent observation here that New York pedestrians don't stay to the right prompts several explanations. One letter writer said that ever since the cave men, humans have sought security by staying as close as possible to buildings - or to caves, as the case may be.

title: Q AND A
description: Increase Upon Increase Question: When the two-year lease expires on my rent-stabilized apartment, not only will the rent be raised by the percentage allowed by law, but also a further surcharge will be added because the rent is less than $400 a month. Is this surcharge allowed? . . . F. K., Flushing, Queens Answer: In your case it may not be. Eric Weinstock, a spokesman for the Rent Guidelines Board, said such an increase is not a surcharge but a supplementary adjustment and it was approved by the board's Order 18. That order allows landlords of apartments that rent for less than $350 a month to raise the rent up to $15 a month beyond the guideline increase upon renewal of any lease that expires between last Oct. 1 and Sept. 30, 1987.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Four Retailers In Village Yard The Village Yard in Chappaqua is an enclave of four retailers offering a considerable variety - plus free parking. All are open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Saturday, and today from noon to 5 P.M., but not other Sundays. Gift certificates are available and wrapping is free on nonsale items. Chappaqua is an exit off the Saw Mill River Parkway, northbound. Turn left at the end of the ramp, left again at the light, and left again on the other side of the bridge, then right up King Street and the Village Yard is to the right.

title: WEIGHT OF POLITICS, PREJUDICE BENDS THE LAW IN ISRAEL
description: HAS there been a decline in the rule of law in Israel?

title: Tough Drunken Driving Law Approved for Massachusetts
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on Thursday signed a tougher new drunken driving law that includes a provision allowing some licenses to be suspended without trial.

title: DELAYER'S GUIDE TO HOLIDAY SHOPPING
description: A FRIEND of mine, a young doctor from Fairfield, recently came to me with a problem. He can never get around to doing his Christmas shopping, even though his successful practice affords him plenty of time to do so. This bothers him.

title: HEADING FOR A NEW YEAR
description: ebuts at the Waldorf Dec. 29 - Fifty-eight young women, ranging in age from 17 to 22, will be presented at the International Debutante Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. Adriana Echavarria-Eisenhower, a great-granddaughter of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, will be among the group, and she will be following in the footsteps of her mother, Anne Eisenhower. The white-tie evening, which benefits the Leukemia Society of America and the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club, begins at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $200, from 212-861-5911. Keeping a Tradition Dec. 29 - John Reed, a veteran of the D'Oyly Carte company, often appears here in productions by the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players as he is now doing in ''Patience'' at Symphony Space. The actress Jean Stapleton will be the hostess at a cocktail party to honor Mr. Reed and to raise money the Gilbert and Sullivan Players. The party, from 5 to 7 P.M., will be at Hanratty's, Amsterdam Avenue at 96th Street. Tickets, $25, include membership in the Players. Telephone 212-769-1000. For Auld Lang Syne Dec. 31 - Just as in homes 95 years ago when Carnegie Hall opened, such Victorian foods as miniature hams, leek pies, flummery and trifle will be served after a New Year's Eve concert at the restored hall. Isaac Stern will be the host at the 8 P.M. concert, and performers will include Robert Tear, Benjamin Luxon, Marvin Hamlisch, Yo-Yo Ma, Richard Stoltzman and Nancy Allen. Tickets for the concert and supper on the stage afterward, $200, from 212-247-7800.

title: Ann Wende Alford to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Keith Alford of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Wende Alford, to Andrew Wade Kittross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffry H. Kittross of Suffern, N.Y. Miss Alford and her fiance graduated in June from Trinity College in Hartford.

title: GROUPS OPPOSE TOYS
description: RAMBO and other so-called action toys are facing their toughest foes ever this year, and the battlegrounds are Connecticut's department stores and toy manufacturing plants.

title: Wrong Image Of Layne
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOT LINE REUNITES RUNAWAYS AND FAMILIES
description: The boy had run away to another part of the country, but his problems had run right along with him. Tears streamed down his face as he stood in a telephone booth on a California street, dialing the number of his family in Texas. Although his voice shook as he spoke, his message was clear. ''I want to go home,'' he said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1986
description: International 30,000 Chinese students protested for democracy and press freedom in Shanghai, according to foreigners who saw the students' demonstrations, the largest since the end of the Cultural Revolution. Page 1 Two prominent Republicans differ in their views about President Reagan's handling of the Iranian arms crisis. Vice President Bush said the idea that he and the President would ''stay down'' is ''complete nonsense.'' But Senator Bob Dole said the President had not yet convinced the public that he had done all he could to get at the truth. #1 Panama companies are used as foils, enabling their foreign owners to do business anywhere in the world anonymously and tax-free. Three such companies were linked to the Iran arms deals last week. #20 Triad America may be near collapse. The Utah-based investment corporation is owned by Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman who played a key role in financing the American arms sales to Iran. #20 Andrei D. Sakharov, in an interview, said he planned to continue advocating human rights when he returns to Moscow after nearly seven years of internal exile. He said he made no promise to curb his public activities. #1 A more flexible human rights policy in the Soviet Union and an acknowledgment that treatment of dissidents affects other issues are reflected in the decision to let Dr. Sakharov return to Moscow, Western diplomats said. #14 A jailed Soviet dissident's notes, reportedly smuggled out of the country, say that he has been in solitary confinement for almost three years and and a hunger strike for more than two years.

title: POSTINGS: Bluster on Clusters; Woodstock Wary
description: Like it or not, attached townhouses are creeping up on Woodstock, N.Y. ''The people around here were up in arms,'' said Harold Graff, a former Hurley town councilman. ''They still glare at me.''

title:
ART;
REALISM TO ABSTRACTION: A SEASON OF MIXED MEDIA
description: AS a windup of its first season, the Benton Gallery in Southampton is offering a group exhibition that more than summarizes its presentations this year. The selection includes artists whom the gallery has not shown before, as well as those featured in individual shows since its opening last spring in the new Benton Plaza.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: THE DREAM DREDGER by Roberta Silman. Persea Books. 223 pages. $14.95.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Builders Taking Steps to Combat Radon
description: GOVERNMENT officials, builders and New Jersey residents are taking steps to find ways to clean dwellings contaminated by radon and to built new ones free of the radioactive gas.

title: Barbara Brancatelli to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Brancatelli of Pearl River, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Ann Brancatelli to John S. Ficarra, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ficarra of Orangeburg, N.Y. Miss Brancatelli, who graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson University, is a registered nurse at the Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. Her fiance, a member of the class of '87 at the Pace University School of Law, graduated from Manhattan College.

title: IMPRISONED PSYCHIATRIST WRITES OF ABUSES IN SOVIET
description: An imprisoned Russian dissident psychiatrist says in notes reportedly smuggled out of the Soviet Union that he has been in solitary confinement for three years, on a hunger strike for two years and confined to a punishment cell for half a year.

title: REPORT FINDS RISE IN UNWED COUPLES
description: Americans are increasingly choosing to live together before marrying or instead, and the number of unwed couples is topping two million for the first time, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BIDNESS: THE BOOMS AND BUSTS OF THE TEXAS ECONOMY. Edited by Joseph Nocera. (Texas Monthly Press, Paper, $12.95.) In the final pages of this anthology of business stories from Texas Monthly, a cowboy and his wife talk about life, describing it - imagine! -''not as a means of accomplishment, but as an end in itself, something done well for its own sake.''

title: Breaking Ground as a Developer
description: OF all the varied aspects of the real-estate business, large-scale development may be the hardest for the complete outsider to break into.

title: JAZZ: VINCE GIORDANO
description: AFTER 10 years of playing jazz and pop arrangements from the time of World War I to the early 1930's, Vince Giordano has built his band, the Nighthawks, into an ensemble that has a remarkable versatility in what he calls ''the musical dialect'' of the period. The group's versatility includes its ability to adapt its full strength of 12 musicians to smaller ensembles without losing the flavor of its performances.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If you affirm the N.Y.S.E. request, it will be a blot upon the escutcheon of corporate democracy and the S.E.C.'' Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum warning against a Big Board plan to list companies with different classes of stock.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF AN I.R.A. ROLLOVER
description: Following are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I just quit my job to start my own business and have received about $50,000 in a lump-sum payment from my pension. I'm tempted to invest it in Australian bonds, which I hear are yielding 14 percent. Is that wise?

title: POSTINGS: Recapturing the Grandeur; Paramount Redux
description: A faded grandeur is signified by the Baroque urns that preside over the dingy neon sign at the entrance to the Century Paramount Hotel, at 235 West 46th Street. Some of that luster could be recaptured with a $30 million renovation, planned by Arthur G. Cohen and Philip Pilevsky, two New York developers who bought the hotel last month for $35 million.

title: SYMPHONY BROADENS NAME AND GOALS
description: A decade ago, when Omus Hirshbein was in his third season as director of the 92d Street Y's performing arts program, he decided to present Bach's six Brandenburg Concertos as a festive holiday concert. For the occasion, he engaged Gerard Schwarz - then the New York Philharmonic's principal trumpeter and a sometime conductor -who assembled and led a freelance orchestra, and played the second concerto's solo trumpet part in the bargain.

title: Reagan's Age and Memory
description: The question of President Reagan's age and memory, discussed fleetingly in the last Presidential election campaign, is back in the news again as he prepares to enter the hospital for minor surgery.

title: ILLUSIVE TREASURES AT THE MUSEUM OF HOLOGRAPHY
description: LEONARD GORDON recently spotted an artistic rendering of Dizzie Gillespie that transfixed him. It looked like a photograph, but it had certain uncanny, eye-catching qualities that photography cannot produce. Remarkably, it existed in three dimensions, with Mr. Gillespie's bloated cheeks and upturned trumpet hovering in midair. And even more surprising, when Mr. Gordon side-stepped to view the image from another angle, it changed. The trumpeter now held his instrument away from his mouth, his cheeks were deflated, and a wide smile swept his face.

title: Still Time to Spare a Tree for Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 3 Bombs in Northern Ireland
description: Bombs exploded tonight in three hotels in Northern Ireland, and the police said the attacks were similar to bombings carried out by the Irish Republican Army. The attacks, two in Cookstown and one in Dungannon close to the border with the Irish Republic, caused no casualties, the police said.

title: NBC Loses One To Wayne Newton
description: Wayne Newton, who has always done well in Las Vegas, was awarded $19.2 million last week by a Federal jury there that found NBC had defamed him in broadcasts linking him to organized crime.

title: POSSIBLE HOAX IN BURGLARY IS INVESTIGATED
description: Police officials here are investigating the possibility that a reported burglary that appeared to be linked to the clandestine transfer of American money to the Nicaraguan rebels was a hoax.

title: BLACK-AND-WHITE KALEIDOSCOPE
description: CRADLE SONG By Jane Rawlinson. 174 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
BLUEFISH
description: Pomatomus saltatrix Size: Average one to three feet.

title: FOR NATO, POLITICAL MOOD SWINGS
description: IN quick succession, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz came to NATO headquarters recently to reassure the allies that American foreign policy was on course. But an emerging full-dress debate on the alliance's health and destiny goes well beyond the turmoil in Washington over the Reagan Administration's secret dealings with Iran.

title: Correction
description: An article in Arts and Leisure on Dec. 7 about Bobby Short incorrectly identified the composer of ''Take the A Train.'' He was Billy Strayhorn. Further, the name of Mr. Short's accompanist on bass should have been spelled Beverly Peer.

title: Testing an AIDS Drug on Humans
description: Ever since 1796, when Edward Jenner began using injections of cowpox virus to inoculate patients against smallpox, vaccines have been developed to trick the immune systems of healthy patients into producing antibodies that prevent infection.

title: BATTLE DEVELOPS OVER WHAT'S RIGHT FOR WILDLIFE
description: EVEN on bitterly cold days, dozens of visitors go to the John F. Kennedy Memorial Wildlife Sanctuary, four miles east of Jones Beach, to watch the hundreds of species of birds that live and visit there.

title: P. F. Moore Wed To Miss Barkhorn
description: At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday Patricia Ann Barkhorn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Barkhorn of Bernardsville, was married to Peter F. Moore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Moore of Stonington, Conn., and Kilcolgon, County Galway, Ireland. Msgr. John R. Torney performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr.

title: CUMOM FORMS PANEL ON U.S. IMMIGRATION LAW
description: Governor Cuomo, responding to widespread confusion over the new Federal immigration law, has formed a special panel to inform New Yorkers about the legislation and protect them from discrimination.

title: THE LONG ISLAND SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS PRESENT
description: From South Shore sand to North Shore highland, Wassail for Christmas on Long Island! And before you wrap that gift-harmonica, Blow us a chord for Happy Hanukkah. Jesus did from evils free us, But so did mighty Maccabeus. This message goes past rhyme or reason: This is everybody's season. On Garden City's Stewart and Franklin Avenues, Lights wink in trees (you've seen them, havenue?) Quogue, Mineola, Greenport, Roslyn -The storefronts' glow is simply dozzlin'.

title: SPY MEMOIR TREIAL ENDS IN AUTSTRALIA
description: A five-week trial involving intense British efforts to suppress publication of the memoirs of a retired member of the British Secret Service has ended here, with the Australian judge expressing skepticism about the veracity of London's chief witness.

title: Albany Approves Drug Subsidies For the Elderly
description: Most of the lobbyists were graying and many were frail, but their combined musclepower swept all before them. Starting next Oct. 1, thanks to a bill passed by the New York State Legislature last week with no dissenting votes, New Yorkers 65 or older whose incomes fall below certain levels may charge to the state as much as 60 percent of their out-of-hospital prescription costs.

title:
LEISURE;
FEARLESS PRUNNING - JUST WHAT THE FICUS TREE NEEDS
description: ''Growth is success to the average indoor gardener,'' Robert Pressner said, ''and that is why homeowners are so afraid to prune their house plants. They're afraid to hamper that success. Right from a small, six-inch plant up to a 20-foot tree, people are afraid to pinch back even though you try to explain that by not pruning, they jeopardize the plant's health.''

title: Genji's Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: FIRST, let me tell you what reading this column will not do. It will not cure your insomnia or make you the hit of the party. It will not give you mastery over earth, wind, fire, fish or most fowl. It will not teach you to speak in tongues or put you on a first-name basis with St. Francis. And your car will not start easier on cold mornings.

title: A Spy Sentenced
description: Ronald W. Pelton apparently picked up a lot of knowledge he didn't need during his 14 years as a communications specialist at the National Security Agency. So, after quitting his job in 1979, Mr. Pelton decided one day to sell some of it to the Soviet Union, making what his lawyer, Fred Warren Bennett, described as ''the biggest mistake of his life.''

title: NEW YORK AND CONTRACTORS BATTLE OVER SLUDGE REMOVAL
description: Everyone wants to get rid of it. And that is why the noxious residue of New York City's 14 sewage-treatment plants has become the subject of a bitter dispute between the city and a group of barge operators.

title: WAITING FOR A VERY SPECIAL DAY
description: AS a child in the 1950's, the Christmas season began for me in Catholic school with the singing of carols, preparing for the pageant, learning again the story of the first Christmas, and making Santa Clauses and manger scenes for our classroom with construction paper, crayons and glue.

title: REBUILDING FROM THE GRASS ROOTS UP
description: TODAY, President Reagan and Jimmy Carter might find it difficult to recognize Charlotte Street, where each made a campaign stop and pledged to do something about the deterioration exemplified by the blighted Bronx thoroughfare's abandoned tenements and littered lots. Now, more than a decade after the first Presidential campaign visit - and promises that fell victim to budget cuts - local citizens have taken redevelopment into their own hands and a transformation is taking shape. Charlotte Street, abloom with ranch houses, looks like a suburban tract under construction.

title: A SINGER AIMS TO OPEN PEOPLE'S MINDS
description: IF pressed to describe her music, Patricia Shih calls it ''issue-oriented.''

title: FANS PERCEIVE RISE IN INJURIES
description: MOST professional football fans do not think there is too much violence in the National Football League, even though they believe serious injuries have increased this season and are caused primarily by dirty play, artificial turf and drug use by the players.

title: On Feeding the Press
description: Reporters covering the closed hearings of the Senate Intelligence Committee, staked out all day in the second-floor corridor of the Hart Office Building, are improving their meager diet.

title: BASEBALL AS ALL-SEASON SPORT: MR. JEFFERSON UNDERSTOOD
description: THE baseball season ended two months ago, but nobody can prove it. The headlines this past pre-Christmas week dealt, like the game itself, with the physical (Gooden's encounter with Tampa's finest), the cerebral (Morris's salary negotiations), and juridical (a verdict for the Shea Stadium parachutist). And when they said Morris they meant not football Joe of the Giants but baseball Jack, the once and future king of the Detroits.

title: COMET SAID TO TOTATE WEEKLY
description: The nucleus of Halley's comet rotates once every week as it sails through space instead of every 2.2 days, the rate previously suggested, an astronomer has reported.

title: A MERGER MANIA HITS TEXAS BANKS
description: Chemical New York will buy Texas Commerce in one of the biggest banking acquisitions ever. Chemical's offer consists of $7 a share in cash and a diverse array of securities, with an estimated total value of $1.19 billion. Many analysts credited Chemical's chairman, Walter V. Shipley, with a courageous move that, they say, may turn out to be brilliant.

title: HOLIDAY MIGRATIONS OLD AND NEW
description: There we were, shivering in the chilly Austrian night, in a narrow street next to the post office, where the pay telephones were. We had staked out the telephones when we arrived in St. Anton a few days earlier, planning our calls home to our families on Christmas Day. Our pockets were full of the unfamiliar coins we had been hoarding. We hoped we had enough to last through the few minutes it would take to say ''Merry Christmas! Yes, I wish I could be there, too.'' to each of the many members of each of our families, who, six hours behind us, would be just finishing up the morning's attack on the packages under the tree. It was 1982, my first Christmas away from home.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Siren, Prism, Prime Minister

title: WHAT HAS FOUR WHEELS, POOR THING?
description: THE parking lot of the local train station is something of a La Brea Tar Pits for fossil cars - littered with rows and rows of jalopies and old relics, formerly splendid coupes and heroic hot rods.

title: A DRAMA OF AGE AND EXILE
description: IT WAS THE FIRST DAY OF rehearsal of a new production at the Arena Stage, in Washington. It was also the first time American actors had had the chance to work with Yuri Lyubimov, the celebrated Russian avant-garde theater director now in exile from the Soviet Union. Invited by Zelda Fichandler, the Arena producing director, he was staging his adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment,'' scheduled to open Jan. 7. Lyubimov, a silver-haired man in his late 60's, seemed as excited about his American debut as the cast.

title: What Was the Biggest Sports Story of 1986?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: New Year, New Fare
description: IT HAS BEEN 16 years since my friend Sherley Koteen and I decided that a small dinner at home with close friends was a more compatible way to spend New Year's Eve than going to the splashiest party at a restaurant or club. Nothing in the intervening years has changed our minds. Or the minds of our regulars, several of whom have been guests at our black-tie dinners in Washington since 1970.

title: Parts of Westchester Are Hit By a 'Very Minor' Earthquake
description: Parts of Westchester County experienced a minor earthquake early yesterday, apparently the latest in a series registered over the last few years. But seismologists said the event was so small that initial checks of their instruments failed to establish its precise time, location or force.

title: PRINTS CAPTURE SEASON
description: SINCE its founding 12 years ago, the Graphic Eye Gallery in Port Washington has gradually assumed an increasingly respected role. Its programming promotes a greater awareness of printmaking techniques, its diversified roster of artists and guest exhibitors present a broad spectrum of styles, and it has been in the forefront of a growing interest in the richly inventive monotype.

title: MSGR. LASZLO KADAR
description: Laszlo Kadar, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Eger, died today, church officials reported.

title: Boy George Seized and Freed
description: Boy George, the British pop singer who underwent treatment for heroin addiction last summer, was arrested today in connection with a possible drug offense, the police said. The 25-year-old singer, whose real name is George O'Dowd, was released more than 12 hours later and ordered to report to the police in February, Scotland Yard said. He was not charged, pending analysis of substances seized when he and two other men were stopped while they walked home from an all-night party.

title: Nancy E. Marx, An Editor, Wed To James Better
description: Nancy Ellen Marx, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Marx Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to James Marc Better, a son of Clifford Better of Los Angeles and the late Sandra Lee Better. Rabbi Leonard H. Poller performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: PUERTO RICO GETS THE OFFICE PARTY FOR CHRISTMAS
description: The Christmas season is slipping into high gear in Puerto Rico and for many the party will not stop until mid-January.

title: THREE DAYS IN THE BACK COUNTRY
description: It was the day before the cobra slithered in front of the car that we rounded the bend in the mountain road a hundred miles or so northwest of Chiang Mai, hit the brakes and stopped just short of the pack of elephants.

title: SEAHAWKS ROUT BRONCOS TO STAY IN PLAYOFF RACE
description: Curt Warner ran for three touchdowns and Dave Krieg passed to Daryl Turner for two more touchdowns today as the Seattle Seahawks kept their wild-card playoff hopes alive with their fifth consecutive victory, a 41-16 triumph over the Denver Broncos.

title: The Critics Were Right
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: Get Ready, Get Set, Grow Created by Ian Clark. Brooklyn Botanic Garden. 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.11225. 15 minutes. $29.95 (plus $2.50 for postage and handling).

title: PORT: FOR THE CIVILIZED ON A WINTER'S EVE
description: PORT poured from crystal decanters into small-faceted glasses is a quintessentially civilized pleasure and one the British know how to enjoy. At this season, when thoughts might turn to figgy pudding and roast goose, having port to sip after dinner or in late afternoon evokes all the richness of a Dickensian Christmas.

title:
GARDENING;
HOLIDAY PLANTS REQUIRE CARE, TOO
description: IT is not uncommon for Christmas plants to die before the end of the holiday festivities. But they have the inherent ability to last much longer. The secret of prolonging their life is that of providing them with optimum conditions. To do so is not at all difficult. All living plants have certain minimum requirements. Let's examine them one by one.

title: ULTRA-ROMANTIC POP-SOUL MUSIC REMAINS A POWERFUL FORCE
description: While the surging popularity of rap music represents a brash, youthful rebellion against the pop mainstream, polished, ultra-romantic pop-soul singing continues to hold its own in the black music marketplace. On Billboard's ''top black albums'' chart last week, the two best-selling records - Freddie Jackson's ''Just Like the First Time'' (Capitol 12495; LP; cassette) and Luther Vandross's ''Give Me the Reason'' (Epic 40415; LP; cassette) - are quintessential examples of a cultivated male pop-soul vocal style that is so prevalent it has become a full-blown genre. ''Gregory Abbott'' (Columbia 40437), the debut album of another New York balladeer, stood at No. 5. And the Caribbean-born, English-based pop-soul singer Billy Ocean recently scored his second million-selling album with ''Love Zone'' (Jive/ Arista 8409; LP, cassette, compact disc), a record also dominated by love ballads.

title: SPORTS SHINE LIGHT ON BOSTON SCHOOL
description: In the days when Northeastern University was a commuter school, its students spent so much time driving to the inner-city campus from outlying suburbs that they were known as the ''thundering herd of Route 93.''

title: Horford Gets 17 in Debut
description: Jim Barton scored 40 points to lead Dartmouth to an 88-86 basketball victory over Miami of Florida tonight and spoil the collegiate debut of Miami's 7-foot-1-inch center, Tito Horford.

title: Where to Fight Communism
description: Forget, for a moment, all the unknowns about the Iran-contra scandal. What cries out for debate is well known - that Ronald Reagan's passionate crusade against Communism is the engine that has powered the Oliver Norths of his Administration.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LET US BUILD US A CITY: Eleven Lost Towns. By Donald Harington. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Cherokee City (pop. 25) ''looks as if a town might once have been there,'' Donald Harington observes.

title: Police Clash With Protesters Over Squatters in Hamburg
description: Riot police and 2,000 youths clashed in this port city today during a demonstration in support of squatters, a police spokesman said.

title: Correction
description: An article about Ghent, Belgium, on Nov. 23 gave an incorrect date for France's takeover of what is today Belgium. The region was transferred to France from Austria by the Treaty of Campo Formio in 1797.

title: IN WAGES, SEXES MAY BE FOREVER UNEQUAL
description: THROUGHOUT the industrial world, women are catching up with men in education and earning power. But if some current trends continue, they may never achieve equality.

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: Mel Lewis and His Big Band V.I.E.W. Video. 38 minutes. $34.95 until Jan. 15, 1987, then $24.95.

title: NEW FILMS RETHINK THE SMALL TOWN
description: There is new life bubbling beneath the barrenness of the American small town, a place that once embodied our rosiest ideals and has long since fallen on hard times. The sober plainness of middle-American existence is seldom represented as such any more; indeed, the town itself has become something of an anachronism, replaced in our imaginations by the suburb, the urban backwater or the family farm. What was once the center of both fond imaginings and satirical outrage - of Norman Rockwell's world and of Sinclair Lewis's Main Street - has grown more and more apt to be regarded, with sadness and pity, as a wasteland.

title: FRANCIS FERGUSSON, TEACHER AND WRITER ON THE THEATER, DIES
description: Francis Fergusson, a literary critic who wrote extensively on the theater and lectured for many years at Rutgers and Princeton Universities, died Friday night at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Kingston, N.J.

title: ALASKA, BY FERRY, AUTO AND TRAIN
description: If those travelers whose bumper stickers boast, ''I survived the Alcan,'' deserve a 10 on the scale of adventurous touring in Alaska, we rate a modest 5. Two of our threesome vetoed any thought of undertaking the 2,350-mile drive from the United States-Canadian border to Fairbanks. Yet the prospect of viewing America's last frontier from the luxury of a cruise ship or the safety of a tour bus struck all three of us as incongruous. Was there a middle way? If so, we would settle without apology for a 5.

title: PINE EAGLES AND BLACK LINCOLNS
description: In ALL-AMERICAN FOLK ARTS AND CRAFTS (Rizzoli, $45), a patchwork of images of American folk arts and crafts, William C. Ketchum Jr. takes a colorful, spirited look at the handmade objects he calls ''America's glory.'' Geared toward collectors, but avoiding the this-is-how-much-it-costs approach of collecting guides, Mr. Ketchum's book is a personalized journey through the distinctively American themes and symbols that have occupied our collective imagination.

title: A 'Bottle Bill' For City Cars?
description: EVERY year hundreds of cars are abandoned in New York City parkland - to say nothing of many more in the city's streets. Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern proposed a solution in June 1985 - ''a bottle bill for cars.''

title: Swiss Pollution Protest
description: Two Swiss protesters associated with the Greenpeace environmental and anti-nuclear group continued to cling today to a chemical plant smokestack despite driving winds and snow to protest pollution of the Rhine River by chemical spills. The protesters ascended the smokestack on Friday and vowed to stay until Christmas.

title: WORLD FINANCE, WORLD POLITICS
description: IN WHOSE INTEREST? International Banking and American Foreign Policy. By Benjamin J. Cohen. 347 pp. New Haven: A Council on Foreign Relations Book/ Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: NEWEST GIANT REALIZES A FANTASY AGAINST OLD TEAM
description: Near the end of a season in which the Giants have done almost everything right, one of them today made a single detached play that is usually only found in athletes' fantasies.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the technology of down-filled clothing in The Week in Review Nov. 30 incorrectly defined a micron, a unit of measure. It is one-millionth of a meter.

title: OF CONFUCIUS, 'E.T.' AND HAPPINESS CANDY
description: DURING THE 10-YEAR period (1966-76) known as The Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, education in China came to a standstill.

title: Custom Building With an Architect
description: ARCHITECT-DESIGNED houses, usually associated with people who get around in yachts and limousines, have in recent years become competitive housing alternatives for less well-traveled home buyers. One reason is that home prices in parts of metropolitan New York have risen faster than the prices that the careful consumer needs to pay for land and custom-home construction.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: VISITING THE ART MUSEUM Written and illustrated by Laurene Krasny Brown and Marc Brown. 32 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: POLICE AND SOME ONLOOKERS DIFFER ON GOODEN INCIDENT
description: At a news conference in St. Petersburg on Friday, Dwight Gooden projected calm and good neighborliness. When the children he plays catch with come by his parents' house and ask him about the fight with the police last Saturday night, Gooden said, ''I just put it as a misunderstanding.''

title: Voyager Aviators Heading for Home
description: In what has been called ''aviation's last great adventure,'' two pilots, Richard G. Rutan and Jeana Yeager, passed the halfway point last week in their attempt to circumnavigate the earth nonstop on a single load of fuel.

title: Snipping Away Since Trafalgar
