description: In London, some will argue, there are three kinds of places for men to get a haircut: the unisex emporiums, the traditional barbershops and Truefitt & Hill on Old Bond Street in Mayfair.

title: LAVA PRESSES FORWARD IN HAWAII
description: Hawaiians scattered sacred ti leaves atop rampaging lava flows disgorged by the fiery Kilauea volcano, but the red-hot river of molten rock rumbled along its destructive path today, consuming four more homes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GANDHI TO PAINE Officials of the Thomas Paine National Historical Association in New Rochelle were surprised recently to receive a phone call from Sir Richard Attenborough, British producer of the film ''Gandhi.'' A great admirer of Paine, Sir Richard is working on the production of a film about the Revolutionary American writer and wanted to establish a connection with the association for research purposes.

title: WALTERS SAYS U.S. SHOULD RESTORE U.N. DUES
description: The chief United States delegate to the United Nations said today that he would ask Congress to restore millions of dollars in dues owed by the United States to the world organization.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS GET DRUG POLICE
description: POLICE officers from the Department of Human Services are being screened for a strike force to be assigned to the state's seven psychiatric hospitals to ferret out patients or employees selling or using illicit drugs.

title: Cardinal Brandao Vilela Dies; Head of the Brazilian Church
description: Avelar Cardinal Brandao Vilela, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Brazil and Archbishop of the northeastern city of Salvador, died of stomach cancer Friday in a hospital there, the hospital said today. He was 74 years old.

title: AFGHAN REFUGEES GET CARE IN STATE
description: IF Abdul Khalig and Naik Mohammad were to make up a Christmas list, Abdul might ask for a new face, and Naik a new hip. The two teen-agers are Afghans who were severely wounded in their country's war against Soviet forces.

title: IN DARIEN, AN UPBEAT 'ANNIE' WITH A CUTTING EDGE
description: THE musical tonic for the real cockeyed optimists among us is not ''South Pacific,'' which recently closed at the Darien Dinner Theater in nearby Connecticut. It's ''Annie,'' which just opened there.

title: Casey's Condition Is Stable
description: William J. Casey, Driector of Central Intelligence, remained in stable condition today, recovering from removal of a tumor from his brain, a spokesman for Georgetown University Hospital said. The spokesman said Mr. Casey's doctors believed his ''postoperative recovery is progressing satisfactorily'' after the surgery Thursday. The hospital said no further medical statement on the 73-year-old Mr. Casey was planned before Monday unless his condition changed.

title: An Instant - and Authentic - 18th-Century Village
description: A MOTORIST driving north on Palisado Drive in South Windsor, Conn., who turns left at Settlement Hill Road may feel as if he's slipped backward two centuries in time. Three faithfully restored 18th-century houses are clustered in their own little village, another is being rebuilt using old-fashioned building techniques and space has been left for three more.

title: Fox Hunting
description: To the Editor: ''It is very strange, and very melancholy,'' said Samuel Johnson more than two centuries ago, ''that the paucity of human pleasures should persuade us ever to call hunting one of them.''

title: COCAINE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE
description: BREAKING THE IMPASSE IN THE WAR ON DRUGS By Steven Wisotsky. Foreword by Thomas Szasz. Tables. 279 pp. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press. $35.

title: LOSE THE COLONIES, KEEP AN EMPIRE
description: MISSION TO CIVILIZE The French Way. By Mort Rosenblum. 470 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: De Sa, 27, Killed In Auto Accident
description: Joe De Sa, a former major-leaguer who was playing for Ponce of the Puerto Rican winter baseball league, died in a two-car accident early today, police reported.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEW REPUBLIC: A Voice of Modern Liberalism. By David Seideman. (Praeger, Cloth, $32.95; Paper, $9.95.) David Seideman has conducted an impressive audit of The New Republic's first 25 years (1914-1939).

title: Caroline Woodward Wed to R G. Grant
description: The marriage of Caroline Newberry Woodward to Richard George Grant took place yesterday in the Alumni Chapel at the Hill School in Pottstown, Pa. The Rev. Robert L. Hammett, assisted by the Rev. John W. Riegel, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Saint on the Sideline
description: WHEN Rueben Mayes, the New Orleans Saints' rookie running back, was named to the Pro Bowl last week, he said that playing in the game had been ''a goal of mine, even since I was a little kid.''

title: Summer Herman to Marry in January
description: The engagement of Summer Diane Herman and Dr. Andrew Pramer has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Herman of Port Washington, L.I. Dr. Pramer is the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Pramer of Highland Park, N.J. A Jan. 31 wedding is planned.

title: AT PLACES OF WORSHIP, CROWDS OVERFLOW
description: LAST Christmas Eve, the pews at First Church of Christ Congregational in Wethersfield were ''so filled, we were just squeezing them in,'' the minister said. So on Wednesday evening the church will raise its number of services to four, to accommodate the hundreds of worshipers expected.

title: OUTRAGE AND APPLAUSE GREET PROPOSAL TO RAISE FEDERAL PAY
description: RALPH NADER is outraged. Dr. Arthur Maass, a professor emeritus of government at Harvard University, maintains that it is a good idea. Mark Russell, the comedian, thinks it is a joke. Those three observers of the bureaucracy and others addressed a special commission's proposal, presented to President Reagan last week, to increase the salaries of members of Congress, Federal judges and high officials of the executive branch, in some cases by more than 80 percent.

title: THE PHONOGRAPH AND ITS IMPACT ON THE ART OF MUSIC
description: Parallels may be drawn between the invention of the phonograph by Thomas Edison about 100 years ago and the invention of a system of musical notation by Guido d'Arezzo about 1,000 years ago. In both instances, the aim was the preservation and conveyance of music - whether in symbols or in the actual sound -and both events proved pivotal in the history of the art.

title: THE DEER CAME, THEY SAW, THEY CONQUERED
description: THESE days I find my neighbor Ted out in his yard getting ready for battle. He is wrapping 50-yard lengths of vinyl-coated fencing around the foundation plantings of his house and spraying the outlying shrubbery with some black, tarlike repellent. When he is through, his tidy house and yard begin to resemble a redoubt during wartime, fortified against the enemy.

title: Inquiry Into Deaver Lobbying Is Broadened
description: Michael K. Deaver, who has during the Iran arms sale crisis re-emerged as a key White House adviser, may soon have more troubles of his own to consider.

title: TEACHER ORCHESTRATES SOME SUCCESSES
description: SHE had practiced the composition at home many times, but playing in front of the teacher made her palms sweaty and her breath rapid and shallow. Patricia Lattanzio, a seventh grader at the Pierre Van Cortlandt middle school in Croton-on-Hudson, was palpably nervous, her anxiety compounded by the approach only three days hence of her audition for the junior high school all-county band.

title: Q and A
description: Tours in India Question:Where can I find out about moderately priced tours of India that include cities and sightseeing? - E. S., Washington Answer:A budget traveler's 16-day tour to four Indian cities for a basic $1,895 is offered by Flag Tours (38 West 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10018; 212-921-3366 or, out of state, 800-223-8889). The price, which is a person, double occupancy, includes air fare from New York to Bombay and back from Delhi, flights within India, hotels and sightseeing but excludes meals, which cost another $140. From June through August and in December there is an air-fare supplement of $107. The tour also goes to Jaipur and Agra.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CLARINET CONCERTANTE If there's strength in numbers, today's contribution from the American Chamber Ensemble should prove invincible. In ''A Concertante of Clarinets,'' the regulars in the Long Island-based group take the afternoon off and turn the spotlight over to 10 clarinetists who, without accompaniment, will make music. The Druckers - Stanley, solo clarinetist with the New York Philharmonic, and Naomi, co-director of the chamber ensemble - lead the group, composed of other ''virtuoso clarinetists,'' in a program designed to showcase their talents. They'll play the Stamitz Concerto No. 1 in F major, Irwin Stack's ''Allegro for Clarinet Quartet'' and, as the piece de resistance, two works by Meyer Kupferman, with the composer conducting: ''O Kkkkanon Ppphodder'' and ''A Little Licorice Concerto.'' All this takes place at 3 P.M. at the North Bellmore Library, 1551 Newbridge Road, and is free.

title: Once More, a President Who Would Be King; Entitled to Due Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Selling Education In New Ways
description: TWO years ago, as Christmas and Hanukkah neared, Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond tried a new way to sell its continuing education courses: gift certificates.

title: TROUBLE OF THE FISCAL, MORAL AND POLICTICAL STRIPE
description: Times are tough at the United States Civil Rights Commission.

title: Miss Teitelbaum Wed To Barry Rosenstein
description: Lizanne Teitelbaum, the daughter of Dr. Seymour Teitelbaum and Lilian Ostrovsky de Teitelbaum of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Buenos Aires, was married in New York yesterday to Barry Rosenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rosenstein of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi David Kahane and Cantor Dov Kerin officiated at the Plaza.

title: GIANTS STAY HOME FOR PLAYOFFS
description: The Giants ended their regular season today with a victory, which was hardly different because they now have won their last nine games.

title: HUMBLED G.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUGH ISSUES FACE LOGRANDE IN NEW POST
description: WHEN Michael A. LoGrande begins work tomorrow morning as the Chief Deputy Suffolk County Executive, he will face about as comprehensive a list of concerns as any local government official in the country.

title: Outdoors; Long Hunt Finds Jugged Hare Recipe
description: THE most heavily hunted small-game animals on this continent, rabbits and hares, do not inspire the culinary attention given other species, most notably ducks, geese and upland birds, and in an effort to remedy this I have resolved to not let another hunting season go by without preparing jugged hare.

title: Jean H. Korelitz To Become Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Burton I. Korelitz of New York and South Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Hanff Korelitz, to Paul Muldoon, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Muldoon of Moy, Northern Ireland. A late-summer wedding is planned.

title: Elisheva S. Urbas And D. M. Morris To Marry in May
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Stanley M. Urbas of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisheva Shulamit Urbas, to David Marc Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Morris of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
HOLIDAY PLANTS REQUIRE CARE, TOO
description: IT is not uncommon for Christmas plants to die before the end of the holiday festivities. But they have the inherent ability to last much longer. The secret of prolonging their life is that of providing them with optimum conditions. To do so is not at all difficult. All living plants have certain minimum requirements. Let's examine them one by one.

title: A Fugitive Found
description: Seventeen years after he ran away from it, the Vietnam War caught up with Pfc. Douglas Beane. A spokesman for the United States Embassy in Sydney, Australia, said last week that Mr. Beane, a United States marine who deserted during the war, had been arrested at the request of American authorities.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
STREISAND RETURNS TO TV, ON HER TERMS
description: Make an extraordinary offer, get an extraordinary answer. Last summer, Martin Erlichman asked Michael Fuchs, chairman and chief executive officer of HBO, if the premium service would be willing to put up $250,000 to help mount a concert by one of the performers Mr. Erlichman manages. The concert was to be a one-time-only event, held outdoors before an invited audience, and thus subject to such uncertainties as weather, health and equipment malfunction, among myriad others. Further, Mr. Erlichman and his client would retain final approval: If the concert did not meet their exactingstandards, then it could not be broadcast - terms virtually unheard of in the television world, where the buyer customarily calls the shots. But if the finished product did pass muster, Mr. Fuchs and company would then be able to purchase the right to present the program, for a fee that Mr. Erlichman said was far higher than any network would pay.

title: COMPUTER IS ACCURATE ON CUP SEMIFINALISTS
description: When Dennis Conner's designers were gearing up for the 1986-87 America's Cup challenge last spring, they used a computer to simulate a kind of sailing war game.

title: Camille Taylor Weds William McDuffie Jr.
description: Camille Williams Taylor and William Robert McDuffie Jr. were married yesterday at the Peachtree Presbyterian Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. W. Frank Harrington performed the ceremony, assisted by Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Denise Falcone to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Falcone of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Ann Falcone, to Stephen Craig Snyder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan J. Snyder of Randolph, N.J. Miss Falcone is a senior at Fairleigh Dickinson University's School of Business Administration, and Mr. Snyder is a senior at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla. He is also a vice president of Heroes World Stores of New York, a 10-store retail chain.

title: 3 DECADES OF ''NUTCRACKER KIDS'' MEET AGAIN IN BALLET SCHOOL
description: WHEN the late George Balanchine first mounted ''The Nutcracker'' for the New York City Ballet at the City Center in 1954, he could not possibly have envisioned a reunion of three decades of ''Nutcracker'' children - former Soldiers, Angels, Candy Canes and Polichinelles.

title: Who Shot John?
description: NOBODY REALLY cares who shot John.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIA'S LEFT TAKES A LOOK INWARD
description: TO the three Communist nations of Indochina, it has been a season for candid introspection and leadership change.

title: Thinking About The City's Poor
description: As holiday lights threw the plight of New York City's hungry and homeless into even sharper relief last week, the struggle to help them continued. Developers pondered a municipal proposal to swap an East Side building site for the construction elsewhere of low-to-middle-income housing and shelter for the homeless. The Citizens Committee for New York City announced a volunteer effort to bolster neighborhood projects such as soup kitchens and job fairs. And a City Council committee urged the creation of a new Office of Food Policy.

title: Fine Art in Spain, Baroque Music in the Caribbean
description: Major Museum Is Reopened In Madrid

title: Winter Break
description: IT DOESN'T TAKE MUCH,'' SAYS one well-traveled New Yorker, reeling off his list of essentials for a midwinter island sojourn: an unfurled tatami mat, a terry-cloth towel, Top-Siders and a toothbrush.

title: PLAYING CHEKHOV FOR THE LAUGHS
description: THE Victory Repertory Theater may be Long Island's smallest theater, housed as it is in a tiny space in the basement of St. Paul's Parish House in Great Neck. But as the troupe has proved over and over again, size has nothing to do with quality. What is lost in space is gained in artistic output.

title: A LIBRETTIST'S LAMENT
description: I have deliberately kept away from the English National Opera's new version of ''Carmen.'' This is not because of forewarnings about its locale having been changed from 19th-century Seville to contemporary Acapulco, or wherever it is, and Micaela's being converted into Don Jose's mother. It is because of fears about what has probably been done to my translation of the libretto into English.

title: 'PLEASE DON'T MAKE ME A JOKE'
description: MARILYN By Gloria Steinem. Photographs by George Barris. 182 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $24.95.

title: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Congressional committee on Friday that President Reagan might not remember approving the first shipment of United States arms to Iran in August 1985 because he was recovering from surgery for colon cancer the previous month and may have been taking medication, a committee member reported. This could explain the conflicting testimony from Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, and Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, over whether the President approved the shipment. A spokesman for Mr. Meese said the member of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative George Brown, misrepresented what the Attorney General had said, but he did not elaborate. [ Page 20. ] Senator Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader and expected candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said President Reagan still had not convinced Americans that he has done everything he can to uncover the truth about secret United States arms sales to Iran. Senator Dole said in an interview that the President had told him, ''People like me, but they don't believe me.'' [ Page 1. ] Vice President Bush acknowledged in an interview that the crisis had made him ''no longer the front-runner'' for the 1988 Presidential nomination. But he predicted that he would recover. Mr. Bush said that ''the truth, when it comes out,'' would clear up any questions about the role he and President Reagan played in the debate over the Iran arms sales and the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Correct the Federal Pay Gouge
description: In 1969, a member of the President's Cabinet was paid $60,000. Today the figure is $86,200. That's nominally a 44 percent increase, but because of inflation it's worth 54 percent less than the 1969 salary. Members of Congress, who make $75,100, have taken a 43 percent hit. Federal district judges, at $78,700, have lost 36 percent.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS WONDERLAND Mervin Whipple's Christmas Wonderland contains 143 animated figures. Begun 18 years ago as a labor of love and a change from his work as a cemetery superintendent, the collection of Santas, elves, reindeer, and all manner of motorized figures has cost him about $150,000.

title: TURNING A CASH DRAIN INTO A CASH COW
description: THEY may be enjoying their new computers, but college newspapers are not enjoying the large debts these systems forced them to incur. But many campus papers are discovering that the same computerized editing and printing systems that caused their financial woes can be the remedy.

title: SIGOURNEY WEAVER PORTRAYING PORTIA IN 'MERCHANT OF VENCIE'
description: She blazed across the cosmos wielding a flamethrower against deadly extraterrestrials in ''Aliens.''

title: THOUSANDS STAGE RALLY IN SHANGHAI DEMANDING RIGHTS
description: In the largest student demonstrations since the Cultural Revolution, 30,000 to 35,000 students marched on the streets of Shanghai today shouting demands for democracy and press freedom, according to foreigners who saw the protests.

title: TEFLON MAKER: OUT OF FRYING PAN INTO FAME
description: Marion Trozzolo looked at Teflon a quarter century ago and had a vision: kitchens across America filled with nonstick cookware. Such prescience has paid off for the Kansas City industrialist in many ways, including propelling him toward a spot in the Plastics Hall of Fame.

title: Boston Teaching Women to Build
description: BOSTON'S 10-year boom in construction helped the state toward its ''economic miracle,'' but not the women of the city's work force.

title: KATONAH BYPASS TO DIVERT TRUCKS
description: THE town of Bedford and State Department of Transportation officials hope that the truck traffic on residential streets that has plagued Katonah for 20 years will be eliminated with the construction of a new road. An $8.7 million state project calls for building a bypass that will divert truck traffic from the hamlet's historic streets onto major roads.

title: A Time Machine
description: PEARL HARBOR WAS BOMBED THREE months after I started grade school, and my schoolyard was transformed into an arena of absolute good and evil. As we boys swallowed our graham crackers and milk, we vowed to fight to the death. The girls would all be nurses to tend our wounds.

title: CUTTING SALES TAXES AFTER A WINDFALL
description: Since returning New York State's income tax windfall as a result of Federal tax reform ought to be a priority of the newly elected State Legislature, I am encouraged that Assembly Ways and Means Committee Chairman Arthur J. Kremer [ ''New York Needs Tax Reform, Too,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 9 ] included a sales tax rate reduction among the options to return the windfall.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FELIX MENDELSSOHN: A Life in Letters. Edited by Rudolf Elvers. (Fromm International, $22.50.) ''Dear silent Schleinitz: Can such a thing be plausible? Isn't your own hair standing on end? That I, the worst correspondent in the kingdom, am writing for the second time already, and you, one of the best, have yet to write one at all. . . . Oh Schleinitz! This is atrocious beyond all atrocity; I am writing this entire letter con fuoco.''

title: Yet Another Arms Twist
description: In January 1985, President Reagan told the American people there was ''a new danger'' in Nicaragua because the Sandinista Government was receiving support from ''Colonel Qaddafi's Libya, the P.L.O. and, most recently, the Ayatollah Khomeini's Iran.''

title: Two Detroit Suburbs Named in Rights Suits
description: The Justice Department has filed separate lawsuits against two Detroit suburbs, charging them with discriminating against blacks in hiring.

title: The Pride and Shame of a Southern School
description: To the Editor:

title: MARYLAND TOWN EMBRACES PRISON IT OPPOSED
description: Two years ago, when the state chose this town on Maryland's Eastern Shore as the site for a new $80 million prison, a storm of protest arose.

title: Europe's Amnesia About the Holocaust
description: An hour before I read Judith Miller's examination of revisionist tendencies which threaten to impede an honest appraisal of the Holocaust in Western Europe, a swastika-emblazoned youth crossed my path in a concourse of Stapleton Airport in Denver.

title: A GRAIN OF SAND WOULD FALL LIKE AN ATOM BOMB
description: THURSDAY'S UNIVERSE By Marcia Bartusiak. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: THE TRUE NATURE OF OFFICE PARTIES
description: NOT long ago, like hundreds of other working people I participated in a ritual that is annually re-enacted by businesses around the nation: the office party.

title: LINK FOUND BETWEEN HIGH SCHOOL ACTIVITIES AND GOOD GRADES
description: Extracurricular activities and good grades tend to go together for high school students, a Government study has found.

title: LIQUOR SALES DIVIDE PENNSYLVANIANS
description: While in the Congo last August on a lecture tour to promote economic development and private enterprise, Gov. Dick Thornburgh did something he couldn't do here: he bought a bottle of wine at a privately owned store.

title: HOME VIDEO: FROM PARIS'S METRO TO THE YUKON
description: Gloriana By Benjamin Britten. Performed by the English National Opera. HBO/Cannon Video. 146 minutes. $39.95.

title: Nicaragua Frees Hasenfus, Plans Spy Trial for Hall
description: Nicaragua evidently decided last week that Eugene Hasenfus would do it more good in Washington than in jail.

title: 'The Pink Triangle'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT DOES SPORT NEED FOR CHRISTMAS?
description: Last week The Times asked readers to respond to this question. The Times also made a special request to Jerry Girard, the WPIX broadcaster, to provide his wish list. Dear Santa

title: John deButts(1915-1986)
description: Up until his death, John D. deButts, the former chairman of A.T.&T., fervently believed in the Bell telephone system.

title: No Headline
description: TALKING HIS WAY TO THE TOP THE FALL OF KELVIN WALKER A Fable of the Sixties. By Alasdair Gray. 144 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95.

title: DALEY, 10YEARS GONE, REMAINS 'THE MAYOR'
description: Even now, a decade later, they still talk of him in the present tense.

title: SAVING THE TREASURES OF ITALY
description: DEEP IN THE BACK streets of Naples, the Convent of Santa Chiara has been an oasis of tranquillity and culture since the 14th century. But on an evening in early November, it provided an exceptional backdrop for a dinner party. Some 300 guests gathered there to help celebrate Naples 99, a foundation that arranges for corporate sponsorship of art restorations in and around that city. First, they sipped champagne in the garden cloister, for which the CIGA hotel chain had financed a technical study of the deteriorating majolica tiles that mimic the foliage with subdued colors. Glasses in hand, some strolled to a vestibule to see a small series of frescoes recently cleaned and restored under the sponsorship of the fashion designer Mario Valentino. Then it was on to the Baroque refectory for dinner.

title: Still Amazin'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PRESENTS THAT CAN STAY IN THE BOX
description: THEORETICALLY, personal Christmas gifts are exchanged by people who know each other well and who, one hopes, have a certain regard for one another. This should mean that these gift-exchangers have some idea of what would be welcome and appropriate, but it doesn't. Talk to anyone - almost - and they'll tell you that an astonishing percentage of the things they receive bear no relationship to anything they like, need or want.

title: Thomas B. Lloyd Weds Susan Ball
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan DeLong Ball, the daughter of Peter Ball of Stuart, Fla., and Brooksville, Me., and Anne DeLong Ball of Palm Beach, Fla., to Thomas Bedford Lloyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lloyd of Palm Beach and Southport, Conn. The Rev. Susan C. Harriss performed the ceremony.

title: WHEN AIR RIGHTS GO UNDERGROUND
description: If New York ran on logic, the combination of an overbuilt midtown Manhattan, a rising vacancy rate in office space, and slightly more restrictive zoning would put an end, at least for the time being, to the mega-projects that have so crowded the city's skyline. After all, why build a huge skyscraper when so many factors argue against it?

title: LIBYAN OFFENSIVE IN NORTHERN CHAD
description: Several thousand Libyan troops, backed by Soviet-made tanks and warplanes, launched a major attack today in northern Chad in an effort to crush anti-Libyan resistance forces, United States officials said.

title: Paying for Transit Once a Year
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's sensible capital program clings to life, thanks to an ingenious suggestion from Stanley Fink, the outgoing Assembly Speaker, and the willingness of Warren Anderson, the Senate Republican leader. The program deserves to prosper.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Dec. 7, about Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's background, misstated his activities from 1969 to 1973.

title: MASSACHUSETTS URGED TO END HOMOSEXUAL CHILD-CARE CURB
description: A state-appointed commission has urged Massachusetts to reverse its policy of not placing foster children in the care of homosexual and lesbian couples or single people.

title: Rolling Again
description: THREE years after he announced his retirement from tournament bowling, Earl Anthony, the sport's leading money winner, has been lured back to the lanes, starting with an event in his home town of Tacoma, Wash., next month.

title: Israeli Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble Spots for Traffic
description: According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE are women I know who open their hearts to me, at least when it comes to certain subjects. There is no reserve between us when they tell me how they detest the aroma of my cheap cigars and, once the ice has been broken, they go on to let me know that they cannot understand the male fascination with trains, full-scale and model.

title: The Costs of Living
description: NIGHTS IN THE GARDENS OF BROOKLYN by Harvey Swados. 381 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95 Josephine Hendin, a professor of English at New York University, is the author of ''Vulnerable People: A View of American Fiction Since 1945'' and the forth-coming novel ''The Right Thing to Do.''

title: 'PLATOON' GRAPPLES WITH VIETNAM
description: The guns are silent and cold, but the memory of their report still echoes across the land. Vietnam lingers, especially for the eager volunteers and luckless conscripts who crossed the Pacific to fight it. They are in their maturity now. They sit in the Congress, they stand along the assembly line, they sell pencils in the street. Some have tried to bury their past and forget the war. Many more have searched for a way to remember. They have a new mission now, one that began when the fighting stopped. This is the mission to make sense of the senseless, to find some provision in a storehouse laid empty by waste.

title: THORNWOOD PLANNING RENOVATION
description: THE commercial area of Thornwood, a hamlet in the town of Mount Pleasant, is, in the words of the Town Supervisor, ''rather dilapidated.'' The sidewalks are crumbling, the so-called parking lot can be reached only after traversing knee-deep potholes filled with last week's rain; there are few trees and few shoppers. But Vincent M. Valenti, the Town Supervisor, discussing plans to ''spruce up the area,'' foresees new sidewalks, trees, lights, a paved parking lot, a community center and new stores attracted by the improvements.

title: DISCOVERING UNCHARTED ATTIC SPACE
description: IT takes a special courage to venture into the family attic. As a youngster it was one of those places to be avoided simply because all of the players in those bad dreams of childhood were hiding in the darkness of that space.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: We wanted to write you to tell you of our great pleasure with the article ''By Rail to the Other Side of Japan'' (Travel, July 27).

title: Arrested in Prague
description: To the Editor:

title: At Least One Is Dead in Fire AtWaterfront Motel in Jersey
description: At least one resident died tonight when a fast-spreading fire broke out in a three-story motel and firefighters were unable to get into much of the building, the authorities said.

title: F.B.I. CELEBRATION CHEERS CHILDREN
description: In an operation involving virtually every agent in the criminal division of the New York branch of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a group of 41 juveniles was rounded up recently and brought to the F.B.I.'s offices in lower Manhattan. The juveniles, escorted by armed agents, were photographed and fingerprinted. Then they were showered with gifts and affection at a lavish Christmas party.

title: NAN GOLDIN'S BLEAK DIARY OF THE URBAN SUBCULTURE
description: What Robert Frank's ''The Americans'' was to the 1950's, Nan Goldin's ''The Ballad of Sexual Dependency'' is to the 1980's. The 800-image ''ballad'' - a sweeping, diaristic and critical account of life within the photographer's own artistic, urban subculture - reflects the same dissatisfaction with contemporary life evident in ''The Americans'' and extends the narrative potentials of still photography that Frank's book revealed. At the same time, it serves to gauge the distance between the existential angst of Frank's time and today's sense of social and cultural atomization. Goldin, at the age of 33, has created an artistic masterwork that tells us not only about the attitudes of her generation, but also about the times in which we live.

title: PHILADELPHIA COURTS ARE CITED
description: A new report has determined that Philadelphia runs one of the nation's most expensive judicial systems, and the director of the group that conducted the study suggested the system was inefficient.

title: CANADA UPHOLDS SUNDAY CLOSING LAW
description: For the last three weeks, Canadian newspapers have focused on two dominant stories: the Reagan Administration's secret arms sales to Iran and a domestic battle over Sunday shopping.

title: AREA IS AN INSULAR COMMUNITY
description: Howard Beach, a community on Jamaica Bay where a young black man was killed yesterday, has long been an insular neighborhood.

title: RHINE POLLUTION IS TRICKY ISSUE IN WEST GERMANY
description: ''When you live along this river, it has a special meaning,'' said Wolfgang Kaiser, the Mayor of this little town of half-timbered houses on the Rhine. ''You love it. And you want to know what is happening to Father Rhine.''

title: Heather Evans, An Executive, Weds an Artist
description: The marriage of Heather Helen Evans, senior vice president of CSB Holdings Inc., a financial services concern in New York, to Matthew Clay Baumgardner, an artist, took place yesterday at The Restaurant in Manhattan. The Rev. Terry Manahan, an independent Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: BRIDGEPORT'S HERD OF URBAN DEER
description: JUST two minutes north of Bridgeport's busy Boston Avenue, wild deer gather several times a day at the back doors of a busy munitions plant to await handouts from factory workers and office personnel.

title: Data Bank: December 21, 1986
FOCUS: Reston, Va.; Downtown Look for a 'New Town'
description: WIDELY hailed as the most esthetically pure city-satellite settlement of the 1960's, this celebrated ''new town'' in the northern Virginia suburbs of Washington is preparing to shed its carefully nurtured urban-village cocoon and go assertively ''downtown.''

title: PIANO: PANAYIS LYRAS
description: PANAYIS LYRAS is a pianist of enormous talent and technical facility, but his recital Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall was a disappointment, especially after his past success here.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SIGNS OF CONFUSION ''WE weren't notified the signs were going up,'' said Eileen Peters of Island Rides in Melville. ''One day we just started getting these phone calls. People call up and say, 'What road should I take to avoid the construction on Route 110?' And we say, 'The Department of Transportation has decided because of the construction delays you should get into a car pool.' ''

title: PANAMA OFFERS A HAVEN FOR SHADOWY CONCERNS
description: This is a land of companies that exist only on paper. There are more than 150,000 of them, and scores more are being set up every day, according to Government officials and corporate lawyers.

title: A SERIOUS COMEDY AT WHOLE THEATER
description: IF THE Italian playwright Dario Fo isn't well known in this country, don't blame the Whole Theatre.

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON THE NOT-SO-HONEST
description: THIS is the annual season of frauds; of the false Santa and the fake charity. So warns W. Richard Bruner, head of the Better Business Bureau office in White Plains. ''Now, more than any other time of the year, it's caveat emptor, or let the buyer beware,'' said Mr. Bruner, who is surprisingly cheerful for one who deals with flimflams, scams, broken contracts and the myriad other problems consumers are heir to year-round.

title: HOW THE SPIRITUAL INFUSED THE ABSTRACT
description: ''The Spiritual in Art: Abstract Painting 1890-1985'' surveys a great adventure. At a time when a new generation of abstract artists experiences the grids of Mondrian not as spiritual threshholds but as prison bars, the exhibition reminds us what was at stake when a handful of artists in different parts of Europe first painted without reference to the external world. It helps us measure the leap they made and understand the doubt - and assurance - that was required to make it.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's About Westchester column the name of a restaurant in Armonk was misspelled. It is Le Gueridon.

title: REPORTER'SNOTEBOOK: DIVINING CUOMO'S MOTIVES
description: When hundreds of elderly people confronted Governor Cuomo outside his office the other day demanding a new state plan to subsidize the cost of their prescription drugs, the angry voice of one elderly Brooklyn man shouted above the others: ''Governor, don't you go to New Hampshire! We want you here with us now!''

title:
ART;
CHINESE FOLK OBJECTS AT YALE
description: EFFERVESCENT and clear are the adjectives that come to mind at the exhibition of Chinese folk art at the Yale University Art Gallery. Though it probably was not the gallery's intention - and certainly not the intention of the Chinese artisans who made these objects - the show is perfect for the holidays. One leaves feeling merry about humankind.

title: A Private Library
description: The reference to Brooke Astor's personal munificence to the New York Public Library, accompanying the pictures of her exquisite personal library, serves as a reminder of our longstanding debt of gratitude to this extraordinary woman (''A Private Library,'' by Barbaralee Diamonstein, Home Design, Nov. 16).

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A GROUP of hikers and naturalists in Morris County is trying to interest county and state officials in preserving the undeveloped area around Pyramid Mountain in Montville Township and Kinnelon.

title: PACERS ROUT KNICKS
description: After every defeat, every embarrassing performance, someone suggests that it couldn't get any worse. And yet it does. Last night, before an announced crowd of 9,535 very displeased spectators at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks sank to new depths, stumbling through a performance so utterly without value that the team was booed throughout the final period. That was when the Indiana Pacers, a team that had lost six consecutive games on the road, humiliated the Knicks.

title: POSTINGS: Long Beach Auction;
description: In real estate, as in many other fields, price is the best measure of value. That was proved again last week in Long Beach, a community that had been in decline but more recently has been enjoying a buoyant revival and attracting the interest and the dollars of developers.

title: Paul Sperry is Named Head of Joy in Singing
description: The tenor Paul Sperry has been named director of Joy in Singing, an organization that helps young singers receive coaching and offers them a chance to perform professionally, with the added goal of furthering the art of the song recital. Mr. Sperry is a recitalist and a teacher of 19th- and 20th-century music at the Juilliard School and the Aspen Music Festival.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Bonus Payoff Here's a thought for the bonus season: According to F. Thomas Juster, professor of economics at the University of Michigan, fewer than 10 percent of American companies give bonuses. If more did, he says, it would give the nation's savings rate - and thus the economy - a lift, as more money would be available for business investment.

title: LA GUARDIA'S GROWTH PLANS IRK QUEENS RESIDENTS
description: For years, say Joan DaCorta Mathes and her neighbors hard by the western edge of La Guardia Airport, life in Astoria and Jackson Heights has been changing for the worse. Now, they say, their patience has run dry.

title: Davids Island
description: To the Editor:

title: ABRASIVE SAW BLADES: NO TEETH BUT PLENTY OF BITE FOR THE JOB
description: EVERY home handyman knows that if he wants to cut a piece of wood he will need a carpenter's saw, and if he wants to cut metal he will pick up a hacksaw. But what does one use to cut a piece of ceramic tile, or a brick?

title: PUTTING A GOOD FACE ON REVLON
description: The stock of Revlon Group Inc., the acquisition vehicle controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, has sold off in recent weeks to about $11, from a 52-week high of $19.25. Two problems beset the cosmetics marketer: its failure to swing another big deal, as Wall Street expected, and its close financing ties with Drexel Burnam Lambert Inc., which has come under regulatory scrutiny in the wake of the Boesky affair.

title: TEACHING THE HUMANE TOUCH
description: ON A RECENT Wednesday morning, six people sat in the waiting room at the walk-in clinic of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. A young man in a white coat, a stethoscope bobbing around his neck, approached one of them. ''My name is Michael Gillette,'' he told a patient in his mid-30's whose neck was in a brace. ''I'm a second-year medical student at Harvard, and if it's O.K. with you, I'd like to interview you before the doctor sees you.''

title: Fox Hunting
description: To the Editor: Hats off to Ray Brady for his story ''Ireland's Zest for the Chase'' (Travel, Oct. 19). Age and economics have prevented my hunting with any of the famous packs he mentions, but I have been in the ''hill toppers'' parade more than once.

title: HOMOSEXUALS FAIL TO ATTAIN DESERT TOWN
description: Dreams of transforming this dusty desert town into a homosexual community have died after promoters of the project were able to raise only $100 of the $2.25 million asking price.

title: OLD DISPUTE ON THE MX ERUPTS ANEW
description: THE briefing officer at the Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha tapped his pointer on a bar graph comparing targets in the Soviet Union to nuclear warheads in the United States arsenal. ''To retaliate,'' he said, ''it would take more than double what we have on the ramp now.''

title: PRETORIA IS HOPING THE UNKNOWN WON'T HURT IT
description: SOUTH AFRICA'S black majority has long been used to being told what it may not do - hold public meetings, for example, or vote on national affairs. But under the newest tightening of emergency rules, blacks and other dissenters were also told what they may not refuse to do - patronize stores, accept the draft, go to school or use the buses that provide apartheid's umbilical link between white-run cities and black labor in the townships.

title: SANTA SENDS ADVICE OVER THE TELEPHONE
description: SANTA CLAUS, who will make his traditional rounds Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, has already come a-calling in the Hartford area. And when he calls, he really does know if you have been naughty or nice.

title: ACCORD STILLS TURNPIKE-WIDENING OPPONENTS
description: AN UNUSUAL agreement between the state and East Brunswick Township has virtually eliminated community opposition to the planned multibillion-dollar widening of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: POLISH NATIVITY PLAY IN NEW BRITAIN
description: IN Poland, the story of the Nativity is usually presented in the Pastoralka, or Shepherd's Play. Whether performed by small community groups or professional theater companies, the Pastoralka uses elements of medieval miracle plays and fuses them with a variety of traditional music.

title:
GARDENING;
HOLIDAY PLANTS REQUIRE CARE, TOO
description: IT is not uncommon for Christmas plants to die before the end of the holiday festivities. But they have the inherent ability to last much longer. The secret of prolonging their life is that of providing them with optimum conditions. To do so is not at all difficult. All living plants have certain minimum requirements. Let's examine them one by one.

title: CANADIENS HALT DEVILS' STREAK
description: Mats Naslund scored a goal and added two assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens ended a three-game New Jersey victory streak with a 5-2 triumph over the Devils.

title: SEX CASE ACCUSER IS DISCOVERED DEAD
description: The body of the woman whose complaint began the McMartin preschool molestation case was found in her home on Friday, and the police today began investigating the circumstances of her death.

title: Burlington Gets a Land Gift
description: Burlington has received an early Christmas gift: nearly eight acres of waterfront beach property from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: A PLACE FOR PASTA LOVERS
description: STAMFORD residents who complain about a dearth of attractive restaurants in their city have not been paying attention. Within the last two years more than a dozen new restaurants have opened there, several to well-earned accolades.

title: A June Wedding For Mary Allen And W.H. Proom
description: The engagement of Mary Winifred Allen to William Harper Proom has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Cary Allen of Newton and Plymouth, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Burt Chandler Proom of West Simsbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. Proom.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS CASE IN SLAYING OF TROOPER
description: After five weeks of testimony by 67 witnesses, the state has rested its murder case against two avowed revolutionaries in the shooting of a New Jersey state trooper.

title: A Good Fur Year In New England
description: THERE should be enough fur to keep many a body warm this winter, judging from the price and volume of sales at the fall fur auction in Bethel, Vt. When the bidding was done, trappers from around New England had sold 7,400 pelts and collectively pocketed $99,000, 400 pelts and $22,000 more than last year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE JOURNAL OF NICHOLAS THE AMERICAN. By Leigh Kennedy. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) This story of a first-generation Russian-American is anything but what one expects, and therein lies much of its appeal.

title: BLACK MAN DIES AFTER BEATING BY WHITES IN QUEENS
description: A 23-year-old black man was struck and killed by a car on a Queens highway early yesterday after being severely beaten twice by 9 to 12 white men who chased him and two other black men through the streets of Howard Beach in what the police called a racial attack.

title: WAR'S TRIALS ''ONLY MEMORIES'' NOW
description: FROM a cafeteria window in the New Jersey Veterans Home here, a wheelchair-bound resident watched a chilling rain fall on wet snow.

title: Sheila A. Heffron Becomes a Bride
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J., yesterday Sheila Anne Heffron, who is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University, was married to Michael Louis Rankowitz, a principal of the fixed income division at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. Msgr. John McDermott performed the ceremony.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A 'LAME DUCK'
description: UNTIL about six weeks ago, those who profess to know who's who in this town said that Paul A. Volcker had become a lame duck - a man whose chances of being reappointed head of the Federal Reserve had fallen well below 50-50 and who had begun to weigh seriously some of the juicy seven-figure-a-year offers dangling before him.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A PROFESSOR JOINS 'THEM'
description: DUE to a late resignation last summer, I was asked by the academic dean and the president to serve as acting associate academic dean for one semester. Appealing to my loyalty (''It's one of the most critical positions of the college as far as students are concerned.'') and ego (''You were the first choice on both our lists.''), they made it difficult to say no. I said yes and my life changed.

title: A DOSE OF THE MALL: IT MAKES ME HIGH
description: I AM an addict, but it is not heroin, cocaine or alcohol that I'm hooked on: It's the mall. To paraphrase A. A.'s introductory greeting, ''My name is Caren, and I'm a mall-aholic.'' Whenever life becomes oppressively mundane, a dose of the Stamford Town Center, or simply ''the mall,'' makes me high.

title: Fern Tracy Grill Engaged to Dr. Richard S. Gold
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford F. Grill of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fern Tracy Grill, to Dr. Richard Samuel Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gold of Plainview, L.I.

title: DANCE: AILEY'S 'MEMORIA'
description: ALVIN AILEY has created stronger and more cohesive dances than ''Memoria,'' which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed on Thursday at City Center, but the piece is certainly one of his most affecting. ''Memoria'' can be seen as a bittersweet elegy with a sudden burst of high spirits at the close. It also alludes in a vivid but poetically understated way to the life and personal qualities of Mr. Ailey's friend and colleague, the late Joyce Trisler.

title: PARCELLS IS 'ONE OF THEM'
description: MOST pro football teams are coached by strangers in town with little or no feeling for a team's past. But the coach who has restored the Giants' glory grew up rooting for other Giants teams of glory. Bill Parcells is a New Jersey guy who had Giant pennants on the wall in his room as a youngster. And now, in guiding his Giants to a 14-2 record, the most victories in any of the franchise's 62 seasons, he deserves to be the National Football League's Coach of the Year.

title: No Ending Yet to Unbelievable Story
description: WHO would have believed it?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Walnut Creek, Calif.;
A Losing Fight Against Nature
description: PART of the bucolic charm of a suburban adult community here - its juxtaposition to a major wildlife refuge - has become its bane.

title: Discrimination Claim Filed by AIDS Sufferer
description: A Sunset Boulevard fingernail salon that refused to give a pedicure to a hairdresser who has AIDS has become the first business to be charged under the city's AIDS antidiscrimination law.

title: GARDENERS CULTIVATE THEIR SKILLS IN WINTER CLASSES
description: IN this season of chilling winds and frozen ground, the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service is looking for gardeners.

title: A Sense Of Direction
description: I agree with Peter Quinn; I have never met a man who could peacefully ask for directions. I have spent hours with men who search rather than pull in at the next gas station: ''Make a left, go two blocks and turn right'' are not the answer to an existential question. They are simple directions. LAURA WINTERS Madison, N.J.

title: NEW HOME EASES VETERANS PLIGHT
description: FOR 40-year-old John Viola, holidays are a time to share with family and friends, and being at a veterans' nursing home that is only an hour away from them is important.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Film buffs can savor an array of family nuggets at home this Christmas Eve. Wednesday afternoon repeats the sterling TV version of ''Little Lord Fauntleroy'' (1980) with Ricky Schroder and Alec Guinness - 1 P.M. on Channel 9. Then comes that golden showcase for young Judy Garland, ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' (1945) - 8 P.M. on Channel 5; and, as Santa approaches, the superb British version of Dickens' ''A Christmas Carol'' (1951) - 12 midnight., same station. At 2 A.M. there's a double flow of Jerome Kern, and Rodgers and Hart -the Astaire-Hayworth ''You Were Never Lovelier'' (1942) on Channel 9; and ''Words and Music'' (1948) on Channel 5.

title: Buckley's Words
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DESIGNED FOR PEACE
description: A new medal,''One Planet,'' reaffirms mankind's hope for world peace, but it does so in a way that people seldom contemplate: by looking at Earth from outer space.

title: XX-Rated Dealings
description: DEAR SIR: We regret to inform you that the person you address no longer does business at this location.

title: MUSIC: THE DUO ARPEGGIONE
description: MUSIC can be used in many ways, and not all of them need involve concert performance. Somehow, Merkin Concert Hall seemed the wrong place for the Duo Arpeggione's Thursday evening program.

title: Shaking the Habit Of Tipping
description: WHEN the owners of the Quilted Giraffe restaurant in Manhattan opened another, less-expensive eating place last July, they advised the customers not to tip the waiters.

title: POPULATION DOWN TO 51, MAINE ISLAND IS SEARCHING FOR A FEW GOOD RESIDENTS
description: Dan Blaszczuk has spent the better part of the last year trying to dispel the notion that life on an island off the coast of Maine is idyllic.

title: CITY'S TRAFFIC PROBLEMS CAN BE QUITE PEDESTRIAN
description: HUSTLE and bustle are integral components of New York's charm. The throngs surging out of the subways each morning in midtown Manhattan attest to the city's vitality, as do the crowds that pour into the South Street Seaport at lunchtime and the holiday shoppers who filled Fifth Avenue and Herald Square last week. In recent years, though, some New Yorkers have begun to wonder if they might have too much of a good thing.

title: A Sense Of Direction
description: Years ago, when I was still a young boy, my mother slapped me after I steadfastly refused to remind a bus driver to let us know when to get off, and we had to take a taxi back to our destination from the outskirts of town.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HIGH STAND. By Hammond Innes. (Atheneum, $17.95.) In an author's note in ''High Stand,'' his 26th novel, Hammond Innes tells us that for a quarter of a century he has been planting Canadian trees in Wales ''to offset the destruction of the world's forests'' and that this book fulfills a longstanding desire to write an adventure novel about trees.

title: MAKEUP ARTIST FOUND GUILTY IN SLASHING OF MODEL
description: A television makeup artist was found guilty last night of assault in the razor slashing of a fashion model's face on the West Side of Manhattan last summer.

title: Miss Conway To Be Bride
description: Allison Brandes Conway, a vice president in the investment banking sector of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, and Richard Brian Carey, a vice president in the London office of the investment banking sector of Manufacturers Hanover, plan to be married in March.

title: Miss Flanagan Weds George Arguelles
description: The wedding of Sarah Flanagan to George William Arguelles took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard Stearns performed the ceremony.

title: A Smoking Encore From Dr. Koop
description: In 1964, the Surgeon General issued a report that eventually led to the now-familiar warnings that smoking can cause lung cancer, heart disease and death.

title: V.C. Andrews, Novelist, Dies; Wrote of Families' Dark Side
description: V.C. Andrews, a novelist whose books dealt with adolescent and family problems against a tableau of horror and suspense, is dead of cancer, according to her publisher.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 26 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: HOLIDAY ALTERNATIVE: THE SURROGATE SHOPPER
description: Telephone lights blink like tree ornaments. Messages pile up. Cheery red bags overflowing with gifts spill into hallways. People staggering under piles of clothing rush in and out.

title: SUFFERN
description: IN its tranquil setting at the foot of the Ramapos, the Rockland County village of Suffern seems somehow out of sync with its bustling neighbors to the south and east.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we're comparing apples and oranges. The American people need to know the facts, but I'm not sure they need to know all the advice every adviser gives to the President of the United States.''

title: CHICAGO
description: Notwithstanding the frigid blasts from Lake Michigan, winter in Chicago offers plenty of warmth and excitement. Residents and visitors alike enjoy the 45-foot-tall Christmas tree in Marshall Field's downtown store, the lights hanging from the trees on North Michigan Avenue and afternoon tea at the Drake Hotel.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated theater information for ''The Morning After.'' It opens Thursday at the RKO National Twin, Gotham Cinema, Embassy 72d Street, Bay Cinema, 86th Street East and Waverly Twin.

title: The Library Gets 'Shelley's Circle'
description: A cat in distress Nothing more or less Good folks I must faithfully tell ye As I am a sinner It wants for some dinner To stuff out its own little belly . . . PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY

title: GUNS THAT DIE OF EMBARRASSMENT
description: THE NEW MAGINOT LINE By Jon Connell. 348 pp. New York: Arbor House. $18.95.

title: Toward Racial Reform in South Africa
description: In South Africa, the picture darkens. The latest repression by the Government makes it hard to know quite what is going on, except that the pace is still set by violence, against or on behalf of the state. The white liberal opposition is helpless, the press stifled. In the circumstances, it is odd that so little has been heard of the latest effort to move toward authentic multiracial reform. But then, the man at the center of the effort is Gatsha Mangosuthu Buthelezi, an ambiguous figure and a widely hated one.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; Paying Tribute To History
description: HOW does a new building, rosy bright in color and designed with a minimum of flourish, fit the stringent requirements of a national historic district?

title: Victoria F. Lawford to Marry
description: The engagement of Victoria Frances Lawford to Robert B. Pender has been announced by Patricia Kennedy Lawford of New York and Southampton, L.I.,, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. James C. O'Shea of Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert B. Pender.

title: SUSPECT FREED AS RESULT OF LINK TO DONOVAN CASE
description: A man charged with beating and robbing a woman on a Bronx street has been freed after the prosecutor in the case refused to cross-examine a witness who is a juror in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: CLUBS GATHER GIFTS FOR NEEDY
description: WHILE they are marking the holiday season with parties, many of Long Island's business clubs and professional associations are also involving their members in activities to benefit local charities.

title: A Hat Named Kerry
description: With the list of prospective entrants in the 1988 Presidential race already beginning to resemble the Washington telephone directory, a group in California is advancing the name of John Kerry, a first-term Democrat from Massachusetts.

title: CONCERT: WESTENBURG 'MESSIAH
description: THE ''Messiah'' performances of Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra chorus have a reputation as the town's liveliest concert-hall version of the beloved work. This listener, visiting the annual celebration for the first time at Avery Fisher Hall Friday, found it lively, polished, deft, dancelike - and wished for grandeur and weight.

title: AUTO INDUSTRY ADJUSTING TO A PAINFUL NEW REALITY
description: GENERAL MOTORS produced another batch of bad news last week. Beset by slumping sales and determined not to return to the generous incentives that led to a whopping third-quarter loss, the automotive giant will temporarily cut production by as much as a third, idling more than 30,000 workers.

title: China Opens Its Doors to Housing for Foreigners
description: FOR the first time since the Communists took power in China nearly four decades ago, opportunities are being created for foreign nationals living and working in its major cities to buy their own apartments or town houses.

title: HOLIDAY SHOPPERS BUY, BUY, BUY
description: CHRISTMAS shoppers have been out in droves at Long Island's malls since Thanksgiving weekend, circling packed parking lots and clogging store escalators and counters on the biggest buying binge of the year.

title: PAKISTANI RIOTS ARE A SYMPTOM OF MANY ILLS
description: IT was shortly before dawn when Pakistani army troops swept through a densely populated slum colony of Afghan refugees in the northern outskirts of Karachi, searching for narcotics and illegal guns.

title: Fox Hunting
description: To the Editor: Granted that there are a lot of foxes, and granted that they occasionally do damage, what right have we to harry them and torture them with a long exhausting pursuit that eventually ends in a frightful death from sheer exhaustion, with hounds behind them?

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the On Language column of Dec. 7 referred to an incorrect address. English Today: The International Review of the English Language is available from Cambridge University Press, 32 East 57th Street, New York 10022.

title: Recent Sales
description: Flanders$242,000 86 Moony Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; 3 brick fireplaces, family room; taxes $3,500. Hackensack$179,000 289 Parker Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; 1-car garage, landscaping; taxes $4,410.

title: SING TO HEAVEN A NEW SONG
description: WOMEN-CHURCH Theology and Practice of Feminist Liturgical Communities. By Rosemary Radford Ruether. 306 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: RECTOR SHUTDOWN HERALDS DEBATE ON PLUTONIUM NEEDS
description: The shutdown of the Government-owned nuclear reactor at Hanford, Wash., one of the main sources of plutonium for the nation's nuclear arsenal, has set the stage for a major debate over how this country produces the raw material for nuclear bombs, and how much more is needed.

title: Korean Fishing Boat Missing
description: A South Korean fishing boat with 26 crew members is missing in rough seas off the east coast, the maritime police said today. Air force planes and 30 fishing boats were searching for the boat, the 103-ton Haepung No. 7.

title: REDMEN TESTED BY NIAGARA
description: For the second time in two visits, a nationally ranked St. John's team moving ahead with full steam was given all it could handle by a hustling Niagara squad bent on an upset.

title: VARIATIONS ON A THEME
description: Subjects for this year's worldwide Christmas celebration range from ancient customs to cartoon characters. The British Post Office offers a set of five stamps that show how Christmas customs have developed through the centuries. The stamps were inspired by five traditional Christmas customs, some of which survive to this day.

title: Mary Fletcher to Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dugald Angus Fletcher of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Martin Fletcher to Kane Kendall Baker, the son of Mrs. Rolla D. Campbell Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Center Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late George F. Baker Jr. Miss Fletcher and her fiance, members of the class of 1988 at Rollins College, plan to be married in June.

title: Miss Mueller Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Mueller of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Mueller's daughter Carolyn Marie Mueller to Joseph Philip von Meister, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William von Meister of Peapack, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: YES, DEAR LISTENERS, THERE ARE SOME CONCERTS AND BALLETS
description: IF the first two weeks of December are among the busiest on the county's cultural calendar, the rest of the month usually turns silent, with only Christmas church services carrying forward the musical torch. This year, however, we find the holiday bracketed by Sunday concerts, with a run of ''Nutcracker'' ballets into the bargain next weekend.

title: N. Carolina Romps
description: For about 32 minutes today, North Carolina was kept at bay by the patient offense and rebounding mastery of a smaller Illinois squad led by Ken Norman.

title: FATHERS GET THEIR OWN CATALOGUES
description: It is Christmas countdown time in the Rockies, and last-minute gift orders are still arriving at Me & My Dad, a catalogue for fathers. A hot item is a book called ''The Father's Almanac'' (''A fine addition to any father's library and a great gift for the new father,'' the catalogue says). Another big seller is the Baby Jogger stroller (''An extra-tall model is available for those over 6-foot-3''), and sets of Magnetic Blocks are moving briskly (''If they were on your desk, you'd feel compelled to play with them''). Dinosaur books are popular, as is the fold-out children's book ''Papa, Please Get the Moon for Me.''

title: Iraq Planes Bomb Iran, Which Puts Dead at 80
description: Iran said Iraqi jets bombed residential areas in western Iran today, killing more than 80 civilians. Iran vowed to retaliate.

title:
WASHINGTON WATCH;
Speculation Over F.C.C. Post
description: Recent top staff changes at the Federal Communications Commission have rekindled speculation that Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the agency for the last five and a half years, will leave this spring and be succeeded by Dennis Patrick, a Republican who has long been considered Mr. Fowler's most likely successor.

title: JAPAN'S POLITICIANS ECLIPSE BUREAUCRATS
description: Sadanori Yamanaka, not a household name even in Japan, suddenly became one of the country's most influential politicians this month.

title: Stock Volatility Possible Today
description: Some analysts are saying the stock market could be in for a bumpy ride this morning.

title: 2 Quakes Hit Iranian City
description: Two strong earthquakes shook the city of Mamassani in the southern Iranian province of Fars early today and damaged at least 80 houses, Iran's official press agency reported. There were no immediate reports of casualties. Last summer, six people were killed and 300 homes damaged in an earthquake in Mamassani, the agency said.

title: I.R.A. CLAIMS 3 ULSTER BOMBINGS
description: The Irish Republican Army has claimed responsibility for wrecking two hotels and a pub in what the police said was a pre-Christmas bombing campaign. An attempt to bomb a nightclub was foiled.

title: RIDING CECIL RHODES'S DREAM ACROSS A STARK LAND
description: Almost imperceptibly, below the blank stone gaze of Table Mountain, a train pulls out of Cape Town every other day, offering its passengers a luxury from the past that seems to contrast with the sadnesses of the present in the land it traverses.

title: ROCK: THE COMMUNARDS
description: AS the lead singer of Bronski Beat, and now with his new band the Communards, Jimmy Somerville has one overriding theme: that homosexual love is legitimate and romantic. ''Our love is like forbidden fruit,'' he sang Wedneday at the Ritz.

title: SINGAPORE'S ORGAN DONOR BILL
description: The Government of Singapore has announced that it would introduce legislation enabling the country's hospitals to remove the kidneys of victims of fatal accidents who have not previously indicated they do not wish to be organ donors.

title: 8 LATIN COUNTRIES PUSH PEACE TALKS
description: Eight Latin American Governments have announced that the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to join them in a new initiative aimed at reviving peace negotiations in Central America.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL SAN ANTONIO SPURS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS VS. DOLPHINS, at Miami, 9 P.M. (TV - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8:50 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Morgan State at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.); Columbia at Delaware (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: What to Teach, How to Teach, Why Teach?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT CAN REAGAN DO?
description: The White House strategy for handling the Iran arms affair, an insider said the other day, has been to offer one concession at a time in the hope of quelling the public furor, then to wait a few days to see what happened. In quick succession, President Reagan has urged the naming of an independent counsel, conceded that mistakes had been made in carrying out his policy, announced that he would permit his aides to testify before Congress and urged that Congress grant immunity to recalcitrant witnesses.

title: I.R.S. PRESSING BANKS TO MOVE ON TAX CHEATS
description: The Internal Revenue Service, contending that at least 1.1 million Americans have failed to provide their financial institutions with accurate Social Security numbers, has begun a tough enforcement program to combat the problem.

title: REPORT SAYS U.S. IS REACHING MANY GOALS FOR BETTER HEALTH
description: The nation is meeting many of its goals for better health but will miss targets for others, such as reducing infant mortality and teen-age pregnancy, the Public Health Service said today.

title: Julie Ellen Hyman Married To Dr. Aron D. Wahrman
description: Julie Ellen Hyman, a third-year medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Aron David Wahrman, a resident in surgery at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. The bridegroom's father, Cantor Henry Wahrman, and Rabbi Mordecai Rubin performed the ceremony.

title: RECORD IN '62 CAME EASIER
description: The man whose 1962 flight set a record that stood until the Voyager broke it says his flight was the easiest of his career and a far cry from the cramped, risky trip of the Voyager crew.

title: Matt Neuman Is Wed To Jan Ellen Cornell
description: The marriage of Jan Ellen Cornell, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Cornell of New York and Centerport, L.I., to Matt Neuman, a son of Estelle Neuman of Miami and the late Milton Neuman, took place yesterday. Rabbi Judah Nadich officiated at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents.

title: OPEC PACT MAY BE FLAWED MIRACLE
description: The agreement announced Saturday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries represents an ambitious bid by the 13-nation group to regain its former role as the price-setting manager of the world oil market. But to achieve that goal, OPEC will have to display a measure of unity, production discipline and political will that the aspiring cartel has often lacked during its 26-year history.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BOOKISH SATISFACTION The modern bookstore, with its here-today best sellers and reprints, often conveys the mood of a flighty society. The browser in search of literary depth may find satisfaction at the Antiquarian Booksellers' Center in the lobby of the Associated Press building, 50 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PUBIS ANGELICAL. By Manuel Puig. Translated From the Spanish by Elena

title: GIFTS TO NEEDY EXHIBIT SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS
description: Some people contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of buying gifts for friends and relatives.

title: VICTIM OF SLASHING CALLS CONVECTED MAN 'VICIOUS'
description: Marla Hanson, the 25-year-old model whose face was slashed in an attack last summer, yesterday called the man who was convicted in the assault ''a dangerous person and a vicious person.''

title: DeLOREAN SAYS HE HAS $20 MILLION FOR NEW CAR
description: John Z. DeLorean, the embattled automobile entrepreneur, said this weekend that he had raised $20 million to build a new car, a $100,000 sports car to be designed by a West German designer.

title: STUN-GUN CHARGES PROMPT POLICE INQUIRY IN WEST
description: The District Attorney here, after charging two former police officers with torturing a suspect, has begun a major investigation into the use of excessive force by the entire Huntington Park Police Department.

title: Racz & Dessimoz Wins Kawasho TV Account
description: Racz & Dessimoz Associates, specializing in boating, camera, hi-fi, video, wine and toy advertising, is going to be promoting television sets for Kawasho International (U.S.A.) with a budget of between $3 million and $4 million, starting Jan. 1. There was no previous agency.

title: DEBATE REVIVES AS JEAN HARRIS SEEKS CLEMENCY
description: Six years after Jean S. Harris was convicted of killing Dr. Herman Tarnower, the author of the best-selling ''Scarsdale Diet,'' the case is once again arousing debate.

title: CHIEFS LATE STARTERS IN PLAYOFF PARADE
description: For the first time in 15 years, the Kansas City Chiefs will be spending the holiday season with more than just family and friends.

title: MEXICO GLAD AS NEW U.S. ENVOY ACCENTS POSITIVE
description: The new United States Ambassador, Charles J. Pilliod Jr., is openly determined to portray Mexico in a favorable light in Washington, according to his aides.

title: IRANIAN IS REPORTED TO FLEE
description: The eldest son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament has apparently fled to Canada ''after receiving at least $6 million'' for his role in the sale of American arms to Iran, a London newspaper reported today.

title: Waiting, Waiting in the Flight Line
description: Travelers during these busiest flying days of the year understand that the combination of winter weather and holiday crowds often means late departures. But what explains the delays that have become almost routine at big airports - delays that waste some 2,000 hours of airliner time a day, all year round?

title: PLANE IS 3,000 MILES FROM WORLD GOAL
description: Uncertain that their fuel supply would last and suffering fatigue after a bruising week of nonstop flight, the crew of the experimental plane Voyager had clear weather today as they neared their craft's goal: being the first to fly around the world without stopping for fuel.

title: Three Children Killed in Fire
description: An intense fire before dawn today killed three children and injured their parents in a mobile home here, officials said.

title: EX-POLITICIAN IN HARLEM
description: Hulan E. Jack, the Harlem politician who in 1953 became the first black Borough President of Manhattan but lost office after a conflict-of-interest scandal, died Friday night at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Jack, who would have been 80 years old on Dec. 29, was a 45-year resident of West 110th Street.

title: Staff Shifts at L.F. Rothschild
description: The investment banking and brokerage firm L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc. announced the completion of its management restructuring in the wake of recent resignations by its chairman, Thomas I. Unterberg, and vice chairman, A. Robert Towbin.

title: Greyhound Accord
description: Greyhound Lines released a statement Friday that said the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents about 6,300 bus drivers and other employees, tentatively agreed to extend the current contract through March 18, assuring passengers that buses would continue to run during the holiday travel season.

title: Sakharov and Bonner To Moscow Tuesday
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident whose banishment to Gorky has been lifted, said today that he and his wife, the human rights activist Yelena G. Bonner, expect to travel from that city to Moscow on Tuesday.

title: If Only Jets Could Trade
description: UNFORTUNATELY for the Jets, the National Football League constitution forbids a team from trading a playoff berth. But now that the Jets have limped into the Super Bowl XXI tournament on a five-game losing streak for a 10-6 record, they would be better off trading their playoff berth to the Seattle Seahawks, who didn't qualify even though they finished at 10-6 with a five-game winning streak. The Jets' price would be an offense to be named later.

title: S.I. TRAINS UNDERGOING RENOVATION
description: It is not even a subway - only 150 yards or so are enclosed in a tunnel. But that did not prevent the Staten Island Rapid Transit system from doing what subways in New York seem destined to do: fall apart.

title: AGE-OLD RITUAL ENRICHES NEW MEXICO CHRISTMAS
description: For the people of New Mexico, Christmas means posole, a hominy and chili stew, and the anise-flavored cookies known as bizcochitos as well as Christmas ham and egg nog.

title: CHINA DENOUNCES STUDENT PROTESTS AS 'ILLEGAL ACTS'
description: The Chinese Government, in its first formal reaction to the student protests in Shanghai, lashed out today at the tens of thousands of demonstrators for trying to disrupt ''stability and unity'' and ''derange production and social order.''

title: Patrick and the Snakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Arbitrator to Apply Experience at USX
description: Sylvester Garrett has spent a lifetime finding common ground between adversaries. He has resolved labor disputes involving shipbuilders, teachers, pilots, bus drivers, postal employees and iron and steel workers, among others.

title: MUSIC: ST. CECILIA CHORUS
description: THE life story of Fanny Mendelssohn, whose ''Oratorio on Biblical Themes'' was given its first American performance by the St. Cecilia Chorus Saturday at Carnegie Hall, is happy with a deep sharp strain of sadness. Like her famous brother, Felix, she was trained in music from an early age, and like him she composed throughout her short life; some 500 of her works are extant. Despite the conventions of her time, she aspired to combine motherhood with a public career as a composer. Her brother, while maintaining close relations and protesting concern for her wifely nature, played a cruel role in the frustration of her wish by refusing his endorsement at a critical juncture (though he had condescended to publish some of her songs, under his name, several years earlier).

title: ANSWERS NOT EASY AS ORMSBY RELECTS
description: Six months after having jumped off a 30-foot bridge after dropping out of a race, Kathy Ormbsy says her suicide attempt was not planned.

title: Gas Prices Remain Stable
description: Gasoline prices remained virtually unchanged from two weeks ago, as retailers battled it out to win over motorists with lower prices, an industry analyst said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., said its president, Nolan D. Archibald, had been elected chairman.

title: 'WEEPING VIRGIN' ICON DRAWS THRONGS TO CHICAGO
description: An estimated 5,000 people a day have been jamming a small Chicago church to see a painting of the Virgin Mary that has streaks of moisture streaming from the eyes and hands.

title: Hall of Fame Inducts Four New Members
description: Carl W. Nichols and Raymond J. Petersen, both former chairmen of the American Advertising Federation, have been elected to its Advertising Hall of Fame along with the late Arthur C. Nielsen Sr., founder of the A. C. Nielsen Company, and the late Robert W. Woodruff, longtime head of Coca-Cola.

title: Advertising; Rumrill Is Gaining Exposure
description: RECENTLY, the R. T. French Company of One Mustard Street in Rochester helped add spice to the life of Richard D. Thomson, president of Rumrill-Hoyt in that city, by slipping his agency a number of assignments.

title: Isidore & Paulson Win Lightolier Assignment
description: Lightolier Inc., of Secaucus, N.J., a division of Genlyte, has decided to give its advertising to Isidore & Paulson.

title: Holiday Visiting In Surrogate Case
