description: A judge has ruled that an infant girl caught in a custody battle between her surrogate mother and the couple who hired the woman to bear the child can be visited Christmas Eve by the natural mother's family.

title:
WASHINGTON WATCH;
A Fight for I.C.C.
description: The Reagan Administration is again planning to propose a zero budget for the 1988 fiscal year for the Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates trucking and rail transportation.

title: ASTRAL RECIPE: EXTREME TIDES
description: A rare coincidence in the relationships between the Sun, the Moon and the Earth next week will produce extreme tides that could increase the threat of coastal flooding, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS TIGHTENING CURBS ON THREE OPPOSITION NEWSPAPERS
description: The South African authorities have further tightened reporting restrictions on three anti-Government newspapers.

title: JETS LOSE, 52-21: SLIDE AT 5 GAMES
description: Faced with the desperate need to start winning with the playoffs looming, the Jets instead collapsed offensively and defensively today, ending the regular season with their fifth straight loss.

title: 1 PILOT DIES IN CRASH
description: One pilot was killed and a second escaped uninjured yesterday when their small, single-engine airplanes collided 300 feet over Kingston-Ulster Airport in upstate New York, the police and the airport manager said.

title: Interco Chief Pursues Expansion and Diversity
description: When Harvey Saligman, the chairman of Interco, announced an agreement last week to buy the Lane furniture company, he completed a corporate shopping spree.

title: Intravenous-Drug Abuse Is the Front Line in the War on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Transamerica Unit to Be Sold
description: The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company will sell its group life and health operations to the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company in a transaction valued at $275 million, the two companies announced Friday.

title: JOKES STILL GO FOR THE CITY'S JUGULAR
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode goes on television here at the end of World War III and tries to explain to unhappy Philadelphians why the Russians ignored the city and did not vaporize it. But if residents are disappointed, the Eagles football team is delighted. They win the Super Bowl. It may be by default, but they will take it. And happily.

title: Couplings
description: Cohabitation, the Census Bureau finds, continues to increase. Some 2.2 million Americans now are counted as ''persons of the opposite sex sharing living quarters'' - and still no one knows what to call them.

title: The Dolphins Depart
description: After 21 seasons, the Miami Dolphins play in the Orange Bowl for the final time tonight. Their next home game is Aug. 16, 1987, when they meet Chicago in an exhibition at Dolphin Stadium, a 73,000-seat park being built with all the luxuries and conveniences by the team's owner, Joe Robbie, on his 432 acres near the line that separates Dade and Broward Counties to the north.

title: LABOR REJECTS MANILA CHARTER
description: The largest labor movement in the Philippines voted today to campaign against the Aquino Government's proposed constitution on the ground that the Government has drifted to the right in its policies.

title: PARRISH SEES END TO DAYS WITH TIGERS
description: IF Jack Morris is back in Detroit, can Lance Parrish be far behind?

title: 2 FACTORS CITED FOR RISE IN POVERTY
description: High unemployment and falling wages were the factors most responsible for the 7 million increase in the number of poor Americans since 1979, not the rise of single-parent households, a Congressional study says.

title: SANDINISTAS FLEX THEIR MUSCLE: 6,500 TROOPS IN WAR GAMES
description: The Nicaraguan armed forces have just completed three days of large-scale military maneuvers in this remote region bordering Honduras, From the Nicaraguan briefings and the way the exercise was conducted, it was clear the Sandinistas wanted to demonstrate that although their army has shortcomings, it is rapidly improving and capable of fighting more than a counterinsurgency war against the contras in the forested mountains of Nicaragua.

title: Transit Chic
description: Only the French could do it. The nation that a couple of years ago had the world chattering about its self-cleaning outdoor urinals now has made a cult item out of its yellow subway tickets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball Blazers 128, Bullets 101: In Portland, Ore., Kiki Vandeweghe scored 18 of his 29 points in the second half last night for the Trail Blazers. Jim Paxson came off the bench to add 20 for the Blazers, who won for the 10th time in their last 12 games and their 11th straight at home. Portland used its fast break and defense, outscoring the Bullets by 16-2 over a four-minute stretch to take a 117-91 lead with 4 minutes 30 seconds to play. (AP) Lakers 103, Rockets 96: Magic Johnson scored a season-high 38 points, including 8 in a fourth-quarter Laker comeback. Los Angeles went into the fourth quarter in Houston leading, 80-77, but the Rockets charged ahead by 91-86 with 4:29 left. The Lakers then outscored Houston, 17-5, the rest of the way. The Lakers played the game without Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who is out with a recurring cornea problem in his right eye. Lakers officials said his status would be determined today.(AP) Georgia Tech 63, S.M.U. 54: Duane Ferrell scored 17 points and Tom Hammonds added 16 to lead Georgia Tech over Southern Methodist in the final yesterday of the Suntory Ball tournament in Tokyo. Hammonds led the Yellow Jackets to two victories in the three-team tournament and was named the most valuable player. (UPI) Hockey Soviet Takes Tourney: The Soviet Union won Izvestia hockey tournament in Moscow with a 1-0 victory over Czechoslovakia, the defending champion, as Sergei Makarov scored the only goal in the 13th minute of the first period.

title: Selling Loans for Phony Savings
description: Americans owe Uncle Sam some $250 billion under various Federal loan programs. Selling those loans to private investors is one of Washington's new tricks for reducing the budget deficit. The Government gets cash quickly and painlessly; the investor gets a discounted loan that should eventually pay off at face value and pays interest in the meantime. While there is some merit to this undertaking, it is poor deficit-reduction strategy.

title: ARMS CONTROL - ART OF THE POSSIBLE
description: The United States has already paid a heavy price for its scandalous weapons sales to Iran. Yet if some of the sweeping arms proposals put forth last October at Reykjavik - which remain on the table at Geneva - are ever accepted, the damage to vital American interests will immeasurably eclipse even the most harmful consequences of the Iran affair.

title: SCIENTISTS PLAN NEW WAY OF PINPOINTING LONGITUTDE
description: On Dec. 31, 1987, the last remnants of a measurement system that used an astronomical device in Greenwich, England, as a reference for determining longitudes will be abolished.

title: Catching Up
description: * Remember Clifford Allen? He's the 6-foot-10-inch center who wound up as yet another unlikely prospect for Coach Jerry Tarkanian's Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team. The 18-year-old Allen, though regarded as one of the best school-age pivot men in California, has been in so much trouble for most of his life that he's managed to play only one high school game - a tournament loss last February in which he scored 32 points and grabbed 18 rebounds for the El Paso de Robles juvenile-detention center in Paso Robles.

title: MERRY REMEMBRANCES
description: IN the island town where I was a child, many Christmases were brown, and a new, shiny sled might hang unused in the toolshed most of the winter to be gazed upon and touched hopefully whenever black clouds hanging low over the gray sea and the sere meadows seemed too heavy to pass by without a gift of snow.

title: FLUTIE STARTS AND SPARKLES
description: Doug Flutie threw two touchdown passes in his debut as a starter for the Chicago Bears today, and Walter Payton tied the National Football League of 106 career rushing touchdowns in a 24-10 defeat of Dallas that gave the Cowboys their first losing season in 22 years.

title: Solarz Meets Pakistani
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, discussed Pakistan's security problems today with Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo, senior Foreign Ministry officials said. Pakistan is expecting $4.02 billion in American military and economic assistance over the next six years, and the aid is subject to Congressional approval.

title: MUSIC: BLUES AND SOUL SHOW
description: A TOURING blues and soul show starring Frankie Lee, Sonny Rhodes and Eddie Ray appeared at Tramps over the weekend. The featured artists have been popular attractions at West Coast blues festivals and clubs for several years now, but this is their first chance to make an impression in New York, and they made the most of it.

title: One Big G.M. Holder Is Not Publicity-Shy
description: In the past, institutional investors operated out of the glare of the public spotlight, but now managers of pension funds and other holders of huge blocks of stock are seeking public attention as they challenge corporate actions.

title: N.S.C. BEING RESTRUCTURED TO GIVE MORE FOCUS TO COORDINATING POLICY
description: The National Security Council is being restructured so that it can assume a more important role in coordinating Government policy when Frank C. Carlucci becomes the White House national security adviser in January, according to experts close to the council.

title: G.M.'S PRODUCTION CUTS LEAVE ANALYSTS WARY
description: The General Motors Corporation's apparent determination to cut production to meet its sagging sales rate may entail as much danger for its current and future profitability as the sales incentives the company has renounced, auto analysts contend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1986
description: International

title: SOVERN SAYS SCANDALS HURT CITY'S RECRUITING
description: Corruption in New York City is undermining the city's ability to attract a new generation of ''first-class'' civil servants, the chairman of a commission appointed to study the city's municipal corruption scandal said yesteray.

title: And Still They Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDEAST PEACE SAID TO BE CENTRAL CONCERN OF O'CONNOR
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who is to leave this week for a 10-day trip to Jordan, Israel and Egypt, hopes to make the achievement of peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors one of the central concerns of his leadership, according to an American Jewish leader who spoke with him.

title: DANCE: 'TWO' AND OTHER WORKS BY BEBE MILLER
description: THERE is sometimes an uncomfortable pull between body and mind in Bebe Miller's choreography. Just as one wonders why she is doing what she is doing, however, a moment of such inherent rightness comes along that one accepts the inevitability of it all. But there is no such dichotomy in ''Two,'' a new duet created by Ms. Miller and Ralph Lemon that was performed by the two on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Heart, mind and acute physicality come together in what promises to be one of the most powerful dances of the year.

title: DANCE: BRONX 'NUTCRACKER'
description: ''IT'S sad when the dream is over,'' a man said as he left the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts (at Lehman College in the Bronx) on Saturday night, after a performance by the Eglevsky Ballet of ''The Nutcracker.'' Staged by Michael Vernon, the ballet was a dream, with well-schooled, lively dancing, an amazing variety of stage effects for a small touring production and inventive bits of dramatic business that for the most part make this holiday classic even more believable. Mr. Vernon has continued to tinker with the ballet, set to the familiar Tchaikovsky score, since it was seen last year at Lehman Center. But it is still a version that does honor to the ballet.

title: City Hall: Politics; The Corporate Route To a Government Job
description: The more imaginative of New York City's politicians have predicted from the start that the scandals of 1986 would lead to reforms -but nobody expected that corruption would bring the practices of corporate America to City Hall. In a way, it has. For the first time in memory, the city is hiring an executive search company - better known as a ''head hunter'' - to recommend candidates for some jobs.

title: Two Killed in Fire In Rooming House
description: Two people were killed when they were trapped by a fire Saturday night in a rooming house here.

title: Lori Fierstein Is Wed To Michael Tutelman
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Lori Marcia Fierstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Fierstein of Elmhurst, Queens, was married to Michael Tutelman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tutelman of Oldsmar, Fla. Rabbi Maurice Aronoff officiated.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Hearing on the Homeless The City Council's Select Committee on the Homeless is to hold a hearing to determine if there are staff shortages at welfare hotels and shelters for the homeless. 1 P.M., 23d-floor hearing room, 250 Broadway.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SINGAPORE LEADER FEARS U.S. CONFUSION
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today that a prolonged crisis over the Iran arms deals could throw American foreign policy into confusion just as the Reagan Administration had begun to give it coherence.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 19 about investors in a partnership with Ivan F. Boesky mistakenly described Lewis Lehrman's affiliation with the Rite Aid Corporation. He was part owner and president, but is not sole owner.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 22, 1986: MONDAY Primark Corp TUESDAY Ameron IncPark Electrochemical Boston Edison

title: WALL ST. FRIDAY: CHICKEN LITTLE TIME
description: It is called the Friday syndrome. And, last Friday, just as was the case for several weeks running, traders in the stock market hunkered down as they approached a weekend, fearing the market chaos that could ensue if the Government dropped the next shoe in the ongoing Ivan F. Boesky insider trading scandal.

title: Audibles for America
description: Only the playoffs will tell whether the defending Super Bowl champions can repeat, but one thing is already certain: The Chicago Bears are the gabbiest team in the land.

title: Imagine: Brooklyn vs. Pawtucket
description: Nearly 30 years have passed since the Dodgers abandoned Ebbets Field for Los Angeles, and Brooklyn has never stopped pining for a team of its own. That may explain the enthusiasm of borough politicians for a dubious plan to build a $58 million stadium for minor-league baseball.

title: GORBACHEV ON THE FUTURE: 'WE WILL NOT GIVE IN'
description: Here are key passages from notes of a talk by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on June 19 at a closed meeting with a group of Soviet writers. The notes, taken by one of the writers, were translated by The New York Times. Although the note-taker's identity is not known, writers who attended have confirmed the authenticity of the material.

title: U.S. Bill Financings Head a Slim List
description: The Treasury is adhering to its regular schedule of financings, even while investor activity and new offerings of corporate and tax-exempt issues decline sharply during the holiday season.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Friday about a Fifth Avenue peddler receiving a summons gave the time incorrectly.

title: IN BUREAUCRACY, TORPOR
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev called for more openness in Soviet society and signaled greater freedom for the arts, the response was heady.

title: Soviet Grain Purchases
description: The Soviet Union is expected to increase its purchases of Canadian grain this year, with total purchases possibly approaching a record nine million metric tons, sources in the grain industry said today. The record of 8.5 million metric tons was set in 1982-83. By contrast, in the last full year of a nonbinding grain agreement with the United States, the Soviet Union has bought only a fraction of the minimum four million metric tons it had agreed to buy.

title: Patient Gets Artificial Heart As Human Donor Is Sought
description: Surgeons implanted an artificial heart into an unidentified patient over the weekend and were searching for a human heart donor, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: WHAT WE KNOW
description: It is time to stop focusing on the unanswered questions, as if they were all that mattered. What remains unknown about the Iran arms affair is much less important than what we do know.

title: U.S. and Beijing Inaugurate $10 Million Satellite Station
description: Chinese and American officials today formally inaugurated the first United States-supplied satellite ground station to be sold to a Communist nation.

title: Farmer Trampled by Ostrich
description: An ostrich farmer was critically injured when he was trampled by a 400-pound ostrich that he was trying to lasso. The farmer, J. T. Coody, 65 years old, of Cache, Okla., was helping to load 13 ostriches into two trucks at a farm near here last Sunday when one of the birds ran over him, John O'Connor, director of Ada County paramedics, said Friday.

title: Face Down in the Mud
description: The right to do something does not mean that doing it is right.

title: New Products Rise
description: November new product introductions into supermarket and drug stores was 230, according to the DFS Dorland New Products News. That was an increase from the 225 in the same month last year. That brings the total for the first 11 months of the year to 2,327, compared with 2,031 in the 1985 period.

title: TEMPORARY PLAN URGED IN BATTLE ON MASS TRANSIT
description: Representatives of Governor Cuomo and of the State Senate today supported a temporary plan that would put off for six months a decision on how to pay for rebuilding New York City's mass transit system and would freeze fares.

title: A DELICATE BALANCE IN LIFE ON A PEDESTAL
description: A LITTLE before midnight in a Florida city a week ago Saturday night, a hero was arrested.

title: RANGERS LOSE GOAL, AND OVERTIME GAME
description: Tony McKegney stomped at the referee. Ron Greschner argued through the glass with the goal judge. Phil Esposito stood on the bench, his arms folded, watching. The ruling would not be reversed. McKegney would not get a last-ditch third-period goal, and the Rangers would be denied a storybook ending.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the days when the Giants were in New York and the Dodgers were in Brooklyn, how many home runs did Willie Mays hit as a visiting player at Ebbets Field?

title: AS PRIEST CENSURES RACISM AS SIN, HOWARD BEACH DEALS WITH ATTACK
description: A hush fell over the congregation at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday morning as the Rev. Kenneth Leona delivered his homily, an unsparing message about racial prejudice and violence.

title: Bonuses Only One Victim of Strong Yen
description: Normally, this is a jolly season for Japanese employees, the time they receive winter bonuses worth several months' salary. But this year, about 7,000 managers at the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company got envelopes stuffed not with cash but with coupons good for Matsushita products.

title: ON VITAL STRAIT, OMANI 'TRAFFIC COPS'
description: On the horizon off the port bow a pillar of smoke climbs to the deep blue sky. That is the direction of Lark Island, where Iraqi bombers struck an Iranian oil terminal and two tankers on Nov. 25 and others since.

title: FLORIDA TO RESUME TRACKING PANTHERS DESPITE COMPLAINTS
description: A project to attach radio collars to Florida panthers is scheduled to resume next month despite criticism from some environmentalists that the program poses too much risk to the endangered animals.

title: CHINESE PROTESTS: TRACING THE ROOTS
description: The wave of student protests in Chinese cities in the last two weeks finds its roots in a tradition of activism, marked by street demonstrations, that ranks among modern China's most venerated forces for social change.

title: BLACK AT HELM OF DALLAS SYMBOLIZES TRANSITION FROM CONSERVATIVE PAST
description: A 41-year-old black who began his working life pumping gas at his grandfather's service station in rural middle Georgia has emerged as a powerful figure of political transition in this city, which is saddled with a reputation for racial intolerance.

title: More Nixon Papers
description: The National Archives will soon try to make public 1.5 million pages of the ''special files'' of the Nixon Administration, papers that officials of the period regarded as sensitive and stored in segregated space in the White House. This material includes the files of key staff officers like H. R. Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman and Charles W. Colson but no classified documents or national security information.

title: GROUPS JOIN TO COLLECT FOOD FOR THE HOMELESS
description: On the Upper West Side, they collected Dutch tea biscuits and artichoke hearts. In Chelsea, macaroni and cheese and V-8 vegetable juice. In Englewood, N.J., powdered milk and tuna fish.

title: M.M. WINTROBE, 85, EXPERT ON BLOOD
description: Dr. Maxwell M. Wintrobe, who invented methods of identifying blood disorders that led to improved treatment of anemia, died of heart failure on Dec. 9 at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 85 years old.

title: Market Place; The Appeal Of U.S. Equity
description: FOREIGN investors have been buying American equities at a record clip.

title: ST. JOHN'S JONES IS BIG SPARK
description: Last year, en route to the conference championship, St. John's arguably had the best starting five in the Big East. The bench was so fragile that each starter was forced to play almost 40 minutes a game, and not foul out.

title: Hall Financial Debt Revised
description: Craig Hall, a real estate syndicator in Dallas, said that his company, the Hall Financial Group, had completed restructuring of $84 million in loans with its second-largest savings and loan lender, Beverly Hills Savings.

title: GIANT PLAYERS TAKE A LONG TIMEOUT
description: The Giants spent Sunday like most people in most lines of work. They took it easy or spent time with their families or watched football on television or visited friends or any combination of the above.

title: POLICE SEARCH QUEENS FOR ATTACKERS
description: More than 50 detectives canvassed homes yesterday in the Queens neighborhood where a black man was struck and killed by a car while he and two other black men tried to flee a gang of whites who had attacked them.

title: In Seattle, Hunthausen Case Will Not Go Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Blast Rattles Westchester
description: Residents in Westchester County were shaken Saturday morning by blasting at a construction site, not an earthquake as some people might have thought, according to a spokesman for the Eastchester police.

title: RELIGIOUS INCIDENT HAS FEW ANSWERS TO MANY QUESTIONS
description: FRITZ GLAUS learned of the incident from several players who belong to his informal congregation known as the tennis ministry. They brought word from Lagos, Nigeria, about the bizarre incident that occurred in late November, when three American tennis players - born-again Christians - destroyed their passports, cash, traveler's checks and a Bible in an act of religious fervor at a hotel housing players during a satellite Challenger Series event on the professional tour.

title: 'A CEREMONY OF CAROLS'
description: LIKE the commercial networks, public television this week is offering a number of holiday specials, most of them crammed with the standard collection of carols. On Christmas Eve, for instance, Shirley Verrett joins the Mormon Tabernacle Choir for a program that includes everything from ''O Holy Night'' to ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.'' That same evening, ''James Galway's Christmas Carol'' is a touch more adventurous, as the Irish flutist also explores a number of English folk and traditional melodies. But of all the special projects - some of them containing appeals to help your local public-television station -none are more thoroughly charming than ''A Ceremony of Carols,'' a choral work being broadcast tonight at 11 on Channel 13.

title: Nigeria, Rich in Oil, Juggles Its Huge Debt
description: Nigeria, once a proud symbol of oil wealth, has in recent weeks won approval of key elements of a complex package to reschedule its crushing foreign debt.

title: STAGE: SOLSTICE CELEBRATED IN 'REVELS'
description: ''THE Christmas Revels,'' an always merry production that mixes music and dance, harking back to ancient solstice celebrations, returned for its annual visit to the Symphony Space this weekend.

title: People
description: * Judy Cacciola, Patricia Deneroff, Jean Fitzgerald and Debra Goldstein have been named senior vice presidents at Ogilvy & Mather, New York.

title: THE LAST CHRISTMAS FOR A ONCE-EXCITING RETAILER
description: The scene, outside on West 34th street, resembles a street bazaar, with vendors hawking Saudi Arabian headdresses, Korean sunglasses and ''Gucci'' watches made in Taiwan.

title: GOAL NEARED TO SAVE OLD OAKS FROM LOGGERS
description: A group of conservationists says it is within $27,000 of reaching its goal of $1.25 million to save a special stand of centuries-old red oaks from logging.

title: BAD NEWS SHAKES VALUES OF THE SWISS
description: A string of national and international incidents involving Swiss financial and business institutions have shaken assumptions about the country's traditional values of discretion and privacy.

title: A CUBAN-AMERICAN 'ADVISER' TELLS OF COMBAT WITH NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: Pedro Gil, a 50-year-old electrician with two grown sons, sat by the Christmas tree in the living room of his modest red-tile-roofed home here today, talking about the three and a half years he spent as a combat adviser to rebel soldiers in southern Nicaragua.

title: UNICEF'S CARD SELLING STRUGGLE
description: Greeting cards from Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, have always said different things to different people - ''Season's Greetings'' to some, ''Meilleurs Voeux'' or ''Felices Fiestas'' to others.

title: Sentence Reduced Against Teen-Ager
description: A Superior Court judge has dropped a six-month suspended jail sentence against a teen-age girl who refused to testify in a sexual assault case against a man she said she loves.

title: 3 NETWORKS VYING FOR DIANE SAWYER
description: ABC, NBC and CBS, locked in a tight evening news race, are competing intensely for the services of Diane Sawyer, the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, whose contract with CBS News expires next week.

title: CHADIAN FIGHTERS ARE SAID TO GAIN
description: Chadian guerrillas have badly mauled a Libyan armored column, killing at least 100 Libyan soldiers in fierce fighting in the mountains of northern Chad, diplomatic sources said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1986
description: International Report

title: JET DEFENSE MISSES THE FAMILIAR FACES
description: The Jets' defense, one that gave up 52 points and 621 yards to the Cincinnati Bengals today, had a patchwork lineup near the end.

title: FORMER U.S. INTELLIGENCE AIDES ASK: WAS A LESSON OF THE 70'S FORGOTTEN?
description: Whether Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, when he was a member of the National Security Council staff, acted on his own to divert money from the Iran arms sale to assist Nicaraguan rebels intrigues several former officials and practioners of the craft of intelligence.

title: Subsidy Fair, Germans Say
description: West Germany today denied charges by Washington that it was providing unfair subsidies to the European Airbus program.

title: 6.2 BILLION WORLD POPULATION FORETOLD BY 2000
description: The Census Bureau estimated today that the world's population would reach 6.2 billion by the year 2000, an increase of 27 percent over the 1985 figure.

title: Utility Accounting
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana said Friday that it had eliminated a $925 million earnings deficit by reorganizing common equity accounts, moving it closer to the clearing of preferred dividend arrears and the resumption of current preferred payouts. The company said it had taken a $141 million loss on the canceled Marble Hill plant and then transferred $925 million to its accumulated earnings account from its common stock account.

title: Twain Said It Better
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: MURPHY SINGS HART
description: THE continuing celebration of the lyrics of Lorenz Hart at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, has taken a new and interesting direction with the appearance of the veteran jazz singer Mark Murphy. Mr. Murphy, who settled into the club for a three-week engagement on Tuesday, is a stubborn iconoclast who projects the risky sense of discovering for the first time the musical components and the lyrical essence of a song in the process of singing it.

title: Moody's, S.&P. Differ on Bonds
description: The Executive Life Insurance Company, whose guaranteed investment contracts have been widely used to back issues of taxable bonds offered by various local government authorities, received a medium-grade claims-paying rating of A-3 late last week from Moody's Investors Service Inc.

title: Reading the Tea Leaves of a New Term
description: With the White House and Congress convulsed by the ever expanding Iran-Israel-Saudi Arabia-Canada-contra arms affair, the Supreme Court has been going about its own measured routine with stately detachment, here carving a little First Amendment hole in the campaign spending laws, there making it a bit harder for corporations to challenge mergers between their competitors.

title: QUESTIONS IN CRISIS MAY LONG GO UNANSWERED
description: The initial Congressional investigations into the Iran arms sales are about to end, but many central questions seem certain to remain unanswered for weeks, at least.

title: KIDDER TAKEOVER FUND SEEN
description: The General Electric Company has agreed to provide several billion dollars to Kidder, Peabody & Company, which it acquired earlier this year, to help fund a move by the firm to invest aggressively in corporate mergers and buyouts, according to sources close to the two companies.

title: ROCK: CYNDI LAUPER IN A VARIETY OF STYLES
description: A CAUTIOUS Cyndi Lauper performed Friday at Madison Square Garden. Visually, she was the same madcap, flamboyant, volatile performer whose 1983 debut album, ''She's So Unusual,'' made her one of the major stars of the 1980's. She wore layers of clothes - a black velvet cape, a red tutu, a puffy-sleeved flowered top, antique lingerie with suspenders - and went through a repertory theater's-worth of facial expressions. Vocally, she delivered shouts, sighs, yelps and hiccups while in constant motion on stage.

title: INDIA-PAKISTAN PACT AIMS AT SIKH ISSUE
description: Indian and Pakistani officials reached an agreement today to step up coordination of their border security forces to prevent Sikh extremists from using Pakistan territory as a base for attacks in India.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch on Dec. 9 from Sighet, Rumania, the birthplace of Elie Wiesel, misstated the place and arrangements for his Nobel Peace Prize award. The prize, conferred by the Norwegian Parliament, is always presented in Oslo. It was formally given to Mr. Wiesel on Dec. 10 by the chairman of Parliament's Nobel committee, in the presence of King Olav V of Norway.

title: GOODEN CASE: ANOTHER LOOK
description: DWIGHT GOODEN may not think so, but he was lucky four different ways in his incident with the Tampa police a week ago Saturday night. 1. He was lucky he was not more seriously injured in a brawl that may have developed racial overtones at some point. 2. He was lucky he is a prominent athlete who can gain a settlement convenient to all. 3. He was also lucky he was not tested for alcohol on the scene, given the .111 level of his blood system in a subsequent hospital test. 4. Since his alcohol level was probably higher at the time of the brawl, he may even be lucky he didn't kill anybody while he was driving.

title: VIOLIN: KOICHIRO HARADA IN JAPANESE WORKS
description: THE cultivation of violin playing has flourished astonishingly in postwar Japan, as we are often reminded by the presence on the musical scene of so many distinguished Japanese soloists and orchestral musicians. We hear less frequently the body of music that has grown up with and around this phenomenon, a distinctive and often fascinating tradition of violin writing. It was impressively sampled by Koichiro Harada, the founder and until 1981 the first violinist of the Tokyo String Quartet, Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society.

title: Polling the Lawyers
description: Roughly half the young lawyers surveyed around the nation five months ago disagreed with President Reagan's contention that the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua is a threat to American national security. The 1,800 members of the American Bar Association, 35 years of age and younger, responded to a questionnaire published in July, long before the public learned that insurgents' efforts against the Sandinistas were being financed with proceeds from secret sales of arms to Iran.

title: Nuclear Power Plant Restarted in Jersey
description: The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant was restarted yesterday after an extended shutdown prompted by concern over corrosion that had left the main containment wall thinner than expected, officials said.

title: Actress, Lawyer, Model, Diplomat
description: On three occasions over the past 20 years, Elizabeth Bagaaya Nyabongo, a Ugandan princess, has fled her homeland to live in exile. And now, for a fourth time, she has left Uganda, but this time to come to Washington as her country's new Ambassador to the United States.

title: Women as Spokesmen
description: Even on Capitol Hill, the old order changeth. In the next Congress, women will function as press secretaries for both the Senate majority leader and the Speaker of the House.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 6 about a gathering of the Securities Industry Association misattributed a remark about the Glass-Steagall Act, which generally prohibits commercial banks from underwriting most corporate securities. The comment, calling the act outdated, was made by John H. Goldsmith, chairman and chief executive of Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., not by John W. Bachmann, the association's new chairman.

title: A Choir of Greetings
description: Just like their constituents, many members of Congress send out Christmas cards each year decorated with pictures of their families. Although no Government agency keeps definitive records, the 1986 population prize for such holiday messages would appear to go to Rep-resentative Howard C. Nielson, Republican of Utah, whose card, signed ''Howard, Julie & Family,'' shows a total of 36 people, ranging from the 62-year-old Congresman down to five babes in arms.

title: PARAMOUNT'S SURPRISE STREAK
description: The Paramount Pictures Corporation is having a boffo year.

title:
Washington Watch;
Action Awaited On Transit Bill
description: THERE will be no shortage of groups pressing for immediate attention to the Federal highway and mass transit program when Congress returns next month.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods OrdersNovember Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

title: STERN'S STATION REBUTS F.C.C. CHARGES
description: In its response to charges by the Federal Communications Commission of obscenity and indecency on a morning radio show, Infinity Broadcasting Corporation has asserted that the Howard Stern Show is humor and that complaints about it are part of a crusade.

title: A HAVEN FOR AIDS PATIENTS
description: It's a pleasant little room that looks out on a tranquil garden in the West Village, a place where people with AIDS can gather for food, conversation, relaxation and the sharing of information. Called the Living Room, it is run by the People With AIDS Coalition, which is operated for and by people with AIDS. And that's what makes it special. ''There are other groups for people with AIDS, but this is the only group of people with AIDS doing something for themselves,'' said Michael Hirsch, director of the coalition and its only paid employee. He and a few volunteers are the only ones of the 20 or so active members who do not have acquired immune deficiency syndrome or AIDS-related complex.

title: THE BOND OF SHARED LAUGHTER
description: ''IT'S no fun playing tennis unles the guy on the other side of the net has a racquet.'' Lewis Frumkes, writer and humorist, was quoting Ring Lardner and speculating on the intangibles in what makes for a shared sense of humor.

title: COACHLESS CELTICS NOSEDIVE
description: Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtics' director of player personnel and an assistant coach, was at the Rockford (Ill.) Metro Centre Saturday night, the final stop of an eight-day scouting trip in which he saw 11 of the 12 Continental Basketball Association teams play. But instead of watching the Rockford Lightning defeat the Savannah Spirits, Rodgers could have been coaching the Celtics in the closing minutes of their 122-100 loss to the Bucks at the Milwaukee Arena, about 100 miles away.

title: Bridge: Barometer Scoring and Field Make Super Final Exciting
description: The first super final of the Greater New York Bridge Association was played Saturday night at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Instead of, as is customary, qualifying about half of the original field for the final, only pairs who had topped their sections during the afternoon were able to advance.

title: INSIDE
description: Free Call for Theater Facts A computer system will provide free nationwide telephone calls for up-to-the-minute information and tickets to theater in New York.

title: Tourist Office Agency
description: Rumrill-Hoyt, New York, has become agency in the United States for the National Tourist Office, which has a budget of $2 million to $3 million. Plans have been made for an ad campaign for print media that will break in March in major markets. The previous agency was Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall.

title: Chief Leaves Posts At Cato Johnson/Y&R
description: Benjamin Colarossi, who has been president and chief executive officer since March of Cato Johnson/Y&R, a Young & Rubicam division with $32 million in billings, is leaving to do something else.

title: Wall Street Week
description: It's been 17 days now since they went public with an offering of limited-partnership units representing about 40 percent of their ownership, and so far the Boston Celtics have fared better under the boards than on the Big Board.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Many people ask a priest: 'Is this a sin? Is that a sin?' Well, racial prejudice is a sin.

title: HIGHER OIL PRICES EXPECTED
description: Reduced output of crude oil by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries during the first six months of next year is likely to raise oil prices from current levels, but not to OPEC's stated target of $18 a barrel, in the view of many oil specialists in the United States.

title: Holmes a Court May Make Bid
description: John Dahlsen, the chairman of Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., Australia's biggest media concern, said Friday that the Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court was considering making a bid to acquire the company.

title: FOR THEATERGOERS, A PHONEFUL OF FACTS
description: A new, ultra-sophisticated information and ticket-buying system to be introduced in February could have the biggest effect on theatergoing habits since the advent of credit-card purchases more than 13 years ago.

title: THEATER: NEW CONCEPTION OF 'MERCHANT OF VENICE'
description: THERE is ample confusion in the conception of James Simpson's production of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' but there should be no mistaking the locale. The evening at the Classic Stage Company begins with a gondola, or rather, with a raft standing in for a gondola. Propelling the craft are Antonio's cronies, Salerio and Solanio, in this production a pair of Venetian clowns. The gondola and gondoliers reappear with such frequency that the play begins to resemble a Grand Canal version of ''Big River.'' The vessel misses only the courtroom scene, but is poled on stage for the climax as the characters - five on a raft - embark, presumably for calmer dramatic waters. As for the play, it sinks.

title: Israel Debates Growth Plan
description: Israel's Cabinet failed today to approve a controversial plan to stimulate growth in the economy. Prime Minister Yitzhak

title: COLLEGE ENROLLMENTS INCREASE
description: The Department of Education reported today that college enrollments rose this fall instead of dropping.

title: Yields Stay in Same Range
description: Hopes for lower interest rates in coming months helped to insulate the note and bond markets from the sharp rise in short-term interest rates last week, but were not enough to move Treasury bond yields from about the middle of the trading range that has prevailed since April.

title: HOUSING AGENCY UNION TO VOTE ON STRIKE TONIGHT
description: The union representing employees of the New York City Housing Authority has broken off contract talks with the city, and is threatening to strike public housing projects on New Year's Day.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1986
description: Markets

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split effected in the form of a dividend on Nov. 26.

title: COMMISSIONER TORRES RIDES WAVE OF CONTROVERSY
description: For Jose Luis Torres, these have not been easy times.

title: CONTINENTAL FEDERAL S&L ASSN reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss includes a $3,208,000 provision for loan losses, a $2,052,000 loss on real estate operations and a pre-tax extraordinary charge of $968,000 relating to the prepayment of federal home loan bank borrowing.

title: REAGAN WEIGHED GRANTING PARDONS TO 2 FORMER AIDES
description: President Reagan considered, but rejected, the idea of granting a pardon to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in the hope that they would then tell what they knew about the Iran arms affair, the White House said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a Washington dispatch in some copies on Saturday, about President Reagan's proposals for MX and Midgetman missiles, omitted part of the identity of President Ford's national security adviser, who headed a Reagan Presidential commission on the subject. He is Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, a retired Air Force officer.

title: South Africa's Ruling National Party Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Sportsman Of the Decade?
description: His athletic accomplishments are hardly the stuff of legend, but there are those who believe that David Derdeyn will prove to be the one college athlete of the 1980's whose name most lives on in history.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL WILL SCREEN JUDICIAL NOMINEES
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy said tonight that a four-member Democratic senatorial panel had been appointed to review and hold hearings on President Reagan's judicial nominees. The Senator, a Vermont Democrat, said he had been named to head the committee.

title: A PROSPECTIVE TEACHER'S JOURNEY
description: IN February 1984, Martha Rusk Sutphen decided that she could make a contribution to New York City's public schools.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $139,267 from the sale of land for the quarter and 6 months.

title: AARON BROTHERS ART MARTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said for comparative purposes the 1985 pro-forma adjustments have been made giving effect to purchase accounting and transaction-related effects of the acquisition of the predecessor by the company as if the acquisition occurred Feb. 1, 1985.

title: IRANIANS SAY IRAQI AIR RAID ON A TOWN KILLED 100
description: Iran said today that more than 100 people were killed in an Iraqi air raid on the western town of Eslamabad-e Gharb.

title: Pakistan and the Bomb
description: Excerpts from ''The Next Nuclear Power?'' by Harold Freeman, professor emeritus of statistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, published in the latest edition of Foreign Service Journal, the magazine of the American Foreign Service Association:

title: Trust the President's Foreign Policy
description: No nation can solve a problem by creating a crisis. At a time when America needs cool heads and calm cooperation to overcome the mistakes of the Iran arms sales - mistakes that President Reagan has admitted - partisan politics are threatening not only the historic recovery of America's leadership in the world engineered under Mr. Reagan's stewardship but also the capacity of the Presidency to conduct foreign policy in a decisive manner.

title: CONCERT: EMPIRE BRASS
description: ''FOR centuries,'' said the program notes at Sunday afternoon's Empire Brass concert at Carnegie Hall, ''these instruments have had specific functions entirely separate from the standard ensembles of 'elevated' music-making,'' and so, in a way, they still do. There is something about the sheer brave sound of brass instruments that appeals beyond the constituency of the normal symphony orchestra, crosses some of the pop-classical dividing lines and rouses an audience to special approval -particularly when the players are as good as Sunday's, and whether or not the music is.

title: KNICKS PUT AN END TO LOSING STREAK
description: When Bob Hill took over as head coach three weeks ago, he stressed that the Knicks would be more concerned with themselves than their opponents. How well they executed was more important than hours of reviewing scouting reports and game films. Or so he thought. Ten games later, and with only one victory for his efforts, Hill changed his strategy.

title: FUNDS TIED TO INQUIRY AT INTELSAT
description: Auditors and lawyers for Intelsat are examining the possibility that two former senior executives may have used contracts with outside consultants to divert funds to the executives' personal use, according to United States Government officials and Intelsat sources.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $660,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: LOUISIANA SHERIFF BACKED AFTER RACIAL REMARK
description: In the stormy aftermath of remarks that were called racist, the sheriff who made them has found wide approval among his predominantly white constituency.

title: S.P.I.-SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOVIET DISSIDENT TO STAY IN WEST
description: Irina Ratushinskaya, the Soviet dissident poet, met today with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The poet's husband said they would stay in the West.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AGENCY URGES NEW YORK CITY TO SCRAP ITS TAXI PANEL
description: A state watchdog agency called yesterday for the abolition of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission and said the Mayor should be ultimately responsible for regulating the taxi industry and setting rates.

title: Judge Approves Plan For Wedtech Loan
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved a plan yesterday to allow the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, to resume limited operations and rehire several hundred employees.

title: PROBLEMS OF FILMING ' NATIVE SON'
description: How do you make a movie out of ''Native Son''?

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WAITING FOR BIG BLUE'S NEXT MOVE
description: WATCHING I.B.M. has long been a favorite pastime in the computer industry, and none of that company's products have been more closely scrutinized than its personal computers. It was Big Blue, after all, that made the personal computer respectable, allowing executives to roll up their sleeves and delve right into Flight Simulator along with the most ardent of the hobbyists.

title: MILASTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: REMINGTON IS BRANCHING OUT
description: With Christmas near at hand, the old Remington Products plant here is stacked to its rafters with thousands of electric shavers. And Victor Kiam, the chairman, marketing guru and sole stockholder of Remington, is an exhausted man.

title: SAKHAROV AND WIFE BACK IN MOSCOW
description: Andrei D. Sakharov returned to Moscow before dawn today, ending nearly seven years of banishment in the city of Gorky for his outspoken advocacy of human rights.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Vanunu M. was hijacked in Rome Itl 30.9.86. 2100 came to Rome by BA fly 504.'' - Mordechai Vanunu, in a message scrawled on his palm. [ A1:3. ]

title: An Iran Leader Again Offers Aid on the Hostage Situation
description: The Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, has repeated Iran's offer to intercede on behalf of American hostages in Lebanon in return for delivery of assets held by the United States, the radio said today.

title: Ford, Nissan Said To Plan Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company is discussing a United States-based joint venture with the Nissan Motor Company to produce V-8 and V-6 engines in the 1990's, American Metal Market-Metalworking News said.

title: Korea Crash Kills 3 Soldiers
description: Two helicopters collided today over western South Korea, burst into flames and then crashed, the police said. Three United States soldiers were killed and three others were reported injured in the accident, which occurred over the town of Sosan 65 miles southwest of Seoul. The bodies of the three Americans were burned beyond recognition, according to the police.

title: New Publisher Named At Better Homes
description: J. Wesley Silk, 63, the publisher of Better Homes & Gardens since 1979, has been promoted by the Meredith Corporation to senior vice president and executive publisher, in preparation for his retirement in 1988. Stepping into the publisher's slot is Del F. Rusher, 45, who has been associate publisher, development, for the last three years.

title: INVESTORS SELLING STOCK TO BEAT TAX DEADLINE
description: Investors are selling stocks these days for what ordinarily might be a most unusual reason: They want to record their capital gains this year, rather than next.

title: A CHURCH'S CHRISTMAS JOYS: MANY SACRED, SOME SECULAR
description: In these final days before Christmas, a change has come over the Ascension Roman Catholic Church on Carnation Drive here. It is more than the addition of the Christ Child to the manger, more than the presents for the poor around the Christmas tree, more than the children's pageant of angels and wise men, more than the voices of the choir members rehearsing.

title: Some Special Attention For Special Forces
description: ''Special operations'' is a military term of art encompassing commando tactics, antiterrorism, insurgency and counterinsurgency, psychological warfare, infiltration, foreign training, rescue and just about anything else short of full-blown war. This little-understood facet of military affairs as practiced by special units of the Army, Navy and Air Force has received increasing attention in these days of terrorism and hostage-taking, and legislation was enacted last fall to reorganize the hierarchy in charge of such forces.

title: S.R.O. LAW RULED ILLEGAL BY A JUDGE
description: A city law that required owners of vacant single-room-occupancy hotels to rehabilitate their buildings and rent the rooms back to low-income renters was declared unconstitutional by a judge in Manhattan yesterday.

title: U.S. SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Belzberg Urges GTE Spinoff
description: Samuel Belzberg, the corporate raider, yesterday suggested that the GTE Corporation spin off its Sprint long-distance telephone service to its shareholders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1986
description: International

title: 3 YOUTHS ARE HELD ON MURDER COUNTS IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Three white teen-agers were charged last night with second-degree murder in the beating of three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, the police said.

title: BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Queen Will Retire Her Horse And Ride Carriage at Parade
description: Queen Elizabeth II will drop her traditional horseback ride at her annual birthday parade, the Trooping the Color, in favor of a carriage instead because her horse is too old, Buckingham Palace said today.

title: Indian Software License
description: The Indian Government has placed imports of computer software under an open general license to help the domestic industry, a Government minister said Saturday. The measure, effective immediately, will reduce long delays in seeking licenses for software imports, according to R. K. Narayanan, the Minister of State for Science and Technology.

title: NEIGHBORS RECALL VICTIM OF BEATING IN QUEENS
description: In the Brooklyn blocks where Michael Griffith grew up, the tension yesterday was as biting as the cold wind.

title: Mail Delivery Set for Friday
description: The Postal Service will deliver mail this Friday, the day after Christmas, even though President Reagan has declared the day a Federal holiday, the agency said today. In a notice informing employees that Dec. 26 and Jan. 2 would be official business days, the agency added, ''The Postal Service simply cannot afford to incur the enormous additional costs which would be involved in declaring these days as nonwork days.''

title: INSIDE
description: Sakharov Back in Moscow Andrei D. Sakharov, free after seven years in exile in the closed city of Gorky, returned to Moscow with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: NO TRACE OF IRANIAN IN CANADA
description: The Government said today that it had no record of an entry to Canada by the son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, who was reported by a London newspaper to have fled here with at least $6 million in commissions from the secret United States arms sales to Iran.

title: McCall Giving Up One of His Titles
description: David B. McCall, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of McCaffrey & McCall, is turning over the chief part of his title to Robert H. Cherins, 46, the president and chief operating officer since February. At the same time, Bruce McCall, 51, who is not a relative, is promoted to vice chairman and chief creative officer from executive vice president and creative director.

title: 37 RIG WORKERS RESCUED IN GULF
description: Thirty-seven drilling rig workers who had been evacuated in two small escape capsules to avoid a possible blowout in the Gulf of Mexico were rescued today in heavy seas.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DAYTIME Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall is working overtime today in the season of joy. In a schedule that rivals the old Palace vaudeville calendar, ''A Holday Celebration'' goes on a two-a-day basis, but for today only. This two-part event performs at 10:30 A.M. and again at noon, with emphasis on song and dance.

title: Nystrom Is Suspended
description: Bob Nystrom, an Islanders assistant coach, has been suspended for 10 games for confronting a fan in the stands following an Islander game with the Devils Dec. 11.

title: Scoring Points for Judge Selection
description: The creation of 23 new judgeships to beef up New York City's ability to try crack cases gave Governor Cuomo a chance to fight the state's boss-ridden system for picking judges. His ''merit selection'' method falls short of convincing reform but still constitutes a welcome step forward.

title: Former Lazard Banker Pleads Guilty as Insider
description: Robert M. Wilkis, a former investment banker with Lazard Freres & Company, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to four felony charges involving insider trading.

title: PARTY SHOES TO MAKE CINDERELLA JEALOUS
description: It's time to put on the dancing shoes and kick up your heels. From now till New Year's Eve, there'll be plenty of excuses to get dressed up.

title: 2 N.S.C. STAFF MEMBERS RESIGN
description: Two members of the National Security Council staff have resigned as part of a shake-up ordered by the new national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci, White House officials said today.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,977,000 for both the quarter and 9 months from the termination of overfunded pension plans. The company said during the third quarter it changed its method of accounting for pension costs to adopt FASB 87. The change increased net income for the latest quarter and 9 months periods by $365,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: THE DANCE: EDITH STEPHEN
description: EDITH STEPHEN called ''The Unthinkables'' an ''homage to Samuel Beckett.'' That it may well have been. Yet the work that the Edith Stephen Dance Connection offered Friday night at the Marymount Theater did little to illuminate the plays and novels of this distinguished writer.

title: The Adelman-Carlucci Tie
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, has been shuttling between his office at the State Department and duty at the White House, where he has had a key role in the reorganization of the National Security Council.

title: QUEBEC COURT REJECTS A BAN ON NON-FRENCH SIGNS
description: The Quebec Court of Appeal today struck down a provision in the province's nine-year-old language law that prohibits the use of languages other than French on public signs.

title: IN PITTSBURGH, THE PENGUINS ARE OFF THE ENDANGERED LIST
description: As the temperature climbed into the high 70's on June 13, 1975, the Penguins' luck ran out: The ice melted and they went belly up.

title: SOLIDARITY ADDS WATCHDOG GROUP
description: The outlawed Solidarity movement has set up a group to monitor legal abuses, opposition sources said today.

title: BEAUTICONTROL COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,440,000.

title: EX-AIDE TO LAROUCHE A FIGURE IN FRAUD CASE
description: A former Ku Klux Klan leader and Government informer who served as a consultant to the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has emerged as a pivotal figure in the Government's fraud case against leaders of the LaRouche organizations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the reaction of residents of Howard Beach, Queens, to a racial attack on three black men misidentified a priest at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church. He is the Rev. Kenneth Liona.

title: Business and Health; Drug Exports: Gains Forecast
description: THE dynamic young biotechnology industry predicts substantial gains from the relaxed drug export measures that Congress approved on the last day of the recent session. ''It will put us on a level playing field with the big guys,'' says Brian C. Cunningham, vice president and counsel of Genentech Inc.

title: URUGUAY APPROVES A MILITARY AMNESTY
description: After an all-night debate that was interrupted by fistfights, the House of Deputies today overwhelmingly approved an amnesty for soldiers accused of human rights violations during the 1973-85 military rule.

title: The Investigations Of the Iran Arms Deal
description: Congress The House and Senate Intelligence Committees: The Senate committee, headed by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, has completed three weeks of closed hearings. The House committee, led by Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, is expected to complete closed hearings within a few days.

title: A South Africa Protest
description: Up to 1,000 youngsters from the Washington area plan to demonstrate today near the South African Embassy to call attention to the plight of young people detained in South Africa.

title: THE ULSTER LOYALIST, MAKING WAR, QUOTES PAINE
description: John McMichael is well known as the owner of the local pub who likes to quote Thomas Paine and lead the Protestant loyalist vigilante group here lately accused of burning the Roman Catholic nationalist minority from their homes.

title: WESTERN STEER MOM 'N' POPS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
There Were No Games and No Deals in Fighter-Plane Decisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Gridiron Graybeards
description: Jeff Van Note is now two days into retirement, and he earned it.

title: Detained Western Reporter Being Expelled, Zambia Says
description: The Zambian Government said today that it was deporting a correspondent for The Associated Press, John Edlin, on immigration charges, but that the proceedings had bogged down in paperwork, the reporter's lawyer said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MEMORIES OF MISTRESSES. Reflections From a Life. By Luigi Barzini. 311 pages. Collier Books/Macmillan. Paper, $12.95. ''MEMORIES OF MIS=

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Figures for 1985 are restated to include investment gains and real estate fees.

title: Q&A
description: Q.To reduce the expense of decaffeinating coffee, why not develop plants that produce caffeine-free coffee beans? A.Caffeine represents only 1 percent of the coffee bean and it is highly unlikely that coffee breeders could eliminate it, according to Dr. William Pardee, chairman of the department of plant breeding at Cornell University. But it could be reduced, he said, if coffee plants were cross-bred with related plants that produce beans low in caffeine.

title: Education Needs Dollars, Not Vouchers
description: The Reagan Administration professes a desire to improve education for poor children - but proposes to do so with tuition tax credits and education vouchers. A new willingness to improve existing remedial programs is welcome; these approaches are not, for they would undermine public schools and vital Federal education programs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Dallas dispatch yesterday about Richard Knight Jr., the new City Manager, misidentified his predecessor. He is Charles Anderson.

title: MERRILL PLANS REAL ESTATE PARTNERSHIP
description: Dissatisfied with the bids it had received since deciding to sell its real estate operations, Merrill Lynch & Company adopted a new tack yesterday. It said it would convert those operations into a master limited partnership, retaining control but selling units to the public.

title: CENSUS STUDY REPORTS 1 IN 5 ADULTS SUFFERS FROM DISABILITY
description: One in five American adults suffers from some type of disability, a Census Bureau study disclosed today. Difficulty in walking and lifting were the most common problems.

title: PROGRAM MAY GAIN $3.2 BILLION FOR CHILD SUPPORT
description: A Federal child-support program helped collect $2.7 billion from absent parents last year and the 1986 figure is expected to be nearly $3.2 billion, the Department of Health and Human Services said today.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $399,000. c-Net income and includes a gain from discontinued operations of $325,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,388,000.

title: President Resigns From Del E. Webb
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation, a Phoenix-based company involved principally in managing and developing real estate, recreation and gambling operations, announced yesterday that its president, Thomas E. Arnold, had resigned.

title: Pactel Unit to Buy Cellular One
description: Pactel Personal Communications of Dallas, a unit of Pacific Telesis Group, said that it had agreed to pay $316 million for cellular telephone companies in Detroit-Ann Arbor, Flint, Lansing and Grand Rapids, Mich., and Toledo, Ohio.

title: On the West Bank, a Wish To Join a Democratic Jordan
description: Although the attention of most Americans is now diverted from the Israeli-Palestinian issue to the Reagan Administration's strange involvement in the Iran-Iraq war, a new drama is taking place in the territories occupied by Israel.

title: Market Place; Stock Pickers' Lists for 1987
description: SOME of the best-performing stock groups during 1986 were tobacco, pollution controls, chemicals, apparel manufacturers and building materials. Since this is the season when stock pickers peer ahead, what looks good to them for 1987?

title: UNIVERSAL LOOK OF CONTEMPT
description: RESEARCHERS have found, contrary to their expectations, that a facial expression of contempt does not significantly vary from culture to culture - but is, instead, universally recognizable, from West Germany toto West Sumatra.

title: Student Moral Passion Doesn't Justify Disruption of a University; No Place for C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CIVIL WARS' SINGER GETS INTO HARNESS, LITERALLY
description: When Harlan Foss was first asked to play the role of Abraham Lincoln in the Rome section of Robert Wilson's opera ''The Civil Wars,'' he was thrilled.

title: OUR DIMMING SUN AND OTHER HAZARDS
description: OUR neighborhood star has been growing steadily dimmer during the last five years, and if the slump doesn't end pretty soon all of us will be in serious trouble.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption yesterday with a review of ''A Ceremony of Carols,'' the Benjamin Britten retrospective on Channel 13, misidentified the subject of the picture. He was not Britten but the tenor Peter Pears, whose recollections of Britten were part of the program.

title: ARGENTINA ACTS TO ACQUIT MILITARY
description: The Senate began debate today on a law that would end the trials of military officers for human rights abuses.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said it could not provide average shares outstanding comparisons for the quarter.

title: Revising 200 Years Of Misinformation
description: History buffs in need of information about any of the 11,700 people who have served in Congress turn to the best available resource, the latest volume of the Biographical Directory of the American Congress. But the best, scholars say, is far from good enough.

title: PREPARING FOR ARRIVAL OF 'STARLIGHT EXPRESS'
description: Crash. Boom. Bang.

title: Student Moral Passion Doesn't Justify Disruption of a University
description: To the Editor:

title: Celestial Celebration
description: Up to now, the thousands of satellites sent into orbits around the earth since 1957 have been strictly utilitarian, serving in global communication, weather forecasting, mineral prospecting, spying and many other practical activities. But in 1989 a consortium of French interests hopes to launch a satellite whose function will be strictly aesthetic: to treat earthlings on all continents to a blazing ring of light in the sky that will circle the world every 90 minutes or so.

title: NEW ZEALNAND GETS WEIGHT APPROVAL
description: New Zealand's fiberglass yacht, bombarded with gamma rays and pierced with a drill, met all weight distribution requirements for a legal America's Cup contender today, ending three months of bitter controversy.

title: KEMP TERMS BUSH FRONT-RUNNER
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, a Republican Presidential hopeful, said today that he still considered Vice President Bush the front-runner in the race for the Republican nomination in 1988.

title: DAVID C. PENHALIGON
description: David Charles Penhaligon, a prominent Liberal Member of Parliament, died today when a skidding van collided with his car on an icy hill. He was 42 years old. The collision occurred in Mr. Penhaligon's electoral district in Cornwall, the police said. Mr. Penhaligon was the Liberal Party's finance spokesman.

title: Professor to Surrender as Fugitive
description: A former criminal justice professor at the University of Nebraska, wanted as a fugitive from justice in New York State since 1975, has decided to turn himself over to New York authorities, his lawyer said today.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lucky Stores Gets Holders' Approval
description: The shareholders of Lucky Stores Inc. approved the reincorporation of the supermarket chain in Delaware, clearing the way for Lucky's repurchase of 14.4 million shares, or 28 percent of outstanding shares, as part of a restructuring. The approval followed the denial earlier today by a Federal district court judge of a request by the invester Asher B. Edelman for a preliminary injunction to block the reincorporation.

title: BIRD NESTS, LOST CAMP
description: A tempest is brewing at a state forest 200 miles north of here that pits the national bird against the National Guard, creating a debate over which is more American.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST CITES SQUALOR IN THE 'SHADOWS OF CHRISTMAS'
description: ''While I marvel at the wonders of this great city, I am saddened by the suffering and the squalor which linger in the shadows of our Christmas lights,'' said Elliott R. Peters, a New Yorker who gave $500 to the 75th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: AS POPE CONFRONTS THE DISSENTERS, WHOSE CATHOLICISM WILL PREVAIL?
description: The Roman Catholic Church, whose 800 million members stretch from the slums of Bangladesh to the wealthy suburbs of San Francisco, is in the midst of a fierce struggle over its identity as it moves toward the third millennium after the coming of Christ.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Virginia Tech has chosen Frank Beamer of Murray State to replace Bill Dooley as football coach. Dooley resigned during a dispute with the school that evolved into a $3.5 million lawsuit. . . . John Paye, the starting quarterback for Stanford, underwent arthroscopic surgery in his right shoulder yesterday and will miss Friday's Gator Bowl matchup against Clemson in Jacksonville, Fla. . . .The former Maryland coach, Bobby Ross, has been named quarterback coach and passing-game coordinator for the Buffalo Bills, Coach Marv Levy announced yesterday. . . . .Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has missed the Lakers' last two games because of an eye irritation, may play tonight against the Sacramento Kings.

title: QUEST FOR CANCER DRUGS: U.S. DEVISES MAJOR NEW STRATEGY
description: EXASPERATED by slow progress against leading cancer killers and armed with a sensitive new testing technology, the National Cancer Institute is making a major change in the way it searches for anticancer drugs.

title: ANATOMY OF A FUROR: CHARTING THE EVOLUTION OF THE IRAN AFFAIR
description: On Dec. 8, 1985, four days after he left his post as President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane delivered what he thought was a final order to the Israelis and arms dealers brokering weapons sales to Iran.

title: NEW MEXICO BACKS LIFTING OF SENTENCES FOR 5 ON DEATH ROW
description: The New Mexico Supreme Court today upheld Gov. Toney Anaya's commutation of five convicted murderers' death sentences.

title: Pro Football Notebook; FALCONS DISMISS HENNING AS COACH
description: In a move not altogether unexpected, Dan Henning was released today as coach of the Atlanta Falcons, a team that began the season with high expectations and four victories, only to finish 7-8-1.

title: U.S. PANEL ADVISES END TO FUEL RULES
description: A panel on Government regulations headed by Vice President Bush today proposed abolishing United States fuel economy standards, saying the standards hampered the ability of domestic makers of automobiles to meet the demands of the market.

title: Chrysler Trims Spending in '87
description: The Chrysler Corporation's automotive capital spending program for 1987 will total $2.9 billion, a slight decrease from the $3.1 billion spent this year, Gerald Greenwald, the chairman of the Chrysler Motors subsidiary, said today. In a year-end statement, Mr. Greenwald said Chrysler would introduce a longer version of its mini-van in the coming year that would be manufactured in a second plant, which would add 400,000 units a year to the company's capacity and would make V-6 engines available as options in minivans.

title: Greeting Winter On the Greenbelt
description: THE sun was bright, the wind whipped off Great South Bay, and the temperature was near freezing. Still, Ray Lyons decided it was better to spend Sunday outdoors in the cold, given the alternatives.

title: POPE SAYS DAY OF PRAYER WAS MODEL
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the day of prayer for peace at Assisi two months ago should serve as a model for interfaith cooperation and ecumenical initiatives.

title: GROUPS URGE U.S. TO EASE POVERTY
description: A coalition of national organizations and individuals joined today in a ''statement of principles'' calling for a major overhaul of the welfare system that would guarantee all Americans a minimum standard of living.

title: Jackson Seeks A's Spot
description: The Oakland A's say one of several vacancies on their roster might be filled by Reggie Jackson. The 40-year-old Jackson, who began his major-league career with the A's, lives in Oakland and has talked to the club about the possibility of returning.

title: Judge Upholds Manufacturer in Bendectin Suit
description: A Federal district judge has set aside a jury verdict in his court against the nausea drug Bendectin, which was made by Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc.

title: Short-Term Rates Up Sharply
description: Some short-term interest rates rose by more than a percentage point yesterday as major banks began borrowing money in anticipation of a flurry of year-end loan demands.

title: UNOCAL'S COSTLY INDEPENDENCE
description: Having escaped from T. Boone Pickens only to come up against plummeting oil prices, the Unocal Corporation is paying a price for its independence.

title: A SEARCH IN NATURE FOR ANTITUMOR DRUGS
description: WITH progress against many cancers virtually stalled, the National Cancer Institute is casting a wide net for new drugs in nature, whose plants, animals and microorganisms first produced perhaps a fourth of the 50 or so drugs commonly used in cancer treatment.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
O'CONNOR URGES STEPS TO PRESERVE S.R.O. HOTELS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has urged New York City to take several dramatic steps to preserve single-room-occupany hotel rooms for low-income and homeless people, including the public acquisition of such hotels and the payment of subsidies to hotel owners who cannot stay in business.

title: PATRIOTS UPSET DOLPHINS, MAKING JETS WILD CARD
description: In a stunning finish that affected the playoff fortunes of three teams, the New England Patriots beat the Miami Dolphins tonight, 34-27, in the final game of the National Football League regular season.

title: IN HOWARD BEACH, PRIDE AND FEAR IN A 'PARADISE'
description: ''This is 'Brigadoon,' '' a resident of Howard Beach told a reporter a few years ago, when questions about the neighborhood were asked in a more innocent context.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for 3mo Nov 30
Bridge: Regional Swiss Teams Ends Year at the Winter Regionals
description: At the Winter Regional Championships during the weekend, the Greater New York Bridge Association ended its first year in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Contestants gave the arena top marks for playing comfort, but were less happy with the external circumstances - a lack of places to eat sites and taxicabs.

title: ROBERT B. BANNERMAN
description: Robert B. Bannerman, regional security officer at the United States Embassy in Kenya, was killed Saturday night in a car accident in Nairobi, the State Department said today.

title: F.T.C. Chief Derides Milk-License Ruling
description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission gave a ''national consumer fleece award'' to the New York State Agriculture Commissioner, Joseph Gerace, yesterday, saying Mr. Gerace had used his authority ''to deprive consumers of the benefits of competition.''

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 22
SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $4,981,000 for the quarter and a gain of $40,247,000 for the year, both from equity in earnings of affiliated companies. c-Net income Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represents one share of common stock. All U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 162 yen equals U.S. $1, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of Oct. 31, 1986.

title: FOR HANOI CHIEFS, A LIST OF PROBLEMS
description: Vietnam's poor economic performance was the overriding concern of Hanoi's governing Communists when they assembled last week for their Sixth Party Congress. But it is not the only problem to which the country's new leaders are giving immediate attention, records of the meetings indicate.

title: MEESE REFUSES RODINO REQUEST FOR DOCUMENTS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d refused today to turn over documents on the Iran arms case to the House Judiciary Committee, saying the material had already been provided to Congressional panels.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Chief Operating Officer Is Named at Wolf Trap
description: The Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts has named Alan A. Rubin as its chief operating officer, succeeding Carol V. Harford, whose retirement was announced this year.

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dr. William Nolen, 58, Dead; Author of Books on Medicine
description: Dr. William Nolen, a small-town physician who wrote several books, including ''The Making of a Surgeon,'' has died at the age of 58.

title: WARNING BY CHINA'S POLICE COOL PROTESTS BY STUDENTS
description: After three days of increasingly large and tumultuous street protests by university and college students here, the Shanghai police today banned all further demonstrations without a permit.

title: Toddlin' Town
description: If it's indeed more blessed to give than to receive, then William Perry's heart, if not gladdened, is at least in the right place. The Bears' coach, Mike Ditka, confirmed yesterday that the 350-pound Fridge had been denied all $38,000 that he would have pocketed had he met weight-loss incentives included in his 1986 contract.

title: INDIA CARRIES ITS DREAMS INTO SPACE
