description: AFTER two decades of dreaming, planning and development, India's space program has come of age. Once merely a symbol of the nation's pride and ingenuity, Indian space technology has become an integral part of its communications, weather forecasting and resource management systems.

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Foreigners in London's Clockwork Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK LEADERS SAY QUEENS ATTACK IS EVIDENCE OF 'PERVASIVE PROBLEM'
description: Black civic and political leaders, both loudly and softly, said yesterday that the attack by white youths on three black men in Queens last weekend was convincing evidence that racially motivated violence was a ''pervasive problem and not an isolated one,'' as some people had maintained.

title: S.E.C. Appeals Ruling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had appealed a recent court ruling that made it easier for banks to compete with traditional brokerage firms in the securities business. The S.E.C. said it had asked the full appeals court here to reconsider a ruling by a three-judge panel of the same court.

title: Post Time Plus
description: Turf writers are a clannish lot, their racing world and the rest of life joined as one.

title: TIPPERARY CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,096,000 and $67,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Giants Being Guided by Old Routines
description: On the morning of a Giants home game, Chris Godfrey arrives at Giants Stadium 3 hours 45 minutes before the opening kickoff, give or take two minutes. That never varies.

title: JAMES H. McMULLEN
description: James Hercules McMullen, a former chief inspector of the New York City Housing Development Administration, died of a heart attack Sunday at the home of his daughter, Patricia Silvestri, in Dongan Hills, S.I. He was 70 years old and lived in Bricktown, N.J.

title: OPEC PACT SENDS OIL PRICES UP
description: Oil prices advanced strongly on world markets yesterday, as the oil community welcomed OPEC's decision to cut production.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 4
The Dirty Little Secret
description: Had Michael Griffith been swifter or luckier, he might have escaped, beaten but alive, from the gang that attacked him and two companions Saturday morning in Howard Beach, Queens. Had he not fled onto a parkway and been killed by a passing car, the rest of us might have escaped confronting this harrowing incident and the attitudes it has exposed. There is no escaping now. The awesome fact, as Mayor Koch said in rightful anger, is that a ''racial lynching'' occurred on the streets of New York. Commissioner Benjamin Ward and the Police Department responded with appropriate urgency, assigning 50 investigators to the case, in which 11 white teen-agers have now been arrested.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Joy Accepts Buyout Bid From Investment Firm
description: The Joy Manufacturing Company, a mining equipment manufacturer that has been fighting takeover attempts by the Pullman-Peabody Company, agreed today to be acquired for $620 million by an affiliate of the New York investment firm of Adler & Shaykin.

title: Foreigners in London's Clockwork Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: JACKIE MASON
description: JACKIE MASON is a man who can move mountains. At least he has moved the mountains to Manhattan. The mountains in question are the old resort-riddled Catskills that were noted for clear streams, cold borsht and hot comics. In his one-man show, ''The World According to Me!,'' which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson, Mr. Mason gives hilarious testimony to the art of the stand-up comic.

title: Young Makes Offer To Acquire Pandick
description: Charles P. Young & Company, a financial-printing subsidiary of the Service Resources Corporation, offered yesterday to acquire Pandick Inc., the market leader in that printing field, for $28 a share, or about $280 million.

title: China Survey Planned For TV Audience
description: Chinese interviewers are conducting interviews in five urban-surburban centers in China in what is probably a first-of-its-kind survey designed to discover the habits and attitudes of the country's television viewers. A different scientifically designed random sample of 1,000 consumers will be interviewed twice each year and subscribers can, for a moderate price, have product-related questions included in the interviews.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Travels With Pierce
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is adding some high-level foreign policy diplomacy to his domestic portfolio.

title: Careers; Getting Aid Following Dismissal
description: THIS year may long be remembered as the Year of the Big Dismissals.

title: 120 Detained Briefly in Peru
description: At least 120 people were arrested in a roundup by the police after a wave of leftist guerrilla bombings in the Peruvian capital on Saturday night, a civil guard spokesman said. He said that most were detained because they lacked identification documents, but were freed by today after relatives vouched for their identity.

title: 'CANDLE IN THE WIND,' ON RELIGION IN SOVIET
description: ''CANDLE IN THE WIND'' is an unprecedented look at religion in the Soviet Union. The word ''unprecedented'' should be used with caution, of course; it is often misapplied. In the case of the documentary on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, however, it fits. ''Candle in the Wind'' is a scholarly, balanced, impressive piece of work.

title: Nuclear Plant Talks Halt
description: The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company have suspended negotiations on converting the Midland nuclear power plant to natural gas and will resume talks after the holidays, the companies said today. The companies have been seeking an agreement on joint conversion of the plant. Consumers stopped work on the plant as a nuclear generator in 1984 after Dow pulled out of an agreement to buy steam from the project amid cost overruns and construction delays.

title: Latins Protest Sugar Quotas
description: Latin American sugar growers are hoping to put pressure on the United States to ease its new quotas on sugar imports, an industry spokesman said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adolph Coors Co., Golden, Colo., said it would start the second phase of construction at its Shenandoah Brewery site near Elkton, Va., in January.

title: Mets Promote Perlazzo
description: Sam Perlazzo, who compiled a 364-237 record as a minor-league manager in the Mets farm system the last five years, has been added to the Mets' coaching staff for 1987. Perlazzo managed Tidewater of the International league to a 74-66 record last season.

title: Bonn's Trade Surplus Dips
description: West Germany's trade surplus, a frequent target of American criticism, fell slightly last month to $5.1 billion, from $5.4 billion in October, but remained just below the record $5.5 billion set in July of this year, the Federal Statistics Office reported today.

title: NEW-CAR BUYERS ARE VICTIMS IN PROMOTION OFFERING TRIPS
description: The deal sounded too good to be true: Buy a new car and receive a free ''trip for two to Mexico, includes airfare, hotel and more.''

title: TWO GUIDES TO BUYING A FUR
description: Buying a fur coat, especially for the first time, can be traumatic. Whether it is a $2,000 opossum or a $10,000 mink, a fur coat represents a major investment. Many women feel they are singularly unprepared to make a wise decision. Still, the consistent increase in fur business over the last 15 years reflects the fact that more women are buying their own furs -for warmth, glamour or as a sign of success.

title: PLANE REACHES PACIFIC COAST AS IT AIMS FOR WORLD RECORD
description: The pilots of the Voyager reached the Pacific Coast of Mexico earlier than expected today on their nonstop flight around the world and prepared to land at their starting point in California.

title: Oil Barge Grounded, Spilling 50 Gallons
description: A barge carrying 86,000 gallons of diesel fuel began sinking in the Hudson River yesterday morning, prompting her captain to run aground near Englewood Cliffs, according to the Coast Guard.

title: Coleco to Close Selchow Plants
description: In a bid to cut costs, Coleco Industries said it planned to close the two plants and offices of its Selchow & Righter Company subsidiary at Bay Shore and Holbrook, L.I., and would lay off approximately 100 people employed there. Although some layoffs have begun, the company said the shutdowns would occur early next year.

title: Dow Drops 2.67 as Volume Eases
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as trading reverted to more normal levels after the record-breaking session on Friday caused by the ''triple witching hour.''

title: Mideast Wheels Spin
description: One thing on which leaders in Egypt and Israel and Palestinians in the West Bank tend to join is their complaint about lack of momentum in U.S. Middle East policy.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $9,302,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,583,000. d-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $32,297,000.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Panel on Municipal Corruption The city's municipal corruption scandal will be discussed by a panel of prosecutors at a public hearing sponsored by the State Senate Investigations Committee. Panelists will include United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens and the city's Investigation Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy. 10 A.M., 25th floor hearing room, 270 Broadway, Manhattan Cab Medallion Hearing Mayor Koch's proposal to issue 1,800 new taxi medallions, which would have to be returned to the city if licensees give up driving their cabs, will be the subject of a hearing by the City Council's Committee on Transportation. 10:30 A.M., Council Chamber, City Hall

title: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: The White House said President Reagan rejected the option of granting a pardon to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to encourage them to tell what they knew about the Iran arms affair.

title: Japan Sets 3d World Aid
description: Japan plans to provide extra money to the World Bank for the establishment of a special fund to help developing countries, Government officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Conchemco Inc., Wichita, Kan., a maker of mechanical controls and plastic parts, said Darwin H. Deaver and William C. Hanes had resigned from its board because of pressures from other business interests.

title: 2 Bodies Are Found In Locked Car Trunk
description: The bodies of a man and woman were found Sunday in the locked trunk of the woman's car. The car had been in an Elks Lodge parking lot here for at least nine days, the police said.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: TOXIC WASTE SITE: CLEANUP OUTLOOK
description: The list of chemicals contaminating the ground here reads like the Periodic Table of the Elements, with special emphasis on the heavy metals.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
First Nationwide In Missouri Merger
description: First Nationwide Bank said it had acquired the St. Louis Federal Savings and Loan Association of Clayton, Mo. The association, which has assets of approximately $959 million and 25 branches, will be merged into First Nationwide, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company.

title: SOFTWARE BY MAIL
description: SHOPPING for software can be frustrating, confusing and expensive. Wouldn't it be nice to have someone else track down and evaluate the best programs, and ship them to your door? That's the idea behind the ''Software-of-the-Month Club.'' An advisory board chooses a series of best-selling programs and automatically sends one or two a month to the subscriber unless instructed otherwise.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL UTAH JAZZ VS. NETS, at Byrne Meadowland Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS VS.

title: Looie at a Loss
description: Lou Carnesecca, basketball coach at St. John's, on the 411 arcane pages of rules and regulations that make up the N.C.A.A. Manual: ''Our Lord gave us Ten Commandments, and look at the trouble we have with those.''

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Title Relinquished
description: Lloyd Honeyghan, the undisputed world welterweight champion, gave up his World Boxing Association title in London yesterday for political reasons, but he will defend his other titles against Johnny Bumphus in February. The 26-year-old Honeyghan, a black Londoner, surrendered his W.B.A. crown rather than obey an instruction to defend it against Harold Volbrecht, the white South African, who is the W.B.A.'s No. 1 contender.

title: Ayer Buys Almost All Of C.&W.
description: N.W. AYER INC., announced yesterday that it had, as expected, reached an agreement to acquire Cunningham & Walsh, or at least big parts of it.

title: Dangers From Lead
description: A new study concludes that many American children may be suffering mild hearing loss from exposure to lead. Using data collected on more than 3,000 children and teen-agers, the researchers found that even low levels of lead in the blood increased the likelihood of subtle hearing loss that could affect a child's ability to understand speech.

title: ARIZONA TORN BY GOVERNOR-ELECT'S PLAN TO DROP KING HOLIDAY
description: Shortly after he becomes Governor of Arizona next month, Evan Mecham plans to do something no other governor has done: rescind a state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The move has angered and surprised many Arizonans and has drawn criticism and concern from civil rights leaders and politicians around the country.

title: WESTCHESTER OFFERS RENT AID AS WAY OF CUTTING EVICTIONS
description: Westchester County's legislature approved an experimental program today that would subsidize the rents of tenants facing eviction, to avoid the higher costs of sheltering them in hotels and motels.

title: CAPTIVE IN NICARAGUA DESCRIBES MOTIVES
description: An American captured outside a restricted Nicaraguan air base was presented publicly today for the first time since his arrest, and gave a confused account of his motives and background.

title: ISRAELI SUSPECT FLASHES A HINT HE WAS ABDUCTED
description: An Israeli nuclear technician who sold information about this country's atomic weapons program to a British newspaper has made an extraordinary gesture to indicate that he was later abducted in Rome.

title: PENN STATE PHILOSOPHY
description: The conversation was becoming heated, as barroom debates between fans of opposing college football teams often do. This one involved a Penn State student and an older Notre Dame fan, their voices rising above the din of the jukebox and more pleasant cocktail conversation surrounding them, in the Gipper Lounge in a South Bend, Ind., hotel in 1982. Just when it looked as if the student was going to discover why Notre Dame is nicknamed the Fighting Irish, his female companion nudged him, as if to say, ''Let's change the subject.''

title: BIG DONORS TO TOP CITY OFFICIALS NAMED
description: Mayor Koch, other members of the Board of Estimate and the Democratic organizations in the five boroughs have raised $30 million in campaign funds in the last six years, much of it from people doing business with the city, a Democratic state senator said yesterday.

title: Chess: Brooklyn Player Is Winner Of Women's Championship
description: The United States women's championship, held at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo., was won by Inna Izrailov of Brooklyn. The 22-year-old international woman master, a Russian emigre, scored 7-2 to top a round-robin field of 10.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
'BLOOD TIES,' MOB DRAMA FROM ITALY
description: MADE in association with the pay-cable service Showtime, ''Blood Ties'' seems to be something of an experiment designed to give Italian television a foothold in the lucrative American marketplace. For the most part, Italian productions have stumbled over obvious language barriers. Subtitles are generally thought to be too cumbersome, and most dubbing processes tend to produce a ''lifeless'' soundtrack. The solution for ''Blood Ties''? Make the film in English, with actors who can speak English, even if heavily accented. Presumably, the production will be marketed elsewhere, even in Italy, as a ''foreign film.''

title: Buchanan for President?
description: In the debate over Iran and Nicaragua, President Reagan's most outspoken advocate has been Patrick J. Buchanan, his communications director, and now some conservative Republicans are starting to talk about Mr. Buchanan as a possible Presidential contender.

title: BERRY HOPES FOR BETTER CLIMATE IN TEXAS
description: Even with its breathtaking scenery and relaxed life style, the Pacific Northwest was no place for Walter Berry. And he made no secret of it. So last Thursday, the unhappy forward got his wish. Sort of.

title: U.S. WEAPONS BEGIN TO REACH CHAD
description: This listless town seemed to shake today as an American cargo plane touched down with the first shipment of United States military equipment since Libya began an offensive in northern Chad.

title: O'BRIEN STILL NO. 1 ON THE JETS
description: Coach Joe Walton remained rigid today in his tenacious support of his young quarterback, Ken O'Brien, in the face of a pervasive slump that cost the Jets a division title.

title: Sator Replaces Ramsay
description: Ted Sator, who was dismissed by the Rangers earlier this hockey season, yesterday became the third man this season to coach the struggling Buffalo Sabres, replacing Craig Ramsay.

title: PACT REACHED ON REBUILDING TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers announced agreement tonight on an $8.6 billion, five-year program to rebuild New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail lines and to freeze their fares for three years. But they put off until next year a decision on how to pay for parts of the program.

title: Descriptions Differ In Jersey Slay Trial
description: A defense witness testified yesterday that Richard C. Williams, who is charged with killing a state trooper in 1981, had short hair 10 days before the shooting, an account that contradicted another witness's description of a long-haired passenger in the getaway car.

title: Sterling National Bank Appoints a New Chief
description: The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York will have a new chief executive and president effective Jan. 5. He is John C. Millman, who was chosen last week at a board meeting.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''Veruschka is a character I created,'' said Vera Lehndorff, who played her creation in 60's fashion magazine spreads and in the film ''Blow-Up.''

title: Containing Qaddafi
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is spreading death beyond Libya's borders again, this time in neighboring Chad. Past efforts by the United States, France and African neighbors have only contained the colonel's adventurism temporarily. But the lesson is to keep trying. Washington and Paris do right to help Chad defend itself against this new surge of aggression.

title: MANILA BARS POWER-SHARING WITH INSURGENTS
description: The Philippine Government rejected Communist rebel demands today. But it said it still hoped for a meeting of minds in peace talks to start Jan. 6.

title: FILM: CARLOS SAURA'S 'AMOR BRUJO'
description: CARLOS SAURA has set ''El Amor Brujo'' on a stage the size of an airplane hangar, with a sand floor and a horizon that changes color with the film's many moods. The landscape is crisscrossed by telephone wires and populated by shacks in which the film's gypsy characters reside. This setting is imaginative and versatile, and it is by far the most striking thing about ''El Amor Brujo,'' Mr. Saura's flamenco film made in collaboration with Antonio Gades. This is their third such collaboration, after ''Carmen'' (1983) and ''Blood Wedding'' (1981).

title: Evacuation at Volcano Ended
description: Residents were allowed back in their palm-shaded homes near a quiescent lava flow, but the authorities warned them today against standing on the cooling, newborn rock that had oozed from Kilauea Volcano.

title: South Africa's Ruling National Party Must Go; Madness of Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: MEANINGFUL ACTIVITIES AND TEMPERAMENT KEY IN SATISFACTION WITH LIFE
description: SOME of the most widespread beliefs about the quest for satisfaction with life are misleading or dead wrong, psychologists have found.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov. 29
description: First quarter earnings were reduced by about $2 million, or 8 cents a share, after restating investment tax credits under the tax reform act.

title: Cannon Extension
description: The Cannon Group Inc. said that the previously extended deadline for a $75 million debt payment to Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. had been extended again, through today. Those close to Cannon, an independent film producer and distributor, said the company was likely to secure the financing through bank credit with the assistance of Warner Communications Inc., which would, in return, obtain rights to some of Cannon's releases.

title: CELIUS DOUGHERTY, COMPOSER AND ACCOMPANIST TO SINGERS
description: Celius Dougherty, accompanist to many of the great singers of the 1930's and 40's and a composer of tuneful, witty songs, many of them used as recital encores, died of cancer yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived in Effort, Pa.

title: Conversation In the Snow
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy's neighbors, taciturn New Englanders through and through, are determinedly protective of his privacy.

title: Alaska Air Deal
description: The Transportation Department cleared the way for Alaska Air Group Inc. to buy Horizon Airlines, a regional carrier that serves five states in the West and Northwest. The Federal agency said the purchase ''does not raise any significant competitive or public interest issues,'' and exempted the transaction from merger approval procedures. Alaska Air Group, which already owns Alaska Airlines and Jet America, had asked for the exemption, arguing that the purchase increased its national market share by only about 1 percent.

title: INSIDE BOX
description: Italy Seeks Abduction Facts Italy has begun an investigation into reports that an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted by Israeli agents in Italy.

title: FAMILY SEES 300 FOSTER CHILDREN COME AND GO
description: In the beginning, Dottie Spatcher tried to bathe the foster children who were delivered to her apartment in the middle of the night, then bundle them in fleecy pajamas and tuck them into warm beds.

title: CASEY'S BRAIN TUMOR IS CONFIRMED AS CANCEROUS
description: The lymphoma tumor removed from the left side of the brain of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, was confirmed as cancerous, his doctors said today.

title: Braille 'Mouse' Lets The Blind Use Computers
description: Using a combination of 1980's computer technology and the 1830's Braille system, an experimental device developed at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center for the first time offers blind computer users the ability to ''read'' characters directly from a computer screen. The device, a ''mouse'' pointer, has been specially modified to include six tiny ''pistons'' that rise and fall, forming standard Braille characters like those on a printed page.

title: VOYAGER SUCCEEDS IN HISTORIC FLIGHT
description: Sweeping out of a clear desert sky and into aviation history, the experimental airplane Voyager landed safely here early today, completing the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel.

title: IN KWANZAA, TWO FESTIVE TRADITIONS
description: ON the day after Christmas, many Americans will turn from the red and green of one celebration to the red, green and black of one that turns 20 years old this year. Kwanzaa, begun as a nonreligious, African-American alternative to what many perceive as the overcommercialization of Christmas, will be observed in homes, churches and cultural institutions, including the American Museum of Natural History. The weeklong celebration, from Dec. 26 through Jan. 1, will be marked by culinary feasts and the exchange of simple gifts.

title: In Perspective; Some New Developments
description: The report of a year-old memorandum proposing an exchange of arms to Iran for American hostages in Lebanon has contradicted the White House's insistence that it sold arms to Iran solely to open a dialogue with Iranian moderates. The document, reportedly written by the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, analyzed the political problems that could arise if the arms shipments were found out.

title: Shelter on East Side Is Damaged by Fire
description: A fire heavily damaged a shelter for homeless women yesterday afternoon, injuring a firefighter and forcing the residents to be housed elsewhere for the night.

title: Preserving the Sparkle In Gift Paper
description: FOR makers of wrapping paper, Santa's red suit is a little bolder this year, Christmas trees are a more brilliant green, and silvery winter scenes are glistening more brightly. The sparkle of this season's wrapping paper has been preserved through advances in resin technology and water-based inks, despite a major change in the way wrapping paper is printed as a result of Federal regulations aimed at reducing air pollution.

title: ITALY LOOKS INTO CASE OF ISRAELI PRISONER
description: The Government has begun an investigation into whether an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted by Israeli agents on Italian soil, and if so, whether any Italian laws were violated.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS SHARP CUTBACKS IN FARM BUDGET
description: President Reagan's new budget will propose sweeping changes in farm programs designed to save more than $16 billion over the next five years, Administration officials said today.

title: 3 WHITE YOUTHS ARE ORDERED HELD WITHOUT BAIL IN ATTACK IN QUEENS
description: Three white teen-agers were ordered held without bail yesterday on second-degree murder charges in the racial attack last week in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: COURT RULES FOR BANK ON COMMERCIAL PAPER
description: In what commercial bankers called an important victory in their attempts to take on Wall Street, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Bankers Trust New York Corporation may act as a commercial-paper agent.

title: Organizer and Top Player Are Now a Married Couple
description: Exactly half a century ago one of the metropolitan area's leading tournament organizers, Al Sobel, married one of the area's top players, Helen Martin White, due to become even more famous with her new name.

title: TORRINGTON'S HOLIDAY TRADITION LIVES ON
description: At Christmas 40 years ago, a young man named Carl Bozenski lay in a tuberculosis sanitarium and made this vow: If he recovered, he would go back to his hometown and build a Christmas Village.

title: Team Tries to Attach Infant's Severed Foot
description: A team of microsurgeons used a rare emergency procedure early this morning to try to reattach the severed foot of a 13-month-old boy whose mother leaped in front of an oncoming A train in upper Manhattan yesterday while carrying the infant.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday, reporting on a cross-country runner who sued the University of Colorado over drug testing, misidentified him. He is David Derdyn.

title: WEINBERGER TO ASK FUNDS TO BUILD 2 MORE NUCLEAR-POWERED CARRIERS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will ask for money next year to begin construction of two additional nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, the Pentagon said today.

title: A Cold War Battle Of Banners and Wits
description: To the Editor:

title: First Woman Publisher At Time Inc. Is Chosen
description: Less than eight years after graduating from Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard and being recruited for Time Inc., Elizabeth P. Valk has been named publisher of Life, the first woman to become a publisher in Time's history.

title: GEORGIA FALLS, 27-24, TO BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Shawn Halloran's 5-yard touchdown pass to Kelvin Martin with 32 seconds remaining tonight gave Boston College a 27-24 victory over Georgia in the Hall of Fame Bowl. game.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT PENGUINS
description: Lately, his goals have been slow in coming and executed with awkwardness instead of the renowned artistry, but Mike Bossy has retained his knack of pure positioning, and tonight it yielded a 4-3 overtime victory for the Islanders. But the scar on the side of the puck revealed that this goal, which moved Bossy into fifth place on the league's career scoring roster with 557 career goals, was inelegantly obtained.

title: Untangle New York's Election Rules
description: Laced with rules that invite annoying nitpicking, New York State's election laws are commonly rated the nation's worst. This year's campaign antics confirmed that judgment. Almost 200 would-be candidates, including an employee of the rule-saturated Board of Elections, were disqualified because of mistakes in their nomination petitions.

title: McKEGNEY HERO AS RANGERS WIN
description: Every time Tony McKegney's name comes up these days, it is followed by ''again'' as in ''McKegney again.''

title: U.S. AGENCY REJECTS CITY'S BAN ON A-FUEL
description: Federal regulators, reaffirming a 1985 decision, rejected today New York City's last attempt to use administrative measures to block the trucking of spent nuclear fuel on city thoroughfares.

title: spending for Research Expected to Rise 7.4%
description: Spending in the United States for research and development in 1987 is expected to rise $8.8 billion, to $127.4 billion, according to a forecast by Battelle, the Ohio-based nonprofit research contractor.

title: KAZAKHSTAN SHAKE-UP LIKELY
description: The new Kazakhstan party leader, Gennadi V. Kolbin, today denounced party operations in the Central Asian republic.

title: Topics: Holiday Jams; Universal Present
description: One recent night, a Christmas shopper we know, armed with shopping list and credit card, plunged into a large New York department store. She was prepared for anything, except for where she found the longest lines.

title: FIRST JERSEY SECURITIES SELLING RETAIL BRANCHES
description: Robert E. Brennan's First Jersey Securities, which has been fighting Government fraud charges, announced yesterday that it was selling its retail branch system to the Sherwood Capital Group Inc., an investment firm based in Jersey City.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is Christmas Day. Following are holiday schedules:

title: REAGAN LIBRARY SITE CHOICE STIRS OPPOSITION IN PALO ALTO
description: All Ronald Reagan's problems are not in Washington: Thousands of people here are protesting plans to build his Presidential library in the rolling foothills west of Palo Alto.

title: Change in China: Divisible?
description: The dilemma for China has long been clear. Without reform and greater openness, the nation was doomed to poverty and decay. Yet with them, Chinese Communism would be threatened.

title: SCREEN: 'NATIVE SON,' BASED ON WRIGHT'S NOVEL
description: BIGGER THOMAS, the 19-year-old hero of Richard Wright's seminal 1940 novel, ''Native Son,'' is not easy to take either as a character or as a man, but he's a figure of mythic proportions. He's a mountain in the flat literary landscape that surrounds him.

title: FIRST 10 MX MISSILES PLACED ON ALERT
description: Eight years after development began and with its ultimate future still in doubt, the MX missile has gained operational status with the first 10 moving to full alert beneath the plains of Wyoming, the Pentagon announced today.

title: REPUBLICAN OBJECTIONS STALL ADOPTION OF PACT ON TRANSIT
description: The Legislature tonight delayed passage of a plan to finance a five-year, $8.6 billion rebuilding of New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail lines and to freeze fares for three years.

title: NEW SYSTEM OF VENTS EASES A RADON CRISIS
description: Last March, dread gripped the neighborhood of Clinton Knolls atop an ancient limestone cliff here in rural Hunterdon County.

title: Why, Santa!
description: Sometimes it's the little things -the way he wears his hat, the way she sips her tea - that say the most about somebody. Sometimes, too, it's the little things that say the most about a state.

title: No Guns, No Barbies
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Falcons Eye Vermeil
description: The owner of the Atlanta Falcons, Rankin Smith Sr., said Dick Vermeil, the former coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, was a ''good prospect'' to replace Dan Henning, who was dismissed Monday as coach of the Falcons. Smith said his family had a candidate in mind, but he declined to say whether Vermeil had been contacted.

title: U.S. AGENCY APPROVES DRUG FOR USE IN TREATING A FORM OF LEPROSY
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that is intended primarily for the treatment of a form of leprosy but also has been used to treat an infection common in AIDS patients. Ciba-Geigy, the maker of the drug, stressed that it was not a potential AIDS cure.

title: Bill Cosby to Appear For Kodak Colorwatch
description: Bill Cosby, one of the country's best-liked and respected entertainers, has signed a three-year contract with Kodak to be an all-media spokesman for its Kodak Colorwatch System, a photofinish program.

title: A.P., FEARING HARM TO HOSTAGES, FACES HARD CHOICES ON IRAN AFFAIR
description: For The Associated Press, covering the Iran arms affair has become a daily balancing act between a responsibility to provide full coverage and a desire not to endanger the lives of the Western hostages in Lebanon, according to the news service's top managers.

title: Younkers Acquisition
description: The Younkers department store chain announced today that it had agreed to purchase a major Middle West competitor, the Brandeis department stores, for $30 million to $35 million, depending on Brandeis's year-end financial performance. Brandeis, based in Omaha, operates 11 department stores in Iowa and Nebraska. The transaction will give Younkers a total of 37 stores in five states.

title: What Makes a Federal Holiday?
description: To the Editor:

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CASES TRY TO SET EXAMPLE
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the wish that others will follow their example. ''May love and caring touch more of us, so that we take a part in helping those who are needy,'' said Lilian Zwyns of Manhattan, who sent a $200 gift to the fund's 75th annual appeal.

title: HOW TO CLEAN UP POLITICAL CAMPAIGNS
description: To the Editor:

title: McKELLEN ON HOW FAR IS TOO FAR
description: As Platonov, the incorrigibly rakish schoolmaster who seduces every woman he meets in ''Wild Honey,'' Ian McKellen has just flung himself in front of an oncoming locomotive -although whether in despair over the romantic muddles he has created or in befuddlement induced by all the vodka he has drunk is not entirely clear.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS BELLS

title: BROKERAGES SCRUTINIZED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating at least six major Wall Street firms in connection with the possible illegal accumulation of stock for clients planning hostile takeovers, agency officials said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Vodkas With a Twist

title: REAGAN AND SENATORS CLASH OVER WHO WILL ISSUE REPORT
description: President Reagan and the Senate intelligence committee disagreed today over whether the White House or the committee should be responsible for making public the panel's findings on the Iran affair.

title: AMERICA AND THE CATHOLIC CHURCH: CONFLICTS WITH ROME AND WITHIN
description: Long before it was popular to do so, a Roman Catholic clergyman from the United States favored celebrating mass in English instead of Latin, the election of the leadership of the American church by its own priests instead of its appointment by Rome, and a strong role for the laity.

title: Democratic Chief Resigning in Nassau
description: The Nassau County Democratic chairman, Martin Mellman, announced his resignation yesterday.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'RIGOLETTO' OF METROPOLITAN SEASON
description: THE first ''Rigoletto'' of the season Monday night proved a dispiriting illustration of the Metropolitan Opera's dilemma over bread-and-butter Italian operas. They must be increasingly relied upon for their box-office draw, yet the company's roster is shallowest in the area of singers who can perform them with distinction. The schedule is inevitably a house of cards, waiting to collapse if there are withdrawals, cancellations, vocal problems or what have you.

title: WRITERS SAVOR CHRISTMAS MEMORIES
description: FOOD and Christmas are inextricably bound in memory. For most people, Christmas conjures up the smell of cinnamon, cider and chestnuts, of turkey or goose roasting and ham baking, and the vision of friends and family at the table making merry. For writers, the holiday often means ritual with food at its heart, ritual that inevitably becomes the seed of a story. This year six writers, Eudora Welty, Garrison Keillor, Mary Lee Settle, Samuel R. Delany, Reynolds Price and Joyce Maynard, share their memories of Christmas food and the people with whom they savored it. EUDORA WELTY

title: New York 'Master Teacher' Plan Is Self-Defeating
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Law Firm Clerk Charged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a former clerk at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and eight of his relatives with illegally trading on inside information about planned takeover bids by the firm's corporate clients.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Crossland Savings named Salvatore S. Citrano executive vice president and chief retail officer.

title: Biography of Hanoi Leader
description: The Vietnamese radio has broadcast an official biography of the new Vietnamese leader, Nguyen Van Linh. The broadcast last Thursday said that his real name is Nguyen Van Cuc and that he was born in July 1915 in Hai Hung Province.

title: The Helms-Weicker Tie
description: Senator Jesse Helms has acquired an unlikely ally in his struggle to become the top Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee in the next Congress. Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, a liberal Republican, has taken up the conservative North Carolinian's cause.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Finding Heroes in the White House
description: Imagine that you were President and two trusted aides were found to be executing their own policy toward Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, a policy so reckless that its exposure threatened the work of your entire Administration. Acting in your name, they had blundered, perhaps committed crimes. What would you do?

title: DANCE: 'VELOCITIES,' NIKOLAIS PREMIERE
description: THE Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater presented the world premiere of Mr. Nikolais's ''Velocities'' Monday night. Like much of the current engagement, running through Jan. 4, the new piece stresses the quicksilver muscular control of the 10 dancers who serve their choreographer so well.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hitachi Chip Plan
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it plans to start making its most advanced variety of computer memory chips at its plant in Irving, Tex., next summer.

title: PAINTER, AUTHOR AND ART CRITIC
description: Maurice Grosser, a painter known for his picturesque landscapes, still lifes and portraits, died of congestive heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Realistic 3-D Images On a Video Screen
description: A system called pixel-planes, now being developed at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, holds the promise of generating realistic three-dimensional images on a video screen at a fraction of the current cost, researchers there said. By manipulating 3-D video images with computer joysticks, an architect, for example, could take a ''walking tour'' of a building before it is built, or a surgeon could examine 3-D images of organs inside the body of a patient. The system contains more than 2,000 computer chips and can perform 12 million operations a second, according to Dr. John W. Poulton, one of the principal researchers. Dr. Poulton said the research group had received a patent on the system and was exploring ways to market it.

title: Owner's Dream
description: Don't tell me you believe that there's collusion, too.

title: The Democrats' Parade
description: The 1988 Presidential season's first big parade of Democratic hopefuls could come next month in California.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1986
description: International

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WITH holiday preparations and parties in full swing, you may be longing for some quiet time at home. By late January or February, however, you may start wondering whether you can stand another dark, cold, lonely winter day. Depression, irritability, sleepiness, inertia, boredom, restlessness, impatience and dissatisfaction seem to characterize the postholiday months for millions of Americans who reside in the so-called frost belt. The problem is so common that medical science has given it a name - cabin fever.

title: British 'Mystery Plays' Focus on Life of Jesus
description: PERHAPS one day, when cable priorities are straightened out in New York City, I shall not have to describe the Bravo pay service as ''currently unavailable in Manhattan, though it is in many suburbs.'' But for the time being, that is the sorry state of things, despite the fact that a service offering top foreign and ''art'' films plus performance specials would seem tailor-made for New York viewers. An exceptionally fine example can be found in ''The Mystery Plays,'' being offered this week at 10 o'clock on three consecutive evenings - tonight, tomorrow and Friday.

title: Tampa to Investigate
description: The Mayor of Tampa, Fla., said yesterday that the city is conducting its own investigation into the arrest of Dwight Gooden, the Mets pitcher.

title: FEWER I.R.S. WORKERS TO PROCESS TAX RETURNS
description: The Internal Revenue Service intends to assign fewer workers to help process income tax returns during the coming filing season, officials said today. There will also be fewer to answer taxpayer questions.

title: To the 'Skins
description: Washingtonians can now raise a special toast to the Redskins. In celebration of the team's 50th anniversary, a northern Virginia vineyard, Meredyth Winery, recently introduced two new wines - one gold, one burgundy, of course - both of which feature the Redskin logo on the label.

title: STAGE: 'RED RIDING HOOD'
description: MORE than anything else in the world, Lone Z. Wolf, the protagonist of the Jule Styne-Bob Merrill-Robert Emmett musical ''The Dangerous Christmas of Red Riding Hood,'' desires respectability.

title: LUNCHEON IS FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: The state's special corruption prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, is investigating a long 1983 luncheon meeting attended by the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci; two police officials; a Queens political leader, and a reputed organized-crime figure, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title:
WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING;
Tate for Chief Spokesman?
description: Sheila B. Tate, former press secretary to Nancy Reagan, has emerged as a leading contender to succeed Larry Speakes as chief spokesman for President Reagan.

title: NO CHARGES IN HAZING DEATH
description: A grand jury condemned fraternity hazing but refused to indict anyone in the drinking death of a University of Texas fraternity pledge who drank a fatal amount of rum.

title: SAKHAROV ATTENDS A MOSCOW SEMINAR AND IS APPLAUDED
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, once vilified in the Soviet press as a ''renegade and turncoat,'' was greeted with applause today by colleagues at a scientific seminar at his Physics Institute.

title: Durables Orders Up 5.9%
description: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, powered by a big military buildup and a last-minute rush to take advantage of expiring tax breaks, soared 5.9 percent in November, the biggest rise in two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SUDDENLY, STRIKES TURN A FESTIVE AIR CONTENTIOUS
description: Sometimes this can be a contentious country, the kind of place where discord can disrupt the calm surface of everyday life like a fist through cellophane, puncturing even a Christmas season with strikes, lines, bad tempers, and memories of even worse conflicts in the past.

title: DANCE: DENNIS WAYNE IN TRIBUTE TO A TEACHER
description: DENNIS WAYNE'S company, Dancers, concluded its engagement at the Triplex on Sunday afternoon by honoring Norman Walker, one of Mr. Wayne's teachers. A versatile choreographer and a former director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, Mr. Walker has taught at the School of Performing Arts and is currently chairman of the dance department at Adelphi University.

title: State v. Defense: A Fight for Nuclear Supremacy
description: Tension between the State Department and the Defense Department on arms control usually arises when the Pentagon hawkishly attacks diplomatic moves to restrain nuclear weapons. The State Department, for its part, is seen as more amenable to limiting nuclear arms.

title: SLOW-STARTING EXPRESS DROPS COACH
description: One of the first steps the New York Express took in an attempt to become a credible franchise in the Major Indoor Soccer League was to sign Rick Davis, the former American star of the Cosmos.

title: Canadian Sikhs Guilty In Airliner Bomb Plot
description: Two Canadian Sikhs were convicted today of conspiring to bomb an Air-India flight from New York to New Dehli that was carrying an Indian Cabinet minister.

title: They Tell Children That Violence Is O.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: BERNARDIN IN PARIS SOLD
description: SO that they can concentrate on their New York restaurant, Gilbert Le Coze and his sister, Maguy, have sold the original Le Bernardin in Paris.

title: Ah, the Holidays
description: The capital's obsession with the Iran arms deal has been unrelenting. Before this uproar, it was the 1986 elections. Before that, it was the change in the composition of the Supreme Court.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1986
description: Markets

title: Lower Profits Seen for I.B.M.
description: FOR the second time in three months, the International Business Machines Corporation has sent analysts scurrying to lower their earnings estimates.

title: Trees, Sweat and Tears
description: EARLY RAISERS: A Christmas tree should never be put up before sundown on Christmas Eve, yet increasing numbers of people have them glittering in the parlor by mid-December. It is an evil custom which people should abandon.

title: Tots and Tables
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: G. NORMAN WIDMARK
description: G. Norman Widmark, chairman emeritus of Butler International Inc., an aviation and engineering services company based in Montvale, N.J., died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: LEG TRAPS BANNED IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Legislature, overriding a veto by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan, voted today to ban steel-jaw leg traps. The law is the first by a county in New York State prohibiting the spring-loaded devices, which are used by trappers to catch small animals including foxes, raccoons and otters.

title: American Express Stock Block Sold
description: The Alleghany Corporation, which is in the midst of a liquidation, sold 3.6 million shares of American Express Company stock yesterday for about $208 million. The sale, which came in a single block of stock handled by Salomon Brothers, leaves Alleghany with about 2.65 million shares of American Express.

title: College Basketball
description: Indiana 67, Louisville 58: Rick Calloway scored 21 points, including 13 in the second half, to lead Indiana at home. Indiana (7-1) trailed by 11 points in the first half but scored the first 5 points of the second half to cut a 6-point deficit to 34-33 on a 14-foot jumper by Calloway. The Hoosiers then took the lead when Steve Alford's field goal made it 37-36 with 14:57 to play. But Louisville (4-5), led by Herbert Crook's 6 straight points, went on a 13-5 run in the next 5:50 to go ahead, 49-42, with 9:07 remaining. Crook finished with 24 points. (AP) Brigham Young 93, Pittsburgh 73: Mike Smith scored 34 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to lead Brigham Young (6-4) at home. Charles Smith led the Panthers (5-2) with 22 points before fouling out. (AP) Georgetown 94, Florida A&M 65: Mark Tillmon scored 17 points and five other Georgetown players were in double figures to lead the Hoyas at home. Georgetown (8-0) got 10 points each from Reggie Williams and Dwayne Bryant in taking a 52-33 halftime lead and never let the advantage slip below 16 points. Williams had 16 points and 10 rebounds, and Bryant finished with 14 points. The Rattlers (2-6) dropped their sixth straight game despite getting 26 points from Leonard King. (AP) L.I.U. 89, Morgan State 80: Calvin Lamb scored 32 points, 19 in the second half, and Freddie Burton added 18 to lead L.I.U. Troy Brown's 22 points paced the Bears (3-4), who trailed at halftime, 43-28.

title: ARTIST SUES U.S. OVER 'TILTED ARC'
description: Richard Serra, whose ''Tilted Arc'' sculpture in Lower Manhattan has been the focus of intense controversy for nearly two years, has filed suit against the General Services Administration, the Federal agency that commissioned the work, charging breach of contract and other violations of the artist's rights.

title: Holmes a Court Bid On Australia Papers
description: The financier Robert Holmes a Court today opened a battle with the publisher Rupert Murdoch for ownership of the nation's largest newspaper group.

title: An Extra Day Off for Many
description: Retailers, bankers, the Postal Service and the stock markets will operate this Friday, the day after Christmas, but many other employers will be shut down.

title: PENTAGON AIDES SAY NORTH SPENT 10 DAYS IN HOSPITAL IN 1974
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North was hospitalized for 10 days in 1974 for emotional distress, but the White House was unaware of his medical history when it hired him in 1981 for the staff of the National Security Council, according to an authoritative Pentagon source.

title: TV HOOKUP IS PLANNED BY U.S. AND SOVIET UNION
description: United States and Soviet officials have agreed to broadcast a series of joint television programs by satellite that will depict the political and cultural life of both countries.

title: Prices Rise in Slow Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday in quiet trading.

title: THE INTELLECTUAL SANTA'S SACK: THINKING SKILLS AND 'DIGIT DAYS'
description: TONIGHT, Santa Claus will deliver lots of toys to little girls and boys - unless they happen to be gifted little girls and boys, in which case he will probably give them distasteful learning aids.

title: DIRECTOR MAY RETURN TO SOVIET
description: Yuri Lyubimov, the Soviet theater director who was stripped of his citizenship two years ago, said today that he has received a message from a colleague that he would be welcome back in the Soviet Union.

title: 6 Paintings Are Stolen From Theater in Paris
description: Burglars broke into a small theater off the Champs-Elysees today and stole six paintings by J. Edouard Vuillard, a post-Impressionist artist who was commissioned to do the works for the theater's opening in 1913.

title: Superscrub
description: Ron Kornegay resigned as Monmouth College's basketball coach last Friday, saying that ''the program needs to go in another direction.''

title: GROGAN'S COOL CALL SAVES PATRIOT YEAR
description: The drive that won it, the drive that made the New England Patriots division champions and pushed the Jets into a wild-card game, took about seven minutes of the last quarter of the season and was orchestrated by a player who hadn't been heard from in quite some time.

title: PROTESTS BY STUDENTS SPREAD TO BEIJING
description: Street protests by students calling for democracy spread to the capital tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This was the last major event of atmospheric flight. That we did it as private citizens says a lot about freedom in America.''

title: SECORD AGAIN BARS TESTIMONY ON IRAN
description: Richard V. Secord, the retired major general who has emerged as a figure in the clandestine arms sales to Iran and has been linked to support for contra rebels in Nicaragua, refused again today to testify before a Congressional hearing into the operations, according to a Congressional official.

title: Diabetic Retinopathy
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: GREYHOUND SELLING ITS BUS OPERATIONS
description: The Greyhound Corporation, after opening up the nation to travelers for 73 years, said yesterday that it would sell its famed bus operations.

title: BOAT WITH 48 DOMINICANS SWAMPS OFF PUERTO RICO
description: At least eight people drowned when a 28-foot boat loaded with 48 people from the Dominican Republic was swamped in turbulent waters within a few hundred feet of shore, the authorities reported today. Officials said the people on the boat were trying to sneak into the United States through Puerto Rico.

title: Coopervision Net Up 32.2%
description: Coopervision Inc., an eye care company, reported earnings today for the fourth quarter ended Oct. 31 of $16.4 million, or 73 cents a share, up 32.2 percent from $12.4 million, or 59 cents a share in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 40.8 percent, to $140 million, from $99.4 million.

title: This Isn't Just Another Talking Dog Story
description: EVER wonder just who thinks up those toys that every kid wants for Christmas? To find out, we take you not to the North Pole, but to the elegant Claremont Hotel in Berkeley, Calif. Walk through the spacious lobby, down one flight of stairs, past the restrooms and into the cluttered offices of one Stephen Beck, engineer, inventor, artist, entrepreneur and elf.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report on Saturday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the headquarters community of the Gannett Company.

title: Jackson Likely to Sign
description: Reggie Jackson will apparently rejoin the Oakland A's. The A's scheduled a news conference for this morning but declined to reveal its purpose.

title: GLASS HOUSE IS DONATED
description: The architect Philip Johnson has donated his Glass House - a six-building complex spread over a 30-acre estate in New Canaan, Conn. -to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced yesterday.

title: AN ITALIAN DELI'S CHARCUTERIE
description: FOR more than 40 years the Salumeria Biellese, a small Italian food store in Chelsea, has been making silk purses out of sows' ears. To outward appearances a hero store (and an outstanding one), this salumeria has another identity better known to chefs and restaurateurs than to the furriers and postal workers who cluster around its counters at lunchtime.

title: Senator Abdnor Is S.B.A. Nominee
description: Senator James Abdnor, the South Dakota Republican who was defeated for re-election in November, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to head the Small Business Administration.

title: L.S.U. Names Coach
description: Mike Archer was promoted from defensive coordinator to head football coach at Louisiana State University, replacing Bill Arnsparger, who resigned to take the post of athletic director at the University of Florida. The school's board of supervisors picked Archer over Mike Shanahan, the offensive coordinator for the Denver Broncos, and George Haffner, the assistant at the University of Georgia. Arnsparger led the Tigers to a 9-2 won-lost record, good for the university's first Southeastern Conference championship in 16 years and a berth in the Sugar Bowl, where Arnsparger will coach his last game for L.S.U.

title: FOG CAUSES BLACKOUT ON THE NORTH SIDE OF CHICAGO
description: Fog caused short circuits that cut power to as many as 200,000 homes and office buildings here today, stopped commuter trains and knocked broadcasting stations off the air.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANYWHERE BUT HERE. By Mona Simpson. 406 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Not-So-Silent Film Fare
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: LAW IN ARGENTINA ENDS PROSECUTION
description: The Argentine Congress adopted legislation tonight that is expected to bring an end to the prosecution of military officers accused of murder, torture, kidnapping and other crimes during the late 1970's and early 1980's.

title: FUTURISTIC-PRIMITIVE PLANE IS A BLEND OF BRAVE DREAMS AND IMPROVISATION
description: Beset by creditors and exhausted by a feat that had defied all others, Richard G. Rutan and Jeana Yeager took their places yesterday among the legendary pilots of history.

title: DOW FALLS ON CAPITAL GAINS SALES
description: Investors looking to take capital gains on stocks in the current year charged into the market yesterday, sending prices broadly lower and volume up sharply.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
More Pasta, Please
description: TELLING people to eat more of their dietary calories in carbohydrates is not the sort of stern, finger-waving admonition we eternal dieters are used to. As a matter of fact, it is more like a joyful release, a new license to eat foods we already love and dream about: potatoes, pasta, rice and beans.

title: Of Punches And Pocketbooks
description: The criminal sanctions threatened by Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston aren't the only legal avenue being discussed these days as a weapon against gratuitous violence in professional sports.

title: A HOSTAGE TRADE POINT OF '85 MEMO, U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS
description: In a memorandum written at the beginning of the United States arms sales to Iran, the Director of Central Intelligence explicitly described the program as a trade of arms for hostages, according to a high ranking Government official who has seen the document.

title: Enhancing Simple Food
description: THE possibilities for garnishing salads, sandwiches and all sorts of cold dishes are limitless, especially if you have a few tricks up your sleeve. When I make a buffet lunch for friends or family, for example, I like to decorate plates with lettuce, hard-boiled eggs and tomatoes.

title: 10 Long Seasons
description: Whose regular-season schedule turned out to be the toughest in all of college football? Here are the 10 schools that hoed the hardest row, ranked according to the records of their Division I-A opponents against I-A teams other than the ranked school.

title: WARNER PACT HELPS RESCUE CANNON
description: The Cannon Group said today that it had avoided possible bankruptcy through a complex $75 million agreement with Warner Communications Inc. Warner will receive a number of considerations in return, including an option to buy into a theater chain at favorable terms.

title: Unisys Navy Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -

title: Offices Rise Near Jersey Stadium
description: IN 1972, when the sprawling 31-square-mile Hackensack Meadowlands Development Area was created, one plan called for a mini-city along Berry's Creek near the Meadowlands sports complex.

title: Nynex Mobile Phone
description: Nynex Mobile Communications has assigned its cellular telephone/paging system to Lohmeyer Simpson Communications in Morristown, N.J. The agency said the billings would be $1.5 million. The agency for the last two years has been doing collateral and sales support material for Nynex cellular markets.

title: Jets Notebook; Chiefs Have Own Problem
description: Surely, things are not bleak only for the Jets. They are, after all, in the playoffs and will be facing either a quarterback with such a severely injured thumb he can't practice or his backup.

title: NEC Home Electronics Won by DDB Needham
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago, has won the NEC Home Electronics (U.S.A.) account with some $5 million in billings.

title: 10-Disk Sun Country Retrospective
description: A PRICELESS bit of recording-studio chatter has been preserved in ''The Sun Country Box,'' a new 10-record boxed set from West Germany's Bear Family label. The country and rockabilly singer Warren Smith has just finished a performance and is asking to try again. ''Let's do it once more so I can put out on it,'' he says. ''I was just gettin' the feel that time.''

title: REDUCING DISCORD OVER FOREIGN POLICY
description: In time, the investigation into the Iranian arms controversy will end. There may be prosecutions, new laws, a reorganization of the National Security Council. But one thing that is vitally necessary may not happen at all - creation of a new compact between the executive and legislative branches that will permit the United States to discharge more effectively its responsibilities as a great power.

title: Boeing Agency
description: Cole & Weber of Seattle, part of the Ogilvy Group, is now the Boeing Company's only agency, which means that the Seattle manufacturer has added two more operating companies to the four already being served by the agency. They are Boeing Vertol, formerly served by VanSant Dugdale Advertising, Baltimore, and Boeing Computer Services, a former account of Stacking, Sanderson & White, McLean, Va.

title: Kidder Picks Executive Who Likes to Fight
description: Michael D. Madden, who will head the day-to-day operations of Kidder, Peabody & Company's expanded investment banking division, is a fighter - in the business sense, of course, but also in the boxing ring.

title: CLEMENCY BID BY JEAN HARRIS DENIED AS PREMATURE
description: The Cuomo administration announced tonight that it had turned down a request for clemency by Jean S. Harris.

title: NEW REPUBLIC BOOKS PLANS VENTURE WITH BASIC BOOKS
description: New Republic Books, a subsidiary of The New Republic magazine, will join Basic Books in a joint publishing venture, effective Jan. 1. The agreement, announced yesterday by Basic Books, Harper & Row's subsidiary for scholarly titles, is expected to result in up to 12 New Republic titles a year.

title: WINE TALK
description: EVERY year in late fall, a group of owners of some of the better-known Bordeaux chateaus pack up their bottles and a few shirts and hit the road to plug their products. They call themselves the Union des Grands Crus de Bordeaux because they represent all the classified chateaus, as they are known, in the Bordeaux region. There are several thousand chateaus, but only 61 hold the classified status.

title: Are the Baileys All Chumps?
description: There's a touch of Bedford Falls along upper Broadway: garlands of red, green and gold Christmas lights hang above the streets, providing the momentary illusion of small-town life chronicled in the classic Christmas movie ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

title: SALARY RESTRICTIONS LIMITING KNICKS
description: Years of fiscal irresponsibility have finally caught up to the Knicks. At a time when they most need to make a trade, the team's general manager, Scotty Stirling, is discovering two things: the first is that every player of any value around the league is being paid more than other teams believe he is worth, and secondly, that the salary cap restrictions have handcuffed him from making the few trades teams are willing to discuss.

title: WOOLRIDG RETURNS, SCORES 23
description: With a dire need for more scoring from the small-forward position, the Nets invested three draft choices and $1.5 million over two years to bring Orlando Woolridge to New Jersey from the Chicago Bulls.

title: Chocolate Shapes Up
description: 1. A Tree for Eating

title: SAFETY AGENCY URGES A RECALL OF AUDI 5000'S, CITING DEFECT
description: A Government safety agency today urged Volkswagen of America to recall about 250,000 Audi automobiles to correct a sudden-acceleration problem.

title: Youngest Head Coach
description: At the age of 30, Eugene (Buddy) Teevens yesterday became the youngest head coach in Dartmouth's 105-year football history and the 19th head coach since 1881. Teevens replaces Joe Yukica, who compiled a 36-47-4 record in nine years before being let go at the end of this season, in which the Ivy League team posted a 3-6-1 record.

title: NEW COALITION CONDEMNS HOWARD BEACH ASSAULTS
description: More than 40 religious and civil-rights groups, condemning the attack by white youths against three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, last weekend, formed a new coalition yesterday.

title: FROM OUTHIER, DISHES WITH HINT OF ORIENT
description: REMOVE the white chef's jacket and Louis Outhier could pass for a stockbroker. Dressed in a pencil-striped shirt with white collar and dark blue tie, the slightly nervous but engaging three-star French chef looks every inch the businessman.

title: CALIFANO CALLED LIKELY CHOICE TO HEAD PANEL ON CORRUPTION
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is the likely candidate to head a new commission being set up by Governor Cuomo to investigate unethical conduct by public officials, according to people familiar with the Governor's thinking.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal to abolish the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission omitted part of a comment from Mayor Koch about a State Commission of Investigation finding that major policy decisions on taxis were made at City Hall. Mr Koch said, ''There is no question that I seek to get the Taxi Commission to agree with me on taxi policy.''

title: Profit Taking Is Cited In Slump of Oil Prices
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped yesterday, as traders decided to take profits ahead of the holiday weekend. Trading was moderate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A theater listing in The Guide on Sunday misidentified the star of ''Me and My Girl.'' He is Robert Lindsay.

title: National Car Rental Deal Set
description: Household International Inc., the diversified financial services and manufacturing concern, said it had agreed to sell its National Car Rental System subsidiary to an investor group led by Paine Webber Capital Inc. for $459 million in cash.

title: ARMY ENGINEERS FEAR FOR CHICAGO SHORE DRIVE
description: The waters of Lake Michigan are rising at such a rate that they soon may engulf as much as 35 feet of shoreline a year in some areas and erode part of Lake Shore Drive, officials of the Army Corps of Engineers say.

title: Giants Show Mixed Feelings
description: The Giants will play their first playoff game here Jan. 3 against the San Francisco 49ers or the Los Angeles Rams and officially they do not care which. Unofficially, they do have preferences, generally depending on whether they play on offense or defense.

title: The Harvard Club Takes Old for New
description: To build for the 21st century, the Harvard Club has borrowed its architectural plans from the 19th.

title: A Time for Reflection
description: One of the reasons for dividing time into years is that it gives us a week or so for reflection on the past and the future. The American people and their leaders here have much to consider at the end of 1986.

title: Honeywell in India Deal
description: Honeywell Inc. said today that it had signed an agreement to form a joint venture company with the Tata Group of India to manufacture and sell Honeywell products.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: HARNESS RACING YONKERS, 8 P.M.

title: AT HOME WITH SENATOR LEAHY
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy sat in a rocking chair in the living room of his secluded 1850 farmhouse, watched the sunset over Camel's Hump mountain and pointed out deer and bear tracks and his own cross-country ski tracks in the newly fallen snow.

title: Year Ends With Bang For Wells
description: WELLS, RICH, GREENE is ending up the year on a sweet note - Cadbury Schweppes.

title: UAL, NOT KLM, TO BUY HILTON INTERNATIONAL
description: The Transworld Corporation said late yesterday that its agreement to sell its Hilton International subsidiary to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had fallen through, but that UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, would buy the hotel chain. The price is about $980 million. Transworld said it had been informed that KLM's supervisory board voted not to approve the agreement. That agreement, according to sources, was for $975 million in cash. KLM's offices were closed last evening, and it was not immediately clear why the board had voted against the purchase. $632.5 Million in Cash Transworld's agreement with UAL consists of $632.5 million in cash, 2.56 million common shares of UAL and $200 million of UAL debentures.

title: Praise for the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK FRIENDS DENY SUSPECTS IN ATTACK ARE RACIST
description: For several months this year, one of the suspects in the Howard Beach racial attack had dated a black girl, who said yesterday that ''he treated me better than all my other boyfriends, even my black boyfriends.''

title: RECITAL: EILEEN DAVIS SINGS
description: THE mezzo-soprano Eileen Davis announced from the stage of the Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night that she was indisposed but had decided to sing anyway.

title: 'Witching' Trade Inquiry
description: A flurry of controversy has sprung up surrounding activities during last Friday's ''triple witching hour.''

title: MARINERS GET STAPLETON
description: The Seattle Mariners signed Dave Stapleton, a free agent infielder who had spent his entire major league career with the Boston Red Sox.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE rediscovery of cabbage may be partly attributed to health-care professionals' announcements that cabbage and all members of that family - broccoli, brussels sprouts and so on - are excellent sources of vitamin C. I prefer to think this newfound passion springs from cabbage's inherent good flavor.

title: HOUSING PLAN WOULD FOX UP 5,200 UNITS
description: The Koch administration yesterday announced a plan to renovate nearly 5,200 apartments in abandoned city-owned buildings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

title: Liebert Acquisition
description: The Emerson Electric Company said it had tentatively agreed to acquire the Liebert Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at about $430 million.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WE will have a cold antipasto and chicken parmigiana for dinner tonight. I could have told you this a week ago. I could have told you this in March. It is an Italian tradition to feast on Christmas Eve, to crowd the table with calamari and scungilli, bacalla and pieces of fried eel.

title: Lawyer Says Levins Will Turn Over Diary
description: The diary of Jennifer Levin, who was killed in Central Park in August, will be turned over to court officials next week for a ruling on whether the book may be used by the defense attorney for the man accused of killing her, the lawyer for the Levin family said yesterday.

title: Critics Fret as Africans Emerge From Tarzan Era in TV Series
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CHRISTMAS EVE With wide-eyed caffeinated stares we struggle to assemble the radio-controlled turbo race car batteries not included while surrounded by overstuffed stockings and a barely decorated tree until we take a break to sneak a look at softly sleeping children and then pretending to find some falling snow we hug recharged and assembled again. - ROGER GRANET

title: BLUEGRASS TOWN COPES WITH ITS 'DIFFERENT' PEOPLE
description: Tony Pinkston was crushed to death the other morning at his last known address, a trash bin where he had spent the night. He died when the bin was picked up by a truck for dumping and no one realized he was in it.

title: U.S. Worries Intensifying
description: THIS has not been the jolliest of holiday seasons. Indeed, as the year draws to an end, the worries about the economy are intensifying.

title: A GENERATION RECLAIMS HANUKKAH
description: THE way they tell it in my family, at first there was no Hanukkah. My immigrant grandparents, once pious, felt overwhelmed, it seemed, by six children clamoring for melting-pot America. In December, presents were exchanged. It wasn't Christmas, but it wasn't Hanukkah either. The calendar obliged: it juxtaposed, or even overlapped, the holidays.

title: REBUTTAL TESTIMONY IS ENDED AT MIAMI POLICE TRIAL
description: The presentation of evidence at the trial of seven former Miami police officers, accused of possession of cocaine, racketeering and involvement in a drug case in which three suspects drowned, ended tonight with the rebuttal testimony.

title: Has the Time Come to Throw In the Credit Cards?
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: FONDA AND BRIDGES IN 'THE MORNING AFTER'
description: Some movies ease their audiences over the credibility gap by being so apparently reasonable. Since everything else makes sense, we accept the film's incredible premise and move on. Other films begin so mysteriously that the audience can't tell right away what's possible or impossible. ''The Morning After,'' Sidney Lumet's entertaining new romantic thriller, opens by challenging the audience. It says, in effect, believe this or not:

title: Editors' Note
description: A dispatch last Friday from Annapolis, Md., reported that Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, had been acquitted of manslaughter in the death of Gian-Carlo Coppola but had been convicted on one count of negligently operating a boat.

title: Lined Up at Night, at Christmas
description: The night is cold, but who can drag himself back to life-size reality from the line in front of Lord & Taylor's Christmas windows? There, animated dolls in period costumes that reflect a century and more of New York's past rehearse over and over the seasonal repertoire. Father holds a ladder, having affixed the star atop the tree. Mother awaits her guests in her finest ball gown. Norah, the maid, touches up with a vacuum cleaner while the two youngest play their own game on the wrought-iron balustrade. Love fills each storied room; peace suffuses the imaginary city surrounding them.

title: It's Better Than Running on Empty
description: If Rube Goldberg had invented an energy policy, it might have looked like fuel economy standards for automobiles. These are so clumsy that most economists and other believers in free-market incentives cheered this week when the Reagan Administration proposed to abolish them after 11 years.

title: CCORD IN RAMADA INNS CASE
description: The Justice Department has obtained a consent decree requiring five Ramada Inns in Virginia and Alabama to insure that blacks are accorded the same bar service as whites.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Christmas Day Parking - Sunday rules. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Financial markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island and Metro-North railroads on Sunday and holiday schedules; some N.J.

title: Reports Describe Casey As in Very Poor Shape
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, may be in more critical medical condition than his doctors have publicly acknowledged, according to news reports today.

title: 50-50 Chance for Boy To Keep Left Foot
description: A 13-month-old boy was given a 50-50 chance yesterday of keeping his left foot, which was grafted to his right leg after his mother carried him when she leaped in front of an A train.

title: RICHARD JOHNSTON IS DEAD AT AGE 76
description: Richard J. H. Johnston, a New York Times correspondent whose 41-year career included assignment to World War II battlefields and extensive service in the Far East, died yesterday at Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke about two weeks ago.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Includes the reversal of about $165,000 of investment tax credits recorded in the first 9 months of 1986. c-Includes a gain of $1,765,340 on the sale of land and building by the company's English subsidiary. The company said the latest year results reflect a change in accounting of pensions, which reduced 1986 pension costs by about $720,000 and increased net income by about $365,000. It was also said that the tax reform act reduced the latest year earnings by about $220,000 due to the repeal of investment tax credits.

title: Dalai Lama Details Support For Student Protest in China
description: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual and temporal leader and a staunch foe of the Chinese regime, proclaimed his support today for the student rallies in China demanding greater freedom.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULITFOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,433,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,804,000 for the quarter and a loss of $373,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the planned discontinuance of certain operations.

title: 2d Union Agrees On L.I.R.R. Pact
description: A second major union agreed yesterday to a new contract with the Long Island Rail Road, thus averting a possible mid-January strike, the railroad announced.

title: Wheeling To Close Rail Mill
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said today that it would close its steel rail mill and that the action would be responsible for most of a $223 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Brothers Gain In Eastern Tennis
description: Sven and Gunnar Salumaa of Huntington, L.I., registered upsets today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Eastern States Hardcourt Tennis Championships at the Blue Point Racquet Club.

title: To Public Servants, Unjustly Attacked
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN ANNOUNCING LOANS FOR DEVELOPING NATIONS
description: Japan's Finance Ministry announced today that it would provide two loans to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank totaling $6.2 billion, and said the loans would be offered with no strings attached.

title: Murdoch Deal With Hearst
description: The assets of the syndicate division of Rupert Murdoch's News America Holdings Inc. are being sold to the Hearst Corporation's North America Syndicate Inc. subsidiary, the two companies said yesterday. No price was announced.

title: HOME REPAIR
