description: MOST people would like noise inside the home held to a reasonable level, but opinions differ as to what that means. What is simply loud music to one listener may be an intolerable racket to someone in an adjoining room or apartment.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday in quiet trading, as securities firms and institutional investors were either closed for the holiday or lightly staffed.

title: Dr. Lisa Mahoney Weds David Woods
description: Dr. Lisa Reeves Mahoney, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse W. Mahoney of Old Field, L.I., was married yesterday to David Woods, a son of Mrs. John Woods of Dunkirk, N.Y., and the late Mr. Woods. The Rev. Dr. James Henry, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Moorten Botanical Gardens in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Arms and the Hostages: 2 Years of Secret Deals
description: These are some of the events figuring in the controversy over the secret sale of American arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to help the Nicaraguan rebels. The shaded areas indicate events that occurred behind the scenes. 1984 March 16: William Buckley, a political officer at the United States Embassy in Beirut, later identified as the C.I.A. station chief, is kidnapped by pro-Iranian Moslem militants.

title: RAINS SOAK FIELDS IN SOUTH, BUT DROUGHT EFFECTS PERSIST
description: Heavy rains in the late fall have helped ease the effects of the South's worst drought in a century. But from Alabama to South Carolina, moisture levels in farm fields and pastures remain well below normal, with the start of spring planting only three months off.

title: NICARAGUANS EXPECT WAR TO WORSEN
description: Unaccustomed to living in fear of the future, Nicaraguans prepared for Christmas this year amid a tense calm that many believe cannot last.

title: Ecuador Bid To Ease Debt
description: Ecuador, hard hit by this year's slump in world oil prices, plans to seek easier terms on repaying its debt to private foreign banks during a meeting next month in New York.

title: New G.E. Planner Sees Acquisitions
description: Nigel D.T. Andrews has a hard act to follow.

title: Exploding Star Is Discovered By Lawrence Berkeley Team
description: Scientists at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory announced Tuesday the discovery of a giant exploding star 250 million light-years from Earth and about 10,000 times too dim to be seen by the unaided eye.

title: KEY RATES
description: n.a. - Not available due to Christmas Day holiday. * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer (Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues)

title: No Meeting With Walesa
description: Lane Kirkland, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. chief who is a leading American supporter of the trade union movement in Poland, learned yesterday that his plans to meet with the Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, in Poland had been dashed.

title: DRINKING LAWS TIED TO FLEEING AFTER WRECKS
description: Tougher drunken-driving laws cause more drunken drivers to flee the scenes of traffic accidents, according to a Purdue University study.

title: BRIDGE
description: The focal point of organized bridge in America is in Memphis, where the American Contract Bridge League conducts its business.

title: Don't Take Those Reindeer for Granted
description: To the Editor:

title: MERRILL TO CLOSE GRAND CENTRAL CENTER
description: The Merrill Lynch Investment Information Center, in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal, is closing after providing market quotations and advice to commuters for more than 20 years.

title: HERS
description: ON the afternoon of May 30, 1667, an inquisitive crowd of onlookers gathered to witness a remarkable sight: Margaret Cavendish, the ''mad'' Duchess of Newcastle, was coming to visit the Royal Society. She had been invited - at her own request - to view firsthand some of the astonishing experiments of the society's members. The gentlemen liquified a leg of mutton, mixed cold ingredients to produce hot and performed other wonders, but the real attraction was the Duchess.

title: Beacon of Hope
description: In a time of so much violence and injustice, the world has one piece of transformingly good news. The release of Andrei Sakharov from his enforced exile in Gorky is a beacon of hope for his people and the rest of us.

title: Walton, Reversing Field, Benches O'Brien for Ryan
description: The Jets made a dramatic switch in quarterbacks today, benching Ken O'Brien for Pat Ryan in their wild-card playoff game Sunday against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Exchanges Closed Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges, banks, Government offices and most businesses are closed today in observance of Christmas.

title: MUSIC: VOCAL ARTS ENSEMBLE IN CHRISTMAS WORKS
description: Gathering around the family piano to sing Christmas songs is the fondest part of many people's holiday memories. Something a little more sophisticated, but homespun enough, was fondly offered by the New York Vocal Arts Ensemble Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: SAKHAROV IN NEW ERA
description: Andrei D. Sakharov's homecoming this week appears to mark a potential turning point in the Soviet Government's tolerance of dissent, in the view of Western diplomats and Russians. At the same time, it has revealed a congruence of views between Dr. Sakharov and Mikhail S. Gorbachev on some issues that may help explain why the physicist's exile in Gorky was ended after seven years.

title: A VICTIM REFUSES SUBPOENA TO TELL OF QUEENS ATTACK
description: One victim in the racial attack last week in Howard Beach, Queens, has refused a subpoena from the Queens District Attorney, according to law-enforcement officials, who said the case could fall apart without him.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $15,528,000 and $18,798,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the loss from discontinued operations in fiscal 1986 includes a pre-tax charge of $21.1 million to cover costs of discontinued businesses.

title: City U. Law School Gets Its First Grades
description: Fewer than half of the first graduates of the City University of New York Law School who took the bar exam in July passed it. The dean of the three-year-old school said, however, it was a good showing for a new program.

title: JOHN W. MACY JR., 69, EX-LEADER OF CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION, DIES
description: John W. Macy Jr., a former chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission and a career public servant for more than 30 years, died of a heart ailment Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 69 years old.

title: Bryant May Play
description: Kelvin Bryant, the running back for the Redskins, was released from Arlington Hospital in Washington and was listed as probable for Sunday's wild-card playoff game against the Rams. Bryant's release came two days after he had been admitted for tests when blood was discovered in his urine.

title: 3 CONVICTS FROM DELAWARE ARE CAUGHT IN ARIZONA
description: Two convicted murderers and a rapist who escaped 23 days ago from a prison in Delaware were captured Tuesday night in a creek bed after a daylong search of the desert near here, officials said.

title: RARE SET OF EVENTS LED TO CHICAGO BLACKOUT
description: A rare combination of foggy weather, dirt and the residue of air pollution caused the power failure that left 200,000 residents without electricity for up to 12 hours Tuesday, officials explained today.

title: COMEBACK OF POETRY'S ROMANTICS
description: In the literary marketplace, the stock of the Romantic poets is steadily on the rise.

title: Ideal Basic Project
description: Ideal Basic Industries said it had completed the financial restructuring approved by shareholders earlier this month. Ideal Basic also said a United States district court had approved an agreement terminating shareholder litigation against the company. The restructuring resulted in the issuance of 125.8 million common shares and $83.5 million in new notes to bank and insurance company lenders in exchange for unsecured debt of about $320 million.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $1.73 billion, to $233.81 billion, for the week ended yesterday, the Investment Company Institute said.

title: Creche Ruined in Fire Is Replaced by Donor
description: A town Nativity scene destroyed by a fire Tuesday was replaced yesterday by a family touched by pleas for donations for a new creche.

title: NASDAQ SHORT INTEREST DOWN BY 2.8%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks was down 6.5 million shares, or 2.8 percent, in the month ended Dec. 15, to 206.4 million shares.

title: JACKSON IS BACK IN A'S UNIFORM
description: Reggie Jackson came home to the Oakland A's today. Jackson, a free agent, signed a one-year contract and rejoined the franchise he began his celebrated career with 19 years ago.

title: Vince's Story, With an Assist by Mickey
description: When the holiday season rolls around and talk of miracles is in the air, Mickey Lolich sometimes remembers a boy named Vince, and wonders what happened to him.

title: Aquino Asks Nation to Help In Effort to End Rebellions
description: President Corazon C. Aquino, in a Christmas Eve address to a nation at peace for the first time in nearly 18 years, called for support in her efforts to settle two rebellions left over from the Marcos era.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
On Competition; Change the Milk Law, Don't Ignore It
description: To the Editor:

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $147,000 for the quarter and $235,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from Saturday, Dec. 20th, editions.

title: GENERAL CINEMA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $34,735,000 and $35,782,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $561,000 and $1,758,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PARIS BUSINESS FORMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,000 on the sale of corporate assets for the quarter and for the year includes a gain of $676,000 from the sale of buildings and insurance settlement proceeds.

title: Greyhound's Purchaser Expects a Bus Revival
description: For Frederick G. Currey, the $350 million purchase of the Greyhound Corporation's domestic bus operations is just the next phase in his long involvement with the transportation industry.

title: Drivers Also Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Webb Out 3 Months
description: Spud Webb will be lost to the Atlanta Hawks for at least three more months because of a knee injury he suffered Dec. 5. Dr. Jack Hughston, who examined Webb's right knee, told the team's president, Stan Kasten, that he had found damage at the connection of the thighbone and knee cartilage. He said Webb would be on crutches for six weeks, and would then undergo six weeks of rehabilitation before he could return.

title: Doctor Released on Bail
description: Dr. Russell F. Manfredi, sentenced last week to 20 years in prison for the bludgeoning death of his wife, was released today from Somers State Prison on bail after filing an appeal of his conviction. Dr. Manfredi, 33 years old, was convicted on Nov. 3 of first-degree manslaughter in the death of Catherine Billings Manfredi, who was beaten with a baseball bat and dumped out a second-floor window of the couple's West Hartford home on March 8, 1985.

title: Zaire Without Mobutu Might Be Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: GTE CHIEF REJECTS SALES TO BELZBERG
description: An obviously annoyed chairman of the GTE Corporation said yesterday that his company would not sell two Canadian telephone subsidiaries to Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian investor who suggested such a move.

title: Loss Narrows At Tandon
description: The Tandon Corporation today reported a loss of $45.2 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $85.1 million for the quarter last year.

title: U.S. INQUIRY IS REPORTED TO TRACE $20 MILLION IN CONTRA DONATIONS
description: The Administration has traced at least $20 million in contributions intended for the Nicaraguan rebels, $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei and roughly $10 million from private donors, according to an Administration official.

title: Data Seized at Northrop Unit
description: Federal agents seized time cards, employee logs, computer disks and other items in a search of the Northrop Corporation's Warner Robins unit in Georgia as evidence in a criminal investigation of charges that the company may have overbilled the Government on military contracts, Federal officials said today.

title: New York State Can Do Better on Prenatal Care
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN AN ALBUM TURNS FROM LARVA TO BUTTERFY
description: Albums of popular music lead two lives, especially for critics. Their first life comes when the album is listened to for the first few times. This is the period when the critic is working - a task that doesn't preclude pleasure, as some critic-critics presume, but working nonetheless - to form an initial opinion.

title: Quarterback Status For Chiefs Clouded
description: With his team beating the Chargers at halftime, but not looking very good doing it, Coach John Mackovic of the Kansas City Chiefs replaced his quarterback, Todd Blackledge.

title: DEATH OF BLACK POLITICAL DETAINEE IS REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A South African civil rights group said today that a black political detainee, held under an emergency decree, had died in a hospital soon after being transferred there from prison.

title: PEDDLER PATROL ON 5TH AVE. CRACKS DOWN
description: As frantic last-minute shoppers struggled from store to store along Fifth Avenue at noontime yesterday, the only sidewalk peddler in sight from 42d Street to 59th Street was Junior Grandison, selling children's books and Webster's Dictionaries on the southwest corner of 45th Street.

title: JAZZ: JOHN BUNCH AT ZINNO
description: It does not take long to realize that the pianist John Bunch, who is playing through Saturday at Zinno, 128 West 13th Street, with the bassist Michael Moore, is firmly rooted in the days of the big bands.

title: INSIDE
description: The Wary Curators Until it can find out more about what it is getting, the Municipal Art Commission will no longer consider gifts of art to New York City. Page 33.

title: Symphony Plans to Buy Land Near Tanglewood
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra plans to buy about 100 acres of land near Tanglewood, its summer home, possibly to build a new concert hall, the president-elect of the orchestra's board said today.

title: Prison Santa Hurt in Accident
description: A deputy sheriff's pistol accidentally fired and wounded a volunteer Santa Claus today at the state penitentiary, the authorities said.

title: Scoring Touch Returns for New Ranger
description: On the November morning in Vancouver that Phil Esposito dismissed his coach, Ted Sator, the general manager talked once again about his desire to make a big trade. That night Tony McKegney scored four times and the Rangers rallied and won. One afternoon, a few weeks later, Esposito said that he still had a ''dream of making the big one.'' That night McKegney scored twice and the Rangers beat Los Angeles by a goal. And two nights ago, after the Devils had scored three times to draw even, McKegney went out, scored twice, and the Rangers won.

title: Bethea Facing Prison
description: Larry Bethea, a former lineman with the Dallas Cowboys, faces up to 20 years in prison after pleading guilty to stealing his mother's life savings of $64,000.

title: Beinecke Holdings On Nantucket Sold
description: Walter Beinecke Jr., credited with transforming Nantucket's aged commercial district and waterfront into a picturesque tourist center, has sold his sprawling commercial holdings on the island to a real estate firm for more than $50 million.

title: THE DIRECTOR OF CORCORAN TO QUIT POST
description: Michael Botwinick said today that he would resign next summer as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, a position for which he gave up the directorship of the Brooklyn Museum four years ago.

title: HEAD OF HOSPITAL AGENCY NAMED
description: A lawyer and longtime member of the board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Paul J. Henry, was appointed board chairman yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Faster Track for the Boarder Babies
description: After months of inattention, Mayor Koch of New York now admits that the city is not acting fast enough to place infants in foster homes. He suggests the city give prospective foster parents conditional approval within two weeks and allow them to take the children pending a thorough investigation. It's a sensible way to ease a genuine emergency.

title: TRANSPORT PLAN DELAYED AS CITY STUDIES DISABLED
description: Eight months after the Koch administration was required to give Governor Cuomo a plan for a ground transportation system to serve disabled residents, the city's consultant has not finished the plan, city officials say.

title: UAL HOTEL ACQUISITION QUESTIONED BY ANALYSTS
description: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman of UAL Inc., has long wanted to offer the business traveler a way to fly, rent a car and stay in a hotel all under the canopy of the parent company, but he apparently still has to persuade Wall Street.

title: 2 NEW STUDIES LINK HIGH CHOLESTEROL TO RISK OF COLON CANCER
description: High cholesterol levels appear to be associated with an increased risk for colon cancer, offering another reason for people to reduce the amount of fat in their diets, researchers said today.

title: Gifts From the Homeless
description: A homeless father of two children whom I met the other day in San Antonio told me that he sells blood twice a week to buy the food to feed his sons. They sleep with him at night along a railroad track.

title: VWR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of investments of $5 million for the quarter and $6.9 million for the 9 months.

title: BABAR SPENDS CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA
description: Laurent de Brunhoff created this story and drawing for The Home Section's holiday issue. Mr. de Brunhoff, son of Jean de Brunhoff, creator of the celebrated elephant, has carried on the tradition. His book ''Babar's Little Girl'' will be published in April by Random House.

title: A Microscopic Look at the Home and Other Exotic, Hidden Worlds
description: EVER wonder what your house is up to when you're not looking? According to David Bodanis, a British science writer, that seemingly sedate structure of brick, wood or stucco shimmers, breathes, melts, hisses and otherwise is often up to no good. His book ''The Secret House: 24 Hours in the Strange and Unexpected World in Which We Spend Our Nights and Days'' (Simon & Schuster, $18.95) zooms in relentlessly on the mundane matters of modern life, proving once again that the difference between the ordinary and the exotic is only your point of view.

title: LOYALTY TO REAGAN SEEN AS A PROBLEM FOR BUSH
description: The disclosures of arms shipments to Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels have created a fundamental problem for Vice President Bush in his effort to succeed President Reagan, aides and other supporters said today.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Heartburn
description: Dave Currey, football coach at the University of Cincinnati, which lost to both Miami and Penn State this year: ''They're both great teams. One you'd date, and the other you'd marry.''

title: REPUBLIC IN BROOKLYN BANK DEAL
description: The Republic New York Corporation, parent of the Republic National Bank, said yesterday that it would buy the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

title: WINDSOR'S PARIS HOME TO BECOME MUSEUM
description: MOHAMMED al-Fayed, an Egyptian businessman who owns the Ritz Hotel in Paris and Harrods department store in London, has taken a 50-year lease on the former home of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Le Bois, in the Bois de Boulogne.

title: Passer Rallies Boston College
description: Shawn Halloran capped a season of redemption Tuesday night in his final game for Boston College. His 5-yard touchdown pass to Kelvin Martin gave the Eagles a 27-24 victory over favored Georgia in the Hall of Fame Bowl.

title: PENTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $2,701 and 11,611 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: TOFUTTI BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net income

title: Hong Kong Stock Index
description: The Hang Seng stock index gained 21.98 points today to end a shortened pre-Christmas session at a new high of 2,523.92 but trading was thin, brokers said.

title: Marquette Frye Dead; 'Man Who Began Riot'
description: Marquette Frye, whose scuffle with the police after a routine traffic incident on a muggy summer night in 1965 ignited the Watts riot, has died of pneumonia, a coroner's spokesman said today.

title: FED PLANS APRIL RULING ON WIDER BANK POWERS
description: The Federal Reserve Board, failing to resolve a battle between the securities and banking industries, said today that it will not decide until April whether to give banks an expanded role in underwriting securities.

title: SYSTEMATICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WARDS SIGNS WITH YANKS AS FREE AGENT
description: The Yankees fulfilled one of their pressing needs yesterday when they announced the signing of a right-handed power hitter, Gary Ward, a free-agent outfielder.

title: MRS. SULZBERGER GIVES ORIGIN OF THE NEEDIEST CASES APPEAL
description: A gift of $10,000 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was given by Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger in memory of her father, Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times from 1896 to 1935. With the gift, Mrs. Sulzberger included a note telling how Mr. Ochs was inspired to start the Neediest Cases appeal.

title: RULES OF THE FIREPLACE: SAFE WAYS TO LIGHT UP
description: MAKING a safe fire is easy once you know the rules. Firewood is generally broken down into two categories: hardwoods and softwoods. Hardwoods like maple, oak and elm - trees that lose their leaves in the fall - give off the most heat and burn longer than softwoods, like spruce and pine, which are easier to ignite.

title: Read-at-Glance Thermometers
description: A THERMOMETER can be your best friend. If you feel sick, reading it can tell you how sick you are. If you get worse, it can warn you.

title: Purolator to Sell Canadian Division
description: The Purolator Courier Corporation, the ailing air freight concern that has been restructuring since a Canadian concern bought a large block of its stock, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian unit to the Onex Capital Corporation for $170 million in United States currency. The unit, Purolator Courier Ltd., operates Canada's largest small package express delivery service.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS STRIKE AT LEBANON TARGETS NORTH OF BUFFER ZONE
description: Israeli troops supported by attack helicopters today struck guerrilla installations two miles north of an Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, the army announced.

title: Fire at Home for Aged Kills 6 And Injures 4 in Tennessee
description: Fire swept through a home for the elderly before dawn today, killing six people and injuring four.

title: The Coach Of the Year
description: Hugh McCabe, the linebacker coach at Seneca Valley High School in Gaithersburg, Md., died of lung cancer last week at age 47. McCabe, a single parent of two teen-age boys, had known the worst since last February, when doctors who performed exploratory surgery gave him six months.

title: NEW REVIVAL: OLD-TIME GUM
description: Gum chewers might remember Beemans gum, once promoted as a cure for indigestion and sea sickness. Or Clove gum, said to help drinkers disguise the rum on their breath. Or Black Jack, flavored with shredded licorice.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $106,000. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split in the form of a 33 percent share distribution issued to shareholders on Sept. 30, 1986.

title: Q&A
description: Q.My kitchen counter top is covered with plastic laminate. The plastic on the top meets the plastic laminate along the edge in a neat angle, but this edge has developed very small chips and one or two small cracks. I fear a cloth may catch on a nick and then tear a larger piece of the plastic laminate. Is there a sealant to prevent this? A.This corner should have been beveled slightly to prevent the chipping. Sharp corners or edges can still be smoothed or beveled with a file, but stroke downward only and use a mill file (made for use on metal), not a rasp or coarse file.

title: JEANTOT REFLECTS ON SEA'S PERILS
description: A few days after arriving here last week on a record-setting pace in the single-handed race around the world, Philippe Jeantot made a discovery that turned him ashen.

title: Himont Plans Initial Offering
description: Two of the world's largest chemical companies, Hercules Inc. and Montedison S.p.A., are offering shares of their joint venture, Himont Inc., to the public in an initial offering worth more than $330 million.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW GIVEN BY THE SAKHAROVS IN MOSCOW
description: Following is a transcript of remarks made by Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, to Western reporters today, as translated by The Associated Press:

title: Australia Group Weighs Offer by Holmes a Court
description: The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., the nation's largest newspaper group, said today that no immediate decision would be made on a takeover offer by Australia's richest man, Robert Holmes a Court.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the formation of a civil rights coalition in New York City misidentified the group and the head of the Research and Advocacy Center for Equality. The new group is the New York City

title: EMPLOYING AUDITS TO HELP DECREASE HOME-ENERGY BILLS
description: A COUPLE of times a year, often before the start of the heating and air-conditioning seasons, residential customers of utilities receive bill inserts urging them to schedule a home-energy audit. These notices are often ignored because many people are unaware of what an audit entails or why they might need one.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BEACHED WHALES HAD FLU INFECTION
description: Scientists seeking to explain why a pod of pilot whales beached themselves and died on Cape Cod this month have found that 14 of them were infected with an unidentified flu virus.

title: TV: 'WORLDS WITHOUT END,' ON 13
description: We know what we know, but why do we know it? In the final episode of ''The Day the Universe Changed,'' James Burke, the exuberant host of the series, argues a case for comfort: What we know, more or less, is what makes us feel good. The episode, ''Worlds Without End,'' can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1986
description: The Economy

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NEW LOOK

title: RIGHTS LEADERS SEE U.S. PATTERN IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: National civil rights leaders and other prominent blacks are citing the incident in the Howard Beach section of Queens as the latest in a growing list of incidents involving racial violence and intimidation not only against blacks, but also against members of other minorities.

title: National Car Sale
description: Household International Inc. said its board had approved the proposed sale, announced Tuesday, of its National Car Rental System Inc. unit for $459 million. The company said the sale was contingent on closing this year to take advantage of current tax laws. The unit is being sold to a group of investors led by Paine Webber Capital Inc. Household International said it would have a fourth quarter after-tax gain from the transaction.

title: Webster Recovering
description: Tom Webster, the Rangers' coach, was in good condition at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after undergoing surgery to relieve an inner-ear infection. He was expected to be released from the hospital today and might be able to coach again next Tuesday night.

title: ZAMBIA FREES CORRESPONDENT
description: An Associated Press correspondent, John Edlin, returned to Zimbabwe today after five days in what he called a ''medieval prison'' in Zambia.

title: MANOR CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,396,000 for debt redemption.

title: BABY RUTH CANDY BARS RECALLED BECAUSE OF BACTERIA IN SOME LOTS
description: Nabisco today announced a voluntary recall of all its Baby Ruth candy bars after tests showed salmonella bacteria in several batches.

title: Flirting With God
description: ''Religion is the sigh of the oppressed creature,'' wrote Karl Marx, ''the spirit of unspiritual conditions. It is the Opium des Volkes - the opiate of the people.''

title: PX'S BATTLE THE DISCOUNTERS
description: The cavernous department store off J.E.B. Stuart Road in the middle of Fort Bliss here has regulation-issue Christmas music and decorations. It has Lazer Tag and Snuggle Bears, Bruce Springsteen and Lionel Richie, Liz Claiborne and Gucci Pour Homme.

title: Hawkins Is Appointed
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, was defeated for re-election last month, but she is certain to be heard from again on a subject that has been one of her principal concerns: drug abuse.

title: Choosing From Earth's Infinite Palette
description: WHEN you pick the furnishings for a room you arm yourself with swatches of curtain fabric, books of wallpaper samples and snips of cushion material. You juxtapose and juggle them this way and that, walk to the window, cock your head on one side, click your tongue, discuss them with innocent bystanders. Does this one go, or that? Suppose we settle for the crimson curtains, does that mean switching from the forest green carpet?

title: Police Officer Found Dead From Gunshot
description: A Transit Authority police officer was found shot to death early yesterday behind a Bronx building, and investigators called the death an apparent suicide.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch yesterday from Palo Alto, Calif., on planning for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library misidentified the president of Stanford University. He is Donald Kennedy.

title: Books of The Times; The Naturalistic Novel
description: FRANK NORRIS: Novels and Essays. Edited by Donald Pizer. 1,232 pages. Library of America. $27.50. There is a fairly straight line in the American naturalistic novel from Frank Norris to Theodore Dreiser to John Steinbeck. Some of the themes they tackled through their characters first appeared in nonfiction form at the turn of the century, when the muckraking magazine journalists examined the excesses of various industries, from the stockyards to the oilfields. Looking at the popular books published today, it's hard to imagine that powerful works of fiction and fact that exposed unsafe conditions in the mines or the travails of migratory workers once led to legislative changes.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT BLUNTED LEADING EDGE OF IRAN THRUST
description: Iraq said today that Iran had mounted a major two-pronged offensive in the southern part of their war front, but that Iraqi forces had ''wiped out'' the leading edge of the Iranian force and blunted the attack.

title: Ohio Reactor Again in Use
description: The Davis-Besse nuclear plant, which had been shut down for more than 18 months, resumed operation on Monday, a Toledo Edison Company official said. The reactor, on the shore of Lake Erie about 25 miles east of Toledo, was running at 10 percent of capacity and should return to full operation around Jan. 5, the official said. It had been idle since June 9, 1985, when 14 pieces of equipment failed, causing a temporary loss of cooling water.

title: Another Victory for Simms and Morris
description: Phil Simms and Joe Morris, who have helped the Giants win their last nine regular-season games, won another kind of battle this week. They finished their Christmas shopping with a day to spare.

title: Fire Cuts Short Jet's Flight
description: An engine fire forced a Delta Air Lines jet to return to the airport just minutes after it took off for New York with 136 passengers aboard.

title: JOHN PAUL, AT THE MIDNIGHT MASS, EXTOLS 'EVENT OF BETHLEHEM NIGHT'
description: As Christmas began today, the bells of St. Peter's Basilica rang wildly at midnight, and Pope John Paul II celebrated an ancient liturgy for a congregation that extended electronically across 41 countries.

title: MEDICAL COLLEGE RECEIVES A GIFT OF APARTMENTS
description: The New York Medical College in Valhalla received a $5.5 million Christmas gift from the Starrett Housing Corporation today in the form of a campus apartment complex for 200 students.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $756,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: DESPAIR FOR MAGIC MOUNTAIN OF TIN AND SILVER
description: In Potosi's central plaza, an oasis of greenery more than 13,000 feet above sea level, people born to the lowlands can become quickly light-headed and deeply burned by the Andes sun.

title: AMERICAN IN MOSCOW: TRAP OF CIRCUMSTANCE
description: ''How do I feel?'' repeated the old man, as the trans-Atlantic telephone line crackled, ''Well, I certainly don't feel like 75. I feel like 17. I do really.''

title: DOMINICAN SURVIVOR TELLS ABOUT FATEFUL BOAT TRIP
description: Angela Guerrero sold her meager belongings in the Dominican Republic to raise $250 for passage on an open boat that was to carry her to a prosperous life in the United States, but all she found was tragedy when the boat swamped 200 feet from its destination, carrying at least 14 of her 48 fellow passengers to their deaths.

title: Obstacles to a Title Recalled by Torres
description: Jose Torres, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, is no stranger to boxing politics.

title: Ford Recalling 1982 Escort And Lynx Autos for Pollution
description: The Ford Motor Company has begun recalling 226,000 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx automobiles from the 1982 model year that exceed Federal and California air pollution standards, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.

title: SCREEN: 'BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIRS'
description: Neil Simon is hardly Norman Rockwell, but his ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' has a warmly nostalgic quality, something that has traveled very nicely to the screen. ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' the first and perhaps the most sweetly rueful play of Mr. Simon's autobiographical trilogy, has become a film of surprisingly gentle charms. Mr. Simon's humor is much in evidence, but it is not the film's strongest selling point. Even more effective are the sense of a place and a way of life long vanished and the care and affection with which they have been summoned up.

title: Prizes Wait at End of Slopes
description: Amateur ski racing has traditionally brought winners simple gold, silver and bronze pins or flashy trophies to display in the family room.

title: COURT SAYS LIDDY OWES TAXES
description: G. Gordon Liddy should pay income taxes on $45,630 he received as a Nixon campaign official, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: UNIOIL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $770,000 writedown of the value of oil and gas properties.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The National Basketball Association has fined Clemon Johnson of the Seattle SuperSonics $3,500 and Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets $3,000 for their roles in a fight last week during a game. Rodney McCray of the Rockets was fined $500 for leaving the bench area during the fight. . . . Mike Sheppard, formerly of Long Beach State, was named head football coach at the University of New Mexico. Larry Reisbig, an assistant under Sheppard, was promoted to head coach at Long Beach.

title: LORD GRADE STILL A WHIRLWIND AT 80
description: Lord Grade, the canny and flamboyant show-business entrepreneur who celebrates his 80th birthday today, has suggested ''What I Promise, I Keep'' as his epitaph.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, has asked its chairman and chief executive, L. Stanley Crane, to continue in those positions through December 1988.

title: 100 IN SELMA, ALA., GET NEW HOUSING
description: About 100 blacks who live outside this city in small, gray structures that have no running water and rent for $40 a month will move next month into Government-subsidized housing at a former Air Force base, according to the Mayor here.

title: GIRL SCOUTS: MORE THAN COOKIES, WIDE SMILES AND GREEN UNIFORMS
description: THIS spring, it will be 75 years since Juliette Gordon Low announced, ''I've got something for the girls of Savannah and all America and all the world, and we're going to start it tonight.'' Gathering up 18 girls, she started the Girl Scouts.

title: 750 Copters Grounded By Army a Precaution
description: The Army has grounded almost three-quarters of its AH-1 Cobra helicopter gunships for a safety inspection of their main rotor-blade fittings.

title: COMMERCIAL RENTS IN CHINATOWN SOAR AS HONG KONG EXODUS GROWS
description: A flood of immigrants from Hong Kong has pushed commercial rents in New York's Chinatown up to the levels of midtown, making the real estate in one untidy corner of Manhattan among the most expensive in the United States.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
From Top to Bottom, Pac-10 to Pac Coast
NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1986
description: International#2-11 The U.S. will offer to delay payment from 38 countries of interest on military loans, the Reagan Administration has decided. The action could cost $3.5 billion in uncollected revenue. Page 1 A French hostage was freed by his Shiiite Moslem kidnappers in Lebanon in a good-will Christmas gesture. Aurel Cornea, a soundman for a French television network, was kidnapped nearly 10 months ago. #1 The release of a French hostage in Beirut came several days after the arrest in a Paris suburb of six Arabs who sources say were Moslem fundamentalist opponents of the Syrian Government. #10 Iran mounted a major offensive against Iraq in the southern part of their war front, but Iraqi forces had ''wiped out'' the leading edge of the Iranian force and blunted the attack, Iraq reported. #8 $20 million intended for the contras, including $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei and $10 million from private donors, has been traced by the Reagan Administration, an Administration official said. #1 Andrei Sakharov praised efforts by Mikhail Gorbachev to change the Soviet system and to encourage public discussion. He said the new openness is important ''because openness has always been in short supply.'' #3 News Analysis: Moscow's release of Andrei D. Sakharov from his exile in Gorky appears to mark a potential turning point in the Government's tolerance of dissent, Russians and Western diplomats said. #3 The Pope can sound revolutionary in his advocacy for the poor, but he has also battled unceasingly against Marxist influences on Catholic theology and efforts to ''politicize'' the Gospel.

title: Growth in Korea G.N.P.
description: South Korea's gross national product has grown an estimated 12.2 percent this year, compared with 5.4 percent last year, the Bank of Korea said today. It said growth this year was led by exports, which rose to $31.1 billion through November, compared with $26.5 billion in the corresponding period last year.

title: CITY'S ART AGENCY PUTS GIFT O HOLD
description: Until it can find out more about what it is getting, the municipal Art Commission, which has the ultimate say in such matters, will no longer consider gifts of art to New York City.

title: FOR ONCE, A CALM TOY SEASON
description: Finally, Naomi Miller says, she approached her Christmas shopping with something resembling relief.

title: CALENDAR: EXPLORING PARK'S WINTER LORE
description: The Parks and Recreation Department offers walks and workshops throughout the winter with the Urban Park Rangers, who are also naturalists. Listed below are possibilities for celebrating the holidays outdoors; the events are free, except where noted.

title: Cirella's Foot Broken
description: Joe Cirella, the Devils' 23-year-old defenseman, felt some pain after he was hit by a puck on the side of his right foot early in the first period in Tuesday night's 8-5 loss to the Rangers. He ignored the pain and played the entire game, not missing a single shift.

title: Renewed Interest In 'Junk Bonds'
description: While the market for high-grade corporate bonds was inactive this week, underwriters proceeded with public offerings of low-quality ''junk bonds'' totaling $550 million and $275 million of convertible debt or preferred stock.

title: As It Should Be
description: President Reagan's Christmas message:

title: GOULD INVESTORS L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain on disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $2,349,011 and includes an extraordinary charge of $577,256, consisting of costs and expenses relating to the reorganization from a trust into a limited partnership. c-Includes a gain on disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $1,519,381. Gould Investors Trust was reorganized into Gould Investors L.P., a limited partnership, in May 1986; figures prior to that date represent the operations of Gould Investors Trust. The figures for fiscal 1986 include Gould's proportional majority interest in BRT Realty Trust on a consolidated basis for the first quarter, with Gould's minority share of BRT's income reflected in the revenue category for the second and part of the third quarter and with BRT's earnings not taken into account for the balance of the third quarter or for the fourth quarter; the fiscal 1985 figures include Gould's proportional majority interest in BRT on a consolidated basis.

title: HUME SAID IT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think that the word 'dissident' may be losing some of its resonance.

title: 2 Partners Oppose Genentech Buyout
description: Two limited partners have opposed Genentech Inc.'s proposed buyout of two of its research and development partnerships.

title: FRENCH ARRESTS OF ARABS SAID TO AID IN RELEASE
description: The release of a French hostage in Beirut today followed by several days the arrest of six Arabs in a Paris suburb. Sources here say the Arabs were Moslem fundamentalist opponents of the Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: 'Ever Hear of a Wood Ski?'
description: While shopping this Christmas season, I felt less like Santa Claus than another bearded character, Rip Van Winkle. Technology had passed me by.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $195,000. The 1985 results includes a gain of $571,000 on the sale of land.

title: 59 ALASKA INMATES SENT TO MINNESOTA
description: Alaska has flown 59 of its most dangerous convicts to Minnesota under an agreement in which that state will keep them for a year, when construction of Alaska's first maximum-security prison is expected to be completed, Alaska corrections officials said Tuesday.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL CHICAGO BULLS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, noon, (Television -MSG, noon) WASHINGTON BULLETS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) FOOTBALL SUN BOWL, at El Paso, Alabama vs. Washington, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) BLUE-GRAY ALL-STAR CLASSIC, at Montgomery, Ala., 5 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 5 P.M., FNN-SCORE, 5 P.M.)

title: FRANCE FITS SANTA WITH A BORDEAUX ATELIER
description: Oui, Vanessa, there is a Santa Claus. But he does not live, as she addressed her letter, on the ''Street of the Shooting Star, fifth floor, left apartment, Milky Way, The Sky.'' Santa lives right here in the Gironde, one of the richest wine regions of France.

title: O, Orangutan
description: Today, when most Americans are probably preparing for a Christmas meal of turkey or perhaps a roast goose, a group of vegetarians will be singing Christmas carols and making gifts of exotic fruits and nuts to the primates in the National Zoo.

title: TALKING DEALS
description: THIS may have been one of the largest years for corporate takeovers on record, but it was also the year of the broken deal. Time and again when a company seemed like a goner, it either bought off a corporate raider with the equivalent of greenmail or decided at the last minute that there was a better alternative to getting hitched.

title: Beijing to Get Stock Market
description: Beijing will open a stock market early next month and issue shares in large state-owned companies, The China Daily reported today. The market would be the second in China since the Communists came to power in 1949.

title: Stocks Advance In a Slow Session
description: Stock prices rose yesterday but trading slowed as investors seemed to care more about the Christmas holiday than the market.

title: PHYSICIST SEES MAJOR CHANGES FOR SOVIET
description: Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he had ''great respect'' for Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his efforts to change the Soviet system and to encourage public discussion.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a provision for income taxes of $710,000 for the quarter and $1,515,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes a credit for income taxes of $84,000. The company indicated that the 1986 results include approximately $2.7 million of pre-tax gain on the sale of fixed assets which resulted from plant, property and equipment disposals during the year, and if the fixed asset gain is excluded, 1986 results continue to indicate approximately $1.6 million of pre-tax operating income for 1986.

title: Wizard of Weird
description: Chuck Foster says he's just trying to give Everyman the chance for a little recognition. He must be trying hard, because the truth is that he has built an entire career on that notion, organizing strange sporting events with big-time trappings for ''the masses, the un-jocks who aren't normally catered to.''

title: THE HOMELESS AND VETERANS: TIME TO SHARE
description: Before the Christmas show began Tuesday in the Fort Washington Armory shelter that night for 936 homeless men, one of them walked up to the makeshift stage. ''You a boonie rat?'' he asked Tom Bird, who was there to play Santa Claus.

title: VATICAN EMBRACING THIRD WORLD AND BATTLING MARXIST INFLUENCES
description: When Pope John Paul II travels the globe, it is in the squalid slums of the third world that his message seems most urgent and compelling.

title: ITALIAN JUDGE OPENS INQUIRY INTO CHARGES OF ISRAELI ABDUCTION
description: An Italian magistrate formally opened a judicial inquiry today into allegations that an Israeli nuclear technician was abducted here and taken back to Israel to stand trial for treason and espionage.

title: UNITED TOTE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $72,792 for the quarter and year.

title: NEWEST TEACHING TOOL: A VIDEO ENCYCLOPEDIA
description: Gerald R. Ford's Presidency took on an element of immediacy here the other day as a high school social studies class viewed footage of the fall of Vietnam, from refugees in the countryside to the havoc at the United States Embassy as the last evacuation helicopter pulled away from the roof.

title: U.S. TO EASE TERMS ON MILITARY LOANS FOR 38 COUNTRIES
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to offer Egypt, Israel and 36 other countries the opportunity to defer some interest payments on military loans, an action that could cost the Treasury about $3.5 billion in uncollected revenue in the next six years.

title: FLXIBLE BUSES, DISCARDED BY NEW YORK, ROLL AGAIN
description: Bedeviled, belittled and finally banished, the Grumman Flxible buses are back on city streets, but in Newark, not New York.

title: VIETNAM PARLEY ON NEW CHIEFS
description: An important session of Vietnam's National Assembly opened today in Hanoi, according to the official radio, the Voice of Vietnam.

title: On the Food Front
description: Gustatory notes from all over:

title: Yields Rise On Funds
description: Yields on money market mutual funds rose sharply for the week ended yesterday, fueled by higher rates on some short-term securities, such as 30-day commercial paper. The rise in short-term rates, however, did not spill over into certificates of deposit or money market accounts, which were unchanged to slightly lower.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
HOLIDAY SERMONS LOOK AT CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
description: Crises of confidence in government and race relations were on the minds of several of the city's spiritual leaders yesterday as they prepared what they would say today when their parishioners gathered to celebrate Christmas.

title: KOCH COMMENT ON 'DEEP SOUTH' ANGERS MAYORS
description: Five Mississippi mayors have complained about a remark Mayor Koch made after the death last weekend of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, after a racial assault.

title: BILL McCUTCHEON'S STARE ENLIVENS 'FRONT PAGE'
description: About midway through the play ''The Front Page,'' a man appears on the stage. He says almost nothing but brings down the house simply by the way he moves - and stares. It's one of the comic gems of the season.

title: Harris Trust Cited As Discriminating
description: An administrative law judge has found Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago discriminated against women and minority employees for the last two decades, the Labor Department said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, has received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to complete its merger with American Fletcher Corp. of Indianapolis.

title: BLACK CLERGY FIND HOMES FOR ABANDONED CHILDREN
description: The Rev. Robert West has a special plea for families in his flock this holiday season. He wants them to make room in their hearts, and their homes, for some of the abused and abandoned black children of Mississippi.

title: Inlays: From Teak to Gold
description: LARRY WOOD'S craft is inlaying gold, silver, abalone, rubies, emeralds, teak and ebony into furniture, walls or musical instruments, even the dashboards of cars. At Magus Design, his studio in Brooklyn, Mr. Wood, left, has inlaid borders on coffee tables, backgammon boxes and briefcases.

title: 'EVEN-TEMPERED' JUDGE CONDUCTS MURDER TRIAL
description: The murder trial of two avowed revolutionaries under way here is one that Wilfred P. Diana, the assignment judge for Warren, Hunterdon and Somerset Counties, calls ''difficult.''

title: JAZZ: NEW VIBRATION SOCIETY
description: JOHN S. WILSON

title: Fire at Home for Aged Kills 6 And Injures 4 in Tennessee
description: Fire swept through a home for the elderly before dawn Wednesday, killing six people and injuring four.

title: Teetering at the Top
description: The top 10 marks among schools now in Division I-A:

title: Tisch's Regimen Built Trimmer CBS
description: After just three months at the helm of CBS Inc., Laurence A. Tisch has made change commonplace at the once-unshakable network. Cost cutting has become routine, layoffs are the norm and entire departments have been eliminated.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL CHICAGO BULLS VS. KNICKS, at Madison Square Garden, 1 P.M. (Television - MSG, 1 P.M.) WASHINGTON BULLETS VS. 76ERS, at Philadelphia, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) FOOTBALL SUN BOWL, at El Paso, Tex., Alabama vs. Washington, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) BLUE-GRAY ALL-STAR CLASSIC, at Montgomery, Ala., 5 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 5 P.M., FNN-SCORE, 5 P.M.)

title: 2d Victim of Tank Fire Dies
description: A man died early today of injuries suffered in a gasoline storage tank explosion and fire, the second person killed by the blaze, officials said.

title: WHERE THE LANDLORDS' REPORTING LAW STANDS
description: Mayor Koch and landlords continue to joust over a new law that would force some owners to reveal how much money they earn on their buildings.

title: ACTIVISTS FOR THE POOR SEEK MONEY FROM FUND-RAISER
description: Agencies concerned with the homeless and the hungry have requested that $15 million raised last spring by the organization Hands Across America be spent immediately.

title: Change Taxi Shifts
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTLE GIRL IS ABANDONED ON CHRISTMAS MORNING
description: Christmas morning, a time of giddy celebration for most children, was colored with sadness for a small girl and the people who found her abandoned on a Brooklyn street corner early yesterday morning.

title: Three Air-to-Air Missile Tests Termed Success by Pentagon
description: The Defense Department says it has completed three more successful tests of its new air-to-air missile, including an experiment marking the first time that two missiles have been fired from the same plane at two different targets.

title: To Make a Start on Fair Sentencing Guidelines
description: To the Editor:

title: Record for Curran
description: Jack Curran of Archbishop Molloy in Queens now has more victories than any other head basketball coach in New York state high school history.

title: EWING, AT BUZZER, STEALS THE SHOW
description: The 15,811 fans drawn to Madison Square Garden yesterday were no doubt expecting and even rooting for a Michael Jordan spectacular.

title: PAELLA TO PANCAKES: SEARCHING FOR FAVORITE FOODS
description: EVERY once in a while, the craving strikes for a favorite food - a crusty and succulent steak perhaps, a mile-high pastrami sandwich slathered with zesty hot mustard, or an unconscionably rich slab of luxurious chocolate cake (''Sure, a scoop of vanilla ice cream with it would be just dandy!''). The following list of 50 wintertime favorites just might be your emergency survival kit when the next overpowering urge arises.

title: ATLANTA'S VAGRANT-FREE ZONE STIRS A PROTEST
description: About 30 advocates for the homeless, some with signs reading, ''Why is there no room in the inn?,'' demonstrated Wednesday against a proposed vagrant-free zone along Peachtree Street.

title: CHOOSING TO WORK WHEN OHTER PLAY
description: Although it's not a national holiday, so many people take off the week between Christmas and New Year's that Detroit can't run its assembly lines, stockbrokers can't reach their clients on the telephone, advertising agencies close their offices, and hospitals reject elective surgery.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A NINE-YEAR worldwide study of photography auctions - one of the newest and most volatile areas of the art-auction market - has produced a highly sophisticated reference work that is expected to have repercussions in other areas of art research.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1986
description: International

title: Kean Signs Museum Grant
description: The Newark Museum will receive a $4 million state grant to help it complete a renovation and expansion project under a bill signed by Governor Kean.

title: A Year of Raiders and Restructurings
description: As raiding and restructuring raised corporate dust during the year, many business people were thrust into the news. The European financier Sir James Goldsmith made a run at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and was met by a defensive restructuring by Robert E. Mercer, Goodyear's chairman. Sir James - Mr. Mercer would not use the ''Sir'' -eventually went away with a profit of $93 million on his stock.

title: A.M.A. SUIT ALLEGES BIAS IN NEW RULES ON MEDICARE FEES
description: Asserting that new Medicare provisions in a law adopted this year would discriminate against the elderly and the disabled, the American Medical Association has asked a Federal judge to declare the law unconstitutional.

title: Man Is Warded Off With Fudge Sundae
description: A woman carrying a sundae used it to prevent a man from taking her purse, the police said today.

title: Protectionism Is No Way To Treat a Trade Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Biggest Marathon
description: According to the race's organizers, 19,689 runners completed the New York City Marathon last month, making it the biggest marathon ever. In figures released by the organizers yesterday, 96 percent of the 20,502 who started the event finished it.

title: 3 Dead After Church Quarrel
description: A man killed his in-laws and wounded the couple's two young sons because he did not want his wife going to Christmas Eve mass with her family, then committed suicide today, according to the Houston police.

title: ISRAEL DENIES AFFRONT TO ITALY OVER FUGITIVE NUCLEAR WORKER
description: Israel said today that it did not infringe on Italian sovereignty when it brought an Israeli nuclear technician back from Europe to face trial for leaking atomic secrets.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Many an ad agency executive, when welcoming a new low-billing industrial client, has harbored the generally futile hope that somehow, someday it would explode into a free-spending consumer account. It has happened in Boston.

title: SEABROOK IS SAFE, REPORT CONTENDS
description: Allegations that shoddy workmanship and drug and alcohol abuse were jeopardizing safety at the Seabrook nuclear power plant either brought remedies or were unsubstantiated, a Federal report said.

title: New Year's Eve Jazz
description: The American Jazz Radio Festival, heard on WBGO, 88.3 FM, will present live music on New Year's Eve from 10 P.M. to 5 A.M. It begins with a live broadcast from WBGO's studios at 54 Park Place in Newark, featuring the bassist Bill Lee's group, including the singer Ronnie Dyson, the trumpeter Virgil Jones, the saxophonist Harold Vick, the pianist Stanley Cowell and the drummer Joe Chambers. They will be followed by the pianist-singer Tania Maria and her trio.

title: PROFESSIONALS BEGIN EMIGRATING FROM TEXAS
description: Richard Keating recalls with wonder those hectic days after he first moved to Houston from Chicago as a young architect in 1976. Those were days of wild Texas growth, when a 20-story building was a small job, when he and his ambitious young colleagues often worked all night, fueled on take-out pizzas and the sheer excitement of building a dazzling new city, with their dogs curled up under the drafting tables.

title: ALABAMA ROLLS IN SUN BOWL
description: Bobby Humphrey, a sophomore tailback, scored on runs of 64 and 3 yards and caught one of two third-quarter touchdown passes by Mike Shula today as Alabama beat Washington, 28-6, in the Sun Bowl.

title: SYRIAN SUCCESS STORY: A HATED MINORITY SECT BECOMES THE RULING CLASS
description: From the coastal road below Latakia, a four-lane highway suddenly materializes, climbing up to this tiny mountain village, and then just as suddenly peters out.

title: Some Bad News For Bonecrusher
description: When James (Bonecrusher) Smith landed the World Boxing Association's heavyweight title by knocking out Tim Witherspoon at Madison Square Garden two weeks ago, he also won a March 7 shot at Mike Tyson for a purse of at least $1 million. That, anyway, is what Smith and most everybody else thought. Now comes another reminder that in the fight game, so little is ever what it first seems to be.

title: WASP KEY WEAPON IN WAR ON ALFALFA WEEVIL
description: A 27-year war against the alfalfa weevil is being won by an imported stingless wasp, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Divorce System Doesn't Work in Suffolk Either
description: To the Editor:

title: Freighter Sinks Near Iceland; 6 Reported Lost and 5 Saved
description: An Icelandic freighter carrying 19,000 barrels of herring sank in rough seas in the north Atlantic early today.

title: A SECRET PLACE FOR THE TORIES TO COMMENT
description: Parliament was finally told recently about one of the worst kept secrets in this nation, where official secrets are at least as rampant as the spies that regularly broker them: ''There is a room in the turret of Westminster which does not exist in which are held meetings that do not take place.''

title: Police Seek Identity of Body Found in Smoke-Filled Truck
description: State police today were trying to determine the identity of a middle-age man whose body was found in a partly burned pickup truck parked at Bradley International Airport.

title: HANUKKAH, WITH LATKES AND LIGHT
description: To all the sparkle of the holiday season another light will be added tonight, as Jews begin the celebration of Hanukkah with the lighting of the first candle on the menorah.

title: SUSPECT IS KILLED IN SHOOTOUT
description: A 37-year-old man from North Carolina, wanted by the police on Staten Island for wounding his daughter with gunshot fire on Tuesday, was killed in a shootout with city and Housing Authority police officers yesterday afternoon.

title: Military Medical Care Tries to Heal Itself
description: Among the biggest headaches suffered in the Pentagon has been the responsibility for the medical care of 10 million people in peacetime and for the wartime treatment of men and women wounded in battle.

title: Trade Ruling Is Issued On East Bloc Fertilizer
description: The Commerce Department has ruled that the Soviet Union, Rumania and East Germany sold urea, a chemical fertilizer, in the American market at prices below the cost of production, the department said Wednesday.

title: Crimson Tired
description: Sonny Smith, Auburn's basketball coach, on his dour counterpart at the University of Alabama: ''It takes 15 muscles to smile and 65 muscles to frown. This leads me to believe Wimp Sanderson is suffering from muscle fatigue.''

title: ART: A RETROSPECTIVE OF WORK OF JOHN STORRS
description: JOHN STORRS may be one of those artists that each generation has to discover for itself. He will never be a household name. There is nothing flamboyant about his work, and his most public and monumental sculptures - in Chicago and Cork, Ireland - may be his most problematical. But he is one of America's most important early modernist sculptors, and artists continue to be inspired by his attempt to realize an international, utopian ambition in economical, unpretentious form.

title: SHIFT OF POWER ON BANK BOARD SEEN
description: The defeat suffered by the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on his proposal to extend a limit on real estate investments by thrift institutions signaled a major shift in the balance of power at the agency, industry experts said this week.

title: PROTESTS REVEAL AN UNSUSPECTED DISCONTENT AMONG ELITE YOUTH AND FEARS ABOUT FUTURE
description: The pro-democracy demonstrations by university students over the last several weeks have revealed a depth of discontent among the elite of China's youth that was unsuspected until now.

title: Barrons at Blue Note
description: The Bill Barron All-Stars, featuring Kenny Barron, will perform Monday and Tuesday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). The Barron Brothers, on saxophone and piano, are appearing with Ray Drummond on bass and Ben Riley on drums. Shows both days are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; $7.50 music charge, $5 minimum.

title: 9TH KENNEDY CENTER HONORS ON CBS
description: FREQUENTLY it is the small detail that is bound to stick in memory. In this evening's ''Kennedy Center Honors,'' while Glenn Close and Hal Linden are singing a love ballad from the musical ''I Do, I Do,'' Nancy Reagan reaches over to hold President Reagan's hand. Not responding immediately, the uncharacteristically subdued President finally turns to the First Lady and manages a smile. A purely impulsive moment? Or the seizing of a good photo opportunity during a period of political and no doubt personal stress? Either way, the image - seen by few in the theater but now available to millions - is striking.

title: TUNDRA APT. 1 RM. 2-SLOUGH VIEW $200
description: In this sprawling tundra community, large rusting shipping containers form ramshackle apartment complexes.

title: 3 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African police shot and killed three black men when a crowd stoned a security force vehicle in the township of Nzanany, near Bethal in Transvaal Province, the Government reported today.

title: LOVE OF NEW YORK CITED IN AIDING NEEDIEST
description: Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund mention their concern for New York City in sending their gifts.

title: Punched, Kicked, Slammed
description: I am neither a writer nor a historian but a victim of torture who was forced to leave his home. My home is Afghanistan, and I left on Dec. 27, 1979, when the Soviet Union invaded.

title: 62 REPORTED DEAD
description: An Iraqi airliner was hijacked yesterday and later crashed and burned on a remote desert airstrip in Saudi Arabia, killing 62 people, Jordanian officials said.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Music and Harmony; Sound Management
description: ''We're making it as good as old,'' read the T-shirts that were worn proudly by the electricians, plasterers and other workmen responsible for the $30 million renovation of Carnegie Hall. The promise was amply fulfilled.

title: Literary Gift in Georgetown
description: Ellen Barry, widow of the playwright Philip Barry, has presented Georgetown University Library with a collection of Mr. Barry's manuscripts and papers. The bulk of his papers went to the Yale University Library after his death in 1949, but Mrs. Barry kept some letters, contracts and drafts of some of her husband's later plays for sentimental reasons.

title: BID TO BAR REMOVAL OF TRIBAL BONES REBUFFED
description: A Federal district judge has refused to block the removal of Chumash Indian bones from an ancient tribal cemetery discovered six months ago in dredging a flood-control channel.

title: RARE ARTIFACTS ACQUIRED BY CUSTER BATTLEFIELD
description: A rare, 1872 enlisted man's dress blouse traced to an Ohio man who rode with Lieut. Col. George Armstrong Custer has been acquired by the Custer Battlefield National Monument.

title: KOREANS ASK, IS THE SOCIETY FAIR TO LABOR?
description: She works in a small clothing factory - or she did until recently, when she was dismissed for refusing to work an extra 12-hour shift on Sunday.

title: CITY CABARETS OFFER FEAST OF DIVERSIONS
description: THE weekend between Christmas and New Year's traditionally brings a lull in performing-arts schedules in New York, but not in the world of cabaret. Clubs around town are teeming with talent. Rising young stars like the singer Laurie Beechman and the comedian Bob Nelson refresh a genre that sometimes seems to languish on the brink of extinction. At the same time, persevering veterans like Anita Ellis and Jon Hendricks continue to define unshakeably high standards of excellence in a different mode of jazz singing.

title: U.S. ENVOY LINKED TO REBEL AIRSTRIP INSIDE COSTA RICA
description: The United States Ambassador to Costa Rica helped secure initial Costa Rican permission to build a secret airstrip for the Nicaraguan rebels early this year and was deeply involved in overseeing its use, according to a senior Government official in Central America.

title: Good Knight!
description: Last winter, Regina Days of Georgia Southern set a single-season record for Division I women's basketball by scoring on 234 of 332 shots from the floor, an accuracy rate of 70.5 percent. As remarkable as that figure is, it's already being threatened with eclipse, maybe with demolition.

title: POPE PLEADS FOR THE POOR AND FOR PEACE
description: Pope John Paul II called today for a radical change in the way man exercises his dominion over the earth, saying the world's leaders should listen to the poor and the silent and those who pray for peace.

title: Date Set in Methanol Case
description: Sentencing has been set for Jan. 29 for John Robert Lowrey, who pleaded guilty Monday to second-degree manslaughter in the death of a man who drank Mr. Lowrey's race car fuel methanol at a party. Mr. Lowrey, 18 years old, was accused of passing the methanol as moonshine whisky at the party Nov. 24. The man who drank it, Timothy Scott Tilson, 23, died Nov. 28.

title: TOASTING THE HOLIDAY IN A SLEEK LIMOUSINE
description: PATRICK MAHONEY said he wouldn't swear to it but he had been told that in Los Angeles they had limousines 40 feet long ''with a midget who serves drinks, and a hot tub.'' He sounded the way Easterners do when they talk about excesses indulged in by residents of that other coast.

title: Minister Sentenced On Abuse Charges
description: A self-ordained bishop convicted of controlling congregants in three states through beatings and sex must spend at least eight years in prison for what a judge called a barbaric crime.

title: Investors Betting on Dingman Touch
description: Michael D. Dingman, chairman and chief executive of the Henley Group Inc., claims that his taste in businesses runs to the pedestrian. ''We like plain vanilla industries, things that are commonplace or have fallen out of favor,'' he said of the mishmash of 38 companies spun off early this year by Allied-Signal Inc.

title: Weekly Paper Says Synanon Paid $100,000 in Settlement
description: The drug rehabilitation program Synanon has dropped its libel and defamation suit against the local newspaper, The Point Reyes Light, and has agreed to pay two journalists $100,000, the paper says.

title: MARKET PLACE
description: TRUE to form, Wall Street security analysts are looking ahead to 1987 with rosier profit projections than economists and market strategists who work for the same brokerage houses. In the past, however, analysts often scaled back their estimates as the year progressed.

title: IN THE BUSHES OF FLORIDA, CUBAN 'BRIGADE' TRIES TO KEEP THE FLAME ALIVE
description: A burst of rifle fire rang out, and two squads of men in camouflage uniforms dived for cover in the scrub brush.

title: FOOTNOTE TO WEDTECH STORY: DEAL WITH IRANIAN WAS HALTED IN '81
description: An Iranian secret agent and arms smuggler went to the South Bronx in 1981 to meet with the top officials of the Wedtech Corporation in an unsuccessful effort to purchase spare parts sought by the Iranian army, according to company officials.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BOSWELL: THE ENGLISH EXPERIMENT, 1785-1789. Edited by Irma S. Lustig and Frederick A. Pottle. Illustrated. 332 pages. McGraw-Hill. $24.95.

title: Bridge: Some of Alice's Adventures Are Tied to the Card Table
description: The topsy-turvy existence of Alice, in Wonderland and in the Looking Glass, often has bridge-table parallels. A quarter of a century ago, some of them were described by Jeff Rubens in a series of articles in The Bridge World.

title: THE BATTLE FOR RERUN RIGHTS
description: The television networks and Hollywood studios may be headed for a showdown over the often-hefty profits from rerun rights to prime-time shows.

title: BOLIVIA STRUGGLES WITH ITS TIN MINES
description: Government efforts to curtail tin mining, for which Bolivia made its mark on the world in pre-cocaine days, have set off a dispute that goes to the roots of the country's political and economic life.

title: CITY DOGS PUT IT ON FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: What is the well-dressed dog wearing for the holidays? Well, a Santa suit in one instance.

title: ATTACK VICTIM TOO ILL TO HELP, LAWYER SAYS
description: A lawyer for a victim in the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, last week said yesterday that his client wanted to cooperate with prosecutors but was not yet well enough to do so.

title: LIBYAN ENVOY KILLED IN LEBANON
description: A Libyan diplomat based in Syria was killed today in a Syrian-controlled section of eastern Lebanon by gunmen who opened fire on his embassy car, the police reported.

title: Soviet Backs Joint Ventures
description: The Politburo today approved the creation of joint economic ventures with foreign companies as a way to increase exports of Soviet-made goods.

title: ADVERTISING
description: David Steinberg, the comedian, has directed six TV commercials to promote the Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company, which comes into being Jan. 1 as the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., as a result of the merger of two of its 80-year-old subsidiaries.

title: Diner's Journal
description: FANS of blazing Southwestern cooking may want to stop by the new Arizona 206 Cafe, a smart and neighborly annex to the Arizona 206 restaurant at 206 East 60th Street. Done in clean desert tones of stucco and unfinished wood, this casual spot sports firm fabric-covered banquettes, little tables scattered about and an exposed kitchen behind a tile service counter. Brendan Walsh, the resourceful young chef, has created an all-day tasting menu that features appetizer-size portions for $6 to $12.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IF you like Jean Jacques Rachou's Cote Basque - and legions do - chances are you will like Le Festival, the two-month-old reincarnation of his former Cafe Lavandou on East 61st Street. While Le Festival's young staff, all-seafood menu and decor are new, the restaurant essentially reflects the classic and copious approach of the boss.

title: WOMAN AND SON, 10, DIE IN A QUEENS HOUSE FIRE
description: A woman and her 10-year-old son were killed by a fire that swept through the upper story of their two-story home in Neponsit, Queens, early yesterday, the fire department said.

title: Bolivia Is Serious in Its Efforts Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: MCA-Motown Talks Reported
description: MCA Inc. is discussing the purchase of the Motown Records Corporation for up to $75 million, The Los Angeles Times reported today. According to the newspaper, Sidney Jay Sheinberg, MCA's president and chief operating officer, on Wednesday refused to deny that MCA is engaged in talks to acquire Motown, which nurtured such musical acts as Stevie Wonder, the Supremes and Smokey Robinson.

title: TUTU IS URGING U.S. TO ALTER POLICY ON APARTHEID
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu is urging the Reagan Administration to institute a new policy toward South Africa, offering Pretoria a choice between extensive financial and diplomatic support for dismantling apartheid, or greatly increased ostracism.

title: PLEA IS REBUFFED ON KIDNEY FILTERS
description: The Food and Drug Administration has rejected a petition by six Senators calling for the agency to regulate the reuse of kidney dialysis filters and conduct clinical studies to determine whether the growing practice poses health risks.

title: MILITARY PROFIT RULES PROTESTED
description: Aerospace industry groups have expressed sharp disapproval of new Pentagon rules meant to lower the profits of companies doing business with the Defense Department.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Webster, the Ranger coach, was discharged from Lenox Hill Hospital a day after undergoing surgery to relieve an inner ear infection. According to a team spokesman, doctors found the infection to be more serious than they had believed, but Webster will probably be able to return to work next Tuesday. . . . Dick Stockton of the United States and Ken Rosewall of Australia were named by Tennis Magazine in its year-end rankings as the top Men's 35 and Men's 45 players, respectively.

title: Harvey Stephens, 85, Dies; Acted on Stage and in Films
description: Harvey Stephens, a longtime character actor who appeared on Broadway and in films, died Monday at the Saddleback Medical Center. He was 85 years old.

title: Fahd Officially Picks Oil Chief
description: King Fahd issued a royal decree on Wednesday naming Hisham Nazer the Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, the official Saudi Press Agency reported.

title: LEVIN DIARY IS AT CENTER OF RAGIN LEGAL DEBATE
description: A memo book that Jennifer Levin kept in the kitchen of her family's SoHo home has become the center of a bitter, but subtle legal debate among prosecutors, defense attorneys and legal scholars.

title: A Buying Spree by Saatchi
description: When Madison Avenue decided last spring that bigger was better for advertising agencies as well as for products, it took a couple of relative newcomers to put together the biggest of them all.

title: The Color of Money
description: The capital is entering its budget season, and among the omens and portents of the Federal Government's fiscal future is this: The cover of the budget document, this year, will be maroon.

title: Substantive Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Multitude of Jordans
description: On Christmas Day, 1986, a crowd of 15,811 gave themselves a gift and came to watch Michael Jeffrey Jordan, a k a Air Jordan, perform his daredevil, death-defying hoop feats in Madison Square Garden.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE are some words particularly appropriate to theater production: planned, hoped-for, scheduled and tentative are just a few. And the sad fact is that a number of planned, hoped-for, scheduled and tentative productions, announced with varying degrees of fanfare each year, fizzle before they even get near a stage. The money people bow out, Dustin Hoffman decides he doesn't want to sing and dance, Mike Nichols is busy for the next five years, the package didn't jell - name a reason, any reason, and it's bound to have been used to explain why a show that was highly touted hasn't yet seen the light of day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It all happened like lightning. The captain had just announced that we'd entered Saudi airspace when one passenger from the economy class jumped up with a hand grenade and ran towards the cockpit.

title: But Is It Fifth Avenue?
description: A group of Washingtonians is apparently hoping to challenge New York's primacy in the area of St. Patrick's Day parades.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1986
description: International

title: The Worm and the Apple: Music and Harmony; Street Smart
description: New York City traffic patterns swirl across state and city lines, but traffic agencies have always been insular. No longer. A compact between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the transportation departments of New York City and State and New Jersey creates a new agency, Transcom, to serve as a clearinghouse for traffic information.

title: ALIENS' CHRISTMAS TRIPS SOUTH APPEAR TO SLOW
description: The migration of illegal aliens across the border with Mexico usually reverses itself this time of year, with people sneaking out of the United States to spend the holidays with relatives to the south.

title: STEEL'S LAST OASES DRYING UP
description: Good times are coming to an end for the only part of the American steel industry that has been consistently profitable.

title: Ineligible Freshman Fitting In
