description: With conference play set to begin in January, coaches are using the semester break to review their teams' progress and chart an early course.

title: Hispanic Groups Aim A Boycott at Japanese
description: Two national Hispanic organizations representing more than 200,000 people have announced a nationwide boycott of all Japanese products in response to remarks made by Japan's Prime Minister.

title: THE ANTICS OF SCHICKELE AND BORGE
description: Two musicians with different styles of madness, Victor Borge and Peter Schickele, will carry on in separate halls tonight, but that should pose no problem for mutual fans. Both men will appear several times in the days ahead.

title: Dancing In the Year
description: Those who want to dance their way into the New Year can choose between ballroom and disco dancing on New Year's Eve at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. Ballroom dancing to three live bands will be featured from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M., followed by disco dancing, also to live bands, till 5 A.M. Admission is $30 till 1 A.M., $25 afterward. Information: 247-0200.

title: ADVERTISING
description: According to A. C. Nielsen, the monitor of the monitorable, the highest per capita sales of grocery products this year have been in Norway, with Sweden being in second place.

title: Travels With Glickman
description: One reason House members value increasing seniority so much is that it enables them to move to what they regard as choicer office space. Generally, the accepted progression is from the oldest, the Cannon Building (1908), to the Longworth Building (1933) and finally to the Rayburn Building (1965).

title: VIETNAMESE GROUP IN CHURCH DISPUTE
description: Vietnamese Roman Catholics, embroiled in a bitter dispute with the Diocese of San Jose over demands for their own parish, rented a high school to ''pray for reconciliation'' with church officials on Christmas Eve.

title: RESIDENTS RESENT HUGE PARK'S PLANS
description: People no longer try to burn down the Adirondack Park Agency headquarters here, nor do they dump manure on the lawn or punch the employees.

title: A FREED HOSTAGE RETURNS TO FRANCE AND SAYS, 'I FEEL AS IF I'M DREAMING'
description: ''I'm glad to see you,'' Aurel Cornea told the Prime Minister of France at Orly Airport today. ''I don't believe it. I feel as if I'm dreaming.''

title: Of Joyce Kilmer's Leafy-Armed Muse
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Opportunities for pop-jazz aficionados to hear their favorite groups are not limited to just the weekend. A sampler of some of the notable acts appearing in clubs and halls in the New York area from Monday to New Year's Eve follows. Most of the groups appearing on Monday and Tuesday also have New Year's Eve shows at the same venues. Monday

title: Columbia Architecture Dean to Resign
description: The architect James Stewart Polshek will resign as dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation on June 30 after 15 years in the post.

title: Pernfors Selected
description: Hans Olsson, captain of the Swedish team that is attempting to win its third consecutive Davis Cup title, named Mikael Pernfors yesterday as his second singles player. The three-of-five-match final series between Sweden and Australia is scheduled to begin today in Melbourne.

title: Arms Control and the Senate 'Gang of Four'
description: Democrats and Republicans have good reason for sitting on different sides of the aisle in the Senate chamber. Political considerations so infect every decision on Capitol Hill that it takes an unusual issue to bring lawmakers together on a genuinely bipartisan basis.

title: JAPAN PLAN ON BUDGET: NO GROWTH
description: Despite strong domestic and overseas pressure to stimulate the economy, the Japanese Government today approved a preliminary budget that provides for the smallest spending increase in three decades.

title: ENGINEER CUTS RED TAPE TO SAVE HIS JOB IN U.S.
description: Noel Ignacio likes his job with the Federal Government - he is an engineer on a small Coast Guard boat -and his superiors like the way he does his work.

title: Volunteer Santa Hurt In Prison Accident
description: A deputy sheriff's pistol accidentally fired and wounded a volunteer Santa Claus Wednesday at the state penitentiary, the authorities said.

title: FOR JURORS IN A DIOXIN TRIAL, IT'S A 3D CHRISTMAS TOGETHER
description: In January 1979, a railroad tank car spilled a tiny amount - less than one teaspoon - of dioxin in Sturgeon, Mo.

title: ARMS-TEST CURBS SET OFF A DISPUTE
description: A sharp debate has developed among Government experts over a tentative plan by the Reagan Administration to improve the monitoring of Soviet compliance with two 1970's nuclear test-limitation treaties, according to classified Government documents and Administration officials.

title: Dining Out Guide: Special Occasions
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - *(May 30, 1986) In winter, any number of occasions may call for particularly festive dining - holidays, birthdays or anniversaries. This West Side restaurant with dark wood walls, lead-paned windows and bucolic turn-of-the-century murals is one of the most gracious and romantic spots in town and might be just the place for your celebration. Appetizer choices are bresaola with figs, Parmesan and rosemary olive oil; sliced duck liver, with toasted brioche and duck cracklings, and white anchovies with buffalo mozzarella and tomato. For a main dish, you might order steak au poivre; sauteed calf's liver with mild sesame-and-mustard-seed sauce; rack of lamb encrusted with basil and breadcrumbs, or rare roasted slices of lamb in pan gravy surrounded by pale-green French beans. Dinner entrees $13.50 to $25; also prix-fixe dinner $25.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. LE CIRQUE, #58 East 65th Street (794-9292) - ***(Sept. 19, 1986) The dining room of this elegant East Side restaurant crackles with high-voltage energy, and the rich and famous from around the world are squeezed in elbow to elbow. The food is classically rooted and generally conservative.

title: U.S. AND IRAN TO MEET AGAIN ON SEIZED ASSETS
description: United States and Iranian officials are to meet Monday to resume negotiations on returning to Iran $500 million in frozen assets. The issue figures in an Iranian offer to intercede on behalf of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Falcons Tempt Vermeil
description: The talk about Dick Vermeil's return to profesional football as a coach continues to heat up.

title: ARCHITECTURE: KINETIC, MACHINE-INSPIRED BUILDINGS
description: DURING the last two years, six young New York architects met regularly at one another's homes and studios to discuss alternatives to what they called ''the flatness of present architectural discourse'' and ''the dense wall of post-modernism.'' The six - Neil Denari, Wes Jones, Peter Pfau, Ken Kaplan, Ted Krueger and Chris Scholz - said they believed that post-modernism's retreat into classicism had limited architecture's range and technical capabilities, and that a machine-inspired architecture offered possibilities for richer buildings better tuned to contemporary culture.

title: WHERE A SEASON TO CELEBRATE IS A TIME TO FORGET
description: Japanese, as a rule, do not fall down on the job. After work, though, it's another story.

title: ADVERTISING
description: * Steven J. Marlow and Darlene Billia have been named senior vice presidents at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 102, 76ers 97: Moses Malone, in his first game in Philadelphia against his former team, scored 28 points and pulled down 21 rebounds last night to lead Washington. Malone, who was traded with Terry Catledge to Washington last June for Jeff Ruland and Cliff Robinson, received a standing ovation that lasted nearly a minute when he was introduced before the game.

title: CAPE COD POTATO CHIPS: A 'LUXURY' JUNK FOOD
description: Cape Cod Potato Chips are not sold in many places, but in the stores that carry the product, it is frequently the top-selling chip.

title: Eugene R. Canudo, 76, A Retired State Judge
description: Eugene R. Canudo, a retired Acting State Supreme Justice, died of a stroke last Monday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Ridge, L.I.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE star of the evening was clearly Alexandra Danilova, the former prima ballerina of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, whose memoirs, ''Choura,'' have just been published. That was the reason for Don Smith's Christmas party Tuesday evening on the Upper East Side, to which the entrepreneur invited 40 or so pals. But when your chums include the likes of Licia Albanese, Margaret Whiting, Julie Wilson, David Susskind, Taina Elg, Al Hirschfeld, Charles Strouse and Carmen, the model, even a prima ballerina is going to have a bit of competition.

title: Seven Years of War in Afghanistan; MAKE MOSCOW WANT TO QUIT
description: The United States cannot guarantee victory to the Afghan freedom fighters, but it can help deny victory to the Soviet Union. Washington must make Moscow want out. The key is to convince the Russians that the continuing costs of the war - military, political and economic - outweigh the potential gains. Only then will they seek a negotiated withdrawal.

title: ADVERTISING
description: THE National Register Publishing Company, whose Red Book directories are a necessary possession on the business side in both the agency and advertiser side of the industry, has acquired the Creative Black Book, which in its 16 years has become fairly indispensable to many people on the creative side, worldwide.

title: An Industry Gathers Political Strength
description: Casino operators here are eager to ease some of the strict anticorruption rules governing their industry, and the growing political awareness of their 38,000 workers may help them press the point.

title: Closings for The Holiday
description: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges, banks, Government offices and most businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas.

title: CARNEGIE PANEL CITES 24 HEROES
description: Bradley Hall doesn't think he's a hero. But the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission and the handicapped man he dragged from a burning home a year ago say otherwise.

title: Pete Crivaro Is Dead at 73; Des Moines Mayor in 2 Terms
description: Pete Crivaro, the Mayor of Des Moines, died Wednesday night of complications resulting from brain cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: R. GORDON WASSON, A MUSHROOM EXPERT AND BANKER, IS DEAD
description: R. Gordon Wasson, a former banker who wrote scholarly books about cults involving hallucinogenic mushrooms, died Tuesday at the home of his daughter in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 88 years old. A former resident of Manhattan, he lived in Danbury, Conn.

title: DICKERSON RECALLS ROUT BY REDSKINS
description: The last time they played was New Year's Day 1984. The Washington Redskins had won the previous Super Bowl and looked no less invincible as defending champions, winning 14 games and a division title. The Los Angeles Rams squeezed into the playoffs as a wild-card team with a 9-7 record, beat the Cowboys and won a trip to Washington. Some prize. ''They were a fantastic team that year,'' Eric Dickerson of the Rams remembered the other day. He was a rookie that season, the National Football League's leading rusher and a man smart enough to know a buzzsaw when he walked into one, especially one he had seen before. The Rams had also played the Redskins during the regular season and lost, 42-20.

title: HONDURAS WARNS NICARAGUA ON CROSSING BORDER
description: The commander of the Honduran armed forces said today that if Sandinista troops violated Honduran territory again, as they did earlier this month in a battle with Nicaraguan rebels, Honduras would consider a retaliatory air strike deep into Nicaragua.

title: FIREWORKS, BIG BANDS AND CRUISES
description: THE long countdown to New Year's Eve has begun. This grand ritual of resolutions and remembrance is as much a state of mind as a place on the calendar. Dangling between old and new, it is also a mini-season for celebration, as champagne corks pop, fireworks explode and reflection gives way to revelry.

title: Vacuum of Ideas
description: In this region, where three great religions were born, the issues of faith and promise are again stirring societies. They are not simple issues, long settled, because religion is about how men and women behave toward each other as well as about belief in their relations to God.

title: Fire Cuts Short Jet's Flight
description: An engine fire forced a Delta Air Lines jet to return to the airport just minutes after it took off for New York with 136 passengers aboard. Delta officials said they did not know what caused the flames to shoot from the L-100 jet's rear engine Tuesday as Flight 144 lifted off. It appeared that a compressor pump stalled, said Ron Gardner, information manager of the Hollywood-Fort Lauderdale International Airport.

title: INTERFAITH TALKS ADVANCE IN BRAZIL
description: After five years of growing cooperation, Roman Catholic and Jewish spokesmen in Brazil have taken a new step toward eliminating generations of mutual distrust by publishing a detailed manual to promote interfaith discussion.

title: Woman Is Assaulted At L.I. Train Station
description: A 25-year-old woman was assaulted and raped early yesterday while waiting to buy a ticket at a railroad station on Long Island, the police said.

title: Casey's Condition Is Stable
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, remains in stable condition at the Georgetown University Hospital, a hospital spokesman said today. Mr. Casey was operated on Dec. 18 for removal of a cancerous brain tumor. There were reports Wednesday that Mr. Casey was in a semicoma and that his doctors were uncertain he had regained motor functions. The reports were not confirmed by the hospital.

title: U.S. Loses, 82-80
description: A Brazilian all-star team defeated a United States squad, 82-80, today to gain third place in a Christmas basketball tournament. The American club was composed of players who formerly played in the Continental Basketball Association in the United States or had been in the European leagues.

title: RESEARCHER SAYS SOME PILOTS NAP IN COCKPIT
description: Commercial airline pilots often fight intense drowsiness and sometimes even fall asleep while flying planes on long overnight trips, a researcher said.

title: Disgruntled Customer Kills Short-Order Cook
description: A customer fired a rifle in a restaurant, killing a short-order cook who refused to serve him chicken on Christmas Eve, the authorities said today.

title: NEW RULES DUE ON FEDERAL WORKERS' LONG-DISTANCE PHONING
description: The Reagan Administration says it will propose new regulations early next year to crack down on many personal long-distance calls made by Federal workers at Government expense.

title: TASS REPORTS FATAL MINE BLAST
description: A methane gas explosion Wednesday at a coal mine in the Ukraine killed an undetermined number of people, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today, and there was speculation that the casualties may have been heavy.

title: Of Arms and Israel
description: For a beleaguered state like Israel, arms exports are a tempting way to seek foreign friends, earn money and promote military self-sufficiency. So tempting that, remarkably, Israel has by some estimates climbed to ninth place in the world's arms bazaar, with annual sales of $1.2 billion or nearly a fourth of its industrial exports.

title: BOSWORTH BARRED FROM BOWL FOR STEROIDS
description: Brian Bosworth, the all-America linebacker, and two of his University of Oklahoma teammates have been barred from playing in the Orange Bowl game against Arkansas Jan. 1 because they tested positive for anabolic steroids, a university spokesman said yesterday.

title: TRADITIONS AND SHARING LINK THOSE CELEBRATING CHRISTMAS
description: On a day when a white Christmas was a distant dream and the runners in Central Park wore shorts, Irene Tar celebrated the holiday yesterday as she has for 12 years, gliding across the ice at Rockefeller Center.

title: It's Our Business, Too
description: The headlines about the Reagan Administration's crisis of leadership and direction have been so thick and constant that the passing of another arms control opportunity was too little noticed or mourned.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: HE is a ubiquitous and, at 6 feet 6 inches tall, a looming figure in the New York art world today. His frequent presence at blue-chip functions is no surprise, however, given his multiple roles as a private collector of 20th-century art, the founder of a major corporate art collection, and, for the past year, president of the Board of Trustees of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Golden Eggs for Rich Farmers
description: ''What I have feared for a long time,'' says Representative Dan Glickman of Kansas, ''is that the public will view agricultural spending in the late 1980's the way they view defense spending in the mid-1980's.'' If so, it will be none too soon. Mr. Glickman thinks of the golden goose as a treasure. To most Americans, when they learn about it, it'll be a scandal.

title: AN ENIGMA, RIGOROUS IN HER CRAFT
description: IN ''Therese,'' the French director Alain Cavalier's detached, elegantly photographed depiction of the life and death of a young Carmelite nun in the late 19th century, Catherine Mouchet radiates a striking mixture of beatified radiance, obsession and stubbornness. Throughout the movie, which was shot in a diorama rather than on a conventional set, the Carmelite nuns emerge before the camera and recede like translucent apparitions in a 19th-century French painting. Perhaps the one image from the picture that sticks the most is Ms. Mouchet's enigmatic gaze, avid with expectation at the beginning of the film, when she is a 15-year-old burning to become a saint, and anguished but still burning at the end of the movie, when she is near death from tuberculosis.

title: BENCHING LEAVES O'BRIEN SUBDUED
description: Ken O'Brien, calm and controlled, supported Pat Ryan today but not necessarily Coach Joe Walton's decision to switch quarterbacks for Sunday's wild-card playoff game against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: GIANT RUNNING: A HARD ROUTE
description: When professional football teams have 14-2 seasons, as the Giants did this year, almost everything must go right.

title: Helen Thurber Is Dead at 84; Edited Writings of Husband
description: Helen Thurber, an editor and the wife of James Thurber, died at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital, on Monday. She was 84 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: TRADITION MARKS CHRISTMAS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, enjoyed a traditional Christmas in the White House today, with an exchange of gifts, a dinner for longtime friends and telephone calls to family members.

title: Man's Legs Severed By Commuter Train
description: A man lost his legs and suffered serious internal and head injuries yesterday when he was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train in Woodside, Queens.

title: Capital Reading
description: 'Corpocracy'

title: MANY SEE CONTINUED DOLLAR DROP
description: Fifteen months after the historic meeting at the Plaza Hotel where the United States and its major industrial partners agreed to drive the value of the dollar down, currency traders and economists are wondering where the governments of the industrial nations want to see exchange rates settle.

title: HORMEL STRIKE: BITTER AFTERMATH FOR MINNESOTA TOWN
description: The Jaycees' sign on the outskirts proclaims ''the good life is here to stay'' in this town where hundreds of meatpackers went through a second straight Christmas without work, the bitter aftermath of the long Hormel strike.

title: 'Expanding America,' On Transportation
description: ''The Entrepreneurs'' has a point of view: risk-taking capitalists contribute to the general well-being. The third episode in the six-part monthly series, on Channel 5 Sunday night at 9, looks at the people who have fostered transportation.

title: Nippon Steel Cutbacks
description: A strong yen, slumping exports and low domestic demand are forcing the Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's-largest steelmaker, to consider sharp cutbacks in its work force and production capacity, a company spokesman said today. The spokesman declined to comment further on the possible retrenchment. The leading Japanese business daily, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, said Nippon Steel would trim its work force by 30 percent and suspend at least three of its 12 blast furnaces over four years beginning next April.

title: Terror Suspects in Israel
description: Israeli security forces uncovered a terrorist cell whose members are suspected in the stabbing deaths of two Israeli civilians in the Gaza Strip in September and October, the Israeli radio said today.

title: Executive Is Urged For Toxic Cleanup
description: A New York evironmental panel has recommended the appointment of a full-time executive to oversee the state's cleanup of hazardous-waste sites.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN ''The Morning After'' opened yesterday, audiences saw Jane Fonda, whose image has been successfully transformed from political activist to physical-fitness specialist, playing a down-on-her-luck has-been of an actress who is also a serious alcoholic. How important is an audience's image of an actress to its acceptance of her in a role? Will viewers believe that a woman with the back muscles of Jane Fonda has lived a profligate and degenerate life?

title: Labor Dispute Settled At Hotel in Disneyland
description: Disneyland Hotel and more than 1,000 of its employees have agreed to a new labor contract, ending 10 months of picketing, officials said Wednesday.

title: INSIDE
description: Homeless in Kansas City Despite data in a national report, local leaders say the growing number of homeless families is a grim problem.

title: Hard-Charging Lorenzo Built Empire in the Air
description: Frank Lorenzo might have finished 9,024th in the New York Marathon this year, but no one in the airline industry came close to him in the running for the most ambitious, colorful and controversial top executive.

title: Sardine-Can Wreaths
description: A holiday wreath made of sardine cans will be among the varieties of wreaths on view through Jan. 9 at the Arsenal Gallery of the City's Department of Parks and Recreation, Fifth Avenue and 64th Street. The wreaths, 29 in all, were made by artists, horticulturists and others. Hours are Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HOLIDAY 'PATIENCE' Ah, for the love of a poet. Tonight, the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players present ''Patience,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta about two poets' ardor for an unpretentious village milkmaid. John Reed, the veteran principal comedian of D'Oyly Carte, the British opera troupe that disbanded in February 1982 after 106 years of touring the world, will star as the poet Bunthorne. His rival is Keith Jurosko as Grosvenor. The object of their affections, Patience, will be played by Maureen Born. The work lampoons the Pre-Raphaelites and the Esthetic movement, championed by Oscar Wilde. The performances this weekend are tonight and tomorrow at 8 and tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Tickets are $15 to $25 (children and the elderly get a $5 discount). Information: 769-1000.

title: Eight Dealers Suing Wang
description: Eight computer dealers who charge that Wang Laboratories breached a contract entitling them to become authorized Wang dealers have sued the computer company for $32 million.

title: About Real Estate; Manhattan Valley's Painful Town House Experience
description: ''Every organization has one project that causes a lot of pain and headaches,'' said Leah Schneider, executive director of the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation, a nonprofit community-based housing group. ''This has been that project for us.''

title: Dorough and Takas
description: Bob Dorough and Bill Takas will appear on Monday at Gregory's, 1149 First Avenue, at 63d Street (371-2220).

title: DESPITE IMPRESSION CREATED BY STUDY, KANSAS CITY'S POOR ARE NO MIRAGE
description: It was only a few weeks ago that Delia Overbaugh, a 29-year-old mother, found herself deeply moved as she listened to a broadcast report on a homeless family.

title: Jazz Duo at J's
description: Ken Peplowski and Frank Vignola will perform Monday night at J's, 2581 Broadway, between 97th and 98th Streets (666-3600). Mr. Peplowski on clarinet and Mr. Vignola on guitar are in the classic tradition of jazz duos of the 1920's and 30's. From 8 P.M. No cover, $10 minimum at tables, two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: AGENCY SENDING DOOMED CATTLE TO THE NEEDY
description: When the Federal Government began a program last spring to slaughter dairy cows in a move to reduce milk production in the United States, a small, nonprofit agency here decided that it was a waste of a valuable resource.

title: ART: 'ADVENT OF MODERNISM' AT BOOKLYN MUSEUM
description: ''THE ADVENT OF MODERNISM: Post-Impressionism and North American Art, 1900-1918,'' currently on view at the Brooklyn Museum (200 Eastern Parkway), feels a bit like a rough draft or an outline of an exhibition that still needs to be properly filled in and shaped. Crowded into the museum's big fifth-floor rotunda, with some 125 works strung out along walls that seem to go on forever or awkwardly displayed on the space's four fat columns, it also looks like an exhibition waiting to be installed.

title: Travels With Hart
description: As the year draws to a close, Gary Hart of Colorado is closing out his Senate office and preparing the official opening of the new headquarters of his Presidential exploratory committee in Denver.

title: G.M. Sent Perot Packing But Paid for His Silence
description: For H. Ross Perot, the scrappy Texas billionaire who founded the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the year was full of new and resurrected crusades.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE year 1987 will confront the United States, Japan, West Germany and the other industrial countries with the necessity of finding solutions to the most dangerous set of problems that the world economy has faced since the end of the 1920's.

title: GIVE CHIEFS A GIFT, THEY'LL RETURN IT
description: The Kansas City Chiefs are one of those middle-of-the pack playoff teams that scare the opponent.

title: Books of The Times; Life in Cleveland, 1990
description: THE BROOM OF THE SYSTEM. By David Foster Wallace. 467 pages. Viking. Cloth, $18.95; paper, $7.95.

title: MOTHER QUESTIONED ABOUT GIRL FOUND ON CHRISTMAS
description: The police yesterday interviewed the parents of a 3-year-old girl who was found wandering the streets in Brooklyn early on Christmas and held the girl's mother for questioning.

title: DREXEL KEEPING ITS GRIP ON 'JUNK BOND' MARKET
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert seems to be holding its ground in the $120 billion ''junk bond'' market, even after weeks of attack by other Wall Street firms.

title: Mail Deliveries Begin For 1986 Tax Forms
description: Mail carriers, just relieved of their heavy burden of Christmas cards and packages, today began to deliver nearly 100 million pieces of much less welcome mail - 1986 tax forms.

title: Bulls Suspend Sellers
description: The Chicago Bulls, sorely in need of big men, primarily a center, gambled that Brad Sellers might be the answer when they used their No. 1 choice, the ninth pick over all, in last June's college draft to select the Ohio State all-American. But the 7-foot Sellers has failed to crack the starting lineup as a rookie, and in his 26 games, he has averaged 5 points a game and 16 minutes of playing time.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION/ INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
INVESTIGATION OF AGENCIES IS FAULTED
description: An internal review by the city's Department of Investigation places blame for the municipal corruption scandals in part on ''serious deficiencies'' in the network of inspectors general that was intended to detect and prevent wrongdoing.

title: GROUP SAYS U.S. IS LAX IN MONITORING AUTO DEFECTS
description: Automobile defects not addressed by the Department of Transportation in the last six years have led to 500 deaths, 7,000 injuries and 20,000 traffic accidents, a consumer group said today.

title: WALKER, TOON HOPING TO RECEIVE NOTICE
description: One is tightly wound, deer-like, spectacular.

title: TV: 'DIAGNOSIS: MALPRACTICE' ON ABC
description: Medical malpractice suits are at crisis proportions; we've been hearing about them for years. At the same time, the question of whom or what to blame has been elusive. ''Diagnosis: Malpractice,'' an ABC ''Closeup'' documentary to be broadcast at 10 o'clock tonight on Channel 7, fixes the primary blame in the obvious and most sensible place: the malpractice crisis is caused by malpractice.

title: Teen-Ager Is Held In Fatal Stabbing
description: A teen-ager was arraigned yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a man who apparently became offended when the youth bragged that he looked better in women's clothes than the man's girlfriend, the police said.

title: BASQUE FACTION ADMITS BOMBING AT A NWE FRENCH HOTEL IN MADRID
description: Basque separatists said today that they bombed a French-owned hotel here overnight in reprisal for France's crackdown on guerrilla suspects.

title: Pilot Rescued After 9 Hours In Wrecked Plane in Kansas
description: An injured pilot spent almost nine hours in the wreckage of his small plane less than a mile from an airport while teams searching for him groped through dense fog.

title: VICTIM OF ATTACK TIES CAR'S DRIVER TO GANG IN QUEENS
description: The lawyer for a victim of the racially motivated beatings in Howard Beach, Queens, last Saturday charged yesterday that the driver of the car that killed one of the victims was a willful participant in the attack from the beginning.

title: Not Those Tiresome Details
description: My name's Hudge. I was details man at the White House.

title: Prices Steady; Trading Slow
description: Prices of fixed-income securities were virtually unchanged yesterday in extremely light post-Christmas dealings. Most senior dealers had taken a four-day holiday; many of those who came in yesterday left by early afternoon.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Centerre Bancorp., St. Louis, said that it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to buy Goppert Bank and Trust, a unit of Goppert Bancshares Inc., and that the aquisition is expected to be completed in January.

title: Reagans Leave Today On Trip to California
description: President Reagan is to leave Saturday for a one-week California vacation, including his usual New Year's stay at the Palm Springs home of the publisher Walter Annenberg.

title: Japan Exports Of Cars Plunge
description: Japan's exports of cars, trucks and buses fell 15.1 percent in November from a year earlier, to 516,928 units, the sharpest decline on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: FUGITIVE KILLS HIMSELF IN L.I. SIEGE
description: An escaped prisoner who had impersonated a college professor and a Federal agent and was wanted for a string of robberies in the south was found dead today from what the authorities said was a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

title: AILEY DANCERS TO STAGE PAST WORKS BY DUNHAM
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Company has announced that it will reconstruct historical dances choreographed by Katherine Dunham in the 1930's and 40's for performance by the company in its 1987-88 season.

title: MANUEL PROGRESSES ON HIS WAY BACK
description: Lionel Manuel is back, more or less.

title: STRIFE ASSAILED AT QUEENS ATTACK VICTIM'S FUNERAL
description: Hundreds of friends and relatives filled the small Our Lady of Charity Catholic Church last night for the funeral of Michael Griffith, the 23-year-old black man who was killed last week in a racially motivated assault in Howard Beach.

title: KISIO SCORES 3 GOALS
description: This was the night that Kelly Kisio was officially discovered by the Rangers. First he scooted down the middle of the ice and scored with the quickest of wrist shots over the goalie's right shoulder. Second, he broke down the middle and scored. And third, he broke down the middle and scored.

title: Soviet Assails West's Curbs
description: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, today accused the United States of waging an economic war against Communist countries by restricting their access to the latest scientific developments.

title: Menorah Permit Is Revoked
description: A city permit allowing an Orthodox Jewish group to display a menorah at a public park was revoked today, the day that Hanukkah begins, after a civil rights group threatened to sue the city.

title: CRAFTMATIC-CONTOUR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said there are no share earnings because it went public in March.

title: Japan Cutting Gold Coin Issue
description: Japan's Finance Ministry said today that the Government would cut the number of gold coins to be issued early next year to one million from the five million originally planned.

title: A Time to Consider Prison Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: AS PROBLEMS GROW, SO DOES THE PUSH FOR REGIONAL GOVERNMENT
description: As the New York metropolitan region's problems with transportation, energy, water, affordable housing and garbage continue to grow, appearing to become more intractable each day, business and academic leaders are renewing calls for some form of regional government.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 7
description: b-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $79,000.

title: 12 DIE IN SINKING OFF ICELAND
description: A British cargo ship sank today after running onto a rock off the east coast of Iceland, killing all 12 crewmen, Iceland's National Rescue Organization said.

title: HOLIDAY AT HOME FOR TECH STAR
description: For Bruce Dalrymple, today's Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference Holiday Festival game at Madison Square Garden is the continuation of what has already been a dreamlike career.

title: FOR VOYAGER TEAM, BILL-PAYING TIME
description: The pilots of Voyager are set for more globe-trotting, this time using more conventional means for a more mundane purpose.

title: TURMOIL AMONG THE JETS
description: The quarterback is not only the most glamorous player in football, he is a symbolic figure, too. He represents stability in a sport with a high turnover rate. He is a leader, by design, if not nature, the coach's emissary on the playing field. Running backs may tumble and defenses crumble, but a quarterback is expected to withstand a blitz of adversity.

title: TWO U.S. NETWORKS TALK TO SAKHAROV
description: Soviet authorities, in a highly unusual move, permitted two United States television networks to use a Soviet studio tonight to interview Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident who was allowed to return to Moscow this week after seven years of internal exile in Gorky.

title: HEALTH PLAN HELPS ELDERLY TO STAY AT HOME
description: Celia Goldberg felt ''so sick I had nothing to lose'' when she signed up last year for a new kind of insurance for the elderly.

title: NOW 60, MILNE'S 'POOH' IS BIG IN SOVIET UNION
description: There is only one creature who would come up with the notion of holding onto a balloon to float across the sky to attract bees to get some honey. That creature, of course, is that bear of all bears, the venerable Winnie the Pooh, who this year celebrated his 60th birthday.

title: The Bomb Makers' Complacency
description: Facilities for producing America's nuclear warheads are decrepit, safety procedures lax and management complacent. The Reagan Administration did not create these problems but it has made them worse.

title: MCI Write-Offs
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that its write-offs in the fourth quarter would total between $500 million and $550 million. The estimate is at the low end of the range of $500 million to $700 million that the long-distance telephone company, based in Washington, had projected early this month when it announced plans to reduce spending, consolidate operations and lay off a portion of its work force. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, MCI's shares closed at $6.625, down 12.5 cents.

title: Article 485286 -- No Title
description: Under strong pressure to increase its aid to developing nations, Japan has confirmed that it is contributing $2 billion in loans and grants over three years to the World Bank.

title:
PATENTS;
Instrument Measures Nuclear Radiation
description: An instrument that measures radiation, particularly nuclear radiation, was patented this week by three specialists.

title: SOMNOLENT, GROUCHY WALL ST. DOES A GOOD MINUTE'S WORK
description: The head trader at one Wall Street brokerage firm had a bone to pick with John Phelan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: EGYPTIAN WARNS OF RISK GULF WAR WILL WIDEN
description: Egypt's Defense Minister said today that the use of more advanced weapons by both sides in the Iran-Iraq war carried an increased risk that hostilities would spread to neighboring countries.

title: COMPANIES ARE CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Many companies in the New York metropolitan area are contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title:
Patents;
Analyzing Movement Of the Body
description: A CONSULTING engineer has invented a system for analyzing and recording movements of the body.

title: Park Communications
description: Park Communications Inc., a newspaper publisher and operator of television and radio stations, announced today that it had acquired The Milton (Pa.)

title: DISMISS TOWN JUDGE FOR MISUSING FUNDS, PANEL RECOMMENDS
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has recommended the dismissal of a Columbia County justice, saying he mishandled court funds.

title: Hazardous Jogger
description: To the Editor:

title: Yacht's Hull Still an Issue
description: Just when it seemed that the controversy over New Zealand's fiberglass hull was a dead issue in America's Cup racing, the debate has resurfaced. The French Kiss syndicate has asked organizers of the challengers' races for more thorough testing of the New Zealand boat.

title: Is This a Telephone or an Early-Warning System?
description: Life is getting easier. I know, because I had to take a lesson to learn how to use my new telephone, which, once I master the instructions, is supposed to save me time and trouble. The company I work for recently installed an updated ''communications system'' known as the SL-100, which I assume stands for ''Submarine Launched - 100 megatons.''

title: AN ELEGANT KIDS' STORE FAILS
description: Gaye and Roy Raymond scored a smashing success with Victoria's Secret, a small chain of stores offering fine lingerie directly and by mail order: In 1982, they sold the chain to The Limited for a reported $4 million.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago results are on a pro forma basis because the company was not public at the time.

title: THE PRESS IS THRIVING IN LEBANON
description: When the Beirut magazine Al Shiraa reported in early November that a former United States national security adviser had been to Iran to sell weapons, it touched off a controversy that continues to reverberate.

title: 2 SEIZED IN KILLING OF U.S. DRUG AGENT
description: Two Mexicans have been arrested in Los Angeles in connection with the murder of a United States drug agent who was kidnapped and tortured last year while working in Mexico, Federal officials said today.

title: Keeping Kids Safe in Homes
description: Every morning thousands of New York City parents leave their children with a friendly neighbor. If that neighbor cares for at least five children or if any of them are under age 2, she is, strictly speaking, running a family day-care center. Chances are, though, that the Health Department won't know it. Almost all such centers are unlicensed. That means they can operate without smoke detectors, fire exits and fire extinguishers, window guards, first-aid kits and adequate space. Never having asked for clearance from any city agencies, they need never fear inspection.

title: IRAN DENIES RESPONSIBILITY IN HIJACKING OF IRAQI JET
description: Amid a flurry of conflicting claims of responsibility by anonymous callers, Iran yesterday dismissed accusations by Iraq and Jordan that it was behind the hijacking of an Iraqi airliner in which Saudi Arabia has said 62 people were killed.

title: TV: STREISAND'S 'ONE VOICE' ON HBO
description: In ''Barbra Streisand: One Voice,'' on the Home Box Office cable channel tonight at 10, we have the entertainer as singer doing battle with the entertainer as concerned advocate. Fortunately, the singer wins, though just barely.

title: BEIJING IMPOSES RULES BANNING PROTESTS IN CITY
description: Two days after thousands of university students demonstrated on the streets of Beijing, the city issued rules today that make any further public protest virtually illegal.

title: 6 Hurt in Durban Brawl
description: Six people, four white and two black, were hurt and two of them were taken to a hospital after a brawl on an all-race bathing beach south of Durban today, a police spokesman said. The battle started when whites complained that a black bather was indecently dressed and asked her to dress properly, the spokesman said.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Signed Mike Wilson, guard, to a 10-day contract.

title: A Connecticut Dairy Recalls Some Milk
description: The Moser Farms Dairy has announced a voluntary recall of all fluid milk in half-pint containers bearing a Dec. 27 expiration date. The milk is sold in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, the dairy said.

title: MINSTRELS: THE MYTHS AND THE MEN
description: In blackface and clown-white makeup, minstrels of the 1800's were gawkers and buffoons, high steppers and jokesters who lived an illusion on stage through a mask of thick makeup.

title: China Output Up 8.7%
description: China's 1986 industrial output has been valued at about 980 billion yuan, or about $264 billion, for a year-to-year increase of 8.7 percent, the New China News Agency said today.

title: Tracking the Truckers
description: Trying to set a national example in Washington, the American Trucking Association is planning to operate a two-car ''safety patrol'' on the Capital Beltway around the city, reporting unsafe acivities by truckers to their employers and, if necessary, to the police.

title: Taxing Worries Charities
description: The word around town (and the country) is that the new tax law will deal charitable giving a heavy blow.

title: CAPITALS HOLD OFF ISLANDERS
description: The game's pivotal play tonight was a personal matter, and a novelty, shared by a rookie goaltender from Washington and a seasoned Islander forward. Bob Mason, who has become something of a savior for the struggling Capitals, had never faced a penalty shot in his life and was attempting to preserve a 2-1 lead that suddenly was very much in jeopardy.

title: CITY LAW INVALIDATES RUG 'DEAL
description: WHEN W. C. Hall Jr., pastor of the Asbury United Methodist Church in Pasadena, Tex., went shopping in midtown Manhattan in New York in May, he found what he thought was the deal of a lifetime, a $48,000 Hereke Oriental carpet for only $5,000.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1986 results included the previously announced $30 million write-down of certain assets and charges related to uneconomic leases and other commitments associated with its oilfield businesses.

title:
PATENTS;
Composite Materials
description: Two chemists and a physicist were granted a patent this week for strong, stable composite materials that can be molded by compression or injection, are resistant to solvents and other chemicals, and withstand relatively high temperatures. They were invented by Wen-Fang Hwang and Thaddeus E. Helminisk, chemists, and Donald R. Wiff, a physicist. They assigned patent No. 4,631,318 to the Research Corporation, a foundation with offices in Tucson, Ariz., and Port Washington, L.I. Licenses are being offered to industry for development and production.

title: Argentine Austral Shift
description: Argentina's central bank adjusted the austral down by 0.96 percent against the dollar at its morning fixing today, dealers said. They said the bank quoted the dollar at 1.243 australs, compared with the previous rate of 1.231. It was the sixth downward adjustment of the austral in December, bringing the total devaluation this month to 5.3 percent.

title: CZYZ RETAINS TITLE
description: Bobby Czyz retained his International Boxing Federation light heavyweight title tonight when he knocked out David Sears in 61 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 15-round bout.

title: Zale Jewelry Chain Takeover Complete
description: Peoples Jewelers Ltd. and Swarovski International Holdings A.G. of Switzerland said they had completed an estimated $650 million takeover of the Zale Corporation, the largest publicly held jewelry store chain in the United States.

title: The Long Road That Led to Daytop Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Moves Toward a Two-Party System
description: The events of the past few months, especially the Dec. 6 parliamentary election, show that Taiwan is moving steadily toward a more representative government and a two-party political system. This is happening just as Beijing is making clear, in its talks with Hong Kong representatives, that it is unlikely to allow either development after it takes over the British colony in 1997.

title: ELSA LANCHESTER, 84, IS DEAD; ACTRESS PORTRAYED ECCENTRICS
description: Elsa Lanchester, the stage and screen actress perhaps best known for eccentric and comic roles such as the monster's wife in ''The Bride of Frankenstein,'' died of pneumonia today at the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 84 years old.

title: CHILD'S PLAY: FUNCTIONING, FULL-SCALE SHERMAN TANK
description: It may be an unusual toy, but 6-year-old Ritchie Alegre and a friend finally persuaded his father to buy one - a genuine, 70,000-pound, World War II-vintage Sherman tank in working order.

title: CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MORE DOCTORS LOOK TO POSTS WITH SALARIES, REPORT SAYS
description: Increasing economic pressures will force more doctors to seek salaried jobs with established health-care organizations rather than to open private practices, a new report concludes.

title: Musical Variety
description: The Oil City Symphony, a quartet of actors and musicians, will give two performances on New Year's Eve at the South Street Theater, 424 West 42d Street. The shows - at 8 and 11 P.M. - will feature a combination of classical, ragtime, rock, gospel and big-band music. Tickets are $20 for the 8 P.M. show and $25 at 11 P.M. Reservations: 279-4200.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Murphy has been elevated from assistant to head coach of football at the University of Maine. He replaces Eugene (Buddy) Teevans, who left to become the Dartmouth coach. Nine months younger than Teevans, the 30-year-old Murphy thus becomes the nation's youngest Division I-A or Division I-AA football coach. . . . Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguin center, has been selected the city's man of year.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to a partnership in July 1985.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Davis Cup Tennis Swedes Tie Australians: Mikael Pernfors, who had played only four previous matches on grass, scored a surprise 6-3, 6-1, 6-3 victory over Paul McNamee yesterday and lifted Sweden into a 1-1 tie with Sweden in the Davis Cup final in Melbourne, Australia. Pat Cash gave Australia its victory by outlasting Stefan Edberg, Sweden's No. 1 player, 13-11, 13-11, 6-4. Pernfors, who played tennis at the University of Georgia, stunned a sellout crowd of 11,000 with his 91-minute victory over the 32-year-old McNamee.(AP) Horse Racing Ferdinand Returns in Form: Ferdinand, the Kentucky Derby winner, making his first start in six months, came from well off the pace yesterday to score a 1 1/4-length victory over Snow Chief in the $117,300 Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif. Ferdinand was timed in 1:21 3/5, well off the track record of 1:20 set by Spectacular Bid in this event in 1980. Ridden by Bill Shoemaker, Ferdinand was last at the start of the seven-furlong race, but worked his way through the field of 12 until the stretch. There, he caught Snow Chief in the final quarter and pulled away for the triumph. Snow Chief, also making his first start in six months, held on for second. A long shot, Don B. Blue, was third.(UPI) M.I.S.L.

title: RENAISSANCE MUSIC
description: The New York Cornet and Sackbut Ensemble, featuring the soprano Julianne Baird, will present vocal and instrumental works of the Renaissance at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street tomorrow night at 8. Admission is $8.50; information: 362-8719.

title: TOKYO REPORTS DIP IN ITS TRADE SURPLUS
description: Japan's huge trade surplus shrank slightly last month, according to figures released today by the Finance Ministry. The decline pleased Government officials, who face growing international hostility over the nation's high level of exports and low level of imports.

title: Hawks Sign Wilson
description: The Atlanta Hawks have signed Mike Wilson, a journeyman guard who was cut last month by the Nets, to a 10-day contract in hopes that he might fill the gap left by the injured Spud Webb. Webb, who backed up Glenn (Doc) Rivers at point guard, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Tuesday and is expected to be sidelined for about three months. . . . The Golden State Warriors, who have been doing well without Purvis Short, their high scorer, may have to wait longer than expected for the 6-7 forward's return.

title: NICARAGUA OFFERS REBEL AMNESTY
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has proposed that Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras be returned under an amnesty program or sent to other countries, the official Barricada newspaper reported today.

title: IRAQ SAID TO REGAIN CONTROL OF ISLES AFTER A 24-HOUR IRANIAN OFFENSIVE
description: Iraq regained control today of four islands in a waterway dividing Iran and Iraq after a 24-hour Iranian offensive, United States Government officials said.

title: BOSWORTH TELLS OF STEROID USE
description: A contrite, hurt and, at the same time, defiant Brian Bosworth apologized today to his teammates and the public for being ruled ineligible to play with Oklahoma against Arkansas in the Orange Bowl Jan. 1 because a test showed the presence of steroids in his body.

title: ISRAELIS OBJECT TO CHANGES IN PLAN FOR O'CONNOR'S VISIT TO JERUSALEM
description: A major diplomatic dispute has erupted over the itinerary here of the Archbishop of New York during a Middle East trip in which he plans to visit Israel beginning Jan. 1.

title: LATE SURGE LIFTS SALES OF RETAILERS
description: With a sales surge in the final week, the 1986 Christmas shopping season ended strongly but with less than the normal seasonal increases, retailers around the nation said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Waste Removal Device
description: Burton Axelrod, a plumber in Girard, Pa., was awarded a patent this week for a device that, with the aid of microwaves, removes solid waste from household sewage and incinerates it. The gaseous products are vented to the atmosphere and the ash is removed by vacuum. Patent 4,631,133 is assigned to Axelrod R.&D.; Inc., Austin, Tex.

title: Bridge; Using Transfer Bid Can Give More Options to Opponent
description: An overwhelming majority of experts now favor the transfer bid, introduced to American players by the late Oswald Jacoby three decades ago.

title: Knudsen Foods In Another Sale
description: Knudsen Foods Inc., the troubled West Coast dairy concern, said it had agreed to sell operations in Texas and Louisiana for $25.5 million to Associated Milk Producers Inc., a dairy cooperative in Arlington, Tex.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 30
REAGAN FORMS UNIT FOR COORDINATING IRAN CRISIS MOVES
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan was creating a special team to coordinate the Administration's responses and strategy in the Iran-contra arms affair, and that it would be headed by David M. Abshire, the departing delegate to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
TV: DRUNKEN DRIVING, A DOCUMENTARY ON 13
description: Strictures about drinking and driving are not new. Indeed, in recent years they have multiplied. More states have adopted laws to punish drunken drivers. In a way, however, the laws are misdirected. They penalize drivers after they have been drinking; they do not necessarily prevent drivers from drinking. ''Drinking and Driving: The Toll, the Tears,'' a remarkable documentary, tries to bridge the gap.

title: Fahd Sees $18 Price as Floor
description: The $18-a-barrel goal of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries is only a minimum price sought by the group, Saudi Arabia's King Fahd said.

title: Shoprite Sale by Big V
description: Big V Supermarkets Inc., which owns and operates Shoprite supermarkets, said today that it had sold its Shoprite store and shopping center in Vestal, N.Y., to FGR Realty. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed but the company said the sale would produce a substantial gain in fourth-quarter results. Big V said the sale left it with 32 Shoprite markets and 10 shopping centers in New York State.

title: Yesterday's Closings
description: All stock exchanges, most commodity markets and banks and some businesses were open yesterday. But Federal offices and the

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit from a tax benefit arising from a net operating loss carryforward of $143,000. c-Net loss

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
MICRON TECHOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 4
SANDINISTA STRATEGY: BORDER PRESSURE
description: The Nicaraguan Government is pursuing a military strategy of ''forward defense'' in its war against the American-backed rebels, Sandinista officials say.

title: Flu Vaccine Shortage Laid to Exaggeration
description: Misleading information about the risk of a new strain of influenza has led to a shortage of the vaccine, a consumer group has charged.

title: M.T.A. IS SPREADING NEWS OF PROGRESS
description: For a while now the Transit Authority has been taking its message directly to its customers, informing riders in black-and-orange-bordered signs of line reroutings and major service delays. Lately, though, the news from the authority's Jay Street headquarters has been distinctly upbeat. A new batch of signs, put up in stations, cars and buses, extol the virtues of the authority's reconstruction efforts. ''New and Overhauled Cars - Subway cars like they ought to be'' is the headline on one. ''Fast Track - the trains are getting up to speed again'' reads another.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $1,000. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $4,749,000.

title: Count McLaughlin Out
description: Ann Dore McLaughlin, the Under Secretary of the Interior who has been mentioned frequently as a possible successor to Larry Speakes as the White House spokesman, plans to resign her post soon, but to work in private industry and lecture, not to speak on behalf of the President.

title: SOMALI LEADER GETS 99.9%
description: Somalia's official radio announced today that President Mohammed Siad Barre had won a new seven-year term with more than 99.9 percent of the vote in an uncontested election.

title: W.R. Grace Sells Restaurant Group
description: W. R. Grace & Company, which has been undergoing a major restructuring, completed the sale of its 690-unit restaurant group to a new company led by the group's management. Grace said the purchase price of $536.7 million might be adjusted, depending on the new company's performance, but a spokesman said that Grace expected to make a profit on the deal.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 5. 1. Mordechai Vanunu, an Israeli nuclear technician who sold information about his country's atomic weapons program to a British newspaper and then was mysteriously returned to Israel, held up his hand to journalists as he was taken to court in Jerusalem. The message said he had been abducted by Israelis in Rome after arriving there on a flight from London. 2. Rescind the state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 3. Paper. 4. Chinatown. 5. A public-opinion poll published in The Des Moines Register showed that Mr. Bush's standing among voters in that state, the site of the first major test in the 1988 Presidential campaign, has plummeted as a result of the Iranian arms controversy. 6. The Greyhound Corporation is selling its bus operations. 7. The French Government's Center of Mail Research, which is the place in France that receives letters addressed to Santa Claus, is in the Gironde, one of the country's richest wine regions. 8. Texas. 9. The first Teflon-coated cookware to be produced in the United States. 10. Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident, was warmly greeted on his return to Moscow after seven years of exile in Gorky. 11. Contempt. Researchers have found that it is expressed on only one side of the face, whereas the other feelings manifest themselves symmetrically. 12. The Duke and Duchess of Windsor. 13. The police banned protests without a permit by students who had been demonstrating for broader democratic rights and freedom of the press and expression. 14.

title: NEW CHIEF FOR 'DETERIORATING' SUFFOLK
description: Michael A. LoGrande, who will become Suffolk County's top official today, is an immigrant to Long Island, one of the hundreds of thousands of people who moved here to flee the tempest of New York City. But Mr. LoGrande, a

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CREATION OF NATIONAL PARK DISTURBS THE QUIET DESOLATION OF GREAT BASIN
description: Here in eastern Nevada, everything is dry: The climate, the rivers, the humor. ''We like to say that nobody moves to Baker - they're committed here,'' said Reita Berger, co-owner of the Outlaw Bar and Cafe on Main Street.

title: Archbishop Leaves Hospital
description: Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle has been released from the Providence Medical Center here after surgery for prostate cancer. His physician, Dr. Jerry Minzel, authorized the release Wednesday because the 65-year-old prelate's recovery ''has gone very smoothly,'' said the Rev. Michael Ryan, chancellor and vicar general of the Roman Catholic archdiocese here. The Archbishop, who has been involved in a running dispute with the Vatican over some of his liberal stands, had been expected to be spend up to 18 days in the hospital after his surgery Dec. 16.

title: KOENIG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BankAmerica Sale
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it had closed the sale of the Banca d'America e d'Italia to Deutsche Bank A.G. for $603 million. The sale of its 98.3 percent stake in the Italian bank, which had assets of $4.2 billion and a book value of $321 million, should give BankAmerica a $282 million pretax gain in the fourth quarter. Analysts have said the sale would give the bank a profit for the quarter.

title: INSIDE
description: Iran Denies Hijacking Role Iran dismissed accusations by Iraq and Jordan that it was behind the hijacking of an Iraqi plane in which 62 people reportedly died.

title: Award to Retired Men Upheld
description: A $43.6 million award to thousands of retired men who contended that Florida's retirement system for government workers was sexually biased has been upheld by a Federal appeals court.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32. 1. Palm readers saw this secret message. Whose palm is it and what did the message say? 2. Shortly after he becomes Governor of Arizona next month, Evan Mecham plans to do something no governor has done. What is it? 3. The Voyager, the experimental aircraft that completed the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel, was made of plastic and another material. What is it? 4. In one untidy area of Manhattan, demand for commercial real estate is so strong that operators of vegetable stalls near a bustling intersection pay more rent per square foot than the owners of Tiffany & Company on Fifth Avenue. The area is (Chinatown/Little Italy/Tribeca). 5. ''I don't think it's bad to get your people all fired up and realize they have a lot of work to do,'' said Vice President Bush. To what was he referring? 6. After opening up the nation to travelers for 73 years, a transportation company said it would sell what made it famous. Identify what that is. 7. Oui, Vanessa. He is in a Bordeaux atelier. Explain. 8. A small but growing number of professionals are emigrating from a state that, for the first time, has more people moving out of it than into it. What state is it? 9. A product called the Happy Pan celebrated its 25th anniversary.

title: Trucks Are Already Too Big for Highway Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of Yen
description: Hiromitsu Ochiai, a three-time triple crown winner in the Japanese Baseball League, was traded last Tuesday by the Lotte Orions to the Chunichi Dragons. Yesterday, he signed a contract worth 130 million yen ($807,000) for next year, which would make him the first Japanese baseball player to earn more than 100 million yen ($621,000) in a season. The Kyodo News Service said the agreement marked an estimated increase of 33 million yen ($207,000) over 1986.

title: 2 Trains Derail in Illinois
description: Two trains collided and derailed today, forcing the evacuation of about 300 people from their homes as a precaution because one of the trains contained hazardous materials. No injuries were reported in the 8 A.M. accident at the Alton & Southern Railway Company's yard in south-central East St. Louis, a railroad official said. At least two tanker cars on one of the trains contained traces of phosphoric acid and other hazardous materials.

title: OPTIONS PROPOSAL CRITICIZED
description: High-technology companies and their financial backers are strongly criticizing a proposed accounting change that could threaten the use by such companies of employee stock options for financing and to attract and keep talented employees.

title: HILL QUIETLY SHARES KNICK JOY
description: In the 25 days since he woke up one morning to find himself a head coach for the first time, Bob Hill has lost 15 pounds. He said he sometimes forgets to eat. He hasn't slept much, either, which becomes evident as he yawns uncontrollably just a few minutes into a conversation.

title: FOOD SURPLUS MAY BANKRUPT EUROPEAN BLOC
description: Western Europe's food surpluses, which have saddled taxpayers with crippling bills and created sharp political tensions with the rest of the world, are now threatening to push the European Community into bankruptcy early next year.

title: LAWYER IN QUEENS CASE IS KNOWN FOR MAJOR TRIALS
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr. has been involved in many widely publicized cases involving juveniles, and colleagues say he has often come up with startling theories.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY WEEKEND

title: POLICE INQUIRY INTO MOTORIST CONTRADICTS LAWYER'S STAND
description: The police said yesterday that their investigation of the accident in Howard Beach, Queens, that killed Michael Griffith indicated that the motorist who struck him was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder.

title: China Arrests 2 as Spies
description: Two Chinese men have been arrested and charged with spying for South Korea, the Chinese television said tonight. It said the pair, Li Xihua and Zho Yongdou, were arrested by public security officials at Tumen, in Jilin Province near the border with North Korea. The television said the two were recruited by Seoul officials when they visited their relatives in South Korea in 1985.

title: SHANGHAI, WHERE PROTEST IS A TRADITION
description: In May 1919, students in this port city, following the lead of students in Beijing, organized a city-wide protest against the Chinese Government's humiliating capitulation to Japan's colonial designs.

title: CAVALIERS SURVIVE LATE RALLY BY NETS
description: Ron Harper, a rookie, scored 25 points and John Bagley added 21 as the Cleveland Cavaliers held off a New Jersey rally in the final period to defeat the Nets, 121-112, tonight.

title: Peres Sees a Possibility Of Palestinian Solution
description: The Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, says a negotiated solution to the Palestinian problem based on ''an equal right to a life of dignity and self-expression'' seems more imaginable now than ever before.

title: SOFTWARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Soviet Solar Power Station
description: The Soviet Union's first solar power station began commercial service in the Ukraine today, the official press agency Tass said. Tass said the station, with a capacity of 5,000 kilowatts, was in the Crimean peninsula, but it did not give an exact location.

title: Times Mirror Deal
description: The Times Mirror Company said it had purchased the 60 percent of the stock of Rhode Island Cable Television that it did not already own.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Count Miller In
description: Marcia Miller has been hired by the incoming Democratic majority to become a trade specialist for the Senate Finance Committee, an indication that the panel will make a strong push for some kind of legislation to protect textiles against lower-priced imports, since that is a field in which Miss Miller has a strong background.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $591,000 and $1,334,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The 1985 results are restated for reclassification of discontinued operations.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
IS THE MONA LISA LAUGHING AT US?
description: It was the latest in a 500-year-old tradition of clever theories explaining the sly smile, the veiled hair, the crossed hands, the regal pose: the Mona Lisa was not a woman at all, but a man. She was, in fact, Leonardo da Vinci himself in the guise of a woman.

title: IN JERSEY, JAPANESE-STYLE NEW YEAR'S
description: For the transient Japanese community concentrated here, the New Year celebration will not be the same as it is in Japan, but it will still be very Japanese. Many people will telephone relatives in Japan to wish them well and to hear the ringing of temple bells at the stroke of midnight Japanese time. The Aki Oriental Food Company has imported such holiday delicacies as sweetened sardines. The Dorcas Japanese bakery has special cakes on hand. And next Saturday there will be celebrations at the Japanese school in nearby Ridgefield.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1986
description: International

title: ON READERS' RAGES, GRIEVANCES AND INSPIRATIONS
description: Over the past few months, just about every kind of complaint has been registered about this column, from disparagement of mother's home cooking to the use of slang, from an inability to find a recommended store to the proper method for opening a pomegranate. But before pomegranates, a word from maligned mothers who think their cooking is better than that of any restaurant.

title: Egyptian Police Arrest 111 During Clashes Over Religion
description: The police arrested 111 people during street clashes today with Moslem militants demanding the application of Islamic law in Egypt, security officials said.

title: Trucks Are Already Too Big for Highway Safety; India's Bad Example
description: To the Editor:

title: MARIE BULLOCK, 75, FOUNDED AND LED ACADEMY OF POETS
description: Marie Bullock, founder and president of the Academy of American Poets, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 75 years old.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE HUNGARIANS OF RUMANIA: A DELICATE DISPUTE
description: Hungary and Rumania are engaged in an increasingly public struggle over one of this region's historically divisive issues: minority rights.

KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 11
description: b-Net income

title: Federal Judges vs. Science
description: Katie Wells was born in 1981 with serious birth defects. Her parents attributed them to a contraceptive jelly and sued the maker, Ortho Pharmaceutical. Judge Marvin Shoob of the U.S. District Court in Georgia ruled they had proved their case and assessed $5 million in damages against Ortho. The Court of Appeals declined to overturn the judgment and last month the Supreme Court refused to intervene. What is wrong with that?

title: REPORT OF VIOLENCE IN QUEENS RETRACTED BY ACCIDENT VICTIM
description: New racial violence was reported in Queens yesterday, but the police soon discovered that the incident had been invented by the victim to disguise a household accident.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 YOUNG WONERS PIN HOPES ON HARLEM
description: Allan Mannarelli, 30 years old, and Erik Jacobs, 27, eventually want to take over Gulf and Western and sign themselves as players for the Knicks. In the meantime they are slum busters.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Protest March Civil rights groups will lead a march down Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens, today in response to the death of Michael Griffith, a black man who was struck and killed by a car after being beaten by a group of white teen-agers earlier this month. 12 P.M., Cross Bay Boulevard and Belt Parkway, Howard Beach. Trouble Spots for Traffic

title: The Teaching Bug
description: It's catching. While he was chairman of the

title: KEY RATES
BANK SWITCHES OFTEN DIFFICULT
description: PAUL CAPELLI, a young executive, came to New York from another state recently to start a new job and, like many other transferees, decided to open a checking account at a local bank.

title: U.S. Orders Increase In Female Laborers
description: The Federal Highway Administration has told the state to increase the number of female construction workers on federally financed highway and bridge projects in New Jersey, a state official said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''David Abshire has what it takes - both the respect and the experience - to be the President's point man on the Iran affair.'' - Senator Robert Dole,

title: CHICAGO MAYORAL RACE: CHAOTIC SCRAMBLE IS ON
description: There are three rules to running for mayor of Chicago. Unfortunately, no one knows what they are.

title: Cubans Adrift Are Rescued
description: Four Cubans, one of them dead, were found floating on a makeshift inner-tube raft in the Straits of Florida off Key West on Christmas Day, the Coast Guard reported today. Officials said the men had been adrift for four days. Two of the survivors were turned over to immigration officials and the third was taken to Florida Keys Memorial Hospital for treatment of exposure.

title: FUEL LEAK DELAYS RIVER SHIPPING
description: The Des Plaines River was reopened to shipping today after cleanup crews contained a pipeline leak that had spilled up to 1,000 gallons of a petroleum product into the river, the authorities said.

title: Airbus Engine Deal For 3-Nation Group
description: Airbus Industrie, the European plane manufacturing consortium, said today that it had chosen a jet engine designed by a group of American, British and Japanese engine makers to power its planned A340 long-haul airliner.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $97,500 for the year. c-Net income

title: Nebraska Incident
description: Tom Osborne, the Nebraska football coach, whose team has a New Year's Day date with Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl, blamed the arrests of nine of his players early Wednesday in the French Quarter of New Orleans on a police misunderstanding. The nine were detained after what the police said was a warning issued for unruly behavior that included shouting obscenities and whacking parked cars. All were immediately released by a traffic judge, and Osborne said no disciplinary action was planned.

title: U.S MERCENARIES ESCAPE BRAZIL TO TELL OF PLAN TO OVERTHROW AFRICAN LEADER
description: Two American mercenaries have escaped from a Brazilian prison and returned to the United States to tell a tangled tale of a foiled effort to overthrow the Government of Ghana.

title: How U.S. Fiscal Policy Affects U.N. Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY INSURERS COVET BROKERS
description: One result of the 1986 tax law that few people in or out of Congress anticipated is that life insurance companies have a greater incentive to acquire brokerage firms.

title: CHIANG'S WIDOW: A POLITICAL RIDDLE
description: Although she is at least in her 80's and uses a wheelchair, Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek casts a long and perplexing shadow over Taiwan's politics.

title: BIT OF HISTORY BURNS IN CHRISTMAS DAY FIRE AT CHURCH NEAR BOSTON
description: For 130 years the bell at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church pealed each Sunday to call worshipers to the imposing white structure, a center of community life that was built in 1810.

title: Imported Car for Japan
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation is importing for sale in Japan passenger cars made by an Australian subsidiary, an official of the corporation said today. The recent rise of the yen against the Australian dollar makes it possible to sell the imported cars at prices below those of many comparable domestically produced models, he said. Twenty of the medium-size cars made by Australia Mitsubishi Motors Ltd. on a sample basis have been sold and 50 to 100 cars may be imported annually, the spokesman said.

title: Indians of South America Still Reap Colonialism's Bitter Harvest
description: To the Editor:

title: Income Drops For Venezuela
description: Venezuela's foreign exchange income dropped $5 billion and revenues will be reduced by 18 percent in 1986 from 1985's levels, the Finance Ministry has announced.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $301,000 and $3,798,482 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Incluedes a gain of $696,039 from the sale of real estate. Share earnings reflect a 5-percent stock dividend paid Sept. 2.

title: TASS REPORTS MACHINE WORK AT MINE BLAST SITE
description: Coal miners were working alongside men installing new equipment when a fatal methane gas explosion rocked a Ukrainian coal mine this week, Soviet reports said today.

description: Markets

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV -MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WPAT 930 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS.

title: FRENCH QUARTER AQUARIAUM: BOON OR BOONDOGGLE?
description: As Louisiana bickers over solutions to its oil-related economic crunch, a quieter but no less acid dispute is simmering over an aquarium proposed for the French Quarter.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ACA JOE EASTERN reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income

title: FOR ABSHIRE, NEW STEP IN CAREER AS CONCILIATOR
description: David M. Abshire, the 60-year-old foreign-policy professional named by President Reagan to help steer the White House through the Iran-contra arms crisis, is an affable and undramatic Republican who has proved adept at working with both parties.

title: Great Debate on the Great Outdoors
description: The lobbying response to the report of the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors is heavy, heated and starting to turn a bit nasty. And the report won't even be issued for several more weeks.

title: Manley Misses Practice
description: With their first playoff game in two seasons two days away, the Washington Redskins found their preparations disrupted today when Dexter Manley, their leading pass rusher, failed to report for practice.

title: Surgery Is Ruled Out For Jean Harris
description: A cardiologist at the Westchester County Medical Center decided yesterday against heart surgery for Jean Harris, the convicted killer of Dr. Herman Tarnower, author of the ''Scarsdale Diet'' and a prominent cardiologist.

title: BARGAINS AND LEISURE TYPIFY DEC. 26
description: People returning Christmas presents collided in the department stores aisles yesterday with people shopping for Hanukkah presents. People who had not yet sent cards for Christmas 1986 were lined up behind people buying marked-down cards for Christmas 1987.

title: Charity Isn't Taxing
description: There is a foreboding implication in the current year-end deluge of fund-raising appeals: give now - before it is too late.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reagan's Happy New Year?
description: Everything looks the same in Washington now, shining in the winter sun, but in a way things are quite different. It's not only a New Year approaching but a new prospect for all the main characters on this political stage.

title: NICARAGUA AGREES WITH SOVIET ON AID
description: A senior Nicaraguan leader has returned from Moscow with promises of aid that the Sandinista Government said would be ''of great importance.''

title: BLACK WOMEN'S OUTLOOK IN WHITNEY FILM SERIES
description: THREE programs of films and videotapes by black women, telling stories that its organizer says ''other film makers and video artists simply have not told,'' will be shown by the Whitney Museum of American Art starting Tuesday.

title: LOOK AT YOUR BAD, BORING LIVES
description: CHEKHOV By Henri Troyat. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. Illustrated. 364 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: WITH THE FIRST CANDLE, MEMORIES OF A HANUKKAH LONG AGO
