description: IT was the start of the seven-day Feast of Lights, Hanukkah, and at dusk, as I took the large bronze menorah down from the mantle piece, memories came flooding in:

title: Game of Survival
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A PALACE FOR BOOKS
description: THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY: Its Architecture and Decoration (Norton, $35) by Henry Hope Reed is not about the treasures stored inside the building but a lavish tribute in word and photograph to the architecture and decoration of the palatial structure on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. This handsome volume pokes into every cranny, every archway, every artifact - from wastebasket to water fountain to flagpole - and forces us to concentrate on the wealth of detail that went into the assemblage of this fantastic storehouse.

title: PRIVATE WELFARE GROUP TO EXPAND ITS PROGRAMS FOR THE POOR
description: With an overhauled program, expanded staff and larger financial resources, the Community Service Society of New York will increase its services to the poor, according to its general director, David R. Jones.

title: Greyhound Hands Over the Wheel
description: After 73 years on the road, during which its racing dog emblem became a symbol of American restlessness and mobility as well as of cheap and reliable travel, the Greyhound Corporation is turning the driving over to someone else.

title: AUSTRALIA TAKES DOUBLES FOR 2-1 MARGIN
description: Pat Cash and John Fitzgerald defeated Sweden's world doubles champions, Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd, 6-3, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1, today and moved Australia to within one victory of ending Sweden's two-year reign as Davis Cup champion.

title: Challenge Facing Cherokee Chief
description: THE descendants of ''The Trail of Tears'' - the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma - broke new ground a year ago this month by installing Wilma P. Mankiller, the daughter of a full-blooded Cherokee father and a white mother, as Chief. She became the first woman to lead a large Indian tribe in the United States.

title: IT WASN'T SUCH A BAD YEAR AFTER ALL
description: When in doubt, say it was a bad year. Nobody would dare question you. It also means that you don't have to defend yourself. When you cite such self-proclaiming lulus as Prince's ''Under the Cherry Moon'' and Willard Huyck's ''Howard the Duck,'' all can nod in safe agreement that movies are continuing the downhill slide they began sometime before the advent of the talkies. I had no idea of the extent of this alienation until, not long ago, a film scholar said to me, quite seriously, ''I don't think I want to see 'The Birth of a Nation' anymore.''

title: Karen Dell, Teacher, Weds William Stratton, a Student
description: The Presbyterian Church of Old Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen Lee Dell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glen Arthur Dell of Old Greenwich, to William Arthur Stratton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Stratton Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Douglas James Rumford performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Jaclynn Faffer, Official Of Jewish Appeal, Marries
description: Dr. Jaclynn Ila Faffer, director of human services for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, and Dr. Leonard Silverstein, a senior human factors engineer for the Grumman Aerospace Corporation in Bethpage, L.I., were married last night at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $350,000 120 Ocean Avenue 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 56-year-old colonial; center hall, 2 fireplaces, large riverfront boathouse; taxes $7,000. Belle Terre $457,000 19 High Path 7-bedroom, 4-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; hearth fireplace, dual staircases, 3-car garage, 1.9 acres; taxes $5,200.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOW FOR DOLL FANCIERS
description: FOR SERIOUS antiques collectors and comparison shoppers, thematic shows offer a feast of opportunity for browsing and buying.

title: HOW CAN ZONING BE USED TO CREATE HOUSING OPTIONS?
description: ON Nov. 19, 1985, the headline in a local newspaper announced:

title: Mixing Judges And Politics
description: I found Robert Gottlieb's logic in ''Politics and Judges Shouldn't Mix'' badly flawed. Mr. Gottlieb argues that the current system of party selection of judges is undemocratic and fails to protect those he calls competent judges who must run for re-election.

title: SMALL POST OFFICES STRUGGLE AS VOLUME OF MAIL SURGES
description: DOROTHY SANKER, postmaster of the Purdys post office in North Salem, likes to tell of the three elderly ladies who meet each day at the post office on their way to the senior citizens center, stop on their way back to check on their mail, and later in the afternoon stop again to chat a little and ''just to be sure nothing else came in.''

title: Miss Van Cleve to Wed John Van Doren
description: Sarah L. Van Cleve, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Van Cleve of LaDue, Mo., and John C. L. Van Doren, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Van Doren of Cornwall, Conn., plan to be married in June, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Britain's Whole Earth Guru
description: The article on James Lovelock and his Gaia hypothesis contained some misleading information. One might inadvertently infer that microorganisms produce heat-regulating, volatile compounds with the goal of maintaining the Earth's atmospheric heat balance.

title:
CRAFTS;
STATE MUSEUM: 'FIBER, METAL AND WOOD'
description: TRADITIONALLY, crafts have been a regional endeavor, made by local artisans, bought and sold at markets or fairs and treasured as cultural artifacts.

title: Boston Claims Custom House
description: BOSTON'S first skyscraper will finally belong to the city it once dominated, now that the Federal Government, which has owned the 495-foot Custom House since it was built in 1847, has agreed to sell the landmark to the city for $11 million.

title: John Q. Donovan Has L.I. Wedding
description: At St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., yesterday Kathleen Ann O'Connor and John Quinn Donovan, 1986 graduates of Princeton University, were married by Msgr. Walter E. Simmons.

title: Program for the Gifted: How Big a Gift Is It?
description: While I was peddling my educational wares a few short years ago in a pristine elementary school overlooking Huntington Harbor, a P.A. announcement persistently demanded, ''Will the gifted come to the bus for your field trip!''

title: Julia Fletcher Averett Weds
description: Julia Fletcher Averett, widow of Elliott Averett of New Vernon, N.J., former chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Edwin Fullarton Peet, a widower and former president of Burns Brothers & Denton, an affiliate in New York of the Toronto investment-banking house of the same name. He retired as an institutional-bond salesman for Wood, Struthers & Winthrop in New York. The Rev. George E. Chorba 3d performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

title: MEASURING THE SUCCESS OF SEEK 20 YEARS LATER
description: IN July 1966, Governor Rockefeller signed a bill that introduced radical changes at the City University of New York. Enacted in response to criticism that black and Hispanic youths were underrepresented in the city's university system, the new law provided the money needed to open the doors of its prestigious four-year colleges to ''educationally and economically'' disadvantaged students who otherwise would have been ineligible for admission.

title: THE HOWARD BEACH INQUIRY: MANY KEY QUESTIONS PERSIST
description: The death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, in what is widely perceived as the worst racial incident in New York City in years has, after more than a week of intense scrutiny, left a host of unanswered questions.

title: In Business To Treat Cancer
description: Those of us at Biotherapeutics thought Ms. Henig's article was balanced and fair.

title: ROLE OF DRIVER CALLED CURCIAL TO MURDER CASE IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Whether the driver of a car that killed a black man fleeing a white gang was part of the gang could be crucial to efforts to convict the gang's members of murder, legal experts say.

title: SHUTTLE CHANGING IN EXTENSIVE WAYS TO FOSTER SAFETY
description: Piece by painstaking piece, NASA is revamping the space shuttle system that disintegrated, along with a good measure of the nation's technological self-confidence, 11 months ago today.

title: Moving to Mobility
description: The Pentagon doesn't really want it, the White House may be playing games with it, and the new weapon will cost billions that the deficit doom-shouters will be reluctant to put up. Nevertheless, President Reagan's decision to seek production of the mobile Midgetman missile may prove to be his most important contribution to national security.

title: THE LINGUA AMERICANA IS 'TUTTO O.K.' IN ITALY
description: Unlike the French, who have tried to limit American influences, Italians think American culture is ''tutto O.K.''

title: PENTAGON TIGHTENS ITS BUYING RULES
description: FOUR times in six years, the Pentagon has changed the nameplates on the offices in which decisions about weapon purchases are made. The latest procurement czar, Richard Godwin, a former Bechtel Corporation executive who was sworn in this fall, holds a newly created title, Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition. He will be dealing with a system of developing and buying arms that has been altered dramatically in the years since the Reagan Administration's defense buildup began.

title: Gains and Losses In City's Efforts To Add Housing
description: It was almost a tie for New York City's housing shortage last week: Mayor Koch announced plans to renovate nearly 5,200 apartments in abandoned city-owned buildings, and a State Supreme Court judge issued a ruling that could reduce the potential number of single-occupancy hotel rooms by as many as 10,000.

title: 3 WAYS TO PLAY BACH, AND ALL VALID
description: Three recent recordings of Bach's choral music, each differing in interpretation, show how different approaches can all be valid. Of primary interest because of the magnitude of the work is John Eliot Gardiner's version of the Mass in B minor (Archiv CD 415514 AH2, two disks). The English conductor, who has made quite a reputation in the field of Baroque music, leads the Monteverdi Choir and the English Baroque Soloists. The singers number 30 (women sopranos, the rest men), and the many soloists are drawn from that group. Their names will not be familiar to most American listeners, but they are equal to the demands made on them. The instrumental ensemble of 38 uses period instruments.

title: GETTING FIRED ISN'T WHAT IT USED TO BE
description: ''Sacked: Why Good People Get Fired and How to Avoid It,'' by Richard Gould. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., N.Y. 202 pages, $18.95. LEE Iacocca's success at Chrysler after he was fired as president of the Ford Motor Company - not to mention his boasting about it in his best-selling autobiography - has helped remove some of the stigma of dismissal. But it has not eliminated the myths surrounding firings.

title: THREE-CHORD MUSIC IN A THREE-PIECE SUIT
description: ROCK OF AGES The Rolling Stone History of Rock & Roll. By Ed Ward, Geoffrey Stokes and Ken Tucker. Illustrated. 649 pp. New York: Rolling Stone Press/Summit Books. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $14.95. WE never did outgrow it, this hopped-up musical hybrid, this raucous noise that ultimately made all of popular culture march to its beat. When rock first began to shake, rattle and roll its way across the American consciousness, we children of the 1950's were told that it was at best a freakish fad - the musical equivalent of the Hula-Hoop or Davy Crockett's coonskin cap. At worst, it was the sound of the civilized social fabric unraveling. By the end of that decade, there were signs that this rude, frenzied musical aberration had spent its energy.

title: BAILEY SCORES 35 IN NETS' VICTORY
description: The Knicks gave up on James Bailey last August and refused to pick up the option year of his contract. The Nets, looking for a backup power foward who could also play center, quickly signed the 6-foot-9-inch, 230-pound Bailey as a free agent for almost $200,000 a year less than the $450,000 a year he earned with the Knicks the previous two years.

title: No Headline
description: IN DAN RATHER'S office on the perimeter of the sprawling CBS newsroom, on a desk next to his aquarium, rests a 1909 copy of Sir Edward Creasy's ''The Fifteen Decisive Battles Of The World.'' To the anchorman, it is a prized volume, and, although its principal considerations are ancient, he regularly gives it current application. There was, for example, the dark Tuesday last summer when Rather and his staff learned that, after more than 200 weeks at the top, the ''CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' had fallen in the ratings battle to NBC.

title: Cologne
description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: 'Robert Frost Himself'
description: To the Editor:

title: SITING OF HAZARDOUS-WASTE FACILITIES REMAINS A TOP ISSUE
description: THE hottest environmental issue of 1986 was siting, or where where to put what nobody wants. Given the progress made (and not made) in the last year, it is a safe bet that the hottest environmental issue of 1987 will also be siting.

title: Housing for Elderly Wins Wider Support
description: AT first glance, Spruce Bank Farm, a brand-new cluster of 24 gray-and-white attached cottage-style homes on a grassy hillside not far from the center of Woodbury - a rustic Connecticut town of some 7,000 people thinly scattered over 37 square miles - looks like a small, elegant condominium development.

title: ILLINOIS UPSET BY LOYOLA, 83-82
description: Bernard Jackson scored 31 points, including three key free throws in the last three minutes today, to give Loyola of Chicago an 83-82 upset over Illinois.

title: IRAQ DISPLAYS SITE OF IRAN OFFENSIVE
description: The bodies of hundreds of Iranians littered the ground and floated in swamp waters east of this southern port city today after a 14-hour battle between Iraq and Iran.

title: COMPASSION AND THE GERMAN HEART
description: AFTER THE FIRES Recent Writing in the Germanies, Austria, and Switzerland. By Peter Demetz. 444 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $27.95. FOR the American reader, German literature remains stubbornly foreign, even where it appears readily accessible. This is particularly true in the case of postwar German writing, which looks quite different to the insider than the outsider. Even its earliest, seemingly apolitical phase was from the start seen by German readers against a political backdrop and with political questions in mind - the aspect of contemporary German literature most foreign to the American reader. For this reason it is the one that needs to be most carefully explained.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE BUCKS
description: There were no last-second heroics needed, and the opposition was not a team with dubious credentials. Rather, this was a rout of a legitimate contender, and it was truly the Knicks' finest moment in a long while.

title: Youthful Win From Northwest Portugal
description: For the visitor to Aveleda, there is, first, the ritual stroll through the gardens of Quinta da Aveleda, past the weathered granite main gate with the family coat of arms, past the monumental window from the ruins of the palace in Oporto where Prince Henry the Navigator was born, past the stone fountains and great masses of mimosa, camellias, azaleas, rhododendrons and other blossoms that form dazzling outbursts of color most of the year.

title: About Cars; DRAG RACING STAR HAS MAGIC TOUCH
description: BACK in the 50's, we did a lot of drag racing in Allentown, Pa., heading west on Linden Street, down 17th, east on Hamilton to Fifth, then back again, round and round. The nightly routine was informal, with worry about Kenny the Cop ranking right up there with worry about missed shifts. But it was fun.

title: RESPITE SERVICES FOR FAMILIES OF IMPAIRED
description: FOR the families of the developmentally disabled, neurologically impaired and frail elderly who cannot rely solely on the good will of friends, extended family and neighbors for relief, the county offers a multitude of respite services through its Department of Community Mental Health.

title: WHAT 1987 BUDGET HOLDS FOR COUNTY
description: AFTER one of the sharpest budget debates in years, the Board of Legislators last week approved a $770.8 million spending plan for 1987 that cuts $3.6 million from the proposal made by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke in mid-November but raises the property tax rate by 8.7 percent.

title: Now Hear This
description: In the normal course of events, the stenotypists who produce transcripts of Congressional hearings are the most literal and colorless of transcribers. But recently, at a field hearing of the House Subcommittee on Energy Conservation and Power, such a recorder added one small touch of atmosphere.

title: A FEW WORDS ABOUT MINIMALISM
description: ''LESS is more,'' said Walter Gropius, or Alberto Giacometti, or Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, or Henri Gaudier-Brzeska, or Constantin Brancusi, or Le Corbusier or Ludwig Mies van der Rohe; the remark (first made in fact by Robert Browning) has been severally attributed to all of those more or less celebrated more or less minimalists. Like the bauhaus motto, ''Form follows function,'' it is itself a memorable specimen of the minimalist esthetic, of which a cardinal principle is that artistic effect may be enhanced by a radical economy of artistic means, even where such parsimony compromises other values: completeness, for example, or richness or precision of statement.

title: Dr. Allan Lauer to Wed Denise Laura Widman
description: Douglas J. Widman of Wayside, N.J., has announced the engagement of his sister, Denise Laura Widman, to Dr. Allan Lauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lauer of White Plains. The wedding is planned for March.

title: Comings and Goings
description: DARRELL GRIFFITH of the Utah Jazz, who missed the last National Basketball Association season because of a broken foot, will be sidelined with a shoulder injury for another 10 days to two weeks. Griffith, who has averaged 16.9 points per game far this season, sprained his left shoulder in Chicago last Saturday when he collided with Gene Banks of the Bulls while both were pursuing a loose ball and hasn't played since. . . . The five-mile Midnight Run New Year's Eve in Central Park will have among its 4,00 partcipants Wendy Sly, who took the silver medal in the 3,000 meters at the Los Angeles Olympic in 1984, and Vince Braddy, the event's defending champion. . . . The World Cup soccer star, Diego Maradona, who led his native Argentina to triumph in Mexico last summer, will lead a South American all-star team against Japan's all-stars in Tokyo next month in a game called XEROX Super Soccer '87.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FREDDY the Frog is ''a college frog,'' explained his creator, Gerry Holzman of Islip.

title: GAS LEAK FREES 70 IN RAID
description: A gas leak forced the police to release about 70 people without making any charges aaainst them early today after a raid on a house where alcohol was believed to have been sold illegally, the authorities said.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Of Business and Boxes In preparing predictions for the new year, some economists count boxes. Not the gift-wrapped goodies under the tree (though they can help measure the economy's current strength), but another sort of box: containers ordered by manufacturers. So far, the count is encouraging for 1987.

title: KOREAN PILOT OFFERS NEW THEORY ON DOWNED PLANE
description: A South Korean pilot who took off behind Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983 believes that an airline policy of punishing crew errors deterred the crew from turning back and led to the plane's being shot down, according to an article published in Seoul.

title: POSTINGS: For the Horsy Set; Quarry Villages
description: If you fancy horseback riding through countryside around an abandoned limestone quarry once owned by Thomas A. Edison, a new residential development in Franklin Township, N.J., may be just the place.

title: Doe Dies After a Break-In
description: A deer jumped through the dining-room window of a home here, raced through the house for 20 minutes, then cut an artery in its leg jumping through another window and died, a state wildlife official said. The doe may have thought she was entering a wooded area when she jumped into the home of Dawn Pizzo Friday.

title: Clemson, Arizona Hold Off Late Rallies
description: Rodney Williams, the sophomore quarterback, guided Clemson to a 27-0 halftime lead today before the Tigers stopped a furious Stanford rally for a 27-21 victory in the Gator Bowl.

title: A NEW BREED PUTS ITS OWN STAMP ON THE MEDIAN
description: This was a year when small gifts seemed to be the biggest blessings. There was no new esthetic, no dominating style, no giant sale of photographs to the J. Paul Getty Museum. But there was enough activity in terms of pictures on the walls to make categorization necessary. Here, then, are the year's highlights:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE HEIST: How a Gang Stole $8,000,000 at Kennedy Airport and Lived to Regret It. By Ernest Volkman and John Cummings.

title: ERNST BLOCH'S PHILOSOPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: GIFT BOOKS IN PHILADELPHIA Bibliophiles will not want to miss ''A Bookman's Holiday: Gift Books in the Fine Press Collection,'' currently on view at the Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia through Feb. 1.

title: SABRA AND SHATILA
description: To THE Editor:

title: Mixing Judges And Politics
description: Many articles have been printed about replacing the system of electing state judges with the system of appointing judges by an executive, usually the governor [ ''Politics and Judges Shouldn't Mix,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 7 ] . No evidence is ever presented that this would result in better judges; the people would simply lose the vote for a questionable and unprovable benefit.

title: Trying to Clear The Sidewalks
description: Big principles are sometimes tested in unlikely places, and last week the sidewalk at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 45th Street was one of those spots. Selling dictionaries and children's books to Christmas shoppers, Junior Grandison claimed exemption from efforts to clear the sidewalks of illegal peddlers.

title: AT PARTY, MODERATION IS THE WORD
description: WHEN Orchestra New England has its fifth annual New Year's Eve party for 700 guests in New Haven's Chapel Square Mall, it plans to make sure that they make it home safely.

title: Jamaica Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction And a Commentary
description: In the Dec. 14 article on holiday music, the captions on pictures of J.S. Bach and Handel were transposed. The Times, we are told, is hardly e'er wrong.

title: O'Neill Aide Departs
description: Jacob Lew, a chief aide to the retiring Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., is leaving Capitol Hill to join the Washington law firm of Van Ness, Feldman, Sutcliffe & Curtis, where he will specialize in energy and regulatory law. He has been serving as executive director of the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee.

title: TELEVISION
description: Film buffs planning a quiet New Year's Eve vigil, with some homescreen sampling, will find the best bets on broadcast TV; cable has the edge on Thursday.

title: ROUGH START FOR NEW CLOSED-END FUNDS
description: THIS year brought the greatest surge in sales of new closed-end investment funds since the late 1920's - about $4 billion worth. While that made a banner year for Wall Street underwriters and the fund managers, results for investors who bought into most of the 28 new funds have been disappointing. All of the largest issues are trading below the prices of their initial public offerings.

title: Lost Child's Mother Charged
description: The mother of a 3-year-old girl found wandering alone in Brooklyn early Christmas morning was charged yesterday with abandoning the girl to attend a Christmas Party.

title: PENGUINS RALLY TO TIE ISLANDERS
description: By now, the Penguins, who tonight played their fourth consecutive overtime game, probably feel they're being toyed with each time they get off to a good start against the Islanders, who nudged them out of second place in the Patrick Division earlier this month.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BUTCHER'S WIFE. By Li Ang. Translated by Howard Goldblatt and Ellen Yeung. (North Point, $14.95.) In Taiwan this first novel by Li Ang won a major literary award in 1983 and outraged a number of critics and government officials who considered it little more than pornography. ''The Butcher's Wife'' is not pornographic, but it omits few details or four-letter words in describing the brutalization of young Lin Shi by her much older husband, Chen Jiangshui, who treats her like the pigs he butchers in his slaughterhouse. Based on a homicide in Shanghai in the 1930's, the novel begins with two fictional press accounts of Lin Shi's harrowing murder of her husband. These reports are dismissive of her motives, but in the ensuing story of her life before the killing, in the small superstitious town of Lucheng, the author is wholly sympathetic to Lin Shi. Her fate, meant to be both shockingly singular and representative of oppressed women, is certainly among the most pathetic in recent world literature. Orphaned at 9, Lin Shi is forced to live with her unscrupulous uncle until he marries her off at 20 to Chen Jiangshui. His numbing mistreatment of her begins on their wedding night and escalates until the moment of her impulsive revenge. The story is simple, uncluttered and powerful in its way but is undermined by its repetitious scenes of sexual violence. Lin Shi is such a naive, defenseless victim and Chen Jiangshui such a vicious, unmotivated monster that our interest eventually wanes.

title: Disagreements on Welfare Revisions
description: At least three major legislative packages introduced in the 99th Congress and dozens of recommendations from policy institutes and political caucuses that are out or expected soon have made clear a general agreement that the Federal welfare system badly needs fixing. But the extent of disagreement about how to fix it was also clear last week as a coalition of national organizations came forward with its approach.

title: BOTH SIDES OF KEYNES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GIANT KILLERS. By Michael Pertschuk. (Norton, $17.95.) With all of the headlines about national security, portentous events, sounding brass and brass sounding off, it is refreshing to read a book about how hard work, imagination and good humor can deflect and deflate juggernauts.

title: 'BAD GUYS'
description: To the Editor:

title: SCRAMBLING TO COPE WITH NEW LAW ON IMMIGRATION
description: LEONEL CASTILLO, the Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner under President Jimmy Carter, spent a lot of his time last week doing what he calls ''playing the hypotheticals'' in Houston's Hispanic community.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PEACE IN A NUCLEAR AGE: The Bishops' Pastoral Letter in Perspective. Edited by Charles J. Reid Jr. (Catholic University of America Press, $44.95.)

title: ENERGY BUY-OUT BY SEABROOK BACKER IS ASSAILED
description: The owner of the largest share of the idle Seabrook nuclear power station has long asserted that the plant is necessary to fill a growing demand for power in New Hampshire.

title: A Disagreement On Surplus Schools
description: Saul Schindler, a retired schoolteacher who lives in Hewlett, wrote an Opinion Page article [ ''Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools,'' Dec. 7 ] expressing his feelings about surplus schools and his views of enrollments and related matters. While I respect his right to hold and express whatever views he chooses, errors of fact need to be corrected.

title: STUDY ON SALARY ARBITRATION OFFERS WAYS TO OVERHAUL SYSTEM
description: MENTION salary arbitration and club officials will recoil in horror. It is just about that time again - eligible players can begin filing next Monday - but to the owners and general managers, it seems like only yesterday (10 months ago, actually) that Orel Hershiser was winning a $1 million salary after earning $212,000 the previous year and Bret Saberhagen was grabbing a $925,000 prize after pitching one season earlier for $160,000. Hershiser, they will tell you even if you didn't ask, had a 14-14 record this year and Saberhagen was 7-12. The club officials still feel the pain.

title: A NEW APPROACH TO MUSEUM DESIGN
description: WHEN United Technologies of Hartford spent $50 million to build the Living Seas Pavilion at EPCOT Center in Orlando, Fla., it wanted to leave the audience with a clear idea of the scope of United Technologies' operations. And to get its message across, it commissioned a Mamaroneck company, BHA Design Inc., to create a corporate logo -a multi-video display.

title: FIGHTING OVER THE OIL IN HALLOWED GROUND
description: WOODROW KIPP, his shoulder-length black hair twisted into braids, sat in his truck and watched as the wind scoured snow from the mountains that tower above the south fork of the Two Medicine River, just east of the Blackfeet Indian Reservation in northwestern Montana.

title: A Plea Rejected
description: A lot of people think Jean Harris has suffered enough since she was imprisoned six years ago for murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, who planned to end their love affair.

title: A TOWN IS LOSING BIGGEST EMPLOYER
description: THE biggest employer in this Camden County borough, the Building Materials Customers Service Center of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, has begun a shutdown process that will terminate all but a handful of its 800 workers.

title: Peggy-ann Murdich, Lawyer, Becomes the Bride Of Robert Edward Shearer, Senior Programmer
description: Margaret Ann Murdich, the deputy general counsel of the Home Group Inc., an insurance holding company in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Edward Shearer, a senior programmer and analyst at the New York University Computer Center and a doctoral candidate in higher education at N.Y.U. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church.

title: FOCUS: Key West; Tropical Backwater Heats Up
description: THIS 12-square-mile subtropical Florida island of 28,000 inhabitants, whose laid-back pace helps it attract two million visitors a year, has become one of the country's hottest real-estate markets.

title: EXPERTS CITE TAINTED SOIL, CALL FOR LEGAL PROTECTIONS
description: THERE is a Clean Air Act and a Clean Water Act.

title: CASTRO SAID TO HAVE SPURNED '59 ANTI-SOMOZA BID
description: A Cuban revolutionary hero who spent 22 years in prison said this week that Fidel Castro, in his first year in power, rejected helping Nicaraguans who wanted to overthrow Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: A FLAWED FARCE AT GEORGE ST.
description: WHAT is a Feydeau farce?

title: The Handball High
description: Having played four-wall handball for the last 35 years, I was delighted to read William O'Fallon's article ''The Handball High'' (About Men, Nov. 23).

title: U.S. Juniors Rout Czechs in Hockey
description: The United States defeated Czechoslovakia, 8-2, today in the World Junior Hockey Championships for players under age 20.

title: CARSON'S DEFENSE FACES HIS OLD TEAM
description: That Jets defense - the one that is last in the National Football League against the pass, the one that has been trampled for five games, the one whose best players watched from hospital beds or the sideline - gets another chance today, led by its combative coordinator, Bud Carson.

title: ALL ALONE BY THE ASTROPHONE
description: THE SEARCH FOR EXTRATERRESTRIAL INTELLIGENCE Listening for Life in the Cosmos. By Thomas R. McDonough. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $19.95.

title: India and Pakistan Resume Talks on Improving Relations
description: Senior Indian and Pakistani officials resumed talks today in a search for better relations between the two traditional rivals.

title: City Vendors and Campaign Giving
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter has made a point in recent years of tracking campaign contributions to top New York City officials, and last week the West Side Democrat produced his latest conclusion: Of the 200 biggest givers to Board of Estimate members and county Democratic organizations over the last six years, 60 percent do business with the city.

title: FROM LINCOLN BRIGADE, FOND MEMORIES
description: FIFTY years ago on Dec. 26, Anthony Demaio, a Hartford native, left New York on the Normandy along with 95 Americans volunteering to fight in the Spanish Civil War.

title: COST OF INTEREST ON U.S. DEBT EASES
description: The cost of paying interest on the Federal debt has leveled off after rising rapidly for more than 25 years and may even decline in the current fiscal year, according to budget experts in the Reagan Administration and Congress.

title: MEESE SAID TO REJECT REQUEST IN E.P.A. CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has rejected a request from an independent counsel to widen her investigation of whether a senior Justice Department official acted improperly in withholding documents from Congress, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title:
ART;
INDIAN COSTUME ARTISTRY: CLOTHES MAKE THE WARRIOR
description: IN the films and popular literature portraying the American West, the figure of the Plains Indian plays a vivid and evocative role.

title: Ethan Solomon Etzioni Marries Hedva Danieli
description: The marriage of Hedva Alegra Danieli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Danieli of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, to Ethan Solomon Etzioni, a son of Dr. Amitai Etzioni of Bethesda, Md., and Dr. Eva Halevy-Etzioni of Canberra, Australia, took place last night at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Efron V. Mordecai, assisted by Cantor Paul Zim, performed the ceremony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In order to promote democracy and in order to give the people the opportunity to select the candidates that they will be satisfied with, this time the election will have more candidates than slots available.'' - She Diqing, of the standing committee of the Municipal People's Congress of Beijing. [ 1:5. ]

title: Caryn A. Lerner Becomes Fiancee Of H.G. Bergman
description: Mrs. Robert O. Swados of Buffalo and Boca Raton, Fla., and Allan S. Lerner of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Caryn Ann Lerner to Hilary G. Bergman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Bergman of Delray Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for April. Ms. Lerner, a dress buyer at Bloomingdale's in New York, graduated from the Harley Day School, attended Vassar College, and graduated from New York University.

title: 'Before She Met Me'
description: Last year American readers were introduced to the British writer Julian Barnes with the publication of ''Flaubert's Parrot,'' a book that virtually created its own genre. Labeled a novel by its author, it was actually more like a literary improvisation on the life and art of Gustave Flaubert, combining stylistic elements of works as wildly disparate as the critical biography, the medieval bestiary and the train-spotter's guide. The result was an irreverent hodgepodge that, for all its playfulness, had serious and provocative things to say about our fascination with the elusive figures of our past.

title: GOVERNMENT AND REBELS IN TALKS IN SRI LANKA
description: A Sri Lankan delegation held talks with Tamil guerrillas today in the island's north in an effort to end three years of ethnic fighting that has cost thousands of lives.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Love Is Sweet as Blue It's reassuring to reflect that love letters continue to exist. In ''Ceremony'' (Henry Holt), the anthropologist Nigel Barley describes the style of the amatory epistle in a North African village.

title: In Business To Treat Cancer
description: As one who is engaged in a race against time with advanced metastatic colon cancer, I applaud Dr. Robert Oldham's move to do research in the private sector if it means that state-of-the-art cancer research can advance more rapidly, with less red tape (''In Business to Treat Cancer,'' by Robin Marantz Henig, Nov. 23). Exciting and sophisticated experimentation is under way in Europe, work that will not occur here for, perhaps, years, due to overregulation by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: SHE OUGHTN'T TO HAVE BEEN IN PICTURES
description: BEFORE SHE MET ME By Julian Barnes. 174 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. Paper, $4.95.

title: Anne Ives to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Lee Pierson of Pottersville, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pierson's daughter, Anne Appleton Ives, to John Lee Hopkins, a son of Mrs. John Hopkins of New York and the late Mr. Hopkins.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE First Jersey National Corporation, a $4 billion bank-holding company based in Jersey City, is awaiting approval of its plan to establish a subsidiary in Fort Washington, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: A CRADLE-TO-KINDERGARTEN AID PLAN IN CHICAGO
description: Victoria Barton looks younger than 17 years old as she crosses a deserted playground on Chicago's South Side.

title: India and Pakistan In Pact on Sikhs
description: For the first time in a year, India and Pakistan found common ground last week on steps to reduce tensions along their border. Officials of the two nations reached an agreement to accelerate coordination of their frontier security forces to prevent Sikh extremists from using Pakistani territory as a base for attacks in India.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE MINT MAKES A DECISION
description: Barring unforeseen developments, Kennedy half dollars dated 1987, will not be produced for circulation.

title: Eason Can Practice
description: THE New England Patriots' quarterback, Tony Eason, injured last Monday night against the Miami Dolphins, got the go-ahead from the Patriots team physician yesterday to resume full practicing for next Sunday's American Conference playoff game in Denver.

title: Some Good News About Radon
description: In a New Jersey subdivision that one official said had ''just unbelievably high'' levels of radon last spring, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has reported success with a new ventilation system for houses.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the tenor Vinson Cole's debut at the Metropolitan Opera next Saturday evening misidentifies the role he will sing in ''Die Fledermaus.'' It is that of Alfred.

title: WHAT'S IN A BRILLIANCY?
description: A brilliancy prize is a grand thing even if it won't pay the rent. It expresses appreciation for the exceptionally creative, imaginative performance that everyone delights in but cannot expect to see often.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON GROWING A SPECTACULAR FLOWER
description: YOU may have received an amaryllis bulb as a Christmas gift, or perhaps you plan to buy one or more for forcing. In either case, it may be helpful to have forcing guidelines to achieve the best possible result with this spectacular flower.

title: Come Out of That TV and Meet the Voter
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Hillsborough $116,900 124 Wildflower Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 4-year-old town-house condominium; wall-to-wall carpeting, monthly charges $75; taxes $1,592 Livingston $145,000 31 Mount Pleasant Parkway 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, full basement, garage; taxes $1,498 Millburn $197,000 31 Bailey Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; den, screened porch; taxes $2,509. Paramus $270,000 151 Village Circle East 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-baths, 35-year-old split-level; central air-conditioning, family room with fireplace; taxes $2169.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: WHO LOST EAST HAMPTON?;
1987, A YEAR WE WON'T SOON FORGET
description: IF you are a corporate executive who resists planning ahead, consider yourself an enemy of America in the competitive world market. Yes, it is holiday time and there are more enjoyable diversions. But big changes are in store and the prudent executive must prepare. Here, accordingly, is a not-so-cautious guide for 1987.Debt on Arrival

title: ADOLESCENT MENTAL-HEALTH SYSTEM UNDER FIRE
description: WITH a suit by the Department of the Public Advocate looming, pressure has been building for the state's Commissioner of Human Services to change the mental-health system for New Jersey's troubled adolescents.

title: HELPED CREATE BETTY CROCKER
description: Marjorie Child Husted, who helped develop Betty Crocker and championed the ideals of ''good housekeeping,'' died Tuesday in Minneapolis. She was 94 years old. Mrs. Husted, born in Minneapolis, graduated from the University of Minnesota with degrees in home economics and German. She developed the image of Betty Crocker from an idea generated in a 1921 contest. By 1948, a national survey reported that the General Mills trademark was known by 91 percent of American housewifes.

title:
DINING OUT;
CRITIC'S CHOICE: THE BEST OF 1986
description: CHANGES in the restaurant world are as frequent as ever - and stock-taking at the end of 1986 shows that some interesting and serious restaurants have joined our county's laudable ranks, although none with the extravagant flair we've come to expect each year. However, many wonderful old favorites continue to please.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MARIE CURIE: A Life. By Francoise Giroud. Translated by Lydia Davis. (Holmes & Meier, $34.50.) This affectionate, quirky, mixed-up biography celebrates one of the truly significant lives of the last 100 years.

title: 'BEARING THE CROSS'
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Wisconsin Educator Chosen As New Westfield President
description: A University of Wisconsin officer has accepted the job of president of Westfield State College, which has been thrown into turmoil by charges that its former president sexually molested two male students.

title: LOUISVILLE ROUTED BY KENTUCKY, 85-51
description: Rex Chapman, a freshman guard, scored 26 points today as Kentucky dominated Louisville in posting a 85-51 victory. It was the worst home loss suffered by Louisville in Denny Crum's 16 years as head coach.

title: MASSACHUSETTS HELPING ITS ENDANGERED TURTLE
description: Something went wrong for the Plymouth red-bellied turtle centuries ago and the development of a modern industrial society in Massachusetts only made things worse.

title: MAKING RUSSIA SAFE FOR BOLSHEVISM
description: PASSAGE THROUGH ARMAGEDDON The Russians in War and Revolution 1914-1918. By W. Bruce Lincoln. Illustrated. 637 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95. THE great battles in the

title: WILLIAMSBRIDGE
description: TO local activists, it seemed like an intractable problem: Midnight dumpers kept throwing refrigerators and mattresses into the empty lots dotting the northern Bronx neighborhood of Williamsbridge.

title: The Firepower of Kindness
description: The best public document of the season - no blather about geostrategic politics - is the annual report published by Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund. It shows that a pittance can save millions of children in poorer countries. What's more heartening, ''The State of the World's Children'' reports that in the last year, countries poor and rich have united to save at least 1.5 million children by vaccines and hydration therapy. The target of total immunization by 1990 looks increasingly feasible.

title: CHANGES FORESEEN IN STRIPED BASS BAN
description: THE ban on striped bass fishing is up for review now, and spokesmen for sport and commercial fishing groups say they believe there could be major changes in the regulations for next year. Most agree that the changes would favor sport fishermen.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE year-and-a-half-long legislative debate over a bill requiring the recycling of solid waste statewide may finally be drawing to a close.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTY
description: SOLZHENITSYN, by Michael Scammell. (Norton, $14.95.) Michael Scammell's biography of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn ''is a vast book,'' Norman Stone said in The Book Review in 1984. ''But the subject itself deserves this: Mr. Scammell has to deal with war, revolution, prison camps, Khrushchev's literary politics and Solzhenitsyn's eventual exile in the West.'' The book is well-written, he said, and the author had the advantage of several interviews with his subject. The work ''puts us all in its debt.'' SELECTED POEMS, by John Ashbery. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $9.95.) The effect of reading John Ashbery's poetry, Michiko Kakutani wrote in The Times last year, is ''not unlike that produced by listening to a piece of avant-garde music,'' and his work ''frequently defies conventional attempts to impute meaning.'' Yet, she added, its ''meditative, allusive beauty retains a powerful ability to entrance,'' and this selection of his poems ''attests to both his maturation as a poet, and his ongoing interest in investigating the formal possibilities of his art.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Ashbery's THREE POEMS ($7.95), a trilogy of poems in prose - ''The New Spirit,'' ''The System'' and ''The Recital.'' ''The language is everywhere magnificent,'' our reviewer, Paul Zweig, said in 1972. ''One forgets to pursue one's hunger for logic amid the glories of pure language.'' MY LONGEST NIGHT, by Genevieve Duboscq. Translated by Richard S. Woodward. (Seaver, $9.95.) The author was a girl of 11 on the night of June 5, 1944, when American paratroopers began landing in the marshlands around her home in Normandy on the eve of D-Day.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON GROWING A SPECTACULAR FLOWER
description: YOU may have received an amaryllis bulb as a Christmas gift, or perhaps you plan to buy one or more for forcing. In either case, it may be helpful to have forcing guidelines to achieve the best possible result with this spectacular flower.

title: Hunting at Yale Forest: Benefits Are Questioned
description: As a participant in the protest theater held in the Yale Forest on Thanksgiving Day, I would like to respond to the hunting apologia offered by David M. Smith of the Yale School of Forestry and James Spignesi of the State Department of Environmental Protection's Wildlife Bureau [ ''Protectors Take On Hunters in Forest,'' Dec. 14 ] . Mr. Smith and Mr. Spignesi assert that there is a ''severe overpopulation of deer'' in the forest. By what measure? In 1984, population estimates went from 200 to 500 in three days' time as we pressed for evidence for ''overpopulation.'' By October of this year, Mr. Smith was using a figure of 540. Mr. Spignesi now says there are 360 deer.

title: A TIME OF REFINEMENTS RATHER THAN GREAT LEAPS
description: The Chinese have the charming habit of naming their years after animals - the Year of the Rat, the Year of the Tiger, and so forth. If the past year in audio were to be characterized in this way, it might well be called the Year of the Badger. It was a time for the cozy consolidation of past gains, of curling up comfortably in one's lair to mull over noble adventures gone before.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;
Where MAX Is the Most
description: WHEN this city inaugurated its new 15-mile-long light rail system in September, riders were treated to a series of stations designed to recall an earlier era of civic architecture.

title: BUSINESSLIKE APPROACH TAKEN TO HEALTH
description: EXECUTIVES who want the truth about how healthy they are and a detailed plan for how to stay well can get an ''Annual Report for the Body'' from the recently opened Executive Health Center of St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford.

title: ONE MAN'S BATTLE WITH BUREAUCRACY
description: IN 1972, when Dr. Bal K. Thaper left his post as the administrator of 200 schools in his native Delhi, India, to pursue his education career in the United States, he had every reason to expect success.

title: L. A. Willis to Marry Lucinda Hale Feb. 28
description: Lucinda Douglas Hale, a manager at Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting firm in New York, and Lawrence Alfred Willis, the partner in charge of bank consulting at Coopers & Lybrand, plan to be married Feb. 28.

title: ABOARD THE BATTLESHIP NEW JERSEY: 'ONE BIG HAPPY FAMILY'
description: ''MAN, this is the place to be,'' said Victor Sampson of Vineland, the payroll clerk on the battleship New Jersey. ''It's the world's best battleship. I mean it's historic and a real thrill to be here. It's taken me to Hong Kong, Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Japan - places I'd never get to see. And I'm only 21.

title: 'BEARING THE CROSS
description: To The Editor:

title: ERNST BLOCH'S PHILOSOPHY
description: Leon Wieseltier replies:

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Lot Costs Squeeze Housing Affordability
description: ON scattered lots throughout Shirley and Mastic, construction is under way on small modular, or factory-built, houses. Sometimes they face the neighboring side yard instead of the street because the lots have such a narrow frontage.

title: GULOTTA AIDES AWAIT MOVE
description: THOMAS S. GULOTTA, the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, is expected to be named the interim Nassau County Executive next month. But he has still not publicly named key aides who probably will make the trip with him from Hempstead to the county seat in Mineola.

title: MINNETONKA'S STRUGGLE TO STAY ONE STEP AHEAD
description: THE Minnetonka Corporation doesn't look like much. Its headquarters are in an anonymous one-story cinder-block building across from some cornfields. But in the consumer products industry, the company has been the mouse that roared, churning out revolutionary new products that have thrown industry giants on the defensive.

title: In Business To Treat Cancer
description: Dr. Bruce Chabner's remark that ''You can't buy high-quality research'' is off the mark. Almost every new antibiotic in the last 20 years was the result of privately sponsored and in-house research done by pharmaceutical companies - obviously for profit. MARVIN S. AMSTEY, M.D. Rochester

title: A MASTER'S IN MANIPULATION
description: ITEM: IN LATE OCTOBER, the New York State Board of Regents granted a charter for the establishment of the Graduate School of Political Management. The school, using the facilities of Baruch College in Manhattan, plans to open its doors next fall to a class of 30 future professional political tacticians. Each will pay $12,600 for a one-year program that will confer a master's degree in political management.

title: 33 FOOD SITES GET CITATIONS IN NEW YORK
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NOT SO SIMPLE AS A LYNCHING
description: AN incident of racially motivated violence that at first seemed as brutally simple as a lynching, to which Mayor Koch compared it, took a twist last week that threatened to heighten the bitterness surrounding it even while jeopardizing the case against those accused of committing it.

title: U.S. PLANNING TOXIC CONTROL OF CAPE GULLS
description: Sea gulls, the toughest and most prolific of Eastern shore birds, are the latest creatures to come to dinner on Cape Cod and stay on to take over the household, and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service would like to be rid of them.

title: WHAT WAS THE BIGGEST SPORTS STORY OF THE YEAR?
description: The year's biggest sports story? Len Bias, unfortunately. JEROME AGEL

title: POSTINGS: Eighth Ave. Rentals; Lost Frontier
description: ''When we first started out, we thought of it as the frontier,'' said Ira Krauss, president of First Sterling Corporation, ''but now I don't think this is pioneering anymore.'' He was referring to the Ellington, the 29-story rental building his company is putting up on the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and West 52d Street in a partnership with Rose Associates.

title: SAVANAH
description: You couldn't hurry through Savannah if you wanted to. The city's 20 squares of parks, landscaped with palmetto trees, azaleas and native flowers and shaded by giant live oaks, are spaced throughout the heart of the city, and the single-lane streets that encircle the squares carry traffic one way only. The mansions clustered around the squares evoke a period of antebellum self-confidence and extravagance. In winter, the squares are uncrowded and it is easy to survey the city's surpassingly lovely landscape. House Museums Three of the most elegant and sophisticated houses in Savannah were designed by a young Englishman from Bath, the fashionable watering place of Jane Austen's England. William Jay designed and oversaw the building of these three Regency houses at a time when Savannah's economy was experiencing a great cotton boom.

title: The Statistics Behind Seat Belt Laws
description: In my interview with your reporter for a recent article [ ''Repeal of Law on Seat Belts Is Sought,'' Dec. 7 ] , I mentioned a certain safety issue sometimes brought up in conjunction with discussions of the mandatory seat belt law, viz., the probability of survival in a car accident if the occupants remain within the car during the collision.

title: Baseball Inc.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. Dauber, Law Clerk, Weds Benni Jakubovic
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., last night Susan G. Dauber, the daughter of Edith Feldman of Brooklyn and the late A. Gerald Dauber, was married to Benni Jakubovic, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jakubovic of Brooklyn. Rabbi Max Zucker performed the ceremony.

title: 'THERESE': A SIMPLE MOVIE THAT WINS ACCOLADES
description: ''I thought there was some mistake,'' said Alain Cavalier about the response to his film ''Therese'' at its Cannes Film Festival premiere. The French director was hardly prepared for the awed reactions of the audience, the unanimous raves, and finally the awarding of the Special Jury Prize.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Trouble Spots for Traffic According to the city's Department of Transportation, these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region today:

title: Today's Sports
description: Basketball L.A. Lakers vs. Philadelphia 76ers At Inglewood, Calif., 10 P.M. TV - WTBS, 10 P.M. Football A.F.C. Wildcard Playoff Jets vs.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hamden, Conn. $152,000 73 Orchard Heights Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; hardwood floors, new heating system; taxes $2,073.

title: FAIRFIELD ATHLETE IS A TRIPLE THREAT
description: AT a time when most athletes are encouraged to concentrate their efforts in one sport, Beth Taterosian of Fairfield is a reminder of another era.

title: RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETTE
description: Verdi's 'Don Carlo' Starring Placido Domingo, Mirella Freni, Grace Bumbry, Nicolai Ghiaurov and Louis Quilico. Metropolitan Opera Orchestra conducted by James Levine.

title: STLL LIFE WITH GENIUS
description: MATISSE The Man and His Art, 1869-1918. By Jack Flam. Illustrated. 523 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $75.

title: NEW N.S.C. STAFF SEEKING ADVICE ON IRAN
description: The new National Security Council staff has sought the advice of a group of former Iran experts in the Government to help produce a policy toward Iran that would avoid the mistakes of the arms-for-hostages operation.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STRANGE AILMENTS; UNCERTAIN CURES. By Bruce Goldsmith. (Mercury House, $17.95.) Poor, poor Michael Marcus. His marriage is falling apart - his gorgeous gynecologist wife, Marilyn, has dreams of fleeing Los Angeles and opening a health spa near San Diego, hopes that have made her driven, high-strung and angry; worse, she no longer responds to Michael sexually, and that makes him feel lonely and unappreciated.

title: AFRICAN ART: FEAR AND FANTASIES
description: THERE are scowling faces of wood and mud, effigies of leather, doors that sprout navels and drawings recounting ancient tales of passion and power. In these and some 80 other objects of beauty, fear, faith and doubt, a little of traditional Africa has come to Nassau County.

title: Riding in France, Museumgoing in San Francisco
description: By Horseback In the Alps Of Provence

title: CHAD FINDS UNITY IN WAR WITH LIBYA
description: FOR the first time in 20 years, Chad's many tribes have suspended their civil war to confront a common enemy: Libya. As recently as this fall, 11 armed factions had been vying for power in the landlocked central African nation, which, in a population of five million, is fragmented into 200 ethnic groups.

title: GAS EXPLOSION KILLS 6 IN WEST GERMANY AT SKI RESORT HOTEL
description: A gas explosion at an Alpine ski resort frequented by United States military personnel and their families killed 6 people today and injured 26, the police said. A seventh person was missing and presumed dead.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A NATURAL MAN The True Story of John Henry. By Steve Sanfield. Illustrated by Peter J. Thornton. 48 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THE best way to tell if a book based on a piece of folklore works is to hold it in the mouth. Tell it aloud. If it has not lost its ability to sing, to pump the heart - buy it!

title: No Thanks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MARYLAND WINS IN BELATED OPENER
description: Maryland scored a 76-58 victory over Winthrop tonight in the belated season-opener for the Terrapins under their new coach, Bob Wade.

title: WHAT'S NEW ON THE CORPORATE BOOKSHELF
description: THE executive suite of any company, large or small, public or private, is fraught with obstacles for the ambitious. A corporation can be thrown suddenly into crisis, like Union Carbide after Bhopal and Johnson & Johnson after the Tylenol poisonings, and careers can hinge on how well executives handle the problem.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHAMBER-STYLE NEW YEAR An unusual way to spend New Year's Eve could be in church. At St. Luke's Episcopal Church at 1864 Post Road in Darien, the Fairfield County Chamber Ensemble will perform all six Brandenburg Concertos beginning Wednesday at 8 P.M.

title: Verbatim: Pluses and Minuses
description: 'On the minus side, maybe the President doesn't have the clout that he might have had because he's being attacked on Iran. On the up side, what might ordinarily be a frenzy of denunciation of the President's budget might not be.

title: Robert Jerome Fishman Married to Stacey Scott
description: The marriage of Stacey Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scott of Montclair, N.J., to Robert Jerome Fishman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Fishman of New York, took place last evening at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. PURSUES PLAN FOR NEW RADARS DESPITE FEARS OF TREATY VIOLATION
description: The United States is pressing ahead with plans to construct two new large radars in Greenland and Britain, according to officials, despite a renewed proposal from the Soviet Union and the opinion of some arms-control experts that building the radars would violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: AN ECONOMICAL diarist looks back at 1986.

title: Prison Surprise In Vermont
description: WHEN Christopher M. Owens, a guard for 14 years at the St. Johnsbury Community Correctional Center in Vermont, signed up for a training session in ''Officer Awareness,'' he expected a lecture, slide show, coffee and doughnuts.

title: ASSURED SUCCESSES AND MEMORABLE SURPRISES By John Russell
description: Watching the crowds at the year's three most conspicuous popular successes - ''Vienna 1900'' at the Museum of Modern Art, ''Henri Matisse: The Early Years in Nice'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and ''Van Gogh in Saint-Remy and Auvers'' at the Metropolitan Museum - we cannot imagine them as even partial failures, but in point of fact it is by a mysterious process, akin to alchemy, that an exhibition becomes unforgettable. Size alone is no guarantee. We can all remember huge undertakings, hugely subsidized, that went nowhere in particular. Timing can be important. People stood in line this year to see what they would not have crossed the road to see 10 years ago. Magic is magic, and cannot be willed into existence.

title: STAGE: VICTOR BORGE AND 'COMEDY IN MUSIC'
description: ''THE first piano was built long after they didn't have any at all,'' explains Victor Borge in his nutty professor's version of keyboard history. ''Since there was only one big white key, it was monotonous to go to a piano recital. It wasn't until someone invented the cracks that everything changed.''

title: Prague Loves Jazz, but Not Tax-Law Dodgers
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON GROWING A SPECTACULAR FLOWER
description: YOU may have received an amaryllis bulb as a Christmas gift, or perhaps you plan to buy one or more for forcing. In either case, it may be helpful to have forcing guidelines to achieve the best possible result with this spectacular flower.

title: The Environment Versus Plastic
description: WHEN the Coca-Cola Company said early this year that it had successfully tested its soft drink in a new plastic can, environmentalists objected loudly to any full-scale marketing of the container, even though it was labeled ''recyclable plastic.''

title: Correction
description: A report on Nov. 30 on Connecticut's celebration of the bicentennial of the United States Constitution misidentified a book by David Bollier about the state and the Supreme Court. The title is ''Crusaders & Criminals, Victims and Visionaries.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1986
description: Internaional A change in Beijing city elections was announced. City officials said that, for the first time, there would be more than one candidate for each seat in the legislative elections that are to be held within the next six months. Page 1 Plans to build two large U.S. radars in Greenland and Britain are moving ahead, officials said, despite a renewed proposal from the Soviet Union and the view of some arms experts that they violate a 1972 treaty. #1 Andrei D. Sakharov will limit his role as leader of the Soviet human rights movement, he said, because of physical infirmity and a desire to renew his scientific work. Dr. Sakharov spoke in an interview. #14 Afghan exiles burned Soviet flags and an effigy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Pakistan in protests marking the seventh anniversary of the Soviet troop move into Afghanistan, witnesses and Afghan sources said. #3 An airline policy was blamed by a South Korean captain for deterring the crew of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 from turning back on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983. The policy punished crew errors. #8 The new N.S.C. staff seeks advice from a group of former Iran experts in the Government to help produce a policy toward Iran that would avoid the mistakes of the arms-for-hostages operation run by the National Security staff. #6 A setback for South African forces occurred when a captured black nationalist guerrilla killed two white police officers and escaped, the police reported.

title: Murder, They Write
description: I have long been a fan of the genre Richard M. Levine writes about in his article ''Murder, They Write'' (Nov. 16). What draws me to these books, besides the fact that they contain all the elements of a fast-paced whodunit, is the alluring, disturbing fact that the stories are true and could happen right in one's own backyard.

title: POP: SMOKEY ROBINSON IN SIX-NIGHT ENGAGEMENT
description: CONNOISSEURS of great singing - any singing, in any style - are hereby directed to the Mark Hellinger Theater, 51st Street west of Broadway, where Smokey Robinson opened a run Friday night that will extend through New Year's Eve.

title: ERNST BLOCH'S PHILOSOPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBUTANTES' WHITE NIGHTS
description: THIS seems to be a time when certain venerable social traditions that all but disappeared in the 1960's and 70's have come back into fashion, proudly and with bells on. The Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball is a striking example.

title: Program for the Gifted: How Big a Gift Is It?
description: The ultimate goal of the Long Island School for the Gifted seems to be to get high scores on the S.A.T. test [ ''School for Gifted: Where the S.A.T. Is Just Another Test,'' Nov. 23 ] . This raises concerns that should be answered: Are children crammed with more knowledge than they really need at that age? Are we increasing the number of lost kids who develop overconfidence? Are we contributing to stress, fatigue and alienation? Are we turning out pupils who are always looking for special privileges for the rest of their lives because educators inflated them?

title: IN A DEPRESSED HOUSE MARKET, SALVAGING SOME SELF-RESPECT
description: YOU have heard the term ''house poor.'' Well, I'm doubly house poor, or is it rich? I am the proud owner of two homes in Fairfield County.

title: Jeanne M. Delsener, Executive, Is a Bride
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Jeanne Marie Delsener, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony H. Delsener of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married to John Curtis Galbraith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Galbraith of Naples, Fla., and Summit, N.J. Msgr. John Nienstedt performed the ceremony.

title: WINTER OFFERS A RARE VIEW
description: RELATIVELY few summertime hiker-naturalists are abroad when the forests and mountains are deep in snow, and this is a pity because there is much to be seen at that time of year.

title: Arthur Baer Cavataro Marries Carin Collins
description: Carin Rand Collins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Collins of Wesley Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arthur Baer Cavataro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas T. Cavataro of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Krantz and the Rev. William Naughton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: It Takes More Than Poverty to Make Criminals; Bring Back R.O.T.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDUCTORS IN OTHER HATS
description: Most conductors are so involved with orchestral sounds and balances that when they write for orchestra (either as composers, like Wagner, Strauss, or, in our time, Leonard Bernstein, or simply as arrangers, like the late Leopold Stokowski) they tend to do so brilliantly. Two highly enjoyable recent releases exemplify each of the categories: one devoted to nine of Stokowski's arrangements (Telarc CD-80129, also on LP), the other devoted to theater music by Mr. Bernstein (EMI/Angel CDC-7 47522 2, also cassette and LP).

title: NEW YORK CITY CRACKS DOWN ON PROSITITUTION
description: Law-enforcement officials say they are beginning a new crackdown against massage parlors that are actually illegal houses of prostitution clustered south of 30th Street in Manhattan after being driven from the Times Square area and from Queens.

title: George Ledes to Marry Allison Eckardt in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harold J. Eckardt of Somers, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter Allison Meder Eckardt to George Macgill Ledes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John George Ledes of Katonah, N.Y.

title: DUMAS MALONE, EXPERT ON JEFFERSON, IS DEAD AT 94
description: The historian Dumas Malone, whose multivolume biography led to a reputation as the foremost authority on the life of Thomas Jefferson, died yesterday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 94 years old.

title: 1,200 PROTESTERS OF RACIAL ATTACK MARCH IN QUEENS
description: More than 1,200 people, showing both anger and grief at the death of a young black man who was attacked by a group of whites, marched through Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday in a protest against racism.

title: CHILDRS' BOOKS
description: MORE STORIES JULIAN TELLS By Ann Cameron. Illustrated by Ann Strugnell. 82 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 8) THE stories Julian tells are good fun.

title: What Is the U.S.O.?
description: The U.S.O. is a voluntary, nonprofit organization serving the men and women of today's military and their families.

title: A REFUSENIK'S STORY
description: LAST FALL, after seven years as a re-fusenik - a Soviet Jew refused an emigration visa - I was abruptly allowed, with my wife, to leave the Soviet Union for New York. The event was precipitated by a remarkable coincidence: the intervention with Soviet authorities of the American industrialist, Armand Hammer, whom I had never met; and at the same time, the fortuitous, if unfortunate onset of an international political crisis in which I unwittingly played a part. Two years earlier, I had refused to cooperate with the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police, when they first tried to entrap my friend and occasional dinner companion, the American journalist Nicholas S. Daniloff. It was only last summer, when Nick was at last arrested on the false charge of espionage, that the previous episode was made public.

title: ADDITIONAL TITLES OF INTEREST
description: ALL IN A DAY. By Mitsumasa Anno and Raymond Briggs, Ron Brooks, Gian Calvi, Eric Carle, Zhu Chengliang, Leo and Diane Dillon, Akiko Hayashi and Nicolai Popov. Philomel.

title: IS THERE LIFE LEFT IN DIGITECH?
description: Digitech Inc. may not be a household word to investors, and it has not attracted much of a following among Wall Street analysts. But the small - 200 employees - St. Louis-based company is near the top of the charts of best-performing stocks of 1986.

title: WORKING 40 HOURS A WEEK, BUT NOT FOR A SALARY
description: DEBORAH RAIZES hesitates to describe herself as a ''housewife.'' Not that the vivacious mother of two isn't proud of her home and family, but the term doesn't quite convey the reality of her daily life. Unlike many women of her generation - Mrs. Raizes is a Scarsdale resident in her late 30's - she does not work at a paid job. She does work, however, often for up to eight hours a day, in volunteer positions with at least nine organizations in the community.

title: Stacy Sternheimer to Wed John R. Smith Jr. in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Sternheimer of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacy Lew Sternheimer to John Randolph Smith Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Martinsville, Va., and Litchfield, S.C. A March wedding is planned.

title: RANGERS DEFEATED IN SLUGGISH GAME
description: There should be a standing joke about the kind of game the Rangers and Blues played tonight. It was long and boring, but then, the hockey was not very good either.

title: Editors' Note
description: A news summary in The Week in Review last Sunday described charges against associates of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who is the focus of a Federal investigation into whether he and some of his supporters violated income tax laws.

title: Rio de Janeiro
description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: One Son, Three Fathers
description: THE FIRST TIME I MET HIM, he fell asleep in his spaghetti. It didn't matter. I was in love. Not with him, but with his mother. She had kept Sebastian from napping so that we wouldn't be interrupted after dinner. He was only 18 months old, a tiny little body topped off by a big head covered with blond hair.

title: 2 STUDENT PILOTS, ONE WEARING HOOD, SURVIVE MIDAIR COLLISION
description: Two private planes with student pilots at the controls collided in flight over the Pacific Ocean on Friday afternoon, but both pilots managed to land their damaged aircraft safely, the authorities said.

title: Seat Belt Law Shows Good Sense
description: Buoyed by the repeal of mandatory seat belt laws in Massachusetts and Nebraska, a group entitled Citizens Coalition Against a Mandatory Seat Belt Law has renewed its efforts to have a similar law repealed in Connecticut [ ''Repeal of Law on Seat Belts Is Sought,'' Dec. 7 ] .

title: ALAMO MAY SHARE FAME WITH A SPORTS DOME
description: Most visitors to this city think of the Alamo as a tiny shrine where brave Texans died fighting for liberty. Mayor Henry Cisneros wants them to think of a domed sports stadium.

title: Fine Art of Coping With Meeting-Mania
description: The person, perhaps Will Rogers, who observed that at any given moment half the American population is on the way to a meeting while the other half is returning from one, was obviously not very familiar with Washington. The situation here seems much worse.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: A Poll Apart; Where's Best For Business?
description: IT is often hard enough to square the findings of one business poll with those of another. But what about contradictory findings in a single poll?

title: POSTINGS: Milford Offices; Fanning a Pond
description: The developers of a large office complex in Milford, Conn., are making the most of a prime site. One side of the 32-acre property overlooks a large natural pond, the other abuts an exit ramp off Interstate 95.

title: AN AMBITIOUS EXHIBITION EXPLORES WORK OF ETHNIC ARTISTS
description: LIKE many a storefront operation, the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery lives from hand to mouth on the support it gets from Federal, state and city agencies and sometimes from corporations. Still, neither this nor the Spartan-ness of its premises at 1087 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx deters the organization from conceiving of ambitious schemes. Or so it appears in its current group show, ''Origins,'' on view through Jan. 7.

title: A Holiday Dispute
description: He says his reasons are merely legal, but Governor-elect Evan Mecham of Arizona is drawing fire as a new kind of grinch. Following through on a little-noticed campaign pledge, he says he plans to rescind a state holiday honoring the Rev.

title: DEVELOPMENT PROPOSALS ENGULF SOMERS
description: THE town of Somers, already suffering growing pains from two new corporations building there and embroiled in both traffic and litigation, is now facing growth of another type: 1,136 new housing units, either in the concept stage or under construction.

title: Miss McGoldrick Is Married on L.I. To Peter Baxter
description: The marriage of Meegan R. McGoldrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McGoldrick of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Peter E. Baxter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Baxter of Cincinnati, took place yesterday. Msgr. John J. Barry performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City.

title: FINDING CLEAN, TROUT-STOCKED WATER KEEPS GETTING HARDER ALL THE TIME
description: FINDING clear and clean trout-stocked waters in New Jersey has become, in recent years, a disappointing search for anglers. The state's waters were once unspoiled, but time, neglect and disrespect have changed all that.

title: POP MUSIC REMAINS A CULTURAL BAROMETER
description: Pop music is a form of entertainment, a medium of expression and a cultural barometer. In 1986, it was all these things and more. Developments such as the Amnesty International benefits, Bruce Springsteen's increasingly evident social consciousness and the rapprochment between black rap and white rock effected by the Run-D.M.C./Aerosmith hit ''Walk This Way'' were evidence that the music can still serve as a kind of conscience for its audience, and perhaps become a catalyst for change.

title: WHEN THE BOSS IS UNBEARABLE
description: ''MY boss ruled like a dictator,'' recalled Iris Marchaj of her days at an executive placement firm in Massachusetts. ''He liked to threaten people, to keep them on edge. He transferred me from one city to another arbitrarily. When I wanted to know why, he said it was none of my business.

title: CASHING IN BOTTLES, LIVING ON NICKELS
description: Jimmy Lyles was third in a line of eight, waiting his turn to feed 116 bottles into a machine outside the A.& P. at 55th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, and get nickels - $5.80 total - in return. The man behind him had about 400 containers in three shopping carts.

title: OIL PRICES MOVE UP, AT LEAST FOR NOW
description: OPEC's agreement to slash output by 7 percent in the first half of 1987 sent oil prices above $17 a barrel for the first time since September. OPEC's target is $18 a barrel, but most analysts say the spurt in prices was an overreaction to the OPEC agreement. Reached after two weeks of disharmonious talks led by Rilwanu Lukman, Nigeria's oil minister and the chairman of OPEC, the agreement requires all members except Iraq to cut production. More significantly, it requires them to adhere to a price system for crude products that analysts say will not likely be followed. Other OPEC agreements have failed as members - fearful of losing revenues - cheated on quotas or undercut pricing agreements.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a recent article about a vacant municipal office in Rockville Centre, it was erroneously stated that the members of the Board of Trustees, who serve part time, are not paid. The trustees receive $6,000 a year, and the Mayor, who is a member of the board, receives $10,800 a year.

title: CHINA PEEKS WARILY PAST THE OPEN DOOR TO THE WEST
description: SINCE the 19th century, Chinese scholars have been debating how to preserve their country's ''Chineseness'' while at the same time embracing Western science and technology. Some Confucian scholars used to argue that Western scientific knowledge was only a tool that could in the end be used to strengthen traditional values. But others insisted that opening the doors would inexorably erode and destroy the Confucian ethos.

title: Iran, Farce and Marx
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Hanna, Student, to Marry
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Gorham Hanna to Stephen Williams Morss has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Hanna Jr. of Old Chatham, N.Y.
