Mr. Morss is a son of Charles Anthony Morss of Lincoln, Mass., and Shelley Christine Morss of Concord, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
IT'S SPECIAL TIME FOR DAVID RIVES AND HIS FAMILY
description: DAVID RIVERS is an athlete who did not die young. He might have. Last August, Notre Dame's star junior point guard was in an automobile accident that nearly took his life. A van he was riding in pitched off a country road sending him through the front windshield, causing a 15-inch gash across his abdomen.While he lay in a deserted field awaiting help, he was convinced he was going to die.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco;
Condos in A Landmark
description: A FORMER private hospital that had stood vacant for years in a quiet residential neighborhood has been renovated into an elegant condominium apartment complex offering spectacular views of the city as well as a unique investment opportunity.

title: W. VIRGINIA COAL TOWN IS UNDER ONE-MAN RULE
description: The normal checks-and-balances system of government has been taken away from this coal mining town of 780 people in southwestern West Virginia.

title: THE VANISHING WISDOM OF AGE
description: NOT every child ''grows up'' to be an adult, and not every adult grows into an ''old person.''

title: The Vanishing Supply of Rentals
description: JACK PARKER isn't selling. Not just now, at any rate. In 10 years, he may feel differently.

title: GETTING SERIOUS ABOUT DIGITAL
description: For video fans, the year was marked by a colorful spectrum of main events, technical, commercial and political.

title: 8-0 ST. JOHN'S BEATS VIRGINIA IN FESTIVAL
description: St. John's, through its first seven games, had followed an interesting pattern of falling behind early, pulling even at the midway point, then being saved, more or less at the end, by a three-man rescue squad: Mark Jackson, Willie Glass and Shelton Jones.

title: THE DAY AFTER THE NIGHT BEFORE
description: I WILL UNDOUBTEDLY spend New Year's in the country with friends,'' Jonathan Waxman was saying, ''and the menu I plan for New Year's Day will probably include at least one dish to be cooked on an outdoor grill. It's good for re-oxygenating the brain cells when you go outside to check on the heat.''

title: SOME MIXED RESULTS IN A NATIONAL HEALTH CHECKUP
description: SEVEN years ago, when the Public Health Service drew up a list of 226 goals for improved American well-being by 1990, no one had even heard of AIDS. So while the agency last week reported progress on many of the objectives it did set, it conceded that acquired immune deficiency syndrome is the No. 1 health priority.

title: A Fee Fight Looms
description: The Reagan Administration budget proposal due next week is expected to include a provision that drug manufacturers pay a hefty fee to the Food and Drug Administration for examining drugs submitted for marketing approval, and the pharmaceutical industry is gearing up for a fight to oppose it.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THERE are 361 days to Christmas, but that doesn't mean everyone has lost the holiday spirit, especially at Nellie K. Parker Elementary School in Hackensack.

title: CITY TRANSIT OFFICIALS LOOK TO ALBANY FOR YET ANOTHER PUSH
description: RETURNING last week from their latest fiscal pilgrimage to Albany, executives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority still had their hats in their hands.

title: James G. Scripps Is Dead at 75
description: James G. Scripps, a grandson of Edward W. Scripps, the founder of United Press and Scripps-Howard Newspapers, died at his home today, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Scripps, who was the head of two newspaper groups, was 75 years old.

title: Subway Rider's Plight Far Worse Than Crowding Index Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets and Chiefs Met Only Once in Playoffs
description: The Jets and Chiefs have met only once before in the playoffs.

title: Amy Wallace Engaged to Steven Sklar
description: Announcement has been made by Jean Wallace of Syracuse of the engagement of her daughter Amy Beth Wallace to Steven J. Sklar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Sklar of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The wedding is planned for May 17.

title: LEADING DEFENDERS TIE FOR THE LEAD
description: The competition among four Australian 12-Meters for the right to defend the America's Cup forced the two leading defense camps into a point-score tie today.

title: New Orleans
description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: Susan Hunter Brown to Marry Feb. 28
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Hunter Brown to Thomas Goodall Bailey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bailey of Nashville. The wedding is planned for Feb. 28.

title: TAKING A HARD LOOK AT THE CLONES
description: LAST week's column gave an overview of the cloning of I.B.M.'s PC, with the promise of coverage of three specific machines to come. Digging right in, let's look at one rather nicely designed machine, the Equity II ($2,690 with a 20-megabyte hard disk from Epson America, Torrance, Calif., 90509, (213) 539-9140).

title: TAKE THE 'TRENTON' OUT OF TRENTON STATE?
description: THE 210th anniversary of the Battle of Trenton, which took place on Dec. 26, 1776, coincides with the current Battle of Trenton State College.

title: 'DROOD' TWIST: UNDERSTUDY NOW THE STAR
description: DONNA MURPHY'S stage career has taken so many unexpected turns, it is no surprise to find her in a musical that is itself full of surprises.

title: POP WENT THE CULTURE
description: HOPES AND ASHES The Birth of Modern Times, 1929-1939. By Alice G. Marquis. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50. ''HISTORY is all explained by geography,'' Robert Penn Warren once said in an interview. In the media age, one is tempted to add that history is also explained by popular culture. Try describing the 1950's without talking about Marilyn Monroe, or the 60's without discussing rock-and-roll. In the 80's, as critics remind us daily, our politics have become inseparable from television, the primary engine that propels popular culture. One could learn more about why President Reagan has been so popular (at least until recently) by watching one week of ''Entertainment Tonight'' than by studying the history of the Republican Party for a lifetime.

title: Elizabeth Briggs Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Irene Briggs, who teaches piano at the Mary Johnson Piano Studio in West Newbury, Mass., and Dr. David Dubuisson Jr., a neurosurgeon at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at their home in Wayland, Mass. Justice of the Peace Robert English performed the ceremony.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Color Workshops And Matchings Sari is the name on the coral canopy outside and the color consultation service shares the premises with the Haute Couleur Boutique in Mount Kisco. The service enables a shopper to be aware of her color needs and to find clothing and accessories in exact matches, or to have certain styles replicated in the needed shade by Elizabeth Ewing, designer and owner of The Feedback Factory in Dobbs Ferry.

title: ISRAEL SEES A LOSS ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: SOON after the Iran affair erupted, Israeli officials rushed to emphasize that it would have no negative effect on bilateral relations with the United States. A troop of visiting Congressmen passing through Jerusalem during the holiday season repeated the message that all is well between Jerusalem and Washington.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION M
description: MYSTERY OF THE SARDINE. By Stefan Themerson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) Who blows up the black poodle, inadvertently killing poor Mr. McPherson, a dull but persistent scholar ferreting out a bit of literary trivia on the English coast? ''The Mystery of the Sardine'' doesn't offer a satisfactory solution to this conundrum but most readers won't mind a bit.

title: It Takes More Than Poverty to Make Criminals; The Gun Lobby's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH TO PUSH PROTEST ON HULL
description: A new wave of controversy over New Zealand's top-scoring fiberglass yacht has cast a pall over the semifinal races set to begin Sunday for America's Cup challengers.

title: Carson Has Flu, Misses Workout
description: The Giants interrupted their three-day layoff with an 80-minute workout today and then started a two-day stretch away from football. They will return Tuesday to begin practice for their first-round playoff game here the following Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers or the Los Angeles Rams.

title: TOMATOES ARE PROLIFIC ON SUNNY WINDOWSILLS
description: A week before Christmas last year, I had what seemed like a great gift idea for my husband . . . tomato seeds to plant in our new home greenhouse. Dancing in my head were visions of juicy, bright red, vine-ripened tomatoes flowing in an unending stream from greenhouse to table throughout the bleakest months of winter.

title: HELLMAN AND THE COMMUNISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: COMEDY SERIES SET IN MEDEIVAL ENGLAND
description: In the comedy trade, competing with a memory of Monty Python might seem a daunting proposition. Yet, ''The Black Adder,'' a 12-part series making its American debut Saturday night at 11 on Arts and Entertainment, is a situation comedy situated in the same milieu as the popular 1974 film ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' - namely, medieval England. And it is not wholly coincidental: The programs were produced by the BBC, the Python's original nest, and star inveterate Python fan Rowan Atkinson, a favorite of British television and stage, whose recent one-man show on Broadway met with disappointing reviews.

title: History Lesson For Jack Morris
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Alpert Plans Feb. 28 Wedding
description: Rosalind Alice Alpert, a vice president in the investment banking department of the Bankers Trust Company, and Toby Salter Myerson, a partner in the New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married Feb. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alpert of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Myerson of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: A LOOK BACK AT THE YEAR'S BEST
description: THIS was the year that some restaurant cliches of the past gave way to a few new ones, notably Cajun-inspired dishes and mesquite-grilled meats and seafood. Chocolate-mania also was rampant. But 1986 was a first for this column: Only one new three-star restaurant was uncovered. Le Coq Hardi, Westin Hotel, 2701 Summer Street, Stamford (357-0098), is the namesake of its Ridgefield parent and like it offers a nouvelle cuisine menu, under the supervision of the chef, Carl Wright.

title: VERMONT DUMPING IS UP TO PROSECUTOR
description: After four months of delay and reinvestigation, a report on the illegal dumping of tons of construction waste in western Vermont has been forwarded to the State Attorney General's office.

title: Miss Dowling to Wed E. Patrick Logue
description: Anne Melissa Dowling and E. Patrick Logue, who are with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in Hartford, plan to be married Feb. 14.

title: A BUST TAKES NOTE OF A CHORAL DIRECTOR'S LIFETIME IN SONG
description: ON a pedestal in the office of the president of the prestigious Manhattan School of Music on the West Side stands a life-size bronze bust of Hugh Ross of Manhattan and Amangansett.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
AMATEUR'S NIGHT OR THE NIGHT?
description: ''AULD LANG SYNE'' stands no chance of being forgotten with Joan Gilbert around. Mrs. Gilbert, manager of community relations for Texaco and a fixture on Westchester's social circuit, is high-powered and gregarious, not the sort one would easily picture yielding to nostalgia. But there it is on New Year's Eve, that old sentimental streak surfacing one more time.

title: W. E. Tinker Jr. And Miss Tracy To Wed in May
description: Mrs. Vincent T. Tracy of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Heddie Virginia Tracy to William Edward Tinker Jr., the son of Mr. Tinker of Falls Church, Va., and Mrs. Sidney Kweller of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for May 30.

title: PEACE IS HELL
description: BROTHER ENEMY The War After the War. By Nayan Chanda. Illustrated. 479 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: PAPERING A PROBLEM WALL: A HEAVY-DUTY LINING WILL HELP
description: PAINTING over a wall that has a rough or textured surface is seldom much of a problem. But trying to hang wallpaper over such a surface is much more difficult.

title: Miss Taggart To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann Taggart to James Latimer Bellis Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bellis of Bedminster, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Taggart of Oldwick, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEWARK IS EVER RICHER IN REAL ESTATE, BUT STILL CASH POOR
description: WHEN he upset Kenneth A. Gibson last spring to become the chief elected official of New Jersey's largest city, Sharpe James recalled recently, ''I knew it would be the worst and the best of times to become Mayor.''

title: NASA RULING OUT UNMANNED ROCKETS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has ruled out using unmanned rockets to ferry space station components into orbit during the early stages of the project, even though such expendable rockets could speed up construction.

title: A Tenant's View Of 'Upgrading'
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDING WAYS TO RELIEVE PAIN IS GOAL OF YALE CENTER
description: LINDA JOSEPH'S neck began bothering her after she spent several evenings reading '' 'The Clan of the Cave Bear' and the two sequels while lying on my side,'' she said. Before long, the pain had grown so agonizing she could barely hold her head up.

title: THE DOOMSDAY HYPOTHESIS
description: THE MEDICAL IMPLICATIONS OF NUCLEAR WAR Institute of Medicine/ National Academy of Sciences. Edited by Fredric Solomon and Robert Q. Marston. Foreword by Lewis Thomas. 619 pp. Washington: National Academy Press. Cloth, $43.50. Paper, $33.50. THE title of this collection of papers, ''The Medical Implications of Nuclear War,'' suggests a discussion cast in narrow clinical terms. In fact, the volume offers a comprehensive survey of the consequences of a major nuclear exchange, ranging from the carnage caused by blast, fire and radiation to long-term effects on the environment and on human society. This marshaling of the work of experts in many scientific fields creates a harrowing prospect, a kind of multidisciplinary vision of doomsday.

title: FEWER RADIO LISTENERS ARE HEARING THE NEWS
description: WHILE politicians of all persuasions are lately encountering crowds of journalists seeking the latest details and comments on the Iran arms scandal, there are few radio reporters among them. But television reporters and camera crews fill the hearing rooms and news conferences, competing to fill expanded news shows.

title: Topics: Lifted Lids; Sakharov's Return
description: After hailing Andrei Sakharov's return to Moscow after seven cruel years of banishment in the closed city of Gorky, hail the sequel: his welcome at the Physics Institute and the Soviet Government's calm response to his public criticism of the Soviet assault on Afghanistan - the very ''crime'' that led to his banishment under Leonid Brezhnev.

title: An Old Flaw in U.S. Thinking
description: Most analysts of the Administration's actions in Iran have spoken of President Reagan's excessive delegation of authority or of his preoccupation with the hostages. But in some respects the Administration's handling of the ''opening'' toward Iran betrays a flaw that has been common among many Administrations: the assumption that an expression of good will on our part is important in modifying the behavior of hostile regimes.

title: Vermont Renews Chief's Quarters
description: CENTURY-OLD inventories of furniture and a 19th century stereopticon image of the Governor's office in the Vermont State House in Montpelier provided the clues for a recently completed restoration that has left the chamber looking as it did 127 years ago.

title: THE TAMING OF A PARK
description: CENTENNIAL PARK in Roosevelt is an ideal place for children to let their imaginations run wild. A large sand area is filled with brightly colored play equipment, and cement animals form a square next to tennis courts. There are slides, picnic tables and swings.

title: STUDENTS JOIN TO COLLECT GIFTS FOR THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: In schools around the New York metropolitan region, pupils have joined to contribute to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Arsenal Defeats Southampton, 1-0
description: Arsenal, celebrating its 100th birthday, beat Southampton, 1-0, today and opened a 7-point lead in the English League First Division soccer standings.

title: 'BEARING THE CROSS'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Cable Cars Fall From Pylon At French Resort, Injuring 36
description: A pylon snapped at this Alpine ski resort today, sending two cable cars crashing 40 feet down onto a parking lot and injuring 36 people, 12 seriously, officials said.

title: The Handball High
description: I think that all players who can lose themselves in a physically demanding sport experience a high.

title: JEWISH DIVORCE LAW PLAGUES WIVES
description: Thousands of Orthodox Jewish women who have received civil divorces remain unable to remarry because their husbands are unwilling to grant them traditional Jewish divorces, according to Jewish leaders.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS 2 OFFICERS KILLED
description: A captured black nationalist guerrilla killed two white police officers and escaped today after a series of skirmishes in northern South Africa. Four other guerrillas were shot to death, the police said.

title: THIS WAS THE YEAR OF THE FOREIGN INVASION
description: The early tidings announced that the British were coming. And so they did - along with the French, the Chinese, the Spaniards, the Canadians and many more. It was the year of the foreign invasion in dance. The impact of visiting companies was the strongest in a decade - both in numbers and the quality they demonstrated.

title: Anti-Drug Camera Protested
description: Students at Beverly High School are complaining that they are being unfairly videotaped by hidden police cameras on the lookout for illicit drug sales.

title: RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETTE
description: The Wine Video Richard Marcus Productions. 250 West 54th Street New York, N.Y., 10019. 144 minutes (two cassettes).

title: GROUP MARKS 20 YEARS OF FIGHTING FOR RIGHTS
description: It began as a legal support network for the civil rights movement then under way in the South, but today the Center for Constitutional Rights is just as likely to be found challenging American foreign policy in Central America as bringing voting rights cases in Mississippi.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Tinton Falls Gets a Surge of Development
description: WITH its abundance of virgin land, Tinton Falls is a borough on the threshold of substantial economic growth.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: McGUIRES IN MILLBURN The McGuire Sisters and their orchestra, direct from Las Vegas with a new nightclub act, will be at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn New Year's Eve for two shows at 7 and 10 P.M. Tickets are $30, $40 and $45. The songs ''Sincerely,'' ''May You Always,'' ''Something's Gotta Give,'' ''Sugartime,'' ''Just for Old Time's Sake'' and ''How Much Is That Doggie in the Window?'' are among the more than 30 hits the sisters have had since they first performed on the Arthur Godfrey Show on radio and television.

title: BEST SELLERS: FICTION
description: 1 1 16 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 2 8 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 3 3 22 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 4 4 9 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $18.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 5 6 13 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 6 5 11 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A top New York model encounters three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 7 7 9 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 8 8 11 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $16.95.) The hero of the ''Foundation'' series searches for the lost planet Earth. 9 9 24 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 10 12 24 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 11 10 12 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.'' 12 5 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. 13 11 17 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's life in 18th-century England and France. 14 15 13 ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers. 15 14 14 THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Forty years in a small North Dakota town near an Indian reservation. (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) MARILYN, by Gloria Steinem. Photographs by George Barris. (Holt, $24.95.) A thoughtful, absorbing biography of Marilyn Monroe, an unusually intelligent woman the greatest of whose many misfortunes may have been her desire to please. THE CENTURY'S DAUGHTER, by Pat Barker. (Putnam, $16.95.) This cheerfully political novel encapsulates the miseries of the century in the final year of an aged working-class Englishwoman. THE FALL OF KELVIN WALKER: A Fable of the Sixties, by Alasdair Gray. (Braziller, $14.95.) Mr. Gray, the Scottish visionary writer and painter, deploys his themes of human subjugation and the corruption of language in the career of his novel's hero, a naive, successful television interviewer. THE PERPETUAL ORGY: Flaubert and Madame Bovary, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) An account of the Peruvian novelist's obsession with Flaubert's heroine and a brilliant discussion of the genesis, execution, structure and technique of ''Madame Bovary.'' LEARNED PIGS & FIREPROOF WOMEN, by Ricky Jay. (Villard, $29.95.) Lively accounts, richly illustrated, of some of history's most peculiar performers, by a magician and archivist of magic. WILLA CATHER: The Emerging Voice, by Sharon O'Brien. (Oxford University, $24.95.) This scholarly, imaginative biography re-creates the first 40 years of a life Cather tried to conceal - her struggle to find her stance as a woman and as a writer. COLLECTED STORIES: 1948-1986, by Wright Morris. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Spare in their furniture but impeccable in their detail, Mr. Morris's frugal stories often focus on dislocation and the difficulty of adjusting to change. 1 1 34 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 8 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 3 3 12 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) From Hoboken to superstardom: an unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 4 4 14 MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 5 5 6 WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Putnam, $16.95.) A new collection of columns by the journalist and television personality. 6 7 32 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 7 6 5 LIFE: The First Fifty Years, 1936-1986. (Little, Brown, $50.) The past half-century as seen in the magazine's photographs. 8 8 4 THE CHRISTMAS DAY KITTEN, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) An illustrated true story. 9 10 42 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 10 11 13 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football by the television commentator and former coach of the Oakland Raiders. 11 9 5 PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A biography of the wife of the 37th President written by her daughter. 12 12 9 ONE MORE TIME, by Carol Burnett. (Random House, $18.95.) The comedian's autobiography, beginning with her impoverished childhood in Hollywood. 13 13 12 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. 14 14 11 THE STORY OF ENGLISH, by Robert McCrum, William Cran and Robert MacNeil. (Sifton/Viking, $24.95.) Companion volume to the PBS series about the world's most widely used language. 15 15 6 EISENHOWER AT WAR: 1943-1945, by David Eisenhower. (Random House, $29.95.) A biography of the general by his grandson. 1 1 9 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 2 2 46 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. 3 4 9 BE HAPPY YOU ARE LOVED, by Robert H. Schuller. (Nelson, $15.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 4 1 BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOK BOOK. (Meredith, $16.95.) The ninth edition; ring-bound. 5 5 2 BETTY CROCKER'S COOKBOOK. (Golden Press/Western Publishing, $19.95.) New, revised ring-bound edition.

title: Poor Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CRIME
description: It may be a common expression out West, but how many on this side of the nation have ever heard Los Angeles referred to as La-La Land? That's in the title of Robert Campbell's IN LA-LA LAND WE TRUST (Mysterious Press, $15.95). Robert Campbell is also known as R. Wright Campbell, whose fine mystery-suspense novel ''Malloy's Subway'' was published in 1981. More recently, writing as Robert Campbell, he came out with ''The Junkyard Dog,'' one of the best crime paperbacks of 1986.

title: Julia Kremer to Wed David W. F. Ross 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen Dean Kremer of Berkeley Heights, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Joanne Kremer, to David William Flemming Ross 3d, the son of Mr. Ross 2d of Stamford, Conn., and the late Joan R. Ross.

title: AFRICAN NATIONS STRUGGLE TO MAKE TELEVISION THEIR OWN
description: AFTER watching a battery-powered television set at the local school, villagers in the Ivory Coast, the West African nation, were asked to comment. A brooding old man inquired: ''Why are whites always stabbing, shooting and punching one another?'' The baffled elder's question, in the largely traditional village of N'zikpi, might have popped up in any of the two dozen or so African countries that have set up television stations but find themselves without enough programs of their own.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH TEHERAN
description: REVOLUTIONARY IRAN: Challenge and Response in the Middle East By R. K. Ramazani 311 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, $27.50

title: DUKAKIS TURNS EYE TO WHITE HOUSE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis smiles broadly when asked if he has ambitions for office beyond Massachusetts, and he promises to think about the question next year.

title: THE WORKSHOP OF HIS FICTION
description: THE COMPLETE NOTEBOOKS OF HENRY JAMES Edited by Leon Edel and Lyall H. Powers. Illustrated. 633 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30.

title: ARGENTINA AND URUGUAY PARDON SOME OLD ABUSES
description: THERE were noisy, emotional and sometimes violent reactions last week to the enactment of a law that will largely halt prosecutions of Argentine military officers accused of human rights violations.

title: A CROWDED EARTH
description: The world's population is expected to reach 6.2 billion by the year 2000, according to a report released last week by the Census Bureau. The bureau found a decline in population growth in all regions except Africa, which it said is growing at twice the rate of the rest of the world. The report also said the number of cities with more than 2 million people would double over the next 15 years, with nearly half the world's population living in urban areas by the year 2000.

title: 10 Killed in Punjab Attacks; Radical Sikhs Are Suspected
description: Terrorists thought to be Sikh extremists killed 10 people, including a family of 4, over a 24-hour span in the Punjab, and the police imposed a curfew today in Amritsar to prevent retaliatory violence by Hindus.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WINK. By Evelyn Harter. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) An American couple, Leland and Andria Holt, arrive in India, each with a mission.

title: PLANNING FOR THE DAY YOU STRIKE IT RICH
description: ''FROM the skewed view of my clientele, 1986 was a terrific year,'' says Robert A. Clarfeld of Clarfeld & Company, a Manhattan accounting firm that specializes in financial planning for executives. For one thing, with taxes on capital gains rising to a maximum 28 percent in 1987, from 20 percent now, many asset-rich owners have been cashing in appreciated stock, real estate and even their businesses, while many professionals profited by helping them cut the deals. One of Mr. Clarfeld's clients, a young investment banker, received a bonus check for $1.5 million.

title: A Return to Work
description: Freed to return to Moscow and to his work after seven years of exile in Gorky, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, had cautious words of praise last week for the man who sprung him. Dr. Sakharov said he had ''great respect'' for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has lately encouraged a more open society and who ordered Dr. Sakharov's release to underscore that policy. The physicist said that when Mr. Gorbachev telephoned to inform him of his release, he encouraged the Soviet leader to free other political and religious dissenters.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 28, 1986
MYSTERY PLAYOFF FOR JETS
description: This is the year of the unknown quarterbacks and the unknown teams in the National Football League playoffs, which start today with the Jets facing the Kansas City Chiefs at Giants Stadium.

title: ALTERNATIVE SOUGHT FOR HEALTH AGENCIES
description: IN central New Jersey, 16 nursing-home operators want to expand or build new facilities.

title: THE CAROUSEL PROJECTOR IS HALE AT 25
description: THIS was a year of significant remembrances, from the centennial of the birth of Edward Weston, the great Modernist photographer, to the 50th anniversary of Life magazine, the erstwhile beacon of photojournalism. These have not gone unnoticed: Weston has been remembered with a half-dozen museum shows, and Life has published a special commemorative issue and a book of its all-time greatest pictures.

title: Israeli Prisoner Shows His Hand
description: With a touch of Hitchcock melodrama, the accused Israeli spy waited until he was close to journalists outside the Jerusalem courthouse where he was about to make an appearance, escorted by police. Then he flashed open his left hand for the reporters to see and the photographers to shoot the message he had written in English on his palm: ''Vanunu M. was hijacked in Rome Itl 30.9.86.2100 came to Rome by BA fly 504.''

title: BEIJING TO OFFER VOTERS A CHOICE IN CITY ELECTION
description: In a dramatic change in the way local elections are held in Beijing, the city government announced today that there would be more than one candidate for each seat in municipal elections.

title: REAGAN SEES GAIN IN U.S. SOVIET TIES
description: President Reagan today offered a favorable assessment of the year in terms of superpower relations, saying that ''this year, relations between the United States and the Soviet Union advanced.''

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: ''YES,'' SAID President Reagan affirmatively, in defense of his stewardship of foreign policy, ''it is in our interest to stand with those who would take arms against the sea of darkness.''

title: Indians Assail U.S. on Housing
description: Thousands of Indian families across the nation are homeless because new controls are severely limiting Federal financing for housing construction, Indian leaders say.

title: Anne Wuesthoff Is Bride Of Robert Shaw Bridges
description: The marriage of Anne Louise Wuesthoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Wm. Wuesthoff of Milwaukee, to Robert Shaw Bridges, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. Willard Bridges of Marion, Mass., took place yesterday in Milwaukee.

title: LOOKING AHEAD TO 1987 CONCERTS
description: THERE'S still time to ring out the old year in music - the Concert Society of Putnam and Northern Westchester has a Baroque fest at 8 o'clock this evening in Somers' St. Luke's Church (Bach, Manfredini and Couperin concertos for trumpets and strings: call 225-9204 or 277-8564 for reservations) - and ballet lovers can pull in three more ''Nutcrackers'' through the Westchester Ballet Company performances at 2:30 P.M. today, tomorrow and Tuesday at Marymount College (762-4228).

title: In Business To Treat Cancer
description: Isn't the key word ''business,'' not a selfless concern for those with cancer? Does there always have to be some kind of selfish motive? Cancer treatment expected to cost $35,000, or more, means that many won't even have a chance to gamble in the Biotherapeutics Inc. ''wheel of fortune.'' ELEANORE TONS SCHNURR New York City

title: Q&A
description: C. of O. for Artist's Lofts Question: We manage a loft building in Manhattan. One floor is used as a business and artists live and work on the second and third floors. The Department of Buildings issued certificates of occupancy for these artist-in-residence spaces in October 1962; they were not registered with the Loft Board because it did not exist at that time. Do we need a C. of O. for the building even though we have these documents? . . . Y. Z., Manhattan

title: IN A CRISIS, 'TELL IT ALL AND TELL IT FAST'
description: ''Communicating When Your Company Is Under Siege,'' by Marion K. Pinsdorf. Lexington Books, D.C. Heath & Co., Lexington, Mass. 171 pages, $21.95.

title: Alison Elise Paul, Administrator, Plans To Marry Douglas G. Miller, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Sachse of Baton Rouge, La., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Alison Elise Paul, to Douglas Gilmore Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Miller Jr. of Stamford, Conn., and East Grand Lake, Me. The wedding is planned for April 25.

title: FLORA IN FLIGHT FROM PLASTIC
description: WET PAINT By Gwynn Popovac. 373 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: A WEEK NO LESS PAINFUL THAN ITS RECENT PREDECESSORS
description: IT was a splendid Christmas present - perfect in its timing, perfect in its fulfillment of national longings - the sight of the frail aircraft known as the Voyager settling awkwardly to earth in California last Tuesday after a nine-day circumnavigation of the globe, an epic journey that bore the stamp of Lindbergh and Magellan.

title:
HOME DESIGN;
THE SUBJECT IS ROSES
description: For centuries, roses have been the subject of poems and paintings. They are also the new American national flower. But their allure is an international one.

title: A New Attack On Standards for Fuel Economy
description: The President's Task Force on Regulatory Relief, established to make good on Ronald Reagan's promise to ''get the Government off the backs of the people,'' was quietly disbanded in 1983, some said in anticipation of potentially bruising debate in the 1984 elections. This month, it was back in action again with a new mandate: to promote productivity and international competitiveness.

title: BETRAYED IN HER FANTASIES
description: PUBIS ANGELICAL By Manuel Puig. Translated by Elena Brunet. 236 pp. New York: Aventura/Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: WRITE ABOUT WHAT YOU KNOW, BIG BANG OR GRECIAN URN
description: OVER dinner recently I became enmeshed, as one still does in the United States 30 years after C. P. Snow's ''Two Cultures'' appeared in The New Statesman and Nation, in a discussion on the relative merits of the sciences and the humanities. One of the writers present, an essayist and medical administrator, argued for the objective truth of the sciences and the overwhelming role of opinion in literature and literary criticism. Another, a much-published science writer, argued that science writing is always about the unknown, its discourse an eternal questioning.

title: SUTHERLAND AND CARNEGIE BRIGHTENED THE PAGES OF HISTORY
description: To designate with confidence a handful of musical events out of the hundreds or thousands that filtered through one's ears during this year is both easy and impossible. Easy, because a couple of eagerly awaited major happenings lived up to advance billing and thus became lock-tight certainties to find a place in musical history. The appearance of Joan Sutherland in the Metropolitan's ''Puritani'' will go down in music's annals, I feel sure, as will the architectural facelift that brightened the face and sound of Carnegie Hall.

title: A DOMINICAN RESPITE FROM REALITY
description: There are 2 18-hole golf courses, 2 polo fields and 150 polo ponies, 13 tennis courts, 8 swimming pools, a small gymnasium with saunas and massage, 9 restaurants, a fleet of fishing and sailing boats, a skeet-shooting range, a discotheque, an art colony, a small museum, a bookstore and several thousand acres of peace and quiet.

title: Basel
description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: THOUGHTFUL, BALANCED JOURNALISM ILLUMINATED THE SCREEN
description: The big ongoing story came only at the end of the year. The Iran arms affair took over news broadcasts and showed signs that it would remain. In a curious, even perverse, way, this was a relief. Think quickly now: When were Reykjavik, Bitburg and Bhopal? Was the midterm election this year or last? Great events, big scandals and terrible tragedies are disposable commodities on television; it is the nature of the medium to hasten on to other matters. News is speeded up, so to speak, and leaves behind mostly images. Reykjavik (or was it Geneva?) was a cold correspondent in a trenchcoat; Bitburg was a row of cemetery markers. This is unsatisfactory. Surely there should be more. How do we make sense of what is happening? What saves us, and also saves television, are the intermittent shafts of light. Someone pauses for thought.

title: DANCE
description: There appears to be revived interest in both Expressionist art in general and, specifically, in the Expressionist modern dance that flourished in Germany until the Nazis squelched it in the 30's. Expressionism is the inspiration for Phyllis Lamhut's ''Klein Kunst (Small Art),'' which the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company presents Sunday afternoon and Monday, Tuesday, Friday and Saturday nights at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: CHANGES IN O'CONNOR TRIP UPSET JEWISH LEADERS
description: Several American Jewish leaders voiced regrets yesterday over changes in John Cardinal O'Connor's impending visit to Israel, saying it has now been tainted by Middle Eastern politics.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A RESOLUTE BREAKER OF RESOLUTIONS
description: LIFE has a way of running away with time and the stoutest of resolutions. I should know.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a review Nov. 30 of ''Northrop Frye on Shakespeare'' incorrectly characterized an earlier book by Mr. Frye, ''Anatomy of criticism.'' Mr. Frye's discussions of Milton's epics, Blake's ''fearful symmetry,'' English Romanticism and T. S. Eliot are found in his other writings.

title: RE-ENACTED RAGEDIES OF STREET LIFE BRING HELP TO JUNIOR HIGH STUDENTS
description: THEY perform plays about cocaine, incest, teen-age pregnancy, fallen heroes and broken dreams. Off Broadway? No, junior high schools -so students can watch on stage dramas that mirror life in the streets.

title: Miss Albert Wed To S.R. Hubbard
description: Elizabeth Jane Albert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Albert of Hamilton, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Stevan Ralph Hubbard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hubbard of Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Francis Malooly performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PATCH BOYS. By Jay Parini. (Henry Holt, $15.95.) Jay Parini's second novel - coming after two volumes of poetry and a study of Theodore Roethke - covers the familiar working-class territory explored by Henry Roth, James T. Farrell and numerous others.

title: Jane Giammattei to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Giammattei Jr. of Greenville, Del., and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Seymour Giammattei, to E. Laurence White 3d, a son of Mrs. White Jr. of Washington, Conn., and the late Mr. White. The future bride is an advertising sales representative of Historical Times Inc. in New York. Mr. White is a vice president in the municipal bond department at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: A 'WELCOME SPOT' FOR YOUNG PEOPLE
description: ''I'M going home,'' the 15-year-old announced joyfully to Terry Evans, who heads the Lincoln Unit for Adolescents at Trenton Psychiatric Hospital.

title: Stacy J. Kanter Plans To Wed Eric Kornblau
description: Announcement has been made by Elaine Kanter of New York and Miami Beach of the engagement of her daughter Stacy Jaye Kanter to Eric Martin Kornblau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Kornblau of New York and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, L.I.

title: Britain's Whole Earth Guru
description: Hats off to Lawrence E. Joseph for his article ''Britain's Whole Earth Guru'' (Nov. 23)! With all respect to James Lovelock and Richard Dawkins, this writer has very well described a quarrel of personal viewpoint that must necessarily get in the way of their science.

title: POSTINGS: Off Grand Army Plaza; A 20's Revival
description: It was built in the 1920's off Grand Army Plaza, in what was then one of Brooklyn's most fashionable areas. But 44 Butler Place started to slip as the suburban exodus accelerated, and by the late 1960's the building had been abandoned.

title: Selling Short
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT IS SO RARE AS A FRUITCAKE EATEN?
description: HAVE I got a treat for all of you. I am about to conduct a raffle. Right now. Today. Right here. ''What on earth is she talking about?'' I can hear somebody out there asking. And, in a rather nasty tone of voice, I can hear another somebody saying: ''What is the fool up to? Raffle what?''

title: Buildings With Room to Hold a Party
description: WHEN Dr. Joel Clifford Newman asked a few dozen friends and potential business clients over for some Christmas cheer and buffet earlier this month, they came not to his fifth-floor condominium apartment at the Kingsley but to the Sky Lounge on the 31st floor.

title: 2 ARMED MEN HELD IN TRUCK HIJACKING
description: Two armed men hijacked an armored van carrying up to $500,000 in a crowded shopping area of West New York, N.J., yesterday, kidnapped the driver and a courier, and fired at least nine times at police officers in a 20-minute chase through four northern New Jersey communities.

title: DRAMAS WITH STRONG CASTS DELIVERED MOVING ENTERTAINMENT
description: The business of television was, more than ever, the significant factor concerning what you may or may not have watched in 1986. The commercial networks appeared to have stemmed, at least temporarily, the severe erosion of their audiences. The enormous success of one sitcom, the two-year-old ''Cosby Show,'' continues to prove a boon not only to NBC and its much vaunted ratings victories but also to industry statistics as a whole. As in the theater, a smash hit is good for everybody's business.

title: MURALS: A HUGE ART FORM THAT IS REGAINING WIDE FAVOR
description: A PISTOL-PACKING Samuel Colt hob-nobs with the rifle-manufacturer Christian Sharps while a nattily attired Mark Twain, poised by his handsome red high-wheel bicycle, looks on. Meanwhile, hot-air balloons race across the New Haven Harbor. Elsewhere, Charles Goodyear is busy vulcanizing rubber, while, across the state, no less than the entire History of Civilization marches on.

title: THE PURCELL LEGACY: STEADY COURSE IN NASSAU
description: ONE of Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell's favorite expressions is ''snow melts.'' Indeed, many of Mr. Purcell's fellow politicians believe that it is more than an expression, it is a Purcell philosophy of government.

title: Next Week; Should Freshmen Athletes Be Eligible?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Jarvis Sets Streak
description: AS soon as Doug Jarvis took the opening face-off for the Whalers against Montreal Friday night in Hartford, he was assured the National Hockey League record of playing in 915 consecutive games. The streak started 12 seasons ago when he broke into the league with the Canadiens, but his pattern of durability had been ingrained long before.

title: AT THIS HIGH SCHOOL, STUDENTS CAN'T WAIT FOR CLASSES TO START
description: EVEN before school began in September, 14-year-old Joseph Williams felt like one of the youngsters on the television series ''Fame.''

title: BEHIND THE GIANTS' SURGE, THE BIG PLAY BY SIMMS
description: IN a pro football game, a team normally has 60 to 70 plays on offense, 60 to 70 on defense and 20 to 25 in kicking situations. Over a 16-game regular season, that works out to 2,240 to 2,640 plays.

title: 62 Are Killed In Hijacking Of Iraqi Jetliner
description: Because of the Iran-Iraq war, Iraqi Airways' Flight 163 from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan, took a detour over Saudi Arabia on Christmas day. Shortly after the plane crossed the Saudi border at 28,000 feet, a hijacker brandishing plastic grenades ran up the aisle, and Iraqi security officers began shooting.

title: TRUCE PANEL CITES PHILIPPINE REBELS
description: A committee monitoring compliance with a cease-fire agreement between the Government and Communist guerrillas ruled today that the rebels had violated the truce by displaying arms at a rally.

title: Citizenry Challenged On Disposing of Waste
description: I agree that we should promote existing recycling processes and stimulate technology to devise methods for efficiently utilizing household waste, but the final solution lies within the citizenry.

title: MAINE TOWN DIVIDED BY BITTER STRIKE
description: The black-suited security guards have left the Boise Cascade Corporation's paper mill in this small town in the mountains of western Maine. Gone, too, are the angry, jeering picketers.

title: SAMPLING THE BOWL GAME INGREDIENTS
description: SEVERAL years ago Notre Dame and Pittsburgh both had potentially good teams, but did not play each other that season. We are both independents, and I remember kidding with the Fiesta Bowl people, telling them that if my school, Notre Dame, and Pittsburgh both wound up undefeated we could go to their bowl and play for the national championship. And I said, ''I bet you'd get enough money to make it worthwhile.''

title: Expect More Racism
description: Three recent events of widely different kinds and in widely separated parts of America remind us that despite all of our self-congratulation - and denials - relations between blacks and whites are rarely better than uneasy, and often burst out terrifyingly.

title: WHEELS WITHIN WHEELS
description: The same instinct that assures us that the sun will rise tomorrow also allows us to believe that an object, transported over any distance, will be the same when it reaches its destination. A lawn mower bought in Dallas and trucked to San Francisco will, barring any catastrophe, be the same lawn mower. But what about cars?

title: WIVES, MISTRESSES AND WORKING WOMEN
description: THE MOTHER OF DREAMS And Other Short Stories: Portrayals of Women in Modern Japanese Fiction. Edited by Makoto Ueda. 279 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $19.95.

title: City Is Advised to Abolish Taxi Panel
description: Its initials stand for tender loving care, and that's just what New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission has been giving the taxi industry too much of, the State Commission of Investigation said last week. The chairman of the watchdog agency, David G. Trager, said the taxi commission had been ''co-opted by the industry that it was set up to regulate.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WHEN a book asks if you really want to make a million, it can be hard to put down. So it is with ''Sweat Equity: What It Really Takes to Build America's Best Small Companies by the Guys Who Did It,'' by Geoffrey N. Smith and Paul B. Brown (Simon & Schuster, New York, $17.95), a collection of accounts about entrepreneurs.

title: It Takes More Than Poverty to Make Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: ART
description: For ''Columns by Artists,'' the 14 Sculptors Gallery, at 164 Mercer Street, asked 38 artists to make columns that in some way reflected their responses to New York City. The restrictions were that the sculptures not be taller than seven feet or wider than two feet.

title: RESIDENTS RACE CLOCK FOR NORTH SEA SITE
description: A GROUP of South Fork residents face a Jan. 1 deadline in their effort to raise enough money to purchase a parcel of wooded land on the shore of Big Fresh Pond, in North Sea, in order to preserve the site.

title: Impressing the Russians
description: Soviet visitors often profess to be unimpressed by American technology, but there are exceptions. Earlier this month, a Soviet delegation that included Viktor G. Afanasyev, the editor of Pravda, was in Washington to confer on arrange-ments for Congress Bridge, a series of satellite television exchanges between policy-makers in the two countries that is scheduled to take place next March.

title: Judith E. Hersh Weds Alan Howard Kurland
description: Judith Ellen Hersh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Hersh of Freehold, N.J., was married last night to Alan Howard Kurland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Kurland of Clifton, N.J. Rabbis Yale Fishman and Stanley Skolnick officiated at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MURDER UNDER TWO FLAGS: The U.S., Puerto Rico, and the Cerro Maravilla Cover-up. By Anne Nelson. (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) On July 25, 1978, Puerto Rican police shot and killed two young supporters of Puerto Rican independence who had allegedly planned to sabotage communication transmission towers on a mountaintop called Cerro Maravilla.

title: SAILORS BRAVE THE BIG CHILL
description: IN summer, Long Island is a playground for boaters; on a sunny afternoon the boat traffic can get as thick as midtown traffic. Winter quells the mayhem, chasing boaters into hibernation, and the waters empty like a playground after sunset.

title: Elizabeth Schreier To Marry in June
description: Elizabeth Rosa Schreier and Thomas Grahame Davis, 1986 and 1985 graduates, respectively, of Tulane University, plan to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Schreier Jr. of Garden City, L.I., have announced. Mr. Davis is the son of Leroy Grahame Davis of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Sheila Higgins Davis of Ridgewood, N.J.

title: THE CARE AND TENDING OF GREAT IDEAS
description: ''Land of Opportunity: The Entrpreneurial Spirit in America,'' by Donald Lambro. Little, Brown & Co., Boston. 176 pages, $17.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Correction
description: An article in Arts and Leisure on Dec. 14 about the ''New Photography 2'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art omitted the name of the show's sponsor. It is Springs Industries.

title: AFGHAN EXILES MARK SOVIET INTERVENTION
description: Afghan exiles burned Soviet flags and an effigy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in protests here today marking the seventh anniversary of the Soviet military intervention.

title: New Peace Move In Central America
description: The start of a new effort to revive peace negotiations in Central American was announced last week by eight Latin American governments, who said the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States would join them.

title: DEVILS ARE TIED ON LATE GOAL, 2-2
description: Michel Goulet scored with 2 minutes 2 seconds remaining in regulation tonight to allow the Quebec Nordiques to salvage a 2-2 tie against New Jersey after Alain Chevrier made 38 saves for the Devils.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: Twenty-three students from four sixth-grade classes of the Ward School in New Rochelle recently had an unusual opportunity to experience life without electricity. In a day spent at Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown, they did farm chores, open-hearth cooking, milling and textile work as they would have in the 18th century.

title: HIGH-LEVEL HIGH TIMES FOR BOSTON'S NEW YEAR
description: Next week, seven teams of sculptors wielding chain saws and chisels will carve oversized statues out of 87,000 pounds of ice that will be delivered to Copley Square in Boston.

title: Venice
description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: MOZART: HSTORY AND INTERPRETATION
description: Mozart is one composer whose music seems to be able to withstand a variety of interpretations, from the most bloated Romantic effusions to the most ascetic historical re-creations. Perhaps because Mozart's mature style is a synthesis of Baroque counterpoint, Rococo elegance, Classical balance and pre-Romantic emotion, different performances are able to accentuate one facet of the music without violating its essential spirit.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: EACH year contains about 8,760 hours, but for a married suburban male - at least this married suburban male - only 42 hours of that is available for listening to the stereo as it is supposed to be listened to, according to the results of a 28-year study.

title: Fear of Blacks, Fear of Crime
description: It's very easy to spot a black person in this neighborhood, and whenever I see one, I know he's up to no good. They come in the neighborhood and rob everybody. It's a known fact. That's why everybody has a thing about them.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: MAYBE it's age, maybe it's that more people are getting smarter, but somehow New Year's Eve doesn't seem to be what it once was. The number of people who stay home that night seems to increase each year, and if they're not home, they're having quiet little dinners with friends at other homes or in restaurants. But no matter how quiet, or even nonexistent, current celebrations are, there's usually at least one memorable eve in most people's backgrounds.

title: 6 AMERICAN TOURISTS ARE AMONG 11 DEAD IN PLANE CRASH IN FIJI
description: Eleven people, including six American tourists, were reported killed today when a light aircraft crashed while attempting a landing at Fiji's international airport at Nadi.

title: WALL STREET BEMOANS A NEW 'GREENMAIL' SEASON
description: ''I THOUGHT greenmail was dead,'' said Martin Lipton of Wachtell, Lipton Rosen & Katz recently. ''Now all of a sudden it is back, alive and well.''

title: Nassau Democrats Are Not 'Moribund'
description: I was appalled to read the article on Thomas S. Gulotta [ ''Gulotta Cautious on Future Path,'' Dec. 7 ] .

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, several words were omitted from a paragraph in Joan D. Abrams's Dec. 14 Opinion article supporting school district takeovers by the state. The paragraph, referring to provisions for the removal of central office personnel and for a one-year review of principal effectiveness, should have read as follows:

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLE TO OPEN 'Y' SERIES
description: THE Claring Chamber Players will be the guest performers next Sunday in the opening program of the Distinguished Artists Series at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey.

title: Kristie Sanford To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Sanford of Fox Chapel, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristie Lee Sanford to Ronald Steven Staffieri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Staffieri of Hicksville, L.I. An April wedding is planned. The future bride, a branch divisional merchandiser at the M. O'Neil Company, a department store in Akron, Ohio, graduated from Southern Methodist University, having studied in Paris her junior year.

title: Barbara Mastoloni to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Mastoloni of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Mastoloni, to Russell Jagoe 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jagoe of Trumbull, Conn. Miss Mastoloni and her fiance graduated with the class of '84 from Pennsylvania State University. Her father is president of Frank Mastoloni & Sons in New York, an importer of cultured pearls.

title: THE MAN WHO DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: MONTY: Final Years of the Field-Marshal, 1944-976. By Nigel Hamilton

title: DISTILLING THE HEADY FLAVOR OF EARLY CHEKHOV
description: Writing about Chekhov's first extant full-length play, Henri Troyat (in his biography, ''Chekhov'') says, ''For all its melodrama, chaos and verbosity, this immature work contains all the great Chekhovian themes in embryo.'' Acting as Chekhov's collaborator and editor, Michael Frayn has reduced the melodrama, trimmed the verbosity and made the chaos seem more comic. The result, ''Wild Honey,'' is one of those rare adaptations that is faithful to the spirit, if not the letter, of the original. The play draws strength from the dual authorship - the young Chekhov's ebullience and incipient sensibility, combined with Mr. Frayn's knowledge of dramaturgy. If Chekhov had had the time and the inclination to revise and polish his early play, it might have become ''Wild Honey'' - the comedy that Chekhov never wrote.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about the Standard Oil Company on Dec. 14 incorrectly reported volume of production from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay oilfield. The correct figure is 1.5 million barrels a day.

title: Yugoslavs Beat Americans, 98-90
description: France and Yugoslavia advanced to the final of a four-team French Christmas basketball tournament by posting victories today.

title: SELF-REPRESENTATION UPHELD
description: A defendant has won the right to a new trial because he was not allowed to act as his own lawyer when he was convicted of burglary and arson.

title: ATHLETE'S DEATH DIMINISHES THE PRIDE AND GLORY
description: THE Mets won the World Series. Jack Nicklaus won his sixth Masters at age 46. Bill Shoemaker won his fourth Kentucky Derby at age 54. Mike Tyson won the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship at age 20. The Giants won 14 games, the most victories in any of the pro football franchise's 62 seasons.

title: PLAYING FOR PAR
description: What the coelacanth is to zoologists, the par contest is to bridge-players. The coelacanth is a primitive creature that was believed to be long extinct and suddenly surfaces, alive and well.

title: Doctor Didn't Know
description: ACCORDING to Bill Arnsparger, the football coach at Louisiana State, it was a private physician who was unaware of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's ban on any form of anabolic steroids who prescribed the steroids to Roland Barbay that were detected in a drug test and that will keep the Tigers' defensive end out of Thursday's Sugar Bowl meeting with Nebraska. The school received notice from the N.C.A.A. Friday that Barbay had tested positive for steroids and was ineligible to play in the game.

title: SHOREHAM, LAND PLAN MARK COHALAN YEARS
description: ''TIME will tell,'' an expression Peter F. Cohalan sometimes used to parry questions about future plans and probabilities during his seven years as Suffolk County Executive, seemed fitting words last week as Mr. Cohalan prepared to leave office.

title:
HOME DESIGN;
THE SUBJECT IS ROSES: PARIS
description: For centuries, roses have been the subject of poems and paintings. They are also the new American national flower. But their allure is an international one.

title: A WHIFF OF HIGH TECH COMES TO CANDLMAKING
description: WHEN Mike Kittredge was 17 years old in 1969, he had no money to buy Christmas presents. So he decided to make them. Using milk cartons for molds, Mr. Kittredge made candles on his parents' kitchen stove.

title: DRUG RAID MAKES MARK ON STREET
description: LONG ISLAND police officers say that Prospect Avenue in New Cassel has long been a major marketplace for illegal drugs, especially the form of cocaine called crack. But a large-scale predawn raid recently conducted by the Nassau County Police Department has left the street, once bustling with drug sellers, almost deserted.

title: A.M.A. Sues Over Medicare Limits
description: The American Medical Association filed suit last week in an effort to keep new Medicare provisions from taking effect Wednesday.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
RESOURCE RECOVERY: FACTS FOR BOTH SIDES
description: THE state's patented march toward a comprehensive network of garbage-burning resource-recovery plants has been slowed by groups citing the damaging effects of dioxin and other stack emissions on people and the environment.

title: REDSKINS AND RAMS SEEKING TO RECAPTURE EARLY FORM
description: A month ago, both teams had loftier ambitions than entering the playoffs as a wild-card team. In one division, the Washington Redskins were tied for the lead with the Giants, as they had been for six weeks. In another, the Los Angeles Rams were leading the San Francisco 49ers by a game and a half.

title: POLITICAL PRISONERS: THE SAKHAROV LIST
description: Andrei D. Sakharov used an interview here today to draw attention to several imprisoned dissidents and to urge that they be freed.

title: DEVELOPERS LEARNED SOME LESSONS AND CUT BACK
description: It may be optimistic, but I hope 1986 will be remembered in architecture as the year in which a few lessons were learned. After all, a lot of big projects changed course this year, and for the better. Most notable, surely, is Television City, the mega-development Donald Trump wants to build on the 76-acre site of the old Pennsylvania Railroad yards on the Upper West Side. The design for Television City by Helmut Jahn that Mr. Trump unveiled with much hoopla last year, an outlandishly simplistic exercise in urban gigantism, has now passed to a well-deserved oblivion and been replaced with a vastly more sophisticated scheme by Alexander Cooper. Whereas the old design looked like a series of rocket ships lined up in bleak open space, the new one attempts to create boulevards, streets and parks that bear some resemblance to real urban places. It is still far, far too big - the overall plan calls for more than 17 million square feet of space - but at least it is a decent and intelligent framework, and if the long process of public review can bring about a reduction in the amount of building that will occur on the site we might actually see a viable project.

title: FOR THE AFTERMATH, THERE'S ALWAYS SPICY FOOD AND, YES, BEER
description: KNOWING how to vary a recipe, to take off on one's own from what is printed on the page, makes for inventive cooking. Some recipes are especially suited to revising. Here's a case in point.

title: Two Republicans
description: Two remarkable Republicans are leaving the Senate in a few days. Barry Goldwater of Arizona departs after 30 years and one hopeless campaign for the White House. Charles Mathias of Maryland goes after 18 years as a Senator following another eight years in the House. One has long been thought of as the Republicans' Mr. Conservative, the other as a leader among liberal Republicans, but such easy labels do them little justice. Whatever their differences in stance, the essential qualities of both men are the same: integrity and service.

title: THE SCHUBERT SYMPHONIES
description: uf9606>Franz Schubert was not a composer whose output could be easily categorized into ''early'' and ''late'' periods.

title: PORTLAND'S BOOM MASKS A POORER SLIDE
description: Three neighborhood groups have filed a petition that demands a halt to condominium development along the city's waterfront.

title: SAKHAROV, CITING ILLS AND WORK, SAYS HE CAN'T BE FOCUS OF SOVIET DISSENT
description: Andrei D. Sakharov said today that because of physical infirmity and a desire to renew his work in physics, he could not serve as the rallying point for dissent in the Soviet Union.

title: Murder, They Write
description: Richard M. Levine writes that the ''Son of Sam'' law ''might prevent Jean Harris from profiting from her own best-selling account of Dr. Tarnower's killing.''

title: RESTORERS IN MASSACHUSETTS GIVE HISTORY A FUTURE
description: Sherelyn Ogden pulled the original manuscript of Laura Ingalls Wilder's popular children's book ''Little House on the Prairie'' out of a cardboard box. She flipped through the thick tablet, with its pages of neat, penciled script, that the author purchased in Springfield, Mo., in 1930.

title: 'OLIVER!' AT BRIDGEPORT CABARET
description: ONCE, the musical theater was ruled by Americans.

title: IRAQ TRIES TO FIND IF AIRPORT POLICE AIDED HIJACKERS
description: The Iraqi authorities have started an investigation into the possibility that security officers at the Baghdad airport aided the hijackers who tried to take over an Iraqi airliner that was on its way to Amman on Thursday, according to a senior Jordanian official.

title: THE 1986 SEASON WAS A SPEEDY ONE
description: Race car designers, builders and drivers spent the 1986 season in their inevitable pursuit of higher speed. And as usual, the rule makers did their best to reduce speeds - or at least slow the rate of increase.

title: YOUNG MAN'S DEATH PROMPTS HARD LOOK AT COLLEGE DRINKING
description: ON the night of Oct. 25, Edward G. McGuire 3d, a sophomore from Falmouth, Mass., attended a school-sanctioned party at Saybrook College, one of the 16 residential colleges at Yale University. Alcohol was served at the party. Later, friends say, he continued drinking at a private dormitory party in the same college, where he eventually passed out and was taken to his room in Silliman College.

title: CELEBRATING AMERICA THE BOUNTIFUL
description: Americana - from ancient pueblo pottery to 20th-century modern - dominated in exhibitions of decorative arts at museums and galleries and in what collectors pursued throughout 1986.

title: INMATES RECEIVE VIDEO GRANT
description: IN what is believed to be a first for New York State's Department of Corrections, a grant has been awarded to prisoners - a group of inmates operating a video-production center at the Taconic Correctional Facility, a medium-security prison in Bedford Hills.

title: TRANSCRIPTS DETAIL GIFTS TO PHILADELPHIA CITY JUDGES
description: Transcripts of a series of conversations, secretly recorded a year ago by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as part of an investigation of two construction unions, have provided a rare glimpse of the relationship between city judges and union officials.

title: Serving An Affluent Clientele
description: LENDERS have long been aware that their more affluent customers frequently need the sort of services that may not not be part of standard banking fare. This is certainly true of home purchase.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WORLDWIDE VIGIL At noon, Greenwich Mean Time, Dec. 31 (7 A.M. here), when the whole world is poised for an hour on the same day of the year, a worldwide vigil observing the International Year of Peace is planned in dozens of locations. Several churches in the metropolitan New York area are holding special services or events. Among them is a nondenominational hour of prayer from 7 to 8 A.M. at Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, in association with Programs for Human Development of Greenwich and Logos World University.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY HANUKKAH It's that time of year again - time for Hanukkah, when Jews all over the world light candles commemorating both a military victory and a miracle. With the third candle poised for menorahs today, celebrations throughout Long Island are in full swing. For example, the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk holds its annual party, complete with dreidel games, songs, dancing, candlelighting ceremony and, naturally, latkes, from 1 to 4 P.M. at the Y, 74 Hauppauge Road in Commack. The family-oriented activities cost $10 a family, $4 for individuals, or $3 for senior citizens; members pay $8, $3 and $2, respectively.

title: W. VIRGINIA PRISON STILL 'VULNERABLE'
description: The bloody New Year's Day riot at the West Virginia Penitentiary, followed by months of unrest, turned 1986 into the most violent year at the prison in 26 years.

title: WORCESTER ACTS TO CURB BOOM ALONG OUTSKIRTS
description: Reacting to the rapid development of this hilly city's wooded suburban outskirts, the City Council has adopted a moratorium on building outside its downtown in an effort to channel development toward the city center.

title: Racial Attack Victim Arrested in Stabbing
description: Timothy Grimes, one of the three men attacked in Howard Beach, Queens, on Dec. 20, was arrested yesterday at his Brooklyn home and charged with stabbing the woman he lives with.

title: LEFTOVER WINE: TIPS ON STORAGE
description: IF you find yourself with some half-empty bottles of wine or champagne in this season of gustatory excess, don't throw them out. At least, don't throw them out without good reason. The good reasons are these:

title: HAIL TO 'THE CHIEF' - THE BEST TEACHER IN THE WORLD
description: DWIGHT D. DOUGHERTY, also known as The Chief, was the best teacher in the world. Mr. Dougherty (he was never addressed otherwise) headed the mathematics department at Eastside High School in Paterson.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WHEN ROCKS DANCE. Elizabeth Nunez-Harrell. (Putnam, $17.95.) Set in Trinidad around the turn of the century, this first novel by the Trinidad-born writer Elizabeth Nunez-Harrell begins with Emilia, a native woman whose lover is an Englishman, giving birth to twin sons whom she has been instructed by an obeahman to sacrifice.

title: Budget Cuts Impair Aid to Poor
description: COMMUNITY organizations that lost city funds last September have had to cut back their counseling services for low-income tenants or find interim subsidies, but the organizers hope their programs will be included in the city's budget next year.

title: WE'RE A NATION OF SPECULATORS NOW
description: WANT to bet?

title: Vermeil Not the Man
description: WHEN Dick Vermeil left his job as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles in 1982, he complained of burnout. When he told the Atlanta Falcons yesterday that he was not their man to replace the dismissed Dan Henning as head coach, it was obvious there was no burning desire to coach again in the National Football League.

title: Dusky Sparrows: A Lone Survivor
description: THIRTY years ago, before there were construction and drainage projects in the marshes near Titusville, Fla., there were thousands of dusky sparrows. Five years ago, there were six.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PORNOGRAPHY OF REPRESENTATION. By Susanne Kappeler. (University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $35; Paper, $12.95.) The author, a lecturer in English at the University of East Anglia, England, argues that pornography is merely the most obvious example of the objectification of women in all areas of modern culture.

title: SIX WHO ADDED THE SPICE TO 1986
description: As in any theatrical event, many of the key players in American business during 1986 operated from behind the scenes. They received little notice although their work this year produced stunning revelations on Wall Street and generated millions of dollars worth of new products.

title: Topics: Lifted Lids; Drugscam
description: ''Buy generic'' would seem to be a good guide for saving money on prescription drugs. Not necessarily so, according to a survey just published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Data Bank: December 28, 1986
OLD DREADS REVIVE ON NEW YEAR'S EVE
description: ON Dec. 31, you will find me slipping into the approaching year as comfortably as a child into mittens, but it wasn't always that way. When I was younger, I was haunted by that universal law: a girl over the age of 15 must have a date on New Year's Eve.

title: RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETTE
description: Watch on the Rhine With Bette Davis and Paul Lukas. 1943. Key Video. 114 minutes, $59.98.

title: TRUE TO FORM, THE THEATER WAS FULL OF SURPRISES
description: ''New York without a theater district might as well be Newark,'' cracked a jaded taxi driver in the comedy that opened 1986, Terrence McNally's ''It's Only a Play.'' Twelve months later, Times Square is still unlikely to be confused with the Garden State, but does anyone doubt that the New York theater district is less a place than a state of mind, as hard to pin down as ''the oldest established permanent floating crap game'' of ''Guys and Dolls''? The most warming new American play of 1986, Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' is to be found in a living-room-sized auditorium two flights up from ''The Common Pursuit,'' 30-odd blocks north of Shubert Alley. The year's boldest musical theater experiment, Martha Clarke's ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' was born in the tiny St. Clement's, in the shadows of the Broadway periphery, before finding a berth at the Public downtown. The most original performer Broadway has seen in ages, Robert Lindsay of ''Me and My Girl,'' turned up innocently at the neighborhood's most widely despised venue - the antiseptic hotel auditorium that usurped three venerable playhouses - and, like it or not, legitimized the place as a theater. And who would have imagined that a 1971 Off Broadway hit by John Guare, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' would reawaken both the Newhouse and Beaumont theaters at Lincoln Center before moving south for its belated midtown debut?

title: China's Military Panel Ends a 'Historic' Meeting
description: China's powerful Central Military Commission, headed by Deng Xiaoping, has concluded its largest meeting since 1978, the official newspaper People's Daily reported today.

title: THE TOWN SO NICE THEY NAMED IT TWICE
description: PEOPLE should not believe what they hear about the callousness of New Yorkers.

title: South Korea to Study Proposals for Change
description: The chairman of the ruling Democratic Justice Party has agreed to consider opposition proposals in a parliamentary debate over how to alter the country's form of government.

title: Mutual Housing Project Awaits a Decision by City
description: A NATIONAL community-revitalization group that came to the Lower East Side armed with innovative plans, $1 million and the backing of Congress to build affordable apartments is finding out how difficult it can be to acquire New York City-owned tenements to produce such housing.

title:
ART;
ALLEGORICAL PRINTS AT YALE RETAIN MUCH OF THEIR MYSTERY
description: IN the Middle Ages allegorical pictures were intended for a public that was for the most part illiterate. By the 16th century, the complexity of allegorical pictures was such that the viewer was involved as one who completed what was frequently a very subtle puzzle. The subjects were not religious themes any longer, but ranged from the nature of love to the nature of wisdom.

title: A Ray of Light for Soviet Rights?
description: As we turn toward the new year of 1987, those who believe that respect for human rights can make an important difference in relations between nations, and particularly between the United States and the Soviet Union, will applaud the hopeful news of the return of Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, to Moscow. They must also be reassured that Anatoly B. Shcharansky is now living in Israel and that Yuri Orlov is no longer suffering in either a labor camp or in exile but rather is resuming his scientific research in the United States.

title: THE SUBJECT IS ROSES: NEW YORK
description: For centuries, roses have been the subject of poems and paintings. They are also the new American national flower. But their allure is an international one. As the following pages illustrate, the thousands of varieties of colors, scents and blossoms make them a favorite among leading florists in Paris, London and New York.

title: DEMOGRAHPICS PUT STRAIN ON SOVIET ETHNIC SEAMS
description: THE official Soviet publishing agency prints textbooks in 52 languages to serve the disparate minorities of the Soviet Union. The state radio broadcasts in 67 languages. Flip on the state-run television here, and the show may be a Georgian comedy or Uzbek folk dancing.

title: Trinidad
