description: The days and weeks before Ash Wednesday, which marks for many Christians a 40-day penitential period running until Easter, are a time for steel bands and sambas, for gorging on pralines and drinking beer in heroic quantities, for masked balls and elaborately costumed processions. In a word, carnival. Music and parades are a constant, but every culture puts its own stamp on carnival, which may embrace just the few days before Ash Wednesday (March 4 next year) all the way to Cologne's 17-week marathon: Mardi Gras and Jouvert, Sambadrome and Vivaldi, the Women's Carnival and even survivals of pre-Christian Roman feasts.

title: Evaluating Cut-Rate Offerings
description: Everybody supposedly loves a bargain. Without making a firm commitment, however, it is often difficult to tell whether a supposed bargain is as good as it may initially seem. Nowhere is this better illustrated than in advertisements, handbills, mass mailings and telephone campaigns that promise large discounts in travel and entertainment if you provide a credit-card number and make a deposit or pay a form of dues in advance.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: FICTION
description: 1 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Valley of Horses'' resumes her adventures in the prehistoric world.

title: Joanne M. Gaderick Engaged to Marry Jeffrey Reynolds, an M.B.A. Candidate
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Gaderick of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Marie Gaderick, to Jeffrey Toll Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Reynolds Jr., also of Greenwich. The wedding is planned for May 23.

title: Susan deGersdorff Married to John Stamatopoulos
description: At St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday Susan van Wyck deGersdorff, a daughter of Mrs. Francis Eugene Gilbertson of Rumson and Carl August deGersdorff of New York and Alford, Mass., was married to John George Stamatopoulos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Stamatopoulos of Melrose, Mass. The Rev. George Willis of St. George's performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George Tsoukalas, a Greek Orthodox priest.

title: TRIBUTES TO MUSIC
description: Music is featured in new releases from New Zealand which is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its national orchestra. A 30-cent value salutes the influence of the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra which performs about 100 concerts annually and is an important part of the country's musical life.

title: In Business To Treat Cancer
description: All Dr. Oldham and his colleagues are doing is providing a privately financed supplement to Government-financed research efforts. Gramm-Rudman will require even more of this as the meat-ax approach is used to deal with the Federal budget deficit. Given the fiscal reality of today, we will see more and more research financed privately and for profit. IRA M. ELSKY New York City

title: FINDING A SURNAME FOR BABY
description: MOST of my friends kept their surnames when they got married.

title: More on Boesky
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The question remains of whether the market will believe in higher prices or consider them like Santa Claus - something you'd like to believe in but really can't.'' Peter C. Beutel, assistant director, Elder Futures, of the surge in oil prices in the wake of OPEC's agreement.

title: No Headline
description: A mild earthquake today shook a small island to which residents recently returned after a volcanic eruption, the Meteorological Agency reported. No damage or injuries were reported. Agency officials said the tremor on O-shima, 70 miles south of Tokyo, registered 3.0 on the Richter scale.

title: DINING ON L.I.: YEARS OF CHANGE
description: THE impossible request, ''Name your favorite restaurant on the Island,'' is more difficult to fill today than it was in 1976 when I began reviewing.

title: Alison Wachtler To Marry in June
description: Judge and Mrs. Sol Wachtler of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Toni Wachtler, to Barry Glenn Braunstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Braunstein of Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for June.

title: LOVE WITH THE PROPER AMPHIBIAN
description: MRS. CALIBAN By Rachel Ingalls. 125 pp. Boston: The Harvard Common Press. $12.95.

title: THE RELUCTANT MESSIAH
description: THE FIRST COMING How the Kingdom of God Became Christianity. By Thomas Sheehan. 287 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Frances Roberts Becomes a Bride
description: Frances Williams Roberts, a daughter of Thomas Williams Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and the late Frances Roberts, was married yesterday to Richard Burger Hill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Hill of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Steven K. Jacobson assisted by Canon E. Rugby Auer performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: MY 3 SONS: A CHAMBER TRIO
description: SUN WHI and Jae Won Lee are not surprised that their three sons are accomplished classical musicians, who perform on the chamber music circuit as the Elwood Trio.

title: THE SPORTING SET THRILLS TO WINTER'S CHILLS
description: WHILE the winter months ahead loom ominously for many people, there are plenty of state residents who say the season is not long enough. Rather than be threatened and bored by the cold, snow, ice and wind, they welcome winter's offerings.

title: JAZZ
description: The pianist Herbie Hancock juggles two careers. One identity is the amiable technophile who leads a funk band and knocks out an electronic-toned dance hit every few years.

title: The Voyager Returns, With Broken Records
description: Jeana Yeager and Richard G. Rutan landed at Edwards Air Force Base last week in their paper-and-plastic airplane, the first ever to circle the earth without stopping or refueling. The pilots were wobbly but elated, and even ahead of schedule.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON GROWING A SPECTACULAR FLOWER
description: YOU may have received an amaryllis bulb as a Christmas gift, or perhaps you plan to buy one or more for forcing. In either case, it may be helpful to have forcing guidelines to achieve the best possible result with this spectacular flower.

title: MAYOR'S ALLIES VOTE TO OUST CHIEF RIVAL FROM CHICAGO POST
description: Democrats loyal to Mayor Harold Washington have voted to oust his City Council nemesis, Alderman Edward Vrdolyak, from the chairmanship of the city's Democratic Party for running for mayor on a third-party ticket.

title: Whither the Democrats?
description: Competition is intensifying for the attention and the affection of the committee choosing the site for the Democrats' 1988 Presidential nominating convention. Kansas City, still regarded as a long shot, has sent each of the 57 committee members an individualized edition of a promotional newspaper that features the member's name in a front-page headline together with a picture of him or her taken during the committee's inspection tour of Kansas City.

title: NEW GLORIES IN CLASSICAL AMID REISSUES
description: More than any recent year within memory, 1986 was the year of the reissue. And not grandly packaged exhumations of disks long dead, like last year's ''Record of Singing'' Vol. 3 and ''Mapleson Cylinder'' sets. This year, fueled by the burgeoning market in compact disks, the record companies devoted a major portion of their resources to the reissuing of fairly recent analog and digital recordings, along with some classics of the 1930's through the 1960's, on digitally remastered LP's or, ultimately, onto CD's themselves.

title: POSTCARDS FROM 1986
description: Biscuits and coffee in a truck stop before dawn, a drive through morning fog to the hometown of Walter Payton. After a pleasant visit with Payton's former coach, Charles Boston, and a sunny afternoon drive through the Delta to New Orleans, Stupor Bowl week will take care of itself.

title: STATE PRESSING TOWNS TO JOIN HEALTH DISTRICTS
description: WHILE most people this week will make New Year's resolutions to change bad habits, state and private health agencies have resolved to make life healthier for more than a million people.

title: VINSON COLE: TENOR ON THE ROAD TO THE STARTING LINEUP
description: When Vinson Cole makes his Metropolitan Opera debut on Saturday, it will be one more of his frequent appearances as a pinch-hitter, a not unusual phase at this point in an operatic career, but one that he hopes is about to give way to a steadier diet of first-time-around appearances. ''This year, I've become the tenor who jumps in for indisposed tenors in the Verdi Requiem,'' Mr. Cole said with a laugh at lunch last week, referring to recent performances with Carlo Maria Giulini in Berlin and a few weeks ago in Chicago with Claudio Abbado.

title: AN ACTOR RELIVES NEIL SIMON'S LIFE
description: Jonathan Silverman, who has spent the last few years of his life playing the alter ego of Neil Simon on Broadway and now, in the film version of ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' on the screen, is the kind of young man every mother wishes her daughter would marry - bright, polite, clean-cut, charming, modest. And he seems to have his share of interested young women - many of whom he meets when they come backstage at the Broadhurst Theater, where he is starring in ''Broadway Bound'' - to tell him how good he is. He is playing Eugene Morris Jerome at the age of 23, as the Simon character begins his writing career. ''It's great for my social life,'' Mr. Silverman said with an unabashed grin. ''I sometimes do ask some of those girls to go out with me. It may be taking a kind of advantage of my position, but heck, I'm 20 years old.''

title: Q and A
description: ISLAND CAMPING Question:Do you know of any books or other sources that describe camping opportunities on any of the Caribbean islands? I do know about the national park on St. John. - H. R., Amherst, Mass. Answer:No one has compiled a comprehensive list of camping sites, according to the Caribbean Tourism Association, which represents most of the islands. Several islands either do not allow camping or do not have any official campgrounds for visitors. Furthermore, Caribbean guidebooks generally do not mention those that do exist, although there is a brief section on the subject in ''Birnbaum's Caribbean, Bermuda and the Bahamas'' (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95).

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boston Edison Co. has elected Stephen J. Sweeney chairman to succeed Thomas J. Galligan Jr., who will retire as chairman but continue as a director.

title: Washington Watch; Broadcast License Renewals
description: Radio and television broadcasters may go back to the Federal Communications Commission or Congress next year for further deregulation of the industry. The target this time is comparative renewal proceedings, the process of handling competing applications for the same license.

title: For Men en Route, the Right to Change Diapers
description: To the Editor:

title: POST OFFICE NAME STIRS ISLAND DISPUTE
description: On St. Helena Island, 45 square miles of flat brown salt marshes and vast plantation fields, a dispute over the mailing address used by the United States Postal Service is pitting advocates of a 100-year-old nickname against the descendants of slaves who favor a name four times as old.

title: Emo Phillips to Perform
description: The comedian Emo Phillips will perform on New Year's Eve at Caroline's, Eighth Avenue at 26th Street (924-3499). Shows are at 8:30 P.M., with a $25 cover and a two-drink minimum, and at 11:30 P.M., with a $50 cover and a $10 minimum.

title: ITALY TIGHTENS SECURITY AMID TERRORIST THREATS
description: Security forces are on high alert at Leonardo da Vinci Airport and other potential terrorist targets around Rome, Government officials said today.

title: JOHN D. MACDONALD, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: John D. MacDonald, the novelist whose best-selling mysteries sold millions of copies, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Milwaukee of complications from heart surgery. He was 70 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Washington 72, Idaho 53: Chris Welp scored 17 points and Phil Zevenberger added 16 points and 15 rebounds yesterday to power Washington in a consolation game of the Far West Classic in Portland. The Huskies (7-5) took a 10-2 and never trailed. Southwestern Louisiana defeated Mississippi State, 62-56, in the first game to advance to the consolation finals today against Washington.(UPI) Adelphi 89, Southampton 69: Charles Webb, a junior guard, scored 34 points and Reggie Fitzgerald added 22 to lead Adelphi in the consolation game of the Adelphi holiday tournament in Garden City, L.I. Villanova 63, Houston 60: The Wildcats' defense forced three turnovers in the final three minutes of play, and Doug West and Harold Jensen sparked an 11-5 game-ending surge as Villanova (7-3) won the opening game of the Sugar Bowl tournament in New Orleans. Tim Hobby of Houston (5-3) hit a 3-pointer to tie it at 60-60 with 14 seconds left, but Villanova's Mark Plansky put the Wildcats back on top to stay with a 15-foot jumper.(AP) C. W. Post 81, San Francisco State 79: Michael Hammond, scored 39 points to lead C. W. Post (8-3) over San Francisco State (3-6) in the opening round of the Porecco Cup in Erie, Pa. Hammond's 15-foot bank shot with two seconds remaining broke a 79-79 tie. Horse Racing Tinchen's Prince Wins: Tinchen's Prince dueled for the lead into the stretch with Landing Plot and the favored Judge Costa, then thrust a nose in front at the wire to win the $70,900 Alex M. Robb Stakes for New York-breds of 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: WHAT'S AHEAD IN '87: FAMILY QUARRELS
description: Law-enforcement experts say 1987 will be a watershed year for the city's five Mafia families. The experts, who monitor organized-crime activities, say that for the first time since the families were formed in 1931 the leadership of each will change all at once.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Make Mine Red-Hot
description: You may recall that last spring Marge Schott, the automobile dealer who owns the Cincinnati Reds, forbade Tom Browning to make a television commercial for a rival dealership. But while Schott is able to tell her players which cars they can pitch, Manager Pete Rose has no influence over which local chili they identify with.

title: ATKINSON GETS A CHANCE AND CASHES IN
description: Jess Atkinson knows about rejection.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REGAINING 'LOST HORIZON'

title: DISSIDENT IRAQIS TERMED KEY HIJACKING SUSPECTS
description: Dissident Iraqi policemen or security agents appear to be the most likely suspects behind the hijacking Thursday of an Iraqi airliner, a senior Jordanian official said today.

title: ROCK: THE BEASTIE BOYS, RAP-METAL GROUP
description: DUMB fun, bad attitudes and rude noise are vital to rock-and-roll, and as the music absorbs one shock tactic, along comes another. Right now, there's a new kind of rude rock in the making. It mixes two styles that grate on parents and appeal directly to teen-agers: rap and heavy metal. Run-D. M. C. pioneered rap-metal music with ''Rock Box''; the Beastie Boys, abetted by Run-D. M. C.'s producer, Rick Rubin, have made rap-metal music a vehicle for teen-agers' jokey, antisocial fantasies. On their album, ''Licensed to Ill,'' the three Beastie Boys - King Ad-Rock (Adam Horovitz), Mike D (Michael Diamond) and the hoarse-voiced MCA (Adam Yauch) - are loudmouthed brats backed by loud guitars and a lean rhythm-box beat.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 29, 1986: TUESDAY Delmarva Pwr & Lt WEDNESDAY Cascade Nat Gas Wash DC Gas Lt FRIDAY Nevada Power NY State El & Gas

title: ST. JOHN'S TO MEET ITS MATCH
description: With a nucleus of three outstanding players and a bench made up of role players with varying degrees of talent, St. John's has gone through its first eight games without a loss and has even looked formidable in stretches.

title: Seattle-First Fined $25,000
description: The Seattle-First National Bank has been fined $25,000 by the Commerce Department, which said the bank gave Arab officials information related to the Arabs' boycott of Israel.

title: Washington Watch; Infrastructure Gets Attention
description: THE deteriorating state of large segments of the nation's infrastructure, particularly in the Northeast and Middle West, is due to get heightened attention from the next Congress.

title: IN A BLACK CHURCH, PAINFUL MEMORIES
description: The minister in a black church in Flushing, Queens, began yesterday by quietly preaching about Jesus weeping over Jerusalem. Soon, emotions swelled and churchgoers fell to their knees or stood waving their hands overhead in a spontaneous memorial service for Michael Griffith.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) E.C.A.C. HOLIDAY FESTIVAL, St. John's vs.

title: WINNING IS HELPING MIAMI OVERCOME ITS COMPLEX
description: THE competition offers huge stadiums right on their campuses, not far from where the alums spent some of the best times of their youth. Here, the campus stadium is an unrealized dream as old as the institution itself.

title: Letter: On Foster Care; Where the Boarder Babies Come From
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAMPION OF CAUSES TURNS TO CHILD CARE
description: The people who champion causes, who know how to form committees and call on their connections to get things done, are as much a part of the life of New York as the artist and the author. They are part banker, advertiser, public relations director and legal counsel. They work long hours, trade contacts, raise capital and wield influence.

title: 1986'S LEGACY: TUMULTUOUS ERA FOR BIG BUSINESS
description: Big business in America is overhauling itself and its operations faster than at any time since World War II.

title: NIGERIA SEEKS THE SLAYERS OF AN EDITOR
description: ''Hello,'' starts one note penned by a 15-year-old schoolgirl. ''Elephant fails and cannot stand up. Dele Giwa, good-bye.''

title: This Week's Financings
description: While the municipal and corporate markets enjoy another week of vacation, the Treasury will be raising more than $8 billion of new cash from short- and medium-term financings.

title: 2 INQUIRIES ON BROOKLYN REAL-ESTATE DEAL
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the New York City Department of Investigation have opened separate inquiries into how a real-estate development firm in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner obtained an apparently bogus document and used it to get public financing of a $6.8 million Brooklyn apartment building.

title: ILLUSIONS GONE, EMIGRES RETURN TO SOVIET UNION
description: Hours before the Aeroflot daily flight was scheduled to depart from Kennedy International Airport to Moscow, Taras Kordonsky sat in the terminal eating and repeatedly looking at his Swiss watch.

title: 20 PROTEST OUTSIDE ST. PATRICK'S
description: About 20 members of the Jewish Defense Group demonstrated across from St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to protest the decision to cancel formal meetings between John Cardinal O'Connor and Israeli leaders, an official of the group said.

title: Paraplegic, 26, Takes Walk Down the Aisle
description: A paraplegic who regained the use of her legs with the help of a computerized system walked down the aisle at her wedding Saturday.

title: JOHN D. MACDONALD DIES
description: John D. MacDonald, whose mystery novels sold in the millions of copies, died yesterday of complications from heart surgery. Page B15.2 NEWS SUMMARY, PAGE A2.

title: I.B.M.'S RIVALS: A JOINING OF HANDS
description: For the nation's computer industry, 1986 was the year when the long-awaited consolidation of I.B.M.'s competitors began in earnest. And if the computer and electronics business fails to improve soon - and there is little evidence it will - more mergers and cutbacks are likely.

title: VATICAN-ISRAELI DIPLOMACY: HOW IT BECAME SO TANGLED
description: In traveling to Israel John Cardinal O'Connor is wandering into an area of Vatican foreign policy that is as delicate as it is ambiguous.

title: HE DEFENDS HIMSELF
description: Two prominent Soviet scholars have leveled charges of scientific fraud against an Ohio professor, saying that he plagiarized the 30-year-old work of a Soviet physicist in an engineering textbook published in the United States in 1983.

title: REVIVING THE DRAFT: PARTISAN DEBATE
description: The revival of a military draft is an issue that endures even though the present volunteer force shows every sign of success.

title: SHIPPING AWAITS A REBOUND
description: Last month, T. Y. Chao sold his collection of jade, lovingly assembled over a lifetime, to help pay his shipping company's $850 million in debts.

title: Advertising; '85 Income Growth Off To 4.4% at 14 Agencies
description: Among the 14 publicly held ad agencies operating in 1985, income growth dropped to 4.4 percent, from 15.5 percent in 1984, according to figures that are included in newly released portions of the Communications Industry Report, a bit of self-promotion issued annually by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, investment bankers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1986
description: The Economy

title: PERPLEXING PROBLEM: WHEN STREETS BECOME PUBLIC URINALS
description: Thousands of New Yorkers, living in a city where usable public bathrooms are few and far between, were fined $50 to $250 this year for using streets, sidewalks and subway stations as urinals.

title: U.S. TO GAIN OWNERSHIP OF KEY TEXAS WETLANDS
description: The southern tip of Matagorda Island, one of the nation's most important natural wetlands, is being purchased by a conservation group, a transaction that will eventually put the entire 41-mile-long island under government control as a wildlife preserve.

title: Problem Causes a Shutdown Of Hanford Nuclear Reactor
description: An apparent malfunction in a water-flow monitor today caused a shutdown of the N Reactor at the Hanford nuclear reservation, a company spokesman said.

title: Joan Monness Is Wed To Keith D. Brickman
description: Jane Ellen Monness, the daughter of Ellen Gretsch Monness and Andrew James Monness, both of New York, was married yesterday to Keith Douglas Brickman, a son of Barbara Leeds Brickman of Peabody, Mass., and Dr. Gerald Sumner Brickman of Malden, Mass. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: RYAN REVIVES JETS AND BURIES CHIEFS IN PLAYOFF, 35-15
description: The Jets found themselves, and the Kansas City Chiefs, just in time today.

title: CLEVELAND COUNTS ON A CLINIC
description: Dark and abandoned on the East Side, factories that once helped to make this city one of the most important manufacturing centers in the United States now stand as a symbol of the nation's industrial decline.

title: Writers Join Column In Times Book Review
description: Beginning Sunday, the writers Denis Donoghue, Cynthia Ozick and Marilynne Robinson will join Anatole Broyard in the About Books column of The New York Times Book Review. The column, which has been printed monthly, will now appear weekly.

title: An Ex-Saint's 14-Year Wait
description: DERLAND Moore used to watch the other guys play the postseason games on television.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1986
description: International

title: Door-Stopper
description: Boxing will look back on the 1980's as a decade of sad decline in the heavyweight division. Except for Larry Holmes, and perhaps Michael Spinks - a special case as a very good light heavyweight who stepped up in class for the larger purses - the landscape has been dotted by a procession of mediocre titleholders whose reigns have lasted roughly as long as the fragrance of the cheapest perfume. It has been an era of revolving-door champions, and devotees can only hope that the emergence of Mike Tyson signals its demise.

title: But Do We Believe?
description: The year of the Constitution is upon us. Through 1987 we shall be celebrating the 200th birthday of the extraordinary document that created our country. There is every reason to celebrate. But there is also reason to wonder whether we really understand and believe in the essential idea of the Constitution.

title: TAIWAN STARTS TO CLEAN UP ITS AIR AND WATER
description: Surrounded by the sheer marble cliffs of what is sometimes called Taiwan's Grand Canyon, Hsu Kuo-shih reflected on Taiwan's rush to curb pollution and create national parks.

title: PENN STATE PURSUING LOFTY GOALS, AS USUAL
description: SEMESTER finals were completed and a cold, gray morning was brightened by the prospect of going home for the holidays. But as their fellow students packed their bags, some assisted by parents playing chauffeur for a day, the Penn State football players prepared for a weekend that would be the equivalent of the first days of fall practice, a time of pure drudgery. As many of them already knew, not all college finals are given in the classroom.

title: HOURS OF ACTION A PRELUDE TO PRIME TIME ON FRIDAY
description: The bowl games this New Year's Day may be remembered more for steroids than for any meaningful game.

title: The Fur Coat Trap
description: The ads promise that your new fur coat will give you ''a wonderful feeling.'' A ''fashion'' page shows toddlers ''making the scene'' in furs. A news story says that grown women ''are turning their fuzzy fantasies into luxurious wraps.'' The financial columns report that the American fur industry is reaching new heights of prosperity, approaching a record $2 billion mark in 1986.

title: Husband Is Charged In Attack on Wife
description: A Connecticut man was arrested on Long Island after a car accident and charged with attacking his wife with a meat cleaver, the police said yesterday.

title: WYOMING, MX SILOS STIR LOVE, HATE AND APATHY
description: For three years, people here have known their community was going to be the home of the nation's MX missile system.

title: CORPORATE AMERICA IN TURMOIL: TAKEOVER FEARS SPUR CHANGE
description: Frank Lorenzo: Chairman, Texas Air Corporation

title: U.S. DROPS ITS FEEDING OF CONGRESS
description: The House of Representatives, faced with union organizers, unhappy employees and mounting deficits, is getting out of the restaurant business.

title: A BIG DIFFERENCE FOR CHIEFS' DEFENSE
description: Pat Ryan or Ken O'Brien, what's the difference?

title: O'Brien Watches
description: Ken O'Brien spoke easily today about life as a backup, even though it was clear it was not a role he wants to get used to.

title: Realty Adventurous For Merrill Officer
description: When David H. Komansky switched from the securities side to the real estate side of Merrill Lynch & Company some 15 months ago ''it was the beginning of an adventure,'' he said.

title: New Year's Eve Comedy
description: Two New Year's Eve shows are planned by the First Amendment Comedy Theater, 2 Bond Street, between Broadway and Lafayette Street (473-1472 or 677-1409).

title: Nomura Gets Half of Eastdil Realty
description: The Nomura Securities Company, the world's-largest brokerage house, extended its reach into the United States real estate industry yesterday with the acquisition of a half-interest in Eastdil Realty Inc., the innovative real estate investment banking firm founded by Benjamin V. Lambert.

title: O'CONNER, DESPITE 'MISTAKE,' FORESEES ISRAEL VISIT AS USEFUL
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said today that he considered calling off his trip to Israel because of the embarrassment caused by his last-minute decision, under Vatican orders, to cancel meetings with Israel's President and Prime Minister.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Michael Mims has been promoted to publisher at Connecticut Magazine, Bridgeport.

title: Iacocca Disavows 1988 Race
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, says he would not want to be President of the United States because the nation's economy will be in a such a crisis in a few years that ''I'd be damned if I know'' what to do about it.

title: How I.B.M. Has Altered Its Role in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; A Rebate Book for Durables
description: A TEST offer for a consumer promotion called The Rebate Book will soon be made on local TV stations so the entrepreneurs behind it can find out what cover price - between $12.95 and $19.95 - viewers find most attractive.

title: INCREASES ARE SOUGHT IN LICENSED DAY CARE
description: There are 68,000 children under 3 years old in need of out-of-home day care in New York City but only 5,000 licensed places for them, according to city officials and child-care advocates.

title: ISRAELI INVESTIGATION CLEARS SHAMIR IN KILLING OF 2 ARABS OR COVER-UP
description: A Justice Ministry inquiry has found that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir did not order the killing of two captured Arab bus hijackers in 1984 and that he did not know of a cover-up of the killings, the Israeli television reported today.

title: Bridge: The Cavendish Club Offers Singular Duplicate Matches
description: The most remarkable club duplicate played anywhere in the United States, and perhaps in the world, is the Wednesday night game at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: Steelworkers Reject Contract But Pact Is Extended Again
description: Workers at the Latrobe Steel Company here have overwhelmingly rejected a 44-month contract that the company said was one of the best offers made to any steelworkers' local this year.

title: JURISTS SET LIMITS ON CORPORATE DEFENSES
description: Next year, corporate boards may have a harder time fighting off suitors because of some key judicial decisions this year.

title: 15TH-CENTURY ICONS FOUND
description: Soviet art experts have discovered a set of valuable 15th-century icons on the walls of a church in the Ukrainian town of Ovruch, the Government daily Izvestia said today.

title: CITY CRITICIZED FOR MANAGING OF ITS SERVICES
description: Many city services continued to improve this year but the Koch administration is doing only a routine or poor job managing some key functions, from cleaning streets to fighting fires, a private study said yesterday.

title: Mencken Supporters
description: H.L. Mencken and Washington did not get along. The writer always hurried back always hurried back to his home in Baltimore so he would not have to spend the night in the capital.

title: A BRAZIL-ARGENTINA CAR GIANT
description: Despite the contrasting market conditions in Brazil, where new cars are in great demand, and in Argentina, where the automotive industry is in a slump, the Ford and Volkswagen subsidiaries in both countries have one thing in common: they are operating deeply in the red.

title: Amy Skopp Is Married To Rabbi Mark Cooper
description: Amy Skopp and Rabbi Mark S. Cooper were married yesterday at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Harold Kushner performed the ceremony assisted by Rabbi Shawn Zell and Cantor Robert Scherr.

title: JET 'BACKUP' RIDES AGAIN
description: HE'S country, he's cool and except for his senior season in high school, Pat Ryan has always been exactly what he is - a backup quarterback. He played behind Condrege Holloway, Randy Wallace and Jimmy Streeter at the University of Tennessee for three years, and behind Tommy Brantley at Putnam City High in Oklahoma City for two years. After he joined the Jets, he played behind Richard Todd for five years.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS DROP 26.3%
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 26.3 percent in November, compared with the encouraging levels of October, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. Analysts and machine tool manufacturing officials attributed the decline to the same factors that have plagued the industry for the entire year: the sluggish economy and confusion surrounding the impact of recent changes in tax laws.

title: MEDIA COMPANIES LOSE THIER MERGER IMMUNITY
description: The communications industry, which once seemed impervious to mergers and takeovers, has been transformed by the same forces that are restructuring the rest of American industry.

title: The M.T.A. vs. Long Island Extortion
description: The 15,000 commuters who can't find seats on the Long Island Rail Road each day stand in witness to the Island's need for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital investment plan. But 13 Republican Nassau and Suffolk County state senators led by Norman Levy now block a reasonable plan to maintain present transit fares and finance $8.5 billion in new capital.

title: Caracas Seeks Payment Delay
description: Venezuela will seek to defer first quarter payments on a total $1.06 billion in capital due in 1987 under its $21 billion public debt rescheduling, Jorge Marcano, the public finance director, said today.

title: Jersey Prison Escape Thwarted by Guard
description: Three Trenton State Prison inmates escaped from their cell by chiseling through the ceiling but were recaptured yesterday when an alert correction officer spotted them in the prison yard, a correction department spokesman said.

title: Candid Dinner Policy
description: The National Security Council may have gotten into trouble for doing everything secretly before, but the new director has promised a more open style.

title: 8 LOST IN OTHER AIR ACCIDENTS
description: A pilot who survived a plane crash that killed his co-pilot spent a cold night in the Tehachapi Mountains and climbed down five miles of steep terrain before he was rescued by deer hunters.

title: CORPORATIONS MATCH GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: Many New York corporations are matching gifts made by their employees to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Advertising; Philadelphia Company Buys Shadow Network
description: The New York-based Shadow Network, which supplies 73 radio stations in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area with traffic reports and lives on the advertising it generates, has been acquired by the Shadow Communications Corporation of Philadelphia for a reported $5.2 million from a group of New York investors.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Lighting the City Hall Menorah Mayor Koch lights menorah at City Hall to mark the Hanukkah holiday. 4:45 P.M., City Council chamber, City Hall.

title: Yes, There Is Education After Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: One way of measuring a baseball player's production on offense for a season is to add his total runs scored and total runs batted in, then subtract his home-run total, since a homer counts as both a run scored and one driven in. Under that condition, would Jose Canseco of the Oakland A's still warrant being voted American League rookie of the year over Wally Joyner of the California Angels?

title: DANCE: PHYLLIS LAMHUT'S 'KLEIN KUNST'
description: PHYLLIS LAMHUT'S dances once tended to be witty, solidly crafted little gems. With ''Passing,'' created in 1980, her pieces took on a look of grandeur and became larger and more spectacular. And her current work refers increasingly to the expressionism that is the modern-dance heritage of Ms. Lamhut, long a dancer with Alwin Nikolais, who himself claims the lineage of Mary Wigman, the German Expressionist modern-dance choreographer. ''Klein Kunst'' (''Small Art''), a full-evening work performed on Saturday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, seems at first to belong unequivocally to Ms. Lamhut's recent body of clearly expressionistic dance. But the piece also recalls her earlier, thematically slighter dances.

title: JOSE MARAVALL, 75, A SPANISH HISTORIAN AND AN EX-PROFESSOR
description: Jose Antonio Maravall, a leading Spanish historian, died of heart failure in Madrid on Dec. 19. He was 75 years old. Mr. Maravall specialized in what he called the history of mentalities, and he was credited with changing the study of Spanish and European history by linking the popular and intellectual mentality of a period to its economic, social and political structures.

title: RETAIL ENVIRONMENT SEEN AS RIPE FOR MORE DEALS
description: It is hunting time in American retailing as the industry undergoes the greatest transformation of ownership in its history.

title: They Might Be Giants
description: John Flansburgh and John Linnell, the two songwriters who call themselves They Might Be Giants, will perform New Year's Eve at Darinka, 118 East First Street, near Avenue A (598-0157).

title: NEW U.S. LAW IS INTENDED TO PROMOTE LOVE OF BOOKS
description: In an age when electronic gadgets and games are everywhere, many teachers, librarians and private citizens are betting that Americans can be encouraged to develop a love affair with the printed word. With the help of a recently enacted Federal law, they hope to refocus attention on reading and books.

title: TWO WORKERS HURT IN FIRE AT QUEENS OIL COMPANY
description: Gasoline that was being unloaded from a river barge spilled and exploded at a Queens oil company early yesterday, causing a fire that seriously injured two employees, fire officials said.

title: ISRAELI TECHNICIAN PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: A former Israeli technician accused of selling Israeli nuclear secrets to a British newspaper pleaded not guilty today to charges of spying and aiding an enemy in wartime, his attorney said.

title: PROTECTING AN ISLAND AND MORE
description: Just when it seems the last Pearl Harbor attack story has been told, a new one crops up.

title:
CORPORATE AMERICA IN TURMOIL: TAKEOVER FEARS SPUR CHANGE;
AIRLINE DEREGULATION COSTLY TO SMALL COMPETITORS
description: The presidents of two airlines, caught huddling in a corner at a recent industry function, welcomed an outsider into their tete-a-tete with the words, ''Oh, we're just price-fixing.''

title: Takeovers Produce More Winners Than Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: FINAL TO AUSTRALIA ON CASH'S HEROICS
description: Pat Cash staged the comeback of his life today to give Australia its 26th Davis Cup triumph.

title: STUDY VOICES FEAR THAT COLLEGE DEBT WILL BURDEN LIVES
description: More and more college students are borrowing more and more money under Federal programs, raising concern that debt will overburden a generation of Americans, a Congressional report said today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Those people who beat and ultimately caused the death of a black man, they don't represent you, they don't.

title: U.N. FILM ON HOMELESS WILL OMIT U.S. SCENES
description: A United Nations film about projects that aid the homeless will not include two New York programs because of objections from the United States Mission, according to American and United Nations officials.

title: Soviet Union Acts to Reduce Tensions on Its Norwegian Border
description: To the Editor:

title: Va. Tech Forfeits 2 Games
description: Virginia Tech officials said today the school will forfeit two basketball victories, including a Dec. 22 upset over Wake Forest, because of an ineligible player.

title: QUINTERO MAY DO O'NEILL PLAY IN CHINA
description: Sha Yexin has returned to China with the hope of taking back something different from the usual high-tech and high-finance concerns that usually bring his countrymen to the United States. Mr. Sha's gift could be Jose Quintero.

title: WAVE OF MERGERS LIKELY TO CONTINUE
description: After working through this year at a breakneck pace, merger and acquisition specialists doubt they will have much time to catch their breath in 1987. They expect that most of the same forces that stimulated deals this year will be at work during the next 12 months as well.

title: SCHOOL MARKS 25 YEARS OF SKIING, RAFTING AND SELF-DISCOVERY
description: Outward Bound, the rigorous program that develops inner strengths as well as skills in outdoor activities, opened its first school in the United States 25 years ago in a Colorado mountain town.

title: Sluggish Activity Continues
description: In lackluster trading the last few weeks, credit market participants have appeared content to accept the standard forecast: a weakening of the economy in the first quarter, accompanied by an easier monetary policy and lower interest rates.

title: INFORMATION CHIEF WHO STAYS CLOSE TO REAGAN: CHARLES Z. WICK
description: As Ronald Reagan spends the last days of his troubled year in relative seclusion in Los Angeles and Palm Springs, he and his wife, Nancy, are surrounding themselves with longtime friends.

title: SECOND-DAY LOSSES PERPLEX RANGERS
description: He held a conference in a grimy cement passageway underneath the seats, standing alongside a van and some spare nets. Phil Esposito, smartly dressed in an off-white sports jacket, dark slacks and cowboy boots, looked as if he had scrubbed up to come talk in somebody's garage about the glory days.

title: MEESE, REPORTEDLY REJECTS REQUEST TO WIDEN INQUIRY INTO THE E.P.A.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has rejected a request from an independent counsel to widen her investigation of whether a senior Justice Department official acted improperly in withholding documents from Congress, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: Just Look at Him Now
description: He coached in the big-time spotlight for so long, and so enjoyed the attention heaped not only on his teams but also on his notable wisecracking, that the thought of his prospering in a low-profile milieu would once have seemed incongruous. But life in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics has been kind to Abe Lemons, whose Oklahoma City University squad has a 13-0 record this season and a No. 1 N.A.I.A. national ranking.

title: Huang Kecheng Dies; Beijing Military Leader
description: Huang Kecheng, a military leader who accompanied Mao Zedong on the Long March and became Chief of Staff of the Chinese Army but was purged during the Cultural Revolution, died today in Beijing. He was 84 years old.

title: Rider Is Killed In Subway Fall
description: A man was decapitated by a Queensbound IRT train when he apparently slipped and fell while walking between cars, the transit police said.

title: Market Place; Food Stocks Are Favored
description: THE increasing preoccupation with fitness and weight control among consumers should combine with growing farm surpluses to again fatten the earnings of food companies in 1987.

title: Susan M. Phillips Married To A. J. LoPinto, a Banker
description: The marriage of Susan Marie Phillips, a creative director at the advertising agency of Hicks & Greist, to Anthony J. LoPinto, the vice president and general manager of the New York real-estate division of the First National Bank of Chicago, took place yesterday. The Rev. George La Porte performed the nondenominational service at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: SOME DARE TO SAY 'DUVALIER' (WITHOUT CURSING)
description: The man was perhaps in his late 40's, and he wore the dark sunglasses that for years had been the trademark of the Tontons Macoute, the thugs who had been the enforcers of the dynastic Duvalier dictatorship.

title: LOCAL CONCILIATION PLANS PRAISED IN STUDY BY U.S.
description: Community centers established to handle disputes such as landlord-tenant disagreements or consumer complaints are a good complement to the traditional court system, a Government report said today.

title: COMEDY: BOB NELSON, IN SPOOF OF ATHLETES
description: AN impish-eyed lug of a man who totes a suitcase full of props onto the stage, the 28-year-old Long Island-based comedian Bob Nelson has a special knack for spoofing athletes whose dumbness is exceeded only by their hulking arrogance. In this vein, Mr. Nelson, who is appearing at Caroline's, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street, through tomorrow, has perfected a routine that may become a comedy classic, as he portrays a football player doing a live television commercial for the United Way at halftime.

title: Global Board Game
description: The Iran arms issue has given the Watergate crowd the status of elder statesmen of scandal.

title: Coghlan Injures Wrist in Mishap
description: Eamonn Coghlan suffered a broken wrist during a training run Saturday night after two youths set a snarling dog on the track as he tried to break up a fight.

title: Washington Watch; Senator Seeks Coal Job
description: Senator Mark Andrews, a North Dakota Republican who is among a group of departing senators who are seeking new jobs, has been campaigning to succeed Carl Bagge as president of the National Coal Association. Mr. Bagge, who has become something of a Washington institution during his 17 years at the helm of the coal companies' group, is retiring next year for health reasons.

title: WALTON'S WAKEUP CALL
description: Something happened today for the Jets - the kind of call and the kind of play that often can elevate a team when it is mired in confusion.

title: O'CONNER MEETINGS WITH TOP ISRAELIES SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: Israeli officials said today that the President, the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister would not meet with the Archbishop of New York during his coming visit here except in their offices in an official context.

title: Reading Reagan's Mind
description: The whole world is going bananas.

title: REBUILT NASA 'ON WAY BACK' AS AN ARRAY OF DOUBTS PERSIST
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has made substantial progress in carrying out the most extensive managerial and technical review in its history, according to space officials and outside experts.

title: Article 814686 -- No Title
description: OPEC should aim for a crude oil price of $28 a barrel, Algeria's energy minister said in a newspaper interview here today.

title: Jody Dee Katz Marries Giulio Andrea Martini
description: Jody Dee Katz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Katz of New York, was married at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan yesterday to Giulio Andrea Martini, a son of Giuseppe Sergio Martini of Callicoon, N.Y., and Leila Mori of Florence. Justice Richard W. Wallach of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Yes, Review School Decentralization
description: Few issues have so divided New York City as the struggle in the late 1960's over school decentralization, which produced the current system of community school boards. Now Robert Wagner Jr., president of the Board of Education, argues that the system has become so mired in politics and patronage as to stifle educational reform. His criticisms, though justified, have raised fears that he means to scrap the present system of decentralization. So far, those fears are unwarranted.

title: 'Weather Man' Counts Oil Rigs for Hughes Tool
description: With the recent accord of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sending the price of oil above the $17-a-barrel mark, Damon S. Ankenman hopes that the much-watched count on active rigs compiled by the Hughes Tool Company will also climb.

title: NEW DETAILS GIVEN IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Detectives investigating the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, reported new details yesterday that they said showed that the motorist whose car killed the victim was not an accomplice of the white youths accused of his murder.

title: CONNER YACHT TOPS USA BY 10 SECONDS
description: Dennis Conner brought Stars & Stripes from behind in the final minutes to score a 10-second victory over Tom Blackaller's USA as the semifinals of the America's Cup challenger series opened here today.

title: 3 Skiers Injured In Fall From Lift
description: Three skiers were injured in a 25-foot plunge from a chair lift at a state-owned ski center yesterday after the equipment apparently malfunctioned, a spokesman said.

title: CORPORATE AMERICA IN TURMOIL: COURTS WEAKEN DEFENSES
description: John E. Olson: Chairman American Telephone and Telegraph Company

title: REDSKINS ELIMINATE RAMS, 19-7
description: At times during the final stages of the regular season, the Washington Redskins played without enough patience on offense and aggressiveness on defense, which is like leaving the yeast out of bread. It leaves things sort of flat. Today, however, the Redskins mixed all the proper ingredients into a 19-7 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in the National Conference wild-card game to set the pairings for the divisional round of the playoffs next weekend.

title: MET OPERA: FAITH ESHAM MAKES DEBUT IN 'FIDELIO'
description: SATURDAY night's ''Fidelio'' at the Metropolitan Opera brought a debut that was promising but not so successful as one had hoped, along with three other changes from the opening lineup.

title: Youth String Orchestra To Play at Carnegie
description: The New York String Orchestra, an ensemble of 60 musicians from 15 to 22 years old from schools across the country, will play Vivaldi's Concerto in C minor for Violin and String Orchestra (''Il Sospetto'') under the direction of Alexander Schneider in a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8.

title: NEW STYLE FITTING FOR KNICKS
description: For 26 days, the Knicks underwent a transition from one coaching philosophy to another that could not have been more traumatic. They were asked to forget that they had been conditioned to respond to the whims of one man, to adhere to the confines of his system or risk the punishment of public embarrassment. Now, they were told to play, as the players call it, ''their game.'' They were free to run and shoot almost as they pleased. And they were ordered to, most importantly, enjoy themselves.

title: 516 PIRANDELLO LETTERS DONATED TO PRINCETON
description: A few years before he received the 1934 Nobel Prize in Literature, the Sicilian playwright Luigi Pirandello, one of the 20th century's great innovators in the theater, wrote another letter to Marta Abba, a leading Italian stage and screen actress, who inspired several of his plays.

title: OUTDOORS: BOOKS ON DECOYS
description: Aside effect of the phenomenal increase in the value of duck, goose and shorebird decoys over the past decade has been the spate of books devoted to the craft or art of creating them.

title: ALBERT W. SHERER JR., 70, AUTHOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS PACT AT HELSINKI
description: Albert W. Sherer Jr., a career diplomat who specialized in Eastern Europe, was thrown out of Hungary at the height of the cold war and went on to write the draft of the human rights provisions of the Helsinki accords of 1975, died of cancer Saturday at Northwestern University Medical Center in Chicago. He was 70 years old and had moved to Chicago in 1984 from Greenwich, Conn.

title: EXPORT BAN TO RUSSIA COULD END
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to remove most controls before the end of January on exports of oil and gas equipment and technology to the Soviet Union, Administration trade officials said this weekend.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: HEAD OF SOVIET FILMS OUSTED AMID CRITICISM
description: Filipp T. Yermash, longtime chairman of the Soviet cinematography committee and the target of some Soviet film makers who complained he was a barrier to creative expression, was sent into retirement today.

title: AIDS VIRUS INFECTS PROSTITUTES AT PHILIPPINE BASE
description: When Jenny leaves for work as a bar hostess in the evenings, her live-in boyfriend, an American sailor, sometimes calls after her jokingly, ''Don't catch AIDS, now.''

title: SYRIA'S WORRYING WINTER: POLITICAL AND FINANCIAL ILLS, AND PLENTIFUL STATUES
description: President Hafez al-Assad, who in his 16 years of power has come to be regarded as one of the most cunning - and ruthless -strategists in the Middle East, is facing a host of problems at home and abroad.

title: Advertising; CES Adds Magazine On Convenience Stores
description: International Thomson Business Press's CES Publishing has bought Convenience Store Merchandiser magazine, having earlier this year acquired four monthly retail magazines from United States Business Press.

title: KOCH, SEEKING RACIAL TALK, GETS IRATE RECEPTION AT QUEENS CHURCH
description: Mayor Koch went to a church in Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday in search of what he called an honest and forthright discussion about race relations and found himself interrupted, booed, shouted down and snubbed.

title: SOME FANCIFUL FLIGHTS ON CONCORDE CHARTERS
description: Bernie and Marilyn Moschenross got married last July - traveling at twice the speed of sound, 55,000 feet in the air.

title: Thick Fog in Atlanta Mars U.S. Air Traffic
description: A thick blanket of fog descended on Hartsfield International Airport today, grounding all flights out of the busy air hub and leading to delayed flights all over the nation.

title: WHEN STUDIES MISLEAD
description: A 36-YEAR-OLD patient recently told Dr. JoAnn Magdoff, a Mahattan psychotherapist, that she had decided to marry a man she did not love after reading a study that suggested a college-educated woman who was single at age 30 had only a 20 percent chance of marrying.

title: Automobile Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERETTA: 'PARIENCE,' BY GILBERT AND SULLIVAN
description: THE joy of seeing John Reed in Gilbert and Sullivan lies partly in the reflection that someone who has done something over and over for 30-odd years can still have fun at it. Ever since the D'Oyly Carte troupe closed down in England, Mr. Reed - who had been its principal comedian - has circled the globe guesting in his old roles, and for his fourth annual engagement with the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players he is appearing as Bunthorne, the opportunistic esthete of ''Patience,'' at Symphony Space (Broadway and 95th Street). The production runs through Sunday.

title: 1986's Legacy: Tumultuous Era for Big Business
description: Big business in America is overhauling itself and its operations faster than at any time since World War II.

title: Officer Is Suspended After Being Arrested
description: A rookie New York City police officer was suspended yesterday after being charged on Long Island with harassment and resisting arrest after a dispute with his girlfriend, authorities said.

title: Why China's Students Are Demonstrating
description: Tens of thousands of university students in China have risked their future careers by demanding democratic freedoms that are guaranteed in the Constitution but denied by China's leaders. Why? Having traveled in China for more than two months last summer and fall, I can testify to the depths of disillusionment with Deng Xiaoping's reforms that motivate such courageous, dedicated behavior.

title: 3 Points or Bust
description: Like a lot of other boys growing up around Lawrenceville, Ill., Doug Novsek had a basketball hoop in his driveway and learned to shoot under the country sky. A 20-footer was a shot he could make stepping out of the kitchen with a bologna sandwich in one hand.

title: U.S. GOODS MADE IN MEXICO RAISE CONCERN ON LOSS OF AMERICAN JOBS
description: After prospering in relative obscurity for 20 years, a rapidly growing manufacturing program in Mexico has become a focus of increasing concern in the United States. Labor and Congressional leaders say it poses the kind of threat to American jobs that is usually associated with the Far East.

title: The Empty Pump Down the Road
description: The price of a gallon of unleaded regular is down below a dollar, and while OPEC has finally agreed to a modest price increase, few analysts believe the squabbling cartel will be able to make it stick. That means our energy policy is working, right? Wrong, oh so wrong.

title: Nebraska House Fire Kills 3
description: Fire raced through a frame house before dawn today, killing two children and their 19-year-old baby sitter, who apparently was trying to rescue the children, the police said. The bodies of the children, Anthony Gill, 2 1/2, and his 16-month-old sister, Savannah, were found in a bed and the baby sitter, Todd D. Thrane, was found on the floor near the bed, Police Chief Gary Spencer said. ''It appears as if Thrane was trying to rescue the children,'' Chief Spencer said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE COUNTERLIFE. By Philip Roth. 324 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Victoriana at Carnegie For New Year's Eve
description: The tenor Robert Tear and the baritone Benjamin Luxon will take part in an ''Evening of Victorian Songs and Instrumental Music'' at Carnegie Hall on New Year's Eve, with Marvin Hamlisch at the piano and guest appearances by Isaac Stern, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman and the harpist Nancy Allen. The concert begins at 8 P.M.

title: 6 DIE AS JAPAN TRAIN PLUNGES
description: An excursion train that had just let off 180 passengers today was hit by gale-force winds and some of its cars plunged 135 feet onto a crabmeat processing plant, killing six people and injuring six, the police said.

title: Advertising; Ad Satellite Company Calls Tests Successful
description: New York-based Ad/Sat, a relatively new company that is in the business of transmitting ready-to-run advertising to newspapers via satellite, announced that it has successfully completed its tests involving a dozen daily papers and now expects to be servicing the top 100 markets by the end of 1987. It eliminates the need to ship hard copy and it gets copy to the papers fast.

title: United Foods Sells Unit
description: United Foods Inc. said it sold a frozen food plant and related equipment to Mrs. Smith's Frozen Foods Company, a unit of the Kellogg Company, for $15 million. United Foods said Friday that the sale and a related adjustment in the value of underutilized properties would produce a net gain of about $4 million, or 29 cents a share.

title: THE CREDIT-CARD FRAUD BATTLE
description: Despite widespread efforts by merchants and financial institutions to combat it, credit-card fraud is still a huge, worldwide problem, and a problem that gets worse at Christmas, when stores are jammed and credit card use peaks.

title: 'AMONG FRIENDS': THE WORRIES AND THE REALITIES
description: The problem with friends is that most people don't feel they have enough of them. ''Or they think the friendships they have aren't close enough,'' said Letty Cottin Pogrebin. ''I interviewed so many people who had rich social lives, yet they were all so worried that they were missing something. When friendship is involved, people really believe they are somehow lacking. They worry if they're calling enough. They feel guilty. They worry that their friends go to others when they want close companionship.''

title: Chief Pushes Plan to Aid Commonwealth Edison
description: As a high school student, James J. O'Connor admits, he spent a fair amount of time in detention after hours for, among other things, devising schemes of which his teachers disapproved.

title: TV REVIEW 'BLUE DE VILLE' ON NBC, AN ON-THE-ROAD TALE
description: CONSIDERED by many to be the Great Reflector of society at large, television entertainment is watched closely for supposed trends. During the last several years, for instance, a somewhat conservative bent in manners and life styles has been detected among the inhabitants of television sitcoms and movies. Marriage is in again, having children is fun, making money is bliss - that sort of thing. What, then, is one supposed to make of ''Blue DeVille,'' the television movie being slipped into NBC's schedule tonight at 9? Here is a genially dopey on-the-road caper that laughingly rejects weddings and family togetherness in favor of having, as the writers put it, ''some stupid, crazy times.''

title: 3 Slain After Houston Wedding
description: Gunmen opened fire during a wedding reception at a Chinese restaurant Saturday, starting a gun battle that killed three people, including one of the attackers, the police said today.

title: BANGKOK IS TRYING TO UNSTRANGLE ITS TRAFFIC
description: Thai national planners have discovered what most Bangkokians have long suspected: The city's traffic is gradually grinding to a halt.

title: DIVIDED ONEIDA TRIBE SEEKS END TO FEUD
description: A few hundred years ago, in the rich wilderness that is now New York State and beyond, the Oneida Indians, at peace with other tribes and themselves, formed a thriving community. They eventually became allies of George Washington, supplying food to his troops at Valley Forge during the harsh winter of 1778.

title: Britain and Guatemala Renew Diplomatic Ties
description: Britain and Guatemala have decided to resume diplomatic relations, broken by Guatemala in 1963 in a dispute over neighboring Belize, the Foreign Office said today.

title: MICHIGAN PLAN GUARANTEES COLLEGE TUITION
description: WHEN Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan signed a bill into law last week creating a statewide tuition-guarantee program, Michigan became the first state to adopt an idea that more than a dozen private colleges are already using to help parents cope with the crunch of college expenses.

title: CAROLINA OVERWHELMS PURDUE
description: Kenny Smith scored a career-high 23 points and led North Carolina into the final of The Dallas Morning News Classic with a 94-81 victory over Purdue.

title: BLACKS REACT WITH DISAPPOINTMENT AND ANGER
description: Reaction among blacks to the dismissal of murder and manslaughter charges in the Howard Beach racial attack ranged from disappointment to the assertion that it was ''predictable'' in a criminal-justice system that they said has often failed to heed cries by blacks for justice.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cigna Investments, Bloomfield, Conn., a subsidiary of Cigna Corp., appointed Neil Kelleher senior vice president and senior portfolio manager in its Common Stock division.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NOTHING is more ephemeral than fashion. But pinning down its passing fancies can tell us something about our world. This year, for instance, saw a dramatic splintering of style. While some believed they could still issue dress decrees, American fashion in 1986 was whatever people wanted to make it.

title: 6-YEAR LOW FOR DOLLAR VS. MARK
description: The dollar drifted to a six-year low against the West German mark yesterday and its lowest level in several months against the Japanese yen in thin year-end trading, With most traders on the sidelines, volume was at best one-quarter to one-third the normal level, foreign exchange dealers estimated.

title: CITY SHELTERING MORE FAMILIES IN NEW JERSEY
description: New York City, faced with a growing number of homeless families, has been increasing its use of New Jersey hotels to provide them with shelter.

title: Kodak Price Rise
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would raise prices on most of its consumer and professional photo products, including all Kodacolor film formats, effective Jan. 24. A Kodak spokesman, Henry K. Kaska, said the increases would range from 3 percent to 6 percent. Prices on photographic paper will increase, Kodak said, but photofinishing charges and videotape prices will remain the same.

title: Guinness Stock Investigation
description: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C., the British-Irish brewing concern, said today that the British Government had ordered an investigation into the circumstances in which a subsidiary of a merchant bank held shares in the company.

title: A Prophet of Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Combating Smog
description: Two scientists at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., have discovered a simple chemical method by which nitrogen oxides can be removed from engine exhaust gases, thereby reducing smog and acid rain.

title: NO XEROX MOVE YET ON PRETORIA
description: The Xerox Corporation, citing the need for further study, declined today to say whether it would sell its South African operations and join the exodus of major corporations from the country.

title: GMINSKI EXCELS FOR NETS
description: Before the game, Coach Dave Wohl was talking about how much the Nets missed Darryl Dawkins, the center who was sitting out his 22d game since injuring his back in a fall while showering at home on Nov. 13.

title: The Menace Is Credulity
description: Leaders everywhere are wringing their hands about the loss of United States credibility after the Iran-contra affair. But the problem may be even more in the wild ideas people are prepared to believe when they can't be sure than in loss of trust in the word of the U.S. Government.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CHINESE OFFICIALS CRITICIZE PROTESTS
description: For the first time since the outbreak of pro-democracy student demonstrations four weeks ago, senior Chinese leaders were quoted by name today as denouncing the protesters.

title: Enduring Agony, A Boy's Made Taller
description: ANTHONY TARABOCCHIA Jr. is an athletic, outgoing boy, normal in every way, except that he was born a dwarf. ''Since birth,'' said his mother, Mary, ''my goal has been to find something for him. I thought if they could transplant hearts and send people to the moon, they could help Anthony grow.''

title: Local Jobs, Foreign Flavor
description: The assignment for the staff member at a Far Eastern embassy here last spring was to write an assessment of American domestic politics in 1986.

title: GRETA MOSHEIM, 81, A GERMAN LEADING LADY OF THE THEATER
description: Grete Mosheim, a leading Berlin and West German stage actress, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: G.E.-Fanuc Joint Venture
description: The General Electric Company, the giant electric and television concern, moved further into factory automation today by announcing a $200 million joint venture with Fanuc Ltd. of Japan. The G.E. Fanuc Automation

title: Accuray-Hercules
description: The Accuray Corporation and Hercules Inc. said their boards had approved a merger agreement under which Hercules would acquire Accuray for $40 a share - $5 more than a recent offer by Combustion Engineering.

title: J.M. Smucker in Shifts To a New Generation
description: The J.M. Smucker Company, the little jelly and jam maker that has giants such as Kraft Inc. and Welch Foods on the defensive, announced a series of management changes yesterday that lay the groundwork for the fourth generation of Smuckers to lead the Orrville, Ohio, company.

title: U.S. AND IRAN RESUME TALKS ON FUNDS
description: The United States and Iran resumed negotiations today on the return of some $500 million owed to Teheran by Washington, and a top American official held out the hope that the talks might lead Iran to use its influence to free the American hostages in Lebanon.

title: MACHINERY WAYLAYS 'LES MISERABLES'
description: The American premiere engagement of the London hit musical ''Les Miserables'' became a bit rocky Sunday, when a $200,000 rotating stage at the Kennedy Center Opera House malfunctioned 30 minutes into the afternoon performance, forcing its cancellation and that of the evening show.

title: DRIVER OF CAR SAID TO AGREE TO TESTIFY
description: Dominick Blum, the motorist whose car killed a young black man 10 days ago in Howard Beach, Queens, has volunteered to testify before a grand jury without immunity, a spokesman for Mr. Blum said yesterday.

title: KOCH CALLS '86 'TERRIBLE' YEAR AMID SCANDAL
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called 1986 ''a terrible year'' for him, and went further than ever before in apologizing for the corruption scandal that has marred the beginning of his third term, the term he had predicted would be his best.

title: Birthplace of Brontes In England to Be Sold
description: The parsonage where the Bronte sisters were born is up for sale and is likely to be converted into apartments, a realtor has said.

title: H. RICHARD WACHTEL
description: H. Richard Wachtel, a senior partner of the Manhattan-based law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, died Friday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 59 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: School for Salmon
description: The National Marine Fisheries Service has opened a school to teach salmon the rudiments of avoiding predatory cod.

title: Simpler Days
description: On the day last week when indoor soccer's New York Express sent Coach Ray Klivecka packing after an 0-10 start, Rick Davis's mind drifted back to similarly frustrating yet happier times.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: Contending Again
description: Following in that grand and glorious tradition of Bill Bradley, Jack Kemp, Vinegar Bend Mizell, Jim Bunning, et al., Ernie Terrell, the former heavyweight champion, is the latest erstwhile athlete to seek public office. He's running against nine other Democratic candidates for one of 50 seats on the City Council in his native Chicago, and Round 1 is the primary election Feb. 24.

title: Chess: Soviet Team, With Trouble, Captures Gold in Olympiad
description: The Soviet Union captured the gold medals in the 27th World Chess Olympiad in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, but not without unexpected difficulties. The team, composed of Gary Kasparov, Anatoly Karpov, Artur Yusupov, Andrei Sokolov, Rafael Vaganian and Vitaly Tseshkovsky, scored 40-16 to top 107 teams in the 14-round Swiss-system tournament.

title: COLOMBIA UPHOLDS REPORTER EXPELLED BY U.S.
description: The Colombian Defense Ministry says it has found no evidence to support an American official's assertion that Patricia Lara, a reporter for a leading newspaper in Bogota, has any links to the guerrilla group M-19 or has ever acted as an agent of Cuba.

title: BLOOD-BRAIN BARRIER BEGINS TO YIELD
description: THE human brain converses with the entire universe, but it maintains a strange and stringent isolation from its own body.

title: ANDREI TARKOVSKY, DIRECTOR AND SOVIET EMIGRE, DIES AT 54
description: Andrei Tarkovsky, the Russian director who won acclaim in the West for films that were criticized and banned in his homeland, died of lung cancer yesterday in Paris. He was 54 years old.

title: AMERICAN JEWISH GROUPS SAY CARDINAL SHOULD CANCEL ISRAEL VISIT
description: Several American Jewish spokesmen said yesterday that even at this late date, John Cardinal O'Connor should cancel a trip to Israel rather than risk snubbing Israeli leaders by refusing to meet with them officially in Jerusalem.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would purchase two of ITT Corp.'s communications companies: All America Cables and Radio Inc. and ITT Communications Inc. Virgin Islands.

title: Need for Screening
description: To the Editor:

title: Name Change Creates Muhlfeld & Wolff Shop
description: What is the name of the country's largest agency specializing in marine goods?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 107, Hawks 106: Phil Hubbard hit a foul shot with 3 seconds left for the winning point last night as Cleveland overcame a 16-point third-quarter deficit to edge Atlanta in Richfield, Ohio. Atlanta's Dominique Wilkins, who led all scorers with 25 points, tied the game at 106 with 15 seconds left with a 3-pointer. Hubbard got the offensive rebound off a missed shot and was fouled by Kevin Willis. He made his second attempt.(AP) Bullets 125, Warriors 105: At Landover, Md., Moses Malone scored 35 points to lead Washington past Golden State. The Bullets led by 19 points in the first period but saw the lead trimmed to 70-69 midway through the third quarter. The Bullets then went on an 11-2 spurt, with Malone scoring 7 of the points.(AP) Jazz 109, Spurs 101: In Salt Lake City, John Stockton scored 9 of his 14 points in the fourth period and handed out 15 assists for Utah. The victory gave the Jazz a 12-1 record in December, the best month in franchise history. The Jazz led by only 102-98 with 1:33 remaining, but seconds later, Stockton hit a 3-point goal and added another basket on Utah's next possession.(AP) Horse Racing Spring Beauty Wins: Spring Beauty took the lead early, relinquished it briefly and then, after regaining command in the stretch, raced to a two-length victory in an allowance feature for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: CHICAGO BANK HEALTHY AGAIN
description: The Northern Trust Company, Chicago's fourth-largest bank, is the most prominent medium-sized bank in this key market that is not yet part of a larger financial company.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago periods include a $4.2 million writedown of assets and inventory.

title: AIDES SAY CHICAGO WILL LOSE 250 MILLION IN FINES AND FEES
description: Antiquated collection methods, legal challenges and uncooperative court officials make it unlikely that Chicago will ever see most of the $250 million it is owed in delinquent fines and fees, officials say.

title: Alton Asa Lennon Dies at 80; Was a Carolina Congressman
description: Alton Asa Lennon, a former United States Senator and Representative from Wilmington who was known as one of North Carolina's most conservative Congressmen, died Sunday at Cape Fear Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Villanova 69, S. Carolina 59
description: Harold Jensen personally outscored South Carolina, 12-5, over a four-minute stretch of the second half to lead Villanova to the title in the Sugar Bowl tournament.

title: WALTON MUM ON QUARTERBACK
description: Everyone who follows the Jets would assume that Pat Ryan will be the quarterback again when the team continues the playoff route next Saturday at Cleveland. But Ryan doesn't know that.

title: FASHION PREDICTS A MORE ELABORATE SPRING
description: The big, pouffed skirts that burst out of Paris recently had something to do with it; they loosened the attitude of many women toward fashion. So did the feeling for luxury and opulence this past fall, reflected in the preference for cashmere in daytime clothes and glitter and lavishness for evening. Whatever the reasons, designers of expensive clothes report that their lists of best-selling clothes for spring are studded with extravagant designs. The more exaggerated clothes have, in many cases, outshone the modified versions of the same design ideas.

title: Shearson Jobs Reported for 2
description: Thomas I. Unterberg and A. Robert Towbin, who recently resigned as senior executives from L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings after losing a key board vote, will join Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. early next year as managing directors, according to Wall Street sources.

title: COURT BARS A SUIT OVER BOOKS LIST
description: The author of a book that was not listed in The New York Times Book Review's compilation of best sellers cannot sue the newspaper for damages, the California Supreme Court ruled today in dismissing a $3 million suit.

title: MANNING TELLS OF KILLING JERSEY TROOPER
description: Thomas W. Manning testified today that he killed a New Jersey state trooper in self-defense after the trooper stopped him for speeding, recognized him as a fugitive and fired at him.

title: U.S. IS SEEN RETALIATING ON EUROPE FARM TRADE
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to announce Tuesday retaliatory measures against some European farm exports, White House officials said tonight.

title: Soviet Health Official Quits
description: Health Minister Sergei P. Burenkov, who has held office since 1980, has retired on grounds of ill health, the Tass press agency reported today. No successor has been named.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1986
description: International

title: New Transistor
description: A new transistor has been designed at the University of Illinois that may improve supercomputers and communication systems, the university says.

title: THE BROWNS AND DON ROGERS
description: Ever since the death of Len Bias from cocaine intoxication last June, the University of Maryland basketball program has been in turmoil. But the similar death of Don Rogers a week later appears to have had a stabilizing effect on the Cleveland Browns, whom the Jets will oppose Saturday in the Super Bowl XXI playoffs.

title: A Little Slip Of Lou's Lip
description: It wasn't quite a matter of loose lips sinking ships, but something Lou Piniella said last week may have poked a small hole in the baseball owners' defense against charges of collusion on the free-agent front.

title: TAILFINS AND SOFTWARE HARDSELL
description: SOFTWARE marketing has attained the stage reached by old cars in '58. Not only are the packaging and the advertising full of fins and flash, but there's an option available for virtually everything and everyone except lefties. As with the cars, however, many of the options in software serve little purpose and are rarely utilized. This lack of real function explains why those once touted integrated packages encompassing everything but the kitchen sink did not sweep the world of personal computing as expected.

title: MALFUNCTION SOUGHT IN AGING REACTOR'S SHUTDOWN
description: Workers at the Hanford nuclear reservation today investigated a device believed to have caused a malfunction that triggered an automatic shutdown of the trouble-plagued N reactor, a spokesman said.

title: LIBYANS ARE SAID TO TAKE TOWN IN NORTHERN CHAD
description: Libyan troops seized control of a strategic oasis in northern Chad today after more than two weeks of heavy fighting against Chadian forces, French officials said.

title: SOFTWARE WARFARE
description: COPYRIGHT battles in the computer business are not new. In Hong Kong, for example, shadowy companies have been making copies of well-known American computers and peripherals for years and selling them to unsuspecting - and sometimes suspecting - customers at a substantial discount. Kevin Jenkins, president of Hercules Inc., the graphics-board maker, said he has seen his boards copied so meticulously that they even included the Hercules trademark. Computer companies have not been shy about suing these foreign counterfeiters.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel like I was born and raised in a plane.

title: Now Is the Time for New York State's Republican Tax-Cut Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR BAG PLAN STIRS DISPUTE ON AUTO SEAT BELT
description: The Department of Transportation's proposal to allow more flexibility in its air bag rule for cars may spur more widespread use of passenger safety devices by automobile makers but it could also damage efforts to get states to adopt mandatory seat belt use laws, some safety groups and advocates fear. Federal officials disagree with the fears on seat belt laws.

title: 557 ACRES ON L.I. ACQUIRED IN PLAN FOR PARKLAND
description: A 557-acre expanse of woods, brush and waterfront in the Hither Woods area of East Hampton town was sold by a developer today for $8.3 million for use as public parkland.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. WASHINGTON BULLETS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) DETROIT PISTONS VS.

title: Rates Move Up in a Light Day
description: Treasury bill rates climbed and bond prices plunged yesterday in a somewhat unsettled and thin money market.

title: Slaying and Suicide Linked to a Mistake
