description: An estranged husband yesterday shot and killed a man he erroneously thought was having an affair with his wife, then called the woman to tell her what he had done and killed himself, the police said.

title: IS THERE A PAST IN THE FUTURE?
description: OF all phenomena that affect the human condition none has perplexed scientists more than the forward march of time, its link to the seemingly relentless tendency toward disorder known as entropy, and to the expansion of the universe.

title: Silence, Not Justice, for Howard Beach
description: The grisly racial attack on three black men in Howard Beach inflamed race relations in New York City. The temperature shot up yesterday when a judge dismissed murder, manslaughter and assault charges against the three defendants, leaving only charges of reckless endangerment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1986
description: Markets

title: Congress's Clumsiest?
description: Bradley O'Leary, a devout Republican, and Victor Kamber, a staunch Democrat, are publishers of the Washington-based political dope sheet called the O'Leary/Kamber Report. They admit they don't agree on much of anything, at least as far as politics is concerned.

title: Any Basement?
description: Manager Jim Leyland of the Pirates, whose 64-98 record was the majors' worst last season, on his new house in Pittsburgh: ''Contrary to popular belief, it is not a mobile home.''

title: FINANCIAL NEWS NEWTWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New Presidential Term Is Voted for Kim Il Sung
description: Kim Il Sung, who has led North Korea since the peninsula was partitioned after World War II, was re-elected President today by Parliament, North Korea announced. A new Prime Minister was also named.

title: WOMEN'S ROLES VS. SOCIAL NORMS
description: The changing world of women has had a dramatic impact on Americans in the last 30 years, and reconciling their many roles poses the challenge of the future, a new study reports.

title: A THIRD OF CITIES SAY TAX RISE WILL BE NEEDED
description: A survey of city government officials made public today found that more than a third of those polled believed they could not maintain current services without raising taxes.

title: USA LOSES AGAIN TO CONNER'S YACHT 871>
description: Tom Blackaller's USA was beaten again today in the America's Cup challengers' semifinals, losing to Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes by 3 minutes 2 seconds.

title: Dow Off 18.28 as Volume Stays Low
description: Wall Street yesterday recorded its sharpest drop in nearly six weeks as trading volume remained unusually low.

title: ARCHBISHOP VISITS PALESTINIAN AREA
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, toured Jordan's largest Palestinian refugee center today, visiting children in their flimsy classroom buildings and walking the rutted streets.

title: Executive's Wife Reported Missing
description: The wife of the chairman of the board of the Wedtech Corporation, a troubled South Bronx military contractor, disappeared six weeks ago from the couple's apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, and has been the subject of wide search by the police and private detectives, officials said yesterday.

title: George C. Escher, 74; Led Cancer Research
description: Dr. George Charles Escher, a leading researcher on advanced breast cancer, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS HOLIDAY FESTIVAL
description: While no super teams have surfaced thus far in the college basketball season, distinct echelons have emerged from the nation's top-20 teams.

title: NEW ALLURE IN TEXAS: BARGAIN BASEMENT PRICES AMID DEFLATION
description: John Mockovciak Jr., an aerospace engineer with the Grumman Corporation, faces the pleasant prospect next spring of moving from Bayville, L.I., to Houston. He will probably be able to sell his 2,000-square-foot ranch house on Long Island for at least $350,000 and buy something similar here for less than half that.

title: THE CITY'S 'OTHER FACE' INSPIRES GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: Concern for the homeless, for needy children and for the elderly poor who are alone are recurring themes in letters that accompany contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: How Federal Aid Drives Up College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES TO STAMP OUT DISSENT IN ITS BLACK SCHOOLS
description: South Africa's white authorities announced new measures under the nation's emergency decree today to combat dissent in segregated black schools and to counter plans for an ''alternative'' syllabus called people's education.

title: Jetliner Pilot Puts Out Fire
description: An engine on a United Airlines jet caught fire tonight while it was making an emergency landing at O'Hare International Airport, but the pilot sprayed foam on the blaze and put it out in less than a minute, officials said. The 85 passengers and seven crew members aboard the Boeing 727 were safely evacuated after the fire was extinguished, officials said. The plane had just taken off from O'Hare on a flight to San Antonio when it was forced to return after one of its engines shut down.

title: A JUDGE DISMISSES CHARGE OF MURDER IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Charges of murder, manslaughter and assault against three white youths in the death of a black man in Howard Beach were dismissed by a Queens judge yesterday after the prosecution's key witness - another black man who was attacked - refused to testify.

title: Ex-East German Aide, Lothar Bolz, Dies at 83
description: Lothar Bolz, a former Foreign Minister of East Germany, died today, the official press agency reported. He was 83 years old.

title: JAPAN FUND CAN INVEST MORE ABROAD
description: Japan's large postal savings life insurance fund will be free to invest $18 billion more in foreign bonds under new rules announced today. The move could increase Japan's growing investment in the United States and other countries.

title: FOG IN ATLANTA DISRUPTS HOLIDAY TRAVEL A 2D DAY
description: Fog at Atlanta's busy airport disrupted nationwide airline operations and delayed thousands of homeward-bound Christmas travelers for the second day yesterday.

title: Business and the Law; Courts Faulted On Buyouts
description: IN a recent letter to clients, Martin Lipton, the lawyer who often helps corporate boards fight takeovers, delivered an unusually stern lecture to the Delaware Supreme Court and two Federal circuit courts. Mr. Lipton said that those courts had failed to understand the dynamics of takeover battles - and ended up favoring raiders and hurting shareholders - when they ruled that corporate boards should not have sided with efforts of management to put together leveraged buyouts to thwart hostile bidders.

title: Giants Impressed By 49ers' Progress
description: The Giants will meet the San Francisco 49ers here Sunday in their first playoff game, and Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, says it will not be easy. Tim Rooney, who scouts future opponents for the Giants, agrees.

title: The Long Shadow of Anti-Soviet Rioting
description: The ethnic, anti-Russian riots that took place earlier this month in the Central Asian city of Alma-Ata are a reminder that racial tensions remain a serious threat to the Soviet empire - to its short-term stability and long-term survival.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $6.3 million. The latest fiscal year results include a charge for possible losses of $23.3 million relating to loan delinquencies and foreclosures experienced by the company's Texas-based savings and loan and mortgage banking subsidiaries. This compares with $5.6 million of such loss provisions in fiscal 1985.

title: THRIFT UNIT IS ACQUIRED
description: First Nationwide Bank, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said today that it had acquired the Lincoln Federal Savings and Loan Association of Louisville, Ky. With the acquisition, First Nationwide, which is based in San Francisco, received the rights to expand into Virginia and Maryland through a bidding process conducted by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 13
RISE SEEN IN CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS LOSS
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company estimated today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would lose $1.6 billion on the troubled loans that Continental turned over to it as part of the Federal plan to rescue the bank.

title: POWER LINE FOR CITY STIRS RURAL ANGER
description: One recent morning Sheldon Hansel, a third-generation dairy farmer in this upstate village, got up at 5:30, as always, to milk the cows.

title: Bucs Dismiss Bennett
description: Leeman Bennett, who won only four games in two years as coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was dismissed yesterday by the National Football League team. Hugh Culverhouse, the owner of the Buccaneers, told a packed news conference in Tampa that he had struggled over the decision to dismiss Bennett for two weeks and made up his mind shortly before the announcement.

title: NEW USE FOR TEXAS LANDMARK
description: The site of a landmark hotel, already under demolition, may be absorbed into the giant Texas Medical Center.

title: MAN WITH RIFLE DAMAGES OFFICE AFTER LOSING JOB
description: A burglar-alarm salesman who had lost his job barricaded himself in his former employer's midtown office with a rifle yesterday, used a hatchet to turn the place into a ''shambles,'' then surrendered after six hours without injuring anyone, the police said.

title: The Fifth Is Now Obsolete
description: ''No person shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.'' These 15 words in the Fifth Amendment have now paralyzed the Government. Everybody agrees the crisis should be ended quickly. Everybody agrees it will instead drag on for months, as long as Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and ex-Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord continue to take the Fifth instead of telling what they know about the Iran arms fiasco. It's frustrating. The President blames the Congress for not granting immunity. The Congress blames the President for not somehow commanding forth the truth.

title: KIROV BALLET PERFORMS 'LA BAYADERE' ON BRAVO
description: ''LA BAYADERE,'' one of the classics of the 19th-century Russian ballet repertory, can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on the Bravo cable network in a fine performance by the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, the company for which it was originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1877. Back then, the Kirov was known as the Maryinsky Ballet, and Leningrad was St. Petersburg. Yet, though times have changed, ''La Bayadere'' remains a splendid example of a form of choreography popular a century ago.

title: Medical Texts for Poland
description: Among the many difficulties of life in Poland in recent years has been a shortage of hard currency for the purchase of medical texts and journals for the country's 10 medical and dental schools, according to Friends of Poland Inc., a nonprofit group based in New Bedford, Mass. Some medical texts retail for $100 or more each.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK REMEDIAL EDUCATION VOUCHERS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would propose legislation allowing local school districts to provide parents with federally financed vouchers to pay for remedial education classes of their choice.

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise To a 10-Month High
description: Crude oil prices rose to their highest levels in 10 months yesterday on world futures markets, signaling increased confidence in last week's production accord of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 50, BACK IN MOSCOW, BEWAIL U.S. LIFE
description: Fifty emigres, disappointed with their attempts to build new lives in the United States, returned to the Soviet Union today to a warm official reception.

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $574,860 for the quarter and $878,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: SEEKING BOARD GAME BONANZA
description: When Trivial Pursuit hit the American market in 1984, it single-handedly revived the board game industry. An estimated one out of five households bought the question-and-answer game, which racked up nearly $800 million in sales.

title: Marks & Spencer at U.S. Malls
description: Marks & Spencer, a retailing institution on Britain's main shopping streets, said today that it would open three branches in New York State in its first foray into American shopping malls.

title: AGENDA
description: Hearing on S.R.O. Moratorium Mayor Koch holds a public hearing on measures recently passed by the City Council, including one that would extend by a month a moratorium on converting single-room-occupancy hotels and another that would broaden the city's anti-apartheid law. The Mayor is expected to sign both bills, thus making them law. 4:15 P.M., Blue Room, City Hall.

title: TOP RATING FOR CITY WATER
description: New York City tap water is as good as the best bottled variety, and so is most of that in Los Angeles, according to Consumer Reports.

title: Ewing Gets Honor
description: Patrick Ewing was rewarded for his role in the Knicks' recent resurgence yesterday when he was named the National Basketball Association's Player of the Week. In leading the Knicks to victories over the Spurs, Bulls and Bucks for their first three-game winning streak in more than a year, Ewing averaged 26.3 points, 13.3 rebounds and 2.0 blocked shots.

title: FEZZES TO FROG COSTUMES FOR NATION'S ARTS GROUPS
description: Michael Schler had just put a large brown felt animal on top of his head and was peering into a mirror to see whether or not he looked sufficiently like a gopher.

title: MANILA SEEKS POSSESSION OF 4 MANHATTAN BUILDINGS
description: The Philippine Government filed suit today for possession of four buildings in Manhattan and a sprawling estate in Long Island, saying Ferdinand E. Marcos acquired them illegally while President.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'LES MISERABLES,' VINTAGE '25 In 1862 ''Les Miserables,'' Victor Hugo's epic novel of poverty and pursuit, appeared, and it has never failed to attract interest since then. At the moment, the story is being performed as a hit musical in London and will open in New York in March. Between its first publication and its appearance as a hit musical, ''Les Miserables'' has appeared as theatrical production and, several times, as film.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aqueduct Suspension
description: Victor Maldonado, a groom employed by a trainer, Joe Aquilino, was suspended 60 calendar days by Aqueduct stewards for failing to report and concealing an electrical device of the type sometimes used illegally to stimulate horses into running faster. According to Manuel A. Gilman, the Jockey Club steward, Maldonado was returning to his lodging at the track about 4:30 A.M. Nov. 15 when he found the device, which Gilman termed a ''cattle prod,'' on the chute leading to the main track.

title: Jersey Bus Driver Is Killed in Crash
description: The driver of an N.J. Transit bus with no passengers aboard was killed yesterday morning when the bus struck a state highway sweeper.

title: JAPAN ARMS OUTLAY TO EXCEED PAST LIMIT
description: Japan crossed a politically critical threshold today, abandoning a 10-year-old policy that had limited military spending to 1 percent of the gross national product.

title: GAS LINE RUPTURED IN JERSEY
description: Gas leaking from a ruptured line of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company forced the closing of the Bayonne Bridge for a little more than an hour today. No injuries were reported. A spokesman for the Port Authouity of New York and New Jersey, Joseph Lanciotti, said a construction crew working on Route 169 in Bayonne cracked the gas line near Avenue A and Fifth Street at 11:37 A.M. The bridge links Bayonne and Staten Island.

title: HOWARD BEACH GETS 22 OFFICERS ON RACIAL DUTY
description: Twenty-two extra police officers have been assigned to Howard Beach, Queens, including nine plainclothes officers, to prevent any more racially motivated violence, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: WALTON BECOMES MASTER OF SUSPENSE
description: The press room at the New York Jets' training camp here was not quite dripping with suspense, though one significant question about the team had not been answered in regard to Saturday's playoff game against the Browns: Who would be the starting quarterback?

title: NO. 1, TWICE
description: If Miami beats Penn State this Friday night, Vinny Testaverde will become the seventh player in college football history - and only the second in 39 years - to capture both the Heisman Trophy and the national championship in the same season. Here are the six earlier Heisman winners whose teams finished with the No. 1 ranking in the major polls.

title: THREAT TO NATION'S LEAD IN SPACE IS SEEN IN LACK OF GUIDING POLICY
description: As workers at Cape Canaveral prepare for the somber task of burying the debris of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo, the greater wreckage of the American space program still lies everywhere, picked over but by no means reassembled into a vibrant whole.

title: America's Obsession Frustrates the Allies
description: The crisis over arms sales to Iran is described in Middle Eastern terms, but it's really about America.

title: Bridge: Steep Penalty for Opponent Proved to Be No Advantage
description: Angry readers reaching for writing materials in order to pen indignant letters about the typography of this column are asked to stay their hands: the bidding shown is an accurate record of the proceedings.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Do ostriches hide their heads in the sand when frightened? A.Although ostriches may lie on the ground with neck outstretched to escape detection, the belief that they bury their heads in the sand is unfounded. Ostriches can usually rely on their speed and keen eyesight to escape predators.

title: PERCEPTION OF TIME EMERGES AS KEY PSYCHOLOGICAL FACTOR
description: CLOCK time is inexorable in its steadiness.

title: Cookied Out
description: In countless refrigerators all over America a turkey is sitting, swathed in Saran Wrap and missing its legs. Yes, there's enough left for another meal.

title: WORDS ANGER MIAMI
description: Five days before the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl, the prime-time match between Miami and Penn State created to establish an indisputable victor in the college football polls, the spirit of respectful competition suffered the first defeat of the week.

title: Parole in 'Onion Field' Case Ordered by California Court
description: Gregory Powell, convicted of the 1963 ''Onion Field'' murder of a Los Angeles police officer, today was ordered paroled by the California Supreme Court, which said the state parole board erred in canceling his 1982 release date.

title: FIREBRAND, TWICE BURNED, OFFERS FIGHTING WORDS
description: Speaking softly and slowly, apparently still nursing his wounded pride after the latest setback in his plan to become President, Leonel Brizola was hardly recognizable as the Socialist firebrand who for a quarter of a century has been the politician most feared by Brazil's ruling elites.

title: E.P.A. Weighs New Air Rules
description: Officials in the Environmental Protection Agency say their agency is being inadvertently pushed into what amounts to an acid rain control program even though Congress has refused to adopt one.

title: A.T.& T. Rate Cut
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its planned price cut for dialed long-distance calls could be greater than the 8.1 percent it previously announced. The price cut follows an order by the Federal Communications Commission for a reduction in the rates local telephone companies charge A.T.& T. for transmitting the local portion of long-distance calls. The F.C.C. is scheduled to announce on Tuesday how much of the $375 million in reductions A.T.& T. will be required to pass on to customers.

title: EXPANDED BANK ROLES WEIGHED
description: The Comptroller of the Currency has begun to approve applications by several major New York City banking companies to set up operations in the District of Columbia that could give the institutions broad new securities powers in addition to full banking powers.

title: Advertising; Magazine Seeking Its Niche
description: BARBARA HANNAH MARKS, who was named a ''young achiever'' by Advertising Age in 1984, has turned 30, decided that is her fighting age and is about to take on some heavyweights.

title: KEY RATES
Dailey Becomes Clipper
description: Quintin Dailey, whose four-year N.B.A. career was interrupted by repeated drug problems, officially joined the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday. ''Everyone knows this is my last chance,'' Dailey said at practice.

title: A HECTIC YEAR-END PACE IN REAL ESTATE INDUSTRY
description: Thousands of real estate lawyers, sales agents and accountants are working around the clock to close deals before the big apple descends in Times Square, ringing in the new year and tolling goodbye to the advantageous income tax provisions that have helped make real estate a favored investment for many.

title: Job Stress May Explain Rise in Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Battles
description: Backers of the immigration bill that President Reagan signed into law only last month are already gearing up for what they believe will be protracted battle in both Congress and the courts over its provisions and enforcement.

title: DIANE SAWYER RENEWS CONTRACT WITH CBS NEWS
description: Diane Sawyer, the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, has agreed to a new contract with CBS News after weeks of negotiations with all three major broadcast networks.

title: SOMERSET SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company went public in July.

title: Roosevelt I. Housing Approved by Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday approved a new housing development that would raise Roosevelt Island's population by about 45 percent.

title: Israeli Court Grants a Delay In Trial of Nazi Camp Guard
description: A three-judge panel agreed today to a four-week delay in the trial of a retired American autoworker accused of killing thousands of people as a guard in a Nazi death camp.

title: Pennsylvania Raising Turnpike Fares 30%
description: Pennsylvania Turnpike officials were restocking toll booths across the state today with new tickets that reflect a 30 percent fare increase, the first increase in eight years.

title: Entries Close For Westminster
description: Entries for the 111th annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 9 and 10 have closed with 2,640 dogs representing 139 breeds or varieties. It was the earliest closing in more than a decade.

title: REVELERS TO BE GIVEN TAXI RIDES
description: New Year's Eve revelers who drink too much in northern New Jersey bars can ride home in a taxi at a brewing company's expense.

title: LAWMAKERS FAIL TO REACH PACT ON MASS TRANSIT
description: Facing a deadline only two nights away, state lawmakers reconvened in special session today but failed once again to agree on a plan to finance New York City's mass transit system.

title: 2-DAY STRIKE IN THE PUNJAB
description: Authorities in the Punjab moved today to minimize the effects of a two-day general strike by Sikh militants, rounding up more than 500 people for what was termed preventive detention.

title: 'STAR WARS' CRAFT CITED AS PENTAGON SEEKS EXTRA FUNDS
description: The Defense Department today asked Congress for funds to speed research on an immense new space vehicle that the Pentagon says will be needed to lift heavy objects into orbit for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program.

title: Books: A Teacher
description: KRISHNAMURTI. A Biography. By Pupul Jayakar. Illustrated. 516 pages. Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: Accounting Shift for Utilities
description: In yet another blow to the nuclear power industry, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ruled yesterday that utilities that cannot recover all the costs of completed nuclear plants must take charges against earnings.

title: THE YEAR FOR VALUES
description: VALUES was the buzz word of education in 1986. Stern demands for the teaching of values came from liberal Democrats like Governor Cuomo as well as conservatives like William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education. Why? Probably because values seemed in short supply everywhere, from Wall Street to Washington. As usual, the schools were asked to undo society's failure. But they got little help in defining the values they were expected to teach.

title: Market Place; Rise of Exxon, Royal Dutch
description: WITH a remarkable absence of fanfare on Wall Street, shares of the world's two largest oil companies have been climbing to record prices. ''It has been an astonishing performance,'' R. Bryan Jacoboski, international oil analyst for Paine Webber, said admiringly.

title: Jacobs Gets More Of Borg-Warner
description: The Minneapolis-based investor Irwin L. Jacobs said he had raised his stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation to the equivalent of 12.4 percent, or 10.6 million shares, from 11.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs reported that Bear, Stearns & Company had agreed to add an additional 970,800 Borg-Warner shares to an option agreement between the New York-based brokerage and Minstar Inc., of which Mr. Jacobs is chairman.

title: The Trojan Horse Missile
description: Gen. John Chain, head of the Strategic Air Command, stirs a passionate controversy with his proposal to base MX missiles on rail cars instead of in silos. His plan goes to the heart of a long-disputed issue - how to protect America's silo-based missiles from increasingly accurate Soviet missiles. Are mobile missiles the best way? No, says a group of Pentagon experts. Their solution is to stick with missiles in silos and add antimissile defenses. This plan would convert the Strategic Defense Initiative from Mr. Reagan's dubious goal of protecting the whole country to the easier task of defending missile fields.

title: FIRST AMERI-CABLE CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
EX-SECRETARIES OF STATE IN 4TH ANNUAL REPORT
description: ONE interesting thing about ''The Fourth Annual Report of the Secretaries of State'' is the date it was taped: Nov. 21, 1986. The attempt to divert funds to the Nicaraguan rebels had not yet been disclosed, although the Iran arms shipments had provoked a furor. The four former secretaries on the program, however, scarcely refer to Iran. They are on to broader, and sometimes more personal, issues.

title: Lawmakers Clash on Missile
description: A Republican Senator today criticized the Reagan Administration for supporting construction of the Midgetman missile, saying it would waste Defense Department funds. But the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee defended the Administration's position.

title: ATTACK CASE: TOUGH ISSUES
description: The Queens District Attorney and the lawyers for the victims in the Howard Beach racial attack will have to make several key decisions in the coming days as a result of the dismissal yesterday of murder charges against three suspects in the case, legal experts said.

title: PEOPLE'S ACQUISITION IS VOTED
description: At an 11-minute meeting, People Express stockholders yesterday approved the airline's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation, ending a tumultuous drama in airline deregulation.

title: WITH 2 YEARS LEFT, MANY REAGAN GOALS ON ENVIROMENTAL POLICY ARE UNMET
description: As the Reagan Presidency enters its last two years, the environmental counterrevolution it began in 1981 has achieved only some of its far-reaching goals.

title: THAI REFUGEE CAMP, DOOR OF HOPE, WILL BE CLOSED
description: Thailand announced today that it was closing Indochina's most famous refugee camp, a symbol of hope to hundreds of thousands of Cambodians escaping a decade of death and dislocation.

title: MUSIC: CORNET ENSEMBLE
description: THE New York Cornet and Sacbut Ensemble returned to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening with a program entitled ''Voice of Gold, Brass of Old,'' and devoted mostly to music from Italy. The ensemble - Allan Dean, Raymond Mase, Ben Peck, Ronald Borror, Terry Pierce and David Titcomb - began with a selection of anonymous Renaissance dance music. One piece, describing the strength of Hercules, brought forth some startling squawks; brass of old is still subject to some mishaps in handling. But both here and in a nicely varied set of six canzonas by Lappi, Gabrieli, Merulo and Priuli, the playing was spirited and alive to the dancing lines of the music.

title: A Polyglot Note
description: Three violin-piano duos have been named winners in a United States Information Agency competition to select musicians to appear as American ''ambassadors'' abroad, and two of the three had foreign-born citizens as principals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FALSE PROPHETS. By Alexander Kohn.

title: Some Also-Rans Must Keep Running for Years
description: John B. Connally would probably just as soon forget the 1980 Republican precinct caucuses in Iowa, which marked the beginning of the end of his Presidential bid.

title: Careers; The Areas Of Growth Next Year
description: THE nation's work force is expected to grow only moderately in 1987, but some industries are likely to show significant employment gains, labor analysts say.

title: Concern at the Vatican
description: Senior church officials expressed concern today about the dispute over Cardinal O'Connor's itinerary in Israel.

title: Eastdil Head Values Link to Nomura
description: By selling half of his company, Eastdil Realty Inc., to the Nomura Securities Company, Benjamin V. Lambert would seem to be giving up some of his hard-won independence.

title: McDONNELL TO BUILD WIDE-BODY JET
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that it would start production of the long-delayed MD-11 wide-body jetliner, a move that will keep the company in the business of building large passenger jets.

title: Copter Crashes Off Australia
description: A helicopter with 17 people aboard crashed off the western Australian coast today as it carried workers from an offshore oil rig, and two passengers were missing. An official of Woodside Offshore Petroleum Ltd. said the French-built Puma helicopter went down seven miles from the Karratha airstrip, 800 miles north of Perth, as it returned from the North Rankin oil rig. Rescue boats picked up the two-member crew and 13 passengers.

title: Group of Blacks Beat Man in Racial Attack
description: A 38-year-old Hispanic man was beaten by a group of black men in Brooklyn late Sunday in what the police said yesterday was a racially motivated attack. The police said that the victim's injuries were minor and that he had refused medical aid.

title: You Can Call Me . . .
description: Anticipating that his colleagues will stumble over the pronunciation of his name, Representative-elect Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Baltimore, has sent a note to all other members of the House stating, ''The following is a phonetic pronunciation of my name, which is of African derivation: Kwhy-E-See Oom-Foo-May.''

title: DANCE: NEUBERT BALLET AND CHILDREN'S TROUPE
description: THE Neubert Ballet Company and the Children's Ballet Theater, two groups of young dancers under the direction of Christine Neubert, joined forces Sunday afternoon at Ms. Neubert's newly renovated Studio Theater in Carnegie Hall. Consisting of short, lighthearted works, their program resembled a box of choreographic sweets for the holidays.

title: EVOLUTIONARY TRAVELS OF KIWIS AND OSTRICHES
description: A LONGSTANDING puzzle in evolution has been the global distribution of large, flightless birds, as well as their small cousin, the New Zealand kiwi. The ostriches of Africa, cassowaries and emus of Australia, and rheas of South America are native to habitats that have been isolated from one another for millions of years.

title: CONTRA ARMS PLAN LINKED TO ISRAELI
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has told Congress that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North told him that the idea of diverting proceeds from the Iran arms sale to Nicaraguan rebels came from a senior Israeli official, according to Congressional sources.

title: AULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: POST-BOWL DRUG TESTING SET
description: The 22 starters for each team in the five New Year's Day bowl games and the Fiesta Bowl on Friday night may be subjected to drug tests after the games, according to Dave Cawood, assistant executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: 4 FAMILIES SETTLE SHUTTLE CLAIMS
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that the families of four astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster had agreed to settle all claims against the Government, the space agency and its contractors in exchange for ''payments over an extended period of time.''

title: WEILL RECITAL HALL TO OPEN
description: The Weill Recital Hall, the space east of the main auditorium at Carnegie Hall formerly known as Carnegie Recital Hall, will open next Monday at 12:30 P.M. with a song recital by the baritone William Parker and the pianist William Huckaby. The program is the first in an expanded schedule of Carnegie-sponsored concerts in the smaller space, which will continue as well in its long-established role as a rental hall for debut artists and other visitors.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Hill, Holliday to Handle Bank of New England
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston has done it again. This time it has won the $10 million plus advertising account of the Bank of New England, which is also based in Boston.

title: U.S. Home Attracts Renewed Interest
description: The Pacific Realty Corporation, which earlier this year was rebuffed in a bid for the U.S. Home Corporation, said today that it had formed a joint venture with Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. aimed at increasing its stake in U.S. Home.

title: Third-World Debt, First-World Net
description: The International Monetary Fund, which provides loans and advice to ailing economies, finally has a new director. It needs a new direction, too.

title: WATERS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ECONOMY CHANGES EAGLE'S FORTUNES
description: Hunters here used to shoot bald eagles for a $2-a-head bounty, and there was anger four years ago when the state carved an eagle sanctuary out of logging and mining land.

title: Interior Dept. Official Quits
description: Ann Dore McLaughlin, often mentioned as a possible successor to Larry Speakes as the chief White House spokesman, resigned today as Under Secretary of the Interior to go back to school as a student and a teacher. Mrs. McLaughlin, who will leave March 1, said she would take courses in business and international economics and lecture on public policy at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Plan Would Curtail Psychiatric Care for Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Flights Delayed Nationwide Heavy fog at Atlanta's busy airport disrupted nationwide flights and delayed thousands of travelers for the second consecutive day.

title: THE REVOLUTION STARTED WITH THE SHOT HE FIRED
description: Beyond his 70th birthday, the man appears taller and sturdier - if a little grayer - than the one in the pictures that were taken in his youth. Fifty years removed from the basketball revolution he began as a junior at Stanford University, Hank Luisetti was talking about the consistency of his game.

title: POLICE CONCEDE COMMUNICATION FAILURE
description: The police said yesterday that a ''failure of communication'' between officers investigating the death of Michael Griffith had caused several hours of confusion over what car killed him after he was chased and beaten in the Howard Beach racial assault.

title: SMALL COMPANY TOWN IS LOSING ITS COMPANY
description: The copper smelter that sustained the economy in this small border community while it polluted the air is about to close, leaving Douglas a company town without a company.

title: Not Guilty Plea in Shooting
description: The man accused of killing Mayor Edward King and wounding two City Council members earlier this month over a dispute about a backed-up sewer pleaded not guilty today. The accused, Ralph O. Davis, filed his plea by mail in Henry County District Court, said County Attorney Michael Riepe. Mr. Davis waived his right to a trial within 90 days, and no trial date was set.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates announced that two catchers, Junior Ortiz and Tom Prince, and a pitcher, Barry Jones, have signed contracts for the 1987 season. . . . The San Diego Chargers announced that John Sanders, the general manager, would be re-assigned and that his assistant, Paul Younger, would be dismissed this week. . . . Ralph Miller, the basketball coach at Oregon State, was hospitalized for observation Sunday night in Portland after suffering dizzy spells before his team's game in the Far West Classic.

title: Injured Redskins Will Face Bears' Trap
description: As prizes go, this one was a doozy: The Chicago Bears. In Chicago. In January.

title: A THEATER GETS ITS DAY AT THE BEACH
description: How do you turn a small stage into a beach with waves, dunes and the timeless rhythms of summer? With a lot of sand.About 170 large bags full, to be precise. Weight: six tons, and not just any sand, either. It has to be expertly mixed: half white sand (the kind you find in hotel lobby ashtrays), half fine yellow sand (the kind with thick pebbles). Be sure to rake well.

title: G.M. Sets Record For Europe Sales
description: The General Motors Corporation said its 1986 European sales of nearly 1.3 million cars - an increase of 5.4 percent from 1985 - was a record. But the auto maker said its share of the European market dipped to 11 percent, from 11.3.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the quarter, and income from discontinued operations of $376,000 and an extraordinary credit of $931,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $368,000 and $575,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: SECONDHAND BOOK STALLS SUSTAIN AVID PAKISTANIS
description: The browser frowned as he tried to make up his mind between an engineering textbook published in 1915 and an old cowboy paperback entitled ''Law Man of Powder Valley.''

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. WORKERS GOT BONUS PAY AFTER BIG DEFEAT
description: The day after the Republicans lost control of the Senate to the Democrats last month, staff members of the committee responsible for electing Republicans to the Senate paid themselves and their consultants $225,250 in bonuses, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: WAS PRIME MINISTER OF BRITAIN
description: Harold Macmillan, who as Prime Minister from 1957 to 1963 helped Britain to adapt to its changing role in the world and its reduced military, economic and diplomatic power, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 92 years old.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Doing the New Year Stamp
description: On New Year's Eve, thousands of New Yorkers will have thronged to Times Square to watch a giant gold ball, dressed as an apple, fall from atop an office building at midnight.

The Government ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to reduce rates an additional $650 million to $700 million beyond what it had been planning, bringing a scheduled New Year's Day long-distance cut to almost $1.9 billion, or 11 percent.

title: CULINARY TALISMANS FOR A LUCKY 1987
description: WHETHER New Year's Day is celebrated on Jan. 1 according to the Gregorian calendar, in September or October as the Jews' Rosh ha-Shanah or in midwinter by Asians, foods serve as edible talismans to assure luck, happiness or prosperity in the coming year.

title: JAPANESE CHIEF SAYS DEFENSE PLAN WILL NOT LEAD TO MILITARY POWER
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, defending his Government's decision to breach a decade-old ceiling on military spending, said today that the action did not mean Japan would become a military power.

title: Florida Edges Illinois As 5th Largest State
description: Florida became the fifth most populous state in the country in 1986, marking the only change in ranking among the 10 largest states, the Census Bureau said today.

title: ITT and C.G.E. Complete Deal
description: The ITT Corporation and Compagnie Generale d'Electricite completed the merger yesterday of their telecommunications businesses, a move that will give ITT $1.25 billion while taking the control of a difficult business out of its hands. The deal creates the world's second-largest telecommunications company, behind the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: AGENCY NOTES RISE IN DRUG SEIZURES
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration said today that it achieved dramatic increases in arrests and seizures in the last fiscal year.

title: A 'Star Wars' Holiday
description: Three Republican legislators spent three days of the Christmas recess visiting research installations where work is under way on President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, a space-based missile defense often referred to as a ''Star Wars'' plan. Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming and Representatives Jim Courter of New Jersey and Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York traveled to Huntsville, Ala., Los Alamos, N.M., and Livermore, Calif.

title: Unisys Sets Write-Off Of Over $250 Million
description: The Unisys Corporation, the computer company formed by the merger of the Burroughs and Sperry Corporations, said yesterday that it would take a write-down of between $250 million and $275 million, causing a ''substantial'' fourth-quarter loss.

title: Topics: Limits, and Heights; The Bronte Arms
description: By some accounts, the old parsonage for sale near Bradford, England, is no beauty. One biographer of its former tenants called it ''drab and little''; another described it as ''almost sordid.''

title: Ohio Inquiry Ordered On Plagiarism Charge
description: Ohio University officials have appointed a committee to investigate allegations that a professor plagiarized material from Soviet engineering books.

title: Tighten the Law on Covert Operations
description: It's clear by now to most Americans that the White House scandal involved some sort of violation of Congressional restrictions on covert operations. Yet many people seem to forget that these restrictions were part of a careful deal worked out between Congress and the executive branch little more than a decade ago to protect our constitutional system while permitting covert operations. Apparently, this tacit deal was not enough, and it ought to be made more binding now.

title: Read Us Some More Of That TV
description: Evidence piles up suggesting that television encourages people to read.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SAN DIEGO (NL) - Named Doug Duennes director of stadium operations.

title: ROBERT E. OSGOOD, SCHOLAR AND AIDE
description: Robert Endicott Osgood, an expert on foreign and military policy who taught at Johns Hopkins University for the last 25 years, died Sunday in Washington after suffering a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Cardinal Parente, 95, A Leading Theologian
description: Pietro Cardinal Parente, one of the Roman Catholic Church's leading theologians and the oldest member of the College of Cardinals, died Monday, the Vatican announced today. He was 95 years old.

title: Brennan's Notes
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., now in his 30th year on the Supreme Court, has had his clerks prepare at the end of each term a behind-the-scenes history of the evolution of important rulings, based on his conference notes and draft opinions and memorandums circulated among the Justices before a final decision.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Bars TV Greetings A renewed exchange of televised New Year's greetings by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev was called untimely by Moscow.

title: First Nationwide Head Pursues Interstate Deals
description: Through the timely acquisition of troubled savings and loan associations, Anthony M. Frank has built an organization that he says has now earned its name, First Nationwide Bank.

title: Hearing on Steroids
description: Robert Collins, a Federal judge in New Orleans, took charge of the Roland Barbay steroid case yesterday and scheduled arguments to decide today whether the Louisiana State University defensive end would be eligible to play in the Sugar Bowl game against Nebraska tomorrow despite test results showing he used banned chemicals.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is New Year's Day. Following are holiday schedules:

title: After Hours With the N.F.L.
description: Glen Pomeroy, a retired industrial engineer from Bettendorf, Iowa, has a lot of time on his hands, but he's getting weary of giving up more than three hours of it just to see a pro football game on TV. He also has a vague sense that most of that time is spent watching something other than the game.

title: DOCTORS WIN A ROUND IN SUIT OVER MEDICARE FEES
description: Doctors won the first round of a legal battle with the Government today in a suit over Medicare fees.

title: Perkins Decision Due
description: Coach Ray Perkins of Alabama met for several hours yesterday with Hugh Culverhouse, owner of Tampa Bay, and then called a news conference for today in Birmingham to announce whether he would leave the University of Alabama, where he doubles as athletic director and football coach, for a job as head coach of the Buccaneers, replacing the dismissed Leeman Bennett. Quoting an unamed Alabama official, The Dallas Morning News said he would.

title: For Nondrinkers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: INDEX ON DIRECTION OF ECONOMY CLIMBS
description: The Government index intended to predict the economy surged 1.2 percent in November, the biggest advance in seven months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: UPSTATE A-PLANT'S LEAKY VALVE COULD ADD $240 MILLION TO COSTS
description: A leaky valve at the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power station in upstate New York could postpone the plant's commercial operations for up to four months and could add more than $240 million to the plant's multibillion-dollar cost.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Patricia Lara, a Colombian journalist barred from the United States last fall, misstated a request she made to the Colombian Government. Miss Lara asked only whether it had evidence to substantiate an American official's assertion that she was a member of the guerrilla group M-19. She neither requested nor received a reply on whether Colombia had evidence that she had ever acted as a Cuban agent.

title: More Poles Stay in West
description: During the Christmas holidays, 287 Polish tourists from three cruise ships stayed in West Germany, officials said today.

title: REAGAN TO SEND KEY OFFICIAL TO 'ASSESS' THE MIDDLE EAST
description: The Reagan Administration's top Middle East official will visit the region early next month to assess Arab-Israeli peace prospects and to demonstrate that American foreign policy is not paralyzed by the Iran arms affair, State Department officials said today.

title: PARK TO COMMEMORATE KEROUAC
description: The City Council today approved a commemorative park to honor the author Jack Kerouac, chronicler of the 1950's Beat Generation. The approval came despite arguments that the action would glorify drug abuse.

title: Bank Board Inquiry Asked
description: A regulatory proposal that would have benefitted a thrift institution that has had extensive dealings with a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has prompted a Congressional request for an investigation into possible conflicts of interest.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: ONE day I was standing in a bathroom in City Hall washing my hands when the City Council President stepped up to the sink beside me. (I will stop here, lest I precipitate another city scandal, to say that at the time the City Council President was a woman.) We began to chat, and eventually our chat turned to matters of moment, and eventually the matters of moment became newsworthy. I left the bathroom with a story. After years of worrying that the best stories were coming out of conversations in the men's room, I also left with the conviction that journalism was going to be all right for women after all.

title: Sid Caesar Quits Play
description: Sid Caesar, who was to appear in Arthur Miller's ''I Can't Remember Anything'' has withdrawn from the production, Lincoln Center Theater announced today. Mr. Caesar and Gregory Mosher, director of the production, ''have mutually agreed not to proceed with rehearsals,'' the theater's press representative, Merle Debuskey, said.

title: Bus Crash Kills 4 Hockey Players
description: Four players of the Swift Current Broncos were killed today when their team bus slid off an icy road into a ditch en route to a Western Hockey League game.

title: RANGERS RALLY BEHIND FROESE
description: Watching the Rangers is like watching climbers scaling a very difficult side of a mountain. You wonder when a piece of loose rock will give, causing them to tumble, and how, if at all, they will manage to catch themselves.

title: NEW YEAR'S FESTIVITIES ON THE HOME SCREEN
description: For a year that began with the Challenger shuttle disaster and ended in a muddle about Iran, hostages and contras, television has not come up with much that is new or especially appropriate in the way of New Year's Eve farewells. Although one station, WOR-TV, is doing something innovative by getting the Marx Brothers into the end-of-year act, elsewhere it is entertainment as usual.

title: FINANCING PLAN FOR TRANSIT AID VOTED IN ALBANY
description: Ending a 19-day special session that had set suburban and New York City lawmakers against each other, the State Legislature voted today to finance a rebuilding of the city's mass-transit system and a three-year freeze of its fares.

title: Short-Term Rates Still Rising
description: Short-term interest rates continued to climb yesterday as demand for credit to cover year-end needs intensified. But a late rally helped the longer-term Treasury debt issues recover most of their earlier losses.

title: Ruling on Mortgage Fee
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, in a move that angered financial institutions, ruled yesterday that home-mortgage lenders must account for ''points'' and other loan-origination fees over the life of a loan, not at once up-front. The ruling by the accounting board will be especially harmful to certain savings and loan associations that have come to depend on points and other fees as an important source of income.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert Getchell, the Hofstra University athletic director for the last 11 years, has resigned to accept a position with Meeting Management Associates, a division of Austin Travel as director of its newly created sports travel program. . . . Queen Elizabeth II's New Year honors list includes three sports figures. The former British Open champion Sandy Lyle was made a member of the Order of the British Empire.The racing driver Frank Williams, who was crippled in a car crash in March, was made a commander in the Order of the British Empire, and the soccer goalie Pat Jennings was made an officer of the Order of the British Empire.

title: A Belt Line
description: Jackie Sherrill, football coach at Texas A&M, responding to his paunchy Cotton Bowl counterpart, Ohio State's Earle Bruce, who had said that one reason he wouldn't want to be like Sherrill was that he could look in the mirror and feel good about himself: ''It was no big deal. I would have been more upset if Earle had said he looked in a full-length mirror.''

title: Security Pacific's Nevada Bank Deal
description: The Security Pacific Corporation and the Nevada National Bancorporation said they had reached an agreement for a subsidiary of Security Pacific to acquire the Reno-based bank holding corporation for $38 million.

title: WALSH MAY TAKE OVER MORE IRAN ARMS CASES
description: The Justice Department will consider turning over additional Iran arms investigations to a special Federal prosecutor named earlier this month, department officials said today.

title: The Koop and Cooper Voices on AIDS
description: The fear of AIDS does strange things to people who should know better. One by one, Federal agencies are trumping up reasons to screen people for the AIDS virus. Both the fear and the remedy are misplaced.

title: In Praise of Losers
description: Among the losers of 1986 you would probably have to include Vice President Bush, but you have to be careful. He may have a key role to play here in the coming year.

title: Welch Has Parcells's Respect
description: Five seasons ago, in their first playoffs since 1963, the Giants were eliminated by the San Francisco 49ers. Joe Montana, the 49ers' quarterback, picked on an inexperienced substitute who was playing because the Giants' starting free safety was injured.

title: Microelectronics Picks Interim Chief
description: Joseph A. Boyd, the chairman of the Harris Corporation of Melbourne, Fla., yesterday was named interim chief executive of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex. He may hold the job just for a matter of weeks until a permanent successor is named.

title: A COURT STRIPS EX-NAZI GUARD OF CITIZENSHIP
description: A former guard at a Nazi concentration camp has been stripped of his United States citizenship after he failed to appear at a hearing in Federal Court, the authorities said today.

title: Officers Are Indicted In Jersey Drug Case
description: Three Atlantic City police officers and a former officer were indicted yesterday on charges they used cocaine that had been stolen from evidence at police headquarters, prosecutors said.

title: U.N. Outpolls Congress in Public Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Oh Coward!' to Close
description: ''Oh Coward!,'' the musical focusing on the songs of Noel Coward, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Helen Hayes Theater. Devised by Roderick Cook, the production will have given 56 regular performances and 14 previews.

title: GUINNESS ADVISER SEVERS TIES
description: The Morgan Grenfell Group, a leading London merchant bank, quit today as advisers to Guinness P.L.C., the brewer that is the target of a Government investigation.

title: MUSIC: SCHNEIDER LEADS YOUNG STRING PLAYERS
description: MOST of us in the music business look back on one or more mentor-figures who inspired us in youth with their dedication, intensity and commitment. Alexander Schneider has played that part in the lives of hundreds of young musicians, and his example as a leader and educator endears him even to those observers who receive his example as a musician with mixed feelings.

title: An Improved Test For Seminal Fluid
description: A highly accurate test for seminal fluid in sexual assault cases has been marketed by Humagen Inc., a diagnostics company in Charlottesville, Va. The test, developed by scientists at the University of Virginia with a grant from the F.B.I., is more sensitive than other tests because it employs monoclonal antibodies that detect minute quantities of seminal fluid even if the assailant lacked spermatozoa.

title: KNICKS PUSH STREAK TO 4
description: The expression was not new to anyone who has frequented Madison Square Garden in recent seasons. The jaw was stern, the eyes were focused and the overall attitude was bold, almost daring, confidence. Yet the player with those looks was not Bernard King, the Knick forward whose scoring often was as close to unstoppable as one can imagine. It was Gerald Wilkins, and the results were just as thrilling.

title: Taylor Voted Top Player
description: Lawrence Taylor was named yesterday as the National Football League's most valuable player by The Associated Press.

title: DEUKMEJIAN NARROWS SEARCH FOR 3 COURT JUSTICES
description: Gov. George Deukmejian named five men and a woman as finalists today for three vacancies on the California Supreme Court. The vacancies were created Nov. 4 when the state's voters removed three justices who had voted to overturn scores of death sentences imposed by lower courts.

title: Gooden Search Revealed
description: Sheriff's deputies, acting on an informant's tip, stopped Dwight Gooden last year and searched his car for drugs, it was revealed today. No drugs were found and no charges were filed.

title: Cavities? Just Wash Them Away
description: EVERY dental patient has a dream: that cavities could simply be washed away and that the torture of the drill and even the annoyance of the anesthesia could be forever done away with.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Going Out Guide on Saturday misstated the time for a New Year's Day performance of George Bernard Shaw's ''Overruled'' at the South Street Theater. It is at 2:15 P.M.

title: Illinois City to Battle Crows
description: The City Council today declared war on crows, giving the police the power to shoot the birds inside city limits. The officers will use shotguns to rid the city of thousands of unwanted crows, Police Chief Robert Dietzen said, adding that the bids would be shot only in nonresidential neighborhoods. City Health Commissioner Jerry Brown said the crows were a health hazard.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS END THEIR MARCHES
description: For the first time in weeks today, there were no student demonstrations reported from any Chinese city, A senior education official described the last four weeks of pro-democracy student protests as ''important,'' but added, ''We don't feel that these things should cause alarm among us.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 103, Bucks 99: Adrian Dantley scored 25 points, including three free throws late in the game for the Pistons last night. Detroit won its third straight game, as Milwaukee's losing streak went to three games. The Bucks also lost for only the second time in 15 home games. The Pistons trailed, 90-84, in the fourth quarter before a free throw by Dantley tied at 95-95 with 1 minute 25 seconds left. Dantley went to the line when the Bucks' Terry Cummings was called for a technical foul for slamming the ball on the floor. A jump shot by Isiah Thomas put Detroit ahead, 97-95, with 1:08 to play, but a tip-in by Cummings with 38 seconds remaining pulled Milwaukee into a 97-97 tie. The Bucks' Paul Pressey was called for a foul with 33 seconds left, and Dantley made one of two free throws to put Detroit ahead to stay at 98-97. A layup by Thomas expanded the Pistons' lead to three, but two free throws by Pressey with 23 seconds left made it 100-99. Two free throws by Joe Dumars with 18 seconds left and one by Dantley with six seconds to play completed the scoring. Cummings led the Bucks with 24.(AP) Warriors 102, Bulls 99: Joe Barry Carroll scored 25 points and Chris Mullin added 23 to lead Golden State. The victory ended Golden State's four-game road trip on a high note, snapping a three-game losing streak.

title: FRENCH BOAT LOSES IN MISHAP
description: A collision less than a quarter-mile from the finish line cost French Kiss a victory over New Zealand today in the America's Cup challenger semifinals.

title: Problem Isn't Insurance Profits, but Tort Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospect Withdraws
description: Paul Hackett, a Dallas Cowboys assistant coach who had been regarded as one of the leading candidates for the Southern California head football coaching job, has withdrawn his name from consideration, The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported yesterday.

title: TALK IS CHEAP AT SHOWDOWN
description: P. T. Barnum would have liked Jerome Brown, Miami's defensive tackle, who apparently is a proponent of the hard-sell approach to the biggest college football game of the season.

title: Civil Service System Demands Eternal Vigilance
description: To the Editor:

title: Which Trains Are Worth Saving?
description: Want to buy a piece of Amtrak? The Reagan Administration seems eager to sell off the passenger railroad's Northeast Corridor system for $1.5 billion. The prospects of Congressional approval are poor, and the President's motive may be merely to include the $1.5 billion on the revenue side of his new budget. Still, the idea is intriguing on the merits.

title: The Year Of the Scold
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SIX was the year of the common scold. Almost everybody was severely criticized by almost everybody else - and usually with good cause.

title: Ulster Bomb Kills Man
description: A bomb explosion early today killed one man and wounded another in a bar in Maghera, 49 miles northwest of Belfast, the police said. The dead man was identified as Liam McShane, 24 years old, a part-time firefighter.

title: FOG FINALLY DISSIPATES AT THE ATLANTA AIRPORT
description: Skies were clear today over the busy airport here, a welcome sight to airline officials after two days of fog that delayed thousands of flights.

title: TEXAS MURDER COUNT DROPPED
description: A judge who threw out a confession by Henry Lee Lucas, who once confessed hundreds of killings but then recanted, agreed Tuesday to drop a capital murder charge against him.

title: POLAND IS CRACKING DOWN ON ILLEGAL PUBLISHERS
description: The Polish security police, in a change of tactics in efforts to suppress underground publications, have begun confiscating the cars of distributors.

title: U.S. BANS RED DRUM FISHING IN GULF
description: The popularity of the Cajun specialty blackened redfish has forced Federal officials to ban commercial fishing for red drum in Federal waters in the Gulf of Mexico in l987, the Commerce Department has made known. The ban was required because of recent alarmingly high harvests of red drum, according to the department's National Marine Fisheries Service.

title: 2 CHARGED IN INSIDER TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced two new insider-trading cases, involving a Chicago merger lawyer and a top executive of a high-technology company in California.

title: LAW CUTS FLOW OF IMPORTED RECORDS
description: A provision of Federal copyright law designed to prevent the sale of pirate recordings and cheap foreign copies of American albums has made hundreds of imported recordings unavailable in the United States.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Capital Reading; Bush on Terrorism
description: Excerpts from ''Prelude to Retaliation: Building a Governmental Consensus on Terrorism'' by George Bush, published in the winter-spring 1987 edition of SAIS Review, the journal of the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, in Washington:

title: SOVIET CALLS TV GREETINGS UNTIMELY
description: The Soviet Union today rejected a proposal by the United States for an exchange of televised New Year's greetings between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, citing what it said was Washington's negative attitude on key arms control issues.

title: Positive Views About Owens
description: DESPITE a sweeping restructuring that has left the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation saddled with a mountainous debt, several analysts have expressed bullish opinions on the prospects of company, the world's largest maker of glass fiber products.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins, 31-10; 266 Yards For Green
description: Gaston Green rushed for 266 yards and three touchdowns to lead U.C.L.A. to a 31-10 rout of Brigham Young in the third Freedom Bowl tonight.

title: Bridge: A Wedding Unites Players From 2 Far-Flung Corners
description: The tournament bridge world often serves to bring together in marriage two players who are widely separated geographically.

title: U.S., Canada in Lumber Pact
description: The United States and Canada reached a last-minute settlement tonight of a softwood lumber dispute that had caused acrimony between the two Governments and threatened broader talks on free trade.

title: O'CONNOR FEARS MIDEAST 'CONFLAGRATION'
description: John Cardinal O'Connor met with King Hussein of Jordan today and said afterward that he was worried about the consequences of deepening tensions between Israel and its Arab neighbors and the Palestinians.

title: Bide-a-Wee Begins Campaign for Shelter
description: Bide-a-Wee, a shelter for animals, has begun a three-month print and broadcast campaign to raise $4.2 million in funds to rebuild and reopen its Manhattan shelter on East 38th Street between First Avenue and the East River.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEW YORK SUING CITISOURCE AND OFFICERS OVER CONTRACT
description: The Koch administration yesterday sued Citisource Inc. and five company officers and directors, including Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, for more than $14 million in damages over a city contract for a hand-held computer.

title: CITY TAXI CHIEF SAYS INDUSTRY FAILS RIDERS
description: The chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, in his first public criticism of the industry he regulates, said yesterday that the city's medallion cab system is fraught with ''fundamental structural problems'' and that the public is not being properly served.

title: Developer Recycling 100-Year-Old Buildings
description: Using a relatively new recycling technique, construction engineers of the Lefrak Organization, a New York developer, are turning old concrete and brick from abandoned buildings into useful material to build a $10 billion waterfront development in Jersey City. The 160-million-square-foot development, to be known as Newport City, will contain 10,000 apartments and 10 million square feet of office space.

title: 2 MEN FOUND SLAIN IN BRONX PARK
description: As the police were investigating a murder yesterday in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx yesterday morning, a passer-by found a second body along the same road, 150 yards away. Each body had a gunshot wound to the head but the police said they had no theories about the murders.

title: Ex-General Resigns From Wedtech Board
description: A former major general in the New York Army National Guard, Bernard G. Ehrlich, resigned yesterday as a director of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, according to the company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association elected Eldon C. Hanes chairman and Raymond A. Lein president and a director.

title: Woman Sues Over TV Arrest
description: A woman has filed a $30 million lawsuit against the television figure Geraldo Rivera, law-enforcement officers and producers, charging that she was defamed when her arrest was shown on television as Mr. Rivera referred to ''a pimp and his prostitutes.''

title: PROSECUTORS WEIGH NEXT STEP IN THE QUEENS BEATINGS CASE
description: After suffering an apparent setback in court Monday, the Queens District Attorney conferred yesterday with aides and detectives investigating the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, to consider what to do next in the case.

title: DERAILMENT SPILLS LYE INTO THE SUSQUEHANNA
description: A derailment spilled 15,000 gallons of lye into the Susquehanna River, forcing municipal water intakes to shut for several hours, an official said today.

title: JOHN T. DOLAN, FOUNDER OF GROUP THAT BACKED CONSERVATIVES, DIES
description: John T. Dolan, co-founder of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, a leading force in the New Right, died Sunday at his home here after a long illness. He was 36 years old.

title: Less Cash Needed For Farm Credit
description: The Farm Credit Funding Corporation, an arm of the Farm Credit System, the nation's largest farm lender, has announced that it does not expect to offer any bonds with maturities of 13 months or more until at least March 2.

title: What the Ads Say
description: Following is a sampling, provided by the National Association of Broadcasters, of the recent public service announcements on drunken driving that have been aired around the country using local broadcast personalities:

title: HE LOOKS AFTER WHAT IS LEFT BEHIND
description: Nothing he studied at St. John's University Law School prepared Bruno Cappellini for becoming the temporary caretaker of a stable of racehorses. Or of the costume jewelry of Nita Naldi, a vamp of the silent screen. Or of a drug-ridden brownstone on the Upper West Side of Manhattan used as a ''crack house.''

title: Where Saffron Grows
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: An Appeal to Reagan and Gorbachev
description: The following statement was signed by Raul Alfonsin, President of Argentina; Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico; Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece; Rajiv Gandhi, Prime Minister of India; Ingvar Carlsson, Prime Minister of Sweden, and Julius Nyerere, President of Tanzania. It was released Monday in each of their respective capitals and made available to The New York Times by Parliamentarians Global Action, whose membership consists of legislators from 36 countries.

title: VICTORIAN SONGS AND SAVORIES
description: TONIGHT there will be revelers, of course, who will be satisfied simply hearing chorus after chorus of ''Auld Lang Syne'' interspersed with the hits of '86. At the same time there will be some 2,800 other celebrants whose evening will be filled with gentler melodies, such as ''Come Into the Garden, Maude,'' ''The Moon Has Raised Her Lamp Above,'' ''Watchman! What of the Night?'' and ''The Dicky Bird and the Owl.'' And about an hour before the New Year is rung in, the appetites of 300 of these fortunates will be sated with such savories as Victorian bisquits and Chatterly cheese rounds, and with sweets such as lemon curd in pastry cups, Yorkshire fat rascals and Richmond maids of honor.

title: 6.2% Elgin Stake
description: A Chicago-based investment group said that it had acquired 6.2 percent of Elgin National Industries and intended to purchase additional shares.

title: Soviet Posters for Sale
description: Liberation Graphics, a wholesaler in Alexandria, Va., has signed an exclusive agreement with Mezhdunarodnaya Kniga, the Soviet book exporting agency, under which 500 Soviet posters a year will become available at retail outlets in this country. Only 10 days after the contract was signed, the first samples are already on sale at a Connecticut Avenue bookstore, Common Concerns, at capitalist prices: $10 for the smaller 19-by-25-inch size and $15 for 36-by-26.

title: Dissidents Who Died In Soviet Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Problem Isn't Insurance Profits, but Tort Reform; What Society Expects
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1986
description: The Economy

title: THE VERDICT ON SHAMIR
description: For many Israeli legal scholars, civil rights campaigners and security experts, a police commission's announcement Monday clearing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of complicity in the 1984 killing of two Palestinian bus hijackers is hardly a reason for national joy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about post-election bonuses for employees of the National Republican Senatorial Committee misstated the origin of Thomas C. Griscom's bonus.

title: Stocks Retreat Again; Dow Off 3.51
description: Stock prices fell on Wall Street for the second consecutive session as weakness in the bond market and year-end tax-related selling continued to take their toll.

title: College Basketball; KENTUCKY BEATEN BY GEORGIA, 69-65
description: Willie Anderson sank two free throws with five seconds left to seal Georgia's 69-65 victory over Kentucky in their Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: O'Neill Seeks Change In Capital-Gains Tax
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said yesterday that he would ask the General Assembly to adjust Connecticut's capital-gains tax in 1987 so that the state would not reap a potential $200 million windfall under the new Federal tax law that takes effect tomorrow.

title: SLIM PROFITS SEEN FOR MCDONNELL JET
description: By leaping into the production of a new jumbo jet, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is entering a growth market, but one that may not yield big profits, analysts said yesterday.

title: Sad Stats
description: All those year-end sports reviews neglected to make note of some remarkable achievements in major league baseball's 1986 season. For the record, then:

title: PICKENS BATTLES HIS HOMETOWN PRESS
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the oilman, issued some ire along with the eggnog and holiday cheer at the company Christmas party. He urged his 400 employees at Mesa Petroleum to cancel their subscriptions to the local newspapers to protest ''negative reporting'' of Amarillo news.

title: Ex-Studio Now Home To Offices
description: IN the last few years East Harlem has strengthened its commercial base. So far, most of the investment has been made by local entrepreneurs who have opened or renovated and expanded modest retail businesses there.

title: TALKS RESUME IN 2-WEEK-OLD FRENCH RAIL STRIKE
description: Negotiations between the Government and railroad engineers began here today in an effort to end a two-week-old strike.

title: Give New York's High Court the Best
description: Judge Bernard Meyer has capped an eminent judicial career with seven years of distinguished service on New York's highest court. His retirement today poses a special challenge to Governor Cuomo, who's about to choose Judge Meyer's successor from a list of seven names provided by a nominating commission.

title: OTHER VIRUSES MAY ACTIVATE DORMANT AIDS VIRUS
description: A dormant AIDS virus can be stimulated by other viruses into reproducing itself, which may help explain why some people suddenly develop AIDS years after becoming infected, scientists reported today.

title: The Old Year, a la Carte
description: A RESTAURANT critic's note pad gets cluttered with all kinds of oddities and observations, not to mention butter smudges, wine stains and sauce splotches, in the course of a year's work. This week concludes another year of investigative dining, roughly 500 field expeditions by my estimate, and I find myself heading into the new year carrying a sack full of undistributed material - sort of like a belated Santa Claus operating with a skewed supply and demand curve. The following random impressions, some timely, some trivial, are my 1986 journalistic nightcap, which clears the agenda and the palate for another year of gustatory sleuthing.

title: The New Year, on the Run
description: WELCOME to the universe of Food-1987, in which the forces of nutrition and convenience will determine the shape of things to come: what consumers buy, what supermarkets sell, what restaurants serve, what manufacturers produce. Periodically these forces will join - a nutritious meal will also be a tasty, quick one. More often, however, the need for convenience in the coming year will outweigh the desire for healthful food on the table.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1986
description: International

title: Canadian Entrepreneurs Get Information Center
description: Seeking to increase its role in the global information marketplace, Canada is building a $57 million information technology center where Canadian entrepreneurs and emerging companies can display their inventions and obtain financial, marketing and management advice. The center, called Exploracom, will also contain a large exhibition area where corporations that manufacture, market or use information technology can demonstrate its applications.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The advantage of this strategy to the foreign company is that it retains access to our markets without any longer having to deal with anti-apartheid harassment at home.'' - Duncan Innes,

title: TONELLI BURNS DEVILS WITH 2 LATE GOALS
description: John Tonelli's first return to the metropolitan area since he was traded to Calgary by the Islanders late last season was rather impressive tonight.

title: LAWYER IN ATTACK CASE: IN PUBLIC EYE
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., the lawyer whose tactics have become a key element in the investigation of the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, is no stranger to the public eye. Over the years, he has frequently and publicly charged Mayor Koch, police officials and the city's district attorneys as being racist or at least insensitive to blacks Either as an adviser or lead counsel, Mr. Maddox and another black lawyer in the Howard Beach case, C. Vernon Mason, have been involved in many of the cases that have arisen in recent years that have involved questions of police brutality and racial attacks on blacks.

title: Bank Charter Plea Is Made
description: In a move that could further deregulate the banking industry, the Comptroller of the Currency, has asked a Florida court to allow the chartering of hundreds of limited-service banks.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: REAGAN'S AMERICA. Innocents at Home. By Garry Wills. 472 pages.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Pizza Hut Adopts Video Training System
description: How about a video pizza (hold the 3-D)? Pizza Hut Inc. has adopted a videotape system to train more than 10,000 employees on such matters as making a pizza, dealing with customers and, of particular importance, increasing home deliveries. The Sony 8-millimeter system replaces conventional films and slide presentations, and was chosen over the more popular half-inch video format because of its smaller size, lower mailing cost and future adaptibility to new training programs, company officials said.

title: SHIFT IN ATTITUDE FOR BROWNS
description: In describing how Bernie Kosar throws his passes, his coach, Marty Schottenheimer, revealed something of the character of his team, the Cleveland Browns.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TEMPUS FUGIT New Year's Eve is a night when prices can become sky-high. But one place they are not is the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where the Fourth Annual New Year's Eve Concert for Peace will take place tonight, free.

title: NORTH KOREAN PRESIDENT URGES HIGH-LEVEL TALKS TO UNIFY PENINSULA
description: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea called today for high-level talks to reunify the divided Korean peninsula. He also predicted a doubling of factory output by 1994.

title: STRAUSS CONCERT IN VIENNA
description: The annual New Year's Concert of the Vienna Philharmonic will be televised by PBS at 9 P.M. Thursday, giving American viewers the chance to join a worldwide audience that is expected to number 700 million - by far the largest audience ever gathered for a musical event. The television and radio audience in more than 50 countries will receive a program devoted entirely to the music of the Strauss family of waltz fame.
