title: THE AMBIGUITY OF SOUTH AFRICAN DIVESTMENT
description: The highly publicized departure of American companies from South Africa is having a far more ambiguous effect than advocates of such divestment might have hoped for.

title: PRETORIA HOLDS WHITE OFFICER AS A REBEL SPY
description: The South African authorities said today that they were holding a white army officer on suspicion of spying for the outlawed African National Congress.

title: ''Golden Child'' Is Top Film At Christmas Box Office
description: ''The Golden Child'' remained No. 1 at the box office over the Christmas weekend as the top seven films brought in nearly $46 million, on a par with last year's successful holiday weekend.

title: Topics: Limits, and Heights; Passion for Restraint
description: Robert Osgood, who died Monday at 65, was a teacher to teachers and a guide to foreign-policy makers. Humanist, professor, policy maker, original thinker, gentle man, he left everyone he touched better off.

title: Judge Delays Ruling On Levin Diary Use
description: A Manhattan judge read the diary of Jennifer Levin ''from cover to cover'' yesterday but said he would not rule for perhaps several weeks on whether it could be used in the defense of Robert E. Chambers Jr., the man accused of killing her.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL PEACH BOWL, North Carolina State vs. Virginia Tech, at Atlanta, 1 P.M. (TV -Channel 11, USA, 1 P.M.) BLUEBONNET BOWL, Colorado vs.

title: The Public Should Bear the Costs of Wetlands Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Preparing Chestnuts
description: FEW foods evoke the warmth and spirit of the holidays as roasted chestnuts do - preferably eaten on the street from a paper bag that is so hot it nearly scorches your hands. At the dinner table, a steaming bowl of chestnut puree makes a soothing accompaniment to all sorts of game, poultry and other roasts.

title: Reagan Appeal Expected
description: President Reagan is expected to make a major new appeal for financing for Nicaragun rebels in an attempt to keep Congress from scuttling a top foreign policy objective, White House officials said today.

title: Auld Lang Syne
description: In the waning moments of the old year, some thoughts, some impressions, some misplaced notes surface.

title: Life Term in Jerusalem Blast
description: An Israeli military court sentenced a 26-year-old Palestinian, Fameer Ibrahim Mahmoud Abu Namah, to life imprisonment today when he pleaded guilty to planting a bomb that exploded on a Jerusalem bus two years ago, killing 6 people and wounding 50.

title: FOR POLICE, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE IS NO LONGER A LOW PRIORITY
description: There was a time, a decade or two ago, when domestic disputes, even violent ones, stayed largely in the family.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AT this time of year, the resolve of even the most ardent exerciser can begin to falter. Who wants to jog when streets are icy, or bicycle under a shower of sleet. Not even swimming may beckon when it means stepping out into a cold, dark morning or night.

title: SCREEN: NEW AMERICAN ANIMATION
description: THE current program at Film Forum 1 shows off contemporary American animation at its most exciting. It showcases three ingenious film makers, Jane Aaron, Robert Breer and Maureen Selwood, whose styles are distinct and disparate yet mesh well together. Miss Aaron's work has the lightest and most whimsical style, Mr. Breer's is the most varied and intricate, and Miss Selwood's has the greatest range and fluidity. Together, these short films present a rich and innovative sampler of an art that, demonstrably, is thriving.

title: Cuomo Approves Simulcasting Bill
description: Governor Cuomo approved legislation today that will allow horse racing teletheaters situated more than 40 miles from race tracks to open without permission from the tracks.

title: ANONYMOUS GIFTS ARE MADE TO AID NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: A couple anonymously honored the teachers of severely handicapped children at a Queens public school by donating $50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: What's Behind Those Drunken Driving Warnings
description: This holiday season has been marked by a flurry of public service announcements on radio and television stations around the country urging people who drink intoxicating beverages not to drive.

title: Pepsi-Cola Bottling
description: The Pepsi-Cola Bottling Group said it had acquired the San Francisco-area Pepsi-Cola bottling operation, franchises in Eureka, Calif., and in Reno and a 50 percent interest in the bottling operation in Oroville, Calif., from the New Century Beverage Company, owned by the Campodonico family of San Francisco. Pepsi-Cola Bottling, a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., declined to disclose terms of the deal.

title: BALLET: CAST CHANGES IN 'NUTCRACKER'
description: HARD to believe but true:

title: Hervey Law, 88, Dies; Developer of Airports
description: Hervey F. Law, who guided the development of major airports in the Northeast, died Dec. 17 at the Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Lake Wales.

title: New Year's Closings
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange will close at 1 P.M. today for the New Year's holiday.

title: COURT DENIES CLAIM TO ITEMS FOUND ON INDIAN BURIAL SITE
description: After a 12-year court battle, a man has lost his claim to two tons of Indian artifacts he secretly unearthed from Indian burial grounds.

title: The Man Who Modernized Electrolux
description: RICHARD DANNHARDT remembers the day two years ago when Homer Moeller first toured the Electrolux Company's vacuum cleaner factory on the rolling outskirts of this small Appalachian city. He had scarcely begun to show off the energy management prowess of the plant's only computer when Mr. Moeller smiled, said ''that's fine'' and strode out.

title: Gain at New Woman
description: New Woman magazine has reported that its January issue closed with 56 ad pages, a 17.4 percent gain over the previous year, while its February issue closed with 75.1 ad pages, a 25.5 percent gain over a year ago.

title: LOCAL EFFORTS TO PROTECT OPEN SPACES ARE URGED
description: The President's Commission on Americans Outdoors sent the White House a summary report today urging a ''community by community'' effort to preserve open space for recreation.

title: ALL DRESSED UP FOR AMERICA'S CUP (AHOY YANKS)
description: This sunwashed harbor town, home to the America's Cup sailing races, abounds with souvenirs, freshly painted storefronts and shopkeepers eagerly awaiting an invasion of American tourists.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CHASE MANHATTAN used to provide a friend. Manny was always on your side at Manufacturers Hanover. One bank said you could call it Irving.

title: Appointments on Staff Are Made by Giuliani
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, announced yesterday new executive staff appointments in his office.

title: WITNESS BACKS DEFENSE ACCOUNT IN SLAYING OF JERSEY TROOPER
description: A leader of a self-styled revolutionary group testified today that a defendant in the slaying of a state trooper was the armorer of the unit whose duties included buying guns for members.

title: Renaming The Bowl Games
description: Viewers of college football bowl games this holiday season might notice something different. Instead of the plain old Sun Bowl, they saw the John Hancock Sun Bowl. The Gator Bowl was transformed into the Mazda Gator Bowl. And the matchup between Nebraska and Louisiana State University on New Year's Day will be the USF&G Sugar Bowl.

title: Ginnie Mae Is Switching To Book-Entry System
description: The Public Securities Association has announced that the Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae, is converting its $250 million market of outstanding mortgage-backed securities from bearer form to a book-entry system, an electronic form of record-keeping whereby all ownership is transferred by computer, beginning Friday.

title: U.S. PLANS 200% DUTY FOR EUROPE
description: In retaliation for European trade policies that the United States says cost American farmers about $400 million a year, President Reagan plans higher duties on imported gin, brandy, cheese and inexpensive white wine, it was announced today.

title: CAPTORS ASSERT THEY KILLED 3 LEBANESE JEWS
description: An underground Shiite Moslem group asserted early today that it had killed three Lebanese Jewish hostages in retaliation for Israeli shelling of southern Lebanon.

title: Hazard E. Reeves, 80; Popularized Cinerama
description: Hazard E. Reeves, a communications entrepreneur who helped popularize the wide-screen Cinerama film system and magnetic stereophonic recording, died Dec. 23 of a heart attack at the Duck Cedar Inn in Tuxedo, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: RANGEL QUESTIONS SILENCE OF VICTIMS OF QUEENS ATTACK
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the senior black elected official from New York City, yesterday questioned the strategy of the attorneys for two black victims of the racial clash in Howard Beach, Queens, that ended in the death of a third black man.

title:
ADVERTISING;
City Sports In New York
description: City Sports, a magazine started in San Francisco 13 years ago, will enter the New York market with an initial press run of 95,000 copies in January.

title: Hanky Alert
description: Another viewer with a gripe - and a solution - is Richard Graham, a 56-year-old prop worker at the Metropolitan Opera. His pet peeve is the gap between the instant a penalty flag is thrown and the moment when broadcasters tell television viewers there is a penalty.

title: An Argentine Court Upholds Convictions of 5 Ex-Leaders
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the convictions of five former military junta members accused of complicity in the torture and killing of thousands of political prisoners.

title: Spain Keeps Abortion Law
description: The Supreme Court today struck down a decree that liberalized Spain's law on abortion.

title: NBC NEWS TOPS RATING FOR QUARTER
description: NBC's ''Nightly News'' broadcast, which has lagged behind the ''CBS Evening News'' for most of the last two decades, won the ratings competition for the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: 2 GROUPS REPORT A BREAKTHROUGH IN FIELD OF ELECTRICAL CONDUCTIVITY
description: After a dozen years of futile efforts to raise the temperature at which materials become superconducting, researchers at the University of Houston and at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in New Jersey have achieved sudden and substantial increases.

title: 49ERS' WALSH: QUIET WINNER
description: Little has changed over the years. He projects the same mannered style and manicured appearance as always, ever polite, ever respectful, and during the work week, ever casual.

title: Westchester Offers Free Rides Tonight
description: Westchester County will offer free bus rides tonight and a local hospital will offer free taxi rides to motorists who drink too much, officials said yesterday.

title: An Urban Condition Spreads to Suburbs
description: Homelessness, once considered an urban phenomenon, is continuing to grow at an alarming rate throughout the region, according to government officials and advocates for homeless people.

title: Jaguar's Record Output
description: Jaguar P.L.C., the British auto manufacturer, said it had produced a record 41,437 cars this year, up 8 percent from 1985.

title: Safe Keeping
description: When a player is traded from one team to another, his jewelry goes along with him, generally. But Butch Lee was gone so fast from the Atlanta Hawks that his N.C.A.A. championship ring just now caught up.

title: Exploring the 'Other' sparkling Varieties
description: ALL that glitters isn't gold, and all that bubbles sure isn't champagne.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
In Praise of Canned Tuna
description: AWKWARD as it is, almost every connoisseur of good food must admit to the occasional tuna-salad sandwich. Don't believe people who say their only experience with canned tuna has been in the form of salad Nicoise. The continued healthy sales of canned tuna, can openers, mayonnaise and celery put the lie to those kinds of protestations.

title: ROCKETS SLOWED BY INJURIES
description: The 1985-86 season ended with the Boston Celtics beating the Houston Rockets for the championship, Akeem Olajuwon being proclaimed the next dominant center and the Rockets, with their big, young, talented front line of Ralph Sampson, Olajuwon and Rodney McCray, hailed as the team of the future. Houston fans responded by purchasing 14,600 season tickets, the most in the league.

title: Club Ends Bar to Women
description: The Detroit Athletic Club has women as members for the first time in 71 years.

title: A Matter of Legal Tender
description: Patrick Jackson, a computer technician, reacting to a divorce decree, recently paid his wife's $1,000 legal fees in 400 pounds of pennies. Her lawyer, Robert Silva, is incensed. He has asked the Family Court in Newport to find Mr. Jackson in contempt and order him to remove the pennies and replace them with a more manageable check.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Organic Foods by Mail

title: Is This Kansas?
description: One of the most breath-taking sights in Washington is the Mormon Temple, whose slender, glistening spires loom suddenly over westbound Beltway drivers as they top a crest in the road at Kensington, Md.

title: CRUCIAL QUESTIONS ON CASEY'S HEALTH UNANSWERED
description: Nearly two weeks after surgery in which a brain cancer was removed from William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, his doctors said again today that he was fully conscious and periodically sat in a bedside chair.

title: KEY RATES
RECORD FINE, $1,025,000, LEVIED AGAINST POLLUTER IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: A New Bedford metals company agreed today to pay a million-dollar fine for violating Federal environmental laws, the largest such fine ever levied.

title: PUBLISHING: 'CLOCKWORK ORANGE' REGAINS CHAPTER 21
description: ''A Clockwork Orange,'' the novel by Anthony Burgess, contained 21 chapters when it was published in England in 1962. But the American edition published a year later omitted the final chapter, in which Alex, the violent young protagonist, becomes bored with violence and opts for a different kind of future.

title: Eason Will Start
description: Despite Steve Grogan's outstanding performance as the backup quarterback against the Miami Dolphins last week, enabling the New England Patriots to win the American Conference East title and make the playoffs, Tony Eason will start at quarterback Sunday against the Denver Broncos in the conference semifinal.

title: GEORGE MASON U.: 29, GROWING FAST
description: When the Nobel Prizes were awarded in Stockholm earlier this month, there was a winner in the audience, too.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Marking Time

title: CHEFS START WITH FEASTS FOR FRIENDS
description: MANY people will begin and end their New Year celebrations tonight with champagne toasts and a midnight banquet. Others will continue the festivities with a feast sometime tomorrow - and they include some Manhattan chefs and restaurateurs, for whom New Year's Day is a rare opportunity to entertain at home in a distinctive personal style.

title: RYAN STILL STARTER, BUT HAS ARM BRUISE
description: The morning after the biggest game of his life, Pat Ryan woke up with a bruised right arm.

title: Dissidents Who Died In Soviet Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKERS BET ON A DANCE CLUB
description: Tonight, as some couples head for Times Square to welcome the New Year, and others head for friends' apartments, Scott Johnston, Michael Kelly and a small coterie of other young investment bankers will make their way to Baja, a dance club on Columbus Avenue near 72d Street. They hope that hundreds of other fashionable young professionals will, too, for this group has poured $700,000 into it.

title: Lyle Blackwood Cut
description: The Miami Dolphins have released Lyle Blackwood and signed nine players as free agents. Blackwood, a 14-year veteran at safety, started the first five games of 1986 for Miami in place of his brother Glenn, who was on injured reserve. Lyle Blackwood, 35, was placed on injured reserve Oct. 10 with a severely sprained ankle, and said at the time he did not expect the Dolphins to call him back.

title: Flying Tiger Cuts
description: Flying Tiger Line Inc., the troubled air cargo carrier, announced a cost-reduction program for its executive and administrative staff as part of its effort to return to profitability. The program, which affects 2,600 of Flying Tiger's 6,100 employees, would eliminate 124 jobs, reduce salaries and benefits for all workers, and expand a profit-sharing and stock-ownership program to all administrative employees.

title: SWISS TO FREEZE IRAN ARMS ACCOUNTS
description: The Swiss authorities said today that they would take further steps early in the new year to freeze accounts controlled by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others involved in the covert arms sales to Iran.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN the midst of cooking fresh chicken livers recently, I realized that I was preparing one of the least expensive foods available. At the same time I realized that, despite the price, chicken livers are not high on people's lists of favorite foods. Still, I have cooked and served them to guests who subsequently revised their opinions of the dish. This is, I feel, a tribute to the technique I used in preparing the chicken livers.

title: Exxon Leaving South Africa
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it is selling its interests in South Africa because of the deteriorating economic and business conditions there brought on by the country's racial crisis. Exxon's involvement in

title: Disenchantment in Soviet
description: The Soviet statement rejecting an exchange of New Year's messages reflects disenchantment with the United States' conduct since the collapse of the Iceland summit meeting.

title: Sales of New Homes Fell 2.2% in November
description: Sales of new homes fell in November for the seventh time in the last eight months, the Government said today. Many analysts blamed soaring prices for the decline.

title: IRAN EXILES REPORT TEHERAN FIRE
description: An Iranian exile group in Paris said today that Iranian soldiers protesting Government policies had set fire to a barracks of the Revolutionary Guards in Teheran.

title: 1986, A MUSICALLY CONSERVATIVE YEAR
description: A DECADE hence, as pop historians look back on 1986, the year may well be remembered as the most musically conservative one since the early 1960's, when the first, impudent upsurge of rock-and-roll had subsided and Beatlemania had not yet arrived.

title: O'CONNOR PLAN: SITE TROUBLED VATICAN
description: A senior Vatican official, discussing the controversy over John Cardinal O'Connor's itinerary in Israel, said today that the Vatican did not object to Cardinal's original plan to meet with senior Israeli leaders, but to the fact that the meetings were scheduled in Jerusalem.
